column2: DRIVING a stock LaSalle V-8, Ralph DePalma last week averaged eighty-two miles an hour in a 500-mile test run over the Indianapolis Speedway. In 1911 Mr. DePalma, in a specially built car, made an average speed of 71.13 miles an hour in the first 500-mile race. Last week he not only broke his own record but that of Ray Harroun, who won the race that year with an average of 74.59 miles an hour.

Winners. Dogs-Roy Swackhamer's Mascot of Althea. Winners, Bitches (Best of Winners)-W. M. Christopher's Chris Belle. Best of Breed-Giralda Farm's Ch. Nancolleth Marquis. Pointers (German Short-Haired) Winners, Bitches (Best of Breed)-E. A. Kerbey's Bonnie Koerber. Retrievers (Chesapeake Bay) Winners, Bitches--Mrs. John R. Meeker's Skipper's Copper Bell. Best of BreedRolew Kennels' Ch. Airline Theresa.

Ten farms in upstate New York reported sold by N. A. Tillson, broker of Walden, N. Y., included that of ninety-eight acres owned by John McLane, 'which was bought by Ruth P. Belden of the Bronx. Another was the 100 acre- farm near Newburgh owned by Charles Baxter, which was purchased by Frank Agor of Peekskill.

Duke University's team-scored 78 points, a new record, today to win its second straight Southern Conference track and field championship. Duke marked scores in fourteen of the fifteen events, including the first three places in the broad jump and five firsts in all.

Loretta Berger, 13-year-old student in William Cowper Junior High School, Queens, has won first place and the cash prize of $100 awarded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, in the city junior public high school division of the Constitution Essay Contest being conducted under its auspices.

WHILE the television showmen in. London were telecasting the coronation procession, American research engineers were reporting to the New York convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers that they too are prepared to televise outdoor scenes from parades to sporting events.
Army shut out Bucknell in a light hitting contest today, 3 to 0. Lipscomb and Monahan were both effective, but sharp fielding saved the Cadet hurler at critical times.

Lester Brockelhurst, 23 years old, wanted in three States on murder charges, alternately screamed and fainted when guards passed his cell tonight while an Illinois Sheriff was planning to question him concerning a fourth slaying.

Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Wadsworth Cauchois of Yonkers, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Wadsworth Cauchois, to Charles George Aubry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules F. A. Aubry, also of Yonkers.

While London is awaiting the official announcement of the Duke of Windsor's wedding plans which Herman L. Rogers, spokesman for the Duke and Mrs. Wallis Warfield has promised to give out Tuesday at the Chateau de Cande in France, where they are guests, there is much speculation as to whether any similar notice will appear in the government's official organ, The London Gazette.

Vermont and New Hampshire decided in 1912 to ask the United States Supreme Court where one begins and the other ends. They have now found out since Special Commissioner Samuel S. Gannett reported on the 238-mile boundary line which follows the meanderings of the Connecticut River between the two States.

The Palestine Lighthouse in Aid of the Blind will be the beneficiary of a Spring festival Tuesday in the ballroom of the Pierre. Well-known operatic and concert stars will take part in the morning musical, which will be followed by a luncheon. Included also on the program will be a motion picture of Palestine.

George C. Becker, chief entomotogist of the United States Bureau of entomology and Plant Quarantine, returned from Europe last week on the United States liner President Roosevelt after conducting investigations in South Africa and England on a new process for destroying the Mediterranean fruit fly.

A movement to remap the area surrounding the site of the World's Fair to accommodate large-scale housing projects on blocks similar to those in the government's lowcost housing development in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn has been started by the committee on civic design of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

The following is the chart showing how the Preakness Stakes was run at Pimlico today: SIXTH RACE--The Preakness; $50,000 added; 3-year-olds; one mile and three-sixteenths. 'Start good' from stall; won driving; place same.

Taxes paid by the domestic steel industry last year were equivalent to a year's pay for 74,500 employes, and represented an outlay of $169 for each employee on the payrolls during the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

Plans are being completed for several June weddings in this city. Miss Josephine A. Swope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Swope of Chestnut Hill, has selectel June 2 as the date for her wedding to Ernesto D. Santa Maria, also of Chestnut Hill.

The Electric Bond and Share company asked the Supreme Court today for a writ of certiorari by which its appeal from the Southern District Court in New York over the Public Utility Holding Company Act would be taken from the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.

The closing of a Catholic boys seminary in Heiligenstadt by Naxi State Police was interpreted in some quarters today as the opening of a police campaign against Catholic educational instituations throughout Germany.
Two big innings liberally sprinkled with extra-base hits paved the way today for the second successive victory of the Browns over the Tigers. The score was 11 to 5.

To two students of the School of Arts and Sciences of Russell Sage College have been awarded German scholarships by the University of Heidelberg. They are Miss Dorothea Hayn of Pittsfield, Mass., a member of the senior class, and Miss Marjorie Smith of New York City, a sophomore.
Although the stock markets here were closed today, money was in demand as it was quarter-day in Scotland and the banks there were calling in funds.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended May 8 continued its forward movement, reaching 108.3, which compares with 108.1 (revised) for the previous week and 96.8 for the week ended May 9, 1936.

The overzealous hunt for "wreckers" by local authorities anxious to please has resulted in so many unjust dismissals and even prison sentences that Andrei Vishinsky, the Soviet Union Attorney General, was forced to intervene vigorously today.

The New York State College of Forestry at Syracuse University is preparing to install its own paper-making machine. Installation of the $50,000, 200-ton device will mark completion of the college's new paper and pulp laboratory.

CANDLE IN THE SUN" is, in the derivative sense of the adjective, a distinguished novel It stands quite by itself-belonging, indeed, to none of those classifications in which novels are so often placed for the sake of ease in description.
FOR the last twenty-five years before his death in 1920 William Dean Howells was the arbiter of literary taste in the United States. The cornerstone upon

The Retail Clerks International Protective Association, through Nathan Wertheimer, its general organizer for the Eastern district, disclosed yesterday that it had chartered a new local with jurisdiction over department store workers in this city.

Miss Florence Meachem Hyde, daughter of Mrs. Dana Cheney Hyde of 12 East Seventy-sixth Street, New York, and the late Mr. Hyde, was married here this afternoon to Henry John Wynkoop 3d, son of Mrs. Henry John Wynkoop of Bath, N. Y., and the late Dr. Wynkoop.

The door of the house at 50 Wimpole Street, London, once the home of Elizabeth Barrett Browning, will be presented to Wellesley College Thursday afternoon, the ninety-first anniversary of the day on which Robert Browning first opened it to visit the invalid poet-who to become his wife.

Before a capacity audience, onethird of which were residents of Scranton, Pa., and environs, "Cavalleria Rusticana" and its perennially plighted "Pagliacci" were seen last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time in the current Spring season.

Exercises marking the opening of a special exhibit assembled from the archives of the University of Pennsylvania Library to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution of the United States will be held in the library at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning.

Italy's struggle to attain complete economic selfsufficiency will be energetically Pursued; Premier Benito Mussolini announced this morning in a speech to the National Council of Corporations, because "to lay down the weapon of self-sufficiency would mean to place one's self in case of war at the mercy of those who possess everything necessary to wage war without limitations of time and materials."

Another sharp increase in land values such as was experienced in this country prior to 1928 cannot be expected in the future, Robert H. Armstrong, president of the New York chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards,

Home building in the Great Neck area of Long Island will be accentuated within the coming week when a forty-acre tract through which the Old Mill Brook runs will be opened for residential development by Robert J. Rose, who has erected a number of houses in Great Neck and other localities on the North Shore.

Bradley Rendell, fleet-footed performer from Falconer High School, Falconer, N. Y., romped away with the honors in the one-mile invitation race, feature event of Newark Academy's first annual track and field meet, today.
Two occupants of an automobile were killed and the driver was injured critically in a collision at 9 o'clock tonight with a Mount Vernon line street car at Yonkers and Cypress Avenues here.
ALBERT RHYS WILLIAMS has set himself the rather formidable task of giving "a picture of Soviet life and institutions, how they came into being, the plans and prospects for the future."

Colonel George M. Russell, Chief of Staff, Sixty-first Cavalry Division, United States Army, will review the Junior Essex Troop of Cavalry, composed of boys from 11 to 16 years of age, at the Roseville Avenue Armory here, on Saturday afternoon, May 22, it was announced today by Lieut. Col. H. C. K. Mattison, commandant of the troop.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley will have a conference with President Roosevelt at Washington on Thursday morning, preceding a national gathering of leaders of the People's Mandate Commission at the home of Mrs. Caroline O'Day. Dr.

"It will be many years," said Dr. CHARLES H. HASKINS in 1920, "before "the history of the Peace Conference "can be written." But his own brief account of its tasks and methods will be a permanent preface. An Chief of the Division of Western Europe he had a major responsibility in helping those who were beginning the new chapter in world history.

The threatened strike by the Screen Actors Guild, which was averted by the recognition of the Guild and its demands by the producers, was handled with a surprising lack of acrimony and there seems to be no probability of the blacklisting and reprisals that marked other uprisings of the "glamour children."
The boom in cotton raising on the island of Ometepe in Lake Nicaragua has suddenly turned the minds of the native growers to pleasure-hunting. A carrousel set up recently is enjoying a large trade.

A total of 255 permits at an estimated total cost of $547,945 were issued during April by the Newark (N. J.) Division of Buildings. This compares with 231 permits, involving a total estimated expenditure of $2,133,376 issued during the same month last year.

The former J. Rich Steers estate, consisting of a twenty-three-room house on sixty acres of land on King Street, Greenwich, Conn., has been sold by Mary Dolores Steers, executrix, to Stewart B. Hopps. who will occupy. the property as his Summer residence.

Glenn Cunningham, holder of the indoor and outdoor world's records for the mile, was among the competitors who. took part in exhibition events at the athletic track and field carnival held in conjunction with the dual meet between Flushing High and Bayside High at Memorial Field in Flushing yesterday.

James Ewing Rowan, managing director of the St. Louis Air Show, said today he had been informed that Miss Amelia Earhart would take off from the West Coast next Saturday, if weather conditions were favorable, on a second attempt to fly around the world.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana. WITH 1937's tourist season apparently keeping its unprecedentedly high level, this, the only British colony on the South American Continent, is giving thought to further development of tourist attractions, hoping to induce even more West Indian cruisers to pause here.

TIME seems to be the last subject time-ridden man dares to study. If our century is to go down as the most daring in history. I predict it will be due to the temerity which dares to question time itself, tries to delimit it, even puts it to experiment!

Mr. and Mrs. James Franklin Sargeant of Charlottesville have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucille Burnham Sargeant, to George Livingston de Peyster of New York. The announcement was made at a dinner in the Monticello Hotel, here, given by Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds Jr. of New York. Mrs. Reynolds is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sergeant.

Two thousand Puerto Ricans and Spanish Americans paraded through Lower Harlem yesterday afternoon to protest the imprisonment in Puerto Rico of Pedro Albizu Campos, leader of the Nationalist party, and seven of his followers.

Is It moral cowardice to condemn all wars when history has proved that the facts, issues and aims that may be involved are of no consequence in face of the actual results of such catastrophes? Our country needs neutrality legislation that will curb the profiteers and political fanatics. Indirect aid to belligerents will only tend to extend the conflict indefinitely.

Standard or "treed plants have long delighted American travelers as they wandered through parks and - public squares abroad or viewed them in small private gardens. In all of these rose, geranium, heliotrope or fuchsia "trees" make charming points of accent, rising through long "panels" of annuals or other bedding plants beneath.
THOUGH the Emperor Nero indisputably killed himself in the year 68 when his Senate and army rebelled against his misgovernment, legends persisted in his Eastern empire that he was still alive.

Alarmed at the frequent success attending small-town local option elections in the last two years, the New York State Organization of Retail Liquor Store Associations, Inc., is devising a plan under which the full weight of the group can be thrown behind liquor stores in the communities that are contending with dry agitation.

The Bluff House at Milford, Pa., has been purchased with its furnishings by Paul M. Wade, former treasurer and managing director of the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, who will open it as a Summer resort on May 29.

Home buying in many sections of Westchester County shows a steadily rising tendency this season and builders report an encouraging improvement in structural activity. Evidences of a growing demand for houses in Yonkers is indicated in sales made during the last few weeks by the Peoples Savings Bank of that city.

NEW YORK's trout fishermen, preparing for the season which opens in April, are now heading toward the tackle stores where new equipment is on display. Among new equipment the fly rod anglers will find an improved breast-kit resembling a small apron, which ties about the neck and waist. The kit provides three spacious pockets for tackle and a sheep's wool pad for drying flies and bugs.
Philadelphia at New York--Passeau vs. Castleman. Brooklyn at Boston--Mungo vs. Fette. St. Louis at Pittsburgh--Weiland vs. Bowman.

Soviet Russia's attempts to deal with American suppliers directly from Moscow have been successful in close to 60 per cent of current orders, but have met a decided obstacle in the refusal of iron and steel companies to comply with her demands, it was learned here yesterday.

swarming over and around forbidding heights that barred their path, the Insurgent armies converging on Bilbao today reported advances along a fourteen-mile front. Dispatches to Insurgent headquarters here said the northern wing had moved beyond Mounts Solluve and Jata and reached the outskirts of Munguia, seven miles northeast of the Basque capital.

More than 1,800 city teachers, firemen and policemen, who will benefit by the Pay Cut Restoration Bills sponsored by State Senator A. Spencer Feld, which will become effective on July 1, attended a dinner in honor of Senator Feld last night at the Commodore Hotel.

Exercise of the great American prerogative of free speech will characterize a luncheon gathering of feminine irreconcilables at the Hotel Commodore on Saturday, under the auspices of the Soroptimist Club of New York.
Close-of-play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today follow: Sussex 200 (J. Parks 97), Middlesex 121 runs for six wickets, at Lord's.

Premier Koloman Daranyi states that Hungary, while adhering to the Rome protocols, cooperation with Austria and friendship with Germany, is prepared carefully to consider all proposals for cooperation with other States in the Danube Basin on the basis of full recognition of Hungarian equality and guarantees for protection by legislation of the rights of Hungarian minorities in neighboring countries.

The Netherlands Fascist leader, A. A. Mussert, won some publicity today by staging a skirmish in a Socialist section of Amsterdam. "I had a narrow escape from the fury of the populace," he said later in his over-emphatic manner.

Kenwood, the fifty-four-acre waterfront estate at Oyster Bay, L. I., which cost William B. Leeds, the sportsman about $750,000, was sold yesterday at auction for $35,000 above a first mortgage of $125,000, bringing the total price to $160,000.

President ROOSEVELT has returned to Washington insisting that he meant what he said when he declared in his last speech of the campaign (the Madison Square Garden speech) that he had "just begun to fight" for the enactment of a long list of progressive social measures.

NORTH and west of the winter resorts of Miami and Palm Beach, almost equidistant from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean, lies Ocala, whose residents a year ago thought that the most important canal project in the recent history if the United States was at their floors.
The Secret Police have issued a warning to young people who show a tendency to get together on their own outside the Hitler Youth organization.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It was consoling to learn from Topics of The Times that the Chinese were saved from the "worst horrors of the white man's apprenticeship to the factory."

Ten years of welfare work in the Synagogue on Welfare Island will be celebrated on Tuesday by members of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, who raised the funds for its erection.

The bank building at 1,554 First Avenue, corner of Eighty-first Street, which the Irving Savings Bank recently acquired for a branch office, will be extensively altered. Plans by Halsey, McCormack Helmer, architects, call for the use
THE last attempt to foist a dictatorship on Britain has never been more forcefully presented than in Mr. Vulliamy's latest biography, which is as brilliantly written as it is historically convincing.

Mr and Mrs. John C. Marscher of Nar berth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hazel Marie Marscher, to John Alexander Crockett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Crockett of King of Prus sia.

Celebration of National Foreign Trade Week will open here tomorrow with the observance of LatinAmerican Day at the Hotel Astor. More than 1,000 high school students of the city, who belong to Pan-American clubs, will participate in the observance.

Dr. James N. Vander Veer, former president of the State Medical Society and widely known surgeon, died at his home tonight. He had been critically ill with heart trouble for a week. Taken ill last December, Dr.

Five months after an airplane vanished with seven persons aboard it was conceded today that it possibly may never be found, though thousands search. "The wreckage may lie in some hidden arroyo in Utah's mountain wilds, under five feet of snow," said an air veteran who preferred to remain anonymous.

Eleven hundred and eighty-eight children, whose drawings had been selected from 12,000 entries, received medals yesterday at exercises held in the Washington Irving High School auditorium as part of the twenty-fifth annual Wanamaker drawing competition for pupils in schools here.

Charles S. Wanless of Springfield, I1l., in his address last week at the Central Atlantic regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in this city declared that the employment of well-established, sound principles of construction will make it possible to build houses that will endure.

The wedding of Miss Elizabeth Tilghman Combs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Combs of Douglaston, L. I., and Richard Neville Carroll of Charlottesville, Va., took place this afternoon at Gros Coate, near Easton, the country estate of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Charles H. Tilghman.

General Kazushige Ugaki, former Minister of War and Governor General of Korea, today became the prospective Mayor of Tokyo. The general, who failed recently in his attempt to form a national Cabinet, was nominated for that post by the Tokyo City Assembly, which gave him thirteen votes to three for Isoo Abe, leader of the Social Mass party.

GERMANY is in the midst of a new Kulturkampf-a war between church and State. There have been many such conflicts in her history, but. for the first time since the Roman Caesars bowed to the cross, the struggle is no longer between temporal and ecclesiastical powers but between two rival faiths-Christian and National Socialist.

A BASIC attribute in the success of President Roosevelt as a radio speaker is that he uses the most commonly understood words, according to an analysis of Mr. Roosevelt's radio vocabulary by -Richard S. Schultz of the Psychological Corporation, reporting the results of his study in "School and Society."

Tempers ran short and debates ran into hours as the Giants and Phillies wrangled their way through the season's first double header at the Polo Grounds yesterday without a soul in a gathering of 22,633 able to detect where either party had gained a foot.

Detectives waiting shortly after midnight this morning in the laundry of Yick Wo at 95-07 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, arrested James Imbraile, alias James Balesto, 26 years old, who gave his address as 150 Ninety-fifth Street, Brooklyn, after he allegedly paid for laundry with counterfeit money.

President Roosevelt's announcement that he will continue to pursue his New Deal aims and that a leading objective will be stabilization of commodity prices evokes hearty approval in National Socialist quarters, where it is hailed as renewed endorsement of Nazi economic policy.
Profit-sharing plans are ordinarily so devised that contributions by the employer will constitute allowable deductions from gross income for income tax purposes.

In view of all that has been written about small pools for small gardens, it is surprising how many amateurs fail to realize that neither much expense nor much labor need be involved in making provision for them. As a matter of fact a small pool usually can be constructed with no more trouble than a small rock garden.
The annual Fairfield and Westchester race meeting will be held on May 31 at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here. Mrs. John H. Vincent of Greenwich heads the women's committee for the event.

For the third successive Saturday at Narragansett Park, horses from the Araho Stable today accounted for the chief stake offering at Narragansett Park, with Mrs. Walter O Hara's Mucho Gusto winning the $3,000 added Governor's Handicap by one length from Philip Bieber's Chuncing. A crowd of 30,000 witnessed the finish.

APPLEBAUM -- To Mr, and Mrs, Morris Applebaum, a daughter, on May 12, 1937, at Park East Hospital. BICK --- A son, to Mr, and Mrs, Irving Bick, on May 9 , 1937, at Park East Hospital, CULLEU-- Mr. and Mrs, Sils Culley announce the B birth of a daughter , at Hunts Point Hospital. .
Seventy-five girls from six schools participated in the New York Women's Lacrosse Association's playday for New York schoolgirls today at the Cathedral School of St. Mary.
Ancient Korakuji temple was set on fire today, police said, by a jealous woman who sought revenge against the chief priest for an unrequited love.

FOR exactly one hundred years The Sun of Baltimore has risen daily, and for the larger part of its century has shone with journalistic radiance. Now four of its staff, whose names testify to the stuff of which The Sun is made, have written a history of the newspaper.
Miss Catherine Lykens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lykens of Overbrook, was married this afternoon to John Stith Arscott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Arscott of Wayne.

An extended educational and follow-up program for boys returning to New York City from CCC camps will begin on June 1, Irving Gerdy, director of the educational department of the Works Progress Administration announced yesterday.

SIR Thomas Beecham, vehemently articulate in matters musical, is quoted in The London Times in a comprehensive broadside against methods of public musical education in England, "the wisdom of the Legislature," the cinema, the radio in general and the British Broadcasting Corporation in particular.
Members of the North Jersey Chapter of Mount St. Joseph College Alumnae have arranged their annual Summer dance for the night of June 19 at the Montclair Athletic Club, Montclair, N. J.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will speak at the seventy-fifth anniversary luncheon of Knickerbocker Hospital at the Hotel Astor on Thursday.

Edward E. Hughes 2d of Pittsburgh was elected president of the Student Council at Corr??ll University today, after a spirit election campaign. Edmund F. Pfeifer of Hackensack, N. J., was elected secretary, Thomas A. Rich of Hobart, treasurer.

Miss F. Virginia Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Rance Wilson of Bloomfield, will be married to William Struble Ackerman June 5 at Westminster Church, Bloomfield. Mr. Ackerman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Ackerman of Turtlepoint, Pa., formerly of Bloomfield. He will be graduated next week from Princeton Theological Seminary.
Percy L. Gassaway, Oklahoma's former "cowboy Congressman," died today in an ambulance -en route to Ada after suffering a heart attack at his ranch near here. He was 51 years old.

Two men believed to have posed as policemen and to have kidnapped and asasulted a 21-year-old girl in Bronx Park early Friday morning were under arrest yesterday. A third man, accused of participating with them, was seized shortly after the crime.

Championship teams from Ireland will engage strong local combinations in Gaelic football and hurling at the Yankee Stadium today in the first matches of their annual visit to this country. Mayo and the New York All-Stars will be the opponents in the featured football contest, while Cork and the New Jersey Rangers will clash in the hurling test.

Led by its captain, Oscar Israel, the lone double winner of the day, Fleldston School today captured the team title at the first annual Metropolitan Association of Private Schools track and field championships, held on the Woodmere Academy field. The New Yorkers registered a total of 20 1/2 points to top six other school teams.
A national Civic Federation three-day field trip to places of interest in the Berkshires was completed today. Objectives included Professor Walter Prichard Eaton's garden at Twin Fires, Sheffield;

More than 1,000 delegates, representing approximately 250 organizations in the United States and Canada, are expected to attend the thirty-eighth annual National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare in Indianapolis starting Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Gluckman, president of the conference, at national headquarters, 67 West Forty-seventh Street.

THERE was a time in this industrious country when a stockbroker's drypoint etchings or a physician's piano concertos were good for columns in the astonished press. But that time is no more, there are so many hobby-riders all over the place.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Newman of 101 Central Park West of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Elaine Newman, to David H. Pasternack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Pasternack, also of this city.

Crystal Star, follower of Father Divine and father of 13-year-old Morning Star, gave himself up to the Children's Society yesterday. Its agents had been searching for him with a warrant charging he had not provided proper medical care to the child who died of tuberculosis two weeks ago.

A sixth-inning rally enabled the Hill School nine to conquer a previously undefeated Lawrenceville team, 12-6, in the traditional Alumni Day contest today. In the sixth Pitcher Bournique of Lawrenceville issued four passes and yielded two hits for four runs. Davis went to the mound and stopped the rally after hits by Walton and Robertson had scored two more.
Abe Simon, Richmond Hill heavyweight, knocked out Leonard Dixon of Philadelphia in the first round of the scheduled eight-round main bout at the Rockland Palace last night.
The Temple track men scored their second victory of the season by defeating New York University, 70-65, in their annual dual meet at the Owl Stadium today.

Selections from the libraries of Mrs. A. Sorg-Walser and others, comprising standard sets in fine bindings, extra-illustrated volumes, first editions, books on horse racing and autograph material will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries,

The Cardinals rallied to tally two runs in the ninth inning today and beat Pittsburgh, 4 to 2, before 13,000 fans. The setback reduced the Pirates' lead in the National League pennant race to two and one-half games.

A NEW, copper-jacketed vacuum tube small enough to slip into a vest pocket like a fountain pen was introduced in the past week as the answer to the riddle of how-to pump high power into tiny wave lengths.

Expanded activities were in sight for the Public-Service Society of Syracuse University as the organization's executive committee today went about preparing formal affiliatio papers uniting the student group with the National Civil Service Reform League.

The national coffee convention here ended last night after a week of discussion. Among the important decisions voted was one to launch an internal loan of 500,000 contos [$30,000,000] through the Banco do Brazil.
SHANGHI. MANY Americans think of Soviet Russia as a strange land half a world away, yet actually the U. S. S. R mainland is only fifty-four miles from United States territory.

A banner year for student publications at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, during which all four showed profits for the first time in several years, has been reported by student managers to the Advisory Council of Undergraduate Publications.

Dr. and Mrs. E. Druitt Crawford of this city and Pennllyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Murray Crawford, to John Buck Morgan 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Rowland Morgan of Chestnut Hill.

LIKE "Composers of Today," to which it is a companion volume, and which, in point of time, it follows by about two years, this book is addressed to the average music-lover. And the average music-lover, Mr. Ewen has learned, always asks two kinds of questions:

The coronation is over, but Great Britain continues to make money on it. A total of 3,893 persons paid $2.50 apiece today for the privilege of walking through Westminster Abbey and gazing at the spot where George VI was crowned Wednesday.

Declaring that the government's program in aid of the unemployed had saved many American cities from economic chaos, Mayor La Guardia of New York today told the Western regional meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors that Federal relief would have to be continued for another decade.

PROGRESS AND CATASTROPHE. By Stanley Casson. 12mo. New York: Harper Brothers. $3. An anatomy of progress. JACOB EMDEN, A MAN OF CONTROVERSY. By Mortimer J. Cohen. 12mo. Philadelphia: The Dropsie College. $3.

J. Alfred Valentine has opened a new residential colony at East Williston in the Wheatley Hills area of Long Island. The property is opposite Old Westbury and is bounded on two sides by the golf course of the Wheatley Hills Club.

A three-run rally in the ninth inning gave Pennsylvania a 4-3 victory over Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game on University Field today. It was the third straight one-run setback for the Tigers.

AUTHOR, educator, scholar, mystic, practical worker in personal philanthropy and Christian Socialist, Vida Scudder has lived a highly individualized life of important public service. And both the activity and the clear and vibrant individuality are followed here through the years of-her busy life, in a beautiful, thoughtful and unusual autobiography.
EVEN a kindly history or psychiatry is, for the most part, a sickening panorama of man's greatest imbecilities and superstitions mixed with a mad cruelty unworthy of even the lower animals.

Split wide open on the amount of money the Federal Government should provide for a new 1938 farm relief plan, national farm leaders received a thinly veiled warning from Secretary Wallace today that "excessive" demands upon the Treasury, in the face of the present move for economy, might result in no program at all.

Looking forward to the first day of September when the women's juror bill will become effective in this State, Mrs. Jane Smith Cramer, chairman of legal status of the League of Women Voters has sent requests to all State branches to set up schools of jury service to train members and other interested women.

Choate was host today at the school's annual Parents' Day and alumni week-end, which was marked by the dedication of the new boat house, presented by the Alumni Association. Among the guests were 240 parents and 100 alumni.

Milton Lins of Milltown, N. J., was elected today president of the Middlebury College Undergraduate Association. This is the highest office a student can hold on the campus. It was also announced today that the 1939 Kaleidoscope, the college year book, would be edited by Robert L. Boyd, Melrose, Mass.

TWO books about presentday Spain are announced for publication this year by Random House. The first of these is "The Life and Death of a Spanish Town," by Elliot Paul. This is the story of Santa Eulalia, where Paul lived for the last five years.

A few minutes before MERRILL and LAMBIE landed at Floyd Bennett Field on Friday afternoon, twenty-four hours out of Southport Sands, near Liverpool, four wild geese, in V formation with a lone rear guard sentinel, sped out of the angry, storm-lashed sky across the field.

Striking barbers today came to blows with "scabs" they were trying to drive from Paris and suburban shops that have remained open. A few eyes were blackened and some material damage was done in scuffles when groups of strikers parading along some of the main boulevards "went after" establishments trying to operate as open shops in defiance of the union.
Behind the four-hit hurling of Claude Walck, the Montclair State Teachers College defeated Wagner College of Staten Island, 6 to 1, yesterday at Gaymes Hill, S. I.

Members of the New York Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy will hold a card party and tea Tuesday in the Florentine Room of Schrafft's, 220 West Fiftyseventh Street, for the benefit of the charitable fund of the organization and the fund for the new organ to be installed in the Lee Memorial Chapel. Lexington. Va.

(Figures in Parentheses Indicate Par) Brookville (72) --Medal play handicap, Class A: G. R. Duryea, 85--14-71; D. P. Seaman, 81-7-74; H. B. Allen, 83-8-75; M. Ryan, 89-14-75; George Meredith, 838-75. Class B: H. H. Coop, 92-22-70; R. McNaughton, 87-16-71.

IN the Springtime the Boy Scouts of many communities are busily engaged in lending a hand in municipal "Spring cleaning." They arm themselves with shovels, rakes and pointed sticks, and then head for vacant lots and roadsides to rid them of untidy boxes, papers, barrels and other refuse.

Norman H. Davis returned from London yesterday expressing pleasure at the outcome of the world sugar conference and optimistic over diminishing political tension among European nations. He returned on the United States liner Manhattan with the staff who accompanied him to London as the United States delegate to the conference.

Senate foes of the Roosevelt bill to reorganize the Federal Judiciary appeared much pleased today at the President's decision to fight for his original plan without compromise. Those who expressed their views, on and off the record, included Senators who want to defeat any enlargement of the Supreme Court and others who would accept a compromise, adding perhaps two justices.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced yesterday the names of student officers in the various undergraduate divisions for 1937-38. Elections were held recently at the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance;
THE fine antique displayed in museums and historical shrines has become a potent source of Inspiration to designers and manufacturers.

Committees representing the children's and infants' knitwear division of the National Knitted Outerwear Association and the National Retail Dry Goods Association will meet on Tuesday afternoon to discuss the fair trade practice rules of the knitwear group, which are now in effect.

An agreement between the Eastern Steamship Company and officials of the National Maritime Union ended a series of strikes late last night and permitted the last two of the ships that had been held up, the New York and the freighter Wilton, to sail more than five hours late.

Eddie Baker, 36, a light-heavyweight wrestler, failed to budge from the canvas after he had been pinned by his opponent, Roy Welsh of Jackson, Tenn., here last night. Eight hundred fans shouted for the match to continue. A physician was called.

Michigan's powerful track team routed Illinois, 92 to 39, today, winning thirteen out of fifteen events. The Illini won only the 220-yard dash, with Bob Ashley first and Bob Grieve second, and the high jump, with Lowell Spurgeon the victor.

Postmaster General Farley officiated yesterday at the opening of a new $1,032,273 postoffice in the Bronx. The building occupies a square block and fronts on the Grand Concourse between 149th and 150th Streets. Others participating in the ceremony included Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York and Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx. About 4,000 were present.

A FEW years ago fashions in garden books ran to handy volumes, covering a small portion of the horticultural field-something which could be purchased at a modest cost by the' amateur to answer his need of the moment.
Dr. and Mrs. Henry J. Noerling of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Alberta Noerling, to Royal L. O'Day Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Royal L. O'Day of Industry.

Plans were filed in Manhattan during the first four months of 1937 for 116 new buildings to cost $12,586,700, as compared with eightyseven, at a cost -of $7,110, 700 in the same -period of 1936, according to Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings.

Dr. Paul S. Havens, Princeton graduate, Rhodes scholar, professor and author, will be inaugurated as president of Wilson College next week. The inaugural program will begin Friday with a conference, "Looking Forward in Education," at which Dr. Mary Emma Woolley, retiring president of Mount Holyoke College;

The new United States Postoffice Building, to house Station D, on the northeast corner of Fourth Avenue and Eleventh Street, will be formally opened tomorrow at 11:30 A. M. It will replace the old home of the branch station on the southwest corner of Thirteenth Street and Fourth Avenue, which was closed yesterday.

That athletic ability may be developed in students of high scholarship by expert coaching in a college which does not make a practice of subsidizing athletes is evidenced by the fact that six of the thirteen seniors elected to Phi Beta Kappa at Amherst College this year have figured

According to "obedience tests" held in the last year, the poodle is the most intelligent of pure-bred dogs, the American Kennel Club has announced. The club is the governing body for shows and registering of pedigreed dogs in this country.

The stock market was lower on the week in quiet trading, bonds were off irregularly, and, for the sixth consecutive week, commodity prices were easier. Developments of the week removed few, if any, of the perplexities that beset traders.

Mrs. S. Maguire Wheeler of Forest Hills, Queens, at a reception yesterday at her home, announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sara Rosalie Wheeler, to J. Edward Hessian, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hessian, also of Forest Hills.

In the presence of an enthusiastic horse show following of nearly 10,000, the grand championship of the threegaited saddle-horse division of the annual Atlantic City Horse Show tonight was awarded to the brilliant bay gelding Fiery Crags, owned by the Dixiana Farm of Charles T. Fisher of Lexington, Ky., and ridden by his daughter, Miss Mary Fisher.

THE first American exhibition of paintings and drawings by a young Spanish artist, Esteban Vicente, now resident in New York, is being held through May at the KleemannGalleries. All are products of the last two years and the storm that has broken over his native land is not reflected in the work.

The Piermont Construction Company, builder of the two six-story apartment houses at 65 Montague Street and 20 Pierrepont Street in the Heights section of Brooklyn, has sold the structures to a syndicate headed by John Avrutis.

With outside markets steadier and reports from foreign sources that recent commodity liquidation appeared to have spent its force, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and ended with gains of 8 to 14 points.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, announced yesterday that the 300th anniversary of the purchase of Governors Island from the Indians would be celebrated from June 13 to 20 by a series of exercises at the army post.

ABONS--Isaac (Isidore), beloved husband of Anna, devoted father of Jack. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St.-Amsterdam Ave., Tuesday, May 18, at 10 A. M. AYERS-William B., at his home, Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., Sunday evening, May 16. Notice of services later.

An audience of modest proportions assembled at the Little Theatre last night. to see Alexander Gavrilov, formerly of the Diaghileff Ballet, in recital with Ada Verowa, who had not been previously seen here.
Foreign oil concerns operating in Mexico are expected to offer voluntarily tomorrow a pay rise of 3,000,000 pe'sos a year to about 17,000 employes, government sources said tonight.
Reports reaching here from Gospic indicate extreme tension in that district following a recent olash between gendarmes and peasants in which six of the latter were killed.

The following forecast for fishing and boating parties was issued yesterday by the local Weather Bureau: Near-by Coastal Waters-Modrate shifting winds increasing today; overcast, probably light showers.

Wade Millman had the time of his life today preaching his own "funeral sermon." Without a collar and tie, and wearing a striped shirt and an unpressed suit, the 88-year-old farmer reached a climax with a squeakily sung solo, "When the roll is called up-yonder I'll be there."

Professor IrvingFisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.7, which compares with 93.3 the week before, 93.5 two weeks before, 93.8 three weeks before, 94.3 four weeks before, and 94.5 five weeks before.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 91 per cent of capacity, down one point from the rate of the preceding week because of labor troubles.

One thousand war veterans, attending a joint memorial service in the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, 341 West Forty-second Street, were warned yesterday that a new enemy, in the form of communistic influences, threatened the welfare of this country.

New York's public employment offices found jobs in private industry for 19,223 persons in April, an increase of 37.8 per cent over the same month in 1936, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced today.

Four simultaneous rallies sponsored by the Brooklyn Diocesan Union of the Holy Name Society in Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties yesterday afternoon attracted 60,000 members to parade formations and religious ceremonies that lasted until sundown.
The Journal des Nations today published the last of the texts of the answers of fourteen governments to the League of Nations' inquiry on the application of sanctions.

A six-foot boat laden with flowers was cast adrift on the Hudson River yesterday by members of the Ella Bixby Tent 18 of the Daughters of Veterans of the Civil War. The launching was part of the twenty-seventh annual memorial service held by that organization in honor of the soldier and sailor dead at the Recreation Pier, 129th Street and the Hudson River.

Despite the effort of a policeman to catch her' plunging body after two other policemen had vainly attempted to dissuade her from jumping, an unidentified woman committed suicide early yesterday morning by leaping from the Boerum Place elevated station." in Brooklyn to the street, .fifty feet below.
The threat of strikes that might begin before the week ends hung tonight over the heads of five of the biggest independent operators in the steel industry.

Senator Bridges of New Hampshire and Representative Case of South Dakota discussed labor relations and social security, respectively, tonight over a Columbia network in the third of a series of Republican broadcasts.

Although scoring victories in all five matches, Czechoslovakia's Davis Cup tennis team officially defeated Poland by only 4 to 1 in their European zone play by using a substitute in one of today's final singles contests.

The Very Rev. Allen Evans Jr., new dean of the Philadelphia Divinity School, announced faculty appointments today at the Protestant Episcopal institution, which will begin operating under a new educational plan in October.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on exhibition this morning the first part of the collection of Japanese art given to the museum by Howard Mansfield, a member of its board of trustees.

Prices of lard here had a good advance last week on short covering and a little better consumptive demand. Stocks continued unusually heavy, although cut down moderately. Hogs advanced, affecting prices of lard in the closing days of the week.

More than 700,000 adults in the United States have been taught to read and write during the past four years and illiteracy has been reduced by at least one-sixth through the programs of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration and the Works Progress Administration, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator. announced today.

Armed police. supported by troops, guarded the Nelson Pillar in the heart of Dublin today as authorities apparently feared an attempt to blow it up. The pillar, 134 feet high and surmounted by a statue of Britain's sea hero, Admiral Lord Nelson, is a famous landmark on O'Connell Street.
Against a background of 50,000 multicolored tulips, manikins displayed Summer costumes to more than 3,000 persons who attended the second annual Tulip Festival at Tudor City yesterday afternoon.

The only murder ever committed in the Paris subway was baffling police investigators tonight. Mrs. Laetitia Touraux, 30 years old, a striking Italian beauty, was found dying in a first-class coach with a stiletto buried deep in the back of her neck. Otherwise the coach was empty.

The biggest crowd in the long history of baseball in this city today saw the Yankees hammer out their second straight victory over Connie Mack's young Athletics and nudge the Mackmen right out of the lead in the American League pennant chase.
Bernard Pearlman, L. I. U. pitcher, drove in the two runs that gave the Blackbirds a 2-1 victory over Boston College before a crowd of 4,000 at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

Magistrate S. Edgar Bromberger, former Deputy Sanitation- Commissioner, who begins his new work on the bench this morning, bade farewell yesterday to 4,800 employes of the department at the sixth annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the Department of Sanitation in Brooklyn and Queens.

Steel production in Great Britain in April amounted to 1,080,400 tons, or 29,100 under the high record of 1,109,500 tons turned out in March, and probably will expand further because of the measures taken to meet the shortage of raw materials.

The vivacious Paula Wesseley, last seen here in "Masquerade in Vienna," is back at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse in another amusing Viennese romance, this being "Episode," which won her the Venice International Exposition's gold cup for the world's best performance in 1935.

Sir David -McCowan, marine insurance broker and director of many oil and other companies, died yesterday at the age of 77. He was created a baronet in 1934. In his younger days Sir David played for five years on Scottish international rugby teams.

The Rev. Dr. Gustav Carstensen, rector emeritus of the Holyrood Episcopal Church, l79th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, returned to his old church yesterday morning as guest preacher to speak on the significance of Whitsunday and trace the historical interpretations of the Incarnation from the beginning of Christianity.

Opposition to the entry of the BiitishAmerican Tobacco Company into Colombia has raised questions of fair treatment of foreign capital for development of natural resources and nationalistic economic isolation.

British trade is maintaining its high level, imports in April amounting to [Pound]82,870,898, against [Pound]82,691,379 in the preceding month and [Pound]66,663,627 in April 1936. The main increases were in foodstuffs and raw materials. Imports for the first four months of this year, at [Pound]14,340,000, were larger.

J. T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways System, announced last night that final preparations have been made for the start before June 1 of the first series of experimental transport flights between the United States and. Bermuda.

Roy J. Straley of Eggertsville, N. Y., one of the Class C amateur entrants in the Albany-to-New York outboard motorboat marathon, was pulled out of the Hudson River off Hastings about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. His craft, Riptide, sprang a leak in midriver and swamped.

A total of 514 athletes from thirtytwo colleges have been named for the sixty-first annual intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium May 28 and 29, James A. Taylor, I. C. 4-A secretary, announced yesterday after the close of entries.

More than 200 rare violins covered by insurance exceeding $2.000,000 were displayed here today at the opening of an exposition commemorating the 200th anniversary of the death of Antonio Stradivari, master violin maker.

The first chapter in the eventful history of "The Eternal Road," one of the costliest modern stage spectacles, was brought to a close at the Manhattan Opera House, with yesterday afternoon's performance taking the form of a testimonial to Meyer W. Weisgal.

The fifty-five-piece orchestra of Port Washington High School, victorious in a national high school orchestra contest in Columbus, Ohio, returned home this afternoon to receive an enthusiastic welcome from the townspeople.
Charles E. Jackson, supreme judge of the Hook, Line and Sinker Club, today came to the defense of tall fishing stories.

When a Cape Cod captain weds a girl from the Antipodes, long voyages should not be too surprising. Anyhow, it accounts for the departure Monday of the Gloucester fishing schooner Henrietta on the. first leg of a 15,000-mile voyage to Australia.

En route to the meeting of the International Olympic Committee at Warsaw from June 6 to 12, Count Michimaha Soyeshima of Japan Frank paused in New York yesterday. The Japanese member of the I. O. C. revealed the tremendous importance of the coming conference as he touched briefly on Tokyo's plans for 1940.
The Baltimore Sun celebrated today its 100th birthday by announcing in a front-page box headed "1837-1937":
John Little of Wilkinsburg, National Adjutant General and State Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, died today in a hospital of pneumonia. His age was 92.

Transatlantic travel in the first four months of the year has increased nearly 30 per cent over the volume in the corresponding period of last year, and bookings and applications for space for the next few months indicate that the improvement will continue throughout the Summer.
The Roosevelt Medal for 1937 will be awarded to Dr. James Hardy Dillard, Southern educator, James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association, announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Leonard Smithers, of Maplewood have sent out invitations to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Winifred Smithers, and Wallace Petrie Coons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd B. Coons of South Orange. The ceremony will take place on May 29 in Morrow Memorial Church here.

A spiritual regeneration is necessary if we are to end war and solve the problems of this hard-pressed generation, the Rev. Dr. Richard H. L. Sheppard of London said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Dr.
The annual report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation for 1936, issued for publication today, presents a comprehensive survey of the public utility situation in the Tennessee Valley;

The buzz of diplomatic conversation in London following the. coronation is reminiscent of similar confabs just two years ago, when the statesmen of. Eu rope and the British dominions assembled for the jubilee of George V. At that time the talk was all of European settlement.

The United States liner American Skipper, arriving today from Liverpool and Belfast has among her passengers Mrs. August F. Schmitthenner, Colonel and Mrs. Bryce W. Cowan, T. W. Caulfield, John Darby, Henry Wattfield Jr., Robert Torrey Hull. Miss A. F. Banwell, Stewart A. Friar, W. D. Andrews and Mrs. Eleanor Bell.
German pig iron output in April was 1,306,200 tons, against 1,303,900 in March. Because of the shortage of steel, dwelling-house construction has fallen sharply.

Marking the introduction of twenty-onepassenger Douglas DC-3 planes on its New York-to-Washington and New York-to-New Orleans routes, Eastern Air Lines yesterday flew a "pre-inaugural" non-stop flight to New Orleans and return.

The seventeenth annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America will begin here tomorrow with 325 delegates from all parts of the country prepared to consider continuing a policy which prohibits the leagues from taking sides on controversial issues.

The Bank of France's report for May 7 shows an increase of 412,000,000 francs in bills discounted, but loans against securities and bonds fell 144,000,000 francs in the week. Circulation dedined 194,000,000 francs and current accounts rose 431,000,000 francs, while the Treasury account declined 886,000,000 francs.
After ten weeks of hearings, -public debates and heated discussions in executive session, President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan is due to come before the Senate for. action this week.

Criticism of the present Congress is contained in a report which will be released today to subscribers by the Tax Research Institute of America, Inc. "In the place of a coordinated legislative policy in Washington, Congressional and administrative proposals are now just so many manuscripts in a maelstrom" the report reads in part.

Marking the end of the first week of their sit-down strike, employes of the La Favorite Rubber Manufacturing Company on Wagaraw Road, this borough, held religious services this morning in the factory.

Frank C. Cooper of 554 West 148th Street, who retired in 1933 as head of the information bureau of the District Attorney's office, with which he had been associated for thirty years, died Saturday in the Mount Eden Hospital, Bronx, after a three months' illness of a kidney ailment. He was 77 years old.

A gasoline station attendant used a novel weapon early yesterday in frustrating a hold-up attempt by an 18-year-old messenger boy. The attendant squirted gasoline from a pump into the boy's face, blinding him temporarily and confusing him so that a policeman subdued him easily.

A petition to Governor Lehman requesting him to hold a public hearing before he signs the Doyle-Neustein bill creating a State labor relations commission, patterned after the National Labor Relations Board was made yesterday by the New York Board of Trade. The bill in question is referred to as "the little Wagner act."

Two alumni of La Salle Academy, Cardinal Hayes and Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, returned to their alma mater yesterday afternoon for the dedication of the new $300,000 fivestory brick building at 44 East Second Street which has been housing the school since March.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American -News Company, Bloomingdaleis, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanmaker's and Womrath's:

Trinity Church observed Whitsunday yesterday afternoon with the fifteenth annual service of the Trinity Choir Alumni Association, more than 100 former members of the choir marching in the procession in addition to the present choir. A feature of the service was the singing of three hymns composed by former organists of the church.

Christians are not accepting the challenge of the Cross when they shirk the responsibility of undoing wrongs they see, declared the Rev. Jule Ayers, the assistant pastor, at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, yesterday morning.

A service of praise and thanksgiving in recognition of the British coronation was held this morning at St. Paul's Episcopal Church of East Chester, one of the oldest churches in America and for almost a century under jurisdiction of London Bishops.

A notable relaxation of tension and apprehension over the international situation is becoming evident here. Soviet officials and the press continue warning the country to be ready for war at any moment and the hunt for spies and saboteurs is being carried on with unabated vigor.

World, national and personal "pressures" inherent in the complexities of modern life were held responsible for the difficulty of leading a Christian life today by the Rev. Dr. Lloyd E. Foster, pastor of Calvary Church, East Orange, N. J., in an address delivered yesterday at the fifth day of the session of the New York East conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Calling the Hindenburg disaster "an act of God" reveals a primitive conception of God that is not in accord with the teachings of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Finis S. Idleman said yesterday in his sermon at the Central Christian Church, 142 West Eighty-first Street.

The Shore Shop, Asbury Park, of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, will be opened May 26 for its third season on the boardwalk. The annual three-day convention of the National Association of Floor Distributors will begin today at the Hotel Commodore. Scheduled speakers are L. J. Schumaker, president of the American Bakers Association, and Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America.

"There is nothing more difficult than to maintain a belief in the supernatural, and that is the challenge of Whitsunday," the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, the pastor, said in his sermon yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.

The engagement of Miss Jane R. Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton F. Stern of 88 Central Park West, to Lawrence Marx Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Marx of New Rochelle, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.
The three-story taxpayer at 625 Bergenline Avenue, corner of Sixteenth Street, West New York, N. J., was sold by the Unison Realty Company to a syndicate headed by John Avrutis.

W. A. Winterbottom, vice president and general manager of R. C. A. Communications, Inc., announced yesterday that the company has filed a new schedule of reduced rates for domestic night letters with the Federal Communications Commission.

The number of unemployed in Germany on April 30 was put today at 961,000, against 1,763,000 on the same date in 1936. It is declared officially that there is no genuine unemployment in Germany, as 300,000 of the total of idle comprise persons not fully fit for work, while 300,000 to 500,000 more are workless only for short terms while changing their employment.
A frog from the ranch of the late Will Rogers at Oologah, Okla., set a new world record of 13 feet 5 inches today in winning the ninth annual jumping frog jubilee of Calaveras County.
A plan to raise $10,000,000 for the American Museum of Natural History, at Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street, was announced today by F. Trubee Davison, president of the museum.

The program of American choral music from the pre-Revolutionary period to the present day, which was given earlier this month at the WPA Theatre of Music by the Madrigal Singers, under Lehman Engel, will be repeated tonight at 8:30 o'clock in the same auditorium.
Peace reigned along the water front yesterday as a result of an agreement reached late Saturday night between the Eastern Steam ship Lines anil the National Maritime Union.
Two electrical musical instruments of novel design will "pinch-hit" for the French horn and the bass clarinet in a concert of the Swarthmore Symphony Orchestra on Thursday night.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following. tabulation:
"Although kings are now regarded as negligible in affairs of government, I had sooner rub my forehead in the dust before King George VI than say one 'Hell Hitler!' I had rather wave the flag

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Charles Whittemore Knapp of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phoebe Whittemore Knapp, to James Burband Knowles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Knowles of Rye, N. Y.

Abraham A. Brown, former head of the Brown Method Company, 216 Fourth Avenue, and well known in the textile industry, died yesterday at the Wickersham Hospital of a heart attack. He was 67 years old. Mr. Brown was a member of the Jewish Center and was on the advisory committee of the Daughters of Jacob.

The Italian press was instructed today to ease up on its anti-British campaign. No further aggressive attacks are to be made and neither are any -anti-British polemics published in other countries to be reprinted, the instructions said.

Definite evidence of bad moral conditions has been found in six Brooklyn high schools as a result of the investigation he launched last week, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan declared yesterday.

MADRID--Premier Largo Caballero gave up efforts to form a new Cabinet at Valencia. Communists objected to his plan to take the war portfolio. A defense council, to conduct the Loyalist operations in the civil war, was urged. Page 1.
Adoption of up-to-date business methods in the city license department has clearly shown that the efforts of the Fusion administration have had results and can be of service to the public. Paul Moss.

A highly mixed situation in the world's wheat markets has caused much uneasiness on the part of the trade, with resultant sharp price fluctuations. -Current and future supplies have come in for more attention. Bulges, especially in wheat, have run into liberal selling and price reactions, while declines have met good support when needed.

The United States Cane Sugar Refiners Association, alarmed over the possibility that Congress might increase the refined sugar quotas of island producers, made public today a pamphlet outlining the opposition of the domestic refiners against such a course.

A sharp increase in Italy's imports, contrasting with Premier Benito Mussolini's prediction that the nation will make herself economically selfsufficient, was reflected in March figures announced today.

Stretching twenty-three hits into thirty-eight bases, the Montreal Royals took both ends of a doubleheader today from the Syracuse Chiefs, 12-6 and 8-4, and stepped into third place in the International League.

A rumor that Sweden may leave the sterling bloc is reviving fears here concerning the future of gold, since any raising of the krona's value might be far-reaching in effect and influence the United States gold policy, as the City does not dismiss the likelihood that President Roosevelt would lower the gold price as a check to rising commodities.

It was the provinces' turn today to enjoy the sights of London bedecked for the coronation. "Whitsun" bank holiday tomorrow brought hundreds of thousands by excursion train, bus and private cars to view the decorations and walk over the six miles of the procession route.

Governor Lehman has been asked by the Public Education Association to veto the Feld bill giving the Superintendent of Schools power to determine the nature and scope of all examinations, and the Steingut bill designed to bring substitute teachers into the service by preferential qualifying examinations, it was announced yesterday by Howard W. Nudd, director of the association.

Forty-nine children, members of the Temple Emanu-El Religious School, were confirmed yesterday morning before a congregation of more than 2,000 parents and friends at the temple, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Plans for the construction in Washington of a $4,000,000 building to be known as the National Capital Club, for the use of legislators, government administrators, foreign representatives and leading American industrial executives visiting the capital on private or official business, were announced yesterday afternoon by Philip D. Slingluff.

A 36-year-old Down Faster and family man with two small children back home in East Weymouth, on the edge of Massachusetts Bay, who can help him spend the prize money and keep the trophies shined, won the tenth annual Albany-to-New York outboard marathon yesterday without knowing it.

Violence broke out anew in the eightweeks strike at the Colonial Press, Inc., here today when two men were beaten and workers housed in a hotel near the plant opened fire with shotguns to repel a crowd bombarding the place with stones. No arrests were made.
A lively and vigorous performance of Bizet's "Carmen" given by the Hippodrome Opera Company last night at the Hippodrome was heard by an intensely demonstrative gathering of 3,500 persons.

The group of patriotlo organizations which has been seeking an appointment with President Roosevelt-since April 16 to present a protest- against his court reorganization plan has been growing steadily and now has more than 1,000,000 members,

The body of a 7-year-old girl whose throat had been cut and whose body had been burned in an unsuccessful effort to destroy it was found this afternoon by a young couple wandering in the woods 100 yards east of this village and barely 175 feet north of the heavily traveled Montauk Highway.
Walter Damrosch's "The Man Without a Country" will be given for a second time at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight. The National Institute of Immigrant Welfare will benefit by the performance.

Federal, State and city officials have been invited to attend a conference Wednesday evening in the Hotel Commodore of the Vigilance Committee of the Construction Industry, which for eight months has been engaged in research for the purpose of elevating construction standards and protecting the public from shoddy and dishonest building.

More than a thousand young women training to be nurses attended last night a service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in memory of Florence Nightingale and all nurses who have died in service. The young women wore their uniforms and their white caps made a white field of the transepts, in which they sat.

While 40,000 spectators watched the Langhorne Inaugural Sweepstakes late this afternoon a racing car driven by Frank Bailey, 24 years old,. prominent dirt. track driver, threw a tire, precipitating an accident which took three lives and resulted in serious injuries to four others.

Nine persons were injured last night in the most serious accident since the opening of the Triborough Bridge. An ice truck with a crowd of merrymakers from a picnic and a bus sidewiped on the crest of the span over the East River.

More than 300 children danced and sang yesterday afternoon at the annual May festival of the Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street. Like the settlement's six previous festivals, it was chiefly Elizabethan in character, but it differed from the others in that this year Queen Elizabeth got a glimpse of the future.
Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Dr. FREDERICK M. ALLEN which makes out the best possible case for a continuance of medical research along the traditional lines.
Stockholders of the Messer Oil Corportion of Bolivar, N. Y., today of approved a merger with the Oil Valley Producing Corporation of Olean in a new company to be capitalized at $3,875,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The great majority of, physicians who disagree with your recent editorials and correspondence regarding organization of both medical research and practice have doubtless been deterred from replying by their knowledge of' the complexity of the subject.

High-goal poloists saw action in two Meadow Brook Club members' matches today on fields at the J. S. Phipps estate, with teams headed by Stewart B. Iglehart and G. H. (Pete) Bostwick registering victories.

Prices fell generally on the Bourse this week despite a firmer government attitude on spending, and the recovery which followed the end-of-April settlement has been wiped out as a result. Bull commitments were not so thoroughly liquidated as was thought.

William Worth Sisson, Binghamton merchant, who had been associated with the Sisson Brothers, Welden Company for fifty-three years until his retirement in 1920, died here yesterday at the age of 86. Grandchildren and great-grandchildren are the only survivors.
Sitting in sunny Seward Park, listening to an amateur orchestra, a thousand men and women thought back yesterday afternoon to the time when they had lived in the neighborhood.

Representative William P. Connery Jr. declared in an address here tonight that the House Labor Committee, of which he is chairman, would report favorably "with Presidential approval" a bill which would provide an $18 minimum wage and 35-hour week for the textile industry throughout the country.

Rivals for the No. 2 singles berth on the United States Davis Cup tennis team, Frankie Parker and Bryan (Bitsy) Grant battled two sets and a part of a third without reaching a decision in an exhibition match at the Merion Cricket Club today.

Although conceding two goals, the First Division poloists routed the Governors Island Blues, 13 to 8, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn. The home squad, in gaining its second triumph in as many starts, wrested the advantage late in the first period on a pair of goals each by Major J. A. Nichols and John Wallace, then set the pace until the finish.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Claire Rowe, daughter of Mrs. E. Eddy Rowe of this city and Samuel Davis Rowe of Chicago, to James Edward Hosac, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wirt Edward Hosac of Bronxville, N. Y.

The caustic tongue of PHILIP SNOWDEN will never again be heard in Westminster. He was the last and most brilliant of the Free Traders and fought until ill health stilled his voice against the abandonment of Britain's traditional tariff policy.

Governor Nice announced tonight he would appoint William P. Lawson, chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, as Police Commissioner of Baltimore to succeed Charles D. Gaither, whose appointment. expires May 31.

After a winding chase through the streets of the lower East Side and over the Brooklyn Bridge to Brooklyn, during which nine shots were fired and a pedestrian injured, four young men in a sedan were arrested early this morning by the two motorcycle policemen who had pursued them for half an hour.

A recovery in short-distance passenger traffic, reversing a trend which has prevailed generally among the railroads in recent years, was recorded in the report of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad for 1936.
Announcement was made today of the receipt by Drew University of two substantial bequests from the estate of Lenox S. Rose, long a Madison resident, who died April 24 in Florida.

The Investors Advisory Council of the Dennison Manufacturing Company has approved the plan of recapitalization of the company submitted to it by the management, according to a letter mailed on Saturday to security holders. Carl P. Dennett heads the council.
The Spanish Government has denied offinally that Professor Jose Robles of Johns Hopkins University ever was imprisoned in Spain and has disclaimed any knowledge of his whereabouts.

The Rev. Dr. John Alexander Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, delivered the baccalaureate sermon in Miller Chapel this afternoon, opening the 125th annual commencement exercises of the seminary.

Miss Dorothy Hoffman Neely, daughter of Mrs. Charles Hoffman Neely of this place and the late Mr. Neely, has selected June 4 for her marriage to Wilton Snowden Burton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger O. Burton, also of Bronxville, in Christ's Episcopal Church here.

A pinch single by Eric McNair that scored Jimmy Foxx gave the Red Sox a 6 to 5 twelve-inning triumph over the Senators today before 16,000 fans. The Sox hopped on Monte Weaver for three runs in the second, on four hits, a fielder's choice and an error.

Flying in perfect formation and with clocklike precision, four of the army's great "flying fortress" bombing planes flew over eighteen cities on a 1,700-mile route today, and returned to this station ten hours thirty-five minutes from the time they left this morning.
The United Automobile Workers "don't expect any resistance" in starting a drive this week to unionize Ford plants, Homer Martin, president, declared today.

The Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker warned in his Whitsunday message to the congregation of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street yesterday morning that the "greatest danger in this nation today is that, in our united efforts to care for the needs of all we breed a race of rightssnatchers instead of a race of responsibility carriers."

Sam Snead, West Virginia exmountaineer, discovered today that the race is not always to the swift, especially in golf. For a time the latest sensation to appear on the golfing horizon threatened to make a one-man dash out of the traditional metropolitan open championship. Then came the deluge on Friday, washing out Sam's sensational 65 and giving his rivals a chance to catch Up..

The Maritime Commission today invited bids for charter for a period of one year of six government-owned steamship lines which are now being operated for the commission by four managing agents. The six lines operate thirty-seven vessels on trade routes. A bond of $10,000 for each ship is required.

Joe Bowman gained his fifth victory of the season today for the leagueleading Pirates when he held the Cardinals to six hits to triumph by 2-1. Thousands of fans who wanted to see the first Sunday game of the season here were turned away from Forbes Field.

As a sort of tryout preparatory to an attempt to launch an Italian repertory theatre here next Fall, the Italian Drama Guild, an organization made up largely of promising amateurs reinforced by some professional actors, presented "L'Ora di Diana" ("Diana's:Hour") to a fair-sized audience at the Comedy Theatre Saturday night.

Chicago's spurting White Sox closed their fortnight's home stand today with six victories and five defeats by reaching Ivy Paul Andrews for four runs in the eighth and a 6-to-4 victory over Cleveland.

The Boerse began the week in quiet fashion, but sentiment was depressed by Farbenindustrie's report referring to the need of capital by industry, from which it was deduced that dividends would be kept down.

The "most unkind" thing a parent can do is to make things easy for his child, the Rev. Dr. Malcolm J. MacLeod, retired pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, declared yesterday in a sermon delivered at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

HARRY L. HOPKINS, the Federal Works Progress Administrator, had prepared a thirteen-page speech on "Unemployment and Education" to deliver in this city, but when the time came to speak he ignored his prepared address and made some impromptu remarks. -Some of these remarks, as reported, were extremely interesting:
The Newark Bears strengthened their hold on first place today by taking a double-header from the Bisons,. 7-4 and 4-3, the second time they have turned the trick in two days.
The Festival Symphony Orchestra tra, under Eugene Plotnikoff, gave a concert at the WPA Theatre of Music last night which was attended by a large and enthusiastic audience.

The promotion of fifteen scholars to full membership in Princeton University's chapter of the Sigma Xi, national honorary scientific society, along with the election of fortyeight students and undergraduates to associate membership, was announced today by Professor Louis A. Turner of the physics department, secretary of the Princeton chapter.

The average American's steadily increasing demand for comfort and health in his daily life is "the foundation of the country's fastest growing industry," J. A. Harlan of Detroit, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation executive and newly elected president of the Air-Conditioning

With the taking of testimony from a score or more of miner witnesses already accomplished, the Department of Commerce inquiry into the cause of the Hindenburg disaster will be more definitely pointed when sessions are resumed tomorrow.

Partners of the old firm of Hickey, Doyle Co. will announce today the formation of two new firms, both of which will conduct a general trading business in unlisted securities and act as underwriters and distributors of new securities.

It is reported in financial circles here that if continued exports of capital make it difficult to maintain the present level of exchange for the franc, the government may have recourse to some such expedient as a monopoly of foreign exchange dealings rather than to a fresh devaluation of the currency.
