The Financial News index of thirty industrial stocks, based on July 1 as 100, on May 13, stood at 114.3, compared with 116.3 a week before, 116.5 a month ago and 111.4 a year ago.

Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Fauver of Middletown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Fay Fauver, to Dr. Ralph F. Bischoff of the Department of Government of Wesleyan University in Middletown.

Forty-seven lots, fronting 700 feet on Junction Boulevard, Sixtysecond Road and Sixty-second Drive, Elmhurst, L. I., have been resold by the Hajada Realty Corporation to a Manhattan investor, who is making his first venture in the Queen market.

Federal officials announced late tonight that John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization had won the right to bargain collectively for shoe workers in three of nineteen Lewiston-Auburn factories involved in a general strike.

Turning a singularly deaf ear to the very frantic knocking of opportunity on the door, the Giants ended their home stand at the Polo Grounds yesterday by bowing to the Phillies, and by way of showing their utter disdain for opportunity's behests, they did it with emphasis, losing, 6 to 0, their second shutout of the year.

Governor Hoffman and Senator A. Harry Moore were the principal speakers this afternoon at the sixth annual conference of the Morris County Youth Council at the Ogden Memorial Presbyterian Church here. The council is composed mainly of church societies in five .districts of the county.

Dr. John Ernest Borland, organist and composer, who last week received the King's coronation medal in recognition of his part in arranging. the Westminster Abbey musical program, died yesterday at the age of 71.

Dr. Harry Timbres, formerly a resident of Baltimore, died of typhus Wednesday at Marbumstroy, near Kazan, Russia. He had been stationed there since the Spring of 1936 by the Russian Government as assistant in malarial research.
The loss of a pair of jewelled clips valued at $3,000 by Mrs. Davies Thacher of New York and Glen Cove, L. I., was revealed yesterday by detectives of the Flushing precinct.
Japan's Second geisha strike in three months began today with a walkout in Asahigawa of 150 girls, the entire geisha population of that important garrison town of the northern Island of Hokkaido.

Neville Chamberlin, Chancellor of the Exchequer, has slipped away to spend the Whitsun holidays in trout fishing and at the same time in making some of the most important decisions of his political life.

Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby's chestnut gelding Easter Morning won the lion's share of the honors for his young Bedford Hills (N. Y.) owner at the fifth annual Rockwood Hall Horse Show at the Washington Irving Country Club today.

Auerbach, Pollak Richardson, members of the New York Stock Exchange, have announced that Winston L. May and Walter Hochstadter, formerly partners of the firm of W. J. Wollman Co., which was dissolved on Saturday,

The outlook for the security markets here remains obscured by many factors, not the least being the uncertainty about gold, while at the same time the position of labor and the knowledge that much wreckage from the recent slump still is floating around are causing uneasiness.
The Social Science Research Council, 230 Park Avenue, announced yesterday grants totaling more than $100,000 to eighty-three scholars for research in this country, Canada and several foreign nations.
A "red herring" prospectus, detailing plans for the annual field day of the Bond Club of New York on June 4 at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, has been sent to members of the club.

A two-run attack in the eighth inning, coming after "St. John's University of Brooklyn had tied the score at 2-all in its half of' the frame, enabled the New York Athletic Club nine to gain a 4-to-2 decision over the Redmen at Travers Island yesterday.
The Chief of National Archives has discovered a file labeled "various curious papers," dating from 1524, in his search of the archives of various colonial towns.
United States Attorney Lamar Hardy has announced the appointment of two Assistant United States Attorneys and one special assistant to fill vacancies on his staff.

With one out in the ninth the veteran Chick Hafey swung his war club for the first time in two years for the Reds today and, flying deep into right field, scored Cuyler with the run by which the Reds won their third game of the season from Chicago, 3 to 2.

The League of Nations Association, Inc., announced yesterday that Winsor Chase Schmidt, 17-year-old high school student of Rye, N. Y., was the winner of the first prize in the organization's eleventh annual examination contest conducted in the high schools of the country.

Mr. Cottontail Rabbit is now due for an investigation. The State College at Storrs, Conn., is conducting a study under the supervision of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey that may change some conceptions of rabbits.

With Mike Phipps, the internationalist, leading the attack with a trio of goals, the Falcons conquered the Bethpage Shamrocks, 7 to 4, today as polo made its debut for the season at the Bethpage State Park.
Anxiety is again being expressed in some quarters over the health of I Pope Pius, but.there is nothing in his condition- to justify immediate apprehension.

Schlater, Noyes Gardner, Inc., have opened a department to specialize in New York State municipal bonds. F. Lawson Benneet, I. K. Fabricand and Alfred G. Wilson are with them. Weldon Barker has joined Du Val Co.

An agreement between Cheney Brothers, silk manufacturers, of South Manchester, Conn., employing 2,500 workers, and the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate, was reached over the week-end, Sidney Hillman, chairman of the workers' committee, announced yesterday.

Waterford, 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. S. C. Register of Glen Cove, I. I., carried off the majority of the honors today in the fourth annual Oaks Hunt Horse Show staged under perfect weather conditions on the Rice Farms.

The well-known French parachutist, Andre Vassart, was killed this afternoon while participating in a local air circus in connection with the annual fair. His parachute failed to open at an altitude of 1,000 feet.

The acceptance by the Rev. Harry James Knickle, curate of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East Eighty-eighth Street, of a call to the rectorship of Grace Church, Plainfield, -N. J., was announced yesterday. He will assume his new duties the first Sunday in June.

Lessened pressure for deliveries has eased the position of steel producers, who now are able to make progress in reducing backlog, according to the magazine Steel. Buying is in satisfactory volume, though in smaller volume than shipments.
With eighty-seven gunners competing, the first annual Long Island open skeet championship was held today on the grounds of the North Shore Club at South Huntington.

Net sales of the General Motors Corporation, excluding inter-divisional transactions, amounted to $336,849,901 for the first quarter of 1937, compared with $341,306,065 for the same period of 1936, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, says in the quarterly report.

With thousands of spectators cheering him onward, 27-year-old John P. Connolly, unattached harrier, captured the first City Hallto-Coney Island modified marathon yesterday. He set a bristling pace for the field of 119 and snapped the tape in 1:15:20 2-5, almost 500 yards ahead of his closest pursuer.

Governor Blanton H. Winship late last night affixed his signature to the new Liquor Tax Law. The measure is designed to bring $2,000,000 into the insular treasury, but it probably will be challenged as unconstitutional by the Cuban rum manufacturers, Bacardi, unless the management decides to fulfill its threat to withdraw from Puerto Rico.

The struggle for leadership in the intracity competition in metropolitan college baseball circles resolved into a three-cornered race for first honors as a result of the games I played during the week, with Long Island University, Manhattan. and Fordham still very much in the running.

The committee of the Cape Cod Institute of Music met yesterday at a tea- at the home of Mrs. Ethelbert Nevin, 136 East Sixty-seventh Street, to discuss plans for the luncheon to be given under the auspices of the institute on Saturday at the Cribari Winery in the to old Chelsea district of West Twenty- Fish sixth Street. Mrs. Martha Atwood, founder and president of the institute, will preside at the forthcomins luncheon.
Government supply contracts for a total value of $3,498,298 were awarded by eleven Federal agencies during the week ended May 13, under the terms of the Public Contracts Act.

The American Prix Femina Committee has made its annual selection of three books by. American authors, one of which will be chosen to receive the Prix Femina Americain. "The Late George Apley," by J. P. Marquand, "Candie Indoors," by Helen Hull, and "All Brides Are Beautiful," by Thomas Bell, were selected.

The lightning flash of luck which comes to a sweepstakes winner momentarily played over three boys yesterday afternoon when they fished a package of currency from the Hudson River between Twentyfourth and Twenty-fifth Streets.

A belief that the ancient bar and dot system of numerals, the development of which originally was attribute to the old Mayans of Guatemala, may have been used first by the Zapotec Indians of Southwestern Mexico was expressed today by Dr. Alfonso Caso,

China is watching "with the closest interest and great anxiety" the talks now going on between Britain and Japan on the Far East, Dr. Wang Chung-hui, the Chinese Foreign Minister, said in an interview yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. John M. Loughran of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Louise Loughran, to Cadet Walter Ralls Lawson, son of Mrs. Walter Ralls Lawson of Kissimmee, Fla.,- and the late Captain Lawson, United States Army Air Corps.

Review and revision of the Equity constitution and by-laws is one of the planks in the platform of administration candidates, it was announced yesterday. Edward Fielding, chairman of the regular ticket committee, said, however, that the administration does not contemplate any wholesale changes in the constitution.

Eleven gold and thirty-nine silver King's Crown charms have been awarded to fifty Columbia students in recognition of meritorious work in non-athletic extra-curricular activities, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin A. Hubbard, director of the King's Crown Advisory Board.

Anelderly woman,, who travels in a sedan driven by a liveried chauft feur, is being sought by East Chester town police for questioning about the poisoning yesterday afternoon of four valuable dogs. Two of the animals have died and the others are seriously ill.
Two proud Brooklyn winning streaks, stretched to a tautness they could not withstand by a long eleven-inning battle with the Bees, snapped sharply today with the crack of Vince DiMaggio's bat.

The New York Public Library's open-air reading room in Bryant Park will be opened today for its third season. This experiment in the informal circulation of books, without cards or red tape, began with a short season in 1935, but had its first real season from May to November last year.

Miss Ada Forbush Dewson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Badger Dewson of this place, was married here this afternoon in the First Parish Unitarian Church-to Edward Goodridge Iselin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Iselin of The Chestnuts, Riverdale-on-Hudson, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Vivian T. Pomeroy of Milton and the Rev. Frederic J. Gauld of Cohasset, Mass.

Christianity makes no more claim upon the exercise of one's faith than does business life, home life or any other kind of life, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks said in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

The Tigers and the Browns got ten hits apiece today, but Detroit's were bunched more effectively and accounted for the final game of the series, 5 to 4, behind Roxy Lawson. Manager Mickey Cochrane juggled his batting order after the Tigers had absorbed two successive defeats from the Browns and the change worked.

An audience of 3,000 attended the annual musical of Georgian Court College here this afternoon. Miss Jessica Dragonette, soprano, was the featured artist, as she has been every year since her graduation from the college. She concluded the program by singing part of the "Star-Spangled Banner," accompanied by the college orchestra. Arpad Sandor was her accompanist for her other numbers.
This would be a perfect publishing season for the student of America if It brought us a book dealing with the social health of

The executive committee of the City Fusion party announced yesterday that it had adopted a resolution asking Governor Lehman to call a special session of the Legislature for the specific purpose of abolishing the Transit Commission because of alleged failure to carry out the mandate for unification of the city's rapid transit lines, first issued in 1921.

A total of 596,523 returns, or nearly oneeighth of the 4,666,504 Federal individual income tax returns filed in the entire United States on incomes for the 1935 calendar year, came from the five counties of New York City, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

Continuation of the economic advance in the world generally and the United States in particular despite the present relapse is predicted by the German Institute for Business Research in its quarterly review issued today.

Mr. and Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis had their initial dinner party of the season tonight at Wheelbarrow Hill Farm here. They entertained Dr. and Mrs. John Dodge Peters and their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Denison D. Dana of Englewood, N. J.
Behind the Danish enthusiasm in the celebration of the silver jubilee of their King, Christian X, there has been a good deal of solid-satisfaction with the Danish national position.

A strike of union employes at the Minneapolis mail-order plant of Sears, Roebuck Co. was settled today when committees representing the management and Local 20,316 of the Warehouse and Inside Workers Union agreed on a settlement.
The spirits of silkworms and cotton plants received the thanks today of 5,000 Buddhist worshippers and forty priests for their "sacrifices" in providing mankind with two basic commodities.

Of about 1,000,000 bushels of corn shipped recently by Argentina for Chicago, 537,000 bushels have arrived in the last week. This corn is used by processors, especially for feed making on the part of the largest industries.

Former Judge Walter Colquitt of Atlanta, Ga., died aboard a Pennsylvania train returning from Cleveland today. His age was 62. Conductor Fred Damming of Cincinnati said Mr. Colquitt complained of feeling ill as the train entered suburban Winton Place.
Horses owned by Simon Guthmann gained two major victories today. Colette Baudoche won the Poule d'essai des Pouliches (filly trials) after Bach Agha had taken the 20,000 franc Prix de Marly.

Ernest Riedel, a member of the last American Olympic canoe team, representing the Pendleton Canoe Club, carried off the laurels in the one-mile double blade event which featured the Middle Atlantic canoe championships on the , Hudson River at Dyckman Street yesterday. The event was held in conjunction with the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association races.

Cardinal Hayes called on all the members of the archdiocese of New York yesterday to observe the eightieth birthday of Pope Pius XI, which will be Monday, May 31, by attending a. mass of thanksgiving for his Pontificate, by receiving holy communion as an intention for the Pontiff and by saying a daily prayer for him.
Lieut Gin. Dmitri Horvath, leader of the White Russians in the Far East and president of the Chinese Eastern Railway in Czarist days, died here today. His age was 76.

Last week's decline on the Stock Exchange brought the averages six points lower; prices had fallen more than seventeen points since they reached the highest of this year, in March. United States bonds rose slightly early in the week, then lost the ground gained.

Miss Dorothy O'Toole, daughter of Mrs. Edward O'Toole of this city, formerly of South Orange, has chosen June 19 for her marriage to Raymond T. English, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry English of Newark. The ceremony will be performed here in Our Lady Help of Christians Chruch.
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McMorrow, who have sold their residence on Brookside Drive, Greenwich, entertained at a farewell breakfast today.

Charles H. (Cy) Pfirman, former baseball umpire in the National League, died in Baptist Hospital here today after a long illness. His age was 46. Mr. Pfirman, an umpire for twenty-six years, worked in more than 4,000 ball games.

THE WIND FROM THE MOUNTAINS, by Trygve Gulbranssen. (Putnam, $2.50.) A new novel by the author of "Beyond Sing the Woods." SOCIAL AND CULTURAL DYNAMICS. by Pitirim A. Sorokin. (American Book Company, there volumes, $6 per volume, $15 set.)

The Feast of Pentecost has special significance for the modern world, the Rev. Philip J. Furlong, Dean of the Cathedral College, declared in his sermon yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, because "western civilization had its inception on the first Pentecost, when the Holy Ghost descended upon the Apostles."

Old time troubles in the Salvation Army were recalled tonight when it became known Commissioner Henry Mapp had formally challenged the recent action of General Evangeline Booth in retiring him: from his post of chief of staff.

For the fourth time this season, Ch. Vigow of Romanoff, white and lemon borzoi (Russian wolfhound) owned and shown by Louis J. Murr of Spring Valley, N. Y., was awarded the special prize for best dog, gaining that honor in the fourteenth annual exhibition of the Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club on the Baederwood golf course today.

A rebellion has broken out in Southern Albania, it was officially admitted tonight. The government has sent military forces to the area to restore order. The rebellion is led by Ethem Toto, former Minister of the Interior, and Captain Gjyben of the army.
The Imperial Conference which is now under way in London is primarily an attempt on the part of the various States within the British Empire to strengthen their commercial and financial ties.

In the current issue of "Public Housing Progress," bulletin of the National Public Housing Conference, the latter urges unification of all forces to push through a housing bill at this session of Congress "despite hell and high water."
The seventieth anniversary of the edifice of St. John's Episcopal Church. Twenty-first Street and Forty-sixth Avenue, Long Island City, was celebrated at the morning service yesterday.

B. G. Dahlberg, president of the Celotex Corporation, announced yesterday that the board of directors at a special meeting on Saturday declared a dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock for the quarter ended on April 30,

The congregation of Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, paid tribute yesterday morning to the late Dr. George U. Wenner, who organized the group in a 'blacksmith shop on Fourteenth Street seventy years ago and was its guiding spirit for sixty-seven years.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,002,544,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

After a battle of two hours, including two extra periods of 15 minutes each, the Brooklyn Hispanos gained the final for the championship of the American Soccer League yesterday, defeating St. Mary's Celtics, 3 to 2, before 3,000 fans at Celtic Park in Brooklyn.

Repassentatives of foreign nations, high officials of the Federal Government and American business executives will cooperate throughout the coming Week, known as "Foreig Trade Week,"-to create "as more enlightened interest in the development of foreign trade and impress its importance on the economic life of the country."

President Lazaro Cardenas today informed local officials of the Federal State that they must obtain the cooperation of fathers of families in the government's sixyear plan for developing "socialistic" schools, of which the government is establishing 2,000 annually.

Standard Distributors, Inc., of 114 East Thirty-second Street, New York, and its president, Louis H. Gellar, were ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to "cease and desist" from certain unfair methods of competition.
Governor Lehman today signed the bill of Senator Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the Senate; appropriating $2,200,000 to finance the State's participation in the New York World's Fair in 1939.

Imports into the Soviet Union in 1936 jumped to about $270,507,000 from $211,443,600 in the previous year, while exports fell from $321,852,000 in 1935 to $271,820,800, 'according to an announcement of the division of regional information of the Department of Commerce.

Apparently hopelessly crippled from. infantile. paralysis and unable to read or write because he could not attend school, Henry Spiak, then 15 years old, was brought to Yonkers General Hospital twenty-one months ago -at the direction of the Westchester County Children's Court.

The American Federation of Labor, aroused by the sweeping victory of the Transport Workers Union, an affiliate of the -Committee on Industrial Organization, in the collective. bargaining referendum held on the Interborough Rapid Transit System on Saturday, is, planning a nation-wide drive for. control of labor relations on transit lines, it was disclosed yesterday.
Stocks lower in quiet trading; turnover, 5,545,920 shares. United States Government and foreign loans irregular; corporate bonds slightly lower; transactions, $46,764,100.

Waging a game, uphill struggle after yielding an early advantage, the selected New York team registered a well-earned triumph over the visiting Mayo Gaelic football fifteen, champions of all Ireland, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. A goal by Mike Moloney, late in the battle, enabled the home forces to erase their rivals' lead and go on to score a 9-7 victory over the invaders from the Emerald Isle.
The body of Miss Helen Lynovitch, 40-year-old waitress of 116 Ferris Avenue here, was found in the Bronx River, about 500 feet from the Westchester County Center Building, this morning.

A two-hit shutout pitching performance by Oscar Judd in the nightcap after Bill Walker had gained a 4-to-3 decision in the first game, enabled the Rochester Red Wings to take both ends of a twin bill from the Baltimore Orioles today. Judd's 5-to-0 triumph gave the Wings the series, three games to one.

State employes and the employes of charitable, religious, educational and other non-profit organizations should be included in the old-age benefits of the Social Security Act, it was recommended yesterday by the committee on old-age security of the Twentieth Century Fund.
B. V. Pavloff-Silvansky, Soviet army commander and one of the country's best-known experimenters with parachutes, was shot and killed today by a scared civilian sentry.

NOVEL that has an excellent chance of being A one of the most widely read books of this year is published today. It is called "The Wind from the Mountains" (Putnam, $2.50). Trygve Gulbranssen, author of "Beyond Sing the Woods," wrote it. It carries on the story of the earlier book, but, though a sequel, with many of the same characters, is complete in itself.

More than 7,000 Norwegian-Americans throughout the city attended the annual outing of the Gjoa Sporting Club at Ulmer Park, Cropsey and Twenty-fifth Avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon held in honor of the Norwegian Independence Day.

The index of industrial production in France in March was 104, compared with 103 in February and 101 in March, 1936. In the mechanical industries production was 115, against 113 in February and 100 a year ago.

Five thousand persons sat in the Greek ampitheatre of St. Elizabeth's College at Convent this afternoon and witnessed a colorful May Day celebration of students in English country dances and the crowning of the May Queen, Miss Mary Delaney of Waterbury, Conn.

THE Dog-Racing Bill comes up for a hearing in Albany today with Governor Lehman on the program as chief listener. Judging from the spirit in which some infuriated citizens are converging on Albany, any stick will do to beat a dog. But in this particular case it wasn't any stick. It was the tall, stalwart, sorrel-topped, distinguished, resolute and resonant Herbert Bayard Swope, the esteemed chairman of the State Racina Commission.

Uncle Sam's official family is larger than at any time since the World War. Civil Service Commission statistics showed 829,193 persons on Federal payrolls April 1, in addition to personnel of the legislative judicial and military branches of government. The figure includes both civil service and-non-civil service officials and workers.

In Gaviota Pass at its narrowest point, where ninety-one years ago Spanish Californians from Santa Barbara failed in an attempt to ambush Lieut. Col. John C. Fremont and his American expedition for the relief of a garrison at Los Angeles, a memorial was dedicated today.

E. M. Thomson, president of the Federal Land Bank of Springfield, Mass., told land bank presidents in conference here that the demand for frm merchage Ananoing in the distrlot comprising New England, New York and New Jersey was holding upo well that the bank was able to relend virtually all amortimation money being paid in on outstanding loans, and also the fundsived from pay-offs.

The Federation of Polish Jews in America made public yesterday a letter it has sent to Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, protesting against the re ous Polish towns and urging that he forward the protest to his government.

With so much stress being placed on the urgency to "interpret" American business to the public, a minor boom in the establishment of new public relations houses and in the addition of such departments to regular advertising agencies has taken place since the start of the year, executives pointed out here yesterday.

Communism is gaining ground because of State and city officials who force the police to be lenient with "agitators," Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens declared yesterday at the father and son communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore of the Holy Name Society of St. Teresa's Little Flower Church of Woodside, Queens.
Despite the being further decline of stocks in Wall Street, banks and financial journals here are inclined to believe that the peak of the United States business recovery has not yet been reached.

E. M. Thomson, president of the Federal Land Bank of Springfield, Mass., told land bank presidents in conference here that the demand for frm merchage Ananoing in the distrlot comprising New England, New York and New Jersey was holding upo well that the bank was able to relend virtually all amortimation money being paid in on outstanding loans, and also the fundsived from pay-offs.

The Federation of Polish Jews in America made public yesterday a letter it has sent to Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, protesting against the re ous Polish towns and urging that he forward the protest to his government.

With so much stress being placed on the urgency to "interpret" American business to the public, a minor boom in the establishment of new public relations houses and in the addition of such departments to regular advertising agencies has taken place since the start of the year, executives pointed out here yesterday.

Communism is gaining ground because of State and city officials who force the police to be lenient with "agitators," Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens declared yesterday at the father and son communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore of the Holy Name Society of St. Teresa's Little Flower Church of Woodside, Queens.
Despite the being further decline of stocks in Wall Street, banks and financial journals here are inclined to believe that the peak of the United States business recovery has not yet been reached.
The Board of Trade's index number for British wholesale prices of all commodities in April, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 108.9, a new high level.

Joseph E. Eidell, for twenty-five years a buyer for Lord Taylor, died yesterday at his home, 421 New Rochelle Road, Bronxville. He was 57 years old. A native of New York City, Mr Eidell had lived in Bronxville for more than forty years.

The foreign exchange market was very quiet this week, with rates showing but slight variations. The equalization fund does not appear to have intervened or, if it has, it has been only on a small scale.

The James D. Sparkman Trophy today went to James Brickell's A1legra, sailed by Arthur Knapp, as| the new International One-Design Class. concluded' the three-race series conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Lexington Ave, 1,051, 17x55: Tishman Realty Construction Co to Newco Realty Corp, 347 Madison Ave ($38). Same property; Newco Realty Corp to Flex Realty Corp, 347 Madison Ave; mtg. $30,000 (50c). 52d St, 440-46 E, 90.3x100.5; Landsboro Corp to Lengran Realty Co, 20 W 43d St ($1).

Richard M. Decker, connected with the John Hancock Life Insurance Company in its New York office, died suddenly yesterday of a thrombosis soon after returning from Boston, where he had flown to attend the funeral of a friend.

In Florida, where in 1931 dog racing first attain legal status, track operators, dog owners and dog trainers were called in by the State Racing Commission and informed that the practice of using live rabbits as bait must not be followed.

The Philippine Commonwealth, which will attain independence in nine years, will need Christian leadership if it is to endure, so missionary activity in the islands must continue unabated, the Rev. Dr. Rafael C. Thomas of the Association of Baptists for Evangelism in the Orient, for twenty-three years a missionary and physician in the Philippines, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

A blaring Bavarian band in Grand Central Station yesterday morning drew attention to the first "foldboat train" in America to be sent out by the New Haven Railroad, to Falls Village on the, Housatonic River in Connecticut.

After writing a "personal 'note" to his parents, Richard Leroy Blumenthal, 18, a freshman at Haverford College, hanged himself early today from the top of a shower bath in Barclay Hall, a campus dormitory.

Miss Millicent Cameron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Clyde Cameron of Des Moines, Iowa, and niece of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Greene of East Orange, N. J., has completed plans for her marriage to Theodore Herbert Henderson of Providence, R. I., formerly of Morristown, N. J., a son of Dr. Theodore M. Henderson of New York.

On both sides of the New Amsterdam Theatre's footlights last night the Broadway world-playwrights, producers, actors, critics, stagehands and playgoers-registered its unanimous disapproval of the Dunnigan bill and the one-man censorship it is held to imply.

The downward movement of cotton prices that began early in April was again in evidence last week. At the close of trading on Saturday prices of active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 28 to 32 points.
Discussion of the right of women to vote in the next elections has resulted in a charge by women that if the law does not permit them to vote the disability applies equally to men.

"If there is one need in the church today, it is for Christians on fire," the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning.

The Screen Actors Guild tonight approved a ten-year contract with producers which prohibits players from striking within that time and issued a statement defending itself against charges made by the striking Federated Motion Picture Crafts.

Two bronze figures representing a dancing bear and a dancing goat have been erected in the fountain basins at the ends of the outdoor eating terrace of the restaurant building in the Central Park Zoo.
Quadruplets were born late today to Mrs. Paul Martel, 30-yearold-baker's wife. The three boys and one girl were said to have a good chance to live, although they arrived two months ahead of time.

The principal event of the business week here was the Reichsbank's new vigor in inducing, or virtually compelling, holders of foreign currency securities to sell them to it. Simultaneously, the financial press resumed its discussions of the need
A nation-wide drive to wreck vice rings and land white slavers behind the bars centered in Baltimore today with about fifty arrests in raids on ten or more establish-' ments.

Two deluxe air - conditioned coaches, the first of fifty which the New York Central Railroad is rebuilding at Beech Grove, Ind., have been placed in service with the Empire State Express, the fastest train in New York State.

With the New York art season reaching mid-May, it was left for this relatively late day of a particularly exuberant year to produce one of the most important exhibitions. For the Metropolitan Museum is opening tomorrow with a private view and to the public on Wednesday its comprehensive Renoir show, reviewed on the art page of THE TIMES yesterday.
Taking the lead in the move toward color photography as the new medium for the screen, Samuel Goldwyn will produce his entire 1937-38 program in color, he announced over the week-end.

Whether the United States will remain faithful to the democratic doctrine is the great anxiety and hope of the European people, Dr. David Saville Muzzey said yesterday before the last Spring meeting of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

Purchasing in the wholesale market here last week was concentrated on "summery" merchandise, with cottons of all types ordered for National Cotton Week promotions Scheduled to take place during the week of May 31. Cotton dresses to retail up to $8.95 moved well. Cotton laces were in good demand.

Lynn H. Korndorff, in 40 5th Ave; Mrs. Benno Rosenwald, entire floor of fourteen rooms and four baths in 910 Park Ave; Mrs. J. A. Muigrew, in 1,105 Park Ave; through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker.

Under heavy Insurgent bombing and artillery fire, Basque militia retired southward on the Amorebieta front after an Insurgent attack on Hill 338, covering Amorebieta to the east, developed into action on a larger sale.

Fire swept the fourstory Loch Arbour Hotel, shore resore, today and firemen from five neighboring communities joined local volunteers in an attempt to prevent the spread of the flames to a colony of Summer cottages. The old hotel, with its 125 rooms, was apparently a total loss.

Lightning tonight lent a dramatic touch to the first dinner of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield away from the Chateau de Cande since their reunion. They were the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Grafton W. Minot of Boston and New York, at the Chateau d'Azay sur Indre, twenty-three miles from their retreat.

Settlement of a one-day strike which had disrupted service in eight of St. Louis's largest downtown hotels was announced early today by William F. Victor, president of the St. Louis Hotel Association. The agreement was reached after nearly sixteen hours' negotiation.

(Figures in Parentheses Indicate Par) Arrowbrook (75)-Kicker's handicap (drawn numbers 79, 74, 80): L. Stein, 9516-79; Harry Feldman, 92-18--74; K. Roberts, 92-12-80; Herman Linde, 105-25--80. Bayside (71)-Kickers' handicap (drawn number 70): H. McCarthy, 83-13-70; H. McCormack. 85-15--70: D. Jacobson. 9725-72; B. Caskey, 73-0-73; Johnny Beyer, 81-8-73.

John Erskine, who announced his resignation several months ago as president of the Juilliard School of Music, to take effect on July 1, was the guest of honor at a reception given last night by the faculty of the Juilliard Graduate School at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hutcheson, 1,107 Fifth Avenue. A painting was presented to him, and also a wrist watch, both farewell gifts from the faculty.

Paul Shields's new Rebel took its turn in leading home the six-meter yachts in another of the class's preseason special regattas conducted off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today. After the start had been delayed for more than two hours because of lack of wind, Rebel outsailed four rivals over a twelve-mile leeward and windward course.
Jersey City made it three in a row over the Toronto Maple Leafs today before 12,206, defeating the visitors, 2 to 0, behind the effective five-hit shut-out pitching of Bob Burke, veteran southpaw.

Four young Presbyterians will meet in a national oratorical contest on "The Duty of Foreign Missions" when the 149th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church meets in Columbus, Ohio, the week beginning May 27.

Harold S. Vanderbilt's new America's Cup Yacht Ranger arrived here this afternoon from her brief stop at Marblehead, Mass., after her dismasting off Cape Ann yesterday, with a tale of the sea and a night of terror in it for the professional crew of twenty-three aboard her that has not had an equal in the long history of the large yacht quest for the old mug.
San Luis Rey, winner of the Inaugural Handicap here a week ago, added the Arden Sunfreeze Handicap to his laurels today, going the six furlongs in 1:111-5 before 10,000 fans.

Commander L. Hewlett Thebaud. U.S.N., and Mrs. Thebaud will come to the Weylin today from Boston. Mrs. Peter Augustus Jay returns from Europe next week, and will be at the Plaza before going to Bar Harbor, Me.
A strong wind which swept across the track from the southwest put an almost complete halt today to qualifying trials for the Memorial Day 500-mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway race.
The zoo opened for the Summer at Retiro Park today giving a taste of ha piness to thousands of children who have spent a grim Winter with no place to go.

William Fyfe Turnbull, one-time instructor at Yale University, died Friday night at his home in this village. His age was 55. Mr. Turnbull was a teacher of mechanical engineering. He served the City of New York for three years and for six years was in the employ of the Third Avenue Railway Company.
Breakfast rally of the Life Underwriters Association marking the fifth annual Life Insurance Week, Hotel Astor, 8:15 A. M. Speakers: Louis H. Pink, Joseph C. Behan, Elizabeth Fraser.

Miss Madeleine Chittenden of Binghamton, N. Y., has been elected president of the freshman class at Mount Holyoke College for. the coming academic year, it was announced today in the undergraduate weekly.

A coronation party abroad the Cunard White Star liner Franconia ended tragically Thursday morning in the death of Mrs. T. Chitenden Hill of Gloucester, Mass., who leaped into the ocean, it became known today when the vessel docked at Los Angeles Harbor.

Two prominent Boston lawyers, Otis T. Russell, 48, of 12 Louisburg Square, and Edward Hutchins, 47, of 282 Beacon Street, were killed at Pepperell this morning when the beach wagon. in which they were returning from a Vermont fishing trip left the highway on a curve; rolled up an embankment, hit two trees and overturned.
An army physician reported today that the honey bee had contributed to a refinement in the treatment of hay fever.

Mrs. Blanche E. MacLeish Billings, widow of Cornelius K. G. Billings, Chicago capitalist and sportsman, who died ten days ago, died this morning in Billings Park, the family estate here, of bronchial pneumonia.
Jersey City made it three in a row over the Toronto Maple Leafs today before 12,206, defeating the visitors, 2 to 0, behind the effective five-hit shut-out pitching of Bob Burke, veteran southpaw.

Four young Presbyterians will meet in a national oratorical contest on "The Duty of Foreign Missions" when the 149th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church meets in Columbus, Ohio, the week beginning May 27.

The plan of Prime Minister Joseph. A. Lyons for a regional understanding and non-aggression pact among the countries of the Pacific is regarded here as a fitting contribution from this Commonwealth to the London Imperial'Conference discussions. Australia is. increasingly being regarded by observers here as having a peculiar responsibility to exert leading influence on British policy in the Pacific.

Commander Jere H. Brooks, a retired naval officer, died of heart disease today at his apartment here at the age of 52. Born in Louisiana, he was appointed to the Naval Academy in 1902 from Michigan and was graduated in 1906. He served in Chinese

The government of Ecuador will enter the business of baking and selling bread to keep the price down and the quality up. A large bakery is being built in Quito by the Ministry of Government for the sale of bread at cost.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-Against SCHWARTZ DRUG CO., INC., 305 Broadway; by Progressive Drug Co.. $250; Chabrowe Drug Co., $400; Max Fox, $25. Petitions Filed-By EDWARD I. GRAFF, village clerk of Larchmont. N. Y.-Liabilities. $9,700; assets. 83.000 in insurance notifies

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12.000 including 3,000 directs. Market 15c-25c higher than Friday's average; packing sows 10c-20c higher, active at advance; bulk good and choice 200-300

Marking the third action by a publishing company to put its books under the price-protection provisions of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, Farrar Rhinehart yesterday notified retailers of the establishment of set retail prices on twenty-two titles. Current popular novels and books to be published before June 30 are included in the list sent to local stores.

A merger of the New York operations of the three steamship lines operated by the Dollar interests has been effected, it was announced yesterday by R. Stanley Dollar of San Francisco, president of the Dollar Steamshin Lines.

Spottiness continued to mark the wholesale apparel markets here yesterday. Interest in Summer merchandise is gaining, but the situation has yet to reach the broadly active stage. Reduction of seasonal

Coldly and calmly yesterday, a young widow, 25 years old, blond, petite and smartly dressed, told detenement at the West Forty-seventh Street station that she had killed her daughter and tried to kill her son in the woods at Brookhaven, L. I., in order to make room in her tenement cubicle at 525 West Fortyseventh Street for the man she wanted to marry.

Mrs. Ovid Butler Jameson, sister of Booth Tarkington, the author, died tonight at her home here. Mrs. Jameson was born in Indianapolis and had lived here all her life. She was the widow of Ovid Butler, founder of Butler University.

At the regular dividend meeting of the directors of the Brooklyn queens Transit Corporation yesterlay no action was taken on the company's $6 preferred stock. The directors indicated that the in??reased costs of labor, raw ma??erials and supplies, the prospect of ??ncreasedd taxes and a fixed rate of fare were responsible for their decision.

Supreme Court Justice Mortimer Patterson reserved decision here today on an application for a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of the seven men recently convicted as restaurant racketeers in New York, who are now serving sentences of from ten to twenty years in Sing Sing prison.
The United Automobile Workers committee directing the campaign to unionize Ford Motor Company workers adjourned tonight without deciding whether to charge Henry Ford with employee intimidation.

Yin Ju-keng, Chief Executive of the Japanese-dominated East Hopei Government, declared today in an interview that there was no chance for a restoration of Nanking's authority over East Hopei while the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] dictated the policies of the Chinese Government.

Edward Louis Cochran, an investigator for the Department of Justice, has projected a trilogy of novels laid in the Yazoo delta land, and has completed the first one, "Son of Haman," just published by Caxton Printers. Cochran formerly practiced law in the country of which he writes. He has written two previous novels, "Flood Tides" and "Black Earth."
Russia enlisted her great Red army of 1,300,000 men today in a fight against followers of Leon Trotsky and against "espionage and sabotage."

A garden party was held by the women's auxiliary of the Metropolitan Lutheran Inner Mission Society yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the Messiah Lutheran Church, 202 Sherman Avenue, near West 207th Street. There were 250 women present and there was a program of music.
Hearing of testimony in the $9,000,000 William Fox bankruptcy case has been postponed indefinitely because of the recent death of Robert M. Steedle, Federal referee in bankruptcy, who was presiding

Newport had a brief visit from Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt today. They came in their plane from Northport, L. I., shortly before noon and were the luncheon guests of Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas at Mapleshade.

Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Barrett, who were married here on April 24, returned yesterday from Bermuda and are at 205 East Seventy-eighth Street. Mrs. Barrett is the former Miss Helen Kuper. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Gilmore Kerley of 10 East Eighty-first Street will open Hilltop, their place at Sharon, Conn., for the Summer nn May 29.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday signed a temporary injunction restraining Victor DeVilliers, head of the Victor DeVilliers Company, 120 Wall Street, and Edward Schofs, his office manager, from dealing in securities in this State.

Dr. Juan Negrin, Socialist former Finance Minister, completed a new Cabinet tonight after having received a mandate this morning from President Manuel Azana following the inability of Francisco Largo Caballero to reassemble a satisfactory Ministry.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 90 per cent of ingot capacity, against 91.2 per cent last week, a decrease of 1.2 points, or 1.3 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. A month ago the rate was 91.3 per cent.

Despite an assertion that the legislation is unconstitutional, the Massachusetts Senate passed today, by a vote of 15 to 8, a bill to penalize employers who discriminate against workers over 45 years of age.

When revolt breaks out in Albania it swings the spotlight back to one of the strangest spots left in the modern world. Albania is still largely feudal, a country in the heart of Europe that saw airplanes before it saw a railroad and skipped from the town crier to the radio. A decade ago Spring risings among the mountain clans were commonplace.

President Roosevelt went over today the preliminary outlines of a message expected to go to Congress soon stating the administration's wishes for a public power policy to be linked with hydroelectric projects at dams built under a comprehensive program of flood control.

Interest rate on a bank discount basis for Treasury bills of 273 days' maturity, as well as for an issue of shorter-term bills sold by the Treasury today, showed a substantial decline, indicating easing in the money market.

"Regimentation" is an overworked word. It has been used, unfairly in many cases, to damn every social experiment and every innovation introduced by the Roosevelt Administration. But there are times when the use of the word is justified, and "regimentation" is the only way to describe accurately the main principle of the new Farm Bill which is to be introduced in Congress today. In its reliance on scarcity

Judge George L. Donnellan was moved to mercy in General Sessions Court yesterday by the written plea of the catcher of the First Ward baseball team in behalf of the second, baseman who pleaded guilty to a charge of illegal entry.

Store leases featured the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. Outstanding among them was that taken by Dunlap Co., Inc., makers of Dunlap Hats, on a store at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

Steadily losing prestige since the tricolor's Davis Cup team was dethroned in 1933, the French hard court tennis championships open in Roland Garros Stadium tomorrow with only a handful of international stars enrolled.
Marriage was listed as the "favorite vocation" of the 104 senior students of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, in the results of a class poll made public yesterday.

Business should stop fighting the politicians and should strive to win public approval and sentiment by proving that business men are as much interested in the broad phases of social welfare as any group, Raymond Moley said last night in speaking at the dinner meeting of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

An automobile was overturned and fist fights ensued today as 300 striking movie craftsmen returned to work. Police dispersed the combatants in the free-for-all fight that followed the crowding into the curb of a car carrying to work four Columbia Studio laborers.
Morgan Run local of the United Mine Workers of America will stand behind "Billy" Green, said Ben Mobley today.

Samuel Kirsch, 45 years old, an itinerant jewelry salesman, was robbed of $8,000 worth of jewelry and $1,700 in cash yesterday by three men ho gained admittance to his room in the Hotel Wellington, Seventh Avenue and Fiftyfifth Street, by posing as prospective customers.

For the fifth time, a grand jury refused today to return an indictment against Edward S. Hubbard, 26year-old Franklin Township County farmer, who had admitted the shooting last September of Layton Hessler, 22, of Williamstown, the finance of Hubbard's 16-year-old sister, Dorothy.
Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the dullest since Aug. 4,1933. The total of transactions yesterday was $5,254,700, compared with $8,?? 400 on last Friday.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Fisher of Chestnut Hill have sent out invitations to the marriage of Mrs. Fisher's daughter, Miss Elise Thayer Dixon, to Pierce Archer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Archer Jr., of Wynnewood, which will take place on June 7 in the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 15: COLONELS Jones, H. W., Med. Corps, 15 days leave, July 1, with permission to visit foreign countries. Jarman, S., C. A. C., General Staff Corps, 2 days leave, May 17. Williams, G., Cav., 3 days leave, May 16.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing American Centrifugal Corporation capital stock, $1 par value; Beaunit Mills, Inc., common stock, $10 par value, and $1.50 convertible preferred stock, $20 par value;

Atop 700-foot windswept Mount Rushmore near here, where features of four United States Presidents are being carved from granite, Gutzon Borglum, sculptor, issued formal reply today to critical comment last week at Washington, D. C.

In a characteristically poetic opinion, Justice Cardozo today announced the unanimous ruling of the Supreme Court that Francis E. Beach of Connecticut is a farmer under the meaning of the Frazier-Lemke law and thus entitled to the law's benefits as a bankrupt.
The Waltham Women's Club, consisting of 150 members of leading families of this city of 40,000, today faced protests that it would be an undesirable neighbor.

The Paris police are ready to admit that the "subway murder" of Laetitia Toureaux, a taxi dancer is "a perfect crime." It is estimated after a close checkup that the person who committed the deed, whom the police call "the ghost murderer," had a maximum of 90 seconds in which to track down and stab the victim and disappear.

Meeting for a luncheon in the New York State Chamber of Commerce Building yesterday, a group of representatives of New York financial houses formulated plans for the organization of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

Edmund J. Cook, a nephew of Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, was named chief attendant for the Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday. He was sworn in immediately by Justice Edward Riegelmann. The salary is $4,500

Presidents of retail liquor package store associations from all boroughs of the city meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday were assured by executives of the National Distillers Products Corporation, that downtown retailers who slashed prices on three of the company's brands, in the first price war to develop since the Feld-Crawford Act became effective, will be shut off from future supplies of the whiskies affected.

The term of the April, 1936, Kings County grand jury, which indicted five persons in connection with the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, was extended indefinitely yesterday by County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn.
President Roosevelt was reported today to be ready to announce soon the appointment of an Assistant Secretary of War to fill an office vacant since Sept. 25.

Religion is losing ground in this country because of the growth of the "liberal mind," Dr. Henry C. Link, director of the Psychological Service Center and author of "The Return to Religion," declared yesterday at a luncheon and conference of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, held at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.
Three men and two women graduate students at Columbia University have received travel scholarships for Summer study at the University of Perugia, Italy, it was announced yesterday.

From the deck of a 6,000-ton freighter in the mid-Pacific, James Stokley, associate director of the Franklin Institute in charge of astronomy, and Dr. John Q. Stewart, Associate Professor of Astronomy at Princeton, hope to watch the eclipse of the sun on June 8 for a longer period than anybody could have seen an eclipse in 1,200 years.

Speaking in his electoral district, Ion Mihalache, leader of the National Peasant party,. revealed today that during a Bucharest reception Premier George Tatarescu, in the presence of Vice Premier Ion Inculetz, had openly said that a state of anarchy in Rumania was widespread. Mr. Mihalache said

Creation of a Federal Power Administration out of the present Federal Power Commission and transfer to it of all government power activities was recommended in a report by the Brookings Institution submitted today to the Senate Governmental Reorganization Committee.
The Guaranty Trust Company is prepared to deliver Houston Lighting and Power Company first mortgage bonds, 31/2 per cent series, due in 1966, in definitive form in exchange for temporary bonds.

At the request of the directors of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, charges against thirty-eight former employes accused of participating in a sit-down strike at the hospital on March 17 were dismissed yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn.

Despite protests of Chief Edward McFeely, of the Hoboken Police Department that there was no police interference with the C. I. O., Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder in Chancery Court today issued an injunction restraining Chief McFeely and the Police Department from interfering in any way with the rights of Local 15, Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

Edward C. Smith, a placing judge on the New York race tracks, who officiated Saturday at Belmont Park, died Sunday afternoon of a heart, attack at his residence, the Hotel Whitman, Jamaica, Queens. He was born near Lexington, Ky., seventy-one years ago. His widow came here- yesterday from their home in Gloucester, Mass.

Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association and Professor of Marketing at Columbia University, was elected yesterday president of the Sales Executives Club of New York. He ran as an independent against Fenelon K. Doscher, sales promotion manager of the Lily-Tulip Cup Corporation, the regular nominee.

Morris Watson, a vice president of the American Newspaper Guild who was reinstated as an employee of The Associated Press after the Supreme Court's decision upholding the Wagner act,. resigned yesterday from the press association to resume work as producer of the Living Newspaper, a WPA theatre project, The Associated Press announced.

A high wind and rainstorm, which had the earmarks of a small cyclone, struck Bruce-Park about 4 o'clock this afternoon, uprooting two maple trees about 4 feet in circumference as well as a huge oak tree, and caused a 10-foot waterspout in the lake.

Charging that Tammany Democrats were "sabotaging" President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the United States Supreme Court, Alex Rose, secretary of the American Labor Party, sent a message to party members yesterday urging them to redouble their efforts for passage of the President's bill.
After President Frank Durand of Monmouth County, a Republican, refused a request of Senator John E. Toolan, Middlesex County, Democrat, for a roll-call, the Senate
The history books ought to say that an Irishman - discovered America, nearly 1,000 years before Colum- H bus, a loyal son of Erin declared today.

Aubrey Williams, Deputy Administrator of the Works Progress Administration; told the National Recreation Congress here today that organized recreation has made great progress during the last few years as a result of the work of the WPA, but he is none too optimistic about the future.

The week-end Cabinet crisis of the Valencia Government-the sixth since the insurrection of General FRANCISCO. FRANCO last July-following on the. heels of the revolt of the Anarchists in Barcelona last week against the autonomous Catalan Government, does not indicate that the divergent elements in the Loyalist ranks are amalgamating. Even though Dr. JUAN

Three cash prizes for papers on safety were presented last night at a meeting of the metropolitan section of the Society of Automotive Engineers to students at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John Walter Scott of South Orange, N. J., of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Theodora Titus Scott, to John Hamilton Bowers, son of Mrs. John W. Vance of South Orange and Seabright, N. J., and of the late Philip J. Bowers, which took place Saturday in the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, South Orange.

Gilmore S. Bell, 26, a radio engineer employed by the General Electric Company in Bridgeport, shot and killed his wife, Marie, 24, while she was sleeping early today and then committed suicide by shooting himself, after revealing the tragedy over a private telegraph line which he and several neighbors operated.
An old-fashioned church social was held last night at the headquarters of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, 285 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, preceding the annual meeting.

Senator Nye of North Dakota introduced a resolution today calling for an investigation by a Senate committee of the activities in this country of aliens in behalf of either of the factions in the Spanish civil war.
Paced by its two stars, Sam Nield and Ed Kringle, Manhattan's golf team closed its dual meet season by defeating the St. John's University linksmen, 5 to 4. over the Sprain Lake course today.
A Federal court judge put two defendants under two years' suspended sentence today on charges growing out of a shortage of $1,300,000 at the closed Commercial National Bank of Bradford, Pa.

Running the fastest mile of the meeting, Carl Laemmle's Savernake scored his success here this Spring in capturing today's Shady Brook Farm Purse at Churchill Downs. It was a standout race in every respect, the first six furlongs being turned in 1:11 flat.

Joseph Berger, 29 years old, who with Gabriel Klar, 34, is being tried in General Sessions for the. murder of Frank Cicero, 33, a truckman of Stamford, Conn., who was fatally stabbed during a testimonial dinner at the Manhattan Opera House on Jan. 17, testified yesterday that he and Klar made three attempts to re-enter the opera house after the killing, but were barred by the police.

A jury before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson began to hear evidence yesterday in retrial of a suit brought by the successor trustee of a $46,421,545 fund, created in 1919 by the first Viscount Waldorf Astor, against the United States Government fer the recovery of an inheritance tax of $10,825,721.
City school officials expressed the opinion yesterday that sex education and regular physical examinations should be given to high school students by specially qualified teachers and physicians.

ABOUT noon on a Spring day in 1932, when the S. S. Orizaba, on a regular voyage from Veracruz to New York, was running northward a few miles off the Florida capes, a young man, 32 years old, clad in topcoat and pajamas, walked quickly to the taffrail, threw off his coat and plunged into the sea.

Charles W. Yeomans, Major in the Quartermaster Corps and stationed at Hoboken as purchasing agent and contracting officer during the World War, died today at the age of 67. He was commissioned a Colonel in the Reserve Corps in 1930.

Informed that Southern newsprint manufacture was assured, the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association gave ovations today to James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville Banner and chairman of its newsprint committee, and to Dr. Charles H. Herty of Savannah, whose research laid the groundwork for bringing the industry to the South.

Traffic accidents showed a decline last week as compared with a year ago, but the number of weekend deaths from such accidents doubled in comparison with the corresponding 1936 period, according to the weekly figures made public yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

American, Japanese, and German buyers eagerly are seeking tantalite, a rare iron black mineral containing manganese, which is found in the northern territory and used in the manufacture of armament. The United States is

If the Steel Workers Organization Committee calls a strike in this "cradle of the steel industry," the Republic Steel Company and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, leading independents, will close their mills and resume work only when their employes show that they wish to return to work, it was indicated here today by leading steel executives.

Sebald M. Hohl, president of the Arcade Glove Company of New York, died here yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old. Mr. Hohl had been active in civic affairs of New Rochelle and was vice president of the Edgewood Park Neighborhood Association.
Endeavour II, T. O. M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger, is expected to arrive from England tomorrow.

The American Academy in Rome yesterday awarded four scholarships, of an estimated value of $4,000 each, in architecture, landscape architecture, painting and sculpture. The winners will be able to study and travel two years in Europe.

Mrs. Roosevelt received two showers of champagne this morning at the Washington airport when she christened the first plane sent out by Eastern Air Lines on its new hourly service between New York and Washington.

So far as, can be judged by surface indications, the President will welcome an occasion to take his Federal judiciary plan to the country and ask it to judge between him and what appeared to be a majority of the Seventy-fifth Congres.

Mrs. Emily Weller Schweizer of Middlesex Farms, Noroton, Conn., widow of Raymond J. Schweizer, was married here at noon yesterday to David Dows of Charlton Hall, Brookville, L. I., in the James Memorial Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary. The ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, was attended only by near relatives.

AYERS-William B., at his home, Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., Sunday evening, May 16. Notice of services later. BAER-Lillie G., beloved mother of Sara, dear sister of Cora G. and Carrie G. Klee. Services Tuesday, 10 A. M., at Universal Chapel, 52d St. and Lexington Ave.
The annual conference of the American Association for Adult Education opened this evening at Skytop Lodge, with more than 200 members and guests registered for the four-day session.

MANHATTAN BLEYLER, FRANK E. (Dec. 31. 1934). Estate, less than $5,000. To Imperial Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine for North America, residue, for the benefit of the Shriners Hospital for Crippled Children. Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Co., Willam and Beaver Sts., executor.

The one-story motor freight terminal and office building on the West side of Coles Street, between Thirteenth and Fourteenth Streets, Jersey City, N. J., has been leased to the York Motor Express Company by the Hoboken Land and Improvement Company.

Cary D. Waters, after being reelected president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce at the annual meeting yesterday, told a luncheon audience of 1,000 persons at the Hotel St. George that, with industrial strife apparent on all sides, it was to the best interests of labor and the community, as well as the employer, a balance of power must be effected.

A committee of representatives of the women's apparel trades will confer this morning with Benjamin Heffner, Assistant Attorney General, in the State Attorney General's office here, on their charges that the paper-box manufacturers are maintaining a "closed" market in restraint of trade and have acted in concert in the fixing of prices, which have advanced from 25 to 40 per cent.

Gladys MacKnight, who will be 18 years old June 6, and her 19-year-old former admirer, Donald Wightman, both of Bayonne, faced an all-male jury today as their trial for the murder of the girl's mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight, last July 31, opened here this morning before Judge Thomas F. Meaney in the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

The Rev. Clark S. Shafer, who had officiated at more funeral services in Washington County than any other minister during the last twenty-five years, died today at the age of 71 in the parsonage of the Christian Church at Fineville, a few miles from here, where he had been pastor for eight years.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on May 12 shows decreases for the week of $35,000,000 in total loans and investments, $26,000,000 in government deposits, $42,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $22,000,000 in borrowings, and increases of $52,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $27,000,000
Imports of American goods in many lines into Czechoslovakia are on the increase, according to reports received from commercial attaches by the Commerce Department.

Sixty-one sprinters have been named for the 100-yard dash and seventy-one for the 220-yard run in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium a week from Friday and Saturday, it was announced by Stanley de J. Osborne, manager of the meet. The shortdistance men hail from twenty-two colleges.

Some of the questions to be propounded at the Congress of American Private Enterprise, to be held on Thursday, June 3, at Carnegie Hall, were made public last night by Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council. Among the questions for which Mr. Hart is confident the congress will provide answers are:
Arkansas won tonight a three-State battle for the privilege of trying Lester Brockelhurst, Midwestern "crime tourist," for murder.

The New York University varsity tennis team won its sixth match of the season yesterday when it defeated the Rutgers net squad, 7 to 2, at the Riverview Tennis Club courts. Five of the six singles engagements went to the Violet. Herbert Abrams, No. 1 for the winners, defeated Don Corwin, 6--0, 6--3. Walter Schwartz won the only Rutgers solo test, beating Ben Theeman, 4--6, 8--6, 7--5.

Trading showed improvement in some sections on beef cuts. Most points were still dull, however, on most major cuts. Other classes were in fair demand. Most salesmen were asking more for steer hinds and ribs, and fresh pork prices were strong to sharply higher. Other classes were little

L. C. Smith and Corona Typewriters, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the March quarter a net income of $352,338 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, interest, Federal income taxes and provision of $26,822 for surtax on undistributed profits.

It is doubtful whether any one will ever know how many fishermen were out at Peconic Bay on Sunday. Nor is it likely that any figure will be more than a rough approximation of the number of weakfish caught.

Drastic changes in the administrative set-up of the New York City school system were recommended yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, who proposed that special teachers, supervisors and assistant superintendents be limited to threeyear terms, with a lapse of another three years before reassignment.
Preparatory to the organization meeting of the new City Commission tomorrow, the elected members at a conference in an Asbury Park hotel today decided to rename Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein as Mayor.

Nebraska's three public hydroelectric projects are negotiating for the purchase of all private power systems in the State with the intention of combining them into a gigantic system which would be unique in the nation, the Omaha World Herald said today.

Embodying the essential features of the original AAA and Bankhead compulsory production control laws, which were invalidated by the Supreme Court, the administration-sponsored Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1937 was started through the legislative processes of Congress today amid expressions of doubt by farm State representatives that it could be made law at this session.

Another increase in gold production in Canada was recorded in March, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Production was valued at $11,413,099, against $10,855,691 in February. By weight the output was 326,275 ounces, compared with 310,074 in February and with 299,102 in March, 1936.

Several apartment houses and private homes figured in the Brooklyn real estate transactions reported by brokers yesterday. Abraham Keene sold to the Tifras Realty Corporation the apartment house at 843 Sixtieth Street, subject to a first mortgage of $54,500 which was recently reorganized by a Supreme Court proceeding.

The property value of the- Sinclair Prairie Pipe Line Company, according to a valuation made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, is $95,100,495. This includes both parallel trunk pipe lines and branches as well as real estate.
Governor Lehman signed twenty-one bills today, including one which increases the term of office of the Richmond County-District Attorney from three to four years. The new law brings

Miss Sarah Elizabeth Choate of 333 East Fifty-seventh Street, a daughter of the late Dr. George C. S. Choate of this city, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. Her father was an older brother of the late Joseph Hodges Choate, former IUnited States Ambassador at London, and of the seventh generation in descent from John Choate, who ly came from England in 1643 and settled in Iswich. Mass.

Governor Barrows ordered National Guard troops withdrawn from the Lewiston-Auburn shoe strike area tonight and at the same time announced failure of his attempts to negotiate a settlement of the fiftythree-day walkout.

The Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that a payment or advance made by a national bank in the course of the banking moratorium of March, 1933, is recoverable by the receiver of the bank if the institution did not resume normal functions at the termination of the

The American Committee for Spanish Relief, of which Basil Harris, shipping executive, is chairman, issued yesterday the following statement: "The purpose of the American Committee for Spanish Relief is to raise funds for the relief of the suffering non-combatants, men, women and children.
Mrs. Dan Chandler of Dallas outstroked a strong field today to win the qualifying medal in the women's Southern golf tournament for the second straight year.

Thomas F. Reynolds Jr. of Hastings-on-Hudson and William H. Rorke Jr. of this city gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the Biltmore for Miss Marguerite McLachlan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. McLachlan of Danbury, Conn., whose marriage to Thomas J. Wall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Wall of New Rochelle,

In recognition of an increase of 49.8 per cent in truck sales in the first quarter of 1937 in comparison with those in the corresponding period last year, Robert F. Gloster, assistant sales manager, and William E. Conway, assistant director of truck sales, gave a dinner last night in the Park Central Hotel, for 250 Studebaker dealers.

The annual meeting of the New York County Lawyers Association, at which a contest between rival slates for directorships will be decided, is to be held Thursday night in the association's building at 14 Vesey Street. Eleven out of thirty
A barber who dabbles in astronomy in his spare moments received today the Pickering Gold Medal of the American Association of Variable Star Observers for discovery of a new star.

Making her first appearance of the season in England, Miss Alice Marble played on the winning side in an exhibition doubles match before a large Whitsun holiday crowd attending the Surrey lawn tennis championships at Surbiton today.
Harold Cohen, 29 years old, who said he lived at 5 Allen Street, was held in $500 bail for trial in Special Sessions by Magistrate McGee yesterday in the Felony Court on a pistol-carrying charge.

53d St, 7 E, 21x100.5; Column Holding Corp (Benj Bernstein, pres), to Edwin Gould Foundation for Children, 595 Madison Ave, eq lien with pr mtg, $46,500; three years, 4 1/2 per cent, $8,500. 83d St 108 W, 19x100.2; Perla Ernsthaft to 108 V 83d St, Inc, 129 E 10th St; purchase money, five years, 4 per cent; $15,000.

A plan to issue $50,000,000 of new $4.50 dividend preferred stock is to be submitted to the stockholders of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., at a special meeting called in Wilmington, Del., on June 18, the company announced yesterday.

State Department officials said today that they were mystified by an announcement in Paris by the Basque mission that 500 children to be evacuated from beleaguered Bilbao, Spain, would be brought to the United States. It was said that no application had been made to the department for admission of the group.

Chain stores will probably end their special promotions of Florida citrus fruits if that State passes its "recovery" act, which virtually abolishes chain stores, Charles F. Adams, treasurer of the First National Stores of Boston, and chairman of the Agricultural Relations Committee of the National Association of Foods Chains, has told the Florida Grapefruit Growers League.
A CARDINAL OF THE MEDICI, by Susan Hicks Beach. (Macmillan, $3.) A novel of Renaissance Italy, the first novel ever published by Cambridge University Press in its 400 years of publishing.

Business failures in the United States for the week ended May 13 were 190, against 177 in the previous week and 206 in the corresponding week of last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday. This reversed the trend of the preceding two weeks, when declines had been shown.

General Sessions Judge Donnellan will draw today a special panel of 100 talesmen for the selection of the jury for the first-degree murder trial of Mischa Rosenbaum, theatrical agent, accused of killing Miss Julia Nussenbaum, violinist, in a rehearsal studio at 132 West Forty-third Street on April 18.

Mr. and Mrs. B. M. Tassie of Meriden, Conn., entertained at dinner in the Colonial Room of the Homestead this evening. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. E. 0. Shreve, Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Pierce Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Stearns, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Swartzbaugh, Mr. and Mrs. T. D.

John A. (Spider) Kelly, boxing instructor at Princeton University since 1902, died at his home here tonight as a result, according to the family, of a cerebral hemorrhage caused by a blow on the head received two months ago while boxing with a student. His age was 65.

Frank Altsohul. has been elected chairman and Herbert G. Wellington vice chairman of the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange. The Exchange has been notified that the time within which Kresge Departments Stores, Inc., 8 per cent cumulative sinking-fund preferred stock may be exchanged for the new 4 per cent cumulative convertible first preferred and common stock of the company has been extended to June 1.

Resolutions calling upon the Board of Higher Education to act to terminate activities of the Teachers Union chapter and the Communist party at Brooklyn College, were adopted yesterday by the-college faculty at a meeting in the administration building of the institution, 383 Pearl Street, Brooklyn.

Magistrate Edgar S. Bromberger, recently appointed to office by Mayor F. H. La Guardia, at the expiration of the term of Magistrate Adolph Stern, took the bench for the first time yesterday morning in Essex Market Court. He permitted no ceremony to mark his first day on the bench.

President Roosevelt was within his legal rights when he supplanted John F. Curran, postmaster at Milford, Mass., with a later appointee, Postmaster General Farley asserted today in - n answer to Mr. Curran's suit in the District of Columbia Supreme Court demanding that a commission be issued to him.

Stocks closed lower in slowest trading since May 13, 1936; turnover, 597,070 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues steady and dull in smallest turnover since Aug. 4, 1933; transactions, $5,254, 700.

More than $1,000,000 in merchandise will be purchased within the next ten days by thirty buyers of Goldblatt Brothers, Chicago department stores, representing the largest contingent of buyers which Goldblatt's has sent here in many months, according to Edward Simon, vice president, who arrived here yesterday with the vanguard.
War Admiral, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, was entered today in the $25,000 added American Derby to be decided at Washington Park June 19. The distance is a mile and a quarter.
Now that it is all over, let it be confessed that at times the pageantry seemed a bit overdone in London last week.
A motor cycle patrolman was knocked down and injured last night as he was escorting a car through 125th Street on the way to a hospital. The policeman, John

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Kitchel, daughter of Cornelius Porter Kitchel and of the late Mrs. Edith Ray Kitchel, to Alexander Lincoln Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lincoln of Brookline, Mass., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's father, 235 Lincoln Street.

Elimination of unreasonable trade barriers and cooperation of agricultural, industrial and commercial forces in readjustment of the economic structure were urged here tonight by Secretary Roper, who opened Foreign Trade Week and spoke under the auspices of the local association of commerce.

A declaration by the Nepsco Appliance Finance Corporation covering the issue and sale from time to time of its 3 per cent deferred debentures due on Dec. 1, 1956, in amounts which will not at any one time exceed $350,000 in the aggregate principal amount outstanding and also the sale of its promissory notes in amounts which, including such notes now outstanding, will not at any one time exceed $1,000,000
