The surprising Athletics brought joy to 7,860 fans at Shibe Park today by downing the Yankees, 3-2, thus retrieving one game from the set of three and moving back into first place.
After advancing a few points at the opening yesterday prices on the Cotton Exchange moved off $1 a bale before the market steadied to close with losses of 8 to 11 points.

A pair of sophomores, Sid Richardson of Northwestern and Bill Ploetz of Wisconsin, fired their way over the windswept Kildeer Country Club course today to reach the 36hole post in the annual Big Ten golf championship tied for the individual lead at 148 strokes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Despite the urgent need for constructive amendments to the Social Security Act, the recent joint action of the Social Security Board and the Senate Finance Committee creating an advisory council to study the advisability of such amendments is far from encouraging.

In a finish so close that the placing judges called for extra pictures from the racing camera, Jake Freedman's Singers Folly won the featured Gaspee Purse by a nose from Mrs. E. I. Wade's Up and Up at Narragansett today.

Despite the slowness and easiness in the security markets in the last few months, dividend declarations have been favorable. In addition to the regular payments, a large number of companies have ordered substantial extra payments. The oil industry has been especially liberal, and indications are that its dividend disbursements for the first
The wildness of rookie Pitcher Lloyd Moore, together with shaky relief hurling, gave the Cubs a 5-to-2 triumph over the Reds today to enable them to salvage the final of the three-game series.

Silas Wright Porter, a justice of the Kansas Supreme Court frown 1904 to 1923, died today after a long illness. His age was 80. Judge Porter, who resumed practice in Topeka on the conclusion of his third term on the Supreme Court bench, was born in Warren County, Ill., a son of Judge John Wright.

Virginia Mulville Spillane, wife of Michael J. Spillane of Waterbury and a former resident of Riverside and Stamford, died yesterday in Waterbury Hospital. She was the daughter of the late John and Ann Sherman Mulville and a sister of the late Rev. Francis X. -Mulville and the late Dr. Frederick Mulville.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, which announced on Feb. 7 the first joint fund-raising campaign in their history, made known their 1937-38 goal last night at a dinner attended by more than 2,500 persons at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The President and Mrs. Roosevelt rehearsed some Washington correspondents and their wives in a Virginia reel at the White House last night. It was in preparation for the dance to be given May 28 for the newspaper men.

Paul Bloomfield Boden, former manager of the old Manhattan Hotel at the northwest corner of Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday at the Hotel Commodore, where he had long resided. He had been ill for five years. His age was 73.

Figures issued today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, showed that disbursements of 646 bank receiverships finally closed since the c banking holiday of 1933 amounted c t6 $217,399,942, or an average re- c turn of 79.41 per cent of the total liabilities. Unsecured creditors reseived dividends averaging 67.45 per cent of their claims.

Frederick Neuman, 28-year-old bank clerk, of 42-11 157th Street, Flushing, waived examination before Magistrate Frank Giorgio in the Queens Felony Court yesterday and was held in $2,000 bail for the Queens grand jury on a grand larceny charge. Neuman is accused

The resignation of Walter A. Bonitz as president of the Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc., was announced yesterday. He had served as a trustee in bankruptcy for the predecessor company and will remain a director.
The first day for the assignment of seats to new subscribers at the Metropolitan Opera House brought the largest turnout of applicants yesterday morning since the days before the depression.

Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street. Meeting of alumni in the chapel, 10 A. M. Addresses by the Rev. Henry S. Leiper and Y. T. Wu. Luncheon in refectory 1 P. M. Graduating exercises in the chapel, 8 P. M. Address by the Rev. William P. Merrill.

Captain Harry Manning has been assigned to command the liner Manhattan, flagship of the United States Lines, for a single voyage in place of Commodore A. B. Randall% who will be ashore on vacation. The ship will sail tomorrow for the Channel ports and Hamburg.
Four children of The Baltimore 'Sun, which was a hundred years old Monday, have just written its chequered and eventful history fairly, fully, often

The constitutionality of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the judiciary, a point seldom brought up during public hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee, was questioned in a memorandum of the American Bar Association, which was circulated here today.

Continuing its incursion into the overthe-counter market, the New York Curb Exchange has made application under the Securities Exchange Act. of 1934 for unlisted trading privileges in nine bond or debenture issues which are not now listed on any Exchange.

Jamaica scored its sixth shutout victory of the season by defeating Cleveland, 2 to 0, yesterday at Jamaica Stadium and held the lead in the Queens division of the P. S. A. L. The nine now has won eleven of its twelve starts. Both sides made four hits. In the third Tom Kelly, winning hurler, walked and came home on Al Bradley's triple.

The Fenway pair of Joe Rich and Henry Payson, the last team to post a score, tied with Alex Watson of Hudson River and Bill Weeks of Tamarack. for first place in the opening Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur best-ball tournament at Gedney Farm today.

In the past eight days the Basques, with heavy Asturian reinforcements, have put up immeasurably better resistance outside Bilbao than ever was offered by Madrid's defenders before the providential arrival of the International Brigades with their seasoned fighters.

Negotiations with Swedish capitalists of the utmost importance in the British rearmament program have been completed, according to information from authentic sources. After discussions, which have been proceeding for the better part of two years, the British Government finally has arranged to buy from the famous Bofors Works in Sweden virtually its entire output of antiaircraft guns.

The six-story apartment at 2,100 Bronx Park East, covering the east block front from Lydig Avenue to Maran Avenue, the Bronx, was sold at auction to Frank L. Weil, as trustee, the plaintiff, in proceedings against the Robak Holding Corporation, on a bid of $1,000.

A collision between two automobiles on Shore Road Drive near Third Avenue, Brooklyn, killed Michael Duffy, 42 years old, of 358 Fifty-eighth Street, driver of one of the cars, and injured three persons riding with him.

The White Motor Company' delivered 4,219 trucks in the first four months of 1937, a gain of 27 per cent over 3,305 trucks delivered to dealers in the same period last year, Robert F. Black, president, said at the adjourned annual meeting of stockholders in Cleveland yesterday.

Acting Mayor William F. Brunner accepted yesterday an invitation from Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia to have New York officials attend the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution in Philadelphia on Sent. 17. 1937.
Paul W. Albright, secretary of the Savings Banks Association of New York State, will address the Savings Banks Officers Forum at its annual dinner tonight in the Hotel Astor. A round-table discussion

Jacobs, University of Richmond mound sensation, pitched his third no-hit game of the season today, a 2-to-0 triumph over Virginia Military Institute. His previous no-hit games had been registered at the expense of V. P. I. and HampdenSydney.
Solomon Siet, a retired clothing manufacturer at one time active in Brooklyn Jewish charitable and religious circles, died yesterday in the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital at the age of 75.

Mrs. Dorothy Campbell, 30 years old, who lived at the Kenmore Hall Hotel, 145 East Twenty-third Street, leaped to her death from the sixteenth floor of the hotel early last night, landing on a second-floor extension
Freddy Miller, 128, Cincinnati, former world featherweight champion, defeated Max Fisher, 134 1/2, Newark, last night in the feature eight-round bout at Dexter Park before a crowd of 3,000.

Slipping into the Dearborn Street Station at 11:48 o'clock this morning, the Santa Fe Railroad's new streamlined train, Super Chief, broke the record for the 2,228-mile run from Los Angeles to Chicago, with an elapsed time of 36 hours and 49 minutes.

Silvery Cloud, given a rousing stretch ride by Jockey Paul Ryan, won the featured Glen Ellyn purse at Aurora today. The winner, from the Chicago stable of Leo Beyda, had to be booted and whipped all the way home to win, just lasting to nip Wegoway, the color-bearer of Mrs. George Spaeth, ridden by Jockey R. Haber, who got his mount up with a belated rush.

The increasing effect of the competition of the city's Independent Subway System on the I. R. T. and B. M. T. was recognized yesterday in a Transit Commission report listing the total traffic carried by the rapid transit lines in the city in 1936.

Jay St, 49, 22.3x57.1; Central Savings Bank to Antonio Manniello, 1,941 E 13th St, Brooklyn ($17). 7th St, 264 E, 22.8x90.10; Moses Keschner to Fifth Ave Bank as trustee, David A. Lauferty; mtg, $7,000 ,held by grantee ($7.50).

The Federal District Penitentiary has adopted a minimum wage land granted union privileges in an experiment for rehabilitating criminals. The prisoners will be known as "Natural Biological Units Susceptible of Correction," and will work in the prison shops like free men.

Production of petroleum in Venezuela in March amounted to 2,227,656 metric tons, compared with 1,940,652 metric tons in the preceding month, and 1,910,505 metric tons in March, 1936, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the office of the American commercial attach, Caracas.

An increase of $24,100 in sales of products made by Sheltered Industries under the supervision of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor was reported at its annual meeting last night at 401 State Street, Brooklyn.

Combining six hits against righthander Gus Rook with four infield errors by their opponents, Harvard's nine took an eight-run lead in the second inning against Northeastern University today and beat the Huskies, 12 to 3. A cloudburst brought the one-sided battle to an abrupt finish after seven innings.

The annual report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for 1936, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $7,094,578, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to 99 cents a share on the common stock outstanding at the end of the period. This compares with a net of $6,296,835, or 85 cents a common share, in 1935.
Among the realty deals reported yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx were several involving properties which will be remodeled by the new owners.

Eighty students of the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street. will be graduated this evening at exercises in the seminary's chapel. Thatcher M. Brown, president of the board of directors, will confer the degrees. Speakers will include Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president, and the Rev. William P. Merrill of the board.

In an exhibition of simultaneous play given at the Marshall Chess Club last night, Frank J. Marshall, former national champion and recent club title winner, defeated twenty opponents. He was held to a draw by Dr. A. N. Rosen.

The latest link in the Salvation Army's coast-to-coast chain of homes for young women, Evangeline House, a six-story residence at 11 Dominick Street, will be dedicated at 3:30 P. M. today. The address of dedication will be made

Governors Island Paragraph 3, Special Orders 99. April 29, 1937, granting Capt. Walter H. Stubenrauch, Med.-Res., leave of absence for three months, effective on or about April 30, 1937, is amended so as to grant him leave of absence for fifteen days, effective on or about April 30.

A. Kyle Mitchell, who started his career as a messenger, was ap??ointed yesterday general sales ??anager of the Western Union ??elegraph Company, it was an??ounced by J. C. Willever, first rice president.

King Christian's silver jubilee festivities ended today after he had driven again in state from Amalienborg to the City Hall. Enormous crowds from the provinces lined the route and jammed City Hall Square In the City Hall the King and Queen received the Lord Mayor and the City Councilors.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn paid $175 to a private Brooklyn attorney out of public funds last year, in addition to expenses of traveling both by train and airplane, to find and return to the prosecutor's custody one of the defendants in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case, it was charged today by the defense in 1th Parker consniracv trial here.
Olin Dutra, Wilshire Country Club of Los Angeles professional, was low man today with 70, 72142 in the qualifying rounds for the national open golf championship in the Southern California area.

Dr. Solomon Goldenkranz, who was for twenty-five years Tammany leader of the Eighth Assembly District, formerly the Tenth, on the lower East Side, died yesterday at his home, 68 St. Mark's Place, after a two-month illness, at the age of 69. Surviving are his widow, the former Gertrude Jacobs, and two daughters, Mrs. Naomi Oltarsh and Mrs. Mary Klein.

J. B. Partridge's Sunanair, who has been knocking at the door all season, finally came into his own yesterday and captured the Novelty Handicap at a mile and a furlong which featured the racing card at Belmont Park. In a driving finish through the stretch he got up to win by a length from Brown Twig from the stable of Mrs. Robert H. Heighe. A. H. Waterman's Count Stone was third.
Eighteen Spanish Government military airplanes became lost in fog today and were forced to land in Southern France.

The Popular Front, which embraces all the left wing parties, was reinforced today as the result of the official confirmation of a decision by the radical groups definitely to join forces for the Presidential elections next year.

Yale today won a varsity tennis tournament from Princeton, 6 to 3, but the Princeton freshmen defeated the Yale yearlings, 7 to 2. In the varsity singles matches the universities were even, each winning three, but Yale swept the doubles.

Donald Chalmers, musical director of the Ocean Grove Auditorium for twenty years and well-known bass soloist, died this morning at his home in Wannamassa, near here. He was 58 years old. Mr. Chalmers appeared with Mme. Schumann-Heink in a nation-wide tour in 1912, and also appeared with Mme. Nordica and Mme. Melba at various music festivals.
A proposal to pay for next year's relief expenditures with new money, backed 100 per cent by the nation's supply of idle silver and gold, came today from Representative Dies, Texas Democrat.
The Republican State Central Committee today unanimously elected former Senator Daniel 0. Hastings of Wilmington as national committeeman to succeed C. Douglas Buck.

The Supreme Court sustained today Interstate Commerce Commission orders directing certain railroads to stop paying refunds to five industrial concerns for moving freight cars about their own plants for loading or unloading.

Mrs. Mildred Brink, a store manager here,had her store receipts of $325.53 back today after the cash and checks had made a trip to the village dump in a waste paper basket where they had been put for safekeeping.

All doubts regarding the place, time and manner of the Duke of Windsor's marriage to Mrs. Wallis Warfield will be set at rest tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 when Herman L. Rogers will hand newspaper men at the customary conference place just inside the gates of the Chateau de Cande a 100-word statement giving at least an outline of. the couple's plans.

Howard Anthony Miller, 39-year-old fence builder, of Newark, who killed his estranged wife, Edith, 36, in her apartment in Haledon, N. J., on March 22, was sentenced to life imprisonment today by Common Pleas Judge Robert M. Davidson, because no premeditation was evident and because Miller used no weapon. He-was permitted to plead non vult, thus escaping trial.

More than 1,200 life insurance executives and agents climbed from their beds early yesterday to attend the "Early Birds Breakfast" in the Hotel Astor at 8:15 A. M., beginning the observance in this city of the fifth annual Life Insurance Week.
The Cardinals of the National League coasted to an easy 14-to-5 victory over the Columbus American Association Red Birds in an exhibition game before 1,500 today.

The New York Athletic Club will hold its annual carnival June 12 on the lawn at the Travers Island Clubhouse, which will be transformed into a playground from 6 P. M. until past midnight. The committee, headed by Eugene B. Sanger, is arranging for a Monte Carlo background with more than $1,000,000 in stage money expected to change hands.
A Louisiana tax on chain stores, expected to have a far-reaching effect on the future of such stores if duplicated by other States, was upheld today by the Supreme Court in a four-tothree decision.

By proudly carrying a plate, containing three slices of bread, a salt shaker and several pennies, across the threshold, Phyllis Joyce, 5-yearold daughter of a department store employee, formally opened yesterday the four-room, FHA-sponsored Little House constructed in Bloomingdale's basement. The house,

A public offering by prospectus will be made today of $1,550,000 of first mortgage 51/2 per cent sinking fund bonds, with detachable stockpurchase warrants, of Struthers Wells-Titusville Corporation at 100 and interest by Van Alstyne, Noel Co. The warrant entitles a

The Senators came from behind in the eighth inning today to tally two runs and win a 4-to-3 decision over the Red Sox and give Jimmy De Shong his fourth straight victory. He was opposed by Wes Ferrell.
Thirty years spent in tracking down pyromaniacs and incendiaries were celebrated yesterday by Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy in his office at Manhattan fire headquarters. Mr.
King Gustav and 40,000 of his countrymen saw England defeat Sweden, 4--0, today in an international soccer match.
For two hours tonight the King and Queen and Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose watched a special full edition of the coronation news reels.

The Rev. James Murdock Huntting, 91-year-old Presbyterian minister of Glassboro, N. J., one of the oldest living alumni of New York University, was among the six men and one woman who by "outstanding service" to the university have been selected to receive the 1937 Alumni Meritorious Service Awards.
A record of its kind was established when 1,758 persons went on an inspection trip to the works of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Altoona, Pa., on Sunday, it was announced by the company yesterday.
George Zengaras, West Side lightweight, pounded out a close victory over Al Casimini of Corona in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.
Oscar O. Barr, Superintendent of Schools of South Amboy, N. J., for twenty-three years, pleaded guilty in Criminal Court here today to a charge of driving an automobile while intoxicated.

Irving Sacks, 55 years old, a resident of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria and head of two concerns in the midtown district, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate penitentiary term of not more than three years by Justices Bayes, Flood and Curran in Special Sessions as a garnishee racketeer.

Operations in the grain markets were restricted today as the result of a holiday in the European markets, but belated short covering in the May deliveries on the Board of Trade resulted in congestion developing and they advanced readily.
St. Louis baseball fans were doomed to disappointment-at least for the present-with the arrival today of Bill Terry's Giants, who open a threegame series with the Cardinals tomorrow.

Nearly 1,000 public officials and friends of William Breitenbach, Democratic leader of the Thirteenth Assembly District in Williamsburg, attended the funeral yesterday from his home, 274 Manhattan Avenue. They all marched

The French liner Normandie, arriving today from Havre and Southampton, is the first ship to return to New York with coronation passengers. On board are Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair, with Mrs. Whalen; Percy S. Straus, chairman of the committee on architecture and

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Margaret S. Donald, daughter of Mrs. Hugh Colligan Donald of Paisley, Scotland, to William D. Plumb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Plumb of Berwyn, is to take place on June 19 in St. Martin's Church, Radnor. The Rev. Richard H. Gurley will officate.

The seven members of the National Bituminous Coal Commission who will administer the Vinson-Guffey Coal Act took the oath of office today from Secretary Ickes, in whose department the commission was put. The members, whose terms are for four years each, are:

Jacob M. Sulke, in 49 E. 86th St.: Regina Kendrick, in 9 E. 96th St.; Bryan Adams, in 111 E. 75th St.; Mrs. L. M. Torrence, in 345 E. 57th St.; Dr. William Hayn, through George F. Meyer, in 111 E. 88th St.; Culver. Hollyday Co., Inc., broker.
Senator Aquiles Concha announced today that a public hearing would be held on Wednesday at the Stock Exchange to consider measures for the nationalization of the copper industry of Chile.

Unknown to most of the 300 diners, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and two plainclothes men from the West Forty-seventh Street station attended a dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore, at which prizes were presented by the editors of the magazine Opinion to three winners of an essay contest who had written on the subject "How to Combat Anti-Semitism in America."

Consummation of the purchase of Goerke Sons, Newark, by the Hearn Department Stores was announced yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, vice president and general manager of Hearn's. The store will be taken over within thirty days and operated as Hearn's Newark branch. The amount of the transaction was not disclosed.

Pierre S. du Pont was called by surprise yesterday, spent four hours on the witness stand, and will resume his testimony at 10 A. M. today in the Old Postoffice Building, still under government questioning concerning $29,000,000 of stook transactions with John J. Raskob in 1929.

Presentation of awards to the winners in the essay contest conducted by America's Good-Will Union among the students of New York City's high schools will take place at noon today in front of the statue of George Washington in Wall Street. Miss Lucille Upfold of 59 Johnson Avenue, Tottenville,

Mile after sandy mile he walks alone, Forgetful of the food upon his back. Perhaps he thinks he doesn't really own The knapsack, for although his lips may crack With thirst, he does not touch the bright canteen. Around him is the desert, but he sees Only mirage-a vision cool and green

To the Filmarte in West Fiftyeighth Street this afternoon comes the Viennese musical film, "The World's in Love," which traces its heritage to Franz Lehar's "CloClo." Chief among the players are Leo Slezak, former Metropolitan Opera tenor; Marta Eggerth and Ida Wuest, Rolf Wanka and Hans Moser.

Pleas for less secrecy in foreign affairs, a reminder that a successful foreign policy requires the support of public opinion, and the suggestion that hunts for spies be officially discouraged among petty officials when dealing with foreign tourists were features of Foreign Minister Naotake Sato's speech to Prefectural Governors today.

While examining the plaintiff in the Bronx Court of Small Claims, Henry Hyman, 49 years old, of 150-51 Eighty-seventh Avenue, Jamaica, the defendant, who was acting as his own counsel, collapsed and died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon. Municipal Court Justice Phillip J. Sinnott was on the bench at the time.

The long-awaited plan of reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, which has been under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act since September, 1935, was announced yesterday with the filing of an amended plan in the United States District Court in Delaware.

Major efforts to obtain a compromise on President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the Federal judiciary collapsed today and an adverse report on the bill tomorrow by the Senate Judiciary Committee is expected.
Rio Grande do Sul women have addressed to Governor J. A. Flores da Cunha a petition urging him to do his utmost to insure peace. The Rio Grande do Sul Medical Association has made a similar appeal.

Gun Hill Rd (12-3344), n e s at w s Tyram Ave, 210x117; Omaha Estates, Inc, to Max Nisnewitz, 1,375 Ocean Ave, Brooklyn. 140th St (10-2592), n s, 368 e of Southern Blvd, 125x100; Prudential Iron Works, Inc, to Prudential Steel Corp, 530 Gruxton St.

Mrs. Mary Norton, chairman of the House District of Columbia Committee and therefore "Maybress' of Washington, joining today in a radio broadcast sponsored by a group of insurance women, said that she previously never had dreamed of the privilege of working women to provide for themselves "insurance security."

Problems of consumer relations, vendors' relations, installment selling and State and national legislation will be studied at the Conference of Retail Executives to be held in Washington on June 3 to 5 under the sponsorship of the American Retail Federation, it was announced yesterday by Colonel C. O. Sherrill, president of the federation.

After weeks of agitation and several exchanges through diplomatic channels with the French Government, the State Department informed the French Embassy tonight that the proposed transatlantic air race to commemorate the tenth anniversary of Colonel Charels A. Lindbergh's solo flight to Paris would not be permitted by the Commerce Department of the United States.

WALTON AVE, 1,356 (11-2841);- Benjamin Goldberg to Franklin Savings Bank, extends mtg to April 27, 1940 at 4 1/2 per cent: $117,000. 224th St, 680 E (17-4825); Julius Weissman to Bronx Savings Bank, extends mtg to April 14, 1942 at 4 1/2 per cent; $109,000.

Another step to widen the schism between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was taken yesterday with the arrival here of Allan S. Haywood, formerly of Peoria, Ill., to direct the regional office of the C. I. O. in New York.

Contending that cordial commercial relations are the key to world peace, James S. Carson, vice president of American and Foreign Power Company, yesterday called for a broader view of international trade in a speech launching a series of celebrations in observation of National Foreign Trade Week.

Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, will sell tomorrow an issue of $50,000,000 of short-term notes of the State against revenues to be received after the beginning of the next fiscal year. The notes will bear interest at the rate of 0.75 per cent and will run six months, being dated May 19 and due on Nov. 19.

Fifteen hundred to 2,000 persons filled every seat and all available standing room at the New Amsterdam Theatre Sunday night to urge Governor LEHMAN to veto the Dunnigan bill. This city and the theatrical profession are evidently in no mood to submit meekly to a dictatorial censorship.
Vince Dundee of Belleville, former world's middleweight champion, decisively outpointed Thys Menger of Paterson in the feature eight-round boxing bout at Laurel Garden tonight.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn announced last night the arrest of three men in Fort Wayne, Ind., as fugitives on an indictment charging them with exploding stench and tear-gas bombs in Brooklyn motion picture houses. Mr. Geoghan asserted that he had facts "proving these three men were the brains of a nationwide ring using these coercive methods -in labor disputes in moving picture houses."

Reports by 142 Class I railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed that these companies earned an aggregate net operating income of $69,379;328 in March, against $35,152,475 in March, 1936, an increase of 97.4 per cent. For the first three months of the year, the increase internet operating income was 39.9 per cent. The statement follows:
Samuel Wagner, president emeritus of the Wagner Free Institute of Science, of which he was president for thirty-seven years until 1921, died at his home here today in his ninety-fifth year.

The "Ship Comes Home," Daisy Fisher's comedy which opened at St. Martin's Theatre tonight, is another play With a ramshackle boarding house as a setting and, as usually is the case when action is built on this plan, it is a dramatic composition more than a collection of acting parts. All characters, however, are real people and come to life at the hands of a fine company.

Eugene Brieux's "Damaged Goods" is quickly over. That is the most commendable aspect of the revival which was staged at the Forty-Eighth Street last evening. For even a new adaptation cannot conjure a play out of the medical facts and case histories about syphilis that Brieux made into a perfunctory stage tract and offered to startled New York audiences in 1913.

Intensification of the drive to eliminate chiselerss" from the WPA rolls in this city was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local administrator, after an experimental survey had indicated that 8,500 relief workers were no longer in need of Federal aid.

The large Renoir exhibition which opens this afternoon privately and to the public tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum covers a span of forty-five years. The earliest of the sixty-two canvases, "Portrait of Mme. Darras," is dated 1871; the latest, a small "Femme Nue Couchee," 1916, three years prior to the great French artist's death.

Hans Freund, only surviving rigger of the Hindenburg crew, testified at the official investigation today that he believed the fire that destroyed the dirigible and took thirtysix lives was caused by an explosion in a hydrogen cell in the stern of the ship. He said he had no idea what caused the explosion.

The Bureau or Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 14: COMMANDERS Hall, R. A., Naval Academy, to the Minneapolis as executive officer. Weyerbacher, R. D., Third Naval District, to home, relieved from all active duty.
AS the Giants headed westward Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick was sporting a flowered tie and promising that the Polo Grounders would rush to the front on the road.

Alexander J. Brady, assistant to the controller of the Erie Railroad, was under cross-examination throughout today's session in the Federal court trial of the suit of that company and the Lehigh Valley, the Delaware, Lackawanna Western, the New York Central and the Central

The Martel quadruplets died one by one in a hospital early today, the last about seventeen hours after their entry into the world in the bedroom of Mrs. Paul Martel's East End home. Premature by two months, they weakened rapidly through the night.

President Roosevelt discussed his forthcoming message on power policies with his Power Policy Committee, conferred with Chairman Jones of the House Agriculture Committee on farm legislation and discussed departmental affairs with Cabinet heads and bureau chiefs.

Lieutenant A. F. Rowe, adjutant of the Bermuda Militia Artillery, which is in camp on St. David's Island, boarded the liner Queen of Bermuda Saturday afternoon to bid good-bye to friends sailing, meaning to disembark by tender at St. George's.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels moved yesterday to discourage appeals from real estate assessments which are made with no intention of seeking a speedy decision in the courts. He asked for a ruling that would pave the way for the immediate dismissal of 400 pending certiorari cases for lack of prosecution.
A monthly high record of 561 young men and women left upState National Youth Administration projects in April for private employment, Karl D. Hesley, upState NYA director, announced yesterday.
Charles Spencer Anderson has resigned as controller at the Ambassador Hotel to become assistant manager of Horwarth Horwarth in Detroit. He will be succeeded by Leroy J. Schellhardt.

Mrs. Eleanor Juliana Betterton Pearsall, who, as Nellie Glover, appeared in theatre and opera in this country for about fifteen years in the post-Civil War period, died yesterday at her home in Tenafly, N. J., at the age of 87.

David J. Hamilton, retired plumbing contractor of Queens, died Saturday in Post-Graduate Hospital of a heart ailment. Born in Manhattan seventy-two years ago, he had lived in Queens forty years. For twenty-seven years he was a member of the firm of Weber Hamilton, Long Island City, retiring sixteen years ago.

The annual New York East conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church ended its six-day session yesterday with the adoption of the social service report endorsing the Wagner act and the age limit for members of the Supreme Court. The C. I. 0. and the sit-down strike, however, failed to receive approval.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Russell S. Coutant, Asbury S. Edmonds, E. Fontaine Broun, Clyde Brown Jr., Clarence W. Nutt and Charles I. Katz of New York City, were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had:

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, predicted tonight that all the mass industries would be organized within six months and "nobody will be talking about it." "It will be accepted as a fact," he added, "and this friction between the big unions and certain industries will be settled as it has been in Scranton for years."

MANHATTAN BUCKLEY, GEORGE D. (Dec. 19, 1935). Gross assets, $204,498; net: $134,937. To Catherine M. Buckley and Mabel V. Buckley, sisters, one-half each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $91,899. Mitchell, Taylor, Capron Marsh, attorneys, 20 Exchange Pl.

With Justice McReynolds alone dissenting, the Supreme Court refused today to open the way to processors of farm products for recovery of $963,000,000 of unconstitutional processing taxes collected under the original farm program.

Lambert B.. Pickwick, architect who designed many homes in the suburbs of Newark, died last night at his home here after a long illness. He was one of the architects for the extensive Druid Hills residential development in Summit' and an organizer and the director of

Great enthusiasm was shown tonight at Varsity Arena as Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, honored British music and one of Canada's most noted conductors. The opening number on the program was an unheralded rendition of Sir Edward Elgar's "Pomp and Circumstance."

The establishment of a new city department to supervise playgrounds was suggested yesterday by Herman E. Cooper, attorney for the Playground Directors Association, in a letter to Acting Mayor William F. Brunner.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Henry Kratch, formerly a member of H. L. 17, residing at 394 Quentin Road. Brooklyn, died May 9. Special Leave In accordance with Section 18-AA of the Labor Law, Chapter 301, Laws of 1936, leave of absence, with pay, is granted to Marine Stoker Hubert Goode, Engine 77, from 12 noon, April 20, to 8 A. M., April 27, 1937, inclusive.

The threat of a strike on the trolley and bus lines of the Third Avenue Railway system was again averted yesterday, when the city Industrial Relations Board, after a meeting at City Hall, announced that it would supervise an election to determine the proper agent for collective bargaining with the company management, from among the competing unions.

Martin W. Littleton Jr., District Attorney of Nassau County, startled the public hearing held today before Governor Lehman on the Hall bill to legalize dog racing by charging that Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission, had "sponsored" lotteries on the Futurity at Belmont and had won twice, collecting $12,000 on one occasion.

INSPECTOR OF SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT (SHOES AND SOLE LEATHER), $2,000 a year, Nayal Clothing Depot, Brooklyn, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the manager, Second U. S. Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher St., New York, N. Y., not later than June 1. Competitors will not be required

Dr. Robert E. Speer of New York, secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, was elected president of the board of trustees of the Princeton Theological Seminary at its annual meeting here today. Dr. Speer succeeds the Rev. Dr. William McEwan of Pittsburgh, president since 1929.

The Senate passed and sent to the House today the Norris resolution which directs the Federal Trade Commission to investigate propaganda by electric utilities, whether privately owned or operated by the government.

Direct news from Tirana, Albania, indicates that the Argyrokastron uprising has been completely quelled and that the situation is rapidly returning to normal. All reports stress that the outbreak was purely local and they point to the ease with which government forces regained control.
Mexico's oil industry offered its workers wage increases totaling $2,000,000 annually today and waited to see whether the move would avert a threatened walkout May 27.

Federal Judge William H. Holly approved today a plan to reorganize the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation and the Chesapeake Export Company, by which the assets of the corporation, approximately $746,900, are to be distributed to the creditors and the various classes of security holders.

Mrs. Joseph L. Sariego of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Griselda De Castro, to James N. Peale Jr., a member of the graduating class at West Point, and the son of

Postmaster General James A. Farley and Postmaster Albert Goldman yesterday dedicated a new building for Postoffice Station D, one of the first district postal stations to be established in New York and the United States.

Final preparations were being made today for the opening of the thirteenth annual Westchester music festival next Thursday night at the County Center here. The festival will continue Friday and Saturday nights.

A series of evening appraisal meetings will be conducted by the Brooklyn Real Estate Board at the Brooklyn Club, starting on Thursday with a talk by James B. Fisher outlining methods of valuing industrial properties. M. C. O'Brien and Charles Partridge will be speakers at later meetings.

The auction sale on Saturday of thirty-four properties at Sewaren, N. J., formerly owned by the Sewaren Estates, resulted in purchases totaling $34,333, Joseph P. Day, auctioneer, reported yesterday. The parcels included residential plots and waterfront industrial and boathouse sites. Bernard P. Day conducted the sale for Mrs. E. J. de Forest.
George Billings took a peak at something behind him yesterday and his head got stuck. He walked for two blocks looking backward, then bounded into the Savre police station for help.

The average class in the elementary schools of this city will be smaller next year than at any time since the consolidation of the five boroughs nearly forty years ago, Rufus A. Vance, Assistant Superintendent of Schools in charge of class organization, disclosed yesterday.

Members of the Junior League were warned tonight against considering themselves a preferred group. Mrs. Peter L. Harvie of Troy, president of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, gave the warning at a dinner opening the organization's annual conference.
Mrs. Victor C. Mather, well-known sportswoman and sister of Governor George H. Earle, died of a heart attack at her home, Avon Wood Cottage, Haverford, this morning.

Dr. Guido Schmidt, the Austrian Foreign Minister, will pay an official visit to the French Government on his way home from London this week. He declares that the Austrian Government is determined to resort to arms to resist a direct and eventual attack by Germany on Austrian territory and insists that France and Britain publish a joint declaration which, in practice, would pledge them to military support.

A sentence of four to eight years in Sing Sing was imposed by General Sessions Judge Donnellan yesterday on John Wight Austin, 36 years old, disbarred lawyer, for defrauding friends and also clients of the firm in which he was a junior member of more than $500,000 since 1932.
A seamen's strike was called today on Lykes Brothers' ships, largest fleet in Gulf waters. At least five vessels, one at Houston, one at Beaumont and three at new Orleans, were affected.
Turpentine firm, 35hc; sales, 206 barrels; receipts, 412 barrels; shipments, 1,403 barrels; stock, 24,468 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 641: receipts, 1,261; shipments, 4,383; stock, 43,592.

A 56-year-old woman was shot land critically wounded at about 11:30 o'clock last night during a street chase in which policemen exchanged shots with two robber suspects in West 170th Street, the Bronx.

Earnings of the Technicolor Corporation for the first quarter of 1937 were estimated at $166,000 before taxes compared with $132,000 in the 1936 period stockholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday. H. K. McCann was elected a director.

A resolution endorsing a bill now before the New Jersey Legislature which would fix a basic retail selling price on all groceries was adopted by the New Jersey Retail Grocers Association at its fiftieth annual convention which closed here tonight after a two-day meeting.
It appeared tonight that London's 25,500 busmen must carry on their strike for shorter hours and better wages without the direct aid of other transport workers.

Walter Damrosch's opera, "The Man Without a Country," had its second performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. A large audience received the work and its interpreters with evidences of pleasure. The composer watched the proceedings from a box.
William C. Chanler, First Assistant Corporation Counsel, said yesterday that he expected the Court of Appeals decision on the constitutionality of proportional representation voting today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for May 25 in connection with a registration statement filed on Feb. 21, 1936, by the American General Corporation of Jersey City, of which David M. Milton is president. The company is one of the subsidiaries of the Equity Corporation.
Belgium's Davis Cup tennis team advanced to the third round of European zone competition today with a 4-1 conquest of Switzerland.

Mr. and Mrs. William Rodman Fay of 176 East Sixty-fourth Street and Northeast Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elise Helen Fay, to James Lindsay Ware, son of Mrs. C. Lindsay Ware of Cambridge, Mass.
Changes in prices on the local commodity markets were irregular yesterday, with coffee, cocoa and cottonseed oil futures firmer, while sugar, rubber and hides declined.

Instead of easing along seasonal lines, automobile production was slightly higher last week and the adjusted index has advanced to 133.2 from 131.3 (revised) in the previous week, comparing with 112.7 for the week ended May 16, 1936.

Manhattan Alterations Pitt St, 17: to five-story tenement and store; Isidore Goldstein, 129 Ridge St, owner; H. P. Epstein, architect; cost, $8,500. Forsythe St, 146: to five-story tenement and store; Citizens Savings Bank, 58 Bowery, owner; Robert Telchman, architect; cost, $3.500.

The attitude of the Catholic Church in New York on the Dunnigan bill, which would empower the Commissioner of Licenses to close shows he deemed immoral, was defined last night in an announcement from the chancery of the archdiocese that the statement of

Lieut. Gov. Thomas E. Knight Jr., special prosecutor in the Scottsboro case, died late today at a hospital there. He was 39 years old. Death was caused by a complication of liver and kidney ailments. Governor Bibb Graves, expressing deep sorrow when notified of Mr. Knight's death, said the State Capitol would be closed tomorrow.

Playing in intermittent showera fifty combinations toured the tricky Wheatley Hills course today in the Long Island Golf Association amateur-professional competition and the ones fortunate enough to escape the rain prevailed in the end.

Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, referee, has submitted a report to Kings County Surrogate George A. Wingate recommending that Assistant District Attorney John J. Kean of Brooklyn and Edward H. Wilson, former attorneys for the estate of Joseph Auditore. wealthy stevedore.
Returning from Philadelphia, the Davis Cup teams of Australia and the United States yesterday launched their second week of practice at Forest Hills in preparation for their match May 29, 30 and 31.
Placements by the Federal Employment Service in private industry in April set a three-year record of 219,441, Secretary Perkins said today.

The State of Mississippi has scheduled for sale on June 2 an issue of $2,500,000 of highway notes, dated April 1, 1937, and maturing on Oct. 1, 1938 to 1955. The notes are to carry interest at a rate not exceeding 4 per cent.
Pitcher Bob Feller took a workout today, and afterward Manager Steve O'Neill of the Indians said he was "100 per cent" recovered from the arm injury which has kept him out of the game three weeks.

Approximately thirty persons, of whom at least twenty were Japanese and the rest Chinese, perished this evening when a boiler exploded aboard a steam launch belonging to the Osaka Shosen Kaisha as it was taking passengers to .the steamer Rio de Janeiro Maru.

The Federal Trade Commission has issued a complaint charging that Reeves, Parvin Co., wholesale grocers, the Tri-State Brokerage Company, and their president, Francis B. Reeves Jr., all of 400 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia, have violated the brokerage section of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination act.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 17 unless specified: Pearl Harbor to San Francisco, May 15: Gannet, Sandpiper. Asheville, Swatow to Hong Kong. Augusta, Hankow to Shanghai, May 15: Bridge, San Diego to San Pedro.

Derbyshire and Worcestershire gained victories in county cricket matches concluded today-a day ahead of schedule. The champion county defeated Essex by 74 runs at Chelmsford, Worcestershire, getting a margin of 113 runs over Warwickshire at Birmingham.

The entire Roosevelt family will attend a wedding June 30 of Miss Ethel duPont and Franklin Roosevelt Jr., at Christiana Hundred. Mrs. Roosevelt said today that Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Roosevelt, who are leaving the White House for
The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's main-line trestle over the Lieutenant River here was destroyed by fire today, causing the rerouting of many fast trains on the New York-Boston run.

The city's general death rate for the week ended last Saturday was 10.4 per 1,000 of population and the infant mortality rate was 42.5 per 1,000 live births, both low marks for the year, Dr. John J. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday in the weekly health survey.

The Giants' dash into the West flattened out like a squash against a brick wall today as the Cardinals, behind Lon Warneke, triumphed over the combined efforts of Clydell Castleman and Hal Schumacher to win the opening game of a three-game series 4 to 3.
N. E. Halbrouck, engineer and designer, told The St. Augustine Record today of plans for a $2,000,000 aquarium and marine studio south of Summer Haven.

By ROBERT FISHEL St. Marks PI, 67, 5-story tenement and stores, 25x93.11; Richard Ely, trustee, against 67 St. Marks Place, Inc.; due, $21,730; taxes, , $1,600; to plaintiff for $20,000. 11th St, 619 E., 5-story tenement and stores, 25x103.3; Emil Reineking against Irving Dankner; due, $4,691; taxes, , $770; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Lenox Ave, n e cor 140th St, runs n e 199.10 to 141st St, s e 225, s w 88.11, w 18.2, n w 135.10, s w 99.11 to 140th St, n w 75 to-beg; New York Railways Corp (H. J. Sheeran, pres) to Street Railway Liquidating Corp (H. J. Sheeran, pres), 123 W 146th St. Same property; Guaranty Trust Co., as trustee, agreement dated April 20,. 1925, to same, quitclaim.

A mortgage of $1,100,000, at 5 per cent interest for ,fifteen years, on the Chester Crest Apartments in Fleetwood, Westchester County, has been placed with the Prudential Insurance Company of America for Anthony Morell, president of the owning corporation. Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., negotiated ,the transactions.
The Yale freshman nine topped Choate School today, 11-8. The cubs made four runs in the first inning and never relinquished the lead.

General economic conditions and the financial situation throughout the twelve Federal Reserve districts were discussed today by the Federal Advisory Council, which met with the Federal Reserve Board in quarterly session.

Al Cuccinello's ninth-inning home run gave the Rochester Red Wings a 9-to-8 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs today. Trailing 8 to 1 going into the seventh inning, the Chiefs drove out ten hits and tallied seven runs off four pitchers in the last three innings to knot up the game in the ninth.

Japan's leading political parties, the Minseito and Seiyukai, announced today their intention to overthrow the government of Premier Senjuro Hayashi, whose army-supported Cabinet met a sweeping defeat in recent parliamentary elections.

Dr. George A. Leitner, a leader in the Democratic party of this State and a noted surgeon, died early yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old.

Fifty-nine nations are expected to return formal acceptance to participate in the New York World's Fair before midsummer, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, who returned on the French liner Normandie.
The German film industry has fallen down completely on its production promises and henceforth until Autumn American films will dominate the German film market.

Adhering to the formula that all French foreign policy shall be "within the framework of the League of Nations and in conformity with its principles," Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos and Premier Leon Blum began today a series of international conversations that are certain to draw much comment in Germany, Italy and elsewhere.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his long letter to Senators Glass, Bulkley and others on the Supreme Court, Ambassador William E. Dodd presented a list of early land decisions of that body as though he were transmitting information which had never before been brought out.

(Israel Cumsky, pres.) to Michael Eisensteat, 760 Montgomery St, Brooklyn; pr mtg, $14,425 due May 15, 1940, 4 per cent; $2,000. 118th St, 264-66 W. 50x100.11; Tampardo Realty Corp. (Wm. P. Doing, pres.) to Central Savings Bank, p m 5 yrs, into per bond; $45,000.

A hearing has been called. for June 3 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an application by the Central and Southwest Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, for approval of the payment of dividends of $1.75 on each outstanding share of preferred stock, $7 dividend series, and of $1.50 on each outstanding share of prior lien preferred stock, $6 dividend series.
Opening dates for the four New York National Guard Summer training camps were announced today by Brig. Gen. Walter G. Robinson, the adjutant general.

The Pere Marquette Railway reduced its loan from the Railroad Credit Corporation to $672,223 in 1936, according to the report to stockholders for that period issued yesterday. The loan stood originally at $1,855.000.

J. M. Daiger, special assistant to Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, has been appointed financial adviser to the Federal Housing Administration. He will maintain offices here and in New York.

Miss Constance E. Matthiessen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Matthiessen of Irvington-on-Hudson, was married to Clarence E. Galston, son of Federal Judge and Mrs. Clarence G. Galston of Woodmere, L. I., yesterday morning in the Presbyterian Church at Harrison, N. Y.
G. William Gale, cashier of the Fifth Third Union Trust Company, largest bank in this section of the country, died at his home here today of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

The only native New Yorker of the twelve debutantes of the Metropolitan Opera this Spring season will make her first appearance Friday evening in the revival of Henri Rabaud's comedy-opera, "Marouf." She is Nancy McCord, who will take the role of Princess Saamcheddine.

In "Ladies and Gentlemen," staged at the Strand Theatre tonight, Norman Hunter portrays an idle, rich household whose antics, dressed up in a kind of gaudy slickness, progress beyond the point at which trifling inconsequential and frivolous nonsense remain tolerable.

Floods of rhetorical denunciation swept the Dail Eireann tonight when President Eamon de Valera's government proceeded to pilot through the House the bill awarding to the Free State's last Governor General, Donal Buckley, a gratuity of [pound]2,000 with a yearly pension of [pound]500 for life.
Justice Van Devanter's letter to President Roosevelt announcing his retirement from the Supreme Court, and the President's reply, were as follows:

Steel-ingot production last week was slightly lower but the decrease was less than seasonal and the adjusted index gained a little, standing at 121.3, as against 121.2 in the previous week. For the week ended May 16, 1936, the index was 92.8.

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, honorary chairman of the Women's Division of the Joint Distribution Committee, which is seeking funds for relief in Eastern and Central Europe, will be guest of honor at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

The founders of the little red brick synagogue on Welfare Island celebrated its tenth anniversary there yesterday. While a bright sun slanted through windows whose sills were brightened by cut flowers, the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women held a special service at which speakers reviewed the history of the place of worship they gave to the city.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City received last night a bronze tablet "for meritorious public service" from the New York Lodge, No. 1, of the B'nai B'rith. Dr. Harold Korn, president of the lodge, made the presentation at the Federation Building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

R. H. Hyde, Federal. Communications Commission examiner, recommended today the granting of the application, of the R.C.A. Communications, Inc., for additional radio frequencies to use in sending commercial messages between New York and Washington, New York and Bostqn, and San Francisco and Los Angeles.

Winning one-day golf tournaments seems to be Miss Grace Amory's favorite pastime this Spring. In her third start of the season today she took her third low gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association weekly affair at the Old Oaks Country Club.

Bonds again moved in an uncertain manner yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. A quickening of the trading pace did not bring about a uniform price trend and, with the exception of moderate strength in the higher-grade corporate loans and local traction issues, quotations reflected hesitancy on the part of traders generally and declines were scattered throughout the secondary corporate list. Total transactions in all bonds amounted to $8,216,400, against $5.254.700 on Monday.

Joe Mulligan, Toronto right-hander, turned in one of the best pitching jobs of the International League season today, setting the leagueleading Newark Bears down with two hits to win by 4-2. The Leafs cut Newark's lead to one-and-ahalf games.

Deaths Announced Fireman First Grade John F. Mulligan Jr., Engine 278, died May 15. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 277 24th St.. Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M. Wednesday, May 19. Interment at Ioly Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

The Consolidated Edison Company and its affiliates filed a memorandum yesterday with Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, asking dismissal of the complaint and charges of violation of the Wagner National Labor Relations Act made against them by Mrs. Herrick on May 12.

County Judge Lee D. Van Woert, 49, of Otsego County, died in a hospitai here today several hours after he was found unconscious in his office, a bullet wound in his head. Coroner Norman Getman said he was satisfied the wound was selfinflicted, although members of the judge's family knew of no motive for suicide.

The sudden resignation of Justice Van Devanter astonished the capital today. Reports that the 78-yearold justice would leave the court had been rife for weeks, but his choice of this day, instead of the end of the term, dumfounded every one.
With cut prices still in effect on three branded whiskies of the National Distillers Products Corporation, the situation in the price war in the downtown area was unchanged here yesterday.

By GEORGE J. KEARNS Fieldston Rd, 4,731, 2-story frame dwelling and vacant plot, 180x147 irreg ; George H. Herbener against Josephine E. Galle ; due, $32,944 ; taxes, , $2,425 ; to plaintiff for $30,000.

An American woman has lost $375,000 as the result of a decision of the Nanking Supreme Court that religious freedom exists in the Soviet Union. The ancient town of Malmyzh in Vyatka Province has profited by the decision.

Louis Winsel, first contrabass player of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, gave a recital last night at Steinway Hall. Accompanied by Siegfried Winsel at the piano, he played a sonata in A major by Misek, "Canto del Pastore"

Charles A. Lindbergh put his entire life savings of $2,000 into his famous New York-to-Paris flight, made ten years ago Thursday, and planned to get his money back by a nation-wide barnstorming tour upon his return to America, Major Ashley C. McKinley writes in the June issue of The American Legion Monthly, published today.

The government will not make any changes in the Law 5580, controlling payments on foreign debt obligations as they now stand, it was announced today following insistent reports that payments would be suspended in accordance with the new policy being considered by the Minister of Finance,
The international stock market indices for May 15, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

New York City is authorized to issue ten-year assessment bonds for improving old-law tenements, the city to have a prior lien on the improved property, under the bill of Senator Murray, New York Democrat, signed today by Governor Lehman.

The Federal Court of Appeals denied a request by the Alabama Power Company and the Iowa City Light and Power Company today for more time to appeal from the court's decision last week on public works financing of municipal power projects.

Sir Evelyn Wrench, one of Great Britain's most distinguished Journalists and founder of the English-Speaking Union, today married Lady Des Veoux in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Knightsbridge. Sir Norman Angell was best man.

If "Orchids Preferred" managed to throw this column for a threeparagraph loss- last week, "Sea Legs" deserves equal consideration. For the nautical musical comedy which went into dry dock at the Mansfield last evening includes Dorothy Stone and Charles Collins, who are an attractive couple with a neat gift for dancing, and a boat deck setting calculated to panic a landsman's imagination.

Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general, has completed his book called "Shadow on the Land," and the publication date is now set by Reynal Hitchcock as June 7. It is a book on the fight against syphilis that Dr. Parran is leading.

While representatives of the Crucible Steel Corporation of America were conferring today with spokesmen for the Steel Workers Organization Committee, a C. I. O. affiliate, petitions were filed by the Employes Association of the company with the National Labor Relations Board, asking for an election to determine the exclusive agent for collective bargaining.
change has come over the outlook for the Winter wheat crop as a result of persistent dry weather. B. W. Snow, crop expert, issued today a special estimate on Kansas, Nebraska and Oklahoma,
The first omnibus Immigration Bill was left in the air by the House today after debating the measure all afternoon.
Jerome Ave (12-332B),. n w cor ot Mosholu Parkway N,. 105x110; Anne Mink to Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Co. Hartford, Conn; extends mtg to May 7, 1947, at 414 per cent: 5110.000.
Activity in Manhattan and Bronx real estate reported by brokers yesterday centered in residential holdings. Several of the properties were purchased by investors.

Numerous cases against friars or lay brothers in Catholic institutions during the last few weeks have been "show trials." These men convicted of immoral conduct, generally with minors, orphans and other inmates within cloister walls in various parts of Germany, had already been pronounced guilty after lengthy painstaking inquiries by prosecutors long before they were brought to public trial before regional courts.
Mrs. V. R. Hopper's Pharlocn scored a decisive triumph in the Hartford Purse, at a mile and onesixteenth for 3-year-olds, which featured today's card at Narragansett Park.

Bill Tobin, Lakeville star, won the eighteen-hole prelude to the annual triangular team matches when he scored a 75 over the difficult Arcola Country Club links today. The triangular matches for the Stoddard Bowl will be contested here tomorrow.
Miss Dorothy Dixon and Miss Millicent Cameron are two future brides. Miss Dixon's engagement to John Goebel Watson of Easton, Md., was announced recently by her father,

John M. Donovan, Dartmouth ace, who will defend both the 120yard high and the 220-yard low hurdles in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships at Randalls Island Stadium on May 28 and 29, will attempt to achieve a rare feat in these sixty-year-old games, the scoring of a repeat double.

A recovery in the outside markets brought about an improvement of nearly $1 a bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with gains of 11 to 17 points. The lowest quotations of the session were made at the opening.

Three confederates of the two gunmen who were,slain in a pistol battle with detectives on March 19 in the hold-up of the loft of Harry Bleweis Son, furriers, at 231 West Twenty-ninth Street, were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan. They had pleaded guilty the week before as they were about to be called for trial.
Stores here were notified yesterday of the establishment of suggested retail prices by Tampax, Inc., on its product Tampax, for feminine hygiene.
A committee for Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway convertible bonds of 1960, headed by Ralph Wolf, announced yesterday that it would cease representing the bondholders because of lack of funds.
Players preparing for the opening of the Meadow Brook Club's Spring championships swung into action on three fields today. Thomas Hitchcock Jr. and Stewart Iglehart, the game's 10-goal players;

Trading was fair on most classes. Lamb and fresh pork prices were strong to higher. Other classes were mostly unchanged. All kosher meats opened higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. BEEF STEER HINDS AND RIBS-Supplies were normal to light. Trading was fair at prices about steady with last week's decline but slow otherwise. A few outstanding prime heavyweights brought $29.
James Marshall, retired president of the Northern Fire Insurance Company of New York, died here early tonight at his home, 171 Vose Avenue, after a long illness. He was in his sixty-eighth year.

With close to 170 players participating, the New York Athletic Club opened its twenty-fifth year of golf today in a one-day tourney over the links of the Winged Foot Club. Flight prizes went to thirty-nine players and as many awards were given as consolation prizes.
Justwice Van Devanter announced his retirement from active service on the Supreme Court in a letter to President Roosevelt, which the President formally acknowledged.
Because of the construction of the new Sixth Avenue subway, the building occupied by the temporary galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, has been declared unsafe.

With the Packard Motor Car Company hinting in its newspaper advertising yesterday that automobile prices may have to go up because of increased costs, the opinion was expressed that such action, if it does eventuate, will not take place before the new models are introduced in September and October.

The alleged confessions of Gladys MacKnight, 18 years old, and her former admirer, Donald Wightman, 19, who are charged with the hatchet murder of Gladys's mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight, last July 31, provided a grim climax to the State's case this afternoon as the trial proceeded before Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a jury in Court of Oyer and Terminer.
Because of heavy imports, the government decided today to ship another 50,000,000 yen (about $14,394,150) in gold bullion to the United States at the end of the month in order to stabilize the yen.

Gina Pinnera, soprano, who has been heard locally on many occasions in the past decade, gave her annual recital last night at the Town Hall. Her appearance attracted, as usual, a sizable audience that gave frequent evidence of its enjoyment.
J. Clarence Bacon, proprietor of the: Palisades Hotel here for the last fourteen years, died last night at his home after. a long illness. He was 68 years old.

Paul Friedman, an attorney, was fined $250 for contempt of court yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff in Brooklyn. He was accused of tearing up a legal paper used in the taking of a deposition from his client, Prudencio Rivera Martinez, Commissioner of Labor of Puerto Rico. Mr. Friedman denied that his act involved contempt.
HARRY L. HOPKINS announces that more than 700,000 persons have been taught to read and write by various Federal relief agencies in the

Governor Harry Nice is about to undergo the removal of his right eye. He expects to leave for New York by June 1 and enter a hospital for the operation, made necessary by injury suffered in a fall shortly before his election in the Autumn of 1934.

The official delegation to represent the United States at the twenty-third session of the International Labor Conference in Geneva on June 3 was approved today by President Roosevelt. The delegates will be:

MINHATTAN Gross assets, $21,793; net, $17,759.- To Leah K. Curtiss, niece, $9,497; James Strange Alexander, son, $4,531; Hortense C. H. Clapp, $2,685; Sarah C. Alexander, granddaughter, $1,350; eight varying bequests. Chief assets,
Administration economists reported today that they have found a half dozen methods by which the government could exercise control over prices.

An appeal for funds to aid the Republican party to "maintain the present form of government," made by John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, has been received by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. He made it public today with this comment:

Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, allotted today $50,000,000 in State six-month notes to sixty-nine banks and bond houses in the State. The notes bear interest at the rate of 0.75 per cent. Dated May 19, they will mature on Nov. 19.

IT'S hard to know which way to look now. There is activity in every direction. The pro golfers are tuning up for the national P. G. A. championship. The auto drivers are tuning up for the 500-mile jaunt around the Indianapolis Speedway.

In the face of the United States decision not to permit the New York to Paris air race, the French press today expressed the view that it is unlikely that any efforts will be made to transfer the starting point to Ottawa or some other Canadian locality, but does reckon on the possibility "that some other air race will be thought up to provide the exposition with a signal event."

Laboratory devices which are among the latest developed foraeronautical research and tests were demonstrated here today at the annual convention of the National Advisory Commit?? for Aeronautics. Leaders in ??nationn industry, officers of ?? and navy air services and ??essors at leading universities are among the 350 in attendance.

Quiet conditions prevailed today as the stock market here reopened after the "Whitsuntide holiday. Price movements were small and business was restricted due to the fact that the current account has only three days to run. Gilt-edge issues remained firm and among the foreign loans German bonds improved. International stocks, after staging a partial rally . Closed lower.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James E. Abbe of Hudson View Gardens of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Edwards Abbe, to David O'Donnell Kennedy, son of Mrs. David E. Kennedy of 39 East Thirty-eighth Street and the late Mr. Kennedy.
Julia, dowager Marchioness of Tweeddale, well known as a hostess here during the late Victorian era and that of Edward VII, died yesterday. She was 90 years old.

Calling for a realistic view of foreign trade problems, Willis H. Booth, honorary president of the International Chamber of Commerce, in an address before the Oslo Group luncheon held at the Hotel Astor yesterday, said that trade barriers will fall only when nations are convinced that it is to their selfish interests to reduce them.
Charles M. (Bud) Young, 30 years old, took over, the executive office of the L. A. Young Spring and Wire Corportion today and became the youngest president of a company in the automotive field.

A debate on the relative merits of a free trade zone and bonded warehouses in the development of the commerce of the Port of New York developed yesterday as a special committee of the Board of Estimate prepared to open bids today for the contract to operate the cityowned trade zone on Staten Island.
Settlement of the first serious jurisdictional dispute in the C. I. 0. was announced yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the Internanational Ladies Garment Workers Union.
King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Elena, accompanied by Princess Maria and many officials, left this morning for Budapest to return officially Regent Nicholas Horthy's Rome visit last year.

The contract to construct the new Queens General Court House at Sutphin Boulevard and Eightyeighth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, is to be awarded to John J. Kennedy Co., Inc., which submitted a low bid of $3,077,800, Borough President George U. Harvey
Turpentine firm, 351c; sales, 52 barrels; receipts, 552 barrels; shipments, 162 barrels; stock, 24,858 barrels. Resin firm: sales. 829; receipts, 2,483; shipments, 879; stock, 45,196.

Active efforts by the Federal Maritime Commission to untangle the marine labor situation and restore peace to the Atlantic and Gulf waterfronts were foreshadowed yesterday by the appointment of Daniel S. Ring, now Assistant WPA Administrator in this city, as labor relations officer for the commission.
A fire of excelsior, waste and old rubber tires was smouldering in the cellar of Engine Company 206, 1,196 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN-William A. Carlin, 46th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 15, 1912. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Thomas J. O'Hara, from 46th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 4 days.

George Cardinal Mundelein, Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, ripped into the German Nazi Government and its highest officials today in protest against Nazism's anti-Catholic propaganda and its treatment of German Catholics.

Frank J. Farrell, a prominent figure in the silk industry and president of two Canadian corporations, died here yesterday at the age of 60. Mr. Farrell was president of the Valleyfield (Quebec) Silk Mills, Ltd., and of Grouts, Ltd. (Canada).

More than 2,000 employes of the Aluminum Company of America walked out shortly after 10 o'clock tonight in a strike for a pay increase. Confusion reigned as the men left their machines at the end of their regular shift and quit the plant in a drenching rain.

George Washington, the first President, holds the record for Supreme Court appointments with a total of thirteen. After selecting the court's six original members, Washington named seven others to fill vacancies during his eight years in office.

The security markets staged a sizable recovery in increased trading yesterday following the announcement that the Judiciary Committee of the Senate had voted to reject President Roosevelt's proposal to add six members to the bench of the Supreme Court of the United States.

Jacques Chastenet, editor of Le Temps of Paris, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to make a quick survey of conditions in the United States. As a liaison officer with the. Second Division during the World War and in later years as the head of one of the world's leading newspapers, Mr.

Frank Klein was elected president of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants last night. He is director of budgets for the Worthington Company and has served the association as a director and vice president. Others elected were W. L.

A conference with the representatives of the leading dress manufacturers' associations throughout the country for the purpose of creating a "National Dress-Trade Council" was agreed upon at a meeting of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers group held last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

There is no room in Italy for freedom of the press as it is understood in liberal democratic countries, Dino Alfieri, Minister of Press and Propaganda, said in the Chamber of Deputies today. The way he actually put it was:

The forthcoming Oxford conference in Oxford University was hailed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry S. Leiper, a secretary of the Federal Council of Churches, as a means of getting at the roots of problems affecting the church.

New wage scale contracts applying to most of the 13,000 coal miners employed in captive tonnage mines of United States Steel Corporation subsidiaries in this area were signed today by company executives and officials of the United Mine Workers of America.
The Delaware Legislature convened at Dover today in a brief special session to enact the $7,028,000 School Appropriations Bill, which it forgot at its recent regular session.
Miss Alice Marble, American tennis champion, scored a 6-0, 6-0 triumph over Miss G. Maynard in the first round of the Surrey championships at Surbiton today.
United States volunteer battalions, used continually as government shock troops in the Spanish civil war, were estimated today to have lost almost a third of their number in death.

Mrs. Mary E. Holmes, widely known temperance and suffrage worker, died today in her home at 4,640 Ellis Avenue at the-age of 97. She was the oldest clubwoman in Illinois and recently was designated as mother of the Illinois Federation of Women's Clubs in their convention at Peoria.

Evangeline House, 11 Dominick Street, the latest link in the Salvation Army's coast-to-coast chain of young women's residences, was officially opened with a simple service yesterday afternoon. Evangeline House has accommodations for eighty-two guests.

Alexander W. Weddell, United States Ambassador to Argentina, and Mrs. Weddell will arrive soon to pass the week-end with Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius at The Shelter, her place in Locust Valley. Mr. and Mrs. Weddell will visit in England before returning to Buenos Aires.

Offering to the public will be made today by means of a prospectus of 300,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of the General Carpet Corporation, Philadelphia, by B. E. Buckman Co. and Eugene J. Hynes Co., Inc. The stock will be priced at$3.75 a share.

Daily average production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,551,950 barrels, a new high record, compared with 3,489,200 in the preceding week, a gain of 62,750, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Mrs. Juliet Tuttle of Larchmont and New York, known for many years as an animal lover and a worker in humane societies, was at liberty in $500 bail today following her arrest last night on a charge of poisoning four valuable dogs last Saturday afternoon in the California Ridge section of Eastchester.

The pairings and starting times for the twentieth national P. G. A. championship tourney were announced yesterday. With 116 of the nation's leading professional golfers entered, the test will swing into action next Monday over the Pittsburgh Field Club course at Aspinwall Pa.
The House of the General Assembly approved today a liquor bill, but only after stripping it of a Senate provision permitting stand-up drinking at bars of restaurants.

Guy C. Myers, who has been authorized by Nebraska's three public power districts to investigate the possibility of their buying privately owned utilities, told The Associated Press yesterday that, if a fair purchase price could not be arranged, the districts might build systems which virtually would duplicate the private systems.

The State Department of Social Welfare will have a budget for the year beginning July 1 of $87,824,319, Commissioner David C. Adie announced yesterday after the monthly meeting of the State Board of Social Welfare.

A demonstration sit-down strike for the announced purpose of obtaining recognition of a C. I. 0. union at the Federal Ship Building and Drydock Company turned into a combined walkout by the men and plant shutdown by the management here this morning.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Bickersteth, former chaplain to the King, died here today at the age of 79. Dr. Bickersteth retired in 1936, after a lifetime of service to the Church of England, in which he was ordained a priest in 1882.
Ernest Hemingway, novelist and war correspondent, returned from Spain yesterday on the French linear Normandie after spending several weeks with the Loyalist forces on the Madrid front.

BILBAO, Spain, May 18.--General Emilio Mola's Rebel troops early today entered Amorebieta, nine miles southeast of Bilbao, after seven machine-gunners, who had held up their advance since midnight at the entrances facing Guernica, Echano and Durango, had withdrawn along the road to Bilbao.

The first Viscount Waldorf Astor died unexpectedly in his seventyfirst year, his nurse, Mrs. Mary Louise Jeffreys, has testified, it was revealed yesterday when the witness's deposition was read in Federal court at the trial of a suit brought for the Astor sons to recover snore than $10,000,000 paid to the government under protest as an inheritance tax.

Pitcher Larry Burger hit a home run in the tenth inning to break up a mound duel with Ray Volpi and give Long Island University's high-flying Blackbirds a 4-to-3 decision over Manhattan on the Jasper diamond yesterday.
Youthful Chubby Dean kept the Athletics on top of the American League today by hitting a three-run homer in the eighth that gave the Mackmen an 8-to-7 victory over the Tigers.
