Mrs. Julia Heuser, 72-year-old recluse, accused of endangering children by neglect of her two-story frame house at 91 Doscher Street, near Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, was committed by Magistrate Folwell in Pennsylvania Avenue court, Brooklyn, yesterday to Kings County Th Hospital for mental and physical examination.
Fifty-three seniors at Hunter College have been elected to the Nu chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, it was announced yesterday by Professor Marjorie Anderson, president of the chapter. They are:

In conformity with Davis Cup regulations, Manager Clifford Sproule of the Australian team and Captain Walter L. Pate of the American will name this afternoon the four men who will compose their playing squads for the final round match of the North American Zone, to be held at Forest Hills May 29, 30 and 31.
A Senate committee, attempting to draft child-labor legislation that will be held constitutional, heard with interest today of the forthcoming change in the Supreme Court.

The team championship of the sixty-third annual Princeton Caledonian games, the oldest branch of inter-class athletic competition at the university, was won by the track and field forces of the junior class, it was announced today by Thaddeus T. Hutcheson, president of the Intracollegiate Athletic Association.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000, including 2,000 direct. Market 15c-25c higher than Monday's average; closing active, largely at full advance; packing sows sharing upturn.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 17: COLONELS Sands, A. L. P.. F. A., Tampa, Fla., to Headquarters, Atanta, Ga.

Miss Margaret Annis Best, daughter of Admiral Sir Matthew Best, commander of the America-West Indies station, and Lady Best, was married to Lieut. Commander Alexander Pollock Gibson of H. M. S. Apollo, son of Dr. and Mrs. H. W. Gibson of Emsworth, England, at St. John's Church, Pembroke, this afternoon.
Chandler Co., Inc., and the Bankamerica Company will offer today an additional issue of $1,022,000 of San Jose Water Works first mortgage 3% per cent Series A bonds at 100.

Commissioner of Markets MORGAN has forbidden the sale of hot dogs from pushcarts and stands in the open-air markets under his sway. He doesn't object to them per se, but holds that they are not pretty to look at, are unsanitary and cloggers of traffic.

F. M. Whitaker, 69 years old, submitted his resignation today as vice president in charge of traffic of the Chesapeake Ohio, Nickel Plate and Pere Marquette Railroads, effective July 1. He has been with the C. O. more than fifty-two years.

Members of the Bond Club of New York this year will reverse the policy customarily followed in the observance of their annual Field Day by dedicating it to bond trading "in a big way," instead of investigating "ways and means" to forget it all.

Everett D. Martin, president of the American Association for Adult Education and Professor of Social Philosophy at Cooper Union, told members of the association, in conference here today, that "philosophy is disturbing the world now, not economics," and stated that Mussolini, Stalin and Hitler had made an intellectual appeal to the peoples of their countries, which was gaining much ground.

Paced by Sophomore Bob Eisner's four goals, the Princeton varsity polo team handed a strong Lawrenceville School quartet its first defeat of the season, 9 to 5, today. The Laurentians had won four consecutive encounters.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week endedyesterday numbered slightly more than in the preceding week but were considerably below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Mrs. Charlotte M. Liberty, who was private secretary to-George C. McKay at the Kellogg Company, was elected today to his position of secretary and assistant treasurer of the company. She is the first woman official of the concern, one of the world's leading cereal manufacturers.
Important administrative changes in the Albany Medical College were announced tonight by Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College and chancellor of Union University.

The Anderson Company, Gary, Ind., is launching a campaign in national weeklies, automotive and petroleum trade papers, posters, radio and direct mail for its new "vision - control" product, SpotMaster.

The engagement of Eva Le Gallienne to appear in the opening play of the eighth Summer season of the Westchester Playhouse at Lawrence Farms, Mount Kisco, was announced today by Day Tuttle and Richard Skinner managers of the theatre.

A thousand employes in 100 buildings in the garment and fur district staged an unauthorized, short-lived strike yesterday morning in protest against what officials of the Building Service Employes Union characterized as delay in arbitration proceedings that have been under way for some time between the union and building owners in the district.

Political circles were greatly calmed today after studying last night's broadcast by Governor Benedicto Valladares of the State of Minas Geraes, in which, as chairman of the national convention to be held May 25, he stressed that all States would be represented and that President Getulio Vargas would not. seek another term.

Stockholders of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation yesterday approved the plan of recapitalization and amendments to the charter necessary to create the new securities offered under the plan, with more than two-thirds in interest of each class of stock in favor of the plan.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Scarborough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harland Scarborough of Montclair, N. J.. to Leo H. Loewy, son of Mrs. braham B. Keve of this city, and he late Samuel Loewy, took place yesterdayy noon at the Olcott. The ceremonyy was performed by Adernon Black of the Ethical Culture society .

Approval of the suggestion of the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, providing for the election of a Coadjutor Bishop in the diocese, was given unanimously this afternoon by delegates to the seventieth annual convention of the Long Island Diocese at the Cathedral of the Incarnation here.

Besides being stripped of the larger part of their possessions, German emigres, mostly Jews, have been forced to pay the National Socialist government during the last four years a total of 170,970,000 marks for the privilege of emigrating with little more than their lives and household possessions.

Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System (Including Brooklyn Queens Transit System)-Ten months ended April 30: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, minority interest charges, Federal taxes and other expenses, $3,914,251, which, after preferred dividend charges, was equal to $3.62

Buffalo won the first game of the series with Baltimore today, 8 to 3, to end a losing string of four contests. The Bisons blasted Chagnon and Rhodes from the mound in less than two innings and counted seven runs.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, called upon all local unions of his organisation today to join in the campaign to unionize the huge Ford Motor Company, with its 150,000 employes.

Arthur V. Youngman, production manager of the De Long Agency of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, was nominated yesterday for the presidency of the Life Underwriters Association of the City of New York, Inc.
A proposal to spend $759,000 of Federal funds to improve Fire Island Inlet ran into opposition at a hearing today before the House Rivers and Harbors Committee.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. Collection of paintings, general tour, 11 A. M.; "Types of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; "The Art and Culture of Prehistoric Egypt," Georg Steindorff, 4 P. M.

Inspired, the police believe, by either childish jealousy or overexuberant playfulness, Noel Galvin, who is not quite 3 years old, struck his 2-month-old sister, Dolores, so hard with a metal toy yesterday that the infant died as a there result of the injuries.

District Attorney Martin W. Littleton of Nassau County announced at Mineola, L. I., yesterday provisional plans to enter the private practice of law about next Jan. 1 with George Morton Levy, former chief counsel for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and attorney for the Nassau Kennel Club, which has operated the dog racing track at Mineola for the last eight years.
Dr. Luther P. Eisenhart, dean of the Graduate School of Princeton University, was elected president of the Princeton chapter of the Sigma Xi Society at a dinner here tonight in Lower Eagle Hall.

A collection of Italian family neirlooms will be shown tonight at the home of Mrs. Darwin R. James Jr., 341 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, by the women's committee for the benefit dinner dance to be given on June 3 at the Half-Moon Hotel for needy Italian families in care of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities.

Waterbury Ave (18-5342), s s, 25 ft w of Fairfax Ave, 51x100; Alfred Rinaldo to John Milano, 3,149 Buhre Ave.. Morris Park Ave. 642 (15-4030); Mollie Liebenthal to Siegfried' L. Tanzer, 586 Morris Park Ave. Clarence Ave, 1,104 (18-5327); Joseph J. Goldsmith, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued orders permanently suspending offering' sheets of producing landowners' royalty interests in the Loual-Carter-Craddock Farm, Pontotoc County, Okla.,

Seven Democrats of the Senate Judiciary Committee joined with the three Republican members today to send President Roosevelt's program for reorganization of the judiciary to the Senate calendar with an adverse report.

Moving swiftly and secretly in a first assault against a huge racket held responsible for cheating New York insurance companies out of millions of dollars, the Federal Government yesterday arrested fourteen men, including two lawyers and a physician, accused of schooling men to simulate disabling diseases and of "doping them like race horses" to deceive insurance doctors.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to unlisted trading the new common stock, $1 par value, of Detroit Gray Iron Foundry Company, in substitution for the old $5-par-value common stock. The new shares are issuable in exchange on a basis of five shares for each share of old stock.

Charles Elmore Cropley, clerk of the Supreme Court, who entered its employ as a page boy many years ago, made the following comment on the Van Devanter resignation: "The-extent to which the whole country and particularly the American judiciary suffers through the retirement of Mr. Justice Van Devanter is great.

Executive committeemen of the striking Federated Motion Picture Crafts formally requested labor unions throughout the nation today to boycott all films in which five well-known actors appear and threatened also to extend the strike to independent studios.

The State Federation of Labor, after protracted and sharp debate today as its convention neared a close, defeated, 73 to 14, a resolution condemning Senators Glass and Byrd for their opposition to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan.

While business failures in the retail division increased in the week ended May 13, as compared with the previous week, they were under those for the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Increases over last year were shown in the manufacturing and wholesale groups. The detailed report is as follows:
The twelfth recital to aid the scholarship fund of the Platt School of Music will be held tonight at Steinway Hall Arthur Bogin, violinist, and Miguel Rosa, baritone, will be heard.

Japanese officials will not express an opinion on the Australian proposal for a Pacific non-aggression pact until it has become less nebulous. Japan's attitude will be largely influenced by that of the United States and it is noted that Washington comments are extremely reserved.

The Holy Cross nine today defeated Dartmouth, leader of the Eastern Intercollegiate League, 7 to 3. Ted Bruce, ace Green twirler, pitched seven innings but was given poor support. He allowed six hits and fanned five. Roy Bruninghaus of the Crusaders allowed only five scattered blows and struck out eight.
Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College will be hostess to the Riverside Quadrangle Land Committee and other guests at a dinner tonight in Barnard Hall.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Adams of Burlington, Vt., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Helen Mae Adams, to Carl Edward Kelsey, son of Mrs. Sarah Greenough of Salisbury, Vt., and the late Julius Kelsey.

Associate Justice Willis Van Devanter was appointed to the Supreme Court by President Taft in 1910 and is the oldest associate member in point of service. The jurist, who celebrated his seventyeighth birthday Monday, is exceeded in age in the court only by Justice Louis Brandeis, aged 80.

Donald M. Forgan, vice president, American Radiator Company, was added to the board of directors of the Merchants Association of New York at the annual meeting in the association's headquarters in the Woolworth Building yesterday. He is a member of the transportation committee.
William Woodward's Perifox remained favorite tonight in a cal1-over of Derby odds at the Victoria Club. The colt was backed at ??5 to 20.

At the end of a three-hour conference, Senators Charles E. Loizeaux of Union County and Edward P. Stout of Hudson County, Republican and Democratic floor leaders, respectively, announced tonight they had selected about sixty bills which they would recommend for passage when the Legislature reconvened next Monday night.

The Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce made public today a series of index figures showing that in March grocery chain stores had reached a point in their trade within less than 1 per cent of the 1929-31 period, which statisticians for the bureau took for 100. On that basis the index figure for 1929 was 102.9.

An official attitude of "conciliation" toward the Catholic Church was pledged in an interview today by Governor Victor Fernandez Manero of Tabasco, the Southeastern Mexican State that more than any other has persecuted religion.

Civil service employes of the Park Department who now work by the day would be put on an annual basis of 313 days a year at a 10 per cent increase in wages under the terms of a bill introduced yesterday in the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly by Alderman Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn.

Governors Island The verbal orders of the Commanding General of May 3, 1937, which detailed CoL John P. Bubb, Inf., Newark, N. J., as a member of the board of officers appointed to select Second Lieutenants, Officers Reserve Corps, for detailed to active duty, vice Lt. Col. Dale F. McDonald, Inf., relieved, are confirmed and made of record.

Delegates attending the New Jersey Venereal Disease Conference here today were asked to develop support for legislation that would call for physical examinations and Wassermann tests in this State before marriage.

The bullet that fatally wounded a 57-year-old woman Mqnday night when she was caught- in the crossfire of a pistol battle between a detective and a fleeing suspect at 170th Street and Ogden Avenue, the Bronx, was fired by the detective. This was revealed yesterday by an examination of the pullet markings. The detective, it was said, fired after the fleeing man had shot at him.

Captain Freeman Hatfield, retired seafarer, lost a two-year fight against extradition to Canada today when Federal Judge George F. Morris revoked a restraining order which had prevented Hatfield's surrender to Canadian authorities on charges of theft arising from a ship reparation claim.

The trial of four men charged with aiding and abetting Robert J. Suhay and Alfred Power in the robbery of the Northern Westchester Bank at Katonah, N. Y., on March 12 took an unexpected turn yesterday when one of them, James J. O'Reilly of 447 East Eighty-sixth street entered a plea of guilty.

Representatives of the Taxi Chauffeurs Union of Greater New York, Local 387, charged yesterday at a hearing at the Police Department Hack Bureau that the United Taxi Inspection Service is a "spy" system that endangers the lives of taxicab drivers by forcing them to street curbs when infractions of rules and ordinances were suspected.

Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, said today that Associate Justice Van Devanter, who submitted his resignation from the Supreme Court bench to President Roosevelt, had been "one of the most eminent and distinguished members of the court in my lifetime." He added:

A joint plan for reorganization of the Cleveland Terminals Building Company and its parent company, the Van Sweringen Corporation, was filed today with Charles I. Russo, special master appointed by Federal court, under Section 77b of the Federal Reorganization Act.

The four-to-three decision of the Supreme Court upholding the Louisiana chain-store tax, far from representing a deparature from the court's previous decisions on this subject, merely carries the tendency of those decisions one step farther.

LONDON, May 18.--Choosing "an imperial conference of youth" for what he said would be his last speech to a large gathering as Prime Minister, Stanley Baldwin tonight exhorted boys and girls from all parts of the British Empire to prepare themselves for the task of saving democracy.

" Some" of the burlesque houses closed by License Commissioner Paul Moss have filed applications for reopening, Mr. Moss said yesterday. He denied reports that negotiations were under way for a general reopening of the theatres.

Fifteen students received diplomas today at the commencement exercises of the Curtis Institute of Music. The degree of Bachelor of Music was presented to two members of the class, Marjorie Tyre and Marjorie Call, harpists.
Edwin L. Neville has been selected for appointment as Minister to Siam, a post now vacant, it was made known at the White House today when he conferred with President Roosevelt.

In celebration of the Feast Day of St. BRENDAN attention has been called afresh to the adventures of that saint, the story of whose voyage across the Atlantic ranks, according to high authority, "with the most celebrated of "the medieval sagas of Western "Europe."

Buried underneath quantities of lumber and lengths of iron pipe when a twenty-foot rack suddenly fell on him, Joseph G. Lachnicht, 30 years old, of 273 Pacific Avenue, Jersey City, was dead when extricated last night on the fifth floor at 419 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Albert J. Kobler, publisher of The Daily Mirror and an editor of Hearst publications, who died on Dec. 31, left an estate of less than $5,000, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

In the quarter ended on March 31, the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries made a net profit of $549,754 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to a report issued yesterday.
Mrs. Mason Phelps of Lake Forest, Ill., has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Betty Brooks, to Thomas Morgan Schriber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rufus Schriber of Oshkosh, Wis.

The U. G. T. [Socialist-Communist labor union] organization in Madrid-the most powerful labor body in Spain-threw in its lot with the new Negrin government today, thus leaving only the Anarchists in open opposition and permitting Loyalist Spain to begin its most hopeful period since the civil war started.
Pierre S. du Pont testified here yesterday that he purchased $20,000,000 of stocks when holders were dumping them into the market after the crash of October, 1929.
The body of Mrs. John Wilson, formerly Beatrice Nelson of Bangor, Me., was found in her apartment today with a bullet wound in her heart. The police said death had been by suicide.

In a grave crisis Mr. Abbott usually can be counted on for a comedy: that is his intention for tonight at the Cort, where he will be setting down "Room Service." This one is a farce about show business, with emphasis on its shoestring phase, and the wails of John P. Murray and Allen Boretz.

Robert R. Young, one of three men who recently purchased control of the Van Sweringen railroad holdings from George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., was elected today chairman of the board of Chesapeake that Corporation, a Van Sweringen holding company.

High school pupils will receive an understanding of modern music along with the fundamental lessons in classical music they now get under a program being worked out to have jazz and "swing" leaders give weekly lectures in the high schools beginning next Fall, Dr. George H. Gartlan, director of music of the Board of Education, revealed yesterday.

NO one can understand the Irish question without understanding Sir Edward Carson, or Carson without reading his biography. The first volume of this work appeared in 1932: "Carson the Advocate," by Edward Marjoribanks. The second volume was Ian Colvin's "Carson the Statesman" (1934). The final installment, now published, is also by Mr. Colvin: "The Life of Lord Carson: Vol. III" (Macmillan, $5).

The marriage of Miss Anne Edwina Tilman, daughter of Steich Tilman of Farnham, Surrey, England, to Thomas H. Hockstader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. Hockstader of New York, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, the rector.

Three German witnesses gave testimony today that enabled the Department of Commerce Investigating Board to establish definitely that the fire that destroyed the dirigible Hindenburg onMay 6 was a hydrogen fire and to localize its origin in or near a gas cell about 200 feet from the stern and 100 feet aft of the rear motors.
So enthusiastic has Captain Walter Willis become over the grand fishing enjoyed by Peconic and Montauk anglers on Sunday that he is writing verse about it.

The Mohlenhoff farm, on Linden Boulevard, consisting of eighteen acres, lying partly in St. Albans, Queens, and extending into Nassau County, has been purchased by Jefferson Homes, Inc., Maximilian Jaeger, president. The tract is said.
The Indians used six pitchers, including the phenomenal Bob Feller, today while rushing from behind with a ninth-inning rally to take the series opener from the Red Sox, 7-4.

James D. Clark, 78 years old, a former member of the Elizabeth City Council and formerly vice president and treasurer of the Havell Manufacturing Company of Newark, died this morning at his home here.

The French liner Normandie will sail today for Southampton and Havre. Among the passengers listed are Dr. Alexis Carrel of the Rockefeller Institute; Martin Beck, theatrical producer; Leon Leonidoff, production director at the Radio City Music Hall;

A mighty drive to right center field by Joe Salerno in the tenth inning enabled the St. John's University baseball team to close its season with a 3-to-2 triumph over City College at Dexter Park yesterday.
Officials reported today the Treasury still was carrying on its books a 100-year-old loan to twenty-six States. They added that there was not much hope it ever would be collected.
Five hundred women and children, who said they had eaten almost nothing for two weeks, streamed out of this burning town today to seek food and shelter in the advancing Insurgent lines.

" Idiot's Delight" was shown at the Paramount Theatre tonight without deletions or changes after Mayor Butler had reversed his previous decision that the play could not be presented without the omission of lines containing profanity and references to the "Governor Bryan Hotel in Omaha."
The New York City Housing Authority approved yesterday the lease presented by the Public Works Administration for the $4,219,000 Harlem River Houses low rent housing project.

Setting a precedent in the annual elections at Long Island University, 300 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, women students have been elected to three of the four offices of the Student Council, it was announced yesterday by Dean Tristram Walker Metcalfe.

A reduction in freight rates dn newsprint, which requires suspension of the long-and-short-haul provision of the Interstate Commerce Act, amounting to more than $1 a ton, was granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to rail carriers whose loads originate in Ontario and are delivered to Gary,

Elisabeth Bergner returns this morning to the Rivoli in "Dreaming Lips," an English-made adaptation of the. Henri Bernstein play "Melo," which served as the basis for the German "Der Traeumende Mund," in which Miss Bergner starred in 1934.

Sid Richardson, a slender, 20-year-old sophomore from Creston, Iowa, brought Northwestern its first Big Ten individual golf championship today when the Wildcats smashed Michigan's five-year lease on the team trophy.

The Ohio Sheet and Tin Plate Corporation of Marietta, Ohio, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 294,000 shares of $1 par common stock, of which 156,000 shares will be offered through an underwriter by the registrant and 20,000 by a stockholder, at $3.75 a share.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation expects to start construction soon after July 1 of a refinery in Venezuela with a capacity of 15,000 to 20,000 barrels daily, E. Holman, president, told stockholders at their meeting yesterday. He estimated that it would require about twelve months to complete the plant.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 97,941 additional shares of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., $5 cumulative preferred stock, no-par value; $3,150,000 additional Indianapolis Union Railway Company refunding and improvement mortgage 3% per cent bonds, Series B, due in 1986;
The cost of filling the housewife's grocery basket is now the highest in six years, reflecting the tribute levied against the consumer's pocketbook by the 1936 drought.

President Roosevelt announced today that he would transmit later this week to the Senate for ratification eight of the eleven conventions and treaties that were signed in Buenos Aires at the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.
The French Government has not yet granted the Spanish war planes that landed in France yesterday permission to return to Spain. The Foreign Office is noncommittal on the subject.
Under tow of an Iceland fisherman, the plain John, T. O. M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger, Endeavour II, from the Royal Yacht Squadron of Cowes, England, arrived here this afternoon.

Contract awards at the Army Quartermaster Depot today were as follows: Invitation 278., for 46,115 gross of olive drab ivory buttons for the army clothing factory, was awarded to the American Button Company at 23.45 cents per gross, net. Five other items on this invitation have not yet been acted upon.

Charges that "hounding by the Securities and Exchange Commission" had handicapped the Atlas Tack Corporation in its search for business were made yesterday in the commission's proceedings against W. E. Hutton Co. and other respondents for alleged manipulation of the stock of Atlas Tack. The hearings, now being held before Edward C. Johnson, trial examiner, are expected to be concluded today.
George A. Rentschler, president of the General Machinery Corporation of Hamilton, Ohio, has been elected to fill a vacancy on the board of directors of the Monarch Machine Tool Company.

The series of garden events arranged for the benefit of the Greenwich House Health Center at 27 Barrow Street will begin today with a luncheon and fashion show in the outdoor cafe at 1 Fifth Avenue. Five gardens in Greenwich Village will be exhibited this afternoon and five others tomorrow.

The annual flower show of the Greenwich Hortulus Garden Club, held in the barn on the estate of Mrs. Stafford Hendrix, Stanwich Road, here, this afternoon and tonight, attracted a large number of society people.

Absorption of British interest in the coronation festivities has not shut off entirely the concern in the Spanish situation. The subcommittee of the Non-Intervention Committee, which is a committee itself under another name, held a meeting today and decided to take further steps toward restricting and, as far as possible, humanizing the conflict.
Governor Lehman signed today a bill to give the State the "lowdown" on why, how and to what extent people collect birds' nests and eggs.
Mrs. Katherine Schoeneck Moses, wife of Robert H. Moses and only daughter of former Lieutenant Governor and Mrs. Edward Schoeneck, died here today at the home of her parents. Her age was 27.

Princeton University's field artillery unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps, 400 strong, passed in review this afternoon before Colonel Franklin D'Olier, a member of the class of 1898 and trustee of the university, on the old polo field east of Palmer Stadium. The ceremonies climaxed a year of laboratory drill for the Princeton cadets.

A list of 130 prominent citizens of Honduras, allegedly held as political prisoners by President Tiburco Carias Andina, is reported by political emigres resident here. The names were compiled from newspaper reports, from correspondence with friends resident in Honduras, and from the reports of the Honduran Secretary of War for 1935 and 1936.
Reporters outside- the Senate Judiciary Committee meeting today heard a roar of laughter from within.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany notilied the French Lawn Tennis Federation today he would not defend his singles title in the French hard court championships, which got away to a rain-swept start in Roland Garros Stadium.

A primary fight against the regular Democratic organization in the Bronx, headed by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, for nominations for county offices was threatened yesterday when it was announced that representatives of thirty-six Democratic clubs in the borough had authorized Arthur H. Murphy Jr. to prepare for such contests.

Mayor Frank Hague, Democratic State leader, began his sixth term as Chief Executive of this city today, as here and in Newark and other New Jersey municipalities candidates elected to local governing bodies last Tuesday took their oaths of office.

SAN JUAN, P. R., May 18.--The American Civil Liberties Union's investigation dealt today chiefly with political matters, such as the suppression of public meetings here recently through government efforts.

A few years ago Spurgeon Chandler came to the Yankee Stadium in the moleskins of the University of Georgia and from behind his goal line kicked nearly the length of the field to help protect a 7--6 victory over N. Y. U.
The Senators defeated the Browns, 7 to 6, today on a single by Walter Millies in the ninth inning, with Stone on base. The Senators scored five runs during a second-inning drive.
The Southern Newspaper Publishers Association was told today that American newspapers constitute "our greatest protection against the domination of the nation by leaders of temporary, majorities."

John K. Thompson, vice president of the Erie Railroad, testified in the United States District Court here today that New Jersey's assessments for purposes of taxation in 1932, 1933 and 1934 were increased despite sharp declines in the carrier's income and Payrolls.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals will hear an appeal May 26 from the action of Federal Judge Guy L. Fake at Newark, N. J., in refusing a temporary injunction to restrain James L. Braddock, world heavyweight champion, from fighting Joe Louis in Chicago June 22.

John Philip Sousa Jr., son of the famous bandmaster and composer, died suddenly of a heart attack today at his home in La Jolla, a suburb, at the age of 56. He came here nine years ago from Port Washington, L. I.
The third-place Royals pounded four Jersey City pitchers for fourteen hits and eked out a 7-6 victory over the Giants today.

The supply-and-demand economists appear at this writing to be the least of the administration's worries over the proposed new farm relief legislation. Their demand that nature should be permitted to take its course, like the renewed outcry against "regimentation" from certain liberals, was expected and does not seem to be feared.

Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, in a letter sent yesterday to the company's 15,000 employes congratulated the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, on its overwhelming victory in the recent collective bargaining referendum held by the company, and pledged himself to work "with absolute faith and trust" with the union representatives in arriving at an agreement on working conditions.

A mass meeting and a pageant entitled "Democracy Imperiled" will be held in Madison Square Garden tonight under the auspices of the American Committee for Spanish Relief, headquarters of which are in the Vanderbilt Hotel. In the pageant will be 500 players from the Union City (N. J.) Passion Play, "Veronica's Veil," and 1,000 other persons from Catholic parishes of the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Long Island.
The trustees of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company today voted to petition the Federal court to cancel the lease for the company's operation of the Delaware River Bridge High-Speed Transit Line.
The Federal Trade Commission has shown a friendly and cooperative spirit in carrying out the Robinson-Patman act, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.,

Mr. and Mrs. C. V. Whitney divided the main events at Belmont Park yesterday, Black Look, the Whichone colt being first in the featured Swift Stakes, While Rideaway took the main prize in the steeplechase.

Dr. Willard L. Wachter, Charles McIntyre Professor of Biology at Lafayette College, died here today after a heart attack. His age was 39. Born in Siam, the son of Mrs. Rebecca Wachter and the late Dr. Egom Wachter, a medical missionary, Dr. Wachter came to this country at the age of 16 years to finish his education.

Ferruccio Lantini, Minister for Corporations speaking in the Senate to close the discussion of the budget for his ministry, said that Italian exports in the first quarter of this year had increased 198 per cent over the same period in 1936, not taking into account exports to the colonies.

The Fifth Ward Savings Bank of Jersey City has sold the nine-family brick apartment building at 34 West Tenth Street, Bayonne, N. J., to the Sirod Realty Company for investment. Carey Lane were attorneys for the bank and James Kearney represented the buyer. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Second Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Sullivan estimated yesterday that with the bulk of pistol-permit applications already filed this year fewer persons in the city would obtain permits in 1937 than in any year since 1920.

After debating all day the pros and cons of Junior League participation in controversial issues, delegates to the organization's conference postponed a vote on the question until Friday. All indications were that the delegate body would vote down the proposal by a large majority.

Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced yesterday the extension of operators' licenses until Sept. 30 and of chauffeurs' licenses to June 30. Both have previously expired May 31.

James J. Dooling was at his desk in Tammany Hall, yesterday for the second time since his return last week after ten months' absence because of illness, The leader of Tammany said he was feeling better and expected to continue to improve.

Pope Pius's condition shows a slight tendency to weaken although his daily tasks are not curtailed. An indication that the Pope so far has failed to improve is seen in the announcement that loud-speakers have -been installed in the large Swiss Hall used for general audiences at the Castel Gandolfo villa to enable visitors to hear the papal addresses distinctly.

Daily average retail sales in April were about 6 per cent greater than in April, 1936, the American Retail Federation announced today. The total was put at $3,600,000,000, a gain of $200,000,000 over April, 1936. The gain in dollar volume for the first four months of this year is approximately $1,300,000, 000. or 12 per cent.

The yachts that may meet for the America's Cup off Newport this Summer, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger and T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II, both built to the top of the Class J measurement rules, are not the same size, but the differences between them amount to only a few inches one way or another.
Justice Willis Van Devanter, one of the most frequent dissenters from New Deal legislation on the Supreme Court, announced today that he would retire on June 2 from "regular and active" service.

Manhattan Alterations 5th Ave, 275; to 5'story tenement and store; Elisha Walker, 52 William St, owner; G. A. Schonewald, architect; cost, $35,000. Madison Ave. 238: to 4-story furnished room and stores; Excelsior Savifigs Bank, 221 W 57th St, owner; J. M. Berlinger, architect; cost, $20,000.

A young mother from whom was coaxed a confession implicating her suitor in the killing of her 7-yearold daughter and the murderous attack on her 5-year-old son recanted her story and assumed all the blame today a few minutes before she was locked in the Suffolk County Jail on a charge of first-degree murder.

Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff presented his letters of credence to President Roosevelt today as German Ambassador in succession to Dr. Hans Luther and in so doing pledged himself to a policy of maintaining friendly relations and of strengthening the political, economic and cultural bonds between the two countries.

Many leases, of which several were for additional space, in the financial district featured the contracts for commercial quarters reported yesterday. The leases covered a wide variety of. trades. A large number were for stores and entire floors.

A rapid increase in consumption of kraft paper for containers, together with new uses for that product, has stimulated the construction of new productive capacity which by the end of 1938 will have doubled that of 1936. Charles W. Boyce,

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 14.325 to 14.575 cents a pound, c. i. f., European 'ase ports, following an advance in prices on the London Metal Exchange. The price on Monday was 14.225 cents.
WASHINGTON, May 18.--An electric alarm system whereby any of the President's secretaries can call an armed guard at a moment's notice has been placed in the Executive offices.

The stage was set tonight for eight sensational matches in the second round of the twenty-sixth annual women's Southern golf tournament, dominated by a meeting between Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., and Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., semi-finalists in the 1936 national.

Daily average retail sales in April were about 6 per cent greater than in April, 1936, the American Retail Federation announced today. The total was put at $3,600,000,000, a gain of $200,000,000 over April, 1936. The gain in dollar volume for the first four months of this year is approximately $1,300,000, 000. or 12 per cent.

The yachts that may meet for the America's Cup off Newport this Summer, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger and T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II, both built to the top of the Class J measurement rules, are not the same size, but the differences between them amount to only a few inches one way or another.
Justice Willis Van Devanter, one of the most frequent dissenters from New Deal legislation on the Supreme Court, announced today that he would retire on June 2 from "regular and active" service.

Manhattan Alterations 5th Ave, 275; to 5'story tenement and store; Elisha Walker, 52 William St, owner; G. A. Schonewald, architect; cost, $35,000. Madison Ave. 238: to 4-story furnished room and stores; Excelsior Savifigs Bank, 221 W 57th St, owner; J. M. Berlinger, architect; cost, $20,000.

The stage was set tonight for eight sensational matches in the second round of the twenty-sixth annual women's Southern golf tournament, dominated by a meeting between Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., and Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., semi-finalists in the 1936 national.

Sussex scored its third victory in the English County cricket championship competition today, defeating Middlesex by 210 runs at Lord's. Yorkshire took the lead in the standing with a fine 10-wicket victory over Lancashire.

Mrs. Sol I. Aiole of Rochester was elected president of the New York State branch of the Woman's League of the United Synagogue of America at the convention here this afternoon and Mrs. Jeremiah Berman of Rochester was elected corresponding secretary.
A blonde at the wheel of a motor car at night is potentially "much more dangerous" than a brunette, Dr. Irving Strauss, optometrist, said today.

George Bertram 'Dill, who for twenty-five years was superintendent of cabinet work and carpentry for the American Museum of Natural History in New York, and who retired two years ago, died today at his home here at the age of 66.

Despite the fact that the Summer outlook for radio time sales. is the best in the industry's history, the networks have practically reached a saturation point, according to one radio executive here yesterday.

Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford of Woodland, Tuxedo Park, N. Y., entertained with a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew, Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw and Henry R. Sedgwick.

Government troops were officially reported today to be still-hotly pursuing small groups of rebels after their unsuccessful uprising in the Argyrokastron region. The rebels were declared to be fleeing toward the Greek frontier.

Esmond Romilly, the 18-year-old nephew of Winston Churchill, and the Hon. Jessica Freeman-Mitford, daughter of Lord Redesdale, were married here today by the British Vice Consul. Their mothers, Lady Romilly and Lady Redesdale, witnessed the ceremony, which was performed in the consulate.

Sixty-five feature productions for the season 1937-38, including a musical in which-James Cagney will make his screen debut as a songand-dance man, were announced yesterday by Grand National Pictures.

The Rev. Hutchens Chew Bishop, rector emeritus of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church, 214 West 134th Street, died Monday night at the home of a friend in Savannah, Ga., where he was recuperating from a heart attack suffered in January.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--The prospect of enactment of Secretary Wallace's ever-normal granary plan at this session of Congress was put further in doubt today when President Roosevelt indicated that, while he favored the program in principle, he would not press for its passage this year.
After bowing to Yale yesterday, Princeton University's tennis team returned to the winning column today by defeating the Williams racquetmen, 7 to 2, for its fourth triumph in eight starts.

Word has been received here of the marriage on Sunday in Austria of Howard Gould, third son of the late Jay Gould, financier and railroad builder, and Miss Margarete Mosheim, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marcus Mosheim of Berlin.

F. H. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, said today that there was a feeling that the type of decisions rendered by the Supreme Court will change when a successor has been appointed for Justice Van Devanter.

Profits of the paper industry in 1937 will be decidedly higher in almost all divisions, with a sellers' market now prevailing, but to hold profits in the next two years, when new sources of supply of wrapping and bag paper and of container board come into the market will call for a new order of cooperative management, Shields Co. say in a report on a comprehensive survey of the field.

The Williams College nine opened its quest for the Little Three title by downing Wesleyan, 8-5, today on rain-soaked Weston Field. The visitors got two runs in the first inning, but Williams came back with four in its half and never was overtaken.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation has declared a special distribution of 25 cents a share and an additional 50 cents a share, both payable on June 30, to stock of record on June 4. A dividend of 50 cents was paid on March 31.

Wilson B. Coleman, in 1,060 Park Ave.; J. H. Audrey, through Duff Conger, in the Lexington, 157 E. 72d St.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker. Mrs. Charles Andrew Willard. in 115 E. 63d St.; Samuel A. Herzog, broker. Gecrge L. K. Morris, through Culver, Hollyday Co., in 340 E. 72d St.: Dr. Robert L. Pattersen Jr., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., in 135 E. 74th St.:

The retirement of Justice VAN DEVANTER from the Supreme Court of the United States at the end of the present term will bring to a close the active career of the senior member of the court in point of service. Twenty-six years have passed since Mr. VAN DEVANTER received his appointment at the hands of President TAFT.

Sweeping changes in national mass distribution methods, emphasizing the establishment by the food chains of "super markets" and the possible elimination by the major chains of from 30 to 60 per cent of the smaller units now in operation, were foreseen yesterday by chain and other merchandising authorities as likely to follow in the wake of the Supreme Court decision upholding the Louisiana Chain York Store Tax Law.

Edward L. Stanley of Lansdowne, Pa., has been voted the Williams senior who has done most for the college, it was revealed today when the annual class elections were published in The Gul, college year book. Mr. Stanley, recently elected permanent president of the class, was chosen the best athlete, the most respected and the most versatile.
Dr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Bailey of 30 Willow Street, Brooklyn, will give a tea at their home on May 31 for Miss Else Kroll and her fiance, John Bayard Cuningham.
The city of Boston, Mass., will consider tenders tomorrow for an issue of $5,000,000 of medium-term notes to be dated May 24, 1937 and payable on March 25, 1938.
Official circles here denied today a report that a technical mission, headed by General Diego Aracena, would make a special visit to the United States after completing a tour of European countries.

The eagerly awaited statement on the wedding plans of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield, handed this afternoon to the press by Herman L. Rogers in the Duke's behalf, named the date of the wedding as Thursday, June 3.
The Pittsburgh Pirates continued today the fast pace that sent them pushing to the lead in. the National League race as Cy Blanton held the Phillies to six hits and fanned eight to win, 2 to 1.

Miss Nancy Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes of this place, will be married on June 11 to Alfred Faris King Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Faris King of Dongan Hills, S. I. The ceremony, which will take place at 4:30 P. M. in the First Congregational Church here, will be followed by a reception at the Noyes home.

The New York Women's Bar Association held its annual reception last night at the building of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Fortyfourth Street. The gathering of 200 women was more than a reception;
The Jurist, owned by Frank Kurinec of St. Louis, won his third consecutive victory at Aurora today when he finished three lengths ahead of the field in the Maywood Purse despite muddy going.

Good-Will Day was celebrated yesterday with exercises on the steps of the Subtreasury Building in Wall Street. Awards were made to the borough winners of the essay contest conducted by America's Good-Will Union among the high school students of New York.
Steve (Crusher) Casey, 228, of Ireland, threw Abe Coleman, 225, of Los Angeles in 21:18 in the wrestling feature last night at the St. Nicholas Palace before 2,000 spectators.

Sixteen telephone toll operators who testified with professional briskness today furnished the important corroboratory evidence that the Federal Government regards as the strongest link in its conspiracy case against Ellis H. Parker Sr. and his son, Ellis Jr.

The Morris High School nine defeated Commerce, 8-3, yesterday at Sterling Oval to gain a tie with James Monroe for first place in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the P. S. A. L. The leaders have won four of their six games.

Irving Eldridge, 135, Bronx, decisively outpointed Red Cochrane, 128 1/2, Elizabeth, N. J., in the main eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 7,000. Cochrane substituted for Johnny Rohrig, who was unable to appear because of an infected jaw.

At President Roosevelt's -press conference this afternoon a newspaper man mentioned Justice Van Devanter's coming retirement, asking if there was any special significance in the fact that a band was then playing on the White House lawn.

A production schedule of fifty feature motion-pictures for the 1937-38 season will be announced today to the annual Universal Pictures Company sales convention at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles by J. R. Grainger, general manager of distribution.

The names of a score of Federal and State officials and former judges figured tonight in a widespread guessing contest as to Justice Van Devanter's successor on the Supreme Court bench. A list of those mentioned follows:
MANHATTAN Estate, more than $10,000. To Emily G. K. Baumann, mother, 86 Avenue Raymond Poincare, Paris, France, residue. Frederick W. Kobbe, 115 Park Ave.. executor.
Racing, which began auspiciously, gave way to the elements this afternoon as a heavy rain and hailstorm swept the Churchill Downs plant between the fifth and sixth races.

Several well-known golfers are scheduled to compete in the fortyfirst annual tournament of the Stock Exchange Golf Association, which is to be held on June 29 at the Fresh Meadow Country Club, Flushing, L. I. Among them are Jason E. Billings, Celestin A. Durand Jr., W. Aliston Flagg, Donald J. Hardenbrook, Harold J. Lamm, William P. O'Connor, Henry Picoli and Ray Torgerson. James McKenna is chairman of arrangements:

Lawrenceville School's crack outdoor polo team defeated the Army Plebes, 5-0, today in a game which was stopped at the. end of the second chukker because of rain. Plaut, riding at back, made three of the visitors' goals, with Osmun scoring the other two.
Stocks closed irregular in less active trading; turnover, 789,760 shares. United States Government bonds dull at slightly lower levels, other issues steady and mixed; transactions. $7.496.200.

Five persons were killed and. two others were burned slightly when the fourmotored Lioret-Olivier flying boat, intended for Air France's South American passenger and mail service, crashed during trials outside the port here at 4 P. M. today. Among the victims is Lucien Bourdin, 41 years old, a prominent flier.

In accordance with eKpectations, Donald Budge and Gene Mako of California, Bryan Grant, Atlanta, knd Frank Parker, New York, were iamed yesterday as the Davis Cup eam that will represent the United states against Australia in the finall round of the North American :one at Forest Hills, May 29, 30 and 31.

Seven - year - old Helen Tiernan, whose mother, 25-year-old widow, is in jail here awaiting indictment for the child's murder, was buried in Lakeview Cemetery here today with her maternal grandfather, George Smith, the only mourner.
J. J. Summersby, assistant vice president of the Worthington Pump and .Machinery Corporation, has been appointed to serve as general sales manager. of the organization it was announced yesterday.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition NEW BLACKSHIRE, INC., dresses, 530 7th Ave.-Voluntary proceeding, under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listng liabilities of $13.550 and assets of 19,000.

KINGS MOELLER, LESTER E. (Nov. 16. 1936). Gross assets, $33,655; net, $27,972. To wife, Elizabeth C. Moeller. Chief assets, real estate, $5,890; stocks and bonds, $13,766; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $13,973. Arthur J. Hayslip, attorney, Bank of Manhattan Building, Bridge Plaza N., Long Island City.

Charges of "skullduggery, crookedness and lawlessness" in the distribution of AAA soil-conservation payments were heard in the Senate today after Senator Vandenberg of Michigan had read into the record a letter from a Missouri farmer who said he had received $15 shortly before the last election for reducing tor cotton acreage, although he had the marketed a full crop and had not on participated in the AAA program.

Captain Lsidore S. Edelstein, Med.-Re., 339 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, N. CASC Middlesex County Area, is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective May 21. He will proceed to Headquarters Binghamnton District, CCC, Binghamton, N. Y., for assignment in connection with CCC activities. Captain Edelstein will rank from Dec. 24, 1936.

Work is 'believed to have commenced se.cretly in the yards of Short Brothers in Rochester in the building of a flying boat with a loaded, weight of 120,000 pounds, or three times that of the huge Empire flying boats now- in service between Southampton and Egypt.

The American system of democracy was praised as the finest of its kind ever devised by Mrs. Julia Cantacuzene, granddaughter of President Ulysses S. Grant, speaking last night at a dinner of the National Society of the Daughters of the Revolution at the Hotel Roosevelt.

As United States Attorney Lamar Hardy prepared yesterday to make more arrests and to open today a grand jury investigation into the lucrative disability insurance racket, his aides placed in custody a fifteenth suspect accused of teaching claimants how to feign weak hearts and other ailments to get insurance incomes.

Apartments and apartment sites in various parts of Queens were included in the Long Island deals reported by brokers yesterday. The property consisting of a frame dwelling and garages on the southeast corner of North Hempstead Turnpike and Lawrence Street, Flushing, L. I., has been sold to Charles Kieserwidder of New York, who plans the erection of a five-story, forty-family apartment house on the site.

In the seclusion of the Cabinet Room at 10 Downing Street, the principal dele!gates to the Imperial Conference got down to work this afternoon. All the dominion Prime Ministers were present. Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin presided and the meeting lasted an hour and three quarters.

Surmounting no end of disturbing influences, including one of the most violent pitched battles seen on a ball field in many years, Carl Hubbell serenely and majestically pitched himself into his twenty-second consecutive National League victory today over a two-year stretch, while a banner mid-week crowd of 26,399 pitched itself into a turmoil.

Stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., will be asked at their annual meeting on June 15 to ap-. prove an increase in the authorized common stock from 4,500,000 shares to 6,000,000 shares and to reduce the first and second preferred stocks by the number of shares that will have been converted into common stock prior to the meeting.
An injunction restraining the Board of Education from favoring so-called closed shop contractors was requested yesterday in a taxpayers' suit on trial before Supreme Court Justice Samuel Hofstadter.

A proposed modification of the reorganization plan for the Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Corporation which would permit creditors and stockholders to exercise full control of the proposed new enterprises drew a storm of opposition in Supreme Court yesterday. The plan,

The Italian Government has assumed control over the country's leading shipbuilding yards and companies as part of its policy of taking over all private enterprises considered vital to national defense, according to advices from the American Embassy at Rome, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

67th to 68th St, York Av to 1st Av, whole block, 333.8x192x irregular; for 12-story and penthouse hospital; Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, 2 W 106th St, owner; Joel D. Marder, representing James Gamble Rogers. 156 E 40th St, architect; cost, $2,800,000.

Syracuse ended its lacrosse season today by trouncing Cornell, 19-6, with fifteen players participating in the Orange scoring. The triumph- gave Syracuse a record of five .victories and four losses for the campaign.

Works of Johanna M. Beyer and Walter Helfer were heard at last night's session of the Composers Forum-Laboratory at the WPA Theatre of Music. Miss Beyer's music, which occupied the first half of the evening, comprised a sonata for clarinet and piano, a suite for clarinet and bassoon, excerpts from piano suites, a suite for violin and piano and a quintet for woodwinds in one movement.

Pierre S. du Pont closed his testimowy yesterday, his third- day on the witness stand in the old Postoffice Building, leaving to John J. Raskob the eventual task of explaining how their sales of stock back and forth in 1929, to a total of $29,000,000, happened to balance within $46 without any design.

Regular transcontinental travel entirely by trains drawn by oil-electrio locomotives will be possible within a few weeks through the completion for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad yesterday of a 3,600horsepower engine of the new type.

Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., new common stock $1 par value, has been admitted to listing on the New York Curb Exchange. The new common was issued in a share-forshare exchange for the old common, in which dealings have been suspended.

Progress in Mexico toward religious tolerance is at a snail's pace. The interview reported yesterday with VICTOR FERNANDEZ MANERO, Governor of the State of Tabasco, who declared that his attitude is one of conciliation to the "church," reveals-as have earlier "conciliatory " statements by other officials, including President CARDENASthat for the millions of Mexican Catholics there is no religious freedom.

New York's Mayor, Fiorello La Guardia, arrived in San Francisco today displaying a gold nugget given him during a motor trip through California's Mother Lode country. He had been at a conference of Mayors in Los Angeles.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nominations of Sumner Welles and R. Walton Moore to be Under-Secretary of State and Counselor of the State Department respectively. Both are now Assistant Secretaries.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and channel ports. On board are Thomas W. Lamont, banker, with Mrs. Lamont; Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, and Mrs. Lowden; Alanson B. Houghton, former United States Ambassador to England; Rudy Vallee, orchestra leader; Mrs. Mary Tytler, Miss Nedenia Hutton, Mrs. Grace Vanderbilt Davis, Mr. and

The Revere Copper and Brass Company announced yesterday an advance Of one-fourth of 1 cent a pound in the prices of all its products except copper pipe, water tube and scrap. It gave as the reason increased costs of production.

Reveling in the sloppy going, the Branncastle Farm's The Schemer ran to a handy victory in the Betsy Williams Stakes, a mile-and-seventy-yard race for 3-year-old fillies today at Narragansett. The Schemer followed her initial victory at Belmont last Saturday with a length triumph over the favored Miss Dolphin from Mrs. A. M. Creech's Stable.

Get-along, winner of Aurora's Aurora's Inaugural Handicap, came back today to score in the Chicago Heights Handicap, the Feature event at six furlongs. Paul Ryan put up a rousing finish to gain the decision by a neck over Norman B. Hernandez's Woodlander. Hernandez's Woodlander.

Manhattan BRODERICK, ELIZABETH FARRELL (Nov. 26). Estate, less than $10,000. To Edmund D. Broderick, husband, executor, 1,382 Lexington Av., checking. account, life estate in specific personalty and in residue; Edna Herrick Brown, 143-35 38th St.,-Flushing, L. I., specific jewelry and personalty and residue after life estate, executrix.

Preliminary plans for a hospital building of twelve stories, with a penthouse, designed to be one of the world centers of cancer research and treatment, were filed yesterday for the block bounded by East Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets, York and First Avenues.

A sewage disposal tax to be added to the water rate to cover the cost of ending pollution in the waters of the metropolitan area was proposed yesterday at a hearing before the Interstate Sanitation Commission in City Hall.

Johnny Vander Meer, making his first start, pitched five-hit ball and struck out eleven men tonight, but the Bees took advantage of three errors by Third Baseman Jim Outlaw to defeat the Reds, 3 to 1, in the first night game of the major league season.
80th St, 212 W, 5-story tenement and stores, 25x102.2; Charles J. Hopburn, executor, against Irene Gribbin; due, $32,852; to plaintiff for $25,000.
The stock market quieted down yesterday and price movements were hesitant. Aside from small gains at the opening, the market showed little disposition to follow through on Tuesday's late recovery.

Bail of $50,000 was fixed by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday for Miss Mary Berd, 36 years old, of 80 Riverside Drive, after she had pleaded not guilty on a first-degree grand larceny indictment accusing her and Rabbi Zeide M. Schmellner, 53, of the theft of $20,000 in 1932 from a Bowery merchant.
Major Gen. Edward Ranulph Kenyon, chief engineer of the British Third Army during the World War, died today at the age of 82.

Dr. Edwin F. Gay, one of the country's leading economists and first secretary-treasurer of the Council of Foreign Relations, was honored yesterday afternoon by a group of his associates when his portrait was presented to the council at the council house, 45 East Sixty-fifth Street. The portrait was painted by Alexandre Iacovleff.
William Weinstein, 49 years old, a former fur manufacturer, of 1,108 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to a second-degree perjury indictment. He was accused of

19. Tommy.Bridges, knocked out of the box at Detroit May 10, came back today to shut out the league-leading Athletics with five hits as the Tigers defeated Connie Mack's team for the first time in five starts, 9 to 0. Despite the defeat, Philadelphia retained first place, 9 percentage points ahead of the idle Yankees.

Strikes of service employes in three buildings in the garment area were declared yesterday by the Building Service Employes Union shortly before the close of the working day because employes had been "docked" in wages for the two hours they were on strike on Tuesday.
The Reichsbank's statement as of May 18 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Thirty piece-gobds buyers and merchandise executives expressed themselves as strongly in favor of fabric identification as a means of insuring greater consumer satisfaction at a meeting yesterday of the piece-goods group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A hearing has been called by the Securities and Exchange Commission for June 9 on an application by six subsidiaries of the United Public Utilities Corporation for exemption from the necessity of making declarations in regard to the issuance of promissory notes.

The Beethoven Orchestral Society of Tenafly, Clifford Demarest, conductor, will give a concert tonight at the Tenafly High School Auditorium. Newell C. Fitzpatrick, baritone, head of the voice department at Knoxville College, will be heard in recital this evening at 140 West 137th Street.

The Roosevelt administration has laid the foundations of a serious inflationary crisis "of which it now solemnly warns us to beware," Ogden L. Mills said last night in an address before the New School for Social Research.

A satisfactory solution of the Supreme Court issue appears to be elusive, and I offer this plan in the belief that it meets the fundamental issue squarely. It calls for the appointment in the usual manner of one additional justice of the Supreme Court within a period of six months after the inauguration of a President of the United States.
Customs duties collected on liquor imports during the first nine months of the 1937 fiscal year amounted to $34,589,041. This compared with $30,040,595 for the corresponding period last year.
Rhe recurrence of a back injury, which forced her to default a naional singles final match to Miss Helen Jacobs in 1933, kept Mrs. Helen Wills Moody from returning o- competitive tennis today.

The Federal Trade Commission issued an order today designed to break up an alleged combination and conspiracy of thirty-three companies and .their officers "to fix and maintain uniform delivered prices in the interstate sale of water gate valves, hydrants, fittings and similar products used for water supply systems."

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area increased 5 per cent for the week ended May 15, in comparison with the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Par cel Service. The gain dropped below that for the preceding week, when -a rise of 12 per cent was noted. Increases thus far this week

The American Management Asso citation, at its sixteenth annual conference at the Hotel New Yorker on June 2 and 3, will make an effort to determine exactly the present status of business in relation to the general social, economic and political picture. The group will review

An approach to the problem of disarmament by discussing the elimination of certain weapons, such as gas and bombs, was suggested today by Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, the new German Ambassador, in a press conference at the embassy.

Hearings in the Securities and Exchange Commission's action against W. E. Hutton Co. for alleged manipulation of stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation sped yesterday to a close and probably will be concluded today. Proceedings yesterday

Dolf Camilli, first baseman, stole home today in the ninth inning while Mace Brown, Pirate relief hurler, was winding up, and the Phillies beat the Pirates, 5-4, in the second game of their Pittsburgh series.
The Department of Justice. and the Securities. and Exchange Commission asked the Supreme Court today -to hasten its decision on a review of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Berle, City Chamberlain, at American Foreign Chamber of Commerce Luncheon, Hotel Astor-WMCA. 4:00-4:30 P. Mansco, the -Tall Trees Stable's recent acquisition, made a show of a small but select band of racers in winning the Tyler Hotel Handicap, today's feature attraction at Churchill Downs.

Bonds continued to mark time in dull trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The apathy was evident especially in the market for United States Government bonds, which drifted to moderately lower levels on turnover of only $583,200, compared with sales of $896,400 on Tuesday.
The Red Wings gained a 5-2 vicory over Syracuse in the first game of a double-header today, but Dropped the second contest to Lefty Jeorge Hockette of the Chiefs. 9-3.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 18: COLONELS Brasted, A. J., chief of chaplains, 4 days' leave. Ma 19.

Presenting a revamped line-up that included five sophomores, Princeton University's baseball team snapped a three-game losing streak on University Field today by repulsing Rutgers, 7-1. It was the second victory of the season over the Tigers' traditional New Jersey rival.
Army's strong baseball team shut out New York University today, 2-0, in a well-played game. It was the Cadets' seventh victory in eight Start.
Miss Virginia Weakley Brandt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Van Cortlandt Brandt of Germantown, has chosen the afternoon of June 12 for

Edward G. Cummings, controller of Arnold, Constable Co., last night was elected chairman of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the annual meeting held ats the Roger Smith restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street. Mr. Cummings succeeds Leo Hart, controller of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc.

Amy Johnson Moinson, British flier, sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday, denouncing the United States Department of Commerce for its ruling on the proposed air race of the Atlantic celebrating the tenth anniversary of the Lindbergh flight.

The Bears lengthened their International League lead to- three and a half games by trouncing the Toronto Leafs in both parts of a doubleheader today,. winning the first game, 6 to 2, and the second, 7 to O.
The fresh-air fund of the New York Methodist Episcopal churches will be augmented by a dinner, fashion show and dance recital to be held this evening in the Villa Venice, 14 East Sixtieth Street.

An electric power strike, paralyzing the industrial cities and smaller communities of the busy Saginaw valley, was halted tonight when 1,500 strikers of the Consumers Power Company returned to work at the demand of Governor Frank Murphy.

Governor Merriam of California today vetoed two liquor bills passed by the Legislature. One sought to abolish the present importers' cense of $500 for beer, $100 for wine and $100 for distilled spirits.

The new government acted energetically today to forestall any attempt by extremists or disguised Fascists to cause trouble. The support the Negrin Cabinet has received in all parts of Loyalist Spain, including Barcelona and Madrid, has been very impressive. But, having

Ellis L. Phillips was charged yesterday with diverting into his own pockets huge sums from the Long Island Lighting Company, of which he is president, through E. L. Phillips Co., in a stockholders' suit brought in Supreme Court.
Electric power production increased less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index declined to 106.1 from 106.5. It was 100.3 for the week ended May 16, 1936.

It appears that Richard Aldrich, who will supervise the drama festival at Central City, Col., this Summer, is not going to miss any of the stunts which old showmen used to pull in that mining town. For,
The shirtless bathing suit is still taboo on Atlantic City beaches, but the - question of giving men more freedom of the seas is not so easy to decide as it once was.

The annulment suit of Mrs. Suzanne Sheets Brandstetter, 18-yearold daughter of an oil company executive of Montclair, N. J., was reopened today by Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich at the request of her husband, Maryan Frank Brandstetter, 25, headwaiter of a tavern in West Orange, N. J.

Dan Tyler Moore Jr. has resigned from the registration division of the Securities and Exchange Commission to accept the appointment offered to him by Governor Davey of Ohio as Securities Commissioner of that State. He will assume his duties

With more than one-third of an audience of 600 participating, the cast and production staff of a WPA dance recital began a sit-in strike at the Nora Bayes Theatre immediately after the final curtain last night as a protest against impending layoffs of workers from the relief rolls.

American flag ship lines are losing heavily in traffic income by reason of restrictions imposed by foreign nations on the activities of their citizens, according to P. V. G. Mitchell, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company. Mr. Mitchell returned to

Completing a ninety-day period of study and research, the five committees of the platform commission of the National Retail Dry Goods Association submitted their reports yesterday to the executive committee of the commission, preparatory to a full meeting of the latter body today.

President Roosevelt vetoed the Merritt bill calling for a $5,000,000 Federal participation in the New York 1939 World's Fair today, on the grounds of economy and unconstitutionality. Members of the New York delegation immediately began making Plans to push a substitute measure for a smaller amount, and which would meet the other objections raised by the President.

Wholesalers of wine are prohibited from selling to consumers, under the bill of Senator Crawford of Kings, which is pending before Governor Lehman, but there has been no intimation from the Executive chamber what action the Governor intends to take on it.

Nathan Mann of New Haven, one of the outstanding prospects among the younger heavyweight crop, triumphed over Eddie Blunt of Corona in a slashing ten-rounder that attracted a crowd of 4,000 to the Hippodrome last night.

An ill-advised attempt to present Wagner's "Lohengrin" last night at the Metropolitan with a cast of singers unequal to the heavy task imposed upon them was foredoomed to come to grief. Three of the chief

The announcement made here tonight that' the United States Government has agreed to send America's premier team to compete in Dublin's famous horse show in August has been received with much satisfaction.

The Mineral Mining Corporation of Kershaw, S. C., is in no manner either directly or indirectly connected with the Mineral Mining Company, mentioned in an injunction granted in the New York Supreme Court restraining Victor DeVilliers of 120 Wall Street and Edward Schofs, his office manager, from dealing in securities in this State.

Scoring 81/2 points out of a possible 10, George Shainswit of the Bronx - International Chess Club captured first prize in the weekly rapid-transit tournament at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Theodore A. Dunst,

A report that the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company had offered a contract to Local 16 of the Marine and Ship Yard Workers, C. I. 0. affiliate, was made tonight by Michael Smith, C. I. O. organizer, at a mass meeting of 1,000 workers at the People's Center here. The corporation's yards at

The Boeing Airplane Company of Seattle, Wash., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 195,610 shares of $5-par capital stock, of which 183,610 shares are to be offered to stockholders and 12,000 to certain officers and employes of the company or its subsidiaries. Net proceeds will be lent to or invested in subsidiaries.

Loring Place, 2,326 (11-3225), Hasac Realty Corp. to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg. to March 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $144,000. Buchanan Place, 50 (11-3208), Marie Dummeyer to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg. to May 1, 1942, at 4 1/2. per cent; $40,000.

Close of play scores in first-class English cricket matches started today follow: Yorkshire, 395 for six wickets (Hutton 88, Sutcliffe 70, Leyland 66, Barber 50), vs. Warwickshire; at Birmingham. Hampshire, 280 (pothecary 100, Pollard zix wickets for 83), vs. Lancashire; at Manchester.

About 3,000 employes of the Alcoa plant of the Aluminum Company of America turned to gardening, fishing and checker playing today while production in the fabricating mill came to a halt following a strike last night.

Three hundred and forty-seven shouting, singing, Japan-hating students of Northeastern University here thought they had started for Nanking tonight on a special PeipingMukden railway train after a twenty-four-hour sit-down in Peiping's main railway station, but later reports from Tientsin said the students had been tricked and held up at the latter city because the Tientsin-Pukow railway refused to haul their cars south.

The twentieth annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America will open with a reception this evening at 8:30 o'clock at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The varnishing day reception for members, exhibitors and guests will be held this morning.

Several supper parties were given last night at Le Coq Rouge as part of the Spring frolic of the Junior Republican Committee of One Hundred. Miss Natalie O. Watts, chairman of the group arranging the event, entertained for Miss Constance Torney, Miss Friede Smidt, William M. Chadbourne, Mason Partridge, John Smidt, Howard Wortham, Donald Blair, Benjamin Fowler, William Moore and Benjamin Hoagland.

Whatever else is to be said of EDWARD, he is not and, in the nature of things, can never be forgotten. To reckon on such an oblivion overtaking him was one of those miscalculations to which officialdom in its stronghold is liable. EDWARD'S accepted place is on the front page.
Out of the mail bag: A letter from M. Strothman of Long Beach, N. Y., suggests some drastic changes in the supervision of trout streams in the State.

Mrs. Isabel Houston Disbrow of Brooklyn, widow of Wallace F. Disbrow, was married yesterday to John Davidson Paxton of Westmount, Montreal, Que., in the chapel of the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector, performed the ceremony.
The five-story apartment house at 1,511-5 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Fifteen-Eleven Corporation, Samuel Brenner, president, through Samuel Spring, attorney.

Miss Beverly Prince Robbins, daughter of Mrs. Beulah Prince Robbins of this city,..was married tonight to John Edgar Holmes, also of Newark. The ceremony was performed in St. Mark's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. John Borton.

An amendment to reduce the salary of Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, from $12,000 to $10,000 was offered by Senator Clark of Missouri today as the Senate began consideration of the bill, already passed by the House, to extend the life of this organization. The House bill extends

Contracts for new space for business purposes with concerns in the various lines comprising the apparel and textile industries were reported yesterday by brokers. Several photographers also were noted among the lessees. The list follows:

Professor Friedrich Schoenemann, back from a tour of the United States, forecast tonight in a lecture that public opinion in America could be mobilized for war against Germany "within a few hours," if such a war were pictured as a great crusade for a great ideal.
The Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of Henry C. and George W. Steneck on a charge of submitting a false bank statement to the State Department of Banking and Insurance.
Strong pressure has been brought to bear on Governor Lehman to have him approve a bill now before him to perpay after twenty years of service.

THE Chicago White Sox, amid general astonishment, put on a fiery campaign last year and climbed up to third place in the American League. Now the club is way down yonder in the cornfield. It took only one glance at Manager James J. Dykes yesterday to discover what was the matter with the ball club.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following order today, dated May 17: COMMANDERS McClaran, J. W., Washington, D. C., to command the Oglala.

Maynard H. Spear of 147-27 Barclay Avenue, Flushing, who was president of the New York and Queens Gas Company when it was merged with the Consolidated Edison Company last June, died yesterday morning in the Fifth Avenue Hospital. He underwent an abdominal operation on May 12. Born in Brooklyn 63 years ago, he had lived in Flushing since 1902.

Announcement was made here today of the marriage yesterday in Kingman, Ariz., of Miss Frances Margaret Anderson of New York, known on the stage as Judith, Anderson, to Professor Benjamin H. Lehman, Professor of English at the University --of California at Berkeley. The ceremony was performed by a justice of the peace.
The Otis Elevator .Company has declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. A payment of 15 cents a share was made on March 20.

Gerard Ave, 1,120-1,134, 1-story brick store, 108.11x100: Continental Mortgage Guarantee Co. against Famax Holding Corp,; due, $17,108; to plaintiff for $500. By GEORGE J.
