KEARNS 235th St. E. ?? 180 White Plains Ave, 25x114; Rose Schwartz against Alfonso Orso; due, $5,160; taxes, , $435; to plaintiff for %5,550.
Paulie Walker, Trenton middle-weight, who was recently suspended for appearing late for a scheduled bout, yesterday was reinstated at the weekly meeting of the New York State Athletic Commission.
Even considered purely as melodrama, critics agree Elmer Rice's "Judgment may Day" at the Embassy tonight is one of the best plays seen in London in a long time.
Ten years ago tomorrow all America held its breath and watched a gray monoplane speeding across the Atlantic toward France with a tall, fairhaired youngster at the controls.

11th St, 63 E, 27x103.3 :'Abbott Estates, Inc; Murray L. Berg, president, to Bankers Trust Co, trustee of Adela A. Dortic, 5 years 4 1/2 per cent, $16,000. 97th St, 57 W, 15x100.11; Lily Clapier to Felix A. Donnelly, 161 W 54th St, trustee of Emma B. S. Huntington, 3 years 5 per cent, $3.000.

Charles T. . Murphy, Assistant United States Attorney, whose investigation of a ring of jewelry smugglers recently took him abroad, caused the arrest and arraignment yesterday of four New York jewelers on a charge of conspiracy to smuggle.
Subject to a recount, the record for the number of entries in the national open golf championship has been broken by about 100, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
Henri Goiran, French Minister to Mexico, and Mrs. Goiran entertained with a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Pierre before sailing on the Normandie for Paris.
One American doubles combination and two other United States players passed out of the French hard court tennis championships today.
FIRST RACE--Purse $1,000; claiming: 3-year-olds and upward; six furlongs.

BALTUCK--Hyman. It is with deep regret that we record the passing of the father of our beloved President, Mary Abramowitz. Funeral services at the Park West Chapel, 115 West 79th St., today at 2:30 P. M. Members are requested to attend. Sunshine League for Orphan Children. ESTELLE KAY, Secretary.

What had been intended to be a second coronation procession, the state drive of the King and Queen to Guildhall to have lunch with the Lord Mayor of London and the great merchants and financiers of the realm had to be canceled today because of the slow but persistent rain.
The class of '26, with a score of 290, won the team honors in the Columbia University Alumni Federation golf tournament, held today at the Upper Montclair Country Club. The class of '05 finished

With the Governor's signature, the Murray bill for improving old-law tenements has now become law. It will at last enable the Tenement House Deapartment in this city to carry out the intentions of the 1929 Multiple Dwelling Law. It provides that if owners are

11th St, 63 E, n s. 27x103.3 Bankers Trust Co and and, trustee of Adela A. Dortic, 11th St, 619 E, n s, 25x103.3; S. Howard Sundell, referee, to Emil Reineking, 85-20 Park Lane South, Woodhaven, L. I. ; foreclosure $1.50).

This may be a changing world, but when the Dodgers come to Wrigley Field the situation remains unaltered. Operating under the jinx that puts spots before their eyes when they meet the Cubs here, the Brooklyn boys today dropped the series opener, 3--1.

Leonard Leopold Mackall, president of the Bibliographical Socity of America and editor of many notes for bibliophiles, died here today in the Mary Washington Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 58 years old.
The funeral of Mrs. Isabella A. Gallagher, pioneer resident of Ogdensburg, will be held at St. Mary's Cathedral, the parish in which she was born, on Saturday morning.

According to reports reaching here from Athens, the Greek dictatorship has recently overcome a crisis of some importance in which Premier John Metaxas had to order a number of arrests to halt a whispering campaign of disagreement between him and King George.

Scientists, engineers and inventors, who assembled at the Franklin Institute today to receive some of most valued awards in the scientific world, were taken aback by the . unexpected suggestion that they apply some of their knowledge of nuclear physics, microchemistry and engineering to the solution of problems in America's "dust bowl."

A fist fight rarely equaled in intensity on a major league baseball diamond embroiled the Giants and Cardinals yesterday at Sportsman's Park in St. Louis. After special policemen and umpires restored order, Carl Hubbell, who had remained on the sidelines, stepped calmly to the pitching mound to finish the job of defeating Dizzy Dean and his St. Louis team-mates, 4--1.

A jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court awarded $10,000 yesterday to George Combes, of. 28 .Hampton Road, Rockville Centre, -L. L., for the loss of an eye when struck by a golf ball on the Dyker Beach municipal golf course- at Eightysixth Street, between Seventh and Fourteenth Avenues, Brooklyn. Combes sued the city for negligence on the ground that the golf course had been improperlv laid out.

The midnight rendezvous at a country cross-roads where Ellis H. Parker Sr. capped his secret inquiry into the Lindbergh baby case by surrendering Paul H. Wendel as the "confessed" kidnapper, was described in cryptic and paradoxical manner today by James H. Kirkham, chief of the Mercer County detectives, friend of Parker for thirty years and his collaborator in constabulary problems in Southern New Jersey.
"Tobacco Road," shown privately at the Gate Theatre tonight, it is said the play may have some native value in America as a social tract, but it is of no value here.

As the State approached this afternoon: the close of its case against Gladys MacKnight, 18 years old, and her erstwhile admirer, Donald Wightman, 19, who are charged with the hatchet slaying of Gladys's mother last July 31, defense counsel opened the way for their defense on the ground of justifiable homicide.

Representatives of the Great Lakes shipping industry, appearing before the Senate Committee on Commerce today, opposed various provisions of the safe ship bill now before that committee. Their contention was

The Progressive party observed its third anniversary today with the assurance of Governor Philip La Follette, its titular head, that future years would see the formation of a national progressive party which would sweep to victory over the "reactionary forces of America."
Mrs. W. Frank Sooy of Atlantic City carried off low gross laurels today in the women's New Jersey Golf Association two-day tournament at the Seaview Golf Club at Absecon. She added a 91 to her

In 1919, an anonymous donor who later turned out to be Mr. STANLEY BALDWIN, gave [pound]20,000, a large share of his fortune, to his country as a symbol that " love of country is better than love of money." Now, at the end of a generation in public life, as his hour as head of the British Government nears an end, Mr. BALDWIN bequeathes another legacy to his countrymen.

The United States cruiser Vincennes left for Havre today and the destroyers Winslow and Conyngham left for 'Oslo after a nine-day visit here. . The government, navy, municipality and the Finnish-American Association arranged luncheons and dinner dances. Captain B. H. Green

Governor LEHMAN has earned the gratitude of all liberals, of all who value freedom of speech and of the arts, by his veto of the Dunnigan oneman censorship bill. That bill would have permitted a minor political official, upon. proof of " immorality " satisfactory merely to himself, to revoke a license for any play without taking the trouble to submit the matter to a court decision.

The new film today at the Palace is "Melody for Two," a Warner musical with Patricia Ellis, James Melton, Fred Keating and Marie Wilson .. . The Fred AstaireGinger Rogers song and dance opus, "Shall We Dance," is continuing for a second week at the Radio City Music Hall.

The action of Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, in revoking the licenses of burlesque houses here was commended yesterday morning by the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at their annual meeting at the Community House, Congregation Emanu-EI, at 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Net earnings of the Consolidated Oil Corporation for the first three months of this year were approximately $5,000,000 after all charges, H. F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. He explained that the earnings

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, praised the role of the small life insurance company in speaking last night at the tenth annual dinner of the Eastern Life Insurance Company, given in the Hotel Astor. Louis Lipsky,

Eugene Unger, 37 years old, an attorney of 416 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, was. held in bail of $3,500 by Magistrate Frank Girogio in Queens yesterday on charges of larceny and forgery preferred by a former client. The hearing was set for June 2.

Sydney B. Wertheimer of 628 Third Street, Brooklyn, an investment broker with offices at 70 Pine Street, Manhattan, died suddenly Tuesday night of a heart attack while walking near Eastern Parkway and Underhill Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 58 ears old.
DREAMING LIPS, as adapted by Carl Mayer from Henri Bernstein's "Melo" directed and produced by Dr. Paul Czinner for Trafalgar Films; released by United Artists. At the Rivoli.

Denying that the major responsibility for the Spanish civil war could justly be attributed to the army because it struck the first blow, E. Allison Peers, Professor of Spanish at the University of Liverpool, predicted last night that "the virtues of traditionalist Spain" would eventually bring back peace and prosperity.

Renewed evidence that the British monetary authorities are operating to absorb some of the large supplies of gold being offered in the London market, thereby lightening the burden placed upon the United States Treasury of buying gold, was provided yesterday by the announcement in London that the Bank of England, for the second time in eight days, had made a large purchase of gold.
Eighth annual convention of New York State Dietetic Association, Hotel Astor. 10 A. M. Morning, afternoon and evening sessions; continues Friday and Saturday.

Mrs. Rhoda Lewisohn of New York was married to Gabriel Prud'homme of Kenya Colony, British East Africa, a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor, at Caxton Hall register office yesterday. They plan to make their home in Kenya.

Governor Lehman vetoed today the bill of Senator Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the Senate, which would have clothed the New York City License Commissioner with drastic powers to revoke theatre licenses for one year.

An appeaf was made to Mrs. Roosevelt. today by Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Generalissimo of China, to mobilize the women of the world for peace, during a. ceremony marking the opening of radio telephone service between America and China.

Turpentine firm, 35 3/4c; sales, 103 barrels; receipts, 489 barrels; shipments, 12 barrels; stock, 25,335 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 616; receipts, 1,270; shipments, 200: stock, 46,266. Quote: B, $7.35; D, $7.50; E. $7.90; F, G, H, $8.27 1/2-30; I, K, M, $8.30-32 1/2; N, $8.35; WG, $8.35-40; WW, X, $9.15.
The state of war [modified form of martial law] will be suspended for twenty-four hours tomorrow to permit Congress to vote on two amendments to the Constitution.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today suspended new freight rate schedules for seven months beginning tomorrow on tobacco, phosphate rock and tanning materials. The rates, filed several months ago by the railroads, called for increases of approximately 10 per cent on all three commodities.

The induction of the newly elected officers of the Student Self-Government Association of Hunter College and the presentation of "H" pins to seniors who have performed outstanding service to the college were the chief features of the Student Council chapel assembly held yesterday morning at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Executives of the privately owned public utility electric systems in Nebraska said here yesterday that they had. not been approached by any representative of Nebraska's public hydroelectric systems with

Milton Weinstein has joined the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., as assistant to Leonard Ginsberg, vice president and general manager, it was announced yesterday. For the last three years he has been general sales'manager for Powdrell Alexander, with headquarters in Danielson, Conn.

Pensloned On their own applications: PATROLMEN-DanieL E. McKeever, 82d Precinct, at .$1,500 per annum. Appointed April 15, 1905. Alexander Mailey, 8th Precinct, at $1,50C per annum. Appointed April 6, 1912.
Two Princeton heavyweight freshman crews scored relatively easy triumphs over the Hun School and Lawrenceville School first eights in an informal regatta today on Lake Carnegie.

With the shoe chains. feeling a definite reaction from their recent price rises, more aggressive advertising campaigns will probably be launched to offset any decline in volume, according to reports here yesterday. A. S. Beck, which
The market for government bonds remains in the doldrums awaiting official word from Washington as to the nature of the Treasury's financing plans for next month.
Army, still undefeated at lacrosse this season, gained its eighth victory today, defeating Rutgers, 14 to 9.

Steel production for the week is estimated at 92 per cent of capacity, with the outlook viewed more hopefully than a few weeks ago, when the new business volume began to decline, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age.

Although Premier Senjuro Hayashi professes to be hopeful about the result when the hostile Diet meets in August, it is felt in responsible circles that he will have to retire. The names of possible successors are quietly being reviewed.

Charles Newton Hulvey, Associate Professor of Commercial Law at the University of Virginia, died here yesterday after a brief illness. He was 50 years old. He had been an associate professor since 1928, having been Assistant Professor of Commercial Law for three years and instructor in mathematics and law for one session before that time.
VENATOR. Sir, you have almost amazed me; for I have always looked upon Anglers as more patient and more simple men than I

Wheat bulls had some uneasy moments today as the result of reports of scattered showers in the dry areas in Kansas and Saskatchewan, and the market followed the weather reports, advancing early on trade advices indicating further deterioration in the crop outlook in the Southwest and dust storms in Saskatchewan.

The uprising in Southern Albania seems to have been definitely suppressed. Some of the rebels have succeeded in fleeing into Greece and the remainder are hiding in mountains and forests along the border, with government forces pursuing them.

Stung by the charge of Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, that the monastery immorality trials here are merely anti-Catholic propaganda, the government news service, the press and the radio launched a bitter counter-attack today.

Head Coach Ed Leader said tonight that the Yale varsity crew for the regatta with Princeton and Cornell on the Housatonic Saturday would be the same as that which defeated Pennsylvania and Columbia on the Harlem several weeks ago.
Arnold J. Gantvoort, nationally known music teacher, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years of age. Funeral services will take place tomorrow.

A red sun, "the sailor's delight," sank above a forest of tapering masts and rakish funnels at Spithead tonight as the assembled might of British seapower plus the men-of-war of seventeen foreign nations rigged their dressing lines and made final preparations for tomorrow's coronation naval review.

Consider the plight of some Kentucky colonels who cannot buy in their own county the principal ingredient own county the principal ingredient for mint juleps. Kentucky, the leading whisky-producing State in the nation, today was about onethird dry.

In the dawn, ten years ago today, an overburdened monoplane struggled into the air from Roosevelt Field, Paris bound. At its controls was young CHARLES A. LINDBERGH, an air mail flier, who had staked his all on this adventure. Until then comparatively

Harry H. Liebovits, founder of the Jewish Education Association and one of the principal supporters of the movement for improving and extending the religious training of Jewish youth, was named president of the, association at its annual meeting last night at the Hotel Pierre. Mr. Liebovitz has been treasurer. He succeeds the late Judge Otto A. Rosalsky.

If man's wage standard is determined by free competition of unmarried youth and women, the floating minority with which capital "wins" its controversy with labor, then the church exacts the impossible in the vows of those that it marries, the Rev. Dr. Nathan R. Melhorn of Philadelphia, editor of The Lutheran, said today.

R. P. Foote has resigned as an assistant manager of the London office of the Bankers Trust Company to accept an appointment as assistant treasurer at the New York office, 16 Wall Street, about July 1.
ROOM SERVICE, a comedy in three acts, John P. Murray and Allen Boretz. Scenery by Cirker Robbins: staged and produced by George Abbott. At the Cort Theatre.

The long-term outlook for construction work in the building industry indicates, substantial expansion, the Lumber Survey Committee of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association states in its twentyfourth quarterly report to the United States Department of Commerce. The nearer outlook is less

Jacob and Emil Leitner, Inc, has arranged, for the Bosa Builders, Inc, Morris Bogdanoff, president, a permanent loan for $125,000 for five years, with the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank on the sixstory apartment house at 3,055 Decatur Ave, the Bronx .

A growing conflict in the House over balancing of the Federal budget was evidenced today by economy and counter-economy moves within the Democratic majority, with chairmen of two important committees going off the administration reservation on the eve of consideration of the $1,500.000,000 relief bill.

Westchester County golfers today won the Stoddard Bowl for the first time when they eclipsed sides from New Jersey and Long Island in the annual triangular team matches at the Arcola Country Club. The final score was Westchester 271/2 points, New Jersey 261/2 and Long Island 18.
Lewis P. Andreas, head basketball coach for the past thirteen seasons, today was appointed director of athletics and physical education at Syracuse University, effective July 1.

Resignation of Clarence E. Huff as president of the Farmers National Grain Corporation was announced today by the directors of this offspring of the former Federal Farm Loan Board following two days of closed meetings at which factional strife was reported to have been virulent.

A stay-at-home strike kept several hundred workers from their jobs today at the No. 2 assembly plant of the Franklin Car Shops of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant. Leaders of the walkout said that 600 to 800 men on two of the three eight-hour shifts were out, while a Bethlehem official placed the number at 500.

Mgr. Patrick Joseph Healy, Professor of Church History in the School of the Sacred Sciences at Catholic University and formerly dean of the theological faculty, died last night in Proviidence Hospital here.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator for this area, turned over yesterday to Russell Forbes, New York City Commissioner of Purchases, a two-story brick and steel structure at New Dock and Water Streets, Brooklyn, which will be used to store material and equipment used by the Department of Plant and Structures.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine charged yesterday that a "great labor organization" was seeking to block the extradition of four men under arrest in Fort Wayne and Kokomo, Ind., charged with the stench bombing of Brooklyn motion picture theatres. The men have been indicted by the Kings County grand jury.

Officials of the Associated Gas and Electric Company indicated yesterday that they probably would proceed with their suit in the Supreme Court of New York State, which was filed in November, 1936, in an effort to force the distribution of the Jersey Central Power and Light common stock to the National Public Service Corporation debenture holders.

Twenty-seven National Youth Administration workers began a sitdown strike yesterday afternoon in the offices of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, on the fifth floor of 79 Madison Avenue, at Twenty-eighth Street.

In a grove of shade trees set off from a little-used Greenwich Village street, a tiny red brick house about which strange and fanciful legends abound was the center of attraction yesterday for a group of welfare workers and their guests, who were roaming through the Village on a benefit garden tour.

Harold Harden, 30 years old, of Blossvale, N.. Y., an executive of the Queensboro Farm Products Company, Long Island City, was killed and four other men were seriously injured tonight in an automobile collision on the Canandaigua-Shortsville highway near here.

Executive committeemen of the striking Federated Motion Picture Crafts voted today to repudiate an appeal which its publicity committee telegraphed yesterday to labor organizations asking a national boycott against films in which five leaders of the non-striking Screen Actors' Guild appear.

Because too few shares remain outstanding, the New York Stock Exchange has made application to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to strike from listing and registration the $7 and $8 cumulative preferred stock of the General Gas and Electric Company. Only 2,618 shares of the
An autopsy showed yesterday that 2-months-old Dolores Galvin died in Brooklyn Tuesday of natural causes and not as a result of injuries possibly inflicted by her 3-year-old brother, Noel, with a toy.

Despite steady liquidation of the July position yesterday which narrowed the premium over October to 10 points, prices on the Cotton Exchange made a further improvement and ended unchanged to 5 points higher than on Tuesday.
Two former champions were eliminated from the twenty-sixth annual Southern women's golf tournament today, while the medalist and the defending titleholder swept into the quarter-finals.

Several close associates of the late Colonel Edward H. R. Green testified yesterday concerning the financier's interests in Texas, Massachusetts and New York at hearings preliminary to the probate of his will, which is being contested by his widow. Mrs. Mabel H. Green.

On the eve of the collective bargaining election by employee of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, declared today that the Republic Steel Corporation had sent its "police and thugs" to Aliquippa, to interfere with the voting.

Nevil Ford, vice president of the First Boston Corporation, has been nominated for the presidency of the Bond Club of New York for the ensuing year, to succeed Frank F. Walker of Eastman, Dillon Co. The election will take place at the annual meeting on June 23.
Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Sutton and their daughter and son, Miss Emily F. F. Sutton and Richard Carteret Sutton, will leave next week for Strathaven, their country place in Brandon, Vt.

Death Announced Captain Edward Schellhaas, of H. L. 161, died May 18. Funeral will take place from the Funeral Parlors of George Englert, 115 Evergreen Ave., Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, May 21. Interment at St. Johns Cemetery.

Testimony by officers who were in the control car of the airship Hindenburg when it took fire and crashed with the loss of thirty-six lives here on May 6 made it clear to the official investigating board today that large quantities of inflammable, explosive hydrogen gas were released in landing operations shortly before the fire and explosion.
Howard Gould, third son of the late Jay Gould, and his German actress bride, attended a new wine festival tonight to watch Austrian peasants in colorful costumes celebrate.

Governor Lehman today heard the NunanMoffat bill, barring the sale in this State of child-labor made-goods, denounced as "unenforceable and unworkable," and praised as a step which eventually would lead to complete abolition of child labor.

Exclusive of Federal income tax claims of $1,132,637, claims against the estate of Arthur W. Cutten, grain speculator, amount to more than the $400,000 in liquid assets shown in an inventory filed last Winter.

Clyde Crouse, veteran catcher of the Bisons, today was named playing manager of Baltimore. Crouse, who took charge immedi%tely, succeeded Guy Sturdy. The latter, retained as a scout, was let Dut as manager last night.

Russell Merrill, president of Studebaker Local 5 of the United Automobile Workers of America, announced tonight there would be "no settlement," until a meeting of all union members Friday morning, of the strike of nearly 7,000 workers which began suddenly today at the Studebaker Corporation plants.

Insistence upon foreclosures by the Home Owners Loan Corporation and dumping of the foreclosed properties on the real estate market would create "chaos," Senator Copeland asserted tonight in a radio address.

William Fellowes Morgan, Markets Commissioner, warned city dwellers yesterday to cast a suspicious eye on the roadside stands in outlying districts which purport to sell home-grown produce to the week-end motorist.

Free entry of Puerto Ricans into this country through the Port of New York is causing "a slum condition" here and is one of the biggest problems confronting immigration officials at Ellis Island, Rudolph Reimer, District Commissioner of Immigration, said yesterday in a luncheon address before the Kiwanis Club of New York at Lhe McAlpin Hotel.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,630,000 of various purpose bonds of the city of Houston, Texas, on a bid of 100.003 for $655,000 of the bonds, maturing from 1939 to 1957, as 3s, and $975,000, due from 1940 to 1957, as 2 3/4s.

Mrs. Sophie Schlesinger of 45 Beverly Road, West Orange, N. J., an organizer and a member of the board of directors of the Jewish Sisterhood and Day Nursery in Newark, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after an operation performed on Monday.

Assurances that England is willing to grant concessions to farmers in the United States in exchange for lower tariffs against some classes of typically British goods in the United States, and that Argentina may eliminate restrictions on foreign exchange affecting imports from this country,
An analogy between Britain's war debt owed the United States and the Irish Free State's land annuities was made by President Eamon de Valera in a speech in the Dail tonight. Declaring that his

Against the backgroundd of a Pilgrims dinner similar to those always used to welcome new United States Ambassadors to Great Britain, James W. Gerard, President Roosevelt's special envoy to the coronation, tonight termed the unwritten pact of AngloAmerican - French friendship the world's greatest defense against fascism and communism.

Four Insurgent airplanes bombed the merchant vessel Legazpi off Benicasim today, killing one sailor and injuring another. The ship was set afire but as a government airplane arrived and drove off the attackers the vessel was beached and the flames extinguished.

The inquiry by the Civil Liberties Union into the alleged suppression of political rights here will be terminated tomorrow without a hearing and the commission headed by Arthur Garfield Hays of New York Will draft its report, Mr. Hays announced tonight after a day of hearing testimony.

The will of General Jay Johnson Morrow, enlivened with jesting references to comic opera, football, golf and jigsaw puzzles; was made public today by Surrogate J. Blauvelt Hopper, who had admitted it to probate May 11.

Mrs. Josephine M. Steacy, 66 years old, who was known in her own home town of York, Pa., as a wellto-do patron of civic causes, was locked in the women's detention prison last night on a charge of embezzling $42,876.

Governor Lehman signed today the Rogers-Allen Milk Bill, authorizing distributors and producers to bargain for prices in marketing areas but closing the door to the fixing of consumers' prices. The Governor said the bill "returns milk control to the milk industry, where it belongs."

Miss Grace Abbott, Professor of Public Welfare at the University of Chicago, sailed yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan as one of the government's two delegates to the twenty-third session of the International Labor Office in Geneva. The other delegate,

The Rev. Dr. Robert J. White was named dean of the faculty of the School of Law of Catholic University of America here today, effective at once, by the Right Rev. Joseph M. Corrigan, rector of the university.

Munguia, nine miles northeast of Bilbao, was heavily bombed today simultaneously with Plencia, on the Bay of Biscay coast, and Maruri, on the road between those two towns. More than twenty Rebel bombers participated in the attack. They were escorted by pursuit planes, which shot at people fleeing from wrecked towns.

A plan to consolidate the Manufacturers Housing Promotion Council and the National Housing Advisory Council with the Producers' Council will be acted upon at the convention of the. latter organization to be held in conjunction with the sixty-ninth convention of the American Institute of Architects in Boston June 1 to 5.

Vassar College prize winners were announced at senior chapel tonight, after which the seniors paraded to the steps of Rockefeller Hall, where they sang their farewell song. The awards were; Helen Kate Furness Awards.in English-First, Joy Hume, '38, Wynnewood, Pa.; second, Barbara Welles, '37, Amherst, Mass.

The Progressive party observed its third anniversary today with the assurance of Governor Philip La Follette, its titular head, that future years would see the formation of a national progressive party which would sweep to victory over the "reactionary forces of America."

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Louise English, daughter of Mrs. Everett W. English of Milton, Mass., and the late Mr. English, to Francis Farrar Goldsborough, son of Mrs. Richard F. Goldsborough of 156 East Fifty-fifth Street and the late Mr. Goldsborough, took place here late yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension. The Rev. Wallace C. Goodfellow performed the ceremony.

Appointment of Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, to succeed Justice Van Devanter on the latter's retirement from the Supreme Court on June 2 was confidently predicted tonight by the Arkansan's colleagues in Congress.
The work of taking the jury rig and ea hatch covers off the Endeavour I was started today as the big, lue-hulled America's Cup chalenger lay alongside the north pier if the Herreshoff shipyard here.

The identical Child Labor Law which Congress enacted in 1916, and which the Supreme Court invalidated in 1918, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Black of Alabama, chairman of the Committee on Education and Labor. He sent to the clerk's desk

The Rev. Mother Blandine of the Western Province of the Order of the Little Sisters of the Poor died yesterday at the age of 31 of pneumonia in San Francisco while on an official visit to one of the houses of her order. Before entering

Railroads no longer have anything even approaching a monopoly in the transportation business, F. E. Williamson, president of the New York Central system, testified today in the $15,000,000 railroad tax litigation in Federal district court here before Judge Philip Forman.

A young woman's account of how her husband caused her to read, in a darkened room two days after their marriage, Charles Dickens's tale of a man whose wife was made mad when she awakened to find him attempting her murder, brought an annulment today of the marriage of Homer L. Loomis Jr., son of a New York lawyer, and Laura Hampton Hover, 19, of Los Angeles, an art and drama student.

Phillips Exeter lost a twelve-inning game to New Hampton today, 11-7, the entire contest being played in a rain storm. Exeter led until the seventh inning, when the visitors found Bill Tully for several hits and four runs to tie the count at 7-all.
Henry Thomas Barnham, Richmond architect and engineer for more than two decades, died here yesterday in a hospital after an illness of more than a year. He was 51 years old.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 8,000, including 2,500 direct. Market 35c-50c higher than Tuesday's average; packing sows 25c-35c higher; bulk good and choice 200-300 pounds, $11.65$11.90; top, $12.00; comparable 150-190 pounds. $11.00-$11.85 mostly.

The National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare, of which Harry L. Glucksman of New York is president, began a five-day session here tonight with an open meeting at which he was chief speaker. He outlined the work scheduled for the sessions.

The Justice Department ordered its G-men into Harlan County, Ky., tonight to investigate charges that coal operators there had violated the National Labor Relations Act by conspiring to throttle union organization through "violence and terrorism."

The Court of Errors and Appeals affirmed today the action of Vice Chancellor Henry T. Kays in refusing a writ of habeas corpus to Giro L. Mei, also known as Jerry May, who sought to escape trial in the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer on an indictment charging him with murder.

The eighty-first annual report of the board of governors of Woman's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street, showed that in 1936 the hospital gave service to 14,262 persons, the United Hospital Fund of New York announced yesterday.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, threatened last night to call a strike on Yonkers bus lines, operated by the Suburban Bus Company, Inc., unless three men, alleged to have been discharged for union activities, were reinstated, and unless the company recognized the union as the sole bargaining agency for the employes.

Japan's Army and Navy Ministers warned fortysix prefectural Governors tonight that Soviet Russia has "positive war plans" in the Orient. Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai, the Minister of the Navy, told the meeting that "not a day must be lost in strengthening our navy from this danger."

The final meeting for this season of the Club of Amateurs organized by Miss Berthe Bert, for the purpose of furthering appreciation of music among non-professionals, took place yesterday at Miss Bert's studio, 170 East Seventy-eighth Street.

The four-story brick and concrete factory and one-story brick power plant and storage building at Avenue A and Gertrude Street, Bayonne, N. J., has been sold by Lanman Kemp-Barclay Co. to the Fitch Company of Iowa.

Carl Grune, managing director of British Chemicolour, which produces colored motion pictures, announced- today that he had signed a contract with William Fox for the latter to become "an active executive" of the British companv.

A "reunion" of the tea companies founded by the late Sir Thomas Lipton in this country and in England was announced yesterday by Sir George Schuster, chairman of Lipton, Ltd., of London, who has just become president of Thomas J. Linton. Inc.. of New York.
Solon B. Lilienstern, lawyer and banker, with offices at 1,501 Broadway, died yesterday of heart disease in his fifty-first year at his residence, 1,130 Park Avenue.

Simon Elwes, through -Gresham Realty Corp, duplex penthouse in 414 E 52d St; Herbert R. Leeds, through First Madison Corp, penthouse in 1,070 Park Ave; W. Montgomery Jackson, through Brett Wyckoff, Inc, penthouse in 383 Park Mrs. Louis De3onge Tim, through Sharp Nassoit Management Corp penthouse in 160 E 48th St; Byron G. Webster, through Brown, Wheelocl, Harris, Stevens, Inc. penthouse in 3 E 66th St; Madison Realty Co, broker.
Army's tennis team defeated New York University today, 6 to 3, with the Cadets defaulting in two of the doubles matches because of lack of time. Army won five .of the six singles matches.

Glenn Morris, Olympic decathlon champion, has forfeited his amateur standing by signing a contract to act in Tarzan movies, a letter from Daniel J. Ferris, national sec retary of the A. A. U. said today.

Sources close to the French Foreign Office said tonight that Austria had reejected a French proposal that she join the Little Entente [Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia] in a bloc designed to combat German and Italian expansionist plans in Central Europe.

Chain store circles here yesterday were concerned over the consideration by the Florida Legislature of enactment of a State chain store tax similar to the Louisiana law which was validated early this week by the Supreme Court.
Fireman James Devney will be the first member of his department to retire under a new retirement system when he turns in his equipment today- at Hook and Ladder Company 147 in Brooklyn.

A new two-acre playground was officially opened yesterday afternoon in Central Park on the site of the once fashionable Central Park Casino with the unveiling of a plaque in honor of the late Mrs. Mary Harriman Rumsey, a founder of the Community Councils of the City of New York, for whom the play center is named.

A total of 65,657 employed men and women in New York City have contributed an average of 45 cents each to the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, it was reported last night by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the campaign. The sum of $306,510.16 has been raised to date in the $600,000.campaign.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on April 30 a net profit of $3,466,355 after depreciation, amortization, normal Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed earnings and other deductions. After dividend requirements on the Class A stock the profit equaled 60 cents each on 5,173,611 shares of common stock.

With-the list of entries completed, the middle-distance and long-distance races at the sixty-first annual I. C. A. A. A. A. track and field championships loom as unusually interesting events as four intercollegiate titleholders and one Olympic champion have sent in their names for the tests.

For nearly two hours this afternoon about 300 crippled war veterans, who with attendants and Red Cross workers made up a throng of almost 1,000, moved about the White House lawn, listened to the United States Marine Band and Negro spiritual songs and partook of refreshments provided by President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

Yale University's team, recently crowned champion of the New England section of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association, will meet either Princeton or Georgetown, Middle Atlantic section colorbearers, for the association title at Springdale, Conn., Saturday, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, executive secretary.
The Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield signed their marriage contract, which was drawn up by Mr. Bertin, a Tours notary, this morning.

The depths to which form players have fallen at Belmont was best illustrated yesterday by the threehorse Ben Brush Handicap, in which the harried backers of favorites went down to their tenth consecutive defeat when Cleaveland Putnam's Moon Side was beaten.

Sir Alfred Welby, Conservative Member of Parliament for Taunton from 1895 to 1906, died today. He was 87 years old. Sir Alfred began his army career in 1867 and twenty-five years later was lieutenant colonel commanding the Royal Scots Greys.

For the first time in thirty-one years Budapest had royal visitors today when King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Elena of Italy and Princess Maria arrived this morning for a four-day visit. Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano accompanied them in order to confer with leading Hungarian politicians.

Fellowships for the Bread" Loaf Writers Conference to be held in late August at Bread Loaf Inn, Vermont, have been awarded to six writers: Fletcher Pratt, biographer, historian and journalist; Robert Francis, poet; James Still, poet and fiction writer; Ira Stephens Nelson, Mary Fassett Hunt, short story writer, and Helen L. Card. The conference is held under the auspices of Middlebury College.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in- local private and public elementary and high schools. The list follows:

President Roosevelt veoued the bill for Federal participation in New York City's World's Fair, sent to the Senate the nomination of Sumner Welles to be Under-Secretary of State and of R. Walton Moore to be Counselor of the State Department and, with Mrs. Roosevelt, attended the annual White House garden party for crippled war veterans.

Word has been received here of the birth of a daughter on Tuesday in Minneapolis to the Rev. and Mrs. Ensworth T. Reisner of Detroit. Mrs. Reisner is the former Miss Charlotte Hanson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Hanson of Minneapolis. The child, whose father is

Buses continued to displace trolleys as the chief means of surface transportation during 1936, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission. The chief gain in bus traffic was in Manhattan, where, during the year, buses replaced trolleys on all the routes of the old Green Lines, or New York Railways System.
The one-thousandth request made at the present term of the Supreme Court for review of a lower court decision reached the clerk today. By nightfall three or four others had been added.

Dr. J. Leon Lascoff, a trustee of the Columbia University College of Pharmacy and a retail pharmacist here, has been named as the recipient of the Remington Honor Medal, the highest honor bestowed by the profession of pharmacy, for the year 1936, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Hugo H. Schaefer, chairman of the committee of the
Although the stock market here continued quiet today, a brighter feeling was evident in most of its sections. Giltedge issues were among the dull spots and foreign loans in general were inactive.

J. Henry Roraback, Republican National Committeeman for Connecticut, and for twenty-five years the chairman of the State committee and dominant party leader, shot and killed himself this afternoon on the grounds of his hunting and fishing estate here.
American painters, printmakers, architects and craftsmen will be represented in the United States pavilion at the Paris International Exposition this Summer but American sculpture will not be shown.
The British Government has made a new attempt to obtain the cooperation of four other. great powers in stopping the Spanish: war, according to The Daily Herald.

Two anticipated events-a retirement from the Supreme Court bench, and the Senate Judiciary Committee's rejection of the Maverick-Ashurst bill-have not had quite their anticipated effects on the outcome of the controversy.
When Dr. Hugo Eckener arrives in Washington this week-end to talk with government officials about Germany's chances to obtain helium for her airships he is likely to find a sympathetic hearing.
Dr. Stephen Herbert Langdon, American-born scholar who became Professor of Assyriology at Oxford University, died in- Oxford today. He was 61 years old.

Plans for remodeling and modernizing were announced yesterday in connection with purchases of Harlem houses by investors James A. and Mary Sullivan, who owned. the five-story apartment house at 17 West 100th Street for twenty-five years, sold it to an investing client to Emanuel Schoenzeit for remodeling.

President Roosevelt will toss out the ball opening a baseball game between newspaper men and members of Congress at the National Press Club's annual frolic Saturday afternoon at the Quantico (Va.) marine base.

Mrs. Marion Turpie, who returned from a long sojourn in New Orleans only a week ago, began her .Long Island golf tournament season auspiciously today by winning the weekly event of the Women's Long Island Association by a threestroke margin at the North Shore Country Club.

Facing more than fifteen police officials from various communities in the Federal Building yesterday, Jewell Ashby Gould, nationally known jewel thief and matinee burglar, was identified as a suspect in the murder of Max Silverstein, a jeweler, and in several burglaries.
Secretary Morgenthau met today with members of the Federal Reserve Board's open market committee to make preliminary plans for the Treasury's mid-June borrowing.

About $40,000 will be spent in converting into two and three room apartments the building at 219-21 East Ninety-sixth Street, sold by the Central Savings Bank to Samuel E. Klein through Edward N. Raber, Inc. The house, the third

Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company so far this month have been showing a greater percentage of increase over last year than in the preceding four months, and all indications point to a substantial gain for the month as a whole, E. C. Mauchly, vice president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Watertown, N. Y.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended April 30, issued for publication today, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $24,951,878, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to $2.74 a share on the common stock outstanding at the close of the period.

Another of the four men on trial for aiding and abetting Robert J. Suhay and Alfred Power in the robbery of the Northern Westchester Bank of Katonah, N.. Y., on March 12, pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz. He was John H.

Members of the exhibitions committee of the New York Junior League gave a tea yesterday at the league's clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, to inaugurate the exhibition of art work by the students at private schools for girls in the city. The exhibition, which will

Persons prominent in the social and musical worlds attended the tea in behalf of the MacDowell Colony for creative artists yesterday at the home of Miss Anne Morgan, 3 Sutton Place. Mrs. Edward MacDowell,

In a series of raids on Brooklyn drug stores last night, sixteen men, all either drug store owners or clerks, were arrested in what District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan described as the start of a drive to protect Brooklyn high school students "from those who are putting temptation in their way.

A famous St. Bernard dog, symbol of compassion and charity, today stands convicted of murder-and a child murder at that. A team from the great St. Bernard hospice in Switzerland suddenly ran amok end one of the infuriated 260-pound dogs sank his teeth into 10-yearold Marianne Bremond, daughter of a Grenoble physician.

Elwood S. Akin, for many years engaged as an importer of European draft horses, died here last night at the home of his son-inlaw, F. Raymond Dominy, Suffolk County Alcoholic Beverage Control Board member, after a long illness. His age was 77.

Legal proceedings were instituted yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in the Supreme Court in Albany against the Niagara Falls Power Company to force it to pay for the water that it diverts from the Niagara River for the production of electric power.
Junior Leaguers today voted for less fiction and more articles on real life in their national magazine.

The thirteenth annual Westchester Music Festival, which began here tonight at the County Center, struck a happy balance in its combination of local and outside forces. There was the chorus made up of amateurs from Westchester's communities.

Because of wrong food habits many Americans shorten their life span and "eat themselves into an early grave," Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, Professor of Surgery at Columbia University and president of the AmeriCan Medical Association, told a meeting of the New York State Dietetic Association yesterday.

With power plants operating under full crews again after an eight-hour strike shut-down yesterday, arrangements were made today to seek an early settlement of the workers' grievances that left the Bay City-Saginaw-Flint area in darkness.

Secretary Morgenthau is expected to reach next week a final determination of the Treasury's financing on June 15. He said today that on Tuesday he would meet again with the Federal Reserve open market executive committee to discuss the situation. Just when the announcement of the financing plans will be made was not disclosed.

Pensioned On his own application. PATROLMAN-Henry L. Monaghan, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 5, 1911. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-Charles H. J. Connor, from Motorcycle Precinct 1 to office of
Contracts for the purchase of 4,903,929 barrels of fuel oil and 9,330,500 gallons of gasoline at a total cost of $5,369,350 were announced today by the Navy Department, as follows:

National League President Ford Frick did some fast throwing himself yesterday by pitching fines of $50 each against Dizzy Dean and Jim Ripple for starting the fist fight that resulted in a player riot at Wednesday's "battle of the century" between the St. Louis Cardinals and New York Giants.

THERE was some discussion of the money Winnings of noted horses, beginning with Sun Beau at the top with $376,744. When they got down to Twenty Grand at $261,790, a tall, quiet fellow who identified himself as "a simple rustic" broke in with a remark that a horse named Goldsmith Maid belonged ahead of Twenty Grand. Goldsmith Maid? That stopped the field. So the "simple rustic" rambled on in a mild voice:
A total of $17,891 has been raised to date toward the swimming pool fund at Mount Holyoke College, according to Miss Margaret Dyer of Cromwell, Conn., chairman of the student fund committee.

Seldom during the Spring meeting has a Dixiana horse gone to the post with as little backing as Tartarus experienced in the Greenwood Purse, feature of today's Narragansett card, but the 3-year-old son of Torchilla came home a victor by a head over J. H. Logan's Virnock.

MANHATTAN COHEN, RUTH M. (April 16). Estate, $19,000. To Mildred Simon, niece, 23 W. 73d St., specific bequest: Isidor Bloom, 20 Northern Ave., and Max Silverstein, 1,450 51st St., Brooklyn, executors, onehalf residue each. DUNNE, MARY A. (Jan. 16). Estate, about $10,000. To Mark Brunswick, 19 Haslnauer Strasse, Vienna, Austria, residue. William J. Mack. 1,192 Park Ave., executor.

William Kelly, vice president of the Niagara Falls Power Company, commenting on the action instituted on Wednesday by the Water Power and Control Commission in the Supreme Court at Albany against his company, made the following statement yesterday:
Frank Ernest Newbury, former Midwest public utilities executive, died yesterday at his home at Avon at the age of 64. He was manager of the Citizens Gas Company of Kankakee, III., a number of years.

One of the few large group exhibitions remaining on the Spring art season's roster of events current or to come opened with a preview last evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. It is the twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America, Inc., scheduled to continue through June 7.

The League of Nations Secretariat announced today that the new Spanish Government had unexpectedly telegraphed yesterday asking that the Council at its meeting opening Monday resume its examination of intervention in Spain under Article XI of the League Covenant. The question will go on the agenda.

A jury in Federal court returned a verdict of guilty yesterday in the trial of Leonard Habermann, former convict, accused of aiding Robert Suhay and Alfred Power, who allegedly held up the Northern Westchester Bank at Katonah, N. Y., last March.

Trading continued fair to slow. Steer cuts were in fair demand in spots, although most sections found business still slow. Veal also continued slow in most sections. Demand for lamb and fresh pork continued fair to good. Fresh pork prices were strong to higher. Other classes were mostly unchanged. Kosher business confined mostly to lamb, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The Rev. Michael J. Duffy, author of two catechisms of Christian doctrine widely used in this country and in China, and formerly for twenty years pastor of St. Raphael's Church, 502 West Forty-first Street, died yesterday in Westchester Square Hospital, Bronx, at the age of 75. For the past two years Father Duffy was pastor of the Church of the Nativity of Our Blessed Lady, East 233d Street and Dyre Avenue, Bronx.

One hundred and fifty-six Columbia athletes and managers of sports teams will receive insignia for participation in the Blue's Winter sports program, it was announced yesterday . by Athletics Manager Reynolds Benson.

In one of the largest realty transactions in Greenwich in several years, Charles H. Babcock Jr. has purchased 400 acres of land between North Street and Lake Avenue from the Greenwich Water Company. Contracts for the major part of the property have been signed and options obtained on other pieces needed to complete the deal.

Dr. and Mrs. Decio de PaulaMachado of Rio de Janeiro gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Carl Otto Henriques, Government State Banker of Denmark, and Mrs. Henriques of Copenhagen. Other guests were Mrs. John N. Willys, Mrs. James A. Farley, Mrs. O. W.

WASHINGTON, May 20.-The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 18: CAPTAINS Clark, G. F., Medical Corps. Chelsea, Mass., to instruction at the Naval War College, Newport, R. I.

Saved from deportation to Italy through the intervention of Congress and President Roosevelt, Salvatore Branchicella, 33-year-old cobbler, quit work today to celebrate with friends after his attorney notified him the President had signed a special bill to permit him to stay in this country.
Parleys were in progress today between the Governor of Minas Geraes, Benedicto Valladares, and delegates of other States to determine on a Presidential candidate.

Many dinners will be given tonight in connection with the annual dinner dance under the auspices of the Metropolitan Chapter of the Alumni Association of Clemson College in the garden of the Ambassador. Mrs. John Calvin Thorne of New York and Columbia, S. C., will be the guest of honor.
When the months roll by and it becomes time for tuna fishing again in local waters, there is at least one deep-sea angler who will be ready and anxious.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
The Cleveland Indians gained the American League's top place today by pounding five Red Sox pitchers for a total of twenty-one hits and a 16-5 victory.

Highly beneficial rains fell over parts of the Spring Wheat Belt in the United States and Canadian Northwest last night and today, and while the precipitation was said to be light in sections where it is most needed, bullish sentiment received a severe check, and with general commission-house selling in evidence, futures declined sharply.

The Buffalo Bisons had no pity today for their ex-mate, Bucky Crouse, on his first active day as manager of the Baltimore Orioles, taking both halves of a doubleheader to sweep a three-game series, 10-3 and 2-0.
The Rev. Henry William McLoughlin, assistant pastor of St. Ignatius Church and for many years instructor at Loyola College here, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital. He was 65 years old.

The Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation today received a contract by the directors of the Panama Railroad Company for three modern, fireproof steamships to replace the present fleet of the company. The cost of each vessel, the War Department announced, will be $4,040,000.

PARIS, May 20.--Belgium had the honor today of being the first country to open for inspection its completed pavilion at the International Exposition to be dedicated Monday by President Albert Le Brun of France.

Betty Colby has joined the sales and rentals division of L. J. Winston. F. W. Westervelt Jr. has become affillated with the Leslie Blau Agency of Newark.. N. J., as executive in charge of the Insurance department. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., has placed a loan for $135.000 on the six-story apartment under construction on the east side of Evergreen Ave., 213 feet south of Westchester Ave., the Bronx,

The nominations of Sumner Welles to be Under-Secretary of State and Walton Moore to be counselor of the State Department were confirmed by the Senate today, only a day after President Roosevelt sent their names to the Capitol.

Engagements of $7,853,000 gold abroad for shipment here, including $7,723,000 in England and $130,000 in India, were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the gold engaged in England, $7,233,000 was obtained yesterday and the remaining $490,000 on some previous date.
The body of Donald C. Thorpe, 24, of Lisbon, N. H., was found floating in the Charles River Basin here today.
Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scarsdale captured the low-gross prize today in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

Behind the one-hit pitching of Joe Harvey, who struck out six, the Mount St. Michael High School nine assured itself of at least a tie for the Bronx-Westchester Division C. H. S. A. A. championship yesterday by blanking Manhattan Prep, 13-0, on Jasper Field. The victory was the fifth in six starts for Mount St. Michael, which has two games remaining on its regular tournament schedule.

Madison Square Garden yesterday announced that tickets would go on sale at the box office today for the so-called "phantom fight" between Max Schmeling and James J. Braddock, world champion, June 3 at the Long Island City Bowl.

Merton Covey Robbins of 134 Cliff Avenue, Pelham, N. Y., chairman of the Robbins Publishing Company of New York City, publisher of industrial magazines, died yesterday of a heart ailment in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 62 years old.
The annual hay fever campaign of the Works Progress AdminisItration was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, administrator.

Miss Alice Nielsen of opera fame won a mortgage foreclosure judgment against her former husband, Dr. Leroy R. Stoddard of New York City, here today. The judgment was granted by Justice Ellsworth C. Lawrence in Supreme Court.
Cracking loose with a roar, a section of Mount Livingston slid into the Yellowstone River today; causing fears that it might dam the stream and overflow surrounding lands.

Municipal CLERK (GRADE 2)-Applications mailed must bear postmarks not later than June 4. Ages, 18 through 25 on June 4. Certification will also be made from the resulting eligible list to fill Grade 1 vacancies in the Emergency Relief Bureau immediately, and in other city departments, at the termination or exhaustion of the present eligible list for Clerk, Grade 1.)

If last evening's trade at the Cort is any criterion, "Room Service" can be safely listed as Broadway's latest wonder-child. And what is more, there is the combined word of George Abbott's company manager and drum beater, Charles Harris and Charles Washburn, respectively, that the receipts were about $2,280, the potential capacity being $2,600.
The Tigers again defeated the Athletics, 3 to 2, today as Roxie Lawson shaded Edgar (Lefty) Smith in a pitchers' battle to win his sixth game of the season before a ladies' day crowd of 15,000.
Four-year-old James Tiernan, who narrowly escaped death when his sister, 7, was killed at Brookhaven last Saturday, learned at Community Hospital here today that there is a new home waiting for him.
Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio is going to get a silver plaque because he likes to play bridge. And he is also going to get an invitation to visit New Hampshire this Summer by airplane.

Leo Francis Donnelly, inventor of the Recordak photo-passbook control system used in many savings banks throughout the country, died last night after an illness of several months at his home here. He was 34 years old.

The washing of gold from Ecuador's rivers gradually has increased until it is estimated that 18,000 persons now are engaged in that work according to the Universe of Quito. However, there has been no sudden rush to obtain gold.

Suddenly resorting to a flying tackle after battling for more than a half hour, Jesse James last night threw Gino Martinelli in the feature bout to a finish at the Hippodrome. The time was 36:09. James weighed 188 pounds and Martinelli 192. A crowd of 2,000 saw the match.
Edward Eyre, formerly president of W. R. Grace Co., died in his London home, Gloucester House, today. He had been ill for some time. His wife was at his bedside when he died.
Miss Alice Marble, American tennis queen, and Miss Katherine Winthrop of Boston won two matches each today and qualified for the semi-final round of the Surrey championships.

The city's streets today resumed approximately normal conditions-allowing pedestrians to move fairly comfortably along the sidewalks and automobiles to proceed without undue delay-for the first time since a fortnight prior to the coronation.

Emigrant from Massachusetts at 19, J. HENRY RORABACK settled as a school teacher in the Connecticut North Canaan, a Democratic town. At 24 he was chairman of the Republican town committee. He used to take voters to the polls in a borrowed horse and buggy.

Thomas D. Niles, chairman of the Oswego County Democratic Committee, arraigned before County Judge Don A. Colony on a charge of violating the State Election Law, pleaded innocent and was released on $1.000 bail.

Mrs. Elizabeth Harding Daly, author, died yesterday in her home at 1,170 Fifth Avenue, after a short illness. She was 48 years old. Mrs. Daly wrote "High Goal," a novel about polo and racing, and several magazine stories. Her husband, William M. Daly, who died last Dec. 3, was former editor of Everybody's Magazine and a former conductor of the Chicago Opera Company.
Harry W. Marsh, Deputy Commissioner of Public Welfare of New York City, was nominated by Governor Cross today to be director of the new Department of Personnel.

There will be general approval of President ROOSEVELT'S move on Wednesday to promote two of the ablest and most energetic members of the Department of State: R. WALTON MOORE to the post of Counselor, and SUMNER WELLES to that of Under-Secretary of State.

Charles P. Meyer, a prominent New York restaurateur of the last century and one of the founders of the Hotel Waldorf, which became the Waldorf-Astoria, died of a heart ailment here today at the home of his son, Emil G. Meyer.

World economic expansion continued during March, while the value of international trade, reElecting the upward price trend as well as the increased volume of merchandise moved, was the greatest during the month since 1931, according to the current issue of The Annalist.

Mrs. Amelia R. Mann, co-publisher of The Cobleskill Index and the Schoharie Republican, weekly newspapers, died today at the Alliany Hospital at the age of 73. She was the widow of Jacob H. Mann, former School Commissioner in Schoharie County and for a number of years senior publisher of The Index.

B. H. Wettlaufer will become freight claim agent of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, with offices at Scranton, Pa., on June 1, it was announced yesterday. Henry W. Ruger and Walter J. Silick will become assistant freight claim agents on that date.

Indicating little concern over her Predicament, Mrs. Josephine M. Steacy, 66-year-old widow, who is ?ccused of having embezzled $42,?76 as non-salaried treasurer of ?he Visiting Nurses Association in York, Pa., smilingly consented yes?erday to return there without ex?radition proceedings.

The Boston Transcript Company announced today the appointment of Powell M. Cabot of Needham as vice president of the company and business manager of the newspaper. Born in Brookline in 1896, he was graduated from Harvard College in 1917, served overseas with the 306th Field Artillery in the World War and then taught for a time at Harvard.

Sidney H. Bourne, first voice teacher of Richard Crooks, Metropolitan Opera tenor, and for more than fifty years organist and choirmaster of Trinity Episcopal Church here, died at his home last night after a long illness. He retired two years ago.

Dr. Frederic Taber Cooper of Old Lyme, author and educator, died suddenly here, where he was residing temporarily following a recent return from a European trip. Heart disease was the cause of death. Dr. Cooper would have been 73 years old on May 27.

The last three bills of the fourth and final week of the Metropolitan Opera Spring season were announced yesterday by Lee Pattison, manager. "Marouf," in English, receives its second performance next Thursday, with Nancy McCord, Thelma Votipka, Mario Chamlee, Louis D'Angelo, Norman Cordon, George Rasely, John Gurney, Daniel Harris, Robert Nicholson, Nicholas Massue and Ludovico Oliviero.
Ellis H. Parker Sr. was permitted to make two secret night visits to Bruno Richard Hauptmann while the condemned kidnapper of the Lindbergh baby was in the death house at Trenton.

Minnie, the six-foot boa constrietor that escaped from a zipper bag in Brooklyn on May 7, was captured yesterday by a police emergency squad which gingerly pinioned her with iron rods, lassoed her head and tail, fastened her to an iron bar and consigned her to the care of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

The final form of the "retailers' platform" will be submitted to a meeting of the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to be held shortly, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the platform commission of the association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Hugh N. Kirkland, 11 rooms and 4 baths, in 1,035 5th Ave; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, broker. W. Earle Andrews, in 25 East End Ave; Mrs. Reginald Willis, in 106 E. 85th St; Kendrick A. Luther, through Tishman Realty Co, in 983 Park Ave; John Goodwillie; Paul B. Holmes, in 24 W 55th St; Mrs. Henry Doscher, in 17 W 54th St; Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc. broker.

Unable to meet its debts as they mature or to borrow money, the New York, Ontario Western Railway Company, operating in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania, petitioned the United States District Court here yesterday for permission to reorganize under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.

Testimony that Ellis L. Phillips and George W. Olmstead together controlled a majority of the common stock of the Long Island Lighting Company from 1924 to 1934 was given yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in the trial of a $20,000,000 accounting action brought by holders of preferred stock of the company.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 19 unless specified: Pearl Harbor to sea: Argonaut, Bushnell, Litchfield, S 1, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 29, 30, 32, 33, 34, 35. Bridge, San Pedro to Mare Island, with the Oriole in tow. Convngham Helsingfors to Antwerp.

Donald Budge .got his hand on one of his own racquets yesterday for .the first time since he arrived in the Davis Cup camp at Forest Hills and the exhibition he gave put a big smile on the faces of Captain Walter Pate and Julian Myrick.

118th St, 519 E, 20.7x100.11; William Dauenhauer and another, executors of Louisa S. Streicher, to Emma Juhase, 519 E 118th St ($1). 118th St, 523 E, 20.5x100.11; William L, Dauenhauer and another executors of Louisa S. Streicher, to Emma Juhase, 519 E 118th St ($1). 71st St, 163 W. 20x102.2; 748 Ninth Ave Corp, Aaron Weiss, president, to John J. Griffin, 814 S 13th St, Newark, N. J.; mtge $18,000 ($3).

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., yesterday obtained the award from City Treasurer Dorsey of a new issue of $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes of the city of Boston on a 1.28 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $55.

The construction of additional grand stands and the introduction of international competition in their championships were made known yesterday by officials of the Meadow Brook Club at Westbury, L. I., scene of national and international polo title tournaments.

Recording forty points, athletes from Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School of Brooklyn retained the team championship at the second annual city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association novice track and field games held at Fordham Field yesterday.
The Syracuse Chiefs fattened their batting averages at the expense of two Rochester hurlers today as they collected twenty base hits to demolish the Red Wings, 17 to 3.

Looking ahead to Independence Day celebrations that will not leave a toll of dead, blinded and maimed youngsters after the last skyrocket and cannon cracker is fired, New Jersey put into effect today a law designed to keep pyrotechnics out of the hands of irresponsible persons. .

The mutual advantages of a reciprocal trade treaty between the United States and Great Britain are so self-evident that Sir RONALD LINDSAY'S hope of such an agreement ought to be realized at no great distance in the future.
Thornton Lee, Chicago left-hander, who is not a Carl Hubbell by any stretch of the imagination, mystifled the Yankees with a bit of pitching magic at the Stadium yesterday.

The action of the security markets here yesterday indicated to most persons who have been following developments abroad closely that the selling of American securities from Europe, chiefly London, has about been concluded for the present at least.
Armfuls of flowers, candles and music tonight greeted Mrs. Grace Reiss of New York in 'ceremonies which made her grand royal matron of the New York Grand Lodge of Amaranth.

The proposed new Farm Bill combines nearly all the worst features of the various forms of agricultural comtrol adopted in the last few years. In addition, it provides for Secretary WALLACE'S favorite idea of an "evernormal granary."

The parents of 4,000 Basque girls from 2 to 15 years old waved tearful farewells tonight as the children embarked on the Spanish liner Habana, due to sail at dawn for Southampton, England, as the Insurgent lines daily draw closer around Bilbao.

Confidence continued in the stock markets here today, with most of the sections quietly firm. Gilt-edged issues were-steady. Among the foreign loans, German bonds showed advances. International stocks attracted -little interest and eased slightly at the close.
Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen with Mrs. Lowden and Alanson B. Houghton, former Ambassador to. England.

The late Colonel Edward H. R. Green, son of Mrs. Hetty Green, never filed An income tax return in Massachusetts, according to testimony given yesterday by Henry F. Long, Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation in that Commonwealth for the last seventeen years.

Further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried the new crop months above 12 3/4 cents a pound and the list ended with gains of 9 to 10 points. Despite the most favorable weather thus far this season and reports of curtailment by the fine cloth mills in New England, owing to absence of new business -ecently, the market strengthened in sympathy with the stronger stock market.

Miss Ann Gordon Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Hanmer Clark of 114 East Seventyfirst Street and Peconic, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage on the afternoon of June 11 to Alexander Pitcairn, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Aiken Pitcairn of Pittsburgh and Stoney Lake, Ont. The ceremony will be performed in the chapel of St. Bartholemew's Church here by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent.

Production of tin plate last year reached a record total of 2,103,153 tons, nearly 25 per cent above the 1935 total and comparing with a previous high ma rk of 1,816,223 gross tons in 1929, the American Iron and Steel Institute records.

Jessup Ave (11-2872), e s, 694 it s of Featherbed Lane, 27x105; William Cohn to Jeanne Gable, 3,030 Valentine Ave. Mulford Ave (15-4188), w s, 179 ft n of Buhre Ave, 27x100; Joseph Majman to John J. Cosgrove, 2,860 Buhre Ave. Brook Ave, 365 (9-2287); Magdalena Kraker to North Side Savings Bank, 3,230 3d Ave.

About 300,000 animals were cared for last year by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, according to the annual report made public yesterday. A total of more than 17,000 stray animals were restored to their owners, and nearly 5,000 dogs and cats were placed in new homes.

Twenty new appointments to faculty and administrative posts at Columbia University and twentytwo promotions were. announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. He also made public nineteen new faculty assignments and four additions to administrative committees of the institution.

Magnus Volk, who in addition to building England's first electric railroad, invented an egg cup for one-armed men and just managed to escape the dangerous honor of constructing an electric plant for Constantinople, died yesterday in Brighton at the age of 86.

Dr. Walter Damrosch was reelected chairman of the board of the Musicians Emergency Fund, and Mrs. Vincent Astor acting president, at the annual meeting of the board of directors yesterday at Steinway Hall.

Marion Ave (12-3292), w s 366 n of Bedford Park Blvd, 70x140; Harsad Realty Corp to Seamens Bank for Savings, installments, 4 1/2 per cent: $15,000. Mosholu Parkway, 179-181 (12-3335). Joseph POrtmann to Bowery Savings Bank, extends mtg to May 5, 1942, at 4 per t cent: $30.000.

Despite the continued reluctance of President Roosevelt to accept less than the full measure of his program for reorganization of the Federal judiciary, administration leaders at the Capitol were actively seeking a compromise today which they hoped would settle the controversy over the proposal for provisional enlargement of the Supreme Court.
Fivehit pitching by Rookie James Turner and a pair of home runs by Outfielder Vince DiMaggio gave the Bees a 4-1 triumph and a sweep of the two-game series with the cellardwelling Reds.

In an effort to get contractors to bid on $2,575,000 worth of school buildings which they have hitherto boycotted, the Board of Education at a special meeting yesterday voted to reopen the bidding, with the stipulation that separate contracts be made for steel and for general construction.
In a speech bristling with figures the Minister of Finance, Count Paolo Thaon di Revel, gave the Chamber today a moderately hopeful picture of the present and future state of Italian finances.

Business offices and governmental departments suspended their activities today to celebrate the thirty-fifth anniversary of the birth of the republic. President Federico Laredo Bru, Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff, and other officials of the government this morning reviewed a parade of 700 pupils of civic and military schools brought from all parts of the island to participate in the celebration.

Bank clearings of the principal cities throughout the country totaled $5,685,044,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compares with $5,275,135,000 in the corresponding week last year, and was a rise of $409,,909,000. The increase of 7.8 per cent contrasted with a percentage gain of 3.4 in a similar comparison a week earlier.
Selectmen of this Cape Cod Summer resort today had a mandate from citizens to bar trailers from their beach for health reasons.

A joint resolution condemning labeling and grading provisions of the proposed amendment to the Federal Food and Drugs Act, was made public yesterday by four organizations, representing among them more than 100,000 retail grocers,
Chancellor Juan B. Soto of the University of Puerto Rico and Arthur Garfield Hays of the American Civil Liberties Union will not debate the question of civil liberties in Puerto Rico.
George McQuinn's second home run of the game, with a man on base, gave the Newark Bears a 7-5 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs today in a thrilling contest which went thirteen innings.

George Brent, screen actor, and Constance Worth, young Australian actress, were -married in Ensenada, Mexico, on May 10, they admitted last night at Brent's Van Nuys ranch home. Brent's first wife was Ruth Chatterton, the actress. He played opposite Greta Garbo in "The Painted Veil."

A new champion will be crowned in the final of the women's 1937 Southern golf tournament on Saturday. Titleholder Mrs. Mark McGarry of St. Petersburg, Fla., dropped from the field today in the quarter-final round of sharp shooting that left two veteran Texas competitors, a youthful Georgian and a North Carolina ace to fight it out.
Sixty-fourth convention of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs, Hotel Pennsylvania, 10 A. M. Speakers: Dr. Charles David Cooper, Mrs. William Dick Sporborg.

In a cautiously worded semi - official statement put out today the Holy See expresses approval of what Cardinal Mundelein said about the religious situation in Germany, which is considered entirely in line with the Pope's encyclical on the same subject, but at the same time indicates that it has no present intention of intervening in the discussion- to which the Cardinal's words have given rise.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation made public tonight a list of bids received on bonds offered at public sale. The bids were chiefly for various public improvement projects in all parts of the United States. Most of them, however, were in Western or Southern States, only one being in New York State and only five in New Jersey. All the bonds bear interest of 4 per cent a year.

The Empire City Savings Bank has sold the four-story flat, containing seven apartments, at 860 East 162d Street, the Bronx, through the Rosenberg-Murray Company, brokers. The property is fully rented and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $14,500. It was acquired by the bank in February, 1934.

The past week's total of engineering awards, according to The Engineering News-Record, reached $55,244,000, representing a gain of 53 per cent over the figures for the corresponding week of 1936, when the total amounted to $36,173,000.

The engagement of Miss Helen Hazell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hazell of this city, to Fred A. Quanjer, son of William Quanjer, also of New York, and the late Mrs. Quanjer, has been announced by her parents.

The marriage of Leon Schwartz, District Attorney of Luzerne County, and Miss Mary Williams, daughter of the late Mayor Evan Williams of Nanticoke, took place on Sunday at Stroudsburg. The ceremony was performed by Judge Samuel H. Shull.
Assurances that "the Japanese Navy contemplates no armament programs whatever that might menace other countries" and an authoritative denial

The Nazi press tonight renewed its attacks on Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York. The official news agency, the Deutsches Nachrichtenburo, under the caption, "Hair-Raising Immorality in New York High Schools," distributed throughout Germany a New York news item describing alleged conditions in Brooklyn.

Manhattan Renwick St. 28-32. 67x150; for 1-story garage; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, 51 Chambers St, owner; Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects; cost, $25,000.
