Alterations 5th Ave, 659-63; to 8-story manufacturing and showrooms, offices and stores; Henry Phipps Estate, 465 E 57th St, owner; Starrett Van Vleck, architects; cost, $25.000.
John J. Raskob was caled to the witness stand yesterday in the old Postoffice Building by counsel for Pierre S. du Pont to take up where mr. du Pont left off after three days of testimony.

Assurances that President Roosevelt's program for the reorganization of the Federal governmental structure would be considered during the present session of Congress were given today after a conference at the White House between the President and the Democratic House members of the joint Congressional committee which has the bill under consideration.
Burleigh Grimes led with his ace today, but he might as well have kept it up his sleeve.' The Dodgers couldn't take a trick from the Cubs and bogged down to the second straight defeat, 6-1.

Testimony that Herbert J. Adaire, promoter who got W. E. Hutton Co. into the Atlas Tack deal, had misrepresented his position in the matter was introduced by the respondents in the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing on the charges of manipulation yesterday.

A protest against the recent administrative order of the Public Works Administration requiring that labor on projects financed by it be taken from the relief rolls was made to President Roosevelt today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and representatives of the federation's building trades department.
Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., and New York and Mrs. Sylvia Menrotin of France reached the third round of women's doubles in the French hard courts tennis championships today.

First Military Area The following Reserve officers, recently released to this area for assignment, are assigned to units as indicated: 392d Infantry-2d Lt. Uel W. Drennan, Inf.Res., 174th Armory, Buffalo, N. Y. 4th Radio Intel. Co.-2d Lt. Philip C. Michel, Sig.-Res., 1,337 Nott St., Schenectady, N. Y. The following Reserve officers, recently promoted, are re-assigned to units as indicated:

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Gorman of Bridgewater, formerly of Greenwich, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Elizabeth Gorman, to Bruce Beach Randall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce B. Randall of Bridgewater.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions MAGINNIS THOMAS, INC., silks and piece goods, 411 5th Ave.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $104,016 and assets of $182,484. The business was founded in 1903 by Thomas Maginnis, father of the present head of the corporation.

Business activity in the United States received a slight setback in April, with lower cotton consumption and electric power production as the main contributing factors, according to the current issue of The Annalist.

A building operation in the Times Square area was announced yesterday when the southwest corner of Broadway and Forty-ninth Street was leased for twenty-one years by the Schulte interests to Jacob Amron, realty investor and operator of hotels and restaurants. The site is 19.6 by 114 feet and adjoins the plot taken recently for the new Moss theatre.

Invitations nave been received here for the marriage of Miss Frances Frieseke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Carl Frieseke of Calvados, France, to Kenton Kilmer, elder son of Mrs. Aline Murray Kilmer of Stillwater, N. J., and the late Joyce Kilmer, war hero, journalist and poet. The ceremony will take place on June 2 in Calvados.

The directors of the Engineers Public Service Company voted yesterday to declare against arrears dividends of $1.25 on the $5 convertible preferred stock, $1.37 1/2 on the $5.50 preferred and $1.50 on the $6 preferred. On April 1, the company distributed $3.75 on the $5 preferred, $4.12 1/2 on the $5.50 preferred and $4.50 on the $6 preferred.

Burco, Inc., reports for the six months ended March 31 a net profit of $180,440, including $180,406 net profit realized on sales of securities, after all deductions excepting provisions for possible surtax on undistribute profits. In the same period a year ago net profit was $96,199, including $88,133 on sales of securities.
The National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare was warned today that "the struggle between fascism and democracy becomes more and more menacing."
Two horses that were last at the break were first at the finish in the Firenze and Saltaire handicaps, joint features for older horses yesterday at Belmont.

Miss Anne Elizabeth Crockett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Crockett, was married this afternoon to J. William Hill. Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Hill of Roland Park, in Franklin Street Presbyterian Church, by the Rev. Dr. Harris E. Kirk and the Rev. Dr. John W. Douglas.

Because newspaper advertising is "our best method of promotion," Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., will spend the bulk of its advertising budget this year with newspapers, Sir George Schuster, K. C. S. I., K. C. M. C., C. B. E., newly elected president of that organization, said yesterday.

A General Sessions jury yesterday convicted two officials of the Council of Independent Milk Dealers of conspiring two years ago to prevent outside competition by threats, theft and sabotage. The jurors deliberated about three hours.

Patrolman Stephen P. Di Rosa, recently reduced from the rank of detective and sent to the West 135th Street Station on patrol duty, pleaded not guilty yesterday morning to charges of violation of the rules and regulations of the Police Department by talking about police business.

Rentals charged in Knickerbock er Village came under attack yes terday in Supreme Court at the trial of a suit to determine whether or not the development is exempt from municipal taxes. The city ap pears as plaintiff in the action and seeks to have the apartments as sessed at $7,000,000 for 1935 for land and buildings, and declared subject to taxes.
The volcano of Santa Ana, rising 7,950 feet above the city of the same name, which has a population of 75,000, is showing signs of activity.

The tenth anniversary of the most famous flight in aviation historythe New York to Paris "hop" of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh-was celebrated yesterday by associates and admirers despite the absence of the guest of honor, who sent his regrets and thanks.
Elizabeth Young, film actress, divorced Joseph L. Mankiewicz, film writer and producer, on their third wedding anniversary today. She testified that Mr. Mankiewicz called her an idiot.

In the tiny back room of the Betsy Ross House. Mayor S. Davis Wilson presented twenty-one United States flags today to Silvina da Silva, foreign trade adviser of the Pan American Union, to be dispatched as "tokens of friendship" to Latin-American republics.

The Federal Trade Commission today issued a complaint against Robert Morris, trading as the D. P. Pen Company, Bordentown, N. J., charging unfair competition in the sale of fountain pens through "the marking thereon of excessive retail prices" The complaint stated that.
General Francisco Franco lost a naval battle in Denmark today when the court of Frederikshavn, Jutland, decided to intern two large trawlers built in shipyards in that town.

A brief strike halted production for several hours today in the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation plants. It was just six weeks to the day after a contract was signed with the United Automobile Workers of America outlawing strikes for one year in the concern's factories.
The dedication this week of the Evangeline Xouse in Dominick Street marks the completion of the "latest link" in the Salvation-Army coast-tocoast chain of homes for young women.
Colonel Harrison Howell Dodge, superintendent since 1885 of Mount Vernon, the estate of General Washington, died in Garfield Hospital yesterday at the age of 85.

The contest between rival slates for the ten directorships open in the New York County Lawyers Association ended last night at the annual election of the group, when the "independents" conceded victory to the slate nominated through the regulation channels. Charles E. Hughes Jr. was re-elected president. The meeting was held at the association's building, 14 Vesey Street.

A new political party nas come into being here. Labeled the Monroe County Progressive League, itsprovoters announced that it would nominate and indorse a slate next Fall. Organization of the league, according to William Gargan, its president, has been completed in all towns and in all except two city wards.

An investing client of Frances Ecker has purchased the six-story apartment known as Royal Court, at 43-07 Forty-second Street, on the southeast corner of Forty-third Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, from Norman-Lila Estates, Inc.

City Commission here adopted today an ordinance which virtually forbids auto tourist camps, trailer camps and trailers in this resort. The new requirements are such that a camp conforming with the ordinance would require an investment and scale of charges comparable with a hotel, thus meeting the organized hotel men's protest of unfair competition.
Powerful churchmen of various denominations rallied to the support of Cardinal Mundelein, Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, today, following his attack on Nazi policies.

Lord Melchett, British industrialist and chairman of the Council of the Jewish Agency in Palestine, declared last night that Palestine was the only hope of millions of Jews facing mass destruction in Germany, Poland and other countries.

Despite a warning by the steering committee that a veto awaited any bill carrying more than budget estimates, the House today passed the Interior Department Supply bill with amendments which raised it $2,390,060 above the amount recommended by the Budget Bureau and $7,131,500 above the amount originally repiorted by the Appropriations Committee. As passed, the measure carries $123,002,764.

Archibald B. Mills, an insurance broker of New York City, was found shot to death this afternoon in the garage in the rear of his home, at 182 Hillside Ayenue, according to Dr. Arthur W. Greenfield, Deputy County Physician of Bergen County.

The future of higher education for women in the United States will be considered tomorrow afternoon at the symposium of educators which will open the two-day program planned in honor of the inauguration of Paul Swain Havens as president of Wilson College.
Bunching its four hits at the right moments in the seventh and eighth innings, the Harvard freshman nine, which has had a poor record all season, beat the Yale yearlings, 6-2, today.

President Roosevelt discussed flood control with Representative Whittington and Acting Budget DIrector Bell, the executive organization proposals with a delegation of House Democrats, the bootleg coal situation with Governor Earle, the New York City World's Fair with Grover Whalen, and PWA relief orders with William Green and a delegation of labor leaders.

Gangster threats of murder forced Federal authorities investigating the widespread disability insurance racket to obtain twenty-four-hour daily police protection yesterday for one suspect who turned government witness and drove another to refuge in jail after "outside parties" sought his release on bail through habeas corpus proceedings.

The Home Office has refused to submit to King George an address in which the Roman Catholic Archbishops and Bishops of Great Britain would have reaffirmed the loyalty of the Roman Catholics of the realm, the current issue of The Universe, a Roman Catholic magazine, declares.
Condition of Federal Reserve Banks: During the week ended May 19 member bank reserve balances decreased $25,000,000. Reductions in
Crew members who survived the Hindenburg disaster on May 6 testified at the official inquiry today that the danger from sparks from the motor exhaust was such that special orders had been issued.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area showed an increase of .7 per cent for the twelve shopping days from May 1 to 14, as compared with the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Board of Estimate at its meeting next Friday will be asked to approve a contract with a private corporation for the operation of the city's Foreign Trade Zone on Staten Island for a twenty-year term, it was learned yesterday at City Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Before the record railroading through Congress of the Wagner act the American public were informed by Miss Perkins and her New Deal colleagues that its passage would mean the. achievement of a utopian mecca. Industrial unrest was to end automatically though the substitution of peaceful methods for the mob violence of picket lines.

Two pairs a year is the average habit of Canadian consumption of leather footwear. This includes boots and shoes, slippers, moccasins and all similar leather wear, reports a bulletin from the Agricultural and Industrial Progress in Canada. The figure for 1935 was slightly above two pairs and that for 1934 slightly below it.

" Moving in" on the bus transportation industry, the militant C. I. O. affiliate, the Transport Workers Union, announced last night that it is preparing to present demands for recognition in collective bargaining for all employes of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, operator of most of the new bus lines in Manhattan.

Brilliant sunshine again favored the Italian royal party today for the big military review. Many thousands more Hungarians turned out to see -their army than for the arrival of King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Elena yesterday. The troops.

A total of $17,562 in cash and pledges has been received by the American Committee for Spanish Relief, it was announced yesterday, as the result of the mass meeting and pageant in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night which opened a campaign for $500,000 for the relief of non-combatants in Spain.

Cardinal Hayes will ordain forty-seven young men to the priesthood tomorrow morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The class is one of the largest to be ordained in the history of the Archdiocese of New York.

A slight increase in reserve, coupled with a decrease of about $2,600,000 in deposits, raised the net reserve ratio of the Bank of Canada to 59.36 per cent on May 19 from 58.80 on May 12, according to today's weekly statement.

George A. Sloan of New York City, has been elected a member of the board of directors of the Selby Shoe Company of this city. The company was established in 1877 and its operations are now world-wide.
Dr. John Boggs Garrison, physician and editor, died yesterday in his home at 15 Greenwood Avenue, here, after an illness of eight weeks, following a fall. He was 88 years old.
Officials of the Staten Island Zoological Society at West New Brighton kept a close watch yesterday on a prize twenty-six-foot python which is expected to hatch its fortyeight eggs momentarily.

In the absence of any further fistic embellishments or other untoward disturbances, Dick Bartell stepped into the breach today to provide a crowd of 6,000 with a thrill from a somewhat unexpected quarter by hitting what is commonly called the jackpot.

Swart, Brent Co., Inc., will hold their annual field day and golf tournament today at Farmingdale, L. I. Brown Brothers Harriman Co., as transfer agents for Spiegel, Inc., cumulative preferred stock, $4.50 convertible series, are prepared to exchange definitive certificates for temporary certificates.

Captain James Jackson, once the hero of a thrilling rescue on Lake Superior, died yesterday of a heart attack at the home of his daughter-in-law here, where he had lived since his retirement eleven years ago from the Inter-Lakes Steamship Company of Cleveland, Ohio. His age was 76.

A grocery store managed by Isador Tabachneck here was open for business again today, and thirty clerks were conditionally assured of a Wednesday half-holiday, all because Mr. Tabachneck thought their picketing was too tame.

Two important scientific symposiums will mark the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York when it gathers here Monday. They will have as subjects "The Blood" and "The Relief of Intractable Pain." An attendance of 3,000 doctors is expected.

The vast sums of money under the control of insurance companies show the confidence thousands of people have in the companies, George S. Van Schaick, former State Superintendent of Insurance, told 150 members of the Brooklyn Rotary Club at their weekly luncheon yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Bossert.

Senator Wagner laid before the Senate today a letter from Governor Herbert Lehman of New York expressing an "earnest hope" that Congress will enact low-cost housing legislation at this session. Governor Lehman enclosed a letter from the City Affairs Committee of New York urging enactment of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill.
Ossie Bluege's single in the twelfth inning scored the winning run today to give the Senators a 5-4 triumph over the Browns and a clean sween in the three-game series.

Under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Vincent Astor and Miss Elsa Maxwell a surprise party was given last night at the Twenty-One Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street, for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Astor is acting president.
Leo Blech, veteran conductor of the Berlin State Opera, has signed a contract with the Chicago Grand Opera Company for an engagement beginning in November. The appointment is for several seasons.

The tournament season on Long Island came in on the wings of a gale today as many of the contestants in the Garden City Golf Club's ancient invitation tournament found out-much to their chagrin-when they came to count up their scores.
The Senate voted today to make the Civilian Conservation Corps a permanent organization, rejecting the House's plan to limit the life of the corps to two more years.

So overcome by emotion" that he "literally burst into tears," as he said afterward, Lieut. Commander Tom Woodrooffe, a member of the British Broadcasting Corporation's outside radio staff, made such a hash of his description of the fleet illuminations at Portsmouth tonight that operators cut him off the air within four minutes.

Three bills designed to improve the condition of New York dairymen were signed today by Governor Lehman. With the Rogers-Allen bill approved yesterday, under which producers and distributors are authorized to bargain for better prices, the measures round out a "New Deal" program for dairymen.
Mrs. Josephine Austin, the former Josephine Sanders, New York actress, has established residence here to file suit for divorce from William L. Austin Jr., real estate man of Atlantic Beach, L. I.
Berks County Commissioners voted unanimously today to accept from the Army and Navy Club of San Francisco the memorial plaque honoring the late Lieut.

To those who believe justices of the Supreme Court should all be of the Holmes, Stone or Cardozo type, Senator Robinson's qualifications to succeed Justice Van Devanter will not appeal. He would probably admit he is not in the lofty legal category of the three just mentioned.

James Daugherty, 31- year - old member of a gang of five accused in a $385 hold-up of a restaurant at 3 West 170th Street and held without bail in the Bronx County Jail, was linked yesterday, according to the police, to three other hold-ups within the last year.

T. B. N. F. Reynolds, brokers, report recent sales of real estate in Westfield, N. J., as follows: 459 Beechwood Place, a residential plot, to Harold E. Jamieson for the Pearsall Company; the residence at 818 Shackamaxon Drive to L. G. Wade for the Modern Building and Realty Corporation.
Gustave Scholle, retired United. States diplomat, formerly secretary of the American Embassy in Paris, died here today at the age of 74 of a heart attack. He had been in ill health for several years.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries, exclusive of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, showed a profit of $135,671 after interest, Federal income taxes and other charges but before depreciation, according to the statement for the first three months of 1937, published yesterday.

While Sir Harry Lauder disclaimed any cinematic ambitions when he arrived in Hollywood Monday, negotiations were under way today between the comedian and R.-K.-O. by which the Scotsman will join Fred Astaire in "Damsel in Distress."

A number of leases for corner stores in midtown Manhattan, as well as several involving additional space in various parts of the city for expansion purposes, were among the contracts reported yesterday.
C. B. Cochran's operetta, "Paganini," got off to a splendid start at the Lyceum Theatre tonight, and judging by the reception it received it should fill the theatre for many months.

Just to show he meant what he said, Erborn W. Wood, 57-year-old sportsman, went to Mystery Pond today, drew twenty-nine trout from its seventy-five-foot depth and started off with them to Washington and President Roosevelt.
The known death toll in last Saturday's Insurgent bombing of Valencia rose close to 100 tonight with the discovery of more bodies under debris. Many of the victims were women and children.

Miss Elizabeth Richardson Park, daughter of John A. Park, editor of The Raleigh (N. C.) Times, and Mrs. Park, was married here yesterday to Marcus George Lynch of this city, in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector, performed the ceremony.

In a second informal vote today, delegates to the Association of Junior Leagues' annual conference indicated that they preferred to keep their present policy against taking sides in controversial issues.

An announcement today by Senator Soto Reyes that John L. Lewis of the Committee for Industrial Organization had definitely accepted an invitation to come to Mexico in September has led to widespread talk in local labor circles here of closer cooperation between unions in the United States and Mexico and probably also Canada.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
St. Louis at New York-Hogsett or Hilderbrand vs. Pearson. Cleveland at Washington-Whitehill vs. Deshong. Chicago at Philadelphia-Stratton vs. Caster. Detroit at Boston-Coffman vs. Grove.

The marriage of Miss Catherine Creighton Cooke, daughter of Mrs. Mayme M. Cooke of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late James Negley Cooke of Pittsburgh, to Alexander James Troy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander J. Troy, took place yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

A report made public yesterday by Allen T. Burns, executive vice president of Community Chests and Councils, Inc., showed that a total of $77,673,099 had been raised since the Fall of 1936 in 382 local drives in all parts of the country for the support of welfare services in 1937. Of this total $16 583.052 has been raised since Jan. 1.

Under the auspices of the Affiliated Schools for Workers, a conference will be held tomorrow at the Russell Sage Foundation Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street, on the subject "White Collar Workers Study Their Own Problems."

H. M. Bassett, transportation engineer of the New York Central, was the main witness today in the Federal district 'court here in the trial by Judge Phillip Forman of the suit of five railroads for a permanent injunction restraining the State of New Jersey from collecting allegedly exorbitant taxes for 1934, 1935 and 1936. The case will be resumed on next Monday morning.

The Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation, recently formed as a consolidation of three operating units in the Niagara Hudson Power system, has filed a petition with the Public Service Commission for authority to issue $17,029,000 of 3 1/2 per cent general and refunding bonds and $7,000,000 of serial notes bearing interest rates of 2, 3 and 3 1/1 per cent.
Acting Mayor William F. Brunner sent a sharp note yesterday to Police Commissioner Valentine asking to know what steps had been taken to "prevent a recurrence"

Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, told a House labor subcommittee today Federal regulation of all industry would be preferable to the proposed "Little NRA" for textiles. His statement followed disclosure by a House leader that the Ellenbogen Textile Bill would be sidetracked by President Roosevelt's new wage and hour legislative program, which is expected to reach Congress within a few days.

MANHATTAN BAGGALEY, LOUISE (Nov. 28, 1936). Gross assets, $1,425: net, $687. To Helen P. McDowell, sister, household and personal effects: William Baggaley. husband, residue. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $1,425. McCanliss Early, attorneys, 31 Nassau St.

An eight-inch bone-handle bread knife was removed from the lifeless hand of Mrs. Helen MacKnight before the police arrived at the MacKnight home at 826 Avenue A, Bayonne, after the woman was murdered with a hatchet last July 31.
Peter Villa, elected Mayor in the Junior City Government of the East Side, will be received at City Hall this morning with his colleagues by Acting Mayor Brunner.

Rejecting the pleas of groups of employers, the New York City Merchants Association and the New York Board of Trade for a public hearing, Governor Lehman signed without comment today the Doyle-Neustein bill creating a "Little Wagner Act" for the State.
Knickerbocker Hospital, which was founded in a tent in old Manhattanville during the Civil War, marked its seventy-fifth anniversary yesterday.
Directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad re-elected G. A. Tomlinson of Cleveland chairman of the board in an organization meeting today.

The Count of Covadonga is determined to marry Marta Rocafort, a Cuban commoner, despite the opposition of former King Alfonso of Spain, according to a statement issued today by Jose Sanchez Arcilla, a close friend of the Count.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 20--William J. Hallahan of Corning, N. Y., and William J. Gunnell of Hamburg, N. Y., were elected managers of baseball and tennis, respectively, for 1938 at Syracuse University today.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national co-chairman of the fund-raising campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, announced yesterday that $1,231,000 already had been raised this year in the drive.

George Isaac Hughes, who astonished the medical world by becoming a father at 94 and again at 96, died today of a heart ailment at the age of 97. At the bedside were his second wife, who is 29 years old, and their two babies, Franklin Roosevelt Hughes, 29 months old, and Mary Gertrude, nearly a year old, as well as some of his sixteen children by his first wife.

General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator, is being considered as a successor to the late W. Forbes Morgan, as president of the Distilled Spirits Institute, according to information in the industry here yesterday.

Hope of a compromise satisfactory to President Roosevelt on the bill providing for Federal participation in the New York World's Fair was expressed today by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair, after conferences with House members and with the President, who yesterday vetoed as excessive an authorization of $5,000,000.

The Maharajah of Alwar died in a hotel here today of apoplexy thought to have been the result of earlier injury received when he fell after a squash rackets match. His age was 55. The injury had prevented the potentate, whose name was Shri Riski Del Servar, from attending the coronation. The body will be sent to India. His widow and a son survive.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw are returning Monday on the Queen Mary after a trip in Africa and a visit to London. Mrs. M. Orme Wilson has left her home at 3 East Sixty-fourth Street and is at the Pierre.

The likelihood that the law taxing corporate surpluses will not be repealed this year, despite the hopes of business, may lead to a repetition in the final quarter of the sharp rise in advertising volume experienced in the late months of 1936,. according to comment here yesterday.

Governor Lehman's "weakness" in yielding to "political pressure" in his recent appointment of Miss Grace A. Reavey to succeed William Gorham Rice as State Civil Service Commissioner was termed disheartening and puzzling in the annual report of the executive committee of the Civil Service Reform Association, presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization at the Downtown Association, 60 Pine Street.

Among the various Brooklyn properties reported sold by John F. James Sons, Inc., brokers, is the twenty-family and two-store apartment house at 634 Union Street for the Auburn Savings Bank. Another was the six-family apartment house at 78 Grattan Street for the Peekskill Savings Bank.

A general upswing in building construction in New York State so far in 1937 was reported today by State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F, Andrews. In the first four months of this year, Andrews said, 28,209 building permits were issued calling for an expenditure of $127,874,000.

Herbert Hoover told the Boys Club of Detroit tonight that the problem of providing decent houses for slum dwellers can be solved only by public subsidies either "as a contribution to the cost of the land and buildings or to the rents."
The possibility of Federal intervention in the problem caused by bootleg coal in Pennsylvania was discussed by President Roosevelt and Governor Earle at the White House today.
The traditional Rittenhouse Flower Market, held for four children's charities by a number of garden clubs under the auspices of the Rittenhouse Flower Market Association, was given today.

Border customs officials said today that purchases by United States residents of lake shore homes this Spring is being stimulated by provision in custom-excise regulations permitting an Amerian buyer to bring in duty free all furniture possessed six months prior to the purchase.

Turpentine firm, 36c; sales, 208 barrels; receipts, 342 barrels; shipments, 222 barrels; stock, 25,455 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 560; receipts, 1,541; shipments, 666; stock, 47,141. Quote: B, $7.35; D, $7.45; E, $7.90; F to N, $8.35; WG, $8.40; WW, X, $9.10.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--The German Embassy has called the attention of the State Department to the recent speech of Cardinal Mundelein, Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, denouncing the Nazi attacks on Catholicism and referring to Chancellor Adolf Hitler as an "Austrian paperhanger."
A happy event in the Bulgarian royal family is expected in the next few days. A noted Italian gynecologist and several nurses already have arrived to attend Queen Joanna.
London's bus strikers, who have been off the road since May 1, met their severest rebuff today when the trolley and trolley-bus workers decided not to strike in sympathy.

A lively tilt between the New York Curb Exchange and over-the-counter interests is expected on June 1, which date was set today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a hearing on applications by the Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in twenty-two bond or debenture issues which are not now registered on any Exchange.

After more than thirty years at 305-7 West 140th Street, the College Station of the New York Postoffice will be moved on Monday to the new government-owned quarters at 217-21 West 140th Street, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.
The annual convocation closing the academic year at Rutgers University was held this morning in the gymnasium, with the announcement of student elections and honorary awards.

Thursday morning a young man carried a miniature figure of King GEORGE VI through the traffic of Fifth Avenue. The King was in full coronation regalia. The synthetic jewels in his crown and the gilded scepter glittered like the real thing.

H. Stokes Lott. Jr., formerly a radio_ writer, director and performer for Station WOR and also formerly engaged in magazine and newspaper work, died on Tuesday in Switzerland after a long illness. His age was 38.

A close friend of the Duke of Windsor said today that he and Mrs. Warfield would be met on their wedding trip by several members of the British royal family. After June 3, when the former monarch and Mrs. Warfield are married, this source said, they will leave the Chateau de Cande immediately by automobile for Biarritz.

A jury in District of Columbia Supreme Court late today acquitted L. Douglas Rice, vice president and general manager of the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, of charges of contempt of the United States Senate.

The Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company, now in reorganization, today instituted civil action through its courtappointed trustee against a lawyer and two textile concerns in Philadelphia. Brought by the trustee, Judge C. Edward Rowe of Athol, three writs of attachment of $50,000 each were served upon Samuel B. Fortinbaugh, the lawyer, as he left Federal court here.

Some form of "compensated" reciprocal trade plan, under which domestic industries hit by concessions granted in trade treaties will be paid for the losses they suffer for the general good of the nation's commerce, will be developed in the future, Dr. A. A. Berle,

Marked strength in secondary and convertible corporation issues featured otherwise dull trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Improvements in loans on no material increase in trading volume were attributed largely to renewed advances in pivotal stocks.

A blond girl, who baffled the police yesterday by identifying herself as three different persons, was definitely identified today as Mary V. Davenport of Troy, N. Y., daughter of Edwin J. Davenport, foreman of the civilian guard at the Watervliet (N. Y.) arsenal.

A warning to Americans that "we cannot consistently champion the cause of oppressed minorities elsewhere until we first set our own house in order" was voiced tonight at the Northern Baptist Convention by the committee on race relations.
T. O. M. Sopwith, owner of the America's Cup challenger Endeavour II, showed no concern when told tonight at Southampton of the mishap to the first Endeavour.

Tammany leader James J. Dooling, at his desk in Tammany Hall yesterday morning, indicated that he had been sounding out the sentiment of the district leaders on the question of the organization's Mayoralty candidate, and that he would continue to do so up to the Official time for conferences with the leaders of the other counties.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by Sunset Gold Fields, Inc., Silver City, N. M. The statement, filed on Aug. 17, 1933,

E. M. Dilhoeffer, executive vice president of the National Carloading Corporation, was elected yesterday president of the Freight Consolidators and Forwarders Institute. The corporation is controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio, the Pere Marquette and the Erie Railroads.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following applications from New York City for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market (symbols: P, partnership; S, sole proprietor; C. corporation):

A public hearing on the new motor carrier safety regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission, which will become effective July 1, was held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania before Examiner R. W. Snow of the commission.

Macmillans have received word from England that the James Tait Black Memorial Prize, an annual British award for the "best novel" of the year, has been given for the late Winifred Holtby's novel of Yorkshire, "South Riding." The book was published here last Spring.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wyckoff Brower of Plainfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Euphemia Brower, to Charles Todd Newberry Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Todd Newberry of Shadowbrook, Irvingtonon-Hudson.

The first disqualification of the meeting marred today's feature at Churchill Downs, styled the Stamping Ground Purse, when the Valdina Farm's Diavolo Boy was set back in favor of Joseph E. Widener's Cuckoo.

Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 92.0 from 86.8. It was 81.6 for the week ended May 16, 1936. Although shipments were higher than those of the previous week, orders declined, according to reports wired especially to THE NEW YORK TIMES from regional associations.

Stocks rallied and closed strong in heavier trading, industrial shares leading; turnover, 1,226,980 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, other groups generally higher; transactions, $7,302,200.

PITTSBURGH, Friday, May 21.--The power and strength of the C. I. O. in the independent steel industry hung in the balance today. Before 1 A. M., all of the 27,000 employes of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation who wished to vote on whether they want the Steel Workers Organizing Committee to represent them as a union were to have marked ballots.
Mungula, still firmly held by Basque militia, was bombed by Germanmade planes this morning. Two houses in the center of the town were destroyed by incendiary bombs.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 19: MAJOR GENERAL Croft, E., Chief of Infantry, three months and 20 days leave, June 11. . BRIGADIER GENERAL Cox, C. F., Chief of Bureau of Insular Affairs, two months and 28 days leave, June 3.
Henry Ford received the highest honor accorded by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers tonight for his contribution to the development of the automobile.

Captain Charles B. Kellogg, Princeton horseman, died yesterday in the Princeton' Hospital. He was 44 years old. He and his wife maintained a large estate two miles north of Princeton, where they sponsored two successful horse shows each year. Captain Kellogg owned a string of horses which repeatedly won cups and ribbons at various shows.

Hope for an emergency flood-control program, concentrated in the Ohio Valley and carrying authorizations for work outside the $30,000,000 provided in the 1937-38 budget, was expressed today by Representative Whittington of Mississippi after a conference with President Roosevelt.
The first two of three sets of trials to select an America's Cup defender were officially postponed yesterday by the cup committee headed by Commodore W. A. W. Stewart.

For the fifth year in succession the picked team of the Long Island division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association won the annual intersectional competition for the Golf Illustrated Trophy today. But for a few minutes at the Upper Montclair Country Club, as the scores of the feature matches came in, it looked as though the Long Island dominance were going to pass to New Jersey.
Norman A. Stoner of Oil City, Pa., won the first prize in the sixtysecond annual Charles R. Lynde debate in Whig Hall tonight.
A model to be seriously considered is the last will and testament of the late Brig. Gen. J. J. MORROW, brother of DWIGHT MORROW.

Applications for writs of habeas corpus to release seven union officials now serving six-months' sentence in the Androscoggin County jail for contempt of court were sworn out here today by Joseph Kovher, C. I. 0. attorney.

Officials of the United Press and of the American Newspaper Guild met yesterday at the office of the National Labor Relations Board, 45 Broadway, to work out plans for an election of the press association's editorial employes to determine whether they wished to be represented by the Guild in collective bargaining.
Blight, Ella S. Booth, Arthur S. Brayshaw, Emily J. Brixey, Austin Day Callahan, Agnes M. Carpenter, Lillie May Claman, Ida Daly, Elizabeth H.

Despite his cavalier treatment of Austria in recent seasons, Richard Strauss was welcomed with cheers and wild applause when he reappeared here tonight, the first time in four years, to conduct a special concert of the combined Philharmonic Symphony Orchestras in the large Konzerthaus hall.

BERLIN, May 20.--The mutually obligatory agreement reached in Paris between German and French historians for removing the poison of untruthful statements from history textbooks is seen here as the first step toward the moral disarmament of these two nations.

The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports, has among her passengers Mrs. Eleanore Pruss, wife of Captain Max Pruss, who is recovering from injuries received in the Hindenburg disaster.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended May 19 were announced today; COMMANDER Trebes, J., the Haida, to command the ShoShone.

Mrs. Gretchen Wilcox Martin of Topfield, Lakeville, Conn., widow of Robert W. Martin, was married to Charles M. Fleischmann of Morristown, N. J., yesterday at noon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Wyckoff Mettler, 640 Park Avenue. The Rev. Dr. John Malcolm McLeod performed the ceremony.

Decentralization of industry, "which means an improvement in living conditions for the worker," is a logical step in the development of the mass production technique, W. J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company, told the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in a session here tonight.

Thirty-five newly elected members of Parliament may lose their seats because of Election Law violations. Figures released today showed there were 5,200 violations during the recent elections, which returned an anti-government majority in the lower house.

Dr. Franklin M. Stephens, educator and ear, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital, 345 West Fiftieth Street. He was 82 years old. Dr. Stephens entered the hospital two weeks ago for treatment for gangrene of the right leg and several days later the leg was amputated.

Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, former United States envoy to Denmark, returned from Copenhagen yesterday, accompanied by her husband, Captain Boerge Rohde. She was a passenger on the Scanstates of the American Scantic Line. To all questions about her plans for the future Mrs. Rohde said,

Chatter Chat, Mrs. Ellsworth Augustus's chestnut gelding, who won the national hunter championship last year, came through in splendid form today to capture the event for registered thoroughbred hunters as the Wilmington Horse Show opened on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Rood.
Yale University announced tonight that its new president, Charles Seymour, would be formally installed in office on Oct. 8, in ceremonies reminiscent of the college's early days in Colonial times.

New life insurance sales in the United States in April were the largest for that month since 1931 and amounted to $692,062,000, an increase of 16 per cent over a year ago, the Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau announced yesterday. The figure represents the total ordinary life insurance sales.
The hustling Phillies made five double plays today, one less than the major league record, but dropped the third and deciding game in their series with Pittsburgh's soaring Pirates, 5 to 2.

The Tennessee Valley Authority appealed to the Supreme Court today from the decision of the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals at Covington, Ky., ordering trial in the Eastern Tennessee Federal District Court of the suit by the Tennessee Electric Power Company and sixteen other interests against the constitutionality of the TVA program.

More than seventy-five members participated in the annual Spring tournament of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the North Hempstead Country Club today. The feature competition was a partner's match play handicap against par, which was won by Charles McAdam and Alfred Pach, who finished 5 up.

The election of William Chase Hull as vice president in charge of traffic of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company and the Pere Marquette Railway Company to succeed F. M. Whitaker, who retired on Tuesday after fifty-four years of service, was announced here today. Mr. Hull will have his offices here and in Cleveland. His residence is in Cleveland.
Seeking a new basis for Franco-Belgian amity, the French Foreign Minister, Yvon Delbos, today arrived here to confer with the Belgian Foreign Minister, Paul Spaak, and Premier Paul van Zeeland.

The 1937 edition of the Directory of Directors in the City of New York will be published today. The first section of the directory contains a list of some 30,000 directors, with their respective directorates, while the second section is an index of about 13,000 corporations, with an outstanding capitalization of $50,000 or over. The book contains 1,125 pages.

The Studio Utility Workers Union, part of whose members were on strike, returned to work today under at agreement with the major motion picture producers which gave to them a closed shop and increased their wages from 60 to 75 cents an hour.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag criticized the Board of Standards and Appeals severely yesterday for permitting the erection of a bus terminal at 167th Street. and St. Nicholas Avenue, within 300 feet of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
Somewhere out on the Atlantic the America's Cup yacht Endeavour, unsuccessful challenger three years ago, was believed tonight to be slowly making her way here alone under jury rig of sail.

Permanent peace rests almost solely on social justice and will be gained only through the lessons taught us by our background of more than seven centuries of international strife, Dr. James T. Shotwell, director of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said yesterday at a-luncheon of the New York Rotary Club at the Commodore Hotel.

The president of the Chilean Caja Amortization (Sinking Fund Bureau) declared today that criticisms made in the United States against the Chilean Government for redemption of its foreign debt bonds in the American market were unjustified.
THE TREE FLLS SOUTH, by Wellington Roe. (Putnam, $2.) A first novel concerned with life in the Southwest. GENTLEMAN OVERBOARD, by Herbert Clyde Lewis. (Viking, $1.50.) A novel.

The Tufts College nine routed Harvard at Soldiers Field, 11-5, today. Harvard relied upon its secondstring twirlers in the annual game, any they were hit freely by the Medford batters and were supported poorly by the Crimson infield.
The Boston Red Sox today turned over Stewart Bowers, young right-handed pitcher, to Minneapolis on a twenty-four-hour option. Bowers,
A class of twenty-three was graduated tonight from the Bloomfield Theological Seminary at sixty-third commencement held in the Westminster Presbyterian Church here.

The Cabinet crisis that has been pending for several weeks was partly solved tonight when three portfolios were given to new men-the Ministry of Commerce to Mr. Baroff. the Ministry of Justice to Mr. Ogljanoff and the Ministry of Agriculture to Mr. Bankoff.

Fiorello H. La Guardia, Mayor of New York, refused to pass through picket lines of San Francisco's hotel strike today and instead obtained accommodations in an apartment building. "I am entirely in sympathy with the hotel strikers and hope there is a speedy settlement," Mr. La Guardia said.

THE REVOLT OF THE BEAVERS, a play in three acts, by Oscar Saul and Lou Lantz, with music by Oscar Waller. Staged by Lewis Leverett and Peter Hyun under the supervision of Jack Rennick; settings and costumes by Samuel Leve; director of dance mime, Sylvia Manning; lighting by Ira Silberstein; presented by the Children's Theatre unit of the Federal Theatre Project. At the Adelphi Theatre.

Several sales of dwellings in Pleasantville, and vicinity, Westchester County, were reported by Nancy McIntosh, broker. Palmer Lewis sold a home on an acre of land in Mount Pleasant, near Chappaqua, to E. Jerome Ellison, associate editor of the Readers Digest. Mrs. Joseph Sykora sold a home on Mountain Road to William Foster New York attorney.

Officers of tne Field Artillery group for the Second Corps Area, among whom are regular army and Reserve Corps leaders, will give their annual dinner with dancing tonight at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park.

Miss Gabrielle Wright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Wright of this place, became the bride of John Lockwood Bradley of San Francisco, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Roger Bradley of New York, today in the garden of her parents' home. The Rev. Dr. John R. Atwell of the Little Church of Our Savior performed the ceremony.

Cleveland has been chosen for the 1937 National Foreign Trade Convention sponsored by the National Foreign Trade Council, it was announced here yesterday. The gathering, which annually attracts more than 1,000 foreign traders, will be held from Nov. 3 to 6.
Forty-four Soviet citizens were shot on charges of espionage and sabotage on behalf of the Japanese at one of the most strategic sections of the Transsiberian Railway, it became known here today.
Representative Matthew J. Merritt of New York introduced today a bill to reduce the margin requirements from 55 to 35 per cent on stock purchases.

Catholic editors sounded warnings here today that they would fight communism and dictatorships with every legitimate weapon at their disposal. Four executives pressed this issue on the first day of the annual meeting of the Catholic Press Association.

Representative Celler of New York introduced a bill today amending the 1936 Revenue Act by repealing the present capital gains and losses tax and substituting a tax on gains on capital assets held. less than one vear.

The statement of condition of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, issued yesterday in a revised form, showed a decline of $4,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday in the total of loans and investments of these institutions.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt left here last night by train with a party of graduates and friends of the Todhunter School, 66 East Eightieth Street, to demonstrate to them her idea of how one should intelligently sightsee in this country.
The power and the glory of Britain rode at anchor upon the waters of Spithead today as the newly crowned King looked upon the empire's "sure shield" and found it strong.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa, sugar, copper and hide futures advanced, while coffee, rubber, silk and cottonseed oil contracts were lower. On the cash market all the grains, rubber, printcloths, flour, lard and wool tops were lower, but cocoa, butter, standard tin and cotton gained.

An underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will offer today $9,386,500 Simmons Company 4 per cent debentures due 1952, representing the rnsubscribed portion of an issue of $10,000,000 offered to stockholders. Other members of the group are the Lee Higginson Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.,

The first incoming commercial call on the new radio telephone service between America and China was made yesterday when William B. Benton, who is on a trip around the world, telephoned from Shanghai to Atherton W. Hobler, president of Benton Bowles, Inc., advertising agency.

The Census Bureau announced today that the cotton-spinning industry operated during April at 146.7 per cent of capacity, compared with 148.3 per cent during March this year, and 110.9 per cent during April last year.
Routing Northamptonshire by an innings and 128 runs at Hove today, Sussex maintained its unbeaten record in the English county cricket championship.
Jacques Dupuy married Miss Marguerite C. Fabre in Notre Dame de Grace Church in Passy today. Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris. officiated.

Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury Department made it clear to associates today that he was unequivocally opposed to general international monetary conferences, believing that nothing could be accomplished by them.

Injudicious personal conduct in the high command of the Salvation Army came into the open today with an official statement that Commissioner Henry W. Mapp, the chief of staff, had been "dismissed from the Army" by General Evangeline Booth on unpublished charges.

News of extensive British purchases of anti-aircraft guns and ammunition from the Swedish Bofors armament works which was chronicled in a recent Copenhagen dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES has reverberated in a distorted form to Continental newspapers and produced a statement from the director of Bofors, Mr. Wingquist, to the Aftonbladet that the Bofors works itself has not been sold.
Generally improved economic conditions were attributed today by the administration as a major reason for a $1,272,506 increase in gasoline tax revenue for the first three months of 1937.

ROBERT ALLERTON PARKER'S "The Incredible Messiah" (Little, Brown, $2.50) is the second book on Father Divine to appear within a year. Less thorough than Mr. Parker's study of John Humphrey Noyes and the Oneida Community, it is far more credible than its forerunner in the field, John Hoshor's "God in a Rolls-Royce."

Passage of the permissive, jury service bill at the recent session of the Legislature was "simply a sop to women," delegates to the convention of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women were told tonight by Doris Byrne, Executive Deputy Secretary of State, lately promoted from Assemblywoman.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is paying agent for $1,250,000 city of Jacksonville, Fla., electric revenue certificates.

WITH deep sorrow it must be recorded that an eminent mathematician has gone off on a tearing tangent, and all because of a spot or two of tennis. College tennis, too; a minor matter even to the undergraduate athletic committee that hands out varsity letters of various shapes and sizes.

239th St (17-5072), s w s, at s e s of Byron St, 99x100; Giuseppe Palumbo to Eastchester Savings Bank, 22 E 1st St, Mt Vernon. Story Ave (14-3637, 3724), s w cor Commonwcalth Ave, 50xlO0; also Rosedale Ave, w s, 100 ft n of Ludlow Ave, 50x 100; Julia Riester to Edna M. Riester, 1 Morris Crescent, Yonkers.

Lusschanya Mobley, American Indian girl, made her debut in opera tonight, singing the title role in "Alda." Miss Mobley, whose family lives in Ardmore, Okla., came to Italy after spending the last two years studying voice in New York.
The morale of the country would improve quickly if prohibition were brought back, Heber J. Grant, president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, declared yesterday in an interview.

Defection of American schools in the performance of their duty has left the burden of education to a shackled press, the Most Rev. Francis C. Kelley, Bishop of Oklahoma City and Tulsa, declared at the annual dinner of the Catholic Press Association tonight.

The chief protection of private enterprise against the threat of consumer cooperatives lies "in putting its own house in order rather than in appealing to the government," Dr. J. L. Palmer, Professor of Marketing, School of Business, University of Chicago, yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Advertising and Marketing Forum of the Advertising Club of New York.
Dr. Theodore Kemp, retired Methodist minister and former, president of Illinois Wesleyan University, died here yesterday at the age of 69.

Abe J. Greene of Paterson was sworn in today as State Athletic Commissioner for a five-year term at a salary of $5,000 annually. Mr. Greene, a Republican, was appointed by Governor Hoffman to succeed George Keenen of Bayonne, a Democrat. Andrew K.

Charles Hallett Graham, retired chief engineer of the City Finance Department, died Thursday night at New York Hospital. He was t born in Harlem seventy-four years ago and lived at 2,226 Loring Place, the Bronx.
George A. Sloan of New York was elected today a director of the Selby Shoe Company. He is former president of the Cotton Textile Institute.
The John Adams nine scored a 2-1 upset over Jamaica, Queens P. S. A. L. leader in a league contest on the victor's field yesterday. It was the second defeat in thirteen encounters for Jamaica.

In the first criminal prosecution under the registration provisions of the Securities Act of 1933, a jury in the United States District Court today acquitted Harry E. Hanes, a partner in and general manager of the Standard Appraisal Company of New York, and Milton Janis a stock underwriter, also of New York.
Manager Steve O'Neill announced today that Bob Feller, the Indians' youthful strike-out king, will do no further pitching on the club's current Eastern trip which ends Thursday.
The Mexican Regional Labor Confederation threatens to call a general strike here next week if 29,000 acres of confiscated land are not returned to small-scale farmers.

Temporary asylum in the United States would be afforded 500 Basque children from Bilbao, Spain, under plans being worked out by the American Board of Guardians for Basque Refugee Children of New York, and now under consideration by the State Department.

Internal revenue collections for the first ten months of the 1937 fiscal year amounted to $3,544,655,191, an increase of $756,412,146 over the same period last year, while receipts for April were $300,389,947, an increase of $97,623,576 over April, 1936.
Engagements of $6,032,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $5,966,000 in England and $66,000 in India were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by local banking institutions.
The Gardner School Alumnae Association, of which Miss Jessie E. Long is president, held a luncheon bridge yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador Hotel for the Louise Eltinge Memorial Fund.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 20: MAJOR GENERAL Croft, E.. Chief of Infantry, leave of absence extended one month. COLONELS Lockett. J. M., Inf.. Roanoke, Va., to 24th Inf., Fort Benning. Ga.
Changes in the tentative Grand Circuit schedule were announced yesterday by E. Roland Harriman, president of the big-time light-harness loop, as he revealed the perfected plans for the coming season.
Even though the weather for the last few weeks has not been altogether friendly to the roof spots and Summer gardens, their number continues to increase and their popularity to grow.

Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc., has arranged the extension of a first mortgage of $116,000 at 41/2 per cent on the sixteen-story loft building at 315-21 W. 39th St. for Textile Crafts Building, Inc., G. S. Gilpatrick, president, with the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

Sufficient rains fell overnight in Eastern and North Central Kansas to take the bull edge off the wheat market today despite the fact that the dry area in the Southwestern section of that State failed to receive moisture.
Striking employes of the United Cigar Stores engaged here today in a new type of labor skirmish.

Passenger revenues of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway increased 28.8 per cent in 1936, according to the annual report of J. M. Kurn and John G. Lonsdale, trustees in bankruptcy. Freight revenues increased 18 per cent.

Further political confusion has been caused by the disbanding of the Showakai, a small progovernment party which has nineteen Diet seats. It was voluntarily dissolved by its president, Keisuke Mochizuki, a former member of the Seiyukai.
Wage increases for 12,000 building service employes in the garment and for districts were granted in an arbitration award by George W. Alger. The increases are retroactive to April 20.
"Larger families and healthier babies in the Third Reich" is the slogan of the Family Exhibition, opened here today under the auspices of the National Socialist party.

When Mrs. Wallis Warfield promises "to love and obey" the Duke of Windsor on June 3 at the Chateau de Cande, it will be before Dr. Charles Mercier, Mayor of Monts only, because it was announced tonight that no church benediction would follow the civil ceremony.
Rudolph H. Lienhart, for many years New York manager of the Winchester Repeating Arms Com Pany, died at his home here last night after long illness.

A decidedly better undertone prevailed yesterday in virtually all sections of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. The improvement was particularly conspicuous among the United States Government obligations, selected foreign dollar bonds and some of the more speculative and convertible corporate loans.

Most commodity futures advanced in moderate activity in the local markets yesterday. Raw silk futures, the only exception, eased. On the cash markets, corn, rye, coffee, cocoa, tins, printcloths and rubber advanced, but wheat, oats, lard, cotton and silk declined.

Oscar Luetke, designer and manufacturer of wrought iron art work, died yesterday of a thrombosis at his home, 140 West 105th' Street. Mr. Luetke, who was 84 years old, retired in 1930 and his business, New York Art Works, was liquidated.

Henri Rabaud's "Marouf, the Cobbler of Cairo," the libretto by Lucien Nepoty, after Scheherazade's 959th story of the "1001 Nights," in English translation by Madeleine Marshall and George Mead, was revived last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, almost exactly twenty years after s North American premiere (in French) during the period of the war in the same theatre, Dec. 19, 1917.

The Textile Workers Organizing Committee announced today that it had canceled a contract with the Colonial Network for a broadcast from Lawrence Sunday of a speech by John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The United States liner President Harding, arriving today from Hamburg, Havre. Southampton and Cobh, has on board Colonel A. A. Vandergrift, commander of the Marine Guards, United States Embassy, in Peking, accompanied by Mrs. Vandergrift; Frederick P. Hibbard, secretary of the United States legation at Bucharest; C. R. Nasmith, United States consul at Edinburgh; Earl Reinsel and Harold Overholt, of the executive staff of the F. W. Woolworth Company in Germany.
Stockholders of the National Supply Company have approved a plan to split the present $25 par common shares into three new shares of $10 par value.
The Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street, gave personal service last year to 189,147 persons in the United States and to 278,629 persons in foreign countries;

Today's business between the Cardinals and Dodgers ought to be reported as no contest, although the regulation number of innings was played and each team started with nine men in uniform on the field.

Apparently shot from behind, the body of John Lapolla, who according to the police was a petty policy racketeer with eleven previous arrests, was found early yesterday morning in front of 308 East 102d Street. His last known address was 4,274 Third Avenue, the Bronx.

These National Guard orders were issued today: Stuart, 1st Lt. James E., Medical Corps, having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to commanding officer 369th Infantry for Assignment to Medical Department detachment. Youngstrom, Lt. Nels C.. communication duties only, 1st Battalion N. Y. N. M., having resigned, he is honorably discharged.

The ordinarily peaceful, uncommercial stretches of blue water which form the racing part of the Housatonic came to life tonight as 144 men in sixteen racing shells that represent four colleges worked out from the Bob Cook boathouse of Yale.

Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller and Miss Eleanor Clark, sister of Mrs. Rockefeller, escaped injury with nine other passengers here today when a Pan-American Grace plane crashed into a fence.
Vittorio Venturi, 146, Italy, knocked out Eddie Ran, 146, West Side, in 1:55 of the fifth round of the scheduled feature ten-round engagement at the Fort Hamilton boxing arena last night.
Wally Moses' homer in the sixth with Bill Werber on base, coupled with George Caster's four-hit pitching, gave the Athletics their third straight victory over the White Sox today, 4 to 3.

Failure of German importers to obtain American tobacco by barter or compensation transactions accounted for a decrease in American tobacco Imports at Bremen from 1,955,710 pounds in April, 1936, to 1,110,600 pounds in April of this year, according to a report from Consul J. W. Benton at Bremen, made public today by the Department of Commerce.
The three-story frame dwelling at 428 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, has been purchased by P. Cashin through Bulkley Horton Company, broker. The building occuDies a plot 36 by 100 feet.

Several members of the Blue Hill Troupe of amateur players who sang leading roles in the performances of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "The Grand Duke," given at the Heckscher Theatre last month for the benefit of Everybody's Thrift Shop, will sing selections from that production and other Gilbert and Sullivan operettas tonight in the Kingsbury Gymnasium of the Spring Hill School. Litchfield, Conn.

The directorate of the All-Union Academy of Sciences has recommended the immediate expulsion in disgrace of Nikolai Bukharin, former high Bolshevik named in the January treason trial as a Trotskyist plotter, from the one remaining honor he holds, that of head of the Institute of Science and Technique.

Governors Island 1st Lieut. Samuel Wenger, Med.-Res., 473 Park Ave., Paterson, N. J., 157th General Hospital, is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective June 1. He will proceed to Baltimore, Md., for duty in that corps area in connection with CCC activities. Lieut. Wenger will rank from May 18, 1937.

Sir John Coode-Adams, manager of the London office of the late Viscount William Waldorf Astor, aided the latter at his request to bring the jewelry of the Astor family from Sorrento, Italy, to England without paying heavy export taxes which were then in force, according to a deposition by Sir John, which was read here yesterday in Federal court.

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers in the overseas markets for the first four' months of 1937 were at a new high record for the period, with a gain of 4.9 per cent over the same period last year. April sales were 34,646 units, a gain of 18 per cent over a year ago.

The profit and loss deficit of the Berkshire Street Railway Company would be reduced from $14,385,000 to $6,061,000 under a plan to extend the due dates of bonds of .three street railway properties of the New York, New' Haven Hartford which was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Samuel Gardner conducted the Federal Music Project Chamber Orchestra last night at the WPA Theatre of Music in the fifth concert of a series devoted to infrequertly heard compositions from the seventeenth century to the present time.

Charles H. Dahmer will make his first report as treasurer of the United Lutheran Synod of New York at its ninth annual convention, which opens Monday at 8 P. M. in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street Mr. Dahmer is vice

John J. Farley of the Hotel New Weston, a brother of the Postmaster General, is now out of a job and has been living on loans obtained from his brothers William H. and Phillip Farley, City Court Justice Joseph T. Ryan was informed yesterday.
Dr. John M. Fisher, Clinical Professor of Gynecology at Jefferson Medical College, died of a heart ailment at his home here last night after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

Temporary wooden scaffolding under the second north lane of the main roadway of Queensboro bridge, in process of repair, took fire at 4:30 P. M. yesterday and shortly thereafter until 6 P. M. Manhattan-bound traffic on the bridge was virtually halted.
By H. LOUIS HOLLANDER Boston Rd, 1,448-56, 6-story brick tenement and stores, 130x90x irreg; P. Walker Morrison, trustee, against Bristow Realty Corp; due, $182,508; to plaintiff for $11,000.

A stunning upset removed Miss Helen Jacobs and her German partner, Mrs. Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling, from the women's doubles division of the French hard court tennis championships today, but Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., and New York, and Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France reached the fourth round.

Seventeen Spanish Loyalist military airplanes which landed here on Monday will remain grounded because Colonel Lunn, Danish border control chief for the non-intervention committee, opposed their return to Spain.

Mr. and Mrs. William Duncan Cameron of Crestwood, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Eustis Cameron, to George William Shine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Michael Shine of Fleetwood, N. Y., formerly of Boston.

The Peddie School baseball team defeated Trinity, 13-1, today for its seventh decision in nine starts this season. The winners now share first place with Blair Academy in the Eastern Private School League title race.

A basic forty-hour work week as a maximum and a 40 cents an hour minimum wage, with provisions for flexibility as between industries and from season to season, has been tentatively decided upon by the administration as a program for presentation in Congress early next week.

It is, indeed, an encouraging "first step toward moral disarmament" and a sign of sanity that German and French historians have undertaken, not merely to eliminate from their histories recrimination and deliberate untruth, but to collaborate in an effort to arrive at a common " textual interpretation of acts and policies" that have affected adverselyFranco-German relations.

Lincoln O. Robertshaw and Thomas Morris Jr. tied for low gross with scores of 80 at the Spring golf tournament of the New York Curb Exchange held on Thursday at the Lakeville Club at Great Neck, L. I. A play-off is to be held soon, with the winner to have his name inscribed on the championship trophy, which must be won three times for permanent possession.
The State Banking Department announced today its approval of the location of a branch office of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation at 298 Fulton Street, Hempstead, L. I.
The one-story taxpayer at 41-02 to 41-16 Queens Boulevard, on the corner of Forty-first Street, Long Island City, has been sold by Corporation 51 to an investing client of William. W. Sweedler.
John L. McKinney, pioneer oil producer in Pennsylvania, died here yesterday. He was 94 years old. Mr. McKinney's early wells were located on Oil Creek, near Titusville, site of the first oil strike.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market continues very slow. Prices naturally favor the buyer, although they yield very slowly. Western growers are frequently refusing to accept bids.

Willett St, 65-105, 25x100; Alma Kraus to 2,076 Eighth Ave. Realty Corp, 1,154 Ogden Ave; mtg $4,000. (50 cents.) 6th St, 816-818 E, 43x97; Florence Waterbury et al to Nass Realty Co, 123 William St. ($4.50.) 21st St, 19-27 W, n s, 104.6x105.8x98.9; John H. Conroy, referee, to Bank for Savings, foreclosure. ($200.)

Both American and Australian Davis Cup doubles teams won practice matches at the West Side Tennis Club yesterday as they tuned up for the American zone final next week-end. The series of exhibitions will be continued today.

Mrs. Forrest Ketcham, 68 years old, was burned to death tonight and her husband, a retired fisherman, 69, was injured seriously when both were trapped by flames in their two-story frame house on East Main Street here.
Rhode Island State led the qualifiers as trial events in the annual New England intercollegiate track and field championships were held at M. I. T. today.

Three parcels of Jersey City real area of estate-an apartment house, a two- leased family dwelling and combination store and dwelling-were involved in an exchange transaction reported yesterday by J. I. Kislak, Inc.

Recipients of awards in the finals of the Catholic School Music Contests, held Thursday afternoon at Town Hall by the Music Education League in cooperation with the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn, were announced yesterday. Leon Barzin, Edmond Roelofsma and Philip Mittell were iudges.
Le Ksar, Warwickshire French-owned winner of the 2,000 Guineas, was restored to the favorite's position tonight in a callover of Derby odds at the Victoria Club.
Their fatherland paid full military honors today to twenty-five members of the Hindenburg crew who lost their lives at Lakehurst.

Regunations pertaining to filing returns under the Social Security Act where employers pay no taxable wages to employes, or pay these wages only in certain months, were issued today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

Mystery surrounds the departure from Gibraltar for Italy of Juan March, Spanish millionaire tobacco king and chief financial backer of the Insurgents, who, in company with several Spanish notables, including the Duke of Alba, sailed aboard the Conte di Savoia last night.

Net earnings of the American I. G. Chemical Corporation for the fiscal year ended on March 31, after all expenses and interest and the normal Federal income tax and surtax on undistributed profits, amounted to $4,684,769, according to the report issued yesterday.
The Bees stopped the Pirates and Joe Bowman's winning streak today by taking the first game of the series, 6 to 3.

The third performance of Walter Damrosch's opera, "The Man Without a Country," will be presented this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The cast will consist of Mmes. Traubel, Votipka, Stellman, Paull, Browning and Matyas, and Messrs. Carron, Royer,

Lewisohn Stadium drew about 800 persons yesterday to observe the manoeuvres of more than 1,000 undergraduate cadet members of the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps in their twentieth annual field day and review.
Peconic Bay boat captains have reported that there are few craft available for those making lastminute reservations to fish today and tomorrow at the great weakfish grounds of Long Island.

The United Automobile Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, served notice today on 3,000 landlords that a "program for rent reductions" would be started unless voluntary adjustments were made by June 1.

Turpentine firm, 36c; sales 143 barrels; receipts 417 barrels; shipments 3 barrels; stock 25,869 barrels. Resin firm; sales 445; receipts 1,550; shipmemnts 1: stock 48,690. Quote: B, $7.40; D, $7.50; E. $7.95; F to N, $8.321/2; WG, $8.35; WW, X, $9.10.

Henry Luskin, operator, purchased the four-story brick-building at 716 Fairmount Place, near Clinton Avenue, the Bronx. This is an eight-family building on a lot 26 by 95 feet. It was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $13,000 through Kleinman Schor, brokers.

An exhibition exemplifying certain phases of culture in New York during the city's three centuries has been opened at the Museum of the City of New York. The display consists of water-color drawings prepared under the Index of American Design, a WPA Federal Art Project.
Miss Alice Marble advanced to the final round of the Surrey tennis championships today. The American singles titleholder defeated Miss Margot Lumb, British squash racquets champion, 6-4, 6-0.

Thomas J. Lipton, Ino., of Hoboken, N. J., filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 52,000 shares of $25 par value 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 200,000 shares of $1 par Class A stock,

Runkel Brothers, wholesale chocolate manufacturers, with head offices at 451 East Thirtieth Street and branches in three other States, filed a petition yesterday in United States District Court asking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

The stock markets, although quiet, were firm today, and the strong recovery in Wall Street assisted the sentiment. Gilt-edge issues registered gains, and among the foreign loans German bonds showed strength after a dull start.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Howard Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin L. Reed, to Robert Bernard Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Baker of Westfield and South Yarmouth, Mass., took place here this afternoon in the garden of her parent's home.

The Federal Government completed its conspiracy case against Ellis H. Parker Sr. today with testimony from high New Jersey officials, including members of the judiciary and State and county prosecutors who figured prominently in the Bruno Richard Hauptmann case.

President Roosevelt has given no thought to the appointment of a successor to Justice Van Devanter, who leaves the Supreme Court next month, and does not intend to do so for some time, he said at his press conference today.

Miss Lynette Fowler, daughter of Mrs. John J. McCall of 42 West Twelfth Street, was married yesterday afternoon in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle to Quentin Raymond Burke, son of Mrs. Walter A. Burke of 1,111 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Burke, by Mgr. Charles Dubois Wood of Middletown, N. Y., a friend of the bridegroom's family.

Members of the Hayden Planetarium expedition will tell of their plans for observing the coming eclipse of the sun in a broadcast from here tomorrow at 6:45 P. M., Eastern daylight-saving time, and another on May .29 at the same hour.

Crude rubber used by manufacturers in the United States in April amounted to 51,797 long tons, compared with 54,064 in the preceding month and 52,031 in April, 1936, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.
The Insurgents' aerial offensive in the Munguia sector carried further today when six fighting planes machine-gunned the road between Munguia and Derio within Bilbao's fortifications.

Fifteen patrol wagons were kept busy shuttling back and forth between West Fifty-sixth Street and the West Forty-seventh Street police station for about an hour just after last midnight as plainclothes men took 350 prisoners to the station house.

Curtailment of government spending to reduce the nation's tax burden was urged by speakers at the thirty-fourth annual convention of the New Jersey Bankers Association here today in the Hotel Traymore.
Because the State Constitution explicitly prohibits pool selling, Governor Lehman today vetoed the Hall bill which would have legalized dog racing and open betting at the tracks.

Mr. and Mrs. Carlton M. Allen of this city have announced that their daughter, Miss Abby Campbell Allen, will be married to Laureat L. Martineau Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. L. L. Martineau of Windsor, on June 4 in St. Justin's Church here.

The fifth annual observance of National Maritime Day will be marked today by exercises on the waterfront and by a dinner tonight at the Hotel Astor which 1,000 shipping men and guests are expected to attend.
About 450 coal miners on a "staydown" strike 360 feet below the surface at Wilsonville cheerfully made preparations tonight for a long siege despite their employer's offer to discuss a settlement.

The Hippodrome Opera Company will present "Il Trovatore" tonight and "Lucia di Lammermoor" tomorrow night. Ezio Pinza, basso; Susanne Fisher, soprano; Mischa Levitzki, pianist; Victor Chenkin, singingactor, and Benno Rabinof, violinist, will appear in a concert tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden to aid Young Israel, a national Jewish youth movement.

Mrs. Ellasworth H. Augustus's handsome chestnut gelding Chatter Chat, who won the national hunter championship last year, gave another brilliant performance today to win the Gibraltar Challenge Platter at the Wilmington Horse Show. Mrs. Cary Jackson, wellknown Virginia horsewoman, had the mount.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on impending currency changes in Sweden is most timely. You are right in saying that apparently the nature of the present Swedish controversy over revaluing the krona in terms of sterling indicates the desirability of concerted international action.
