Two-day conference of the Pan American Students League, begins at Hotel Victoria, 9 A. M. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Painting in Germany, England and France," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "Furniture Styles of Louis XVI and Adam," Alfred Busselle Jr., 2 P. M.;
A story of how the undercover activities of a 27-year-old girl led to raids on Reno's Chinese quarter and the arrest of a veteran Federal agent was told here tonight.
In death the exiled Maharajah of Alwar, sportsman - Prince of India, is going back to his native State in the splendor that attended him in life.
Having been terri ied by its recent brush with censorship-the Dunnigan bill, which Governor Lehman vetoed earlier in the week--the theatre hereafter will take no chances.

Cotton mill activity was maintained at the same level last week. An easing in the seasonal trend was not sufficient to affect the index, which continued at 144.8. The previous week's number was revised to that figure. The index for the week ended May 16, 1936 was 107.4.

An independent stockholders' committee represented by Archibald Palmer opposed yesterday a plan for reorganizing the United Cigar Stores Corporation of America under the Bankruptcy Act at a hearing before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jeanette Clarke Dickie, daughter of Walter Scott Dickie of this place, to Archibald F. Bogle of New York, son of the Very Rev. and Mrs. Andrew N. Bogle of Edinburgh, Scotland.
A twenty-five-foot American elm was planted at the south end of the Mall in Central- Park by Aviators Post 743 of the American

The William Riker Foster Award, established this year by the Chemistry Teachers Club of New York, was presented last night to Benjamin M. Jacquish, chairman of the Chemistry Department of Erasmus Hall High School, at a dinner held by the organization in the Webb Room of City College.
Youthful George Coffman, making his bigleague debut with the Detroit Tigers, today pitched his teammates to an eleven-inning 4-to-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

Trinity Sunday will be observed tomorrow in all ritualistic churches. It is on or near this day that young men are ordained. , For Roman Catholics Trinity Sunday-is the end of the paschal time and of the period in which all are obliged to go to confession and to receive holy communion.
Movements at vessels follow (all dates are May 19 unless specified): At Pearl Harbor, May 20: Argonaut, Litchfield, S-21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 29, 32, 33, 34, 35.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt escorted a group of friends today on a tour of Federal subsistence homesteads in West Virginia and Western Pennsylvania.

A three-to-two decision that may pave the way for the return to street railways and rapid transit companies of about $5,000,000 they have paid the city in emergency relief taxes was handed down by the Appellate Division yesterday.

High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt is reported to have advised foreign consuls to give him precedence over President Manuel L. Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth in public toasts at consular affairs, evoking an immediate reaction among Filipino officialdom.

During the first four months of this year twenty new industrial plants have located in the territory served by the Public Service Corportion of New Jersey and its subsidiaries, against seventeen in the similar period of 1936, according to an announcement by the corporation.

An amended reorganization plan of the Scullin Steel Company has been filed in the Federal District Court at St. Louis, Mo., in accordance with instructions of Judge C. B. Davis, following objections to the original plan filed in January.

Department-store sales here this week were reported by executives yesterday as "fair." Cold weather held down expansion of the consumer demand for Summer merchandise, although Summer home wares fared well by comparison.

Cooperation between motion-picture companies and schools in the greater use of films in education was discussed last night by fifty educators from New York, Connecticut and Rhode Island at the semi-annual dinner of the committee on motion pictures of the secondary school department of the National Education Association, held at the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 15 amounted to 773,669 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,188 cars, or 0.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 92,261 cars, or 13.5 per cent.

E. L. Phillips Co. performed many operating functions of the Long Island Lighting Company, according to testimony read yesterday at the trial in Supreme Court of a $20,000,000 accounting action brought by preferred stockholders of the latter company.
Clashes between rival Moslem sects brought down a curfew here today after one Hindu had been killed and two others injured at Shikarpur.
The Rev. Robert J. Haggerty, curate of St. Stephen's Catholic Church, Arlington, died here yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital after an illness of six months. n illness of six months.

The Cortland teachers' nine registered its fourth victory in six starts today, defeating Panzer College, 6-1, on Columbus Field. Carter's triple in the first inning set the pace for the home club, which collected twelve hits off Markewicz.

Mrs. Loren Montague Cowdrey gave a luncheon yesterday in the Mirror Room of Le Coq Rouge for Miss Miriam T. Neftel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Knight Neftel of 16 East Eightieth Street and Cornwall, N. Y., whose marriage to Thurlow Marshall Gordon Jr. will take place on May 29 in St. John's Church, Cornwall.
Miss Marietta Chapin Ewald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ewald of this place, became the bride tonight of Winthrop Olmstead Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clifford Cook of Quincy, Mass.

The decline in United States bonds, amounting in some issues to 5 points on the average between January and April, has aroused much conjecture over the Government's next quarterly financing, which will occur less than a month from now.

An optional dividend of cash or stock was presented to stockholders of the General Refractories Company yesterday under a plan which would permit the company, if the stock dividends were accepted, to apply an equal amount of the net earnings to the reduction of the outstanding bonded indebtedness.
A hope that James M. Landis would continue in his post as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission as long as possible was expressed today by President Roosevelt at his press conference.

MANHATTAN BAER, LILLIE G. (May 16). Estate, more than $10,000. To. Sara G. Baer, sister, executrix, 112 Central Park West, residue; Carrie G. Klee and Cora G. Klee, sisters, specific jewelry. Leon Klee, Hotel Chatham, Vanderbilt Ave. and 48th St., executor.

Miss Anna A. Person of El Paso, the first woman to enter the Stratton Prize Contest at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, won second prize in the competition for the best technical papers submitted by undergraduates. She is a sophomore.

The first consignment of wood pulp and paper to be discharged at the Port of Newark in two years arrived yesterday on the freighter Milos of the Norwegian America Line from Helsingborg, Sweden. A group of city officials, including Joseph Byrne, Director of Parks and Public Property, and R. J. Dempsey, Director of the Port, were on the pier when the ship arrived.
Gene Homans, former metropolitan amateur champion, played sensational golf today to reach the semi-finals of the Morris County Golf Club's annual invitation tournament.

RUNKEL BROS., INC., wholesale chocolate, 451 W. 30th St.--Voluntary proceeding under section 77 b of the Bankruptcy Law. An attached statement lists assets of $1,615,042, including a valuation of $250,000 for good will, and liabilities of $479,105, exclusive of capital stock. The petition states the plant has been closed for the past five days due to lack of operating capital.
Mrs. Richard Sydney Newbold of New York gave a dinner here tonight in the Planet Room of the Bellevue Stratford for her daughter, Miss Marguerite de Longpre Newbold.

Melodist, Wood Memorial winner and fourth in the Kentucky Derby, looms as the favorite for The Withers, scheduled for its sixtysecond running this afternoon at Belmont Park, where 25,000 persons are expected to attend.

The German secret police are seeking suspects who may have given Cardinal Mundelein, Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, information for his anti-Nazi speech last Tuesday, and who under German law could be charged with treason. Death from the executioner's axe is the penalty upon conviction.

None could call the Japanese an impassive race who witnessed this afternoon in the pouring rain scores of thousands of exuberantly happy people singing and cheering, welcoming the Asahi fliers home. Traffic in the center of the city was at a standstill for hours.

Rosaline Naderson, 22 years old, a ballet dancer, of 224 West Fortyninth Street, who was arrested last week and charged with robbery, had was discharged yesterday by Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky in the way Bronx when the man who was robbed testified that no woman "was in any way involved."

Mrs. Maude Yohe, president of the Woman's Club of South Orange, died last night at her home here after an illness of one month. She was 58 years old and the wife of John W. Yohe, a New York manufacturer.

The elimination of one-fourth of the weight of the 1,745,299 freight cars owned by railroads in the United States would result in an annual saving of $154,000,QOO, based on current traffic volumg, Albert F. Stuebing, railroad mecanical engineer of the United States Steel Corporation, told the New York Railroad Club in the Engineering Societies Building last night.

If hospitals are to remain "free and independent," there must be greater reliance on public philanthropy and less on governmental aid, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Hospital Association of New York State at the Hotel Astor.
An effort by employes of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to revive the employee representation plan, outlawed by the Federal Labor Relations Act, was under way today.

Norman Kleinke pitched the Rochester Red Wings to a 4-to-3 triumph over Montreal today. Rochester tallied all its runs off Harry Smythe in the first two frames. Kleinke got out of a hole in the ninth by fanning Gus Dugas.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Colt of East Orange, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Clyde Colt of this city, to Robert Mitchell Ekings Jr., son of Robert Mitchell Ekings of Paterson and the late Mrs. Ekings, took place this afternoon at the Woman's Club of Orange.

The poll of the employes of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation on the question of union recognition is the most important action which was been taken under Section 9 of that Wagner Labor Relations Act. To 27, ?? employes eligible to vote, one question was submitted: Did they war Mr.
The Reds snapped out of a three-game losing streak today to defeat Philadelphia, 6 to 5, and move ahead of the Phillies into seventh place in the National League race.

A plan for the reorganization of the American Woman's Realty Corportion, operator of the American Women's Association clubhouse at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, was approved as fair and equitable under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

Dr. Ludwig Duerr, a member of the German investigating commission headed by Dr. Hugo Eckener, testified as an expert in the official inquiry today that in his opinion there was an explosion of great magnitude on the airship Hindenburg before she was destroyed by fire here with a loss of thirty-six lives on May 6.

Big Bill Watson, latest in Michigan's line of great Negro track and field stars, drum-majored a parade of seventeen Wolverines into the finals of the Big Ten's thirtyseventh annual championship meet today with a new conference record and the best performances in three events.
Governor Lehman vetoed today the bill of Senator Crawford of Brooklyn, which would have prohibited wine wholesalers from selling direct to consumers.
Charges by the Civil Service Reform Association that he had yielded to political pressure in naming Miss Grace A. Reavy to the Civil Service Commission were denied tonight by Governor Lehman.
Mrs. Reba C. May Bamberger, long a leader here in Jewish and non-sectarian welfare and civic organizations, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a twoweeks illness.

The Dallas Morning News announced tonight that employes of the editorial, art and photographic departments of The News, The Dallas Journal and allied publications had "almost unanimously" decided against organization as a unit of the American Newspaper Guild.

The consolidated income account of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended March 31, issued yesterday, shows a profit on a "since acquisition" basis, after Federal taxes and other expenses and charges, of $3.466.922.
Real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday included sales of dwellings in the midtown and upper West Side areas and tenement houses in Harlem.

The veteran Ted Bruce, appearing in a surprise relief ro1e on the mound, halted a Pennsylvania rally today and Dartmouth defeated the Quakers, 4-3, for the Green's seventh league victory in a row, tying the record.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Jeanora Don of New Rochelle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Don of Elizabeth, N. J., to R. Paul Weingarten of this' city, which took place on May 22, 1936, at the home of friends of the couple in Harrison, N. Y. A Justice of the Peace performed the ceremony.

A committee composed of prominent business men, a doctor and a clergyman was formed yesterday to study means of improving living conditions in the tenement sections of the West Side and of combating the high new-case rate of tuberculosis, cancer, heart ailments and other diseases among the residents of the area.

Pensioned On their own applications: PATROLMEN-Daniel Donoghue, 63d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 2, 1907. Michael C. Erb, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 24, 1910.
Atley Donald, rookie Newark righthander, registered his sixth straight victory of the season today, blanking the cellar-dwelling Orioles, 7 to 0, and tightening the Bears' grip on first place.

The Norwegian America Line's first organized tour to America arrived yesterday on the liner Stavangerfjord and the fifteen tourists started to see the city as their bags were unpacked at the Hotel Taft.
General Hugh S. Johnson, considered as a successor to the late W. Forbes Morgan as president of the Distilled Spirits Institute, announced here yesterday that he was not available for the post.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, won the election of employes of the Borden Company and its subsidiary, Willowbrook Dairy, Inc., conducted on Thursday under the supervision of the National Labor Relations Board, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director, announced yesterday after the vote had been counted.
Speedy ending of the three-week film strike, possibly tonight, was indicated at a conference of screen producers and strike leaders late today.

While Dominion Prime Ministers discussed British foreign affairs at Downing Street today a little group of bankers met in the greatest privacy in another unofficial "imperial conference" in the board room of the Bank of England.
Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Greensboro, N. C., and Miss Dorothy Kirby, youthful Georgia sharp-shooter, will meet tomorrow for the championship of Southern women's golf in a thirty-six-hole match.
A referendum on the question of repealing Tennessee's-twenty-eightyear-old dry laws was assured today when the Senate passed a House-approved bill, 22 to 10. Aug. 12 was fixed as the date.
Rear Admiral and Mrs. David Potter of Philadelphia are at the Vanderbilt. Dr. Edmund Le Roy Dow, who returned recently from Palm Beach, left the Plaza yesterday for Newport.

Robert M. Sands, successor to the late Edward L. Doheny as president of the Petroleum Securities Company, and executor of the Doheny estate, died of a heart attack yesterday in Harwich, England, according to word received here. He was 60 years old.

Russell S. Rountree, president of Rountree-Jones, Inc., died yesterday at his home here. He was 45 years old. A son of the late Henry W. and Elizabeth S. Werst Rountree, he attended Augusta Military Academy in Staunton and the Pough- Por keepsie (N. Y.) Business College.
Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kleinteich of Merrick, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Alice Kleinteich, to Dr. Richard Jones of Berlin, Wis.

Mothers and their children danced and sang folksongs last night in the first of three performances of the annual Spring festival of the Grand Street Settlement before 200 persons in the auditorium of the settlement building at 283 Rivington Street.

Striking members of the International Association of Machinists, Lodge 1548, affiliated with the A. F. of L., staged a mass picketing demonstration yesterday in front of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company's repair plant at 1 Park Avenue.

The law of contracts being what it is, the Madison Square Garden Corporation took a couple of more steps yesterday toward living up to its agreement with Max Schmeling to promote a heavyweight championship fight in the Long Island City Bowl on June 3, with Schmeling in the role of challenger.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday he had ordered an investigation of police action, or lack of it, in the mass picketing early Thursday morning in West Forty-fourth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, during a sit-in strike of WPA dancers and the audience at the Nora Bayes Theatre.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 19: COMMANDERS Phillips, W. B., Third Naval District: Quinley, W. M., Naval Academy, and Thomas, A. 'C., Washington, D. C., to instruction at the Naval War College, Newport, R. I. Morey, F. L., Dental Corps, Puget Sound, Washington, to Naval Air Station, San Diego, Calif.

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock A Spring today came within a stroke of equaling the Englewood Golf Club course record, established by tc Miss Maureen Orcutt on July 21, U 1928. Miss Glutting shot a 78, after te a poor start, to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association oneday tourney. Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong had a 79.
The Labor Department today asked the Consolida foundry officials to explain their discharge of 800 workers who have, nevertheless, remained on the job without working since yesterday.

Employes of the Studebaker Corporation who are affiliated with the United Automobile Workers of America voted by acclamation today to return to work as soon as operations can be resumed in the various departments.

The American Federation of La. bor and the Committee for Industrial Organization clashed openly yesterday morning when the C. I. O. Transit Workers Union called a strike of drivers of the Suburban Bus Company, which operates routes in the North Bionx, in Yonkers and in other sections of Westchester.

The engagement of Major Walter Greatsinger Farrell, United States Marine Corps, at Quantico, Va., and Mrs. Mary Belcher Trapnell of Coronado, Calif., has been announced here by her father, Frank J. Belcher Jr., San Francisco and San Diego bank executive.

Amelia Earhart's rebuilt $90,000 flying laboratory round-the-world plane suffered another mishap tonight when fire broke out in one of the engines a moment after she had landed at Tucson, Ariz., after a swift test flight from Union Air Terminal at Burbank.

The first returns from persons more than 65 years old who had applied for Social Security account numbers to be used in connection with State unemployment compensation showed yesterday that of 1,509 applicants, only 63 were unemployed.

"Aida" was presented by the Hippodrome Opera Company last night with a cast of tried favorites of the institution. The name part was taken by Iride Pilla, Amneris by Louisa Caselotti, Radames by Enrico Coppellotti, Amonasro by Ettore Nava, Ramfis by Vladimir Zorin, and the King by William Hargrave.
Production was resumed today in the Ecorse plant of the Murray Corporation after an overnight sit-down by workers objecting to the speed of production.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for May 15 showed that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation had declined to 129.04 per cent from 134.08 per cent on April 30. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities had risen to 90.71 per cent from 89.31 per cent.

The Roof Athletic Club yesterday took title to the five-story building at 109-11 West Fifty-fourth Street, near Sixth Avenue, formerly the international branch of the Y. M. C. A., for a reported consideration of $150,000. Irvin Simon acted as broker in the transaction.

The Tilo Roofing Company, Inc., of Stratford, Conn., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 60,000 shares of $25 par value $1.40 cumulative convertible preferred and 145,000 shares of $1 par common.

Dr. Edward M. Van Cleve, one of the outstanding leaders in work in behalf of the blind, died at 9:15 o'clock last night in his apartment at the New Weston Hotel, where he had been ill for the last year.

Louis Waldman, State chairman of the Social Democratic Federation, the right-wing Socialist organization, whose members are affiliated with the American Labor party, urged Mayor La Guardia last night to withdraw from the Republican party and run for re-election as the candidate of the Labor party, the Progressive City Committee and other progressive groups.

The House today fixed $1,500,000,000 as the amount to be spent on relief in the 1938 fiscal year, 210 members voting to support President Roosevelt's request, while 128 voted to follow the economy bloc bent upon cutting the amount by $300,000,000 or more.

John Dopp, third officer of the American Export steamer Exhibitor, was imprisoned here today on the charge that he was responsible for the death of a Turkish laborer who, while discharging cargo from between decks, fell into the lower hold and was killed.
Mrs. iron Louis Botha, widow of the Boer general who became premier of the Union of South Africa in 1910, died at South Natal today.
Of the $100,000 being sought in this country toward the expenses of the two world religious gatherings to be held this Summer in England and Scotland, $65,000 has already been raised.
The transfer of jurisdiction or six express highways on June 1 from the Long Island State Park Commission to the Park Department of the City of New York was announced yesterday.

The Field Artillery Group of the Second Corps Area held its annual Spring dinner dance last night at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park. The party was attended by regular army and reserve officers from the 570th, 441st, 442d, 566th.

After walking five of the first six men to face him, Jake Mooty settled down and delivered a three-hit pitching performance to give the Syracuse Chiefs a 3-1 triumph over Jersey City in the first night game of the International League season tonight.

The Christian Church was called upon today, in a report presented to the Northern Baptist Convention, to "fight for industrial democracy and justice, for a more equitable economic order, for Christian attitudes and understanding between labor and capital, for a curbing of the acquisitive instinct."

Several milk bills passed by the last Legislature have now been signed by the Governor and become law. The most important of these is the RogersAllen act, which, according to the Governor, "returns milk control to the milk industry, where it belongs."

Miss Barbara Kane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kane of Locust Valley, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to Samuel Wynne Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Denckla Mills of Glen Head and Georgetown, S. C. The wedding will take place on the afternoon of June 12 in St. John's Church of Lattingtown.
Although Frank Escott struck out fifteen men, Villanova lost its final game of the season to Ursinus today, 5 to 4. Gemmel of the Bears walked fourteen batters but was effective in the pinches.

Science must accept the sociological responsibility for the use of inventions it develops in the future, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, said last night at the fiftieth anniversary dinner of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Petit Bleu, a 5-year-old chestnut, owned by Captain G. S. Barnes. today won the Manchester Cup over one and a half miles, beating Lord Manely's Emborough and Sir Abe Bailey's Valerian in a close finish.

Looking over the list of survivors in the Garden City Golf Club's annual invitation tournament after the first two match-play rounds, one is inclined to say that only members are able to deal with the Travis-conceived course successfully.
School teachers of the city were urged last night by Allan S. Haywood, regional director of the C. I. O., to ally themselves with his organization for the sake of the "future welfare of democracy."

The latest promotion drive to be undertaken by the National Association of Food Chains will be on eggs from the Central California region. Poultry raisers in that district have obtained the cooperation of the chains, it was announced yesterday.

Amid the buoyant and ear-splitting shrieks of a ladies' day crowd of 23,000, the Giants lost their opening clash with the Cubs today, 8 to 5, and aside from the disconcerting shrieks there seemed to be other contributing factors to this somewhat stunning defeat.

John J. Raskob finished his testimony in the old Postoffice Building yesterday by declaring it was he who brought about a mutual balance of stock losses with Pierre S. du Pont which the Treasury now regards as evidence of an income tax evasion in 1929.

The sum of $48.50 in contributions to the Conscience Fund was received by Secretary Morgenthau today, bringing the total since the establishment of the fund in President Madison's administration in 1811 to $637,227.

A Soviet airplane made a successful landing at the North Pole yesterday, and established a permanent weather and scientific station as the first step in the long-cherished plan for regular air communication between Russia and America by way of the polar region.

Fortysix issues of bonds offered yesterday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation have been awarded to the highest bidders. The face amount of the bonds sold was $8,175,650 and the sale price $8,309,970, a net premium of $134,320, RFC announced.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The gymnastics team at the University of North Carolina, though still young and inexperienced for intercollegiate competition, provoked loud praise and admiration from the masses after horizontalbar and parallel-bar exhibitions between halves of basketball games during the past season.

Jacob Gould Schurman, former United States Ambassador to Germany and president of Cornell University from 1892 to 1920, arrived here from New York this evening to observe his eighty-third birthday tomorrow with relatives. He is visiting at the home of his son, George M. Schurman, on Cantitoe Road.

Following an early advance to the best levels of the week and more than $2 a bale above the recent low figures, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined nearly 20 points yesterday and closed with losses of 11. to 13 points.

President Arturo Alessandri opened the session of Congress at noon today in the presence of the diplomatic corps and high officials with an annual message that was animated by a spirit of optimism land confidence throughout his three-hour reading of it.

In the June issue of Survey Graphic Magazine, Park Commissioner Moses suggests a popular referendum on whether the city's park system is an expensive luxury or a necessity. He says he would have no doubt of the verdict.

Armistice in Spain is far from an immediate probability. The first statement issued by the new Cabinet at Valencia declared that "there will be no peace until the rebellion has been completely crushed."
Mrs. Lola Duvall Williams, newly elected president of the Camp Fire Girls of America, arrived yesterday from Dallas, Texas, for her first official visit here.
Shiploads of women and children from Bilbao bound for France and England carry the mind back twenty-three years

Movements in the Chicago livestock market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 6,000, including 1,500 directs. Market generally 10c-15c lower than Thursday's average; packing sows 15c-25c lower;

News that there is strong sentiment in the Congress of the United States in favor of a bill to empower President Roosevelt to send an official invitation to the Finnish Government to take part in the tricentennial celebration next Spring, commemorating the founding of the Delaware Colony, has been received with appreciation throughout Finland.
Three men indicted for a bankruptcy fraud described as concealment of $75,000 assets of the Dartmouth Dress Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell.

The yacht Goizeko Izarra, owned by Ramon de la Sota, Basque millionaire who has espoused the Basque separatist cause, got away from Bilbao today and was reported to be carrying about 400 refugees and gold and jewelry worth $50,000,000.

Michael J. Hogan, 66 years old, a former Representative in Congress and Alderman from the Seventh district in Brooklyn, escaped with a suspended sentence in General Sessions yesterday on his plea of guilty to conspiring with John J. Hassett, former head of the abolished Municipal Board of Examining Plumbers, to shake down two men for $750 on a promise to get them master plumbers' licenses.
Bill Dickey's timely single gave the Yankees an eleven-inning decision over the Browns yesterday before a gathering of 10,504 in the Stadium. The score was 4 to 3.

After a full day of play under a hot sun, the field of 106 players, representing forty Eastern preparatory and high schools in Princeton University's seventeenth annual tennis tournament, had been reduced to nine men tonight, one fourth-round match remains to be completed.

Mrs. Gilbert Weld Goodridge of North Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Louise Jenkins Hall, to Robert Philip Ellis of Nash Street, son of Harry B. Ellis of Springfield, Mass., and the late Mrs. Ellis.

The Morning Choral of the Woman's Club of Garden City held a musical and tea today at the home of Mrs. Royal Toner on Oxford Boulevard. Mrs. Gladstone V. H. Cairns was chairman, and Mrs. John Mears was vice chairman. Mrs. Louis H. Dutton is conductor of the group.

Glamorgan and Gloucestershire turned in victories in county cricket championship matches concluded today. The Welsh County whipped Leicestershire by an innings and 49 runs, while Gloucestershire overcame Middlesex by 85 runs to take the runner-up position in the table.
The volume of new bond financing this week, while slightly larger than during the preceding period, continued relatively light with a total of only $19,748,000 in new bonds placed on the market.

Germany's foreign trade drive, made possible by the international armaments race, was able to score a new success during April, when it rolled up record figures for both exports and imports for the entire four years since Adolf Hitler came into power.

Olin Dutra of Los Angeles, tuning up for the national P. G. A. championship beginning here Monday, shot a sub-par 69 today in a practice round. Although he was three under par, the Field Club course itself interested him more than his score.

By a twothird majority vote delegates to the annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America today re-enacted a "hands off" policy on politics and all other matter's of a controversial nature.

President Roosevelt reiterated to farm organization leaders today that he favored the pending legislation to. carry out Secretary Wallace's evernormal granary plan "in principle," but declined to press for its passage at the present. session of Congress.
When General GOERING recently complained that the dictator's lot is not an easy one, he was not telling anything new to observers of dictatorships in operation.

Surroundings have been begun by the British Government through diplomatic channels in all the countries that are members of the Non-Intervention Committee regarding the possibility of a joint move tending toward bringing about the cessation of hostilities in Spain.

Reorganization of the State Department through abolition of the Mexican division and consolidation of its functions with those of the LatinAmerican division into a new division to be known as the division of the American Republics was announced by Secretary Hull today coincident with the assignment of duties to the Under-Secretary and Counselor of the department.
The first annual award of the City Club of New York to a nonelective public official for meritorious service was presented yesterday to Park Commissioner Robert Moses.
The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company announced today that it was discontinuing its Detroit plant, which had employed 400 or more workers until it was closed by a strike March 9.
Establishment of a pension system for employes of the city libraries was approved yesterday by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate. The motion was made by Controller Frank J. Taylor.
Sir Danlel Levy, for many years Speaker of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, died here yesterday at the age of 63. He was knighted judge in 1929.

The community, through Federal, State and local agencies, should undertake to teach the nation proper food habits as part of the program for longer life and immunity from disease, Dr. W. H. Sebrell, past assistant surgeon of the United States Public Health Service in charge of nutritional investigations, told the annual convention yesterday of the New York State Dietetic Association at the Hotel Astor.
Lautaro Nitrate Company, Ltd., first mortgage 6 per cent.convertible gold bonds, due in 1954, and certificates of deposit for such bonds have been suspended from dealings.

President Roosevelt indicated today that $11,000,000 of relief labor funds already on hand would be spent for flood control, in addition to the $30,000,000 ear-marked for flood projects in next year's budget.

The undefeated Holy Cross nine kept its record intact today, defeating the Brown varsity, 2 to 0. Brown errors following a double by Brucato and a sacrifice by Kelley in the third inning gave the Crusaders their runs.

Staged as a climax to a threemonth series of cultural, athletic and novelty contests, the closing ceremonies of the Hunter College Silver Jubilee Olympics took place late yesterday afternoon in the Little Theatre of the Bronx buildings of the college, Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue.

Thirteen colts were named today to run in the $12,000 added Illinois Derby at Aurora tomorrow. It will be the sixth running of the race, at a mile and one eighth, and should all thirteen thoroughbreds named in the overnight field face the starter, the event will be worth $13,500.

Cold and rain retarded retail trade activity in many parts ofthe country this week, although all of the leading centers showed gains over last year, the increase for the country as a whole being estimated at 8 to 20 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Willard Gibbs gold medal of the Chicago Section of the American Chemical Society, one of the highest distinctions in chemical science, was conferred tonight upon Dr. Herbert Newby McCoy for his achievements in radioactivity.
The House Rivers and Harbors Committee approved today a proposal to authorize competition of the Florida Ship Canal.

The directors of the American Sumatra Tobacco Corporation have declared an extra dividend of $1.25 a share and the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the common stock. Dividend disbursements in the fiscal year ending on July 31 will be $2.75 a share, according to Seton Porter, president.

Another period of inactivity in the market for new State and municipal loans is indicated for next week, when a total of only $5,065,385 in new tax-exempt issues is scheduled for award. They will be represented by one State and thirty-nine municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $25,733,605 for this week.

Dartmouth students elected today a new Palaeopitus which will serve as their governing organization next year. The new Palaeopitus elected as president Robert F. Archibald of San Gabriel, Calif., vice president of the junior class and a member of Green Key and, the track squad.
The Pittel Corporation sold to Fred Zlotkin for investment the five-story tenement house on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 71 Eldridge Street, near Hester Street, through Arthur Eckstein, Inc., broker.

Trading was slow on veal hindsaddles and prices were weak to lower. Steer beef sold with slightly better undertone. Demand was fair to good on lamb and fresh pork with lamb prices slightly uneven but mostly steady and fresh pork strong to higher.

Georgetown defeated Princeton, 6 to 3, at the Woodway Country Club today to win in the southern division of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf League and gain the right to meet Yale in the thirty-six-hole championship play here tomorrow.
Richard H. Brokaw, one of the first Mayors of the borough and the treasurer of -the Bound Brook Building and Loan Association for fifty years, died today at his home here.

Mr. and Mrs. Meverell Bryarly van Doren of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Herndon van Doren, to Turner Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Augustine Rose of King George County.
Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York suggested today that German press comment on asserted immorality in New York high schools be referred to the New York official in charge of sewage disposal.

Charles W. Posthauer, former Assemblyman, Alderman and Deputy Public Welfare Commissioner, died last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. J. L. Harkness, at Stratford, 'Conn. Mr. Posthauer, who was 68 years old, left his home in College Point because of failing health recently to live with his daughter.

The Piping Rock Club women's team defeated Queens Valley, 3-2, in a play-off for the Long Island Interclub Class B honors today at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club, and thus qualified for the Intersectional B Division tournament at Fresh Meadow on June 14.

James Maxton, fiery Laborite member of Parliament, in a political speech tonight attacked the Labor party for supporting the recommendation of a grant of ?6,000 a year to 11-year-old Princess Elizabeth, heir presumptive to the throne.
By a vote of more than two to one, the 27,000 employes of Jones Laughiin Steel Corporation have chosen the Steel Workers OrganizingCommittee as their collective bargaining agent with the company.

Admission of tenants with incomes ranging from $3,000 to $10, 000 a year into "low cost" apartments in Knickerbocker Village was defended yesterday by George Gove, secretary of the State Housing Board.

The American Press Association was yesterday urged by five weekly newspaper publishers in a joint letter to sponsor a campaign to be known as the "Consolidated Drive for Country Newspaper National Advertising."

With one defendant-witness under constant police guard and another taking refuge in jail against gangster murder threats, United States Attorney Lamar Hardy's investigation into the disability insurance racket continued yesterday behind closed doors.

The Rev. Denis A. Maloney, pastor of St. Edmund's Catholic Church, Ocean Avenue and Avenue T, Brooklyn, died suddenly in his rectory while, near by, children of .the parish were rehearsing a playlet with which they were to have celebrated the thirty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to. the priesthood.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kay V. Bense of 943 Kilsythe Road of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caja Bense, to George G. Coombe, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Coombe.

Magistrate William A. Farrell in Jefferson Market Court yesterday discharged Edward Mehderian of 351 West Forty-second Street, manager of the Eltinge Theatre, one of the fourteen burlesque theatres closed recently by city officials.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Sears of Boston and Beverly, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean S. Sears, to Archibald Stevens Alexander of Bernardsville, N. J., son of the late Archibald S. Alexander and of the late Mrs. Helen Barney Watriss.
In answer to a number of inquiries: the title of Millen Brand's new best seller, "The Outward Room," is taken from lines by John Donne. They are: "Think then, by soule, that death is but a Groome,

Mr. and Mrs. George S. Birdsong gave a dinner at their home in Bronxville, N. Y., tonight for Miss Treva C. Wampler of Miami, Fla., and Edward J. Lucke Jr. of Greenwich, whose marriage takes place tomorrow. Last night Mr. and Mrs.

Although few of the life insurance companies have rushed to take advantage of the amendments to the New York State insurance laws permitting a broadened field for investments, many of the companies have made inquiries regarding offerings now in process of preparation and eligible for purchase under the revised act.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt opened the gardens of Welwyn, their estate overlooking Long Island Sound, this afternoon for a benefit pilgrimage for the Protestant Epicopal diocese of Long Island. There were more than 200 visitors.

Sir Alexander Grant, millionaire biscuit manufacturer, who began his career as a baker's boy with McVittie Price and rose to the chairmanship of that company, died at his home in Edinburgh today at the age of 72.

Kingsley Montgomery, an attorney, died in his sleep today at his home here in his sixty-third year. He was solicitor of the Chester-Cambridge Bank and Trust Company, a member of the boards of the First National Bank and the J. Lewis Crozer Library and president of the board. of managers of the Chester Hospital.

Two non-comparable periods form the basis of that portion of the contract between directors of Pararmount Pictures, Inc., and Adolph Zukor, calling for payment to Mr. Zukor of a percentage of profits, it was ascertained yesterday. Mr.
The Indians protected their slim American League lead over the Athletics and Yankees today with a 7-to-5 triumph over the Senators.

Members of the Italian royal family visited today the National Museum here. The King, a famous numismatist and archaeologian, was impressed by the museum's collection and received from it three antique Dalmatian silver coins not included in his large collection of Roman coins.
The Rev. J. J. Brune, head of the Alton Deanery of the Springfield diocese of the Catholic Church, said today that the diocese would conduct "motor mission," beginning June 14.

Funeral services for Mgr. Patrick Joseph Healy, Professor of Church History in the School of Sacred Sciences at the Catholic University of America, will be held at 11 A. M. today in the Church of the Holy Innocents, Thirty-seventh Street, west of Broadway.
Miss Flora Matilda Gannett, sister of Frank E. Gannett, publisher, died here yesterday after a brief illness, according to The Associated Press.

Mrs. Lulu Smith Howard of Corson Co., Inc., was elected yesterday president of the Women's Bond Club to succeed Miss Clara I. Taylor, and Miss Catherine Papper was elected vice president to succeed Miss Vera M. Shantz. Miss Ruth F. Stevens remained secretary and treasurer.

Two Chicago youths whom police skid admitted killing a school teacher at Onida, S. D., to get her car and $10, were rushed here tonight to prevent possible mob violence. The victim, Miss Ada Carey, 26, of Blunt, S. D., was said to have identified her assailants just before she died.
Four men were found hanging from a tree in the town of Tetla, 100 miles from the capital, yesterday. They were bandits who for several weeks have been holding up travelers along country roads.
The Bureau of Mines estimated today a daily average production of 3,366,000 barrels of crude oil would be required to meet the nation's demands next month.
Miss Flora Matilda Gannett, sister of Frank E. Gannett, publisher, died here yesterday after a brief illness, according to The Associated Press.

Two Chicago youths whom police skid admitted killing a school teacher at Onida, S. D., to get her car and $10, were rushed here tonight to prevent possible mob violence. The victim, Miss Ada Carey, 26, of Blunt, S. D., was said to have identified her assailants just before she died.
The Bureau of Mines estimated today a daily average production of 3,366,000 barrels of crude oil would be required to meet the nation's demands next month.

In a dramatic conclusion to a day of surprises, in which her counsel announced that she would place responsibility for the crime on Donad Wightman, her co-defendant and former admirer, Gladys MacKnight, who will be 18 years old June 6, took the witness stand in her own defense this afternoon at the trial for the hatchet murder last July 31 of her mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight.

With Labor Department figures showing current factory employment within a few points of the 1929 total, Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, urged business men and industrialists today to pay less attention to stock market movements and more to "business indexes that more accurately reflect the trend of recovery in the United States."
Members of Congress were still chuckling today over President Roosevelt's veto of the New York World's Fair bill, based on "unconstitutional invasion of the province of the Executive."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stanford Brooks of Ardsley-on-Hudson and Woodstock, Vt., of the engagement of their cousin, Miss Mary Vail Hewitt, to Edwin H. Mairs 2d of Irvington, N. Y., son of Mrs. John Dows Mairs of this city and the late Mr. Mairs.

Arthur Garfield Hays, national director of the American Civil Liberties Union, late today was notified by City Manager Carlos de Castro that the report on the investigation of civil liberty in Puerto Rico might be read in the Plaza Principal tomorrow night.

A sharp rebound in commodity prices late last week was responsible for the regaining of the four previous weeks' losses by The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices, which rose to 144.4 on Tuesday from 142.4 (revised) the Tuesday previous, and is now, except for the weeks of March 23 to April 6, the highest since 1929.

Kaufman Brothers Bondy, pipe manufacturers, in International Building, RockeSeller Center. Duane Sport Shop, store and basement in Barclay Building, Broadway and Duane St; Snack's Food Shop, store and basement in 83 Chambers St; Pioneer Air Compresser Co, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc, store, basement and subbasement, in 120 Chambers St; Wm. C. Walker's Sons, broker.
Congress can effect an important reform in our revenue laws if it gives serious attention to the bill introduced by Representative CELLER of New York to

With a new batch of suspects at his disposal, Warner Oland comes to town again tonight at the Central as the philosophical Oriental sleuth in "Charlie Chan at the Olympics." Katherine DeMille, Pauline Moore, Allan Lane and Keye Luke also are in the cast.
A Smith College professor has been the subject of some rallying lately in connection with a recent visit to the college of Secretary Perkins..

The concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, at the County Center tonight, as the second event of the Westchester music festival, was attended by an audience of 3,000 persons.

The wedding of Miss Harriette Jane Stull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Stull of 32 Brittin Street, to Ernest P. Frahm, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Frahm of Florham Park, N. J., took place this evening at the bride's home.

Government Crop Experts revised their estimates of the 1936 cotton crop today and placed the yield at 12,399,000 bales, a change of less than one-tenth of 1 per cent below their December estimate. This compares with 10,638,000 bales produced in 1935.

Member trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange aggregated 2,920,083 shares bought and sold, or 21 per cent of total volume., in the week ended on April 24, compared with 3,125,285 shares, or 22.33 per cent, in the preceding week, according to the week- I ly analysis issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In a move to gain a better control over the distribution of oil royalties involving less than $100,000, which are exempt from registration under the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a revision of its rules providing that after June 1 a period of at least seven days must elapse after the filing of offering sheets with the commission before such sheets shall become effective.

More than a half century of Princeton University's baseball history was spanned tonight by the thirtyfour graduates who gathered informally at dinner in Nassau Inn to pay tribute to Bill Clarke, who is completing his twenty-third season as varsity baseball coach.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for alterations in Manhattan and new houses in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. The plans follow:

Mrs. Margaret Nichols Fonda of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, daughter of the late E. Remington Nichols, was married this afternoon to Donald Graham Overman of East Orange, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Overman of this place.

Moving to the front at the head of the stretch, H. C. Hatch's Gold Lure went on to win the seventy-eighth running of the classic King's Plate as a crowd of 18,000 packed Woodbine Park for the opening of the Canadian racing season today.

By streamlining someancient locomotives built in 1907 the Paris, Lyon Mediterranean Railroad has produced a new crack train which covers the 536 miles from Paris to Marseille at an average speed of 59.5 miles an hour.

Four hundred British schools have adopted a new approach to the once dreary textbook subject of geography. About a year ago each of the 400 "adopted" a British merchant ship. The schools range from Eton to elementary schools all over the country, and the ships from liners. to tramps.

Miss Doris Carver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Carver of Maplewood, will be wed to Charles F. Fearon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Fearon of Oneida, N. Y., on June 24 in Morrow Memorial Church here. The Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, the pastor, will officiate.

WHILE America and Europe are rebuilding their fighting forces and developing their trade, Tibet, the Hermit Kingdom of Asia, is searching for a little child. In December, 1933, the last Dalai Lama died. He must have been reborn of some fortunate mother, but Tibet is a large country and it is difficult to discover the young boy. Though many are praying
-Prominent persons in many walks of life attended funeral services today for J. Henry Roraback, who for more t han twenty-five years guided the destinies of the Republican party in Connecticut.

Due to rising construction costs, home building operations are being considerably curtailed, reports Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards. Many operative builders, he declares, have informed him that the principal cause is the current uncertainty as to material and labor costs.

Russia's program for strengthening her national defense includes modernization of her air fleet, construction of more submarines and other naval vessels and improvement of her transportation facilities, it was learned today.

Former residents of Greenwich House will commemorate the thirtyfifth anniversary of its founding on Wednesday with a gift of a portrait of its only surviving founder and present director, Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch. Gerard Swope,
ALBERT-FLEISCHMAN-Mr. and Mrs. M. L. Fleischman of 390 West End Ave. announce the engagement of their daughter, Pearl, to Melvin A. Albert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Albert of 685 West End Ave.

AGAINST adverse weather conditions in many sections of the country last week, retail trade was not able to improve very much on its former gains. Some districts' reported, in fact, that they were barely even with last year's figures. Apparel trade is receiving the brunt of unfavorable weather, while home furnishings volume seems to hold up fairly well.

The United States Army information service has issued a warning to shipping to steer clear of the coast of New Jersey below Fort Hancock next Thursday, when Coast Artillery guns will be engaged in target practice.

Upon recommendation of the mu nicipal securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association o America, the board of governors o the association adopted a resolution at their meeting this month a Hot Springs, Va., designed to unify the practices of municipal bond houses in advertising revenue bonds, as well as to guard against any possible confusion in the mind of the investor between revenue bonds and general obligations.

Miss Elizabeth Corson Ellis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John MacEwan Ellis of Bethlehem, Pa., and Rumson, was married today to Randolph Henry Beardsley of New York in St. George's-by-the-River here. The Rev. Dr. Earl G. Lier performed the ceremony.

A second season of open-air productions of operetta will be given this Summer at Jones Beach by Fortune Gallo, managing director of the San Carlo Opera Company, by arrangement with J. J. Shubert and in collaboration with the Long Island State Park Commission, it has been announced.
THE debut of Rocco Pandiscio, American baritone, and the first performance of the ballet "The Bat," will be features of the fourth and final week of Metropolitan Opera Spring season.

Close cooperation between the renting department and the operating department is imperative if the management of a building is to achieve its highest efficiency, William J. Demorest, vice president of William A. White Sons, told the operating forum of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York last week in the Town Hall Club.

Public exercises and a notable exhibition of Hardyana will be held at Colby College to celebrate the 97th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Hardy, it was stated today by Professor Carl J. Weber, head of the Department of English.

From the Annual Review of Legal Legislation for 1936, just published by the American Bar Association, it appears that the number or admissions to the bar in that year was 8,591, less by 380 than the new recruits of 1935. Not a marked relief of the congestion so much complained of, but- let us be grateful for small favors.
A Plymouth Rock hen mothered today the seven kittens of a cat which prefers to spend- her time gadding about.
The parents are prepared to campaign for more school buildings and a reduction in the size of classes, according to the annual report of the United Parents Association.

The question of woman's fitness for the Supreme Court, the Presidency and for greater power in political and legislative bodies was argued by a strongly feminist group of women at the Spring luncheon yesterday of the Soroptimist Club at the Hotel Commodore. More than 300 women attended.

Miss Harriet M. Franklin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Franklin of this place, will be married to W. Raymond Boyd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Boyd of Glen Ridge, N. J., the night of June 4 in St. John's Church here.
Amassing a total of 49 points by scoring in nine of the thirteen events, Barringer High School of Newark emerged victorious in the eighth annual Montclair invitation track meet today at Essex Field.
The fourteenth annual commencement of the Barrington School for Girls will open on Friday evening at the school here with a concert by Miss Katherine Bacon, New York pianist.

A GLANCE at the personnel list of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra-which has just come to light here-confirms the fact that the organization has a uniquely cosmopolitan membership. Its seventy-odd musicians

Miss Leonora Genevieve Warfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Guy Warfield, was married to Noah Edward Parlett today in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception at Towson, near here.

Holders of mortgage certificates of the Lawyers Westchester Company and the Westchester Title Company having a face value of more than $150,000, obtained today a show cause order returnable on next Saturday before Supreme Court Justice Syme in Yonkers, in which they seek to have the Northern Westchester Trust Company of Mount Kisco and eight cotrustees removed.

The Western Conference faculty athletic committee appointed a committee today to prepare a resolution to prohibit Big Ten athletes from competing in any meets or events except those sponsored by colleges or conferences of colleges.

The seniors at Skidmore College took their last chance this week of poking fun at the faculty and underclassmen. It is the custom for the last assembly of the year to be turned over to the seniors, who satirize college customs, traditions and faculty. The assembly this year depicted the twenty-fifth reunion of the class of 1937.

Three hundred and seventy-four Peiping students, including seventy-eight girls, who started southward, ostensibly for Nanking, to petition the government are reported to have been sidetracked at Hsuchow, in Northern Kiarigsu, although free transportation to the national capital was promised them after a twentyfour-hour sit-down strike in Peiping's principal railway station.

Exhibiting his prowess as a climber before two boy companions by mounting a pole supporting high-tension power lines near the Long Island Railroad station at St. Albans, Queens, Richard Markley, 15 years old, was injured fatally about 9 o'clock last night when he lost his footing and fell eighteen feet to the ground.

IN the year 1533 Messer Tiziano Vecelli, that great painter with the sadly clear seeing eyes, journeyed from his home in Venice to Bologna. His purpose was to paint Charles V, called by many the greatest Emperor since Charlemagne but certainly no fascinating subject for a paint brush, and he so well succeeded that when the hookjawed Hapsburg monarch departed from the city of

End-of-the-year elections of club staffs in Westchester County are virtually complete, bringing the usual shift of responsibility in important posts. The opening of the club season next Autumn, however, will find a number of the heads of these groups continuing through a second year, either because of a two-year tenure or through re-election.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Kiess of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frederika Ludwig Kiess, to William Leffingwell Wilkinson of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Wilkinson of Meriden, Conn.

Led by Carl Morgan, the Manhattan College nine defeated Rutgers University, 11 to 4, before 1,500 on Neilson Field today. Morgan, Jasper left fielder, in five times at bat collected four hits, including two homers and a triple, and batted in. five runs.

THE legitimate theatre versus the films is a topic for hot debates in all sorts of forums these days, and artists, critics, students and professors of assorted esthetics are forever rushing in from all sides with their two cents.

Jeremiah K. Cronin, manager of the management division of the mortgage and real estate department of the Bankers Trust Company, has been re-elected chairman of the board of directors of the management division, Real Estate Board of New York.

Checking up on its two years of kaleidoscopic existence, the WPA Federal Theatre estimates that it has played to more than 5,000,000 children and young people, to most of whom the professional drama was previously unknown.

Plans have been completed by Miss Isabel Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hale Anderson of Caldwell, N. J., for her marriage to Richard Stedman Holden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Holden of Old Bennington, Vt., which will take place Saturday afternoon in St. Peter's Church, Essex Fells, N. J.

An outing for women of the Peabody Home for Aged and Indigent Women at 1,000 Pelham Parkway, New York, will be held on Tuesday at Naumkeag, the estate here of Chester L. Dane, vice president of the board of trustees of the home.

Members of the senior class of the Finch School will give their annual Spring tea Tuesday in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Guests of honor will be Mrs. Jessica Cosgrave, president, and members of the faculty of the school.

IT will be a dramatic moment in British history when a Chamberlain goes to Buckingham Palace to receive his seals of office as Prime Minister from the King. For Neville Chamberlain, son of Joseph, half brother of Sir Austen, inheritor of a rich and glowing tradition,

WITH the nation more stabilized than ever before, and all forms of transportation advancing rapidly, China for the first time is making a bid for tourist travel. The Printing Bureau of the Nationalist Government, for so many years busy with decrees and manifestos, is at last finding time to turn out gayly colored posters advertising such famous sights as the Yangtse Gorge, the Temple of Heaven and tha Great Wall.

WASHINGTON.-The Rural Electrification Administration has borrowed an idea from the circus to supply power until the government is ready. The idea is the portable electrical generator mounted on wheels which circuses and carnivals use for energizing ferris wheels, merry-go-rounds and other mechanical devices at stops where no regular power is found to be available.

The Frances Hodgson Burnett Memorial Committee will present the Burnett memorial children's fountain in Central Park, near 105th Street and Fifth Avenue, to the city on Friday at 4 P. M., it was announced yesterday.

Students of New Jersey College for Women-this week chose officers of eight departmental clubs, who will take office in the Fall. Those named are as follows: Psychology Club-President, Miss Priscilla Stevens; vice president, Miss Katherine Schick; secretary, Miss Leslie Gordon; treasurer, Miss Josephine Stefanick.

Gustavus W. Bergner Sr., Mayor of this resort since 1925 and former member of the Delaware River Bridge Joint Commission, died today in Fitzgerald Memorial Hospital, Darby, Pa., at the age of 63. He was taken to the hospital last night from his Winter home in Kirklyn, Pa.
At 73, grandmother Louise McCabe is "Getting ready for old age" by playing volley-ball and stepping over chairs twenty-five times a day.

WASHINGTON. - The army hostess, a familiar figure at nearly every army post and training camp in World War days, seems doomed to extinction.. For the coming fiscal year the War Department will keep only eleven hostesses on its rolls, and unless the General Staff changes its mind vacancies by death or resignation will not be filled.

THIS book is the story of Emperor Karl of Austria, King of Hungary, of whom Anatole France said: "He was the only honest man who occupied a leading position during the war." He was the only man, too, who not only prayed for peace but staked his crown to get it. He lost his realm and, a few years later, also his life, the last ruling head of the Hapsburg dynasty.

OF a total of 2,548 miles of major routes contemplated in the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs, announced some eight years ago, progress was reported yesterday on 1,026, or about 40 per cent of the whole, by the Regional Plan Association. Giant strides,

The Valencia [Spanish] Government's appeal to the League of Nations for further investigation of "foreign intervention" prompts Virginio Gayda to print in the Giornale d'Italia today another three-column alleged revelation of contraband traffic in men and arms into Spain.

Citing the fact that a housing shortage exists throughout the country as a whole and in Manhattan, I. Jerome Riker, president of the realty firm bearing his name, says that a recent survey indicates that there is no housing shortage in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.
Clubwomen will join this week in celebrating the tenth anniversary of National Poetry Week, opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the National Poetry Center, Rockefeller Center.

ALEXANDER KIPNIS seems to work in whatever studio happens to be most convenient to him at the moment. His name has appeared on several labels, and in this country he has been recorded by Columbia, and his European disks have been re-pressed by both that company and Victor.
More than 600 persons yesterday attended a funeral service for Rev. Michael J. Duffy in his church, the Church of the Nativity of Our Blessed Lady, East 233d Street and Dyre Avenue, the Bronx.

Machine-gun bullets from one of four Spanish Rebel planes rained into this frontier town this morning after a raid on Portbou and Culera, on the Spanish side of the border. A stone splintered by one of the bullets that fell here slightly injured a French boy.
The opening for the season of the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton on Tuesday night will be a benefit for the Judson Health Center. A special program will be

A SOCIAL AND RELIGIOUS HISTORY OF THE JEWS. By Salo Wittmayer Baron. 3 volumes. 8vo. New York: Columbia University Press. Volumes I and II, $3.75 each; volume II, $4. From the origins of Israel to the present day.

Residential air-conditioning, providing complete control of the atmospheric conditions within the home, is a practical thing today, according to the current issue of Electrical Merchandising, which adds that air-conditioning is available to the man building his own home, the architect specifying for the builder, or the man whose business it is to build homes and sell them at a profit.

NEW BERN, N. C.-Planned as a major historical observance, the celebration of the 350th anniversary of the first English settlement in the New World and of the birth of Virginia Dare, first white child born of English parentage in America, will begin Sunday, July 4, and end Labor Day, Sept. 6, on Roanoke Island, off the North Carolina coast.

To establish a larger and more equitable representation of the classes in the City College Student Council, an amendment to the council charter was introduced and passed last week by the Faculty Committee on Student Relations.

Thrice thwarted in the finals of the Morris County invitation golf tournament, Gene Homans of Englewood today chased the jinx which has dogged his footsteps and defeated W. Stanton Barbour of the home club, 1 up, in nineteen holes to capture the event.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Countess Erice Wilhelma Eva Matria Johanna von Hacke, daughter of Erica Huberta, Countess von Hacke of Castle Atlwarthau, Silesia, Germany, to Abraham Gottlob Heinrich Reimold, son of Mrs. A. G. Reimold and the late Mr. Reimold of Orange.

Miss Florence I. Kutz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Kutz of Union Grove, was married to Dr. E. Herbert Sexton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin K. Sexton, this afternoon in the Union Grove Methodist Episcopal Church.

Haverford College seniors this week set a precedent for a class gift to the college upon graduation in June. Instead of making the customary donation at commencement time, the class voted to pay a fixed sum each year for twenty years into the Wellington Fund.
King Victor Emmanuel of Italy and his party concluded their visit here this evening and departed amid the cheers of crowds in the streets and a military display at the railroad station.

The Henry Hudson Parkway Authority announced that yesterday the two millionth car passed the Henry Hudson Bridge at 2:05 P. M. Perpetuating the custom it started with the one-millionth car, the Authority issued a fifty-trip book of tickets free to Stephen Purcell of Riverside, Conn., driver of the car.

Marvelous Melvin Ott, the Giants' compact little powerhouse, who has been struggling desperately with a short circuit these many weeks, snapped out of his batting slump with a loud bang today and the result was almost electrifying.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Mrs. Hooker Kirkland, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Burnham Kirkland of Greenwich, to Ralph Musil of New York will take place in the chapel of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, New York, on the afternoon of June 5. Dr.

A six-room house, built in accordance with the Johns-Manville principle of triple insulation, is open for inspection at Suassa Park, Port Jefferson, L. I. Situated on a plot 75 by 125 feet, the dwelling overlooks Port Jefferson Harbor.

The Davis Cup campaign in the North American zone will come to a climax at Forest Hills on Saturday, Sunday and Monday with the most important international tennis match held in this country in a decade.
Soldier volunteers of the United States Coast Artillery struggled 500 yards along jagged rocks today, rescuing seven children from the motor schooner Star, stranded on on the Cristobal breakwater.

It was so peaceful and pleasant out at the front-line trenches beyond Guadalajara this afternoon that this correspondent and a British colleague hated to come back to Madrid, where our hotel and the entire Gran Via were subjected to a terrific shelling this morning just before we left.

An increase of 6 per cent in the volume of home loans accepted for insurance by the FHA during the first quarter of 1937 is reported by the building and loan associations of Newark, N. J., according to Thoma E. Colleton, FHA State director.

Real estate commissions and fees reported by the 36,137 real estate agencies and brokerage offices making returns to the Bureau of the Census amounted to $117,844,000 for the year 1935. An average of 47,689 persons were employed by these organizations, their payrolls aggregating $59,332,000 and, in addition, there were 34,747 proprietors devoting the major portion of their time to their respective businesses.

New impetus for a truce in Spain was given today by the non-intervention committee which met in London this morning and finally produced its report for withdrawing foreign volunteers on which a truce may be based.

From a trustworthy source the following details are available here as to the results of an inquiry recently conducted in Berlin by Maurice Frere, Belgian economic expert and right-hand man to Paul Van Zeeland, the Belgian Premier, who has been entrusted by Great Britain and France with the task of investigating and reporting the best means of reviving world trade.

Bushwick High's nine received its third set back in six Section A, Brooklyn P. S. A. L., battles yesterday when it bowed to Boys High, 4-2, at the Boys High Field. A three-run outburst in the fourth session provided the home nine with its fourth verdict in nine tournament clashes.
KARL KRUEGER of Kansas City, who recently conducted a special concert of the Vienna Philharmonic,

Passage of a bill for a new criminal court house and city prison and the barring of good-will broadcasts were among the accomplishments in which committees of the New York County Lawyers Association played an important part during the session of the State Legislature, Charles E. Hughes Jr. declared in his annual report as president of the association.

The Senate Committee on Education and Labor voted today to report favorably the Murray-Hatch resolution calling for the appointment of a Federal commission to study the general problem of unemployment and relief.
THE American auction season which terminates its uneven course this month was saved from the blight of mediocrity by the last-minute arrival of the Armour sale.

Some stories of big sea fighters to be found in Nova Scotia waters have been compiled by Provincial officials. One of them has to do with tuna. It seems that the first sportsman, according to the records, who set out after Nova Scotia tuna was a schoolmaster, Thomas Pattilo.

A demand that all forms of transport be regulated by the Interstate Commerce Commission in order to assure fair rates, good service and safety was voiced in a resolution adopted by the United States Chamber of Commerce at its recent annual meeting.

The third annual Macfadden "Health and Rejuvenation Walk" began yesterday. It will last fourteen days and will cover 325 miles--from Broadway and Sixty-fourth Street to Dansville, N. Y. A large crowd watched the hikers depart.

The C. I. O. unions will be signing a contract with Henry Ford "when the new production season starts," Alan Haywood, regional director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, predicted yesterday afternoon at a conference on white-collar workers' problems under the auspices of the Affiliated School for Workers at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twentysecond Street.

Three triples and four singles in the first two innings gave Syracuse all the runs it needed to defeat Jersey City tonight, 6 to 1. Doc Legett hit a home run in the eighth for the final Syracuse tally.

NEW electrical instrument, the Helertion, has been construct ed by Bruno Helberger, pianist of Frankfurt, Germany, now on a short visit to this city. It is played like a piano or organ, but there the resemblance ceases, the sounds being produced by means of oscillating tubes.

The eighty-nine-acre estate, containing a restored old stone house, owned by Selden E. Gill in Bucks County, Pa., has been sold to William J. Guthrie, vice-president of the General Motors Corporation. Mr. Guthrie plans to build an addition to the house and construct a large recreation building and swimming pool.
Mrs. James H. Perkins and Mrs. James Goldmark will give a tea today at Mrs. Perkins's home in Greenwich in behalf of the MacDowell Colony for creative artists at Peterborough, N. H. Stephen

For the fifteenth time in the last seventeen years Andover won the Class A crown in the annual Harvard interscholastic track and field meet today in the Harvard Stadium. The Andover total was 55 points, and trailing was its ancient rival, Exeter, with 30.

With the tall bearded iris rapidly coming into flower, Spring gardens everywhere will soon be at their best. These flowers, so orchid-like in quality, give an enchantment to flower borders and gardens that is not quite equale at any other time.
A bill prohibiting royalty collection in Florida by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Producers-ASCAP-passed the Senrate today, 29 to 1.

A bill prohibiting royalty collection in Florida by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers passed the Senate today, 29 to 1. It was sponsored by Senator Beacham of West Palm Beach, owner of a radio station, who said the society collected 5 per cent of the gross receipts of stations playing music of its composers and received a fee for every hotel radio and theatre seat.

In behalf of Irvington House, a sanatorium for cardiac children in Irvington-on-Hudson, officers of the organization will give a reception and motion picture showing of the institution's enterprises Tuesday afternoon at the Madison. Mrs.

Retailers limited their purchases to reorders in the wholesale market here last week in order to keep stocks normal, according to the report for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. While volume has improved, the retail situation finds apparel and "soft" lines lagging behind home furnishings.

TO many travelers, a projected trip to South and Central America or through the West Indies and Spanish Main is looked forward to as a glorified meal of many days' duration, for "time to eat" is a phrase that all wanderers beneath the Southern Cross will come to love before their ship has turned northward.

Timothy J. Quillinan, former District Attorney of Rensselaer County, died this afternoon shortly after he was stricken while playing golf. He was the father of Francis J. Quillinan, New York City attorney, who is the husband of the former Catherine Smith, daughter of ex-Governor Alfred E. Smith. His age was 66.
James N. MacLean, general chairman of the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, announces that the committee is making a survey for a new plan for modernization and repair loans.

The South African, Ballington, today won the 511/2-mile London-to-Brighton road race in the amazing time of 5 hours 53 minutes 42 seconds. Norman Dack of Hamilton, Ont., was second in 6.57:56, and Jim Phillips, also of Hamilton, third in 7:18:54.

Union College will conclude this week an unheralded but highly successful experiment when the daily chapel assembly programs come to an end on Friday. The experiment has brought about arevival of interest in study of public speaking at the college.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Howell of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Augusta Williams Howell, to Linn M. Brantley, son of Mrs. William G. Brantley of Jacksonville, Fla., and Washington, D. C., and the late Mr. Brantley.

When on June 3 his former Majesty, King Edward VIII, now His Royal Highness, Edward, Duke of Windsor, marries Wallis Warfield of Baltimore, he will break English traditions extending over fifteen centuries. He will be marrying outside the rules.

A five-run rally in the ninth and a second uprising that produced three tallies in the tenth, both by the Montreal Royals, gave the men of Maranville a 12-to-9 decision over the Red Wings today as the visitors pounced on four Rochester pitchers for twenty hits as they evened the series.
Many social events will be held in connection with the Fairfield and Westchester race meeting on Memorial Day on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here.

WASHINGTON. GOVERNMENT officials looking out upon the unprecedented number of tourists in the capital city this Spring have quickened their program for erecting in Washington permanent exhibits depicting the activities and objectives of the Federal departments.

In the five-acre Thompson Memorial Rock Garden in Bronx Park will be displayed the 2,000 varieties of plants to the public beginning today in connection with the celebration of rock garden week. The plants were collected throughout the world.

We had a lot of different chauffeurs in Madrid. The first one was named Tomas, was 4 feet 11 inches high and looked like a particularly unattractive, very mature dwarf out of Velasquez put into a suit of blue dungarees. He had several front teeth missing and seethed with patriotic sentiments. He also loved Scotch whisky.

Plans have been completed by Miss Peggy Larimer, daughter of Mrs. William Gray Larimer of 405 Park Avenue, and the late Mr. Larimer, for her marriage to Thomas F. C. Frost, son of Mrs. Thomas F. C. Frost of London, and the late Mr. Frost, which will take place on June 3 in St. Thomas Chantry.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Catharine will give a reception this afternoon at their home, 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, at which they will announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Catharine, to John J. Mueller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mueller of Montclair, N. J.

The arrangement of each floor in the twenty-story apartment building under construction on the northwest corner of West End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street has been planned by H. L Feldman, architect, as a separate unit, distinct from any other, according to Mose Goodman, president of the Sari Corporation, the builder.
