Leading from start to finish, Case Ace, entry of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars, Chicago owner of the Milky Way Farm Stable, captured the $12,000 Added Illinois Derby today, beating Grey Count by a neck in a thrilling finish.

Travel agents report the development of a new volume of transatlantic traffic due to the arrival of hundreds of persons from foreign countries to visit relatives in the United States. Almost daily, as ships arrive, scenes are enacted on the piers that reflect the movement.

Ethiopia Spain are the big unknowns as the European Foreign Ministers return to Geneva for sessions of three League of Nations organs in the coming week. The ninety-seventh session of the Council opens on Monday, and on Wednesday begins the special session of the Assembly to admit Egypt to the League.

THE old game of lotto, long familiar to most American homes, has been revived and given the name bingo and is enjoying wide popularity. Dressed up a little, the pastime of the Genoa of centuries ago provides a popular diversion.

The engagement of Miss Helen Elizabeth Peck, daughter of Mrs. Charles Fletcher Peck of Premium Point Park, this city, and the late Mr. Peck, to John Kent Lincoln, son of Mrs. Frederick Dame Lincoln of Marblehead, Mass., formerly of New Rochelle, was announced today at a luncheon held here.

Dr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Brown of 277 Park Avenue and Sands Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Alberta Brown Wood of 115 East Eighty-second Street, to Frederick Theodore Pierson, son of Mrs. Frederick T. Pierson of Kolaneka Farms, Pittsford, N. Y., and the late Mr. Pierson.

Superintendent of Schools, York City Preparation of two separate school budgets, one for the calendar year 1938 and the other for the first six months of 1939, will begin within the next week or ten days.

A GENERATION ago the horse problem in the West was comparatively simple one. The ranches were all fully stocked with cow horses for riding the ranges and for the round-upsseveral mounts for each cowboyand the draft horses or mules for such hauling as might be necessary.

A review by Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Multiple Dwelling Law Committee, of measures designed to amend the Multiple Dwelling Law which were introduced in the last session of the State Legislature, reveals that the bills totaled forty-one and exceeded the average introduced during a session by-fifteen and the maximum in any previous year by six.

Issuance by the Minister of the Imperial Household of a statement to the press dealing with the daily life and duties of the Emperor of Japan-published on His Majesty's thirty-sixth birthday--may mark the inauguration of a new policy that will have tremendous significance and influence on Japan at home and, to an appreciable degree, on Japanese foreign policy.

Tests to measure the "engineering horse sense" of incoming students have been -adopted by the Cooper Union Engineering Schools, and will be included experimentally in the aptitude examination to be taken in the Fall, Dean George F. Bateman announced yesterday.

Between the strong central national power urged by Hamilton and the federation of sovereign States advocated by followers of Jefferson, there may yet develop a real working partnership of Federal and State governments, along lines evolved through the research work of a Barnard College professor, Miss Jane Clark of New York.

Dedication ceremonies for the new James Cameron Mackenzie Administration Building at Lawrenceville School were held today in conjunction with the annual alumni week-end, which was attended by 300 alumni.

DIVING for pearls in the Gulf of Lower California is carried on today by "skin" divers in the same way in which their ancestors sought for pearls in the days long before the Spanish conquest. Doubtless the pearls, "big as pigeon eggs," that were found among the jade and gold ornaments in the tomb of an Indian chief opened at Monte Alban during 1931, were taken from the waters...
The country at large may still regard New England as the citadel of thrift and prudence, but in the last four years it has become a paradise of legalized gambling.

Invitations have been issued for the marriage of Miss Ora Otis Worden, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Beatty Worden of Princeton, to Mr. James Miles Hubball, son of Mr. Samuel Williams Hubball and the late Mrs. Hubball of Pasadena, Calif., and Vancouver, British Columbia. The wedding will take

From the standpoint o price changes, the stock market last week made its best showing since the first week in March. The net gain in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks was 3.70 points; trading continued dull.

WHAT with the approach of the exhibition, when there will be all sorts of special dramatic festivals, French and foreign, and the advance of Spring toward Summer, the theatres have tended to resort to revivals of past successes or new presentations of the classics rather than to the production of original works.

Plans for commencement festivities at Upsala College, here, are being completed, it -was announced today. Decoration of the campus will begin in a few days. The first event scheduled is a track meet at the Ashland Stadium, directed by Percy Arnstein, on Friday, June 4, at 2 P. M.

Hobart and William Smith Colleges held their annual Alumni Day homecomings today. Alumni and alumnae meetings and luncheons were followed by a la crosse game between Hobart and Colgate, the second meeting of the teams this year.

Senator Royal S. Copeland received yesterday afternoon the Nolan-Stirling trophy for "distinguished service in promoting the interests of the American merchant marine." The trophy was awarded on the steps of the Custom House during memorial services commemorating National Maritime Day.
More than forty persons were killed or wounded late last night in a battle between police and bandits, armed with machine guns, who raided the border town of Hotaili and kidnapped twenty villagers.

A wave of buying lifted May corn to $1.35 3/8 a bushel, the highest level in twelve years, on the Chicago Board of Trade today. Profit-taking later reduced a small part of the advance, and the contract closed at $1.35 1/4 for a net gain of 13 cents on the day. The July and September
-Trinity took the second game in the home-and-home series with Wesleyan today, 9 to 3. Patton pitched a fine game for the visitors, holding Wesleyan to six scattered hits.

Winlock, director of the Metropolitan, in a pamphlet just issued by the museum, writes in part as follows:

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Stanley Richmond of 14 East Sixtieth Street and Laurel, Miss., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Thelma Richmond, to Lieutenant Carl Laverne Rickenbaugh, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Swander Rickenbaugh of Hudson, Mich. The wedding will take place here June 24 in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

One hundred and nine members of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party were arrested Friday night after a meeting in Reichenberg attended by 14,000 persons. Those arrested had greeted each other with the Hitler salute, which is prohibited in this country.

THESE radio columns first felt the imprint of ink fifteen years ago today, and since then the presses have rolled off a magic story of scientific achievement. From the first feeble voices that whispered in space, a billion-dollar industry has grown up nurtured by both science and art.

By the slender margin of two points, Harvard missed providing a crowning touch to this topsy-turvy track season today as Yale, scoring a little slam in the final event on the program, defeated the Cantabs, 68% to 661/2 in their forty-fourth annual dual engagement.
The "Sam Smith" farm has turned out to be none other than the farm of Owen D. Young, lawyer and official of the General Electric Company.
James Melton, concert singer, has purchased the James I. Clark estate of twenty-six acres of Weston, Conn. The property includes an eight-room house, a guest house, studio, tool house and large barn.

Freed at last from the long nightmare of air raids and hunger, 3,800 Basque children from Bilbao and its neighborhood arrived off Southampton tonight on the Spanish liner Habania to start a new life in the peace and quiet of England.

At this writing it appears that Jose Americo de Almeida will be chosen by the administration as its Presidential candidate. It also appears that Armando Salles de Oliveira of Sao Paulo, an independent candidate, will not withdraw from the contest.

Mr. and Mrs. James Fairchild Adams of Newtonville, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Joy Adams, to Henry Elliot Mallinckrodt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mallinckrodt Jr. of St. Louis.
The board of delegates of the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations will hold a meeting at the Hotel Commodore on Thursday, to fill vacancies in the executive board of the association.
New Utrecht Evening replaced Dickinson Evening as metropolitan Evening High School track and field champion today at Pershing Field. Dickinson held the crown for the last four years.

Consumer groups of every stripe and pattern, ballooning into existence at intervals since the drear days of depression, demonstrate the mounting curiosity of purchasersespecially women--about the merchandise for which they plunk down their dollars.

On Sunday Brock Pemberton wrote in THE TIMES some notes on the forthcoming convention of the legitimate theatre. He remarked, "For the first time since 1930 the theatre finds itself with more customers than product." He also said, "Since the dearth of good plays is generally admitted to be one of the most serious ailments of the theatre."
Mr. and Mrs. David Chester Noyes will give a supper dance for their debutante daughter, Miss Frances Noyes, on July 1 at their Summer home, Netherwood, Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

This resort is crowded for the week-end. During the week Mrs. Frederic de Rham was made chairman of he Autumn ball committee. The ?all will be held Oct. 23. Serving ?n the committee with her will be Mrs. S. Sloan Colt, Mrs. David Vagstaff, Mrs. Reginald L. G. Auhincloss, Mrs. George B. St. ?eorge and Mrs. E. Victor Loew.

The class which is to be graduated from the Naval Academy on Juue 3 contains 327 members, as against 262 last year. This indicates the enlargement of the student body, and, consequently, graduating classes under the law which increased the number of appointments to the academy.
More than a dozen persons have died in the West this Spring of infection from woodtick bites, although the spotted fever season has hardly begun.
Carl Fischer, a Cleveland castoff, held his old team-mates to two hits today in a six-inning game which the Senators won, 4 to 1. Rain washed out the last three innings.

Before a crowd of returning alumni the varsity nine of the Peddie School today defeated Rutgers Prep, 15 to 6, in seven innings. This was the eighth victory for Peddie. Peddie scored in the first, second, third and fifth innings. In the fifth frame, the home team tallied six runs. Rutgers Prep was held to four safeties.

The marriage of Miss Rose Virginia Hook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Hook of this city, to William Haunton Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hayes Smith of South Hadley Falls, Mass., took place here this afternoon in Center Church, on the Green. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Oscar E. Maurer.
The coronation in London automatically added one more queen's bookplate to the extensive collection of Charles P. Morse.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 19, aggregated $8,799,000,000, or 2 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 9 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Edgar of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bette Perry Edgar, to John Dorrance Warriner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dexter Warriner of Philadelphia and Montrose.

Palestine Arabs outdid themselves today in celebrating Mouled el Nebi, the birthday of the Prophet Moham med. Never before have there beer such elaborate festivities, decorations and processions as throughout the country today.

Yale pounded three Dartmouth pitchers today to win, 10-3, and hand the pace-setting Indians their first defeat in eight Eastern Intercollegiate League starts. Ben Lane lasted little more than the first inning, Pyrtek was hit hard during
Guests invited today to the wedding of Miss Ethel du Pont and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. found enclosed with each invitation a privately printed railroad time-table and a miniature road map.

A more friendly attitude is being shown by bankers throughout the country toward the establishment of a Federal mortgage bank than was the case when the plan was originally suggested by the National Association of Real Estate Boards, Edward A. MacDougall, chairman of that organization's committee on real estate finance, told the delegates at the recent Central Atlantic regional realty convention in this city.

A strike by seventy-one operators employed by three independent bus lines forced thousands of persons to seek other transportation today. Called at the peak traffic period late yesterday, the strike brought quick action by the State Labor Department, whose representatives conferred with Mayor Jasper McLevy in an effort at settlement.

Striking employes of the Fleischer Studios, 1,600 Broadway, creators of animated moving-picture cartoons, picketed the Paramount Theatre, Seventh Avenue and Fortythird Street, and the Roxy Theatre, Fiftieth Street and Seventh

Volunteer Girl Scout leaders will begin training at Camp Edith Macy at Briarcliff Manor on Tuesday when the national personnel division opens a program of forty-four courses in recreation and administration techniques. The schedule includes study of special activities, modern education methods and psychology, and their practical application to the movement.

A recent decision in the Surrogate's Court here affecting the administration of trust estates may have a wide bearing on the handling of such properties, according to Eugene Ashley of the realty firm of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

Jascha Heifetz will appear as soloist at the opening concert of the second season of the Essex Symphony Society, Erno Rapee, director, Tuesday evening, June 8, in Newark Stadium, it was announced yesterday.
General Emilio Mola's Insurgent troops pushed a great encircling drive from the east and south tonight, sweeping around the mountains southeast of Bilbao and foreing Basques to flee from hills.

The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, has on display a special exhibition of drawings by the Index of American Design, a WPA art project, illustrating the decorative arts in early New York.
AFTER sitting twice through the coronation newsreels last week we realized how perceptive Shakespeare had been when he wrote "Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown."

Movements in the Chicago livestock market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 1,500, including 1,400 direct; nominally steady; very few fresh hogs on sale; one load, good to choice, around 215 lbs. $11.85; nominal top $12; compared week ago around $1 higher; shippers took none; estimated holdover 1,000.

Rounding out their first quarter century, the Camp Fire Girls are preparing to begin their second auspiciously with a welcoming dinner on Thursday for their new president, Mrs. Lola Duvall Williams of Dallas, Texas, who will also attend the national board meeting on Friday.

Rising building costs have apparently had little effect thus far in curtailing home construction in Queens and adjacent sections of Long Island. Nathan Brait, who has been developing a large tract in Jackson Heights at Eighty-sixth Street and Thirtieth Avenue, has acquired an adjoining plot which will provide facilities for twentyfive additional medium-priced homes.

Martin Sullivan, a 73-year-old former policeman, accused of the murder of five of his Duquesne neighbors in a mad rage last Dec. 17, laughed today as the jury brought in a verdict of death in the electric chair.

Walter Damrosch's new opera, "The Man Without a Country," received its third performance yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, attended by an audience of moderate size but cordial disposition. The composer viewed
THE lost words of the language have finally come to roost. The unmentionables are mentioned and carefully placed in proper alphabetical form in Eric Partridge's new slang dictionary.

Social and economic trends are changing the type of urban civilization in this country, James C. Downs Jr. of Chicago, editor of The Journal of Real Estate Management, published by the Institute of Real Estate Management of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, told the delegates at the recent Central' Atlantic regional convention in this city.

ON several recent occasions John D. Rockefeller Jr. has been headlined as an advocate of unity among the churches. At first sight this seems to be a well-worn subject-Mr. Rockefeller himself has been talking in these terms for twenty-five years-and people are asking whether there is anything fresh to be said about it.
An extension of the Green Mountain horse trail is being planned by the Green Mountain Riding Club, which r will make a new trail joining those in Roxbury, Westford and Fairfax.
The Dartmouth Winter Carnival has projected itself as a problem into the month of May, and a committee of twenty-nine members, made up of leaders of the faculty and undergraduates, is pondering it.

The marriage of Miss Hester Hewlett, daughter of James Monroe Hewlett of Rock Hall in this community, to James Britton Stearns, son of Mrs. Cooper Stearns, also of Lawrence, took place this afternoon in Trinity Church, Hewlett.

The battle for abolition of compulsory military training in American schools "epitomizes" the "struggle between democracy and Fascism," according to a report adopted unanimously today by the Northern Baptist convention here.

Miss Eileen Patricia Collins, daughter of Mrs. Charles J. Collins and the late Mr. Collins, was married to Vincent Depaul Fay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Fay of Rowayton Beach, and Brooklyn, this morning, in St. Augustine's Church.

A conference of cooperating groups will be called at an early date by Judge George W. Pratt, chairman of the New York State Tax Limitation Committee, to propose plans for amending New York State's Constitution to provide stricter limitations on real estate taxes and municipal indebtedness.
Vigorous support of Cardinal Mundelein of Chicago in his defense of religious freedom in Germany was voiced today by the Catholic Press Association.

Miss Evelyn B. Adriance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Adriance of Maplewood, will be married on June 17 to Dr. E. Kenneth Miles, son of Mrs. Kirk Miles of Appleton, Wis., and the late Mr. Miles. The ceremony, which will take place in the Adriance home, will be performed by the Rev. Norman H. Sibley of Wyoming Presbyterian Church. Millburn.

WITH the opening of a Summer country camp for dogs, a new town bath club, and the improvement of other facilities for canine comfort, New York dogs can look forward to pleasant dog-days this season, whether they travel or stay at home.

The Robert E. Farley Organization reports a substantial demand in the rental of Summer cottages and the purchase of building sites at the Candlewood Lake Club in Brookfield, Conn., and at Timber Trails in Sherman, Conn. The clubhouse at Candlewood Lake has been completely renovated for the season.
ABBOTT-Elsa Hoxsey, wife of C. Westley Abbott, on May 21, 1937, at her home, Middle Brook, Ailsa Farms, Haledon N. J. Services at Haledon on Monday May 24, at 11 A. M. Interment private.

In the final competition of the thirty-fourth annual exhibition of the Ladies Kennel Association of America, Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N. J., president of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, today awarded the highest honors to a famous toy dog that has won innumerable victories in the past.

The hatchet that killed Mrs. Helen MacKnight in the kitchen of her Bayonne home last July 31 was held by Donald Wightman, Gladys MacKnight testified this morning at their joint trial for murder which at noon ended its sixth day in the court of oyer and terminer before Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a Jury.

IT is the springtide of the New York convention year, with congresses, conclaves, conferences. trade shows and the warmth of good fellowship all over town. In a few days, the writer understands, .we will see Earl Baldwin enter the House of Lords to take up a task for which he is eminently suited as an elder statesman and keeper of the national conscience.

A 17-year-old school girl, Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, drove on with the competitive spirit of a veteran today to win the women's Southern golf championship. She turned back Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Greensboro, N. C., one of the bestpoised competitors in the tournament, 2 and 1.

Minus the bitterness which characterized a meeting of their grandfathers seventy-four years ago, Colonel U. S. Grant of the United States Army and J. C. Pemberton, a lawyer of New York, clasped hands today in the shadow of the "Surrender Monument."

The President, who has a very good intelligence service-subject to the personal prejudices of its personnel-has known for a long time of Senator Joseph T. Robinson's ambition to end his public career as a member of the Supreme Court of the United States.

Miss Elizabeth Stone Gibbs was married here today to James Alexander Holloway in St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church by the Rev. Franklin Coleman Sherman of Cleveland. friend of the bridegroom's family.
Miss Margaret Louise Rusling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William James Rusling of Lansdowne, was married this afternoon to William Clendenin Pickett, son of Dr. Elizabeth Lovelace Pickett -of Aldan.
Big John, a son of Noel, and the national champion in 1935, staged a remarkable comeback to win the hunter championship of the Wilmington Horse Show which ended today.

The wedding of Miss Louise Viomack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Lillie of West Hartford, and Edwin Hall Lyman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Hall Lyman of Springfield, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents in the presence of relatives.

Miss Elizabeth Mellick Smyth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ayer Smyth of this city, has chosen the afternoon of June 18 as the date for her marriage to Dr. Frederic Geake Hirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton Pike Hirsch of Toledo, Ohio.

James D. Gill, art dealer, died here today after a long illness. His age was 87. He was one of the first to specialize in the works of American artists. Many artists first gained recognition at the annual February exhibition which he staged here for a full half century.

TWO years ago next September I arrived in Manhattan with fear and trembling for what the future miight have in store for me. Of one thing only could I be quite certain-that by joining forces with Miss Katharine Cornell I was in safe and kindly hands.

Pointing out that the accumulation of rook and sand in Westchester Creek eventually will interfere with navigation, the Bronx Board of Trade has requested the War Department to make an emergency appropriation for maintenance dredging in the channel. The sum required for the work, according to War Department estimates, is $30,000.

THE good old days have returned to Forest Hills. Around the ramparts of the big stadium in the Long Island suburb is the smell of fresh paint. Ticket booths and the flags of nations have been refurbished.

It was ten in a row and the second straight victory in the three-game series when the Maroon from Lafayette won a wierdly-played game from Lehigh today. Scoring in five of the nine innings, Lafayette rolled up the one-sided score of 15 to 7.

PLAYGROUND DIRECTOR (Temporary Service). Separate lists, men and women. Salary-Seasonal service at $4 a day. Vacancies-Occur from time to time in the Department of Parks. Ages-21 through 29, on June 7. Applications-Received 9 a. m., Friday,

A FEW weeks past Vice President John N. Garner, a group of Senators and two-score members of the House of Representatives watched a squadron of tiny pursuit planes set fire to a target at Langley Field, Va., headquarters of the General Headquarters Air Force.

Film actors, charging that strike pickets were molesting them, declared today that they would drive them from the studios. "Lay off molesting, intimidating or attempting to intimidate actors or we will get out a 'wreck crew' and run every picket away from the studios," was the ultimatum issued by the Screen Actors Guild.

Bill Gillespie, Scarborough School ace, captured the singles championship of the seventeenth annual Princeton interscholastic tennis tournament today by routing his unseeded team-mate, Don Buffington, 6--0, 6-2, in the final round.
HIS study of worship begins with a definite attack on what the author calls "all merely subjective and imma-nental explanations of Reality."

HERE is a romantic mystery novel in which the love story and the mystery walk hand in hand without either of them interfering in the least with the other. According to the pundits such a combination is all wrong,

The Mammoth Mines Corporation of Twin Bridges, Mont., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed issue of 100,000 shares of $1 par-value, noncumulative, preferred stock and 100,000 shares of 50-cent par-value common, for a total cash value of $150,000.

Mary Brophy of Brooklyn has been elected president of the student body of Marymount College here, it was announced today. She will be assisted in office by Joan Lalley, president of the senior class, and Margaic first councillor. Representatives to the student council will include Margaret A. Smith, Betty Fee, Jean Owens and Margaret Brown.
Seth W. Long, for eighteen years an instructor in civil engineering at Pennsylvania State College, died at the Centre County Hospital here last night. He was 42 years old.
The excellent playing of its captain, Peter Dominick, earned for Yale a 10-7 victory over Harvard on the Myopia Hunt Club polo field today.

Miss Jeanne Grandeman gave a buffet supper tonight at her home for Miss Sanchia Doorly and her fiance, Charles Lundgren, and Miss Mildred Smith and her fiance, Wilbur Ellmore. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Dana Carroll, Mr. and Mrs. Wilmot Losee, Mr. and Mrs. Norman E. Martin, Miss Natalie Hart, George Mattues and Thomas Losee.

Aided by sterling support, Carl Sherry, Providence pitcher, gave Holy Cross its first setback of the season today, 6 to 3, before of 3,000. Two fast double plays and sparkling catches by Crowley and Hazel in the outfield cut off Crusader runs. A home-run drive by Charlie Gallagher with two on in the third put Providence out in front.

The five-story building at 162 East Thirty-third Street, having a frontage of 25 feet and extending back 200 feet to Thirty-second Street, and the adjoining structure at 160 East Thirty-third Street, having a frontage and depth of 25 feet have been purchased by the Modernage Furniture Corporation which will merge them into one as a part of an expansion program.

The marriage of Miss Lois Swan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rockwell Swan of 435 East Fifty-second Street, New York, and Stillwaters Farm, this place, to Joseph de Forest Junkin 3d, son of Mrs. Erastus T. Tefft of New York and of Joseph de Forest Junkin Jr., took place at noon today in St. John's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Chierce.

As a result of the activities of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and its affiliated agencies, H. E. Hoagland, a member of the board, declared in a recent address that the need for emergency measures such as the refinancing operations of the Home Owners Loan Corporation would doubtless be minimized in the future.

The Osservatore Romano, semi-official Vatican newspaper, published reports from German Catholic sources today saying that eighteen Catholic printing plants have been seized by the Gestapo, the German State police.
The fulfillment of a $5,000 quota for Palestinian projects will be observed by the New York Unit of Junior Hadassah at a luncheon today in the Hotel Astor.

The plea of Louis Waldman, State chairman of the Social Democratic Federation, to Mayor La .Guardia to withdraw from the Republican party and run for re-election as the candidate of the American Labor party and the progressive city committee, was disclaimed yesterday by Luigi Antonini, State chairman of the American Labor party.

Seven Sweet Briar College students will spend their junior year studying at foreign universities. Three will go to France with the University of Delaware foreign study group and four to St. Andrews University in Sctland.

Five seniors of Russell Sage College are eligible for general honors and will be graduated cum laude this year, it was announced today by Dr. James Laurence Meader, president of the college. They are Betty Armitage,

Losing only four games in the two sets, Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., and New York teamed with Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France today to gain the final round of women's doubles in the French hard-court tennis championships.

An aggregation of football players who shone on college gridirons last Autumn will oppose the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds on the night of Wednesday, Sept. 8. The game will be played under the auspices of The New York Herald Tribune and the profits will be presented to the Tribune Fresh Air Fund, Inc.

Miss Ethel Leslie Primmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Primmer of Hillside, became the bride of Robert W. Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowland C. Johnston, also of this place, in St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

Dedication of a new Angelus bell for the chapel of Georgian Court College, tomorrow, will end the annual reunion of the National Alumnae Association. Rev. Thomas U. Reilly of Spring Lake, chancellor of the Trenton Diocese, will conduct the ceremony.

While M. V. Vodopyanoff was piotirig the Soviet Arctic explorers in a plane toward the North Pole yesterday, the premiere of his play," "The Dream," told a Moscow audience the seemingly fanciful story_ of Soviet fliers landing at the Pole.

The regular examination in freshman English, chiefly a composition course, was eliminated this week by the Williams College faculty in a move designed to make the study of more constructive value while at the same time lessening the examination burden.
A new suburban residential development known as Rose Valley Acres has been opened in the Moylan-Rose Valley section near the Pennsylvania Railroad station, in the Philadelphia suburban area.

Baby Salvy Saban, Greenwich Village welterweight, knocked out Ray Napolitano of Williamsburg in twenty-two seconds of the final round of their scheduled eightround bout at the Ridgewood Grove last night. Saban dropped his rival for counts in the first, seventh and eighth before Referee O'Sullivan intervened.
Miss tillie May Clarkson, daughter of a Mrs. Rutgers Clarkson of this city and the late Mr. Clarkson, has competed plans. for her marriage June 5 to Walter Edward Stager of Nutley.

Annual communion breakfast of the Board of Transportation and Independent Subway System Holy Name Society of New York, Hotel Astor, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. Joseph Daly, the Rev. William A. Cassidy, Frank Stevens, Charles V. Halley Jr.

Miss Phebe Root, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Root of this place, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Whitman Mead Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. R. Reynolds, also of Greenwich, in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, which was decorated with apple blossoms and white lilacs. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson.

ATHENS-For the first time, according to archaeological authorities here, science is able to throw light upon the nature of ancient Greek drapery, which hitherto has remained a mystery although its simple beauty has long been recognized and admired.

Marked sex differences appear in the reading tastes of elementary school children, adventure stories being highly popular with boys and fairy tales with girls, Dr. May Lazar, research assistant of the Board of Education disclosed yesterday in making public a survey on the reading interests of pupils in this city. Poetry was favored by one boy and twenty-five girls.

German film producers were reprimanded today in semi-official film organs for "being afraid of humor." The Film Courier says: "You do not get any nearer present realities with heavy-footed tendeniousness.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Ruth Elizabeth Norwood, daughter of Dr. J. Nelson Norwood, president of Alfred University, and Mrs. Norwood of Alfred, N. Y., to William H. Dennis of Rocky Hill, Conn.

Hope for an early settlement of the underground sit-down of coal miners here grew tonight when the strikers, who have refused for three days to come out of Superior Mine 4, agreed to permit their committee to meet tomorrow with company officials.
Another "no compromise" challenge was issued to the supporters of President Roosevelt's court reorganization program today by Senator Johnson of California.

Animal crackers for all passengers will be one of the features of the "jungle train" when it moves out of the North Station this afternoon. Elephant boys in native costume will go through the Boston Maine train to present the crackers as souvenirs of the ride.

Mrs. Louis Albert Sussdorff of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elsie Purdy Sussdorff, to Ernest Ellsworth Randall of this city and Dayton, Ohio, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Randall of Dayton.
MY feeling about the Spain in M which I have Just spent three months, mostly in and about Madrid, is that Spain is destroying itself in the moot shocking manner.

Dr. Danjo Ebina, Japanese Christian leader and president emeritus of the Christian Doshisha University at Kyoto, died today at the age of 81. Dr. Ebina made many visits to the United States and Great Britain and had scores of friends among American foreign mission and church leaders.

Miss Winnifred Emily Scott, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Beckett Scott of Auburndale, Mass., was married at noon yesterday to Dr. John Lyon Caughey Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. John Lyon Caughey of Glens Falls, N. Y., in the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, this City.
Alfred E. Smith fulfilled a life-long ambition and came to Europe today, with "time and money" to travel.

J. D. Tew, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, received $63,857 in 1936, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday. J. J. Newman, vice president, received $34,650, and David M. Goodrich, chairman of the board, $32,901.
Cornell's track forces won a close battle from Princeton today, 68 to 67, as J. Hamilton Hucker of the Ith. acans broke three dual meet records in the hurdles and 440-yard run.

A house divided worried Constable A. J. Bartholomew today. Charles Mehl, owner of the house, sued for recovery of two rooms of his three-room house. The January flood carried them onto the adjacent property of G. H. McAllister, who refused, Mr. Mehl asserted, to let him take them home.

Informed circles declare that negotiations for a new commercial treaty between Yugoslavia and the United States will begin in August. The present treaty, concluded between Serbia and the United States in 1881, needs drastic revision.

THIRD among our regional museums of the age of sail is the Penobscot Marine Museum recently established at Searsport, Me. The purpose of its founders is to collect and preserve the relics and memorabilia of the builders and masters of sail who hailed from the Penobscot Bay sector of the New England coast.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Edmund Beardslee Smith of Los Angeles of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Babcock Smith, to. Kyrill Sidney Schabert of this city, son of Baroness Faber du Faur of Florence, Italy, and the late Paul Schabert.

Behind the fine three-hit pitching of Luke Hamlin, the Dodgers today downed the Cardinals, 4--1, before a ladies' day crowd of 12,723 to push themselves back into fifth place and gain an even break in the short series.

To Middle Western farmers, head over ears at work getting a corn crop into the ground and making ready to fight grasshoppers, there came this week news that a plan to make secure their long-sought goal, parity, had finally been evolved at Washington.

Hard on the heels of a report by Chicago economists that food costs are now at their highest point since 1931-10 per cent higher than a year ago, 50 per cent higher than the low point of 1933-comes the assurance of government food experts that the peak has been reached for this year at least and that from now on retail prices will go down.

ASKIN-Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Askin (nee Alma Durst) announce the birth of a daughter, Wednesday, May 19, 1937, at Lenox Hill Hospital. BECKER--Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Becker announce the birth of a son, May 20, at Doctors Hospital.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Huntington of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Willard Huntington, to Charles Farrand Taplin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Taplin of Cleveland.

ALWAYS a favored objective for Memorial Day excursions, Gettysburg National Military Park acquires a special significance with the approach of the holiday this year. The traditional opening date of the visitors' annual season at the park will

The retirement of Joseph Cramer, veteran member of the buying staff of the Melville Shoe Corporation and the company's oldest employee in point of service, was announced yesterday by Ward Melville, president, following a luncheon in Mr. Cramer's honor at the Columbia University Club.

New England architecture has not been noticeably influenced by "modernism" and the charm of architectural designs of former days still holds sway, says William Riger Greeley of the Boston Society of Architects in a survey of trends made public through the American Institute of Architects.

Too much modesty on the part of engineers has prevented the proper recognition of the engineering profession as a vital influence in our present-day civilization, Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, State Superintendent of Public Works, declared yesterday.
While home buying throughout Westchester County continued at an active pace during the past week, an important deal was closed in New Rochelle which will result in a large business improvement.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding period and consisted principally of the retirement of entire issues of land bank and public utility bonds.

Smith College will hold its twentieth annual Float Night next Saturday. Participating for the first time, the Dance Group will present a series of eighteenth century Watteau pictures under flood lights in the Great Quadrangle. The theme will be a garden party.

ANOTHER type of marine architecture is being retrieved from disuse; a pinky is on the stocks of a shipyard at Millbridge, on the east coast of Maine. Pinkies have been so long non-existent that Henry Ford has found no specimen of these narrow-sterned schooners to place among his antiques,

THE historic Turkish Mosque of Banya Bashi, familiar to every one who has visited Sofia, is at last scheduled to be moved from Boulevard Maria Louisa, where it has blocked any number of plans for widening the thoroughfare and opening up the heart of the city. The Mousman plan, recently adopted by the Sofia City Council, definitely calls for the dismantling and removal of the ancient mosque to a new site on the city's outskirts.

URRENT at the Pennsylvania Museum in Philadelphia is an unusual exhibition called "Forms of Art," embodying "a fresh approach to-the understanding of the art of the past and of the present." It was organized by E. M. Benson, the wellknown critic and author, who has been at work upon the idea for several years.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Samuel Holmes of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elsie Holmes, to John Gregg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hayes Gregg, also of Montclair.

WASHINGTON. WERE Mr. Justice McReynolds to alter by a hair's breadth his intransigent attitude toward the New Deal, it would be a greater occasion for surprise than if Demosthenes had reversed himself and prepared a public reception in honor of Philip of Macedon.

Now that most of the regular planting has been completed and the garden is all set for a long period of colorful Summer bloom, it Is well to give a little consideration to Autumn, and even to next year's garden.

Josiah C. Read, grand marshal of the Memorial Day parade, and his staff will be honored at the annual testimonial dinner of the New York Unit of the Women's Overseas Service League, on Thursday at 7 P. M., at Schraffts, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street.

President R. H. Macy Co., Inc. Professor Robert S. Lynd in the Business Section of THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday gave a timely warning to the consumers' movement, which, as he pointed out, is entering a "critical next stage."

Simple business transactions entering into the calculation of taxable income sometimes give rise to troublesome litigation. Much of this is due to uncertainties in the application of rules governing the reporting of income and expenses on an annual basis.

The following Foreign Service changes since May 15 were announced by the State Department today: Alexander C. Kirk of Chicago. Counselor of the American Embassy at Rome, assigned Consul General at Singapore.

Cardinal Hayes ordained fortyeight young men to the priesthood in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday at a service which began at 8 A. M. and continued until almost noon. Four thousand persons attended.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 21 unless specified: At Mare Island Yard: Bridge Neches. At San Pedro: Sonoma. Kanawha. Pearl Harbor to San Francisco, May 20 Lexington Louisville. Badger, New London to Boston Yard, May 22.

The Valdina Farm's Eagle Pass, coupled in the betting as odds-on favorite with Valted, showed a sterling performance to account for the Au Revoir Handicap, feature attraction of the closing day of one of the most successful meetings in recent years at Churchill Downs.
The Valencia Government won a victory this week that should prove more worth while than any it could have won in the field.

THE youth of the world is going to war-two wars in two years, and who shall say there are not more to come? The dead lie buried over the plateaus of Ethiopia and Castille, but the ranks are never thinned. since men want to fight.

The secret political police arrested during the last week six Protestant pastors charged with attacking the State at church election assemblies. To date it has been impossible to discover whether they are in concentration camps.

Mr. and Mrs. Maurice L. Fleischman of 390 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pearl Fleischman, to Melvin A. Albert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis I. Albert, also of this city.
Henry T. Merrill, transatlantic flier, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Aeronautical Science from Pennsylvania Military College at commencement, June 7.

An assertion that Warren County and several other small counties up-State might lose their identity unless Republicans controlled the constitutional convention next year was made here by the Republican State Chairman, William S. Murray, addressing a gathering today of 200 men and women of the party.

Dr. Jacob Gould Schurman, former United States Ambassador to Germany and former president of Cornell University, celebrated his eigthy-third birthday tonight at a party in the home of a son and M daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs.
M ARKET stands have undergone a considerable change as warmer weather has advanced on the city. Here Summer is putting on a preview of her garden and orchard produce for Manhattan housewives.

Fresh from three weeks of mimic aerial warfare, the chief of the Army Air Combat Forces today declared the nation's aerial defense was inadequate. Major Gen. Andrews, director of the sham bombing and strafing that theoretically almost leveled Los Angeles, said:

The Soviet Union claimed the North Pole as its own today to have and to hold forever on the grounds that it was the first to establish a permanent settlement in the vicinity. [Washington authorities said the North Pole region could not be annexed by the Soviet Union because there was no land, only international water covered by ice.]

Miss Alice Marble's bid for her first 1937 tennis title ended in failure today when the San Francisco girl, holder of the American crown, was beaten by Miss Freda James of England, 6-4, 6-3, in the final round of the Surrey championship.

Miss Eleanor Hooper Eastman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Eastman of 96 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, has chosen June 13 as the date for her marriage to Jay Alan Abercrombie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Abercrombie of Denver.

Through the aid of the Works Progress Administration new teaching techniques and demonstration materials have been developed in the New York City schools which have become a vital part of the educational system, George H. Chatfield, director of the Bureau of Child Welfare and Attendance, stated yesterday.

Harold T. Donaldson, president of the United States Building and Loan League, reports that during the first quarter of this year the savings, building and loan asociations of the country sold to new family-owners about 18,500 homes which had been taken over by those organizations during the worst years of the depression.

There was much ado about a rhesus monkey on Park Row yesterday morning. Persons with business at City Hall, old-fashioned tourists with an eye for the Woolworth Building and hundreds of those who work in the neighborhood dropped what they were doing and joined the pursuit.

While the Navy band played "It Ain't Gonna Rain No More," a rainstorm of near gale force lashed the Marine Base here today and prevented the annual baseball game between Congressmen and Washington newspaper correspondents, which was to have been started with President Roosevelt throwing out the first ball.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today a large increase in exports of newsprint in April, compared with the same month last year. Exports last month totaled 5,055,809 hundredweight, valued at $9,217,217, compared with 3,857,876, valued at $6,653,098, a year before.

Miss Elizabeth Elliott Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Gordon Wilson of this city and the late Dr. Wilson, has chosen the afternoon of June 12 for her marriage to Dr. Herbert Budington br Wilcox Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Wilcox of New York.

Fuller St (15-3996) s e s. 375 ft n e of Berega Ave, 37x95; Kingston Savings Bank to Natale Fratarcangeli, 2,432 Fuller St. Story Ave (14-3698-14-3702), s w cor of Zerega Ave, 91x103 ft, also Zerega Ave, e s, at center line of 3d St, 266x323; Westchester Creek Corp to Exner Realty Corp. 441 E 109th St.

FAMILIAR classics and compositions of a modernistic cast stand cheek by jowl on the majority of the ten programs arranged by Carlos Chavez for the season of ten weekly concerts of the Symphony Orchestra of Mexico, which The will conduct in Mexico City July 2 to Sept. 10.

The Federal Trade Commission ordered today a group of radio dealers and manufacturers, together with certain manufacturers of name-plates and emblems, to stop manufacturing and using "as marks or brands on their products certain wellknown and long-established names of other manufacturers and dealers in the. radio and like industries without consent of the lawful owners of such names."

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Gilder Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Martin of this place, to John Bartol Dunning, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Bartol Dunning of Upper Montclair, N. J., will take place here on June 19 in the Presbyterian Church of Rye. The Rev. Charles G. Sewall, former pastor of the church, will perform the ceremony.
Listed Securities, Inc., of Jersey City, has filed with the Securties and Exchange Commission a proposed offering at the market of $6,750,000 in 25-cent par value common stock.

The engagement of Miss Elisabeth Stearns Bradford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Bradford of Scarsdale, N. Y., to Robert Handley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Handley, also of Scarsdale, has been announced by her. parents.

Startling shifts in store operating plans and in food distributing methods are expected to follow the Supreme Court decision last week in the Louisiana chain store tax case, brought by the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company and several other chain store systems, according to the bulletin issued yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution.

Decisive victories gave Lawrenceville School a sweep of three contests with its traditional rival, the Hill School, today and made the sports portion of Lawrenceville's alumni week-end a complete success.
Nearly 250 members and guests attended the opening dinner dance of the season at the Round Hill Club tonight. Among those who had reservations and entertained guests were:

A number of corrective measures must be instituted by general business if it is to succeed in its growing desire to "sell' itself to the American public and to protect itself from attacks by government, labor, consumer groups or the socalled radical element, industrial leaders, advertising executives and others agreed here yesterday.

INTEREST in radio, either as a cultural force or as entertain ment, is if anything decreasing, according to a Cambridge student, who reports his observations on "why undergraduates don't listen," in a discussion in The Radio-Times, journal of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

The prospect of losing. completely or winning a questionable battle and at the same time winning the war seemed to face President Roosevelt this week in his history-making fight to remake the Supreme Court.
GENEVIEVE TAGGARD began publishing poetry when poets were romantic individualists, some, like herself, going in for reform. In those days

Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, in a petition filed today with Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan, recommended that a claim of $850,355 held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation against the closed Jefferson Trust Company of Hoboken be compromised for a book credit of $650,000. The court will pass on the proposal on June 1, the commissioner said.
Miss Joyce Crandon Plumb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Plumb of Berwyn, was married this afternoon to Nicholas Waln Morris, wellknown aviator and son of Mrs. Alfred Paul Morris of Villanova.
More than 600 Columbia Univer class of 1865, will be in the front line of Columbia's annual commencement procession, which will wind its way to the degree awarding ceremony on Tuesday, June 1.
Standing on the old Capitoline Hill. Premier Mussolini addressed the third National Assembly of Corporations on Saturday. Through this assembly,

In behalf of the New Society of American Sculptors, Sonia Gordon Brown has written a letter to Frederick A. Sterling, United States Commissioner for the Paris International Exposition, protesting , against the omission of sculpture from the exhibition of contemporary American art in the American Pavilion at the Fair.

Long George Campione, sophomore pinch hitter, ended thirteen innings of a thrilling baseball game yeste-day as he singled to drive in Mike Stelmach from third with the winning tally, giving New York University a 5-to-4 decision over Long Island University at Ohio Field.
Mortgages Realty Service, Inc., real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company, as agent for various individual and institutional investors, reports the following sales: In Kings County,

For the first time in thirty-four years, the outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A., the oldest track body in America, will be held in New York when the sixty-first annual title games are staged at the new municipal stadium at Randalls Island on Friday and Saturday.
Properties held by the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York for the benefit of certificate holders are enjoying a ready market, the commission announced yesterday. The demand is marked
Wherever the writ of the Nanking Supreme Court runs it is now settled doctrine that religious freedom exists in Soviet Russia. A wealthy Russian woman

The curtain will descend on social activities at Cornell University next Saturday with the observance of Spring Day.
H. R. Tolley, Soil Conservation Administrator, said today that Senator Vandenberg had made "baseless accusations against the farmers' AAA conservation program" in a recent Senate speech.

ALMOST simultaneously, two volumes of political philosTrophy have appeared in this country by Spanish writers. One, "Invertebrate Spain," by Jos .Ortega y Gasset, was reviewed in these columns two weeks ago;

Ever since taking office in 1934 Mayor La Guardia has discouraged people from sending gifts to him.. He thinks most senders of gifts have ulterior motives. But the other day, from the Pacific Coast, a large box of juicy California oranges arrived at City Hall for the Mayor's staff-sent by the Mayor himself from Los Angeles. They were quickly consumed.
Cornell's lightweight crew pulled away from Pennsylvania's 150-pounders to a 2 1/2-length victory over the Henley distance on Cayuga Inlet today.
Diagnosticians for the ailments of the Christian religion are on their way to the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School at Rochester, to attend a four-day "clinic."

The marriage of Miss Anne Thomas Stewart, daughter of John A. Stewart 3d of this place, to T. Wilkinson Satterthwaite Jr., son of Mrs. Weeks Satterthwaite of New York and of T. Wilkinson Satterthwaite, will take place here on the afternoon of June 10 at the home of her grandfather, John A. Stewart Jr.

The two-story brick taxpayer at the northeast corner of Kingston Avenue and Union Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Seamen's Bank for Savings to the B. I. M. Realty Corporation. It is on a plot 100 by 40 feet and contains seven stores and lofts. Fully rented,

An increase during April in the number of workers leaving the WPA rolls for outside employment was cited yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local administrator, as an indication that "the relief worker is alive to the current upswing in private industry and is getting himself a regular job when a favorable opportunity offers."

NATURE lovers are awaiting the outcome of a dramatic battle now being waged in Congress over one of this country's most superb remaining primeval forests-the Carl Inn tract of sugar pines bordering the Yosemite National Park in California.

Commencement activities at Stevens Institute of Technology here will take place on June 10, 11 and 12, it was announced today. The trustees will hold their annual commencement meeting on Thursday, June 10, after which they will attend a tea at the home of Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the college.
The Eleventh Engineers Veterans Association celebrated its twentieth anniversary last night at a dinner held at the Merchant's Restaurant, 72 Park Place. The regiment,

Mrs. William Gordon Mathews of this city has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Helen Clayton Mathews, to Taylor Langston Palmer, son of Mrs. T. O. Palmer of Suffolk, Va. The wedding will take place on June 16 at the home of the bride-elect's mother.

The program for senior week and the 171st anniversary commencement of Rutgers University, in the college gymnasium, on June 13, was announced today by President Robert C. Clothier. This is the first time in the history of the university that commencement ceremonies will be held on a Sunday.

PARIS. IT is now possible for American travelers in France to eat, sleep and reside temporarily in the chateau in which the Marquis MarieJoseph de Lafayette was born-the Chateau Chavaniac-Lafayette, 400 miles south of Paris in Auvergne. Fifteen rooms with bath have been equipped for the accommodation of American tourists.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Max J. Ortman of 680 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor J. Ortman, to Ralph H. Wiener, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Wiener, also of this city.
The Associate Alumnae of Hunter College will hold its fourth annual Spring formal dance on June 5, in the social hall of the Bronx buildings of the college, Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue.

The marriage of Miss Julia Dolce Bastedo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orrin W. Bastedo of this city and Scarsdale, N. Y., to Henry G. Paulson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Paulson of Union City, N. J.,
Yale's big varsity eight headed for New London and Harvard tonight with its Blue banner still nailed at the masthead of victory.
Mrs. Frere Kemper of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Frances Kemper, to John Martyn Gunn, son of Mrs. Alice Townsend Gunn of Boston, and the late Percy Pickard Gunn.

New York women, to many of whom the Federal Industrial Institution for Women at Alderson, W. Va., is an experiment in social reconstruction rather than a triumph of penology, will be well represented at the tenth anniversary celebration scheduled for Alderson on Saturday.

The Princeton freshman nine today defeated Yale, 5 to 1, in their annual game. Pitcher Schweizer not only held the Yale batsmen to five hits but hit a home with Foote and Bordley on the bases in the fifth inning. Jackson for Yale fanned

FIRST experimental transport flights over the Atlantic for Bermuda will start before the end of this month, probably sometime during the final week. On that day the U. S. A. Bermuda Clipper, an S-42B, will take off from Pan American's temporary f service base, at Port Washington, L. I., on the first of a series of exploratory flights over the several Atlantic courses between terminal sites along the Atlantic seaboard and the islands of Bermuda.

Advertising problems, new food and drug legislation, the campaign against the "discriminatory" manufacturers' excise tax, the situation of the industry with respect to recent fair-trade legislation and developments connected with the establishment of a board of standards will be featured topics of discussion at the second annual convention of the Toilet Goods Association, Inc.,

Piet van Kempen of the Netherlands and Henri Buysse of Belgium won London's six-day bike race tonight, beating Emile Diot and Emile Ignat of France and Al Crossley and Jimmy Walthour of the United States by the margin of points scored in sprints.

Prizes totaling about $2,300 are offered in the tenth annual smallhome competition of House Beautiful, details of which were announced yesterday. Architects and architectural designers are eligible. They may submit photographs and floor plans of houses within the past three years.
Is Woman's Place in the Home?" was debated here last night by representatives of Adelphic Union from Williams College and Elmira College students. The Elmira debaters

WHAT about getting ready for the big game season? It is about to swing into full activity. The onlooker, as well as the players, must be prepared to be in good form. There are no end of ways in which the spectator can score. Her best stroke is to wear something that will keep her looking well not only until the game has been played and won, but until she gets back home.

PLEA: "Instead of improving the breed of dogs, let us do something to improve the environment of our youths,"Judge. Charles Colden. NO BAR: "One does not cease to be a farmer because drought or wind or pest may have rendered the farm barren."-Jwstice Cardozo.
Mount Holyoke College undergraduates held tonight their formal Spring dance in the Chapin Auditorium, as a climax to the annual field day events. More than 350 couples were present in the auditorium.

President Roosevelt virtually completed his message on wages and hours legislation today, and a bill carrying out its recommendations will be introduced immediately after its delivery to Congress, probably on Monday.

The 1,549 members of the Chicago Board of Trade will be asked to assess themselves $150 apiece for each of. the next four years in order to carry out a program for refinancing the $10,218,000 first mortgage on the Board of Trade Building.

A. plan for general examinations in major subjects, designed to give the students a broad view of their major subject as a unit, has been adopted at Connecticut College and will go into effect in 1939 for the class of 1939.

Officials of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service announced yesterday the fifteen prize winners in the organization's contest among art students in the high schools of Manhattlan, the Bronx and Queens for the best posters symbolizing a Henry Street visiting nurse.

In an effort to provide a basis for the "scientific" management and appraisal of real properties, the Institute of Real Estate Management of-the National Association of Real Estate Boards will make a national study of the relation between income and maintenance cost of buildings, Harry A. Taylor, president of the institute, said in an address before the recent Central Atlantic regional convention of the association here.

A NEW and powerful 200-kilowatt transmitter is being tested at Radio Central at Rocky Point, L. I., for overseas communication. The engineers of the Radio Corporation of America, who made the installation, report the power to be five times the amount heretofore used for a shortwave transoceanic circuit.
Mrs. Dodge Sloane was hostess tonight at a large supper dance at Brookmeade, her estate on the Latingtown Road, a party that has become an annual aftermath of the running of the Withers at Belmont.

Jimmy Snyder, the Chicago milkman turned race driver, stole the show at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today by setting an amazing record of 130.492 miles an hour for a single lap before a crowd of 10,000.

One-year enlistments of young men between the ages of 18 and 21 years for the West Point Preparatory School opening at Camp Dix, N. J., on July 1 have been authorized by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding general of the Second Corps Area.

James Monroe, White House occupant from 1817 to 1825, made no Supreme Court appointment during his first term of office, a distinction enjoyed by no other full-term President until Franklin D. Roosevelt took his New Deal to Washington. Mr. Roosevelt
James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, was guest of honor last night at the forty-first anniversary dinner of the Unity Club in the organization's quarters, Grant Square, Brooklyn.

Miss Sarah Elizabeth Best, daughter of Mrs. Gilbretta D. Best of Stanhope, N. J., was married here yesterday afternoon to Arthur Birger Johanson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Johanson of this city, in the Broadway Presbyterian Church, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb.

AMERICAN travelogue shortwave broadcasts, on the air weekly since March over W2XAF and W2XAD, Schenectady, have proved so successful that the series will be extended another twenty weeks and continue until November.

Myron Higbee of Idaho is in training here to conquer new worlds as a log sawyer at the opening of the Golden Gate bridge in San Francisco. His big cross-cut saw goes swish four times and sinks another inch into a redwood log, 38 inches across.

The British Broadcasting Company blushed to the tips of its corporate ears today as all London echoed with goodnatured taunts the exclamation "The fleet is all lit up!" which was all an unfortunate radio announcer could think of to describe the illumination of the fleet at Spithead.

A parade of 400 Boy and Girl Scouts through downtown Manhattan and exercises in Battery Park yesterday afternoon marked the annual tribute of the Columbus Volunteers of America to their members who died during the World War.
