To the Music Editor: The advancement of our musical culture can be seen from the progress which has been made in the establishment of symphonies in many of our greatest cities, with widespread efforts at present to organize and initiate women's symphonies. I would like to suggest

The village of Freeport, L. I., was originally known as Raynortown, states Justice Hilbert R. Johnson, who has made an extensive study of Nassau County history. The present name, he says, came from the fact that for many years it was virtually a "free port," as sailing vessels could come in directly from the ocean through Jones Inlet and land their cargo without paying.
Brokers and builders in practically all of the New Jersey suburban centers in the metropolitan territory report that since the beginning of May a decided impetus has been noticed in home demand.

The Princeton baseball team averted the possibility of dropping into the Eastern Intercollegiate League cellar today by sweeping both ends of a double-header from Cornell, 5-3 and 9-5, before-1,200 on University Field.

TWELVE automobiles have started from Detroit on a 25, 000-mile "road laboratory" test arranged by the Texas Company in cooperation with the chief engineers of motor factories.. The 1937 Texaco national road test is the second annual drive for the collection of information pertaining to lubrication and fueling and to performance of the oars themselves.

More than 500 persons, half of whom motored from New York, today visited the gardens of Caumsett, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field at Lloyds Neck. The fee charged at the gates was for the funds of the Greenwich House Health Center.

The Accident Board of the Bureau of Air Commerce today made public the results of its investigation of the three fatal private airplane accidents, one in November at Noverino, N. Y., in which Pilot John H. Shobe of Boston and two passengers were killed; one near

Bancroft Smith of 100 Montague Street, Brooklyn, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and of the brokerage firm of Leopold Spingarn Co., 29 Broadway, died Friday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness which included an operation. He was 66 years old.
A watch all along the coast was kept up today for the America's Cup yacht Endeavour, but no sign of her was reported. It has been eight

Latest estimates place the number of refugees from Germany at present in other European countries at 35,500, according to a report of the American Joint Distribution Committee, made public yesterday. Of this number about 29,

A survey of real estate activity during the first three months of the year in Pittsburgh and the Allegheny County section of Pennsylvania by the business research bureau of the University of Pittsburgh calls attention to a new low level record in residential vacancies, a marked impetus in building activity and a volume of real estate sales in that period aggregating $11,500,00,000 as compared with about $7,000,000 for the similar period one year ago.

Mr. and rector Mrs. Irwin Laughlin gave a dinner dance this evening in honor of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Laughlin. Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent and Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall of Philadelphia were the guests in whose honor Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bell Sweeney entertained at dinner this evening.

Mrs. Walter E. O'Hara's Araho Lass won the Old Colony Stakes, a five-furlong dash for 2-year-olds, by a neck at Narragansett Park today, defeating W . C. Stroube's Huskie Boy. The latter had only a head on C. H. Trotter's Historic Era. The time was 0:594-5.

IN spite of the fact that so many people play contract bridge, I most attempts to produce a good radio program about bridge have proved disappointing. The' principal difficulty has been the same as that facing bridge lecturers.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that stipulations had been entered into by fifteen companies and individuals agreeing to discontinue "false and misleading representations in advertising concerning therapeutic value of the medicinal preparations they sell in interstate commerce."

The daring Captain Gabriele Rossetti, noted anti-Fascist who was one of the few ever to escape from the Lipari prison islands, has taken a high command in the Spanish Loyalist fleet, it was reported here today.

A youth identified as Joseph Fea, 22 years old, of 36-51 Twentyeighth Street, Astoria, Queens, was shot in the head and wounded critically by a patrolman early this morning at Twenty-eighth Street and Thirty-seventh Avenue, Astoria. He had drawn a revolver while fleeing, the police charged.

Mr. and Mrs. Bertram F. Thompson of this place have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Estelle Thompson, to Robert F. Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Staley of Port Washington and New York.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lydig Ebsen of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Margaret Ebsen, to John Lewis Buckley, son of Mrs. Cornelia Lewis Buckley of Tenafly, N. J., and the late Major Thomas J. Buckley.
One of the heaviest dust mantles of the season, which showered d sand and silt over more than half of New Mexico last night, began to lift today.

With the final examination period beginning Tuesday and commencement week ahead, the student body, honorary fraternities, clubs and publications staffs of the College of William and Mary have sought to bring to a close their year's activities and have held elections for next year.

Striking employes of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, which announced yesterday that it was closing its Detroitdivision as "unprofitable," addressed an appeal for help tonight to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. The plant made locks for automobiles.

Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., reports that work has started on the Arnold Snowe residence on Braxmar Drive North, and on the Jane K. French residence, at the end of Braxmar Lane, in Winfield Glen, Harrison, N. Y.

dian Press).-This was the Bonduro family's day in court. Steve Bonduro was sent to the reformatory for from six to twelve months for receiving stolen tools, although he pleaded he was to be married soon.

For the benefit of the Police Athletic League, a police show will be held at Madison Square Garden on June 2, 3 and 4, beginning at 8:30 o'clock each night. Various phases of police activity will be demonstrated.

A dog's life in the city is not so blad after all, in the opinion of Mrs. George Bethune Adams, who is the guiding spirit of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital, run by the New York Women's League for Animals at 350 Lafayette Street.

Dr. Herbert Ellsworth Slaught, Professor Emer- I itus of Mathematics at the University of Chicago, died last night in his home at 5,548 Kenwood venue. He was 76 years old. Dr. Slaught was widely known for his books on mathematics.

Mr. and Mrs. Jaires A. Macart of East Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss to Ruth Elizabeth Macart, to Preston H. Hadley Jr., of Newark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston H. Hadley of Bellows Falls, Vt.

T. M. Schumacher, chairman of the board of the Denver Rio Grande Western and chairman of the executive committee of the Western Pacific, described conditions in Colorado, Utah, Nevada and California as exceedingly favorable, on his return yesterday from an inspection of the two railroads.
The last in the annual series of garden days conducted by the School Nature League will take place -on Wednesday, when the gardens of three country estates on Long Island will be opened to visitors.

James W. Gerard, President Roosevelt's representative at the coronation, will be the guest of honor at a dinner on June 7 in the House of Commons to be given by Lord Phillimore and members of the imperial policy group. The Duchess of Hamilton welcomed Mr. Gerard and other distinguished coronation visitors at a luncheon given by the Travel Club at Price's Restaurant.

Labor warfare between the teamsters and the longshoremen has become one of the bitterest interunion combats in the history of the Far West. It no longer is a clash to decide which group will have jurisdiction over warehouse workers.
The Red Sox re-focused their batting eyes today and clouted four Tiger pitchers for fourteen hits, three of them home runs, to defeat Detroit, 11 to 9.

Rolling up a total of 70 points, Coach Lou Werner's Newtown High School athletes won the team championship for the fifth year in a row at the thirty-third annual Queens Public Schools Athletic League track and field games at Jamaica High yesterday. It also marked the thirteenth time in the last fifteen years that Newtown has won.

Miss Laura J. Walden, executive secretary for the Union County Hospital Tuberculosis League, died today in Muhlenburg Hospital after an operation. She was born in Eatontown, N. J., and was 46 years old. After her graduation from

The league-leading Pirates made use of a three-run rally in the seventh inning today to down the Bees, 5 to 2. The victory evened the Boston series and kept intact the Pirates' record of not having lost two straight this season.

An elaborate funeral service was held here today for Dr. Enrique Olaya Herrera, former President of Colombia, who died in Rome on Feb. 18. The half-mile funeral cortege followed two days of homage with all Bogota and provincial delegations at the bier.

POINTING out that motor fatalities in eighty-five major cities are running 28.per cent ahead of last year, the American Automobile Association said last week that affiliated motor clubs in all sections were launching vigorous program for strict enforcement of motor laws.

Independent steel corporations opposed to the Steel Workers Organizing Committee were reported today as hastening preparations for the showdown in the next week or two with the union forces now further encouraged by their victory in the elections just completed in the Jones Laughlin Corporation plants.

Sergeant Major Joseph Krejza, a Czech, was executed by a firing squad at dawn today as a Hungarian spy. The execution, carrying out a death sentence decreed Feb. 22 by the army division court, was the first for betrayal of military secrets in the nation's history.

Miss Miriam R. Ephraim, director of activities for the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of Pittsburgh, was elected president today of the National Association of Jewish Center Workers. She is the first woman in its twelve years to head the association, which is one of the three member groups of the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare.

Estate. less than $10,000. To Elizabeth McGuire, sister, Fermanagh, Ireland, residue; two minor bequests. Bank of Manhattan Co., 40 Wall St., executor. MAY, DOROTHY T. (April 22). Estate, more than $5,000. To Rose A. McGuire, 2,290 Andrews Ave., Bronx, and Catherine V. Curran, 560 W. 192d St., equal shares in residue. George J. Smith, son, executor. Providence. R. I.

LAST week a silvery streak of stainless steel sped out of Los Angeles, climbed swiftly over the Arizona Rockies, up the old Santa Fe Trail and across Kansas, taking in a corner of the dust bowl, and hit Chicago for a new rail record between the two cities2,228 miles at more than a mile a minute.

Twenty-six hundred persons braved a driving rain tonight to hear the Philadelphia Orchestra and a'choral group of 335 voices in the American premiere of "Festival Overture," played from the manuscript of Cyril Scott, British composer, the third and final night program of the thirteenth annual Westchester music festival at the county center.

The Times-Dispatch said tonight that the discovery of a hitherto overlooked law of the Methodist Episcopal Church South had "virtually dissipated" hope for early adoption by that church of the unification plan, already approved by the Methodist Episcopal Church and the Methodist Protestant Church.

According to William Lescaze, New York architect, there has been no architecture in this country deserving of the name during the last one hundred years. In a recent address to the Friends of the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration, he said that "designing buildings has become a genteel game of looking at pictures in books and trying to fit our needs into these pictures."

PENNSYLVANIA'S first traffic officers training school, con ducted under the auspices of the Pennsylvania State College, will become an annual event on the campus as the college prepares to bring its services even closer to municipal and State governments.
For over an hour this afternoon Walter Merrill Hall, former president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, gave Martin Buxby and Elmer Cook a lesson in tennis tactics and steadiness.
Close of play scores in first class English cricket matches started today follow: Yorkshire 368 for four wickets (Barber 103, not out; Mitchell 88, Sutcliffe 69, Turner 60) vs. Sussex, at Sheffield.

Miss Helen Elizabeth Wallis, daughter of Mrs. Hamilton Wallis of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Mr. Wallis, has completed plans for her marriage to Lyle A. Christensen of East Orange, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Austra Christensen of Mankato, Minn., which

Thousands of men, women and children picketed the offices of the Works Progress Administration at 70 Columbus Avenue yesterday to indicate their belief that the $1,500,000,000 appropriation which the House of Representatives has fixed as the Federal Relief Bill for the fiscal year 1938 is too small.

THE AMERICAN THEATRE COUNCIL--The first convention of those working for and interested in the theatre will be held at the Astor Hotel starting tomorrow. The program, subject to the usual convention shifting, will be: TOMORROW--Luncheon at 12:30 P. M., with an address of welcome by Helen Hayes and short talks by Frank Gillmore, Sidney Howard, Marcus Heiman, Fred Marshall and James J. Brennan. At 2:30 P. M. is the first general
Charles C. Shoemaker, who founded the Penn Publishing Company fifty-six years ago and had been its president ever since, died today in the Bryn Mawr Hospital of a heart ailment at the age of 76.

This week will bring the second anniversary of one of the Supreme Court's most momentous decisions-the unanimous invalidation, on May 27, 1935, of the New Deal's attempt to regulate wages, hours and business practices through the National Industrial Recovery Act.
May lakes grain freighter William J. Conners put back to port so that a trapped grain trimmer could be saved from suffocation in the hold was told today by Captain Thomas Stevenson.

BY far the most thrilling spectacle we have seen in over 7,000 miles of journeying-or ever expect to see-is the underworld called Carlsbad Caverns, hidden deep beneath the scorching desert of New Mexico.
Mrs. Woodrow Wilson, widow of the President, is expected to attend the dedication of the new Woodrow Wilson Memorial Room of the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirtyninth Street, on Tuesday afternoon.
Athletics Top White Sox in 11th; Red Sox Vanquish Tigers by 11-9

Bonds held steady to firm yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the dullest trading since Aug. 22, last. Total transactions amounted to only $3,863,400, compared with $4,043,500 on the preceding Saturday.

Miss Frances Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Hall of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to William Franklin Eldridge, son of Shirley H. Eldridge of Waltham, Mass., and the late Mrs. Eldridge, which will take place here on June 19 in the First Presbyterian Church.
Aircooled soldiers will be a necessity in any future war in warm countries, a physician said today, if their fighting ability is to be kept up to par.
Dr. Frederick A. Cook, former ex- E plorer, said tonight he was confi- t dent Russian scientists at the North Pole would substantiate his claim of being the first white man to reach the Pole.

American Gas and Electric Company-Twelve months to March 31: Net profit after all deductions, $12,357,891, equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.28 a share earned on 4,482,737 common shares, against $10,735,588, or $1.91 a common share, the year before;

THE Daniel Guggenheim memorial concerts will be held on the Mall in Central Park and in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, under Edwin Franko Goldman opening June 16. A different type of program will be offered at each event. Some of the schedules
Newark strengthened its position at the head of the International League by downing Baltimore, 8 to 4, today for its fifth straight victory. It was the Orioles' seventh consecutive setback.
Eulace Peacock rounded out his dual meet career by helping Temple University defeat Manhattan College at the Temple Stadium today, 77-58, to climax the Owls' most successful track season in history.

Over a mile course on the Harlem River yesterday, Manhattan's varsity crew registered a three-length victory over the Williams eight. The visitors, making their first appearance in this vicinity, are not official representatives of the college, since the sport is not recognized there as yet.
Miss Josephine Pomeroy Stelwagon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Stelwagon of Merion, was married this afternoon to William 0. Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Jackson of Brookline.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Harry G. Currie of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Gordon Currie, to Wilson F. Reeder of Newark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay W. Reeder of Norwalk, Ohio.

The fair trade practice bureau of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board has conducted 4,225 examinations of manufacturers' books in behalf of trade regulation observance in the New York area alone during the two years of the existence of the board, the anniversary of which will occur on Thursday, it was announced yesterday

-When able-bodied men of this town responded to an S O S call sent out the other night by the selectmen and installed a 2,500-pound safe in the Beach Hill home of Mrs. Alfred S. Beach, town clerk, she was practically elected to the office for life.

American furniture, silver and lmu other lots from the collections of op Miss Ella Parsons of Philadelphia Rc and others will be auctioned at the of American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.

The Atlantic Beach Club at Atlantic Beach, L. I.; will inaugurate its eighth consecutive season with a dinner dance Saturday night. The party will constitute the informal opening of the club, and from next Sunday on all the facilities of the place will be available.

Closing of about half of the hog alleys on Monday in the Chicago stockyards was announced today by the Union Stockyard and Transit Company because of small receipts caused by high feed prices and a liquidation of hog supplies on farms.
By unanimous vote at their convention here today, nearly 200. members of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women pledged themselves to qualify and serve on juries next Fall.

Some interesting and suggestive facts are contained in a survey of taxation in the United States being made for the Twentieth Century Fund by a research staff under the direction of Professor Carl Shoup of the Columbia University department of business administration. In some extracts

A sense of permanency and security is the outstanding contrast between ownership of a private house and rental of an apartment, according to L. B. Elliman Jr., who adds that a house purchased at a price somewhat less than the aggregate of two years' rent will provide a permanent home.

Plans have been completed for the Spring festival of the Woman's Board of the Church Charity Foundation of Long Island to be held Thursday at the Home for the Aged, 452 Herkimer Street,.Brooklyn. The tea room will be in charge

When the gates of Giralda Farms in Madison, N. J, are opened at 9 o'clock Saturday morning, dog fanciers of the world will be privileged to enter and for eight hours enjoy and thrill to the ceaseless and vivid activities of the greatest outdoor canine exhibition ever to be staged in any land.

Miss Dorothea Grace Eggers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto R. Eggers of this place, was married here today to Frank A. Tichenor Jr., son of Mrs. Lillian Stott Tichenor of New York and of Frank A. Tichenor of Mamaroneck, in St. Augustine's Church.

Miss Kathleen Antoinette Buse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Buse of Plainfield, and Richard Lesie Beals, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen F. Beals of North Plainfield, were married this afternoon by the Rev. Dr. L. W. Warren of the First Presbyterian Church in this city. Mrs. Willard L. Tunison...

ABRAMSON-DIAMOND-Mrs. Rose Diamond, widow of the late Abraham J. Diamond, announces the marriage of their daughter, Ruth, to Mr. Joseph Abramson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Abramson, to take place May 29.

One of the loveliest of German fairy tales is "The Blue Flower" by Novalis. Outside fairyland real blue flowers are not plentiful. Experiments have shown that blue is the favorite color with bees, after which come in order of preference white, yellow, red, green, orange.

Announcement of the award of the Daniel Guggenheim Medal to Dr. HUGO ECKENER for his "notable contributions "to transoceanic air transport and to "international cooperation in aeronau" tics" was happily timed.
The Brooklyn Edison Company and the Shelter Island Light and Power Company filed lower rate schedules yesterday with the Public Service Commission.

The body of an unidentified woman, about 40 years old, was discovered floating in the Harlem River at the foot of 179th Street, the Bronx, shortly after noon yesterday. It was removed to the Fordham Morgue.

Fifty-nine women, wearing white capes and carrying pennants, marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon to celebrate the 120th anniversary of the Rush-Bagot agreement, which in 1817 disarmed the 3,000-mile frontier between Canada and the United States.

Likening education to a contract, Dr.'Paul Swain Havens, at his inauguration today as thirteenth president of Wilson College, pointed to the duty of both student and college to live up to such a pact.

The twenty-week course in real estate appraising, offered jointly by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers and the Division of General Education of New York University, has been concluded.

PITTSFIELD, Mass.--Sportsmen are looking forward to the open season on rainbow trout, yellow perch, pickerel and horned out at Onota Lake, Pittsfield, which starts next Sunday. Within the past year the Pittsfield Sportsmen's Club has placed in the lake 7,000 rainbow trout varying in strength from seven to ten and onealf inches. Next to Big Pond in tis, Onota Lake is the largest natral body of water in Berkshire;

Former Champion Paul Runyan and Eddie Williams, with 70s, set the pace today for professional golfers who practiced under a blistering sun preparing for the annual national P. G. A. championship starting Monday over the Field Club course.
The Senate ' committee investigating railroad financing announced today that it would resume hearings on Monday. These witnesses have been subpoenaed: Carl Weisheit, formerly

With 861/2 points, believed to be the greatest total ever amassed in the senior competition, the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School contingent romped off with the principal honors In the twentieth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championship at Baker Field yesterday.

Resplendent in robes and bearing their brilliantly hued church banners, 1,500 children from the choirs of Sunday schools in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York passed in review before Bishop William T. Manning yesterday afternoon as part of the annual service for the presentation of missionary offerings.

With the stock market here closed today, loans were plentiful at one-half of 1 per cent and bill rates were steady at seventeen-thirty-seconds to ninesixteenths of 1 per cent for fine three-month bills.
Miss Leonice K. Merrels and Robert C. Knox Jr. were married here this afternoon at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church. The Rev. David McKeith Jr. performed the ceremony.

Manhattan College's senior class Milbank has gone forward with its plans for the exercises preliminary to the seventy-fourth commencement on Tuesday, June 8. An outline of the program for Class Day, which has been set for a week from next Saturday, was announced yesterday by president of the graduating class.
Tiger Jack Fox, Spokane (Wash.) light heavyweight, scored a knockout victory over Jersey Joe Walcott of Bernardsville, N. J., in the feature ??bout of ten rounds at the Rockland Palace last night.

WITH the bright days of Spring, each Sunday finds more and more hikers leaving New York to tramp the mountains of New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Connecticut. In the early hours of day men and girls, clad in rough clothes and heavy boots, many with

A request has been sent to the Board of Estimate by Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade and chairman of the Bronx Joint Committee, and the other members of that committee to approve the immediate

More than $10,300,000 will. be spent in research work by the steel industry of the United States this year, or 12 per cent above the $9,200,000 spent in 1936 and nearly 20 per cent above the 1929 research budget of $8,700,000, it is indicated by reports from companies representing nearly 90 per cent of the country's productive capacity to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The breach between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization in the local transit field was widened yesterday when the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electrio Railway and Motor Coach Operators of America, an A. F. of L. unit, signed a closed shop agreement with the Suburban Bus Company.

WHEN the Golden Gate Bridge, spanning the entrance to San Francisco Bay, is thrown open on Thursday, it will not only close the last gap in U. S. Highway 101 that parallels the Pacific Coast from Canada to Mexico, but will render more accessible to San Franciscans and residents of Central and Southern California a vast touring area rich in impressive scenery.
Lafayette's eighth annual alumni college will be held on Wednesday and Thursday, June 9 and 10, during commencement week. The lectures and discussions will be held in Kirby Hall from 9:30 to 12:30.

A syndicate headed by Nathan Wilson-has taken title to the property, 361-363 Central Avenue, Jersey City, fronting fifty feet in the business section. The two-story building on the site is under lease to the W. T. Grant Company for a long term. The second floor is used for offices.

Brisk renewals of commercial leases are providing the feature of the Spring-renting season in the Plaza district centering in Fifth and Madison Avenues, between Fiftieth, and Sixty-second Street, according to members of the office-building group of the Plaza district rentals conditions committee of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Van Lingle Mungo, ace pitcher of the Dodgers, today was fined $1,000 and suspended for three days without pay as the result of an early morning brawl from which he emerged with a black eye.
Constitutionality of the National Anti-Racketeering Act was upheld by Judge Charles G. Briggle of the Federal District Court here.

-Robert A. Gurley, a resident of New Hartford, has a hobby of riding in the last trolley car that goes over a line to be abandoned. Last Sunday he was one of those who rode on the last "honeymooners' " trolley from Buffalo to Niagara Falls.

AN advance in artistry is marked by this season's wallpaper designs, and in some rooms which feature these designs new arrangements have been worked out. Light, gay colors are seen, as well as rich, dark backgrounds, individual yet adaptable to period as well as modern furniture.

WRITERS of real distinction, by avoiding the cliches of their contemporaries and stressing the essentially human traits of the characters they create, keep their work enduringly fresh and periodic. Gertrude Atherton did

Mrs. Emily Morgan Hooker, widow of Thomas Hooker of the law firm of White, Daggett Hooker of New Haven, died at her home last night. Mrs. Hooker was the daughter of the late Dr. George Brinley Morgan, for more than a quarter of a century rector of Christ Church. Surviving are a son,

ALEXANDER KIPNIS seems to work in whatever studio happens to be most convenient to him at the moment. His name has appeared on several labels, and in this country he has been recorded by Columbia, and his European disks have been re-pressed by both that company and Victor.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, the world's foremost authority on lighter-than-air craft and head of the German commission investigating the Hindenburg disaster, testified before the American board of inquiry today that he believed hydrogen leaking from a gas cell was ignited by static electricity.

To the Editor of The New York Times It is to be feared that the proposed withdrawal of Justice Van Devanter from the Supreme Court has compli-cated, rather than simplified, the situation in relation to President Roosevelt's bill to "reform" the court.

THE TREE FALLS SOUTH. By Wellington Roe. 241 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $2. HERE is a plain tale from the Dust Bowl-that enor mous area in this nation which is bigger than many a European country.

Six newspaper men connected with New York publications will survey the modern newspaper and report their clinical findings during the third annual Pennsylvania Press Conference at the Pennsylvania State College Friday and Saturday, May 28 and 29.

A rally in the final period that netted three goals, the last one just before the bell, gave Tommy Hitchcock's Whites a victory over Raymond Guest's Reds at Mitchel Field today in a polo match that was nip and tuck throughout the six periods.

Country clubs and yacht clubs of the North Shore colonies, which have membership from among society residents of the Summer sections, have shown early activity this season and many of them had their official openings tonight instead of next week or early in June as in former years.
THE Paris Opera's version of Gluck's "Alceste," one that represented a faithful study of the historic score, was performed at Covent Garden, May 6.

THIS is the first American edition of an annual guide book in which every coun try in Europe is assigned to its special author (Great Britain and France to several), and attention is focused on the human side of travel rather than on formal sightseeing "or anything else that can be found in an ordinary guide."

First loads of the 500,000 tons of earth and rock which will constitute the big Quabbin Dam on the Swift River to provide an additional reservoir for the metropolitan water supply of Boston were dumped this week.
Gold in the amount of $6,461,000 was purchased in London yesterday for shipment to this country, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought the total of

Experiments in the transmutation of elements, made possible by the completion of the installation of one of the world's most powerful cyclotrons in the Palmer Laboratory of Princeton University, have resulted in the discovery of one change in atomic structure which has not been previously reported by science.

A PHILATELIC mystery of 1936 was unexpectedly solved by a recent dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Rome, and the incident serves as a striking example of how the humble postage stamp is sometimes a significant forerunner of a national development which may have international repercussions.

The execution of more than twenty antigovernment plotters at Tiflis in the Georgian Socialist Soviet Republic was reported tonight. One of those put to death was Bydy Mdivani, once reported related to the "marrying Mdivani princes," said an account from Laurentius Beria, Communist party leader in Georgia.

The lists of school prize winners in the senior Constitution essay contest are divided as follows: city senior region, 116; suburban region, 259, and country region, 359. The names of the winners and their schools are:
Governor Lehman reached tonight the halfway mark in the "thirty-day bill period" during which he considers the mass of bills which the Legislature dumps into his lap.

Senior Week at Barnard College wlil begin with the traditional stepsinging ceremony at which the senior class will officially become alumni. The ceremony will be held next Friday at 7 P. M. in Milbank Quadrangle on the campus.

SCOTCH and soda seemed extraordinarily appealing to Henry Preston Standish just then. He would like a cool drink, and perhaps a cigarette, when he got back to land again and began to tell his wife and his two admirable children and his financial partners about the amazing experience. But most of all. he
Elizabeth Colleen Tuthill, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Roy E. Tuthill of this city, was married this afternoon to Raymond Edwin Hutchinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. Hutchinson of Bristol.

Statistics compiled by the Federal Housing Administration show that the volume of business done under the modernization credit plan of Title I of the National Housing Act represented 1,419,453 loans aggregating in value $542,808,055. Title I terminated on April 1 last.
Professor Schede, noted orthopedist, attacked here today the custom of putting young Germans in heavy boots and marching them about-the Hitler Youth's favorite exercise.

The death in Montgomery this week of 39-year-old Thomas E. Knight Jr., Lieutenant Governor of Alabama, who has been prosecutor in each of the Scottsboro trials, may have an important bearing upon the notorious case.

ALTHOUGH Governor Lehman would doubtless have vetoed the Dunnigan bill once he understood its mischievous significance, the general outcry against political censorship was something worth cherishing in this jaded community, and his veto last Wednesday was a fitting reward to aroused public opinion.
New provisional members will be introduced at the annual Spring luncheon of the Junior League of Brooklyn on Wednesday on the Marine Roof of the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

Repossessed homes having a total value of $200,000 have been sold since March 1 by the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York City, points out George E. Palmer, secretary-manager of the Association.
A $38,000 program for building or repairing beachfront jetties and bulkheads to prevent further beach erosion will come up for approval of the Ocean City public June 2.

IN these two volumes Ernest de Selincourt continues the monumental work which he began with his publication two years ago of the early letters (1787-1805) of William Wordsworth and his sister Dorothy. He now brings the reader to 1820 or. as he puts it, through

Each of the following Infantry Reserve officers is ordered to active duty, effective June 20, at Camp Dix, N. J., for training. Each officer will ranK from June 20, with the exception of those who have permission to delay en route, but not to exceed three days. Each will revert to inactive status July 3:

Brooks School swept three races with Exeter on the Swampscott River today. The crews rowed against a strong tide and made good time. The Exeter first four was beaten by a length, Brooks taking the lead at the start. The Brooks second boat had the same margin, while the third shell won by six feet.

Mrs. Elizabeth Singer Proctor died Friday of heart disease at her residence, 630 Park Avenue, after an illness of seven months. She was a daughter of the late W H. Singer of Pittsburgh, a prominent steel and ??, manufacturer, who was at one time a partner of Andrew Carnegie.

Foreign cotton interests, particularly in Bombay, transferred business yesterday to the New York Exchange, owing to a holiday in Liverpool, and active removal of hedges brought an improvement of 9 to 13 points here. Steadiness in outside markets and absence of selling pressure in new crop positions influenced professional sentiment.
A field of sixty-seven players will take part in the qualifying round tomorrow when the women's metropolitan golf championship gets under way at the Upper Montclair Country Club in New Jersey.

Commencement activities in schools and colleges will get under way this week and continue through June. A summary of the events in the principal colleges and universities in New York City and vicinity follows:

THE event of the week in automotive circles is the formal introduction by Oldsmobile of its automatic safety transmission. It is to be available immediately only in the Detroit district because of low initial production, but soon will be shown publicly in New York, Chicago and a limited number of key cities.

Scoring in ten of the fifteen events and holding up where Holy Cross faltered, Rhode Island State won the fifty-first New England intercollegiate track and field championship today. It was the first triumph in its history.

The Brooklyn Hispanos, who narrowly missed gaining the national cup finals this year, bowed to the Scots-Americans, 5-2, today in the first game of the double-header for the championship of the American Soccer League.

ESSEX'S rise and decline," says Mr. Harrison in his brilliant summing up of that part of the earl's career which preceded his fatal rebellion, "affected the nation more deeply than any event since the Armada."
George Mr. Burns of Riverhead was elected president of the Riverhead Savings Bank by the trustees today. He fills the vacancy caused by the death of Erastus F. Post.

AT a height of twelve to fifty miles lies a blanket of ozone (a form of oxygen) which is all that prevents us from being struck blind by the sun and life from being destroyed, and. which is likewise the despair of astrophysicists.

Erection of two new factory divisions, together with enlargement and rearrangement of the manufacturing facilities in Moraine City, Ohio, of the Frigidaire division, General Motors Corporation, will begin within the next few weeks in preparation for 1938 production activities.

Under the auspices of the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop a luncheon fashion show will be held Thursday at the Versailles. Guests have been requested to bring packages of rummage which will be sold later at the shop maintained for the benefit of various philanthropic terprises.
The powerful Confederation of Workers changed its stand tonight and decided to support an oil industry strike set for Thursday at midnight.

Faced with a vast accumulation of certiorari proceedings brought by property owners seeking a review of ??e valuations placed on their holdings for tax purposes, the Corporation Counsel's office and other city departments are working out plans which they hope will speed up the settlement of these appeals.

Success of the University of Rochester's cooperative dormitory program, now in its sixth year, is attested in the dedication of the new Junior Year Book, The Croceus, to Miss Hazel J. Wilbraham, the director of the movement.
Mr. and Mrs. Morris Baer Finkelstein of Houston, Texas, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hortense Hazel Finkelstein, to Philip F. son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Feldblum of Brooklyn.

Criticism of the Philadelphia police force by Patrick J. McGee, counsel for the Retail Liquor Dealers' Association, was repudiated today by the association. It assured Mayor S. Davis Wilson that it had no evidence linking vice and gambling with liquor sales.
IN some professions a man looks forward to retirement, to quitting the routine, hectic or dull. Not so in vaudeville; a vaudeville player never retires.
Army's previously undefeated lacrosse team met a stubborn and hard-fighting Princeton team today and lost to the Tigers by a single point after a fast and well-played game, 12-11.

The "Birds" of Aristophanes was presented in the open-air theatre of Randolph-Macon Woman's College by the Department of Greek, the twenty-second production of an ancient play in Greek under the direction of Miss Mabel K. Whiteside, head of the department.

Miss Doris Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Jones of this city, will be married to Horton Peace of Frederick, Md., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Peace of Monson, Mass., on June 15, in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. George L. Grambs, rector of the church, will officiate.

The students of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here will present a pageant on the campus on Monday in conjunction with the celebration of the Feast Day of the Rev. Mother Mary Aloysia, president of the college.

The CCC this year will plant 20,000,000 tree seedlings in national and State parks under the supervision of the National Park Service, it was announced today. The program will aim largely at protection of the landscape and its restoration to its primitive condition.
Raymond Scheib, a senior in the prelegal course at the University of Pittsburgh, has a correspondent in Ireland whom he has never met. She is Miss Peggy Murphy, Reenraugh, Waterville, County Kerry.
The last group of rebels under Ethem Toto, former Minister of the Interior, is reported still in the Albanian -Mountains near the Greek border. All efforts to capture them have been in vain.

THIS translation of a Russian book has an impact like a blow in the prize ring. You sit down to read it lazily in an easy chair with something liquidly accessory near your elbow, and almost immediately you are sitting bolt upright and pointing like a setter. Farewell to repose until the last page.

Many things should be carefully considered by the prospective home builder and owner in selecting not only the site but the locality in which he intends to live, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Miss Betty Naudin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Naudin of Gloversville, N. Y., gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre for Miss Marguerite McLachlan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George McLachlan of Danbury, Conn., whose marriage to Thomas Joseph Wall of New Rochelle will take place on Friday.

Announcement of the award of thirty-four fellowships to British students and public officials for study in this country was made yesterday by the Commonwealth Fund at its offices, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The antics of a large flock of goldfinches had naturalists in this village buzzing with excitement the other day. Miss Claire R. Silliman estimated that the flock contained 100 to 200 birds.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 21: MAJOR GENERAL Croft, E.. Chief of Infantry, upon own application, is retired from active service, effective Oct. 31.

Affenpinschers-Winners bitches, best of breed, Mrs. H. Proctor Donnell Reilly's Lile v. Zwergleufel Afghan Hounds (Winners, Dogs)-Dr. W. G. Drown's Sanisu. Winners, Bitches (Best of Winners, Best of Breed)-Dr. W. G. Drown's Shepset.
The Phils pounded four Cincinnati hurlers today with a barrage of twentytwo hits and knocked the Reds into the National League cellar with a 19-to-9 victory before a paid attendance of 3,025.
Wyndham Mortimer, vice president of the United Automobile Workers of America, said today that striking employes of the Chevrolet parts plant in Saginaw would return to work Monday.
Just when everything seems nicely stabilized in Russia something usually happens.

ONE screen actress who never worries about how old she looks is Beulah Bondi, who is paid to look old, and whowith her splendid, early American face-is now breaking our hearts on a continuous basis in the film "Make Way for Tomorrow," at the Criterion Theatre.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporations of New Jersey and Maine reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 27 a net income of $11,316,128 after Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the income was equivalent to $4.74 each on 2,291,958 shares of $25 par common stock, excluding 37,631 shares held in the treasury.

Monsignori and other clergymen from several cities, many of whom studied under him at Catholic University in Washington, attended the funeral service yesterday morning for Mgr. Patrick Joseph Healy at Holy Innocents' Church, Thirtyseventh Street West of Broadway.

Miss Geraldyne Fitz Gerald of this I place will play the leading role on Tuesday in a production of "Kind Lady" by the dramatic group of the Mercier Club of Northern New Jersey at Mount Hebron School, Upper Montclair.

Miss Dorothy Ada Ruestow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Ruestow of Maplewood, was married this evening to Gordon Kendrick Burns, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Burns, also of this place, in Prospect Presbyterian Church, here.

The withdrawal of Works Progress Administration employes from athletic and educational projects sponsored by the Westchester County Recreation Commission has created a financial emergency which will compel the commission to curtail its activities during the bed rest of the year unless the county car Board of Supervisors grants an additional $6,914 appropriation, ac- the cording to Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the commission.

Samuel J. Graham of Greenwich was the winner of the fortieth annual thirty-six hole competition for the E. Vivian Bond Queen Victoria Diamond Jubilee Challenge Cup today on the Greenwich Country Club links. He had a score of 82--6--76 and 75--6--69 for 145.

The frontispiece of a famous atlas of the seventeenth century shows Atlas Who bore the skies upon his back Just as the pedlar does his pack standing not on Mount Atlas in North Africa but at the North Pole, looking down upon the spinning planet at his feet as if seeking and sorting the weather for its various localities.

Miss Grace Virginia Dettmel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Henry Dettmer of Brooklyn, has chosen June 18 as the date of her marriage to Frederick Earl Welch, son of Mr, and Mrs. Robert Joseph Weloh, also of Brooklyn. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Irving D. Wildey in the Kings Highway Congregational Church. A reception will follow at the home of Miss Dettmer's parents, 1,715 East Twenty-second Street, Brooklvn.
The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Lion Shoe Company', Lynn, Mass., to withdraw "all recognition of the Lynn Shoe Workers Union, a plant organization."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert B. J. Frawley of Brewster, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Grace Frawley, to Frank D. March Jr., son of Frank D. March of Yonkers, N. Y., and the late Mrs. March.

ROAMIN': A few years ago John D. Rockefeller gave Sir Harry Lauder, the famous Scot singer and entertainer, eight shiny dimes. "I'll always keep them," Sir Harry said. Last week he landed in California on a world tour made possible, he declared, by the dimes he had saved during his career.

Given continued production at the current rate and no new business in the meantime, backlogs of orders held by print cloth and sheeting mills. would be equaled by stocks on hand by about the second week in August, according to estimates by gray goods selling agents yesterday.

MONEY MAD-Tomorrow evening at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre. This would be Fritz Blocki's revised version of "Bet Your Life," originally the Mr. Blocki-Willie Howard comedy which ran a week at the Golden in April. The cast includes Ludwig Satz, Doris Underwood, Gladys Shelley, Bernice Caryl and David Milton.

RED beams piled on the Jersey wharfs, black beams sketching plane geometry in midtown space, ancient automobiles yielding up their metal in empty lots, new steel saucepans in the shops for brides-those are the visible signs and symbols of steel's new prosperity, the New York equivalent of the smoky blur that screens the sun from Pittsburgh.

If Congress adopts pending bills extending the supervision of the Securities and Exchange Commission over protective committees, reorganizations and the corporate trustee under indenture, it is forecast that it will be asked to provide- for expansion of the membership of the commission and a considerable increase in its staff.

The police at Auxerre are investigating the alleged suicide of Nicolo Ricotta, a New York Italian, who was said to have jumped from the Paris-Modane Express at that station last night.

WASHINGTON.-- Under a bill recently approved by Congress, the Library of Congress will be given $175,000 for the coming fiscal year to publish and distribute "talking books," or sound-reproduction records, for the adult blind.

Governor Lehman vetoed today a bill which would have exempted members of the supervising or teaching staff of a Board of Education from jury service. Saying that under a law enacted last year the classes of persons exempt from jury service, including teachers, were reduced materially, the Governor continued:

Mikhail Vassilievitch Vodopyanoff, who was knighted as a Hero of the Soviet ba Union, in-an interview with me recently described the aims and methods of the North Pole station" established by Russian airmen yesterday.

Mrs. Sarah J. Clark's farm estate comprising a reconditioned Revolutionary homestead, a pond and 100 acres of land in Ridgebury, Conn., has been purchased by Daniel Manning McKeon of Chappaqua through Duncan Bulkley, broker.
The international motor boat race next Sunday for the $5,000 sterling silver trophy donated by Mortimer Auerbach tops the week-end's entertainment program here.
John T. Suter, who "broke" the story about Justice Willis Van Devanter's decision to retire from the Supreme Court, has known many justices intimately since he began newspaper work at 19 in 1885.

The variety of interests in photography at Smith College is expressed in the abundance of amateur photographers about the campus, in the photography courses which are offered by the physics and astronomy departments and in the research work being done in the field of photography by members of the foculty.

James Barlow and Agnes Solacki of 257 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, were killed and four other Brooklyn residents were injured, one critically, when a sedan driven by Joseph Maritato of the same address crashed into- the rear of a parked truck at 12:15 A. M. today on Route 28 near North Branch, six miles west of Somerville.

NEW scenic trails, enlarged beaches and picnic groves, more cabins and shelters, even a newly developed park never before opened to the public, all await New Yorkers this season as rising temperatures and "outdoor weather" send vacationists in search of relaxation and play to the State's recreational and historical areas.

The five-day strike at the local works of the Federal Ship Building and Drydock Company, a United States Steel subsidiary, was settled this afternoon when strikers approved a contract the company offered the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, a C. I. 0. affiliate.
THE expert handling of critical situations by the functionaries of those daylight-to dawn bistros along Fifty-second Street is one of the routines of this complacent city.

NEARLY three centuries ago two birch-bark canoes skirted the northern shores of Lake Michigan, carrying a cargo of smoked meat and Indian corn. Their paddlers were Louis Joliet and Father Jacques Marquette, a Jesuit priest. A month or so later the two explorers sighted the Mississippi River. They were the first white men to view the upper reaches of the Father of Waters.

CORONATION stamps from Nauru have been received. In appearance the stamps resemble the "streamlined" Edward stamps of England. The new adhesives bear a profile of the new King with the inscription "Coronation of King George VI" below. Values received are 1 1/2

Empire Parley In the Cabinet Room at 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin presided last week over a meeting of the Premiers of the British Commonwealth of Nations. It was another of those periodic gatherings which for a half-century have come together to cement the ties of empire.

Winners of the "Quest for the Exquisite" contest, sponsored by The Violet, yearbook of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University, were announced yesterday by Warren Quadland, editor in chief.

Ten pensions will receive honorary degrees from the University of Pennsylvania at commencement exercises on june 9. The degree of Doctor of Laws will be conferred on Secretary Hull, who will make the commencement operation Dr. Fred P. Corson,

Delegates from twenty-five organizations interested in peace held round-table discussions on the problems of peace from the educational, national, international and cultural aspects yesterday afternoon at the Biosophical Institute, 23 West Eighty-seventh Street.

Plans for a cruise supper dance to be held on June 18 at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, Conn., under the auspices of Stony Wold Auxiliary, No. 8, the Greenwich chapter, will be discussed at a luncheon for committee members aboard the Holland-America liner Statendam on Wednesday at its Hoboken (N. J.) pier.

A hard-hitting Georgetown nine kept its season's record unstained by defeating the Naval Academy, 7 to 3, today in the last game of the season for the Middies on their home grounds. The local contingent was pleased, however, by the seven good innings pitched by Jerry Bruckel, who will almost certainly face the Army hitters next Saturday.
Preliminary skirmishes in the impending battle between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers of America were enlivened the past week.

Political parties' efforts to form a united front against the government are being answered by the right wing. Four somewhat obscure Right leaders yesterday urged Premier Senjuro Hayashi not to resign. They proposed the formation of a new nationalistic political party.

More than 15,000 children attended yesterday the annual May party of the' Michael T. McCarron Association, Democratic organization club of the Fourteenth Assembly District on the East Side, of which Edward V. Loughlin is Tammany leader.

A visitor entering a certain lecture hall at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute might wonder whether he was in a class room of a school of science and engineering or had wandered by mistake into a court room.
All nations were urged tonight by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull to redouble their efforts toward liberal and cooperative economic policies, to provide an enduring foundation for world peace.

Noted economists, among them Paul H. Douglas and Harold G. Moulton, hold that the wide spread between costs and prices is holding down consumption. Is industry keeping prices high to make excess profits, therefore preventing reabsorption of the unemployed?

Domestic sugar futures, after touching new low levels early last week in all positions under the weight of a lower raw sugar market and unabated fears that the sugar quota system would be scrapped because of differences of opinion between Congress and the administration, staged a moderate recovery at the week-end.

The interest the younger generation is showing in the Constitution was measured anew last week in the final reports of the school eliminations in the tri-State Constitution Essay Contest being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Punishment and not reformation is the code on Alcatraz Island, the government prison in San Francisco Bay for incorrigible criminals, Warden James A. Johnson said in an interview.

As a climax to its first year of existence as an extra-curricular activity at Bryn Mawr College, the Camera Club is sponsoring an exhibition of photographs this week-end in the common room of Goodhart Hall.

Instead of venerable gentlemen of scholarly aspect, with bulging foreheads and wispy beards, Uncle Sam's "answer men" run manicured fingertips through the manifold files of the United States Information Service, and go clicking down the hall on slim high heels.

This week's unsuccessful revolt in Southern Albania is the latest of a series of forcible reminders to King Zog that his popularity depends on his respecting the intensely nationalist feelings of a passionately patriotic people.

More than one-third of the total dividends paid in 1936 by 204 companies whose shares are listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange were paid by the Canadian mining industry, according to a survey made this week.

Any fear that the steel industry might move from the Pittsburgh area was dispelled today, when William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, and Benjamin F. Fairless, president of its subsidiary, the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, indicated that United States Steel was considering the building of even more mills in this vicinity.

WHAT with tentative announcements of an official character, reports from various unofficial ?ces, and the cloud of rumor that always hovers over the field, it looks very much as if there were about to be a general upheaval in these parts in the ballet, Russian and Russianesque.

Two brokerage firms in New York and their partners individually were accused today by the Securities and Exchange Commission of violation of the Securities Exchange Act by manipulating the market in common stock of the Root Petroleum Comnpany.

A symposium on anti-Semitism, a dinner in honor of Mrs. Bernard S. Deutsch, treasurer, and the election of officers will be the chief events of the second annual convention of the women's division of the American Jewish Congress to be held Tuesday and Wednesday at the Hotel Roosevelt. A perpetual trophy for an ocean race was announced today by the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass. The donor is Gerard B. Lambert, owner of the America's Cup sloop Yankee and former commodore of the Eastern club.

Winning six of the eight track events, St. John's University of Brooklyn scored the first track and field victory in its history over City College yesterday when it conquered the Lavender by 69 to 57 in their annual dual meet at the Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON-- Prisoners in Federal penitentiaries are now working in about twenty different industries, requiring widely diversified skills. Under the direction of the Prison Industries Corporation, set up two years ago, prisonmade goods are sold to other government agencies.

The Duke of Windsor found himself entirely surrounded by Americans tonight. First and foremost was his duchess-to-be, Mrs. Wallis Warfield, Then there were Mrs. D. Buchanan Merryman, Mrs. Warfield's aunt from Washington, D. C.; Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Rogers of New

Dr. William A. Boylan, president of Brooklyn College, whose faculty called upon the Board of Higher Education last week to terminate activities of the Communist party at the institution, criticized the activities of "ungrateful" students as "discouraging" last night.

An outdoor fashion show, followed by dinner and supper dancing, will serve to open the new Skyline Terrace of the Madison on June 15. Net proceeds from the entertainment will advance the educational, cultural, recreational and welfare work of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.
Verdi's "II Trovatore" was presented last night by the Hippodrome Opera Company, attracting a good-sized audience. All the were in capable and familiar hands, and enthusiasm ran high.

The Supreme Court's approval this week of the Louisiana chain store tax, though only by the narrow margin of four to three, will markedly stimulate efforts toward this type of legislation in other States, according to Washington students of the subject. The impact of the decision

The marriage of Miss Treva Wampler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Wampler of Miami, Fla., to Edward J. Lucke Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Lucke of Milbrook, took place this afternoon in the rectory of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Greenwich. The Rev. John Q. Dolan, the pastor, officiated.

WASHINGTON. WHATEVER may be the status of the Congressional schedule of legislation, the White House secretariat is working at top speed. The speed will continue till President Roosevelt takes his next vacation, and will slow down very little even then.

Deputy Cafe Filho condemned Nazism in a speech in Congress today, declaring that Germany maintained an accredited agent here instructed to spread Nazi doctrine. He warned the Brazilian Government to halt Nazi propaganda.

The marriage of Miss Mary Foster, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold A. Foster of Montclair, N. J., to Allen Bailey Bunker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Bunker of Greenwich, Conn., took place here yesterday at noon in the chapel of the Riverside Church. The Rev. Eugene C. Carder performed the ceremony.
The Athletics swept a two-game series with the White Sox and climbed back to the top of the American League by taking an 11inning battle today as Cleveland lost to Washington.

Commenting upon a recent survey conducted by the Niagara Hudson System which found that at least 11,207 American home owners desire air conditioning, automatic heating and a modern, electrified kitchen, the Electrical Merchandising Magazine points out the importance of providing those conveniences when building.
PARIS. WHENEVER the name of the the pianist Ricardo Vines appears in Paris a large audience is sure to assemble, eager to experience the spell of his magnetic personality.

The Jews of Poland will cease work for two hours Monday, closing their shops and factories all over the country to protest the growing persecution that culminated in the Brzesc-litewski [formerly BrestLitovsk] pogrom nine days ago.

St. Lawrence University is already preparing for an influx of some 200 students from more than fifty colleges and universities in November when the annual Middle Atlantic Conference of International Relations Clubs will be conducted here.
Argentina had a population of 12,561,361 on Dec. 31 last, according to an estimate of the National Statistical Bureau, published today.

The Rev. John R. Bartlett, 28, former Quincy High School track star, gave his life today in an effort to save his 16-month-old son from a fire in the parsonage. The baby is apparently dying of burns at the Blue Hills Hospital. in Ellsworth.

Edward E. Stringham, adjutant and past commanded of Union County Chapter, Disabled Veterans of the World War, has been named chairman of the committee in charge of arrangements for the convention of the Department of New Jersey to be held in this city July 14-18.

College students' recent interest in the cooperative consumers movement has resulted this year in making the study of it a regular part of the economics and sociology courses on 131 campuses, as against twentyfour three years ago.

William Aberhart, Social Credit League Premier, indicated today that he would ask a general election if "insurgent" members of the league gained control of the Alberta Legislature, opening June 7.
Apparently taking advantage of an improving labor market, thousands of young Irishmen from town and country are pouring into Great Britain.

While business moved at a faster pace in some sections of the country last week as the result of improved weather conditions, which stimulated the demand for Spring wearing apparel and household goods, conditions continued spotty in other districts.

Completion of a $50,000 endowment fund to establish an experimental supplementary school for Jewish education will be celebrated tomorrow with a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of Ivriah, the women's division of the Jewish Education Association. Reservations are expected to reach 1,500, at $18 per plate.

Luncheon for Birmingham School Graduates to Be Held Thursday Mrs. William Ballantine Wallis is in charge of the arrangements for a luncheon to be held Thursday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the purpose of organizing a New York chapter of the Alumnae Association of the Birmingham School for Girls. Hun School continued its unbroken string of rowing victories today by lifting the Stotesbury Cup in the annual schoolboy regatta on the Schuylkill. The Princeton schoolboys sent their stub-nosed shell, the Flying Dutchman, over the line three lengths ahead of Lawrenceville.
C. C. Hamlin, editor and publisher of The Colorado Springs Gazette and The Evening Telegraph, announced today his resignation from the Republican State Central Committee.

The Yankees emerged from their batting slump yesterday at the Stadium, at least for a day. While 22,956 highly pleased fans looked on, the world champions, in a hitting demonstration reminiscent of their 1936 power, buried the Browns under a mathematical landslide. When the figures were tabulated the score was discovered to be 14 to 2.
The bugle and drum corps championship competition sponsored by American Legion Post 717 of the College of the City of New York was held before 2,000 persons at Lewisohn Stadium last night.

President BUTLER, in speaking at the celebration of the Knickerbocker Hospital (which was founded in a tent in Manhattanville seventy-five years ago), applied his well-known distinction between "public" and "private" educational institutions to activities in the field of medical service.

There was a little incident in the Senate a few afternoons ago which showed that Senators are not bound by the rules confining ordinary mortals. Senator William H. Smathers of New Jersey, a new member, was occupying the chair, in place of Key Pittman of Nevada, president pro tempore.

A spokesman for the United Automobile Workers of America predicted today that at least 8,000 Pontiac families would go on a "sit-down strike" against their landlords on June 1 unless rental rates were "adjusted."

Miss Wilhelmina A. Blanken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony H. Blanken of this place, was married to the Rev. Lowell M. Atkinson, pastor of the Wesley Methodist Episcopal Church, last evening in the church of which Mr. Atkinson has been pastor for the last three years.

Fourteen of the sixteen students who will constitute the membership of Princeton University's undergraduate council for the academic year 1937-38 have been announced by John N. Irwin 2d, present chairman of the council. Elections in two branches of extra-curricular activity were also held this week.
An exhibition of early textiles woven in Kentucky was opened yesterday afternoon by the National Committee on Folk Arts of the United States at the Folk 'Arts Center, 673 Fifth Avenue.

The land-planning section of the Federal Housing Administration reports that more than 80 per cent of all subdivision cases presented for its consideration involve areas which have been partially developed, but have serious flaws in the subdivision arrangement.

Mr. and Mrs. G. E. J. Pistor of Montclair have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Arley Pistor, to Olin Henry Timm, son of Mrs. Henry Timm of Dixon, Calif., and the late Ml. Timm. The ceremony will be performed on June 12 in the Montclair Heights Reformed Church by the pastor, the Rev. Elwood Erickson.

Captain Robert D. Osgood, a lanky senior from Lakewood, Ohio, scissored over the 120-yard high hurdles in the dazzling world-record time of 14 seconds today to embellish a smashing Michigan team triumph in the thirty-seventh annual Western Conference track and field championship meet.

Mrs. George M. Strohsahl of Hillside, scoring 40 points, won the sweepstakes prize at the Spring flower show held here today by the Sun Dial Garden Club of Hillsdale at the home of the show chairman. Mrs. W. W. Livengood, here.
When the Flatbush Reformed Church marks its 130th anniversary June 9, old Dutch farm houses in the vicinity will be thrown open for Inspection.

A. McKay Smith, president of Universal Utilities, Inc., of Great Neck, died last night in Polyclinic Hospital, Manhattan, after an illness of five days. He was 67 years old, and lived at 23 Cedar Drive, Great Neck Estates.

Violent wind and rain storms in West Virginia caused three deaths and destroyed crops through the central part of the State to- I night. Two men were killed near Clarksburg when a falling tree threw a power line against a truck in which they were sitting.

Fifteen students will receive certificates or diplomas at the graduation exercises of The School for Jewish Studies in the City of New York, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, tonight at 8 o'clock, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Candace Loud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Richardson Loud of New Yok, will be married ? Charles Haven Sawyer of Oneida, N. Y., son of Mrs. Charles H. Sawver of Bangor, Me., and the late Mr. Sawyer, on June 19 in the hapel of the Riverside Church.

A cotton worm plague was sweeping with alarming rapidity over the Upper Nile regions today. It had destroyed 1,000 acres of cotton, it was estimated, and another 1,000 acres was believed endangered. It was being fought by more than 125,000 peasants working in 6,000 gangs.
