Now that the Steel Workers Organization Committee has won exclusive bargaining rights as a result of a consent election in the mills of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the union's energies will be directed against other major independents still holding out against union agreements.

An assertion that Yale University was not justified in its dismissal of Professor Jerome Davis of the Divinity School faculty, is made by the Council of the American Association of University Professors in a statement published in the bulletin of that organization.

Diamonds valued at. thousands of dollars were used in making the exploratory borings for the construction of the Queens Midtown Tunnel which is being built at a cost of $58,365,000 to link Queens and Manhattan, Arthur S. Tuttle, State Director of the PWA, and the New York City Tunnel Authority revealed yesterday.

Despite the defeat at the closing session of the recent Legislature of the Joseph-Pack bill providing for a mortgage bank, George S. Horton, head of the Brooklyn realty firm of Bulkley Horton said yesterday that plans are being made to wage a vigorous campaign for the adoption of a mortgage bank act at the 1938 Legislative Session.

Consideration of the outstanding problem facing manufacturers and wholesalers in most lines for Fall of how to meet the increased costs featured group planning meetings conducted last week by the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, composed of cloak jobbers having annual sales of about $100,000,000.

Fordham, always formidable at West Point, snapped the winning streak of the Army nine today and won handily, 9-3. The contest was witnessed by 5,000 spectators, more than 1,000 of whom were Maroon rooters.
This week Harry L. Hopkins completed his fourth year as general manager of the nation's biggest business "this business of relief."

SAMUEL GOLDWYN became the man of the moment last week-in film circles, at least by promising to produce his entire 1937-38 program in Technicolor. He has three items in mind at the moment for the color cameras: "Goldwyn Follies,"

Announcement has been made by Mrs. James Cason Pickett of Columbia, S. C., of the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Isabel Donaldson Pickett of Washington, to James Partington Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Partington of East M Orange, N. J.

Checks instead of tax bills for their citizens is the objective of more than 100 New England towns which are beginning to put into practice the "town-forest" idea which has been so successful in Germany and other European countries.

An increased demand for indus.rial sites in the Bronx is reported by Michael Santori, broker, who Specializes in industrial property. "Out-of-town manufacturers are establishing distributing points in the Bronx area," he says.

Manufactured and natural gas utility revenues in March amounted to $76,613,000, compared with $72,489,500 a year before, it was announced yesterday by Paul Ryan, chief statistician of the American Gas Association. The increase was 5.7 per cent.

The Colon Theatre's opera season opened last night with Franco Alfano's "Cyrano de Bergerac." Pedro Mirassou in the difficult title role aroused repeated enthusiastic applause. It is one of the longest

SOME of the thousands of Americans visiting England this Summer will perhaps in clude a trip to Sulgrave Manor, Northamptonshire, in their itinerary. It was here that the Washington family lived for three generations before emigrating to the American colonies.

Establishment of a meteorological station at the North Pole by a group of Russian scientists is of "tremendous significance" to weather forecasting in the United States, Dr. James H. Kimball, senior meteorologist in charge of the New York office of the -United States Weather Bureau, said yesterdav.

Four American-born children accompanied by their Spanish mother, Mrs. Carmen Leal, 30 years old, arrived yesterday on the United States liner President Harding as refugees from Spain. They are en route to Michigan, where Mrs. Leal's parents live.

Mrs. S. C. Register's big Irish hunter, Waterford, swept through the hunter classes of the ninth annual Vassar Horse Show held today at the Greenvale Farms estate of Homer B. Gray, M. F. H. of the Rombout Hunt Club.

The success of six legislative measures which the New York League of Women Voters advocated during the last year is expected to give a triumphant tone to the city-wide convention tomorrow at Essex House, the first in fifteen years. Mrs. Harry C. France is assisting Mrs. Louis J. Darmstadt, chairman of arrangements, for the all-day sessions.

Many of the gardens to be exhibited at the Westchester Flower Show (June 9 to 12 at County Center) will be well-landscaped units of small dimensions. Those as small as 7 feet by 10 feet will set attainable standards for home owners who have spaces 10 feet by 20 feet which they want to develop into gracious garden areas.

Experiment in growing gerberas from seed-requiring eight to twelve months-has shown that seeds and which were planted as soon as they were collected gave a high percentage of germination, while those allowed to dry at room temperature gave a low percentage.

New light on the Bible, including recent archaeological discoveries that are said to authenticate the antiquity of the Bible story, and to upset the recent German theory that the books of Moses were allegories of Ahab's time, will be among the subjects to be discussed at institutes on Biblical and postBiblical literature. The conferences,

Originally scheduled to open May 25 and continue to June 2, the Rockville Center Building and Industrial Exposition has been postponed until June 25 to July 10, Francis J. Klaess, president of the sponsoring organization, announces. The show has been extended to sixteen days in order to tie in with the Nassau County American Legion convention which will be held in Rockville Center July 9 and 10.

Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge of Greyston, Riverdale-on-Hudson, president of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York, was hostess yesterday at her home at the May meeting of the organization's membership assembly.

Conference House, overlooking the Staten Island Sound at Tottenville, scene of the first peace conference between Benjamin Franklin, John Adams and Edward Rutledge, representing the Colonies, and Lord Howe, representing the British, was rededicated yesterday at ceremonies marking the restoration of the historic building.

Abolition of postal savings and balancing of the Federal budget were advocated in resolutions adopted today by the New Jersey Bankers Association at the closing session of its thirty-fourth annual convention here in the Hotel Traymore.

ON the stage, after the first performance of his new piece, "Sarah Simple," Mr. A. A. Milne made a little speech. "We wanted," he said, "to make you laugh. You have laughed. There is nothing more to say except, 'Thank you.' " It is a speech which might well serve as an epi taph on the English theatre as an imaginative and intellectual force. But Mr. Milne knows on which side his bread is buttered.

A prediction that the present boom in the shipping industry would hold up at least three years longer, was made here the other day by Harry S. Scott, president of the General Steamship Company, upon his arrival from the Orient.

The longest International League game of the season ended in an 8-to-7 victory for the Toronto Maple Leafs today as Ted Petoskey's single in the fifteenth inning with the bases loaded sent Buffalo down to defeat.
TRYGVE GULBRANSSENS second book continues the story begun in "Beyond Sing the Woods," the novel which became a best-seller in nine countries. The story he tells
Yale today won the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf League team match championship for the seventh consecutive year by defeating Georgetown, 7 to 2, at the Woodway Country Club.

MORE and more the screen's year-old antagonism to the Dramatists Guild contract is settling down to a major Theatrical Trend: as far as possible, it is seeking its material abroad for play production here. Comes a hint now and then that Hollywood's united front is not so united as it might be, but the fact remains that the West Coast is on closer terms with the foreign market than it ever was before.
Three Chinese were sentenced to State prison today and two men were held for Federal grand jury action as officials moved to clean up what they asserted was a widespread narcotic ring.

The engagement of Miss Elyse Marie Kohn, daughter of Mrs. Sedonia S. Kohn of this city, to M. Julian Heilbroner, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. M. J. Heilbroner of Tarboro, N. C., has been announced by her mother.

Moses W. Faitoute of Short Hills won three saddle horse events with as many horses at the eleventh annual horse show of the Watching Riding and Driving Club today. Starting at 9 o'clock in the morning and continuing until dark, twenty-seven classes were run off during the first day of the two-day exhibition.

In an address outlining the policies of the new Maritime Commission toward the builders and operators of ships and the men who man them, Joseph P. Kennedy, its chairman, told members of the Propeller Club of the United States at its annual dinner at the Hotel Astor last night that the government was prepared to take the lead in an immediate program of building.

The first general regatta of the season on Long Island Sound, the American Yacht Club's special invitation, was sailed today, a week before the Yacht Racing Association championship season opens. Forty-five boats turned out in eight classes from the twelve-meters down to the Stars.

Under a newly developed system requiring constructive fairness and impartiality the student editors of The Harvard Daily Crimson are compiling their annual critique of the college's courses and teachers, the "Confidential Guide" forfreshmen charting their academic careers.

Norris Harkness Bokum, active in the insurance field for thirty-one years, died in the Presbyterian Hospital today of leukemia. He was 54 years old. For twenty years he had been general agent in Chicago for the Massachusetts Life Insurance Company, as a member of the firm of Bokum Dingle.
Sketches for three mural paintings representing incidents in the life of John Brown, the abolitionist, have recently been accepted by the Treasury Department for the new postoffice in this city.

The number of persons receiving public old-age assistance in this city has increased by 63.5 per cent in the seven months since the age limit was reduced from 70 to 65, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, announced yesterday.

To get any view at all of the American League race, Rogers Hornsby has to tilt back and look upward at a sharp angle. The Rajah and his St. Louis Browns are nestling in the American League cellar at the moment and it may be they have taken a lease on it for the season.

The Belvedere Roof Garden of the Hotel Astor, which has been dec- of the orated to resemble a garden on the Italian Riviera, will be opened for the season tomorrow night. Many reservations have been made for dinner and supper parties.

The purchase by Norman Lila Estates, Inc., operators, of the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 588 West End Avenue was announced yesterday. The structure, which was erected in 1924, occupies a plot 60 by 100 feet and contains seventy suites of one, three and four rooms.

CERTAINLY no Anglo-Irish poet has devoted himself more exclusively to the world of Irish heroic legend made it more his own, than has Austin Clarke. All but one of the long narrative poems in this collection, for which Padriac Colum has written one of his skillfully appreciative introductions, draw their matter from the cycles of Irish romance.

AN ESSAY ON THE NATURE OF CONTEMPORARY ENGLAND. By Hilaire Belloc. 91 pp. New York: Sheed Ward. $1.25. ENGLAND is "the only Aristocratic State in the white civilization," avers Mr. Belloc; but it is changing.

Miss Jane Palmer Crary was married to Paul Whitman Cooley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Parsons Cooley of this city yesterday afternoon in the garden at the home here of the bride's mother, Mrs. Roy P. Crary. Dr. Melancthon W.

Industrial purchasing agents from all parts of the United States, Canada and Mexico, who spend an estimated $15,000,000,000 to $20,000,000,000 annually for the raw materials, semi-finished and finished goods required by industry, will gather in Pittsburgh today and tomorrow for the opening of the twenty-second annual international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

For more than six months one of the main questions of European politics has centered on the future treatment of Soviet Russia. Was that country to be treated as an equal in negotiations of a general settlement, if any could be negotiated? Or was it to be put aside as an Oriental power not to be considered in the arrangements to be made in Central and Western Europe?

NINETEEN new coins have been issued by Great Britain showing the head of King George VI. The values include the gold [pound]5, [pound]2, [pound]1, 10 shilling; the silver crown, half-crown, florin, shilling (one each for England and Scotland), 6d and 3d; the King's Maundy money 4d, 3d, 2d and Id; new 12-sided 3d, and the bronze Id, 1/2d and farthing.
RESULTS of a year of experimentation in the continual search by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics for the ultimate airplane were demonstrated last week.

Fearing a recurrence of drought that in 1934 and again last year withered crops and killed off livestock by the millions, Senators and Representatives from the Great Plains States descended on Secretary Wallace today and demanded his support for a drought aid program.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd today praised the flight of Russian scientists and airmen to the North Pole as a "superb undertaking," but predicted they would "have to move their base periodically in the direction of Alaska."

IN spite of all the libraries of material, scientific and popular. that have been written about the American Indian, this is probably one of the first attempts to tell his whole story, from the time of Columbus to the present day, within the limits of a single handy-sized volume.

BY 1747 the pirates who had once menaced the little towns along the Delaware River had become in the memories of the colonists scarcely more than terrors half-forgotten. to be revived in sailors' talk as they sat yarning over their flip-glasses after a successful voyage. Penelope Hood,

The class of June, '37, at Hunter College has selected Alice Wren, its president for four years, as the most likely to succeed, the most respected, the most popular, the girl with the most personality and the one who did most for the class.

A new recovery high for THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity has been made. For the week ended May 15 the index reached 109.0, which compares with 108.4 (revised) for the previous week and 97.1 for the corresponding week last year.

Harvard defeated the University of Pennsylvania by 4--1 today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. Ed Ingalls, the Crimson's right hand pitching star, had the visitors beaten, 4 to 0, with two men out in the ninth. Then, with Dick Field

SPRINGS, W. Va.-West Virginia has set up a commission to mark about 400 of the most famous historical spots within its borders. In Greenbrier County there are to be thirteen such markers, with four additional signs on its county line.

More than 200 taxicab drivers, at a meeting in the Broadway Central Hotel, yesterday voted to organize a city-wide union which will seek affiliation with the American Federation of Labor. Those who attended the meeting had been elected the day before to represent 3,500 taxi chauffeurs in the city.

Lower Bay, New York Harbor's entrance basin that is enclosed except for the main transatlantic channel between Sandy Hook and Rockaway Point, is the place to study nautical flags. It is one of the croosroads of the world.

President Lazaro Cardenas will ask the Mexican Congress to approve a constitutional amendment in Mexico setting the minimum working age for the country at 15 years, according to an official announcement.
Cornell University celebrates tomorrow the leadership of its students in the World War, on a campus now intensively organized to further collegiate anti-war movements.

A contract plan for employers and workers which is designed to insure industrial peace, prevent union labor racketeering, protect the public from risi??g prices and reassure business has been drafted by A. C. Rees, vice president of the Associated Industries of Salt Lake City and former chairman of the Council of American Industry.

Two New York farm boys and two farm girls will represent the State's 27,000 4-H Club members next month at the National 4-H camp in Washington. Selected for their achievement, community service, leadership and personal health. they are:

Major oil companies of the mid-continent area watched for the effect of the Magnolia Petroleum Company's increase of 8 cents a barrel in the price of East Texas crude oil, which went into effect today. The rise brought oil to a new level of $1.35 a barrel.

When he was a baseball star at Yale some years ago, Johnny Riddell probably learned the value of "waiting 'em out." So now when he plays golf, chiefly on week-ends, he uses the same strategy. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

The German people are urged at least two or three times daily through the radio and every other medium of publicity available to the National Socialist government to visit the exposition in Berlin entitled "Give Me Four Years' Time," an exposition
Nazism in its Netherland form will meet its greatest test at the polls next Wednesday, and indications tonight were it would meet defeat just as its Belgian manifestation did recently.

Pope Plus XI is scheduled to broadcast greetings and a papal benediction from the study of his country home, Castel Gandolfi, on the occasion of his eightieth birthday, Monday, May 31. The WJZ network will rebroadcast his remarks beginning at 12:30 P. M., Eastern daylight time.

Colgate won the up-State college baseball championship today by beating Syracuse, 8 to 5, for the third straight victory over the visitors in the triangular relationship with Cornell and Syracuse. Colgate has won four games and lost one, Cornell has won two and lost two and Syracuse has won one and lost four.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. Leon Trotsky, the Russian exile who nearly two decades ago helped found both the Soviet regime in Russia and the Third International, described today the "Fourth International," which he hopes will destroy that regime, now under Joseph Stalin.

Miss Jacqueline Godwin gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 125 East Fifty-seventh Street, for Miss Mary I. S. Brown, daughter of Mrs. Harold McCleave Brown and the late Mr. Brown, and Bradford Willet Stiles, son of Mrs. Francis W. T. Stiles and the late Mr. Stiles, whose marriage will take place on June 5 in the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

The Southland, Cincinnati-Atlanta train of the Louisville Nashville Railroad, was wrecked near here shortly after 6 o'clock tonight. Engineer Vaze Elam, 50, of Latonia, was killed and five other employes injured. No passenger was hurt.
Tickets for the James J. Braddock-Joe Louis world's heavyweight title bout June 22 at Comiskey Park will go on sale Tuesday, Promoter Joe Foley announced tonight.

Long Island University's unexpected defeat by New York University on Saturday threw the race for the baseball championship among the metropolitan colleges into a wide open one with four teams still in the running. N. Y. U.,

Financial support from the C. I. O. today was offered striking coal miners, who disregarded demands of Progressive Miners of America officials to evacuate the Superior Coal Company's No. 4 mine at nearby Wilsonville.

One American, Dick Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., has the British all worried about keeping their amateur golf championship at home when the tournament starts tomorrow over the 6,776-yard Royal St. George's course at Sandwich.

World Jewry, faced with "one of the greatest persecutions in history," is uniting more firmly than ever behind the traditions of the Jewish people and is determined to withstand any attack of bigotry and hatred, former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer said last night.

A tempest in a Philippine teapot threatens to become a "diplomatic crisis." PAUL V. MCNUTT, the new High Commissioner-according to current reports which are not denied either in Manila or Washington-has instructed foreign consuls accredited to the Philippine capital that ?? their communications to Commonwealth officials must be dispatched through the High Commissioner's office,
Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,052,664,600.

Passengers carried in April on the Interborough Rapid Transit System, including subway and elevated divisions, numbered 88,524,484. according to the monthly report of Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, filed with Federal Circuit Judge Julian W. Mack.

High-goal poloists saw action in two Meadow Brook Club members' matches on the J. S. Phipps estate today. A White side headed by the internationalist, Michael Phipps, recorded a 9-to-7 victory over a Red quartet in the feature contest.

Corn is as much of a puzzle as ever to traders, not only on the Board of Trade here but also throughout the Corn Belt States. Argentine corn is supplying a large part of the demand and is expected to continue until another crop is raised or general conditions are changed.

Elliot R. Brainard of Oceanport, N. J., died here yesterday morning in the Rockefeller Institute Hospital after a long illness. Born in Syracuse forty-two years ago, he was graduated in 1916 from Syracause University, where he specialized in art.
British diplomatic initiative for an armistice in the Spanish civil war and complete liquidation of that international crisis will receive the Reich Government's full moral and political support.
A meeting between former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York and Premier Benito Mussolini was arranged today to take place Wednesday or Thursday.

The Administration's wishes in the matter of a work-relief appropriation for next year have prevailed in the House of Representatives. By a vote of 210 to 128, or somewhat less than two to one, the House has fixed the figure at $1,500,000,000, the sum desired by the President, rather than at the smaller sum of $1,200,000,000, which was favored by the "economy bloc" in Congress.

Mrs. Twachtman Pell of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Varick Pell, to L. Emery Katzenbach 2d, son of Mrs. L. Emery Katzenbach of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Katzenbach.

Milton F. Untermeyer Jr., captain of the Eastern Polo League champion Evergreen Farm four, paced a Monmouth County Country Club White team to an overwhelming victory in a round-robin match played on the club's No. 1 field today.

The question of lowering the price of gold is considered as buried by well advised financial circles here, which realize the impossibility of coming to an agreement in view of the difficulty of putting such a measure into practice.

An even half-dozen drivers won places in the starting line-up today for the Memorial Day 500-mile automobile race, leaving fifteen positions yet to be filled. The battle of high speed, expected by the railbirds, failed to materialize, however, for the second successive day.

The Social Security Board issued an analysis of State unemployment compensation legislation today showing that the Legislatures of the several States have varied ideas concerning how this type of employe benefit should work. The trend, however, was found to be toward extending coverage to small firms and requiring contributions from employers only.
Amelia Earhart flew here today from New Orleans in the plane which cracked up with her at Honolulu on a proejected globe-girdling flight and in which she plans a second attempt soon.

The threat of labor difficulties among independent steel producers has brought about only slight efforts to obtain earlier deliveries, although it has caused some acceleration in demand, the magazine Steel says this week.
Wheat in the market here is coming much under the influence of the weather reports, and unfavorable reports from the United States and Canada largely explain the current week's rise.

Opera-goers in wild scenes tonight acclaimed the performance of Lusshanya Mobley, American singer of Chickasaw Indian descent, as she closed her debut in the title role of "Aida." Three hundred persons surrounded her automobile, cheering and demanding autographs.
Tributes and acknowledgments from many lands of the world-wide benefits conferred by his philanthropies were evoked by news of the death today of John D. Rockefeller Sr.

Ernest Di Mayo, general organizer for the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union, a Lewis union, said tonight that he had filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board charging collusion between the National Electric Products Corporation and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

Former Special Sessions Judge Daniel F. Murphy died yesterday in the Harbor Hospital after a fiveday illness of pneumonia. He was 64 years old.

Enjoying the Sabbath respite from the murder trial of 17-year-old Gladys MacKnight and Donald Wightman, 18, the jurors went on bus rides and attended church services today, well guarded by deputy sheriffs.

Thirty-nine are dead in a flood in the Upper Vistula Valley in Kielce Province caused by a cloudburst early this morning. Torrential rain, followed by hail, lasted for four hours, but in that short time an area of many square miles of rich agricultural district was turned into a stormy lake.

Young Israel, the orthodox Jewish Youth Movement in America, observed its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday with a program that included an automobile parade through different sections of the city in the morning, a luncheon meeting in the afternoon and a pageant and celebration in Madison Square Garden in the evening.

Just before the heavy rain began yesterday afternoon, Bridget Sweeney, who is 15 years old and lives at 116 100th Street, was pedaling furiously around the track at Lewisohn Stadium with a wobbly potato in a tablespoon in her right hand.

Uncertainty regarding the wheat crop in leading producing countries, combined with the close adjustment of supplies to requirements, has placed the world's wheat markets in a highly mixed condition, with the movement of prices more largely dependent than usual on the outcome of the crops.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American Book Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:
Trailing, 3 to 1, until the ninth inning,. the White Sox today blasted Johnny Marcum from the box and beat the Red Sox, 6 to 4, in ten innings before 20,000 fans.
Possessor of one of the world's greatest individual fortunes, John D. Rockefeller was beset with pleas for help. His benefactions were huge, $530,853,632 to various institutions.

One hundred and fifty years of French history filed past the Arch of Triumph this morning at exercises commemorating the centenary of the completion of that great monument to French military glory designed by Napoleon.
The Rev. Wilfred Riordan, one of forty-seven priests ordained by Cardinal Hayes on May 22 in St. Patrick's Cathedral, celebrated his first solemn high mass there yesterday at 11 A. M.

Completing the second leg of a 325-mile hike from New York City to Dansville, N. Y., fifty-eight men and women participating in Bernarr Macfadden's third annual "Health and Rejuvenation Walk" arrived here at 5 o'clock this evening in a pouring rain.

The National Association of Manufacturers indicated yesterday that it would oppose Federal regulation of wages and hours, as proposed in the bill which the administration will present to Congress this week, on the ground that "new restrictive, experimental legislation" in this direction would threaten the nation's progress toward recovery and re-employment.

The seal patrol cruise of the Coast Guard cutter Tallapoosa was interrupted briefly while the commander performed his first marriage ceremony after successfully hunting a husband for an anxious widow.

State Senator J. Kenneth Bradley of Westport, Conn., and Miss Ina Trivers of Bridgeport, Conn., were married here yesterday afternoon by a Presbyterian clergyman. Samuel Pryor Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., assistant treasurer of the Republican National Committee, and Mrs. Pryor were attendants for the couple.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Cyril DeA. Bogart of Yonkers of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth DeA. Bogart, to Philip H. Milner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfrid W. Milner of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y.

The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company has announced that it is discontinuing its Detroit plant, which had employed 400 or more workers until it was closed by a strike on March 9.

War, the agony and suffering it inflicts, the liberties it destroys, the dictators it enthrones and the unspeakable wickedness of the mass slaughter that attends any modern conflict, were given as reasons yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. H. R. L. Sheppard for his strong pacifist position.
Cleveland at New York-Andrews vs. Chandler or Hadley. St. Louis at Philadelphia-Blake vs. Thomas. Chicago at Boston-Rigney vs. Walberg.

The fact that only 15 per cent of the Jewish children in this city are receiving formal religious education was deplored yesterday morning by Rabbi B. Benedict Glazer and Frank L. Weil, chairman of the school committee, at the closing exercises of the religious school of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

The passing of JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, whose life had nearly reached the century mark, brings to mind two very different aspects of a notable career. The building up of the Standard Oil Company, which was organized in 1870,
Work has been started by the Bureau of Air Commerce on an airways modernization program, estimated to cost $5,000,000, on 23,000 miles of government airways.

The jewelry shop, like the drug store, has widened its scope considerably in recent years to deal in a variety of salable goods. This was demonstrated here today in exhibits at the opening of the twenty-eighth annual convention of the New Jersey Retail Jewelers Association.

Yesterday a right-handed pitcher gave Burleigh Grimes his biggest headache of the season. Today two port-siders had him seeking aspirin and perhaps wishing fervently that Van Lingle Mungo, his wayward right-hander, was available for duty.

Michael Francis Loughman, State Tax Commissioner from 1927 to 1929, captain and twice president of the New York Athletic Association, died yesterday morning at St. Luke's Hospital. Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street, from a complication of diseases. He was in his seventy-first year.

Public support of a proposal for State acquisition and development of mineral springs in New York State was urged today by Assemblyman Wadsworth, chairman of a joint legislative committee studying such waters.

John D. Rockefeller Sr. was famous to his friends not for his wealth but for his sense of humor. An excellent raconteur, he had a varied stock of stories and enjoyed the joke just as much when it was on himself as he did when it was on some one else.

For four days, beginning at noon today, the legitimate theatre will discuss its hopes and problems in the convention to be held at the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the newly formed American Theatre Council.

Mayor La Guardia has been asked to appoint a special committee to investigate vice and crime in New York City and to prepare legislation for reorganizing the criminal courts and prosecuting offices, the City Affairs Committee announced yesterday.

Thirteen noted Genesee Valley hunting and jumping horses were burned to Death early today in a $35,000 fire that destroyed two barns on the Avon Vale Farms, owned by Thomas Clements, sportsman and breeder.
German trade is active. The average monthly value of-industrial output is 6,000,000,000 marks, against 2,900,000,000 marks in 1932.

A large dance pavilion and several small concessions in Palisades Park were destroyed by fire shortly after 2 A. M. today when flames of undetermined origin swept through the hall and spread to the adjoining buildings.

The marriage of Miss Sylvia Silk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Silk of New York, to Martin Binder, Assistant District Attorney of the County of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan J. Binder, also of this city, took place last night at the Plaza.

There are contagions of the mind and spirit as well as physical contagions, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.
The two-day flower show of the Garden Club of Mount Vernon closed here today in the gymnasium of Washington Junior High School. Mrs. Charles Jeckel won a tricolor for an exhibit of a shadowbox.

People who resist change fail to realize that change makes life interesting, the Rev. Dr. Malcolm J. i MacLeod, retired pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the church, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.
Throwing light on the rumors of a revaluation of the krona by the Swedish Government, The Economist in its current issue says:

The longdrawn-out coronation festivities will assume the character of an "empire" celebration this week. Tomorrow will be Empire Day and King George and Queen Elizabeth will drive to St. Paul's for a service in which the dominion

Bruce Walter Sanborn of St. Paul, Minn., has issued invitations for the marriage of his daughter, Hildegarde Eunice, to Frederick Brewster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Brewster of this city and Dublin, N. H., on June 11 at the Church of St. John the Evangelist in St. Paul. The Rev. Conrad H. Gesner will officiate.

President Roosevelt conferred for more than an hour this afternoon on his message on wages and hours legislation with Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, and Senator Black, who will introduce the measure in the Senate.

One hundred and thirteen workers in New York industry were taken by accidental death during April, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, said today. The fatalities were eleven fewer than in March and two more than in April, 1936.
Although the stock markets here still bear evidence periodically of the storm through which they recently passed, they are slowly recovering confidence.

The political weather here has cleared since Governor Benedicto Valladares of Minas Geraes took a hand in the situation. Next to President Getulio Vargas, Mr. Valladares is at present Brazil's mosttalked-of person.
The Tigers littered Griffith Stadium with hits today and defeated the Senators, 13 to 3. The game was called because of rain at the end of eight innings.

Adams, McEntee Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $75,000 of Bronxville School District of East Chester, N. Y., 2.70 per cent bonds. The bonds will mature serially on May 15, 1940 to 1954, inclusive, and will be priced to yield 1.60 to 2.70 per cent, according to maturity.

Mrs. Charles A. Bradley of Southampton, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ursula Solace Bradley, to Jacob Painter Howard, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hartley Howard of Sewickley, Pa.

The Bethpage Diamonds, with two well known poloists, G. H. (Pete) Bostwick and Terrence Preece, setting the pace, halted the First Division quartet of Fort Hamilton, 15-11, today at the Bethpage State Park.

Official announcement was made tonight that thirty-seven warriors of the Fakir of Ipi had been killed and thirty seriously wounded last Tuesday when a British punitive force clashed with the tribesmen in the Sham Valley in Northern India.

Napoleon's war chest, in which he carried perfume as well as campaign equipment, will be placed on exhibition at the National Museum of the Smithsonian Institution here for about a month beginning tomorrow.

The Community Church of New York, founded in 1825 but which has had no permanent home since February, 1931, has regained its original property holdings at Park Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets and plans to build a new place of worship there.

A central educational exhibit for the World's Fair in 1939 has been suggested by William M. Lewis, president of Lafayette College, who returned yesterday on the French liner Lafayette after a visit to France with Mrs. Lewis.

French imports in April amounted to 3,297,000,000 francs, an increase of 70,000,000 compared with the preceding month and a rise of 1,169,000,000 francs from April, 1936. Foodstuffs at 830,000,000 francs, showed increases of 40,000,000 and 154,000,000 francs, respectively; raw materials at 1,986,000,000 francs, showed rises of 88,000,000 and 868,000,000 francs, respectively, and manufactures, at 481,000,000 francs represented decreases of 58,000,000 and 147,000,000 francs. respectively.

Intercollegiate rowing now heads into the closing week of its preliminary season. On Saturday, for the major crews, at least, there will be the final day's racing of the college year before the New London and Poughkeepsie regattas.
Conferences looking to the makeup of a Democratic city ticket and possible change in leadership of Tammany Hall are off until the second week in June, it was revealed yesterday.
Philadelphia's league-leading Athletics handed the Browns their seventh straight defeat today, Harry Kelley holding them to six hits to register his fifth victory, 6 to 2.

Thorne Sherwood of 425 East Eighty-sixth Street has received the Perkins and Boring Traveling Fellowship in the Columbia University School of Architecture, it was announced yesterday by Dean Leopold Arnaud, who also made public the winners of eighteen other awards.

The town of Compiegne has its own memory of John D. Rockefeller Sr. It paid his caddy bill after he spent the Summer of 1907 here-because he forgot. The tale was recounted today by Fournier Sarloveze, long Mayor of Compiegne, who says he is the only surviving Frenchman who knew the American capitalist well.

Editors of school publications and committee chairmen at Hunter College for 1937-38 have been announced by Janet Mears, 3,155 Rochambeau Avenue, the Bronx, outgoing president of the Student SelfGovernment Association at the college. They are:

President Roosevelt's popularity is shrinking because of opposition to his plan to reorganize the Supreme Court, an article in the June number of the magazine Fortune says. A questionnaire circulated by the magazine on the President's court plan shows the following results.

With benefits to the United States from the reciprocal trade treaty with Colombia doubtful, further inroads in American exports to Colombia are expected to result from the new trade compensation agreement with Germany.

Finding that poverty and highway traffic -congestion on Sunday were keeping children from church, St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church decided four weeks ago to bring the church to the children of Haverstraw Township.

Although John D. Rockefeller Sr. was an infrequent visitor to Chicago, the university that bears the name of the city does so only because he.refused to permit it to be named for him. It received the largest single beneficiary of his philanthropy.

Henry Witty of 215 West Ninetieth Street, part owner of Witty Brothers, clothiers, 50 Eldridge Street, died yesterday at his country home in Deal Beach, N. J. He was born in Russia sixty-six years ago.

Scoring in every period except the fourth, the strong Blind Brook Esquires conquered the Governors Island B four by an 11-to-4 margin at Morris Memorial Field on Governors Island yesterday. Three goals in the fifth period by Wilber Fink featured the visitors' triumph. The line-up:

Nikolai Sokoloff, national director of the WPA Federal Music Project, conducted the Federal Symphony Orchestra in a noble and exacting program at the Federal Music Theatre last night. This was the first time Mr. Sokoloff had appeared on the podium at this house since his activities as orchestral leader in January, when the theatre was opened.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Goepel of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Goepel, to Nathaniel Warner, son of Mrs. Anne Pearson Warner, also of Greenwich, and the late Robert L. Warner.

George Hulse, 35-year-old Negro of this village, was arrested this evening for the murder of Herman Brewster, 30, also a Negro, of Port Jefferson Station. His head split open, Brewster's body was found early this morning on Route 25, a mile east of here.

The Western Pacific Railroad Corporation, which holds all the stock of the Western Pacific Railroad Company, incurred a net loss of $501,640 in 1936. This loss reduced earned surplus from $2,629,866 to $2,128,225. The net loss in 1935 was $509,471. Total assets decreased from $116,327,793 to $114,457,655.

William J. (Bill) Stewart, veteran baseball and hockey arbiter, signed a contract tonight to manage the Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League in 1937-38. Stewart, referee-in-chief of the league last season and an umpire in the National League since 1933, signed to lead the Hawks after a conference with Major Frederic McLaughlin, owner of the team.
John Owen, for several years a sales executive with the Fox River Paper Company, has become associated with the Hobson Miller Paper Company.

Following a custom he established years ago, the Rev. W. Harold Weigle, rector of Historic St. Paul's Church at Eastchester, held his annual memorial Sunday service. Patriotic, veterans' and military groups participated.

The paradox of Europe is that, while the nations prepare to fight to the death for the fiction of their independence, all are fully aware that an obscure event cannot happen anywhere on the Continent without affecting them all.
With light receipts, the price of hogs here rose last week to $12.15 a hundredweight, causing short covering of contracts for lard and a general advance in prices of that commodity.

Relations between the occupants of the Chateau de Cande and the press are becoming strained. Until now Herman . Rogers, who has been the official spokesman for his guests at the chateau--the Duke of Windsor and

John D. Rockefeller Jr. and members of his family remained in seclusion at Pocantico Hills, the Rockefeller country seat, here today after receipt of the unexpected news of the death of Mr. Rockefeller Sr.
The latest losing streak of the Baltimore Orioles reached nine straight today when Syracuse took both ends of a double-header, 8 to 3 and 14 to 2.
Violent Nazi demonstrations occurred today when 42,000 persons witnessed the Austro-German handball game in Prater Stadium here.

Mrs. Walter Kobbe is chairman of a committee sponsoring a rummage sale to be held Thursday at 1,106 Second Avenue, under the auspices of the Humane Society of New York. The sale, which will be open from 10 A. M. to 5:30 P. M., will aid the clinic and society's headquarters at 313 East Fifty-eighth Street.

The towering "city within a city" known as Rockefeller Center stands in New York as the greatest monument to John D. Rockefeller. It expresses the vastness of his accomplishments, the phenomenal scope of his interests and the link between industry and culture that reached fulfillment in the life of Mr. Rockefeller.

America as a nation would be better off if it possessed a national game with the standards of England's cricket, the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, the rector, declared yesterday morning in his sermon in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

The Gaelic Society of America will hold its thirteenth annual Victor Herbert festival on Wednesday night at 8:30 o'clock on the Mall in Central Park. In addition to the musical program, there will be addresses by Mayor La Guardia and other prominent men.

The Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line will arrive early this morning from Southampton and Cherbourg. Among her passengers are Sir Josiah and Lady Stamp, Marquis of Sligo, Marchesa Carignani, Sir William Wiseman, Sir William Wheeler,

Everett A. Thatcher, 40 years old, an insurance agent, described by the police as a captain in a Brooklyn regiment of the New York State National Guard, committed suicide yesterday in his apartment at 346 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, according to detectives of the Vanderveer Park station.

Nearly 3,000 of the 3,800 Basque children brought here from the Bilbao war zone were sleeping tonight in a tent city among the buttercups and sweet grass of the Hampshire countryside. As soon as they can be distributed among homes and institutions, it is hoped to bring 4,000 more here.

A campaign to pass at this session of Congress a bill introduced by Representative William B. Barry which would restore the two-cent postage rate on all first-class mail deposited in New York City for delivery in the city has been started by the Merchants Association of New York and other civic groups, it was announced yesterday.

Thirtyseven pupils of Miss Beard's School here will be graduated at exercises in the recitation house of the school at 4:30 P. M. on Tuesday, June 1. Dr. Robert Russel Wicks, dean of the chapel, Princeton University, will be the speaker.
The feature of the week's stock market here was activity in shipping shares due to favorable press reports. Hapag, North German Lloyd and Hamburg Sud advanced to the year's highest levels.

A program calling for the construction of from thirty to fifty or sixty ocean going vessels a year until the American Merchant Marine equals that of the leading maritime powers is regarded as necessary both by shipping men engagedin international trade and by members of the Maritime Commission, it was learned today.
The return of the Bank of France for May 18 shows decreases of 308,000,000 francs in bills discounted and 250,000,000 francs in loans against securities and government bonds.
The Chinese Art Club at 175 Canal Street opened yesterday its first exhibition of art work by Chinese children. The odd thing about the show 'is that scarcely any of it is Chinese in character.
Golf once was John D. Rockefeller's hobby and the game furnished him with an opportunity to drive home his philosophy. Never a long driver, his sole aim was to hit the ball straight down the fairway.

The major concern of John D. Rockefeller's late years was to live as long as possible. His, entire existence was ordered to the end that life be prolonged. Physicians constantly checked upon his health. At Lakewood, N. J.

Jersey City's little Giants drew first blood in their International League inter-city rivalry with Newark today by staging a three-run rally in the ninth inning to top the Bears, 6 to 5, before a crowd of 20,712.

Dan Voter, 5-year-old chestnut gelding owned by the Rice Farms of treat Neck, finished first in the $250 champion jumper sweepstake, at the fifth annual exhibition-staged by the Queens County Horse Show Association in flushing yesterday.

Maria-Theresa, one of the six adopted daughters of Isadora Duncan, gave her first Broadway recital in half a dozen years at the Guild Theatre last night, assisted by a group of twelve young GreekAmerican girls whom she has named the Heliconiades.

While making it clear that they were not ready to accept as conclusive Dr. Hugo Eckener's hy pothesis as to causes of the destruction of the German airship Hin denburg, members of the Department of Commerce Inquiry Board, which is investigating the disaster, prepared today to explore the possibilities of his theory.
The disassociation of John D. Rockefeller from Wall Street had been so complete and of so long duration that little effect on the market was expected to result today from the news of his death.

The United Automobile Workers' drive to unionize the Ford Motor Company's workers here will come "out in the open" tomorrow with the opening of campaign headquarters. The union's goal is to sign as members a majority of the 90,000 employes in the suburban Dearborn Ford factory, the world's largest single industrial unit.

The National Civil Service Reform League, in a letter made public today, urged the Senate Committee on Education and Labor to restore the merit system clause to the Civilian Conservation Corps Bill, which was removed through an amendment in the House exempting civilian employes from civil service.

Nate Andrews, sent to Rochester by the Cardinals Saturday, put his name on the Red Wing victory book today against the Montreal Royals, letting the visitors down with eight hits to score a 6-to-4 victory.
The Cubs bombarded Ira Hutchinson and Bob Smith with sixteen hits, including home runs by Rip Collins and Joe Marty, to defeat the Bees, 11 to 1, today before more than 20,000 fans.

Manuel C. Tellez, former Mexican Ambassador to the United States, died here today of a heart ailment at the age of 54. He went to Washington in 1919 as first secretary of the Embassy. He became Ambassador in December, 1924, serving until 1931, being dean of the diplomatic corps in Washington during his last three years there.

Captain John J. McManus, who retired from the New York Police Department last November after thirty-one years of service distinguished by several departmental citations and election to the Honor Legion, died yesterday at his residence, 200 Dyckman Street, of bronchial pneumonia after a ten days' illness. He was 55 years old.
Led by Captain Robert Dulaney, who registered four goals, the Fort Hamilton polo team swept to a 10to-3 victory over the Bethpage Falcons on the Fort Hamilton reservation in Brooklyn yesterday.

Cornelia Otis Skinner returned from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Britannic, accompanied by her father, Otis Skinner, the veteran actor, and Alden S. Blodget, her husband, who is a Wall Street broker. Miss Skinner had her first television broadcast while in London, and also made several stage appearances.

Men and women today cannot remain neutral on the question of Chiistianity; they cannot compromise on the eternal verities, if civilization is to be saved from destruction, the Rev. Dr. S. E. Gerard Priestley, associate minister of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West at Seventy-sixth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Anita Browne, director of the National Poetry Center, announced last night that Carl Sandburg had been picked as the outstanding American poet for 1937 by a committee of members of the various councils for Poetry Week.

Cotton regained last week part of its recent losses in prices. On the New York Cotton Exchange. active futures at the close on Saturday were up 9 to 20 points from the close of the previous week. New crop futures were stronger than the remaining old crop delivery.

The decks were cleared over the past week-end for the sixty-first Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium on Friday and Saturday and the view that was left by the clearing-out process is a very bewildering one.

The Buffalo Bisons avenged yesterday's extra-inning setback at the hands of Toronto by scoring a 12--3 victory over the Maple Leafs today. The Bisons collected fifteen hits, including four home runs and three doubles, for a total of thirty bases.

Headed by the season's largest crowd at Yankee Stadium, baseball fans gave the big league magnates something to cheer about for the second straight Sunday with 187,425 fans flocking to eight ball parks, according to The Associated Press.

Miss Katharine Huntington Bigelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mason Huntington Bigelow of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Carter Chapin Higgins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Woodman Higgins of Worcester,

Justice of the Peace Donald W. Shaw of Bellport received a telegram today from a California couple offering to adopt 4-year-old Jimmie Tiernan, who is recovering from a throat slash in Patchogue Community Hospital. The boy's mother.
Captain Harry Ellsworth Smith, pioneer newspaper publisher here and Spanish American War veteran, died today after a short illness at his home here at the age of 68.

Thirty-four students of the Biblical Seminary in New York will be graduated at exercises at 8 o'clock this evening in the auditorium of the seminary, 235 East Forty-ninth Street. Three others already have received their degrees and two others, whose work has been carried on with the cooperation of New York University, will receive their degrees at the university's commencement next month.

With six of the ten competitors to finish covering the distance in record-breaking time, Morris Fleischer, unattached, captured the 15,000meter national A. A. U. junior walking championship at Clove Lake, S. I., yesterday. The winner,

The English America's Cup racer Endeavour, unreported since her towline from the motor yacht Viva II mysteriously let go nine days ago while they were 950 miles from here, passed Nantucket Lightship at 5 P. M. today, Eastern standard time.

Aroused from a nap in a chair just at the moment that made him the only victim of an attempted hold-up, Bert Grandine, 30 years old, of 402 West Fifty-fourth Street, a porter in a bar and grill. at 805 Ninth Avenue, above Fifty-third i Street, was taken to Roosevelt Hospital last night with a bullet wound in his stomach.

Dean Irving H. Berg of the New York University College of Arts said at Lafayette College baccalaureate services today that the American undergraduate was lacking in a genuine sense of humor and good taste, as was evidenced in the quality of most so-called humorous magazines published by students.

Mr. and Mrs. Dana Carroll of Wyatt Street gave a tea this afternoon in honor of Mrs. Carroll's cousin, Miss Jeanne Grandeman, and her fiance, Thomas Losee. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. William Grandeman, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H. Martin,

La Salle Military Academy's battalion of cadets staged its annual review and drill this afternoon before an audience estimated at 5,000 persons. Colonel U. S. Grant 3d, chief of staff of the Second Corps Area, Governors Island, was the reviewing officer.

A 14year-old boy was drowned and four men and four children were rescued from the Hudson River here about 4:30 P. M. today after a boat in which they were crossing from Alpine, N. J., overturned in a sudden squall.
Two members of the crew were wounded when the British steamer O. K. Grove was struck by fragments of a bomb dropped a few yards away by an Insurgent plane today.

A severe attack on the Federal Relief Administration, which was accused of "deliberate misappropriation" of public funds to cover the cost of political patronage while destitution persisted in the land, marked the opening tonight of the annual meeting of the National Conference of Social Work.

The attitude of the Washington administration toward public ownership is a factor to "disturb" the public utility industry, Bernard W. Lynch, president of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, said in his report for 1936, issued yesterday.
British commodity prices, although steadier, still are following a rather erratic course. In most cases, only a small

Thomas H. Raynor was broker in the sale of 400 acres of land in Greenwich, Conn., to Charles H. Babcock Jr. Samuel Hurwitz has sold for C. A. Marsland a first mortgage of $3,500 on 10 Cheever Pl. Brooklyn.

A rather fascinating work of checking the breeding areas of the continent's waterfowl supply is being conducted by the United States Biological Survey. To do this, various means of transportation will be used by the field agents who will invade Canada and penetrate later into Arctic regions.

Beginning tomorrow, 1,200 firemen are to receive special training in fire hazards of the home and business at the department's Fire College in Long Island City, Queens, it was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

Dr. William Hall Goodwin, for more than twenty-five years a member of the medical faculty of the University of Virginia, died suddenly early today of a heart ailment at the age of 55. He retired a year ago from active teaching because of illness.

A delegation of officials of the International Longshoremen's Association, headed by Joseph P. Ryan, president, left yesterday for Cincinnati to place before the executive council of the American Federation of Labor a plan for the unification of the maritime labor organizations on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

A strike, effective at 8 o'clock this morning, was voted yesterday by more than 500 Bronx barbers at a mass meeting in the offices of the Journeymen Barbers International Union, Local 560, at 1,087 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx.
The German harvest outlook continues unfavorable. The index of the condition of Winter wheat, rye and barley is at the lowest for many years.

Fire today destroyed the main building of the Napanoch Country Club, privately owned Summer resort, near here. Samuel Moll, the proprietor, estimated the loss at $150,000. Cause of the blaze was not determined.
The appointment of Charles H. Carroll as assistant vice president of the commercial department of the Western Union Telegraph Company was announced last night by J. C. Willever, first vice president.
Unfavorable weather retarded sales in the wholesale markets here last week, although there was some call for Summer merchandise and retailers purchased goods for bridal and Cotton Week promotions.

Headed by T. Suffern (Tommy) Tailer, former metropolitan amateur champion, the Meadow Brook Club's ten-man golf team scored an easy victory today on its home links in the annual Spring quadrangular interclub matches with representatives from the Piping Rock Club, Rockaway Hunting Club and Nassau Country Club.

Sorrow at the death of John D. Rockefeller Sr. and appreciation of his philanthropies were expressed yesterday by leaders in government, religion and education. Tributes also came from many foreign countries.
Formal dedication of the newly acquired campus and buildings of Bergen County Junior College on River Road here this afternoon brought to a close a three-day program of events at the institution.
The index of French prices, compiled weekly, stood on May 15, at 532, compared with 536 on May 8 and with 533 on May 1.

The annual Greentree Fair will be held on the afternoon of June 11 at Greentree, the country place of Mrs. Payne Whitney in Manhasset, L. I., for the joint benefit of the Baby Milk Funds of the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County and of the New York Hospital.

This week's further purchase of [Pound]2,600,000 gold by the Bank of England generally is regarded here as an operation intended further to strengthen the banking reserve not only against the recent large expansion of the note circulation but also in preparation for a fresh rise which may occur in the Summer months.

Three bills that would have appropriated $1,760,000 for parkways in New York City and Westchester and Dutchess Counties were vetoed today by Governor Lehman on the ground that the State's financial condition did not warrant the expenditures at this time.

A plague of grasshoppers is afflicting El Salvador, and the government is pushing measures to combat them. One day recently clouds of the grasshoppers filled the sky, dimming the sun. They attack cereal crops principally.

About 300 members of the alumni of Hebrew National Orphan Home here returned today to hold their semi-annual reunion. There were baseball and soft-ball games and a dinner at which Dr. Harry Goldwag presided.

Harry Greenstein of Baltimore was Conference of Jewish Social Welfare today as the conference ended its convention. He was Maryland CWA Administrator in 1933 and 1934, Maryland State Relief Administrator from 1933 to 1936 and director of the Maryland Department of Public Welfare from 1933 to 1936.

Three persons were killed and three injured, one critically, in a collision of two automobiles that were going in the same direction on Route 28 near here this afternoon. Joseph Malesky, 24 years old, of 128 South Walnut Street, WilkesBarre, Pa., sought to pass a machine driven by Joseph Korpics, 50, of Bethlehem, Pa., the police reported.

The Committee for Industrial Organization will not call a general textile strike if it can possibly be avoided, John L. Lewis, C. I. O. chairman, and Sidney Hillman, head of the Textile Workers' Organizing Committee, declared on their arrival in New England today.

Four candidates for the priesthood and a deacon were ordained by Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York at a Trinity Sunday service yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Rev. Richard Townsend Henshaw, rector of Christ Church, Rye, preached.

As a result of the relatively high activity which prevailed through March from the time buying for the present Spring season began last September, unfilled orders for men's wear cloths held by 138 concerns on March 27 exceeded 58,000,000 yards, according to the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Miss Panchita Wall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francisco Wall of Scarsdale, N. Y., has chosen June 11 as the date for her marriage to Joseph Fowler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Coolidge Fowler of Bronxville, N. Y. The ceremony will take place here in St. Thomas Church, and will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif Brooks.

Class 43--Hunters, over outside course: Won by Blue Mill Farm's ch. g. Dan Corry; second, William K. Reber's ch. g. Pompo; third, Vinebrook Farm's bay g. Ticmer fourth, Mrs. Rene G. Lebrosi's gr. g. High Mass. Class 28--Jumpers, amateurs to ride: Won by Edward K. Simpson Jr's piebaid g. Mix-Up; second; J. B. M. Murdock's Skewald g. Happy Landing.

The Kings County American Legion held its annual memorial services yesterday afternoon for Brooklyn men killed in all wars. A threefold ceremony was enacted by legionnaires, members of the auxiliary and their children and a company of thirty Gold Star Mothers before 10,000 persons.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., who inherited the responsibilities of his father, has made his wide philanthropic and cultural activities one of the main objectives of his life. He venerated his father, who reciprocated with deep respect for the son's ability.

Appearing before the Association of Theatrical Agents, Managers and Treasurers yesterday afternoon at the Capitol Hotel, James J. Brennan of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes said that he approved of a closer affiliation between the two organizations.

Senator Byrd today called upon Secretary Wallace to investigate charges of "gross waste and inefficiency" in connection with the Shenandoah Park homesteads in Virginia, a $1,500,000 Resettlement Administration project, and, if the charges are sustained, to "salvage what you can of this allocation and return it to the public Treasury to be applied to reduce the deficit in our revenue."

Corporations may be on the point of increasing their flotations to obtain new capital, according to a report by Karl Weisheit of Edward B. Smith Co., chairman of the industrial securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association.
A tract of fifteen acres at Valley Stream, L. I., has been purchased by Birchwood Estates, Inc., Margaret C. Graham, treasurer, for cutting up into sixty building lots and improvement with dwellings.

This city knew John D. Rockefeller years ago, when he was a poor young man hunting for a job. It knew him when he got a start in his first business, and it was the scene of his first great commercial triumphs, including the founding and first operation of the great oil business with which for a half century the Rockefeller name has been synonymous.
About 500,000 workers are building military airplanes for Europe, and probably factories as well, it is indicated by a partial survey of European employment figures just completed.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. S. Eugene Jackson of Providence, R. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriett Goff Jackson, to Bernard E. Pollak Jr., son of Mrs. Frances M. Pollak of 1,185 Park Avenue and of Bernard E. Pollak, also of New York.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine warned members of the force yesterday against the "demagogue" and the "peanut politician" who seek votes by recommending measures which would "brutalize and degrade" the department.

The present development of the sitdown strike, with its tendency to provoke violence, has reached a stage where it is time to speak out without consideration of political expediency. The cause of labor itself is being endangered.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1937, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

The church is on the horizon of greatness and eternal power, declared the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church on Seventy-seventh Street.

The substitution of direct relief for work relief, according to discretion of local authorities, was advocated tonight by John Hamilton in a nationwide broadcast, the fourth and last of a series sponsored by the Republican National Committee, of which he is chairman.
The need for a more sympathetic treatment of youthful delinquents was stressed last night at a dinne dance of the Italian Board of Guardians at the Hotel St. George. Brooklyn.

Bishop William J. Manning went to Welfare Island yesterday afternoon, where he confirmed a class of seventy-nine patients and inmates of the city home and hospital. It was his seventeenth visit to the island for the annual ceremonies that were begun fifty-three years ago.

At Joseph Stalin's own wish Sigismund Levanevsky, one of the Soviet Union's greatest pilots and the Soviet aviator best known in America, will have the honor of being the first to use the newly established Soviet North Pole station on an inter-continental flight.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate which has been active in organizing bus and subway workers, produced yesterday an "automobile picket line" which not only advertised its strike on the bus lines of the Suburban Bus Company, but cut into the revenues of the company, which runs buses from the 238th Street subway station, in the Bronx, to Yonkers and other parts of Westchester.
New chiefs of the infantry and chemical warfare branches of the Army, and a new head of the Bureau of Insular Affairs will be inducted into office tomorrow. Major Gen.
Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Volk of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vivian H. Volk, to Peter Keber, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Peter Keber of New York.

Reports of United States and British arrangements for handling Russian gold have attracted interest here because it is expected that the delivery of Soviet gold to Germany on a large scale ultimately will be resumed.

Christopher Morley, who for twenty years has been associated with Doubleday, Page and Doubleday, Doran, as author and editor, will in future be represented by J. B. Lippincott, it has just been announced.

Members of the graduating class of the Scudder Preparatory School were warned yesterday morning in a baccalaureate sermon preached by the Rev. J. V. Moldenhawer, the pastor, in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, that they were going out into a world where the the politeness of school life is practically non-existent.

Manuel Magnus, 140 W 79th St; Samuel A Herzog, broker. Mrs. Daisy A. Walker, in 1,085 Park Ave; Mrs. Alfred J. Lyons, also Charles P. Ryan, in 115 E 92d St; Elizabeth K. Dale, also Rufus S. Cole, in 205 W 54th St; Blanche A. Anthony, in 439 West End Ave; Rosalie Thompson, in 853 7th Ave; Dr. A. Allen Goldbloom, in 65 E 96th St; Byrne Bowman, brokers.

Five concerns in the vicinity of New York and Philadelphia, as well as the Hershey Chocolate Corporation of Hershey, Pa., and the Peter Cailler Kohler Swiss Chocolates Company, Inc., of Fulton, N. Y., were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with entering into a conspiracy to monopolize the sale of a special chocolate bar made for vending machines.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions FRASER CO., cosmetics, 24 W. 51st St.--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing partial liabilities of about $13,000. No estimate of the assets was contained in the petition.

The Madrigal Singers, under Lehman Engel, will repeat their program of American music from preRevoutionary days to the present time at the WPA Federal Music Theatre tonight. Virgil Thomson, composer of the music for Gertrude Stein's "Four Saints in Three Acts," will be the guest conductor in the "Processional" from that opera.

Miss Florabelle Barclay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Barclay of Malagash, N. S., will be married to Clifford C. Beebe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Beebe of this city, on June 12 in Plymouth Congregational Church here, by the Rev. Harold G. Jones.

Half of the ninety-two miles of abandoned trolley tracks in Manhattan have been ripped up and the pavement restored, Borough President Samuel Levy said yesterday. These figures are exclusive of the work being done at present on Seventh Avenue, from Times Square to Eleventh Street.

There are thirty-eight living members of the family of John D. and Laura Spelman Rockefeller. Of Mr. Rockefeller's five children only two are alive today. They are John D. Jr., the only son and Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice; a daughter. The remaining members of the family include a daughter-inlaw, three sons-in-law, eight grandsons, five granddaughters, four grandsons-in-law, four granddaughters-in-law, four great-grandsons and seven great-granddaughters.

Mr. and Mrs. James S. Lawson of 7,211 Shore Road, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Lawson, to Frederick van Duzer Longacre Jr. Miss Lawson attended Packer Collegiate Institute, Dana Hall and Wellesley College.

Gatherings along the CanadianUnited States border today marked the 120th anniversary of the signing of the Rush-Bagot Treaty, which resulted in 3,000 miles of unfortified border between the Dominion and the States.

Considerable opposition to the re ciprocal trade treaty with the United States has developed in Congress and the press. The defense of the treaty apparently is being made by Raul Gurdian, Minister of Finance, instead of by Foreign Minister M. F. Jimenez.

Speaing in the room in Independence Hall in which the United States Supreme Court first sat, clergymen of three faiths joined today in extolling the Constitution as the guardian of personal and religious liberty.

Briggs Cunningham's Lulu won among the six-meters today in a race which was almost wrecked by a squall that struck as the yachts were halfway between Captain's Island and The Cows on Long Island Sound.

The Scoville School for Girls, 1,008 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday the winners of its various art prizes. Betty McDermid won the only scholarship. Next year she will attend the Saturday morning sketch class without charge.
Mrs. Joseph Leiter has come from Washington to the Pierre and will leave shortly for Beverly Farms, Mass., to open her Summer home, Edgewater. She is accompanied by her mother, Mrs. John R. Williams.
Approval of twenty-three applications for membership in the Investment Bankers Association of America has been announced by Edward B. Hall of Harris, Hall Co., Chicgo, president of the association.

A new week of crisis opens tomorrow in the steel labor controversy. The Steel Workers Organizing Committee, a unit of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization, frankly seeking to capitalize to the utmost its recently won mandate to represent every one of the 27,000 workers of tile Jones Laughlin Steel Company, will meet the management of Crucible Steel Company to demand that it open the door to the C.. I. O.

One hundred and fifty alumnae of Georgian Court College attended the annual week-end reunion here today and participated in the dedication of an angelus bell weighing 800 pounds. Blessing ceremonies were performed by the Rev. Thomas U. Reilly of Spring Lake, chancellor of the Trenton Diocese.

The Rev. Lawrence A. Walsh, dean of the Graduate School of Fordham University, announced yesterday that the Rev. Andre Bremond and the Rev. J. Hunter Guthrie, both of whom are now in France, would arrive in this country next month to become members of the faculty of the school's Summer session. They will give lectures in the Department of Philosophy.

An agreement for joint participation in providing radio-telephone service with American vessels operating in coastal and inland waters and transoceanic trade was announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America for its subsidiary, the Radiomarine Corporation, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Holdsworth Gordon Jr. of Flushing have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Gordon, to Bard Pendleton Rogers, son of Mrs. E. Victor Loew of this city and Tuxedo Park and of the late John Shillito Rogers.

The church must admit the power of organized opposition today and openly acknowledge that only the best of organized religion can meet the needs of modern men, the Rev. John W. Houck, the pastor, said in his sermon yesterday morning in the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx.
Italy's Fascist government today was formulating plans to send her expanding navy beyond the Mediterranean' as a challenge to the world's leading sea power, Great Britain.

Thirty-five girls and twenty-one boys were confirmed at the morning services yesterday of the Immanuel Evangelical Lutheran Church, Eighty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue. All but four of the children live in Yorkville.

John D. Rockefeller's 600-acre estate, Golf House, here, was being prepared for his return to New Jersey on June 2 when news of his death was received. Most of the staff of twenty-six servants were with Mr. Rockefeller in Florida.
Stocks higher in quiet trading with average gains widest since week ended on March 6; turnover, 5,063,050 shares.

The $600,000 wing of six stories that is being added to the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, Howard and Dumont Avenues, Brooklyn, was praised by Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday afternoon at the cornerstone laying ceremony as "the kind of an institution the city needs."

The fight on social diseases was endorsed and birth control was attacked by speakers yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Club -for Nurses of the Archdiocese at the Hotel Commodore. About 1,000 uniformed student and graduate nurses representing thirty hospitals attended after receiving communion at St. Patrick's Cathedral at a mass celebrated by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle.

The example of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, from the time of his transatlantic flight to the present day, should be followed by many persons, especially those who a fail to realize the benefits of religion, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, the rector, said yesterday of morning in his sermon in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

Miss Adele Virginia Bacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis S. Bacon of Middletown, will be wed on June 12 to William Walter Hatfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Hatfield of Bridgeport, in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Middletown, by the Rev. Dr. Frank F. German. A reception will be held in the garden of the bride's home.

To the charges of embezzlement in the Commissariat of Internal Affairs on which Henry G. Yagoda is awaiting trial were added today charges of similar misbehavior in the Commissariat of Communications which Mr. Yagoda headed between his removal as head of the political police following last Summer's treason trials and his recent arrest.

Gerald P. Tameling, formerly a member of Rose, Cammann Co., has been admitted to partnership in the investment firm of J. E. Baker Co. He will represent the firm on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.
The years slide by like waters over sonte, Hurrying. ...Their careless, shifting touch Is cold upon the heart, upon the bone Benumbed until it does not matter much.

Too often men and women consider their lives commonplace because they cannot understand that the "holy ground" lies within themselves. the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

A Filipino Assemblyman termed High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt an "enigma" today, as the Commonwealth capital discussed reports the newly appointed official had advised all foreign consuls that his office was to have precedence over the Philippine President in public toasts.

Aided by a four-goal handicap, the Governors Island A team blanked the Blind Brook Knights, 8 to 0, in a four-period contest curtailed because of rain today. Major C. E. (Stub) Davis, Governors Island veteran, starred, tallying three of his team's goals.

The New York State picked team triumphed over the German-American Football Association eleven, 3 to 2, yesterday in an exhibition soccer game which was the feature of the field day arranged for the German-American sports societies throughout the city.

Carl Schweinler of West. Orange won the New Jersey State all-gauge skeet championship today by topping the field of thirty with a score of 147 at the ninth annual championship meet held on the field of the Dover Consolidated Sportsmen.

George A. Longstreet of 17 Locust Avenue, a copy reader of The Newark Evening News for the last twenty-seven years, dropped dead here today of apoplexy in the First Methodist Episcopal Church while on his way to conduct the Delphi Bible class, of which he recently had been elected teacher and president for the thirteenth time.

Miss Elizabeth Taylor Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Garfield Stone of this place, was married to Franklin Fisher Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Edwin Pierce, last evening in the South Congregational Church, Hartford, by the Rev. Warren S. Archibald, the pastor.

John D. Rockefeller Sr., who wanted to live until July 8, 1939, when he would have rounded out a century of life, died at 4:05 A. M. here today at The Casements, his Winter home, a little more than two years and a month from his cherished goal.

Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews warned wage-earners yesterday that they were not required under the State Unemployment Insurance Law or the Federal Social Security Act to supply employers with information about their religion, union affiliation, home ownership, physical disability, previous employment record or family status.
