The German wholesale price index on May 12 stood at 105.8, against 105.6 on May 5. In the first four months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index ranged between 106.2 on March 17 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

The increase in the market supplies of money here 15 is ascribable to the return to circulation through State expenditure of the proceeds of the recent loan, out of which 3,500,000,000 francs were 2 still in the Treasury's account at the Bank of France a few weeks ago.

Showing in splendid form, with a coat in full bloom, the black chow chow dog Tally Ho Black Image of Storm, owned by the Tally Ho Kennels of Mrs. L. W. Bonney of Flushing, today entered the circle of best-in-show winners when he was awarded the highest honors in the thirty-sixth annual exhibition of the Long Island Kennel Club.

If the Supreme Court hands down a decision today on the Social Se curity Act, it will probably exercise a marked influence on life insurance advertising, according to opinions held by advertising managers of various companies.

Japanese Spaniels, WInners, Dogs, Best of Winnes, Best of Breed-Mrs. E. H. Berendsohn'sch. Kumochi No Koban, Winners, Bitches-Mrs. Berendsohn's ch. Kumochi No Chiko Chan. Pomeranians, winners, Bitches-Mrs. John P. Laflin's princess Erika. Best of Breed -Mrs. Anderw W. Rose's Ch. Perfection of Emotose Hill.

Miss Josephine Horsfail Champlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Champlin of West Hartford, who will be married to Robert Bacon English Jr., son of Mrs. Robert B. English, also of West Hartford, on June 12, has chosen her sister, Miss Elizabeth H. Champlin, as maid of honor.

No reference to the death of.John D. Rockefeller Sr. was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick at the morning services at Riverside Church. He delivered his scheduled sermon on "The Most Neglected Real Estate in the World."

WELLINGTON ROE has written the " ... And Sudden Death" of the new American Desert. In a first novel of power and promise, "The Tree Falls South" (Putnam, $2), he tells what life was like in South Central Kansas in 1936 with "a whole country snowdrifting in brown and black clouds into some unknown place," with credit gone at the stores and the banks, and the gasoline pumps shutting down for lack of customers.

Income received in the South Atlantic region held up better during the depression than in any other section of the country, according to a study just completed by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Mrs. Angelina Loring Avery, one of the few surviving "real daughters" of the American Revolution, died late tonight at her home here. She would have been 98 on July 16. She was born in Lebanon, near here, when her father, Solomon Loring, was 73. Her mother, his third wife, died at her birth.

Contractors will start work Monday on the 102-foot high downstream gate of the navigation lock at Bonneville Dam, the highest lock gate ever made, Captain Colby M. Myers, resident army engineer at the project, said today.
With an effort born of despair, the Giants brought one up from the floor today and the result was a transposition of moves that stunned a gathering of 29,486.

Ninth annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York begins at the Holy Trinity Church, Sixty-fifth Street and Central Park West at 8 P. M. today and continues Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.
The Rev. Dr. Robert S. W. Wood, rector of St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church here since 1912, died late last night in the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital at the age of 68.
The last Sunday of the six weeks' Pacific manoeuvres found the United States fleet of 122 fighting ships about midway between the Hawaiian Islands and the California coast.

An effort to scrap or reduce taxes on which the government is depending for $320,000,000 in revenue for the next fiscal year was instituted today by some members of the House Ways and Means Committee.

Tomorrow delegates of Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Luxemburg, Norway, Sweden and the Netherlands-the seven countries that so far have joined the Oslo convention-will meet at The Hague on the Netherland Government's invitation for a conference that, it is hoped, will bring a multilateral convention for closer economic cooperation nearer to conclusion.

Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan of the Plaza have announced the engagement of their youngest daughter, Miss Natalie Ryan, to Thomas Ludlow Clarke, son of Mrs. Thomas Ludlow Clarke of this city and the late Mr. Clarke.

Pledges totaling about $50,000 were made today at the initial gifts breakfast of the United Jewish Appeal campaign, which has as its goal the raising of $100,000 for twenty-one Jewish causes here and abroad.
The plunge of a disabled heavy army bombing plane into the heart of Osaka today resulted in death for one man and injuries for five others.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 91 per cent of capacity, down one point and comparing with the recent high rate of 93 per cent.
Golfdom's most celebrated collection of straight left arms will start swinging in the hills of the Pittsburgh Field Club tomorrow for Denny Shute's Professional Golfers Association championship.

Mrs. May Bloomfield de Raismes, who was principal of the Madison Monroe School here from 1916 until her retirement in 1935, died today in the Elizabeth General Hospital after a four-months' illness at the age of 63. She was born in this city and had lived here all her life. Two sisters survive.

The body of Alfred D. Stark, 48 years old, of 200 West Eighty-sixth Street, Manhattan, a stock broker, was found in Lake Hopatcong on the west side near the bath house early this morning. A fisherman, casting about sixty feet from the shore, hooked his line in Mr. Stark's topcoat as the body floated near the surface.
The Mayo Gaelic football team, champions of Ireland, defeated a picked Pennsylvania team today, 29 to 6. The Irish clearly outplayed the home team and held a 20-to-6 lead at half-time.

A convention was signed here yesterday by Turkish and Greek delegates to replace Article 107 of the treaty of Lausanne relating to traffic on the railways traversing Turkish and Greek territory alternately between the Bulgarian frontier and Lule Burgas.
The movement to oppose Mayor La Guardia for renomination by the Republican party received impetus yesterday -when Bronson Trevor sent letters to the enrolled

Efforts of Canadian mining interests, backed by most of the principal Ontario and Quebec newspapers, to induce the Canadian Government to take the same stand against international unionism as that taken by the Ontario and Quebec Governments are apparently making no progress.

THE visit of the Cleveland Indianas brings to mind a nice point that was raised by a scholar and a gentleman when Bob Feller's final high school report card was exposed to public view a bit over a week ago.
Just back from the West, Sidney Howard yesterday confirmed the report that the next new play he writes might be one based on the Supreme Court's momentous Dred Scott decision of 1857.
Heads of the Northern Baptist convention, in session here, expressed their denomination's grief today over the death of John D. Rockefeller, a benefactor and highly esteemed member of their faith.

The Rev. Augustine J. Schulte, noted linguist, authority on Catholic literature and for fifty-two years associated with the seminary of St. Charles Borromeo, Overbrook, died there this morning at the age of 81.

Playing to a 3-3 tie with the Brooklyn Hispanos and finishing the post-season play-off of the American Soccer League with an unbeaten record, the Scots-Americans of Newark captured the championship of the professional circuit before a crowd of 4,000 at Starlight Park in the Bronx yesterday.
The biggest baseball crowd of the year yesterday saw the Yankees overcome the Cleveland Indians and the elements with equal ease at the Stadium.

Lawson Robertson and Russell S. (Rusty) Callow, track and crew coaches, respectively, today were reappointed for three years as Assistant Professors of Physical Education at the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced by Dr. E. Leroy Mercer, dean of the deapartment.

Mrs. Diana Kasner Neuman, wellknown concert pianist, who served in the theatre unit overseas and entertained many members of the A. E. F. during the World War, died today in St. Agnes's Hospital here of heart disease, after an illness of five months. Her age was 43.

Although the resort season does not open officially until Saturday, beaches, parks and recreation centers in the metropolitan area were thronged yesterday. Coney Island, as usual, reported the greatest crowd-more than 500,000, according to the police.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week,. based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 93.5, which compares with 92.7 the week before, low point of the recent reaction, 93.3 two weeks before, 93.5 three weeks before and 93.8 four weeks before.
Basque troops were pushed out of a strategic pocket south of the Bilbao-Amorebieta-Durango highway tonight in what Insurgents described as one of the most extensive manoeuvres on the Basque front.

Industrial purchasing agents of the country were advised to follow a policy of cautious buying in the next three months, in a special report by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released here tonight.

Ping-pong, DaseDall and soccer have replaced bayonet charges against the Rebels for American volunteers in the Loyalist army on the Jarama River front southeast of Madrid. Since the end of February this front has been relatively quiet, except for localized attacks now and then.

Bolivia and Paraguay have agreed to renew diplomatic relations immediately, the Chaco peace conference announced last h night. The move is expected to lead to early inauguration of direct negotiations to settle the territorial dispute that underlay the Chaco conflict.

Catholic Bishops finally have decided to take the aggressive and join the battle on Hitler Youth leaders. Orders have gone forth to all dioceses that on St. Boniface Day-June 5-a general appeal will be made to Catholic youth to join the Catholic youth societies.
Captain Walter Pate brought the American Davis Cup team to his home club today to work out on the beautiful turf courts of the Nassau Country Club.

Manuel Alonso, former Spanish Davis Cup star, and Robert Harman, Berkeley, Calif., schoolboy, scored a popular victory in the Rockaway Hunting Club's annual invitation doubles tennis tournament today.

At the meeting here today of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, President William Green indicated that the federation might oppose the Roosevelt administration's wage and hour bill.
The Phillies slammed Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean for eleven hits today, but except for two innings, in each of which they got three safeties, they could not score and the Cardinals won, 6 to 2.

The general average of staple prices, given out on Thursday by the Labor Bureau, shows the sixth consecutive weekly decline since the reaction began in April. The decline has not been at all spectacular; the bureau's figures indicate that the average has fallen about 1 5/8 per cent, and it is still 2 5/8 per cent above the beginning of the year.

With only a shadow-now lifting-of a threatened nation-wide coal strike to mar the end of a remarkable career, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin tomorrow will begin his last week as the first servant of the Crown.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, urged early consideration of remedial measures for the pollution of the water surrounding the city in a letter yesterday to Jeremiah D. Maguire, acting chairman of the Interstate Sanitation Commission.

During his stay at Washington as the Mexican Ambassador, a post he held with distinction, Manuel Tellez had many difficult diplomatic situations with which to contend. At the time of his recall in 1931 he was credited generally with having done more than any one man to establish cordial relationships between the two nations.

When he joined the Euclid Avenue Baptist Church in Cleveland, Ohio, in his fifteenth year, John D. Rockefeller began to give his spare pennies and dimes to the church and the missions. As his wealth grew, his contributions grew in proportion, until his total gifts to Baptist Church activities amounted to more than $30,000,000.

Dr. Lucian R. McCollom of 149 East Sixty-second Street, New York, a throat and nose speclalist associated with the Tonsil and Midtown Hospitals, died here yesterday in a private sanitarium at the age of 64, after an illness of three months. He received his medical degree from the Long Island College Hospital in 1897.

The Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science (The University in Exile) of the New School of Social Research will confer the degree of Doctor of Social Science for the first time since its establishment four years ago at exercises this evening at the school, 66 West Twelfth Street.

The Paris Exposition of 1937, a flag-decked panorama of the pavilions of fiftyfour nations, was ready tonight to throw open its gates to the world. France hopes the exposition will attract 50,000,000 visitors in the next six months.

New England horse racing shifts tomorrow to Suffolk Downs, where for twenty-four days the thoroughbreds will battle. Eight races are carded for each day and post time is set at 2:15 P. M. (Eastern daylight-saving time).

There is a widespread spiritual hunger beneath the seeming indifference to religion of the day, the Rev. Leon M. Flanders, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street, the Bronx. He said:
When word was received here today of the death of John D. Rockefeller hundreds of local possessors of "Rockefeller dimes" placed an added value on their keepsakes.
Thirteen Federal agencies let ninetythree supply contracts valued at $6,280,300 under the terms of the Public Contracts Act during the week ended May 20, the Labor Department announces.
Bucknell University today named Albert E. Humphreys, North Tonawanda, N. Y., High School mentor

Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., and her French partner, Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin, were beaten in the women's doubles final of the French hardcourt tennis championships today by Mrs. Rene Mathieu of France and Miss Billy Yorke of England, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 86.0 on May 19, compared with 85.7 three weeks before, 86.8 on April 14 and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
A couple married fifty years ago marched up the church aisle to the strains of "Lohengrin" again today while ninety brides and bridegrooms of the Eighteen Seventies and Eighties looked on.

John D. Rockefeller's huge Standard Oil Company received a severe shock that appeared capable of destroying the entire organization almost thirty years ago when Federal Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, now high commissioner of baseball, levied a fine greater than the company's total capitalization at the time.

The council of administration of the Illinois Bankers Association approved today a resolution asking the General Assembly of Illinois to remove double liability from shareholders of State banks. The resolution will be acted upon by the association at its annual convention opening tomorrow in the Palmer House.

Although gold imports from Russia appear to have ceased, no importance is attached to the rumors that arrangements have been concluded for Russian gold to be bought directly by the United States Treasury.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday the appointment of eighty-three persons to instructional staffs of the university. Among the appointments were Dr. Harry Stoll Mustard and Dr. William Smith Tillett, both of Johns Hopkins University, to the faculty of the College of Medicine.
Many readers, no doubt, just broke down and cried over the revelatino by WILLIAM FELLOWES MORGAN, Commissioner of
Plans for expanding the suburban shopping facilities of Arnold Constable Co. were announced yesterday by George E. Hite Jr., president of the Fifth Avenue department store.

Children today are being sold on the auction block to the highest bidders. It is only a question as to who will buy them, declared the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, in his sermon yesterday morning celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the church Sunday School.

A harmless milk snake which was mistaken for a venomous copperhead caused considerable excitement yesterday afternoon when New York and New Jersey police staged what they thought was a race against death to rush a 14year-old boy, who was bitten by the snake, from the woods on the Palisades near Fort Lee, N. J., to the Bronx Park Zoo for an injection of antitoxin serum.

A MIGHTY FORTRESS, by LeGrand Cannon Jr. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A young man's progress toward unselfishness. BILLIONS FOR DEFENSE, by William T. Stone and Ryllis Alexander Goslin. (Headline Books, 35 cents.) An examination of armament spending.
Four students were ordained as rabbis at the commencement exercises yesterday of the Jewish Institute of Religion in the institute's auditorium at 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

When the executive committee of the Westchester Republican County Committee, of which Charles H. n Griffiths is chairman, meets next Thursday, candidates for the county and judicial ticket will be selected.

A good demand for tenement houses in the Yorkville section was indicated in sales to investors reported over the week-end. The five-story building at 424 East Eighty-fifth Street, between First and York Avenues, was sold by J. Lemle Sons, Inc., through their Rutlyn Realties, Inc., to a client of Otto Dommash.

Dorothy Parker and Alan Campbell have been won away from their countryside near Doylestown, Pa., by a five-year writing contract with Samuel Goldwyn, signed yesterday. They will join the Goldwyn staff on June 7, and their first assignment will be the screen play of. "The Cowboy and the Lady," by Frank R. Adams and Leo McCarey.

Miss Justine Arnold, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Sears Arnold of New Haven and Woodbridge, Conn., will be married to Edward Mortimer Linforth, son of Professor and Mrs. Ivan M. Linforth of Berkeley, Calif., on June 19 in Christ Church, New Haven.

Five blues, including one in the saddle horse sweepstakes, were won by Moses W. Faitoute of Short Hills during the second and final day of the eleventh annual horse show of the Watchung Riding and Driving Club today. Faitoute took three firsts yesterday.

Industrial activity in Great Britain in the first quarter of 1937 was estimated by the Board of Trade to have been 0.2 per cent below the fourth quarter of 1936, but 7.1 per cent above the first quarter of 1936.

Interest in soy beans on the Board of Trade was moderate last week. No. 2 yellow sold at $1.73% a bushel, track basis, a half cent under the May. The week's receipts of 49,000 bushels compared with 160,000 a year ago.

Charles A. Andres, who recently was elected vice president of the Herring-Hall-Marvin Safe Company, has been appointed general manager with headquarters at the home office in Hamilton, Ohio. This completes the reorganization of the executive staff, which has been under way for some time.

E. G. Buckland, president of the Railroad Credit Corporation, has announced that the institution will make a liquidating distribution of 2 per cent on May 31, amounting to $1,470,814, of which $1,198,109 will be paid in cash and $272,705 will be credited on carriers' indebtedness to the corporation.

The Jewish war veterans of the United States, 4,000 strong, marched down Fifth Avenue from 110th Street to Seventy-sixth Street yesterday morning, where they attended their forty-second annual national memorial service in Temple Beth-El.

Miss Lillian E. Prudden, organizer, pioneer and active in Connecticut of philanthropic and religious work for a half century and a founder of the New Haven Visiting Nurse Association, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at her home here. Her age was 84.
A dinner in honor of Julian W. Curtiss, honorary president of the Greenwich Country Club, was given at the clubhouse last night by 200 members. William T. Taylor was toastmaster.
The Supreme Court ruled today that a labor organization had the right, under the Wisconsin labor code, to engage in peaceful picketing to call attention to activities of a nonunion employer.

The Hippodrome Opera Company will revive Rossini's "Barber of Seville" as a special holiday performance on the evening of May 31, it was announced yesterday. Because of this Memorial Day presentation there will be no performance at the Hippodrome on Friday night.
The Supreme Court opinion on the unemployment insurance provisions of the Social Security Act was as follows:

Mrs. Theodore Sheaffer of Gulph Mills captured the medal in the qualifying round of the Philadelphia and district women's championship golf tournament, shooting an 84 today at the Cedarbrook Country Club. Mrs. Sheaffer used 42 strokes on each nine.
A forerunner of June Week, which begins at the Naval Academy on Saturday, was the opening today of the com petitive infantry drill among the twelve companies of the regiment of midshipmen.

Nelson Burton of Dallas, Texas, defeated Andy Varipapa, veteran Brooklyn star, 2,089 to 2,065, as they opened the first half of their eightygame bowling match for a $2,000 purse at the Capitol Health Center last night.

Empire defense and the problem of coordinating the rearmament programs of Britain and the dominions engaged the Imperial Conference today in the first of a series of meetings on this topic which are expected to occupy a week.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were authorized today by the United States District Court to consent to the postponement for ten years of the maturity date of about $2,000,000 of bonds of the Berkshire Street Railway Company and to consent to the establishment of sinking funds for their partial payment.

Maxwell Howard's Sceneshifter, trained by the former star jockey, Earle Sande, and who finished fifth in the Kentucky Derby, may not be able to beat War Admiral or Pompoon, but he is still considerably better than many of the current 3-year-olds. He demonstrated this at Belmont Park yesterday when he romped home winner by four lengths in the Pantigo Purse at seven furlongs.
Faced with a deadlock, nine union and company officials attempting to settle Wilsonville's mine sit-down strike, ended negotiations for the present early tonight.

Incomes amounting to $2,166,883,296 for 1936 were reported to Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, by the nineteen life insurance companies in New York, according to figures made public yesterday. The total assets of these companies on Dec. 31 were $10,576,432,326.

The names of 150 prospective jurors were drawn yesterday from the special jury panel for the trial of James Plumeri and John Dioguardi who are charged with conspiracy, extortion and malicious mischief in the city's garment trucking industry in the racket investigation of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

Sales on national Securities Exchanges in April, at $2,373,658,233, showed a decrease of 30.5 per cent from March but were 8.5 per cent larger than in April, 1936, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Dr. Ambrose Kirk Brennan died in the Muhlenberg Hospital here tonight, following an illness of two weeks. Dr. Brennan was born in New Haven, Conn., sixty-six years ago and was graduated from Hill House Preparatory School and, in 1893, from the Yale Medical School.
At a meeting yesterday of the board of trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., A. Augustus Low, David C. Johnson and Harry R. Woodrow, were elected as vice presidents. Mr.

With Bryan Grant and Gene Mako taking the afternoon off to go to the ball park, there was little activity in the American Davis Cup camp at Forest Hills yesterday, but what there was gave considerable comfort to Captain Waiter Pate.

Finding Johnny Babich and Tom Delacruz for a total of 16 hits that included a home run by Bob Seeds, the Newark Bears gained an even break in their two-game series with the Jersey City Giants today by a 10-4 triumph.
Charles F. Noyes Co has arranged a first mortgage loan of $137,000 at 4 per cent with a savings bank on 47-49 Cortlandt St and 165 Greenwich St, for the Bobdick Realty Co, Maurice Brill, president.
The North Community Hospital of Glen Cove, L. I., has sold the ten-room residence at 35-12 154th Street, Flushing, Queens, to H. Robert Stephan. Halleran Agency was the broker.

Miss Elizabeth Spotwood Ralph, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Harrison Ralph of Overrock Lane, has chosen June 26 as the date of her marriage to Robinson Davis Bullard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph William Camp Bullard of Southport.

Despite the State Department's ban on United States volunteers for Spain, recruiting continues in the United States. Proof of this was obtained by the writer today when he interviewed Paul Burke, 26-year-old Minneapolis bricklayer who arrived at Havre last night aboard the steamer Georgia with twenty-nine fellowvolunteers, who had all enlisted at various points in the United States and had undergone hasty military training prior to leaving.

In the Phi Beta Kappa address today at the commencement of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Frank E. Gannett, publisher of the Gannett newspapers, called education an important safeguard against the perils of personal government.

Fourteen athletes were named by Harvard and Yale authorities today as a nucleus for the American team that will meet an Oxford-Cambridge track group in the Crimson's stadium in July. The initial selections include ten men from Yale and four from Harvard, all of the latter being freshmen.

THANKS to a quiet week-end, the 964 pages of Meyer Levin's "The Old Bunch" (Viking, $3) have been at last consumed. It turns out that they tell the story of a group of Chicago youngsters during the period 1921-1934-the story of Dave Plotkin, Mort Abramson, Harry Perlin, Lil Klein, Celia Moscowitz, Joe Freedman, Thelma Ryskind, Lou Margolis, Rudy Stone, Rose Heller and the rest. Some marry during- these years;

Reciprocal trade WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, pacts, now completed with sixteen nations, are not only providing domestic employment by imports of raw materials in exchange for finished products, but also are resulting in increased export trade, James A. Ferrell, former president of the United States Steel Corporation, told the American Steel Warehouse Association at the opening of its convention here today.

Scoring once in the sixth inning, James Monroe High School's nine beat Morris High, 1-0, at Sterling Oval in a play-off game for the upper Manhattan-Bronx P. S. A. L. title yesterday. Monroe and Morris finished their regular schedules with four victories and two setbacks apiece.

The proposal of Joseph P. Ryan president of theInternational Long shoremen's Association to merg the maritime branches of the Amer ican Federation of Labor in Atlan tic and Gulf ports in a single coun cil was met yesterday with the an nouncement of plans for a similar body by the Committee for Indus trial Organization.
Leaders of unionized steel labor and management signed a contract today averting a threatened strike involving the 18,000 workers of the Crucible Steel Company of America and its affiliates.

SERGEANTS-From precincts indicated to Emergency Service Division: Otto W. Behrens.. 45Peter J. Roche... 102 THIRD GRADE DETECTIVE-Walter E. Stanton, from 18th Division, 4th Detective District to 23d Precinct, designation as third grade detective revoked.

Until the President speaks out, no one can say whether today's three Supreme Court decisions upholding Federal-State Social Security Laws, as a climax to other favorable New Deal decisions and the retirement of Justice Van Devanter, have persuaded him to abandon his judiciary plan or accept the compromise which is open to him.

Sidney E. Dickinson, in Carnegie Studios, 152 W. 57th St.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker. Mrs. Edna Rhodes, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., in 944 Park Ave.; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., broker. The Rev. Minot Simons, in 64 E. 86th St.; Samuel A. Herzog, broker.

Mrs. Florence Irene Bradley Fairchild, member of an old New England family and resident of Brooklyn for sixty years, died of an embolism on Sunday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Frank E. Simmons, at 160 Henry Street, Brooklyn.
Annual convention, women's division of the American Jewish Congress, Hotel Roosevelt, 9 A. M. Sessions this evening and tomorrow. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Oriental Art: the Far East,"

Mrs. Helen R. Stetson, widow of the Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson, for many years rector of Trinity Church, left a net estate of $517,133.74, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Eighty per cent eventually will go to the General Theological Seminary and the Caleb R. Stetson -Memorial Fund of the University of the South at Sewanee, Tenn.
Plans for a seven-story apartment house, to be erected on the northwest corner of 235th Street and Webster Avenue, the Bronx, at a cost of $200,000, were filed yesterday.
The Yankees are back on top in the American League and are all square for the season with the Indians.

The Legion of Decency was praised yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Edward Roberts Moore. representative of Cardinal Hayes on the motion picture council of the New York archdiocese. He said it was one of the outstanding examples of Catholic action in this country.

Introduction of an individualized public-relations service for banks by the American Bankers Association, as an aid to members in promoting good-will toward banking in their communities, has been announced by Tom K. Smith, president of the association.
The Biblical Seminary in New York held its thirty-seventh annual commencement last night in the auditorium of the institute, 235 East Forty-ninth Street. Thirty-four students were graduated.

By way of change in the long list of trials of Catholic clergymen, a Protestant, Pastor Rettig, was convicted today of immorality and sentenced to four years in the penitentiary by the regional court at Saarbruecken.

The apparel industry and its allied lines were well represented among the firms reported yesterday to have leased space for business purposes. Many rentals of store space also were included in the list, which follows:
Elizabeth St, 120, 25.4x99.7, Arthur F. Lamanda, ref, to Citizens Savings Bank; foreclosure ($1). Greene St, 78. 25x100; Robert D. Van Royen to 117 East Sixty-ninth St Corp; 1-110 interest.

Dr. Edward A. Dodd, a retired Episcopal clergyman, died here day. His age was 68. A native of Portland, Ore., he held degrees from Amherst College, the University of Halle, Germany, and the Philadelphia Divinity School.

Captain James R. Hawkes, 41, a former World War army officer, was ordered to the Boston Psychopathic Hospital today for observation after, police said, he had terrorized fellow-apartment-house dwellers by firing a pistol at imaginary prowlers.

Natalie Elliott Carr of Clinton, Conn., and New York City, who was the subject of a nation-wide search when she disappeared in June, 1933, filed suit for divorce today against her young husband, Walter Burke Coll of Stamford, charging him with cruelty within ten days of their wedding in 1936.

James M. Landis, who had planned to retire as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission on June 6, prior to becoming dean of the Harvard Law School next Fall, agreed today at the request of President Roosevelt to remain as head of the SEC through the Summer.

Manuel Quezon, Presiden. of the Philippine Commonwealth, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Queen -Mary yesterday, unperturbed by the tempest that has arisen in his native land over the question of precedence when toasts are drunk.

Orie R. Kelly, president of the New York Athletic Club, issued the following statement yesterday on the death of Captain M. F. Loughman: "Every member of the New York Athletic Club mourns the sudden death of Captain M. F. Loughman, who passed from this life on Sunday. He was one of our most indefatigable workers in the interests of the N. Y. A. C.

Wesley Ramey, 1321/24, Grand Rapids, Mich., outpointed Charley Gomer, 134 1/2, Brownsville, in the star attraction of eight rounds on the boxing card at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, last night. A crowd of 3,000 attended.

Members of New York's Seventyseventh Division, which won fame in the World War, will hold their twentieth annual reunion during the 1937 national convention of the American Legion here from Sept. 20 to 23, it was announced yesterday by Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, chairman of the convention's reunion committee.
The death of John D. Rockefeller will in no way curtail the work of the great institutions he established for the public good, it was indicated yesterday.
The League of Nations Council began its ninetyseventh session today with a meeting headed toward becoming a drive for withdrawal of all foreign troops from Spain.

Recent archaeological discoveries in the Bible lands re-establish the early books of the Bible as historical contemporaneous records of conditions as they existed in the days of the Patriarchs and Moses, it was declared last night at the opening session of the Institutes of Biblical and Post-Biblical Literatures by Professor William F. Albright, Biblical authority of Johns Hopkins University.

A new two-floor building containing a lagering cellar and a fermenting cellar, totaling about 16,320 square feet of floor space, is being added to the Piel Brothers brewery plant at Liberty and Sheffield Avenues, Brooklyn.

Colonel T. Bentley Mott, who was Ambassador Myron Herrick's military attache for ten years, has written the story of his career, "Twenty Years a Military Attache." He has served in Paris, St. Petersburg, London, Rome, Constantinople and Berne.

Two doubles in the ninth inning netted Panzer College a victory over Upsala in the annual game at Soverel Field today, 4-3. With the score tied, Markewicz, first Panzer batsman up, sent out a low fly, which Graef failed to get, and reached second. McGonigle then drove over Graef's head, ending the game as Markewicz crossed the plate.

The 800-room Hotel Montclair at Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Ralph Hitz, president of the Hotel New Yorker and head of the National Hotel Management Company.

T. M. Schumacher, president of the Western Pacific Railroad Corportion, received salaries amounting to $45,249 in 1936, according to a report by the corporation to the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday.

A closed shop in the steel industry carries with it the probability of a 100 per cent increase in production costs and a $3,000,000,000 rise in the cost of steel to consumers within two years, John H. Van Deventer, editor of Iron Age, warned 1,600 industrial purchasing executives here tonight.

Washington Park opened Chicago's metropolitan racing season today before a crowd of nearly 10,000. The thirty days of .cing will find $350,000 in purse money distributed, with seven stake events on the program.
German press comment on John D. Rockefeller's death was rather perfunctory and so far no mention has been made of the millions he gave to aid German science.
The wage and hour legislation introduced today was far different from the NIRA enacted for the same purpose in President Roosevelt's first administration.

The Columbia and Harvard baseball teams will play off their postponed Eastern Intercollegiate League contest on University Field here Saturday morning at 10:10 o'clock, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics in Princeton University.

More than 2,000 barbers in about 1,000 shops went on strike in the Bronx yesterday as the first step in a city-wide movement by locals of the Journeymen Barbers International Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Agreements covering 12,000 workers were negotiated over the weekend with employers in the textile industry by the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate, Sidney Hillman, president of the committee, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip and Mrs. Edward W. Harden will be hostesses this afternoon to members of the Southern Woman's Edunational Alliance when they open the gardens of Beechwood and the Wilderness, their estates at Scarborough-on-Hudson, N. Y., to aid the program of the alliance. Tea will be served at Mrs. Harden's estate.

For the first time in the history of the American stage, the legitimate theatre-almost every branch of it-sat down yesterday for four days of intensive conversation at the Hotel Astor. Welcomed by Helen Hayes to the first national convention of the American Theatre Council, some 500 representatives of all theatrical interests were given to understand that, in general, the living drama has not expired.
Frank Kracik, union leader, announced tonight that a meeting of the Canning and Pickle Workers Union had voted to call a strike of about 1,500 workers at the plant of the H. J. Heinz Company.

Despite several clemency pleas to the court, Alexander Kinderman, 49 years old, was sentenced by General Sessions Judge Allen yesterday to three and one-half to ten years in Sing Sing for starting three fires last March 26 and 27 in the West Side Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street, in the last of which damage of more than $80,000 was reported.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 21: CAPTAINS Cummings, D. E., the Utah, to Thirteenth Naval District, Seattle, Wash. Dutton, B. Jr., Washington, D. C., to command the Portland. Theobald, R. A., Newport, R. I., to command the Nevada, in September.
Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Mabee Compton, who left for a wedding trip in the South after their wedding on May 15 in White Plains, are now at the Cavalier Hotel, Virginia Beach, Va.

By B. HOLLANDER SON Southern Boulevard, 1,326, 5-story tenement, 33.4x100: State Mortgage Commission against Mary V. G. Zimmerman; due, $25,361; taxes , $3,923; to plaintiff for $1,000. City Island Ave. 232-38, 74x91.5 irreg; State Mortgage Commission against Annie Kane; due, $26,880; taxes , $4,765; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Miss Mary Louise Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mitchell of this place, will be married on the evening of June 19 to John Reynolds Young, son of Mrs. Charles W. Leland of La Jolla, Calif., and Charles Sommers Young of San Francisco.

John F. Callaghan of 177 Smith Street, Brooklyn, an insurance broker for twenty-eight years with offices at 32 Court Street, died on Sunday in St. John's Hospital. He was 50 years old and during the World War served overseas in a machine-gun battalion of the Seventy-seventh Regiment.

Angry followers of Father Divine after vainly seeking to persuade a process server to take back a large number of summonses and complaints threw them into the street in front of the principal heaven at 20 West 115th Street yesterday, according to an affidavit later filed in Supreme Court.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and subsidiary companies reported yesterday for the twenty-six weeks ended on Feb. 27, a net operating profit of $4,040,389 after deducting amortization, depreciation, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but without providing for Federal surtaxes on undistributed earnings.

THERE was some discussion of the $1,000 fine slapped on Van Lingle Mungo of the Dodgers for his revelry by night, and one of the Yankee followers said it was the biggest fine-if it sticks--since Babe Ruth was tapped for $5,000 by the late Miller Huggins.

Plans for an experimental school for Jewish boys and girls, for which a fund of $50,000 has been established, were presented yesterday at a Springtime breakfast of Ivriah, the women's division of the Jewish Education Association, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BERNSTEIN, EVA (Dec. 3, 1936). Gross assets, $3,550; net, a deficit. Mary B. Peaks, attorney, 165 Broadway. FERULLI, IRMA (April 13, 1936). Gross assets, $123,562; net, $112,703. To Ida Domenica Ferulli, daughter, temporary estate in half residue;

Two experts on electro-static electricity, one American and one German, testified before the official board of inquiry in the Hindenburg disaster today that if a mixture of escaping hydrogen and air inside
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 3857-Edward M. James v. Benjamin Clayton, Walter B. Kerrick, and Henry M. Stadt. Argued.
The majority opinion of the Supreme Court on the old-age provisions of the Social Security Act was as follows:

WPA writers, beginning a combination sitdown strike and walkout yesterday against prospective cuts in the Congressional appropriation for work relief, instructed their families to apply at once for home relief to carry them through the period of the strike.

Through almost two and a half hours of a gently spoken cross-examination by Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan this afternoon, 18-year-old Gladys MacKnight, co-defendant in the hatchet murder trial before Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a jury, clung to her story that Donald Wightman and not she wielded the hatchet that killed her mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight, in their Bayonne home last July 31.

Fatalities due to motor accidents declined last week and week-end compared with figure. covering the corresponding periods of 1936, according to tables made public yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.
Henry F. Holtorf, prominent Lutheran layman and retail grocer, died early yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 101 East Seventy-fifth Street. He was 70 years old.

Filling the creel: A party of potential weakfishermen trolling at Moriches Bay over the week-end report a catch of eighteen striped bass. ... Dick Boeckl of Syracuse and Charles Hartner of Shinnecock Hills among others aboard with Captain James Coulochi were rather surprised when they snagged the fish between East Moriches and Westhampton, with weakfish bait.

The Rev. John Allison Nesbitt, pastor of Catonsville Presbyterian Church more than thirty years, died yesterday at the age of 59. A native of Maryland, he was graduated from Lafayette College in 1902 and from Princeton Theological Seminary in 1905.

Professor William Foster, a member of the Chemistry Department at Princeton University for thirtyseven years and author of several well-known textbooks, died tonight at his home here after a long illness. He was 68 and would have retired from the Princeton faculty at the end of the current academic year.
The market for United States Government bonds was quick yesterday to respond to the Supreme Court's decision upholding the constitutionality of the Social Security Act.

With weather conditions at the week-end conducive to shopping for Summer merchandise,. retail trade picked up somewhat and resulted in a greater volume of reorders reaching the wholesale markets yesterday on dresses, coats and sports wear. The volume, however,
Extensive playground improvements along Riverside Drive formed the highlight of an inspection trip conducted yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses and a group of city and State engineers.
The arrival here today of the Japanese cruiser Ashigara, the first Japanese warship to visit Germany in thirty years, was hailed with great satisfaction by the German press.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking before an estimated crowd of 7,000 persons tonight, said the Supreme Court's validation of the Social Security Act "means a great deal to all the people of our country."

Arthur J. Hopper, secretary and manager of the Chesebrough Building Company, 24 State Street, Manhattan, a subsidiary of H. L. Doherty Co., with which he had been associated for thirty-seven years, died at his home here this afternoon after a fortnight's illness, at the age of 67.

President Roosevelt's leaders in Congress looked hopefully to him tonight for a signal to compromise the controversial judiciary reorganization program, after the Supreme Court had given the government a wide-sweeping victory on the Social Security Act and thus further cut the propulsion from behind the court bill.

Numerica, although apparently unknown to most persons who read of it in the obituaries of John D. Rockefeller as a game in which the financier found relaxation after meals for many years, is said to have been played for more than a century in England.

In the $1,800,000 income tax proceeding against John J. Raskob and Pierre S. du Pont in the Old Postoffice Building, the Treasury yesterday called as an expert document witness Wilmer Souder of the National Bureau of Standards.

The Fort Worth Denver City railroad has ordered four passenger cars from the E. G. Budd Manufacturing Company, according to Railway Age. The Aliquippa Southern is inquiring for twenty rack cars; the American Railroad of Peru for forty tank cars;

The Supreme Court decision upholding the unemployment insurance section of the Social Security Act will cost the railroads $16,000,000 as of 1936, $32,000,000 this year and $48,000,000 next year, according to an estimate made by Dr. Julius H. Parmelee, economist of the Association of American Railroads.

After floundering around for hours off No Man's Land, squat sea mole out in the Atlantic southwest of the island of Martha's Vineyard, the America's Cup yacht Endeavour, which had been nineteen days out from Southampton, England, arrived here this afternoon.

POLITICS FROM INSIDE, by Sir Austen Chamberlain. (Yale, $5.) Excerpts from intimate letters, 1906-1914. THE BEST SHORT STORIES OF 1937, the Edward J. O'Brien. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50). Mr. O'Brien's annual selection.

The Prix Strassburger, a $1,000 award for the best newspaper or book contributing to Franco-American amity, for 1936 was won by Raoul de Roussy de Sales, New York correspondent of the Paris-Soir and the Paris Midi.

After weeks of wet and gloom, lovely sunshiny weather, with larks singing, ushered in the British amateur golf championship today. The course was still wet, slow and heavy, eminently on the side of the big battalions,

The body of John D. Rockefeller left here this afternoon at 6:42 o'clock (New York time) bound for Pocantico Hills, N. Y., the first stop on the way to its final resting place in the Rockefeller family plot in Cleveland.

On second thought and sight "Bet Your Life" is still one of those little pieces of friskiness that should be resolutely discouraged. When it first opened early last month the pregustators let out a powerful lot of groaning.

Striking automobile workers in Saginaw plants of the General Motors Corporation agreed tonight to go back to work tomorrow as requested by the International officers of the United Automobile Workers Union.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Dennis Blakeslee of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Greene Blakeslee, to John Rionda Doty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Keese Doty of Cuba and Sandis Field, Mass.

More than 1,500 persons attended a solemn requiem mass yesterday morning at St. Edmund's Roman Catholic Church, East Nineteenth ON Street and Avenue T, Brooklyn, for the Rev. Denis A. Maloney, the pastor, who died in the church rectory on Friday.
Setting a terrific pace for forty-one rival pairs, the veteran Jim Barnes of Crescent and the youthful Frank Strafaci of Shore View scored a 32, 32--6 to win the Long Island P. G. A. one-day
The 117th annual commencement week exercises of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, Chelsea Square, opened last evening.

Acceptance of a settlement offer of $1,350,000 in a stockholders' suit brought against various banks and former officers and directors of the National Surety Company was stayed yesterday by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division at the request of Mrs. Lillian Boehm, owner of 200 shares.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation is expected to be called soon to approve a $10,000,000 bond issue for refunding purposes and to provide funds for expansion and for additional working capital.
Bobby Pacho, Mexican welterweight, received credit for a knockout victory over Joey Greb of Herkimer, N. Y., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Carl Hubbell's phenomenal mastery over all his rivals in the National League hung by a slender thread today. But the thread held, and by dint of a heroic piece of relief work by the tall, blond-thatched Dick Coffman, the sensational two-season winning streak of baseball's foremost pitcher remains intact.

Kenneth Franzheim, New York architect, has been named by Arnold Constable Co. to draw the plans for the company's new suburban store to be erected on the site formerly occupied by Loew's Theatre with frontages on Main Street and North Avenue, in New Rochelle.
First survey flights in both directions for the New York-Bermuda air service are scheduled for this morning if the weather provides good visibility.
A summary of the principal assets and liabilities of the reporting member banks, together with changes for the week and the year ended May 19, follows:
Dudley Dawson, general manager of the Dominion Bank of Canada, died here tonight at the age of 57. Mr. Dawson began his banking career with-the Dominion Bank in Uxbridge, Ont., in 1896.

Two homers by Bud Hafey today evened up the Montreal Royals' International League double-header with the Buffalo Bisons. The center fielder's clouts accounted for all the Royals' runs in the nightcap and gave them a 3-1 triumph after a 1-0 loss in the opener.

For the first time in its history the Medical Society of the State of New York formally offered tonight definite proposals for cooperative action by the medical profession and government in providing medical care.

Lloyd George, former Prime Minister of Great Britain, was an "extreme radical" between 1917 and 1919, but "old age has mollified and modified him," according to a deposition made last year in London by Ralph Blumenfeld, Wisconsinborn editor of The London Daily Express.

The Hamburg-American liner Reliance returns today from a 136-day cruise around the world in which she visited thirty-seven ports in twenty-nine countries. Among her passengers are Judge Ferdinand Jelke Jr., of Bayville, L. I.; William Cromwell Knox, retired English actor; Dr. Eberhard von Stohrer, former German Minister in Bucharest,

A mob entered an undertaking parlor here tonight, took the body of a Negro identified by Sheriff W. J. Catledge as Willie Reed, confessed slayer of two white women, and dragged it around the public square behind a procession of automobiles.

Again the brimming pushcarts hold New miracles of flowering gold. Last year, perhaps, from distant hills, They brought their yellow daffodilsNot these, not ever these before, Were offerings at April's door!

Miss Virginia Waugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Morton Waugh Jr. of Scarsdale, has completed plans for her marriage to William Amos Grier, son of Mrs. L. Scheer Grier of Baldwin, L. I., which will take place the night of June 12 in the Hitchcock Memorial Church, Scarsdale. The Rev.

The purchase of gasoline and oil valued at $972,270.28 was announced today by the Navy Department. Out of eight separate purchases, the largest single order was awarded to the Standard Oil Company of Kentucky for 2,574,000 gallons of aviation gasoline at a cost of $212,562.50.

A strong. protest against the "fulsome adulation" accorded to the monarchy was made in the House of Commons today by Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor opposition, in a speech that in a sense was post-mortem on the coronation.

Haggard but determined, Philip A. Baumgartner maintained a one-man hunger strike demonstration today against the current distribution of Federal CCC funds. The CCC clerk, father of six children, insists he should receive more than $105 monthly.

Postmaster General James A. Farley said here today that the Supreme Court decisions upholding the unemployment insurance and old age pensions provisions of the Social Security Act were "splendid but not unexpected."

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 91 per cent of capacity this week, as compared with 90 per cent last week, a gain of 1 point, or 1.1 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimates. A month ago a high record of 92.3 per cent was set.
Miss Faith Rockefeller, grandniece of John D. Rockefeller, who died yesterday, has filed a permit with the building inspector here to erect an $80,000 home on Lake Avenue, Greenwich.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called the Supreme Court's decision today on the Soicial Security Act "one of the finest the court ever rendered."

Yesterday's decisions of the Supreme Court, upholding both major sections of the Social Security Act and a supplementary State law, constitute another historic step in the process of adapting the great charter of American democracy to the changing needs of changing times.

Lewis Allen Browne, author, dra- die matist and newspaper man, of West Englewood, died this morning in the Englewood Hospital. He became ill Saturday and underwent an emergency intestinal operation Sunday.

Miss Allegra Knapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Knapp of Bayside, Queens, was married to James Bain Brickell, son of Mrs. Charles C. B. Brickell of Miami, Fla., and the late Mr. Brickell, yesterday afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church, Bayside, by the Rev. Dr. Richard W. Trapnell, the rector.

The Browns divided a two-game series with the Athletics by taking the concluding contest today, 8 to 6. The defeat halted the Athletics' winning streak of three in a row and dropped the Mackmen into second place behind the Yankees.

The a Kempis-Groote Academy, commemorating the publication of the English translation of "The Following of Christ" from the original text of George Groote, fourteenth century Dutch author, was formally opened last night at the Catholic Book Club,140 East Fortyfifth Street.

Crown Prince Michael of Rumania arrived here from London this morning as the personal representative of his father, King Carol, to invite President Ignaz Moscicki of Poland to visit Bucharest. The Prince's visit has little political significance. It was arranged only to settle a complicated problem of international protocol.

If "unsound and unreasonable" efforts to gain exclusive control of markets or to drive competitors from the field by special legislation are continued, "we are certain to see increasing unrest and commercial conflict," Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, recently elected president of the Sales Executives Club of New York, declared yesterday at the organization's luncheon meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Water St, 497, 24x160 to 252 South St: J. and J. Kauffman Realty Co. Isidore Kauffman, president, to Josephine M. Crow, 314 Park St. Montclair, N. J.; prior mtg $11,500, due Jan. 15, 1940, 6 per cent; $3,000. 88th St, 504 E. 25x100.8; Windsor Equities, Inc, Aaron Tuchmann, president, to Jacob R. Schiff, 515 Park Ave, due, , as bond; $5,000.

The National Bible Institute will hold commencement exercises for a graduating class of twenty-nine students at 8 o'clock tonight in the institute auditorium at 340 West Fifty-fifth Street. The Rev. Dr.
Every liberal mind must endorse the objectives outlined in the President's message to Congress and the intentions embodied in the Connery-Black bill on wages and hours.

Legisolation to limit incomes to a definite maximum and to establish "a living minimum wage for every worker" was advocated today by the resolutions committee of the Northern Baptist Convention, headed by the Rev. Clarence W. Kemper of Denver, Col.

Tributes from leaders in several fields reached the Rockefeller offices in Rockefeller Center yesterday. They came from many parts of the world. At the chancery office in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Cardinal Hayes in a brief statement declared that although Mr. Rockefeller had accumulated an "unparalleled" fortune, he disposed of it "wisely and beneficently."

AHBENS--William H., beloved husband of Augusta M. (nee Hunken) and father of Augusta W. and brother of Mrs. William G. Koelle, in his sixtieth year, on Monday, May 24. Funeral services will be held at his home, 635 East 18th St., Brooklyn, on Thursday, May 27, at 2 P. M. Relatives and friends invited to attend. Interment Lutheran Cemetery.
The Madrigal Singers, directed by Lehman Engel, presented a program of choral music from preRevolutionary to post-prohibition periods at the WPA Theatre of Music last night.

Governor Lehman's approval of the Rogers-Allen Milk Bill and his veto of the McElroy-Young Milk Bill were criticized yesterday by John J. Dillon, chairman of the New York State Milk Committee and publisher of the Rural New Yorker.

Governor Lehman signed today the bill giving women the right to serve on juries. The measure, supported by Senator Kleinfeld of Brooklyn, becomes effective Sept. 1. Under the terms of the bill qualifications similar to those required of men are provided.
William Woodward's Perifox turned up with an injured leg today and dropped into third place in tonight's Victoria Club call-over of betting odds for the Derby to be run at Epsom Downs June 2.

Replying to questions by the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., Allen E. Throop, general counsel of the Securitles and Exchange Commission, has sent to the conference a ruling dealing with exemption provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 intended to clear up many uncertainties and misunderstandings which the conference said existed among brokers and dealers throughout the country.
Toeliminate ill-will among campus fraternities, the Student Senate of Dickinson College has abolished all class offices except those of the senior class. The Senate of 20,

Samuel Moll, proprietor of the Napanoch Country Club, a Summer resort at Napanoch, N. Y., denied yesterday, through his New York offices, that fire had destroyed the $150,000 main building of the place on Sunday.

The liner Normandie, which arrived here from New York at 7 o'clock this evening and is scheduled to return Wednesday, may be unable to sail as a result of a seamen's strike that has broken out in major French ports.
Early prices on the Cotton Exchange proved to be the best in yesterday's light trading and a setback left the list with losses of 4 to 6 points.

The Duke of Windsor and- Mrs. Wallis Warfield abandoned plans today for a honeymoon yachting cruise. Herman -L. Rogers, New York spokesman for the couple, in announcing the decision, also said there would be no aerial honeymoon. The duchess-to-be:does not like airplane trips.

County Judge Peter J. Brancato of Brooklyn, who charged recently that Police Commissioner Lewis V. Valentine had discriminated against policemen of Italian extraction in the matter of time off, was denounced yesterday by Commissioner Valentine as "a five-cent peanut politician" who "can be found sitting five nights a week in a political clubhouse accepting political contracts." He also called Judge Brancato's discrimination charge "a lie."

The "pay-as-you-kill" attitude of motorists covered by automobile liability insurance was condemned by more than one speaker at the eighth annual conference of the American Management Association here today.

Stocks closed steady and mixed in slowest trading in weeks; turnover, 684,014 shares. United States Government bonds strong in heavier trading, corporate and foreign issues firm and dull; transactions, $8,911,900.
Dr. and Mrs. Austen Fox Riggs will come today from Stockbridge, Mass., to the Carlyle. Viscount Hinchingbrooke has returned from Chicago and is at the Pierre.

The golden jubilee celebration of the Sisters of the Divine Compassion, who conduct the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here, was held today in conjunction with the annual celebration of the feast day of the Rev. Mother Mary Aloysia, president and founder of the college.

Turpentine firm, 35 1/2c; sales 143 barrels; receipts 445 barrels; shipments 904 barrels; stock 25,741 barrels. Resin firm: sales 579; receipts 1,602; shipments 2,209; stock 49,506. Quote B, D. $7.40; E, $7.85; F to N, $8.32 1/2; W. G. $8.45; WW, X, $9.15.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 1,200,000 shares of $1 par common stock of the Cosden Petroleum Corporation.

Funeral services as simple as his life during his last few years were arranged yesterday for John D. Rockefeller Sr. as his body was started north on a special car from Ormond Beach, Fla., his Winter home, where he died early Sunday morning.

King George and Queen Elizabeth went to St. Paul's this morning and there joined a great congregation in the Empire Day service, which also was in the nature of a service of thanksgiving for their successful coronation.

Insurgent troops routed three "lost battalions" of government soldiers tonight in a swift charge up the slopes of mountains south of Amorebieta, nine miles east of Bilbao. Prisoners captured included Basque and Asturian groups, apparently wandering about in the mountains without knowing their exact position and the close proximity of Insurgents.

Stockholders of the Phelps Dodge Corporation yesterday approved the issuance of $20,285,000 debentures, the funds from which will be used for development and improvement, and they are expected to receive by June 8 rights to subscribe to $4 in debentures for each share of stock held. The terms of the issue,

Miss Natalie Folsom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hiram Tuttle Folsom of Hamilton, Mass., will be married to Francis P. Clark, son of Mrs. J. Francis A. Clark of this city and Newport, R. I., on Friday noon. The ceremony will be performed in Christ Episcopal Church, Hamilton, in the presence of relatives.
Funeral services for Mrs. Alice Morris Mills, wife of the Rev. Charles S. Mills, were held this afternoon at her late home, 36 Gillett Street. Mrs. Mills died on Friday at the age of 78.

The Cunard White Star Line flagship Queen Mary will start her second year in service during her eastbound voyage tomorrow. She sailed from Southampton for New York on May 27, 1936, on her maiden voyage and has since crossed the Atlantic forty-one times.

Studies being made by the Mayor's Committee on City Planning are producing facts which indicate the need for drastic changes in zoning and housing in order to eliminate social and economic ills, Lawrence M. Orton, secretary to the committee, announced yesterday.
Isaac H. Appel, a former proofreader on The Sun for fourteen years, died Sunday at his home, 2,004 East Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, of a cerebral hemorrhage, at the age of 71.

Governor Lehman tonight issued a statement expressing gratification over the decision of the Supreme Court in upholding the constitutionality of the unemployment insurance and old age pension legislation. His statement follows:

Automobiles, razor blades, cameras and films are the American products which appear best capable of breaking into foreign colonies, dominated by European nations, H. S. Gardner, chairman of the board of the Gardner Advertising Company, reported here yesterday on his return from a round-theworld trip, which began in January.
A statement explaining the proposed Fair Labor Standards Act introduced in the House today was made by its sponsor, Chairman Connery of the House Labor Committee, as follows:
The birth of a third son to Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh was disclosed today by the famous aviator in the family's English retreat.

Invoking the Wagner Labor Relations Act on the ground that it gives employers the same rights as labor, the Apex Hosiery Company filed suit in Federal court here today seeking to oust 250 sit-down strikers from its plant and to compel the strikers to observe the collective bargaining provisions of the law.

The long-established two-cent deposit on regular beer bottles will be reduced to 1 cent on June 1 in New York, while the recently introduced "steinie" bottle, originally planned to be "non-returnable," to compete with cans, will also be redeemed at 1 cent, it was learned here yesterday.

Two midtown restaurants were ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter to drop "Rector's" from their names within three months. They are Rector's Tavern and Rector's Midtown Cafeteria, Inc.

The fiftieth anniversary of Josef Hofmann's debut in this country as a concert pianist will be celebrated at a jubilee concert at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday evening, Nov. 28, according to plans worked out yesterday.
Home runs by Debs Garms and Gene Moore gave the Boston Bees a 3-to-1 victory over the Cubs in the final of the series today.
The prospects for Canadian business in the coming Summer are favorable, according to the Bank of Montreal.

While Mrs. Henry Dietrich of Gedney Farm, the defending champion, was qualifying with a sure but unspectacular 84, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg completely stole the show in the women's annual metropolitan golf championship today.

President Roosevelt called upon Congress today to "extend the frontiers of social progress" by enacting a maximum hour-minimum wage law which also would abolish child labor. A bill embodying those aims was introduced in both houses immediately after the reading of the Presidential message.
youth stricken with food poisoning who walked several blocks to summon aid before collapsing, was credited by physicians today with saving the lives of five members of a Troy family.

Charles Dexter Owen Sr., treasurer of the Beacon Blanket Mill here, a director of the Firemen's Mutual Insurance Company of Providence, R. I., and of the Dexdale Hosiery Mills, Lansdale, Pa., died at the age of 61 this morning in his home here.

The Rev. Dr. James J. Dunlop, a retired Congregationalist minister, died in Pennsylvania Hospital here yesterday in his sixty-eighth year. Born in New York, he was educated there at City College and at Princeton Theological Seminary.

Constant attention to the activities not only of professional drys but also of business groups whose selfinterest aligns them with the drys, was urged upon some 500 retail liquor dealers at the opening session of the convention of the New York State Organization of Retail Liquor Store Associations at the Capitol Hotel yesterday by several speakers.
Five seniors of the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School were recommended for graduate scholarships today in President Albert W. Beaven's annual report to the trustees.

The New York Employing Printers Association, at its annual meeting last night in the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street, elected Nathan Goldman of Isaac Goldmann Company, 80 Lafayette Street, as president.
We will take away their children. These we will train and educate to become new Germans. We will not permit the to lapse into the old way of thinking, but will give them thorough training.

Isaac Sigler of 104 Alexander Avenue, oldest native resident of Montclair, whose ancestors came here from Holland in 1751, died here last night at the age of 99. In the Civil War he served as a carpenter, repairing military equipment. He cast his first vote for Abraham Lincoln.

Artists began registration yesterday at Hotel Brevoort for the eleventh semi-annual outdoor exhibition of the Washington Square Association, which will open at 10 o'clock next Friday morning. More than 200 artists are expected to exhibit.

As soon as the Legislature passed tonight under suspension of the rules a bill exempting fourth class counties from the statutory requirement that prosecutors be counselors-atlaw, Governor Hoffman sent to the Senate for confirmation the nomination of C. Lloyd Fisher to be prosecutor of Hunterdon County.

The Terrace Restaurant at Sherry's and the roof garden of the Astor were opened yesterday for the Summer season, the former at noon, and the latter, which has been redecorated to resemble a garden on the Italian Riviera, for the dinner hour.

Tne Supreme Court upheld today in three historic opinions the constitutionality of the Social Security Act affecting 26,000,000 workers and 2,700,000 employers. It was a decisive victory for the administration.

The insured mortgage plan developed by the Federal Housing Administration was described today as beneficial to both the home owner and the banker by Stewart McDonald, FHA national administrator, who predicted the plan would continue as a healthy influence away from speculative building.

Following is the text of the Hours and Wages Bill as introduced in the House by Representative Connery: A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF FAIR LABOR STANDARDS IN EMPLOYMENTS IN AND AFFECTING INTERSTATE COMMERCE, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES.

The Woodrow Wilson Medal was presented to Ambassador Norman H. Davis for his efforts on behalf of peace at an informal gathering yesterday afternoon in the Woodrow Wilson Memorial Library, 8 West Fortieth Street.

The Browns divided a two-game series with the Athletics by taking the concluding contest today, 8 to 6. The defeat halted the Athletics' winning streak of three in a row and dropped the Mackmen into second place behind the Yankees.
All camouflage about the real military purpose of the Hitler Youth training was thrown aside here today at a congress of Hitler Youth leaders.

Dr. Frank H. Lattin, for fourteen years a Orleans County Assemblyman, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 76. Mr. Lattin served in the Assembly from 1917 through 1930. A fruit farmer, he acted as judge of fruit exhibits at the annual Syracuse State Fair for thirty-five years.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simpson of this place today observed the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. Born in Pocklington, England, and wed in New York, they have been residents of Clifton for more than forty years.

Roderic H. Davison of Auburn, N. Y., as the outstanding member of the Class of 1937 in Princeton University's School of Public and International Affairs, tonight became the first recipient of a prize in public affairs established this year by the New Jersey Society of the Sons of the Revolution.
Detroit at New York-Rowe vs. Broaca. Cleveland at Philadelphia-Harder vs. Smith. Chicago at Washington-Lee or Lyons vs. De Shong. St. Louis at Boston-Walker vs. Grove.

Creditors and stockholders of the New York Woman, Inc., publishers of the magazine of that name, must post $5,000 by June 3 if they wish to continue its publication, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson ruled yesterday, dismissing a request for a delay of thirty days in liquidation proceedings.

The New York Central completed today presentation of its case in the suit of five railroads and their subsidiaries before Federal Judge Phillip Forman for a permanent injunction restraining New Jersey from collecting the full amount of taxes levied for 1934, 1935 and 1936.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, which is being issued in revised form beginning with this week, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 19:

Deposits in national banks amounted to $26,515,110,000 on March 31, a decline of $1,093,287,000, or 3.96 per cent, since Dec. 31, 1936, J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today. The deposits, however, were $1,655,655,000, or 6.66 per cent, greater than on March 4. 1936.
Thirty men's clothing plants, employing , ??000 men and women, were forced ?? close down here today when several hundred hand tailors went on trike.

Solicitors for Lady Robert Houston, who left a fortune estimated between $17,000,000 and $25,000,000 when she died last December, said today that distribution of the estate had been held up while they searched for a lone relative, believed to be in Australia.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 24, unless specified: At San Pedro: Algorma, May 23; Tern, May 22. Norfolk to Annapolis: Arkansas, Decatur. At Boston Yard: Badger, May 22; Tillman, May 23. At Washington Yard, May 23: Cuyahoga, Potomac.

Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, speaking as toastmaster at the commission's annual dinner to the press at the Manhattan Club last night, stated that, in the eventuality of favorable action being taken on pari-mutuel betting in the 1938 constitutional convention of the State, he would strongly oppose any exorbitant "take" by either the State or the tracks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the defeat of the Republican party in the last Presidential election, grave doubts have arisen that it can survive. The fact that 17,000,000 people voted for Landon does not mean that there is today an irreducible minimum which will continue to vote as Republicans under any leader and on any platform.

The Navy Department announced today the purchase from the United Aircraft Corporation of eleven Sikorsky twin-engined amphibian monoplanes to cost $1,960,790. The planes, which: are heavy load car-. riers of long range, can be adapted to patrol duty as well as transport..

Judge John J. Freschi of General Sessions, in a fourteen-page decision, yesterday sustained the demurrer of three of the twelve directors of the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company on their indictment, in November, 1934, for alleged misdemeanor violations of the State Insurance Law.
A wild throw by Cecil Travis handed the Detroit Tigers two runs today, enough to give them their second victory in two days over Washington. The score was 3 to 1.

Professor August Piccard and Max Cosyns will make a minor ascenoion tomorrow in a balloon named Piccard-Cosyns in order to verify certain of their scientific calculations regarding the properties of gases.

The report of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor to the federation conference here today was as follows: To the Representatives of National and International Unions Affiliated with the American Federation of Labor in Attendance at This Conference:

A record school budget of more than $150,000,000. for 1938 - an increase of $8,000,000 over this yearwas predicted yesterday by school officials in announcing the first public hearing on the new budget to be held tomorrow evening at the Board of Education hall, 500 Park Avenue.

Estate, $550. To William Dudde, friend, 590 E. 3d St., Mount Vernon, N. Y., executor. DITTEMORE, JOHN V. (May 10). Estate, less than $5,000. To Edith L. Bingham, former wife, 525 W. 238th St., residue. Mark de B. Rafailovich, 245 E. 39th St., executor.

Miss Florence E. Jardine, daughter of Mrs. Andrew C. Jardine of this place and the late Mr. Jardine, was married tonight in the West Side Presbyterian Church here to Charles A. Corson of Painted Post, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Corson of Tenafly, N. J.

Professor OTTO SCHMIDT'S magnificent achievement in flying to the North Pole and establishing there a little scientific tent colony which is sending regular weather reports by radio to Moscow is not an accident but another step in that systematic Soviet conquest of the ice which has been progressing ever since the Commission for the Study of the North was formed in 1919.

John J. Sullivan, general organizer for the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Operators, an A. F. of L. affiliate, announced last night that he planned to protest to the Public Service Commission, the Yonkers police and the Yonkers Mayor against the free transportationtion service given by the Transport Workers Union in competition with the bus lines of the Suburban -Bus Company.

The unsolved murder of Norman Redwood, leader of a New York sandhog's union, at Teaneck, N. J., three months ago was the subject of an angry exchange of statements yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and John J. Breslin, Prosecutor of Bergen County, N. J.
News reports dealing with the official etiquette crisis at Manila are rather vague.

Colden Ave (16-4446), w s, 300 s of Allerton Ave. 100x100; Saltzer-Shelnman Realty Cor, to Meggos Realty Corp, 2,566 Radcliff Ave. Bedford Park Blvd, 245 (12-3303), Sarah Johnson to Helen C. Cavanaugh 245 Bedford Park Blvd.
Following the departure of her husband, Al Jolson, from Warners, Ruby Keeler has received her release from the studio, it was learned today, and is negotiating with RKO and Universal.

Governors Island So much of paragraph 8, Special Orders 116, May 19, 1937, relating to Major Carroll M. Gale, Infantry, is revoked. So much of paragraph 3, Special Orders 117, May 20, 1937, relating to 2d Lt. Charles A. Karazia, Infantry Reserve, is revoked.

Contention that the Chase National Bank of New York, as trustee, possesses an independent right and duty of suing to prevent injury to holders of bonds of the Indianapolis Gas Company was laid today before Federal Judge Robert C. Baltzell by Newton D. Baker.

Miss Helen Wright Bradley, daughter of Mrs. Charles J. Bradley of Berwyn, Pa., and the late Mr. Bradley, has chosen June 12 for her marriage to Stephen L. Demarest, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. L. DAmarest of this city.

The 500 Basque children to be evacuated from Bilbao by the American Board of Guardians for Basque Refugee Children will be distributed here among private families and Summer camps, and in September a children's home will be set up in New York City for the younger groups, according to plans announced here yesterday by Dr. Frank Bohn, secretary of the board.

WASHINGTON, May 24.-The War De apartment released the following orders to day dated May 22: COLONELS Pickering, R. R., Adjutant General's De apartment, detailed with the Organized Reserves in addition to other duties in Washington, D. C. Babcock, C. S., Cay., to retirement.

By H. LOUIS HOLLANDER Elizabeth St, 120, 6-story tenement, 25.4x102 irreg; Citizens Savings Bank against 118-20 Elizabeth St, Inc; due, 21,723; to plaintiff for $1,000. By WALTER JACOBSON 36th St, 346 W. 5-story tenement, 25x98.9; Kathryn McGuire against Margaret F. Murray; due. $10.702; taxes, , $3,434; to plaintiff for $4,000.

Notably sharp increases in merchandise inventories for local department stores at the end of last month, compared with April, 1936, were shown in the analysis issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The Casco Products Corporation reported sales for the two months ended on April 30, compared with a year ago, as follows:

With the basic constitutionality of the Social Security Act established by the Federal Supreme Court, the New York State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance prepared to press for 'three major amendments to the unemployment insurance title of the act.

Lusty Red Sox batting, led by Jimmy Foxx with a homer and two doubles, today enabled Rube Walberg to defeat the White Sox, 9 to 5, for his first victory of the season. Boston collected ten hits off John Rigney.

The city of Dallas, Texas, will offer for sale in competitive bidding on June 4 two new issues of bonds aggregating $790,000. The financing will consist of an issue of $750,000 of school improvement bonds for which bidders have the option of designating either twentyyear or thirty-year serial maturities, with coupons of 2 1/2, 2 3/4 or 3 per cent;
