To Fire Hazard School The following members shall be directed to report at the Fire Hazard Inspectors' School, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 1:30 P. M., on the dates specified: Group 1, Platoon 1, May 25, June 8, 14. 18, 24.

Receipt of a gift of $150,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for construction of a museum to house the findings of American excavators in the ancient Athenian market place was announced today, twenty-four hours after the death of John D. Rockefeller, who made the benefaction possible.

Second Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Sullivan, in charge of the Bureau of Licenses, warned night club owners yesterday that they would have to "clean up" their shows or face revocation of their licenses.

John Woodruff, the Olympic 800meter champion from Pitt, yesterday picked the events for his anticipated double in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium on Friday and Saturday. He eschewed the mile, despite the fact that he is a 4:20 man, and chose the harder pairing of the 440 and the 880.

Miss Cynthia Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin - Arnold Smith of Bayside, Queens, has selected the afternoon of June 12 as the date for her marriage to Rfobert Edward Holmes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Joseph Holmes of Newton, Mass., formerly of Flushing, Queens.
Meyer Berkman, convicted of compulsory prostitution with the Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania gang, received a suspended sentence yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

The 3,000,000 Jews of Poland went on strike for two hours today in protest against the latest serious outbreak of anti-Semitic violence, the flare-up in Brzesc-litewski [BrestLitovsk], in which 1,200 Jewish shops and homes were reported wrecked and looted, although the actual casualties were held down to about forty wounded through Jewish non-resistance.

Glamorgan, Lancashire and Derbyshire turned in victories in county cricket matches concluded a day ahead of schedule today. The Welsh county won from Northamptonshire by an innings and 54 runs; Lancashire defeated, Warwickshire by at innings Warwickshire by an innings and 124, and Derbyshire had an 82-run margin over Kent.

Miss Elizabeth Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Crescens Hubbard of this city, will be married on June 12 to Clifford Lee Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clifford Lord of Mount Vernon, in the Presbyterian Church here.

The Araho Stable's five-year-old Mucho Gusto gained his fourth victory in five starts today by nosing out Miss A. Doris's Lady Higloss in the $2,500 added Pilgrim handicap, feature event of the Suffolk Downs opening program.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000, including 3,500 directs. Generally strong to 10 higher than Friday's average; top 12.10:
A Park Avenue apartment building figured in one of the largest of the real estate transactions reported by brokers in Manhattan yesterday.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Herman Finkelstein, Louis D. Frohlich, Bernard Sobol, Herman A. Benjamin, Peter Seitz, Ernest Angell, Frank Aranow and David Schenker of New York City were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had:

Aaron Gellen, president of the Iceland Fur Dying Corporation with offices in New York and Haverstraw, N. Y., died Sunday at the Beth Israel Hospital after an illness of ten days. He was 57 years old. Mr. Gellen was active in Brooklyn philanthropic affairs. His home was at 92 East Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

The four-story brick apartment and store building at 509 Washington Street and the three-family brick dwelling at the rear of the plot, known as 508 Court Street, Hoboken, N. J., have been sold by George B. Spath Jr. to Sophie Beck.

Topping thirty-four teams, one of the largest fields of the current season, Joe Donato from Amawalk and his amateur golf mate, Frank Carino of the home club, came out ahead in the Westchester P. G. A. best-ball event today with a 64 over

President Albert Lebrun, accompanied by Premier Leon Blum, several other Cabinet Ministers, a great many foreign Ambassadors and Ministers and all of the principal directors of the International Paris Exposition of 1937, today inaugurated the great fair along the banks of the Seine.

The Rev. John H. Esquirol, former attorney and local Democratic leader, was ordained to the priesthood of the Protestant Episcopal Church by the Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Bishop of Long Island, at services this morning at the Cathedral of the Incarnation here.
Miss Helen Jacobs blasted her way into the third round of women's singles in the French hard court tennis championships today, but two young Americans in the men's division were eliminated.

Commercial and industrial failures reported to Dun Bradstreet in the week ended May 20 were 187, against 190 for the previous week and 174 in the corresponding 1936 week. The current figure marked the third increase over the 1936 comparative week.
A partial breaking of the drought in the Canadian Northwest which had threatened to reduce this year's harvest was responsible in part for a lower range of wheat prices today.

The report of the Federal Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,723,310 after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.
Harry H. Learned, a lawyer, of New London, Conn., died here yesterday after a long illness in the Hotel Wentworth, 59 West Fortysixth Street, where he spent the Winter. His age was 68.

Dr. Lewis McFarland Gaines, one of the South's leading physicians, died here today. He was 59 years old. Dr. Gaines was the son of the late Dr. Frank H. Gaines, founder and president of Agnes Scott College.

Leonard Haberman, who was convicted last week of aiding Robert J. Suhay and Alfred Power, both facing murder charges, in holding up and robbing the Northern Westchester Bank at Katonah, N. Y., last March, received a prison sentence of eight years when he appeared yesterday before Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz.

An overwhelming demand for war against the Committee for Industrial Organization dominated the special conference of the American Federation of Labor today after the 300 delegates heard the executive council's recommendations calling for creation of a war chest and for a purge of C. I. O. unions from State federations and city central labor bodies.

Scoring a pair of runs in the first inning on two errors, a fielder's choice and two errors a fielder's choice and an outfield fly, the Toronto Maple Leafs coasted to a 2-0 victory over the Rochester Red Wings this afternoon.

While they still have five rounds ahead of them, two of the thirteen players who are fighting for the four unfilled places on the United States Ryder Cup team made a good start in today's qualifying round of the national P. G. A. championship.

Fordham's newest Flash gave the Rams a 1-0 victory over City College yesterday at the Maroon field, the mercury-footed Mike Hearn racing home from third base on a pop fly that few ball players could have converted into a run.

A warn- higher; ing that legislation impends which will outlaw railway holding companies was given today when Senator Truman of Missouri, acting chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee investigating the financing of railroads, asserted that action to this end should be the early business of Congress.

Demand for few cuts improved but in a general way trading lacked action. Traefa steer beef ruled steady to higher; veal mostly steady: lamb declined; pork advanced. Early trading in kosher meats only fair to slow. Opening prices about steady on beef. Other classes lower as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Regional committees representing the managements of railroads in the East, West and Southeast are to meet the heads of fourteen railway unions in Chicago on June 3 to negotiate demands by these unions for increases of 20 cents an hour in wages.
Two of the dissenting opinions rendered in the Supreme Court today on the unemployment features of the Social Security program are as follows:
Automobile output declined last week, although no change was called for seasonally, and the adjusted index receded to 129.0 from 131.8 (revised). It was 106.0 for the week ended May 23, 1936.

Legislation that would penalize employers who discriminate against persons more than 45 years old, because of their age, was passed in the Senate today, 17 to 14, and sent to Governor Charles F. Hurley.

Mr. and Mrs. John F. Kelly of Irvington, N. J., have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Rosemary Kelly, to Charles Arnold Hannen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Hannen of Nutley, N. J.

Eight persons were injured, including a patrolman who was clubbed accidentally by another policeman during a strike disturbance yesterday afternoon at the Eagle Electric Company plant at 59 Hall Street, in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn.
The New York World's Fair was accused yesterday by Paul J. Kern of the Municipal Civil Service Commission of running "a patronage mill" in the selection of the fair's employes.
The Fuertes Medal has been awarded to Charles Smith Whitney, '14, by the Cornell School of Civil Engineering. The award,
Dr. Hansford M. MacCurdy, an authority on eugenics and heredity and for thirty-one years Professor of Biology at Alma College, died today at the age of 72.

The Supreme Court's decision today upholding the Social Security Act and its previous decision on the National Labor Relations Act "makes it certain now" that Congress may enact laws to fix maximum hours, minimum wages and abolish child labor, Senator Robert F. Wagner declared here tonight.

Dr. Hugo Eckener arrived in Washington tonight to spend several days discussing with government officials ways and means to make available to the Deutsche Luftschiffbau Zeppelin and its operating subsidiary enough helium to supply a fleet of transatlantic airships.

A triple bill consisting of the ballet "The Bat," "Pagliacci" and "Cavalleria Rusticana" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight. "The Bat," with music from Johann Strauss's "Fle-, dermaus," will be danced by the American Ballet ensemble. Wilfred Pelletier will conduct.

Editorial comment on the President's hours and wages proposal, as gathered from newspapers in key cities of the country, indicates a general approval of the. program. Some, however, show opposition to the plan. The comments were as follows:

The Art Institute of Chicago has acquired from the Newhouse Galleries, Inc., 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, a portrait of "Squire Hyde of Hyde," painted by John Singleton Copley in 1777. It is a gift to the museum from the Friends of American Art.

Miss Alice G. Carr, director of the Marathon Health Clinic of the Near East Foundation in Greece, was guest of honor at a garden party given yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge at her home, Greystone, Riverdale-on-Hudson.
Scattering six hits and pitching himself out of half a dozen tight spots, Big Max Butcher today hurled the Dodgers to a brilliant 1-0 shut-out of the Reds for an even break in the two-game series.

Within a week of becoming Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, showed the nation today that he could stand firm against the bitterest attack he has ever had to face from the financial and business community.

The first annual Paley Amateur Radio Award was presented yesterday, at a luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, by William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, to Walter Stiles Jr. of Coudersport, Pa. ,Mr. Stiles received the award for his service in supplying, through his amateur transmitter, the sole direct means of communication for the 4,000 citizens of Renova, Pa., who were cut off from the outside world by flood waters in March, 1936.

To the Congress of the United States: The time has arrived for us to take further action to extend the frontiers of social progress. Such further action initiated by the legislative branch of the government, administered by the Executive and sustained by the judicial is within the common sense framework and purpose of our Constitution and receives beyond doubt the approval of our electorate.
The conference of the Oslo powers opened today at The Hague, thus bringing to a conclusion the long series of preliminary conferences held in Belgium and the Netherlands in recent months.

Armand A. Durante, securities dealer at 117 Liberty Street, and Irving W. Goodwin, his associate, both of whom sold oil royalties representing them to be as good as old-age pensions, were found guilty in Federal court yesterday on a twenty-four-count indictment alleging mail fraud and conspiracy, as well as violation of the Securities Act of 1933.

Mary Eaton of the stage and screen, one-time featured dancer in the "Ziegfeld Follies," was married here to Charles A. Emery of Los Angeles yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building by Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines.

That the investment community interpreted the Supreme Court's decision upholding the Social Security Act as a "life-saver" to the government's financial program was reflected by the brisk response made by outstanding Treasury oblizations in late trading yesterday.

The State Senate passed . three appropriation bills tonight before adjourning until tomorrow morning. The Assembly recessed earlier until Wednesday noon, after leaders of both parties had predicted that the Legislature may end its main session Thursday or Friday, to return either late in June or in the Fall.

Heavy increases in the holdings of gold by the United States were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. Imports yesterday and over the week-end amounted to $12,206,100, all from England, and at the same time $6,755,900 was released to this country from the stock of the metal held here under earmark for foreign account.

That W. H. Auden-Christopher Isherwood play, "The Ascent of F.6," now is reclining gracefully on the shelves of the Theatre Guild, under option for six months with the usual secondary option for six more.

The Misses Elizabeth Mandeville and Cornelia Housman Bracher, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Vasa K. Bracher of Dongan Hills, S. I., will be married in a double ceremony on Saturday afternoon, June 5, in Richmond, S. I. Miss Elizabeth will become the bride of Robert C. Vincent of New York, and Miss Cornelia will be married to John Thomas Gwynne, also of this city.

The Bolivian bondholders' protective committee, headed by United States Senator Bennett Champ Clark and David Gordon, an individual bondholder, took action yesterday in the Supreme Court of New York State in its suit against the Chase National Bank for more than $7,000,000.

Mrs. Emily E. Jacobs Muench, long active in Catholic charities here, died yesterday at her home, 217 Cleveland Street, after a long illness. She was the widow of Frederick B. Muench, who was president of the August Moll Manufacturing Company of New York, makers of silk braids.

R. B. Morrow, State adjutant of the American Legion, said that the Mississippi delegation would head the parade at the national convention in New York City, Sept. 21, by virtue of winning the membership trophy.

Edward F. Dunne, former Governor of Illinois, former Mayor of Chicago and a prominent figure in Democratic State and county politics for more than forty years, died this afternoon in his home, 737 Gordon Terrace. He was 83 years old. His death was the result of a complication of liver and heart ailments.
WPA workers, repairing parts of the Statue of Liberty, are fashioning a 250-foot copper apron to keep Miss Liberty's feet dry, the Works Progress Administration announced yesterday.
Prices in the stock market here improved. today in a cheerful atmosphere due to continued good industrial reports and Wall Street's Saturday strength.

A snowstorm, driven by a high wind, swirled over the North Pole today and this, together with heavy low-lying clouds, held back the remaining three planes, waiting at Rudolf Island to take off with the rest of the Soviet North Pole expedition's forty-two members.

THE NEW YORK TIMES quoted Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan incorrectly yesterday in connecting his statement on investigation of bus franchise bribery charges to former Mayor John P. O'Brien.

The Rev. Dr. Ellis B. Burgess, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, condemned what he called a "frittering" ministry in a sermon last night opening the ninth annual convention of the synod in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.
Queen Mary is 70 years old today. All the newspapers pay remarkable tributes to the "wonderful Queen" who with an amazing display of courage has put sorrow and distress behind her.
President Roosevelt, it was said today, is having his National Power Policy Bill redrafted, chiefly as a result of sharp differences of opinion among three Cabinet members.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine accepted yesterday a challenge from Prosecutor John J. Breslin of Bergen County to appear before a special session of the grand jury and tell what he knows about the murder of Norman Redwood, sandhog union leader, who was assassinated three months ago outside his home in Teaneck, N. J.
Mrs. Sally Davis, 31 years old, of 1,555 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, who was arrested May 12 and charged with violating the Sullivan law, was acquitted yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are May 24 unless specified: At Annapolis: Arkansas, Decatur, Wyoming. Pearl Harbor to San Diego, May 19: Dolphine, Holland, Nautilus, Pike, Porpolse, Shark.

A combination of the most favorable weather so far this season and declines in both the stock and grain markets increased selling pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. A tendency by some consumers to hedge either unsold goods or reserves of raw material furnished contracts which left prices 14 to 17 points lower.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000, including 2,000 directs. Market uneven, 10-25 lower than Monday's average, spots off more on light lights and sows; outlet narrow at full decline late; top $12.05;
Intractable pain and its alleviation and new anesthesia aids for surgery were described today at the annual meeting of the medical society of the State of New York.

Honorary Deputy Chief Michael F. Loughman died May 23. The funeral will take place from the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72d St., Manhattan. at 10:15 A. M., Wednesday, May 26, 1937. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Mr. and Mrs. Warren Prosser Smith will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at their home, 550 Park Avenue, for Miss Caroline A. Sayles, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Clark Sayles of Aldwill, Irvington, N. Y., and Ward R. Clark, whose marriage will take place next month in Irvington-on-Hudson.
The Valencia [Spanish] government has sent troops to Barbastro, thirty miles southeast of Huesca, to quell an Anarchist rising there. At least 100 persons have been assassinated.
This column some time ago heard the story of an American visitor in Greece who was a student of the classics and,

Miss Mary Elizabeth Brawley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Ellis Brawley of Chicago, has completed plans for her marriage to Thomas McChesney Torrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Cates Torrey of Grovedge, Scarsdale, N. Y., which will take place in St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church, Chicago, on June 19.

J. Edward Fagen, 50 years old, a Camden attorney, who was president of the Camden County League of Building and Loan Associations, was found dead of a shotgun wound tonight on the grounds of the Tavistock Country Club, near here.
Efforts to check the existence of a training camp for Americans to fight in the Spanish civil war in the area between Fallsburgh and this place in Sullivan County failed today.
MANHATTAN Estate, more than $10,000. To Augusta H. Barrett, widow, 600 W. 116th St., and Edward E. Barrett, brother, executor, 14 Clifton Terrace, Weehawken, N. J., onehalf residue each.

It's going to be a hard job keeping Byron Nelson, tall ex-Texan, off the American Ryder Cup team. Continuing in the form he displayed in winning the Masters tournament at Augusta this Spring, the 25-year-old Reading (Pa.) Country Club professional shot a 71 and walked off with the qualifying medal in the annual Professional Golfers Association championship today.

Eugene H. Amory, in 30 E 71st St; Agnes P. Keyes, in 115 E 67th St: Frederick Suydam, through Walter Samuels, Inc, in 108 E 66th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker. Flora Spiegelberg, through First Madison Realty Corp, in 1.070 Park Ave; Warren L. Marks. Daniel Brener, Inc. broker.

Two hundred and fifty policemen and eighty-three pickets responded yesterday to a call for a "mighty mass protest demonstration" of WPA employes outside the offices of The Daily News at 220 East Forty-second Street, between Second and Third Avenues.
The election of Inman H. Payne as president of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York was announced yesterday.

Miss Barbara Chisholm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm of the Savoy-Plaza and Strathglass Farm, Port Chester, N. Y., has completed the plans for her marriage to Robert L. Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Scott of Wellesley, Mass.

Al Roth, Bronx lightweight, evened the score with Irish Eddie Brink of Scranton, Pa., by gaining the decision in their feature eightround bout at the New York Coliseum last night. The return battle, furiously fought, was witnessed by 16,000 persons, 15,745 of whom paid.

AHRENS--William H., beloved husband of Augusta M. (nee Hunken) and father of Augusta W. and brother of Mrs. William G. Koelle, in his sixtieth year, on Monday, May 24. Funeral services will be held at his home, 635 East 18th St., Brooklyn, on Thursday, May 27, at 2 P. M. Relatives and friends invited to attend. Interment Lutheran Cemetery.

Twenty-four-hour express service on the Queens division of the city's Independent Subway will begin in July concurrently with the opening of the new Brooklyn-crosstown link in the same system, it was learned yesterday.

Irenee du Pont testified yesterday at the Old Postoffice Building that the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company was making "an enormous quantity of war explosives" when the Armistice was signed; but that it has since diverted its activity into the manufacture of paints, dyestuffs, organic chemicals and artificial silk.

Miss Hilkdegard L. Raubenheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Raubenheimer of Brooklyn, was married last night to John J. Klobasa, son of Mrs. Joseph Klobasa of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Klobasa, by the Rev. George Wells Arms in the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

Three errors by the Browns in the initial stanza led to a 4-2 Red Sox victory over St. Louis today and provided Lefty Grove with his second triumph of the year. The speedball southpaw allowed the Browns six safeties, three of them by Outfielder Ethan Allen.

Fred Berger, formerly an official of Joseph P. Day, Inc, has formed the Fred Berger Co, with offices at 70 Pine St, to engage in a realty brokerage and auction business. Harry A. Reffelt, formerly with L. J. Phillips Co and with Benjamin Benenson, has opened a general realty brokerage office at 9 E 40th St.

Gordon Stanley (Mickey) Cochrane, manager of the Detroit Tigers, one of the best-known and most popular figures in baseball, was in St. Elizabeth's Hospital last night in a serious condition with a fracture of the skull.

Sound working of the capital system has brought recovery from depression and resumption of the forward movement, Alexander Dana Noyes, financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday in an address at a luncheon of the New York Financial Advertisers Association at the Lawyers Club.

Bringing the Suffolk Downs crowd of 15,000 to its feet as they battled down the stretch, Mrs. Raymond Russell's Slavonia, 4-year-old daughter of Escobar, had a nose the best of it over Mrs. A. M. Creech's Miss Dolphin in the six-furlong Columbia Purse to pay $25 for $2 in the mutuels today.

Sales of a number of residential properties and' plots in Staten Island were reported yesterday by Cornelius G. Kolff, Inc., broker. The dwelling at 50 Townsend Avenue, Clifton, has been sold to Stephen Doty for occupancy;

The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced four additional applications for registration under the Securities Act of 1933 as follows: American Fldelity and Casualty Company, Inc., Richmond, Va.--90,000 shares of $5 par common stock to be offered at $11.50 a share, the net proceeds to be used for working capital.

Woodrow Wilson's qualities as a statesman, humanitarian and educator were praised by Robert Bridges, the poet and Princeton classmate and intimate friend of the wartime President, speaking yesterday at dedication ceremonies for the new Woodrow Wilson Memorial Room at the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street.

Alfred E. Smith, former Governor of New York, and his party arrived in Rome early this afternoon. Their first thought was to perform their devotions in the principal church in Christendom. Without even pausing to go to their hotel they drove from the station straight to St. Peter's, accompanied by Mgr. Ralph Hayes, rector of the North American College, who was the first to welcome them to Rome.

The Warners screen edition of Frank Wallace's novel of the prize ring, "Kid Galahad," starring Edward G. Robinson and Bette Davis and introducing a newcomer, Wayne Morris,. will go on view this morning at the Strand. . . The other opening of the day is "Three Years Without Women," an Italian importation, at the Broadway Cine Roma Theatre.

Thirty-one deaths from diphtheria have occurred in the city since the first of the year, compared with nine in the corresponding twentyweek period last year and a total of thirty-five deaths for all of 1936, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday in his health survey for the week ended last Saturday. Two deaths were reported in the week, one in Manhattan and one in Queens.

Taxicab drivers in this city would be restricted to working a ten-hour day at a minimum wage of $3.50 with one day off in every seven, under an amendment to the Code of Ordinances proposed yesterday by Alderman Newbold Morris, Manhattan Republican.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Mrs. Helen Frothingham Manning, the daughter of Mrs. Samuel Frothingham of Lenox, Mass., and the late Mr. Frothingham, to Warren Shepard Matthews of this city and New Milford, Conn.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,550,450 barrels, compared with 3,551,950 in the preceding week, a decline of 1,500, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

An apartment building, a warehouse and a garage figured in the Bronx real estate deals reported yesterday. The six-story multi-family house at 1,326 Commonwealth Avenue, 275 feet north of 172d Street, was sold by the State Mortgage Commission to a client of Isidor Tankus through the Kempner Realty CorPoration.

On the spacious lawn of Fordham University yesterday afternoon 3,500 school girls of the Bronx, ranging in age from six to thirteen, performed folk dances of many countries. The fete was under the auspices of the Girls' Branch of the Public Schools Athletic League.
Members of all parties in the House of Commons begged the British Government today not to miss the present opportunity for concluding a sound and useful trade agreement with the United. States.

A dispatch from Almeria tonight said the British freighter Greatend had suffered "considerable damage" when it was struck by bombs from Insurgent airplanes that today raided Almeria for the third successive day.
Edward West Mead, descendant of an old Greenwich family, died at his home in Texarkana, Ark., yesterday. Funeral services will be held for him at Christ Episcopal Church here tomorrow.

Today was another glorious, hot day at Sandwich, such as should have gladdened the hearts of all golfers from sunny countries overseas-a day for golf in shirt sleeves. The first American to start was Billy Sixty, widely known golfing and bowling writer from Milwaukee. He lost a good match to Harry Braid, son of the illustrious Jim of Walton Heath, by 2 and 1.
Nineteen Japanese business men financiers and industrialists, on a good-will trade tour of the United States, concluded a two-day stay here today and left for Chicago by train.

Less than twenty-four hours after the Supreme Court's decision upholding the constitutionality of the Social Security Act, plans were completed today for extending its benefits to an additional 2,500,000 aged and unemployed persons.
Three hundred cadets, marines and bluejackets of the Japanese cruiser Ashigara marched through the Brandenburg:Gate down Unter den Linden to the Soldiers' Memorial today.

Henry Lattey, whose invention of a telescopic sight was chiefly responsible for British success in overcoming the initial German superiority in sniping during the World War, died here last week at the age of 80.
The stock market here was generally dull today and most sections were slightly lower at the close. Gilt-edge issues held firm and foreign loans were quiet.

Jimmy De Shong, youthful Washington hurler, kept on even terms with Ted Lyons, White Sox veteran, for six innings today, but weakened in the seventh and Chicago won, 9 to 2. It was the Senators' third straight defeat.

The forward impulse giventothe government bond market on Monday by the Supreme Court's declsions upholding the Social Security Act carried through yesterday with diminshing force in trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchanges.

Townsend Ave, 1,770-74 (11-2850); 1,774 Townsend Ave Realty Corp to N Y Life Insurance Co, 51 Madison Ave: extends rftg to April 1, 1940, at 5 per cent' $140,900. Stratford Ave, 1,235 (14-3776); 1,225-35 Stratford Ave Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. 1 Madison Ave; due April 1. 1942. at 43A per cent; $45,000.

Mr. Justice CARDOZO delivered the opinion of the court in two momentous cases Monday. That happened to be the sixty-seventh anniversary of his birthday. Eager as he is to shun fuss and parade, he cannot object if a country which regards him with respect and affection congratulates itself on having such a son and such a judge. And he is more than a great judge.

The three-story concrete building at 459 Main Street, New Rochelle, has been sold by the New Rochelle Trust Company to David S. Meister. The building is on an irregular plot 51 by 110 feet. A resale of the property is reported pending to a restaurant chain which intends to demolish the structure and erect a new building for its own use.
One hundred members of the Inland Marine Underwriters Association attended the seventh annual meeting of the association here today at the Crescent Athletic Club.

J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, told the Illinois Bankers Association in convention here today that the banking structure of the nation is "in a healthy condition" and that remarkable improvement has been shown since the banking holiday in March, 1933.

Dartmouth's baseball team, behind the fine pitching of Bud Clifford, had little trouble with Vermont today, defeating the visitors, 9-2Ray Ratajczak, Joe Urban and Gordon Clark all made three hits, with Brad Jenkins starring in the field.
Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin gave his last official dinner as the head of the Cabinet tonight and as a tribute to his stewardship it was attended by King George and Queen Elizabeth.

Directors of Remington Rand, Inc., began interim dividend payments on the common stock yesterday with the declaration of 25 cents a share. Previously, quarterly distributions of 15 cents a share in cash, as well as 1 per cent in stock, were paid by the company. The regular quarterly dividend of $1.12 1/2 also was voted on the preferred stock.

Henry Johnson's four-hit pitching, combined with the 14-hit attack of his mates, gave Montreal an 8-2 victory over Buffalo today. The victory moved the Royals into third place ahead of the Bisons, who dropped from second to fourth.

Eldward Knapp Jr, residence of Conrad G. Goddard in 'Roslyn; Mrs. L. Clarke Winter, estate of Mrs. Frances McClure at Glen lead: Mrs. Herbert S. Darlington, home of Mrs. Willis D. Wood, Lloyd's Neck, Huntington; John J. Trask, home of Mrs. Madeline Morrison, at Huntington; L. I. rentals by Clark-Ryle Co.

Allen St, 167, 25.6x87.6 irreg; Adolf Goldstein to Sarah S. Steiman, 1,203 Findlay Ave; pr. mtg. $13,000; 3 years, 4 per cent; $3,200. Mulberry St, 227-229, 49.10x98.11; Louise H. Archibald to Mutual Life Insurance Co: p. m.. due. as per bond: $15.000.

The 117th commencement exercises will be held this morning at the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, 175 Ninth Avenue. Twenty-five members of the graduating class will receive diplomas.

All the terror and cruelty of modern war are summed up in the panic of the Basque children on their first day in England when a fleet of airplanes flew over their temporary camp in the flowery fields of Hampshire.
Stocks weakened moderately in final hour and closed lower; turnover, 842,380 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly higher, other issues steady and dull; transactions, $8,747,700.
Behind the competent pitching of Jack Eldridge the Pingry baseball team won its fifth straight game today, defeating Stevens Academy of Hoboken, 14 to 2.

Miss Elizabeth Rogers Sage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merton Sage of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Theron Batchelder, son of Mrs. Mabel Batchelder of Worcester, Mass., on June 12 in Christ's Episcopal Church here.

Gerald M. Livingston of Huntington, L. I., was elected president of the Westminster Kennel Club at the annual meeting and dinner of that organization held on Monday at the Union Club, it was announced yesterday. John G. Bates, who had guided Westminster for eleven years, declined reelection and Mr. Livingston was advanced from the vice presidency.

Four persons were injured, one of them critically, at about 6:30 o'clock last night when an automobile crashed into a parked taxicab and then bounded across the sidewalk and through the plate-glass front of a store at Broadway and 207th Street.
Dr. Luis F. Alvarez, one of the world's leading authorities on leprosy, died in his eighty-fourth year yesterday at his home here. Private funeral services were held today.

Hundreds of pickets milled about the gates of the North Side plant of the H. J. Heinz Company today in a strike called last night to obtain recognition of the Canning and Pickle Workers Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate. Police patrolled the picket lines.

Federal grants-in-aid must continue and only through such grants can States and local governments be made to contribute their fair share of the cost of eliminating unemployment, Charles P. Taft, son of the late President and Chief Justice, told the National Conference of Social Work tonight.

It was learned today that Dr. Diego von Bergen, the German Ambassador to the Vatican, yesterday presented to Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, a formal protest against the recent speech by Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, criticizing the situation created for the Catholic Church by the Nazi regime in Germany.

President Roosevelt indicated anew today that he would push forward with his program to reorganize the Federal judiciary, against all suggestions of compromise, until the constitutionality of his long-range plans for economic and social reform was definitely established by the Supreme Court.

An award of about $250,000 in back pay made by the National Railroad Adjustment Board to train-operating employes of the Lehigh Valley Railroad as compensation for running empty trains from the Pennsylvania Station to the Sunnyside yards in Long Island City caused a decline in the company's net operating income for April, although gross revenues increased in that month, it was announced yesterday.

Although outscored by De Witt Clinton in yesterday's events, the lead compiled in the five contests held Monday enabled Evander Childs to retain its laurels as the championship track and field meet for Bronx high schools, held under the auspices of the P. S. A. L., came to a close yesterday at Macombs Dam Park.
Jose Americo de Almeida was unanimously nominated today as the official candidate for the Brazilian Presidency by a convention here of the nation's majority political forces.

The marriage of Miss Rosamond Margaret Rosenbaum, daughter of Samuel R. Rosenbaum of Germantown, to Lewis Adams Riley Jr. of Mexico, D. F., son of Lewis A. Riley of Los Angeles and the late Mrs. Riley, took place here this afternoon in the garden of her father's home.

Included in the deals in Brooklyn reported by various brokers yesterday was the sale for cash of the apartment house at 720 Fenimore Street to a client of the Cross Brown Company, broker in the deal. 'Ronald K. Brown, attorney, represented Mrs. Alice W. Rabing, the seller.

Action of the directors of the United States Steel Corporation in declaring an additional dividend of $2 on the preferred stock, on account of arrears, took the financial community entirely by surprise yesterday, since it has been the practice to take dividend action only on the last Tuesdays of months following the end of a calendar quarter.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt broke the string of hard luck which has been dogging his stable this season when his Dusky Prince lasted to capture the thirty-ninth running of the Harlem claiming stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

The organization of the new Division of American Republics in the State Department by consolidating the LatinAmerican and Mexican Divisions-recently announced by Secretary HULLis evidence of Washington's punctilious regard for the sensibilities of the Spanish and Portuguese republics. By that graceful move the United States Government has shown officially that it has no desire to monopolize the adjective "American," which it regards as applicable equally to the people of all the Americas-North, Central and South.

Current account deposits in chartered banks on April 30 were $731,961,610, an increase of $21,000,000 from March 31, according to. the m thly statement issued today by the Finance Department. Savings deposits were about unchanged at $1,583,327,255.
The showboat Dixiana, a reproduction of a Mississippi-Ohio River packet of the old days, sank at a dock in the harbor here today after being towed on the lake from Chicago.
The directors of the United States Steel Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on account of arrears on the preferred stock, payable on June 29 to stockholders of record of June 4.

Servel, Inc., announced yesterday that its net profit for the quarter ended on April 30 amounted to $1,904,242 after depreciation, bond interest, Federal income tax, estimated undistributed-profits tax and other charges.
The Reichsbank's statement as of May 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The firm of Kraut Co. has been formed to continue the business of the Kraut, Cohan Company at 120 Broadway. Hubert F. Young has been elected a vice president of the Fidelity Investment Association and the Fidel Association of New York, Inc.
Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh is almost ready to leave the maternity hospital where she gave birth to her third baby boy on May 12, members of the hospital staff said today.

Professor Auguste Piccard and Max Cosyns, his associate, narrowly escaped death this morning when the balloon in which Professor Piccard made his first stratosphere ascension five years ago caught fire prior to a new experiment and was destroyed in two minutes.

At an adjourned special meeting yesterday stockholders of the New York Dock Company approved the company's plan of recapitalization proposing the issuance of new 5 per cent notes due 1947 in exchange for present notes, the new notes to be convertible into stock at the rate of twenty preferred shares and fourteen common shares for each $1,000 of notes.

President Roosevelt, suffering from a slight cold, canceled all engagements except his press conference. He sent to Congress the report of his Cabinet committee on helium and sent letters to Senator Wagner and Representatives Sumners and Lea asking for early action on three bills to broaden the powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The last section of the new Marine Parkway Bridge, spanning Jamaica Inlet and connecting Brooklyn to Queens, was placed in position on Monday afternoon and night, it was announced yesterday by the Marine Parkway Authority.

Andrew F. Allen, chief of the Bureau of Camp Sanitation of the New York Department of Health, speaking here today at a conference of health officers of the metropolitan area, deplored the meager information available about the status of automobile trailers, which he called a new factor in sanitation problems. It is possible, however, he said, to predict that their history will be similar to that occasioned by the rise of tourist camps.

Turned into a flying hospital the China Clipper was roaring northeastward across the Pacific this evening carrying in a specially arranged suite George Sumers of New York, a broker, whose back was broken in an automobile accident in Manila on May 17, and who is going home to his own doctor as fast as aviation engines and wings will carry him.

To facilitate the importation of higher grade steels for munitions the government has amended schedules exempting from additional duty beginning Thursday consignments of ingots, blooms, billets and slabs, the value of which exceeds [Pound]7 10s a ton;

The Agriculture Department reported today the naval stores industry has bought 17,204,900 cups for gathering gum turpentine and gum resin this season. The cup sales were 325,100 less than for last season but well above the last five years' average of 12.750,000. The peak was 32.310,000, in 1927-28, and the low 1,085,000, in 1931-32.

Amendments in the 1935 Workmen's Compensation law were held constitutional today by the Court of Appeals in affirming dismissal of a claim of Dr. Eugene Szold, who sought payment of $208 from the Outlet Embroidery Company of New York City for the care of an employee.
Haile Selassie notified Joseph Avenol, secretary general, in a letter published by the League of Nations tonight that he would not be represented at the special Assembly tomorrow to admit Egypt.

After nine straight losses, the Baltimore Orioles defeated Syracuse, 3 to 1, in a well-pitched game today. Fred Fussell and Ray Kolp toiled for the Chiefs, while Bill Lohrman worked the game for Baltimore. Eacn side collected seven hits.

George B. Post, banker and broker, one of the founders of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Post Flagg, 49 Broad Street, died at his country home here at 8:15 o'clock tonight after a week's illness of influenza followed by pneumonia. He was 72 years old.
Members of the City Council, who were re-elected for a four-year term on May 11, held their organization meeting here today.

The Associated Glee Clubs of America will assemble near-by subsidiary clubs for a grand Spring sing to be held June. 12 in Randalls Island Stadium, it was announced yesterday. It is believed that this will be . the first open-air male chorus "pops" concert ever to be given in New York.
The United States Consulate is trying to locate relatives of Florence Hayes, 21year-old New York cabaret dancer, who was killed in a motor accident here early this morning.
Frank Strafaci of Shoreview set the pace for the field in the Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

The Wendel Foundation, represented by Stewart Shearer, has sold the five-story building on a plot 20.5 by 80 feet at 783 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of Sixtyfirst Street, to a client of Pease Elliman.

Declaring again that he was connected with the Fourth Revolutionary International that is seeking to overthrow the Stalin regime in Russia and to promote world revolution, Leon Trotsky issued today a press statement attacking Carleton Beals, who resigned from the inquiry commission here, and others.

The new Schrafft's restaurant at 462 Fourth Avenue, at the northwest corner of Thirty-first Street, was opened yesterday. Extensive changes on the ground floor of the business building there were carried out by the Frank G. Shattuck Company to accommodate the new unit.
The fourth and last week of the Spring season of the Metropolitan Opera Association opened last night, offering a triple bill: "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci" and the ballet, "The Bat."

Commodity futures were irregular in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, silk, tin and hide futures fell, but coffee, cocoa, zinc and wool top futures gained. Sugar, copper and lead futures were barely steady.

Nineteen-year-old Donald Wightman, who for three days had heard himself accused by his former fiancee, Gladys MacKnight, of the hatchet murder of her mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight, took the stand this afternoon in his own defense and hurled back the accusation.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Hirsch of 300 Central Park West of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth L. Hirsch, to Bernard A. Kornblum. son of Morris Kornblum of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Kornblum.

The wedding of Eugene Gladstone O'Neill Jr. and Miss Janet Hunter Longley of this city took place this afternoon in Dwight Memorial Chapel of Yale University, and was followed by a reception at the residence of the bride's parents, Professor William R. Longley of Yale University and Mrs. Longley.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation has been called for June 15 to vote on a plan to increase the authorized capital shares from 400,000 to 1,200,000 shares to provide for a two-forone split-up of the 350,000 shares now outstanding and for the sale of a new issue of $3,500,000 of convertible debentures.

Health hazards within plumbing lines must be eliminated if the nation is to reach the maximum health standards, Dr. Clifford E. Waller, Assistant Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, told the fifty-fifth annual convention of the National Association of Master Plumbers here today.

The consumption of crude rubber in the United States in April, as reported by the Rubber Manufacturers Association, amounted to 51,797 tons, bringing the total for the first four months of this year to the record level of 208,566 tons, an increase of 15 per cent over the first four months of last year.

The engagement of Miss Mary Treat Nettleton, daughter of Professor George Henry Nettleton of Yale University and Mrs. Nettleton, to Gordon Sherman Haight, a member of the Yale faculty and son of Louis Pease Haight and the late Mrs. Haight, has been announced. The wedding will take place June 24.

Employes of the First Wisconsin National Bank today announced the organization of a union for collective bargaining. There are about 700 employes, aside from officers and executives. The latter are not eligible for membership.
Last June Daniel Muir, a soldier, 28 years old, dived into the River Thames and rescued a woman from drowning.

The Institute of International Education, in cooperation with the College Art Association, awarded yesterday twenty scholarships for graduate study in the history of art at the Institute of Art and Archaeology of the University of Paris.

The United States liner Washington will arrive today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. On board are Helen Morgan, entertainer; H. B. Warner, screen actor; Rear Admiral William H. Allen, U. S. N., commander of the Yangtse River Patrol; John C.

With the Assembly in recess until tomorrow, the New Jersey Senate confirmed today several nominations made by Governor Hoffman, passed a veritable flood of bills and then adjourned until Friday with its own calendar cleared.

The Hebrew Technical Institute held its fifty-third annual commencement exercises last night in the Great Hall of Cooper Union. The graduation class of 103 heard addresses by Dr. K. George Falk, president of the board of trustees, and Dr. Edgar S. Barney, principal.

Governors Island Each of the following Infantry Reserve officers is ordered to active duty, June 19, at Caminp Dix for training: Capt. Austin D. Higgins, 514 Main St., Buffalo, N. Y. Capt. Joseph A. Smith, 33-17 156th St., Flushing, L. I. Capt. Irving Thurston, 37 Prospect Blvd., Utica. N. Y.

The Senate Commitee on Interstate Commerce asserted today in its investigation of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad and its subsidiary, the Virginia Transportation Corporation, that the same conditions which in 1926 caused the Interstate Commerce Commission to reject an application for the consolidation of the C. O., the Erie,

It looks tonight as if Mrs. Wallis Warfield and the Duke of Windsor will have few guests present at their wedding, out of the score originally invited, because word has spread here that King George VI was compelled to ban attendance of persons occupying British Government or court positions.

Building construction awards in the New York area in the first four months of 1937 showed a substantial improvement over the total for the same period of last year, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

Frankie Blair will oppose Atilio Sabatino in the feature eight-round bout at the Hippodrome tonight. Both are promising welterweights and a rousing battle is anticipated. Blair, who hails from Camden, N. J., boasts of victories over Johnny Clinton, Harry Dublinsky,

The Jamaica High School nine moved closer to the P. S. A. L. Queens Division title yesterday when it crushed Newtown, 15 to 4, on the latter's diamond. John Adams beat Cleveland, 1 to 0, at Dexter Park, to move into a fourth place tie with Far Rockaway in the Queens race.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today another $100,000,000 block of Treasury bills. One-half of this amount will be added to the working balance, increasing to $350,000,000 the amount of cash borrowed for the government in this way in seven weeks.
Four games, two at the club and two on Phipps Field, today, provided action for 24 of the players preparing for the Meadow Brook Club Spring polo championship which starts early next month.
President Alfonso Lopez presented his resignation to the Senate today as the result of the hostility of Congress to government measures at the first meeting last night of its second special session.

The stated. purpose of the Administration's new substitute for NRA is to establish " fair labor standards " for all industries which are engaged in interstate commerce or which substantially " affect " interstate commerce. To this end the bill proposes to prohibit the employment of children under the age of 16 in all such industries.

John W. Hering, former internal revenue collector here and a leader for many years in Delaware Republican politics, died at the home of his wife's family in Felton, Del., this morning of a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

George Clinton Van Wart, a retired minstrel who played with George Primrose, died here last night at his home, 493 Kimball Avenue, at the age of 76. He was a descendant of Isaac Van Wart, one of the captors of Major Andre in the Revolution.

Additional grants of $728,390.19 have been distributed to hospitals in this city by the United Hospital Fund, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of trustees of the fund in their offices, 370 Lexington Avenue. These grants brought the total so far to $1,441,866.97, according to Edwin P. Maynard, vice president of the fund, who acted as chairman yesterday.
SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-Against BLUE STAR JEWELRY, INC., 10 W. 47th St.-By Supreme Jewelry Corp., for upward of $500: Max Geldzahler, upward of $400; Nathan Weintraub, upward of S500.

Burton Rascoe is taking an extended leave of absence from his work as an editor for Doubleday, Doran. His autobiographical "Before I Forget" is the Book of the Month Club choice for June and will be published this week by Doubleday, Doran.

Arthur Dingham of Amsterdam was elected Grand Patriarch today at the annual Grand Encampment of the New York State Independent Order of Odd Fellows. Other new officers are: Otto Kahsnitz of Portville,

A $780,000 contract involving the construction of and manufacturing rights on Seversky amphibian airplanes, which can operate from land, water, ice or snow, has been placed with the Seversky Aircraft Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I., by the Amtorg Trading Corporation on behalf of the Russian Government, it was announced yesterday.

There is an increasing wave of anti-Semitism in this country, which constitutes not only a threat to Jews but a threat to democratic institutions as well, speakers declared last night in a symposium on anti-Semitism at the evening session of the second annual convention of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress at the Hotel Roosevelt.
The liner Normandie will be able to sail as scheduled for New York tomorrow because the leaders of the striking seamen and the government reached

Mr. and Mrs. J. Cecil Prouty Flushing have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sallie B. Prouty, to Lyford M. Brown, son of Mrs. Maybell L. Brown of Flushing and Fred Brown of Jackson Heights.

Three farms in various sections of New Jersey have been sold through Charles E. Sweeney, Rumson broker. One was that of Eugene Gardella, consisting of 100 acres in land in Atlantic Township, with an eight-room main house and a five-room tenant house. C. J.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday at the opening for the Summer of the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Thomas F. Gilroy was a luncheon hostess there to Mrs. Frank Laurence, Mrs. Graham Giddens, Mrs. Claude C. Pinney, Mrs. Harry Harryson and Mrs. George H. Handel.

Major George Austin Hauck, reserve officer attached to the Army Base in Brooklyn, who supervised National Guard payrolls in the Second Corps Area, died on Sunday of pneumonia in his home at 1,340 Pacific Street, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.
The three remaining airplanes of the Soviet North Pole Expedition, which had been delayed at Rudolf Island by storms on the Polar ice cap, have now flown the 558 miles to the Pole.

Twenty-four parcels of real estate in the New York metropolitan area, assets of title and mortgage guarantee companies in liquidation or rehabilitation, were reported sold yesterday by the Title and Mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department.

Boy, 10-year-old mongrel dog, has been adopted officially by the city of Brigantine, little resort community north of here. Brigantine school children have made Boy their pet for the last eight years, since he wandered into the neighborhood.

John H. Fahey, chairman of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, wrote today to members of Congress asking them to select three "typical" cases in which the board had completed foreclosures in each Congressional district, and he promised to use the examples to show that the board did not force undue hardshins upon any of the borrowers.

Newspaper editors and publishers of New Jersey gave a testimonial dinner here tonight to Professor Kenneth Olson, who is retiring as head of the Department of Journalism at Rutgers University and as executive secretary of the New Jersey Press Association to become head of the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University.
A. F. of L. leaders In Cincinnati voted war against C. I. O., ordering battles in the latter's own fields, Lewis's mine union included. Page 1.

Praising the convention's purpose of exchanging information to safeguard the interests of consumers as well as producers, eliminating favoritism in placing contracts and maintaining reasonable quality ih goods, President Roosevelt yesterday extended a greeting to the 1,600 delegates attending a four-day international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in the Hotel William Penn here.

Clarence R. Bitting, president of the United States Sugar Corporation, which operates cane-sugar plantations in the Florida Everglades, said yesterday that more than 70 per cent of the sugar produced by the company had been sold and that "if the same average price is realized for the balance of the crop, preliminary figures indicate a profit from operations of about $1,000,000."

James Playfair, Great Lakes shipping man and lumber manufacturer, died today after a brief illness at the age of 76. Mr. Playfair had been ill since returning a few weeks ago from his California home. He suffered from a heart ailment.

Miss Beverly Sanders of Bath, England, great-great-granddaughter of Lieut. Col. Roger Morris and his wife, Mary Philipse, who built the Jumel Mansion at 160th Street and Jumel Terrace, was the guest of honor yesterday at the annual May party held at the mansion by the Washington Headquarters Association and the Department of Parks.

Charles H. Dahmer, vice president of the Fifth Avenue Bank of New York, was elected yesterday by the United Lutheran Synod of New York as its treasurer at the ninth annual convention in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

A swastika flag of Nazi Germany was torn tonight from downtown decorations for the opening of the $35,000,000 Golden Gate Bridge, Friday, and maritime labor organizations threatened to withdraw from the festivities after city officials refused to remove other similar banners.

The Certificate of Valor of the Civilian Conservation Corps has been awarded to Walker Lake, a former CCC worker of 174 Fleming Avenue, Newark, and four others for acts of heroism beyond the regular call of duty.

Governor Lehman signed today the bill establishing a State Board of Mediation. The bill, sponsored by Senator O'Brien of New York, was recommended by the Governor in a special message to the Legislature.

The A. C. A. Gallery's second annual competitive exhibition, which provides a one-man show sponsored by the American Artists Congress for the winner, is open to all artists who have not yet had a oneman show in New York. Artists may submit two pictures or two pieces of sculpture for consideration by a jury. Work will be accepted on June 9 only.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 22: CAPTAIN Friedrick, E., Long Beach, Calif., to home, relieved from all active duty.
Kid Chocolate, 130, Cuba, gained the decision over Henry Hook, 124 1/2, Indianapolis, in the feature ten-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night.

Plans have been completed by Miss Charlotte Van Bibber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Edwin Van Bibber of Valley Forge, Pa., formerly of Bronxville, for her marriage to Frank Rutledge Davis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Rutledge Davis of Scarsdale, which will take place the afternoon of June 19 in the gardens of Argyle House, Echo Valley Farms, Valley Forge.

On a cot in St. Elizabeth's Hospital on Washington Heights Gordon Stanley (Mickey) Cochrane, manager of the Tigers, last night learned that a spirited ninth-inning rally by his team yesterday had failed to avert a 4-3 defeat at the hands of the league-leading Yankees at the Stadium.

Declaring that advertising is the crux of the public relations problem, Lee Bristol, vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company, declared yesterday that "if industries do. not take steps toward the control of the advertising of their members, a few short-sighted concerns will destroy the effectiveness of even good advertising." Mr.

Dr. Paul Klapper, dean of the School of Education at City College, was appointed president of the new Queens City College by the Board of Higher Education at a special meeting last night in the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. George Williams Seaman of The Beeches, Beaconon-Hudson, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hurtin Seaman, to Robert Campbell Barry, son of Mrs. Edmund Henry Barry of Rochester, N. Y., and the late Mr. Barry.

Delancey St, 326, 5-story tenement and stores, 24.11x75; Carrie K. Hoverman against Thehama-Clara Holding Co; due, $15,536; taxes, , $1,988; to plaintiff for $1,000. 109th St, 184 E, 4-story tenement and stores, 19.6x100.11; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Augusta C. Moore; due, $9.123; taxes, , $200; to plaintiff for $1.000.

Bryan Grant made a last despairing lunge at one of Donald Budge's rifle-shot drives in the Forest Hills Stadium yesterday, shook his head in admiration and threw down his racquet as the workout ended.

T. Arthur Johnson of Pelham carried off the low gross prize in a one-day tourney of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Pelham Country Club today. Johnson scored a 77, which was four over par for the course.
Representative Eicher, Iowa Democrat, demanded today a guarantee to farmers of prices equal to the cost of production.

Cracking down on Wild Willie Hallahan for six runs in the opening round, with two riding home on a circuit clout by Johnny McCarthy, the Giants toppled the Reds, 9 to 3, in the opening clash of a three-game series today and for the first time in weeks were able to view the standing of the clubs with a feeling that at last they were getting somewhere.

Firenze Red Tape, owned by Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim, scored a surprising triumph today in the model middleweight hunters event when he beat Big John from the Holiday Hill Farms for the blue ribbon as the Devon horse show opened. Big John only last week was awarded the championship at Wilmington.

Valentine Ave (11-3144), a e cor of 182d St, 116x115; Mian Realty Co, Inc, to Sun Management Corp. 152 W 42d St; mtg, $223,875. Astor Ave (16-4387), n s, 68 ft w of Morgan Ave, 32x86: Gottfried Wegleiter to Aline Trondle, 1,411 Astor Ave.

The Daily Mail reported today that it understood Crown Princess Juliana of The Netherlands was expecting the birth of a child. It said the Princess, who married Prince Bernard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld on Jan. 7, 1937, had been "advised to take as much rest as possible and will shortly cease to fulfill public engagements.
Steel ingot output was unchanged last week when the seasonal trend was upward, and the adjusted index declined to 120.4 from 121.3. It was 92.3 for the week ended May 23, 1936.

Driving Nubs Kleinke from the mound during a four-run rally in the third inning, the Toronto Maple Leafs gained a 6-4 victory over Rochester today for their third straight triumph at the expense of the Wings. The result moved Toronto into second place.
In the presence of Chancellor Adolf Hitler the Reich Research Council was inaugurated here today. National Socialist Cabinet members and a large body of scientists attended.
Twenty-nine principal European nations are spending almost $20,000 a minute during the 1937 fiscal year for direct armament expenditures.
A slight cold kept President Roosevelt away from his desk and caused him to cancel all appointments today, except the press conference.

Declaring that there were 580 employes on the payroll of the World's Fair Corporation and that sixty-one had been taken from civil service lists, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, denied yesterday the charge by Municipal Civil Service Commissioner Paul J. Kern that the fair was running a "patronage mill" and ignoring the city's civil service lists.

Strongly criticizing some of the "market letters" sent out on the raw silk situation, Paolino Gerli, president of the International Silk Guild, declared last night at a forum meeting of the Textile Salesmen's Association that, contrary to predictions, Japan, China and Italy are entering the new season with a carryover and all information points to good crops.
A bridge party and reception, marking the twenty-first anniversary of the establishment of the Bonnie Brae Home for Boys here, was held at the farm this afternoon.

The war between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, and the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Operators, the A. F. of L. union, increased in bitterness yesterday as Michael J. Quill, president of the T. W. U.,

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have today addressed the enclosed letter to the editor of The Washington Post, by which I am employed, in reply to the letter of Arthur Krock appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of this date:

Te War Department released the following orders today, dated May 24: COLONELS Hester, J. H., Inf., General Staff Corps, one month leave, June 7. Lynch, G. A., Inf., appointed as chief of infantry, with rank of major general. Baker, W. C., Chemical Warfare Service, appointed as chief of the Chemical Warfare Service, with rank of major general, to proceed from Boston, Mass., to Washington, D. C.

Following his usual custom, Controller Frank J. Taylor arranged yesterday to have salary checks ready for 135,000 city employes on Friday, so that they might have the money for use over the Decoration Day holiday.

Elphege J. Daignault, leader of an insurgent group in the Roman Catholic Church which provoked Pope Pius XI to order their excommunication in 1928, died here today of heart disease. He was 58 years old.

W. J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, was yesterday elected president of the Trade Association Executives in New York City, succeeding W. J. Parker of W. J. Parker, Inc., at the group's annual meeting at the Hotel Astor Mr. Donald has been vice president of the organization.
The Interstate Commerce Commission granted authority to the Bangor Aroostook Railroad today to issue $420,000 in equipment trust certificates to draw interest at 2 1/2 per cent.

Clarence E. Jones, president and treasurer of the New Hartford Trust Company, which he helped found in 1900, and president of the Farmington Valley Telephone Company, died at his home here last night. He suffered a heart attack ten days ago. His age was 72.

John McD. Murray, president of the New York Produce Exchange, in delivering his annual report to members of the Exchange yesterday afternoon, said a special committee had been appointed to look into the question of reopening a securities market on the Exchange, and to arrange for filing an application for registration as a national securities exchange.

A House revolt brushed aside administration opposition today and succeeded in earmarking for specific purposes $505,000,000 of the proposed $1,500,000,000 relief appropriation. It also added an amendment designed to force persons on relief rolls to accept private employment when it was available.

Bermuda was brought within five and one-half hours' traveling distance of the New York metropolitan area today with the successful completion of survey flights in both directions by Pan American Airways and Imperial Airways.

United States Senator Gerald P. Nye, chairman of a committee for the protection of holders of bonds of the Republic of Cuba, arrived here this morning from Washington to appear before the Cuban Government Commission that now is studying the possibility of a resumption of payment on the long-defaulted public works bond issues.

The position of the Republican organization of New York County on the renomination of Mayor La Guardia may be determined tonight at a meeting of the Fifteenth Assembly District Club, 122 East Eighty-third Street, with the foes of the Mayor determined to put through a resolution opposing his candidacy and his supporters seeking to avoid a vote and leave the club uncommitted.

Plans for a concerted city-wide drive by the C. I. O. were discussed yesterday by John L. Lewis, chairman, with local leaders of his organization, headed by Allan Haywood, who came here recently to direct the C. I. O. campaign in New York.

Twenty-seven awards of prizes and medals to students of the Cooper Union Day and Night Art Schools, to be presented at the commencement exercises June 10, were announced yesterday by Austin Purves, director of the schools. There were six silver medals, six bronze medals and fifteen cash prizes.
The men of the police emergency squads proved their mettle again yesterday and brought peace of mind to 2 1/2-year-old Bobby Coughlin and his family.

Miss Margaret Sprague Lippincott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sprague Lippincott of Wayne, Pa., will be married to Alfred Rockwell Sumner, son of Eliot Sumner of Villanova and the late Mrs. Sumner, on June 5 in the Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

Included in the long list of commercial leases reported yesterday were many involving space in the midtown district. Stores appeared to be in brisk demand. A number of leases in the office buildings of the downtown district also were noted. The list follows:
The Cleveland Indians nosed out the Athletics in the first encounter of a three-game series today, winning by 4 to 2.

Spurring the drive on the illicit narcotic traffic started when the Treasury's Narcotic Bureau was shaken up six months ago, the Federal Government obtained yesterday prison sentences for three men arrested as sellers and five alleged "big-shot distributors" were held in high bail.
Only those Germans who profess to be loyal supporters of the National Socialist regime will be allowed to attend the Paris Exposition this Summer.

Another revival of an old court drama was heralded today when Judge W. W. Callahan set July 6 for the resumption of trials in the Scottsboro case in which nine Negroes are accused of attacking two white girls.
The United Automobile Workers, aiming its unionization drive at the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant, named the six-hour day and $8 minimum daily wage today as objectives.

The question of the withdrawal of foreign combatants from Spain moved another step forward today when the Valencia government delegation informally agreed in principle to accept foreign supervision of its execution of this withdrawal provided General Francisco Franco, the Insurgent commander, did so.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of an issue of $500,000 State of Virginia road bonds, bidding for $180,000 as 3 1/2s and $320,000 as 2 1/4s on a cost basis to the State of 2.422 per cent. The bonds will be reoffered today to yield 0.90 to 2.50 per cent, according to maturity.
William H. endrick, a founder of the National 4-H Movement and State director since 1921 of the 4-H camp here, the first camp in the nation, died tonight of a heart malady at the age of 55.

Ireland will continue to be Ireland in the English text of the new Free State Constitution, and Eire will be included only in the Gaelic text. As the English version will be the one read in the world at large, the name thus remains unchanged.

It might appear that one of the Fall's major events will be the arrival on Broadway of Ephraim Tutt, attorney at law, and if Walter Huston plays Mr. Tutt there can be no further question of the event's importance.
Six Scouts of various parts of the country were signalized last night for heroism by the National Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America, 2 Park Avenue.

Contradictory statements regarding the financial position of France were made today in the Chamber of Deputies by Finance Minister Vincent Auriol for the government and by Pierre-Etienne Flandin and others on the opposition benches.

In recognition of safe driving the Shell Union Oil Company put a sign on one of its five-ton trucks, reading, "The driver of this truck, Deeb Schamie, has been a driver of this company for two years without an accident." Schamie was killed yesterday in his first accident.
Steel workers affiliated with the John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization went on strike last night at the Canton and Massillon plants of the Republic Steel Corporation.
The use of a stamp or label for every article sold stating how much of the purchase price is being paid for taxes was suggested yesterday by Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr.

The New York Unit of the National Piano Playing Tournament, sponsored by the National Guild of Piano Teachers, will be held at the Wanamaker Auditorium beginning Tuesday, Ira Allison, founder, president and local chairman, announced yesterday.
Confidential reports from British agents in Arabia have aroused some apprehension in official circles here regarding the immediate future of that part of the world.

The suggestion was advanced today that the Duke of Kent, youngest brother of King George VI of England, be made "Prince-President" of the Irish Free State when the proposed new Constitution takes effect.

The position of Yale University in the case of Jerome Davis, associate professor in the Divinity School, has been upheld by the investigating committee for the American Association of University Professors, a statement by Yale officials asserted tonight.

The question of the dramatic critic's importance to the theatre, which was raised by Brock Pemberton at the opening session of the American Theatre Council's first national convention on Monday, emerged yesterday as the most controversial issue yet brought before the convention, now meeting in a four-day conclave at the Hotel Astor.

A dinner reunion of the former pupils of Grammar School 22, which was at Stanton and Sheriff Streets, on the lowest East Side, and the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the claps of 1887 of that school, were held last night at the clubhouse of the Grand Street Boys Association, 106 West Fiftyfifth Street.

Engagements of $9,430,000 of gold in England for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by local banking institutions. Of the amount $4,750,000 had been purchased on Monday and $4,680,000 yesterday.

Miss Louise Fiske Stark, daughter of Theodore Fiske Stark of this city, was married to Ramond Theodore Zwack, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Theodore Zwack, tonight in the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation by the rector, the Rev. Carolus R. Webb.

The tentative list of seedings for all trial heats in the qualifying events of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championship meet at Randalls Island Stadium on Friday was announced yesterday.
William Woodward's great 5-year-old, Omaha, will be sent to York tonight to run in the twomile Yorkshire Handicap tomorrow, his trainer, Captain Boyd-Rochefort, told The Associated Press today.

Vigorous opposition to the McAdoo bill permitting establishment of branches of national banks beyond the State boundaries of the parent institution was expressed today by the National Association of Supervisors of State banks, which contended that such a move virtually would eliminate most of the State banks and place financial operations of the nation in the hands of a comparatively few institutions.

The question of whether asylum will be permitted in this country for 500 Basque children refugees from Spain rested today with Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, after the State Department had announced its policy as one of humanitarianism.

The Harvard baseball team gained a 5-2 victory over the New Hampshire University Wildcats at Brackett Field today. Sheen and Walsh continued their steady pitching and the outfield played smart ball as Harvard batted its way to victory.

A double by Charlie Keller in the eighth inning followed by Catcher Buddy Rosar's single gave the Newark Bears a 9-to-8 victory over the Jersey City Giants today and a two-to-one edge in the opening series.

Canal St, 207, 26.3x55.7x25.4x64; Philip Rhinelander, trustee, Cornelia B. Kip to Carmelia K. Livermore, 410 E 57th St. Dyckman St, 207, 50x124 ; Louise H. Archibald to David Zipkin, 1,175 Park Ave, and Saul Levy, 301-319 Park Ave; mtg, $61.125.
Mrs. Rene Mathieu and Yvon Petra gave France the mixed doubles title of the French hard court tennis championships today as Hal Surface of Kansas City gained the fourth round of the men's singles.
Art (Lefty) Kenney defeated George Hines in a well-pitched ball game today to give Holy Cross a 4-1 victory over Rhode Island State.

Endeavour, possible challenger for. the America's Cup, arrived at the Herreshoff shipyard today to be put in racing trim.. Shipyard officials said work would be started at once on stripping the British yacht of her oceangoing spars and sails, after which she would be fitted with. her lofty racing rig for the preliminary trial races beginning. off Newport next week.

By air and by land State troopers late today hunted three members of a "new Dillinger" gang who shot a State policeman and a deputy sheriff in ambush west of this city after robbing a bank at Goodland, Ind. The policeman probably will die.

" You fellows do the playing and I'll do the fighting," Burleigh Grimes told his Dodgers before the season opened. Today Van Lingle Mungo, who had ignored that sound advice to such an extent that it cost him $1,000 and three days' pay, returned to action after his suspension and hurled the Kelly Greens to a 2-1 triumph over Bill Swift and the league-leading Pirates.

Henry O. Tanner of Pittsburgh, a painter, died here today at the age of 78. His pictures have been hung at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, the Philadelphia Museum, at the Chicago Art Institute and the Luxemburg Museum.
The Court of Appeals today denied to Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, the widow, permission to appeal in her efforts to break the will of Colonel Henry H. Rogers, wealthy Standard Oil official.

Private funeral services for John D. Rockefeller will be held at 11 o'clock this morning in the living room of his home at Pocantico Hills near Tarrytown. About fifty persons-relatives, close friends and servants of many years standingwill attend.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:
The Rev. and Mrs. C. Thurston Chase of Hartford, Conn., and Monterey, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Tyler Chase, to Dr. Reginald Charles Farrow of Newark, N. J.

Heavy and persistent selling of wheat futures In the market in Winnipeg, which reopened today after being closed since Saturday, carried prices in the Canadian market off 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit for one day under Exchange regulations, and started liquidation in the markets in the United States.

Hitting out at politics and newspapers as the main causes of the disturbed state of the world, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Reich Economics Minister, arrived here today to open Germany's pretentious pavilions in the Paris Exhibition tomorrow in the name of Chancellor Adolf Hitler.
The Cubs scored their fourth straight victory of the season over Philadelphia today, 5 to 3, behind Bill Lee's effective pitching.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced today the appointment of Archibald R. Graustein of New York, former president and chairman of the board of the International Paper and Power Company, as special counsel for the commission in charge of corporate reorganization.
