Charles S. Hirsch, a partner in the brokerage firm of Hirsch, Lilienthal Co. and manager of its foreign offices, arrived yesterday on the Holland-America liner Statendam.

A drop of 30.6 per cent in mentions of "national" brands in seventeen grocery classifications in twenty newspapers in the first two months of 1937 as against the first two months of 1935 is shown in a study by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, and a drop of 21.2 per cent is shown in "field" products of the same classifications in the same newspapers.
ear Admiral Jehu V. Chase, for?? commander of the United states fleet, died yesterday in a oronado hospital at the age of 68.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals postponed today until Friday a hearing on whether Heavyweight Champion James J. Braddock can meet Joe Louis in Chicago June 22 or whether he must fight Max Schmeling in New York June 3.

Public offering will be made today of 74,600 shares of no-par common stock of the Birdsboro Steel Foundry and Machine Company by a group consisting of Riter Co., Battles Co.,, Inc., and Bioren Co. at $15.25 a share.

Van loads of the furniture of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and Neville Chamberlain, who will become Prime Minister Friday, will soon pass each other between 10 Downing Street and fashionable Eaton Square as tangible evidence of Mr. Baldwin's retirement.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today to adopt three pending bilis which would give to the Securities and Exchange Commission farreaching control over issuance of bonds and debentures, reorganizations and protective committees.

Two American experts testified at the Hindenburg inquiry today that they saw no possibility that an electrostatic phenomenon, a high-frequency radio beam, or a spark generated in one of the electrical gas pressure instruments on the ship could have ignited the mixture of hydrogen and air now accepted as having accumulated in the ship just before the disaster.

While a special grand Jury devoted its entire session yesterday to a suspect who decided to aid the Federal 'Government's investigation of the disability insurance racket, the authorities arrested another man, making a total of eighteen who have been rounded up since the government first acted a week ago to end frauds reported to have mounted into millions of dollars.
The consumption of tin in the first quarter of this year was 49,432 tons, against 39,999 in the same period of 1936, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

MIANHATTAN Gross assets, $104,602; net, $89,508. To Paul S. and James B. Brinsmade, sons, $41,096 each; Henry B. Van Sinderen, nephew; Margaret B. .Wingfield. niece. $2,000 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $63,088. Heywood Benedict, attorneys, 43 Cedar St.
The House Merchant Marine Committee heard conflicting testimony today on legislation to provide speedy settlement of labor disputes involving maritime workers.

The number of buyers registered in town during the week ended yesterday was slightly more than in the preceding week. But the total was below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

The marriage of Miss Ellen Louise Hess, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Smith Hess of Bloomsburg, Pa., to Robert Rylee, son of Mrs. William J. Rylee of Denison, Texas, and the late Mr. Rylee, will take place Saturday afternoon at the home of the prospective bride's parents. The Rev.

The electric output of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system for April totaled 725,223,359 kilowatt-hours, as compared with 609,458,904 kilowatt-hours in April, 1936, an increase of 18.9 per cent.

IT may be War Admiral in the Belmont, but in what is labeled the "First Exhibition of Contemporary American Sporting Art" at the Squibbs Building Galleries they have Pompoon in front. Possibly Karl William Zoeller, the director of the show, fancies himself as a picker and is willing to give visitors to the show a friendly and helpful hint.

The earliest known autograph letter by George Washington about a love affair has come into the possession of Dr. Gabriel Wells after having remained in the possession of Virginia families since it was written in 1752.

In his oral comment yesterday on the social security decisions, Justice McReynolds re-enunciated the fundamental attitude of the Constitutional conservatives, a viewpoint that has periodically prevailed and periodically has been abandoned by the Supreme Court majority in the course of our history.

Miss June Louise Dudley, 20 years old, of 1 Hazen Street, Pelham Manor, N. Y., was killed at 12:40 P. M. yesterday when she jumped or fell from the window of her bedroom in a psychiatric nursing home on the eleventh floor of 544 East Eighty - sixth Street.

A request that the New York State Legislature consider and impose "appropriate taxes on chain stores and house-to-house retail stores on wheels in order to equalize the economic disadvantages of independent and individual store owners," was contained in a resolution passed by the New York State Association of Manufacturing Retail Bakers at its session at the Hotel Astor Yesterday.
Plans were filed yesterday for the construction of a number of dwellings in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. Many alteration projects also were recorded. The list follows:

Judson Health Center was the beneficiary of the dinner dance last night in the Japanese garden of the Ritz-Carlton. There was dancing in the Oval Room adjoining the garden and tables for bridge In the Palm Court.

New officers of the National Paper Box Manufacturers Association were elected today. They are Allen K. Schleicher, St. Louis, president; Charles K. Shaw, Pawtucket, R. I., vice president; Walter H. Deisroth,
John Fennell, 78 years old, who had spent yesterday afternoon decorating graves for Memorial Day, was killed here early this morning in a fire at 189 Roberts Avenue.

Charles S. Campbell, president of the Durham-Duplex Razor Company, and Samuel W. Meek, vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, have been elected directors of the J. B. Williams Company of Glastonbury, Conn.
The answer of Ellis H. Parker Sr. and his son Ellis Jr. to the Federal Government's conspiracy charges will be outlined to the jury at opening of court tomorrow before Federal Judge William Clark.
According to a statement issued yesterday, New Jersey's restoration program "is taxing the capacity of the State Fish and Game Commission with the funds available."
Fifty-one Girl Scout leaders from all parts of the nation were enrolled today at Camp Edith Macy when the camp was opened for its annual Summer training courses.

Steer beef ruled steady to higher and pork held firm in a generally dull market; other classes with the exception of cow and bull declined. Early kosher market slow and generally lower as reported by the U. S. Department of Agriculture.
Premier Benito Mussolini's Milan newspaper asked the Jews of Italy today to give whole-hearted support to Fascism or to leave the country and to cease criticism of Germany.

Oscar Johnston, vice president of the Commodity Credit Corporation and former manager of the Cotton Producers Pool, will deliver an address to members of the Commodity Club of New York at a dinner tomorrow night in the Park Central Hotel.
Three alleged counterfeiters were killed and two policemen were wounded this afternoon in a battle that resulted when the police sought to capture the men.

Winners in the tenth annual competition for the Warren O. Van Brunt scholarship at the American School of Design, 625 Madison Avenue, were announced yesterday by Douglas John Connah, president. Walter Johnson of Dwight Morrow High School, Englewood, N. J., received first prize of a two-year scholarship; Joseph Melillo of Nutley (N. J.) High School, second prize of one-year scholarship.
The election of Harvey C. Couch, Southwestern public utilities operator, as chairman of the board of the Kansas City Southern Railway was announced yesterday.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended April 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $15,128,029, which,
The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing was celebrated last night at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Fortythird Street.

Acting under Mexican law, the chief foreign petroleum companies here today established what in effect amounts to a nation-wide employers' union with which labor unions must treat as a unit rather than dealing with individual companies.

Miss Charlotte Glutting of South Orange, Curtis Cup team star, stroked her way back to a ranking position today in the first match-play round of the women's metropolitan golf championship when she defeated Mrs. Walter C. Smith of Westfield, N. J. 7 and 6.

The ordinance adopted by Yonkers to keep persons wearing shorts off the public streets is "so vague and meaningless as to reach many harmless and insipid foibles," the seven judges of the Court of Appeals agreed today in reversing the conviction of Rose O'Gorman and William Matthias, who were arrested for violation of the ordinance.

Hitting up the highest score of the season, Sussex retained its place at the top of the county cricket championship today, although held to a first innings victory in a slugfest with Yorkshire at Sheffield.

The Journeymen Barbers International Union ordered extension of its city-wide strike yesterday to the Grand Central and Times Square districts, but a walk through the section failed to disclose any considerable number of pickets or any shutdown of. activity in barber shops.

Clarence S. Day Jr., writer, left a gross estate of $171,956 and a net estate of $17,180, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mrs. Katherine B. Day, the widow, of 130 East End Avenue, is the sole beneficiary. Mrs. Day died on Dec. 28, 1935.

By a substantial majority and without debate the Northern Baptist Convention today adopted the report of its resolutions committee urging. among other things, the fixing of a living minimum wage for every worker and placing a Federal limit on income. A predicted fight over the report failed to develop.

Pensions On his own application: SERGEANT-Daniel O'Neill, 24th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed June 30, 1909. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Assignments to desk duty continued: Howard J. Smith, from 2d Dlv. to 1st Div.; Joseph F. Murray, from 4th Div. to 16th Div.: John O. Becker, from 13th Div. to 4th Div.; Jeremiah F. O'Shea, from 14th Div. to 1st Div.

Mrs. Charles William Gano entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre for her sister, Miss Clare Baxter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Baxter, whose marriage to Norman Hilborn will take place on June 3. Other guests were Mrs.

Mrs. Simeon B. Chapin of this place was elected president of the Greenwich unit of the New York Junior League at the annual meeting at the Field Club yesterday. Mrs. Chapin succeeds Mrs. Edward Emerson.

EDWARD J. O'BRIEN, caliph of the shortstory world, has edited another selection of his favorites. It is called "The Best Short Stories, 1937" (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50) -which, being interpreted, means nothing more than that the volume contains what one man liked best of the stories published by Americans (and one Canadian) during the calendar year 1936.
Edward Albright, United States Minister to Costa Rica and former Minister to Finland, died here today at the age of 63.

While the New York State Organization of Retail Liquor Store Associations was holding its second day of sessions in its convention at the Capitol Hotel yesterday, two importers revised prices partly in line with the retailers' pressure for better mark-ups.
Employes of the Independent subway in New York are entitled to all the benefits of the prevailing Rate of Wages Law, the Court of Appeals decided today.

Professor Arthur M. Hulbert, for the last twenty years in charge of New Jersey's 4-H Club program that is credited with enlarging educational and other opportunities for thousands of rural boys and girls in this State, died suddenly of a heart attack in St. Peter's Hospital here early this morning. He was 67 years old.
The waters of Newark Bay should be classed for industrial use, speakers for communities in the bay area urged today at a hearing at City Hall before the Interstate Sanitation Commission.

With a display of harmony over the British rearmament program exceeding the most optimistic expectations of British officials, the Imperial Conference established today a highly important committee to study dominion cooperation in the handling of munitions and war supplies.
George Schuck Jr., 42 years old, of 1,650 Jefferson Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, a private watchman who shot a burglar suspect last May 9, was exonerated yesterday in Ridgewood Felony Court.

The Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., has sent copies of its rules of fair practice and complaint procedure to its more than 1,700 members for a formal vote. The rules were adopted by the governing committee of the conference on May 6 after copies had been sent to all members for comment and suggestions.
Charles J. Oppenheim, president of Jay Thorpe, Inc., has purchased about sixteen acres of land with a four-acre lake on Rock Rimmon Road, Stamford, Conn., formerly owned by John J. DeForest. Mr.
Ernest Bevin and other moderate leaders of the Transport and General Workers Union took control of the London bus strike from the busmen's committee today and moved to end the deadlock.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. The American wing, general tour, 11 A. M.; "The Egyptian Cult of the Dead," Georg Steindorff, 4 P. M. Annual testimonial luncheon of the Women's League of Jewish Science, Hotel Westover, 12:30 P. M. "An Appreciation of Jewish Science," Rabbi Louis I. Newman.

Lieut. Gen. Robert Lee Bullard was re-elected president of the National Security League for the twelfth term, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the league at 45 West Forty-fifth Street. At the twenty-third annual meeting held Tuesday, Franklin Q. Brown was re-elected honorary president and Palmer E. Pierce was re-elected vice president.

Dr. Charles Seymour, presidentelect of Yale University, has received an honorary fellowship, its highest honor, from King's College, Cambridge University, it was stated here today by Dr. Charles T. Loram, Sterling Professor at Yale.
The Montreal Royals won their third straight victory over Buffalo when they defeated the Bisons, 6 to 1, today behind the six-hit pitching of Lauri Myllykangas.

With the conclusion yesterday of testimony before Edward C. Johnson as trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission at the hearings on charges of leged manipulation of Atlas Tack Corporation stock brought against W. E. Hutton Co. and other respondents, it was intimated that no decision would be rendered until late this year.

Price movements of commodity Sutures were mixed in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber and coffee futures gained, while sugar, cocoa, silk, lead and zinc futures eased. Copper, hide, wool top and cottonseed oil futures were irregular.

Mayor Cornelius D. Scully and representatives of the Regional Labor Board office conferred with company and employee leaders in an attempt to end the strike that has kept more than 2,000 workers out of the H. J. Heinz Company North Side plant since Tuesday.
The American Federation of Labor's executive council decided today to start war against John L. Lewis and the C. I. O. immediately on the waterfront and in the automobile industry.

Receiving the Gregory Medal, the premier award of the Irish Academy of Letters, of which he is president, here this evening, William Butler Yeats, noted Irish poet and Nobel Prize winner, made a striking valedictory address.
The Snug Harbor Development Corporation, large owner of real estate throughout New York State which it plans to develop, has leased offices in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

A ruling, intended to avoid any conflict with a regulation suggested recently by the Securities and Exchange Commission, on the switching from one stock to another by members of the New York Stock Exchange or partners, was made public yesterday by the committee on business conduct of the Exchange.

The trustees of the Warner Quinlan Company, which is in reorganization proceedings, yesterday recommended approval of a plan to recast the company before John E. Joyce, special master, in the Federal Building.
THE DANCE GOES ON, by Louis Golding. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A love story. NEW HAMPSHIRE NEIGHBORS, by Cornelius Weygandt. (Holt, $3.50.) Human aspects of country life.

Three new films will enter the Broadway sector today. "This Is My Affair," at the Music Hall, will present Robert Taylor, Barbara Stanwyck and Victor McLaglen, among others, in a story of the McKinley period.

George J. McLean, newspaper man, died suddenly of a heart attack today at his home in Marshfield Hills at the age of 64. Mr. McLean had been in the newspaper business for forty-eight years and at his death was a member of The Boston Globe editorial staff, publicity director for the Eastern Steamship Lines and New England correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune.

Mrs. Frederic Robert De Young of Chicago has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ruth Miriam De Young, to Herbert Vollrath Kohler of Kohler, Wis., son of the late- Mr. and Mrs. John Michael Kohler.

Almon G. Rasquin, Collector of Internal Revenue for Kings, Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Richmond Counties, announces that in view of the decision of the United States Supreme Court upholding the Social Security Act, his office will move promptly for the full collection of taxes under that act.

The War partment released the following orders today, dated May 25: COLONEL Ireland, M. L., Q. M. C., to duty as superintendent. Army Transport Service, Ma- 2d nila, P. I., in addition to other duties; vice Colonel C. A. Clark, Q. M. C., relived.

Miss Josephine B. Doughten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Doughten of Chestnut Hill, has completed plans for her marriage to George Frederick Tyler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Tyler of Indian Council Rock, Newtown, which will take place June 26 in St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill. The Rev.

Robert R. Young, head of the syndicate now in control of the 23,000-mile Van Sweringen network of railroads and other industries, testified today before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce that the Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the Van Sweringen system, will be eliminated from the set-up within a few weeks.

Religion is "the one history-making force," Dr. William Ernest Hocking of Harvard University declared today at commencement exercises at Crozer Theological Seminary. Economic interpretation of history is not enough, said Dr. Hocking. He continued:

Displaying the same easy, graceful speed which made him national interscholastic indoor mile champion, Leslie MacMitchell of George Washington High School yesterday set a new mark for the 880-yard run at the Manhattan P. S. A. L. track and field championships at Baker Field.

Ford workers beat union organizers and chased them from the Ford Company property in the first battle of the C. I. O. drive at the Rouge plant. Sixteen were reported injured, including seven women. National Labor Board and Wayne County prosecutor began investigations as the company charged a "frame-up" by, the union.-Page 1.

The twelve-story store and office building at 261 Broadway, northwest corner of Warren Street, has been leased for forty years by the Gerry Estates, Inc., to the Siack Realty Corporation. Adams Co. acted as brokers.

While millions of British patriots were clearing their throats before singing " God Save the King," Lord BLEDISLOE, who has held many distinguished posts and may be said to represent the agricultural interest, proposed a slight amendment of the national anthem.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses drew a sharp rebuke yesterday from Frederick J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, who criticized him for having sold broadcasting privileges for a Randalls Island track meet, to the exclusion of WNYC, the city's station.

Taking of testimony in the trial of Gladys MacKnight and Donald Wightman, who are charged with the hatchet murder of the former's mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight, last July 31, ended abruptly shortly before 3 o'clock this afternoon, after a theatrical morning session devoted to cross-examination of the 19-year-old Wightman.

The numerous "unjustified" attacks on advertising by various groups, while conceded as "partly justified," were "challenged" yesterday by advertisers, agency executives, media representatives and others in the advertising field, who paraded an array of facts on the steps being taken to control unfair copy at a symposium conducted by the Proprietary Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

Twenty-nine lifelong friends and neighbors of Ellis H. Parker Sr. and his son, Ellis Jr., came to their aid today as the Parkers replied to the government's conspiracy charges by disclaiming any knowledge of a plot to kidnap Paul H. Wendel. They blamed Wendel himself and their co-defendant, Murray Bleefeld, who earlier in the trial pleaded guilty and testified for the government.

The story of Russia's new Arctic empire and of the groundwork that paved the way for the establishment of Professor Otto J. Schmidt's party of Soviet fliers at the North Pole will be told in a book called, "40,000 Against the Arctic" that Morrow will publish.

The fascinating exhibition of fac simile reproductions of cave paintings and rock carvings by primitive man, from the Frobenius Collection will continue to be shown at the Museum of Modern Art through Sunday.
State executives of New Jersey will join with officials of the General Motors Corporation in the formal opening and dedication today of the new General Motors assembly plant in Linden, N. J.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, who retires today as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, will preside at the morning session of the annual convention of the institute, which will be held in the Waldorf-Astoria today, and will deliver the opening address.

A "Little Wagner Act," guaranteeing the right of Pennsylvania workers to organize and bargain collectively and outlawing company-dominated unions, was enacted today by the Legislature, both houses of which adopted a conference committee report.

With only two days of practioc left before the start of the Austra lia-United States Davis Cup tie at Forest Hills, it was learned yesterday that Adrian Quist, one of the strongest members of the team from Down Under, has been confined to his bed for two days with intestinal flu, under the care of a doctor.

Field Marshall, noted black gelding from the Rolling Rock Farms of Richard K. Mellon, captured the blue in the lightweight thoroughbred hunters class at the Devon Horse Show tolav. Field Marshall defeated Mrs.

Miss Mary Jane Harrison of Napoleon, Ohio, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Arthur McCann Harrison of Bowling Green, Ohio, was married here yesterday afternoon to John Scott Sellenings, son of Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Henry Sellenings of Columbus, Ohio.

Mrs. Foster Douglas gave a dinner last night at the Meadowbrook Restaurant for her sister, Miss Ann R. Foster, and Thomas Le Boutillier 3d, whose marriage will take place this afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection. Other guests,

William Lathrop Kingsley Memorial Scholarships, given for promise in the literary field, were awarded today by Yale University to Harold D. Kelling, '37, of Cleveland Heights; Curtis C. Page, '37, of Hartsdale, N. Y., and David R. Kerr, '39, of Springfield, Mass.

The Imperial Airways flying boat Cavalier made a perfect landing at the seaplane base in Hamilton Harbor late this afternoon, completing the first round trip survey flight between New York and Bermuda.
A baby health show, designed to promote higher health standards, will be held at 1:30 P. M. today in the auditorium of the nurses' residence of St. Vincent's Hospital, 158 West Twelfth Street.

Following the validation of both the old-age annuity and the unemployment sections of the Social Security Act, suggestions have come tumbling in for extending the coverage of these sections and for revising the act in other respects.

Elimination of manufacturing by syndicates through contractors and demands that they stop seeking "special prices" were included in seven proposals for improving conditions in the millinery industry which were presented yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission at a second conference with representatives of the hat syndicates, held at the offices of the commission, 1,450 Broadway. Irving C.

Renewed criticism was heaped on Neville Chamberlin, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in financial and industrial circles yesterday because of his refusal to make any but minor changes in his proposed tax on the growth of profits.

Carlos A. Vial, president of the Santiago de Chile Stock Exchange, who is visiting here prior to his departure for Europe next week, denied in an interview yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that the Chilean Government intended to nationalize Chile's copper industry.

A couple of fellows named George ran unsuspectingly into a heavy fire of Yankee hits at the Stadium yesterday as the champions hammered out their sixth straight victory, their longest string of the year, at the expense of the leaderless Detroit Tigers before a gathering of 11,643.

In a surprise visit to her famous quintuplet daughters two days before their third birthday, Mrs. Elzire Dionne was almost swept off her feet today by the five wildly yelling babies, who clung to her skirts and begged to be taken in her arms.
The American Olympic Committee for the 1936 games wound up its affairs last night at the New York A. C. Reports from the various subcommittees were received and a complete report was ordered printed.

Mrs. Muriel P. Ross of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Peck of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married to J. Ernest Stern of 270 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon in the bridegroom's home by Supreme Court - Justice Edgar J. Lauer.
P. N. Kelly, research engineer for the Central Railroad of New Jersey, testified before Federal Judge Phillip Forman today that the company operated in New Jersey at a loss in 1932, 1933 and 1934.
The remains of what is believed to have been an antediluvian animal, twenty-four feet long and ten feet high, were found near Somoto, in the Department of Madriz.

Mrs. Helen Tiernan of 525 West Forty-seventh Street, Manhattan, who confessed she killed her 7-yearold daughter, Helen, and seriously injured her 4-year-old son, Jimmy, in the woods at Brookhaven May 15, was indicted by the May Suffolk County grand jury today on charges of first-degree murder and first-degree assault.
Newtown H. S. strengthened Its grip on third place on the Queens P. S. A. L. baseball race when it defeated Bryant, 7 to 6, yesterday at Bradley Oval.
Atilio Sabatino of Puerto Rico scored a close victory over Frankie Blair, Camden welterweight, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the New York Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 2,000 was present.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Tuesday at Shanghai, China, of Ernst .B. Filsingef, an expert on foreign trade, who was president of the Export Managers Club of this city in 1927-29. He was president of Filsinger, Hines Campbell, Inc., 1,775 Broadway, exporters.

The Rev. Dr. William Hiram Foulkes, pastor of the Old First Presbyterian Church of Newark, N. J., was hailed tonight as virtually certain to be elected Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, which opens its 149th General Assembly tomorrow.

Senator Aquiles Concha explained before Congress this afternoon his plans for the development of copper mines controlled by Chileans in order to create a properly organized industry with government support.

Byrnes MacDonald, Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner, officiated yesterday at the opening of a new juvenile indoor recreation center at 202 Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Police Athletic League and the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department.
Exeter defeated Andover by 6-4 in their third annual lacrosse game today. The contest was exciting throughout, the half closing with Exeter in the lead, 3-2.

" CONTACT" (Little, Brown, $2), by Charles codman, is remarkable for its story and its style. It is the war memoir of an American aviator who, after a number of successful flights, was shot down inside the enemy lines and spent the Autumn of 1918 in German prisons. Stylistically it is an aristocrat among war books. Mr.

Commencement exercises of the Collegiate School; 241 West Seventyseventh Street, will be held tonight for a graduating class of twentytwo. Cornelius B. Boocock, associate headmaster of Haverford School, Haverford, Pa., will speak.

Tallying once in the eleventh, the St. Mark's nine turned back Groton, 3-2, in the forty-ninth game of their old series today. Kaye raced across with the deciding marker after the catch of Wheeler's long fly to right field.
A home run by Johnny Mize, big first baseman with two teammates on base, supplied all the punch needed by the Cardinals today as they downed the Bees, 6 to 4.
Turpentine firm, 36c; sales, 187 barrels; receipts, 525 barrels; shipments, 325 barrels; stock, 26.014 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 335; receipts, 2,026; shipments, 3,007; stock, 43.423.

The two-story business building at 72 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester, which recently was remodeled, has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank of New York to a client of Harry Levy for cash above a mortgage of $40,000.

Plans have been completed by Miss Margaret D. Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. D. Evans of Summit, N. J., for her marriage to J. Stiger Ferry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Ferry, also of Summit, which will take place June 12 in Calvary Church, Summit.
The Canadian Pacific Railway Company today applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to inaugurate a steamship service between Port McNicoll, Ont., and Milwaukee and Chicago.

Miss Gertrude L. Orgel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Orgel of 1,192 Park Avenue, was married last night to Howard E. Sandman, son of Mr. and Mrs. O. H. Sandman of Brooklyn, by Dr. Israel Goldstein at the Savoy-Plaza.

Thomas Bradford Drew, chemical engineer, of Wilmington, Del., today was declared the winner of the William H. Walker award, conferred annually by the . American Institute of Chemical Engineers, meeting in convention here.

Drastic revision of the by-laws of the Board of Education, which in effect takes many powers from the Board of Superintendents and gives more authority to the Superintendent of Schools, was voted yesterday at the board's regular meeting at 500 Park Avenue.

The bond market yesterday was exceedingly .dull, with the general apathy on the part of traders being, on the whole, at the expense of prices. The turnover in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange dwindled to $7,447,700, against $8,747,700 on Tuesday.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range yesterday and under an unusually light volume of business ended 2 points higher to 2 points lower.

Colonel and Mrs. Edwin M. Watsen of Washington are at the Gotham. Mrs. Robert L. Bigelow is expected to arrive at the Plaza today from West Chop, Mass. Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Isham, who had been at the Drake, have returned to their country place in Dorset, Vt.

The Regional Labor Board will start hearings at 10 A. M. today, at the State Labor Building, 80 Center Street, on an application of the National Maritime Union for an election by the sea-going personnel of the International Mercantile Marine Company, the Luckenbach Steamship Company and the Black Diamond Steamship Company.

Potential means for the creation of a permanent committee coordinating the activities of Britain and the dominions were seen by observers today in the naming by the Imperial Conference of a committee to consider mutual interests In the supply and production of munitions and war material.
Governor Lehman signed today the Gamble bill, providing that a new charter government for Westchester County be submitted to the county's voters at the Fall election.

Operators were active yesterday in deals involving house properties in the Bronx. Joseph L. Ennis Co. bought from the estate of Mary E. Blodgett the five-story building for ten families at 375 East 137th Street, between Alexander and Willis Avenues.
Father Fidelis of St. Joseph's Rectory, East Rutherford, N. J., and a former president of St. Bonaventure's College, died today at St. Francis's Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 63.

Everybody knows about that hit, "Room Service." The news this morning is that its authors, John P. Murray and Allen Boretz, are at work on another. Call it, tentatively, "Peace Prize"--less broad in style than "Room Service,"

The daily statement of the United States Treasury showed a rise of $32,300,000 in the inactive gold fund as of last Monday, which was the largest single day's increase in the fund since the government began to sterilize gold last December.

A filly who some day will improve the calibre of the stock on the thousands of acres comprising the King Ranch in Texas yesterday drove down the stretch at Belmont Park to capture the $12,675 Acorn Stakes and vindicate the hopes and expectations of her owners and trainer.

The Republic Steel Company's statement to its employes was divided into five parts under bold face headings and read: THE REAL ISSUES Republic Steel Corporation has been asked to sign the C. I. O. contract.

Early action is expected on the signing of a contract between manufacturers and salesmen in the coat and suit industry, calling for uniform rates of commission, it was announced last night at a meeting of the Coat and Suit Salesmen's Association of America, Inc., at the Governor Clinton Hotel.
One thing the Supreme Court has insisted uponthe present nine unanimously-is that Congress cannot grant "a roving commission" to any Federal agent.

Although the gross revenues in April of the first sixteen railroads to report for that month showed increases compared with April, 1936, not all the companies in the group showed increases in net operating income. In the East, for example,
The marriage of Miss Pearl Hill, Hartford pianist, to Laurence Wray, who is with the Mc-Graw-Hill publishing house in New York, will take place June 12 in the Church of the Ascension, New York.
The Red Sox and Browns took turns hammering rival pitching quartets today, but the home forces had a four-hit edge and gained their third straight victory by an 11-to-9 margin.

The long-expected reorganization of the battle force and destroyer divisions in both the Battle and Scouting Forces of the Navy will be put into effect early next month, Secretary Swanson announced today.

Rear Admiral David F. Sellers, superintendent of the Naval Academy, has sent letters of commendation to ten midshipmen of the graduating class who have contributed most by their officerlike qualities and positive characters to the development of naval spirit and loyalty within the regiment.

The New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad Company directors announced today a plan for extension to Aug. 1, 1940, of maturity of the carrier's first mortgage refunding bonds, and second mortgage refunding bonds would be declared inoperative unless 85 per cent of each issue is deposited or covered by deposit agreements by May 28, when the present extension of time expires. The bonds matured on Jan.

Several hundred motorists visited the gardens of Peacock Point, the home of Mrs. Henry Pomfroy Davison; the estate of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anton Hodenpyl and the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Theodore Scheepers this afternoon in the last of the garden pilgrimages given in behalf of the Nature School League.

The Tanners Council of America and the National Shoe Retailers Association have selected Sept. 9 and 10 as the dates for the next official leather opening and style conference, which will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Clydell Castleman today returned to the scene of one of his outstanding achievements last season, and if he did not quite achieve what he did a year ago, the result was far more gratifying.

Berton Lewis Maxfield, a lawyer in this city for twenty-seven years, with offices in the Woolworth Building, died on Tuesday at his home, 3,088 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

Miss Marie L. Butler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Butler of this city, was married to Arthur D. Sullivan, son of Mrs. Margaret Sullivan, also of Elizabeth, this morning at St. Patrick's Church here.

Hearings of the Treasury case against Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob for the collection of about $1,700,000 additional income tax for 1929 were completed yesterday at the Old Postoffice Building, where they have been under way since May 3.

Some forty members of the Commercial Artists and Designers Union, Local 20329, American Federation of Labor, again picketed the Paramount Theatre in Times Square last night during the peak of the evening theatre rush, interfering with pedestrian traffic and causing many persons to walk in the street.

Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, commanding officer of the Naval Air Station here, indicated his belief tonight that further investigation should be made into the possibility that the hydrogen fire that destroyed the dirigible Hindenburg was of incendiary origin.

One match overshadowed all others in the British amateur golf championship today. Bobby Locke, the 19-year-old prodigy from South Africa, twice both open and amateur champion of his native country, went down before one of the best of the young Scotsmen, Gordon Peters.
By B. HOLLANDER SON West Farms Road, 1,309, 2-story frame dwelling, 28.2x83.6 irreg; Charles Quattlander against Rita N. Schmidt; due, $4,686: taxes, $523; to plaintiff for $100.

Commencement exercises of the Collegiate School, 241 West Seventyseventh Street, 9:30 A. M. Address by Cornelius Brett Boocock. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Art of Italy," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.: "The Egyptian Collection,"

Travelers from Spain brought new reports of an Anarchist revolt in Huesca Province today. The travelers said the revolting extremists, hitherto supporters of the Madrid-Valencia government, had proclaimed a free republic at Barbastro, thirty miles southeast of the city of Huesca.

Announcement of the retirement of Dr. Irvin Stewart from the Federal Communications Commission, of which he is vice chairman and head of the telegraph division, was made today. He will become head of a Committee of Scientific Aids to Learning, appointed by the National Research Council.

A window glass factory with a capitalization of about $383,000 and an estimated annual production of 3,200,000 square feet of drawn and rolled window glass will shortly be established in the Province of Limburg, Netherlands, probably near the Juliana Canal, which connects with the whole of the Netherlands and a large part of Germany and Belgium, according to a report from the American Consul at Rotterdam, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Successive doubles by George McQuinn and Babe Dahlgren with two down in the eighth broke up a mound duel today and gave the Newark Bears a 1-to-0 victory over the Jersey City Giants. The triumph was Newark's third in the four-game series.

President Roosevelt again cancelled all engagements because of a cold and remained in his study in the White House. He transmitted to the Senate eight of the principal agreements reached at the Buenos Aires Conference.
Frederick B. Richardson, founder of the former Richardson School in this city, died today in his home here at the age of 77. Mr. Richardson was graduated from Amherst College in 1882.

That the Paris Exposition was not finished for the formal inauguration this week is not remarkable. Big international fairs depend so much on improvisation and on circumstances and exhibitors beyond the control of their sponsors that they are seldom completely ready on the opening date.

Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol provided the first upset in the women's metropolitan golf championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club when she defeated Mrs. Wiliam Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, 4 and 2, in the second round today.

Verdi's "Alda" received its first and only performance of the Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Despite the hot, sultry weather, the ever-popular work attracted a large audience, which apparently enjoyed the earnest presentation.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public summaries of registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933 as follows:

Gordon Stanley (Mickey) Cochrane, manager of the Tigers, was reported resting comfortably last night in St. Elizabeth's Hospital on Washington Heights. The baseball star is suffering from a fractured skull after being hit by a ball pitched by Irving (Bump) Hadley of the Yankees in Tuesday's game at the Stadium.
The Duluth, Missabe Northern Railway Company and the Spirit Lake Transfer Railway Company, which for many years have been operating as a single system through lease arrangements,

The National Federation of Music Clubs will hold its 1939 Biennial Convention in Baltimore, it has been announced by Mrs. Vincent Hilles Ober, national president. The convention probably will be held in May.

Philip A. Baumgartner, hunger-striking clerk of the Civilian Conservation Corps at Fort Oglethorpe, Ga., was dismissed today on charges of "attempting to coerce the government" and "insubordination in conduct."

The Special Assembly of the League of Nations unanimously admitted Egypt to the League today as the fifty-ninth member. The ceremony was, as usual, bare in its simplicity, with speeches of welcome - twenty of themsupplying the only pompous and protracted note.

The six-family apartment house at 48-39 Forty-seventh Street, Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for cash above a first mortgage of $10,400 to a client of William Adam Schulz Co., Inc., brokers.
The Indians made four runs against the Athletics in the ninth inning today to gain an 8-to-6 victory and climb from fourth to second place in the American League.

Jacques Doriot, leader of the Rightist French Popular party and a former Communist leader, was removed tonight from his office as Mayor of Saint Denis, a "Red" suburb of Paris, under a decree of the Ministry of the Interior charging him with irregularities in office.

Assisted no little by the comforting presence of Edward G. Robin on, Bette Davis and Harry Carey in his corner, young Wayne Morris, the Warners' latest astronomical discovery, comes through with a natural and easy performance in "Kid Galahad," the Louis-Braddock preliminary at the Strand.

Legislation making possession as well as sale of non-tax paid, liquor illegal, and a ban on importation by private citizens of liquor from Canada, were asked by the New York State Organization of Retail Liquor Store Associations at the closing session of its three-day convention at the Capitol Hotel here yesterday.
President Roosevelt formally submitted to the Senate today eight of the agreements reached at the InterAmerican Conference for the Maintenance of Peace held at Buenos Aires last December.

China is adopting a firm but reasonable attitude in the face of Japan's demands and complaints concerning the imprisonment of a Japanese policeman at Swatow and the moving of a regiment of salt revenue guards to the vicinity of Tsingtao.
Eddie O'Brien, Syracuse University's crack middle-distance runner, will not defend his title at the I. C. A. A. A. A. meet at New York Friday and Saturday. He won the 400 meters last year.

Now that the ceremonies incident to the coronation no longer occupy most of the time of the delegates, the Imperial Conference, representing all the self-governing dominions and India, is getting into its stride.
The United Automobile Workers of America fired their "first gun in the war against Henry Ford" today with a strike which tied up the Ford assembly plant here for the second time in five weeks.

The London bus strikers have been called upon by their union to return to work Friday as the result of a provisional agreement reached tonight. As far as is ascertainable they have gained nothing more than was offered to them after the public court of inquiry into their grievances before the coronation.

Mayor La Guardia returned to City Hall yesterday morning after a two-week absence, during which he attended the meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors in Los Angeles. Mrs. La Guardia accompanied him on the trip.

After having been held by the Haddock family for more than seventy-five years, the two threestory buildings at 570-74 Hudson Street, at the southwest corner of West Eleventh Street at the upper end of Greenwich Village, have been sold to the 570 Hudson Street Corporation.

Thomas E. Elder, 65, retired dean of the Mount Hermon School for Boys at Northfield, scene of the unsolved shotgun slaying of Dr. Elliot Speer, headmaster, in 1934, was brought here tonight from the Holden Barracks of the State police, under arrest on the charge of assault with intent to murder S. Allen Norton of this town, former treasurer of the school. He will be arraigned in the District Court here tomorrow.
Support of Local No. 1 of the Progressive Miners of America was given tonight to more than 350 sit-down strikers occupying the No. 4 mine of the Superior Coal Company at Wilsonville.
The three-story warehouse building at 61 Wyckoff Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Phileth Holding Corporation, a subsidiary of the Borough Hall Sash and Door Company.

A woman turned in a fire alarm about 6:30 A. M. yesterday at York Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street and as she turned away from the alarm box, Patrolman Edward Moran of the East Sixty-seventh Street station inquired: "Where's the fire?"

Bookings of fabricated structural steel during April totaled 148,152 tons, as compared with 112,195 tons in the same month last year, while shipments were 136,042 tons, against 134,162 tons in April, 1936, the American Institute of Steel Construction records.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: In the cotton belt the week was warmer than normal. Light to moderate rains were general from the Mississippi Valley eastward, but in much of the belt, especially Texas.
The "Florida Recovery Act" to outlaw chain stores was killed in the Senate today, 18 to 16, by indefinite postponement.

The Malvern Cold Storage Company agreed today to increase the wages of its employes $1.50 to $3 a week, and in return the workers pledged themselves not to become affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., Virginia, and its wholly owned subsidiary, Philip Morris Co., Ltd., England, reported yesterday for the year ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $3,573,617 after all charges, including provision for normal Federal income tax and $144,447 provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.

Lester M. Wilson, Professor of Comparative Education at Teachers College, died early last night in his penthouse apartment at 200 West Fifteenth Street. He had served as a professor at Teachers College since 1923. For some time he had suffered from a stomach ailment.

The Colonial residence of R. F. Riffee on a large plot at Oak Street, Edgewood, Greenwich, Conn., has been sold to George Purdy Hall. The property is said to have been held at $34,500. Thomas A. Raynor was the broker.

The Central West Company yesterday declared a distribution $1 a share in cash plus one share of common stock of the Central Electric Telephone Company, for each five shares of common stock of Central West stock held, to holders of voting trust certificates representing common stock of Central West.
Close-of-play scores in English .first-class cricket matches started today: Essex, 370 (Eastman 90, Pearce 65, Bray 52, O'Connor 51); Kent, 23 for one wicket: at Gravesend.
The sale of the new 5-cent stamp, depicting a view of the Military Academy as seen from the West Point Plains, was formally opened here this morning at the West Point. postoffice.

A large group of official, business and trade organizations in New York City and vicinity have filed protests with the Interstate Commerce Commission against the limits of the New York "metropolitan area" as defined for purposes of enforcing the Motor Carrier Act of 1935.

Mansfield Freeman, chairman of the United States Life Insurance Company, who arrived Monday from the Orient, said yesterday that the life-insurance business in the Far East has shown a marked increase.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey advanced the price of gasoline yesterday one-half of 1 cent a gallon the regular and premium grades in tank-wagon and tank-car lots in Northern New Jersey.
Amid threats of an anti-Nazi boycott and in the face of a hotel strike, San Francisco began tonight a week's celebration of the opening of the $35,000,000 Golden Gate Bridge.

A portrait of Mrs. Mary Kingsbury Simkhovitch, founder and director of the Greenwich House, was unveiled yesterday afternoon at the community center, 27 Barrow Street, in a ceremony held in observance of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the institution.

Assertions that the United States had failed to solve its unemployment relief problem with establishment of the Social Security Law were made today at the National Conference of Social Work. A three-point program was proposed to care for the nation's idle on a permanent basis.

Edward Lawford, 24 years old, a real estate broker, of the Hotel Gladstone in East Fifty-second Street, was discharged yesterday in the Felony Court on a Sullivan law charge growing out of the recent shooting of Martene W. (Bill) Corum, a sports columnist on The New York Evening Journal.

Miss Mary Gertrude Lanigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Andrew Lanigan of Riverdale-onHudson, has completed plans for her marriage to James Maxwell Charlton, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. E. A. Charlton of Scarsdale.

After tallying up the amount spent in Canada in the first four months of 1937, as evidenced by bank checks, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics announced today that the total was $12,525,000,000, compared with $11,132,000,000 in the same months of last year.
The House held a memorial service today for the six Senators and fifteen Representatives who have died since the last similar service two years ago.

The directors of the New York World's Fair, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Bankers Club, presented to Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, a check for $1 "as one token not only" of public recognition but also of our own deep appreciation of his unceasing activity and devotion to the interests of the New York World's Fair."

Officials of twoBritish Columbia gold mining companies said today that their crews had called strikes, demanding higher pay and recognition of their Ininternational Mine, Mill and Smeltermen's Union, an affiliate of the C. I. O.

Forty-one students will receive diplomas tomorrow night at the commencement exercises of the Horace Mann School for Girls, 120th Street and Broadway. Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Teachers College, will give the address and Dr. William F. Russell, dean of the college, will preside.
Despite 16 points garnered by John Collier, hurdles star, the Hill School faculty bowed to the varsity, 66-60, in their annual track meet today.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Twenty-eight provisional members were introduced at the annual Spring luncheon of the Junior League of Brooklyn yesterday on the Marine Roof of the Hotel Bossert. Before the luncheon a reception was held in honor of Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., who was made an honorary member of the league.

Sixteen of the thirty persons invited will attend the marriage June 3 of Mrs. Wallis Warfield and the Duke of Windsor. Several of the guests hold British government positions, but there will be no members of the royal family.
Seyid Abdul Adir Sinawai, one of Iraq's most able senior officials, was shot dead, it was learned today, by Hamul Jawdat, a retired army officer. The assailant was arrested immediately.

The Adams Express Company announced yesterday that it had provided a supplemental indenture for its ten-year 4 1/4 per cent debentures under which these obligations will I be secured by collateral and made non-callable prior to maturity on Aug. 1, 1946.

Miss Margaretta Trasel Rowland, daughter of Mrs. George T. Rowland of Haverford and the late Mr. Rowland, was married this afternoon to Alexander Boyd, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Boyd, formerly of Haverford.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, in his recent speech to the Propeller Club brought the merchant marine problem out in the open, where it belongs for the good of the public as well as the cause itself.
Seven former champions began match play in the twentieth P. G. A. title tournament on the Pittsburgh Field Club links today, but by nightfall there were only two of' them left.

L. R. Powell Jr. and Henry W. Anderson, receivers for the Seaboard Air Line Railroad, received salaries of $30,000 and $24,000, respectively, in 1936, according to the company's report for that year to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Domestic sales of electric household refrigerators amounted to 311,769 units in April, valued at $26,858,772, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Senator Byrd of Virginia was taken to task by Secretary Wallace today for his published charges of extravagance in connection with Resettlement Administration expenditures on a rural housing project in the Senator's State.

The Rev. Ernest J. Mollenauer of Syracuse, N. Y., in an address last night before delegates to the United Lutheran Synod of New York, sharply condemned "quack ministers," imbued with a "man bites dog spirit," who will "do anything for notoriety."
Stocks moved narrowly and closed irregular in slowest trading since May 13, 1936; turnover, 585,830 shares.

Still in pursuit of a title she never has been able to win, Miss Helen Jacobs reached the fourth round of the women's singles in the French hard court tennis championships today as Hal Surface of Kansas City was eliminated in the fourth round of the men's division.

President Roosevelt was encouraged directly by Premier Benito Mussolini to take the initiative in calling a world arms limitation conference through a call made at the State Department today by Fulvio Suvich, the Italian Ambassador, who outlined his government's views.

Senator Gerald P. Nye, chairman of a bondholders' committee for Republic of Cuba bonds, returned to the United States by airplane today following his appearance yesterday before the cuban government commission which is studying the possibility of a resumption of payments on public works bond issues that have been in default since 1933.
Alfred E. Smith held a long conversation with Pope Pius XI, who received the former Governor of New York and his party this morning in the Papal Summer residence, Castel Gandolfo.

Most of the financial district will have a three-day holiday over the Memorial Day week-end as a result of the actions of the boards of governors of the New York Stock and the New York Curb Exchanges yesterday.

Violent fluctuations featured the trading in grain for May delivery on the Board of Trade here today as shorts in corn, oats, rye and soy beans rushed to cover their commitments and found little for sale.

The Struthers Wells-Titusville Corporation of Warren, Pa., has called for redemption on Nov. 1 at 103 and interest its $1,032,000 of fifteen-year 6 1/2 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1943. The Marine Trust Company of Buffalo, trustee, will pay bonds presented to it then or before that date.

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday applications for listing of securities as follows: Dicvo-Twin Truck Company-220,000 shares of common stock, par value $1. with authority to add 2,500 additional common shares to the list upon official notice of issuance.

William Woodward's Perifox and Ralph Beaver Strassburger's Le Bambino will carry America's hopes in the Derby against twenty other 3-yearolds, it was indicated today when twenty- two thoroughbreds were nominated in the final acceptance for the mile-and-a-half classic to be run at Epsom Downs next Wednesday.

Hotel charges for telephone calls made by patrons were -defended today at a hearing before the Public Service Commission on the ground that the fees aided in defraying the cost of telephone equipment and service generally in the hotels.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 4 per cent for the week ended May 22, over the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain compares with one of 5 per cent for the preceding week.

While Britain, seconded by France, urged at Geneva the advisability somehow of withdrawing all foreign volunteers serving on both sides in Spain, General Francisco Franco, Insurgent chief, made an extravagant gesture today, by freeing unconditionally forty-five foreign prisowners of the International Brigade who had been captured on the Madrid front.

The Scoville School for Girls, 1,008 Fifth Avenue, will graduate eighteen students this afternoon at its commencement exercises. Dr. Pennington Haile, an officer of the National League of Nations Association, will give the commencement address.

Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin in one of his final acts as head of the government will announce in the House of Commons tomorrow a rise in pay for its members. This was decided by the Cabinet today, it was learned.
Out of the mailbag: The secretary of the Rockland County Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs, P. R. Hansen of Pearl River, N. Y., takes pen in hand to describe some of the organization's activities:

The Old Testament, through its influence on Puritanism, played an important part in the development of American ideals of religious and political liberty and exerted "an enormous influence" on the authors of the Federal Constitution, it was declared last night at the Institute of Biblical Studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary by Professor Abraham A. Neuman of Dropsie College.

The stock market here continued dull today and movements were irregular. Giltedge issues were quiet while among the foreign loans German bonds sagged. International issues opened dull but rallied during the afternoon. Domestic industrials were irregular.
A charter was granted today by the Chester County Court to the Lukens Employes Association, which is made up of employes of the Lukens Steel Company of Coatesville.

An unhealthy boom situation has been dissipated and a more orderly state of industrial affairs will ensue, Fred K. Heaslip, chairman of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents advised that body here today in incorporating majority views of those who attended convention group meetings on specific commodities.

Control of United Artists Corporation may pass into the hands of Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda if negotiations begun here last week are carried through successfully, it was learned today. Mr. Goldwyn and Mr. Korda virtually have concluded a deal whereby they will buy out the three other member-owners of the film company, Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks and Charles Chaplin.
C. A. Call of Batavia, Syracuse, '07, issued a challenge today to any member of classes from 1907 to 1911 to a one-mile race as a feature of "Carnival Day" at the Univeristy Saturday.

A plan for reorganization of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad, known as the Monon, was filed today by H. R. Kurrie, president, with Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson in the United States District Court here and with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

Although aggregate orders for steel have been running about 75 per cent of current shipments, the pressure from consumers for deliveries has been relaxed to such an extent that much earlier shipments of such products are possible

The Hudson Evening Register temporarily discontinued publication today following the action of The Morning Daily Star yesterday. Raymond D. Kennedy, publisher of The Register, said that sixteen printers had walked out after refusing to print editions for The Star, whose thirteen printers struck yesterday.
Moly Cross today made a clean sweep of its annual series with Yale by pounding out a 7-3 victory. The Crusaders turned Yale back in Worcester recently, 8-5..
Senators A. Harry Moore and William H. Smathers of New Jersey proposed today that their State be divided into two judicial districts and a fifth Federal judge appointed.
Baseball's High Commissioner, Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, is trying to land an extra pitcher For the all-star game here July 7. The hurler's name is Franklin D. Roosevelt.
About 650 bankers, members of their families and friends will embark this afternoon for Bermuda on the convention cruise of the New York State Bankers Association.

The fair isles of the Bermudas have been joined in the last two days by a new strand in the world's air web; invisible but factual and permanent. The 783 miles of sea which lie between Port Washington, L. I., and the waters of Hamilton Harbor off Darrell's Island, already have been spanned three times with a nonchalance which makes the deed the more impressive.

Cardinal Mundelein's classification of Chancellor Adolf Hitler as a "paperhanger" was protested here tonight in a resolution adopted by Paperhangers Locals 306 and 587 of the International Brotherhood of Painters, Paperhangers and Decorators.
Electric power production increased last week when a slight dip was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 106.4 from 106.1. It was 99.6 for the week ended May 23, 1936.

Included in the apartment leases reported yesterday was one for fifteen rooms at 895 Park Avenue taken by Francis F. Randolph of J. W. Seligman Co. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., negotiated this lease through Douglas L. Elliman Co. Other leases reported were:
Renomination of Mayor La Guardia by the Republicans was urged last night by Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh at a dinner in his honor at the National Republican Club.
John Dwight Sullivan, Deputy Controller for the last two and onehalf years, is leaving city service next Monday to resume his private law practice, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

The Hecker Products Corporation, formerly known as the Gold Dust Corporation, announced yesterday the resignation of Randolph Catlin as president, effective on June 30. Guy Lemmon, formerly a vice president, will become president on that date.

Mr. and Mrs. Veryl Preston of 25 West Ninth.Street have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Preston, to George W. D. Symonds, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hale Symonds of Warehouse Point, Conn.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 10,000 including 3,500 directs. Uneven, 10-25 lower than Tuesday's average; mostly 15-25 off; pigs, packing sows and light lights slowing most decline; top, $11.90; bullM - good and choice 200-300 pounds, $11.60-$11.85; 150-190 pounds, $10.50$11.65. Few pigs up to $10.50; good packing sows, $10-$10.60; shipper, 500; estimated holdover, 2,500.

To two of college sport's most ancient rivals has fallen the opening match of this year's intercollegiate polo championship, which starts on Saturday, June 12, at Governors Island, according to the draw announced yesterday by J. C. Rathborne, president of the Intercollegiate Polo Association.

The Douglas Aircraft Company must appear before a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board June 7 to answer charges that it has engaged in unfair labor practices involving interstate commerce.

Congressional sources disclosed today that Raymond B. Stevens, who recently resigned from the Tariff Commission to support President Roosevelt's judiciary plan, would succeed Robert Lincoln O'Brien as chairman of the commission next June 16.

BILBAO--Insurgent planes shot down a French transport ship flying from Biarritz to Bilbao. The pilot and a woman, one of four passengers, were hurt and the plane was damaged in landing in a field twelve miles from the Basque capital.
General business activity in New England during April continued to expand, with the New England Council's Index of Business Activity moving up from 109.3 in March to 111.0 in April.
Two runs in the ninth inning gave Long Island University an 8-7 victory over City College in a see-saw battle at Dexter Park yesterday.

Adolph Lewisohn, financier and philanthropist, will celebrate his eighty-eighth birthday tomorrow and in the evening will give a dinner party for forty-two friends and relatives at his estate, Heatherdell Farm, on Daisy Avenue in this village.

Among the eight Manhattan properties sold at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday was the fourteen-story apartment building at 2,401-07 Broadway, on the northwest corner of Eightyeighth Street, occupying a plot 100.9 by 135.9 feet.
Admiral Henry Thomas Mayo, U. S. N. (retired), commander-inchief of the Atlantic fleet during the World War, was buried today with full military honors in Lake View Cemetery. beside Lake Champlain.

The forty-ninth annual commencement exercises of the Ballard School, Central Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association, will be held at 11 o'clock this morning in the auditorium at 610 Lexington Avenue.

Strikes affecting between 75,000 and 80,000 employes in the plants of the Republic Steel Corporation, Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and Inland Steel Company became effective at 11 o'clock tonight.

A short-lived "sit-down strike" of the eleven Essex County Democrats failed today to interrupt the proceedings of the Assembly, the Republican minority giving the votes needed to clear the calendar of about thirty bills.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens declared yesterday that he would advocate the closing of the new Queens City College next semester if there should be any evidence of communism in the new school.
Dr. Ludolf von Krehl, Emeritus Professor of Medicine at Heidelberg University, died here today at the age of 75. Dr. von Krehl was director of medicine at Heidelberg University's medical clinic.
Jimmy Snyder of Chicago cracked all records for a 25-mile qualifying run today, driving his blue speedster around the two-and-one-halfmile oval at a speed of 125.287 miles an hour.
The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendations of the committee on Stock List to list the following securities:
The Maryland Court of Appeals refused today to order Baltimore County to admit a Negro girl to the Catonsville High School.

Chancellor Juan B. Soto of the University of Puerto Rico today gave 225 degrees to graduates of the university, following commencement exercises at the Municipal Theatre. On Monday fifty-four were graduated from the College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts, making a total of 279 receiving degrees, 221 others received diplomas.
Princeton University's polo team was defeated by a Rumson quartet today on Herbert Memorial Field. 9-8.

Vittorio Giannini's new Requiem Mass was performed for the first time anywhere tonight at the Musikverein Hall by the chorus of the Society of the Friends of Music, the boys' choir of the Vienna Saengerknaben and the Vienna Symphony Orchestra directed by Oswald Kabasta.

The report of the International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net profit, after all expenses and charges, of $1,443,333, compared with a net of $675,014 in the twelve months ended on March 31, 1936, an increase of $768,319.
The abolition of school homework for children under 12 years of age is recommended by the Board of Education in a report that states that "nervous disorder of some young children is due to anxiety"

Taking advantage of the inauguration of the German pavilion at the Paris Exhibition today Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister who represented Chancellor Hitler, made a direct appeal to his French listeners to try to understand German problems better and realize that Germany was seeking to live in economic harmony with the rest of the world.

FIRST ROUND Denny Shute, Boston, defeated Joe Turnesa, Tuckahoe, N. Y., 2 and 1. Olin Dutra, Los Angeles, defeated Clarence Doser. Philadelphia, 3 and 2. Ed Dudley, Philadelphia, defeated Herman Barron, White Plains. N. Y., 5 and 3. Pat Wilcox. Norfolk, Neb., defeated Bruce Coltart, Haddonfield, N. J., 2 and 1. Paul Runyan, White Plains, defeated Levi Lynch. Dallas. 4 and 3.

Leaves of absence, with pay, for twentyfour hours, from 9 A. M., May 31, (Decoration Day), are granted to the following members of the Department, who are veterans of the Army, Navy or Marine Corps: Deputy Chief John J. McCarthy (2), 13th Division.
Today we are immensely happy, for into the ice camp at the North Pole came the airplane of Vassily Molokoff.

Roy C. Smith, head of the oil and gas unit of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will give an informal talk today on the new rules and regulations governing the sale of oil interests at a meeting in the Park Centfral Hotel.

Secretary Perkins told a House committee today that she favored specific wage and hour treatment for four major industries to supplement the President's minimum wage and maximum hour program for industry as a whole.

The engagement of Miss Helen Margaret Haselmayer of this place to Edward Gilman Slingerland, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. F. Slingerland, also of Millburn, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Haselmayer.

The elaborate recommendations of the technical subcommittee appointed to plan the withdrawal of foreign volunteers from Spain was submitted to the full Non-Intervention Committee today and it was agreed to refer them to the governmts represented.

The annual report for 1936 of "Sofina" (Socift6 Financiere de Transports et d'Entreprises Industrielles), one of the largest public utility holding companies in Europe, ! with headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, reviews in detail economic, political and social progress in Europe and other parts of the world.
David L. Milne, from Estate of Edith N. Putnam, house at corner of Grace Church and Ralston Sts. Beaumont, Rye, Westchester; E. V. Siedle, broker.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday took official cognizance of the fact that a contract is on file with it calling for a bout in which James J. Braddock is to defend his heavyweight championship of the world against Max Schmeling in the Long Island City Bowl on June 3.
Marshall Field 3d of New York has bought the 13,000-acre estate of the Chelsea Club, twelve miles from Ridgeland.

William Emerson Marshall of Bayville, L. I., well-known horticulturist, founder and president of the seed company bearing his name at 150 West Twenty-third Street, New York, died yesterday at the home of his son, Donald E. Marshall, near Califon, at the age of 63.

The fight of Protestant Confessional churchmen against Nazi domination entered a new acute phase today following the imprisonment by the secret State police of all five members of the executive committee of the Confessional Synod's provisional church government.

Premier Hendryk Colijn's "policy of adaptation" to the economic crisis won the approval of a greater part of the Netherland electorate judging by the results of today's election for both houses of the States General.

A further step in the plan to merge the Brick Presbyterian Church, 412 Fifth Avenue, with the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street, was taken last night when the corporation of the Brick Church voted unanimously to approve submission of the proposal to the Presbytery of New York and to the Supreme Court for ratification.

Loss of foreign markets to overseas competitors by units of British industry now overworked as a consequence of the armament program is causing fear to some industrialists in the United Kingdom, according to a report to the Commerce Department from Consul James R. Wilkinson at Birmingham.

Louis S. Cates, president of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, held options on April 5, last,. to buy 11,594 shares of the common stock of the company by the end of this year, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made available yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange.
Count Covadonga, eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain, is seriously ill in the home of Dr. Blas Rocafort following an internal hemorrhage yesterday.

Governor Lehman vetoed today the bill which would have permitted members of the State police to retire after twenty years' service on half salary. The bill was sponsored by Assemblyman Rapp of Genesee.
Wayne La Master, rookie left-hander from Louisville, gave only three hits and struck out ten today as Philadelphia scored its first victory over the Cubs in five starts this season, 6 to 1.
Five men lost their lives and two others were hurt when fire destroyed an oil-laden truck and a coupe after a head-on collision near West Coxsackie early today.

Dr. Charles W. Ballard, Professor of Materia Medica in the College of Pharmacy, Columbia University, was named yesterday as acting dean of the school by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

The British Government's determination not interfere presently with the private manufacture of armaments or to attempt regulation was stated by Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense,

Flushing civic and welfare leaders joined yesterday in denouncing the plan of the Emergency Relief Bureau to close its district office at 135-36 Thirty-ninth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, and transfer the 1,469 cases now on the rolls of that office to the ERB precinct at 21-21 Forty-first Avenue, Long Island City.
The Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army obtained 353,277.50, Chalmers Wood, chairman of the campaign committee, announced yesterday following the final meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

THE calendar is entirely too crowded. This was brought to mind sharply yesterday when Captain Eddie Rickenbacker was a caller. His siren song was "Come Take a Ride In. My Flying Machine" or words to that effect. Mr. Steven Jerome Hannagan probably put him up to it.

The Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, presented diplomas yesterday morning to twentyfive members of the graduating class of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, 175 Ninth Avenue, at the 117th annual commencement.

A man who insisted, Police Lieutenant Allen B. Crone -said, that he stabbed and fatally wounded Municipal Court Justice John F. O'Neil of New York on April 27, surrendered to authorities here tonight and requested he be turned over to New York police.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had resigned from an honorary vice presidency of the National Indian Association, a fifty-year-old organization with offices at 156 Fifth Avenue, devoted to "teaching the Indian to live like a white man."

Miss Anna Harte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin S. Harte of 45 West Eighty-first Street, was married last night at the Ambassador to Allan C. Shedlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Shedlin of Far Rockaway, Queens, by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum.

Contracts for the purchase of 1,225,000 pounds of electrolytic copper, Grade A, were announced today by the Navy Department. One contract for 200,000 pounds at $.14175 for delivery at the Washington Navy Yard was awarded to the American Smelting and Refining Company, 120 Broadway, New York.

Morris Pierce Paley, 37 years old, of 525 West End Avenue, who used tne name Morrison P. Paley in his law practice, and Julius A. Fosburg, 32, of 22-74 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, resigned from the bar yesterday following investigations in the last two months by the Accident Fraud Bureau of bogus indemnity claims in which they appeared as attorneys.

The clear inference that the Republican party will not renominate Mayor La Guardia unless it has to, and that it might support a Democratic candidate provided that he is not of the Tammany Hall type, was contained last night in a statement issued by Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican county leader. Mr.
Ethem Toto, former Minister of the Interior, who led the revolt that broke out May 15 at Argyrokastron against the government of King Zog, has been tracked down and shot.

After Ranger was towed about the lower bay for awhile today, Harold S. Vanderbilt lost no time in getting sail on his new Class sloop which he hopes will be selected as the defender of the America's Cup against one of the Endeavours.

Cabinet ministers, diplomats and more than 100 Members of Parliament joined in a memorial service at St. Margaret's, Westminster, today for Viscount Snowden, former Chancellor of the Exchelquer. who died May 15.
Mrs. Stephen S. Wise was reelected president of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress yesterday at the closing session of its annual convention at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Use of tubulin, prepared from animal kidney, in the treatment of nephritic hypertension has restored patients from uremic coma, caused by inactive kidneys, in as little as six hours, Dr. Benjamin Jablons of New York told the convention of State Medical Society today.
Seventeen members of the Charlton Athletic Club of the First Division, English Football League, arrived today on the liner Empress of Australia for a tour of Canada and the United States.

To Marlborough House, where Queen Mary was receiving this morning the Prime Ministers of Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, who had brought her the good wishes of the dominions on her seventieth birthday, came a taxicab containing two outwardly placid and inwardly excited persons of the Queen's own generation.

There was rejoicing in Wall Street yesterday when the action of the governing committee in approving the petition of 670 members of the New York Stock Exchange to close on Saturday and thus permit a three-day holiday over the Memorial Day week-end was made known.

The Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, pastor of Holy Cross Church, will preside and give the commencement address this afternoon at the graduating exercises of the Holy Cross Academy in the school auditorium at 343 West Forty-second Street.
