John Gielgud's eagerly awaited return to the London stage in "He Was Born Gay," Emlyn Williams's play of the legendary Dauphin, Louis XVII of France, came as an anti-climax.

A sentence of five to ten years in State's prison was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Fred B. MacLaren, 48 years old, a research engineer and one-time Pennsylvania State College student, after Judge Wallace had denounced him as ??a man of brains who would rather be a thief."

Mrs. Abby Parsons MacDuffie, educator and a member of the first class of Radcliffe College, died early tonight at her home. She was 76 years old. The wife of Dr. John MacDuffie, she served with him as a principal of the MacDuffie School for Girls from the time of its founding forty-nine years ago until both retired last year.
George Robert McDermott, Emeritus Professor of Structural Design at Cornell University, died at Memorial Hospital today after an illness of several days. His age was 76.

Estate, less than $5,000. To James Barrette, husband, 523 W. 152d St., household effects and specific bequests; Mrs. Frank Matthews, mother, 47 Gitron Road, Sydenham, S: E. 26, London, England, specific stock; 10 varying bequests; Anton Church, executor, 119 W. 71st St., interest in bank account.

Pleading was postponed yesterday until next Tuesday in General Sessions on the grand larceny indictment against Rabbi Zeide M. Schmellner, involving the alleged theft of $20,000, in 1932, from Bernard Rudolf, electrical supplies dealer, at 114 Bowery.

Industrial development has made possible in this country the greatest widespread distribution of wealth the world ever has seen, our banks being custodians of more than $24,000,000,000 of savings owned by holders of more than 40,000,000 accounts, according to Philip A. Benson,

Miss Lavone Dickensheets, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dickensheets of this city, and Hugh Lenox Scott 2d, son of Mrs. Mark Edwin Andrews, also of Houston, and the late Colonel David Hunter Scott of Princeton, N. J., whose engagement was announced recently, will be married on June 2 at the home of the prospective bride's parents.

After a Federal court hearing in the proceeding to reorganize the United Cigar Stores Company of America, Archibald Palmer, counsel for dissenting common stockholders, declared yesterday that he would ask for an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission if the class which he represented did not get better treatment under a proposed plan for recasting the company.

A delegation of 450 firemen, fifty members of the New York Athletic Club and about-500 city and State officials and friends of Captain Michael Francis Loughman. who died on Sunday, attended his funeral service yesterday morning at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street and Broadway.

The resignation of Flint Garrison as director general of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, to become effective July 1, was officially announced yesterday, and reports here indicated he will become affiliated with the Consumer Distribution Corporation as executive vice president.

President Roosevelt disclosed today in a letter to Representative Andrews of Buffalo that "exploratory conversations" were under way with Canadian authorities concerning a new treaty for power and navigation development in the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence area.

The State Mortgage Commission's proposal to create a contingency fund by levying a charge of onetenth of 1 per cent against the face amount of mortgages which it originally took over from forty-seven closed title companies was attacked sharply yesterday in Supreme Court by attorneys for certificate holders.

The United States Embassy today received 880 pounds of beans, lentils, rice and sugar from Valencia. The food came in the nick of time, for the reserves at the Embassy were exhausted and the American refugees were particularly pleased that the Valencia staff and the State Deapartment in Washington at last had permitted a positive move to help them.

Industrial activity in April and the first half of May' was maintained at the relatively high level of recent months, with iron and steel, automobiles, food products and tobacco manufactures featuring the manufacturing list and textiles falling off somewhat, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in its monthly review of business conditions.
Detroit at New York-Bridges vs. Broaca or Ruffing. Cleveland at Philadelphia-Whitehill vs. Caster. St. Louis at Boston-Walkup vs. Marcum. Chicago at Washington-Stratton vs. Weaver.
A slight head cold again kept President Roosevelt confined to the White House today. He did not go to his office or receive any callers, but spent the day working in his study.

Gross assets, $74,293; net, $68,906. To Gertrude J. Howard and Edith M. B. Moncrieffe, nieces, one-half residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $74,293. Duryee, Zunio Amen, attorneys, 20 Exchange PI.

Hinze Ambrosia, Inc., 114 Fifth Avenue, and the General Drug Company, 170 Varick Street, both of New York, have entered into stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue making misleading representations in advertising concerning the therapeutic value of their medicinal preparations, sold in interstate commerce, the commission announced today.

The Broad Realty Company has purchased for investment the threestory brick office and store building at 2,849 Hudson Boulevard, in the Journal Square section of Jersey City, N. J., from the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

James Edward Perry Butts, a member of an old New England family and a retired Geneva (N. Y.) banker and lumber dealer, died on Tuesday in a nursing home at Fairhaven, N. J., after a long illness. His age was 83.

Extension of the barbers' strike in three parts of the city was reported yesterday by the joint board of the Journeymen Barbers International Union. According to union officials, the number of strikers was augmented by 1,100, making the total 7,100 employed in 3,000 shops.

In the face of a formal vote of disapproval by the executive committee of the Central Trades and Labor Council, officers of the Workers Alliance and other sponsoring organizations predicted last night that more than 20,000 WPA employes 'would respond to a call for a one-day work stoppage today.

R. W. Griffith, formerly works manager of the Briggs Stratton Corp., has been appointed vice president in charge of manufacturing. E. V. Oehler, formerly general sales manager, was made vice president in charge of sales. 6 per cent serial gold bond certificates of .the Ellda Corporation, otherwise known as the Hotel Elysee, 56 East Fifty-fourth Street.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies has started an "inventory" of magazine advertising, with twelve of the leading publications coming under the constant scrutiny of six members, including three copy men and three "censors," John Benson, president of the group, revealed yesterday.

The Italian liner Rex, arriving today from Mediterranean ports, has among her passengers Count Francesco Campello, Edoardo Mazzia, Mr. and Mrs. James Powers, Mr. and Mrs. Gilson Black, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Strelsing, William Dausey, Duke and Duchess Averardo Salviati, Dr. William McCallum.
All pretense of a truce in the ranks of organized labor has now been dropped, and open war has been declared by Mr. GREEN'S A. F. of L. against Mr. LEWIS'S C. I. O.
' New York's own high tribunal has just handed down a decision on social security or insecurity, we are not quite sure which.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the Union Electric Light and Power Company of Illinois to issue $14,750,000 of 2 per cent promissory notes and has permitted to become effective a declaration by the East St. Louis Light and Power Company covering an issue of $2,335,000 of promissory notes and the assumption by it of the notes issued by Union Electric Light and Power.

Dr. Karl Kramar, Premier of the First Czech Government, died today at the age of 76. Candidate for Presidency Dr. Kramar headed a political party which held that the Germans must be enemies of the Czech republic and that they could be controlled only by a strong hand.
Simple undenominational funeral services of prayer, Bible reading and organ music were held today for John D. Rockefeller in the flower-banked reception hall of his home at Pocantico Hills.
The New York Chapter, American Institute of Banking, will graduate a class of 204 students tonight at its commencement exercises in the Brick Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. of Bergen County indicated yesterday that he would wait until next week before calling the grand jury into special session to hear what Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine has to say about the investigation into the murder of Norman Redwood, leader of a New York sandhogs' union.

H.. Gordon Calder, vice president and treasurer of the Scranton Spring Brook Water Service Company, Chester Water Service Company, Pittsburgh Suburban Water Service Company and other subsidiaries of the Federal Water Service Corporation,

Retailers do 67.8 per cent of their business for cash or on the C. O. D. basis, 21.3 per cent on open account and 10.9 per cent on the installment basis, according to another section of the 1935 business census made available today by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census.

A decision to continue the work of the board of standards of the Toilet Goods Association for another year was reached yesterday morning at a closed session of the second annual convention of the organization being held at the Hotel Biltmore.
Vilhjalmur Stefansson, explorer, will be the speaker tonight at the commencement exercises of the Calhoun School, to be held in the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Grand Concourse (11-3159), n e cor Field PI.. 196x84; Cecilia A. Doran, referee, to Henry Lichtig, trustee, 760 Grand Concourse. Loring PI (11-3225), e s, 95 ft s of Fordham Rd. 75x129; Hasad Realty Corp to Edison Estates, Inc. 1,501 Bway; mtg $144,000.

Each of the following Ordnance Department Reserve officers, is ordered to active duty, June 20, at Raritan Arsenal, Metuchen, N. J.. for training: 2d Lt. William M. Smith Jr., 119 East Maple Ave., Bound Brook, N. J. 2d Lt. John G. Sweetman, 271 Warburton Ave., Hawthorne, N. J.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 24: CAPTAINS Dowling, O. C., Dover, N. J., when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y., to home, relieved from all active duty.

Professor Malcolm P. McNair, marketing authority, defended "the price differential" enforced by Standard Brands, Inc. in the sale of baker's yeast to various classes of purchasers, in testifying yesterday at the hearing conducted by the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway.

Stockholders of the Skenandoa Rayon Corporation approved yesterday a plan to reclassify the outstanding preferred stock, eliminate arrears thereon and change the common stock from no par value to $5 par value.

Canadian wheat in store on May 21 was 60,688,822 bushels, a decrease of 3,461,416 in the week and 113,871,855 less than at the corresponding date in 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
Nineteen one and two family homes in Brooklyn and Queens have been sold by the Easy-to-Own Homes Organization. In Brooklyn the house at 1,550 East Twenty-ninth Street was sold
The White Sox pounced on a Senators' relief hurler in the closing inning today to snare a 6-to-5 victory.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed upon the eligible list of names of persons licensed for service in day technical high schools, as teacher of machine shop practice, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license, under date of May 24:
SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-Against RIALTO HOSIERY UNDERWEAR CORP., 349 Broadway-By H. Eckstein Sons, for about $200; Ganis Bros., about $360; M. Zwaifler Co., Inc., about $280.
The Rev. Dr. Adolf William Meyer, Lutheran minister, educator and writer, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 38 Alexander Avenue, Yonkers. He was 76 years old.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, former woriien's national champion, easily disposed of Mrs. Norman Lack of Wilmington, 6 and 4, to enter the semi-finals of the Philadelphia district golf championships today.

The development of younger talent in the theatre and the encouragement of potential audiences outside New York, both present and the future, were the two necessities of the theatre's successful continuance most frequently stressed at yesterday's session of the first national convention of the American Theatre Council, meeting at the Hotel Astor.

House leaders mapped plans today to quell the revolt which resulted yesterday in the earmarking of $505,000,000 of the $1,500,000,000 Relief Bill for so-called pork barrel projects in defiance of administration wishes.

Lord Feversham's Silversol won the Yorkshire Handicap today. William Woodward's Omaha, United States 3-year-old champion of 1935, failed to start because of the condition of the track, made extremely heavy by an all-day rain.

Movements of vessels follow: At La Haina: Montgomery, Quail, Ramsay Tanger, May 25. Cassin, at Guantanamo, May 26. Claxton, Norfolk Yard to sea, May 26. Fairfax, Norfolk Yard to Chesapeake Bay area, May 26.
Alexander Afinogenoff, Soviet playwright, whose wife is an American, has been expelled from the Communist party by the party committee of the Moscow Art Theatre, of which he formerly was a member.

Mrs. Mary Ella Worden, former organist at the Disciples of Christ Church in Auburn, N. Y., of which she was a member for seventy years, died here last night at the home.of her daughter, Mrs. Ada E. Kelland.
A 7-year-old schooboy was bitten badly in the right forearm by a Sun bear in an open-air cage in the Central Park Zoo yesterday.

Elizabeth St. 118, 25.6x99.26; William H. Hickin, referee, to Citizens Savings Bank, foreclosure ($11). Essex St. 11. w s, 25x87.6; Mary Levison et al. to Everal Realty Corp, 11 Essex St; mgt $18,000 (50c).

The twelve swimming pools which the Department of Parks operates in the five boroughs will be opened for the season next Saturday at 10 A. M. Until June 26 the pools will stay open until 6 P. M. and after that date they will close daily at 10 P. M.

Miss Frances Eagles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Penn Moore Eagles of this city, was married this evening to Edwin Winter Eastman, son of Mrs. Edwin G. Eastman of Exeter, N. H., and the late Mr. Eastman.

A quiet little rebellion is brewing in Filipino official circles against High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt's "arbitrary" assumption of the ranking official position in the Philippines through his precedence formula laid down to foreign consuls regarding formal toasts.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for numerous alterations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The activity also consisted of heavy filings in Queens, where builders plan to erect numerous small dwellings and several large apartment houses.
The WPA Federal Music Project will open its fourth annual Summer program of outdoor dance and concert music Monday evening, June 7. From that date,

A bill providing that all heads of companies, both foreign and national, established in Cuba must be Cuban citizens has been reported favorably out of committee to the House of Representatives and is expected to come up for discussion in the near future.

At 4:50 o'clock this afternoon the supply airplane, piloted by Anatoly Alexieff, arrived at this -Soviet polar station. He made an artistic landing on the natural airdrome and taxied into alignment with the planes of Mikhail Vodopyanoff and Vassily Molokoff.

Turpentine firm, 36c; sales, 153 barrels; receipts, 40?? barrels; shipments, 218 barrels; stock, 26,205 barrels. Resin firm sales. 359: receipts, 1,479; shipments, 75; stock. 44,827. Quote: B, $7.25; D, $7.35; E, $7.80; F to N, $8.17 1/2; WG, $8.25; WW, X, $9.10.

Enactment of President Roosevelt's program for executive reorganization at this session of Congress was thrown further into doubt today after the special joint Congressional committee, set up to handle the matter, had broken up permanently over a question of procedure.

The Railway Equipment and Airbrake Union, local affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, asked the Westinghouse Airbrake Company today to recognize the union as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for its 7,200 employes. Vice President O. W.

George F. Baker, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of New York, underwent an emergency operation for peritonitis on Wednesday on board his yacht Viking, cruising in the South Seas, according to a brief announcement given out yesterday at the bank.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house a plot 96 by 125 feet at the northwest corner of 235th Street and Webster Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by F. J. S. Builders, Inc. The proposed structure will cost $200,000, according to Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers in the sale.

G. Russell Clark has been pointed assistant manager of the New York Clearing House, it was announced yesterday by William S. Gray Jr., president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, who is chairman of the Clearing House committee.

Mexico's utilities, transport and factories were paralyzed at midnight tonight 2 A. M. Friday in New York] when 17,000 oil workers in the $500,000,000 foreign petroleum industry walked out in a nationwide strike for higher wages and better working conditions.

This sleepy - looking provincial city, which made its mark in history through the unsuccessful peace treaty between Germany and Russia concluded within its walls, is again in the news-this time as a result of the violent outbreak that terrorized its predominantly Jewish population on May 13.

The Russell Sage Foundation made public yesterday a report on "Physicians and Medical Care," which "assembles the main facts about the growth and present status of the medical profession and considers recent proposals for bringing medical care more adequately to all the people."

The following Coast Guard orders for the week ended May 26 were announced today: Price, District Commander J. A., orders of May 18 canceled. Hirshfield, Lt. Comdr. J. A., Coast Guard Academy, to Headquarters, report not later than Sept. 15 for resident course in law at George Washington University.
AT BANK OF ENGLAND Due to [pound]0 Decrease in irculation---eserve Ratio
John D. Rockefeller was buried today between the graves of his wife and his mother after a short ceremony in Lake View Cemetery.

No two countries have been so exposed to National Socialist influence as Belgium and the Netherlands. Both have lately asserted their intention to pursue an independent line in foreign affairs, Holland by reaffirming the non-alliance policy she has consistently pursued, Belgium by formally withdrawing from her obligation to defend England and France against aggression.
Joseph M. Schenck asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine a $124,641 deficiency assessed on his 1935 gift taxes by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

An increase of about $700,000 in deposits with the Bank of Canada was shown in the weekly statement of the bank issued today. The total was $214,757,825 on May 26, compared with $214,097,071 on May 19.

The American film industry is threatening to boycott the international film exhibition in Venice this Summer as a result of renewed tenseness in the relations between American producers and the Italian authorities.

Miss Florence Marjory Knight, daughter of Mrs. Robert Seabury Corbett of East Orange, was married to Kenneth Edmund Pinnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pinnell, also of East Orange, this morning at the Corbett home.

Four more games were staged by Meadow Brook members preparing for the club's polo championships today, three of them on the home grounds and one at Mitchel Field. The famous stretch of Cochran Field was opened to play, with Tommy Hitchcock leading a White team in action against a Red side that had Mike Phipps as the highest-rated player on it.

'Despite a seasonal decline from the previous week, bank clearings of the twenty-two principal cities in the United States in the week ended on Wednesday rose 12 per cent above the total in the corresponding period a year ago.

The Polish press expressed national resentment today over an attack on a Polish newspaper correspondent and two companions in Soviet Russia. An apology has been received from the Soviet Foreign Office.

The Burealu a Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 25: COMMANDERS Ashe, G. B., Washington, D. C., to command Destroyer Division 6. Kenworthy, J. L., Jr., the Quincy, to Naval Air Station, Lakehurst, N.. J., as execun tive officer.

An exhaustive analytical survey of the retail- installment selling trend will be a feature of the midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to be held at the Palmer House, Chicago, from June 21 to 24, it. was announced yesterday by W. S. Martens, credit manager of Carson, Pirie, Scott Co., and chairman of the credit management division of the association.

By a vote of 563 to 308, which later was made unanimous, the Rev. Dr. William Hiram Foulkes, pastor of the old First Presbyterian Church of Newark, N. J., was today elected Moderator of the 149th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. During the year's term he will also be chairman of the Presbyterian General Council.

Leading honors for the year :at the Naval Academy went today to midshipmen from New York State, Jack Arthur Obermeyer of New York City being selected to graduate at the head of his class of 325, while the two leading companies in the color competition were commanded by midshipmen from Brooklyn and Larhmont.
The Ford Motor Company issued a statement tonight, blaming the Rouge plant riot of yesterday on newspapers and the United Automobile Workers of America.
Dr. and Mrs. Austin Flint have come from Venice, Fla., to the Ambassador. Mrs. Newton C. Boykin of Pittsburgh has arrived at the SavoyPlaza from Camden, S. C.

Carl Van Doren, literary critic, will be the commencement speaker such this afternoon at the graduation exercises of the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, to be held me the Lincoln few School auditorium.

A battle between the New York Curb Exchange and the over-the-counter interests was forecast today as the Securities and Exchange Commission postponed from June 1 until June 15 a public hearing on applications by the Curb for the unlisted trading privileges in twenty-two bond and debenture issues which now are traded only over the counter.
Here's how the eight survivors in the Professional Golfers Association championship won their 36-hole third-round matches today, the winner being named first in each case:

Officials of Union County, N. J., yesterday awarded to the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark a new issue of $1,246,000 of general improvement bonds, dated June 1, 1937, and maturing on June 1, 1938 to 1965, on a bid of 100.17 for 2.70s.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-Against VICTOR D. ORLOVE, doing business as Victor Food Products Co., 90 E. 149th St.-By Coast Flour Corp., for $195; The Red Wing Flour Co., $337; George Dudman Co., $163. Petitions Filed-By LUIGI GAROFALO, mason (unemployed), 81 Myrtle Blvd., Larchmont-Liabilities $1,382, no assets. SALVATORE GAROFALO, mason (unemployed), 12 Woodland Ave., Larchmont-Liabilities $985. no assets.
Harry Garfinkel, women's underwear manufacturer, died yesterday afternoon in Mount Sinai Hospital, Fifth Avenue and 100th Street, after an operation. He was 44 years old and lived at 885 Park Avenue.

Running over an oval made sloppy by the morning rains, Cary Grayson's Ocean Roll held off the challenge of D. J. Sullivan's Trina to win the Aleppo Temple Handicap, one-mile feature of today's Suffolk Downs Shriners' program. The gelding scored by a neck and paid $6 for $2 in the mutuels. Third, four lengths back, was Mrs. F. Lanbebartel's Prince Sador, who had a length margin on Mrs. T. Marshall's Palan.

Since all good things must come to an end, the Yankees yesterday reluctantly parted with their winning streak and sent a crowd of 10,000 persons away from the Stadium disappointed as they dropped a 5-4 decision to the Tigers after a thirteen-inning struggle.

President ROOSEVELT has chosen a favorable moment in the relations of the American States to submit to the Senate, and urge prompt ratification of, eight treaties and conventions signed at the Buenos Aires Conference last December by the twenty-one American republics.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

A resolution requesting the Federal Trade Commission not to issue the fair trade practice rules for the perfume, toilet goods and cosmetics industry "until after a clarification of. the provisions of the RobinsonPatman Anti-Price Discrimination Act" was unanimously adopted yesterday at the closing session of the second annual convention of the Toilet Goods Association in the Hotel Biltmore. Herman L. Brooks, again elected president of the organization, resided.

The Swedish - American liner Kungsholm, returning to New York with 500 "coronation" passengers, collided late yesterday afternoon with the tanker A. C. Bedford, as the two ships manoeuvred in a dense fog off Nantucket Light Vessel.

The House of Representatives has been in revolt this week against the Administration's wishes in the matter of the Relief Bill. The President had asked that $1,500,000,000 be allotted to WPA in a lump sum for the support. of " work-relief" during the next fiscal year.
Gladys MacKnight and her former admirer, Donald Wightman, were found guilty of murder in the second degree tonight by a jury which deliberated three hours and two minutes.
The tolowmng Marine Corps changes for the week ended May 27 were announced today: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Stephenson, L. B., to duty as commanding officer, Marine Barracks, Navy Yard, Washinoton. D. C.

John Edmund Gibbs, general agent for Northern New Jersey of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company for the last four years, died today of heart disease at his home on Windermere Terrace here. Mr. Gibbs was born in Cranford, N. J., thirty-seven years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By what stretch of reason can the constitutional power to "regulate commerce among the several States" be held to confer on the Federal Government quasi-proprietary rights in the conduct of private enterprises with respect to acts not constituting interstate commerce? In other words, what constitutional authority is there for the proposed Federal law fixing hours and wages generally in private industry?

Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden captured the low gross award in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Scarsdale Golf Club today. She scored 41, 48-89, thirteen strokes over women's par.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution sold to the Fairmont Holding Corporation the five-story elevator apartment house at 2 Amsterdam Place, southeast corner of South Fulton Avenue, Mount Ver-y non, N. Y. The Joseph Milner Company was the broker.

Fearing that shipbuilders may submit "excessive" bids for the construction of the first new battleships authorized by President Roosevelt in accordance with law, and also that the bids may be for nearly equal amounts, the administration has decided, in the event that this situation develops, to discard all the bids and construct both of the authorized new battleships in navy yards.

Berta May Crawford, canadian-born opera singer, died at her home here yesterday. She returned here from Warsaw about two years ago, and her last public performance was at the Promenade at Toronto University arena two years ago.

At this time of the season, when harried theatrical producers institute economies in operating expenses, along comes Marc Connelly with tidings of an increase in salary affecting more than half of his acting personnel in "Having Wonderful Time."
Twelve girls will receive diplomas this morning at the twenty-first annual commencement exercises of the Lenox School, 52 East Seventyeighth Street.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the current series of $50,000,000 weekly in Treasury bills for cash would be concluded with the issue dated June 2. This will bring cash borrowing through bills to $350,000,000 in seven weeks.

Retailing is equipped, because of its rapid development in recent years, to accept the responsibility it faces in distributing to the public the products of an incredibly efficient manufacturing system, Kenneth Collins, executive vice president of Gimbel Brothers, said last night at the annual banquet of the New York Chapter of the National Institute of Credit.

Judging of the dachshunde dog classes today will raise the curtain on the eleventh annual Morris and Essex Kennel Club all-breed show, the world's largest outdoor dog exhibition, that will attract thousands of canine lovers to the Giralda Farms in Madison, N. J., tomorrow.

As "the first white-collar union to affiliate with the C. I. O.," the National Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians last night received a charter from the Lewis organization at a ceremony at the Manhattan Industrial High School, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-second Street.

Arthur F. Lynch and Gerald Shattuck, both of Winged Foot, turned in a 69, two under par, to lead the field in the qualifying round of the best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.
Max Baer, California heavyweight, began his English "comeback" tonight with a technical knockout victory over Ben Foord, former British Empire champion from South Africa.

Miss Sarah Diodati Gardiner of 3 East Eighty-second Street and Sagtikos Manor, Bay Shore, L. I., and a member of the Gardiner family of Gardiner's Island, was revealed today as the purchaser of the historic island, thereby halting a foreclosure sale which was scheduled for June 10.
The Westminster Choir School of Princeton will hold its eighth annual commencement exercises tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock in the school chapel.

Miss Loretta Darling Barto, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William T. Barto of West Hartford, will be married to George Laurence Blauvelt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Blauvelt of White Plains, N. Y., June 19 in the West Hartford Congregational Church. The Rev.

Miss Marjorie McPherson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott McPherson of 1,192 Park Avenue, has completed plans for her marriage to Braman B. Adams 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. c. Robert Adams of Pelham Heights.
Almost at the eleventh hour Australia's hopes of victory over the United States in the Davis Cup tie starting tomorrow at Forest Hills have suffered an unfortunate setback.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo of Spain submitted to the Council of the League of Nations today a White Book entitled, "Italian Aggression." composed of 101 facsimiles of all kinds of documents said to have been selected from some of the 2,000 allegedly captured from Italians at Guadalajara.

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, Curtis Cup team member, today eliminated Mrs. Betty Pietsch Dietrich of Gedney Farm, defending champion, in the quarter-finals of the women's metropolitan golf championship, 3 and 1.

Rallying for five runs in the fifth inning, the Indians made a clean sweep of a three-game series with the Athletics by winning the final contest today, 8 to 7. Rain halted the contest for forty minutes in the Athletics' turn at bat in the eighth inning.

Following the lead of the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges, many of the principal security and commodity markets in the country will be closed tomorrow and observe a three-day holiday over the Memorial Day week-end.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has appointed George S. Parlin to be Assistant Regional Administrator of the New York regional office and John H. Kelley to be chief attorney of the New York office succeeding William Prager, who resigned to enter private practice.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today extended the due dates of Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to the Erie Railroad aggregating $16,200,000, staggering the dates of payment with most of the loans maturing on June 1, 1942.

The Grand Opera Artists Association has elected Giuseppe Interrante president, it was announced yesterday. Other officers elected were Nino Ruisi, Delfina Calzolari, Lavinia Darv, Lee Sherman and Lloyd Harris, vice presidents; Armand Marbiny, secretary; Stella Marketti, secretary of advancement, and Silvio Paglia, treasurer.
After nineteen years at. 512 Fifth Avenue, A. Sulka Co., shirtmakers and haberdashers, have leased for a long term the street store and two floors in 661 Fifth Avenue from Henry Phipps Estates.
William Green warned the Progressive Miners of America tonight that they would have to keep out of United Mine Workers' territory if chartered by the American Federation of Labor.
Stockholders of the Hartman Tobacco Company have approved the plan of recapitalization, involving the elimination of the preferred dividend arrears aggregating $682,825, it was announced yesterday.

A veteran golfer, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, six times national champion, and youthful 19-year-old Helen Sigel, taking part in her second year of competition, meet tomorrow for the Philadelphia district women's golf title.

Relieved from its arduous toils by a series of recesses, the Legislature of New Jersey is now about to take and give to the people of the State a long period of rest. In a belated fit of industry Wednesday the Senate passed a fat batch of bills. Having cleared its calendar and conscience it took a day off Thursday.

Prediction of a stiffening in mortgage interest rates was made by Norman R. Lemcke, head of the New York mortgage loan department of the Prudential Insurance Company, in a speech yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Real Estate Club of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies. The meeting was held in the Hotel Commodore.

A new technique for detecting nerve deafness, affecting more than 5,000,000 persons in this country alone, was described today at the seventieth annual meeting of the American Otological Society. The two-day convention is being held at the Lido Beach Country Club, with many of the nation's foremost authorities on ear, brain and nervous disorders attending.

A huge column of smoke swirled upward from the center of Orduna today as General Emilio Mola's Insurgent battalions hammered at the "back door" of beleaguered Bilbao in the upper valley of the Nervion River.
The court struggle for the millions of the late Colonel Edward H. R. Green produced testimony today that he paid no tax to any State on a $20,000,000 income between 1917 and 1929.
Two destroyers, the Blue and the Helm, were christened today in the first twin launching in the history of the local navy yard.

Darryl Zanuck, the eminent historian of Twentieth Century-Fox, has been indulging in his favorite chantey again-"backward, turn backward, 0 Time in thy flight"and has magic-earpeted Robert Taylor and Barbara Stanwyck into the watch-fob and leg-of-muttonsleeve decade commonly identified as "the turn o' the century."

The Federal Theatre Project has received permission from Eugene O'Neill- to reproduce such plays of his as the project wishes, and plans are now going forward which will involve a good many, say in September or October.
Captain Christopher Kemmler, commander of Troop K of the State Police, died late tonight of a thrombosis at his home on Gramatan Road here. His age was 40.

The New York Railroad Club will hold its annual outing, including golf, field sports and dinner, at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y., on June 8, Charles A. Gill, president of the club, has announced. More than 1,000 persons are expected to attend, according to Samuel F. Pryor Jr., general chairman of the committee on arrangements.

All eager for their American debut, scheduled for Sunday afternoon at the Polo Grounds, seventeen members of the Charlton Athletic Club of London, England, accompanied by five officers, arrived here yesterday from Quebec.

Gerard B. Lambert's Class J sloop Yankee, which-was hauled out last Monday for a cleaning and polishing, was launched again at high water tonight. Mr. Lambert, who had just returned from a visit to Princeton, N. J., saw his racer slip into the water.

At the close of today's session of the Parker conspiracy trial, sixty-seven leading citizens of Burlington County had sworn to the good reputations of Ellis H. Parker Sr. and his son, Ellis Jr., who are accused by the Federal Government of plotting the kidnapping and torture of Paul H. Wendel.

Members of two striking locals of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America voted overwhelmingly today to accept terms settling the four-week strike at the plants of the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company and return to work on Tuesday.

By I. LINCOLN SEIDE Varick St, 26-8, 6-story brick tenement and stores, 50x59.11; Lena D. Wolff against Ben~amln Albert; due, $52,698, taxes, , $1,910; .to plaintiff for $5,000. By WALTER M. JACOBSON Bleecker St, .192, 6-story brick tenement and stores, 25x98; Mortgage Commission of New York against Serra Realty Corp, due, 526,500, taxes, , $1,800; to plaintiff for S1.000..

During the week ended May 26 member banks reserve balances increased $26,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $9,000,000 in Treasury cash, other than inactive gold, and $37,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, offset in part by a decrease of $8,000,000 in reserve bank credit and an increase of $11,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Commencement exercises for the Riverside School, 316 West 104th Street, were held last night at the Hotel Plaza. Dr. Margaret Elizabeth Wells, director of the, school, presented the diplomas and certificates. Members of the graduating class gave an entertainment entitled "The Wheel of Life," Miss Marjorie Freedman was valedictorian.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, denied yesterday the charges that he sold the broadcasting rights for an intercollegiate track meet at Randalls Island today and tomorrow to the exclusion of WNYC, the municipal radio station, and in doing so violated his written pledge and moral obligation.

Convinced that fishing and hunting in this State is at a low ebb and that something must be done about it, Thomas E. Brady, president of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, urges a drastic change in the Conservation Department.

Commencement exercises Lenox School, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, 11 A. M. Speakers: Mrs. Jessica Garretson Cosgrave, Olivia Green. Forty-eighth annual commencement Spence School, 22 East Ninety-first Street, 11 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. George A. Buttrick, the Rev. H. Adye, Dorothy Brockway.
The Phillies produced a fourteen-hit attack in scoring an 11-to-2 triumph over the Cubs at Wrigley Field today. The victory gave the visitors the series, two games to one.

Jacques Doriot, leader of the Rightist French Popular party, and a former Communist leader, who was ousted yesterday as Mayor of Saint Denis by the government of Premier Leon Blum, has "accepted battle" today.
Superior Judge John C. Lewe today heard a divorce suit brought by Mrs. Janet Brodsky Bashein, daughter of Judge Louis B. Brodsky of New York, against her husband, Dr. Hyman Bashein, New York surgeon.

Taking full advantage of the three-day Memorial Day week-end and the prevailing Summer weather, thousands of New Yorkers will start an exodus from the city today to spend a short vacation in various sections of the country.
Movements ao vessels follow: At Naval Operating base, Norfolk: Olaxton, Fairfax, May 26. At Pearl Harbor: Quail, Tanager, May 271 Oglala. At San Francisco: Relief, May 21; Thrushd May 26.

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended March 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $10,424,087, as compared with a net of $8,526,797 in the twelve months ended March 31, 1936, an increase of $1,897,290.

In the presence of Governor Hoffman, other State and municipal officials of New Jersey, William S. Knudsen, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the Board of the General Motors Corporation, dedicated yesterday the new assembly plant at Linden, N. J., which marks an important step in the decentralization of the company's automobile manufacturing business.
The Federal wholesale liquor dealer's permit of Connecticut Distributors, Inc., of Bridgeport, Conn., today was ordered suspended for seven

The Chiefs handed the league-leading Bears a 6-to-1 defeat in the opener of a five-game series before 3,000 fans tonight. Jake Mooty scattered six Newark blows, while the Syracusans hopped on Rookie Southpaw Marius Russo for four hits and three runs in the sixth to clinch the victory.

Pensioned On their own applications: PATROLMEN-John F. J. Hofmann, 83d Pct., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 26, 1911. John J. Quigley, 71st Pet., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 3, 1905. Harry B. Schopper, 34th Pct.. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 3, 1908.

The Hamburg-American liner New York, arriving today from Hamburg, Bremen and Channel ports, will bring among her passengers G. Lipscomb, Count Helmuth von Moltke, Max Waldhausen, Paul Isenberg, Mrs. Claire Arnold, Colonel and Mrs. John G. Churton, Mrs. Hermine Jordon, Mrs. James P. Kinard Jr., Mrs. Irmgard Post and Mrs. Herta Meyer.
New York Stock Exchange membership of Lawrence Turnure has been transferred to Warner J. Banes of Wrenn Brother Co.

The German Government is reported by a trustworthy authority to have received from the Vatican a note on Cardinal Mundelein's Chicago address which is anything but an apology. The German Ambassador to the Vatican asked for an official explanation.

Gottfried Hansen, Arctic explorer and one-time colleague of Roald Amundsen, died at his home today. His age was 61. He had carried out extensive explorations in Greenland and recently had been appointed an Admiral.

Silver mugs and spoons were given yesterday afternoon to eight of ninety-six babies entered in a health contest at St. Vincent's Hospital. The ceremonies were held in the nurses' residence, 150 West Twelfth Street.
A mass flight by twelve military airplanes, mostly piloted by student fliers ended in disaster today.

The towering two-mile span across the Golden Gate opened today with a rush of pedestrians across its neck. Hailed as an achievement of the "impossible," the $35,000,000 structure began its useful existence by bearing a milling army of visitors and San Franciscans, all in fiesta mood.
Nowadays a person has to read an item like the following twice in order to convince himself that he is not mistaken:
United Engineering and Foundry Company announced yesterday that it had received substantial new orders for rolling mill machinery from foreign steel companies, mainly in Canada and Japan.
A new plan for reorganization of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company has been offered to the liquidator by Harrison Co., investment dealers, of Toronto.

ACCORDING to men on the field or along the track, it will be either Pitt or Columbia for the team title in the I. C. 4-A track and field championships that start at Randalls Island today. Pitt never has won the title. Columbia won it away back in 1879.

The eighteen-family brick apartment building, with two stores, at 730-2 Broadway, West New York, N. J., has been sold by the Weehawken Trust Company to the A. L. Improvement Company. The building stands on a plot 40 by 100 feet, and was sold subject to a mortgage of $32,000.

Three Americans today were among the last eight survivors in the British amateur golf championship. Here is the order of matches in the sixth round tomorrow: Dick Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., meets Count Alaric Bendern, who is an old friend, Alaric De Forest, under a new name which makes him appear as a crusading knight.

A team of Italian amateur boxers, selected from various sections of the Peninsula, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Rex of the Italian Line. The warriors, twelve in number, will oppose a Golden Glove aggregation in a tournament sponsored by The Daily News A. A. at the Yankee Stadium on June 9.

Contracts for engineering construction awarded during the week ended yesterday again showed an increased volume over last year's figures, according to The Engineering News-Record. They totaled $57,616,000, which was 62 per cent greater than the 1936 figure of $35,466,000.

Governor Blanton Winship, flying to Washington today, said before his departure that he would return. This is considered here as discounting the reported unbridgeable difference between Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, and the Governor over the "verdict" of the American Civil Liberties Union report that placed the responsibility for the Palm Sunday killings at Ponce on the Governor as commander-in-chief of the insular police.

It is possible to welcome the reassertion by Congress of independence of the Executive's domination, and yet not find that principle wholesomely expressed by the House's recent performances with the Relief Bill. It is also possible to admit the influence of local politics in relief, and favor steps to eradicate it, without believing that Congressional earmarking of the funds presents a desirable alternative.

This statement of its position on present labor troubles in its plant was issued by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company to its employes, together with a letter signed by Frank Purnell, the president:

A further attack on the proposed fees of the State Mortgage Commission for administering defaulted mortgage - certificate issues was made yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler by attorneys for certificate holders.

Although visitors were still prohibited from seeing him yesterday, Mickey Cochrane was reported to be showing improvement at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, where he is suffering from a fractured skull, a result of being struck by a pitched ball in the Tiger-Yankee game Tuesday.

The Board of Higher Education in selecting an executive head of the City College in Queens has recognized the eminent fitness of Dr. PAUL KLAPPER for the organization of a new institution. He is, to begin with, a scholar of highest authority in educational theory and practice, of philosophical temperament and of administrative experience in a college of like type with that of which he is now to be the head.
Mrs. Barbara Barstow Hubbell received a divorce today from Roswell E. Hubbell of New York City. The decree, uncontested, was granted on grounds of cruelty.
The Bees shaded the Cardinals, 8 to 7, in a slugfest today as they continued creeping toward the top of the lower division.

Norman Thomas, American Socialist leader, visited the Spanish war front today and told government soldiers their "fight against fascism is not only for the interests of Spain but for those of the United States and the whole world."

Miss Mary Mershon Kessler, the daughter of Mrs. Percy M. Kessler of Washington and the late Colonel Kessler, was married tonight in the chapel of Fort Myer to First'Lieutenant Laurence Hilliard Brownlee, U. S. A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Bedell Brownlee of Woodmere, L. I.

The Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation of Buffalo has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $17,029,000 of general and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series C, due on June 1, 1967, and $7,000,000 of serial debentures, proceeds from which will be used in refinancing and in an expansion program.
Charles Schwartz, Mrs. Ida Miller, Mrs. Rhea Slttenfield, in the Beresford, 81it St and Central Park West: through Real Extate Bureau of the State Banking Departrqent.

Abraham C. Isaacson, an attorney, who lives at 718 East Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn, is in no way connected with the alleged liability insurance frauds now being investigated by United States Attorney Lamar Hardy, in which an Abraham Isaacson of 439 East Fiftythird Street, Brooklyn, is now under arrest.

Dr. Paul Klapper, president-elect of Queens College, promised yesterday that under his administration the college would "dedicate itself to safeguarding democratic government in America." This statement was a reply to Borough President George U. Harvey. Dr. Klapper, who is dean of the School of Education of City College. said:

Passage at this session of the evernormal granary plan, designed "to safeguard the nation's food supply and to protect farm income;" was urged by Secretary Wallace today before the House Agriculture Committee, which is considering a bill to carry out the plan.

A basic agreement for settlement of the barbers' strike in the Grand Central and Times Square areas was reached yesterday between the Journeymen Barbers International Union and the Broadway Master Barbers Association.

The financial and other material arrangements prevailing in the stories various "heavens" and "extension heavens" operated as part of Father Divine's Peace Mission movement may get an early airing in court, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook indicated yesterday.

A program to alter the status of church and industry in government-held Spain is under serious consideration by the reorganized MadridValencia regime, informed sources said tonight. This program would:
Anglo-Japanese economic cooperation has taken positive form in North China with the organization of the North China Mining Company to exploit the gold resources of Japanesecontrolled East Hopei.

An agreement providing for a 10 per cent wage increase, a basic forty-eight-hour week, a minimum wage of $25, vacations with pay and the closed shop was signed last night between Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate.

A motion for approval of a plan of reorganization for the United Cigar Stores Company of America was made yesterday by Boykin C Wright, counsel for the reorganization committee that is sponsoring the proposal under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act. Hearings with this end in view will begin this afternoon.

Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 93.8, the highest point since the week ended Aug. 2, 1930. It was 92.0 for the previous week, and 80.7 for the week ended May 23, 1936.

Dr. John L. Lapp, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, ruled today that the board had jurisdiction in the LewistonAuburn strike and ordered hearings involving twelve shoe factories to proceed.
More than 10.000 WPA workers left their posts yesterday in a oneday demonstration against proposed reductions in the Federal relief appropriation for the 1938 fiscal year.

Despite the barbed-wire frontiers and border fortifications, regardless of differing political philosophies and antagonistic national aspirations, the products of international armaments salesmen are still being offered throughout Europe to any country that will pay in cash or kind.

A plea for support of a drive by the Woman's Christian Temperance Union for $1,000,000 to "educate the public in the dangers of alcohol" was made last night by Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, national vice president of the organization, at the annual convention of the New York County wing of the W. C. T. U. The convention was held in the Tremont Methodist Episcopal Church, 178th Street and Washington Avenue, the Bronx.

The Department of Commerce board of inquiry investigating the Hindenburg disaster closed its work here today with a long conference with its technical advisers and members of the German investigation commission. The session was held behind closed doors.
Allen L. Lindley, chairman of the business conduct committee of the New York Stock Exchange, has joined the firm of Shields Co. as a limited partner.

The American Iron and Steel Institute, meeting in an atmosphere of tension caused by the Midwest strike against three of its most powerful independent members, elected as president yesterday the head of one of the plants affected and applauded the assertion of Eugene G. Grace, its retiring president, that "outside" influences were causing labor unrest that was retarding recovery.

More than 100 persons are believed to have been killed and 300 homes were crushed to bits when 3,000,000 tons of gold mine tailings, impelled by torrential rains, crashed down upon the sleeping town of Tlalpujahua in the State of Michoacan at 5 A. M. today.

More than $781,000 of unexpended balances of appropriations made by the city for purchase of real estate needed in connection with subway work came back to the city yesterday in the form of a refund by the Board of Transportation to the Board of Estimate.

The Pan American Airway flying boat Bermuda Clipper landed here tonight on the return trip from Bermuda, after its survey flight Tuesday. Captain.Harold E. Gray and his crew of seven men reported low visibility, rain squalls and head winds between Bermuda and Baltimore.

Mrs. Gertrude Starbuck, 28-year-old wife of Charles Starbuck, an engineer employed by the Western Electric Company in New York City, died this morning of a bullet wound in the right temple as she was being rushed to Nyack Hospital from her home on South Mountain Road on the outskirts of this village.

Successful operation of the reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Canada was an important factor in a marked increase in trade between the two countries last year, it was declared today in a report by a committee representing the State, Commerce and Agriculture Departments and the Tariff Commission.

April sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district averaged about 14 per cent higher than in the corresponding period in 1936, a smaller increase than in the previous two months, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent here.

Victor M. Maurtua, Peruvian Ambassador to Brazil, died suddenly last night of a heart stroke aboard the Steamship Northern Prince on the way to Rio de Janeiro from Washington, where he was the Peruvian delegate to the jurisprudence congress. He long resided in Rio de Janeiro, representing Peru. His age was 71.

The League for Political Education announced yesterday the adoption of a resolution by its board of trustees and directors expressing appreciation of the work of Robert Erskine Ely, who resigned as director of the league on April 30.

A drive for improvements along Sixth Avenue to keep pace with the anticipated business gains there in view of the prospective demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated structure will be inaugurated by the Sixth Avenue- Association on June 9, V. Clement Jenkins, president, announced yesterday.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 26: MAJOR GENERAL Sunderland, A. H., Chief of Coast Artillery, 2 days' leave, May 30.

The high domestic bidder on twentyeight obsolete steel cargo vessels, four of which are laid up at Staten Island, was the Hoyne Industrial Salvage Company of Chicago, offering $350,050, the Maritime Commission announced after opening bids of ten concerns at noon.

Democratic members of the Essex County delegation in the Assembly won their fight today for passage of the bill backed by Leo J. Carlin, a Newark union leader, creating in the State Labor Department a commission to function similarly to the National Labor Relations Board under the Wagner act.

Governor Martin L. Davey intervened today in the strike affecting 75,000 to 80,000 steel workers by asking officials of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Steel Workers' Organizing Committee to confer with him in Columbus Monday or Tuesday.

The touring New Zealand cricketers defeated Cambridge University by eight wickets in a low scoring match at Cambridge today. Against the students' totals of 102 and 128, the tourists replied with 135 and 96 for two wickets.
BEFORE I FORGET, by Burton Rascoe. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.) Mr. Rascoe's memories of the Middle West, where he made his start in journalism and as a literary critic.
Frances Pelton Jones gave her annual harpsichord salon musical at the Pickwick Arms Hotel this afternoon. The assisting artist was Miss Mabel Beddoe, Canadian contralto.
Leaders of the steel industry attending the forty-sixth annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute joined yesterday in painting an optimistic picture of the immediate future of steel.
Nineteen graduates of the Scoville School for Girls heard an address on world cooperation yesterday at their commencement exercises at the school, 1,008 Fifth Avenue.

Heavyweight Champion Jim Braddock, examined before and after a brisk boxing workout, was pronounced today in excellent condition as he prepared for his title bout June 22 at Chicago with Challenger Joe Louis.
Montgomery Ward Co. filed exceptions today to a National Labor Relations Board examiner's report supporting charges that the company violated the Wagner Labor Act.

A tall, white-haired woman sat yesterday afternoon in the apartment she has occupied for seventytwo years and recalled the time when farmers living in midtown Manhattan could catch enough fish, pick enough vegetables and get enough milk from their own cows to be independent of other food supplies.

Behind the brilliant pitching of Bill Morley, the Seton Hall Pirates scored a 2-1 victory over the Brooklyn College nine today. This was Seton Hall's eighth victory of the season and their fifth consecutive triumph.

Mrs. Irene Squier Breingan, a teacher in the Newark public school system for forty years before her retirement ten years ago, died last night in Homeopathic Hospital here after a short illness at the age of 69. She lived at 18 South Munn Avenue here and was the wife of Robert L. Breingan.

The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, fourth grade, in this department, Bureau of Fire, with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per annum:
Emulating Dillinger's contempt for the law, the Brady gangsters came into Indianapolis today, telephoned to a lawyer and fled again without seeing him.

Miss Cynthia Hare, daughter of Mrs. Conrad Hare of Rosemont and of Alfred G. Hare, was married to Robert M. Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Miller of this city, in a secret ceremony today in Elkton, Md. The ceremony was performed. by J. W. Baker.

An investigation of conditions in Palestine failed to support any plea for the restriction of immigration or land sales to Jews, United States Senator Royal S. Copeland of New York said last night at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the Food and Allied Trades Division of the United Palestine Appeal and Joint Distribution Committee, at which he was the guest of honor.

The legislative committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board last night adopted a resolution calling for a provision in the Black-Connery Minimum Wage-Maximum Hour Bill permitting the suspension of certain features of the anti-trust law for industries whose labor standards have been approved by the board administering the labor law.

Edward F. Dolan, 57-year-old dancer and female impersonator, was found murdered early yesterday in a two-room flat he shared with another man at 38 Ludlow Street. The man who shared the apartment, Kenneth Reese, an orderly in a hospital, was on duty at the time.

The attendance and income at the current Belmont Park meeting shows an increase over last year, which in turn revealed a rise over 1935, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Racing Commission.

Thanks, to another one of those Pittsburgh downpours, the Dodgers left tonight for home only one game under the .500 mark and with the record of "sweeping the series" against the Pirates by winning the one contest played.

An original wash painting by Frederic Remington, "Episode of the Spanish-American War," was sold at auction yesterday for $175 by Irwin Kurtz, bankruptcy referee, in winding up the affairs of the Imperial Manhattan Corporation.

MANHATTAN AUSLANDER, AUGUSTA J. (Jan. 26, 1937). Gross assets, $27,656; net, $23,536. To Tillie Davis, sister. $1,000; Felice A. Dworetzky, jewelry and one-half residue; several specific bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $23,502. Lilienstern Gettinger, attorneys, 1,501 Broadway.

The Bank of New York and Trust Company, which has an uptown office at 706-708 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Sixty-third Street, has purchased the adjoining four-story building on a lot 40 by 70 feet at 702-704 Madison Avenue. Brett Wyckoff, brokers, arranged the sale, which was the first involving the property in fifty years.

Plans for four foreign scientific expeditions and one to collect the vanishing mammals in the United States were announced yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History in connection with its project of raising $10,000,000 for a ten-year development program.

The marriage of Miss Ann Ridley Foster, daughter of Mrs. Barrows Porter of 521 Park Avenue and the late. Herbert I. Foster, to Thomas Le Boutillier 3d, son of Mrs. Thomas Le Boutillier 2d of Westbury, L. I., and the late Mr. Le Boutillier, took place yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection, which was decorated with pink mountain laurel and peonies.

Frederic Eugene Ives, inventor of the half-tone engraving process used by newspapers and magazines throughout the world and who did early research in color photography, died in Hahnemann Hospital here today after a long illness. His age was 81.
Thomas Langdon Elwyn, senior partner in Biddle, Whelen Co., brokers, died in Abington Memorial Hospital today after a month's illness. He was in his seventieth year.
Universal's aviation melodrama, "Wings Over Honolulu," will settle down this morning at the Roxy. Ray Milland, Wendy Barrie, William Gargan and Kent Taylor head the cast.

Sixteen parcels of real estate, including a variety of properties, were sold at auction in the Bronx yesterday. Four of the sales were held in the Bronx County Building and the remainder in the salesrooms at 3,208 Third Avenue. The list follows:

Delivery of free cake ice with milk, which has cost the milk companies about $2,000,000 a year and has caused disturbances in the ice business, will be discontinued under a plan announced yesterday by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner.

Michael Matteo, a Republican attorney living at 11 St. Luke's Place, was sworn in by Mayor-La Guardia yesterday as a municipal court justice to fill the vacancy caused by the recent death of Justice John F. O'Neil.

Miss Helen Scott UIorris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caspar W. Morris of Haverford, has chosen her cousin, Miss Eleanor C. Walker of New York, to be maid of honor at her marriage to Edwin P. Halsey, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Taylor Halsey of New Orleans, on June 25 in All Saints Church, Wynnewood.

The forces of recovery are bigger than any of the many dangers lining its path and advancement over the next few years is "irresistible," Dr. Neil Carothers, director of the College of Business Administration of Lehigh University, said before a general session of the twenty-second annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel William Penn here today.

Nathan Freedman lost in the Court of Appeals his $500 judgment against the New York Society for the Prevention of Vice and John S. Sumner, its secretary, which he obtained as a result of a trial before Justice Rosenman.

The Boot and Shoe Workers Union, with 14,000 members in seven locals in the metropolitan area, voted last night to leave the American Federation of Labor and join the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The seventy-ninth commencement of the Gardner School for Girls, 154 East Seventieth Street, will be held tonight at the school. Dr. Pennington Haile of the National League of Nations Association will be the graduation speaker.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, urged the National Industrial Conference Board last night to investigate the problem of the 2,000,000 school graduates who have been thrown each year recently into a world in which they have found no gainful occupation.
Calling of contracts yesterday by spinners for the end of the month in Liverpool strengthened foreign cotton prices and widened differences to an extent that absorbed contracts in the local market.

Charles H. Griffiths, chairman of the Westchester County Republican Committee, issued a statement today urging his constituents to join in a State-wide campaign to prevent the Democratic party from gaining control of the State Constitutional Convention to be held next year. Delegates will be elected in the Autumn.

The New York Academy of Public Education conferred its medal for distinguished service in the field of public education" upon Dr. John H. Finley. editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at its silver jubilee dinner, which was held last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

The elections today to the Upper House of the States General followed identically the trend in the elections to the Lower House, giving further proof that the majority in this country is with Premier Hendrik Colijn.

Joseph' Curran, maritime labor leader, said yesterday that strikes on ships of the International Mercantile Marine Cormpany, the Luckenbach and Black Diamond steamship lines were inevitable unless immediate action is taken to clarify the labor union situation.

A half hour after notices of a pay increase and a vacation with pay had been posted in the Driver-Harris wire manufacturing plant at Harrison, the majority of the 300 employes on the day shift walked out this afternoon.

Andy Varipapa, turning in a splendid exhibition of bowling, took the lead over Nelson Burton of Dallas, Texas, in the fourth block of their eight-block home-and-home match at the Capital Health Center last night.

Barker Ave (16-4424), w s, 204 ft of Mace Ave, 29x100; Martha V. Epstein, trustee. to Francesca Becchetti, 467 146th St. Sylvan Ave (13-3421K), w e, 374 it n of 254th St. 31x100; Luke J. Lerolle, referee, to Edbro Realty Co, Inc, 6 E 45th St. Crotona Ave (11-2944), s e cor 175th St, 96x22; Hyman Rubin to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.
Miss Dorothea M. Landwehr, founder of Miss Landwehr's School for Children, died suddenly early today at the age of 50. She was born in Babylon, the daughter of Henry J. and the late Amelia Landwehr.

F. Spencer Chapman, 30-year-old British climber, has become the first person to scale Chomolhari, 23,930-foot Himalayan peak, about 150 miles east of Mount Everest, according to a laconic message received by The Daily Telegraph's Calcutta correspondent.
Anxiety for Gabriele d'Annunzio's safety is being expressed by some of his friends in consequence of letters he has written in which it is understood that he has manifested suicidal intentions.
Italian newspapers today carried a dispatch- saying a bomb had struck an Italian warship during a bombardment of Palma, Majorca, by Spanish Government aircraft.

Frank M. Maloney, promoter of mining stock, and the brokerage house bearing his name were found guilty by a jury in the Southern District Federal Court last night under an indictment charging twelve counts of mail fraud and one count of conspiracy.

In the first quarter of 1937 the net operating income of first-class steam railways was $146,174,643, compared with $104,443,349 in the corresponding 1936 period, and a number of the major Eastern lines turned defficits into earnings, or largely reduced deficits after allowance for depreciation, according to the official report of the Interstate Commerce Commission made public today.

A new chapter in the political history of Britain will be opened tomorrow when Neville Chamberlain, son of the great Joseph and half brother of the late Sir Austen, goes to Buckingham Palace to receive the prize of the Premiership, which neither of them was able to attain.

R. B. White, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company and president of the Central Railroad of New Jersey from 1926 to 1933, testified before Federal Judge Phillip Forman here today that in his opinion bankruptcy was inevitable for that carrier "unless the assessed valuations can be reduced so that it can earn its taxes."

Federal Theatre Project workers who went out on strike yesterday were "striking for what was once described as life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness," Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national director of the WPA theatre, told the afternoon session of the American Theatre Council convention at the Hotel Astor.
Sir Gerald Hemmington Ryan, former chairman of the Phoenix Assurance Company and one of the best-known British actuaries, died today at his home in Ipswich. He was 76 years old.

The Lee Lime Co has named Frank R. Loftus as its representative for the metropolitan district, with offices at 101 Park Ave. Several thousand visitors are expected at Mountain Lakes. Smallwood. N. Y.. for the week-end. The Decoration Day program includes a golf tournament and dances.
Fifteen per cent more wedding rings burg, are being sold this year than in will 1936, Russell G. Scheer, president of the New York State Retail Jewelers Association, estimated today.

A program of motorcycle races will be presented at the Yankee Stadium tonight, with eighteen events listed on the card. The feature race will bring together Benny Kaufman of the East Side and Crocky Rawding, Bloomfield (N. J.) daredevil.

A jury in Federal court, after deliberating two and three-quarter hours, returned a verdict yesterday in favor of the government in retrial of a suit brought by sons of the late Viscount William Waldorf Astor for $20,000,000.

S. Allen Norton, retired treasurer of the Mount Hermon School for Boys, gave authorities new and vital information about the unsolved murder of Dr. Elliott Speer, headmaster of the school, only a week before an attempt was made on his life at his home here Tuesday night, State detectives disclosed tonight.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine conferred yesterday with Prosecutor John J. Breslin at Hackensack, N. J., about the murder of Norman Redwood, labor leader.

Miss Alyce Pressprich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Williams Pressprich of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Samuel Lord Brookfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Brookfield of 580 Park Avenue, New York, on June 11 in Christ Episcopal Church, Rye.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the System as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

Five scholarships, each valued at $128 and entitling the winner to study at the Art Students League for eight and one-half months, beginning next Sept. 15, have been awarded to high school students of the city.

Monte Weaver held the White Sox to six scattered hits today to win a 2-to-1 victory for Washington. The Senators' outfielder, Ben Chapman, scored both runs for Washington with a single, double and triple in four times at bat. Kreevich, Sox centerfielder, tallied for his side.

Miss Julia Dolce Bastedo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron W. Bastedo of 310 West Seventy-ninth Street and Scarsdale, was married last night to Henry G. Paulsen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Paulsen of Union City, N. J., at the home of her grandmother, Mrs. Raymond C. Penfield, 336 Riverside Drive.

Harold Voelbel of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company won the high average prize in the pistol tournament sponsored by the Bankers Athletic League with an average of 298.9 for ten matches, it was announced yesterday.

HERE are a few of the things I never knew before. reading Burton Rascoe's "Before I Forget" (Doubleday, Doran, $3), which carries the story of his life up to about 1920: That Mr. Rascoe was born some forty-five years ago in Fulton, Ky., and passed his boyhood there and in Shawnee, Okla.
Margie Adams, repertory actressproducer for twenty-nine years, died at her Summer home at Massena Point today after a long illness in her fifty-seventh year.

Bank St, 32, 19.6x93; Lena Rancolf to Ellen H. Ringer, 4 St Lukes P1; mtg $25,000 ($5). Madison St, 400, 25x100; Alfred J. Scott, referee, to East River Savings Bank; foreclosure ($14.50). Same property, Adele Shapiro to same, quitclaim.

Armand A. Durante, securities dealer of Great Neck, L. I., and Irwin W. Goodwin, his former business associate, of 234 West Forty-eighth Street, were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum to two years each in prison.
A good demand for store, office and showroom space in buildings in scattered sections of Manhattan was indicated in business space rentals reported yesterday.

Governors Island Each of the following prospective graduates of Syracuse University, Syracuse, N. Y., is assigned to the First Division, effective upon acceptance of appointment in the Officers' Reserve Corps, as Second Lieutenant, Infantry Reserve:

Granting of government pensions to children handicapped by poverty, who have "a right to a fair start in life," was proposed tonight by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, before the American Public Welfare Association, meeting in conjunction with the National Conference of Social Work.

Net earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in the first three months of this year were about $12,900,000 after all charges, reserves and taxes, John A. Brown, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. This would be equal to about 41 cents a share on the 31,151,071 capital shares outstanding.

Aggregating $41,311,301, installed cost of equipment sold by the members of the Air-Conditioning Manufacturers Association broke all records in the first four months of this year, it was announced here today by William B. Henderson, executive vice president.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., announced yesterday that it had closed negotiations with representatives of the American Guild of Radio Announcers and Producers and had signed an agreement covering hours, wages and working conditions for announcers and assistant directors employed in its New York studios.

The Camp Fire Girls gave a dinner of welcome last night for their new national president, Mrs. Lola Duvall Williams of Dallas, Texas, elected at their conference in Lincoln, Neb., last Autumn. The dinner was in the nature of a jubilee celebration also, rounding out the organization's first quarter century. It was held at the clubhouse of the American Women's Association, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Sixteen-year-old Lillian Apken, a senior at James Monroe High School, who said she had been writing poetry since she was 3 years old, won first place yesterday in the fifteenth annual high school contest to discover New York City's junior poet laureate.

Corn again assumed leadership in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today. The July and September soared the permissible limit of 4 cents a bushel for one day's trading while the December was 2 1/2 cents higher.

Members of the Association of American Railroads approved today agreements reached with the American Train Dispatchers Association and the Brotherhood of aintenance of Way Employes under which the two labor organizations agree not to press certain legislation in Congress.
New guiding principles for Reform Judaism were adopted by the Central Conference of American Rabbis at its annual meeting here today after a six-hour debate.

Two city-owned plots in the Bronx acquired in connection with the construction of the municipal subway system were sold at auction yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. John J. Reynolds was the auctioneer.

MANHATTAN Estate, $5,000. To Dudley Buck Jr., 202 E. Walton Pl., Chicago, Ill., $1,000; five varying bequests; Helen Babcock Buck, daughter, executrix, 580 Park Ave., $500 and residue. CUMMINS, ANNA (Jan. 8). Estate, $400. To Max Cummins, brother-in-law, executor, 1,025 E. 14th St., Brooklyn, residue.
Sir Archibald Boyd Carpenter, M. P., an ardent imperialist who held office under Prime Minister Andrew Bonar Law and Stanley Baldwin, died today at Harrogate at the age of 64.

Wholesale prices moved upward in the week ended on May 22 for the first time in seven weeks, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, rose to 87.4 from 86.9 in the preceding week, and compared with 78.2 on May 23, 1936.

Miss Mary Denniston, for the last fourteen years director of leadership training, department of religious education, Greater New York Federation of Churches, died here on Wednesday. Her home was at 430 West 119th Street.

The stand taken by Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican county leader, indicating that the Republican party might support for Mayor a Democratic nominee not too closely identified with either Tammany Hall or the New Deal, was attacked yesterday by four prominent proLa Guardia Republicans as indicating a complete surrender by Mr. Simpson of the Republican party's traditional anti-Tammany stand.

The Oliver Farm Equipment Company and its subsidiaries showed a consolidated net income in the first four months of this year of $1,405,357, after taxes and other deductions but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings, according to figures filed with the Securities Exchange Commission.

The engagement of Miss Ivis Ethel Helen Goulding, daughter of Mrs. Charlotte Goulding of London and Westwood Village, Los Angeles, to Frederick William Procter, son of Mrs. Sanford Procter of Fish House, N. J., has been announced.

The four-story apartment house at 41-26 Seventy-third Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Samuel Reznick, operator. The building is on an L-shaped plot 60 by 179 feet, irregular, and contains 177 rooms, divided into fifty-nine apartments.

The Misses Joan Downing, Dolores Hale and Mary Louise Bradley starred at the first annual horse show held by students of the Academy of Mount St. Vincent of Riverdale on the grounds of the Hutchinson Riding Academy today.

Exports of United States brands of whisky in the first quarter were almost twenty-three times as great as those of the corresponding 1936 period, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.
Diplomas will be presented to twenty-three graduates this morning at the forty-fifth annual commencement of the Spence School, 22 East Ninety-first Street.

A hint that President Roosevelt might be ready to offer a compromise and a personal plea by Representative Rayburn as majority leader brought at least a temporary halt today to the House revolt on the $1,500,000,000 relief bill, which had resulted in the earmarking of $505,000,000 of relief funds for flood control, the Public Works Administration and Federal roads.

The admission of Egypt to the League of Nations by unanimous vote caused little excitement here.
