The fact was accepted merely as the final step in this nation's rise to complete independence-beginning with the signing of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty of alliance and friendship last August, then the abolition of capitulations at the Montreux conference this month, and now the admission to the League of Nations.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jay Edson Eddy of 1,158 Fifth Avenue and Out-OBounds, Osterville, Cape Cod, of the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Doris Isabel Eddy, to James Raymond Boyce of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Raymond Boyce of Englewood, N. J.

Lower wheat prices caused a fresh decline in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices. The index declined 0.8 point to 143.5 on Tuesday from 144.3 (revised) the Tuesday previous. But for the drop in wheat prices, which carried with it the other grains and flour, the index would have shown little change..

The second of the three new city ferryboats built with the aid of PWA funds will be launched at Mariners Harbor, S. I., at 4 P. M., on June 3, it was announced yesterday by Frederick J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures.

Supreme Court Justice McCook took under advisement yesterday an offer of various banks and former officers and directors of the National Surety Company to pay $1,350,000 in settlement of a stockholder's suit for about $50,000,000.
Stocks drifted and closed steady and mixed; turnover, 596,500 shares. United States Government issues generally higher, other bonds firm and dull; transactions, $6,359,000.
Miss Ethel Swope, assistant director of the American Nurses Association, died today of leukemia after several months' illness. Her age was 52 and she was a native of Ohio.

Ben Cantwell, ace of the Jersey City pitching staff, held Baltimore to three hits today to defeat Hy Vandenburg in a pitchers' battle and give Jersey City the opening game of the series by a score of 2 to 1.

Clarence L. Watts, counsel for Heywood Patterson, one of nine Negroes who have spent six years in Alabama jails while their cases growing out of the alleged criminal assault upon two white women in March, 1931, have shuttled through the courts, today asked the State Supreme Court to set aside his client's seventy-five-year sentence.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress was made the occasion by the Tribuna for a comparison of social legislation in Italy and the United Statesa comparison from which, as is to be expected, Italy emerges as the easy winner.
Only one place remained to be filled tonight in order to have a full field of thirty-three starters in the 500mile Indianapolis motor speedway race Monday.

The thirty-second annual commencement of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music will be held tonight in the concert hall of the school. Felix M. Warburg, president of the board of trustees of the institute and member of the board of directors of the school, will be the commencement speaker. A class of sixty-four students will receive diplomas.

Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark Jr., president of the Alumnae Association of the school, was the commencement speaker yesterday afternoon at the exercises for the graduates of Miss Hewitt's classes of 74 East Seventy-ninth Street, held in the Great Hall of the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.
Wedding presents for the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield arrived from the British royal family tonight.

The first London bus to appear in the streets since May 1 swung out of the Hammersmith garage at 4:02 A. M. today and thus ended the most unpopular and the most completely defeated strike in the history of the British trade union movement.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh the cast and Professor Alexis Carrel are coming to Denmark in August to Confir continue the conferences with leading scientists that were begun last year when they demonstrated a Korda, model of Colonel Lindbergh's "artificial heart," it was announced today by Dr. Albert Fischer, Denmark's foremost cancer specialist.

Miss Adele Lippincott, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Lippincott, was married at her home here today to John Raymond Meagher, son of Mrs. Thomas F. Meagher of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and the late Mr. Meagher, by the Rev. Dr. Homer D. Whitfield of the Sewickley Methodist Episcopal Church.

Directors of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share, an increase of 25 cents over the last payment on March 29. Disbursements so far this year amount to 75 cents. The company paid $1 and 25 cents extra in 1936.

Dr. Joe R. Clemmons, assistant director at Strong Memorial Hospital here, has been appointed director of the Roosevelt Hospital in New York City it was announced today by Dr. Basil C. MacLean, Strong director, who said that Dr. Clemmons had been a valuable aid to the University Medical School and to the hospital.
In "People in Love," the first play by Arthur Reid which is being given a short trial run at the Arts Theatre, another light comedy is added to the present theatrical vogue for airy trifles.

Commodity futures displayed an easier tone in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, copper, tin, hide and world sugar futures were lower, while silk, wool top, cottonseed oil and coffee contracts were steady. Cocoa gained. On the cash market, wheat, rye, oats, cocoa, lard and cotton advanced, but corn, flour, tins, silk and rubber declined.
Daniel Daley, 57 years old, convicted in Special Sessions of unlawful practice of medicine in his office at 171 West Seventy-first Street, was sentenced yesterday to a sixtyday workhouse term.

The marriage of Miss Jeanne Endelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Endelman of 221 West Eighty-second Street, to Joseph H. Fuld, son of Herman Fuld, also of this city, and the late Mrs. Fuld, took place last night at the Sherry Netherland.

Oscar Johnson, vice president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, in an address before the Commodity Club of New York at a dinner meeting last night in the Park Central Hotel, said the cotton farmers of America recognized no obligationmoral, economic, patriotic or other -to live in "penury and poverty" in order that a sufficient volume might be produced to support an economy built upon the production of past years.
Embarrassed by the receivership of its correspondent in Chicago the New York Curb Exchange house of Frank C. Masterson Co. requested yesterday and was granted a suspension by the Curb Exchange.

William Palmer Dixon entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Cushman, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Beal, Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Norman Jr., Mr. and Mrs. George Sloane, Mr. and Mrs. Everett W. Cady, Mrs. Jean Hiller, Mrs. Banks Bertschmann, Miss Anne King Carley, Robin Wilson, Arturo Ramos and Tom L. Johnson.
The solidly Democratic Florida Senate approved a bill today to prevent the loss of the Republican party's official standing in the State.

Plans for altering a wide variety of buildings in Manhattan were filed yesterday. The changes will be made in a hotel on Park Avenue, an office building in Rockefeller Center, as well as -in a club property, a factory and numerous dwellings and tenement houses.

Behind the superb pitching of its star southpaw, Joe Dooley, who gave only two hits and struck out fifteen, the Jamaica High School nine clinched the Queens P. S. A. L. title by downing Flushing High, 8--2, at Flushing Memorial Field yesterday.

The annual election of officers of Typographical Union No. 6 (Big Six), in which more than 7,518 printers participated, resulted in such a close vote for two candidates for president that a run-off for the office will be held on June 9, it was announced yesterday.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, today designated a committee of nine university professors to investigate the cases of Dr. J. Raymond Walsh and Dr. Alan R. Sweezy, economics instructors, who recently received notices of their virtual dismissal from the Harvard faculty.

A move to have a mammoth livestock exposition held as a feature of the 1939 World's Fair in New York was initiated at the State Agricultural Experiment Station at Rutgers University here today when a group of twenty leading livestock breeders from New Jersey, New York,

Sam Witoffsky, 41 years old, of 749 Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, suddenly pleaded guilty in General Sessions .yesterday as a jury was about to be drawn for his trial on a charge of defrauding an insurance company in a fake accident claim.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed trustee for $450,000 of ten-year 4 per cent income debentures of the Comstock Canning Corporation, due May 1, 1947. It also has been appointed registrar for capital stock of the Shawnee Pottery Company.

Danise M., an eligible for the Chicago Handicap to be run Saturday, showed fine form as she marked her 1937 debut with a victory today at Washington Park. Racing in the colors of the Arcturus Stable, Danise M. turned back a fast field in the featured Hyde Park Purse. Second was Sir Quest, with Silverette third.

The death of Fenton Lawson, manufacturer of metal articles, at his home in Cincinnati yesterday was announced here last night. Mr. Lawson was 80 years old. He was president of F. H. Lawson Company of Cincinnati.

A decrease in arson this year throughout the United States was reported yesterday by officials of the National Board of Fire Underwriters at the seventy-first annual meeting of that organization held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Elimination of all holding companies emplayed to control railroad systems was advocated today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in commenting on testimony given yesterday before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce by Robert R. Young, head of the syndicate now in control of the old Van Sweringen network, to the effect that it was planned soon to put an end to the Alleghany Corporation.

The Union Electric Light and Power Company of Missouri, a subsidiary of the North American Company system, is planning to issue approximately $110,000,000 of bonds and preferred stocks in a huge refunding program of practically all present senior securities, it was reported yesterday.

A pacifist memorial, including a promise "to preach with courage the gospel of peace," which was presented to the United Lutheran Synod of New York at the closing session of its annual meeting last evening, failed to come to a vote.
The directors of the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday chose Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, as president for the forthcoming year.
Promoter Tom Gallery predicted today Los Angeles' biggest fight card in years would draw more than 35,000 persons and gate receipts of about $115,000 tomorrow night.

Official statements tonight indicated that the condition of King Carol, who has been stricken with influenza, had grown worse, so all arrangements for his forthcoming visit to Transylvania were canceled. Crown Prince Michael arrived here last night from Warsaw.
Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Senator Livingston of Brooklyn tightening the State's Old Age Assistance Law and bringing it into line with the Federal act.

Unexpectedly entering a fray which in the beginning was not at all of his choosing, Carl Hubbell today came up with his twenty-fourth consecutive National League victory in a two-year string as the Giants, riding handsomely on the crest of Melvin Ott's seventh homer of the year, brought down the Reds, 3 to 2.
The idea that the government regards the recent election as a defeat bringing resignation as its penalty is summarily rejected by Lieut. Gen. Gen Sugiyama, the War Minister.

Three armed hijackers made the mistake yesterday morning-of taping too loosely the eyes of their captive, a truck driver, and the result was the capture of one suspect and the recovery of a cargo of woolen goods, valued at $5,000 to $10,000.

More national advertisers have tied in with Cotton Week this year than ever before, C. K. Everett, head of the New Uses Sections of the Cotton-Textile Institute, said here yesterday. The promotion, which starts on Monday, will also attract the greatest volume of retail advertising for any similar event in advertising history, he added.

G. Fred Berger, a member of the executive council of the American Bankers Association, said today that the Federal Government has the machinery to keep inflation from getting out of hand but expressed doubt that it would have the "intestinal fortitude" to use it.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a public hearing would be held in its offices here, beginning on June 2, on the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, the name of which subsequently was changed to the Pacific Eastern Corporation, New York City, and its subsidiary and affiliated companies.

President Roosevelt, still suffering from a cold, again remained in the White House, where he conferred with Secretary Morgenthau on taxation and Secretary Ickes on the work of the Advisory Committee on Education.

Mrs. John Hay Whitney's brown mare Spring Hope opened the third day of the Devon Horse Show this morning with a victory over Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim's brown gelding Firenze Clifton's Beau in the lightweight hunters test over the outside course.

"Al" on the sidewalks of New York but "Alfredo Schmidt" in Italy. When former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York arrived here this week Rome editors Italianized his Christian name and called him Alfredo.

Knights of Columbus from all over Knights of Columbus from all over the State turned today toward Geneva for their convention which opened tonight. By special train, bus and automobile the Knights converged on the city, its streets gay with flags and bunting.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $30,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $940,000,000, according to the weekly report of the Reserve System issued yesterday.
Irving D. Tressler, who writes the "Scribner Quiz" for Scribner's Magazine, has written a book called "How to Lose Friends and Alienate People." It will be published this Summer by Stackpole Sons.

"Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will be the double bill at the Hippodrome tomorrow night. Irra Pilla and Coppellotti will be featured in the former opera. Mario Doro makes her debut as Nedda in the Leoncavallo work, the cast of which will include Giuseppe Radaelli and Ettore Nava. Sunday night's bill is "Rigoletto." A special Memorial Day presentation of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" is, scheduled for Monday night.

Three men were injured, one of them seriously, and seven persons, including a woman, were under arrest last night after a street brawl in front of Bill's Gay Nineties night club at 57 East Fifty-fourth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

Urging friendly economic cooperation between the United States and the Third Reich, which ne said could be attained if "insults against the other country's flag and against the other country's head of state" were avoided, Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, newly appointed German Ambassador to Washington, suggested yesterday in his first public speech since his recent arrival the "unshackling of world trade."

Will Durant, author, will deliver the commencement address tonight at the thirty-seventh commencement exercises of the Finch School, to be held in the Lenox Little Theatre, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street. Mrs. Jessica Garretson Cosgrave, founder and president of the school, will present the diplomas.

The Imperial Conference turned today to a study of international trade at a session in which Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, outlined the proposals the United States would like included in an Anglo-American commerce treaty.

With Columbia and Pitt holding fast to their ranking as co-favorites, the sixty-first annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. will be staged with all their color and pageantry at the new Randalls Island Stadium today and tomorrow as picked athletes from thirty-two colleges strive for the fifteen titles at stake.

More than 92 per cent of the certificate holders of the $4,088,300 mortgage on the Hotel Taft, Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street, have agreed to the plan of reorganization approved by the New York County Supreme Court in February, the hotel's reorganization committee, George V. McLaughlin, chairman, announced yesterday.
The stock markets were fairly quiet today, but a generally better tone was evident in most of the sections. Gilt-edged issues were somewhat easier, while foreign loans were idle.
The Sunday ban on beer and wine sales in Virginia, which would have been three months old tomorrow, was ordered lifted today by the State Control Board. Adopted Feb.
A Congressional investigation of income tax evasions by wealthy persons will be demanded by President Roosevelt in a public statement to be issued, probably tomorrow.

Sam??nead, brilliant 24-year-old shotmaker who has been causing golfdom to go into ecstacies over his achievements during the last few months, came to the end of his trail in his first Professional Golfers Association championship today.

The Bureau of Air Commerce hereafter will invite "outside experts" to sit with its boards of investigation in an effort to offset any loss of faith in aviation caused by recent accidents, Fred D. Fagg Jr., director of the bureau, declared today at a luncheon of the National Press Club.

Are the foreign and Spanish forces of General FRANCO deliberately flouting world opinion? Certainly the slaughter of civilians in the Loyalist capital yesterday by bombers, presumably of Italian make, swooping in from the sea before dawn, is another heavy count in the indictment of the Rebel methods of warfare.

Garnet Warren, illustrator and writer, died yesterday afternoon of an intestinal disorder at Hackensack Hospital here. Mr. Warren, who was 64 years old, resided on East Saddle River Road, Upper Saddle River.

Dr. Fiesel was visiting Professor of Linguistics at Bryn Mawr College. She came to Bryn Mawr last September under a three-year appointment made possible by gifts from the Rockefeller Foundation, the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars and from private sources.

Gross assets, $567,729; net, $525,492. To Church of St. Vincent de Paul, 120 W. 24th St., $5,000; Katherine Thompson, sister, specific jewelry and life estate in one-half residue; Martina L. Downing, sister, specific jewelry, life estate in specific real property and one-half residue in trust;

Walter W. Templin, formerly executive vice president and a director of the Pepsodent Company, yesterday became president of J. Stirling Getchell, Inc., advertising agency, succeeding Mr. Getchell, who, as the company's chief executive, became chairman of the board.

Democratic members of the Board of Estimate blocked the construction of five new Sanitation Department garages yesterday by refusing to approve a preliminary appropriation of $110,000 in tax notes to cover architects' fees and other initial expenses.

Following an executive session of the Senate, when the seven members of the State Unemployment Compensation Commission were confirmed for full terms ranging from one to seven years, the Legislature recessed tonight until June 28.
Jimmy Gibb, holder of the championship in 1935, rode through to victory in one of the feature events on the inaugural program of motorcycle races at the Yankee Stadium last night.

Here is a complete list of qualifiers and their times thus far for Monday's 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway: First Row-Bill Cummings. Indianapolis, 123.445; Wilbur Shaw. Indianapolis 122. 51; Herb Ardinger, Glassport, Pa. 121.983.

The conference of the seven Oslo powers, Holland, Belgium, F Luxemburg, Denmark, Norway, Sweden and Finland, ended today with an agreement to provide F greater freedom of trade among the signatory nations.
A stay-in strike by which Catholics hoped to force the Mexican Government to reopen their long-closed churches spread today throughout the State of Sonora.

Professor Alfred Adler, Viennese psychologist, whose theories made the "inferiority complex" known to thousands and gained him world renown, died of a heart attack today while walking in Aberdeen. He was 67 years old.
Nine crews worked over the surface of the Schuylkill, sleepy under a muggy, half-clouded sun, this afternoon for the final- act of the sprint race season of American college rowing.

Petitions signed by about 10,000 persons urging Federal action to provide more adequate housing for families in the low income brackets were forwarded yesterday to Senator Robert F. Wagner in Washington by the New York City Housing Authority.

The marriage of Miss Edna Lucille Atwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Atwood of West Orange, to Dr. Ernest E. Linke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Linke, also of West Orange, took place this evening in the First Presbyterian Church of Orange.
Sixteen horses have been nominated for the Greenwich Cup race, outstanding event of the Fairfield and Westchester race meeting, Monday at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club at Rye, N. Y.
G. Frederick Hawkins, identified with banking and brokerage in Wall Street for more than thirty years, died today at his home here of a heart ailment. He was 63 years old.
A shortage of pants created a major crisis today in the Army Air Corps.

The engagement of Miss Shirley Gardiner White, daughter of Charles P. White of this place and the late Mrs. White, to Edwin Francis Kittle, son of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Kittle, also of Glenbrook, has been announced by her father.

E. M. Durham Jr., executive officer for the trustees of the Rock Island Railroad, announced today that a plan for refunding the railroad's equipment trust certificates, totaling $29,716,800, would be presented to the Federal court here on June 1.

121st St, 322-4 E, 6-story brick tenement and stores, 37.6x100.11; Citizens Savings Bank against Isidor Simonowitz; due, $42,616: to plaintiff for $1,000. By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Carpenter Ave, 4,250-54, 6-story brick apartment, 114.8x79: Frank L. Weil, trustee, against Samrich Holding Corp.; due, $175,514: taxes, , $1,849; to plaintiff for $_3,0000.

The wave of water and mining tailings that yesterday fell upon the town of Tlalpujahua, causing a heavy loss of life, today swept twelve miles on down the valley burying extensive El Carmen and Somosa ranches.

Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslav Minister, and Mrs. Fotitch are at the Ritz-Carlton from Washington. Miss Gloria Baker, who returned on the Monarch of Bermuda, has joined her mother, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A ninth-inning Rochester rally fell short of its mark tonight and the Red Wings bowed to Buffalo, 7 to 6. Jumping on Rochester's ace flinger, Norbert Kleinke, for eleven hits and seven runs in the six and two-thirds frames he was on the hill, the Bisons were in the driver's seat most of the way.

TODAY we have another report. on the. state of the Soviet Union, this time not by a political exile or a disappointed man of letters but by the leader of the British Trades Union Congress. It is Sir Walter Citrine's "I Search for Truth in Russia" (Dutton, $3), the informal diary of a month's tour during the Autumn of 1935.
The centennial celebration of the founding of St. Mary's Hall, a girls' boarding school at Burlington, was held there today, with a service in historic St. Mary's Church as the opening event.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's three-day visit here, while it led to no definite negotiations, resulted in instructions nevertheless to be issued by the Reich Economics Minister to his aides to make every possible effort to arrive at a Franco-German trade treaty.
The State Banking Department today announced it had granted a license to the Madison Personal Loan, Inc., New York, to transact business at 250 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, with $25,000 capital.

Heavy smokers and persons who indulge in the use of alcoholic beverages to excess run the risk of becoming hard of hearing and, in serious cases, totally deaf, according to Dr. H. Marshall Taylor of Jacksonville, Fla. Dr. Taylor was a speaker today before the convention of the American Otological Society at the Lido Beach Country Club here.
From 11 A. M. until 6 P. M. today a golden drum of fortune revolved continuously in Dublin Mansion House and with every revolution some stub owner in the United States became the richer.

Future Vancouver babies will have their names burned on their backs at birth with rays of a water-cooled quartz lamp, it was announced today after a meeting of the board of directors of the Vancouver General Hospital.

Negotiations are under way for the rental of a large part of the front of the sixteen-story Fitzgerald Building at 1,482 Broad Way, on the southeast corner of Fortythird Street, in the Times Square district, for an illuminated sign. Occupants of office space above the second floor of the building have been asked by the Leblang interests, the owners, to vacate the premises at an early date, it was learned yesterday.
Germany cut today the interest rates on certain private debts abroad to a maximum of 4 per cent.
Two men are dead and four others are badly injured as a result of today's preliminaries to the annual 500-mile automobile race to be run here on Monday.
Cotton-mill activity showed more than season decline last week, and the adjusted index receded to 143.8 from 144.8. It was 107.9 for the week ended May 23, 1936.

About 7,500 WPA projects workers joined in the one-day stoppage on Thursday called by the Workers Alliance and other groups in protest against reductions in the WPA rolls, it was disclosed yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell. local WPA administrator, who based his figures on a final check of the walkout.

Total net sales of 582 manufacturers throughout the United States showed an increase of 27.9 per cent in April compared with April a year ago and total net sales of 1,186 reporting wholesalers increased 27.4 per cent, according to a joint statement today by the Bureau of For- t eign and Domestic Commerce and t the National Association of Credit Men.

Earnings of the Brillo Manufacturing Company, Inc., in the first three months of this year were the largest for any quarter since the last three months of 1931, according to the statement issued yesterday.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of May 26. 1937. upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of accounting and business practice in day high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:
Recovery of a needle containing $1,000 worth of radium from a heap of ashes in the incinerator of the Presbyterian Hospital here was reported at the hospital today.

New bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to the tax-exempt field, with a total of $5,035,000 in new issues placed on the market. This is the smallest volume for any similar period since the week of April 9, when only $4,443.000 new issues were placed.

Forty-one girls from all parts of the country received diplomas and certificates last night at the thirtyseventh commencement exercises of the Finch School held in the Lenox Little Theatre, 52 East Seventyeighth Street. The school is at 61 East Seventy-seventh Street.
Corporation presidents, as well as laborers, got many pay rises in the last year.

Announcement was made today of the engagement of Anita Lizana, Chilean tennis star, to Ronald Ellis of Inder-Gowie. Mr. Ellis and Miss Lizana met a year ago when they competed in the Scottish tennis championships.

Ulen Co. announced yesterday that the modification of its holdings of National Economic Bank of Poland 8 per cent bonds has been carried out with the Polish authorities and a first payment under the modification has been received.

Miss Mollie Owings Shriver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Nicholas Shriver of this city, was married here this afternoon to Rutherfurd Stuyvesant Pierrepont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherfurd Stuyvesant Pierrepont of New York and Far Hills, N. J., at the Mount Vernon Club.
Four men held up the watchman at the Terminal Warehouse here last night and handcuffed him to a pillar in the building, escaping with a truckload of cigarettes valued at $7,500.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith found words to describe his loss of words when he made his first speech in Europe today.

Frank Shaughnessey, president of the International League, stated through The Associated Press yesterday that the four-and-a-half-inning tie game played by Buffalo and Rochester Thursday night would go down in the records as an official regulation drawn contest.

There is an old Danubian ballad which sings of the soldier who, buried on the field of battle, rejoices in his "deep dark grave" not only over the victory of those who have borne their banners in triumph forth but even over the forgetfulness of the living who are happy in their loves.
The Italian liner Rex will leave for Mediterranean ports today with 1,782 passengers, including Mr. and Mrs. Walter Damrosch, Gene Pope, New York newspaper publisher;

The League of Nations Council heard and inconclusively discussed tonight the Spanish Government's appeal to it against what Julio Alvarez del Vayo, the Valencia spokesman, called "the invasion of Spain by Italian and German troops," the horros of "totalitarian war" and the danger of gas attacjs.

Dictating an opinion from the bench for twenty minutes yesterday afternoon, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe `gave his unqualified approval to and confirmed the plan for reorganizing the United Cigar Stores of America under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Honor awards to students of the Gardner School, 154 East Seventieth Street, were presented last night at the seventy-ninth commencement of the school. Dr. Pennington Haile of the League of Nations Association was speaker.
The School of Architecture and Allied Arts of New York University held its ninth annual dinner last night at the Roger Smith Broadmoor Restaurant, 40 East Fortyfirst Street.
John C. D. Harding, a member of the faculty of the University of Delaware since 1928, died today in Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, at the age of 47. He was an instructor in mathematics.

An attractive program of amateur trotting races has been arranged for the holiday week-end. This afternoon, followers of the sport will gather at the Fair Grounds at Mineola, L. I., where the first matinee program of the Nassau Driving Club will be staged, while on Monday they will make their way to Good Time Park at Goshen. N. Y..

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 6,000, including 3,000 direct. Market generally strong to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than Thursday's average; quality and weight considered.
Stanley Shepard Jr. of New York City has been appointed headmaster of Rutgers Preparatory School, President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University announced today. He succeeds Philip M. B.

The marriage of Miss Lucy Thompson, daughter of James Cary Thompson of this city, to Alva Ray Simmons, also of Baltimore, formerly of Floyd, Va., took place this afternoon in the Protestant Episcipal Church of the Redeemer. The Rev.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in May was the slowest of any month since March, 1935, when 15,849,017 shares were dealt in. Sales for May, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 18,564,979 shares, compared with 34,613,169 in April, and 20,614,690 a year ago.

Estate, more than $5,000. To Anna M. Eggers, daughter, 154 W. 101st St., one-half personal estate outright and one-half in trust; Herman G. Eggers, husband, executor,-154 W. 101st St., all real property.

Miss Mary Eleanor Kelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Kelley of Maplewood, formerly of Short Hills, was married here this evening to Frederick Charles Hanker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Hanker of Pittsburgh.

Joseph Berger, 29 years old, of 643 Warwick Street, and Gabriel Klar, 31, of 618 Chestnut Street, both of Brooklyn, who were investigators for separate truck drivers' labor unions, were convicted of manslaughter in the second degree at 6 o'clock last evening at their trial in General Sessions on a first-degree murder indictment.

Performing with maximum efficiency and showing even more power than had beeu suspected, the University of Pittsburgh spiked shoe brigade flung its challenge to its fellow-members of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. as the sixtyfirst annual championships began yesterday under dreary skies at the Randalls Island Stadium.

Paul O. Carter, examiner, recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today that it dismiss the complaint of the Weyerhaeuser Timber Company against the Pennsylvania Railroad and other carriers serving the Port of Newark.
Net sales of McKesson Robbins in the first four months of this year totaled $56,627,145, an increase of 18 per cent over sales of $47,975,898 in the same period last year, it was reported yesterday.

As the navy returned to its West Coast base after annual manoeuvres in the Hawaii-Panama-Alaskan triangle, Secretary Swanson sent to Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, Commander-in-chief of the fleet. a message of greeting to the officers and men who took part in the annual mis- me sions.

George D. Cochrane, J. W. Armstrong, lodges on Sunset Trail, Candlewood Isle, Conn. Lillian M. Sorch, at 46 Lismore Road, Lawrence, L. I., for David Blauer; Edwin L. Boosin, at 35 Broadway, Lawrence, for Morris Realty Service Corp; Mortimer R. Levy, at 2 Tulip St, Cedarhurst,

This is the holiday week-end during which the nocturnal bonifaces are expecting their ships to come in, and, considering the comparatively lean nights which they have been forced to endure of late, the same are definitely due.

Dr. Eva Fiesel, linguistic expert, died on Thursday at Post-Graduate Hospital. She was one of the outstanding authorities in the world on Etruscan and other ancient languages. She studied under Gustave Herbug, famous leader in investigating dead languages of the Mediterranean peoples.

Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Walker of 33 East Sixty-ninth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adele Walker, to Joseph M. d'Assern, son of Mrs. George H. Burr of New York and the late Baron Joseph d'Assern.
Sir H. B. Popham, newly appointed Governor of the Windward Islands in the British West Indies, arrived here today to take over his new duties.

An "audit" of advertising linage figures to prevent improper competitive use of linage claims and to make them a better guide for advertisers was suggested yesterday by Don Bridge, advertising director of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an address before the Pennsylvania Press Conference at Pennsylvania State College.

F. B. Williams has been appointed district salesmanager of the Southeastern district of the Edison General Electric Appliance Company of Chicago, with offices at Atlanta. J. W. Pentecost Jr., who has been in charge of the Charlotte, N. C., office, will become district sales supervisor for ranges with headquarters in Atlanta.

W. A. Fairburn, president of the Diamond Match Company, received last year $100,000 from that organization, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday. H. F.
Real estate sales by building and loan associations in New Jersey in the last year were two and one-half times more than in the preceding twelve .months.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously reversed yesterday the second degree murder conviction of Fred J. Hull, who, with Meyer and Harry Luckman, is serving twenty years to life imprisonment for the killing of Samuel Drukman on March 3, 1935. The court ordered a new trial for Hull.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted authority to carriers to establish and maintain rates on citrus fruits in carloads from points in Texas to Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York and Boston without observing the long-and-short haul provisions of the Interstate Commerce Act.
Average daily sales of chain men's wear stores in April were 10.4 per cent lower than in April, 1936, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today in preliminary statistics.

A black cat, slipping through railings in front of the Chancellor of the Exchequer's official home at 11 Downing Street and jumping onto a window ledge next door, was the first visible sign today of the change in occupancy of historic No. 10.
Walter Damrosch's "The Man Without a Country" was heard for the fourth and last time of the Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

In one of the largest memorial services ever held indoors, members of the 245th Coast Artillery, the oldest active regiment in the United States Army, paid the annual tribute to their dead in the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, 357 Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn.

In spite of the fact that his physical condition, while considerably improved, is still doubtful, as a result of his attack of intestinal flu, Adrian Quist was named with Jack Crawford yesterday to represent Australia in the singles of the final round Davis Cup tie of the North American zone, which begins today on the stadium turf of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

The steel strike settled down to an endurance contest today. The strikebound corporations let it be known that they would attempt full operation when they were assured prosection by the civic authorities, but that they were determined not to sign a union agreement.

Miss Helen Sim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Sim of Westfield, was married to Harold Ayers Mellen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rufus Harold Mellen of Brooklyn, this evening in her parents' home. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William Kerr McKinney. minister of the Presbyterian Church.

Thirty-seven years ago a tall, stringy farm boy from Auburn, Mo., just graduated from the University of Missouri, counted his share of the proceeds from the sale of the paternal farm and struck out for New York.

Trading in securities and commodities throughout the United States will be sharply curtailed today, as most of the Exchanges will begin a three-day holiday in observance of Memorial Day. The New York Stock and Curb Exchanges will be closed, and most other markets here and in major centers are following suit, but the Chicago Board of Trade and the Mercantile Exchange, the New Orleans Cotton Exchange and the coffee market here will be open today.
The American Federation of Hosiery Workers, a C. I. 0. affiliate, was made defendant today with four of its officers in a $3,000,000 damage suit filed in Federal court by the Apex Hosiery Company.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 928,000 bales, against 928,000 a week ago, 930;000 two weeks ago, 940,000 three weeks ago and 704,000 a year ago; of which American 400,000 bales, against 404,000 a week ago, 405,000 two weeks ago, 417,000 three weeks ago and 290,000 a year ago.

Turpentine firm, 35%@353/4c; sales, 222 barrels; receipts, 385 barrels: shipments, 17 barrels; stock, 26.573 barrels. Resin steady; sales, 368; receipts, 1,436; shipments, 1,641; stock, 44,622. Quote: B, $7.20; D, $7.30; E, $7.75; F to K, $8.721/2w, M, N, $8.10; WG, $8.20; WW, X. $9.00.

Bob Pastor, 183 1/4, of New York, punched young Bob Nestell, 191, of Los Angeles out of the front rank of the nation's heavyweight hopefuls tonight. He won by a wide margin in ten rounds before more than 30,000 fans at Wrigley Field.
Helium, noted bay mare owned by the May Top Stables of Port Cheater, N. Y., and ridden by Morton W. Smith, scored in the Great International Hunter Course Stake at the Devon horse show today.

Recent student "peace strike" demonstrations here were denounced as Communist-inspired and "abhorrent to all loyal Americans" by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, speaking yesterday at graduation exercises at Marymount School, 1,028 Fifth Avenue.
The Treasury today marketed an issue of discount bills of 273 days' maturity at the average rate of about 0.562 per cent on a bank discount basis, the price representing another sharp decline.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Eberhard Faber of 820 Fifth Avenue and Pinehurst, N. C., of the engagement of their niece, Miss Helen Louise Heim, to John Evans Love, son of Joseph Kirk Love of Johnstown, Pa.
Mrs. Mary N. Rice, the "nation's oldest mother," died tonight at the age of 105 years. She suffered a heart attack a week ago. Two daughters, who have lived with her for a number of years,

One of the least exploited branches of the service-the navy wife-has been scrutinized interestedly by Universal in "Wings Over Honolulu," and its findings, romantically summarized, are being presented for what they are worth at the Roxy. What they are worth seems, at this moment, to be curiously dubious, except of course as motion-picture entertainment.

The Hudson Trust Company has sold the three-story brick apartment at 786 Polk Street, West New York, N. J., to Polk Realty, Inc. There are twelve apartments of three and four rooms in the building, and the buyer will install a new plumbing and hot water system and renovate the property.

Miss Charlotte Frances Reil, daughter of Mrs. Otto Reil of this city, was married this evening to Richard Chew Miller, son of Colonel and Mrs. Alexander Macomb Miller Jr. of Washington, D. C., in the home of the bride's mother.

On his own application: PATROLMAN Dennis W. Callahan. 11th Precinct. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 2, 1908. Temporary Assignments SERGEANTS-James P. Dermody, from 46th Precinct to 19th Division. office of the chief inspector, for fifteen days.

An elaborate program of organ music by Dr. Charles M. Courboin, Belgian-born American concert artist, has been arranged for the marriage of Miss Ethel du Pont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont of Owl's Nest, Greenville, Del., to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, which will take place on June 30.
Mrs. Augusta Therese Young of Albany, a teacher for many years in the Albany School of Religious Education, died here today after an illness of several months.

Doubt whether the Social Security Act, as now constituted, will accomplish its purpose either effectively or economically was expressed today by M. A. Linton, president of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia.

Associated Telephone Company, Ltd.-Twelve months to April 30: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes, provision for retirement and other expenses, $589,079. Figures subject to audit and year-end adjustments.

A certain historic irony marks Egypt's entrance into the League of Nations. If it had not been for the fate of Ethiopia, the neighboring State would not now be taking a place near the vacant chair of the representative of the King of Kings.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Wood Song, full brother to Singing Wood, and rated by admirers the best juvenile in training, will face the acid test this afternoon when he goes to the post in the sixty-first running of the Juvenile, one of Belmont's traditional 2-year-old stakes which has the place of honor on a sevenrace program.

Republic's radio revue for 1937, "The Hit Parade," featuring Frances Langford, Phil Regan, Pick and Pat, George Givot, ventriloquist Max Terhune and his dummy, the Voice of Experience, Oscar and Elmer and the orchestras of Carl Hoff, Eddie Duchin and Duke Ellington, will come into the Rivoli this morning. ...
Elisabeth Rethberg, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, was among the 773 passengers who .sailed on the French liner Paris yesterday for Paris and the Italian Riviera.
A cargo of Wisconsin "mud," which has aroused the curiosity of scientists and shipping men, was transferred from a steamer to canal barges here today for shipment to Carteret, N. J.

Miss Natalie Folsom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hiram Tuttle Folsom, became the bride of Francis Poultney Clark, son of Mrs. J. Francis A. Clark of New York, this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church here. The Rev. William A. Stride, the rector, performed the ceremony.
Formation of a group of prominent Republicans to support Mayor La Guardia for renomination and re-election is in progress, it was learned yesterday.
The United Automobile Workers convoked a "strategy session" tonight to plan a renewal of its distribution of union literature at gates of the Ford Motor Company, interrupted Wednesday by a riot.

Announcing, simultaneously, that the entry list for the 1937 national open golf championship had hit a new all-time high of 1,404, the United States Golf Association yesterday made public the pairings for sectional qualifying rounds to be played on Tuesday, June 1, at 30 points throughout the country.

The Metropolitan Museum will open today in Gallery B-14 an exhibition composed of recent acquisitions of contemporary American paintings. Seventeen canvases make up the list, all of them purchased in 1937.

Washington Ave, 1,991-1,993 (11-3035); Ilma Realty Corp to Alexander Bruskin, 602 Ocean Pkway, Brooklyn; 5 per cent; $14,000. 3d Ave, 3,604.3,606 (11-2925); Minnie Trevaix to Metropolitan Savings Bank, extends mtg to June 1, 1940, at 3 per cent: S21.000.

Lieut. Col. John Richards, a retired Salvation Army officer, died yesterday after an operation in Newark Memorial Hospital. Colonel Richards had passed. most of his adult life serving men's social service centers of the Army in the East. He was 73 years old.

While nearly all of the leading centers of distribution showed an increase in retail sales this week, temporary disturbances brought a moderate decline in industrial production in many divisions, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Some of the decline in industry was brought about by an effort to adjust operations closer to incoming business.

The Securlties and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the East St. Louis Light and Power Company, a subsidiary of the North American Company, for approval of Its acquisition of 2,500 shares of $100 par value common stock of
Major R. Earl Boyd, army chaplain, died this morning at Walter Reed General Hospital in his forty-ninth year. He was born in Irwin, Pa., and was a chaplain of the Methodist Episcopal denomination.
Stocks steady and mixed in slowest trading since April 3, 1935; turnover, 558,950 shares. United States government bonds higher; other groups steady and quiet; transactions, $6,516,100.

Two of the tournament's outstanding favorites reached the final of the women's metropolitan golf championship today when Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring and Mrs. Marion Turpie came through to victory.
Participation in a world-wide campaign against communism - and atheism was.pledged here today at the State convention of the Catholic Daughters of America.

Opposition to any attempt to balance the Federal budget at the expense of social services and against any curtailment of work relief through the earmarking of appropriations was voted unanimously here today

The charge that several thousand girls had been illegally brought here by unlicensed agents and hired out as maids in the last two years, many of them later becoming public charges, was made in Flatbush Court yesterday by Arthur Hirsch, secretary to License Commissioner Paul Moss.
Frank Pearce, Syracuse righthander, pitched a four-hit game tonight, but lost a 3-1 decision to the Newark Bears before a crowd of 6,000.
The jinx that began dogging Lighthorse Harry Cooper's footsteps ten years ago, denying him two championships in the meantime, is still, villain-like, pursuing him.

The commencement exercises of Erskine Junior College closed today with an address by Dr. Harry A. Overstreet, head of the Department of Philosophy of the College of the City of New York; presentation of diplomas to thirty-one students from nine States and a tea to students' parents and friends.

One hold-up man was shot and killed and two suspects were captured at 2:30 o'clock this morning in a tavern at 2,112 Lexington Avenue, near 126th Street, when a recalcitrant customer, balking at joining the other customers in the rear, drew a pistol and fired on one of the thugs. The customer was Patrolman George Maurer of the East 126th Street Station, who was off duty.
The State of California sold on last Thursday an issue of $6,700,000 relief warrants to a banking group composed of the Bankamerica Company, the Anglo-California National Bank,

President Roosevelt announced officially today that he would press for action at this session of Congress against "immoral and unethical" evasion of Federal income taxes by wealthy persons and thus prevent the further diversion of millions of dollars in needed Treasury revenues.

Henry (Zeke) Bonura cracked a two-base hit against the right-field wall of League Park in the tenth inning today, allowing Ray Radcliff to score from second base with the White Sox run that defeated the Indians, 3 to 2.

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler censured yesterday the State Mortgage Commission for failing to accept a bid of $214,000 submitted at a foreclosure sale of property at 11-13 East Sixty-third Street.
Nine students were graduated last night at the annual commencement of the Scudder-Collver School of Homemaking, held at the Hotel Plaza.

Varieties of iris never before shown were placed on display yesterday afternoon on the eleventh floor of the R. C. A. Building in Rockefeller Center by the American Iris Society, which is holding its first iris show in this city. The show will be open to the public until tomorrow from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M.

The muchdiscussed bill making sweeping changes in Great Britain's ancient Divorce Law, which allows adultery as the only ground, was passed in the House of Commons today and went to the House of Lords, where it is expected that with minor amendments it will be passed.

The American Federation of Labor's executive council decided tonight to seek amendment of the administration Wage and Hour Bill to fix minimum wages and maximum hours for men by collective bargaining standards.
The Little Entente meetings here ended today with a decision to offer Hungary a classic choice as regards rearmament.

The sale of a large taxpayer property in Ridgewood, Queens, in its first transfer in more than twentyfive years, featured the Long Island realty transactions reported yesterday. A number of dwelling properties also changed hands.

Harvard's chances of overhauling Dartmouth in the Eastern Intercollegiate League were set back today when Pennsylvania humbled the Crimson on Franklin Field, 11 to 4. It was the first time the Red and Blue had won a baseball game from Harvard since 1934.

A 79-year-old woman was removed yesterday from the dingy two-room apartment in which she had been without food for several days. Among her effects police of the Sheriff Street station said they found several solid-gold necklaces and other objects, a quantity of shares of mining stocks and bankbooks showing deposits totaling $1,449.

The marriage of Miss Marguerite Annette McLachlan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George McLachlan of this city, to Thomas Joseph Wall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wall of New Rochelle, N. Y., took place here this morning in St. Joseph's Church.

Miss Helen Auth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Auth of South Orange, was married here this morning to Joseph T. Gallagher, son of Joseph T. Gallagher of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Gallagher, in the Church of the Sacred Heart.

While workmen put the finishing touches on the elaborate setting for tomorrow's eleventh annual Morris and Essex all-breed exhibition - the canine world's outstanding outdoor show-judging of the dachshund dog classes was held today at the Giralda Farms, country estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge.

The way has been opened to government regulation of all industry similar to that imposed on the railroads because of the Supreme Court's decision upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act, Samuel O. Dunn, editor of the trade magazine Railway Age, asserted today.

Suppression of civil liberties in Puerto Rico resulted in the Palm Sunday riot in Ponce, in which twenty persons were killed and almost 200 were wounded, according to a report yesterday by Arthur Garfield Hays, general counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

President Roosevelt pledged himself to "do everything within my power" to win early approval for the program of the St. Lawrence seaway and hydroelectric development in a telegram to the National Seaway Council, made public yesterday.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, replied tonight before 20,000 shouting National Socialists in Deutschland Hall to the recent antiNazi speech by Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, in the most scathing public attack on both the Christian confessions delivered to date by any member of the government.

The Rev. Bernard A. Cullen has been elected director-general of the Marquette League for Catholic Indian Missions. The election, which took place at a meeting of the board of directors, of which Alfred J. Talley is the head, May 7,

Retail trade here this weeK was featured by a fair pre-holiday demand for Summer merchandise, but the sales gains were spotty and the average increase for the week ranged around 4 to 5 per cent, department store executives said yesterdav.
George F. Baker, New York banker, stricken with peritonitis, rallied today aboard his Honolulu-bound yacht after navy, Coast Guard and public health service workers raced to his aid by air and sea.

Directors of the Virginia Carolina Chemical Corporation declared yesterday against arrears a dividend of $1.50 a share on the 6 per cent participating preferred stock After this payment, accumulations will amount to $53.50 a share.
Electric corporations in New York State with revenues exceeding $250,000 a year are affected by new accounting procedure outlined by the Public Service Commission in an announcement yesterday.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $13,789,603, to be represented by three States and forty-three municipalities. This compares with the revised total for this week of $8,048,058.
The following detailed notice defining the future status of the Duke of Windsor and his bride-to-be appeared tonight in the official London Gazette:

Miss Katherine Frances Wertheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanders A. Wertheim of this place and New York, was married here this morning in St. Mary's Church to Clement Graham Larkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Larkin of Newark.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 26: COMMANDER Smith, R. C., the Oglala, to treatment at the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Geheres, L. E., Pensacola, Fla., to the staff of the Commander of Carrier Division 2 as Operations Officer.
Advices received today said government authorities had frustrated a plot calling for an expedition of 3,000 soldiers from Insurgent-held Majorca Island to seize the island. of Minorca.

All but 2,400 of the 7,400 barbers in the Times Square, Grand Central and downtown sections of Manhattan and in the Bronx, who were on strike, returned to work yesterday under agreements signed with two master barbers associations and 300 independent boss barbers, it was announced by John Tartamella, international representative of the Journeymen Barbers Union.

The Milwaukee Railroad hailed today its streamlined speed train, the Hiawatha, as a financial success, reporting that the flier clipped off a net profit of $2.49 at every milepost-and it passes a post each minute.

Dr. William H. Kllpatrlck, veteran Teachers College educator, who is slated to retire at the end of this year as a result of an age ruling, announced yesterday that he had accepted an invitation from Dr. E. O. Melby,

The St. Augustine's High School nine tightened its grasp on the lead in the Brooklyn Division of the C. H. S. A. A. race yesterday by downing St. Michael's High, 12-3, at the Prospect Park Parade Grounds.

Essex came through with its third victory in five starts today to vault into the runner-up position in English county cricket championship play. The Eastern eleven defeated Kent, its neighbor, by 322 runs at Gravesend.
Miss Alice Ruton Bunnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Bunnell of this city, was married this evening to C. R. Stephen Coryell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Coryell of Orange.
Dr. and Mrs. Walter B. Mount of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Mount, to Frederick C. Marston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Marston of Montclair.

A $10,000,000 mining deal, the largest in Nevada in many years, brought sudden riches today to the Austin family, enterprising operators of a small desert hotel and general store in the rugged hills northwest of Winnemucca.

The recent course of events in agricultural markets goes far to show the hazards and imperfections of governmental planning for the crops. In its 1936 report the Agricultural Department thus summed up the Government's achievement:

Phil Duey and Clyde Bain of Bonnie Briar and Ellgio and Marie Del Guercio of the Westchester Country Club emerged today as the finalists in the best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Bonnie Briar Country Club.
Lionel Munn and Robert Sweeny will play for the British amateur golf championship over thirty-six holes at Sandwich tomorrow. Both Ireland and America can put forward claims to the honor.

Alberta has applied to the Dominion Government for a loan to meet the full amount of bonds for $1,650,000 due on June Solon Low, Provincial Treasurer said today. The Federal Government has not yet replied to the request.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation in a letter to stockholders yesterday stated that the proposed issue of $20,285,000 of 31/2 per cent debentures will be convertible at the op tion of the holders at any time into the capital stock of the company at $50 a share.
A brisk pre-holiday rally in United States Government bonds featured yesterday otherwise quiet trading and narrow price movements in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.

Union Electric Light and Power Company of Illinois first mortgage Series A 5% per cent gold bonds due in 1954 have been suspended from dealings by the New York Stock Exchange, having been called for redemption.

Felix M. Warburg counseled the graduating class of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music against any "dreams of appearances in Carnegie or Town Halls to give the cruel critics a I chance to pick you to pieces."

Mrs. Matilda Henderson Atkins, former supervisor and superintendent of private hospitals, died at her home here Wednesday night. She was born in Coxsackie and received professional training at Hudson River State Hospital. Later Mrs.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook ordered yesterday a preliminary examination into the financial and other material arrangements prevailing in the various heavens and extension heavens where Father Divine is worshiped as God.

Cardinal Hayes will bless a monument that has been erected in memory of the Most Rev. John J. Dunn, who was Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, on the grounds of Mount St. Mary-onthe-Hudson,
A strike-harassed employer today offered to turn his business over to the union and go to work for that organization, giving twelve hours a day for $30 weekly, "enough to support my family."

Free this afternoon under $10,000 bail, Thomas E. Elder, former dean of Mount Hermon School for Boys, tonight appealed to a "fellowlodger" at a Keene hotel to help him refute a charge that he intended to kill another retired official of the Northfield school Tuesday night.
A mare's nest of perplexing and unfamiliar radio phenomena at the North Pole is both handicapping the Soviet polar expedition and providing a fruitful and fascinating field for research.

The Hayashi Cabinet was summoned to resign forthwith at a combined meeting of the largest politcial parties, the Minseito and Seiyukai, today. They charged the Cabinet had violated national unity and hindered the carrying out of Japan's defense and continental policies.
Llewellyn Barry, lawyer well known both in Philadelphia and New York, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital at the age of 75. He had been living recently at the Hotel Plaza.
Senate and House conferees agreed today on a compromise Civilian Conservation Corps bill. As the bill passed the House the life of the corps was limited to two years, beginning July 1.

Two of the city's most popular shows are going away after this evening's performances, and both will tour during the coming season. They are "Victoria Regina" which, in two incarnations, has rolled up a run of 515 performances at the Broadhurst Theatre, and "King Richard II," now holding the record. run for that play after going on 132 times at the St. James.

Under persistent foreign absorption of contracts, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday, to end unchanged to 6 points higher than on Thursday. With holiday until Tuesday and no adequate rainfall in sight in the Southwest, operators were not inclined to furnish contracts over he week-end.

Mrs. Marie J. Correll, 32, was granted a divorce today from Charles J. Correll, the "Andy" of the radio team of "Amos 'n' Andy." Mrs. Correll charged two instances of cruelty, one being a slap in the face on Christmas Eve, and said the radio performer deserted her May 1 when they were in Palm Springs, Calif.

Industrialization of the Irish Free State is reflected in its reduction of imports of ready-mixed paints, coldwater paints and enamels from 6,390,000 pounds in 1931 to 1,341,000 pounds in 1936, according to a report made public today by the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce.

Louis H. Egan, president of the Union Electric Light and Power Company, said today that preliminary steps had been taken for a refunding operation intended to retire $92,041,200 in bonds and preferred stock, mostly bearing interest at 5 per cent, of the company and its subsidiaries.

The "Pavilion of Israel in Palestine" was opened at the Paris Exposition this afternoon in the presence of French and British officials. Dr. N. Goldmann, permanent Geneva representative of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, stressed in a speech that the organization he represented was bent upon establishing and consolidating friendly relations with the Arab peoples.
At a time when other countries have turned to their young men for leadership, conservative Britain now calls an old man to the highest position in the State.

Washington Arms, a seventy-twofamily apartment house at 180th Street and Washington Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Second Junior Corporation to Chesterbrook Estates, Ltd., a syndicate of investors headed by Herman L. Bitterman.
Henderson E. Van Surdam has been appointed executive secretary of the Hotel Sales Managers Association to serve until the regular Fall meeting, when a permanent appointment will be considered. Mr.
Canadian Government, provincial and municipal financing in May amounted to $156,897,614, the largest for the month in the last five years, according to figures compiled by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

Jurisdiction of the American Newspaper Guild is limited to the newsroom, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, ruled in identical telegrams dispatched to Seattle's three daily newspapers. Receipt of the telegrams was disclosed today.

While the nation's military dead will be honored tomorrow and Monday at Memorial Day exercises, a survey of veterans' hospitals here and throughout the country revealed yesterday that the Federal Government had not forgotten to care for the disabled veterans of its wars.

AMERICAN MOTOR PRODUCTS CORP., 160 Varick St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $108,332 and assets of. $115,176. The petition states the corporation has lost nearly $50,000 on government contracts.
Stanley Baldwin was thrice Great Britain's Prime Minister, and both in victory and defeat he stood out as a typical Englishman who did not permit himself to be unduly disturbed by either.
Twenty thousand members of the newly organized Portuguese Legion in all parts of Portugal celebrated today the eleventh anniversary of the present regime.

George H. Moore, 34 years old, who was arrested in Baltimore four days ago when he said he was the man who fatally stabbed Municipal Court Justice John F. O'Neil last April 21, denied yesterday to Assistant District Attorney Marro in the Homicide Bureau he had any connection with the slaying.

Indications yesterday were that Mickey Cochrane has started on the it long climb back to health. At St. Elizabeth's Hospital, where the Detroit Tigers' manager was taken from the Yankee Stadium last Tuesday suffering from multiple fractures of the skull after being accidentally hit in the head by one of Irving (Bump) Hadley's pitches, Dr. Robert Emmet Walsh issued the following bulletin last night:

The question of today before the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America was whether it should take a stand on the President's program for reorganization of the judiciary.
President Roosevelt announced today that he would leave tomorrow night for a short visit to his mother's house in Hyde Park, N. Y., returning here Tuesday or Wednesday.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals took under advisement today the appeal of the Madison Square Garden Corporation for an injunction to prevent James. J. Braddock, world heavyweight boxing champion, from fighting Joe Louis in Chicago June 22.

Inspired by their victory in getting a closed shop contract, wage increases and better working conditions from the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, leaders of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, moved yesterday to extend their sway to all transportation agencies in the city.
"Darling Nellie Gray" will be sung again Sunday, June 13, in the little house here where Benjamin R. Hanby wrote it eighty-two years ago when he was 22 years old.

The Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors recommended today the dredging of Flushing Bay and Creek to a depth of 12 feet for a channel 160 to 200 feet wide and an anchorage basin to a depth of 8 feet, at an estimated cost of $505,000.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated May -27: COLONELS Jones, C. (C.A.C.). General Staff Corps, two days leave, June 1. Dravo, C. A., Inf., Fort Moultrie, S. C., to duty as adjutant general, Militia of the District of Columbia, Washington, D. C., about Sept. 1.

Each of the following reserve officers, unassigned. is assigned to the organization indicated: 40TH INFANTRY (RAI) 1st Lt. Herbert N. Cowles, Inf.-Res., 254 Seaman Ave., New York. N. Y. 1st Lt. John A. Darcy. Inf.-Res., 221 W. 15th St., New York, N. Y.
The Interstate' Commerce Commission has authorized W. W. Smith and William McCullcy Strunk, both of Philadelphia, to operate as common motor carriers.

John Dominick Lore of 244 East Twenty-first Street, who was mustered into and out of the army on Nov. 11, 1918, brought suit yesterday to compel Purchase Commissioner Russel Forbes to restore him to the city payroll as a pharmacist at $1,680 a year.

The one-family dwelling at 525 Highview Avenue, Ardsley, Westchester County, has been sold for occupancy to Albert Gauthier. The National City Bank of Troy, trustee, was the seller. Roemer, Kenny Company, Inc., were the brokers in the deal, with John G. S. Swanston acting as co-broker.

Three hundred and eight winning tickets were drawn in the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes at Dublin yesterday for that many or more residents of New York City and near-by New Jersey and Connecticut points, the lucky ones among the estimated 4,000,000 Americans who had purchased counterfoils at $2.50 each.
Miss Margaret S. Vauclain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Vauclain of Overbrook, was married this afternoon to John R. Roberts, son of 'Mrs. Charles P. Roberts of Hamilton Court.

The end of a fortnight's talks by the British and dominion Prime Ministers and other delegates to the Imperial Conference today found them generally agreed on proposals for voluntary empire cooperation in wartime, but at least uncertain about one of the cardinal points of discussion-the proposed Anglo-American commercial treaty.
Communism and the child labor amendment were assailed here today as the State convention of the Knights of Columbus began its business sessions.

Mrs. Mary Clark Hopkins, widow of E. Washburn Hopkins, Professor of Sanskrit at Yale for three decades, died tonight after a long illness. Her age was 74. Surviving are a sister, Mrs. M. Gustav Schwab of New York, and five sons, including Professor Clark Hopkins of the University of Michigan, Professor Francis Hopkins of and Howard Hopkins of Washington, D. C.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Erikson of this city gave a reception this afternoon and evening to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. They were married in New York at the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church.

Johnny Marcum, who started the season with four victories and then was belted out four times in a row, came back with all his stuff today and pitched the Red Sox to a 7-to-0 victory over the Senators.

Meeting yesterday in Boston, the Allied Kid Company's shareholders voted to simplify the capital structure by eliminating all classes of stock other 'than the authorized 300,000 shares of $5 par value common stock.
The Pennsylvania Title Association reelected all but one of its officers here today at the close of its sixteenth annual convention in the Hotel Claridge.
Two bills amending the election law to guard against fraudulent designating and independent nominating petitions in New York City were signed today by Governor Lehman.

James (Big Jim) Shortell, who as deputy sheriff transferred hundreds of convicts from the Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn to Sing Sing and other State penal institutions for the last twenty-two years, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 810 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn.

Blow Advertising Co, 6,000 sq ft in Nine Rockefeller Plaza, Rockefeller Center; Irving Judis, broker. Marcella Johnson Studio, fashion model instruction. in International Building; . A. Owen Publishing Co, in Nine Rockefeller Plaza, Rockefeller Center leases.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market continues generally quiet, with little indication as yet from the piece goods market of the trend for the new season.

WHILE waiting around for the big three-day battle to start in all directions, there is time for a brief survey of a somewhat complicated situation. In advance, the Davis Cup contest between our gallant court-coverers and the distinguished visitors from Australia looks like a stand-off. But, under the rules, they will play to a decision. Adrian Quist has been under the weather.
Glynhir Golden, white wire-haired fox terrier with tan head and markings, swept away all opposition today to gain the highest honors in the fiftyfifth specialty show of the American Fox Terrier Club.
Dedication of the James A. Ten Eyck Boathouse, new home of Syracuse University crews, was marked today by a reunion of 125 former Orange oarsmen.

Prices of grains, except July corn, dropped sharply today with general selling developing in wheat, which disclosed a lack of aggressive support until the last fifteen minutes of the session on the Board of Trade here, when a moderate rally got under way.

The death from a pistol shot early yesterday morning of Mrs. Charles Starbuck was officially listed as a suicide today by Coroner E. Hall Kline of Rockland County, after an inquest at State police headquarters here. Mrs. Starbuck was 28 years old, the former Miss Gertrude Waltho Balliett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton James Balliett of Manhattan. She had been a member of the Junior League.
The business of the Canadian General Electric Company this year is close to 50 per cent ahead of that a year ago, according to A. E. Dyment, chairman.

Elder Ave (14-3739), w s, 300 ft s of Westchester Ave, 100x1OO; Jador Holding Corp to Primel Realty Corp, 211 W 145th St. 182 St (11-3143), n s, 100 ft w of Webster Ave, 80x100; North Side Savings Bank to Johnad Realty Corp, 2,380 Grand Concourse; mtg $26,000. Vyse Ave (11-3131). e s, 64 ft s of 179th St, 50x86; Edbar Realty Co, Inc, to 2,012 Vyse Ave Corp, 349 E 149th St; mtg 530,850.

A thousand steel strikers marching on the South Chicago mill of the Republie Steel Corporation were beaten back by police tonight after a sharp fight. Twenty strikers were injured, two so seriously they required hospital treatment.
The Rev. Dr. Schurmann Haisted Watkins, retired Protestant Episcopal minister of Arlington, Vt., died Thursday at the Albany Hospital, Albany, N. Y. He was 74 years old.

Nicholas Duffy, a public official here since 1898, died early today in the United Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 68 years old. Flags on village buildings will be flown at half-mast for thirty days.

Professor Robert A. Millikan, physicist of Pasadena, Calif., struck out forcefully tonight against what he termed efforts to turn the world's thoughts from facts to "irrationalism" when he addressed a gathering of Danish scientists as the guest of the American-Scandinavian Foundation.
Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, six times national champion, regained the Philadelphia district women's golf championship today by defeating
Fifty members of the Workers Alliance who tried to stage a sit-in at City Hall yesterday were removed from the Board of Estimate chamber by a dozen policemen who yanked them from their seats.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan said today the matter of toasts did not arise while he was High Commissioner to the Philippines, but added that the longer "Paul V. McNutt stays there the higher he will be regarded."

The Interchemical Corporation, formerly the International Printing Ink Corporation, has proposed to the Standard Textile Products Company a substantial investment by Interchemical in Standard Textile, as reorganized, it was announced yesterday.

The Tower Mutual Insurance Company of Cincinnati today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to suspend for one year Rule 8, fixed under the Motor Carrier Act of 1935, which requires insurance companies covering motor carriers to be licensed in all States traversed by the carrier operations.
Two financiers from New York told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that investment trusts should be regulated.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a tenement house at Third Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street to cost $140,000. Othe building activity consisted of plans for altering various structures in Manhattan. Several small homes were projected in Brooklyn and Queens.

Rebellious House Democrats, who had joined in the movement to earmark more than a third of the $1,500,000,000 work-relief appropriation for purposes other than work relief, advanced a compromise late today by which only $223,000,000 would be set aside instead of the $505,000,000 already tentatively voted.

The Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company filed suit yesterday in the Supreme Court to foreclose a $1,000,000 mortgage it holds on the former home of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church at Madison Avenue and Sixtloth Street.

The reaction to Premier Benito Mussolini's suggestion that President Roosevelt shall take action toward world disarmament takes two forms, official and public, which are alike only in withholding from II Duce's proposal the slightest credit for either goodwill or good faith.
The big bat of Hank Greenberg, who played despite a strained leg muscle, aided the Tigers to a double victory over the Browns today and put them in second place in the American League.
Eugene Seligman, retired lawyer, left a gross estate of $1,212,525 and a net estate of $1,126,005, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. He died Nov. 28, 1936, at the age of 79.

The Maritime Commission today rejected the bids received yesterday on twenty-eight obsolete vessels and announced plans to readvertise under terms which would give consideration to the Maritime Navigation Company of Nova Scotia, the only foreign bidder. It was expected that the new bids would be opened Thursday. July 8.

Mrs. Louise G. Pollak, wife of Dr. Berthold S. Pollak, medical director of the Hudson County Tuberculosis Hospital, died this afternoon of a heart ailment at her home on the hospital grounds at Secaucus, N. J. Mrs. Pollak was stricken on Wednesday.

Harry C. Perry, Tammany leader of the Nineteenth Assembly District, is facing a serious primary fight to retain his leadership with half a dozen Negro candidates and Martin J. Healy, former leader, in the field against him.

With groups of United States tourists out of gasoline and stalled in many parts of Mexico as a result of the nation-wide strike against foreign petroleum companies, United States consulates are attempting to arrange for the sale of sufficient motor fuel to alleviate their situation.

A capacity crowd of 23,000 sweltering spectators watched the all-star European amateur boxing team fight the Chicago Golden Glove team on even terms in the Chicago Stadium tonight. Each team won four bouts.

More than 200 young people, ranging in age from 5 to 23, have already enrolled in the ninth annual National Piano Playing Tournament, New York division, which begins Tuesday at the Wanamaker Auditorium, it was announced by Irl Allison, local chairman.
The Pure Oil Company's directors called today for redemption on July 1 the outstanding balance of $28,500,000 of fifteen-year 41/4 per cent sinkingfund notes.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson of 277 Park Avenue gave a dinner and supper party last night in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria to celebrate the twentyfifth anniversary of their marriage.

General Francisco Franco, chief of the Insurgent forces, was reported tonight to have ordered the exile of the onetime leader of the powerful Fascist Falange, Manuel Hedilla. It was reported he would go to Germany.

President McConaughy of Wesleyan University has a busy schedule in June. Besides officiating at the three-day commencement week-end at Wesleyan from June 18 to 20 he will take part in seven other events.
Not everybody in and around New York changes his residence every two years, as the general impression goes.

Opposing compulsory arbitration in labor disputes, Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan, addressing National Conference of Social Work tonight, outlined a "positive role" which the government might play as an impartial moderator in bringing about peace and orderliness in industrial relations.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 22 amounted to 779,276 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
