William Perry Doing continued yesterday his Manhattan realty operations with the sale of the six-story elevator apartment house at 549 West 163d Street to G. R. Estates, Inc., represented by M. A. Rabinovitch.

The refusal of Sir John Simon, Home Secretary, to submit to the King the address reaffirming the loyalty of the Roman 'Catholics of the realm, was termed a "mere impertinence" by The Universe, Roman Catholic weekly, in its current issue published today.

Award of architectural contracts for five World's Fair exhibition buildings, with a total estimated erection cost of $1,500,000, was announced yesterday by Grover Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

Testimony for Standard Brands, Inc., in defense of an alleged violation of the Robinson-Patman act, brought by the Federal Trade Commission, was concluded yesterday at the final hearing held at 45 Broadway.
A suitcase full of rare currency was hacked to pieces and burned today at the Treasury. Authorities said it would have been worth $1,000,000 in the collectors' market.
President Roosevelt announced that he would send to Congress a request for an inquiry into income tax evasions and for corrective legislation.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended March 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges of $7,591,190, comparing wi.h a net of $6,217.965 in the twelve months ended March 31, 1936.

Retired Captain Samuel Allcorn, formerly a member of Engine 265, residing at 390 Bainbridge St., Brooklyn, died May 27. Funeral will take place from the Fairchild Funeral Parlor, 86 Lefferts Pl., Brooklyn, at 10 A. M., Monday, May 31. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 15th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

One-sixth of the steel-producing capacity of the United States is now crippled by the most severe strike which this industry has experienced in years. Other industries-particularly the manufacture of glass, the manufacture of automobiles and the shipping industry--have suffered heavily from strikes in recent months.

In line with his American method of conducting his election campaign for the Presidency, Armando Salles de Oliviera was reported today to have chartered a steamer to take him northward for speech-making.

Miss Maria Gerard Messenger, benefactor of churches and philanthropic institutions in central Westchester County for more than a half century, died last night at the Orchards, her home here. She was 87 years old and tomorrow would have been her birthday.
The Dionne quintuplets, happy and well, paraded their lively spirits before the world tonight in celebration of their third birthday by beating toy drums and singing into a radio microphone.

Basque forces this morning recaptured Hill 11, which is the northern apex of the triangle of three hills near Orduna, twenty-two miles south of Bilbao, lost to the Insurgents Wednesday. The hill is 1,500 feet high and confronts the other hills, San Pedro and Sobrehayas, which still are in Insurgent hands.

Cuban exports in 1936 were valued at $154,847,000, compared with $128,017,000, while imports were valued at $103,215,000, compared with $95,465,000, resulting in an advance of the favorable trade balance from $32,552,000 in 1935 to $51,632,000 in 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today.

New York City courts are so laden with gross political patronage grabs that a new method of selecting judges must be found, the law reform committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York declared in a report made public yesterday.

East Broadway, 124, n s 22.2x63.4. John P. Yelton to Henrletta H. Clulow; 5 Scroope Terrace, Cambridge, England; deed dated June 30, 1932. Monroe St. 125 n s, 25.11x104; John P. Yelton to Henrietta H. Clulow; 5 Scroope Terrace, Cambridge, England; deed dated June 16 1932.

Mayor La Guardia, In behalf of "the children of New York," accepted yesterday a bronze bird bath created by Mrs. Bessie Potter Vonnoh as a memorial to Mrs. Frances Hodgson Burnett, author of "Little Lord Fauntleroy" and other popular novels.

President Roosevelt came to the aid today of the ever-normal-granary legislation now facing an uphill battle in the House Agriculture Committee. He stated during his press conference that it was his "hope" that the measure might be adopted before adjournment of the present session.

While a score of men were working yesterday afternoon in the north tube of the new Lincoln Tunnel under construction between West Thirty eighth Street, Manhattan, and Weehawken, N. J., an explosion showered them with ragged chunks of rock, killing- three and injuring four-others. The blast occurred 130 feet east of the Weehawken entrance.
The Empire Gas and Electric Company has been merged into the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, it has been announced.

Ever since March 15, when the tax returns were considerably below what the Treasury had expected, there has been a great deal of concern in Washington regarding " tax avoidance." The President has finally spoken about the matter and cited examples of it.

President Roosevelt vetoed today, as discriminatory, a bill extending for the fourth time the date on which the term insurance written for soldiers and sailors under the War Risk Insurance Act must be converted into permanent insurance.
The veteran Harry Smythe pitched the Montreal Royals into second place today, holding the Toronto Leafs to seven hits while his mates collected fourteen to gain a 9-3 triumph.
Forty-five members of the yearling and graduating classes of the United States Military Academy are expected to spend their Summer vacation this year in Ecuador.
The Barrett Cup, awarded annually to the Dartmouth senior showing the greatest promise, has been won by Donald C. McKinlay of Chicago.

Three Cardinal pitchers were unable to stop an avalanche of doubles by the slugging Pirates today and the league leaders easily captured the first of a four-game series, 10 to 3. It was Pittsburgh's first victory since last Saturday.

William Church Osborn of New York applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to be a director of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company, to which position he was elected by the stockholders on May 11.

The stock markets were quiet and generally weaker today. Gilt-edge loans were dull and most of the issues lost ground. Foreign loans were inactive. International stocks were irregular, United States Steel being among the strong features of this section.
Leon,Barzin will conduct and Ar nold Eidus will be violin soloist at the first Naumburg concert tomorrow evening at 8:15 in the Central Park Mall.

When Mrs. Helen K. Harper, 33 years old, mother of a 10-year-old daughter, was sentenced yesterday to a term of three to six years in the Westfield State Farms at Bedford Hills for the theft of $57,824 from her former employers, General Sessions Judge Donnellan scored her husband, James. Harper, as a "ne'er-do-well who frequents barrooms."
Private unit banking may disappear if it fails to fulfill its functions properly, the floating convention of the New York State Bankers Association was told today.

Magazines and newspapers were illustrated both in black and white and in color before the late FREDERIC E. IVES was born in 1856; yet the thousands of periodicals that depend on illustrations today have reason to pause for a moment and honor his memory.

A strike of longshoremen on the Munson Line pier was threatened yesterday over a radio operator's employment but it was averted when officials of the line assured pier workers that the man would be retained.

The senior ball of the class of '37 of Barnard College will be held tonight in Barnard Hall on the campus. Among those invited are Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard, Miss Mabel Foote Weeks, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Read,

The Florida Senate asked the House today to. join in ordering a legislative investigation of published charges that Miami racing interests bribed State officials during the administration of former Governor Dave Sholtz.
Miss Alice Marble, American singles champion, reached the final round of the Middlesex tennis championships today, defeating Miss Mary Whitmarsh of Great Britain, 6-3, 6-0.
Annual Memorial Service of the Honor Legion of the Police Department for members killed in action in the World War, Police Headquarters, 10:45 A. M. Address by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

Plans for the new parish house connecting with St. James Protestant Episcopal Church on the upper East Side of Manhattan were filed with the Manhattan Department of Buildings yesterday by Grosvenor Atterbury, architect. The estimated cost of the new structure is $140,000.
To Sports Editor of The Neto York Times: The new Randalls Island Stadium out in the East River under one of the spans of the Triborough Bridge is now one of the finest arenas for sports in the East.
Miss Sara Allen of Cranford, N. J., a junior at Mount Holyoke College, has been awarded the Kathryn Irene Glascock Memorial poetry prize.

Mrs. Winifred Hathaway of New York, associate director of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, has been selected by the St. Louis Society for the Blind as the 1937 winner of the Leslie Dana gold medal, awarded annually for outstanding work in conservation of vision.

Directors of the Standard Bank of South Africa, Ltd., have decided to transfer [Pound]500,000 (roughly$2,500,000) from the contingency ,account to the reserve fund, thereby restoring part of the amount transferred from the reserve fund to the contingency account in the year ended on March 31, 1932, according to advices received yesterday by the local agency of the bank.
Insurgent General Francisco Franco's war planes, in a surprise dawn attack on Valencia today, killed an estimated 200 persons, bombed ships in the harbor and demolished buildings.
Philip Northrop Miller, senior partner in the New York accounting firm of Miller, Donaldson Co., died today at his home here, 234 Irving Avenue, after a short illness. He was 52 years old.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are May 27 unless specified: At San Pedro: Argonne, Vestal. At Norfolk Yard: Downes, May 28; Tucker. At San Francisco: Langley, Wright. At Pearl Harbor: Montgomery. Ramsay. Drayton, Norfolk Yard to sea, May 28. Hannibal, survey area to Cristobal, May 28. Isabel, Ichange to Hankow, May 28. Kalmia, at San Diego.

All city churches will mark Memorial Day tomorrow. American Legion Posts and other patriotic organizations will attend special services. Monday being the eightieth birthday of Pope Plus XI, every church in the Archdiocese of New York will have a mass

Cram's Reports, Inc., reports today automobile production for the current week at 134,940 cars and trucks, compared with a revised estimate of 181,306 units last week and 109,821 in the week ended on May 30 last year.

Seven cars of a Washington-bound Pennsylvania Railroad express left the rails in the Bay View yard here tonight, injuring six persons slightly. The wreck was believed due to a faulty rail or wheel flange.
This city became a musical mecca today for devotees of Johann Sebastian Bach as the famous Bethlehem Bach Choir of 265 voices, conducted by Dr. Bruce Carey, began its thirtieth annual festival.

Major Hans Hugo Witt of the German Air Corps, a passenger who escaped from the airship Hindenburg when it was destroyed by fire at Lakehurst, N. J., on May 6, told the Department of Commerce investigating board yesterday that the Zeppelin company had received sabotage warnings before sending the dirigible on her final voyage to the United States.

The holiday exodus from the city has started. For this week-end at least, fishing will furnish recreation to thousands of city dwellers who may utilize this opportunity to visit that friend who lives so conveniently close to a trout stream, or make that salt-water trip they have been discussing for the past few weeks.
"Drink good whisky, eat meat and potatoes and smoke good cigars if you want to be as old as I am," Daniel Demarest of 32 South Prospect Street said today, his ninety-ninth birthday.

The Cubs reached four Cincinnati pitchers for a total of fourteen hits today to score a 12-to-3 victory in the opener of a four-game series. Charlie Root limited the Reds to eight hits to win his fourth game of the season.

Most commodity futures in the local markets displayed yesterday a typical pre-holiday tone in lessened activity. Sugar, coffee, silk, wool top, copper, tin, lead and zinc futures held steady, but cocoa, rubber, hide and cottonseed oil futures eased. In the cash markets,
Miss Helen Jacobs's bid for the French hardcourt singles tennis championship failed today for the seventh time.

What is described by Yale University Press executives as one of the most important publications ever undertaken by the Press, will be introduced in October when the first two volumes of the Yale Edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence will be published.

The American Can Company will launch its Spring and Summer advertising campaign on Keglined beer cans about the middle of next month in 134 newspapers in the principal beer-consuming markets of the country and, in space ranging up to 1,000 lines, will continue it until Labor Day.

Summer shoes that are a riot of color have appeared in the shops They will be dashing compliments to the gay gowns one can wear all day long or in the evening. These gowns, with their flared or uneven hemlines that carry the eye naturally to the feet, make the shoes worn with them exceedingly important.

IN the forty-eight States, Hawaii and Alaska there are twenty-six national parks, covering almost 14,000 square miles. In most of them are spacious areas allotted to the camper and trailer-dweller, but thought is now being given to the necessity for increasing present facilities.

A brave attempt by Tony Manero to add the match play title to the national medal play crown he won in such glorious fashion at Baltusrol last year foundered today when Denny Shute, defending Professional Golfers Association champion, beat him in the semi-final round.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Eagles of Montclair, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Eagles of Newark, to James Edwin Knowlton of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Knowlton of Sunset, Deer Isle, Me., took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. R. P. M. Eagles of this city.
ONE difference between Fifth Avenue and Piccadilly is the heraldic zoo of lions and unicorns which adorns every fourth or fifth shop front in Piccadilly.
Matchmaker James J. Johnston of Madison Square Garden said tonight he will try to match Max Schmeling of Germany and Bob Pastor of New York for a heavyweight bout in June.

As president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women, Miss Lena Madesin Phillips of New York will sail tomorrow on the S. S. Pilsudski for Stockholm, to preside at the meeting of the board of directors June 15 to 18. Participants in the deliberations, which Miss Phillips designated yesterday as the most important in the history of the organization, will include representatives from many European countries.

Continued rumors from the Continent of Europe that the price of gold was about to slip caused an upset in the bullion market here today. When the large total of 419 bars, worth about [Pound]1,178,000, was offered at 140s 9d a fine ounce, or 3d above yesterday's rice. there were no buyers.

The death of J. Henry Roraback, for twenty-five years head of the Republican party in Connecticut, not only leaves the party with three vacancies in major offices, but creates a situation in which a different plan of party control seems certain.

Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Heath Hinsdale of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Hinsdale, to John Paul Faude, son of Mrs. Paul Faude, also of West Hartford, and the late Mr. Faude.

Recent open-house demonstrations in the Science Departments at Wheaton, the first for students, faculty and their guests, and another especially for alumnae, have stimulated campus interest in the laboratories and explained many things which formerly were mysteries to non-scientific visitors.

The body of Norman Prince, killed in World War service with the famous Lafayette Escadrille, will arrive here Tuesday from France. Burial of the flier will take place at Washington Cathedral in a sanctuary provided by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince of Boston. The body has been in the Pro-Cathedral of Paris.
Eligio and Mario De Guercio of the Westchester Country Club today captured the best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Bonnie Briar Country Club.

FIVE seconds on the brink of the Grand Canyon at sun down and you absorb more religion than any man-built church could give you in 10,000 years. A week of it and you forget there's another world outside.

Miss B. Isabel Boren, daughter of Addison Boren of this city and the late Mrs. Boren, was married this afternoon in the First Congregational Church, to John Jerome Brennan of Kansas City, Mo., son of Mrs. Josephine Brennan of St. Louis, by the Rev. Allan Hackett, minister of the church.
I AM ravished, ravished , with what I see," wrote Van Gogh from Arles. "It absorbs me so much that I

There are puzzles but no surprises in the composition of the Chamberlain Cabinet which received the seals of office from the King on Friday. Though the Conservatives retained fifteen of the twenty-one chief posts, the "national" character of the new Ministry is determined by the inclusion,
The sixth annual Westchester Flower Show will open its doors at the County Center in White Plains Wednesday afternoon, June 9, and will continue for the rest of the week.

Miss Eleanor May Class, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Class of 315 Riverside Drive, was married to Frederick J. Burfeindt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeachine Burfeindt, also of this city, and Truesdale Lake, N. Y., yesterday noon at the Plaza by the Rev. Cecil C. Hine.

OF the many unwarranted generalizations regarding the Soviet Union none is more pernicious and offensive than the alas! only too readily accepted assertion that no one can write about the U. S. S. R. in an objective and judicial manner.

FROM the time a small group of business men foregathered beneath a buttonwood tree at the easterly end of Wall Street a few years after the Revolutionary War, to "buy and sell public stocks," the ro1e of the stockbroker in the financial drama has varied as greatly as the markets with which he has been concerned.

Four hundred and ninety children were cared for last year at St. Joseph's Burghardville, a convalescent home at Palenville, N. Y., for children recently discharged from New York hospitals, according to the annual report of Mother Superior M. Rudolphine of the Franciscan Missionaries of Mary, who conduct St. Joseph's.

It seemed to this observer of the week's technical events that of all those who testified at Lakehurst Dr. Hugo Eckener advanced a plausibel hypothesis of the manner in which the Hindenburg came to her horrible end.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Robert Scandrett Holbrook of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances Irving Holbrook to Nelson Childs Freeland of New York and Sea Girt, N. J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Freeland of Philadelphia.

The large bronze efficiency trophy, awarded annually by the New York Society, Military and Naval Officers of the World War, was presented this afternoon to Headquarters Battery, Seventh Coast Artillery, after a review on the parade grounds.

At the home of Mr. and Mrs. William R. C. Stephenson of Edge Hill Road in Brookline yesterday their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Stephenson, was married to Rama A. B. Braggiotti of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Braggiotti of Florence, Italy, and Boston.

A STRONG temptation to the investor in odd lots presents itself at Sotheby's on the twenty-first of next month. It is another remnant of the Vanishing Race of Gutenberg Bibles, a second volume only, and an incomplete copy at that.

Miss Helen Dorothy Lafore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Armand Lafore of Penn Valley Farm, Penn Valley, was married to Edward Logan Forstall, son of Walton Forstall of Rosemont, this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gibson Bell, rector of All Saints Church, Wynnewood, at the home of the bride's parents.

There'll be no beacon fires lighted on the hills to celebrate the passing of the club season, which expires, for the majority of women's groups, this week, although they would be warranted in view of victories registered. But neither will an elegy be sung.

The climax of Field Day and Float Night at Smith College, the vast outdoor program which brings the Spring sports season to a close, came tonight with the announcement of the award of five AllSmith blazers, the highest athletic honor a girl can attain at Smith.

Miss Virginia B. Smith of Albany was announced yesterday as the winner of the fourth annual $500 award of the New York City Panhellenic, with headquarters at the Beekman Tower Hotel. Miss Smith, who is an Alpha Delta Pi, was one of thirty-nine applicants from among members of the twenty-three national fraternities comprising the Panhellenic, which offers the scholarship for graduate work to be done in New York.

The value of permits issued during April for new residential buildings in principal cities throughout the country was 4 per cent greater than in March, according to a report from Washington by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

The condition of Gordon Stanley (Mickey) Cochrane, manager of the Detroit Tigers, who is in St. Elizabeth's Hospital suffering from multiple fractures of the skull, yesterday was so improved that Dr. Robert Emmet Walsh, in charge of the case, declared it unnecessary to issue a formal bulletin.
A 15-year-old Negro girl was shot and wounded seriously yesterday afternoon while watching a motion picture in the Harlem Opera House, 211 West 125th Street, near Seventh Avenue.
THE ASCENT OF F 6" is the third of Auden's remarkable poetic dramas to find some sort of theatre audience in America. His "The Dance of Death" was done briefly in New York by the WPA Federal Theatre.
Nineteen new bungalows have recently been completed at Rockaway Point by the Rockaway Point Realty Development Company which also is expending approximately $94,000 for improvements in the section.

Casualty and surety insurance companies operating in the United States are expected to report in the near future total premiums of more than $1,000,000,000 annually and are likely to pass the fire insurance companies in volume soon unless there is more activity in business and building construction increases, according to Edgar H. Boles, president of the General Reinsurance Corporation and of the North Star Insurance Company.

America, the national Catholic weekly edited by members of the Jesuit Order, withdrew its approbation and retracted its appeal for support of the American Committee for Spanish Relief in an editorial announcement in its issue published yesterday.

While next Friday will mean a full day's outing at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club for some 600 members of the Bond Club of New York, it will mean also for those who have to stay in Wall Street the annual appearance of The Bawl Street Journal.

The United Automobile Workers of America, seeking to unionize the 150,000 Ford Motor Company employes, pushed plans today for another drive at the gates of the company's Rouge plant, largest industrial unit in the world.

The Seawanhaka Yacht Club on Center Island opened the season today with a simple ceremony that put the club formally into commission for 1937 and followed this with a large dinner dance attended by more than 200 members and their guests.

Plans for what is believed to be the most comprehensive program of research in banking and finance ever attempted in this country have been drawn up by the National Bureau of Economic Research in cooperation with the Association of Reserve City Bankers.

Announcement has been made by John Harry Campbell of Mount Vernon, N. Y., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Catharine Sebring Campbell, to Richard Sims Wisner of this city, formerly of Shanghai, China, and Nashville, Tenn., son of Mrs. Percy Francis Wisner of Nashville.

Disposition of the remains of Hernando Cortes, that swashbuckling adventurer who, with a handful of men, conquered Mexico for the glory of Spain and his own enrichment, is a problem with which the Mexican Government must soon deal.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of May 27, 1937, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of orchestral music in day high schools the names of the following applicants who have been granted said license:

Landmarks are disappearing with considerable rapidity in Greenwich Village. A few days ago old New Yorkers were informed that the quaint homes known for more than threequarters of a century as Cottage Row, on the westerly Seventh Ave. nue block front between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets, were being torn down and no physical vestige of them now remains.
Nearly fifty years ago the Dialectic and Philanthropic Societies of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill made a gift of books to the recently founded woman's college in Greensboro.

The Earl of Plymouth, British chairman of the committee of twenty-seven nations on non-intervention in Spain, sailed last week on a tour of the Baltic States. He was reported well content with the progress made by his international group, whose record stands:

Miss Barbara Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Stratford Johnston of this place, was married to Penn Harvey Holsapple, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Taylor Holsapple, also of Scarsdale, here this afternoon in the Hitchcock Memorial Church.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville will open their estate here on June 15 for a garden party to aid the International Garden Club. The proceeds will go to the preservation of the Bartow Mansion, near Pelham Bay Park in New York, the club's headquarters.
The American New Deal, in due course, produced a New Deal in Canada. In Canada, as in the United States, the Supreme Court killed certain regimenting features.

Marjorie Mansur of Spencer, Mass., president of the class of '38 at Stoneleigh College, has been reelected to serve as president of the class next year. Mary Flint, '38, of Fitchburg, Mass., was elected as president of the Student Government Association.
Mrs. Louise Wise Francis, heiress to part of the fortune of the late Henry M. Flagler, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit. Mrs.
Pennsylvania, fresh from its victory over Harvard, could not keep step with Columbia in the closing innings today and lost an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on Franklin Field, 7--5.

With one of the most courageous and stirring finishes ever witnessed by a gallery in New Jersey, Mrs. Marion Turpie of Plandome added the women's metropolitan golf championship to her Long Island title today by defeating Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, 1 up, in the 36-hole final.

MR. CROWTHER'S famous American men of science are only four-Benjamin Franklin, Joseph Henry, Josiah Willard Gibbs and Thomas Alva Edison. These are presented not as heroes who stand apart but as social products of the periods in which they lived.

The President's proposal for Federal regulation of hours and wages, transmitted to Congress this week, embodied in bills introduced by Senator Black and Representative Connery and scheduled for committee hearings beginning next Tuesday, marks another step toward the piecemeal restoration of parts of the old NRA.

Unless Jewish immigration to Palestine ceases immediately, another uprising, far worse than any of the seven that have occurred, faces the Jews in the Holy Land, Dr. Izzat Tannous, member of the National Arab-Palestine Commission, predicted yesterday.

More than 3,000,000 graves of veterans who served in one or more of the wars fought by this country have been located in New Jersey by WPA investigators, according to William H. J. Ely, State WPA Administrator.
Amelia Earhart announced tonight that she would take off "soon" in a second attempt to circle the globe, flying from west to east in the equatorial zone this time.
The Naval Academy's June Week began officially today with a program of varied events, attended by thousands of persons from all parts of the country.

WHAT station or network will be the first to broadcast from the North Pole, now that the Russians are sitting on top of the world? Such a cooling broadcast from a tent studio, walled in by snow fences, suggests itself as ideal and most refreshing for listeners sweltering in the land of summertime.

Describing a failure of courage as the chief threat to liberalism today, Rabbi Maurice Eisendrath of Toronto, in a sermon to the annual meeting of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, today attacked a tendency to reaction which he declared to be present in modern Jewish religious life.
The second Spring season of the Metropolitan Opera Association went into the records last night with the presentation of an old standby: Verdi's "Il Trovatore."

ANOTEWORTHY semi-novelty was Perosi's recent "Inno al Gran Sasso d'Italia," a motet originally scored for voices alone (so premiered at Aquila last September) and now heard for the first time anywhere at San Remo with his new orchestral accompaniment, under the composer's baton, as closing pezzo grosso of the Riviera season.

A second place by Edgar Mason in the 220-yard dash, last event on the Randalls Island program, gave Pittsburgh a halfpoint triumph over Columbia in the battle for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championship. Pitt finished with 30 1/2 points, Columbia with 30. John Woodruff, Olympic titleholder, took two firsts for the winners, while Ben Johnson of the runner-up squad was the victor in three contests.

The Federal Reserve Board today announced the designation of W. H. Kettig of Birmingham, Ala., as chairman and Federal Reserve agent at the Federal Reserve Bank at Atlanta for the remainder of this year.

Sales of real estate in Manhattan reported yesterday included several purchases of housing properties by investors. Some of the buyers paid all cash for their properties. An investor bought from Embassy Estates, Inc., the six-story apartment house at 6 Jones Street in the second deal in five months involving the property.

Pickets picketed pickets at a downtown fiveand-ten cent store of the McCrory chain today. A tall, raw-boned Negro in prison stripes and two Negro women, dressed as Southern "mammies," marched beside union pickets, who were assigned to the store by three unions, seeking recognition as bargaining agents.
The marriage of Miss Juditha Arati, daughter of Mrs. Onorato Arati of this place and the late Mr. Arati, to Rodman Parsons Getty, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tolan Getty of Brick Top.
A murder charge was filed today against W. H. Redding, a Los Angeles policeman, for the shooting of Norman ("Big Bill") Gregg, a San Pedro longshoreman and World War veteran.

Robert Boyer, a senior student in the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics of New York University, won the Chance Vought Airplane Design Prize for 1937, it was announced yesterday by Thorndike Saville, dean of the College of Engineering. Mr. Boyer, son of Dr.

A special isophonic curved ceiling, designed to produce almost perfect who acoustics, will be installed in the new Princeton Playhouse, one of the units in the $4,500,000 Civic Square under construction here in the business section of the town.

Josephus Daniels, Ambassador to Mexico, said today that the "doctrine of laissez faire is on the scrap heap" and that "people properly look to the government to touch life at every point necessary for the public weal."

Interest in stocks almost faded out in today's two-hour session of the Toronto Stock Exchange, only 184,500 shares changing hands, the smallest number since Oct. 12, 1935. Despite the scant buying, the index of industrial shares closed about 1/4 point higher; that of the gold-mining issues gained 3/4 point, while the miscellaneous mines indicator dropped 2 points.
The Cubs swept a double bill with the Reds at Wrigley Field today, winning both games by the same score, 4 to 2. More than 20,000 fans saws the Bruins extend their winning streak to three games.

Dennis A. O'Neill, 36-year-old lawyer, was killed with a razor in his home in the Curren Terrace section today during a quarrel with his father-in-law, Joseph J. McGinley, 68, a former newspaper publisher and business man.

Location of the land, suitability of the improvement, nearness to railroad sidings and piers, rental and sales values of surrounding properties and other similar factors are more important in determining the value of industrial property than the use of formulas, according to James B. Fisher, past president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.

JUST as every one was mentally closing the season and planning the annual villegiatura, George Abbott put on "Room Service." That is an item worth a little discussion at this languid time of the theatrical year.
Striking out thirteen batters, Captain Ed Kobak of Hill School pitched a 1-0 shutout over Hotchkiss in the victors' last game of the season today before a Father's Day crowd.

Elmer Rice's "Judgment Day" having been enthusiastically received on its initial English presentation at the Embassy last week, it will move to the West End next week, and is destined for the Phoenix Theatre, to which Ronald Adam, managing director of the Embassy, has extended his activities.

The volume of new offerings of bonds placed in the market here in May was the smallest for any month since February, 1935. New offerings of stock also dwindled to the smallest volume since May of last Year.

State police tonight revealed that the man who tried to kill S. Allen Norton, retired treasurer of Mount Hermon School for Boys, here last Tuesday night was observed stalking his intended victim after dusk on that day.

Brogan, the big brown gelding by Guy Trogan-Anita Brook, won the opening event of the Nassau Driving Club today over the Mineola Fair Grounds. The Guy Trogan gelding, owned by ex-Sheriff David Dows and driven by his son-in-law, Club President C. N. Bliss, showed the way the entire distance, trotting the first mile in 2:09, the fastest in harness racing thus for this season.

The sixth annual Westchester Flower Show, on June 9, 10, 11 and 12 at the County Center here, will feature gardens of many ??ations as well as an exhibit of a typical American June garden. Mrs. H. Edward Manville of Pleasantville is chairman of the show, which is sponsored by the Westchester Horticultural and Agricultural Society.

Citing the desirability of hom buying as a protection against a higher rental period and menace of inflation, N. K. Winston, New York builder, who is now developing a home community in Astoria, says that a survey recently made by building material interests

A study of culture through language and art is the particular field of anthropology which has taken Miss Gladys Reichard, assistant professor of Barnard College, into the Southwest where the Navajo Indians are making a gallant stand to preserve their tribal customs.
Over the bitter protests of concessionaires, and while throngs stared after clanging patrol wagons, the police last night began removing what they regarded as the taint of gambling from Coney Island.

FOR the pre-holiday week which ushers in the Summer season, trade results could be put down as rather disappointing, The dullness which has crept into retail activity since Easter was relieved only in part.

The 300th anniversary of the purchase of Governors Island from the Indians, which will be celebrated during the week of June 13, will close with an all-day ceremony on the island on June 19, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, U.S.A., commanding the Second Corps Area.

The annual garden party of Barnard-in-Westchester will be held Saturday afternoon at the Croft, estate of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Swope in Ossining. The feature of the party, proceeds of which will be contributed to the group's scholarship fund for girl residents of the county, will be a program of dances by members of the Polish Folk Dance Circle.

Leaders of the American Federation of Labor conferred in Cincinnati last week about means of disciplining the parent body's disobedient offspring, the Committee for Industrial Organization. With much revenue lost by the defection of more than 1,000,000 dues-payers, the leaders ordered the remaining unions to double their contributions.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Aylward of the Chateau Lafayette, Greenwich, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jane Aylward, to Alfred Reed Pennell, son of John F. Pennell of New York.
MOUNTAIN climbers, trail riders and other such nature lovers are assembling their kits and studying their itineraries preparatory to setting out on Summer trips.

FIRST, in 1848, Guys knew Gavarni, "and through him Gautier and the Goncourts, and through Gautier, Baudelaire." But Baudelaire would have discovered Monsieur G. even if the natural course of esthetic events had not brought the hand of one genius to clasp the hand of another.

Four years ago President HOOVER proclaimed from the White House to a vast radio audience and to representatives of all the Western States gathered at the Presidio, San Francisco, that work on the Golden Gate Bridge was to begin.

A survey of general business conditions in the Borough of Queens presenting in many instances statistics of former years to indicate the ratio of progress or otherwise, has just been concluded by the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce with the cooperation of many of the industrial and banking interests in the borough.

Mexico's industrial unions paralyzed the life of the nation to an increasing extent today as strikes developed in sympathy with the nation-wide petroleum walk-out, now in its second day, and a strike at the chief port of Veracruz halted shipping activities.
A portrait of Dr. Franklin B. Hough, North County historian and pioneer conservationist, has been presented to this village by Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, President of Union College, Schenectady.

The combination of loose play in the Lion infield and Frank Owen's heavy hitting gave the Harvard baseball team a 6-4 Eastern Intercollegiate League victory over Columbia in a seven-inning contest on University Field this morning.

Mrs. Frederick Starr Pendleton, president general of the Colonial Daughters of the Seventeenth Century, will represent the organization on Thursday in the presentation of a wrist watch to the member of the graduating class at Annapolis having the highest standing in history for the four years.
The Cleveland Indians divided a twin bill with the Chicago White Sox today, cutting loose with a 15-hit attack to win the second game, 15 to 3, after dropping the opener, 4 to 1.
MARK TWAIN was a journeyman printer and had spent four years as a Mississippi River pilot before he caught the gold craze and went to Nevada. Too visionary and temperamental to make much of a miner,
WAS Captain Kidd a "beastlie pirate" or a much-maligned English seafaring gentleman most unjustly hanged? Harold T. Wilkins, who has concerned himself for a long time with pirates and buried loot,
Germany clinched final-round places in the men's and women's singles divisions of the French hard-court tennis championships today.
Alumni dinner. June 13-Baccalaureate by President Norwood. June 14-Class day exercises: commencement; oration by President Valentine of the University of Rochester.

All bungalows in the Manhattan Beach development have been rented for the season, according to the management of Manhattan Beach Baths, which points out that members of many professions and several prominent merchants are included in the list of tenants.

Mrs. Ellen H. Fanshawe, realty broker in Morristown, N. J., for the past twenty-five years, is celebrating her eighty-second birthday today. She is one of the oldest active realty dealers in New Jersey.

A survey of the foreclosure records of the State Mortgage Commission indicates that the mortgage situation is improving. Figures compiled yesterday by Lewis F. X. Cotignola, in charge of the foreclosure division of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation, show 1,300 foreclosure actions now pending. This is said to be a "substantial" reduction as compared with the same period a year ago, and a "progressive improvement" since the beginning of the year.

Requirements for admission to Brown University for 1937-38, according to Dr. Bruce M. Bigelow, director of admissions, will be coordinated with the requirements for the Bachelor of Arts degree under the new curriculum which Brown is introducing in September.

MR. RASCOE'S memory of his life falls so easily and loosely into the shape of a book because he has always had the habit of remembering everything. He has been a reader and writer from his earliest years, for himself as much as for his public:

The Council of the League of Nations closed this session's examination of the Spanish conflict today by unanimously adopting a resolution endorsing London's move for the withdrawal of alien combatants, leaving it to the Non-Intervention Committee to work out.
The City College tennis team defeated Fordham, 9 to 0, yesterday on the Maroon courts. The Beavers won three singles and one doubles match and took the other five matches by default.

The riot which occurred unexpectedly this week at the gates of the Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company is proof that the campaign of the United Automobile Workers of America to unionize Ford workers will have plenty of pyrotechnics.

The engagement of Miss Marion Louise Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jacob Fisher of Mount Vernon, N. Y., to John Shortridge Vansant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Vansant of New Rochelle, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.
This capital city of steel has in some respects the unique experience of being on the sideline as one. of the greatest strikes of years in the industry is begun.

Joseph Patrick Hartnett, vice president, a member of the board of directors and former president of Cartier, Inc., jewelers, 653 Fifth Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack today in his home here. He was 75 years old.

Eighty distinguished scholars and teachers, and outstanding figures in law, business and medicine, tonight honored Dr. Albert G. Keller on the thirtieth anniversary of his appointment as Professor of the Science of Society at Yale University.
Bernard M. Baruch congratulated the graduating students of The Citadel here today on facing with the advantage of disciplined training a world with a brightening Economic outlook.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Graham, daughter of Oscar R. Graham of Martine Avenue, Fanwood, and Boston, and the late Mrs. Graham, to Earle Hastings Beatty, son of Mrs. Fred F. Beatty of Winthrop, Me., and the late Mr. Beatty, will take place July 17 in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, Plainfield. The Rev. Robert B. Rock, associate minister, will officiate.

Farmer Franklin D. Roosevelt may look forward to a "good harvest" after a successful Spring planting at Pine Mountain. Otis Moore, superintendent of the President's 2,250-acre estate, made the forecast today, basing it on years of contact with Georgia's soil and weather.

The Fordham bat-swingers gave the Brooklyn College baseball team their own version of a Hit Parade yesterday and did it so convincingly that when the game had reached seven innings and the Maroon led,

The unique thermometer -- barometer that sessions of the League of Nations Council provide for those who need to know as precisely as possible the existing world political atmosphere and its immediate future registers at this session a moderate increase in the improvement it marked in January.
IN TRAINING: The heir to a throne starts training early for the role of ruler he expects some day to assume. Michael of Rumania had had even more of such preparation than the
JUERGEN FEHLING has given Shakespeare a new lease on the German stage. Not that the Bard's deed of title to the Fatherland's best seller of dramatic ware had expired;

Syracuse tossed away a 6-to-1 lead over Newark tonight, allowing the Bears to tie the score with three runs in the ninth, then the Bears won in the tenth, 8 to 6. Joe Gordon and Frank Kelleher contributed home runs to Newark's cause, Kelleher's coming as a pinch blow with a man on base to tie the score in the first of the ninth.

Pitcher Ed Mele of James Madison High won his own game when he singled in the eighth inning to drive in his battery mate, John O'Donohue, yesterday, defeating Tilden, 3 to 2, at Boys High Stadium. The triumph put Madison in the final round of the P. S. A. L. championship tourney.

Quotas, gentlemen's agreements and import duties are three of the major topics which local importers of Japanese goods will discuss with members of the Japanese Economic Mission at a special luncheon in the Hotel Astor on Thursday.
Justice Cardozo, appointed to the Supreme Court by Republican President Herbert Hoover, has led his colleagues in supporting Roosevelt administration legislation.

President Roosevelt's intervention in the tangle into which the House of Representatives has woven itself during the consideration of the pending Work Relief Appropriation Bill appeared to have been only partially successful as leaders of the various groups weighed tonight the assurances he sent to them through Representative Rayburn of Texas, majority leader.

Imports of the Argentine Republic in April were valued at 131,068,799 pesos ($43,690,000 at the official rate of exchange), or nearly 20,000,000 pesos above the imports in March, and above the imports of any other month in the last six years, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

Holy Cross drove Karl Sherry, ace Providence College pitcher, from the mound in the ninth with none out and then scored eight runs to defeat the Friars, 11-3, today. Sherry has pitched Providence to three victories over Holy Cross in previous seasons, but the heavyhitting Crusaders were not to be denied today.

Sixty years ago this month the Civil Service Reform Association (now League) was formed. Two years before, President GRANT, overcome by the spoilsmen in his party, had suspended the operation of the civil service rules adopted by the first Civil Service Commission of 1871.
In one of the finest exhibitions of his career, the Three D's Stable's crack 3-year-old Heelfly defeated a band of older horses in today's twentysecond running of the Inaugural Handicap.
Robert Morgan, vice grand president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, said today a vote was under way among the union's members to determine whether they would strike.

Under perfect rowing conditions, the third national interscholastic championship regatta was held today on Lake Quinsigamond. Interest ran high on the outcome of the one-mile senior eight-oared race, feature of the regatta.

Members of the Japanese Economic Mission to the United States arrived in New York last night to wind up their tour of American industrial centers and to confer with representatives of business and industry in the Eastern States.

Miss Ruth Simon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. R. Francis Taylor, 913 Spruce Street, has completed plans for her marriage on June 26 to William Howard Gluck of New York. The ceremony, followed by a reception, will take place at the Bellevue-Stratford.

Fourteen thousand persons, cluding war veterans, members of women's patriotic organizations, Boy and Girl Scouts, firemen, policemen and public officials will march in Memorial Day parades in Westchester County tomorrow and Monday.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4044-United States v. Gustav Oberlaender. Opinion by Judge Graham. The United States Customs Court judgment is reversed. Judges Bland and Garrett dissent.

Chang Soo Lee, 37-year-old Korean houseman, will seek in Supreme Court Saturday to win freedom from Sing Sing prison, where he is serving terms aggregating from five to ten years for administering poisons last Summer to Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves in the White Plains home of Mrs. Reeves's aunt, 83-year-old Mrs. Ida L. Churchill.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Francis Donnelly of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Donnelly, to Gregory Field Keenan, son of former Judge John Joseph Keenan and Mrs. Keenan of Washington, D. C.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through the daily press, farm papers and dairy trade journals, the public has been informed concerning the provisions of the Rogers-Allen Milk Bill, which was enacted at the recent session of the New York Legislature and signed by Governor Lehman.

Within the next four months eight new city health centers, all built with Federal funds, will be put into service, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday. They will be the first cityowned, city-built health center buildings actually put into service.
Jonas Hapgood Brooks, one-time Albany financial figure and prominent Episcopal layman, died here tonight after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

A novice known only as Walter of the monastery of the Alexian Order at Neuss pleaded guilty of immorality charges yesterday and was sentenced to fourteen months in the penitentiary by the court at Bonn.

Miss Tarjorie Estelle Gould, daughter of ??r. and Mrs. Norman F. Gould of omerton, Pa., has completed plans or her marriage on June 18 to Robrt Ritter Eyerly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Eyerly of Bloomsurg, Pa.

Baltimore blasted four Jersey City pitchers for thirteen hits today to score an 8-to-3 victory and even the series at one game apiece. Smokey Joe Martin led the attack, connecting for a triple and two singles.
N interesting seven-room house has been built by A. Gordon Lorimer, architect, for his own occupancy in Sherwin Cody's Hilltop Park community at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.
There are living now, on the eve of Memorial Day, 1937, almost 4,500,000 men who have worn the uniform of the United States Army or Navy during this nation's wars.
The United Gas Improvement Company was accused today, in a protest filed with the National Labor Relations Board, of fostering company unionism and intimidating its employes.

The presentation of a bronze plaque to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia for distinguished service in public office will feature Senior Week activities of more than 4,000 graduates of New York University, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary.

Despite rejection in committee of a proposed overture to delete sanction of war from the Presbyterian Confession of Faith, peace advocates in the General Assembly began a new and more drastic pacifist movement today.
In our Wintering camp here, where three heavy planes are now standing, life is very lively. The station is getting into good working order.
Heidelberg Castle was th?? scene today of memorial ceremonies?? honoring Leopold Mozart, compose?? and teacher of Wolfgang Amadeu?? Mozart, his famous son.

The Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, of which James N. MacLean is chairman, will open on Tuesday its second office in Queens. The new quarters, arranged with the cooperation of Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Harvey of Queens, will be in Borough Hall. Lone Island City.

The Admiral Scheer arrived off Algeciras, Spain, April 2 for patrol duty. Named in honor of the late commander of the German fleet in the Battle of Jutland, the Admiral Scheer is one of three "pocket battleships" of the German Navy which aroused the attention of the entire naval world by their extraordinary efficiency and fighting power.

BYRON C. FOY, president De Soto Motor Corporation, has been appointed chairman of the show committee in charge of the National Automobile Show to be held in Grand Central Palace from Oct. 27 to Nov. 3, it is announced by Alvan Macauley president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

Support of American business and labor for a proposal to establish a universal forty-hour week through international agreement was urged at one of the closing sessions of the National Conference of Social Work today by Miss Mary Van Kleeck of the Russell Sage Foundation, New York.
WITH the short-trip season now opening for motorists, the announcement that paving operations on Merritt Parkway are now under way comes at an appropriate time.

How a group of local officials in Velizhansk District in Western Siberia to use their own phrase "shook up individual peasants like cabbages," piled exorbitant illegal taxes on them and then confiscated their property for failing to pay, was told in a trial just concluded at Omsk in Western Siberia.

THE detective hero of this story is a blind man, Captain Duncan Maclain, who has developed and trained his other senses to such a degree that he is better able to perceive what is going on about him than are most men whose sight is unimpaired.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Nearly 2,000 members of the Fordham University Alumni Association are expected to return to the campus next Saturday for the annual Alumni Day. The parade of alumni will take place at 2:45 P. M., with members of every class for the last two decades represented in the procession.
Hundreds of school children will receive cash awards next month for "kind, good manners" because a small boy refused to accept a reward when he picked up and returned a man's hat ten years ago.

AMID preparations for the wedding day, the June bride and bridegroom must spare a weighty thought for the traditional cake. Confectioners and caterers are busy now building up elaborate designs of spun sugar and bright icings.

THE oldest national organization of its kind, the American Whist League, will hold its forty-seventh annual whist congress in Hanover, N. H., the week of June 21. Preliminary announcements list five events for whist players and two for contract bridge players. The old game of whist still has thousands of adherents, and the American Whist League's tournaments draw entrants from all parts of the country.

IN Denver, Col., a group of citizens has created a unique organization. This is the Denver Civic Symphony Society, which now maintains three orchestras on a budget which is always balanced and very small.

Increases in four of its components sent THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity up to 109.5 for the week ended May 22, 1937. It was 109.0 for the previous week and 96.4 for the week ended May 23, 1936.

Three seniors, three juniors and one sophomore in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have received awards for excellence in the work of the Military Science Department. The awards came at the end of the last year of compulsory military science at the institute. Next year the course will be optional.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Geoffrey Widdows of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Widdows, to Robert James Lincoln, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Burnham Lincoln of Rutherford, N. J.

The naval board of investigation on Tuesday will inquire into the Hindenburg disaster to ascertain damages to navy property, injuries to naval personnel and the performance of navy members of the ground crew when the big airship burned here on May 6.

The American Forestry Association, founded in Cincinnati fifty-five years ago, will return here Monday for a four-day convention during which conservation and flood control are expected to be major topics of discussion.

The marriage of Miss Louisa Bright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright of Cedar Hill Farm, this city, to William Henry Peace 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Peace of Shangarry, Rydal, Pa., took place this afternoon in the walled garden of the home of the bride's parents.
The following shows how Denny Shute and Harold McSpaden progressed to the final of the Professional Golfers' Association championship:
Transfer of the rayon department headquarters of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. from New York to Wilmington was practically completed today with the arrival of about 100 office employes.

The engagement of Miss Jessica Perlman, daughter of Mark Perlman of this city and Miami Beach, Fla., to Morton Kline, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Kline of Brooklyn, has been announced by her father.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Irene Farr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Farr of this city, to Milton Schlesinger, son of Mrs. Max Schlesinger of Woodmere, L. I., and the late Mr. Schlesinger.

Leon Trotsky was accused of "breaking Mexican hospitality" in an editorial in the conservative newspaper Ultimas Noticias today as the "Fourth International" plastered this capital with a call for a general strike in support of the oil strikers.

AT this time of the year, when the season is to all intents and purposes over, it is customary to wax a bit statistical. Perhaps as a throw back to the days when the year was considered to begin with the Spring, there is a desire to look back at what has been done, give a few prizes here and there, and wipe the slate clean for better luck next year.

Mexican women, whose emancipation from an exclusively domestic routine is a matter of only the last decade and a half, will be hostesses next month for the first convention of business and professional women on an international scale, to be held within their country's borders.

Newtown High School in Queens has turned a course in selling into one in buying. Originally started to teach future storekeepers and clerks the secrets of the merchandise with which they must deal, the course has been literally taken over by 400 students,-most of whom are interested in the subject from the consumer's angle.

Forecasters and botanists who examined an oak tree felled here in a Winter gale, said that it was well over 300 years old, and it is declared by those expert in sylviculture that the oaks now standing at the foot of Newbury Street, Bangor, were there, and of considerable size, when Champlain, the French explorer, came up the Penobscot in 1605.
The National Federation of Temple Brotherhoods will hold its second Northeastern regional convention here, next Saturday and Sunday, it was announced today by Jesse Cohen, general chairman.

Miss Mary Scott Piel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. J. Piel of 30 Fifth- Avenue, New York, was married to William Evans Ward, son of Mr. and. Mrs. Evans Ward of Port Chester, N. Y., in St, Mary's Roman Catholic Church this afternoon.

The typical Mount Holyoke alumna goes on to some form of graduate work after completing her college course and then enters either the teaching field or one of the other professions. She marries at the age of 26, and her husband is a college graduate.

Twenty-two of the world's finest 3-year-olds, bred in three countries, were being put through the final stages of training today in preparation for Wednesday's 158th running of the Epsom Derby, most colorful of England's turf classics.
Two species of animals never before exhibited in this country were added to the population of the Zoological Park in the Bronx yesterday.

Restriction of the world's output of gold through an international agreement, which has been suggested by economists at the British Empire Conference in London as a solution of some of the problems caused by that metal, is considered impractical by some important mining interests here.

Miss Mildred Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Smith of Huntington Road, was married this afternoon to Wilbur A. Ellmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Ellmore of Tremont Street. Dean Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d performed the ceremony in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

In the United States Court of Claims today the following calendar for Tuesday, June 1, was announced: Call of the June Calendar Rule to show cause: Plaintiffs to show cause why the following cases should not be dismissed:
CARBON MONOXIDE is the product of the imperfect combustion of carboniferous materials in internal-combustion engines. It is a colorless gas and in average concentrations is also odorless.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

The Devon Horse Show ball was given tonight at the Philadelphia Country Club as a climax to the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair, which had been held this week for the benefit of the Bryn Mawr Hospital.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred Ward Pardee of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Pardee, to Howard Ward Beebe, son of Mrs. Howard Franklin Beebe of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Beebe.

Miss Alice Elizabeth Campbell, daughter of Mrs. James J. Campbell of this place and the late Mr. Campbell, was married this morning to Dr. William Martin Sullivan Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. William M. Sullivan, also of Passaic.

The trustees of Sarah Lawrence College here have removed the restriction on the number of students permitted to continue their work beyond the two-year course, in order to obtain the B. A. degree, it was announced today. In 1931 the trustees limited the number of such students to thirtyfive. This number was later raised to fifty.

The National Seaway Council made public today a message from President Roosevelt advising it that he would do all in his power to promote the earliest possible construction of the proposed Great LakesSt. Lawrence waterway.

Bob Retz, 25, of Farmland, and Vernon Medsker, 16, of Hagerstown, met instant death early tonight when the plane in which they were riding, piloted by Retz, crashed just west of the airport, north of Farmland.

EARLY in the last century Josiah Winfield dreamed a college in the wooded hills of Ohio--and somehow a dream conceived by Josiah Winfield was apt to be more substantial than most. Not all the town agreed with him.

Revenue authorities disclosed today they hope to transfer $100,000,000 from the pockets of tax evaders to the Federal Treasury. Power to do so will be asked of Congress by President Roosevelt in a special message, "probably Tuesday," White House officials said today.

Three and a half minutes before the end of a sizzling lacrosse game today, Jimmy Posey, first attack of the Army team, took the ball after a series of passes, and slammed it past Nat James, Navy's capable goalie, to give the cadets a 6-5 victory.

The aid of Secretary Perkins in settling the month-old film strike was sought today by the Federated Motion Picture Crafts. Blocked by the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, whose officials demand that producers negotiate through them, the crafts today appealed to the executive Fed committee of the American Federation of Labor, with which both are affiliated.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Weinberger of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Weinberger, to Belmont Corn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Belmont Corn, also of this city. The prospective bride was graduated from the Calhoun School and expects to receive the degree of Bachelor of Science from Columbia University in June.
A crowded commencement weekend of activities at Choate School came to a climax this afternoon with prize day exercises in the chapel. The School Seal Prize, highest honor at Choate, went to Edwin C.
The University of Maryland clinched the National Collegiate lacrosse championship today by trouncing Penn State, 15 to 0. The victory closed an undefeated season for Maryland.

MRS. HORAN says in her dedication that these memoirs would not have been written but for the prodding (only she puts it more politely) of Burton Rascoe, so we have him as well as herself to thank for a delightful story of life in Michigan under McKinley and Roosevelt as seen by a little girl.

Miss Madge Haas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Charles Haas of Mount Kisco, N. Y., and Tibwin Plantation, S. C., has chosen June 19 as the date for her marriage to Christopher Sylvester Donner, son of Mrs. Christopher Donner of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Donner.

Reductions of from one-sixteenth to one-eighth of 1 per cent in open market discounts on bankers acceptances, which were put into effect on May 7, comprised the only changes in money market rates this month.

SUCCESS in televising the coronation procession of George VI has greatly interested American radio men, who during the past week have been reading detailed reports on how the cameras of the air worked in the downpour of rain, so that 100,000 might look in.

Mrs. David Wagstaff and her Horse Show committee have completed their plans for the show next Friday and Saturday. Entries closed this week and the forty-eight classes to be shown during the two days include the best horses now in competition.

THE San Francisco Opera Company, Gaetano Merola, general director, will open its fifteenth annual season, Oct. 15, at the War Memorial Opera House, San Francisco, Calif. During its four weeks' activity the company will offer three distinct series of performances. The regular series will consist of eleven, the repeat series of two, and the popular series of three presentations.
Dr. Albert W. Harned, founder and director of the National Capital Choir and organist of the Universalist ME National Memorial Church here, died today at Takoma Park, Md. His age was 74.

Headed by General John J. Pershing and United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt, Americans in France tomorrow will honor the memory of almost 30,000 American soldiers and sailors who died in the World War and are buried here.

Many engagements were announced yesterday and several of them will be followed within a few weeks by the weddings. In some other instances also the date of marriage is made known simultaneously with the betrothal.

Miss Elizabeth Martine Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wood Smith of Orange, was married to Donald Wilson Roe, son of Mrs. Harriet E. Roe of East Orange, here this afternoon in the Church of St. Andrew by the Rev. Francis G. Urbano of St. John's Church, Far Rockaway, L. I.

BAAR-WOHLFELD-Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Wohlfeld announce the engagement of their daughter, Ethel, to Mr. Stanley Baar. BURNSTINE-JAMES-Mr. and Mrs. Henry James, Jersey City, announce the engagement of their daughter, Vera, to Mr. Horace B. Burnstine, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. A. Burnstine, 333 West End Ave., New York City.
TWO 50-kilowatt stations are to be immediately started for Toronto and Montreal, according to Chairman L. W. Brockington of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

Mrs. Franklin Q. Brown of this place, chairman of the bridge parties to be held here on June 8 and 9 in the cottage homes of the Children's Village, has announced that reservations have been made for more than 500 women.

Temple University will award honorary degrees to four persons at commencement exercises on June 10 in the Municipal Auditorium. The graduating class will number about 1,300 Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and Dr. Post Wheeler will receive the degree of Doctor of Laws.
Senator Byrd's apparently unprecedented action in asking for the withdrawal of a $1,500,000 Federal grant to his State has brought him little but praise in Virginia thus far.

The Misses Elizabeth Mandeville Bracher and Cornelia Housman Bracher, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Vasa K. Bracher of Dongan Hills, Staten Island, will be married to Robert C. Vincent and John Thomas Gwynne, respectively, on June 5 in a double wedding.

Arguments for and against proposed freight rates on manufactured cotton goods from Southern territory, scheduled to go into effect on June 8, will be heard in Washington at the offices of the Interstate Commerce Commission on June 4, W. P. Bartel, secretary of the commission, announced today.

THIS bulky volume is meant by its author to supply the newspaper reader with the background of world events. It is also designed to serve as an introduction to the understanding of the second World War, which Mr. Wittmer thinks is not far off.

Plans for the annual commencement exercises of St. Bonaventure College on June 8 included a baccalaureate address by the Most Rev. John A. Duffy, new Bishop of Buffalo. He will also preside at the ceremonies and receive an honorary degree.

The honorary degree of Doctor of Letters was conferred upon Mrs. William Kinnicut Draper, chairman of the board of directors of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, by the Moravian Seminary and College of Women at a special convocation this morning in the Central Moravian Church.

Chiseling the New York City consumer is not so easy as it used to be. Before the drive that was launched a few months ago by the Department of Markets, Weights and Measures, and persistently maintained today, many housewives could expect to be duped in a certain percentage of their purchasing by short weights and measures.

A three-day academic ritual begins today on Morningside Heights, where Baccalaureate Sunday ushers in the 183d Columbia University commencement. The chiming of the St. Paul's Chapel bells at 4 o'clock, when prospective graduates of eight university branches will be summoned to the baccalaureate services,

The twenty-first annual Summer session of City College will open on Thursday, June 24, and close on Wednesday, Aug. 18, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Charles Upson Clark, director. Day and evening courses will be given in the main building, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, and at the School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Reviews of the seven regional conferences conducted by the Y. W. C. A. this Spring, and reports from the representatives present at the recent National Conference on Social Work at Indianapolis will occupy the national board and members of the national staff on Wednesday at the last meeting until October.
World War history has been repeating itself in many ways here in Spain and this week came the first serious effort to bring about an armistice and a peaceable solution of the civil conflict.

Rome and Berlin for weeks have been trying to tell mankind they had established an "axis" on which the affairs of Europe, if not those bf the political world, were hereafter to revolve. Today, in view of certain developments, it is well to recall the definition of the word. According to the Standard Dictionary it denotes "a straight line, real or imaginary, passing through a body, on which it revolves, or is supposed to revolve."

NEW LONDON, Conn. NAVY-WISE Lloyd Bacon, with camera crews and a corps of assistants, has been engaged at the United States Submarine Base here for the last ten days filming background shots and effects for the Warner production of Frank Wead's "Submarine 262."

The marriage of Miss Marion Ward, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Rankin Ward of this city, to Alvin Walck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Redman Walck of Weatherly, Pa., took place today at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Dr.
The British are reported to have [Pound]50,000,000 invested in iron and manganese mines as well as smelters around Gamiz and business interests in the Port of Bilbao.

Miss Josephine Dale Carnegie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer Clifton Carnegie of Kansas City, Mo., was married yesterday morning to Gerard B. Nolan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Nolan of Long Branch, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. P. Holland at the home of the bride's uncle, Dale Carnegie, author, in Forest Hills, Queens.

Mrs. Weston Green of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Green, to Harold Brewster Seydel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Seydel of Jersey City, N. J. The announcement was made tonight at a dinner dance given by Mrs. Green at the Dayton Country Club.

Miss Jane Baylis, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Wanton Baylis of Germantown, was married this afternoon to Robert McNeil Morse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gorham Morse of Marblehead, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nathaniel B. Groton in St. Thomas Church, Whitemarsh.

The excellence of the wine of our own New York State was attested to last week when a light blended wine of the white Burgundy type, from Penn Yan, N. Y., competed for popularity with some of the best wines of -France, Germany, Italy and Spain at a wine-testing at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Imports of gold received here this month totaled $123,482,900, compared with a revised total of $162,326,300 in April and $161,026,100 in May 1936.

More than 450 surgeons from all sections of the country will attend the first convention of the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel Tuesday and Wednesday,

Violette de Talleyrand, only daughter of the Duc and Duchess de Talleyrand, formerly Anna Gould, was married today to Comte James de Pourtales. Owing to a recent illness of the bride, the engagement was kept secret until a few days ago.

BATURIN--ECKHOFF--Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Eckhoff announce the marriage of their daughter, Gloria, to Murray Baturin on May 27. BEHRSTOCK--ROSENTHAL--Mrs. Herbert Rosenthal announce the marriage of her daughter, Alice, to Arnold W. Behrstock, to take place Tuesday, June 1, at Chicago.

BARG--Mr. and Mrs. Ben B. Barg (nee Rose L Stein) joyfully announce birth of Irwin Samuel's brother, Peter Hugh, May 23, Woman's Hospital. BARR-Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Barr (nee Abramson) announce the birth of a daughter May 27, 1937.

Freeport High School today won the third annual Nassau conference track and field championships. The victors totaled 34 1/2 points. Chaminade was runner-up with 31, Hempstead third with 25, Westbury fourth with 22 and Sewanhaka last with 8 1/2.

A warship reported to be the German battleship Admiral Scheer, which had opened fire on two Spanish Government airplanes off the Balearic Island of Iviza., was bombed at 5 o'clock this afternoon. Smoke from several explosions was seen to come from the battleship.

The American Federation of Actors announced yesterday that it had signed a closed shop agreement with Ringling Bros. Barnum and Bailey Combined Shows, Inc. The agreement was signed in Philadelphia by Samuel W. Gumpertz, representing the circus, and by Ralph Whitehead, representing the American Federation of Actors.

When school children are taught that "ten times ten equals 100," they are misled, because the answer may range anywhere from 90 to 110, according to a survey on "Approximate Computation" made public yesterday by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics.

The engagement of Miss Carmelita McCormick, daughter of Mrs. Daniel L. McCormick of this place and the late Dr. McCormick, to Hugh T. Hurley, son of Mrs. David J. Hurley of Short Hills, N. J., and the late Mr. Hurley, has been announced by her mother.

The Society for Stability in Money and Banking will consider suggestions for legislation to strengthen the banking system and close the channels through which' inflation develops, at a meeting to be held next Friday at the Commonwealth Club, Richmond, Va., according to an announcement by the society yesterday.

Lecturing to other members of the class displaced the writing of "blue books" for ten Bowdoin College juniors in the course in advanced calculus and differential equations on two evenings of mid-May. In past years the men would have received the third hour examination of the semester at this point in the course.
One man was killed by a falling manhole cover today when a series of explosions in sewers under Fullerton Avenue rocked a mile-long section of the North Side.

The Twenty-third Street Association has notified the Board of Standards and Appeals that it is opposed to the proposed use of the vacant property at 116-24 East Twentyfourth Street for automobile parking. Five four-story dwellings which formerly occupied this site recently were razed. The association expressed the belief that use of this land for parking was "undesirable"
The Keys quadruplets looked back today on a college career about to close and chorused the hope that they would be able to remain together for a while longer.

Four thousand women from thirtytwo countries will view the world temperance map here next week in the sixteenth triennial convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union-but the Italian delegate will be among those absent and fourteen other countries will not be represented.

Miss Helen Katherine Campbell, daughter of Mrs. William Campbell Jr. of this city and the late Mr. Campbell, was married this evening to John William Baile, son of Mrs. Joseph F. Baile, also of this city, and the late Mr. Baile.
Temple University defeated Penn A. C. at Shibe Park today by a score of 5 to 4 in twelve innings. Temple tied the score in the ninth on Mottola's single, Bekampis's sacrifice and Coyne's single.
MR. ALFANGE might have called his book "The Supreme Court in United States History" if Charles Warren had not preempted that title.

The five-day week in the securities markets was extremely dull. Price changes generally were without significance. Trade and industrial news of the week was mainly favorable. Although reports on industrial labor troubles were studied carefully, the stock market gave little outward sign of undue concern;

President Federico Laredo Bru today sent a message to Congress covering the budget for the fiscal year 19371938, amounting to about $78,700,000, and recommending numerous new taxes to meet expenditures $5,400,000 in excess of the 1936-37 figure.

Edward T. Gushee, this year's winner of the J. Shipman memorial award, presented each year by the National Association of Purchasing Agents to the purchasing executive considered to have made an outstanding contribution to the profession, is vice president of the Detroit Edison Company.

Frank Polomka, declared legally dead nine years ago on petition of his wife, Valeria, whom he left ten years before, was brought back to life in the eyes of the courts today at the request of the Prudential Insurance Company.
With clearing weather, the three America's Cup defense sloops were under sail for the first time together on lower Narragansett Bay today.
The report in yesterday's TIMES concerning the excellent hospital care that is given disabled veterans throughout the country is a gratifying word for Memorial Day.

Gabriele d'Annunzio, noted poet, playwright, novelist and patriot, tonight was reported to have "passed the crisis" of an illness. The hero of the siege of Fiume has been confined to his bed since yesterday in his lakeshore villa, suffering from what was called "disturbances of old age."
Premier Aberhart announced today that Alberta would apply to the Bank of Canada for a loan to meet a $1,650,000 bond maturity due June 1. The full amount will be sought.
