Miss Bernadette Marie Whelan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Whelan of Grantwood, will be married to Lieutenant John Edward Watters, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Watters of Belleville, on June 16 at the Church of the Epiphany here.

Including the few additions made to the list last week, the total of bonds called for redemption before maturity to be paid this month amounts to $134,925,000, the smallest volume for any of the last six months.

Governors Island Leave of absence is granted to each of the following Reserve officers, effective on or about the date specified: 1st Lt. Arthur L. Mattern, Fin.-Res., 26 days, June 7, 1937. Capt. William E. Campbell, Q.-M. Res., 3 months. June 24, 1937, to terminate not later than Sept. 24, 1937.

More than 500 city and county employes have filed entries for twenty track and field events to be contested in the Randalls Island Stadium next Saturday, the Mayor's committee on municipal athletic activities announced.

Encouraged by its success in drawing a "cordon sanitaire" around warring Spain, Great Britain this week embarked upon a campaign to evacuate foreign troops and let the Burgos and Valencia governments fight it out between themselves.

Beginning in June are the summering flowering shrubs, which produce their flowers upon wood of the current season. In late June appear Spiraea bumalda and the varieties Anthony Watereri and Froebeli, which are showy with their pink or rose-colored flowers.

One of the distinctive features of John D. Rockefeller's huge benefactions, finally summed up during the past week, is the large proportion that went to education. No other cause, neither health, nor religion, nor relief, nor civic matters, apparently interested the oil king so much.

A stunned community buried its dead in rough, wooden boxes today while stalwart miners dug in a mountain of mud and sand seeking other victims of Thursday's avalanche. Mayor Pedro Juarez estimated 168 died when the 3,000,000 tons of "tailings" from the Dos Estrellas gold mine engulfed this sleeping town of 10,000 inhabitants.

Miss Camilla Wilson Hayward, daughter of Mrs. James Waldemar Hayward of this city and the late Lieut. Commander Hayward, has chosen June 12 as the date for her marriage to Charles Julian Melville, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. S. Melville of New York and Jamaica, B. W. I.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Stanwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Stanwood of Wellesley Hills, Mass., to Horace Guy Crockett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Guy Crockett of this place, will take place June 18 in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Philemon Sturges, rector of the church, will officiate.

VIRGINIA THE OLD DOMINION. By Matthew Page Andrews. 8vo. New York: Doubleday. Doran Co. $6. A chronicle of Virginia. AUDUBON. By Stanley Clisby Arthur. 8vo. New Orleans. La.: Harmanson, 333 Royal Street. $5. A biography.
Free textbooks will be provided next Fall for needy students at the University of Michigan under a plan completed by Alexander G. Ruthven, president of the university, and four faculty members.

Former Premier Andre Tardieu, France's most obstinate bachelor, has announced his intention to marry. His bride will be Miss Julia Angelique Largenton of Chaumont-sur-Taronne, where Mr. Tardieu now is staying.
The State Department sent its Spring bills for $1,520,159,863.43 today to the legations and embassies of twelve foreign nations in default of their war debts.

Expanding retail credit sales, while productive of increased immediate sales volume, are nevertheless becoming a disturbing factor that may well be reflected in retarded future buying by consumers, with current developments demanding new emphasis on the financial rather than the merchandising side, according to executives in close touch with the retail credit situation.

Teaching children to think is the great aim of the modern school, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, told the recent conference of parents and teachers held at Richmond, Va.

Despite some recessions in gray goods last week, mills handling other classes of dry goods were confident yesterday that they will be able to withstand pressure from retailers and other distributors for from four to six months without booking any appreciable additional business. Only a few items, it was insisted, have yet yielded to this type of pressure.

GERMANY is administered from Berlin, capital of the Third Reich. It is inspired and spurred onward from Munich, capital of the National Socialist movement. But it is ruled from a mountain top--the mountain

The term of the Supreme Court which will end next Tuesday will go down as one of the most remarkable in history. Not once since the term began in October has the court, which previously had ruled against much New Deal legislation, handed down a majority decision against a Roosevelt law.
Mr. and Mrs. Peter O'Rourke of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wynifred Joan O'Rourke to John M. Keane, son of Mr. and Mrs. P. A. Keane of New York.

John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization is proceeding with the organization of filling-station employes here, it was revealed yesterday. Local 377 of the International Association of Oil Field, Gas Well and Refinery Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, announced through its attorney, Harvey H. Viskin, that it would begin negotiations on Tuesday.

INTERESTING group exhibitions and one-man shows continue-to appear on the calendar as May gives way to June. A score of artists, including notable names of the last generation and newcomers from our own day, are represented by water-colors or pastels in the well-diversified attraction at the Kraushaar Galleries.

LIKE a great green quilt, the forests of the Far West roll away to the horizon. Over sharp ridges and undulating hills they spread. From the ramparts of the Cascade Mountains the traveler looks out across a vista of neverending woodland.

Three events scheduled for today will terminate the celebration of the tenth anniversary of Poetry Week, with Miss Anita Browne, founder, in charge of the official and final program, at 6 P. M. at Rockefeller Center. Winners of the scholarship contest conducted on Thursday afternoon at Washington Irving High Echool will be guests, and messages of congratulation received by Miss Browne on the observance, from Governors of several States, will be read.

THE twenty-one essays included in this volume are the fruit of discussions carried on in the general seminar of the graduate faculty of political and social science, organized under the New School for Social Research, during the academic year 1935-36.

Two bandits captured by Patrolman George Maurer in an attempted hold-up of a bar at 2,112 Lexington Avenue at 2:45 A. M. were held yesterday by Magistrate Michael A. Ford in Felony Court. A third man, killed by Maurer, was identified as Richard Mahoney, 44 years old.

World consumption of American cotton for the season ending on July 31 is expected to exceed the 1936-37 United States crop by close to 1,000,000 bales, representing a world carry-over of American cotton of about 1,000,000 bales less than a year earlier, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics announced today.

THE BAT--Tomorrow evening at the Majestic Theatre. This is a revival of the Mary Roberts Rinehart-Avery Hopwood mystery play, whose first incarnation rolled up a total of 867 performances, starting in 1920. May Vokes, who was in the original company, will be in this one, also. Among the others are Hermann Lieb, Robert Ober, Linda Lee Hill, Norman Stuart, Richard Barrows, Minnette Barrett and Eric Kalkhurst.

That it was not ready when it was opened was normal. But that it should open three weeks after the scheduled date and still not be ready hurt everybody's pride when finally last Monday the President of the Republic inaugurated the Paris 1937 Exhibition.

Miss Catherine Genevieve Diegmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Joseph Diegmann of this city, was married to Francis Hugh McGuiness, son of Hugh McGuiness of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. McGuiness, yesterday morning in the Church of the Incarnation on Washington Heights.

Delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Court of the Catholic Daughters of America balloted in closed session for several hours today and re-elected the present slate for another two-year term.

THOUGH it may be perhaps as long as three years before Walt Disney gets his final decree from United Artists (it will take the corporation about that long to clear out the last of the Disney items from remote distribution tributaries) preparations for the union with RKO are going on apace.

The Syracuse Collegians defeated the Crescent A. C. in a closely waged lacrosse game today, 10 to 9. The home team led at the end of the first half, 7 to 6, but could not stave off the strong closing drive made by the Syracuse players. Gould, inside home for Crescent, was the high scorer with four goals.

Miss Elvia Adele Spencer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgard D. Spencer of this place, was married to Walter S. Hixson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Hixson, also of Westfield, this afternoon in her parents' home.

Numerically speaking, the most important change incurred in recent elections among influential feminine organizations in the Long Island area within the past few weeks was the accession of Mrs. Webster F. Williams to the presidency of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs.

Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, stated today that the WPA airport program, which is to cost $87,847,518 and includes improvements and enlargements of 864 airports, wasabout, 70 per cent completed on March 31. A monthly average of more than 44,000 workers have been employed since last September, he said.

The twentieth annual commencement exercises of the Child Education Foundation Training School will be held Tuesday evening at 8:30 in the assembly room of the Child Education Foundation, 535 East Eighty-fourth Street. Dr. C. C. Little, director of the Jackson Memorial Laboratory, Bar Harbor, Me., will deliver the commencement address.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today financing and conversion plans of the New York Central Railroad whereby the railroad expects to save in interest and finance charges more than $360,000 a year.

The marriage of Miss Gladys Todd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cammeyer Todd of this place, to Noel Day Sidford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Day Sidford of Summit, N. J., will take place the afternoon of June 19 in the Scotch Plains Baptist Church, Scotch Plains, N. J.

A list of bonerss" made by New York City school pupils was revealed yesterday by Raymond N. Kellogg, chairman of the speech department at Morris High School. He reported an "amazing" ignorance among many pupils on the correct pronunciation and use of even, common words.

The marriage of Miss Mary Agnes Doogan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Hugh Doogan, to Paul Joseph McGuire took place yesterday in the Church of St. Francis de Sales. The Rev. Leo Harkins was the celebrant of the nuptial mass.

The marriage of Miss Martha Bush Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Booker Clark of Maryland, and Charles Whitney Birdseye, son of Colonel and Mrs. Claude Birdseye of Chevy Chase, took place at Elk Ridge Farm, home of the bride's parents, this afternoon.
VIENNA. "WHEN we two are long dead our work will serve as a shining beacon to coming generations and hearts will glow in rapture for this God-given, this eternally living art."

The Village Welfare Society of Port Washington, L. I., will be the beneficiary of the fourth annual Sands Point Horse Show on June 13 at the Luckenbach Estate, Sands Point, L. I. Edgar F. Luckenbach heads the executive committee for the event, which is attracting entries from various well known stables.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated May 28; MAJOR GENERAL Westover, O., chief of the Air Corps, 7 days' leave, June 7. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Munson, F. J., Judge Advocate General's Dept., 5 days' leave, June 15.

A tribute to Dr. Simon Baruch, who died in 1921, as the "most prominent alumnus" of the Medical College of Virginia will be paid by members of the New York alumni association of the college at a meeting on Tuesday evening at the Hotel Westover, 253 West Seventy-second Street.

A resolution urging that the personnel of the District Attorney's office be chosen by competitive civil service examination has been forwarded to Governor Lehman and the New York State Civil Service Commission by the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild.

Miss Charlotte Florence Heffner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley E. Heffner of Maplewood, and Earl A. Lamb, son of Herbert W. Lamb of Syracuse, were married this afternoon in the Church of the Holy Communion, South Orange.

BIT by bit the celebrated cave temples of Elephanta Island in Bombay Harbor are crumbling. Recently a 100ton slab of rock slipped from the face of the eastern shrine and smashed a stone lion which adorned the entrance below.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Powers of this place gave a tea this afternoon at their home, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nathalie Tucker Powers, to Richard Franklin Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin T. Miller of Auburndale, Mass.
The government found a use today for honorary. vice presidents of corporationa. It uses them in figuring social security tax liabilities.

THE French themselves are never quite sure whether they ought to be governed roughly or gently, whether they should be dragooned or cajoled. They prefer to think that the mild manner is the better, for they believe themselves to be a reasonable and moderate people--"bons enfants" is the phrase-who can be led much more easily than they can be driven.

IT is unlawful and extremely dangerous to molest, tease or touch bears." Many of the 600 black bears in Yellowstone National Park apparently are well aware of these rules and regulations, prominently posted at their favorite haunts. To the delight of some and the annoyance of others, these semi-wild animals patrol the park highways and make the rounds of auto camps, always in search of food, to satisfy their ravenous appetites.

More than 150 members of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and their guests witnessed the ceremonies today which marked the opening of the club for the season. Sea scouts assisted in the firing off of the gun and the mast-heading of the colors, which was followed by the dressing of ships in the harbor.
The Browns, paced by Sam West with five hits in six times at bat, scored a 13-to-9 victory over the Tigers today in the third of a four-game series.
Foreign Minister Manuel Francisco

In anticipation of a more severe Summer slump in a number of staple lines -than had been originally expected, national advertisers are planning to draw on their advertising reserves and put extra pressure behind goods to keep them moving, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by advertising managers and agency executives.

Beginning on Tuesday, lumber used in the construction of new dwellings financed under the PHA plan in New Jersey must bear the grade mark and symbol of the association under whose grade rules it is produced, according to Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey State director of the FHA.

British troops fighting tribal followers of the Fakir of Ipi in the Shan Pain of Waziristan today counted three missing and believed dead, three known dead and seven wounded after a skirmish yesterday. All were from the Argyll Highlanders.

Miss Mary Louise Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mitchell of 83 Forest Avenue, has completed plans for her marriage on June 19 to John Reynolds Young, son of Mrs. Charles W. Leland of Los Angeles, Calif., and Charles Sommers Young of San Francisco. The ceremony will be performed in Christ Episcopal Church, Bloomfield and Glen Ridge, by the Rev.

With Miss Helen Lilly, the inside home, caging half of its goals, the Boston women's lacrosse team today opened the national tournament by-defeating a squad composed of New York and Chicago players, 12-2.

A Paulsboro (N. J.) housewife and cannery worker, an unemployed Queens County butcher and a young Newark lawyer with matrimonial intentions were among the five Americans who drew residual prizes of $31,170 each yesterday in the final draw of the twentyfirst Irish Hospital-Sweepstakes in Dublin.

One hundred and twenty-five fur coats, valued at more than $1,000,000, will be displayed on Wednesday and Thursday nights at the Fur Fashion Show at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, under the auspices of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers Association.

The British flying boat Cavalier landed in Manhasset Bay shortly after 7 P. M. today, after its second flight from Bermuda this week. A stop was made at Baltimore. Captain William Neville Cummings commanded.

Corporations in May declared the largest amount in dividends for any month since last November. Payments authorized aggregated $524,198,349 by 993 companies, compared with $232,449,421 declared by 806 corporations in the preceding month, and with $883,202,332 by 1,127 companies last November, when disbursements reached a record as a result of the Federal tax on undistributed profits.
Ralph R. Hylind, '38, was chosen president of the Student Council of Fordham College in the undergraduate elections held by twenty-three campus organizations and completed yesterday.

Officials of the Superior Coal Company declined again today to negotiate with representatives of more than 350 miners who have been sitting-down underground for more than a week in its mine at Wilsonville.

A NEW symphonic association made its first public appearance recently under the direction of M. J. Zadikoff. This new orchestra is composed of young musicians most of whom are recent prize-winners of the National Conservatory. Their rendering of Faure's "Shylock" and "Danse de Caligula" was of a high order, and enthusiasm greeted the excellent performance of Marcel ciampi who played the fourth Saint-Saens plano concerto, skill-fully accompanied by the young musicians and their conductor.

IT is probably not an important distinction, especially on Memorial Day, to have been a trap drummer in the mauve decade, but it is worth mentioning because Charles Winninger is prouder of that noisy interlude in his life than he is, for example, of his career as skipper of the showboat; says he knew drumstick tricks at 6 that Abe Lyman is just learning. Mr.

Frank Howell Holden, an architect, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 327 Lexington Avenue, at the age of 67. He was associated in architecture with Robert Kohn and Charles Butler, with offices at 56 West Forty-fifth Street, Many of New York's important buildings have been designed by this firm.

Justice and Mrs. Thomas J. Brady of this city have announced the engagement of Mrs. Brady's daughter, Miss Rita Roberta Zurmuhlen, to Robert W. Lehrfeld, son of Mrs. William H. Lehrfeld of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Lehrfeld.

Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., June 1. SERGEANTS-18th Division, 6th Detective District, designated as acting lieutenants; Emanuel KlineM. G. Meyers Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT--Michael F. Sullivan, Traffic Precinct C, assigned in command, for 30 days, from 8 A. M., July 8, during absence of captain with leave.
The Beechwood Players Club and drama students of the Scarborough School presented "A Midsummer Night's Dream" on Thursday and Friday evenings, at the Woodland theatre on the Frank A Vanderlip estate.
Today's short session in the cotton market was tame, as the New York market was closed and will remain closed until Tuesday.

Miss Margaret Josephine Lepied, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul George Lepied of this city, was martied here this afternoon to Thomas Joseph Costello of New Rochelle, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Costello of New York, in St. Gabriel's Church. The bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. John J. McCahill, officiated.

PARIS.--The number of American citizens residing in Paris was increased by about 500 during 1936 to reach a total of 8,254, French census figures, released by the American consulate here, reveal. The number of American citizens living in all France was given as 11,881.

Only two women have utilized their newly won enfranchisement by registering for the elections to be held July 12. They are Flora Guzman and Emma Ortiz, both Socialist party workers. The ten-day registration period started last Wednesday.
" Unalterable opposition to atheistic communism" and to any public office seekers supporting such doctrines, was pledged today by delegates to the annual State convention of the Knights of Columbus.

Today New York League of Girls' Clubs--Week-end holiday, auspices United Club, Miller Place, L. I. Tuesday A. W. A.--Party. Essex Dane, Shawni Lani and Cassandra, entertainers, 8:30 P. M., clubhouse. Delphian Federation (Montclair Chapter)-Meeting, 10:30 A. M., home of Mrs. Harold Ressler of Short Hills, N. J., on "Figures of the Italian Renaissance."

When the Supreme Court handed down this week its decisions upholding the constitutionality of the Social Security Act the statute was a year and three months old. It had been one of the outstanding issues of a Presidential campaign.

The Interstate Commerce Commission postponed again today the effective date of its order limiting, for trucking companies, the "metropolitan area" about New York City to a region including only the towns adjacent to the city's boundaries and abutting on the Hudson and the waters about Staten Island east of the Hackensack River.
ONE scene does not make a biography. But in one scene Mr. Horton can give you enough of an idea of Hart Crane's melodramatics to illuminate his reputation.

Charles Wesley Hallett of 178 Fifth Avenue, New York City, a banker, sought probate of a will today which names him owner of property his ancestor, William Hallett, acquired by grant from Peter Stuyvesant in 1652.

Dr. William P. Graham has been elected as the sixth chancellor of Syracuse University, the climax of a career of thirty-nine years on the faculty as Professor of Engineering, dean of the College of Applied Science and vice chancellor.

FROM time to time it appears peculiarly fitting to discuss purchases of American art made by the Metropolitan Museum. A little more than a year ago these columns reported that some seventy paintings had been acquired in the decade 1926-36.

Preliminary details of the Princeton Theological Seminary's financial campaign for $2,640,000 for its general needs were disclosed today. Announcement of the campaign, to be carried out over a period of years, was made last week at the 125th annual commencement exercises of the seminary.

Vacant apartments on the West Side, particularly the units of seven rooms and larger are rapidly being leased and the rental outlook for the section is seen as encouraging by Eugene R. Hagemeyer of Slawson Hobbs.

For the first time in its history the charter of Middlebury College will be publicly displayed at commencement in the Sheldon Museum. The charter, 137 years old, will have the most prominent place in an exhibit of scores of old college documents, manuscripts and illustrations which were brought to light during the recently published history of Middlebury, "Father Went to College."

THIRTY channels are now allocated in the international broadcast band of the United States, according to the Federal Communications Commission. There are less than thirty stations, however, since several of the transmitters operate on two or more waves.

LONDON.--Hollywood has come to the rescue of the harassed recruiting department of the British Territorial Army. Patrons of a large cinema in a London suburb were surprised to find recruiting sergeants stationed in the entrance hall of the building busily soliciting the young men who emerged.

The marriage of Miss Aileen Timothy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wililam George Timothy of 955 Park Avenue, to Phillips Roome Turnbull of this city and Montclair, N. J., took place here yesterday at noon in the Central Presbyterian Church.

Coach George Eastment's Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School athletes continued their winning streak today by carrying off the team laurels in La Salle Military Academy's fourth annual interscholastic track and field games on the academy's field.

Des Moines, one of the first cities in organized baseball to play under lights, will pioneer in a different phase of the game tomorrow--helmets for the batters. The Des Moines and Cedar Rapids Western League teams will test the use of polo headgear at the plate.

Lefty Bob Weiland turned in a fine pitching performance today to keep the St. Louis Cardinals in third place in the National League race, deeating Pie Traynor's Pittsburgh Pirates, 2 to 1, in the final game of a twin bill after the Bucs had clouted Dizzy Dean at will in the opener to win. 9 to 4.
Long Island Sound's championship racing season opened this afternoon with the regatta -of the Riverside Yacht Club. The largest fleet for an initial- event in recent years competed.

The Manila Tribune said today that Marshal Douglas MacArthur believes the Philippines will be able to defend themselves after they gain full independence without aid from the United States or any other country.
More than $6,000 in cash and several trophies will be distributed to pilots participating in the eighth annual national soaring contest here June 26 to July 11.

Known as the world's richest Indian, Enus Wilson, 35-year-old Creek, died today of typhoid fever at a hospital here. He was brought here ten days ago from. his $80,000 home at Bald Hill, near Okmulgee, after contracting typhoid on a fishing trip.
Harvard astronomers announced today that they have found a temperature drop of 1,500 degrees centigrade between the surface of the sun and its overlying atmosphere.

Factory, steamboat and locomoative whistles blared today to herald the opening of the Great Lakes Exposition's revised edition for 1937. James Roosevelt, son of the President, cut the ribbon in ceremonies at the gates.
Opposition to the Lyons Residence Bill was strongly expressed yesterday by spokesmen for civic and political groups at a statutory hearing before Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

Forty-seven-knot speed boats, each armed with two 45-knot torpedoes, a machine gun and depth charges, form a small but important part of Italy's sea power, a visit today to the important naval base of La Spezia revealed.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Harriet Littler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Ellsworth Littler of Upper Montclair, N. J., to William Charles Seabrook, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Seabrook of Southampton, England, took place here yesterday in the chapel of the Church of the Ascension. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wallace Goodfellow.

GARRICK," the comic opera by Robert A. Simon and Albert Stoessel, will be given at the Woreester (Mass.) Festival some time in October. The composer, who is director of the festival, will naturally be on hand to conduct his opera. The title role will be taken by Donald Dickson, baritone (now of the Metropolitan Opera Association Spring season), who, at the Juilliard School of Music, was the Garrick at the American premiere last season.

No skipper should cruise to the Peconics for a week-end or even limited to a week. This is too much of an aggravation, certainly during the month of June when the weakfish, two, three and more pounds heavy, are so plentiful and fairly itching to be hooked.

IT was a startled Hollywood that awoke the other morning to learn that Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda had bid successfully to buy up the shares held by Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin and Douglas Fairbanks in the United Artists Corporation for a sum estimated at $10,000,000.

The Chamber of Deputies today refused to act on the Senate's demand for an apology because of illtreatment that Senator Abel Chermont declares he received while in jail awaiting judgment on a charge of connivance in the Leftist revolt of November, 1935.
Premier Leon Blum predicted important disarmament developments within a few days in a speech today at a convention of State employes in the subuch of Montrouge.

The section of the ocean underlying the ice floes at the North Pole is much deeper than has generally been thought heretofore. The first soundings taken by the Soviet wintering party show a depth there of two and a half miles.

Business moved at a faster pace in many of the leading centers of the country last week, with retail sales figures rising to higher levels as a result of a large volume of purchases for the holiday. In some districts, however, labor troubles had a disturbing effect on business in general.

The Committee for Industrial Organization widened its campaign on the city transportation front yesterday, calling upon the Parmelee System, operators of some 2,300 taxicabs, either to agree to a referendum of its 3,200 employes for selection of an exclusive bargaining agent or face a strike.

The Yankees did just about everything to the Athletics in a twin bill at the Stadium yesterday for the edification of a gathering of 39,903 fans. They hit homers in profusion, smacked doubles and were prolific in their fire of singles.
Mrs. Birdie Fluker, aged 50, was found beaten to death in her burning home today and two hours later her Negro chauffeur, Milton Jackson, was arrested for questioning.

The Federal Government's conspiracy case against Ellis H. Parker Sr., the Burlington County detective, and his son, Ellis Jr., with its setting of almost fantastic human relations and factional New Jersey politics, will enter Tuesday its sixth week of trial before Judge William Clark in Newark.

One hundred full years of history will pass in review when Davidson College celebrates its centennial here June 6, 7 and 8. Alumni and friends from many parts of the world will return to this historic campus to take part in the festivities.

In announcing yesterday that he has accepted E. A. Filene's invitation to join him in organizing a chain of cooperative department stores, Flint Garrison said that the act is a logical step in a policy he has long advocated.

MOTORISTS driving north one the west bank of the Hudson River and travelers by rail and river have long been familiar with High Tor. Airplane pilots flying between Albany and Newark rely on its faithful beacon. Yet it took a Broadway success to introduce its steep sides to new batches of hikers.

BARRY--On May 27, Liewellyn Barry Funeral services at St. James's Church, Madison Ave. and 71st St., On Monday, May 31, at 2:30 P. M. Interment private. BATTERSON--Ida Wooster at St. Luke's Hospital, on Friday, May 28, 1937, mother of Walter E. Batterson of Hartford, Conn. Funeral services at Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave., Monday at 10:30 A. M. Interment cedar Hill Cemetery, Hartford, Conn.
The Legislature was prorogued today after yielding to Governor Charles F. Hurley's demand to divert $6,600,000 from the gasoline tax fund to the general budget and to reduce the State tax.

Miss Elsie Winifred Smithers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Leonard Smithers of Maplewood, was married this evening to Wallace Petri Coons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd B. Coons of South Orange. The ceremony took place in Morrow Memorial Church here with the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton officiating.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Sentiment, wrote George Eliot, will live in the heart of humanity as long as people refuse to fashion spoons and knife handles from the bones of their ancestors. On the other hand, the development of machinery in modern times has created an-unsentimental machine psychology.

The marriage of Miss Loretto Noonan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Noonan of Rochester, to Francis P. Beattie, son of Mrs. Frank Martin Beattie, also of this city, took place this morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral here.

Close of play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today follow: Essex 247 (Vere-Hodge 100, not out; Robbins four wickets for 52 runs); Middlesex 137 for four wickets (Hendren 59, not out): at Lord's.

The Dramatic Club of Mercersburg Academy presented Percy MacKaye's "A Thousand Years Ago" this evening before an audience of students, parents and alumni. The presentation was a feature of the graduation week, which began on Thursday with the senior dinner.
An unusually large number of weddings of note have been arranged for June, especially for the second Saturday of the month, and mostly in the country.
Dr. Stanley High, author and educator, will be the principal speaker on Friday at the commencement exercises of Briarcliff Junior College. Twenty-eight students will receive diplomas.

Miss Glenn Rhodes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Rhodes of Montclair, has selected June 18 as the date of her marriage to John Romeyn Litch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln Litch of Bloomfield, formerly of Montclair.

Colgate swept its baseball series with Syracuse by defeating the Orange, 6 to 4, before an Alumni Day throng of 2,500 today. Bob Schlude was credited with the victory, but it was Lefty Paul Allen's relief twirling in the closing frames that stopped Syracuse.
Slowly but none the less surely our native Mountain Laurel (Kalmia latifolia) is gaining recognition as one of the most dependable and most beautiful of broad-leaved evergreens for landscaping.

To the Drama Editor: At a meeting the other day everybody was keen, reporting in turn upon special matters which had been referred to him. A big enterprise was in the making. New ideas snapped out, enthusiasm was rife, yet the success of the scheme would not benefit any one of them personally.

A junior year in Mexico will be conducted by Smith College for the first time this Fall, instead of the usual year spent in Spain by juniors majoring in Spanish. Miss Katherine P. Reding, assistant professor of Spanish at Smith, has been named director of the group in Mexico.

Miss Anna Geraldine Keen, daughter of Mrs. Howard Watkin Keen of this place and the late Mr. Keen, was married this afternoon to Dr. George Bronaugh Ewing of Smith's Grove, Ky., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Ewing of Cincinnati.

Miss Doris Thomsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Thomsen of East Orange, was married here to William A. Brog Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Brog of this city, this afternoon in Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. L. Ward McCreary, pastor of Disciples of Christ Church, East Orange.

Investigations promising "very important contributions on the cause and prevention of virus disease" are being carried on at the Pasteur Institute of Paris with funds granted by Child Neurology Research, endowed last year by the trustees of the Friedsain Foundation.

The return of Dr. Zatae Longsdorff Straw, the girl who endured bell-ringings during her chapel orations to become the first woman to graduate from Dickinson College, will be a feature of the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of co-education at Dickinson.

The President was on familiar and well-loved ground when, facing his Friday press conference, he told of tax evasions and escapes by the very rich. This condition has been the theme of many of his discussions of social and economic reform. Revelations of this general sort in the Pecora inquiry were used as a partial basis for the Securities and Stock Exchange reforms now being administered by the SEC.
Percy Brower has resigned as sales and advertising director of N. K. Winston Co. to become associated with Realty Associates, Inc.

Summons for jury duty will land impartially in the laps of both men and women next September under C the legislation enacted just prior to adjournment of the Legislature, Assistant Commissioner of Jurors James McGurrin informed questioners yesterday.

Housing and community planning will be among the major topics of the sixty-ninth convention of the American Institute of Architects, opening in Boston on Tuesday. The four-day meeting is expected to attract more than 1,000 architects, builders, educators, producers of building materials and representatives of allied industries.
Henry H. Sprague, founder and chairman of the board of the Sprague Meter Company of this city, died today at his home of a heart ailment. He was 79 years old.
A visit to Ireland is part of the itinerary of a well-known American elder statesman now touring Italy and identified in the press of that country as one ALFREDO SCHMIDT.

AS part of its April release, Columbia issued Beethoven's fourth quartet (Opus 18, No. 4, in C minor), played by the Leners, in Masterworks Album No. 288. Of the six to which this belongs, the C minor stands apart. Rather than being an integral part of Opus 18, it is the link between the other five in the group and the three "Rasoumovskys" (Opus 59) that came six years later.
The Franconia of the Cunard White Star Line will return today from her 35,000-mile cruise around the world, on which she visited thirty-three ports in twenty countries. Her passengers include Mr.

The average American, who consumes about 125 pounds of potatoes a year, may expect to pay considerably less for his mashed, hashed brown and French fries this Summer than he did last. Already the effects of a 57 per cent increase in early potato production are being felt.

The necessity for repairing and thoroughly cleaning the exterior of the tomb of General Grant, at Riverside Drive and 123d Street, was emphasized yesterday by officials of the Grant Monument Association.

The election of Tom M. Girdler as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute at the annual meeting of its directors on Thursday does not signify any change in the association's duties and policies as a national service organization for the steel industry, with respect to labor or any other matters, according to steel men who attended the meeting.

Two weeks ago Bunyan Travis, living in Clay County, Southeastern Illinois, was an ordinary farmer. Now he is the envy of his neighbors, for on May 23 the Pure Oil Company, which had a lease on his land, brought in an oil well which even under a 1 1/2-inch pipe choke is flowing about 3,000 barrels a day.

The "dole" in its many forms is on the way out in Canada. A steady reduction in the numbers on direct relief in the industrial centers and the prospects for expanded employment on farms have made Federal and Provincial governments hopeful of being able next year to make relief outlay an incident to and not a big fraction of their budgets.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Orton of Utica, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Orton, to Nelson Sharpe 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Nelson Sharpe of Germantown, Pa.

While New England industry enjoyed its best April since 1929, John L. Lewis's Committee on Industrial Organization put 100 agents into the district to unionize its largest industry, the textile trades.

120-YARD HIGH HURDLES Final Won by John M. Donovan, Dartmouth; James H. Hucker, Cornell, second; Kenneth Ryden, Pittsburgh, third; William H. Watson, Dartmouth, fourth; William W. Rossiter, Cornell, fifth. Time-0:14.8.
A heavily-armed bandit, identified tentatively by Deputy Sheriff Carl Dennin as Lester Howard, 24, of Anderson, was killed here today in a hold-up of the Standard Elevator Company.

Fish Marvin, Westchester realty specialists for many years, opened their Pelham branch yesterday in the old offices at Pelhamdale Avenue and Post Road which the firm occupied for fourteen years, from 1918 to 1932.
Taking 50 out of a possible 63 points in the track event, the Andover track team defeated Exeter, 87 1-3 to 38 2-3 today. Don Donahue of Andover clipped

Students of art at Bennington College, most of them from New York, Boston and other metropolitan areas, have turned to Vermont for the current exhibition of paintings and sculpture at the college, which will run until June 3. A student committee, under the chairmanship of Janet Fraser of New York City, selected fifteen State artists, who are represented in the show.

Local soccer fans will have the opportunity of watching one of Europe's best teams in action today at the Polo Grounds, where the Charlton Athletic Club eleven will oppose a selected American aggregation.

MANY people are receiving an elementary introduction to music in these days in ways that are meant to be painless, not to say enjoyable and interesting. This latest book intended to effect such an introduction will be found enjoyable and interesting and, it may be hoped, painless.

Miss Jeanne Lyman, daughter of Mrs. Burton A. Lyman of this place and the late Mr. Lyman, was married this afternoon to John E. Tunstall, son of Mrs. Harry A. Tunstall, also of Garden City, and the late Mr. Tunstall.

Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow dismissed today a suit of the Schenley Products Company, liquor distributors, to restrain sale of its wares by the Franklin Stores Company at prices below those fixed by the Schenley firm.

Julius S. Gassner will be valedictorian and George J. Dougherty will be salutatorian at the commencement of St. Peter's College, Sunday, June 20, the Rev. Thomas I. O'Malley, S. J., the dean, announced today. Mr. Gassner lives at 151-79 Nineteenth Avenue, Whitestone, L. I. He has been an honor student for four years.
ONE of the last of the season's big group shows--the twenty fourth annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America-opened May 20 at the American Fine Arts Building in Fifty-seventh Street.

Senator Byrd of Virginia, alleging discrepancies between statistics provided by Secretary Wallace and the Assistant Resettlement Administrator, C. B. Baldwin, today requested of Mr. Wallace a complete file of information on the cost of the Shenandoah homestead project in Virginia.

Roger Don Rae, champion pilot, crashed today before 22,500 spectators at the opening of the St. Louis air races at Lambert-St. Louis flying field when his propellor broke in the eighth lap of a ten-lap fifty-mile race.
High school seniors who plan to enter college in the Autumn are advised by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, on how to succeed as freshmen.
THE hours and wave lengths used in the broadcasting of weekly bulletins by the infor mation section of the League of Nations from Geneva are reported by the secretariat of the League as follows:

The marriage of Miss Martha Elizabeth Lerner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Lerner of Brooklyn and Cambridge, Mass., to Edwin Pierce Creede, son of Mrs. George Creede of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Creede, took place yesterday morning in St. Thomas Aquinas Church, Flatbush.
Muddy waters, sweeping down the usually dry Hondo River bed, inundated this Pecos Valley city of about 13,000 tonight after the heaviest storm in thirty-three years.

BERLIN. IN recent years Ernst Wiechert has gained so large a circle of cordial admirers of his delicate yet vigorous writing that many grateful German hearts joined in the celebration of his fiftieth birthday on May 18.

Obscured by the more spectacular success of individual women in Cabinet and diplomatic posts, an imposing number of women have been quietly making history as librarians of some of the most important and technical governmental departments and bureaus in Washington.

AMONG the interesting sights at the recent NACA Conference at Langley Field was that of such outstanding engineers as Igor Sikorsky, G. M. Bellanca, R. B. Beisel of Chance Vought Company, B. C. Boulton of Glenn L. Martin and others seated quietly watching the demonstrations held by newly graduated engineers who had conducted the research necessary for the demonstration over a period of a year.

DUBLIN. ONCE for all I should like to salve my conscience by wondering, in public, how long it will be before American friends will realize that George Moore is dead, that AE does not now hold court, and that all that colorful Dublin is non plus.
At a moment when politicians and political observers are trying desperately to read Neville Chamberlain's character, the new Prime Minister has obligingly supplied a clue.

Engagements of $4,386,000 gold abroad for shipment here--$1,840,000 in England and $2,546,000 in Canada--were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank reported also the arrival here of $5,472,300 gold from England.

THE firing at Forest Hills was started by Jack Crawford, the stalwart Australian with the smooth tennis style. He seems to flow rather than to fly about the court. He doesn't slam the ball; he wafts it. But the red-headed J. Donald Budge on the other side of the net wasn't in any wafting mood. He was bidding for little slams and grand slams, vulnerable.
JUNE beckons the microphone outdoors and away from the padded, windowless studios. Station WNYC will go afield to the various parks and recreational centers to pick up symphonic and band music.

Miss Jean Scott, daughter of Commander Leon B. Scott, U. S. N., became the bride today of Ensign Bernard Clarey of the submarine base, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Clarey of Oskaloosa, Iowa, in the Sacred Heart Church, Groton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond J. Clabby, the pastor.
A timely single by Fabian Gaffke with the bases loaded in the seventh today enabled the Red Sox to come from behind and gain their fifth straight victory by topping the Senators, 4-2.
Spanish Insurgents tonight put into effect strict border vigilance because of what officers said was "a big attack" General Emilio Mola planned to launch tomorrow mornine.
IT will be just as well this Summer if visitors to Maine and Vermont omit references to passports and refrain from inquiring why the said States did not send diplomatic delegations to the coronation.
William Henry Meadowcroft, former confidential secretary to the late Thomas A. Edison, observed his 84th birthday at his home on Lathrop Avenue today.

The Spanish civil war is resulting in the loss of Spain's pyrite business to foreign competitors and is facilitating shipment of pyrites to Germany since Spanish pyrite mines are under the control of General Francisco Franco, the Commerce Department announced today.

Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels's uncompromising challenge to the Catholic Church in his address last night looms today as a historic point of departure into a troubled future. Unless all signs fail it is to be a war without quarter to reduce Catholicism to obedience to the National Socialist regime.

A call to Democratic Socialists, organized labor and progressives to unite for the formation of a third party that would be ready to take the field in the next Presidential election was issued at the national convention of the Social-Democratic Federation in its opening session here today.

Army gained an even break with its traditional service rival, Navy, in two sports today. The Cadets gained their nineteenth baseball victory over the Middies by winning the thirty-first game of the series that started in 1901 by 8-3.

Miss Elisabeth Reynolds Lieb, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clarence William Lieb of the Grange, this place, will be wed to George Douglas Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Bates Lawrence of Mount Kisco, on June 18 in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Arthur Ketchum.
Music Hall of the Air presents an all-instrumental concert with Erno Rapee directing the symphony orchestra: WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.

Miss. Ruth Miriam Jacobson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Jacobson of Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Hilton Abbott Leff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon S. Leff, also of Brooklyn. The ceremony will be performed on June 20 by the Rev. Harry Halpern in the East Midwood Jewish Center, Brooklyn.

Miss Florence Allen Branigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter I. Branigan of this city, has chosen June 28 for her marriage to Dr. Edward C. Berger, son of Dr. Grace Berger of 77 Park Avenue, New York, and the late Dr. Theodore Berger.

The Princeton varsity tennis team brought its 1937 campaign to a successful close today on the Church courts by overwhelming the U. S. Naval Academy, 9-0. The match, also the last of the season for the visitors, leaves the Tigers with a seasonal record of six triumphs in ten starts.

The late Summer blooming aconites are flowers capable of making up for a possible earlier disappointment with delphiniums. The aconite or monkshood is closely related to delphinium, and is characterized by the same tall stateliness.
Six free lectures for persons interested in entering the financial field will be delivered on the mornings of Wednesday and Thursday next at the offices of William J. Frye Co., 19 Rector Street.

Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, said today that the depression situation for the New Jersey building and loan associations had been cleared up and that their structure rested now on a stronger foundation than ever.

LAST year the National Safety Council launched a drive to reduce traffic accident deaths 7 per cent annually through 1940. The national toll increased, but a surprising segment of total population actually accomplished a 7 per cent reduction in spite of greater volume of travel.
Worthington Dodd, Cornell righthander, held Dartmouth to a single hit in the nightcap of an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League double-header today to give his team an even break.

THOUSANDS of Americans departing for Europe at this season of the year walk up the gangplank, taking for granted a great, steady liner which will speed them across the ocean. Of course it is well ventilated, agreeably heated, brilliantly lighted and equipped with every device for safety and comfort. The staterooms are spacious, have beds with spring mattresses, have hot and cold running water, a telephone for service and often a private bath.

Mr. and Mrs. George L. Ohrstrom of Greenwich entertained with a ball tonight for 250, in connection with the annual Fairfield and Westchester race meet to be held on Decoration Day on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here.

ENCOURAGED by the response to the one-day recreational excursions, the rail roads are going ahead with more ambitious plans to get the city dweller out into the country. A new type of train-a sport and hobby train-left New York yesterday on a run to Great Barrington, Lee and Lenox in the Berkshires.
Members of the New York State Bankers Association, who are holding their annual convention on a chartered ship, arrived here early today for two days of social activities.

Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast president of the International Longshoremen's Association, threatened today to call a union referendum to consider withdrawing from the American Federation of Labor and joining the Committee for Industrial Organization.
The annual Spring festival under the auspices of the Vocational Service for Juniors will be held Thursday afternoon at the Hudson Guild Settlement, 436 East Twenty-seventh Street.

With the recent addition of Dover, N. J., to membership in the Lakeland Council of Morris and Sussex Conties in that State, the original group of six Lakeland communities has now been increased to eight, the other late addition being Mount Arlington. The object of the organization is to improve so far as possible the residential and recreational facilities in the various lake areas and to stimuate public interest in their many Summer attractions.
FOR American readers this book presents itself specifically as a companion to motorists in England and Western Europe. It is an excellent guide, aid and counsel for motoring abroad.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Frances H. Huddleson, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. George Herman Huddleson of Schofield Barracks, Hawaii, to August Merz Jr. of Hanover, N. M., son of Mr. and Mrs. August Merz of East Orange.

Physicians tonight awaited a crisis in the condition of George F. Baker, as the New York banker, who underwent an operation for peritonitis Tuesday night, slept, aboard the yacht that brought him here early today after a 300-mile dash from mid-Pacific.

Premier Hendryk Colijn having resigned, as is customary after a general election, Queen Wilhelmina has had consultations with political leaders in the past two days. After having received the heads of the six most important parties, she had a long talk with Mr. Colijn today despite the fact that he is not officially the leader of his party.

Walter C. Gilbert, founder and president of the Gilbert Storage Company, 39 West Sixty-sixth Street, New York, and vice president of the Bowling Green Storage and Van Company, died suddenly at his home here today of a heart attack at the age of 69.

Very often the flower garden is in need of an edging to define the border, tie the color scheme more closely together or to add that final touch which makes the garden a finished picture. Choosing flowering plants for this purpose is a fairly simple task once the requirements for edging purposes are met.

With the ailing Adrian Quist lost to the team, Australia's crippled Davis Cup forces were put to rout by the United States in the opening two singles matches of the North American Zone final at Forest Hills yesterday and little short of a miracle can stop the Americans from qualifying for the interzone final in Europe.

C. V. (Sonny) Whitney's polo team of white-shirted players accounted for a decisive victory on No. 2 Field at the Meadow Brook Club today when they defeated a four led by Mike Phipps, 11 to 5, in one of the members' matches.
Fifty policemen, reinforced by additional officers in twelve radio cars, were required to check a riot today in "Polk Gulch," unofficially renamed from Polk Street for the Golden Gate Bridge fiesta.

Thomas Tullo, 14-year-old schoolboy who was rescued last night from the basin of the Passaic Flls by police and members of the General Hospital staff, died this morning at the hospital from shock and internal injuries.

From the press and studios of the Rivista Illustrata of Mussolini's paper, Popolo d'Italia, of Milan, comes a folio of 1.000-odd heavy calendered pages entitled "Imperial Italy." The binding and format are the last word in "new art" book-making;

Specific government problems will be attacked by the Institute of Local Government at the Pennsylvania State College next semester as it begins a research program in fulfillment of one of the objectives stated at its organization seven months ago.
The output of Ontario gold mines in April amounted to $6,979,588, according to a report from the Department of Mines. The output in March was $7,308,394 and it was $6,646,735 in April, 1936.

Miss Beatrice Alexandria Bennett, daughter of Mrs. Frank G. Bennett of Nutley, formerly of this place, and the late Mr. Bennett, was married today to William Ernst Haberland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Haberland of Nutley.

A buying movement of substantial proportions and involving practically all industrial commodities will develop early this Fall and carry through the balance of the year, purchasing executives, who returned from their annual convention last week in Pittsburgh, agreed yesterday.
The East offered a threat to the West today as Navy's crew cleared its decks for action at Poughkeepsie with a clean record of victory behind it.

Undergraduates in colleges for women have made their selections of officers for next year, among them the most coveted position of all, head of Student Government, or "Stu-G," as it is called in most institutions.

Miss Leila Hood Walters of 444 East Fifty-eighth Street, daughter of Jerre Hilsman Walters of Albany, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Walters, was married here yesterday noon in Grace Church, to David Hill Murray, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Tucker Murray of Cambridge, Mass.

Warmer weather produced a spurt in activity in the wholesale market last week and mail requisitions were much heavier than during the previous week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. The report continues:

The first meeting of the Consumers National Federation since the announcement of its formation early this month will be held this week with the return from the West of its chairman, Helen Hall, it was learned here yesterday.

RECENT Shakespearean revivals in New York have had one surprising reaction in the Maryland countryside. Quickened interest in the acting editions prepared by Edwin Booth, and now resurrected, is sending Shakespearean students and lovers of the stage

Clearing Spring skies have already begun to send the annual parade of students to the Holden Observatory at Syracuse University. During the past month more than 300 persons have visited the gray stone building atop Observatory Hill, the register shows.
Discovery of a secret traffic in arms for Spanish Government armies in which more than twenty persons were implicated was announced here today.

TOMORROW night another theatrical season will go into the records, humbly there to await such judgment as a busy history may accord it. As a matter of fact, the last month or so has been quiet, so still as to suggest only the ghost of the theatre,

Although authorities in New York and other States have been advised of the extension granted to New York automobile operators whose licenses normally would expire tomorrow at midnight, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, issued another reminder yesterday.

An analysis of the tragic lives of 400 women embezzlers throughout this country was made public yesterday by the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company of Baltimore. The names of the women were not disclosed.

The Police Department will put on a three-day exposition and show in Madison Square Garden beginning next Wednesday evening which will depict, in a manner as complete and graphic as possible, what the residents of New York get for the $165,000 or so they spend every day for police protection.

Pres ident Roosevelt devoted most of to day to work on his message recommending study and legislation designed to stop income tax avoid ance and evasion, a message ex pected to go to Congress on Tuesday.

Anouncement has been made by Mrs. Charles G. Stupp of Rye, N. Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Betsy Cheney, to George C. schweizerhof o Spuyten Duyvil, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert G. Schweizerhof of Philadelphia.

The pre-commencement program at Drexel Institute of Technology will be marked by three events this week, the most important of which is the traditional Institute Day on Wednesday, at which time scholastic honors for the entire year are announced.
The so-called Oslo powers--they are seven and all small-met here this week in an attempt to bring back prosperity to the world. They signed accords destined to reinforce the original Oslo convention.

AMERICANS are flocking to Paris, lured by the travel season and the city's exposition. After the usual tourist fashion, they are taking in the Tuileries Gardens, the Louvre, Versailles, Napoleon's Tomb -- and the restaurants.

BERG--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph (nee Peggy Ellenson), announce the bar mitzvah of their son, George Shepard, June 5, at the Jewish Center, West 86th St. GILBERT-Mr. David, announces the bar mitzvah of his son, Marvin (Buddy), Saturday. June 5. at Institutional Synagogue, 148 West 85th 9:30 A. M.

Wellesley College freshmen have just had their first experience with "room-drawing," one of the most democratic features of their college life. The Wellesley system is based, not on how much a student can afford for a room, but on how lucky she is at drawing a low number.

Patriotic, civic and religious organizations throughout the city will pay tribute today and tomorrow to the nation's military dead. While religious and memorial services will be held today, three parades will hold the main interest in the celebrations tomorrow.
The official list of Marylebone Borough births today disclosed that the third son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh was born on Coronation Day, May 12, at a Devonshire Place clinic.

Peaceful Harbor, the two-and-onehalf-acre waterfront property of Mrs. Olga B. Osborn, in Norwalk, Conn., has been leased to John and Lewis Trounstein. The residence is a white Colonial house built in 1781 and restored in 1929.

A new syllabus in spelling for elementary and junior high schools, which reduces the number of required words, has been sent to the schools of this city, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced last week. Suggestions on method, diagnostic analysis and remedial measures are given in the syllabus.

Plans for Manhattan College's eighty-fourth commencement, which will be held on the campus in Riverdale a week from Tuesday, were announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, president of the college. Cardinal Hayes, a graduate of the class of 1888, will preside at the exercises, at which about 250 will receive degrees.

St. Cecilia's array of athletes from Greenpoint regained the senior division championship after a lapse of five years at the thirtyfirst running of the Catholic Schools Athletic League elementary schools track and field meet at Wingate, Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Announcement was made today of the marriage on March 30 in Elkton, Md., of Miss Vera Walden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Walden of this city, to Thomas MacGillery Barkley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Barkley of WinstonSalem, N. C. Mr. and Mrs. William L. Kuebler of Allentown, Pa., were the couple's only attendants.
Twelve swimming pools were opened by the Department of Parks at 10 A. M. yesterday in the five boroughs. The pools will be open to 5 P. M. until June 26. After that date they will close at 10 P. M.

" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" were given last night by the Hippodrome. Opera Company with familiar casts. The first emplayed Irride Pilla as Santuzza, Mildred Ippolito as Lola, Enrico Coppellotti as Turiddu, Norman Roland as Alfio and Gina Castro as Lucia.

With improved footing in the ring today after the recent rains, Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim's Firenze Red Tape gave a splendid performance in the thoroughbred hunters middle and heavyweight class at the Devon horse show.
The United States Ambassador and Mrs. Bingham were present at the coronation ball held at the American Woman's Club in Grosvenor Street on Monday night.

Still riding high on the momentum gained during its triumphant sweep through the West, the Giant Express ran rough shod over Jimmy Wilson's luckless Phillies today, ironed them out backward and forward, and extended the New York winning streak to eight in a row by bagging both games of a doubleheader.

Nine men were killed today in view of thousands of spectators at Empire Air Day celebrations that were to mark the rebirth of Britain as an air power. Many persons received serious burns and other injuries in attempts to rescue the crews of more than a dozen wrecked airplanes.

Douglass C. Fonda of Orange, N. J., took the lead on points in the amateur outboard races at Liverpool today in the opening regatta of the New York State Power Boat Racing Association's State circuit.

The German press greet Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Great Britain with reserve born of hope. It is suggested-and the attitude is undoubtedly official-that Mr. Chamberlain can be expected to make an effort to reach better relations with Germany, but the comment suggests that in case of failure he will be more difficult to deal with than Stanley Baldwin was.

HOLLYWOOD is altogether endearing when it turns its attention to the period drama. It spareth not the research expert, it stinteth not the artisan, it goeth to town. No matter what liberties the producer may take with the historic or biographical truths, the settings generally can be counted upon to be correct in large and small detail.

A memorial service for members of the Police Department who were killed during the World War or who died in performance of official duty was held yesterday morning in police headquarters. Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Valentine were present.

The Lionel Corporation of New York manufacturer of electric trains and other toys, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed issue of 77,500 shares of $10-par common stock at $12 a share, for a total cash value of $930,000.
Edward A. Lewin, a barber, now in his seventy-fourth year, and familiarly known to his patrons in the Wall Street district as "Ed," holds a unique record in tonsorial annals.

If the moves toward consolidation of railroads, which provided some of the more spectacular developments of financial history immediately before the stock market panic of 1929, are to be resumed, Wall Street believes they will be made along new lines.
Plans for construction of a second addition to the Diesel locomotive plant of the Electro-Motive Corporation here about June 1 were announced today by H. L. Hamilton, president.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Mintz of Brooklyn have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Lucile Mintz, to Herbert P. Wilson, son of Paul Wilson of the Bronx, and the late Mrs. Wilson. The ceremony was performed on Friday by the Rev. Dr. B. Benedict Glazer in his study at Temple Emanu-El, New York.

Nine new meet records, including a Long Island mark, were shattered today as Central High School of Valley Stream scored 32 1/2 points to win its third straight South. Shore Athletic League track and field title in the third running of the games.

LONDON. IF there is any man living who has earned the right to an opinion on musical biography it is surely Ernest Newman, whose recent life of Wagner has enhanced his reputation as an authority in this field.
Mr. and Mrs. James W. Wadsworth gave a dinner tonight at the 1,925 F Street Club. Dinner was served in the garden at small tables and the guests included officials and diplomats.

Architectural education in this country would be improved if it were confined to fewer schools with greater resources, according to the report of the committee on education of the American Institute of Architects. The report will be submitted next Wednesday at the sixty-ninth annual convention of the institute, which will be held in Boston.
THERE was, Mr. Wells tells us, blood on the moon the night he was born. There was also a conjunction of stars which gave the son of the fighting Wellses an itch to travel, take risks and see things.

The University of Pittsburgh will celebrate its sesquicentennial this week with exercises centering largely about two buildings nearing completion on its "new campus" in Pittsburgh's civic center. Tuesday and Wednesday will be given to the dedication and inspection of the Stephen Foster Memorial.
The boys in blue who repulsed successive waves of gray at Gettysburg in '63 are in full retreat themselves today before a more relentless foe-old age.

" CONSIDER me for the nonce as one retired from the racket"--that is the latest winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, Eugene O'Neill, wiring from San Francisco that no part of his eight-play cycle will be produced next season;
The Samuel H. Kress Foundation has presented to Rollins College the Florentine tempera painting on panel, "Madonna and Child Enthroned," by Cosimo Rosselli (14391507).

An address by the Very Rev. Dr. Aloysius J. Hogan, dean of Georgetown University, will open baccalaureate week at Georgian Court College here tomorrow afternoon. Commencement exercises of the twenty-seventh graduating class take place next Saturday afternoon.
Roland Allison, 27, and his wife, Rose, 25, will never be on any relief rolls while they have their health-and they are fine physical types.

On a floe which a few days ago marked the location of the North Pole, but which has drifted from that purely mathematical conception of the top of the world, sit bearded Professor Otto J. Schmidt and a little colony of Soviet scientists.

THIS place, whose tourist season is just beginning, got its start as a white settlement a few decades before the Pilgrims waded toward Plymouth Rock. Easterners are not aware of that, or, if they ever knew, just forgot about it.

A survey to ascertain the percentage of business done by representative coat and suit firms with chain stores discloses that "the independent retailer is still the dominant factor in apparel distribution," according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

OLD-TIME hand-woven coverlets recall a distinctly native American handicraft. To the collector they offer a wide variety of types and patterns, their picturesque names identifying them often with localities and sometimes even with families which produced them. Blue and white cotton or wool, or the two combined, were the usual materials, and these spreads were often from start to finish a truly homemade product.
H. R. Tolley, AAA Administrator, defended the government's farm program today, saying that most of the "sensational" criticism of it is "without foundation in fact."

An empire press conference attended by delegates of all the British dominions and colonies closed last night with a dinner given by them at the Mayfair Hotel to Major and LadyViolet Astor at whose town house its sessions have been held during the last week.

With 300 athletes from twenty-two New Jersey schools participating, the annual New Jersey prep school track meet was held today on the Annenberg Field at Peddie. Five records were set, two each in Classes 3 and 4 and one in Class 2.

Mr. and Mrs. James C. M. Millard of Ridgewood, N. J., gave a dinner last night on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Kate Davison Rice and her fiance, Roger Williams. Miss Rice is a daughter of Schuyler Nelson Rice of Highland Park, N. J., and the late Mrs. Rice, and Mr. Williams is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Williams of this city.
Bubblesome, 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by S. Paranella, won the Agawam Handicap, feature event of Agawam Park's opening program, before a crowd of 15,000 today.
Within eight hours of the death of his wife Samuel M. Knoop, 68 years old, of Brooklyn, died in the Oil City Hospital today of a fractured skull and other injuries.

Four years of racing in Texas with legalized pari-mutuel betting at the track has resulted in such a change in sentiment that Governor James V. Allred has called a special session of the Legislature to act on repeal of the Texas Racing Law.

Preparations for an active homebuilding campaign are under way in the large tract known as the Briarwood section of Queens, reports Major Herbert O. Yardley of the Willis Co. realty firm at Forest Hills West. The Briarwood area, he explains, is just beyond Queens Boulevard, in the Kew Gardens section at the Van Wyck Avenue station of the municipal subway station.

A bridge and garden party, another in a series of entertainments being held this Spring in various communities throughout Westchester County for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help, will take place Friday afternoon in the garden of Miss Marian Stewart, 161 Primrose Avenue. Mount Vernon.

Angelo Trulio, unattached, scratch man, defeated Sam Berlowitz, Union Temple, with an eight handicap, 21--16, 21--12, yesterday as the invitation four-wall handicap tourney sanctioned by the A. A. U. began at Ravenhall, Coney Island. Henry Herz, Bedford Y. M. C. A., with 4 points, topped Ken Schifferson, Pastime A. C., with 8 points, 21-14, 21-12.
Polar Flight, a 5-year-old owned by F. M. Alger Jr., won the $3,000 added Inaugural Handicap, first stake race of Detroit's Spring meeting, before a crowd of 15,000 today.

Manager Burleigh Grimes made the magnificent gesture before 22,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday and only the want of one timely single prevented the perfect reward of two ninth-inning triumphs for the Dodgers over the Boston Bees.

A noteworthy performance by Miss Erna Kompa, holder of numerous back-stroke records, and two upsets featured the inaugural A. A. U. swimming meet of the new outdoor season in the Manhattan Beach pool conducted yesterday by the Women's Swimming Association of New York. Miss Kompa turned in the best feat of the day in winning both her heat and the final of the 150-yard dorsal event in fast times.

Mr. and Mrs. William Rogers Breck of Philadelphia are at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran are at Ranley House, Southampton, L. I., for the Summer. Mrs. A. Henry Higginson, who had been at the Madison, sailed on the Britannic for England.

A powerful Rollins varsity eight beat the Kent School sixth form boat and the Williams varsity over the mile course on the Housatonic River. The crews got off to an even start, then the Rollins boat shot ahead to gain a quarter-length lead.
A baccalaureate service tomorrow will open the annual commencement exercises at New York Military Academy. The Rev. John F. Hagen, Chaplain, will conduct the service.

WHETHER in his native Pennsylvania, where he is Professor of English at the university, or in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, where he spends the Summers on his farm, Cornelius Weygandt loves old things, simple things, things that grow naturally from, and that always belong to, their own soil.

Miss Isabel Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hale Anderson of Caldwell, was married here this afternoon in St. Peter's Church to Richard Stedman Holden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Holden of Old Bennington, Vt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold R. Onderdonk and the Rev. David N. Kirkby.

Max Kaesche of the Ridgewood (N. J.) Country Club won the qualifying medal in the Houvenkopf Country Club invitation golf tournament today with a score of 41, 36-77. Match play will begin tomorrow, with the final Monday.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, addressing alumnae and students of St. Mary's Hall here today, said "the greatest obstacle to progress that the world faces in 1937 is the selfish and selfcentered individual."

Baccalaureate degrees will be received by 188 seniors of New Jersey College for Women Saturday at the sixteenth annual commencement of the college. The opening event of Senior Week will be a class picnic at Indian Cove on Tuesday.

Representing the most unusual extracurricular activity at the University of Pennsylvania, the Peregrine Club, composed of devotees of falconry is completing its first year as a formal organization and is laying plans for a series of meets next Fall.

A two-day Irish carnival. or feis, for the benefit of the Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary, 7 State Street, will be held next Saturday and Sunday at Innisfail Park, Broadway and 240th Street, and the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.

After three weeks of testimony before the Department of Commerce investigating board and its advisory committees, including the foremost German and American experts on lighter-than-air craft, it is still impossible to determine conclusively the cause of the fire and explosions

The six-story Lincoln Apartments at 306-310 West Fifty-first Street, on plot 60 by 100.5 feet, west of Eighth Avenue, will be sold in foreclosure on Tuesday, in the Vesey Street rooms by B. Hollander Son. The action is brought by Emil J. Winterroth et al. to satisfy a judgment of $55,799 and interest.

Princeton University's unpredictable baseball forces scored their outstanding triumph of the 1937 season on university field today, before 1,200 spectators, administering a 7-2 defeat to a favored Harvard nine to gain their first sweep of a Crimson series in more than a decade.

ACTION of leading car manufacturers in the lower-price field indicates that motorists still are thinking in terms of economy in the operation of their automobiles. This is particularly true of fleet owners who are interested in saving even a fraction of a cent per mile.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH the threat of an actors' strike (which had been viewed here with apprehension not unmingled with anticipation) dispelled, the thoughtful quarters of the industry are currently concerned with another problem--one which has its humorous side.

In three of the closest races in many years on Lake Cayuga, two Syracuse crews triumphed over Cornell eights in their annual Spring day regatta today, with Cornell scoring its only victory in the freshman contest.

Andrew M. Conneen Jr. of this city has announced the engagements of his daugthers, Miss Nancy Conneen, to William G. Hetherington, and Miss Mary Conneen to Charles M. Denise Jr. The announcement was made this afternoon at a reception at the Conneen home.
By declaring war on the Committee for Industrial Organization the special conference of the American Federation of Labor this week opposed its methods of organization to those of the C. I. O.

WASHINGTON. IS the nation coming back? After the mistakes and the disasters of the post-war years, is it headed toward permanent recovery? Is it building a future that will be more secure than the past?

Miss Joan Veronica Bergin, daughter of James E. Bergin of this city and the late Mrs. Bergin, was married yesterday to Edward L. Steiniger, son of Stephen V. Steiniger of Jackson Heights. The Rev. Walter Kellenberg performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

For the eighteenth time in the less than five years of his show career, Championn Sturdy Max, English setter, owned by the Maridor Kennels of Dwight Ellis, East Longmeadow, Mass., today was awarded the best-in-show title.
The holiday social activities began here tonight with a dinner dance at the Stamford Yacht Club and a supper dance at the Hubbard Heights Golf Club.

The Maidstone Club's second Saturday luncheon of the season was held today. Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley has again rented the David Green Mulford house, while her daughter and son-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Boots, have taken the E. C. Mulford house near by.
Sir Emerson and Lassator, both owned by the Valdina Farm of Texas and ridden by Leroy (Buddy) Haas, made it a field day for that establishment at Washington Park today as they swept the stake card.

Cornell's polo team, holder of the Eastern Intercollegiate indoor title, scored a spectacular victory over the New Mexico Military Institute today. Nearly 5,000 Spring Day visitors saw the Ithacans register a 9-7 triumph after staving off the visitors' rally in the final period.

Miss Marjorie Apgar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Apgar of Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday to James Acton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oakford W. Acton of Salem, N. J. The ceremony, which took place in Grace Episcopal Church, Jamaica, was performed by the Rev. Joseph H. Titus.
Under the auspices of the Loyal Workers, of which Mrs. A. Frank Imhof is president, the final card party in a series for this season will be held the afternoon of June 7 at the Hotel McAlpin.

Samuel Untermyer will give a Spring garden party Thursday afternoon in the amphitheatre at Greystone, his place in Yonkers, for members of the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities. The occasion will mark the first general meeting of the entire membership since the amalgamation of the women's divisions of the two federations.

Pope Piux XI, who will celebrate his eightieth birthday Monday, received several hundred pilgrims today. Among them was a group of thirty Italian-Americans headed by the Rev. Giles Rutulo of New York.
