Disagreement with the view of Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County. Republican Chairman, that the party might well support for Mayor a Democrat of the type of George B. McClellan, William J. Gaynor or John Purroy Mitchel, was expressed yesterday by former Representative Charles G. Bond. Mr.
Camp Jane Addams, maintained by the National Youth Administration on Lake Tiorati, Harriman State Park near Suffern, N. Y., will open the second term of the season on Friday.

The friction that has been growing steadily between Congress and the military, the latter supported by President Federico Laredo Bru, for the last few weeks brought forth a flood of rumors today that the Chief Executive may dissolve Congress.
The American Federation of Labor, its battle plans completed, began formally today its offensive against John L. Lewis and the C. I. O. for supremacy in the labor movement.

THE midseason collections are in full swing, offering much that is new for Summer and holding forth promise of fresh ideas for the early Autumn. Once again Paris designers have set their imaginations to work.

An accident prevention campaign will be launched by the Police and Health Departments on Wednesday. It will be continued throughout the Summer, Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday. The importance of home accident prevention and disease prevention will be stressed.
DURING the coming Summer a number of Courts of Love, similar to the romantic tribunals which flourished seven centuries ago, will be revived throughout Provence.

At noon last Monday the two houses of Congress were called to order at opposite ends of the Capitol in Washington. Members answered to the roll. Routine matters were considered. Then in both House and Senate legislative clerks read amid applause a message from the President of the United States.

For year-round beauty few trees surpass the horse-chestnut (Aesculus hippocastanumm), which blooms about this time. Throughout each season it adds distinctive charm to lawn, park or roadside. The unfolding of a horse-chestnut bud in early Spring affords one of the most delightful studies in nature.

THE coronation over, first nights have begun again. Yesterday produced an over elaborate and unsatisfactory thriller. by Noel Scott called "And the Music Stopped," and every evening, as far ahead as we can see,

A RECENT visitor to the city of Washington, D. C., went there to attend a music festival at which music new and old was presented to an invited public. Some of the new music had unmistakable vitality and physiognomy. Some of it appeared mannered, or altogether lifeless. This is no denigration of modern music, for similar conditions have existed through the centuries.

Indications that Germany's foreign policy is being subjected to a fresh review by Chancellor Adolf Hitler and that it has already experienced a significant reorientation in respect to Anglo-German relations are affording intriguing speculation for neutral diplomatic circles.

Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Senator Dunnigan of New York authorizing the Board of Transportaltion to construct a spur from the city's Independent Subway Lines in Queens to the site of the World's Fair.

TANTALIZED by warm, sunny days, New Yorkers need not swallow their longing for the outdoors until the yearly two-weeks-with-pay rolls "found. They can play outside now-at home-for the city invites them to take part in a far greater variety of sports than most resorts can provide and at much lower cost.
Alabama and Fordham Universities will renew football relations Oct. 7, 1939, Coach Frank Thomas announced today.

Benjamin Stolz, lawyer, civic and philanthropic leader and a Democratic candidate for State Attorney General in 1926, died this morning at his home here. He had been in ill health for a long time and recently grew much worse. He was 68 years old.
An impressive performance of the Mass in B Minor with Dr. Bruce Carey conducting climaxed the Bethlehem Bach Choir's thirtieth annual festival here today.

Wholesale extension to the American market of a French lottery practice of "splitting" tickets and reissuing them at a large profit has been revealed here through numerous inquiries to French official offices in Washington and this city.

With a four-run rally in the ninth inning the Fordham freshman baseball team defeated the Milford Prep nine today, 8 to 6. The visitors went into the lead in the third inning, but were overtaken, and at the end of the eighth trailed by six runs to four.

Thirteen hits and twelve errors contributed by Trinity gave Williams a 15-7 victory today. Out-hit by the visitors, the Purple nine bunched its drives to score seven runs in the fourth inning as the Trinity fielding crumbled. Neither starting pitcher lasted the route.

Mrs. Tullio Romano of 3,803 Avenue M, Brooklyn, will open her home Tuesday night for a meeting of forty young women serving on the junior committee for the dinner dance to be held under the auspices of the committee for Italian families of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities Thursday night at the Half Moon Hotel.

REVIVAL: In Alabama last week Judge W. W. Callahan set July 6 for resuming the trials in the Scottsboro case. For six years the State courts have been involved with the nine Negro boys accused of criminal attack upon two white women in March, 1931. Efforts are now being made to end what amounts to an impasse by some sort of compromise.

A delay of at least six months in establishing an official seal of quaity for products of members of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., appeared certain here yesterday when officials admitted that the plan had not progressed far enough to be voted upon at the association's semi-annual convention opening at Hot Springs, Va., tomorrow.

Two houses, similar to the one now on exhibition in the John Wanamaker store in this city were opened yesterday, at Orchard Hill, Hartsdale, Westchester County, and at Chatham, N. J. A third similar house will be opened next Saturday at Harbour Green, Massapequa, L. I. All are named "Shutters and Shingles" and were built by the Harmon National Real Estate Corporation and furnished by John Wanamaker. Albert E. Olson is the architect.

MANHATTAN JACOBSON, SAMUEL LOUIS (April 6). Estate, $1,000. To Laura C. Eadie, sister, executrix, 1,411 E. 68th St., Chicago; Aimee E. Walls, 1,445 E. 67th St., Chicago; Lillian C. Jacobson and Sadie J. Samuel, 6,646 Stery Ave.

Mr. and Mrs. Leland Day Albin of Plainfield have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jean Albin, to John H. Griesel Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur H. Rogers, also of this city, on June 22.
Ray Volpi, Manhattan's ace moundsman, limited City College to six hits while his team pounded out fifteen safeties to score an 8-to-3 victory yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.
WITH the signing by Governor Lehman of a bill providing for rapid transit to the Rockaways, the time is near when another Summer playground will be made convenient to New York City's millions.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 26, 1937, aggregated $8,330,000,000, or 5 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 12 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry H. Phillips of 911 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabel Phillips, to Harold Vineberg of Montreal. Announcement has been made also of the engagement of Miss Jane Katherine Appleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Appleman of Omaha, to Miss Phillips's brother, John Henry Phillips.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Julius Ackermann of Flushing, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Janice Ackermann to Dr. Theodore Jerome Prowda of Fulton, N. Y.

Charles Hooper, well known as the writer of 78,000 letters to newspapers in every country of the world, wrote to The Associated Press yesterday to announce that he was going back West. Mr. Hooper, a 'native New Yorker, who went West twenty-four years ago, returned' here from Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, last November.

Foreign Minister Wang Ching-hui has declined to consider Japan's request for immediate settlement of the Swatow affair, saying that because the versions differed widely China would await the report of the joint investigating commission.

The nine Supreme Court justices used their weekly conference today to decide whether to hear cases Involving six administration laws. They will announce their decision on Tuesday, the closing day of the momentous eight-month term.

THE Essex County Symphonic Society will open its second stadium concert series Tuesday night, June 8, in Newark, N. J., with Erno Rapee as director. Jascha Heifetz, violinist, will be the soloist in the Mendelssohn concerto.

Dr. James J. McDevitt, a retired physician and former city of Boston police surgeon, died today of pneumonia at his home. His age was 76. Dr. McDevitt stu??ed medicine at the Bellevue Medical School, New York, and was graduated in 1884.

Few of the popular garden flowers continue to show such real and diversified improvement in the new varieties which are constantly being introduced as the Tall Bearded irises. In the pure yellow selfs, which now range from the palest primrose and lemon to deep gold, and in the new red tones, this development has been particularly striking.

Plans have been completed for the annual program of Union College interneships in government. Twelve juniors and seniors from the course in State and local government have qualified to work in eight governs ment offices in Albany, Schenectady and New York City.

By authorization of Secretary of War Woodring, Mrs. Julia O. Flikke will become "Major Flikke" on Tuesday, and for the next several years will be the ranking woman officer of the United States Army, the dierecting head of the Army Nurse Corps, whose personnel is limited by law to 625 commissioned officer nurses.

Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, the Minister of Finance, who seldom speaks without purpose, protested here yesterday reports that Germany had entered on an inflationary course. He asserted that there was not the least danger of either currency or credit inflation and that the Reich's financial position was continually improving.

Calling the capital gains tax an obstacle in the path of general business recovery, the board of directors of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York urges that the capital gains sections of both the Federal and State income tax laws be repealed.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 27: CAPTAIN Tennet, E. H., Dental Corps, granted sick leave of three months; to await orders at Portsmouth. Va.
Miss Anita Lizana of Chile defeated Miss Alice Marble, American singles titleholder, 9-7, 9-7, in the final round of the Middlesex tennis championships today.

Creation of a hydrostatic or liquid pressure of 1,500,000 pounds per square inch, equivalent to that which would exist 420 miles under the sea, or beneath a mass of limestone 100 miles thick, is reported by Dr. Thomas C. Poulter, director of the research foundation at Armour Institute of Technology.
Many of the country, yacht and beach clubs in Westchester started their programs of sport and social events today in celebration of the Decoration Day week-end.
The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to think long and hard before passing the administration's Labor Standards Bill.

A map showing the World's Fair site and its relation to Forest Hills has been prepared by the Cord Meyer Development Company for distribution. J. Edward Breuer has been appointed sales agent for Lido Realty Corporation, which is offering 600 acres of property for development at Lido Beach, L. I.
Darling Stores Corporation and Subsidiaries -- Three months to April 30: Sales, $1,244,381, net profit after depreciation but subject to taxes and year-end adjustments, $67,324.

Erasmus Hall High School of Brooklyn and Charles E. Gorton High School of Yonkers won team championships in the two divisions of the third annual interscholastic Latin sight- reading contest at New York University's Washington Square College, it was announced yesterday by Dean Milton E. Loomis.

Mrs. Emma Ovenshine Harbord, wife of Major Gen. James G. Harbord, U. S. A., retired, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, died at her home in Dogwood Lane here this morning after a five weeks' illness. Her age was 70.

Unmarred by accidents such as the death of two men and serious injuries to five others yesterday, qualification runs in the silver anniversary 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Speedway were completed today.

A collision between a truck and a street car of the Willis Avenue line resulted in slight injuries to three women and the treatment of five others for shock at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The accident occurred at 187th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx.

HAVING built a solid reputation as conductor and organizer, Sir Thomas Beecham now seems to court fame as a witty speaker. There are few public occasions concerned with music and musicians where Sir Thomas's voice is not heardwhich is perhaps natural; musicians, as a rule, are not witty speakers, and Sir Thomas can often be witty and can always be trusted to say something to stir the conscience of the public.

A college president who in twenty-five years has transformed his institution from the smallest to the largest private junior college in the United States is being feted this week. Students, faculty and alumnae, with a number of persons prominent in the junior college movement, are holding a week's celebration in honor of President James Madison Wood at Stephens College in Columbia, Mo.

Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, the Minister of Finance, who seldom speaks without purpose, protested here yesterday reports that Germany had entered on an inflationary course. He asserted that there was not the least danger of either currency or credit inflation and that the Reich's financial position was continually improving.

Calling the capital gains tax an obstacle in the path of general business recovery, the board of directors of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York urges that the capital gains sections of both the Federal and State income tax laws be repealed.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 27: CAPTAIN Tennet, E. H., Dental Corps, granted sick leave of three months; to await orders at Portsmouth. Va.
Miss Anita Lizana of Chile defeated Miss Alice Marble, American singles titleholder, 9-7, 9-7, in the final round of the Middlesex tennis championships today.

Creation of a hydrostatic or liquid pressure of 1,500,000 pounds per square inch, equivalent to that which would exist 420 miles under the sea, or beneath a mass of limestone 100 miles thick, is reported by Dr. Thomas C. Poulter, director of the research foundation at Armour Institute of Technology.
Many of the country, yacht and beach clubs in Westchester started their programs of sport and social events today in celebration of the Decoration Day week-end.
The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to think long and hard before passing the administration's Labor Standards Bill.

Plans have been completed for the annual program of Union College interneships in government. Twelve juniors and seniors from the course in State and local government have qualified to work in eight governs ment offices in Albany, Schenectady and New York City.

By authorization of Secretary of War Woodring, Mrs. Julia O. Flikke will become "Major Flikke" on Tuesday, and for the next several years will be the ranking woman officer of the United States Army, the dierecting head of the Army Nurse Corps, whose personnel is limited by law to 625 commissioned officer nurses.

Eleven students received diplomas at the annual commencement of Brunswick School, Greenwich, this morning at 11 o'clock. Members of the class are Prentiss Manning Hatch Jr. of Stamford, Conn.; Charles Fletcher Peck of New Rochelle, N. Y.; Robert Abendroth of Harrison, N. Y.; Allen Flanagan of Larchmont, N. Y., and Albert George Boesel Jr.,

Miss Eleanor McGrath of Waterbury, Conn., has been elected by the student body of Marymount College here to receive the Marquis George MacDonald Medal at the commencement exercises on Monday at 11 A. M., it was announced today. The medal is awarded each year to the student who "by her character and example has exerted the greatest influence for good on her classmates."
General Oscar Novoa, Commander-in-Chief of the army, today gave out orders that the army be ready to repress with the utmost severity any repetition of last Friday's throwing of tear gas day bombs.

An illustration of how an oldstyle private house can be renovated and placed on a good income basis, is presented by William F. R. Ballard, architect, who purchased last Spring the four-story dwelling, containing seventeen rooms, at 38 East Seventy-fifth Street. He explains that his object in making the purchase was due to belief that it would be cheaper to buy such a house and live there,

The marriage of Miss Virginia Marie French, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Krafft French of Brooklyn, to Francis P. Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Reilly, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in St. Theresa's Catholic Church, Brooklyn.
More than 200 persons attended the opening dinner dance of the season tonight at the Wyantenuck Country Club in Great Barrington. Mr. and Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis had sixteen guests at their table.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wilmot Stevens of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Stevens's daughter, Miss Myrtle Vaughn Wilson, to Thomas Franklin Spear of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross L. Spear of Athens, Pa.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.--The Pocono resorts are practically filled to capacity for the holiday week-end, which is really the opening of the Summer season. Cottages and bungalows are open and the social season is getting into full swing.

The graduating class of Hunter College has planned a series of precommencement festivities for the week of June 9-16, it was announced by Alice Wren, president of the Class of June, '37. The activities will include teas, a class night, a boat-ride, banquet and a formal dance.

Coming up from the foot of an eight-horse field with a relentless rush in the last half mile, F. L. Flanders's Blackbirder, 5-year-old Bostonian gelding, raced off with the mileand-a-sixteenth Puritan Handicap by two and a half lengths, before 31,000 fans at Suffolk Downs today.

JUNE, the month of graduates and roses, brides and perfect days, also brings new radios. Up to now considerable secrecy has guarded the 1937-38 plans of the various manufacturers, but beginning this week the new instruments will be introduced and carted into the market places from coast to coast.

There was read from the bench of the Supreme Court last week by Justice CARDOZO an opinion which seems destined to take its historic place among the great decisions of the court. This was the decision upholding the constitutionality of Federal insurance for the aged.

The marriage of Miss Helen Elizabeth Stoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Stoll, to Kent Day Coes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold V. Coes of Upper Montclair, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents. The Rev. Dr. Archibald Black of the First Congregational Church performed the ceremony.
An Insurgent air armada like the one that struck at Valencia yesterday roared in from the sea today to attack Barcelona. Seventy persons died in the rain of bombs.

Celebrations of the tercentenary of Father Jacques Marquette, the Jesuit missionary who was the first white man to explore, the Mississippi Valley, started today in several localities visited by the explorer in his early travels.
Chief Inspector John J. Seery suspended five detectives and twenty patrolmen yesterday as a result of a raid inspired by the wife of one of them, who wanted to stop her husband's gambling.

Miss Gladys Mildred Chatterton, daughter of Mrs. William O. Chatterton of this place, and the late William 0. Chatterton, was married to Harry 0. Miller in the Park Methodist Episcopal Church here today by the Rev. Dr. William Barton Kelly, the pastor.

Robert Sweeny is the new British amateur golf champion. Today he beat Lionel Munn after a really fine match by 3 and 2, and he deserved to win. Sweeny was born of American parents but belongs to Ireland. As a golfer he belongs to Le Touquet, to Oxford and to England.

WHY is it that with all the remarkable progress accomplished in building safer, better and cheaper airplanes we do not yet see an airminded country taking to the plane, as it took to the automobile thirty-five years ago? The answer lies in the danger of bad visibility.

Southern California's sensational William Sefton and Earle Meadows soared 14 feet 11 inches to an unofficial world pole vault record and Washington State's quartet clipped threetenths of a second off the listed world mile relay mark in the thrillpacked Pacific Coast Conference track and field championships today.

The wedding of Miss Virginia Ruth Paxton, daughter of Mrs. Edythe Edwards Paxton of East Orange, to Charles Smith Adams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Adams of Macon, Ga., took place this afternoon in St. Agnes Episcopal Church here, with the rector, the Rev. Nelson B. Gildersleeve, officiating.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are May 28, unless specified. At San Francisco: Astoria, Broome, California, Colorado. Childs, Cincinnati, Concord, Detroit, Houston, Idaho, Indianapolis, Lexington, Louisville, Milwaukee, Memphis. Maryland. Mississippi,
Members of the Alumnae Association of the Academy of Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson will hold a reception and reunion next Saturday afternoon in the Academy Study Hall at Mount St. Vincent.

British military authorities here reported today an amicable settlement of an incident at Shanhalkwan on the China-Manchukuo frontier which the Japanese press had described as a serious AngloJapanese clash, involving an insult to the Japanese flag.

A brilliant round of golf by T. Suffern Tailer enabled the former metropolitan amateur champion and his partner, J. S. Frelinghuysen Jr. of Somerset Hills, to lead the qualifiers with a par 70 in the best-ball tournament of the Meadow Brook Club today.

Members of the Alumnae Association of the College of New Rochelle, numbering more than 2,500 women, are assembled on the campus here this week-end for their annual reunion, with special programs for the classes of 1912, 1927 and 1932, Miss Laura Tolman, executive secretary of the association, announced today.

The Accident Fraud Bureau of District Attorney William C. Dodge's office, which was organized last July 1 at the request of the Appellate Division, the Bar Association and the County Lawyers Association to investigate crooked lawyers, doctors and others in bogus accident indemnity suits, went out of business yesterday.

HERE is a book that in both form and content suggests the coming of Spring and the delight of long days in the country. In eight chapters, written with exquisite clarity, the author describes the life of the frog, the scorpion, brown bat, stickleback, the mud dauber, garter snake, an ant colony and the "quick lizard."

An appeal to State bankers to "write, telephone or wire" their representatives in Congress in protest against the McAdoo Branch Banking Bill has been sent out by H. M. Chamberlain, president of the State bank division of the American Bankers Association, it announced here yesterday.

Miss Miriam Neftel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Knight Neftel of this place and 162 East Eightieth Street, New York, was married to Thurlow Marshall Gordon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thurlow Marshall Gordon of River House, New York, here this afternoon in St. John's Church.

The two hundred and forty-fourth commencement program of the College of William and Mary will begin next Friday, the examination period ending on Wednesday. William and Mary will award 205 degrees to the class of 1937, 100 Bachelor of Arts degrees, 84 Bachelor of Science, 4 Bachelor of Civil Law and 2 Master of Arts.
When Fiorello H. La Guardia was elected Mayor of New York on the Fusion ticket in 1933, a good part of his support came from the Republican party.

The formation of an inspection bureau with authority to recommend certain building standards toward improving the construction industry of the city was presented before several hundred leaders in the affiliated building trades at a recent meeting at the Hotel Commodore of the vigilance committee of the construction industry in his city.

Ralph J. Talamo-Rossi, electrical engineer in charge of construction work for R. C. A. Communications, Inc., of New York, died today in Homeopathic Hospital here after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 302 Sixth Avenue, Newark.
Service was curtailed in fourteen leading hotels here tonight when workers began walking out in response to a strike call planned to tie them up.

Tension increased in marked degree today in the steel strike in this area as pickets, armed with baseball bats and clubs, barred freight cars and food trucks from entering the property of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Republic Steel Corporation.

Associations being taxable for Federal income tax purposes as corporations, trusts which are held to be associations are taxed like corporations. The great variety of trusts, both as to functions performed and mode of administration, has made it extremely difficult to lay down definite rules by the application of which true trusts can be differentiated from associations.

Invitations to organizations of newspaper women, as well as to individual members, to affiliate with the newly formed National Federation of Press Women are being received in New York as the result of formal establishment of the larger group in Chicago on May 6. Mrs. Douglas Malloch of Chicago, who is president of the Illinois Women's Press Association, is the first president of the National Federation.
Three Princeton students were injured early today, one of them seriously, when the automobile in which they were riding skidded and crashed against a tree and flashing road-marker in Bristol.
Federal Judge Frank Cooper refused today to dismiss Federal indictments against Manning (Manny) Strewl in connection with the 1933 kidnapping of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr.
When the events of the last week bearing upon the court controversy are subjected to the usual additions and subtractions, the net result would seem to stand something as follows:

A SCOUT is thrifty," says the Scout law, and "saves his money so that he can pay his own way." Many of the 25,000 boys who will attend the national jamboree at Washington, D. C., from June 30 to July 9, are now putting this tenet into practice. For attendance at the jamboree requires railroad fares, a fee to cover camping expenses at the capital, and other sightseeing and incidental expenditures.

The Ministry of Instruction denied today a report that Athens had received a $150,000 gift from John D. Rockefeller Sr. for the construction of a museum to house findings of American excavators in the ancient Athenian market place.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Steinback of Cincinnati have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their niece, Miss Helen Julie Flagg of 502 Park Avenue, to Myron Engelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Engelman, also of this city. The wedding will take place here on June 14 at the Delmonico.

The New York and Sandy Hook Pilots' Association, whose members board incoming ships in the lower harbor and guide them to their piers, on Friday resumed its Summer system of boarding liners to offset the difficulties of navigation created by the presence of fog.

THIS is the banner season for the bird lover. At the first vibrant twitter of the wood thrush from atop a sprouting tree or the haunting laughter of the seagulls as they wing their way along the outer beaches, the bird enthusiast takes to the marshes and the woodlands with his binoculars and camera to renew acquaintance with the hundreds of colorful species which have arrived from the South to nest.

Elaborate tests of building materials and illumination effects for the World's Fair buildings are being conducted at the fair site with a test building, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, said yesterday.

The Long Island University baseball team defeated the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, 9-3, at Manhattan Beach yesterday to close its home campaign. It was the nineteenth triumph for the Blackbirds in twenty-two starts.

The refunding plan of the Union Electric Light and Power Company of Missouri, which involves issuance of $80,000,000 of long-term bonds and $15,000,000 of five-year 3 per cent debentures, if put into effect, will eliminate all subsidiary securities held by the public and give the system as simple a capital set-up as its officers believe can be developed with its various properties operating in different States.

AN announcement from Washington that the government this Summer will.commemorate on a stamp the 350th anniversary of the birth of Virginia Dare, the first English child born in this country, has a particular fascination for philatelists. The promised stamp will have a direct historical association with adhesives released several years ago by British Guiana and Newfoundland.

Opposing a nine from the sand lots from which Klimczak, Doonan, Albinger and Horton were graduated, Yale today defeated the Story Athletic Club of Cedar Hill, 6 to 2. Joe Sezdek allowed Yale only five hits, while Ted Horton turned back the Story sluggers with the same number.

James J. Donahue, treasurer of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Paterson, N. J., died at his home, 82 Rock Road, here tonight, following an illness of three months. Mr. Donahue recently underwent an abdominal operation.

Columbia's rowing squad, composed of twenty-eight oarsmen, coaches, trainers and managers, left yesterday morning for the Krum Elbow headquarters on the Hudson, two miles above Poughkeepsie, to start preparation for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 22.

Reinforcements of gendarmes and tourists swarmed into Monts today as preparations for the wedding of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield, just five days off, threw this French community into a new high pitch of excitement.

The joint committee of American and Philippine experts which is conducting studies of the various problems entering into the relationships of the United States and the Philippines in connection with the Independence Act expects to submit its report with recommendations to tee President Roosevelt and Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Commonwealth Government, before the end of this year.

Registration once more is picking up after a brief period during which the figures fell somewhat below last year's totals. During the month of April 6,975 new names were entered in the Stud Book, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Kennel Club.

Some of the older residents of the State, who as boys went fishing in the Hudson River, will be familiar perhaps, with some of the facts and findings that have been brought to light in a recent survey conducted by the State Bureau of Biological Survey.

Generally recognized as "fairly reasonable," the bills introduced in Congress. last week calling for a forty-hour week and a $16 minimum wage will not seriously affect Northern industry, but will probably result in some cost increases in Southern manufacturing, trade association executives said here yesterday.

Referring to the care observed by the Federal Housing Administration in its appraisals for loans, George B. Underwood, of the New Jersey FHA office, states that the architects of the FHA underwriting staff are not only concerned with the plan, proposal and cost of a house built under the insured mortgage system, but also with the actual construction.

The Ernest Williams School of Music held the finals of its fourth annual composition contest and band festival yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, who annually offers medals to students of composition at the Williams School, made the awards.

Columbia's rowing squad, composed of twenty-eight oarsmen, coaches, trainers and managers, left yesterday morning for the Krum Elbow headquarters on the Hudson, two miles above Poughkeepsie, to start preparation for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 22.

Reinforcements of gendarmes and tourists swarmed into Monts today as preparations for the wedding of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield, just five days off, threw this French community into a new high pitch of excitement.

Quezon, President of the Commonwealth Government, before the end of this year.

Registration once more is picking up after a brief period during which the figures fell somewhat below last year's totals. During the month of April 6,975 new names were entered in the Stud Book, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Kennel Club.

Some of the older residents of the State, who as boys went fishing in the Hudson River, will be familiar perhaps, with some of the facts and findings that have been brought to light in a recent survey conducted by the State Bureau of Biological Survey.

Generally recognized as "fairly reasonable," the bills introduced in Congress. last week calling for a forty-hour week and a $16 minimum wage will not seriously affect Northern industry, but will probably result in some cost increases in Southern manufacturing, trade association executives said here yesterday.

Referring to the care observed by the Federal Housing Administration in its appraisals for loans, George B. Underwood, of the New Jersey FHA office, states that the architects of the FHA underwriting staff are not only concerned with the plan, proposal and cost of a house built under the insured mortgage system, but also with the actual construction.

The Ernest Williams School of Music held the finals of its fourth annual composition contest and band festival yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, who annually offers medals to students of composition at the Williams School, made the awards.

A new 2-year-old star swept across the turf horizon at Belmont yesterday when Robert L. Gerry's Perpetuate, a son of Infinite from Citrus, captured the sixty-first running of the Juvenile Stakes by a head before 25,000 persons. Mrs.
THE original, unpublished first chapter of Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" is to be issued late in the Summer by Viking Press in an edition limited to 1,000 copies for sale.
Granted a parole only last Monday by Governor M. Clifford Townsend, George Davis, 53-yearold life term prisoner, died yesterday of tubercular peritonitis after an illness of several weeks.

Miss Gladys Hoage, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin J. Hoage of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to John P. Brady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Brady of Newark. The ceremony will take place on June 19 in Our Lady of Good Counsel Church here.

THE Baldwin-Wallace Conservatory, Berea, Ohio, will give its fifth Bach festival Friday, June 11, and Saturday, June 12, at the Fanny Nast Gamble Auditorium of Baldwin-Wallace College. The festival chorus will be directed by Albert Riemenschneider; the festival orchestra, by Carl Schluer, and the a cappella choir, by Cecil Munk.

TOURISTS are rediscovering Alaska these days, and with an increased number of cruises, and a new air service in the upper Yukon Valley, it now becomes easier to get a view of American life where it is gayest, most light-hearted and contented.

A new approach to the problem of truancy, wherein "bad" boys and girls obtain vocational rehabilitation and are made useful members of society, is being attempted in the New York City school system, George H. Chatfield, director of the bureau of attendance of the Board of Education, disclosed yesterday.

Shortly after pickets of the American Federation of Labor started picketing shops in the business section where clerks had been organized by the Committee for Industrial Organization, the C. I. O. sent out its own pickets today to march in front of shops organized by the A. F. of L.
Fortune seekers are moving westward again today over the old Oregon Trail which an intrepid band of Indian-fighting ox-driving pioneers charted 105 years ago.

The weddding of Miss Louisa Bryan Price, daughter. of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marshall Price of Cocoanut Grove, Fla., to Roger Sherman Robinson of this city will take place on June 14 in Trinity Episcopal Church, Miami. The Rev. G. I. Hiller will officiate.

Max B. Kaesche of the Ridgewood Country Club. defending champion, moved into the semi-final round of the second annual invitation golf tournament of Houvenkopf Country Club today with a 5-and-4 victory over Tom Talbot of Sleepy Hollow.

After asserting that the approach of war would be "appreciably lessened" if there were "no profits in armaments," the Rev. Dr. George the Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, discussed yesterday the doubts among young people about the profit-sharing economic system. Dr. Sargent said:

An appeal to Americans to preserve the foremost example of Russian church architecture in America, the St. Nicholas Cathedral, at 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, was' sent out yesterday by Archbishop Nicholas Kedroff, head of the Russian Orthodox churches in North America.
The Father Duffy Chapter of the Rainbow Division, (the 165th Infantry), held its annual Memorial Day services yesterday afternoon for the 857 men of the regiment who were killed in the World War.
Harry East's goal from a sharp angle with less than a minute to play enabled the Burnt Mills Polo Club to defeat Long Island, 5 to 4, today.

Jack Rutherfurd, commodore of the Palm Beach Yacht Club and one of the leading speed-boat pilots in the United States, added another triumph to his already long list with a fine' victory in the international Atlantic City motor boat race today.

Miss Florence Hershfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Hershfield of Jamaica, Queens, was married to Harry L. Selden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Selden of Yonkers, N. Y., yesterday at the Hershfield home by the Rev. Dr. Nathan G. Meltzoff of New York.

Mickey Cochrane, ailing leader of the Detroit Tigers, suffering from multiple fractures of the skull after having been hit in the head by a pitched ball at the Yankee Stadium last Tuesday, had made so much progress in shaking off the effects of his injury yesterday that it was said at St. Elizabeth's Hospital that "an uneventful recovery" is expected. Dr. Robert Emmet Walsh,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bartlett Scott of Braceholme, Tarrytown-on-Hudson, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cbrnelia Scott, to Andrew Heiskell, son of Mrs. A. Hubbard Heiskell of New York and Paris, and of Morgan Heiskell of Paris.
Art Chester, Los Angeles speed pilot, narrowly escaped a crash today when the motor of his cream-colored Jeep stalled on the take-off for a fiftymile race at the St. Louis air show.

More than 100 distance runners, including Walter Young of Verdun, Que., winner of the last Boston A. A. marathon, are listed to start in tomorrow's 26 miles 385 yards race from this city to Salisbury Beach.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, directed by Eugene Plotnikoff, presented a program of diverse interest at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. The soloist was Arturo de Filippi, tenor, who was heard in the "Lamento" from Cilea's "L'Arlesienne" and in the Prize Song from Wagner's "Die Meistersinger."

Were the Anglo-Saxon nations of the world to stand more firmly together for the maintenance of justwice and collective security the hope for peace would be more promising, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Guatemala has solved a difficulty with its judiciary by ordering justices of the peace to sleep at Police Headquarters. This assures having justices on hand when cases requiring their attention comes up.

BERNARD BARUCH'S great public service and wide acquaintance with the "sour foundations of life" give him right to be heard sympathetically by those who, as he said, have come to look upon themselves as "the lost generation." There is, indeed,

Lethargy reigned in the market here this week, and, although stocks on the whole were firm, activity was checked by the refusal of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, to sanction three proposed private stock issues. The Boerse is entirely without political stimulation.
Pope Pius XI will enter his eighty-first year tomorrow and characteristically he will celebrate the occasion by adding to the heavy burden of work resting on his was shoulders.
The death of ALFRED ADLER, the Viennese psychologist, serves to remind us how deeply psychoanalysis has. influenced popular thought.

The Cunard White Star liner Franconia arrived yesterday, completing her round-the-world cruise which began in New York on Jan. 7. The liner steamed 35,000 miles, visiting thirty-three ports in twenty countries.

Heralded as the "wonder team" of the English Soccer League, the Charlton Athletic F.. C. of London launched its American tour before 20,000 persons at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and, though the invaders impressed the onlookers considerably, they had to be content with a 1-1 tie with an all-star aggregation composed of American Soccer League players.
George F. Baker, 59 years old, New York banker, died today aboard his yacht Viking in Honolulu Harbor, a victim of peritonitis, despite efforts by air and sea to save his life.

Condemnation of Fascist forces in Spain and an expression of direct sympathy with the cause of the Loyalists was expressed here today by the Central Conference of American Rabbis in a resolution adopted just before the adjournment of their annual meeting.

Offerings of new Canadian bond issues in May amounted to $113,518,500, compared with $19,651,500 in May, 1936, according to the Dominion Securities Corporation. The increase was accounted for by issues of Dominion bonds amounting to $113,500,000.

The French liner Normandie will arrive today from Havre and Southampton, bringing among her passengers Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt and her sister, Lady Thelma Furness; Mrs. Bernard Gimbel, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince, Admiral William H. Standley, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Standley; Dr. and Mrs.

The index for French wholesale prices on May 22 stood at 532, which was unchanged from a week before and which compared with 536 on May 8. The gold index for world prices of raw materials stood at 55.4, against 54.7 on May 15 and 55.5 on May 8.
On this last night of the 1936-37' season, at the Majestic Theatre, Ben Lundy and B. F. Kamsler will rediscover the first of a series of mystery melodramas of other days.

Stephen F. Voorhees, president of the American Institute of Architects, which will open its sixty-ninth meeting here Tuesday, announced tonight the election of two honorary members and twenty-three fellows.

Only a few scattered hisses and boos broke the peace that accompanied rival steel workers' rallies of the Committee for Industrial Organization and Security League today near the mills of the Weirton Steel Company.

Madison Grant, to whose inspiration New Yorkers partially owe their famed Bronx River Parkway and Americans the country over the preservation of California's huge redwood trees, died yesterday at his home, 960 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 71.
The ball game between the Yankees and the Athletics at the Stadium yesterday was over before it got well under way, at least as far as the McCarthymen were concerned.
Before the largest crowd of the season, 4,000 spectators, the First Division quartet routed its reservation rival, the Fort Hamilton officers combination, 11 to 5, yesterday at Fort Hamilton.
Placer gold mining in the States of Guatemala, El Progreso and Baja Vera Paz since January has been successful, it was reported today.

An effort to destroy the evils of modern life should go forward concurrently with endeavor to establish world peace, Frederick E. Crane, chief judge of the Court of Appeals, said last night at a civic memorial service held in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, to honor five city officials who have died in office in the last three years.

22d St, 429 W, 16.8x98.9; Mary F. Duke to Samuel Rothman, 314 W 30th St, purchase money mtg, $7,000 ($8.50). 103d St, 158 E, 27x100.11; City Bank Farmers Trust Co, executor of Harmon W. Hendricks, to Weneeda Realty Corp, 526 E 82d St ($4.50).
A prediction that there would be no strike at the Ford Motor Company's main plant here this Summer came today from members of the United Automobile Workers of America.

Marlu Millady, a puppy that will not be a year- old until July 12, this afternoon captured the highest honors at the annual specialty show of the Scottish Terrier Club of America, given on the lawns of Brookside, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Matthews of this town.

While parishioners of the exclusive Emmanuel Episcopal Church in the Back Bay section held memorial services this morning, Miss Alice Mariett, 52, who said she was the daughter of a deceased minister, was arrested for stealing a marked one-dollar bill from the collection plate.
A tea at which there were 200 guests was given by Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Knapp at their home on Maple Avenue, Greenwich, this afternoon to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage.

General relief from State and local funds was administered in March to 1,710,000 families and single persons as compared with 2,007,000 in March, 1936, but despite this decrease the number receiving general relief throughout the United States in March was 2.4 per cent above January, the Works Progress Administration announced today.

An authoritative interview with Mrs. Wallis Warfield on various statements circulated about her has been obtained by a distant kinswoman on the eve of her marriage to the Duke of Windsor. The writer is a senior practicing woman barrister of the English bar. This is the first of two articles.
News of the bombing of the German warship Deutschland Saturday by airplanes of the Valencia Government spread in Rome last, night and caused a profound sensation.
After the coronation and the Whitsuntide holiday, there has been a record demand for currency at the Bank of England, with circulation again falling.

THAT was a fine cup of tea. The distinguished visitors came all the way from Australia for a spot of tennis at Forest Hills, and that's about all they got. Just a spot, not a full set in two days' play. Extraordinary, no end, what?

The conquest of Australia's luck-less Davis Cup team was completed in the Forest Hills Stadium yester- day as Donald Budge and- Gene Mako of California defeated Jack Crawford and Vivian McGrath in the doubles, 7-5, 6-1, 8-6, before T,000 spectators.

Celebrating the first anniversary of the release from tolls of all highways, the Peruvian Touring Club, assisted by automobile and tire importers, held a mammoth parade through this capital this morning. The procession included a large number of trucks loaded with food products that had arrived over the central highway yesterday from the central departments of Peru.

Behind Walter Brown's four-hit pitching, the league-leading Newark Bears earned an even break in their twin bill with the Chiefs today, taking the second game, 2 to 1, after Syracuse had won the opener, 6 to 2.

From one point of view the new Federal Wages-and-Hours Bill disarms criticism. If it fixed definite maximum hours, definite minimum wages, definite differentials, there would be something to get one's teeth into.

Rochester made it two in a row over Buffalo today, walloping three Bison pitchers for sixteen safeties and a 13-1 victory. Howard Krist, young Red Wing hurler, held the Bisons in check throughout, while his mates pounded out their victory.

-In the five red brick buildings here in which the late Thomas Alva Edison perfected many of his inventions, more than 2,000 of his notebooks and marginal notes made by the inventor on many of his 11,000 library books will be preserved for posterity by photography and cataloging, it was learned today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,102,819,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:
Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sellner of South Paterson yesterday held open house in observation of the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. Mr.

In the presence of more than two hundred nuns, a score of clergymen and several hundred laymen, Cardinal Hayes dedicated a memorial this afternoon in the cemetery on the grounds of Mount Saint Maryon-theHudson here to the Most Rev. John Joseph Dunn, Auxiliary Bishop of the New York archdiocese, who died on Aug. 31, 1938.

A female counterpart of the dilettant detective type portrayed by William Powell, Edmund Lowe and others will be attempted by Irene Dunne for RKO in Wilson Collison's "The Mad Miss Manton," in which a Junior Leaguer involves her set in a crime by dabbling in the art of solution. It will follow "The Joy of Living" on Miss Dunne's schedule at RKO.

The Giants' gallant winning streak of eight straight games came down with a grand crash on the sidewalks of Broad Street today when a trio of circuit clouts by Dolph Camilli, Earl Grace and Chuck Klein paved the way for a 6-to-3 triumph for the Phillies in the closing engagement of a three-game series.

The Naumburg Orchestra opened its Summer season on the Mall in Central Park last night with a Decoration Day concert which was attended by an enthusiastic audience of 7,500. Leon Barzin conducted and Arnold Eidus, 15-yearold violinist, was the soloist.
About seventy-five men, women and children of all ages attended the season's opening today of Sunshine Park, nudist camp at Mays Landing, about eighteen miles from here.

Sailing before a southeast wind, Centaur, owned by Adam Wahl, captured the laurels in the first of a series of Dutch canoe races for the Dolphin Trophy, held under the auspices of the American Canoe Association off City Island yesterday.

Miss Sara Blair Huntington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Huntington of this city, has announced the plan for her wedding to Martin H. Johnson, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. B. Johnson of Lakeville, Conn. The ceremony will take place Saturday, June 19, in Trinity Church. The rector,
The report of the Bank of France dated May 20 shows no important changes. Bills discounted decreased 219,000,000 francs, whereas loans against securities and government bonds felt 130,000,000 francs.

The Pope is 80 years old today. He began his pontificate at '65, the retirement age under the Social Security Act but a fairly young start for a Pope, a ruler chosen out of an electoral college whose members seldom become Cardinals until they are pretty venerable.

THE HIT PARADE, from a story by Bradford Ropes; screen play by Mr. Ropes and Samuel Ornitz; music and lyrics by Lou Handman, Walter Hirsch, Ned Washington. Sam H. Stept. Cliff Friend, 'Mat Malneck and Duke Ellington; directed by Gus Meins; produced by Nat Levine for Republic Pictures At the Rivoli.
Soy bean trading here last week was largely in liquidation of old contracts, but the volume was not heavy. Prices at times had a wide range.

It was "Big Poison," "Little Poison" and all poison today as the pace-setting Pirates bounced the Cardinals down a notch into fourth place. Pittsburgh won, 7-4, for its third victory in a four-game series here.

Several hundred volunteer firemen participated this evening in the annual memorial service of the Huntington Volunteer Firemen's Association at the Central Presbyterian Church here. The service was preceded by a parade through the business district to the church.

The "shallowness and superficiality" of modern education is due largely to the fact that it is based on "subjective principles," the Rev. Dr. Gustav Dumas of Fordham University Graduate School, declared today in his baccalaureate sermon to members of the graduating class of Marymount College here.

Cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued last week the irregularity of the previous week but substituted a slight decline for a moderate gain. Active futures in this market showed net losses of 2 to 5 points.
Anybody who desires a close view of one of the world's largest flowers can get it almost any day now at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The plant,
Miss Martha Root White, youngest daughter of the late Horace White, former editor of The New York Evening Post and The Chicago Tribune, died here yesterday of pneumonia.
Jambino, the WPA elephant who has been playing in the government circus on a Canarsie vacant lot, went on a sit-down strike yesterday and sat for nearly five hours.

The WPA Federal Music Project will present a series of ten weekly concerts devoted to works of Johannes Brahms an Wednesday evenings at the Theatre of Music, beginning June 16, it was announced yesterday. The programs will include performances of the German master's instrumental and vocal chamber music, piano pieces and lieder.
A hoard of silver coins bearing the inscription "Ethelbert Dux Anglorum" has been found by peasants digging in a field near the Polish village of Rakoczyn.

Undaunted by the strike riot which caused several lives and resulted in injuries to many more in South Chicago, strikers in the Youngstown district today declared that they were more determined than ever to hold "at all costs" the gates of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Republic Steel Corporation.
One puts down the Spanish Government's White Book accusing Italy of intervention in the civil war wondering what has become of young Mrs. Ardita.

Wilnette Keeling Mayers, soprano, gave a recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Church of St. Martin. Marion Cumbo, a talented 'cellist, was the assisting artist. Miss Mayers was heard in selections in Italian, German, French and English, all of which were well received.

The foreign exchange market here showed little activity this week, and a better tendency of the franc against the British pound and the United States dollar was of short duration. It is evident that if capital is not leaving France in large quantities, it is not coming back, either.

The antichurch campaign here has reached such a pitch that the National Confessional Synod has issued special instructions to Protestant pastors for combating propaganda and National Socialist party official interference with church life. A commission has been organized to the same end.

The most sweeping Amnesty Bill in the history of the republic was approved by the House of Representatives early today after more than twelve hours of stormy debate. Twice during the night reporters and spectators were ejected and secret sessions were held.

The German wholesale price index on May 19 stood at 105.8. This was unchanged from the week before. In the first four months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index ranged between 106.2 on March 17 and 105.2 in the first week of Januarv.

An audience of about 4,000 persons attended a holiday performance of "Rigoletto"; at the New York Hippodrome last night. The cast was headed by Dea Lovati as Gilda, Ettore Nava as Rigoletto, Enrico Coppellotti as the Duke, Mildred Ippolito as Maddalena, Nino Carboni as Sparafucile and Norman Roland as Monterone.
Boosting their victory streak to seven games, the Montreal Royals beat the Toronto Maple Leafs twice today, 12-8 and 7- 5, to tighten their grip on second place in the International League.

An nouncement of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Hope Jackson, to Francis Patrick Garvan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of New York and Roslyn, L. I., was made today by Robert Jackson of Concord, N. H., and Washington. The date for the wedding was not announced.

Devotion to the cause of social justice was described as a necessary attribute of education among Catholics in a baccalaureate sermon yesterday afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents, Beverly Road and East Seventeenth Street. Brooklyn.
Pete Appleton, pudgy Washington righthander, ended the five-game winning streak of the Red Sox today by pitching and batting the Senators to an 11-to-4 victory before 16,000 fans.
Insurgent General Emilio Mola opened the sixtieth day of his offensive against Bilbao today with a heavy attack on Lemona, a strategic highway junction about ten miles southeast of the city.

On a tiny coral island 200 miles below the Equator and 5,000 miles southwest of San Francisco members of the National Geographic Society-United States Navy Eclipse Expedition dedicated a Memorial Day monument yesterday.

The Right Rev. Dr. C. K. Gilbert, Suffragan Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, conducted the confirmation service yesterday morning at the French Church du Saint-Esprit. 229 East Sixty-first Street. Seven were confirmed and five were received from the Roman Catholic Church in France.

W. Kingsland Macy, who as Republican State Chairman four years ago played a major part in bringing about the nomination of Mayor La Guardia on the Fusion ticket, declared yesterday against the renomination of the Mayor on the Republican ticket.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The significance of Memorial Day was discussed from pulpits throughout the city yesterday. Several members of the clergy warned that too much emphasis was now placed on the present and too little on the past and others assailed the world armament race.

Relatives and friends of the 1,400 disabled veterans at the United States Veterans Hospital here attended Memorial Day exercises this morning and afternoon. The Rev. Father J. Brennan, pastor of St. Philip Neri's Church, held Catholic services this morning, followed by Protestant services under the direction of the Rev. William Fanton of Northport.

Providing the children with Nazi uniforms has become a serious budget problem for the average German family. The Nazi regime urges parents to raise large families and then enrolls the children in its youth organizations.

The city was on exhibition yesterday for thousands of visitors who came to town by train, bus, plane and automobile. They had the city pretty much to themselves. With bright sunny skies and a temperature reaching a high of 81, it was a splendid day for visitors to see the city in its best dress.

The necessity for choosing one loyalty and serving it faithfully was discussed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, in a sermon at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

About 8,000 persons participated yesterday in an outdoor service in celebration of the feast of Corpus Christi on the campus of Fordham University, in the Bronx. Yesterday was the Sunday within the octave of the feast, which occurred on Thursday.

Cornell University today announced purchase of a 100-acre farm to raise "heebie jeebies," its population to be Achilles the pig who has a nervous breakdown, Homer the goat who has one too, and a flock of other animals who will imitate man's artificial civilization to discover the cause and cure of nerves, psychoses and delinquency.

World War veterans holding temporary government war-risk insurance have until Tuesday to convert their policies into other forms of insurance, officials of the Veterans Administration explained, following President Roosevelt's veto Friday of a bill to extend the time.
Six persons are dead and twelve others are injured, one critically, as the result of three separate automobile accidents in this vicinity today.
"A recovery of the reality of ideals" is the most needed thing in the thought of the world today, Chaplain William N. Thomas told the graduating class of the Naval Academy in the annual sermon today.
Former Mayor Joseph E. Nowrey died at his home here today. Mr. Nowrey had been successful several times a quarter of a century ago in a predominantly Republican area, although he was a Democrat.

A company of actors from the Old Vic Theatre in London arrived here today to give ten open-air performances of "Hamlet" in the locale that Shakespeare prescribed, the ancient castle of Kronborg near Elsinor.

Wearing tattered cotton suits and with 'comparatively mild criticisms of their former captors, twenty-three British members of the Loyalist International Brigade arrived in London today after their release by General Francisco Franco.

Charles Wells, 30 years old, of 818 East 150th Street, New York City, was drowned early this evening when he fell between two rowboats into Peach Lake. He-was attempting to step from one craft into the other.
President Lazaro Cardenas's National Labor Board today ruled the nationwide oil strike legally declared. Such a ruling is the first step toward declaring a strike itself legal.

Lard prices, as well as meats, eased here last week in sympathy with the decline in corn and hogs, the latter selling off sharply. Injection of a little new buying, combined with a rally in hog prices from the low point, created a better feeling.

Four were killed and eighty-four injured when about 1,000 C. I. O. strikers, marching on the Republic Steel plant in South Chicago, were repulsed by police. The strikers hurled rocks and bolts and fired some shots. The police used their clubs, tear gas and guns. Page 1.

The law announced today which reduces, in certain circumstances, the interest rate on foreign loans is especially drastic, for it not only quashes the contracts concerned but it overrides express decisions of the Reich courts.
Republie Steel Company officials complained to police tonight that strikers and their sympathizers were picketing the homes of loyal employes who have continued to work in the besieged plant.

It is not all work at the North Pole, though the expedition has been so busy thus far unloading planes and setting up living and storage quarters for equipment that there has been hardly time for Sleep.

The National Maritime Union will seek agreements with all ship lines operating from Atlantic and Gulf ports as the bargaining agent of their sea-going personnel if they are successful in their efforts to get an election from the International Mercantile Marine Company and Luckenbach and Black Diamond Lines.
In Washington the final month of the current fiscal year will begin tomorrow with a Treasury deficit which has now reached approximately $2,400,000,000.

Freedom of debate with "free, frank discussion" on questions of the day was urged in a sermon yes terday morning by the Rev. Dr. J. Lane Miller, at Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

Discovery of the first actual bones of the tallest creature ever known, a "super-leviathan" thirtyfive feet in height who walked with sixteen-foot strides along the primeval ooze of Wyoming, Utah and Colorado some 100,000,000 years ago, was revealed here yesterday by Dr. Barnum Brown, curator of fossil reptiles at the American Museum of Natural History.

Here is the official starting line-up for tomorrow's 500-mile automobile race. showing the number of the cars, driver, type of motor (cylinder, rear drive, front drive, or four-wheel. drive) and qualifying speeds:

Liquidation by tired holders of oats, combined with a decline in other grains, carried prices here down last week, but there was a rally on new buying and short covering. July oats closed at 45 cents a bushel, a net advance of 3/8 cent for the week.

The Mayo senior Gaelic football team of New York triumphed over Louth by 10 to 4 before 1,500 fans at Innisfail Park yesterday. Ed Kelly, who filled the full forward position for the victors, led the scoring with two goals and 1 point.

With his message suggesting to Congress concerted action against evaders and avoiders of income taxes in the higher brackets virtually ready for transmission Tuesday, President Roosevelt tonight settled down for a quiet week-end with his mother at her house at Hyde Park, six miles up the Hudson from here.

Miss Margaret Joy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sumner Joy of Bristol, will be wed to Olivet McCartney Willard, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Patten Willard of San Francisco, on June 19, in the First Congregational Church. here, by the Rev. Francis T. Cooke. A reception at the Endee Club will follow the ceremony.

The six crack quarter-milers who will compete in the 440-yard run at the fourth annual Princeton invitation track meet on June 19 in Palmer Stadium were announced tonight by Asa. S.. Bushnell, Graduate Manager of Athletics.
Benny Kaufman, 1936 Eastern champion, will head an all-star field of speedsters in the eighteen-event motor cycle racing program scheduled for tonight at the Bay Ridge Stadium in Brooklyn.
Edmond J. Butler, former chairman of the State Probation Commission, died Saturday at his home in Belle Harbor, L. I., at the age of 82, after an illness of three months.

An upper West side property that had been altered to comply with the Multiple Dwelling Law was sold in a deal announced over the week-end by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to the Colcent Realty Corporation.
There is no such thing as a tax which is just to everybody. The income tax is said to be as fair as any, but as actually administered from

Clarence R. Deas, who retired this week after fifty years' service with the Great American Insurance Company of New York City, traveled 747,972 miles as a commuter, or the equivalent of thirty trips around the world, via the Equator.
A Mexican export bank to facilitate sales operations abroad is to be formed here this week, the newspaper Excelsior reports today.
A small but smoky fire laid to defective wiring caused little damage yesterday morning in an eighteenth floor apartment in the Ritz Tower, Park Avenue and Fiftyseventh Street.
Thirteen high school students from eight States and the District of Columbia were announced yesterday as winners of a nation-wide essay contest conducted by the Propeller Club of the United States.

Foreign Minister Jose Ramon Gutierrez addressed communications to the Foreign Offices of Paraguay and Bolivia yesterday, congratulating them on the resumption of diplomatic relations after the settlement of the difficulties that remained after the Chaco War.

The recent debate in the Chamber of Deputies about the government's budgetary difficulties has merely served to confirm the magnitude of the expenditure which the Treasury will have to meet between now and the end of the year, solely by shortterm borrowing.

John Glynn, 65 years old, who once stole the police shield of Lewis J. Valentine, was under arrest yesterday for burglary. It was his twenty-first arrest in a criminal career that began forty years ago.
Wireless dispatches received here today said serious volcanic eruptions and earth shocks have led to the evacuation of nearly all the population of Rabaul, on the Pacific island of New Britain.

The observance of Memorial Day, which will be celebrated officially today, began yesterday with religious and veterans' organizations throughout the city holding services in tribute to the nation's military dead.

The Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, 156 Fifth Avenue, has awarded the first prize of $150 for the best missionary sermon preached in honor of the centennial of the board to the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Walker, pastor of the Market Street Presbyterian Church.

Baltimore gained a two-to-one ledge in its three-game series with the Jersey City Giants today by taking the final game, 11 to 1. The Birds fell on Rollie Stiles, starting Jersey City pitcher, for nine hits in the first six innings to drive him from the box.

In every church throughout Westchester County special Memorial Day services were held and at White Plains more than 3,500 members of thirty-nine American Legion Posts of the county paraded to the County Center this afternoon, where a two-day memorial program was started with religious services.
Government economists estimated today that the income of farmers for the first half of this year will approach the $4,000,000,000 mark and set a seven-year peak for cash income.
ORANGE COUNTY COLLATERAL CORP. Middletown.-By B. C. S. Corp., for $6,762; Post Garage, Inc., $155; Crawford Furniture Co., Inc., $164; Stivers Commrcial Printing Co $144.
Kenneth McCarty, 14 years old, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin McCarty of 245 East Twenty-first Street, New York City, was shot in the groin while on a targetshooting expedition today.

Senator A. Harry Moore told the smallest assemblage ever gathered at Memorial Day rites at Camp Merritt Monument here today that the very least the people of the nation could do on this day was to dedicate a few moments to their war dead.

Miss Josephine Kleiman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob S. Kleiman of this city, was married to Frederick Weinger Novis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Novis of Waterford, Conn., this evening in EmanuEl Synagogue by the Rev. Morris Silverman.
The annual Spring outdoor art show in Washington Square, the opening of which on Friday was dampened by bad weather, enjoyed a fine sunny day yesterday.
The conservative newspaper Correio da Manha reprints today a year-old editorial condemning the Gtrman-Brazilian compensated trade agreement.
E. N. Brown was re-elected chairman of the board of directors and chairman of the finance committee of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Rairoad at the annual meeting of the board on Saturday.
Driving Earl Whitehill from the mound in an eight-hit attack in the first two innings that produced six runs, the White Sox scored an easy 9-to-6 victory over the Indians today.

Memorial services for Jewish patriots of the Revolutionary War days were held yesterday morning at the New Bowery Cemetery at Chatham Square under the auspices of the New York Council of Jewish War Veterans. The cemetery,

The convention of the Social Democratic Federation, which will seek to become the nucleus of a third party in the United States by uniting all labor and progressive elements, today completed the federation's organization and elected Mayor Jasper McLevy of Bridgeport its national chairman.

Miss Mabel A. Cheney will be maid of honor at the wedding on June 25 of her sister, Miss Elizabeth Simpkins Cheney, to Thomas Crowell Taylor Buckley of Geneseo, N. Y. The ceremony will take place here at the home of the bride-elect's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Austin Cheney, in the presence of relatives and intimate friends of the young couple. The Rev. Dr. Remsen B.

IT seems that the dark scares Mignon G. Eberhardt most. There are some mystery writers who are afraid of sharp weapons and when they are being their most effective they commit murder with a stiletto. Others get the biggest kick out of poison. Mrs. Eberhardt mixes the weapons used but is consistent about lack of lighting.

The Marblehead Perpetual Challenge Cup was won by the Millpond Model Yacht Club of New Jersey in races on Lincoln Park lake yesterday and today among boats entered by twelve clubs associated with the Model Yacht Racing Association of America.

When his father, for whom he was named, died on May 2, 1931, George Fisher Baker inherited about $60,000,000 which he had materially helped his father to accumulate during more than a quarter of a century.

The Sunday Referee in a front-page story today said: "Earl Baldwin, the most popular man in Great Britain, is to become an unofficial ambassador to the empire. "Next year he will make a long tour of the dominions, representing the King.
A city-wide strike of beauty parlor operators for higher wages and a 48-hour week was threatened last night by the Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Union.

Seventy-one racing craft were out on Long Island Sound yesterday in the special regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club, including the two 50-foot sloops Barbara and Spartan, which engaged in a race that was a treat for the thousands of persons afloat.

The Rev. James A. Hurn of Kingston, a retired minister of the Methodist Church whose last pastorate was at Cairo, N. Y., died here on Thursday. He belonged to the New York Conference of Methodist Ministers and was an active clergyman thirtynine years.
Fluctuatins in the wheat market here are comparatively small. The market is dominated almost completely by weather reports and is likely to continue so for the next few critical growing months.

With many major refinancing programs by industry out of the way and a temporary unsettlement at that time in the money market, registration statements for fixed-interestbearing securities which became effective in April under the Securities Act of 1933 dropped somewhat precipitately to $90,015,714, according to an analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A contract for a loan of 2,000,000 pesos to this city has been signed, although the original plan provided for a loan of 6,000,000 pesos.

The John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization answered the American Federation of Labor's new bid for supremacy in the labor field with an announcement today of a membership drive intended to penetrate every unorganized industry.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 93.3. which compares with 93.5 the week before, 92.7 two weeks before, 93.3 three weeks before and 93.5 four weeks before.

Plans for the wedding on June 30 of Miss Ethel du Pont and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. include the choice of simplee green and white decorations. The couple have decided on white lilies and palms to bank the altar of the church in Christiana Hundred, and dozens of white taper candles for the chancel.

Governor Lenman signed today the bill of Senator Twomey of Brooklyn under which a $40,000,000 bond issue to finance improvements in State hospitals and charitable and correctional institutions will be submitted to the voters at the Fall election.

Annual Memorial Day parade and review of the Grand Army of the Republic begins at Seventy-second Street and Riverside Drive and proceeds past reviewing stand at Eighty-third Street and Riverside Drive to Ninetysecond Street, 9 A. M. Josiah C. Read, grand marshal.

The stock markets have fallen upon the dullest times experienced probably within the last two years at least. Public interest is indeed smaller than at any time since the business revival really got into its first strides in 1935.

A distinct improvement was revealed today by the Boston twelve when it scored a 14-to-1 victory over the Westchester Association squad in the second session of the fifth annual national women's across tournament.
The number of persons occupied in industry here in April was 7 per cent above the total in April, 1936, and the number of hours worked was 11.3 per cent more than a year previous.

The National Youth Administration today called upon private industry to supply jobs to the more than 400,000 young persons on its rolls who are I now going out from schools and colleges throughout the country for their Summer vacations.

More than half of New York's seventy theatres are empty, and the road, "despite the nonsense of superoptimists," is nearly gone, John Golden, New York producer, said today in accepting the honorary degree of Doctor of Public Service at Oglethorpe University.
A syndicate headed by A. H. Levy purchased from the Peck Estate eighty lots in Bayside, L. I., adjoining the Gross Morton development, through the Ira L. Terry Company. broker. Joseph L.

Memorials of the future will commemorate "the servants of society rather than the Conquerors of men," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said in his serrmon yesterday morning at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. Dr. Sockman declared:

To the Editor of The New York Time: The sit-down strike in New York staged by a group of writers employed by the WPA moved me to write this letter. I have sympathy with the hardworking head of a family who loses his job and is unable to find employment.

About 100 members of the ClanNa-Gael and the Sarsfield Club of Queens, Irish organizations, attended a memorial service yesterday afternoon for Dr. William James McNeven, Irish patriot, who served with the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War. The exercises were held at the grave of Dr. McNeven in the Riker family burial plot near North Beach, Queens.

Most churches would profit by reducing rather than increasing their membership, the Rev. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fiftyseventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Officials began an investigation tonight of one of the most disastrous weekends in British aviation history-a period in which seventeen persons were killed. The fatalities marred the celebration yesterday of Empire Air Day.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries have reported a consolidated net income of $4,425,095 for the twelve months ended on March 31, against $2,505,602 for the preceding twelve months.

A session of the German Cabinet was held here last night to deal with the bombing of the German pocket battleship Deutschland by Spanish Government airplanes Saturday. [The Admiral Scheer was erroneously reported yesterday as the ship bombed.]

The Dodgers are having no luck at beating the ex-Dodgers. Yesterday three of the former Flatbush favorites, now wearing the comparatively drab livery of the Bees, led a twenty-hit assault on three of the Kelly-green pitchers and romped away with the deciding game of the series by an 11-to-4 score.

Tennis-The United States Davis Cup team advanced to the interzone final by scoring its third straight victory over Australia at Forest Hills yesterday. Donald Budge and Gene Mako beat Jack Crawford and Vivian McGrath in the doubles, 7-5, 6-1, 8--6, to clinch the series.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Mrs. Butler will sail on Wednesday on the Normandie for Europe, where Dr. Butler will attend several meetings as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
The Right Rev. John M. Mogan, chancellor of the Diocese of Nashville and pastor of St. Mary's Catholic Church, died today of a heart attack. His age was 46.

If Dr. JOSEPH GOEBBELS outdid himself in the characteristic tirade delivered Friday night in reply to Cardinal b MUNDELEIN and other critics of the n church policy of the Nazi Government, n the follow-up comment on his address o printed the next day in his newspaper, the Angriff, went much farther in fulminating what amounts to a declaration of religious war.

Pope Pius XI received today an automobile with gears and body designed especially for his comfort as a present for his eightieth birthday tomorrow. The Pontiff, his face thinned by his long illness, smiled brightly when he saw the car and he stepped into it and sat down virtually without assistance.
