The scarcity of corn offerings, especially of the May delivery, threw shorts into a panic toward the close here last week, forcing them to bid the price up to $1.40 a bushel, a new high level for the crop and the highest price in several years.

Due to the success of last year's expedition, the Father's Day committee has announced a father and son fishing trip for Sunday, June 20. The. party will be aboard Captain Jake Martin's Sachem, which. leaves Sheepshead Bay for off-shore fishing.

Seven hundred and fifty candidates for the bachelor's degree in eight departments of Columbia University filed across the campus in academic procession yesterday into St. Paul's Chapel to participate in Columbia's 183d baccalaureate Sunday services.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, commenting on criticism of his Residence Bill at a statutory hearing before Mayor La Guardia on Saturday, predicted yesterday that the bill would become law despite opposition.
Length of race--500 miles. Starting time-10 A.M. (Central standard time). Number of starters--33 (two alternates). Expected crowd-More than 160,000.

In a game filled with free hitting and repeated bases on balls, the New York Athletic Club baseball team downed the Brooklyn College nine, 12 to 9, on the victor's diamond at Travers Island yesterday. Ten safeties and eight bases on balls combined to give the clubmen their triumph, their third in a row.

George F. Baker, the second to bear one of the most influential names in American banking, still had at his death the bulk of his fortune in stock of the First National Bank, which he and his father raised to pre-eminence, associates said yesterday.

Denny Shute, the Old Man River of golf, is still rolling along as the P. G. A. champion, thanks to a few unfortunate lapses on the part of Harold (Jug) McSpaden, his opponent in today's final round of the championship on the sun-drenched Pittsburgh Field Club course.
Baccalaureate services, preceded by ground-breaking exercises at the site of the new science building, were held this evening at Bryn Mawr College.

The baccalaureate service, the initial ceremony of commencement week at New York Military Academy, was conducted here today by the Rev. John F. Hagen, chaplain of the academy. A large list of parents and guests, here to attend the cadet graduation exer cises, witnessed the service in Davies Chapel.
Great satisfaction is expressed here that the dispute over the district of Alexandretta has now been settled and approved by the League Council.

Nineteen operators of pin-ball games in Coney Island, who were arrested Saturday night in raids by the police, resumed business at 2 P. M. yesterday after word had been sent to the police inspector there that there were to be no more arrests for the time being.

Three, radio operators who had held the liner Oriente at her pier Saturday night by locking themselves in her radio room with the aid of David E. Grange, old-guard labor leader of the International Seamen's Union, surrendered to the pangs of hunger at 10:20 A. M. yesterday and walked off the ship.

Clinton H. Crane's Gleam Totem, owned by A. E. Luders Jr. and. Clifford D. Mallory, and Duncan Sterling's Felicity were the victors in a special regatta held by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.
The Knights subdued the Esquires, 8 to 4, today in a game between the two Blind Brook quartets which will compete in the Eastern Polo League campaign next month.

172d St (11-2858), s e cor Inwood Ave, 84x123; Eva Rubin to McCombs Inwood Corp, 939 Intervale Ave; mtge, $418,000. 176th St (11-2851), n s, 165 ft w of Walton Ave, 125x125; Park Lane Estates, Inc, to Max Nisnewitz, 1,375 Ocean Ave, Brooklyn.

Construction of the proposed $28,000,000 vehicular tunnel across Manhattan is urged upon Mayor La Guardia and the Municipal Assembly in a report made to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The report,

The rapid progress of China toward unity and self-reliance in recent years was attributed largely to Christian leadership by two visiting clergymen from that country who preached from New York City pulpits yesterday.

At his own request, Winston Churchill tomorrow will second the resolution naming Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain as leader of the Conservative party to succeed former Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin.

Miss Gertrude Sampson and Charles E. Sampson, who were at the Pierre, left yesterday for Bar Harbor, Me., to open their villa, Rockhurst, for the season. Colonel and Mrs. Frank Knox of Chicago will arrive from Europe today and will be at the SavoyPlaza.
Daniel Noble, former surrogate of Queens County, died at his Summer home on Brentwood Road here early today of a heart ailment after eight weeks' illness. He was 77 years old.

Pitted against twenty-four opponents at the newly organized Kings Chess Club at the Hotel Touraine in Brooklyn, Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State champion and a member of the United States team going to Stockholm, made a score of twenty-one victories, one draw and two losses yesterday.
Brooklyn at New York--Frankhouse and Jeffcoat vs. Hubbell and Castleman. Boston at Philadelphia--MacPayden and Turner vs. Walters and Johnson.

Six memorial chapels in A. E. F. cemeteries were dedicated today to the memory of the men who died in the World War and who are buried here. In the Meuse Argonne Cemetery at Romagne-sous-Montfaucon, General John J. Pershing made the dedicatory address. Theodore Rousseau, president of the American Club, also spoke.

The City Industrial Relations Board promised yesterday that it would give "earnest consideration" to the request of the Taxi Chauffeurs Union of Greater New York, a C. I. 0. affiliate, for a referendum to determine the union's right to represent the 3,200 employes of the Parmelee System in collective bargaining.
T. S. Tailer, Meadow Brook, and J.S. J. A. Moffett and Henry Picoli, Garden City Golf, 6 and 4.

Three apartment houses at 991, 993 and 995 Boston Road with frontages on 164th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by the Lemust Holding Corporation, represented by Levy, Murphy Stolz, attorneys.

Thousands of Sunday motorists got an unscheduled glimpse of the Bermuda Clipper this afternoon as it completed its second round trip between here and the island resort. After reaching the South Shore the plane passed over Hempstead, Garden City, Mineola and Roosevelt Field at about 2,000 feet. It landed in Manhasset Bay shortly after 4 P. M.

Entangled by harness straps in a fall from his perambulator, a 9month-old baby strangled to death near here today while his mother went to decorate the grave of an earlier born son, accidentally drowned last August.

Mrs. Christine B. Fowler, wife of B. Sherman Fowler, a composer, died suddenly last night at her home in the Hotel Dorset, 30 West Fiftyfourth Street. Mrs. Fowler, who was 66 years old, was the former Christine B. Ritter, daughter of the late John Ritter.

Though the flood of exhibitions which would have made the 1936-37 season notable has dwindled to a stream of modest propositions with the advent of June, there is still discernible a current in the stream.

A special mass in thanksgiving for the recovery of Pope Pius XI and in honor of the Pontiff's eightieth birthday, which will be observed today, was offered yesterday by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Dr. and Mrs. Leo Mayer, twelve rooms in 1,155 Park Ave. from the Gresham Realty Co.: Florence S. Bass. broker.
Germany's steel ingot output in April amounted to 1,644,500 tons. In the first four months of 1937 the total was 6,279,700 tons, against 6,107,600 in the same period in 1936.

Building of an international organization to prevent the inevitable consequences of national exploitation and selfishness is the responsibility facing this generation, Dean William H. Powers declared this morning in a baccalaureate address to 2,000 graduates and alumni of Syracuse University.

ALLEN-Anna (nee Duffy) May 30 beloved wife of William and devoted aunt of James Duffy and Mrs. Philip Schmidt. Funeral from her late residence, 425 East 86th St., Wednesday, 9:30 A. M. Solemn Requiem Mass will be offered at St. Joseph's Church. 87th St. near 1st Ave., 10 A. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

The American colony here bade farewell to United States Ambassador Fred Morris Dearing and Mrs. Dearing at a dinner and dance last night. Mr. Dearing is to be Minister to Sweden. He and his wife will leave shortly for the United States, whence they will sail for Sweden.

Two of the youngest members or the college rowing fraternity provided the grand finale to the golden anniversary regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the debris-filled Harlem River yesterday as Manhattan's varsity eight fought back the closing bid of Rollins College of Florida to win by three-quarters of a length.

Bishop William T. Manning preached a sermon of thanksgiving this morning at a service in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the union of the Colonial Parish of St. James in the Old Church in Salem Center.

Eager to repeat their success of last Fall, the Rutherfurd BrothersJohn and Hugo-recorded two. impressive victories today to move into the final round of match play in the Meadow Brook Club's annual Spring invitation best-ball golf tourney.
Feeling was high between Jews and Arabs here tonight following charges by the Grand Mufti, Haj Amin el Husseini, that a party of Jews had attempted to take his life.

The American Labor party organization of the Twenty-first Assembly District, through Eli Tittler, temporary chairman, and Betty Rapkin, temporary secretary, announced yesterday that it had appointed a committee to arrange for a meeting to protest against the defacement of the three-story home of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Parker, Negroes, at 20 Hamilton Terrace, Washington Heights.

In a house party with Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay C. Hoguet at Council Grove, here, are Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. McVeigh, Mr. and Mrs. J. G. Blaine Ewing, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney P. Henshaw, Mr. and Mrs. Robert White and Dr. John A. McCreery.
As in 1933, but without the competition of the Century of Progress Exposition, the Edison Electric Institute will meet this year in Chicago for its annual convention.
Dunlap Co, Inc, hat manufacturers, ?? for retail headquarters at northwest corner of Park Ave, and 53d St from the Robert Goelet estate; the cross Brown ??, broker.
More than 6,000 members of youth organizations attended a peace festival yesterday in the Municipal Stadium on Randalls Island sponsored by twelve groups as an observance of Unifed Youth Day.

President William Green of the American Federation of Labor announced late today that seven truck drivers employed by the Rochester (N. Y.) Democrat Chronicle, recently on strike, had been ordered to return to work pending arbitration of a dispute.

More than 800 persons gathered over the week-end at the Atlantic Beach Club for the informal opening, which included a dinner dance last night and many large luncheons and dinners today. Members and their guests lunched in the open patio overlooking the ocean, and dined and danced in the newly decorated dining room.
Grain future purchases on the Chicago Board of Trade last week were of smaller volume in wheat and rye than in the previous week, but larger than a year ago.
Coast Guardsmen rescued today eight persons who had jumped from a disabled yacht and were being beaten by the surf against the rocks of North Jetty, a half mile from shore.
The Cubs swept their four-game series with the Reds today by taking the final, 7 to 1, before a crowd of 19,385. It was the eighth straight reverse for the floundering Reds.

An increasing American interest in world affairs during 1936 and a continued departure from "the narrow isolationism of recent years" was seen by the Geneva Research Center in its annual report on the relationship of the United States to the League of Nations, republished yesterday by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
Twenty-seven degrees were conferred yesterday by Yeshiva College Teachers Institute at commencement exercises held in the school auditorium at Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

Sir Gareth, the brown son of Sir Gallahad, owned by Mrs. Verver Z. Reed, will be seeking his second victory in succession in the Greenwich Cup feature at the race meeting to be held under the auspices of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club today.
Finding no need for a one-goal handicap, the Governors Island polo team subdued the South Shore Polo Club of Long Island, 9 to 7, yesterday at Governors Island before a large holiday crowd.
Arthur George Perkin, Emeritus Professor of the University of Leeds, who was one of the pioneers in the development of new methods of British dye manufacture, died today at Leeds at the age of 75.

Disturbed by the apparent willingness of thousands of WPA workers to make careers of their relief jobs, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator here, disclosed yesterday that he had drawn preliminary plans for returning such workers to the home relief rolls and replacing them with

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor adjourned its week-long conference late today, instructing President William Green to launch a four-point campaign against the John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization. The council will meet again in Atlantic City Aug. 21.

Diplomas will be presented to eighty-six students of the Horace Mann School for Boys, 231 West 246th Street, at exercises at 3 P. M. today at the school. Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, will be the principal speaker, and William F. Russell, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, will preside. The list of graduates follows:
The Communist weekly Trabajo, which means work, has found an ingenious way to evade Costa Rica's press law which prohibits attacks or criticism of the policies or heads of foreign governments.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 90 per cent of capacity, down 1 point because of strikes started later in the week by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee or Amalgamated Association.

Warning of "subversive influences of foreign origin," Aldermanic President William F. Brunner yesterday told a Memorial Day gathering of 1,000 members of the Brooklyn Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars to beware of "a new philosophy which seeks to build up by tearing down."
President Roosevelt will face further tests of his influence in both the Senate and the House when Congress meets on Tuesday.

Miss Katherine Shack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Shack of Newark, was married today to Melvin David Brod, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Brod of New York, by the Rev. Dr. Solomon Foster of Newark, in his study.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Four fishermen were rescued from the waters off Rockaway Point about 9 o'clock yesterday morning after their fourteen-foot outboard motorboat Sea Nymph had been cut in two by the forty-five-foot fishing trawler Oceanbird.
The first voting test of the relative strength here of-the Committee for Industrial Organization and a local shoe workers' union has given the Lewis faction a decisive victory.
Sales in the retail trade in April were only 1.5 per cent larger than those of April, 1936, this increase comparing with one of 15.2 per cent in the preceding month over a year before.
Having the approval of no less a tribunal. than the New York State Court of Appeals, hundreds of young women hikers from New York City passed through Yonkers today wearing shorts.

Thirteen-year-old Muriel Arthur of'Larchmont, N. Y., carried off the major share of the honors at the third annual Staten Island horse show, staged under a warm Summer sun on the grounds of the Fifty-first Cavalry Brigade near Clove Lake yesterday.

The three America's Cup sloops, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new Ranger, Chandler Hovey's Rainbow, successful defender of the cup three years ago, and Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee had two perfect days for sailing tryouts over the week-end in preparation for the trial race series which will start off Brenton Reef on Wednesday.
Masonic and religious services were held this afternoon for Captain Christopher Kemmler, commanding officer of Troop K of the State police, who died suddenly Thursday night.

Mrs. Edward Henry Little of Newburyport and Boston has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marion Thorp Little, to Dr. David Woolfolk Barrow of this city, Lexington, Ky., and Boston, son of Mrs. David Woolfolk Barrow of Lexington and this city and the late Dr. Barrow.

For years Patrolman James Leone has prided himself on his 100 per cent record for restoring lost children to their parents. Yesterday, a frantic call was received at Police Headquarters from the Policeman's wife saying that their 4-year old son, Patty, was missing.

Manhattan and New York University last week were eliminated from the running for baseball honors among the metropolitan colleges although the Jaspers triumphed in their only game and the Violets were idle in intracity competition.

The wages of all hourly paid employes of the Canadian International Paper Company will be increased by 5 per cent as of Sept. 1, it has been announced. This increase will affect about 5,000 employes at the company's plants at Gatineau, Three Rivers,

Better weather for the growing crops, due to a more general supply of moisture in most of the largest surplus crop-producing sections last week, induced liquidation and resulted in an irregular decline in prices, with a distrustful feeling all along the line.

Featured by the dashing play of Miss Marjorie Le Boutillier, prominent woman poloist, the Bethpage Shamrocks defeated the Long Island Knaves, which had Miss Mary Maxwell in the starting line-up, 6 to 3, today.

Heinrich Henkel, Germany's No. 2 player, crowned his quick rise to tennis stardom today when he defeated Henry W. (Bunny) Austin of England, 6-1, 6-4, 6-3, to capture the French hard court singles championship.

With the arrest of Jose Bernardo Casanueva, a shopkeeper who is alleged to have had $1,000 in counterfeit United States notes, the police believe they have discovered an international counterfeiting group.

Ernest E. Von Zengen, for thirtyfive years foreman of the bindery department of the. New York Theatre Program Company, died Saturday night at his home, 37-42 101st Street, Corona, at the age of 77. Surviving are his widow,

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Arrowbrook (70)-Leaders in 36-hole Decoration Day tournament: Harry Parker, 85 gross; William Himlyn, 87; H. Feldman, 88. Bayside (71) - Decoration Day tournament: A. Cunningham, 80-9-71; Allan Craig, 86-14-72; Johnny Beyer, 84-1173: Dr. I. Epstein, 91-16-75; Dr. Clarence Cohen, 97-18-79; Dr. Jack Mandell, 10119-82.

Corporations in the United States in 1934 reported $100,831,253,000 in gross incomes to the Treasury Department, but showed net incomes of only $4,275,197,000 after taking allowable deductions and marking off deficits, Guy T. Heivering, Internal Revenue Commissioner, announced today.
The Detroit Tigers laid down a barrage of twenty hits today to rout the St. Louis Browns, 18 to 3, for the third victory of a four-game series.

Dr. and Mrs. Clarence C. Guion of New Rochelle, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Guion, to Walter Shillaber Rogers, son of Mrs. Jason Rogers of Brookline, Mass., and North Falmouth, Mass. The announcement was made at a tea yesterday at the Guion home.

Memorial services for men of the Grand Army of the Republic were held yesterday afternoon before the statue of General Sherman in the plaza at Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, by the Past Circle President's Association of the Ladies of the G. A. R.
The labor situation in Great Britain and the United States is attracting increasing attention now that some check to the growth of boom conditions has been accomplished.

An appeal to youth to provide a leadership of character and faith in democracy was made by the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, in his sermon yesterday morning.

The United Spanish War Veterans held their annual memorial vesper service yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of St. Cornelius the Centurion on Governors Island. After the service the veterans, their wives and friends witnessed a review of a battalion of the Sixteenth Infantry.

In his term of nine years each of the seven judges of the Illinois Supreme Court sits as its chief justice for at least a year in the order of rotation. Tomorrow Judge FARTHING, totally blind since he was 12, becomes chief justice.

Harpers have had revised and are reissuing some of the books on at business subjects that they pub. lished prior to 1930. Two such books to be brought out in the near future are "How to Do Publicity," by Raymond C. Mayer, and "Organized Training in Dusiness," by James H. Greene. Both books have been rewritten.

Two aces in America's successful defense of the Westchester Cup in England last year-Stewart Iglehart and Michael Phipps-led White sides to victories today in Meadow Brook Club members' polo matches. At near-by Mitchel Field, Iglehart headed a successful White quartet which turned back Tommy Hitchcock Jr.'s blue-shirted riders, 9 to 8, through a last-minute goal by Gerald Dempsey.

Having experienced one aerial bombardment in Valencia, Spain, and having seen the effects of another in Barcelona, Norman Thomas, United States Socialist leader, who arrived here today with his wife, characterized these raids as "cold-blooded murder" of innocent people by foreigners.
Four criminal maniacs, three of them known as dangerous, overpowered three guards and escaped late today at the State Hospital for the Criminal Insane at Howard, near here.

Establishment of an annual $1,500 award for research in surgery was announced yesterday by the 'executive council of the United States Chapter, International College of Surgeons, which will open its first American convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow afternoon.

Miss Mary Hopple of New York was married to Samuel Augustus Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Duncan of Englewood, at noon today in the First Presbyterian Church here, by the pastor, the Rev. Carl Hopkins Elmore.

Declaration of a distribution of $558,219 to certificate holders of Series F-1 mortgage certificates, the $28,000,000 issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, was announced yesterday by Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Lawrence N. Martin, trustees of the issue.

Great Britain's horse racing experts, faced with one of the most wide-open races in' Epsom Derby history on Wednesday, were groping around unhappily tonight trying to place their fingers on the winner.

George F. Young. Philadelphia soap manufacturer, died at his seashore home here today after an illness of five months, at the age of 52. He was the president of Charles W. Young Co. in Philadelphia and also had a home in that city.
A holiday gathering of-40,100 fans who literally stormed the gates saw the Yankees held to an even break by the Red Sox: today.

Legal action brought against Nazi elements and the publication, the Trabajo, as the result of the teargas bombing when President Arturo Alessandri returned to the palace on May 21 after the opening of Congress, has been delayed, it is admitted, to round up persons suspected of having participated in the disorders.

In an eyelash finish, by far the closest ever to mark the 500-mile automobile race, Wilbur Shaw of Indianapolis, driving a Shaw-Gilmore Special, nosed out Ralph Hepburn of Los Angeles for first by 2.16 seconds today and set a new record at the silver anniversary of the Speedway of 4 hours 24 minutes 7.81 seconds for an average speed of 113.580 miles an hour.

When the last blow had been struck in the North American Zone Davis Cup final with the United States at Forest Hills yesterday, the erstwhile mighty team from Australia found itself the victim of the same 5-0 shut-out that the Americans inflicted upon Japan.

A. C. Blumenthal, promoter of theatrical enterprises, returned on the Normandie yesterday from England, where he organized a company to introduce American hamburgers to the British. The company will set up twenty "whitefront" shops this year to test the English appetite on this American dish.

The Queens Seventy-third Street Corporation, Sam Minskoff, president, will erect a motion-picture theatre at the northeast corner of Seventy-third Street and Albemarle Terrace, in Jackson Heights, as a result of a lease for the proposed building made by the Brandt theatre circuit, headed by Harry Brandt and Dave Weinstock. The total rental under the lease is said to be about $250,000.
Officials of the State Hospital at near-by Howard reported today that four criminally insane patients who escaped last night after beating a guard had been captured and returned to the hospital.
The Christian Endeavor World will be resumed in July as a monthly publication of the International Society of Christian Endeavor, 41 Mount Vernon Place, Boston.

Columbia University, celebrating its 183d commencement, will award 4,501 degrees, 185 certificates and diplomas, 12 honorary degrees and 6 medals at tonight's graduation ceremonies, to be held in the South Court. The exercises are scheduled to begin at 6 o'clock.
The Guilmant Organ School will hold its thirty-eighth in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, with the Rev. Dr. J. V. Moldenhawer, pastor, presiding.

Spokesmen from five railroad brotherhoods will confer here tomorrow with Steel Workers Organizing Committee officials concerning the handling of rail ship ments destined for the strike-bound plants of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, John Mayo, S. W. O. C. sub-regional director, said today.

Miss Lucy Payne Pinder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Benjamin Pinder, became the bride of L. Scott Townsend Jr., son of Mrs. L. Scott Townsend of Rockland Farm, near, Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Townsend, today in Watts Memorial Chapel of the Presbyterian Theological Seminary here. Dr.John A., MacLean Jr. officiated.
Harry P. Hermance, president of the Florida Young Men's Christian Association, died of heart disease at his home last night at the age of 69.
British officials continued preparations tonight for large-scale air raid rehearsals to be held Wednesday in Malta despite the grave Spanish-international situation.

Tributes to soldier dead' should not obscure provisions for the "just deserts" of living veterans, Representative William M. Colmer of Mississippi said in memorial exercises attended by other members of Congress at Confederate and Federal cemeteries here.

AT 1:15 P. M. yesterday Carl Hubbell hitched A up his pants and ambled out of the Giant dugout at the Polo Grounds to warm up. It was an important occasion. Apparently the news had spread around, too. The park was packed. The firemen had closed the gates. The gendarmes were turning back late arrivals as they debarked from overflowing subway trains.

Industry's chances of surviving the world trend toward State control will be discussed at a two-day general management conference of the American Management.Association, starting tomorrow at the Hotel New Yorker. Speakers will include James 0. McKinsey, chairman of Marshall Field Co.; Andrew W.

joint luncheon meeting of the Mortgage Conference of New York and the Real Estate Board of New York will be held in the Hotel Commodore on June 11. The purpose will be to explain to reality and mortgage interests the significance of the laws adopted at the last session of the State Legislature affecting real estate.

Commencement activities will start today at the Birch Wathen School, 149 West Ninety-third Street, in preparation for the graduation exercises on Thursday afternoon. The Rev. Wendell Phillips of New Rochelle will give the commencement address at the exercises. Mrs. Edith Wathen and Mr.

The report issued by the Central Bank of Chile says business conditions during the early months of the year were favorable, although mining production, principally that of copper, heads the list with an unusually high output.

Even favorites will be 10-to-1 shots today when, at thirty points from Providence, R. I., to Fort Worth, Texas, the nation's golf hopefuls will battle for places in the 170-man starting field that will tee off in the United States open championship June 10 at the Oakland Hills Country Club. Birmingham, Mich.

Richard H. Albertson of 1,803 Beverly Road, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of his sister, Miss Elizabeth Jessica Albertson, to David Graham Walsh, son of Mrs. Ralph Walsh of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Walsh. The wedding will take place here on June 5 in the Church of the Transfiguration.

The Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America at their midyear session here today endorsed the "social objectives" of the Connery-Black Wages and Hours Bill, but cautioned Congress that the bill must be drawn "to make it economically workable."

Miss Elizabeth Marie Bartner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Bartner of Bay Shore, L. I., has chosen June 24 as the date for her marriage to Ward Henes Bolter, I son of Mrs. Carl Eggers of 850 Park Avenue and the late Edward Bolter of Chicago.
Members of the alumni society of Trinity School, 139 West Ninetyfirst Street, will give a testimonial dinner and reception for the Rev. Dr. Lawrence T. Cole on Thursday night at the Hotel Astor.

Thirteen Federal agencies awarded last week 108 -supply contracts valued at $6,770,668, the Department of Labor has announced. Awarded under the terms of the Public Contracts Act, the contracts included $1,277,782 to contractors in New York State; $13,998 in Connecticut and $25,502 in New Jersey.

Orchestral compositions by Philip James and David Diamond have been selected for publication by the Juilliard School of Music as a result of the school's annual competition for composers, it was announced yesterday.
The 324 seniors of Columbia College gathered yesterday with the faculty in Van Amringe Quadrangle for the traditional class day exercises, at which five of their number were honored with prizes.

Early 150 members of the Piping Rock Club at Locust Valley had luncheon there yesterday during innormal tennis matches. Among the hosts were Mr. and Mrs. Walbridge S. Taft of Glen Head, who entergained for Mr. and Mrs. Henry

Recommendations for modifications of the Federal tax on undistributed earnings of corporations were submitted yesterday to the Treasury Department, to the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives and to the Senate Finance Committee by the Committee on Federal Taxation of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

Dr. Paul Van Zeeland, President of the Assembly of the League of Nations and Prime Minister of Belgium, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Princeton University at the university's 190th commencement exercises June 22, according to a formal announcement made today by President Harold Willis Dodds.
From the looks of New York town during the three-day holiday it is asy to predict one major effect of the forty-hour week. City folk and outside folk will

A first mortgage of $26,000 on the five-story tenement house at 76 La Salle Street, assessed at $26,000, was arranged by Samuel Hurwitz for Frank Strobel. The same broker sold for the estate of John Hudson Hall a first mortgage of $16,500 on the five-story tenement at 10 Pitt Street, assessed at $15,000.
The seventy-first anniversary of the Wartburg Orphans Farm School was celebrated here today in conjunction with the institution's annual Spring festival.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway will ask permission of the Federal District Court in Chicago tomorrow to refund its $29,716,800 of equipment-trust certificates, E. M. Durham Jr., general manager, said here today.

Exchanges are the object of experiment today that may prove a costly obstacle to the country's recovery, in so far as it hampers the proper functioning of markets, said Thaddeus R. Benson, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange, in the annual report issued tonight. The fiscal year ended on April 30.

Boris Schwartsburg, 45 years old, of 595 Midwood Street, Brooklyn, was shot and fatally wounded last night in his drug store at 223 Monroe Street. He was found lying unconscious on the floor of the shop by a passer-by at 9:45 P. M.
Angelo Trulio, unattached, scratch man, defeated Alex Silverblatt, Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A., four points, 21-11, 21-8,
The Calumet Farm Stable's Count Morse today won the $5,000 added Blue and Gray Memorial Handicap over a mile and a furlong before a crowd of 33,642 spectators at Washington Park.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Spain's representative on the Council of the League of Nations, denounced the bombardment of Almeria in a formal note to the League of Nations tonight as "a fresh and flagrant act of aggression on the part of the Reich's naval forces, which constitutes the greatest outrage against an independent sovereign State."

T. O. M. Sopwith's new Class J sloop Endeavour II, which is soon to vie with the first Endeavour in a-series of races off here for the honor of trying to wrest the America's Cup from this country, was tonight moored in Brenton Cove.
Meeting the Commons as Prime Minister for the first time, Neville Chamberlain encountered deep and universal hostility today to his new tax on growth of profits.
Diplomas will be presented to thirteen students of the Highland Manor School, a private institution here, when commencement exercises are held tomorrow evening in the school gymnasium.

120-Yard High Hurdles-Won by Richard Craw, Newark Academy: Jerry Ackerman, East Orange, second: Thomas Garland, Bishop Loughlin, third; Jay Harris, Evander Childs, fourth; J. Schroeder, Textile, fifth. Time-0:15.2.

The protective committee for holders of Standard Gas and Electric Company $4 cumulative preferred stock has sent a letter to holders asserting that the committee will oppose the amended plan of reorganization of the company which has been filed in the United States District Court in Delaware.
Commencement exercises' for a class of 115 will be held today in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium of the College of Mount Saint Vincent, in the Riverdale section.

Cardinal Hayes, who conferred degrees on twenty-six graduates of Marymount College here today, declared that millions of dollars were being spent throughout the world for universities and colleges and "yet many of them are denying God."
Joint convention, National Association of Shellfisheries, Oyster Growers and Dealers Association of North America and Oyster Institute, Hotel Pennsylvania, 10 A. M. Continues Wednesday and Thursday.

Veterans administration officials warned 2,200 World War veterans whose war risk term insurance policies expire today that they would have only until tomorrow midnight to apply for new permanent policies.

The league-leading Newark Bears celebrated Memorial Day with a double victory over the Jersey City Giants today. They won a morning contest in Jersey City by a score of 6 to 0 and triumphed in the afternoon game here, 2 to 1.

Paul S. Carter of New York was elected president of the Gunnery Alumni Association at the annual meeting today at the Gunnery School. Charles F. Neilson Jr., '29, of New York and Rumson, was elected alumni representative on the board of trustees.

The unusual story of a man whose throat was slashed severely two years ago and who was believed dead, only to recover completely, was related to the American Laryngological Association here today and the man himself appeared as the living witness.
The cellar-dwelling Reds divided a double-header with the league-leading Pirates before 14,352 fans today.
J. M. Darden, vice president and member of the board of directors of the National Bank of Suffolk, died yesterday at his Summer camp on the Nanseemond River. He was 71 years old.
A home run by Bernie Coyle in the ninth inning with the bases full enabled Seton Hall College to defeat the New York A. C. nine on the latter's diamond at Travers Island yesterday, 9 to 5.

Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Laughlin of Pittsburgh and Washington announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Laughlin, to Lieutenant Hubert Winthrop Chanler, U. S. N., son of Mrs. Winthrop Chanler of Geneseo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Chanler. Lieutenant Chanler is at present detailed as an aide at the White House.

A notable gathering of society attended the annual Fairfield and Westchester racing meet held here today on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club. Mrs. John Vincent of Greenwich headed the women's committee.
Following oral and written examinations for seniors at Swarthmore College, the names of seventyone students who will receive degrees with honors at commencement were announced.

Investors and financial groups interested in London Terrace, multifamily apartment project occupying the block bounded by Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Streets, Ninth and Tenth Avenues, have agreed upon a new financial set-up for that property, according to mortgage and property transfer papers which have just been filed in the Register's office.

Wilbert Products Company, Inc., manufacturers of furniture and shoe polishes, are planning to expand their present plant at 805 East 139th Street, the Bronx. Drawings are being made for a new twostory building, for erection on a site adjoining the plant, as part of the program laid out by Francis Chilson, industrial engineer, to provide for increased production.

The Williams freshman baseball team wound up its season today by trouncing Brooklyn Poly Prep, 9 to 4. Two other Poly teams played at the same time, the lacrosse team defeating the Purple yearlings, 8 to 1, and the tennis team bowing, 9 to 0.

Warm weather in some sections produced a marked increase in orders for Summer apparel placed in the New York wholesale market last week. Cotton dresses for street, sports and formal wear were ordered generously for National Cotton Week promotions.

Thirty-four of the most important works in this country by the great seventeenth century Dutch painter Frans Hals, valued at approximately $6,000,000, will leave on Friday as a loan by American museums, collectors and dealers to the special exhibition of Hals paintings this Summer in Haarlem, Holland.

The Kellogg Company, makers of Kellogg's corn flakes and other cereal products is launching a $54,000 prize contest in 700 daily newspapers from coast to coast and in three Sunday newspaper magazine groups.
Evidence that prosperity has returned to the art world came at Christie's today, when a sale of Rembrandt etchings comprising the collection of the late Dr. Leonard Gow brought [Pound]16,878.

Unskilled labor's right to strike and the right of a woman to sue for divorce on the grounds of incompatibility were part of "New Deal" legislation by the Talmudic interpreters of the Mosaic Laws between the third and fifth centuries of the Christian Era, Dr. Louis Ginzberg, Professor of Talmud at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, said last night.

The church having canonized PERE JOGUES and other missionary martyrs of the St. Lawrence and the Mohawk valleys should be adding to the list the name of PERE MARQUETTE, of what we now call the Middle West. He did not as JOGUES come to a death by violence; but he faced like perils and looked death in the face more than once.

Five thousand spectators, watching Memorial Day races on the Hatfield Speedway's dirt track near here, saw a speeding car driven by Preston Norcross, 27, of Pitman, N. J., burst into flames after being wedged between two other machines.

Automobile production last week increased over the revised figures of the previous period, when a sharp seasonal drop was to be expected, and the adjusted index has advanced to 137.2 from 123.2 (revised). For the week ended May 30, 1936, the index was 104.4.
Memorial Day parades were held in all the cities and most of the twenty-four villages of Westchester County today, and flowers were strewn upon Long Island Sound i memory of the war dead.
The possibility that Jackson E. president of the First National Bank, might return as chairman, at least during a readjustment period following George F. Baker's death, was seen yesterday.
The Russian Government, sympathetic to the Spanish Madrid-Valencia republic, awaited detailed information tonight on the German bombardment of Almeria.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 will offer this country a "marvelous opportunity" to serve the cause of world peace, King Carol II of Rumania declared in a message promising Rumanian partieipation in the fair, which was made public here yesterday.

Memorial Day tribute was paid here today to those who lost their lives in the destruction of the German airliner Hindenburg May 6. Representatives of Germany and the United States joined in an almost privately conducted ceremony at the bow of the fire-scarred frame of the airship.

Alberta's Social Credit Government will default on a $1,650,000 bond maturity due tomorrow, Solon Low, Provincial Treasurer, announced here today after the Bank of Canada had notified the Province that it would not lend the Province enough money to meet the maturity.

The Federal Trade Commission has issued a complaint against Educators Association, Inc., 307 Fifth Avenue, New York, charging unfair competition in the interstate sale of a reference book entitled "The Volume Library." The corporation has twenty days in which to file a reply.

Bill Farns-worth, fleet. 4-year-old gelded son of Crack Brigade-Bridgeen, broke 'the Suffolk Downs track record for six 'furlongs today while winning the $5,000 added Decoration Day Handicap before a crowd of 45,000.

While several thousand persons watched from the street, firemen using eighty-five-foot aerial ladders rescued twenty-five men, women and children trapped on fire-escapes on the upper floors of a five-story tenement at 47 Allen Street shortly after 2 P. M. yesterday.

Mr. Watt, Newbrook Stables' star 3year-old trotter, and Watson Hanover, trotting colt, owned and driven by Dr. John Young of Montclair, captured the feature events of the holiday matinee at Weequahic Park today.

Trinity College defeated Yale today, 11 to 5, for its eighth victory in ten starts this season. The Trinity batsmen found Monroe Jubitz and Tom Crosby, sophomore pitchers, for thirteen hits, and these, combined with eight passes, gave the visitors an easy triumph.
The Memorial Day holiday ended yesterday in a blaze of sunshine and a great rush of traffic as thousands- of visitors left the city and more thousands of New Yorkers came. home.

In a day replete with shining performances, Edward Morgan, 16year-old Overbrook High School boy of Philadelphia, covered himself with glory yesterday in the onemile run, feature event of the interscholastic track and field meet staged by the Grand Street Boys' Association at the Randalls Island Stadium.
Plans for a national organization, with headquarters in Washington, were completed today at the first meeting of the national executive committee of the newly formed Social Democratic Federation.
Yale University will offer in the Graduate School a new program of studies in American thought and civilization for the next academic year, Dean Edgar S. Furniss said today.

Mrs. Bert Levy, whose husband was released last week from a Spanish Insurgent prison camp, said today that she had r- ceived the following cable from Mr. Levy in London: "O. K. Home shortly. Love. Bert."

By its unexpectedly easy defeat of the Australians, the American Davis Cup team will see Europe this year, and America now has as hopeful a prospect of getting the cup back as it has had at any time since it was lost just ten years ago.

AHERN-(By Cable) May, 30. 1937. Elizabeth, age 23, youngest child of the late William Ahern, J. P., and Mrs. Ahern, Ross Mountnugent, County Meath, Ireland; beloved sister of Annie W. Getty, Geraldine and Vincent Ahern.

The creation of a committee to draft and promulgate a code of ethics for the prosecution and defense of criminal cases was announced yesterday by Robert Daru, president of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association. The code will be formulated for the guidance of the bar throughout the United States, according to Mr. Daru.
John A. Kelley of Arlington, Mass., former winner of the Boston mara thon and Olympic team member in 1936, won the national 15-kilometei run today. His time was 51 minutes I second.

It is by setting an example that democracy can do most for countries under autocratic rule. It is by keeping our own house in order and by guarding against extremes even in denunciation that free peoples can resist the intolerance of dogmatic States and demonstrate that compromise is the atmosphere distinguishing democratic societies from totalitarian dictatorships.

Although outhit, the White Sox defeated the Browns in both ends of their holiday double-header today, 5 to 2 and 9 to 8, before 35,000 fans. The Sox thus climbed above the .500 mark for the first time this season.

Surpassing the time performances of such famous stars as Equipoise, Head Play, Crusader, Mad Hatter and Grey Lag, Aneroid, the supposed sprinter, ran the mile and a quarter of the Suburban Handicap in 2:0135 at Belmont Park yesterday.
The Basques took the initiative last night and this morning in four sectors of the Bilbao front, from the center to the extreme south.

Upon surrender of Anchor Post Fence Company first closed-mortgage 6 1/2 per cent gold bonds dated May 15, 1927, to the Chase National Bank, holders of bonds with the Nov. 15, 1934, and subsequent coupons attached may receive the new registered first closed-mortgage 5 per cent income bonds issued pursuant to the plan of reorganization.

Germany tonight gave a favorable reply to a Franco-British plan to create naval "safety zones" around Spain, informed sources said, to liquidate quickly the crisis over the Spanish bombing of the German warship Deutschland and the German reprisals at Almeria.

Miss Marie Lemdres, 33 years old, of 71 Boyd Street, Jersey City, who had been missing since May 26, jumped from a fifth story window at the Elizabeth Carteret Hotel here this morning after a detective who had been assigned to locate her tried to enter her room.

Business reports for May have been of the same general character as those for April-the industries have well-filled order books and production in most lines is holding at peak levels past the time when a seasonal tapering off is usually expected, says the National City Bank in its monthly bulletin.

Marshall Faillace, at 209 Oakland Ave, Rye; Henry Lemcke, broker. Jack E. Jackson, at 28 Woodmere Blvd, from Lawrence Ave Realty Corp; George Wolf, at 925 Mayfield Rd, from Morris Realty Service Corp; Doris Barnett, on Club Drive, from Fairfax Colonial Corp; Woodmere (L. I.) rentals by Lewis H. May Co.

Mgr. Robert G. Connor, chaplain of St. Ursula's Convent of Brown County, St. Martin, Ohio, since December, 1935, died here today of pneumonia, at the age of 67. Prior to his appointment there, he was pastor of the Church of Assumption for more than ten years.
Allan Cameron, Oriental manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway until his retirement five years ago, died here yesterday. His age was 73.
A 5 per cent wage decrease "to adjust payrolls" to the present level of metal prices, will become effective in Arizona's copper industry tomorrow.

Fine cotton weather over the Memorial Day week-end ushered in National Cotton Week in the metropolitan area under unusually favorable circumstances. Hundreds of shop windows throughout the five boroughs of the city are showing a profusion of cottons-apparel and household-to mark New York's observance of the annual event which this year has enlisted some 40,000 retail merchants in every section of the country.

At no time, since the arguments over constitutionality between the present administration and the present Supreme Court began, has there been any attempt to alter unbroken limitation of the powers of Congress under the "general welfare" clause of Article I, Section 8. By maijority.
The New York University School of Retailing will give its annual dinner for members of the graduating class at the B. Altman Co. store tonight, it was announced yesterday by Dean Norris A. Brisco.

Hollywood must have caught up with me at last-taking a hot day to do it, too-for here I find myself confessing that my chief objection to the Little Carnegie's "Under the Red Robe" is its selection of Con rad Veidt for the dashing, romantic role of Gil de Berault.

More than 3,000 lovers of light harness racing, mostly society from Long Island and Orange County, were treated to six closely contested events today, at the first matinee sponsored. by the newly formed Hambletonian Sulky and Saddle Club, held at Good Time Park.

The death toll in yesterday's battle between steel mill strikers and police at South Chicago mounted to five today. Meanwhile, Governor Henry Horner began conferences to effect a settlement of the strike and union leaders voiced demands for murder indictments against Chicago lawenforcement authorities.

The stock market here was 'extremely depressed today and all sections declined. Gilt-edge issues gave way, and among the foreign loans German bonds were weak in a generally dull list. International stocks fell off; among them, United States Steel and International Nickel shares lost ground.

Two or more scholarships at the Juilliard School of Music will be awarded next Fall to piano and violin students of Northern New Jersey with funds allocated from the proceeds of four Bamberger-sponsored concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra here last season, it was announced today by William J. Wells, president of L. Bamberger Co.
Several acres of wooded land on S Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, Conn., have been sold by the Oenoke Property Corporation to Mrs. Mary deP. Charles of New York, who will build an all-year residence there.

Little Victor Emannuel Albert Charles Theodore Humbert Boniface Amadeus Damianus Bernard Januarius Mary, 3-months-old first born son of the Prince and Princess of Piedmont, was baptized this morning in the Pauline Chapel in the Quirinal.

A contract for the construction of fifty-three coke ovens at the Algoma Steel Corporation's plant has been awarded to the Wilputte Coke Oven Corporation, New York, T. F. Rahilly, plant manager, announced today.
Wallis Warfield has been accused, by some of her detractors, of being an ambitious intriguer for the throne of Great Britain and the Empire. Her answer is a spirited and indignant denial.

I. P. Mazuruk's airplane, on a different iceflow from that of Professor Otto J. Schmidt's polar camp, is steadily drifting away, according to a report from the North Pole station today. Originally twenty-five miles distant from the polar base, it was at last report forty-eight miles distant.

Walter W. Schwaab, an attorney, died today following an operation at the age of 53. Mr. Schwaab, a son of the late Judge John Schwaab, was graduated from the University of Cincinnati School of Law in 1926.
In his first speeches as leader of the nation, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain pledged himself and his government today to work unceasingly for reconciliation in Europe and unity at home.
Skagerrak Day, the anniversary of the naval battle of Jutland, was observed here today with a parade in-which an honor company from the visiting Japanese cruiser Ashigara took part.
Seven-year-old Totem, owned by Clifford D. Mallory and A. E. Luders Jr., once more showed the way to this year's crop of sixmeters in a race conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.
Flanked by the second largest crowd in the history of the Polo Grounds-a gathering that totaled 61,756 sweltering enthusiasts-the Giants and Dodgers split a torrid double-header yesterday.

Germany and Italy have withdrawn from participatior. both in the international supervision around Spain and in the proceedings of the London NonIntervention Committee until they receive sure guarantees against such incidents as last Saturday's bombing of the German battleship Deutschland.

Yesterday's extra matinees, indulged in by thirteen of the city's seventeen shows, turned in a surprisingly good score. The usual theatre tradition is that on Summer holidays the business is in inverse ratio to the weather:

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene G. Hanford of West Dudley Avenue today observed the fifty-fourth anniversary of their marriage. They were wed in Albany, N. Y., home of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Green, parents of Mrs. Hanford.
An timated crowd of 40,000 persons witnessed a Memorial Day parade ere today, which included reprentatives of 110 units of military, vie and fraternal organizations ld twenty military bands.

Ramsay MacDonald's old age is well secured by a bequest to him in the will of Sir Alexander Grant, his old-time friend, filed today. Under the will the former Lord President of the Council receives the income from [Pound]40,000, estimated at about [Pound]1,500 annually, as long as he lives.

More than 1,000 persons, including members of the Society of the North Shore Colonies, civic organizations and city officials, took part in the unveiling of a bronze plaque to Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt here this morning at the main entrance to the Harriet Barnes Pratt Park.

Running up a total of 169 runs against 81 for the home team, Hudson County of the Brooklyn Cricket Club today defeated Plainfield in the opening match of the annual series at Cedar Brook Park. R. A. Wiles, first batsman for the winners, started with 41, but P. B. Green hit up the top score of 64.

The Shell Company of California was ordered by the National Labor Relations Board to withdraw all recognition from the Shell Conference Delegate Plan, which was found by the board to be subject to company influence and therefore not a valid agency for collective bargaining.

The committee for preferred stockholders of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, in a letter to stockholders says it will make an effort to elect two "independent" directors at the adjourned annual meeting on June 15.

Senator William E. Borah declared today in regard to the German bombardment of Almeria, Spain, that it would appear an act of war had been committed and that "we should apply our Neutrality Law to all participants."
A plea to "save America for democracy" was made here today by Harry W. Colmery, National Commander of the American Legion, in a Memorial Day address.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, arriving today from Southampton and Cherbourg, has among her passengers Sir Lenthal Cheatle, surgeon of King's College Hospital, London, accompanied by his wife and daughter. Others on the liner are R. Nagaoka, E. H. Murrant, the Rev. and Mrs. G. Campbell Morgan. Mr. and Mrs.

Since his retirement from active service in the army ten years ago General John McAuley Palmer has devoted much of his time to work on a life of Baron von Steuben. He has just delivered the manuscript of this work to Yale University Press. It will be published in the Fall under the title "General von Steuben."

Hans Dann, 56 years old, captain of the Savannah Line lighter Ohio, was shot and fatally wounded early last night in his apartment at 42 La Salle Street, near Amsterdam Avenue. His wife, Rose Marie, 40,
Mechanics completed today the adjustment of navigation instruments to guide Amelia Earhart to South America on a second attempt to fly around the world.
Bob Feller, the Indians' young strikeout artist, who has pitched in only two league games this season because of an ailing arm, packed his bag tonight and went away for a rest.
With unified vocalization, about 7,000 students in Roman Catholic Church schools of the Newark diocese participated here this afternoon in the fourth annual demonstration of liturgical music.
The net wholesale value of trailers sold by 357 factories in the United States in 1936 was $27,421,763, the Department of Commerce announced today. The total number sold was 53,646.
In bombarding Almeria, the Germans not only retaliated for the bombing of the pocket battleship Deutschland but also may have aided the Rebel cause. This city,

Funeral services were held yesterday in a flower-filled chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, for Mrs. Emma Ovenshine Harbord, wife of Major Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America.
Orson Woolsey, prominent horticulturist and former Utica contractor, died at his home here late last night at the age of 70.

The Maryland Trust Company, as trustee for Houston Oil Company of Texas ten-year secured 5 1/2 per cent Series A bonds due in 1940, has announced that it has drawn by lot for redemption on Aug. 1, at 101 1/4 and accrued interest, $592,500 of the bonds, which will be paid at the office of the Maryland Trust Company, Baltimore;

Marshal I. B. Gamarnik, 43, Vice Commissar of Defense and one of the leading officials of the Communist party, committed suicide yesterday, the party central committee announced today. The terse announcement said Marshal Gamarnik was involved with anti-Soviet elements in a plot. against the government,
Several sales of private dwellings featured the Brooklyn deals reported yesterday. Also included in the transactions in that section was the sale of a four-story tenement.

Whopper, Hal Price Headley's giant 5year-old, won the $5,000 added Colonel Frederick M. Alger Memorial Handicap at the Detroit Fair Grounds track today, leading all the way and standing off a final challenge by Azucar.

Two automobiles were damaged and a woman was injured slightly at about 8:30 o'clock last night as a runaway horse wtih a helpless rider ran across West End Avenue at Eighty-ninth Street, after a gallop from Central Park.
The text of the protest to the League of Nations Council on the bombing of Almeria by German warships by Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Spanish representative on the Council, is as follows :

Miss Lucille Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ford Hall of Merrywood, this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Burrall Barnum of New York, which will take place here on the afternoon of June 12 in Christ Episcopal Church. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Albert J. Wilson, and will be followed by a reception in the garden of Merrywood.

The newspaper Ultimas Noticias says the government is considering plans for the general electrification of Chile, with the construction of numerous hydro-electric plants to supply power and light to all cities and towns.

Relatives and friends will attend a reception tomorrow evening to mark the fiftieth wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grant Pierson of West Orange at their home. The couple have lived in West Orange forty-seven years.

Fernand Cuny, French boxing promoter, died today in his Paris home after a fortnight's illness. He had been called the father of French prize fighting because he introduced and popularized the Queensberry rules which the French call "boxe anglaise" as opposed to the French style, "savate," wherein a contestant also is allowed to use his feet.
The Starlight Theatre at Pawling opened its fourth Summer season this evening with a production of "Across the Blue," by Maryverne Jones, who operates the theatre.
Catalan Government officials announced today that they had confirmed that an Italian submarine launched the torpedo that-sank the Spanish passenger liner Ciudad de Barcelona.

COPPERSMITH, $1.056, $1.116, $1.176 per hour, Navy Yard, Brooklyn, N. Y. Applications will be rated as received until further notice by the Recorder, Labor Board, Navy Yard, Brooklyn, N. Y. Competitors will not be required to report for a written examination, but will be rated on their experience and fitness, on a scale of 100, such ratings being based upon competitors' sworn statements in their applications and union corroborative evidence.

The Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation will offer today to its preferred stockholders an exchange of two new series of a new cumulative prior - preferred stock and additional shares of common stock, for which a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission has become effective.

Marshall W. Taylor, executive secretary of this city's Sesquicentennial Exposition in 1926 and well known in the show business, died last night in the Skin and Cancer Hospital here. He had been ill seven months. His age was 69.

The Long Island Real Estate Board, in a resolution adopted by the board of governors, has asked Mayor La Guardia to press for early action by the Board of Estimate on the plan to have the city acquire property now owned by the Long Island Railroad to provide rapid transit facilities for the Rockaways.
The cotton market here was quiet today because other markets throughout the country were closed for the Memorial Day holiday. The losses were 9 to 10 points.
T. Kearney Vertner, former vice president of the American Bank and Trust Company and 'associated with the receivers of that institution, died at a hospital here yesterday. He was 52 years old.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday the assignment of various topics to special and regular committees of business men for study and report so that the business viewpoint may be brought before the New York State Constitutional Convention in 1938.
Italy is seething with excitement over the attacks suffered by Italian and German warships and over the first reprisals carried out by the German Government.
The Senators had a big inning in each game of a double-header with the Athletics today and won by scores of 6 to 3 and 6 to 1.

Walter Young, who ran himself off the dole and into a Verdun, Quebeo policeman's uniform by winning last month's Boston A. A. marathon, overcame terrific heat and 51 rivals today when he captured the Lawrence-tothe-sea race with almost five minutes to spare on Clarence DeMar, the Keene, N. H. veteran.

Not long ago one of our judges threw out a case concerning resale price-fixing on the ground that the wording of the law supposed to cover it was unintelligible. Such boldness on the part of a judge is unusual.

Governor Lehman signed today two bills by Senator McElroy of Syracuse, one appropriating $300,000 to finance the State's participation in Federal flood control projects, and the other $10,000 for a temporary commission to assist in a Federal longrange program to regulate flood waters within the State.

For the five months ended May 31, 1937, the average price of real estate bond issues showed a decline of 3 per cent, according to the June 1 Amott-Baker Realty Bond Averages, based upon 200 selected issues of properties in New York, Buffalo, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and other Eastern cities.
Mr. and Mrs. George Lurcott, who were honored a year ago as New York City's ideal parents at a publie ceremony in Central Park, had a celebration of their own yesterday.

The Credit Retailers of America, composed of 200 credit apparel stores, will establish a new buying division, to be known as the Credit Retailers Buying Association of America; they claim to have a purchasing power of between $35,000,000 and $40,000,000 annually, Hyman Settel, executive secretary, announced yesterday. Aaron Cohen,

Willard A. Curtis, retired banker of Hackensack, N. J., once an associate of J. P. Morgan Co., died last night in a hospital here at the age of 68. Funeral services will be held Wednesday with burial in Hackensack.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the heading "Henry Street Housing Project," you published a letter signed by Maurice Gersing, president Brooklyn Housing Slum Clearance Association, which contains errors of fact.

With Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as a guest, the Naval Academy plunged into June Week festivities with a day of perfect weather ending this evening with the superintendent's annual garden party for the graduating class and the traditional ceremony of the Ring Dance at which the members of the second class put on their academy rings for the first time.

The marriage of Miss Jane Corrigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Corrigan, to Professor Vernon A. O'Rourke of New York took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents on Beaver Dam Road. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Borthwick, pastor of the South Haven Presbyterian Church.
The soldier dead of this Republic--particularly the Union dead of the Civil War-were honored yesterday by 20,000 Memorial Day marchers who paraded up Riverside Drive under bright skies.

Turpentine firm, 34 1/2@35c; sales, 327 barrels; receipts, 464 barrels; shipments, 286 barrels; stock, 27,193 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 1,084; receipts, 1,888; shipments 3,733; stock, 44,949. Quote: B, $7.15; D, E. $7.40-50; F, to N, $8; WG, $8.15; WW, X, $9.

The British Government has begun a genuine effort to work out a formula for an Anglo - American trade compact through the medium of the Imperial Conference on the basis of the list of items submitted recently by the United Staes.

Andrew Luck, a musician and composer who helped Victor Herbert in arranging scores, died at his home here last night in his seventyseventh year. Born in Bavaria, he was a trumpeter in the German cavalry before coming to this country, where he became a proofreader in a music publishing house.
Henry Ford arrived here today for a short vacation. He accompanied Mrs. Ford, who is here for a meeting of the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association, of which she is a former president.
Leaders of a kneel-down strike of Catholic parishoners here announced today that Federal authorities in Mexico, D. F., had instructed border officials to return the church to their possession.

Miss Elizabeth Hillman Kirkpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harlow B. Kirkpatrick of Schenley Farms Terrace, was married to Sanford Lewis Hotchkiss, son of Mrs. Hariet Smith Hotchkiss of Milford, Conn., Saturday night in the Church of the Ascension here. The Rev. Dr. H. Boyd Edward performerd the ceremony.
The 5-year-old pomeranian Ch. Little Sahib, owned by Mrs. Vincent Matta of Astoria, N. Y., was selected best of show in the eighth
The Rev. Dr. Johann Emanuel Nidecker, pastor emeritus of old Zion Lutheran Church, died at his home in Narberth today after an illness of several months. He was 77 years old.
A "witch doctor," Kancubina, staggered into Roper River police station with a leper boy on his back.

Pope Pius celebrated his eightieth birthday today on the very day his health suffered such an appreciable setback that he was obliged to cancel the inauguration of the Pontifical Academy of Science, which he himself was to have performed this evening.
The three days' holiday brought a large number of visitors here. Practically all the Summer homes were open and the hotels were filled to capacity.
Dr. James Lawson Patterson, for twenty-five years headmaster of Chestnut Hill Academy, Philadelphia, and former mathematics instructor at Lawrenceville School, died here early today at the age of 87.

A survey of the domestic banking structure, intended to encourage consolidations, mergers and migration of banks where such changes would bring about stronger banks and better service, has been undertaken by the Executive Committee of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, Luther A. Harr, chairman of its executive committee and Secretary of Banking of Pennsylvania, announced today.

For one dollar, or the tenth part of a sawbuck, you can see a revival of "The Bat" at the Majestic, where a program of Summer stock opened last evening. According to the bulletins, it is "the first in a series of mystery melodramas" if people who are city-pent want their blood to run cold during the torrid months at slight inconvenience to their pocketbooks.
Oil refiners of the nation began today a series of committee meetings and round-table conferences opening the American Petroleum Institute's seventh midYear meeting.

President Lazard Cardenas late this evening refused to have a formal meeting with representatives of foreign oil companies for the time being, as the fourth day of the nation-wide petroleum strike drew to a close.

Settlement tomorrow of all differences over the $1,500,000,000 relief bill and its passage by the House was predicted tonight by Congressional leaders, who also prepared to receive President Rooseveit's message
Two boys were drowned about 4 P. M. today when caught in a whirlpool while swimming near Tiffany Falls in the Second River inside the Essex County Park Reservation here. The youths,

Somerset and Middlesex registered their first victories of the English county cricket championship series today. The Cider County routed Northamptonshire by an innings and 13 runs, Middlesex gaining an eight-wicket decision over Essex.
The Mediterranean seaport of Almeria was bombarded today at dawn by five German warships in reprisal for the Loyalist air attack on the pocket battleship Deutschland last Saturday.

Fred Jacoby Jr., for the past two years.America's high-point scoring champion in outboard racing, added three new titles to his long string today on a placid, sundrenched Raritan River in the first annual regatta of a new series for .the New Jersey State Spring championships.

Vincent A. Currie, 32, a nurse at the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane, was charged today with second degree manslaughter following the death of Alexis St. Pierre, 58, a patient who was a former resident of Cohoes.

With all four Cadet riders scoring, Army's polo team defeated Harvard, 11-3, on Howze Field today. Harry Wilson had a severe shaking up in a bad spill, but remounted to continue in the game. The line-un:
Three telephone company employes have won the Theodore N. Vail medal for "noteworthy public service," it was announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Three young thugs, one armed with two pistols in the Western style of the movies, staged an early morning hold-up yesterday in a garage at 1,167 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn.

Arthur L. Kingsley, Highland Park publisher, who narrowly escaped death last year at the hands of the Black Legion, died early this afternoon in Highland Park General Hospital from burns received in his apartment.

B. Rush Wendell died here today at the age of 81 at his home, Weltevreden. A graduate of Yale in the class of '78, he belonged to the Union Club, St. Nicholas Society and Yale Club of New York and the Society of the Cincinnati.

John Ford's first production for Renowned Artists will be "Quiet Man," by Frank Walsh. For the purpose of production, a subsidiary, Ford Productions, is being formed and will be owned jointly by the director and Renowned.

Suffering from what was diagnosed at first as morphine poisoning, and later as coronary thrombosis, Dr. John Wyckoff, dean of the New York University and Bellevue Hospital Medical College, was taken last night to the emergency ward of Bellevue, where he died at 3:10 o'clock this morning.

Treasury finance is not in these days a field in which one can see very far ahead. One entry in the daily Treasury report under the title "Assets and Liabilities," is just now attracting perplexed attention; it shows how consequences wholly unforeseen may arise from our highly experimental legislation. When, in 1933,
Dr. Rockwell H. Potter, dean of Hartford Theological Seminary, gave the address to the class at Clark School commencement Saturday. The twenty-nine graduates were:

World's Fair Committee Eastern Presidents' Conference, in New York Central Building, 230 Park Ave. Brown-Forman Distillery Co., Inc., additional space; May A. Taylor, Maurice Emataz, Walter Kidde Co., Inc., in Brady Building, 140 Cedar St.; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.

It would be difficult to exaggerate the gravity of the crisis precipitated by Germany's naval shelling very early yesterday of the Spanish port of Almeria as an act of "reprisal" for the bombing by Loyalist planes on Saturday of the German pocket battleship Deutschland. The news that the Reich,

The field.for today's heroes lies in conquest of "the knowledge of how to live in this new world," Dorothy Thompson, wife of Sinclair Lewis, told the graduating class of 964 at Syracuse University today.

Old Ira Fisk seat sunning himself yesterday afternoon on board the barge Louis Gans moored at Pier 9 on the East River when he became involved in the kind of adventure usually associated with tropical waters.

IT would be pleasant to report that Sir Herbert J. C. Grierson's "Milton and Wordsworth: Poets and Prophets" (Macmillan, $2.50) is exactly what the subtitle declares it to be-a, study of their reactions to political events.

Everything was ready here tonight for the handling of Pan American and Imperial Airways planes on experimental flights between Ireland and New York, preliminary to proposed regular commercial flights.

BOLINVAR, by Marguerite F. Bayliss. (Derrydale Press, two volumes, $15.) A historical novel of the sporting life in early nineteenth century America, much of it based on the records of a New Jersey family, 1815,1820.

Germany notified the International Non-Intervention Committee in London today of her refusal to participate in further deliberations of that body or in patrol service off Spain until complete protection against further air attacks on ships of the international patrol fleet is assured.

Dr. Clarence C. Little, director of the Jackson Memorial Laboratory and managing director of the American Society for Control of Cancer, will be the commencement speaker tonight at the exercises of the Child Education Foundation Training School, to be held in the assembly room of the Child Education Foundation, 535 East Eightyfourth Street.

First Military Area A board of officers is appointed to meet at Syracuse, N. Y., at the call of the president thereof, to examine such persons as may be properly ordered before it to determine their fitness for appointment or certificate of capacity in the Officers' Reserve Corps.

Local 819 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters (formerly the Drivers Brotherhood of the Parmelee System), the newly chartered American Federation of Labor taxicab drivers union, matched strike threats with the C. I. O. group last night.

Frederick H. Prince, financier of Boston and Chicago, predicted on his return from Europe yesterday that the United States would witness the political.phenomenon of a Republican-Democratic coalition if the.growing power of labor resulted in the nomination of John L. Lewis for the Presidency.

The United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons, whose first assembly will be opened this afternoon at the WaldorfAstoria by Governor Lehman, yesterday announced the appointment of a national council of examiners and three national regents.

Zeffarino Sylvestre Poli, founder of a group of twentythree theatres, pioneer of vaudeville, a sculptor and artist, died this afternoon at his residence, Villa Rosa, of a heart attack. His age was 77.

Miss Mary Elizabeth LaDucer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William LaDucer of this place, was married this afternoon in the Franklin Reformed Church to Kenneth Simpson Glover, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Glover Sr. of Nutley, by the Rev. Arthur Roosenraad, the pastor.

The newly selected 1937 women's United States lacrosse team combined brilliant work with competent scoring tactics to tally a 16-to-4 victory over the U. S. Reserve twelve in the final match of the closing session of the fifth annual national lacrosse tournament today at Buckingham Field.

Hotel interests headed by Sidney Claman, now owning and operating the Hotel Times Square, will take over formally today the management of the 400-room Hotel Breslin at Twenty-ninth Street and Broadway. Sale of this property to the Claman interests was announced several days ago.

Irked no little by the defeat the New York selected fifteen handed them a fortnight ago, the Irish chanipions from County Mayo swung right from the floor in the second battle of the international Gaelic football series at the Yarikee Stadium yesterday and completely floored the Americans.

Sir Thomas Neill, one of the three commissioners who inaugurated England's system of health insurance, after aiding Lloyd George in preparing the law which was passed in 1911, died today at the age of 81.

The problem of poachers or trespassers is not often discussed. Edward R. Hewitt, eminent author and authority on trout, has made public a letter in which he explains his stand in dealing with the problem along the famed Neversink. But before he tackles the subject he has a word to say about his own fishing:

Captain Chester W. Minitz, assistant chief of the Bureau of Navigation of the navy, delivered the memorial address today at ceremonies marking the unveiling of memorial plaque to Rear Admiral Charles Frederick Hughes, at Admiral Farragut Academy here.

In the closest-finish that has been seen at any of the hunts meets this season, Charles the Second, a French-bred son of Le Traguet-Nell Gwynne, making his first race in this country, thrilled 8,000 spectators at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club today as he closed through the stretch to win the Greenwich Cup by a nose.

Miss Phyllis Ruth Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Philip Smith of this place, has chosen the night June 22 for her marriage to Montgomery Stevenson Blake, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Blake of Glen Ridge, N. J. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. John Gordon in the Second Congregational Church, Rockford.

The Rev. Walter E. Hopper, C. S. P., oldest Paulist Father in the United States, died yesterday of pneumonia at the age of 78 at his residence in the rectory of the Paulist Fathers Church at Fifty-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue. Five nieces and a nephew, all of this city, survive.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hoepli and their daughters, the Misses Eleanor and Nancy Hoepli, will arrive tomorrow on the Rotterdam and will join Mrs. Hoepli's mother, Mrs. Lawrence J. Mead, at 157 East Seventy-second Street. Mr. and Mrs. Hoepli, who have lived in Europe for twelve years, plan to make their home in this country.

The German pocket battleship Deutschland unexpectedly steamed off at full speed this morning, leaving her chaplain and the German Consul as representatives of the Reich at the funeral of the twenty-four killed in the Loyalist bombing of the ship on Saturday.
Arrowbrook (70)-Thirty-six-hole Decoration Day tournament: Harry Parker, 171; William Himlyn, 176; Harry Feldman, 183. Bayside (71)-Medal play handicap: C. Hall, 81-14--67; R. Solomon, 81-13-68.
The 100th anniversary of the birth of Admiral George Dewey of Spanish-American War fame and a Norwich cadet was commemorated at the Memorial Day "open house" of Norwich University today.

In a ceremony impressive in its traditional simplicity, some 200 members of Old Glory Naval Post of the American Legion set afloat a tiny ship of flowers yesterday on the green and ever-changing grave of the "Unknown Sailor." It was the post's annual Memorial observance.
