Miss Dorothy Ford MacIver, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Connell MacIver, of this city, formerly of Portland, Me., was married here to Karldon Gordweadge Apgar of Westfield, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Apgar, this afternoon in the garden at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Harvey, 120 North Chestnut Street.
The offerings of the Cardinals' two ace pitchers, Dizzy Dean and Lon Warneke, failed to baffle the Cubs today and Chicago swept a doubleheader, 4 to 2 and 6 to 3.

Roy N. Scribner, 39 years old, of 95 Park Avenue, Brooklyn, a student pilot, was injured here today when his plane crashed into the upper branches of a tree. The accident was witnessed by thousands of bathers in the lake. Scribner, with severe cuts and a fractured elbow, was taken to the Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson.

Adolf Hitler drew the censure of the Presbyterian General Assembly today. The assembly left untouched the overture to condemn the President's proposed Supreme Court change but condemned any encroachment on "civil and religious liberty."

In connection with the maritime commision's plans to start a long time merchant ship building program, Chairman Kennedy announced today that studies were underway, looking to an increase in the American hull insurance market.

One down going to the fourteenth tee John Rutherfurd proceeded to win three of the remaining five holes today to bring victory to himself and his brother, Hugo, in the topflight final of the Meadow Brook Club's annual Spring. invitation best-ball golf tourney.
Booming guns and the bugle notes of taps echoed throughout the city yesterday as religious, civic and patriotic organizations paid tribute to the nation's military dead in Memorial Day exercises.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, said last night that no meeting was required to carry out William Green's order for the expulsion from the central body of C. I. O. unions, with a combined membership of 250,000 workers in the metropolitan area.

With Major C. E. (Stub) Davis stroking six of his team's goals, the Governors Island poloists downed the South Shore Polo Club, 8 to 2, on Hazard Field today. It marked the second victory in as many days for Governors Island over South Shore.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, sent a demand yesterday to the Board of Transportation, operator of the city's Independent Subway System, demanding that an election be held immediately to determine which union shall be the sole bargaining representative for the 4,500 employes of the system.

The election of Frank K. Houston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as president of the New York State Bankers Association at the conclusion of the association's forty-fourth annual convention aboard the S. S. Washington, on its way back from Bermuda, was announced at the office of the association here yesterday.

The Harlem Yacht Club's annual Memorial Day regatta, second of the Long Island Sound championship series, was sailed to the eastward of Execution Lighthouse yesterday afternoon. With a light southwesterly breeze there were late finishes.

Industrial building contracts during May kept near the high level set in this field during the first four months of the year, and with no decrease in inquiries evident for new plant, factory and research facilities, the high rate of construction probably will continue through the Summer and Autumn, in the opinion of George E. Bryant Jr., executive vice president of the Austin Company.
The opening of trading of the New York Mercantile Exchange this morning will mark the. sixtyfourth anniversary of its inception on June 1, 1878.

The outstanding lesson to be learned from the war in Spain is "the enormous power of modern propaganda," which has the "rest of the world absolutely hoodwinked," according to Sir Walter Maxwell-Scott, retired major general of the British Army, who spent three weeks in Spain in late February and early March.

Invoking for the first time powers conferred in the Town and Country Planning Act of 1932, the Ministry of Health has forbidden the demolition for the removal to the United States of the historic Grange Court in Leominster, Herefordshire.

Edward A. Kerr, for many years secretary of the National Canners Exchange, died suddenly here yesterday at the age of 67. Two sons and a brother will officiate at the requiem mass. One son, the Rev. Edward A. Kerr, S. J., will be the celebrant;

Mrs. Owen J. Toland's Justa Boy, a thoroughbred chestnut who is hunted regularly with the Radnor Hunt, won the top honors of the Devon Horse Show, which ended today, being judged the champion hunter of the show and also taking a leg on the Edward F. Beale Challenge Trophy.
News from Europe was decidedly unhealthy for the stock market today and Toronto weakened along with the others as fears grew that the Spanish trouble might spread.
Dr. Louis Gershenfeld of Philadelphia was elected president of District 3, B'nai B'rith, at the annual convention today. The district includes Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and West Virginia.

The Indians captured both games of a double-header from the Tigers today before 40,000 persons. They won the morning game, 7-1, behind the six-hit pitching of Willis Hudlin-who recorded his fifth straight victory of the year-and bagged the nightcap, 6-5, in eleven innings.
The Phillies defeated the Bees in both ends of a doubleheader today before 15,000 fans. The score in the first game was 6 to 3 and in the second. 9 to 6.

Fordham's nine, out to avenge the early season setback at the hands of N. Y. U., achieved its purpose most emphatically before 1,500 persons at Ohio Field yesterday. After Jack Coffey's charges had run the Violet outfielders as well as themselves ragged under a blazing sun, the Rams had to their credit a 17-5 victory.
William Hill, 50 years old, of 233 Griffin Street, Jersey City, was killed and six others were hurt in a collision today on Route 6 at Liberty Avenue here.

Water four feet deep in streets and buildings still kept Nulato residents crowded in hillside tents or upper stories today. Nulato was the first Lower Yukon River town to restore communication with Fairbanks.
Mr. and Mrs. Victor H. Polachek of 471 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of,their daughter, Miss Jane Polachek, to Dr. Siegmund H. May, also of this city.

Eight of the twenty-two members of the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions and the Rev. Charles J. Woodbridge, its general secretary, submitted their resignations tonight at the close of the board's annual meeting, a heated session lasting more than eight hours.

Carl Hubbell of the Giants, seeking his twenty-fifth straight National League pitching triumph over a two-season stretch, was beaten by the Dodgers. A crowd of 61,756, the second largest in the history of the Polo Grounds, saw him driven from the mound in the fourth inning of the opening game of a double-header, the Brooklyn team going on to win, 10-3.

Alexander Hamilton, in 375 Park Ave; Edward B. Levy, in 270 Park Ave; Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc, broker. Mrs. Clara Kerbs Rosenthal, Mrs. Dora T. Oliver, Mrs. Clothilde Huot, renewals, in Essex House, 160 Central Park South.
Premier Senjuro Hayashi handed the resignation of himself and his Cabinet to Emperor Hirohito yesterday. His action came suddenly.

New York University received $96,991 in gifts and bequests made directly to the corporation during the last three months, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University.

Harley C. Albee, president and manager of the Wisner Manufacturing Company, 241 West Broadway, makers of dairy equipment, died yesterday at his home, 123 West Ninety-third Street, after a month's illness of rheumatic fever and a heart affection. He was born sixtyone years ago in Roscoe, N. Y.

Mr. and Mrs. George David Baker of 325 East Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cor nelia Isabel Baker, to Thomas Corwin Mendenhall 2d, son of the late Professor Charles E. Mendenhall of the University of Wisconsin.
Mickey Cochrane, ailing manager of the Tigers, was said to be improving yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, where he has been confined for the past week, suffering from a fractured skull.
Executives of the Labor and Commerce Departments will speak at the Conference of Retail Executives to be held in Washington on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.
Tex! Rankin, Hollywood stunt flyer, won the international aerobatic contest and $2,000 in prizes before 25,000 persons at the air show today in a stock model low-wing monoplane.

Miss Jeanne Millet, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. P. Millet of 770 Park Avenue, New York, has decided on July 3 as the date for her marriage, to Shaun Kelly Jr., of Glen Crannie Farm, Richmond, Mass. The ceremony will take place in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

Wheat futures were erratic and lower on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today ending with losses of 1 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel on weakness in Liverpool, improved crop conditions in North America and practically no export business. May wheat,
Executives of the Labor and Commerce Departments will speak at the Conference of Retail Executives to be held in Washington on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.
Tex! Rankin, Hollywood stunt flyer, won the international aerobatic contest and $2,000 in prizes before 25,000 persons at the air show today in a stock model low-wing monoplane.

Miss Jeanne Millet, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. P. Millet of 770 Park Avenue, New York, has decided on July 3 as the date for her marriage, to Shaun Kelly Jr., of Glen Crannie Farm, Richmond, Mass. The ceremony will take place in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

Wheat futures were erratic and lower on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today ending with losses of 1 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel on weakness in Liverpool, improved crop conditions in North America and practically no export business. May wheat,
Adela Rogers St. John, news commentator, heard on WEAF five days a week at 9:30 A. M., was listed among the program "kills" sent out by the National Broadcasting Company yesterday.

Long-silenced church bells pealed throughout the State of Sonora to-. day, calling Catholics to the first legal services in almost three years. A continuous procession filed into the places of worship, padlocked in September, 1934, and knelt at altars to say prayers they had dared repeat only in the privacy of their homes since the church ban was invoked.

The Autocar Company, Ardmore, Pa., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 21,097 shares of 10 cents par value common stock now outstanding to be sold for the Phoenix Securities Corporation publicly at the market or privately below the market.

Graduation exercises will be held at the Somerset Hill School here tomorrow afternoon at 5:30 o'clock on the school campus. James H. S. Fair, headmaster, will make the address and announce the scholarship winners.

Mark A. McCloskey, local administrator of the National Youth Administration, was selected yesterday as director of the Bureau of Recreational and Community Ac- p tivities of the New York City school h system by the Board of Superintendents. Mr. McCloskey had previously passed the examination given by the Board of Examiners.
Lord Castletown, a former lieutenant colonel of the Fourth Prince of Wales Leinster Regiment (Royal Canadians), died today at his estate, Granston Manor, here. He was 88 years old.

An 8-year-old boy was killed by in automobile last night while playing tag with other boys in the street in front of his home at 44 Summit Avenue, Dongan Hills, S. I. The boy, William Devine, was the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Devine. The father is a building contractor. The driver of the car.

Fourteen diplomas will be presented at the Kohut School for Boys, Harrison, N. Y., at commencement exercises to be held on the school lawn this afternoon. Dr. Joseph Tenenbaum, author, will address the graduates. Harry J. Kugel, principal of the school, will preside.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Saturday in Florence of the Rev. Henry Rawle Wadleigh, a Protestant Episcopal minister whose last charge was as vicar of St. Luke's Chapel in Paris. His widow is the former Julia Hutchinson Fincke.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering an intensive study of member trading on the New York Stock Exchange covering the months before and after promulgation of "daylight trading" rules and the regulations intended to restrict certain activities of specialists which now have been made effective.
Guy E. Osborne, 24, fugitive wanted for the slaying of Truett E. Rowe, Department of Justice agent, was captured without resistance tonight a few hours after the agent was shot and killed.

Trade association members of the Apparel Industries Inter-Trade Bureau are putting into effect the policy and procedure for the conciliation and arbitration of returns determined upon in agreement with the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was learned here yesterday.

Miss Adelaide Clarke Hardenbergh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Hardenbergh Jr. of this place, was married this afternoon in St. Bernard's Church here to George William Knight, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Aston Knight of Paris and New York. The Rev.

Enrico Venturi, 140, Italian lightweight, won the decision from Irving Eldridge, 133, of the Bronx, after ten close rounds in the feature event last night at the New York Coliseum before 5,000 spectators. Venturi forced the pace from the start and earned the verdict.
The Reclamation Bureau reached today the point at which it could anticipate repayment of the government's $114,000,000 investment in Boulder Dam.

Frank K. Houston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and newly elected president of the New York State Bankers Association, has been chosen to represent bankers of this State on the executive council of the American Bankers Association, it was announced by W. Gordon Brown, executive manager of the State association upon his return yesterday from the association's convention cruise to Bermuda on the liner Washington.

Francis Brothers Co. of St. Louis and Mackubin, Legg Co. of Baltimore will offer today to the public 60,000 shares of no-par value common stock of the Midwest Piping and Supply Company, Inc. The price will be $11 a share.

William Graff, 43-year-old foreman of a city pumping station at 201 Douglass Street, Brooklyn, was drowned yesterday in a twelve-foot sewer tunnel under the station, after he had gone to the rescue of two other employes who had been overcome by sewer gases.

The address of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, delivered at the 183rd commencement of Columbia University follows: The notion persists that, like the age of man's body, the age of his mind and soul is measured by years. Nothing could be farther from the truth.

Extensive use of mirrors and large windows will bring the surrounding trees and gardens into Hampshire House, tall apartment structure which is being completed on Central Park South for occupancy thiS Fall.
Six men arrested last Saturday as suspected card sharps on the Panama-Pacific liner California were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Ford in Felony Court for lack of evidence.
Congress overrode President Roosevelt's veto today to give 23,000 World War veterans the privilege of extending their temporary government insurance Policies for five more years.

Held to an even keel by the return of Hal Schumacher to one of his top-flight pitching performances, the Giants toppled the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday without seeming to put undue strain on either their muscles or mentality.
A woman was suffocated and four other persons were painfully burned yesterday morning when a fire started on the ground floor of a four-story brick building at 178 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn.

Louis Lack, 47 years old, of 5,116 Eleventh Avenue, Brooklyn, and Morris Guttelman, 50, of 95 Christopher Street, Manhattan, were named in an indictment handed by the Federal grand jury to Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in the Federal court, in Brooklyn,

While Mrs. Edward J. Noble of Round Hill Road looked on from her bed, too frightened to scream, a burglar collected jewelry and cash valued at $8,500 early today, went downstairs and escaped through a window.

Half a dozen cargoes of food were landed within the Republic Steel Corporation's enclosure from planes here today while snipers fired at the supplies intended for the workmen who remained inside the plant when the Steel Workers Organizing Committee called a strike last Wednesday.

Due to the holiday, the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably below the preceding week. The total was also well under a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
Sixty-six feature productions, plus 204 one and two-reel subjects, including the Movietone News releases, will comprise the 1937-38 program of Twentieth CenturyFox. The schedule,

Miss Phoebe T. Whitney, member of an old family of the Woodbury farming section, died here last night in the parsonage of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, of which her brother, the Rev. Charles Whitney, is pastor.
Edmund W. Arthur was appointed special master to hear testimony in the matter of the Follansbee Brothers Company reorganization by Federal Judge R. M. Gibson in Pittsburgh yesterday.

Samuel W. Reyburn, chairman of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, told members of the graduating class of New York University's School of Retailing last night that upon entering the retail field they should beware of "certain species" of middlemen, politicians and labor leaders and not cause management any trouble, "for they have enough as it is."
The task before Congress and the Treasury, in stopping holes in the tax laws as the President today requested, is to find a way to make collections as nearly self-operating as possible.

Sam Snead, the young White Sulphur Springs (W. Va.) professional who vaulted into golfing stardom on the Winter tournament circuit, continued his sensational play yesterday as 131 golfers passed sectional qualifying tests for the United States open championship, to be held at the Oakland Hills Club, Birmingham, Mich., June 10-12.
James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, made it known yesterday that the had had a talk with Senator Robert F. Wagner at the Belmont race track on Monday.

Testimony presented here today before a naval board of investigation showed that there had been no damage to naval property as a result of the Hindenburg disaster on May 6, in which thirty-six persons lost their lives, and that injury to navy personnel consisted of minor hurts to three enlisted members of the navy ground crew.

Behind the masterful pitching of Jim McCarron, Curtis High School of Staten Island defeated James Monroe of the Bronx, 3 to 0, yesterday at Sisco Park, S. I. The triumph earned the winners the right to play Jamaica.

The political crisis tonight is in sight of a solution that promises to give the country a better Premier and a stabler administration than the public had hoped for. Instead of selecting one more mediocrity the Emperor's advisers played their strongest card by recommending Prince Fumimaro Konoe, who has accepted.
The longstanding threat of civil strife in Szechwan can be considered dissipated with the assumption of control of key positions by Nanking government armies.

Connecticut farms sold by the Housatonic valley Insurance Agency included the property of John Tobin, consisting of 135 acres, with an old New England home, in Kent. It was purchased by Mrs. Marie K. Fowler of New York city.

Peter (Buck) McNeil, dockmaster at The Battery, rescued his sixtyfirst victim from drowning yesterday afternoon. Buck has received in his time numerous medals for his rescues, but, in his own words, he never wears them because "if I pinned them on and jumped in the water I'd never come up at all, at all."

Kentucky's growers of burley tobacco received $27,261,946 more for their last crop than for that of the previous year, according to Tom Middleton, tobacco expert for the State Department of Agriculture. He said today that receipts totaled $59,487,634, against $32,225,688 for the 1935-36 season.
The flag on the German Consulate here flew at half-staff today in memory of the twenty-five sailors killed when the pocket battleship the Deutschland was bombed by Spanish Government airplanes.

The Viscose Company, one of the world's largest producers of rayon and a pioneer in the industry, has changed its name to the American Viscose Corporation. The company manufacturers Crown rayon and sponsors Crown Tested Quality identification in rayon. William C.

D. H. Holmes Company, Ltd., a New Orleans, in some of its men's wear newspaper advertising, is making a unique tie-up with billboards displayed in its section by the General Outdoor Advertising Company.

Sales of several residences in Westchester have just been closed by brokers. The sales campaign of the Bowery Savings Bank to dispose of properties owned by that institution continues to show results.

Governors Island 2d Lt. Harold B. Wetherbie, Fin.-Res., 115 Harding Rd., Red Bank, N. J., C. A. S. C., Mitchel Field, N. Y., is ordered to active duty for a period of six months. effective June 1. He will proceed to the Army Building. New York, N. Y., for physical examination.

Sidney L. Solomon has been appointed general merchandise manager of Abraham Straus, Inc., succeeding Neal D. Mooers, who has resigned as operating vice president and general merchandise manager to become vice president and general manager of Gladding's, Inc.. Providence.
Mayor La Guardia will buy the first registration for the American Legion convention, to be held here in September, when he greets a group of Legionnaires at City Hall this morning.
Sales of residences on the upper East Side of Manhattan, and of apartment houses on the West Side, featured the real estate transactions reported in this borough yesterday.
John L. Lewis approved today a request of the United Office and Professional Workers of America for affiliation with C. I. O. as an international union.
Mrs. Aruthur F. Elliot, 12 rooms and 5 baths in 1,120 5th Ave; Roy Sinclair, in 1,125 5th Ave; Richard T. Wharton, in 444 E 57th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

The War Department was notified today of the death yesterday of Captain Thomas Kenney, Quartermaster Corps, at the Army and Navy General Hospital, Hot Springs, Ark. He would have been 54 years old on July 3.
The Supreme Court today, among several scores of orders, granted reviews to some applicants and refused them to others. The actions were as follows:
Kid Chocolate, former featherweight champion of the world, now engaged in a comeback campaign, will oppose Al Reid of the Bronx in the feature ten-round bout at the Hippodrome tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler has signed an order approving a plan for the reorganization of the $825,000 Bond and Mortage Guarantee Company certificated mortgage on, the apartment house at 25 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Ninth Street.
The governing body of the International Labor Organization convoked today for next April a tripartite conference on coal mining similar to that on textiles recently held at Washington.

An agreement between Great Britain and her dominions on concessions necessary to the writing of an Anglo-American trade treaty may be expedited considerably as a result of the Spanish developments, it was indicated today as the Imperial Conference returned to study the international fo situation in a session with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress on income tax evasions lays before Congress a situation which has been noted here for several yearsnamely, the steady flow into the Bahamas of Americans forming companies.
Amelia Earhart completed here the first overseas leg of her west-east round-the-world flight today, having flown about 1,200 miles from Miami, Fla., in slightly more than seven and one-half hours.

The discovery of the circulation of the blood, which transformed medicine into a living science, might have been made severalhundred years earlier than Harvey if the successors of Asaf, a tenth century Jewish physician, had followed up theories of his that clearly point ed to the fact that the blood circulated.
Administered Fund Second, Inc.Net investment income for the first three months of this year amounted to $19,888, equal to 6 cents each on 313,566 capital shares.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 29: COLONELS Fulmer, J. J., Inf., Ithaca, N. Y., to 8th Infantry, Ft. Moultrie, S. C., about Dec. 3. Potter, W. C., F. A., Oakland, Calif., to Cornell University, Ithaca, N. Y.; to sail from San Francisco about Nov. 2, for New York.
First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler, in announcing yesterday a continued improvement in automobile accident rates over the Memorial Day week-end, said:

Miss Virginia Welsh, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Wickes Welsh of 950 Park Avenue and Lawrence, L. I., has selected June 23 for her marriage to Mark Leavenworth Sperry 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leavenworth Porter Sperry of Waterbury, Conn.

Colonel and Mrs. John L. Roberts of 79 East Seventy-ninth Street have returned from a world tour and are at Mayfair House. Mrs. John A. Logan of the SavoyPlaza left yesterday for Saratoga Springs and will go later to Camden, Me., for the Summer.

Bids for t the initial delivery of 9,650,000 double sheets of stamped paper of nine different denominations as part of t an order that may total 15,000,000 c sheets over a period of three years his been asked by the International Finance Commission at Athens, Greece, the Commerce Department announced today.
Supreme Court Justice Harlan F. Stone turned art critic today and handed down a favorable opinion on a portrait of himself.

Philip Le Boutillier Jr. of New York City, completing his first season as a varsity oarsman, was elected to the captaincy of the Princeton University crew for the 1938 season at the annual crew dinner tonight. The New Yorker succeeds Harlan J. Swift of Buffalo.

The America of 1960 was pictured by engineers here today as a country with a $57,000,000,000 system of overhead highspeed highways, buildings towering 2,000 feet into the air, all but local traffic driven from city streets, and highways on which overhead crossings eliminate all grade interseetions.
Presentation of medals to members of the Police and Fire Departments for distinguished service, City Hall Plaza, noon. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, Commissioner Valentine, Commissioner McElligott.
Problems of large-scale low-rent housing, expected to cost the nation $12,000,000,000 in the next decade, came before the convention of the American Institute of Architects today.

Craig Wood, long-hitting New Jersey star, left 102 rivals far behind in today's metropolitan section qualifying test for places in the United States Open Championship, which will be played on the Oakland Hills course, Birmingham, Mich., starting a week from Thursday.

Traders in wheat on the Board of Trade here were extremely nervous early today, unable to understand the weak action of the future market in Liverpool in view of the developments in the Spanish situation.

Commissioner Valentine issued an order yesterday permitting patrolmen and officers on traffic duty to remove their coats during the hot weather. An order sent over the teletype system by the Commissioner said:
The Oil and Gas Journal reported today a new high record for national production of crude oil--a daily average of 3,586,806 barrels for the week ended on May 29.

With trade interest focused on whether unscheduled issues, including the problem of style piracy, will be brought up, the fair-trade practice conference called for the popular-price dress industry by the Federal Trade Commission will begin today at the Hotel New Yorker.

Mrs. Gertrude T. Ross has filed suit for divorce against I. Arnold Ross of the Park Crescent Hotel in New York City. They were married June 29, 1924, and have two children. Their mother seeks their custody and $30 weekly.

Two persons here were prostrated by the heat yesterday as the thermometer rose to a peak of 89 degrees at 4 P. M. and remained there for more than two hours. A third person was fatally injured diving into the Hackensack River in New Jersey.

Ignorance of God is responsible for most oi the evils in the modern world, Cardinal Hayes said yesterday at the 1937 commencement exercises of Mount St. Vincent College in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium on the college campus in Riverdale.
Several important properties in Manhattan changed hands yesterday through auction sales in the Vesey Street salesrooms. Eleven buildings and one vacant lot were involved.
Flood waters of the Hondo River swept over Roswell tonight the second time in four days, At least two persons were dead and hundreds fled their homes.

Although the stock market here today again suffered from a lack of business, a more confident tone prevailed. Some of the gilt-edge issues showed further slight declines and among the foreign loans, movements were small. International stocks were stronger, United States Steel and International Nickel shares going ahead.

Faced with a tax on chain stores. provided for in a bill passed today by the Legislature at Harrisburg, the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company and the American Stores Company have closed 130 of their chain food stores in this vicinity.

Alderman Newbold Morris, who has taken the lead among young Republicans for the renomination of Mayor La Guardia, came to the defense of the Mayor last night by replying to the charges made by Republicans opposed to renomihation.

In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today: H-219-Soshone Tribe of Indians, Judgment for plaintiff, $4,408,444.23. Opinion of Judge Littleton. Judge Whaley dissents on the ground that the valuation placed on the land taken is excessive.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Perry of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss E. Marjorie Perry, to Frederick C. Anthony of Boston and Philadelphia.

An application for a total of $146,057 in fees and disbursements was made in Federal Court yesterday by Wright, Gordon, Zachry Parlin, counsel in reorganization proceedings for the New York Railways Corporation.
A number of projects for the alteration of business buildings and multi-family dwellings in Manhattan and Brooklyn featured the building-plans filed yesterday.

Two things are understood here to help account for today's slackening of tension over Spain. One is that the Valencia Government in Spain before deciding whether to appeal to the League of Nations wishes to know Washington's attitude and policy particularly as regards making its neutrality act applicable to Germany and Italy as well as to all Spain.

The protective committee for holders of Standard Gas and Electric Company $4 cumulative pre- sal ferred stock, in a letter to holders, of opposes the amended plan of reor- Go ganization filed in the United ma States District Court in Delaware on the ground that it betters the position of all other classes of securities.

Mickey Cochrane's condition continues to improve steadily, it was reported yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, where the stricken manager of the Detroit Tigers is recovering from the skull fracture he received more than a week ago at the Yankee Stadium.
Sales of two apartment houses, a two-family dwelling and a vacant plot, all in Long Island City, are reported by Rudolpph Bruer Jr., broker.
Stone Webster, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a net income of $733,554 after all deductions, ineluding $41,000 Federal surtax on undistributed profits for 1936.

A new statesmanship-a business statesmanship in which the business men themselves are assuming the common responsibility of protesting the economic welfare of mankind-is rapidly developing in the United States, despite "the political uncertainties and clam-shell nationalism in many parts of the world," Chokyuro Kadono, chairman of the Japanese Economic Mission to the United States, declared yesterday.
Dr. Lee Wallace Dean of St. Louis, one of the nation's leading authorities FOLI on hay fever, received today the highest award in the nose and throat field in the United States They and Canada.

Miss Gladys Baker of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and-Mrs. A. Herbert Baker of Jacksonville, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Howard E. Coffin of New York and Sea Island Beach, Ga., at the bride's home, 1 Fifth Avenue.
Mrs. Mary Stiles Hathaway, wife of John T. Hathaway and a distant cousin of President Taft, died at her home here yesterday.

Wounded or injured while on duty, three patrolmen who became incapacitated were retired at midnight last night on two-thirds pay, in accordance with the new law. They will receive $2,050 a year. The retirements were approved by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing Bath Iron Works Corporation capital stock, $1 par value; A. C. Horn Company common stock, $1 par value, in substitution for old no-par value stock; National City Lines, Inc.,
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Discussions are being carried on by the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., and the unlisted dealers of Chicago for providing uniform quotations on unlisted securities.
Lloyd C. Doty, credit manager of the Hotel New Yorker, was elected president of the Hotel Credit Managers Association at its annual election.

Gypsies and merry-go-round operators for this year's Derby were reinforced today by a lady appearing in a side show under the billing, "America's premiere fan dancer," who camped out on Epsom Downs-probably in honor of Perifox.

Second Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Sullivan warned night club operators yesterday "drastic action," probably resulting in revocation of licenses, would be taken against them if found guilty of presenting objectionable shows. The clubs he said, could expect "the close supervision that they have been receiving in the past."

A readjustment of the high school curriculum to place more emphasis on oral than on written English is recommended in a course of study for "slow learners," made public yesterday. A committee of six teachers at Seward Park High School has been working on this report for the last two years.
Tehbroeck Ave (15-4276), w s, 277 ft s of Neill Ave, 45X86, Dale Housing Corp to Emily Kniesch, 1,110 Shore Drive. Cruger Ave, 3,211 (16-4596); Harry H. Heepon to Paul Campo, 3,042 Holland Ave.

Mrs. Mary A. Pouch Smithers, widow of Austin L. Smithers of this place, was married here this afternoon to Henry Sears, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Sears of Boston and Beverly, Mass., at the home of her grandmother, Mrs. Edward A. Wood.
President Roosevelt ended a short vacation at his Dutchess County home tonight and departed for Washington on his special train.
President Fox of Union College, in delivering the commencement address at the Horace Mann School for Boys in New York City, began a schedule of twelve addresses.

John Reilly, known in professional baseball fifty years ago as "Long John" Reilly, died at his home here today at the age of 78. He was first baseman of the old Cincinnati baseball club for ten years and later became a commercial artist.
Richard H. Savage, a former gymnastics instructor at the Friars Club in New York, where he trained many celebrities of stage and screen, died last night in St. Mary's hospital here at the age of 59.

Dora, Doris and Dorothy Zehr, 24year-old triplet sisters living at Croghan, went off on a, honeymoon tonight with their three farmerhusbands after a wedding ceremony attended by hundreds of northcountry folk.

It will, we think, be a source of gratification to New Yorkers that Columbia University should have followed the long series of American institutions learning which have conferred on Senator CARTER GLASS their LL. D. degree.

A horse walked through the Holland Tunnel yesterday afternoon for the first time in the ten and one-half years of its operation. It started as a passenger in an open truck and ended the trip afoot after having created a rumpus that brought emergency equipment to the scene and caused one man to be taken to a hospital.

Net profit of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of America and subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, 1937, amounted to $17,084,622, equivalent after preferred dividends to $7.31 a share on the common, as against $16,593,252, or $7.08 per common share, in the preceding year.
The five-story apartment and store building at 1,354-1,360 Boston Road, the Bronx, has been sold to Nathan London by the Greencha Holding Corporation, Charles Greenberg, president.

In the face of a strike threat by the Committee for Industrial Organization, the Parmelee Taxicab System signed a closed shop contract yesterday with Local 819 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, an American Federation of Labor union.

A complete photographic record of the total eclipse of the sun on June 8 will be taken from a Pan American-Grace Airways plane at least 28,000 feet above Chimbote, Peru, it was announced here yesterday by J. D. MacGregor, vice president of the corporation.

Dr. Frederick A. Cook was assured of a forum in which to renew his claim to discovery of the North Pole in 1908 in a decision handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora in the explorer's $125,000 libel suit against the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

A funeral service will be held at 3 P. M. today in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, for Madison Grant, president of the New York Zoological Society. Mr.

Week-end potpourri: Among the other records in sports established over the holiday weekend is one by local fishermen.; Exactly 1,051 anglers set out on the Long Island Railroad's Fisherman Special Sunday, which exceeds a former mark, made on June 7, 1935.

Sharp revision of the realty assessment rolls of the city "to establish more equitable tax rates" is recommended in a report of a special committee on certiorari proceedings to be acted upon at the June meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York tomorrow at 65 Liberty Street.
At the annual meeting today of the Bank of the Netherlands, L. J. A. Trip, president of the bank, reviewed with satisfaction Holland's progress toward economic recovery,

At Barnard College class day exercises yesterday afternoon in Barnard Hall, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve declared that "the college has been usurping the functions of the parents in recent years," and that "it is a curious development that these obligations should be forced on the college."

Approximately 1,000 newspapers from coast to coast will be used to announce a new automobile tire, which will be placed on the market Soon by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, it was announced here yesterday.

Directors of the New York Steam Corporation yesterday omitted dividend action on the $6 and $7 preferred stocks for the first time since the issues were brought out. On Oct. 1, 1922, the initial dividend of $1.75 was disbursed on the $7 series and that amount was paid regularly each quarter until April 1, this year. On the $6 issue, $1.50 quarterly was distributed since the initial payment on Jan. 2, 1927.

A controlling interest amounting to 87.69 per cent by the Midamerica Corporation and the Alleghany Corporation in the Pittston Company, one of the last of the holding companies formed by the late 0. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen, was disclosed in a report by the Pittston Company to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday.

Miss Mary Emily Ridgway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Grosvenor Ridgway of this place, was married here this morning to William George Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Barrett of Scarsdale, in the Church of the Resurrection.

Miss Polly Horsey, daughter of Mrs. Outerbridge Horsey of 151 East Sixty-first Street and Seven Hills, Southampton, will be married on June 19 to Charles Frederick Moulton, son of Mrs. Donation Moulton of Dinard, France, and the late Mr. Moulton.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association, a C. I. O. union, announced last night that it had been recognized by the Postal Telegraph Company as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for the company's 2,600 employes in the metropolitan area.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Bernard L. Miller, Abner Hirsch Goldstone, Felix S. Cohen, Howard J. Lichtenstein and Telford Taylor, of New York City, and Henry Pearlman of Brooklyn, N. Y., were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

The Rev. Dr. Ralph K. Hickok, president of Western College, Oxford, Ohio, warned the graduating class at the commencement exercises of Randolph-Macon Woman's College today against what he termed the prevailing tendency to cynicism and sophistication. His daughter was a member of the class.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled this week at 77.4 per cent of capacity, a decline of 13.6 points, or 14.9 per cent from the 91 per cent rate of last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

The tragic possibilities that can conceivably follow from the German bombardment of Almeria and the withdrawal of Germany and Italy from the Non-Intervention Committee are being weighed here with gravity but no outward signs of alarm.

Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, welcomed the cooperation of delegates of the Smoke Prevention Association toward the solution of problems in this field of health and sanitation at the opening of the annual convention of that group yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Pairings for the first three races of the defense yachts in the America's Cup competition were made tonight by the cup committee of the New York Yacht Club. Harold S. Vanderbilt's new Ranger will race Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee tomorrow.
Archbishop Edward A. Mooney of Rochester, N. Y., today was named Archbishop of Detroit, a new archdiocese embracing the dioceses of Marquette, Grand Rapids and the new diocese of Lansing, Mich.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 28: CAPTAIN Giffen, R. C., Naval Academy, to the Boise about Aug. 15 and in command when commissioned. COMMANDERS Du Bose, L. T., Naval Academy, to the Brooklyn and on board as executive officer when commissioned.

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler adjourned yesterday for two weeks a hearing on the proposed merger of the New York Title Insurance Company and the Lawyers Title Corporation to give attorneys for various parties an opportunity to reach a settlement out of court.

Governor Earle jumped fully clothed into the Susquehanna River today to save Mickey, one of his dogs, from drowning. Wading and swimming to the edge of the channel, where the dog was disappearing, the Governor dove from view.

An 8-year-old boy played a halfhour recital of classical, romantic and modern music yesterday and carried off one of seven "superior" ratings given by judges to child pianists at the opening day of the piano tournament of the National Guild of Piano Teachers held in Wanamaker's auditorium.
A possible clue to the fate of Air Commodore Sir Charles KingsfordSmith and J. T. Pethybridge, lost Australian airmen, has been found on the seashore near Moulmein, Burma.
Executors of the estate of Oris P. Van Sweringen, railroad magnate, filed suit today asking $750,000 on an accident insurance policy.

The motion picture strike ended tonight and 2,500 men prepared to return to work in the studios tomorrow, following announcement of an agreement by which the Painters Union becomes absorbed with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.
1st St. 34, 24.11x100; Mario De Optatis, referee, to Citizens Savings Bank; foreclosure ($1).

The Paramount will provide Broadway with a new film today. It is "I Met Him in Paris," a romantic comedy worked out by Claudette Colbert, Melvyn Douglas, Robert Young and Mona Barrie against a background of Paris and St. Moritz.

United support of all classes for the steel workers' efforts to form an industrial union is urged in a survey released today by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches of America. The survey was made by Harold O. Hatcher, research director of the council.

In view of the present crisis in Europe and threats. in this country to the American form of government, speakers at the annual Columbia University alumni luncheon in John Jay Hall pleaded yesterday for Anglo-American cooperation and the preservation of democracy.

President Roosevelt summoned Congress today to a finish fight on tax avoidances "by a minority of very rich individuals," not only to save millions in public revenues but to meet a challenge to "the decency of American morals."

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Lake Hopatcong, defending champion, tied with Miss Gail Wild, 19year-old Baltusrol star, for the lead at the end of the first round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association championship at Green Brook Country Club today, each carding an 81.
Cleveland made it three straight over Detroit today by rallying in the eighth inning to snatch a 4-to-3 victory from the luckless Tigers. The setback dropped the Tigers from third to fourth place.

Anna Grace Lucirn, a 26-year-old waitress of 337 East Ninety-fifth Street, became the first June bride married this year in the Manhattan Municipal Building chapel when she was married yesterday to Charles Corpis Jr., a carpenter of 414 East Eighty-first Street.

Under the plan of capital readjustment of the Globe Steel Tubes Company, holders of common shares will receive warrants to subscribe to additional stock at $6.50 a share in the ratio of four shares for each five held, W. C. Buchanan, president, said in a letter sent to stockholders yesterday.

A large portion of the old Packer farm originally comprising 160 acres on the east side of Webbs Hill Road in Stamford, Conn., in being subdivided into plots for home sites or country estates in plots of two acres or more.
Lord Beaverbrook's Daily Express publishes today a long article "by a correspondent in Tours" purporting to give "an authentic account of the former King's attitude and outlook."

The threat of a strike of 35,000 unionized cloakmakers in this city was deferred for at least twelve days when the manufacturers and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union decided to extend agreements, which expired yesterday, until June 12.

Adoption of a seal of quality for the oyster industry was advocated yesterday by J. B. Glancy of Blue Points Company, Inc., in an address before 200 oyster growers and dealers participating in a three-day joint convention of the National Shellfisheries Association, the Oyster Growers and Dealers Association of North America and the Oyster Institute of North America at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Two youths who police said confessed they bludgeoned a man to death for fun after a drinking bout were sentenced to prison today.

Stockholders of P. R. Mallory Co., Inc., will vote in Indianapolis on June 9 on a plan to increase the authorized common stock from 200,000 to 500,000 shares, the preferred stock from 25,000 to 100,000 shares, all of no-par value.

Pope Plus, who caused alarm about his, health by canceling personal inauguration of the Pontifical Academy of Science last evening, resumed his normal work today. He granted a large number of private audiences.

With the heaviest rainfall in two months in Texas and relief afforded most of the dry counties west of the Mississippi River, prices on the Cotton Exchange were down $1 a bale from last Friday's levels at one time yesterday.

Under the terms of an arbitration award announced yesterday by Lester B. Stone, special arbitrator, employes of more than 1,000 Manhattan and Bronx garages will receive wage increases ranging up to $4 a week.

The police campaign against illegal parking brought an increase of 28,375 in the cases in the Downtown Traffic Court for the first five months of this year compared with the same period in 1936, it was announced yesterday.

Commencement exercises of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart will be held this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the college, Convent Avenue and West 133d Street. Degrees will be conferred upon a graduating class of sixty-four members. The speaker will be Dr. Richard Dana Skinner.

Miss Ruth Walker Brooks, daughter of Mrs. Harlow Brooks of this city and the late Dr. Brooks, eminent physician, was married last night to Kenneth Landers Hoffman, son of Mrs. Otto Hoffman of Larchmont, N. Y., and the late Mr. Hoffman.

April industrial employment and payrolls in Pennsylvania were the highest since 1930, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported. The bank said a widespread increase in wage rates was the "most striking development" of the month.

Miss Elizabeth Arnoux Eskridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Webb Eskridge of this city, has chosen June 21 for her marriage to Cadet William Perry Baldwin, son of Major Perry L. Baldwin, U.S.A., of Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., and th late Mrs. Baldwin.

Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury said today that the tripartite agreement entered into by Great Britain, France and the United States had averted sharp fluctuations of foreign exchange during the disturbed political conditions in Europe.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company has filed with the Securities al and Exchange Commission a request to withdraw a registration statement filed under the Securities trust Act of 1933 on March 3Q covering Prese $10,000,000 of 5 per cent debentures due in 1952 to be exchanged for outstanding securities.
Commercial and industrial failures reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., in the week ended May 27 were 189, against 187 in the week preceding and 180 in the corresponding period last year.

Lou Gehrig celebrated the twelfth anniversary of the start of his unbroken string of championship baseball games, now at 1,843, in an exhibition game today with a skeleton Yankee crew against the Akron club of the Middle-Atlantic League.
Twenty-six Spaniards alleged to be Communists, now in jail at Sao Paulo, will be deported this week on the French steamer Alsina.

The first step toward severing diplomatic relations with the Vatican was taken by Germany today with the withdrawal of her Ambassador, Dr. Diego von Bergen, following a communication delivered to the Papal Secretariat of State to the effect that the German Government was not satisfied with the present state of the relations with the Vatican. The embassy's counsellor, Dr.

Sales of the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, Inc., amounted to $160,900 in the first four months of this year, compared with $85,482 in the corresponding period of 1936, a gain of 86 per cent, it was announced yesterday by L. E. Woodcock, manager. M. E. Arnold,

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one "man on the street," I desire to express my views regarding the seriousness of the situation confronting us today. After following the course of events from 1933 to the present day, I find cause for great alarm.

Concerning the general principle involved in the President's message on tax evasion there can be no disagreement. The Government cannot tolerate evasion or fraud, and it must act against them the instant they make their appearance. In addition,
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes fortheweek ended May26:

The Lutheran minister who gave spiritual comfort to Bruno Richard Hauptmann during his last minutes in the death chamber last year appeared in the Parker conspiracy trial here today in the rle of accuser against Paul H. Wendel.
The Nursing Bureau of Manhattan and Bronx, Inc., 149 East Fortieth Street, opened yesterday an hourly service for patients requiring short periods of skilled nursing.

A solemn high jubilee mass commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary as a priest of the Rev. Edward S. Mahoney was celebrated yesterday morning in the Church of St. John the Martyr, 240 East Seventy-second Street, where Father Mahoney is assistant pastor.

The Westchester Lighting Company filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission an application for approval of the issuance and sale of $25,000,000 in mortgage bonds to be guaranteed by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. The Consolidated joined in the application.
Senator Lucilo de la Pena of Pinar del Rio Province was elected president of the Senate this afternoon by a vote of 19 to 12. Senator Pena,
Former Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin is now Sir Stanley Baldwin. It would be incorrect to style him Earl until letters patent are issued under the great seal, probably some weeks hence.

Arrangements are being made, it was announced in official circles today, materially to help a French scientific mission that will study the southernmost inhabited territory in the world - Tierra del Fuego, which belongs to Chile.

Conrad W. Woehler, general merchandise brokers, in 155 E. 44th St; Robert A. Johnston Co, confectionery, additional space in 437-453 11th Ave; Spencer, White Prentis. engineers, additional space in 10 E. 40th St: Newport Knitting Co. Inc.. floor in 149-51 W. 36th St.; John L. Miles, in 118 E. 28th St: Cross Brown Co, brokers.

The situation created by the withdrawal of Italy and Germany from the Non-Intervention Committee assumed a totally new aspect today with an announcement that Italian warships would not only remain in Spanish waters, but also would continue to repress traffic in contraband arms and munitions.

A golf tournament between bond men of New York and Boston for the Morgan Cup will be a feature of the seventeenth annual Field Day of the Bond Club of New York, to be held at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club on Friday.

The Senate received the Presidential message on tax evasion and passed the joint resolution for an investigation, passed the Walsh bill authorizing construction of six auxiliary naval vessels, overrode- President Roosevelt's veto of the bill to allow veterans a five-year extension of their war-risk insurance, and recessed at 3:49 P. M. until noon Thursday.

Official quarters appeared more confident today of the strength of the German position respecting the Almeria bombardment and despite attacks in the British and American press the impression in responsible quarters was that the bombardment fitted "the outrage on the Deutschland."
The monthly average of commodity prices as of June 1, compiled by Dun Bradstreet, makes the decline in May 1 3/4 per cent.

Miss Elizabeth P. Yallalee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. P. Yallalee of this place, whose wedding to Bayard Dominick 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gayer G. Dominick of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, will take place on June 29 in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here, has chosen her sisters, Mrs. Jacob S. Ancona and Miss Dorothy Yallalee, as her matron of honor and maid of honor.
Adrian Van Sinderen, president of the American Horse Show Association, gave a luncheon for the other officers yesterday in the Carpenter Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.
President Getulio Vargas signed today a decree appointing Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, former Foreign Minister, as Minister of Justice and Interior.

Checks aggregating $300,000, representing rebates on water bills paid between Nov. 1, 1935, and May 1 of this year, were mailed by the New Rochelle Water Company today to 16,000 customers in New Rochelle, East Chester, Tuckahoe, Bronxville, North Pelham and Pel ham Manor.

Experimental evidence that at least one of the two major types of goiter, and possibly all other types, is caused by a specific fungus transmitted by drinking water and vegetables in particular localities, was presented yesterday before the first assembly of the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
The German naval bombardment of Almeria yesterday constituted a scientific and methodic destruction, according to advices received from that city today.

A mass funeral for the victims of Sunday night's rioting in front of the Republic Steel Corporation plant in South Chicago, where pickets clashed with police guarding company property, was being planned tonight as the death list rose to six, with more than thirty still in hospitals.

Four British Army nursing sisters, required to assist in nursing the Germans who were injured in the bombing of the battleship Deutschland and are now in a hospital in Gibraltar, left Southampton at 4:40 A. M. today in two Royal Air Force flying boats that are expected to make the 1,070-mile flight non-stop.
Albert W. Beyer Sr., city official and building and loan executive, died at his home here today after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

The wish expressed by President BUTLER as the epilogue of his address to the graduating class of Columbia University is one that countless persons high and low around the world would offer in antiphonal response:

The adoption of a group life insurance plan for officers and employes of the National City Bank was announced yesterday by James H. Perkins, chairman of the bank's board of directors. More than 95 per cent of those eligible have subscribed to the plan, which became effective yesterday.
Dr. Paul C. Stetson, superintendent of Indianapolis public schools, died here today of heart disease. He was 52 years old.

The general unsettlement in security markets yesterday on the disturbing European news over the extended week-end was reflected in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices in virtually all classifications were lower in relatively light trading.

Nathan Katz, an attorney, has been appointed to the European executive staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, an agency for aid to distressed Jews overseas, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Katz will sail for Europe on the Normandie.

John D. Rockefeller 3d, eldest son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., was operated upon in Doctors Hospital yesterday for the removal of his tonsils and adenoids. The operation, performed by Dr. Stuart L. Craig of 135 East Sixty-fifth Street, was pronounced successful. At midnight Mr. Rockefeller was reported to be resting comfortably.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 31 unless specified: At San Francisco: Arctic, June 1; Thrush, May 30; Bridge. At San Diego: Brant, Kingfisher, Partridge. Rail Robin, Wasmuth, May 29; Bushnell, S-1, 30, May 30.

The shelling of Almeria by German destroyers had the effect today of uniting all Loyalist Spain against the Rebels, and as a result the Anarchist labor organization, the C. N. T., pledged its "moral and material support" to the new government headed by Dr. Juan Negrin.

Mrs. Mary C. Tiffany Pratt of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, daughter of Mrs. George S. Tiffany of Syosset, L. I., formerly of St. Louis, and the late Mr. Tiffany, was married yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building to Harry Hall Knight of 1,230 Park Avenue, formerly of St. Louis.

Probably the government controls the weather. When the lights went up for the opening of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" at Silver Lake in Staten Island last evening, the skies were glowering and the drums in the heavens were outroaring the percussion in Mendelssohn's score.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, which is completing a $250,000,000 electrifiction project, announced yesterday that it was developing a steam locomotive which would have a net performance in passenger service a equivalent to that of its new electric types.

Americans can be confident that the aggravation of the European crisis will provoke no precipitate action in Washington. Yesterday's developments and the pressure of Congressional leaders for and against the immediate application of the Neutrality Act to all participants in the Spanish war forecast the difficulties that will confront this country should the conflict spread.

In The New Statesman and Nation some whimsical humorist deplores such walkers for walking's sake as HAZLITT and STEVENSON and confesses himself a stroller who gets his pleasure from what he hears and sees on his stroll.

A 50 per cent cut in fixed charges and a broad divestment of leases and guarantees were proposed today in a reorganization plan for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company submitted by the management.
Intent on living up to his end of the bargain to the minutest detail, Max Schmeling, accompanied by his manager, Joe Jacobs, and his trainer, Max Machon, pulled into town yesterday.
A petition filed by the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad to Fix reorganize under the terms of Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act was approved here today by Federal Judge William Clark.

Long Island University opened a five-day tour of New England colleges with an easy 9-to-2 triumph over Northeastern University at Huntington Field today. Bernie Pearlman, the all-around Long Island star, pitched a steady game, leaving eleven Northeastern runners stranded on the bases.
THEY BROKE THE PRAIRIE, by Ernest Elmo Calkins. (Scribner, $2.50.) The settlement of the Upper Mississippi Valley.

Taking as his topic, "Court, Contemporary Need, and Fundamentals," Irving A. Appleman of Brookline, a freshman in the Boston University School of Law, won the $25 first prize in the annual Boston I University Bacon Essay Contest sponsored by Mrs. Robert Bacon.

William Haas, formerly manager of the Manufacturers Safe Deposit Company, has been elected a vice president. A pamphlet summarizing and explaining the amendments to Articles III and V of the New York State Banking Law is being distributed by Manufacturers Trust Company.

Pensioned On their own applications. LIEUTENANTS-Richard Reynolds, Traffic Precinct B, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 30, 1909. Samuel W. Johnson, Grand Central Parkway Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. APpointed April 1, 1897.

Gross revenues of the Union Pacific Railroad in May were from 10 to 12 per cent ahead of those in May, 1936, according to Carl R. Gray, president. He described crop conditions in the company's territory as generally favorable.

The furnishings and art collection in Dudley Place, the residence of Mrs. Muriel Vanderbilt Phelps at Newport, R. I., will be sold at public auction, it was announced yesterday. Indications are that Mrsm Phelps will dispose of the estate later.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses took a dig at one of Mayor La Guardia's pet projects yesterday when he told members of the Board of Aldermen that Hoffmans Island in the lower bay, where the Mayor proposes to build a children's camp, was thoroughly undesirable for the purpose.

Frederick H. Thompson, member of an old East Haven family, died yesterday at the age of 82. His father, Merritt Thompson, was prominent in the shipping trade of New Haven seventy-five years ago and Frederick Thompson was for years an officer of New York and New Haven steamboats.

Trading was fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were in demand and prices stronger. Veal cuts were steady to lower. Lamb and fresh pork prices were uneven. The kosher markets opened lower on most classes, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Dewey Bentham's Abner, who has been one of the most consistent performers on the New York tracks this season, got home in a driving finish to take the featured Hewlett Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday and reward those who kept faith in him at 5 to 1.
Associate Justice Van Devanter left the Supreme Court bench today after more than twenty-six years' service.

To the intense relief of the business community and the entire House of Commons, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain suddenly withdrew tonight his contentious tax on growth of profits, which had aroused more criticism than any other financial measure for a quarter of a century or more.

A six-wicket victory over Derbyshire sent Yorkshire into the lead in the English County cricket championship series today. Sussex dropped to the runner-up position after gaining first innings' points over Surrey.

The President spoke of red herrings which would be drawn across his trail. He is, of course, the master drawer of herrings himself. Indeed, this particular message stands out as one of the best examples of his skill in this art.

The Senate declined to accept the ?? resignation of President Alfonso tore Lopez after hearing his second res- Jos ignation message last night and ex- ma tended to him a vote of confidence. President Lopez, in his message, charges that the Liberals and Con- bur gress are failing to live up to party Ku ideals.
Four honorary Doctor of Laws degrees will be conferred by Seton Hall College at the eighty-first commencement in the college quadrangle at 2:30 tomorrow afternoon.

Dr. Nichoas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, is among the passengers booked to sail today on the French liner Normandie. Others listed are John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee;
Advanced ground taken by the Presbyterian Committee on Social Welfare in an 8,000-word report was approved today by the General Assembly.

Organization of a maritime council which will include all branches of maritime workers in this port in affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization was announced yesterday by Mervyn Rathborne, president of the American Radio Telegraphists Association.

After all, the commercial theatre may treat itself to a Broadway premiere before August and "Virginia." For A. H. Woods said yesterday-and seemed to mean it-that he hoped to make a late July event of "Censored," which he now describes as a play by Conrad Seiler and Max Marcin.

The Basque government took a decision today that may have important consequences on Spain's naval war. Basque sailors were suddenly substituted for existing Loyalist crews on the government destroyers Jose Luis Diez and Ciscar, which long have been virtually inactive here.
W. Leslie Harriss, cotton merchant, died on Monday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in Greenville, S. C., according to word received here yesterday. He was 51 years old.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull annou??ced today that he had appealed to the German and Spanish Governments through their Ambassadors here for a peaceful adjustment of the situation arising out of the bombing of the German battleship Deutschland and the shelling of Almeria, Spain.

The bill carrying $1,500,000,000 for relief purposes during 1938 was passed tonight by the House and sent to the Senate in substantially the form asked for by President Roosevelt. The record vote was 323 to 44.
Steel ingot production last week was about unchanged and the adjusted index has advanced to 122.0, which compares with 120.4 for the preceding week and 92.3 for the week ended May 30. 1936.
The H. J. Heinz Company granted 10 per cent wage increases today to about 2,300 employes, but delayed reopening its north side plant, closed by a strike.

Chokyuro Kadono, chief of the Japanese Economic Mission now visiting New York, said Exchange control in the form instituted early this year, when traders had to get licenses for import bills, was likely to continue. The original restriction was supposed to expire in July.

Governor Lehman signed the bill today which makes the State's constitutional officials, judges and legislators pay taxes on their incomes. The measure, sponsored by Senator Dunnigan, is expected to increase the State's revenue by from $150,000 to $250,000 annually from a group hitherto exempt from the levy.

In a forty-five-minute session ending a notable term, the- Supreme Court agree ?? today to review next Autumn the constitutionality of the government's authority to make Public Works Administration loans and grants for municipally owned and operated electric power enterprises.

Mental Examination The mental examination for Promotion to the rank of captain in this department will be held at 641 Washington St., Manhattan, on Thursday and Friday, June 3 and 4. The following candidates shall be directed to report at 9:30 A. M., each day:
Fines were assessed yesterday against more than 150 persons found guilty of peddling ice cream, candy and peanuts in Central Park without a permit, by Magistrate Henry H. Curran in Yorkville Court.

The United States Supreme Court news yesterday was in the main favorable to the public utility managements, in the opinion of executives. The utilities obtained reviews in two cases relating to PWA loans and advances to municipalities for building of power plants in competition with private companies.

Reginald L. Brooks, a nephew of Lady Astor, obtained a divorce here today from Mrs. Aline Rhonie Brooks. Mr. Brooks is 36 years old. He is the son of Reginald Brooks and the late Mrs. Robert H. Brand of London.

Mrs. Ann O. Edison of West Orange, N. J., wife of Theodore Edison, son of the late inventor, was a recipient of one of the fourteen senior prizes awarded tonight at the annual senior-alumni dinner of the New Jersey College of Pharmacy at the Hotel Douglas here.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society of New York City asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine a $267,677 deficiency assessed on its 1933 income taxes.

The executive committee of the Westchester County Republican Committee will meet here Thursday afternoon to endorse candidates for the Fall election, according to notices sent out today by Charles H. Griffiths, county Republican chairman.
The city of Memphis sold late today a $3,000,000 issue of bonds to defray the cost of constructing a municipal distribution system for TVA electricity.

The Spokane, Portland Seattle Railway Company, owned jointly by the Northern Pacific and the Great Northern, has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $1,200,000 in 23/4 per cent ten-year equipment trust certificates.
As the Naval Academy's June Week approached its climax tonight Miss Janet Cunneen, a Smith College sophomore, whose home is Washington, assumed her position as "color girl."

The St. Augustine's baseball team continued its fast pace in the Brooklyn division of the C. H. S. A. A. by beating Cathedral Prep, 6 to 2, yesterday at the Parade Grounds. It was the ninth victory in ten games for the group leader. Nick Perrotta sent in three runs in the fourth when he doubled with the bases full.

W. S. Farish, formerly chairman, today became the president and chief executive officer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, W. C. Teagle, retiring president, announced at the conclusion of the annual stockholders' meeting here this afternoon.
Three games, two on Phipps Field and one at Mitchel Field, brought action to twenty-five of the players entered in the Meadow Brook Club polo tournaments today.

The eighty-seven members of Bryn Mawr College's graduating class, attired in caps and gowns, relinquished their places as student body leaders to the junior class at "Step Singing" exercises tonight and prepared to receive their degrees tomorrow.

Construction of a cross-bay tunnel between Greenville, Jersey City, and Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to be used for the switching of railroad cars, would cost about $57,000,000, according to a report published yesterday by a special committee of Port Authority and railroad representatives.

William F. Kenny, contractor and close friend of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, appeared yesterday in Supreme Court to defend a $500,000 suit brought against him and his son by Joseph McGarrity of Philadelphia, the son's former brokerage partner. Trial of the suit started before Justice Aron Steuer and a jury.

The Turkish budget for the financial year beginning June 1 was passed by the national Assembly today. Revenue and expenditure balance at [pound]231,000,000 (Turkish) an increase of [pound]18,000,000 (Turkish) over the preceding year.
William I. Hull, who is the Howard M. Jenkins Professor of Quaker History at Swarthmore College, has written a new type biography of William Penn.

The New York City police force in all its activities will be on show for three nights at Madison Square Garden, beginning tonight, for a performance that promises to be as varied and exciting as a circus.
Faithful Mary, a tall buxom Negro, testified yesterday in Supreme Court that the net profits from the Harlem "heavens" that she formerly supervised for Father Divine range from $300 to $700 a week.

The increase in the reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System that went into effect on May 1 has been followed by an easier situation in the money market and by greater stability in the market for investment securities than prevailed in the period of preparations for the increase, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its current monthly review, published yesterday.

Celebrating its 183d commencement, Columbia University awarded last evening 4,501 degrees to men and women students in course, granted 185 certificates and diplomas, and conferred 12 honorary degrees and 6 medals upon men and women for distinguished services.
The line-up for tomorrow's running of the 158th Derby, with owners, jockeys and odds as quoted at the final call-over at the Victoria Club tonight, follows:

APPLETON-Annie Bender, on June 1, 1937, beloved wife of the late John S. and loving mother of Libbie E., Edwin, Herbert, Warren and Mrs. George E. Doscher Jr., and sister of Elizabeth Dennell. Funeral service at her late residence, 354 East Mosholu Parkway South, Thursday, 9 P.M.

Funeral services for Dr. John Wyckoff, dean of the New York University College of Medicine, who was found unconscious in the college's anatomical laboratory at 477 First Avenue Monday evening and who died at 3:10 A. M. yesterday in the emergency ward of Bellevue Hospital, will be held in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas at 10:30 o'clock tomorrow morning.
With the backing of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine the Board of Aldermen adopted a city ordinance yesterday forbidding the sale or possession of air rifles and air pistols.
Bespectacled Bill Dietrich, whose major league baseball career appeared at an end Less than a year ago, achieved pitching fame today with a no-hit, no-run masterpiece against the Browns.
Coming from behind in a sharp drive down the stretch, Mrs. T. Marshall's Brown Prodigy won the Hyde Park claiming purse, mile and one sixteenth feature today at Suffolk Downs.
MacDougal St, 106, 25x100; 106 MacDougal Street Corp (Geo J. De Martini, pres) to Adolph Levy, 755 Park Ave, p m, $9,000; install, 6 per cent; $2,150.

The National Collegiate A. A. committee on swimming records has approved for registration thirteen national intercollegiate and seventeen interscholastic standards established this year, it was announced yesterday by Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the committee.
Estimates indicated yesterday that about three-quarters of the estate left by George F. Baker on his death last Sunday would be taken by the Federal and State Governments as an inheritance levy.

A quest of nearly five years for Scanderberg Vangieri, 51 years Old, on a charge he defrauded depositors of his private. bank in Newark, N. J., of about $50,000 in an investment scheme ended yesterday with his capture in an apartment he occupied with his wife and three children for about a month at 939 East 220th Street. Later,
An estimated 2,000 buyers attended the opening of the annual Boston Shoe Fair here today, at which some 500 manufacturers and their representatives were present.
Rabaul, principal town of New Britain Island, northeast of New Guinea, is now a lake and an undersea earthquake has raised the ocean bed and blocked the harbor entrance.

Bankers, business men and other leaders of the financial community called at the headquarters of the First National Bank, 2 Wall Street, yesterday in a steady stream to express their condolences to officers and directors of the bank upon the death of its chairman, George F. Baker, who died on board his yacht Viking, in Honolulu Harbor on Sunday, following an emergency operation for peritonitis performed at sea four days before.
A condition has been developing during the past few months so serious to the nation that the Congress and the people are entitled to information about it.
Re-election of Premier T. D. Pattullo in his home constituency was conceded tonight, first concession of today's British Columbia general election.
We have acrimonious constitutional debates on our hands for more than one reason. Not only have the conditions of life changed

Miss Rachel Hixson, daughter of Professor and Mrs. Arthur Warren Hixson of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Dr. Richard Wilhelm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Richard Wilhelm of Richmond Hill, L. I., which will take place June 19 in the Presbyterian Church here.
Fellowships and scholarships totaling $6,900 for the next academic year were awarded today to students at the Harvard Medical and Law Schools.

The third General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of America convened here today in an atmosphere charged with repercussions from the internal battle waged for more than eight hours yesterday by the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions.

Officials of Pan American Airways denied last night that any definite date had been yet set for the beginning of survey flights over the North Atlantic between Port Washington, L. I., and Ireland, via Botwood, Nfld.

Commencement exercises for seven graduates were held last night by the Guilmant Organ School at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth- Avenue and Twelfth Street. Each graduate played an organ selection as part of a recital held in conjunction with the graduation.

A blood-stained belaying-pin beside him, William Walter Williams, 37 years old, a Negro butler employed in the home of Louis G. Pedlar, advertising executive, at 68-35 110th Street, Forest Hills, Queens, was found dead in his quarters there at 6:30 P. M. yesterday. The police said he had been murdered.

The Supreme Court adjourned yesterday at the end of one of the most momentous sessions in its history. Throughout the greater part of this session attention has been focused, as seldom before in the whole life of the nation, on the powers and the functions of the court, on the role it plays in American society, on its philosophy of law, on its personnel and on its methods of procedure.

The personnel of the American temporary embassy at Valencia, Spain, will spend their nights in a house that Walter C. Thurston, the United States Charge d'Affaires, is leasing at Torrente, a suburb three and a half miles inland, in order to lessen the danger of injury from air and sea attacks.
Secretary of the Interior Ickes was a patient in the Naval Hospital today for what associates termed an "examination of a stomach ailment and a rest."

The announcement in Rome that Italian warships in the Mediterranean had been ordered to prevent Russian war materials from reaching Spain through stretches of government seacoast left unguarded by German and Italian relinquishment of their patrol duties caused a slight flurry in London official circles tonight.
