The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, has again arranged an exhibition composed of material belonging to the permanent collection. It opened yesterday afternoon, contains oils, water-colors and sculpture, and will be current through part of the Summer.

Henry A. Truslow, for many years vice president and treasurer of the Armstrong Cork Company of Lancaster, Pa., and before that its Eastern representative, died last night at his home here of a heart attack.

Benjamin Taylor, 34 years old, a patient at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, was killed and two operating-room attendants were injured when anesthetic gases exploded during an operation yesterday, it was learned today.
H. Treadwell Steers, funeral director and member of an old Staten Island family, died Tuesday night at the Staten Island Hospital at New Brighton, after a brief illness, at the age of 56.

These National Guard commissions were issued today: Carton. Capt. John D., assigned to 106th Infantry for further assignment to Co. F. Toms, Capt. Raymond W., assigned to 165th Infantry for further assignment to Co. C.

Six jurymen were selected yesterday as the trial of James Plumeri, alias Jimmy Doyle, of 65 Second Avenue, and John Dioguardi of 245 East Eleventh Street on an indictment charging them with conspiracy, assault and extortion on ten counts opened before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.
A program calling for the production of thirty feature-length pictures, twenty-four Westerns and four serials was announced yesterday by Republic Pictures for the 1937-38 season.

Miss May T. Lippincott, founder and former head of Miss Lippincott's Sanitarium, 667 Madison Avenue, where hundreds of babies of prominent families were born, died on Tuesday of a heart ailment at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. She closed her sanitarium, which was devoted to maternity cases, in 1934.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

Sonia Greenova of 750 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, former night club entertainer, withdrew her claim yesterday that she is the widow of Edgar S. Appleby, 73-year-old lawyer and realty dealer, and an heiress to his $5,000,000 estate.

Miss Ina J. Tracy of Buffalo has received a fellowship for graduate study in the University of Dijon, France, according to Dr. Julian Park, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences of the University of Buffalo.

Patrolman Ralph Goldstein, 31 years old, of 2 Stoddard Place, Brooklyn, was acquitted yesterday by a Kings County jury of a charge of accepting a bribe from a man he had arrested for the possession of policy slips. The jury deliberated only seven minutes.

Governors Island Each of the following Reserve officers is ordered to active duty June 6, at Camp Dix N. J., for training Colonel Archibald E. Tanner, CA.-Res., 3,208 Market St., Wilmington, Del. Lt. Colonel John E. Earle. Qid.-- s. 169 Silver Lake Rd., Staten sland. N. Y.
The Committee for Industrial Organization began yesterday a drive to organize 25,000 milk bottlers, processors, drivers and other dairy workers here on industrial lines.

Miss Dorothy DeGolyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett L. DeGolyer of Dallas, was married to David Perry Stephenson, son of Mrs. ida Stephenson of San Antonio, this evening in the garden of her parents' home.
After thirty-six holes of play over the rugged Ridgewood Country Club course today a triple tie developed for the qualifying medal in the New Jersey State amateur golf hampionship.

Back on the battlefield where they clinched their pennant last year, the Yankees jolted the flag hopes of the Indians at League Park today before a gathering of about 8,000. With a ten-hit attack supporting the pitching of Charley Ruffing, the McCarthymen won. 8 to 4.

Adding a fine 79 to her first day's score of 81, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Lake Hopatcong was four strokes ahead of the field at the end of the second round of the Women's New Jersey State Golf Association championship at the Green Brook Country Club today.

The complete cast for the production of Strauss's "Salome" to be given in the original German at the Lewlsohn Stadium Wednesday and Thursday evenings, June 30 and July 1, with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Alexander Smallens, was announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Reba Louise Edelman, daughter of Mrs. Louis Edelman of Washington and the late Dr. Edelman, to Robert Lawren, son of Mrs. William Loweth of 336 Central Park West.

On the heels of Spring comes the and la first indication of warm weather high in reconditioning the Sandy Hook retract steamers'Sandy Hook and Monmouth, which began operation on Pratt May 23, marking the seventy- With seventh year of this service linking ers, m New York with the North Jersey expen?? plane, coast resorts.

Twenty men were overcome by gas today during a mock air raid in preparation for a scheduled fulldress rehearsal of war drills and rescue work. Indian troops, homeward bound from the coronation last month of King George VI in London, witnessed the air-raid practice.

The Deutschland and Almeria incidents appear to have been disposed of for the present and today's press contains no reference to them. Contrary to earlier reports, the Deutschland has been ordered to remain in Spanish waters.
Alban Berg's posthumous opera, "Lulu," based on Frank Wedekind's plays, "Erdgeist" and "Die Buechse der Pandora," received its world premiere in the Zurich Municipal Theater tonight.

Offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of a new issue of $10,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on June 1, 1967, of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company.

Private crop estimates for June indicating a total wheat harvest in the United States of 878,000,000 bushels, with the possibility that final returns will show 900,000,000 bushels, started renewed and heavy selling of wheat today and resulted in net declines of 2 7/8 to 33 cents a bushel.

The marriage of Miss Mary A. Ingraham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham of Brooklyn and Asharoken Beach, Northport, L. I., to Dr. Henry Bunting, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Bunting of Madison, Wis., will take place at the home of Miss Ingraham's parents at Northport on June 22.

Two men and a woman were injured yesterday when a wall of a four-story building which was being demolished to make way for the westerly approach to the Triborough Bridge toppled into Southern Boulevard at 134th Street, the Bronx.

Secretary Wallace announced this afternoon the administration's firststep toward carrying out a long range, coordinated program to prevent the Southwestern dust bowl from becoming a desert. The program follows closely the recommendations of the President's Great Plains Committee.

Two huge Royal Air Force flying boats completed at 4 o'clock this afternoon the first service non-stop. flight from England to Gibraltar to bring four army nurses who will care for the seamen wounded in the bombing of the German pocket battleship Deutschland by Spanish Loyalist planes. The flying boats,
Kenton Kilmer, elder son of the late soldier-poet, Joyce Kilmer, today married Miss Frances Frieseke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Frieseke.

Beginning its investigation of the financing and operation of the Chicago Great Western Railroad since control of that property was acquired by the Bremo Corporation, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, sought today to show that that control was obtained largely through marginal transactions in the New York Stock Exchange.
The Morris County Junior College held its first commencement today. Diplomas were presented to twentyone graduates by James Bruen, President of the Morristown Board of Education.

The Marine Midland Trust Company announced yesterday that Arthur W. Mellen, vice president in charge of its Chambers Street office, will in the future serve the bank in an advisory capacity on a semi-retired basis.

The movie crafts strike took on the aspect of a bitter interunion struggle today, with the strikers repudiating a peace treaty announced last night and maintaining picket lines around ten major studios.
Commencement exercises for sixty-three graduates were held this afternoon at Seton Hall College, with the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark, presiding.

Mrs. Ruth O'Day Boyd, widow of William B. Boyd, was married to Victor F. Ridder, newspaper publisher and former New York WPA Administrator, yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The Millsdale Stable's Infantry, a nominee for the Great Western Handicap, Saturday, equaled the track record for six furlongs today at Washington Park in beating a good field in a Grade A handicap.

Mid-Day Sun, an outsider at 100 to 7, confounded the experts today and made his owner, Mrs. G. B. Miller the first woman ever to lead in a winner in all the years since 1780 whey the first Derby was run over Epsom Downs.

Fair and warmer weather was forecast for today, followed by showers at night. It will be fair and slightly cooler tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night.
Miss Ruth Eleanor Crane, daughter of to Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ellsworth Crane of this city, was married this S afternoon to John Ballantine Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Young, also of this city.

Miss Lavone Dickensheets, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dickensheets CE of this city, was married to Hugh Lenox Scott 2d, son of Mrs. Mark Edwin Andrews, also of Houston, He and the late Colonel David Hunter Scott of Princeton, N. J., this afternoon in the garden of the bride's parents' home.
Since the start of the week, sales of straw hats in this area have picked up steadily, following a disappointing showing in the previous ten days, men's wear retailers reported here yesterday.
Miss Agnes Driscoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Driscoll of Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to John W. Kickham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kickham of Granville, N. Y.
Herman L. Ekern, former Attorney General of Wisconsin, attacked today the proposed revision of the Railroad Retirement Act as "unfair" to employes and the Treasury.

While expressing pride in the accomplishments of the Department of Health during the last three years, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, told the Progressive City Committee at a luncheon in the Town Hall Club yesterday that the department was only "just getting started" in its program to improve facilities and services.

In one of the largest acreage deals reported in Westchester County in several years, a developing group has acquired the Iselin property consisting of 440 acres bounded by Old Mill Road, White Plains Avenue and Wilmot Road, in New Rochelle and East Chester, and will develop the tract into one of the major home centers of the county.

Miss Isabella Lois Burnham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander 0. Burnham of Bellerose, L. I., has selected June 26 as the date of her marriage to Benedict Frank Haberle 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict Frank Haberle of Syracuse, N. Y.

The marriage of Miss Angelyn S. Hoffman, daughter of Mrs. William Gilmor Hoffman Jr. and the late Mr. Hoffman, to Richard L. Rianhard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McMahon Rianhard, will take place June 12 in Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church.

A contra-seasonal increase in April brought the value of United States export trade above all preceding months of this year to the highest seasonally adjusted level reached since the third quarter of 1930, while a more than seasonal decrease lowered the adjusted value of imports, the Department of Commerce's monthly trade survey showed today.

The reappointment of Arthur Frank Payne, radio psychologist and head of the Personnel Bureau of City College, was denied last night by the Board of Higher Education, at least temporarily, on the ground that the "student body had lost faith in him."

The State's Attorney prosecuting here and throughout the Rhineland more than 90 per cent of the Catholic immorality trials revealed today that the trials might continue for years as new arrests are being made almost daily.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: The week in general was favorable in the Cotton Belt though rain is still needed in some western sections.
The Maritime Commission today announced the rejection of all bids for the building of a new cargo and
The Journal Company, publishers of The Milwaukee Journal, offered a one-fourth interest, amounting to $1,050,000, in the company's capital stock to 531 of its employes today.
Plans for structural changes in one wing of the Metropolian Museum of Art were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings. The estimated cost is $264,000.
The United Automobile Workers went into court as a minority stockholder in a strike-closed company today, in an attempt to compel the management to open negotiations.
Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Assemblyman Moffat of New York barring the sale in this State of goods manufactured wholly or in part by the labor of children under 16 years of age.

Mr. and Or Mrs. Frederick Rice of this city anc have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patrice Rice, to Wilfred D. Howell, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Howell M of Augusta, Me. The wedding will of take place in the late Summer.

Ridgefield School for Boys will have its twenty-ninth commencement exercises Saturday, when thirteen will be graduated. The address will be given by the Rev. Roger B. T. Anderson, rector of Trinity Church, Waterbury.

Phillippa Duke Schuyler, 5-yearold Negro girl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Schuyler of 320 Manhattan Avenue, was one of several children who received "superior" ratings yesterday for piano playing in the second day of a tournament being conducted by the National Guild of Piano Teachers in Wanamaker's Auditorium.

Random House has relinquished the American agency for the Nonesuch Press. The agency has been taken over by Heritage Press, 551 Fifth Avenue, which will handle the twenty-three-volume Nonesuch edition of the Works of Charles Dickens.

With the turnover on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the smallest for a full session in two years and that on the Curb Exchange, save for last Friday's, the smallest since June 5 of last year, there was little cheering among the brokerage houses.

A new contract calling for cooperation along broader lines between the Uptown Retail Guild'and the Fashion Originators Guild of America has been approved by the two organizations and goes into effect immediately, according to joint announcement made yesterday by Adam Gimbel, chairman of the retail group, and Maurice Rentner, chairman of the' manufacturers' body.

Wood D. Loudoun, who retired in 1933 after eight years as chief accountant of the Board of Transportation, died Tuesday at his residence, the Hotel Empire, at the age of 80. His widow, Imogene M., and a son, Harry H. Loudoun, survive.

A contract for eighty-five "basic combat" airplanes, which with spare parts equivalent to ten complete airplanes will cost $1,372,255, was awarded by the War Department today to North American Aviation, Inc., of I Inglewood, Calif.

MANHATTAN BAMBERGER, REBA C. (May 21). Estate, more than $10,000. To Jay Anthony Lukas and Christopher W. Lukas, greatgrandsons, 1,361 Madison Ave., $2,500 each; Morgan De Witt Blair also known as Morton Bamberger, son, 74 Portland PI., London, England, and May B. Schamberg, daughter, executrix, 135 So.
Louis Vierne, organist at the Cathedral of Notre Dame since 1900, collapsed and died tonight while giving a concert at the famous church.

The decision of the Court of Appeals confirming the determination of Louis .H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, not to pay reinsurance claims out of policyholder trust funds will affect several companies now being liquidated by the New York Insurance Department, Mr. Pink said yesterday.

With the arrest of ten more suspects, making a total of thirty, in the Federal Government's widely ramified investigation of the disability insurance racket came the disclosure yesterday that Dr. John Wyckoff, dear of the New York University and Bellevue Hospital Medical College, who died Tuesday morning, and other prominent doctors had been tricked into lending their authoritative names to false disease claims.

With a growing demand from consumers for greater information on the merchandise sold in stores, members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at their mid-year convention in Chicago, June 21 to 24, will study the type of data the shopping public wants.
Barrow St. 6-10, 57.3x90; Power Holding Corp. Bernard B. Block, president, to Bardon Holding Corp. 285 Madison Ave; mtg $65,800.

Bishop John A. Duffy of the Roman Catholic diocese of Buffalo will preside this afternoon at the commencement exercises of Notre Dame College of Staten Island, Grymes Hill. Degrees will be conferred on twenty-five .students.
The first Government witness to testify before a committee of Congress in behalf of the President's new wage-and-hour plan said yesterday that it is "distinctly not an NRA or anything like an NRA."

Mayor La Guardia "cracked down" yesterday on those who believe in rubber-hosing political agitators and promised complete police protection to all political groups that stayed within the law in expressing their opinions.
The press is nearly unanimous in expressing surprise at the decision of President Arturo Alessandri not to allow newspaper reporters to enter the palace or any government quarters.

The State Department of Labor reported yesterday that-its public employment service had been unable during April to fill 900 jobs, 60 per cent of them in skilled and semi-skilled trades, even though the names and job qualifications of 450,000 unemployed persons in the metropolitan area are registered with the department's division of placement and unemployment insurance.

118th St, 114 2, 20x100.11; Today Realty and Holding Corp (Jacob D. Goodman, pres) to N Y City Mission Society; p m, 5 years, 5 per cent; $7,000. Hudson St, 527, 27x100; 527 Hudson St Corp (Cosimi Fillberto pres) to Bertha Greenblatt, 172 E 4th St; p m, 2 years, 6 per cent; $6,800.

The Imperial Conference turned today to the discussion of the Pacific situation in a session that gave the clearest demonstration yet of the vague character of the convocation of Dominion Prime Ministers.
More than 350 persons gathered at the Hotel Plaza last night at a testimonial dinner in honor' of William Weiss, president of the Union of Orthodox Congregations of America.

The Arkansas Corporation Commission petitioned today the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to intervene in favor of the application now before the I. C. C. of the Louisiana Arkansas Railroad to buy the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana Railroad.
Harvey T. Woodruff, a writer of sports for more than forty years, a former sports editor of The Chicago Tribune and for the last eighteen years conductor of the "In the Wake of the News" column,

Twenty-two employes of the New York Stock Exchange and of member firms last night received certificates indicating that they have completed the full course of study at the New York Stock Exchange Institute. Forty others received "customers' man certificates"

Graduation exercises were held yesterday afternoon at the Shore Road Academy, 9,249 Shore Road, Brooklyn. More than 300 parents and friends gathered on the lawn for a presentation by the students of Shakespeare's "Much Ado About Nothing."
King Carol cabled to President Roosevelt today thanking him for the invitation to attend New York's World Exposition in 1939 and announcing that he gladly accepted.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Van Cleaf Mathis Weaver, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John Franklin Weaver, to Louis Bowles Bresee, son of Mrs. Bowles Bresee of Baltimore and Arthur Fitzgerald Bresee of California, took place this evening in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd, Ruxton.

Miss Vella M. Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln E. Andrews of Columbus, was married to Bradford Lindsay Fairfax of this city yesterday afternoon in the Broadway Tabernacle, West Fiftysixth Street. The Rev. Allan K. Chalmers performed the ceremony.
Bob Feller, youthful pitching star of the Indians who has been out of action most of the season with an ailing arm, will decide when he returns from Milwaukee Sunday or Mon
In spite of official denials that a change in the price of gold is imminent, financial markets here and in Europe continued yesterday to hear rumors of an impending change.

The closing of eighty of its smaller stores in the Philadelphia area by the Great. Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, as the result of the Pennsylvania chainstore tax bill, is part of the plan to. revamp its entire set-up in that State, it was stated here yesterday by A. and P. officials.

The Chinese Government has challenged Japan's position in North China and invited a test of Nanking's power in Hopei and Chahar Provinces by ordering the immediate suspension of the Tientsin-Tokyo air service which was inaugurated today.
Clark Gable will appear this morning at the Capitol as the famed Irish patriot in the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer translation of the late Elsie Schauffler's "Parnell."
Dawn Play, the Acorn winner, captured the Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park yesterday, thereby stamping herself as the champion 3-year-old filly in the country.
The Department of Justice has "just begun to fight" in the government's prosecution of the Aluminum Company of America, under the anti-trust laws, Attorney General Cummings asserted today.

Apartment buildings featured the active trading in Bronx real estate reported yesterday. One of the largest properties changing hands was the five-story apartment house at 712 Fox Street, containing 215 rooms arranged in sixty-four suites.

Miss Susan Prudence Underhill, daughter of John Garrett Underhill of 2 Grace Court, Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Louisa Wingate Underhill, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Crane, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mitchell Crane of Scarsdale, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the bride's uncle, Surrogate George Albert Wingate, at his home, 26 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

State troopers were ordered tonight to come to the Little Falls Laundry plant by Governor Hoffman to prevent a repetition of this morning's riot, which followed an attempt by more than 1,000 silk dyers and other strike sympathizers to close the plant.
The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company of New York has been appointed registrar for the stock of Educational Pictures, Inc.
In the solution, announced late yesterday, of the Ministerial crisis the Japanese political parties have won an appearance of victory but perhaps little more.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 1 unless specified: At Mare Island Yard: Concord, Arctic, June 2. At San Francisco: Overton. Portland, Dahlgreen.

A committe of six directors of the Farmers National Grain Corporation today continued its work of drafting a new program designed to bring about greater harmony among -the regional bodies of the- marketing organization of farmers.
Dr. Roderick Byington, a former Brooklyn. physician, who had been practicing in Summit since 1923, died at his home here today at the age of 63.
The Duke of Windsor, as Prince of Wales and as the thirty-eighth monarch of England since the Norman Conquest in 1066, was one of the most popular figures the world has ever known.
Last night's session of the Composers' Forum-Laboratory at the Theatre of Music enjoyed one of the largest attendances of any in this series. It was devoted to works of American composers.

The International Harvester Company will construct a plant in Indianapolis in which it will concentrate the building of engines for its entire line of trucks, Sydney G. McAllister, president, annonunced today.
The faculty, student body and officials of the University of Chicago honored the memory of the institution's founder, John D. Rockefeller, in a solemn, service. today in the University Chapel..

Miss Betty Ritchie Kerr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chichester Charles Kerr of Llewellyn Park, has completed plans for her wedding to Alastair Douglas Robertson; son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Douglas Robertson of Hewlett, L. I.
Dr. Charles A. Currie, who played on the University of Pennsylvania's first football team in 1876, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Germantown. His age was 81.

The international tension, heightened by the provocative events of the past few days, has overshadowed the domestic struggle in Germany, but internal and external policies are so closely related in the totalitarian state that developments within the Reich have an important bearing on the general situation. In any event,

The Paramount can take credit this morning for the brighest comedy of the year-a gay, urbane and witty show called "I Met Him in Paris." It has, thanks to Claude Binyon, the cleverest script of the season.
The various associate companies of General Mills, Inc., have discontinued their corporate identities, James F. Bell, chairman of the board, announced today.

The Curb Exchange: building at Trinity Place, near Rector Street, at the rear of Trinity Church, was the center yesterday afternoon of what seemed like a snowstorm. Millions of tiny insects skimmed like snowflakes from the roofs of tall buildings down to the street under the elevated.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, successor trustee, has invited tenders of sufficient HydroElectric Corporation of Virginia first mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds, Series A, at prices not to exceed 104 per cent and accrued interest to exhaust a sum of $7,623, until June 16.

Private enterprise has now become so regulated that it must not only produce wages for employes, and a little something for the employer, but also taxes to support the government, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, told the American Management Association at its dinner meeting at the Hotel New Yorker last night.
Municipal MECHANICAL DRAFTSMAN (HEATING AND VETILATING), GRADE 4. (Simultaneously with the holding of this examination a promotion examination will be held.

In the heat of the House argument between advocates of the "pork-barrel" and the "lump sum," which some partisan and some sincere administration critics hoped would reassert "the independence of Congress," fiery oratorical sparks arose.

Remington Rand, Inc., and its domestic and wholly owned foreign subsidiaries had a net profit of $3;516,732 after all deductions, including provision for United States and foreign income taxes and $73,000 for Federal surtax on undistributed income, according to the pamphlet report for the year ended on March 31, 1937, released yesterday.

New York State Economic Council Congress of American Private Enterprise, Carnegie Hall, 9:30 A. M. Unveiling, Constitution Shrine, Bloomingdale's, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, 10 A. M. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, Representative Sol Bloom.

A series of new taxes must be imposed if Cuba is to cover her proposed 1937-1938 budget of $78,856,665.43, according to the budget message to Congress by President Federico Laredo Bru, made public yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. E. Cantelo White of Riverdale of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Sherman White, to Gibson Fuller Dailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke Gibson Dailey, also of Riverdale.

Wiley Blair, president of the Holly Sugar Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that sugar beet acreage contracted for this year by the company was about 1.5 per cent less than that of a year ago, and that this year's crop had been favored by excellent weather.

In conferring a C. I. O. charter on the newly organized United Office and Professional Workers of America yesterday, John L. Lewis wished the group "all success in organizing the millions of unorganized whitecollar workers in your field."
Turpentine firm, 34 1/4c; sales. 55 barrels; receipts, 501 barrels; shipments, 1,192 barrels; stock, 27,044 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 434; receipts, 1,259;
Snipers' bullets and crashes ended the use of airplanes to deliver food to workmen in the striketorn Republic Steel plants. Page 1.

The executive committee of the Central Trades and Labor Council announced last night at a meeting at 265-West-Fourteenth Street that forty-six locals affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization had been- suspended from the American Federation of Labor.

By noon tomorrow Mrs. Wallis Warfield will have become the wife of the Duke of Windsor in French law and by British law, as the British consul will be present, and with the blessing of a clergyman of the Anglican Church.

Adler, Blumenthal Co. have proposed to the New York Stock Exchange a dissolution of their partnership, effective next Tuesday. The interest of the late Thomas L. Elwyn in Biddle, Whelen Co. ceased on May 31;

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Spanish Government delegate to the League of Nations, declared here today that his government was more than willing to have an impartial inquiry into all the circumstances of the presence of the German pocket battleship Deutschland, twenty-four of whose sails were killed by bombs from Loyalist planes, in a Rebel port, and on which side the first act of aggression had been committed.
Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Old Colony Railroads applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to abandon 21.34 miles of track.

Pensioned Retired on their own applications after more than twenty years of service: Captain Lawrence E. F. Nelson of Engine 11, on an annual pension of $2,250. Fireman First Grade Martin Golding of Engine 52, on an annual pension of $1,500. Fireman First Grade Henry Robin of Rescue 2, on an annual pension of $1,500.

Miss Maida Du Gaust Cain, duaghter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Cain of Boston, was married yesterday morning to Robert Lawerence Rockefeller, son of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Rockefeller of this city and Allenhurst N. J., in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 16,000, including 6,000 directs. Market closing 10c lower than Tuesday's average. Packing sows fully steady:

A new surgical operating procedure designed to remove safely any part of an inflamed colon, or the entire colon when necessary, was described yesterday before the. first assembly of the American Chapter of the International College of Surgeons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Dr.. A. A. Berg of Mount Sinai Hospital.

A painting of "St. Isaac Landing attract at New Amsterdam" was presented the c to the Museum of the City of New during York, 103d Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon by M. Knoedler Co., Inc., at exercises in the museum. The picture is the work of Nina Barr Wheeler.
Voters of British Columbia have endorsed the Liberal administration of Premier T. D. Pattullo and given him a clear mandate to administer affairs until 1942.

The Continental Mortgage Guarantee Company yesterday announced plans to redeem all of its outstanding guaranteed mortgages, totaling $4,705,000. The guarantees were called for redemption as of June 2, 1937.

The Guadarama Mountain sector, northwest of Madrid, continued active today, with one Loyalist force attacking Leon Pass, on the road to Avila, while another was reported to have reached a point within six miles of Segovia, forty-three miles from this city.
The Johns Hopkins University declined to participate in the 200th anniversary of the University of Goettingen, Germany, this Summer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like to add a few suggestions to the editorial in your issue of May 30, on the subject of the "general welfare" clause of the Constitution, and also on the same subject contained in an article by Mr. Krock in your issue of June 1.

Sirens wailed and brakes screeched in the sawdust-powdered arena of Madison Square Garden last night as a cast of nearly 1,000 members of "New York's Finest" opened a "three-day stand" before a crowd of about 10,000 persons.

Close-of-play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today follow: Middlesex, 361 (Human 77, Robins 71, Edrich 57, Hulme 56, Mayer 4 for 73); Warwickshire, 123 runs for 2 wickets; at Lord's.

Prince Bernhard, Crown Princess Juliana's husband, visited the former Kaiser today. As the Netherland royal family does not officially maintain relatins with Wilhelm--Queen Wilhelmina has never seen him since he was exiled--this visit caused much comment.
Senator Wagner will not be drawn into the Mayoralty rac in New York, but will stay in the Senate and seek reelection when his term expires in 1939, persons close to him said today.

The Wall Street Golf Association, of which Jeremiah R. Morris of Jacquelin De Coppet is president, announced yesterday that foursomes from twenty-three Stock Exchange firms and from the Stock Exchange itself and from the Stock Clearing Corporation had entered in the competition for the Charles R. Gay Cup.

NORMAN BAKER of Iowa claims that in 1930 he was making $75,000 a month as a cancer specialist. Operating with strong political support, he advertised himself by means of a magazine and a radio broadcasting station. The American Medical Association assailed Baker as a quack, and Baker lost the $500,000 libel action that he brought against the association.
Frankie Cinque of New York, 148, punched his way to a victory over Mickey Makar, 1431/2, Bayonne, tonight in an eight-round bout.

Robert H. O'Brien of Chicago has been appointed an assistant director of the registration division of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He has been practicing law in Chicago and previously was on the commission's staff. He succeeds Alexander.
Patrolman Isidore Astel, cited for one of the two Police Combat Crosses for 1936, was too ill yesterday to be brought to the City Hall in an ambulance, but he received his decoration nevertheless.

Supporting John Esposito's threehit pitching with a hard-hitting offensive, Salesian High's unbeaten nine gained its eighth straight victory at the expense of a neighborhood rival, Iona Prep, winning by 15--2 yesterday at Iona Field, New Rochelle The victors,
John Hanscom, 15 years old, of 3-15 150th Street, Whitestone, Queens, died in Flushing Hospital early yesterday morning of a bullet wound just below the heart.

New York's plan for aid to, dependent children has been approved by the Social Security Board. New York becomes the thirtieth State to participate and it is estimated by State officials that about 65,000 dependent children will receive assistance during June.

To place its traffic control and accident reduction campaign on a permanent basis, the Automobile Manufacturers Association announced tonight the incorporation of its Automotive Safety Foundation, which has been functioning on a somewhat informal basis for a little more than a year.

In a unanimous decision the Court of Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of a law described by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey in New York City as one of his most effective weapons against racketeering.
Eighty-one students of the Long Island College of Medicine will receive degrees tonight at commencement exercises in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Dr. Frank L.

Mr. and Mrs. Milo William Krejci have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Edith Helen Krejci, to Emmons Bates Bulson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Bulson, which took place at their home here on Sunday.

The Dauphin County Court today granted to the Pennsylvania Railroad a temporary injunction restraining the State from putting into immediate effect the Full-Crew Bill signed by Governor Earle last night.

The Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, who is described as "a romantic Christian," has done little more than provoke mild irritation among leaders of the Church of England by offering to read the marriage service to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor after tomorrow's civil ceremony, according to authoritative information here.

The Newspaper Guild of New York voted last night at a meeting in the Hotel Astor in favor of the American Newspaper Guild leaving the American Federation of Labor and affiliating with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

With a fire raging in her holds, the German freighter Oliva radioed an appeal to the United States Navy here today to rush a destroyer or airplanes to her side to remove two officers and three sailors who were badly burned.

Having determined the amount needed in the government's June financing program, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau has decided to make the announcement tomorrow morning, fifteen minutes before the stock markets open in New York.

Exports of sulphite pulp from Sweden during the first quarter of 1937 were 20 per cent larger than last yesr and kraft pulp continued in active demand, the American Trade Commissioner has reported to the Commerce Department.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,573,700 barrels, a new high record and 23,250 more than the daily average of 3,550,450 in the preceding week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Real estate activity in Manhattan extended yesterday from the lower West Side to Washington Heights. Housing properties formed the bulk of the turnover.

Colonel Kenneth E. Clayton-Kennedy, engineer and oil promoter, accepted yesterday $32,500 in settlement of a $300,000 suit he had brought in Supreme Court against former business associates charging them with falsely causing his arrest in Canada several years ago. The compromise was made as trial of his suit was about to enter its sixth day.

AARON-Annie (nee Adelson), beloved wife of Jacob, devoted mother of Beatrice Weinberg, dear sister of Kieve Adelson, Bessie Sloan, Julia Silverman, Rebecca Weisman and the late Philip and Thomas Adelson and Lottie Berlin. Services at Park Memorial Chapel, 4,511 Fort Ham ilton Parkway, Brooklyn, on Friday, June 4, at 2 P. M.

The Finance Ministry, which Prince Konoe called the pivotal post of his Cabinet, remained unfilled when the Premier's headquarters closed last night in circumstances that spread a depression over financial circles.
Manhattan Alterations 5th Ave, w s, 80th St (Metropolitan Museum): to 2-story museum: Department of Parks, City of New York, owner; John R. Pope, architect; cost, $264,000.
Dr. and Mrs. Albert Clarke White of Glenargie Park, this place, and Stanmore, Pembroke, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter,

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced yesterday the promotion of eightyeight members of the faculty, including the appointment of an assistant dean and three new chairmen of departments.

Fair trade practice rules for the popular-price dress industry were approved in a resolution adopted by manufacturers yesterday at the conference held in the Hotel New Yorker by the Federal Trade Commission at the request of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group, representing the bulk of the 450 makers of dresses wholesaling at $4.75 and below, whose annual output is valued at more than $200,000,000.
Gliding along in an easterly breeze, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new Ranger today won the initial race in the first of a series to decide upon the defender of the America's Cup at the end of next month.

Charges flew thick and fast between counsel in the Parker conspiracy trial here today as Federal Judge William Clark, himself considerably nettled, demanded whether the defense was implying through the testimony of one of its witnesses that he was party to an agreement to provide-special consideration for Murray Bleefeld, one of the defendants who pleaded guilty and testified for the government in the present trial.

Several hundred persons including many leaders in the professions and philanthropic organizations attended funeral services yesterday for Madison Grant, president of the New York Zoological Society, held in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Mr. and Mrs. John Pierre Zerega of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, and Bayport, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arlene Hill Zerega, to William Joseph Kent Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Kent of Brooklyn and South Norwalk, Conn.
The administration's purpose to abolish child labor was voiced today before a joint Congressional committee considering wage and hour legislation by Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General.

Higher prices than those originally set under the Feld-Crawford, Fair-Trade Act were made effective yesterday by two manufacturers in notifications sent to retailers here. Burroughs Wellcome Co. revised the maintained retail prices upward on four items:

New Yorkers got relief from the hot spell yesterday-about 8 A. M., after their night's sleep had been ruined by oppressive heat. The high of 80 degrees was recorded at midnight and 1 A. M. The temperature then slowly tapered off, but not sufficiently to make sleeping comfortable.
For twenty-two years RICHARD ALDRICH held the position of music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES in a manner which conferred equal distinction upon him and upon the newspaper which employed him.

Most commodity futures were firm in less active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, copper, tin, hide and coffee futures advanced, while sugar, wool top, cottonseed oil and cocoa futures were steady. On the cash markets corn, lard, tins, cotton and rubber advanced, but wheat, rye, oats, flour, pork, printcloths and silk declined.

Opposition to student oaths not to fight in any war was expressed tonight in a radio talk by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. "Becase," she explained, "you never can tell what position you may find yourself in.

Among the leases for business space reported by brokers yesterday was a contract for five floors, -involving approximately 50,000 square feet in 87-91 Van Dam Street, for the Forest Paper Company, Inc.

Supreme Court Justice O. Byron Brewster ruled yesterday that Masonic Hall at. Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue was exempt from New York City real estate taxes because its profits are used for charitable purposes.

Prominent physicians of this city will join with Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, as honorary pallbearers today at funeral services for Dr. John Wyckoff, dean of the New York University College of Medicine.

Unable to meet the wage scales of governmental relief agencies, potato growers of Nassau and Suffolk Counties are bringing in bus-loads of Negro labor from the South to relieve an acute labor shortage. The top wage offered the Negroes is $2 a day, but some are receiving $9 a week for a twelve-hour day.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil company, Inc., today will advance the price of all grades of gasoline by all methods of delivery one-half cent a gallon in the metropolitan area. The new tank-wagon price in New York City will be 9 1/2 cents a gallon, excluding all taxes.

The price at which Hiram WalkerGooderham Worts, Ltd., and Hiram Walker Sons Distilleries, Inc., ten-year 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures may be converted into common stock is now $55 a share, according to notice received by the Guaranty Trust Company as trustee.
The Reds took the first game of the series with the Phillies today, 8-4, making twelve hits off four pitchers. Pettit, making his first National League start, was charged with the loss.

Frank R. Frost, president of the Superior Steel Corporation, who sailed yesterday on the Washington for a six weeks' business trip to Europe, said the company's earnings this year had been running at a high rate and that second-quarter results should exceed those for the first quarter.

Mayor La Guardia's plan for a chain of district health centers covering the city will approach realization on Monday, June 21, when the first of eight new district health centers will open at 158-164 East 115th Street.

William F. Brunner, President of cert the Board of Aldermen, told members of the parliament of Community Councils, at a meeting last night in City Hall, that he favored purchase by the city of the Rockaway division of the Long Island Railroad.

Seniors at the New Jersey College for Women will hear Dr. Henry H. Tweedy, Professor of Practical Theology at the Yale Divinity School, preach the sermon tomorrow morning at their baccalaureate service. Dr. Tweedy's theme will be "Doing the Impossible."

Lawyers for the United Mine Workers, the union which produced John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization. arrived here today and took charge of the legal battle between the striking steel workers and the Chicago police, who, the strikers say, wantonly shot down their pickets outside the South Chicago plant of the Republic Steel Corporation on Memorial Day.
BULWARK OF THE REPUBLIC: A BIOGRAPHY OF THE CONSTITUTION, by Burton J. Hendrick. (Little, Brown, $3.50.) A book club choice.

Remuneration of $182,040 paid to Harry Cohn, president of the Columbia Pictures Corporation, for the fiscal year ended on June 27, 1936, topped the salaries reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission which were made public yesterday.

Claire L. Barnes, president, was elected yesterday chairman of the Houdaille-Hershey Corporation and was succeeded as president by Charles Getler, vice president. Melville G. Mson was elected vice president and Ralph F. Peo and Don S. Devor were chosen as additional vice presidents.
The announcement, criticism and finally the withdrawal of the propoised tax on excess profits in Great Britain combine to form an instructive lesson.
Removal and sale of the old Hunter. College. Building at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, erected in- 1872, was authorized yesterday by the Sinking Fund Commission in a meeting at City Hall.
The text of the recent agreement among the Oslo powers, published today, confirms the general outline previously made public.
Edgar Astwood, former British Consul and a member of civic and social- improvement groups here, died yesterday in his home at 185 Dean Street, Brooklyn. He was 68 years old.

A general increase in rates on cargoes moving between the Atlantic seaboard and South Africa will be put into effect on July 1 by the member lines of the conference operating in that trade, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Edward M. Townsend, who returned recently from abroad, gave an illustrated lecture on "Sulgrave and the Washington Country" yes- d terday afternoon in the new head- t quarters of the English-Speaking Union at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Voters of 168 municipalities located in ten States approved bond issues in May aggregating $9,331,670 as compared with $17,426,503 during April, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for May, 1936, was $10,140,820 as compared with $8,713,314 in May, 1935, and $44,670,750 in 1934.

Stocks closed steady and generally higher in slowest trading in more than two years; turn-. over, 535,680 shares. United States Government bonds steady at fractionally lower levels, other issues firm and dull; transactions, $7,910,800.

Graduation exercises for the two elementary schools of the Ethical Culture School system, with a total of eighty-eight boys and girls receiving certificates, will be held today. Sixty-five are in the main elementary school at 33 Central Park West and twenty-three in the lower school at Fieldston.

The new United States Ambassador, Anthony J. Drexel Biddle, today presented his credentials to President Ignaz Moscicki in the ancient royal castle and drove through the principal streets escorted by a squadron of light cavalry with trumpeters. His reception, which was marked by much pomp, was very cordial.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., L. B. Pulsifer, vice president, said that the "volume of business and profits in the first four months of this year were substantially ahead of last year."
Government officials reported today that sugar deliveries in the first four months of this year were 236,315 short tons larger than in the same period last year.

Miss Ric Josephine A. Swope, daughter of Cla Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Swope of Chestnut Hill, was married this Yo afternoon to Ernesto B. Laine for Santa Maria, son of Mr. and Mrs. cru Adolfo B. Santa Maria of this city L. and Havana.

Early approval by the House of the proposed investigation of tax avoidance and evasion was predicted tonight, but by a resolution largely altered from the Roosevelt plan adopted by the Senate yesterday.

Jack Arthur Obermeyer, New York Citymidshipman who was graduated with the highest honors from the Naval Academy this year, was the hero of the final day of the general exercises of June week when, at the final dress parade this evening, he received seven prizes for excellence in scholastic and professional branches.

Chester Lee O'Brien, husband of the late Marilyn Miller, dancer and actress, yesterday won his legal battle to share in his wife's estate but lost his fight to have a $64,000 trust fund created for the actress's mother made a part of the estate.

Miss Priscilla Steers, daughter of Mrs. Peter Greig of this place and Henry Coster Steers of New York, has completed plans for her wedding to John Tolar Henry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Henry of Brooklyn, on June 29 in Christ Church here. The Rev. R. Townsend Henshaw, the rector, will perform the ceremony.

Franklin D. Mooney, chairman of the board of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Company, was elected chairman of the American committee of Lloyd's Register of Shipping at its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Whitehall Club. He succeeds Robert Haig, vice president of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

An order for 300 heavy-duty General Motors trucks valued at $1,22 ,000 has been placed by the New York City Department of Sanitation, according to J. P. Little, vice president of the truck company, which delivered 315 similar trucks to the department in March.

Speaking in his own defense for the first time since his dismissal from the Yale Divinity School, Professor Jerome Davis commented tonight on the statement given out by Yale University in response to the report made by the American Association of University Professors on circumstances surrounding his dismissal.

Catholic college graduates, particularly those of this year, were urged to participate in the work of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine by Cardinal Hayes, speaking yesterday at commencement exercises at the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, at Benziger Auditorium on the campus, 131st Street and Convent Avenue.
More than 100 lots on the Shrewsbury River at Port-au-Peck, N. J., have been sold by J. Edward Breuer, agent and auctioneer, for the Mount Vernon Trust Company, trustee.

Walter James Scharf, 26 years old, of 91-22 120th Street, Richmond Hill, a locomotive fireman for the Long Island Railroad, received a medal yesterday for saving the life of a trespasser in Glen Cove, L. I., last Feb. 26.

Bringing their nice, shiny winning streak into the Polo Grounds, PA which of late seems to have had an evil influence on streaks of all sorts, the Cubs had a mighty close call yesterday as they moved on to the Harlem to open a three-game series with the Giants.

Dave Paley, 39-year-old partner with his brother, Milton, of the Hamilton Sandwich Shop, 2,441 Broadway, at Ninetieth Street, was found murdered early yesterday morning in his store. He had been hit on the head several times with an iron pipe. Robbery apparently was the motive.

The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and president of St. Joseph's College for Women, 253 Clinton Avenue, conferred degrees and scholastic honors on seventynine seniors last night in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn.
Barred under the State Constitution from succeeding himself, Governor Hoffman may become the director of a State agency to advertise New Jersey's resources when his threeyear term ends in January.
The text of Robert H. Jackson's statement to the Joint Congressional Committee on the constitutionality of the Wages and Hours Bill follows:
Hearing a tapping in the dark hallway at 317 West Thirty-fifth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, at 3 P. M. yesterday, Barnett Martin discovered a man, bound and gagged, lying on the floor.

Within the framework of the llight. good-humored dialogue of "Lovers Meeting," produced by Margaret Webster at the Embassy Theatre tonight, the American author, Gladys Hulbut, has effectively woven a seriuos theme.
Transfer SERGEANT--Nicholas J. Nagle, 52d Precient to 100th Precinct. Temporary Assignement ACTING LIEUTENANT--Willaim L. Mott Jr. from Mounted Squadrom 2 to Mounted

By ninety-five votes to seventysix the Chamber of Deputies today voted a bill granting an amnesty to Flemish Separatists who were accused of having negotiated with the enemy during the German occupation.

New Yorkers reaching here today from Mediterranean ports on the Italian motorship Vulcania include Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Hall, Miss Louise Field, Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Hanson, Miss Marguerite Adam, Miss Ruth B. Moran and Philip Warren. Others are Mr. and Mrs.

If Washington and Navy fight it out with each other for first in the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta at Poughkeepsie June 22, as many persons believe they will, they will do it almost shoulder to shoulder.

Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, the second woman to be appointed to a diplomatic past, sailed yesterday at noon on the Wsahington of the United States Lines on her way to Oslo, Norway, as United States Miniser. She avoided comment on European affairs.

A world public even large than the one that listened to EDWARD VIII's speech of abdicatino will now wish the Duke of WINDSOR a long life of happiness in the company of the wife for whom he made so extraordinary a sacritice.

Total advertising in New York and Brooklyn newspapers during May registered a gain of 3.9 per cent, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Linage was 12,089,353, as against 11,631,498 in May of 1936.
Steady relief pitching by Walter Brown, 265-pound right-hander recently shipped here by the Yankees, enabled Newark to score a 6-to-5. victory over the Jersey City Giants today.

There were no deaths from diph- G theria during the week ending May 29, the first week without such deaths since February, Dr. John J. Rice, Commissioner of Health, an- 2 nounced yesterday in the weekly health survey. There were twentyseven new cases, however, and Dr. Rice again urged that all children d under 6 be immunized.

The State's unemployment insurance fund has passed the $50,000,000 mark, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, said today. Ninetyseven per cent of the employers subject to the law's provisions have been making periodic payroll reports and contributions to the fund for eighteen months, he stated.
A number o dwelling properties in Brooklyn changed hands in deals reported yesterday by brokers. The four-story brick tenement at 117 Van Buren Street was sold to Mary Wagh by the Jones estate.

The Spanish situation and world conditions in general were surveyed by President Roosevelt today at a White House luncheon-conference with his principal diplomatic assistants. Afterward it was said definitely at the State Department that no new move was in prospect.

Otto C. Rohde, 49, vice president and chief engineer of the Champion Spark Plug Company of Toledo, died today at the City Hospital from injuries received last Friday in an accident during the preliminaries of the 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean, Cardinal pitching ace, yesterday was indefinitely suspended by President Ford C. Frick of the National League. The date of his reinstatement will depend on the out- whether I come of a conference at 11 o'clock this morning among Dean, Man- he is. ager Franck Frisch, Frick and "Dean Ernest C. Quigley, the circuit's admits t supervisor of umpires.

Current business opinion is about equally divided between optimism and anxiety, says Banking, official journal of the American Bankers Association, in its June issue. There is a fairly general expectation of lower activity throughout the Summer, the. magazine says,

Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister, arrived from Berlin by air early this afternoon on an official visit to Italy's armed forces. Particular interest was lent to his presence by the tense situation brought about by recent events in Spain.
A banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,100,000 of bridge revenue project No. 12 bonds of the State of Kentucky on a bid of 101.04 for 2 3/4s.

Announcement has been made by Charles H. Duncan of Pasco, Wash., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Virginia Lee Duncan, to John Becker Lucke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Lucke of 186 Riverside Drive.

Interest has been aroused here by the attempts being made by a foreign concern to refloat the Peruvian vessel Mancocapac, which was sunk by its crew in 1879 during the war with Chile in the Bay of Arica when the Chilean forces captured the Morro Hill fortifications.
The stock market here reacted favorably today to the government's decision to abandon the projected tax on growth of profits, and the recovery in many sections of the market was substantial.
Charlton Athletic, English soccer team on tour, scored its first victory in America tonight, defeating the Pittsburgh All-Stars, 2 to 0. A crowd of 2,000 persons saw the game.

Dr. Nicholas Murray-Butler, president of Columbia University, sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie to attend the annual meetings of the Committee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Geneva on June 15 and 16.

Southern notables of two races paid honor today to the scientific genius of a humble Negro who was born in slavery and once traded for a horse. The man is George Washington Carver; the occasion an unveiling of a bronze bust bought by dollar contributions of his admirers.

Air Associates, Inc., declared an initial dividend of 10 cents on the common stock. Gilbert Colgate, chairman,- stated that sales for the first seven months of the fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, were about 50 per cent greater than for the corresponding period of the preceding year.

A strike against sixty beauty parlors in the Bronx was declared yesterday by the Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Union, Local 560B, in an effort to unionize the industry. Strikers picketed the shops, most of which 'are situated in the eastern section of the borough. Later the pickets turned their attention to establishments in the western section.
Ireland's champion Mayo Gaelic football team defeated the New York Kerry fifteen by 12 to 6 at Innisfail Park last night before 2,590 persons.

Development of a strong national association in preparation for expected labor and legislative problems was advocated by directors of the Oyster Growers and Dealers Association of North America, meeting yesterday in joint convention with the National Shellfisheries Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Fourteen residents of New York and the metropolitan area won $1,125,000, less taxes and, in some cases, less shares sold to ticket brokers, yesterday to tickets in the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes on the Epsom Downs Derby in England.

Mrs. Mary Canby Fuller, a resident of Brooklyn for seventy-seven years and a great-great-granddaughter of Betsy Ross, died on Tuesday at her home, 266 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, in her eightyfourth year.

Brother Constantius Paul, a member of -te Roman Catholic Brothers of the Christian Schools (the Christian Brothers) died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Joseph's Normal Institute, Barrytown, N. Y. Brother Constantius Paul long was a teacher of delinquent boys at Catholic institutions before his retfrement to St. Joseph's last September because of ill health. His age was 61.

Miss Alice Marble, United States champion, defeated Miss Margot Lumb, British squash racquets star, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, in the third round of the women's singles in the St. George's Hill tennis tournament today. Miss Ruth Mary Hardwick of England eliminated Miss Katherine Winthron of Boston. 6-1, 6-3.

The proportional system of electing Councilmen, as provided in the new New York City Charter, was declared valid by the Court of Appeals today in a prevailing opinion written by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Evans Edge, who are at the Ambassador, will leave today to visit relatives of Mrs. Edge in Bath, Me. Rear Admiral and Mrs. William H. Standley of this city and Washington are at the Commodore.

Representative Maverick of Texas proposed in the House today a Congressional inquiry into unemployment and the administration of relief, and called for adoption of a rule setting up a standing committee to have charge of such legislation.

Ten Cornell athletes and twelve Princetonians have been named as members of the track and field team that will meet the combined forces of Oxford and Cambridge in Palmer Stadium, July 17, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of Princeton athletics.
Mrs. M. Roe MacLachlin of Newburgh, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Emily Dean MacLachlin, to Croxton Morris, son of. Mr. and Mrs. James T Morris of White Plains. N. Y.

A subpoena summoning Edsel Ford, president and son of the founder of the Ford Motor Company, to a oneman grand jury inquiry into the beating of eighteen union sympathizers a week ago went unserved tonight. Ford attorneys challenged the jurisdiction of Common Pleas Judge Ralph W. Liddy.

Long Island University defeated the Providence College nine, 11 to 6, tonight. It was the twenty-first victory for the New Yorkers in twenty-four games. They collected thirteen hits off two Friar pitchers and played a fine game in the field to lead throughout.

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, arrived today completing the United States delegation to the International Labor Conference opening tomorrow. It is understood that he frowned on the suggestion that he accept the conference presidency. That office now is assured Sean F. Lemass, Minister of Labor of the Irish Free State.

Trading was fair on beef and slow on other classes. Beef prices were steady to firm and other classes steady to lower. Demand for kosher meats was slow and all classes were weak to lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Praising the "old fashioned" virtues of honesty, thrift and kindness, Dr.. Harvey C. Minnich, dean emeritus of Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, declared yesterday at the opening of a McGuffey exhibit at Wanamaker's that the civilization of the Middle West was built around the McGuffey Readers.

The War Departnemt today released the following orders, dated June 1: COLONELS Rose, J. B., (Ordnance Dept.) General StafF Corps, 13 days' leave, June 1. Goldthwaite, R. H., Med. Corps. Panama, to Ft. Sill, Okla.

The United Securities Company of Missouri, Kansas City, an investment trust, has filed two registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 covering issuance of certificates and estimating the aggregate amount of the cash offerings at $10,000,000.

Fred C. Moffatt, president of the New York Curb Exchange, in his annual report, issued yesterday in pamphlet form, indicated that there was a substantial increase in "fully listed" stock and bond issues in 1936.

Righthander Cy Blanton stopped all but three Bees while hurling the Pirates to a 2-0 shut-out today and gaining his sixth victory of the season. He had six strike-outs and gave six hits. The triumph gave the National League leaders from Pittsburgh a two-game edge over the second-place Giants.

Life Insurance for buildings is now possible in this State through a law introduced by Senator Duncan T. O'Brien and signed May 19 by Governor Lehman. The measure permits the formation of insurance companies to write insurance policies for buildings and equipment.
On the eve of the second anniversary of her maiden arrival in this port, the French liner Normandie yesterday was declared able to cross the Atlantic in less than four days.

Kid Chocolate, former featherweight champion of the world, scored another victory in his comeback campaign last night. The flashy Cuban rounded out a triumph over Al Reid, courageous Bronx battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome.
Mrs. Louise F. G. Grlmke, in 64 E 86th St; Samuel A. Herzog, broker. John Goldfrank, through Gresham Realty Co, in 59 W 71st St; M. Morgenthau-Seixas Co, Inc, broker.
A more official character was given to Italian participation in the Spanish civil war today by the appearance in newspapers of the first list of casualties among the Italian Fascist volunteers.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty granted an application yesterday of Mrs. Dorothy Browning Hood of Dunn, N. C., adopted daughter of the late Edward W. Browning, for an increased allowance out of her share in the estate. The allowance is increased $500 to $1,500 a month.
Imprisoned in an "iron lung" to maintain respiration, Frederick B. Snite Jr., 26, of Chicago left today for Shanghai, the first leg of a homeward journey half-way around the earth.

Sir Alexander Hood, former treasurer to Queen Mary, died today in hiss eighty-third year. Life Tenant of Duchy Sir Alexander Nelson Hood, Duke of Bronte, had a life tenancy of the extensive estates granted to his great-granduncle, Admiral Lord Nelson, along with the Dukedom of Bronte, by King Ferdinand of Naples in the early part of the last century after the battle of the Nile.
George Howard Fall, former Mayor of Malden, former member of the Legislature, and for forty years teacher of Roman and Constitutional Law at Boston University,

Experiments in the smashing of atoms in which particles may be shot through a tube at a speed of 100,000,000 miles an hour were described here today by Dr. W. L. Chubb, director of research of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.
LONDON-Britain saw the tension over the Spanish situation lessening as she worked on proposals to win Italy and Germany back to the Non-Intervention Committee. Page 1.

Commencement exercises will be held this afternoon for seventy-three graduates of the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing, with Dr. Lewis Perry, principal of the Phillips Exeter Academy, as the speaker. The exercises are scheduled for 4 P. M. in the garden at 622 West 168th Street, but in the event of rain they will be held in the 102d Engineers Armory on 168th Street.
LONDON-Britain saw the tension over the Spanish situation lessening as she worked on proposals to win Italy and Germany back to the Non-Intervention Committee. Page 1.

Commencement exercises will be held this afternoon for seventy-three graduates of the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing, with Dr. Lewis Perry, principal of the Phillips Exeter Academy, as the speaker. The exercises are scheduled for 4 P. M. in the garden at 622 West 168th Street, but in the event of rain they will be held in the 102d Engineers Armory on 168th Street.

The combined net income of thirty-two major oil companies last year amounted to $456,514,394, compared with. $282,449,659 in 1935, an increase of about 61 per cent, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 29: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Connor, F. H., Newport News, Va., Asiatic station. Laws, C. C. the Owl, to 5th Nv

With swagger and-Princess styles and luxury furs featured at the Fur Fashion Show held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, and record registration of buyers at the exhibits at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, the Autumn season in furs was officially opened here. Both events were held under the auspices of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., and will be repeated today and tonight.

Harry F. Sinclair Jr., 21-year-old son of the chairman of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, was elected yesterday a member of the board of directors, the executive committee and the finance committee of the corporation.

Showing a resiliency that Frankie Frisch would rather have seen displayed in some other league, the Dodgers yesterday bounced back from their disastrous Polo Grounds adventures to knock the Cardinalsdown below the .500 mark and come within half a game of the fourthplace Gas House Gang.
A plea for "untrammeled academic freedom" was voiced by Dr. Abraham Flexner, director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, in an address at the Bryn Mawr College commencement today.

George Tebbetts, Detroit catcher replacing the injured Mickey Cochrane, borke up an eleven-inning baseball game today with a home run over the left-field wall, scoring two mates ahead of him to give the Tigers a victory over Washington, 11 to 8.

Strength in foreign cotton markets brought about a recovery on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and left prices 2 to 4 points higher Early prices were the highest of the day as a result of foreign buying.

Dr. Charles Orrin Townsend, chief of the sugar division of the United States Tariff Commission from 1925 until his retirement in 1934, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 41-06 Fiftieth Street, Woodside, Queens, at the age of 74.

The Public Service Commission voted today to make effective rate schedules providing for the sale of electric power to industrial corporations under five-year contracts proposed by the Niagara Falls Power

Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd.-For 1936: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization and other expenses and charges, $6,243,888, against $5,210,238 in 1935; gross revenues, $32,197,610, against $30,221,757.
An innovation for the Women's Long Island Golf Association today at Piping Rock was a par-point tournament, in which points instead of gross and net scores determined the winners.

Thirteen years after the Kellogg-Briand Treaty was written and ratified renouncing war as an instrument of national policy the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America acted today toward obliterating from the doctrines of the church support for any kind of war.

James J. Braddock is scheduled to defend his world's heavyweight championship against Max Schmeling, the German battler who once held the title, in a fifteen-round bout at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City tonight. But James J. Braddock will not defend his world's heavyweight championship against Max Schmeling tonight, in the Madison Square Garden Bowl or any place else.
President Lazaro Cardenas late today delivered an ultimatum to the nation's striking oil workers and the seventeen foreign companies affected by the nation-wide walkout.

A sharp increase in contracts for the construction of new plants, equipment and distribution systems in the public utility industry for the first five months of this year was indicated yesterday by the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation.

At the business meeting of the Associate Alumnae at the Barnard College annual commencement reunion held in Brinckerhoff Theatre yesterday afternoon, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced that the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund had passed the half-million mark in its attempt to raise $4,500,000 by the Autumn of. 1939.

Members of the Board of Trade voted overwhelmingly today to assess themselves $150 each annually for the next four years to carry out a refinancing program for the $10,218,000 first mortgage on the Exchange's building, at the foot of La Salle Street.
The Reichsbank's statement as of June 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Dr. William E. Grady, associate superintendent of schools, will be the speaker this morning at the twenty-eighth annual commencement exercises of the Mills School for Kindergarten-Primary Teachers, to be held in the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. Thirty-one students will be graduated.

Notwithstanding a few conspicuous weak spots, such as local traction issues, a decidedly better tone prevailed in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The improvement in price undertone was most apparent throughout the list of secondary corporate loans, including many of the convertible industrial bonds.
Fifty thousand acres of tobacco for flue curing will be grown in Ontario this year, an increase of 15,000 acres over 1936, it was announced today by the Ontario Department of Agriculture.

Loans on securities to member firms decreased $35,066,396 in May, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The amount outstanding at the end of the month was $1,152,212,988, against $1,187,279,384 at the close of April.

Grant Williams,. retired police lieutenant and organizer and first head of the Bureau of Missing Persons, was found dead in a furnished room at 244 West Seventy-fifth Street shortly after noon yesterday.

Thomas E. Elder, once dean of Mount Hermon School, facing a hearing tomorrow on a charge of assaulting with intent to kill A. Allen Norton, the school's former cashier, suggested today that both he and Mr. Norton take a "truth-finding test."

Officials of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, top holding company of various subholding and operating utility companies throughout the country, indicated yesterday that the action of the company's subsidiary, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation,
Arthur B. Archibold, former Mayor and district court Judge, died at his home in Arlington last night. He had been confined to West Hudson Hospital here for five weeks following an operation.
The experiences of a party of salt water anglers fishing at Peconio Bay are described in the following letter from the Garden City Rifle and Pistol Club:

The marriage of Dr. Helen Miller of this city and Kinnelon, N. J., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Miller of Corvallis, Ore., to Alexander F. Armstrong of Albany took place here yesterday at noon in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Martin D. Hardin Jr. performed the ceremony.
Amsterdam Ave, 1,926-28, 6 and 9-story storage building; 50x100 irregular; Harlem Savings Bank against Broadway Storage Warehouse. Inc; due, $165,447; to plaintiff for $2.000.

An easy flight of 750 miles, the second leg of her world-girdling attempt, put Miss Amelia Earhart in South America today with no more water to cross until she starts for Africa across the South Atlantic from Natal, Brazil.

Two home runs enabled Fordham University's baseball team to defeat a strong Montclair State Teachers College nine, 4 to 3, at Fordham Field yesterday. It was the third straight triumph for the Rams in five days.

The Nova Scotia Government announced today that fishermen's assistance sums of $1 a quintal on dried cod and 662-3 cents a quintal on dried cusk, haddock, hake and pollock would be paid to fishermen of the province, starting immediately.

The romance of Archduke Albrecht, who at one time aspired to the Hungarian throne, ended today before the Royal Court here, which decreed him divorced from his commoner wife, the former Irene Lelbach Rudnav.

A serious outbreak of anti-Japanesq mob violence occurred shortly after midnight at - Tunglu, near Tientsin, when, according to Japanese reports, a mob of Chinese peasants attacked a farm and burned four buildings-a warehouse and three dwellings. Japanese consular police rushed to the aid of the farm staff.

Catchings of New York, a banker, testified today that the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, an investment trust of which he was president, suffered a $289,566,330 depreciation in the value of its assets between 1928 and 1932.
Eddie Cool, 140, Philadelphia, and Al Casimini, 136%, Corona, battled to a draw in the ten-round feature bout at the new Queensboro arena last night before 2,500 persons.

The schoolgirl signature of Wallis Warfield, written twenty-four years ago beneath a quotation from "Much Ado About Nothing," was found here in a birthday book by a former schoolmate at Miss Oldfield's finishing school at Glencoe, Md.

John Hay Whitney, a member of the Jockey Club and of the New York State Racing Commission, has been honored as the outstanding horseman of the last decade by the magazine Horse and Horseman, according to an announcement yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Asay, one of the oldest women in the country, died here today at the age of 114 in the Burlington County Hospital. She was born on Feb. 19, 1823.' She had been ill eight months. No relatives survive.

The House passed and sent to the Senate today legislation authorizing 3,000 additional miles of air-mail routes. The miles flown over airmail routes annually would be increased from 45,000,000 to 52,000,000.

Dr. and Mrs. Decio de PaulaMachado, who will sail for Europe on Saturday, gave a farewell dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis. Before her marriage early last month, Mrs. de Paula-Machado was Miss M. Helen de Machado Gaynor.
Richard Aldrich, music critic emeritus of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died this morning of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Villa Aurelia home of his brother, Chester, director of the Ameircan Academy of Rome.

More than 150 building service employes, mostly elevator men, members of the Building Service Employes Union, went on strike yesterday in thirty apartment houses in the Washington Heights and West Side sections.

C. T. O'Neal, president of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway, told stockholders at' the annual meeting today the road had a cash balance on May 26- of $2,435,816, a gain of $1,461,498 over last year.
Scoring in her first outing of the year, John Hay Whitney's Peggy Porter drove to a half-length victory in the Priscilla Alden Handicap, six-furlong feature today at Suffolk Downs.

Naturally, Charles B. Cochran's arrival from London on Tuesday stirred up all manner of reportsrumors that his productions, of "Paganini" and ''Home and Beauty" Would be brought here, other rumors that he would take back with him the English rights to "The Show Is On" and other local entertainments.

Japanese consular police rushed to the aid of the farm staff.

John Hay Whitney, a member of the Jockey Club and of the New York State Racing Commission, has been honored as the outstanding horseman of the last decade by the magazine Horse and Horseman, according to an announcement yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Asay, one of the oldest women in the country, died here today at the age of 114 in the Burlington County Hospital. She was born on Feb. 19, 1823.' She had been ill eight months. No relatives survive.

The House passed and sent to the Senate today legislation authorizing 3,000 additional miles of air-mail routes. The miles flown over airmail routes annually would be increased from 45,000,000 to 52,000,000.
Scoring in her first outing of the year, John Hay Whitney's Peggy Porter drove to a half-length victory in the Priscilla Alden Handicap, six-furlong feature today at Suffolk Downs.

Naturally, Charles B.
