Cochran's arrival from London on Tuesday stirred up all manner of reportsrumors that his productions, of "Paganini" and ''Home and Beauty" Would be brought here, other rumors that he would take back with him the English rights to "The Show Is On" and other local entertainments.

Cadets Robert J. Kasper of Kansas City, Mo., David 0. Byars and Caldwell Russell, both of Louisville, Ky., and James H. Lynch of Governors Island, New York, have been elected to captain four of next year's Army varsity teams. Kasper,
Ninety-seven students will be graduated this morning at commencement exercises to be held by the Scudder School in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

The United States Army transport Luddington, with a cargo of 700 tons of explosives and a fire in her hold, is racing to this port, according to a report made to army headquarters. The fire was discovered today in the No. 5 hold, and the hatches and ventilators were sealed after the release of a fire-smothering chemical.

No change was recorded in the week ended on May 29 in the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of wholesale prices, Commissioner Lubin announced today. The index, based on the 1926 weekly average, remained at 87.4, compared with 78.4 on May 30, 1936.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 2: BRIGADIER GENERAL Roberts, C. D., Washington, D. C., to retirement. COLONELS Beckham, D. Y., Adjutant General's Dept., 5 days' leave, June 3. Pope, W. R., Cav., Oklahoma City, Okla., to Omaha, Neb.
A jury, divided evenly between tenants and property owners, convicted a tenant of illegal possession today in the first eviction trial held here since a "rent strike" began June 1.
Mrs. William A. Stevens was chairman of hostesses for the annual luncheon meeting of Putnam Hill Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, at the Putnam cottage here this afternoon.

The Federal Music Project Chamber Orchestra, under Herman Neuman, with Edwin and Jewel Bethany Hughes, pianists, as assisting artists, will give a concert tonight at 8:45 o'clock at the WPA Theatre of Music.

Members of the faculty, alumni and students of New York University's College of Medicine yesterday morning paid tribute to Dean John Wyckoff of the College of Medicine at funeral services in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fortyeighth Street and Fifth Avenue.

These National Guard commissions were issued today. MacArthur, 2d Lt. Donald P., assigned to 165th Infantry for further assignment to 'Lewis, 2d Lt. Robert E., assigned to 165th Infantry for further assignment to Co. E. Dowling, 1st Lt. William B., Quartermaster Corps, will report to State quartermaster for assignment to State staff.

The New Jersey Power and Light Company has filed a motion in the Supreme Court of New York for an injunction to restrain the New York Trust Company from selling at auction on next Wednesday 712,411 shares of common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

A 9-monthold baby may become the titular ruler of the roof of the world. Since the thirteenth Dalai Lama, political pontiff of Tibet, died in 1933, the search has gone on unsuccessfully for his reincarnation.

The unsuccessful search for a suitable and receptive candidate to fill the unprecedentedly long vacancy of the Assistant Secretary of War has so worried the administration that a close observer today suggested that a newspaper advertisement be "promulgated."

The weading of Mrs. Wallis Warfield and the Duke of Windsore was just another day at the office for Ernest Aldrich Simpson, the new Duchess's second husband. He went about London quietly, as he describes himself: "Of very poor news value, I'm afraid."
Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday by the Park Association to support a resolution appropriating $587,054 to pay 802 playground directors in the Park Department for the remainder of the year.
Mrs. C. T. Botts, a daughter of General and Mrs. Samuel Hance Lewis, early Virginia settlers, died yesterday at the home of a son-in-law, Peyton W. Greene, at the age of 93.

The twentythird annual International Labor Organization conference opened today, with the president, Sean Lemass, Irish Free State Minister of Labor, offering as a motto the Irish proverb, "It is better to be quarreling than lonesome."

The induction this afternoon of Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares as Minister of Justice and Interior Affairs is considered of great political significance because of the disturbance due to the Presidential campaign.

Twenty-two members of the fiftyfirst graduating class of the Barnard School for Boys will receive diplomas tonight at the commencement exercises at the school, on West 244th Street, Fieldston, in the Riverdale section. Dr. William L.

Subscriptions totaling $80,451 have been received by the Citizens Cominittee on the Control of Crime in New York since its campaign for $200,000 began three weeks ago, it was announced yesterday by Harry F. Guggenheim, president, at a luncheon of its directors at the Bankers Club.

Continued business recovery, it is hoped, will reduce the national relief rolls from the present level of 2,200,000 to 1,640,000 during the next fiscal year, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, today told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee considering the Relief Bill.

The Literary Guild selection for July is "American Dream," a novel by Michael Foster, who is a newspaper man in Seattle. The book was first announced for publication early in the Spring, but was held up because of the book club choice. Morrow is the publisher.

Flatly refusing to sign a second letter of apology written for him by President Ford C. Frick of the National League--and just as resolutely declining to write one himselfDizzy Dean, under suspension for allegedly having directed derogatory remarks toward the circuit's head, struck back vehemently last night.

Dr. Frederick Porter Hammond, 70 years old, who had attended employes of the Third Avenue Railroad for twenty-five years as 'a physician, was killed at 4:10 P. M. yesterday by a trolley car of the Third Avenue Railroad System as he tried to cross Broadway at Ninety-first Street.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion..decreased [pound]30,000 Reserve in banking

The ivy ceremony and the senior dinner held last night ended the Senior Week events at Barnard College. At 6 P. M. the class of '37 marched in academic procession to Milbank Quadrangle for the annual planting of the ivy.

Judging from the sale of London evening newspapers, with their front pages twothirds covered by dispatches and pictures telegraphed from Monts, France, the British public shows real interest in the Duke of Windsor's wedding.

Rookie Lou Fette, the Bees' 30-year-old righthander, stretched his winning streak to four straight games today as he handed the Pirates their first shut-out of the year, 6 to 0. Between Fette, who muffled the league-leaders with seven hits, and Wally Berger, who clouted two homers, driving in four runs, Pittsburgh never had a chance after the Bees posted a four-run lead in the first inning.
The President was among those who tried his hand at writing the Wages-and-HoursLimitation Bill before it went to the Capitol. His effort was rejected by the administration lawyers.

Trans Barth. the Charles McMorrow estate of twenty acres in North Salem Township. Westchester; Julius Michel, the Louise E. Brundaw- home in Byram Lake. near Mount Kisco: De Forrest Hibbard, broker. Walter E. Strong. in 23 Grandview Ave, White Plains; Robert E. Farley Organization. broker.

The Frigidaire division of the General Motors Corporation will broaden its manufacturing and marketing activity in the near future, making its entrance into the general appliance field, E. G. Biechler, general manager, announced today at the annual Summer convention of Frigidaire's distributing organization heads.

Mrs. J. Harold Spencer of 35 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, and Quotonset Beach, Westbrook, Conn has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Jane Gelpeke, to Joseph C. Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Ryan of Brooklyn.

Miss Mary E. Maroney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Maroney of this city, has chosen June 26 as the date of her marriage to John J. Daly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Daly, also of Elizabeth. The ceremony will take place in St. Patrick's Church.

An increase of 61.4 per cent in aeronautical sales for the first four months of 1937, compared with those of the corresponding period of 1936, has been reported by Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.
A lease for fourteen rooms in 625 Park Avenue taken by Eliot Cross, architect, featured the contracts for residential space reported yesterday. Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., were the brokers.

The forty-fifth annual commencement exercises of the New York Law School were held last night at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Diplomas were presented to fifty-three graduates. The commencement speaker was John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General.

What the world seeks from college graduates today is "courageous young enthusiasts who will tackle great undertakings which a large part of the world believes impossible," according to Dr. Henry H. Tweedy, Professor of Practical Theology at the Yale Divinity School, who gave the baccalaureate address this morning at the New Jersey College for Women.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor boarded the Simplon-Orient express at this small station in the department of Yonne early today and sped away on their wedding journey to Austria.

Three hundred and nineteen members of the class which graduated from the Naval Academy today received their diplomas from Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, chief of the Department of Navigation of the navy. Another, Leonard E. Ewoldt of Hartley, Iowa, who is in the academy hospital, had his diploma later in the day.

Boasting that sixty-eight complaints had been made against them to the authorities in one year without a single conviction resulting, one of the alleged leaders of the trucking racket used the name of a district leader to intimidate his prospective victims, it was charged yesterday in the Supreme Court.
Mrs. ROOSEVELT'S well-known sympathies with progressive youth lend particular authority to her much-needed warning about anti-war oaths.
Joan Bennett divorced Gene Markey today, testifying that the movie scenarist wrote her only four months after their wedding that he was convinced the marriage was a mistake.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The shelling of a Spanish port by German war vessels, last Saturday, brings to mind the late John Hay's description of German foreign policy, which he characterized as "generally brutal but seldom silly."

The Aero Club of France met today to discuss the possibilities of a substitute for the canceled Lindbergh race between New York and Paris and tentatively agreed upon a round-trip flight between Istres, France, and Damascus, Syria.

An attempt to ban the publication of a Chinese-language version of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek's recollections of the Sian coup and the Generalissimo's diary of the event has been override by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in an order telegraphed to Nankine from Kuling.
A banner wishing happiness to the Duke of Windsor and his bride was stretched along the balcony of the Piccadilly apartment of an American, Captain Reginald Jaffray, and it caused trouble.

James J. Blake, chief engineer of Queens County highway construction at his retirement in 1929, died at his home at 41-42 Gleane Street, Elmhurst, on Wednesday. Mr. Blake came to Queens in 1894 and took charge of engineering construction for the New York Queens Railway Company.

Notices of issues of well over $120,000,000 reported received today by the Securities and Exchange Commission after a lull in corporation financing were regarded as indicating reassurance as to the stability of the money market.
Women owners, who play so large a part in racing, dominated the card at Belmont Park yesterday, victories in three of the six events going to them.

S. W. O. C. moved to close Republic Steel plants still operating by cutting off ore supplies. Page 1. A stoppage on the B. M. T. here was threatened by 6,000 workers protesting "arbitrary dismissals." Employes of the Third Avenue Railway will vote today on their bargaining agency. Page 1.

The American Institute of Architects approved a national low-cost housing program today after A. O. Eberhart, special assistant administrator of the Federal Housing Administration, assured the convention of close government cooperation.

Strong indications of a new administration plan to compromise the judiciary reorganization program and shove it through this session were given by Senator Robinson, the Democratic Senate leader, following a two-hour conference tonight with President Roosevelt.

Manhattan College has honored 110 members of its athletic teams for participation in Spring sports activities, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, F. S. C., director of athletics. It was also announced that awards had been granted to intramural athletes.

Launching their sixth counter-attack on Lemona Ridge since Saturday, the Basques today recaptured the massif and with it a chain of smaller hills southeast of Bilbao. Their advance guard is now pursuing the Insurgents in the direction of Amorebieta.

Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, will be the speaker tonight at the thirteenth anniversary commencement exercises of the Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson. George McAneny, chairman of the school's board of trustees, will preside.

The marriage of Miss Elisa Anthony Hoppin Cross, daughter of Mrs. Gammell Cross and of Harry Parsons Cross, to Curtis Bush Brooks, son of Mrs. Augustus W. Brooks of this city, formerly of Mobile, Ala., and the late Mr. Brooks, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, where the library was converted into a chapel with a screened altar of tapers and cathedral lilies.

Plaques and grants of $2,500 each were presented last night by Stevens Institute of Technology, in behalf of the Research Corporation of New York, to Professor Percy W. Bridgman of Harvard University and to Professor Ernest O. Lawrence of the University of California for their pioneer contributions in physical research.

The National Labor Relations Board, with Trial Examiner Robert M. Gates presiding, held a hearing yesterday in the case of the Consolidated Edison Company on the complaint filed by the United Electrical and Radio Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, charging violations of the Wagner act.

Miss Olivia M. Dunican, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Flusk Dunican of Rockville Center, L. I., was married yesterday morning to Dr. James A. Rogers, also of Rockville Center. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Peter Quealy in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church, Rockville Center.

Mrs. Natalie Wales Winslow, daughter of Mrs. Charles Edward Greenough of 1,212 Fifth Avenue and of Nathaniel Brackett Wales of Boston and Braintree, Mass., will be married to Edward Latham of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Louis Latham, on Monday in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $880,000 of various purpose bonds of the city of Yonkers, N. Y., on a bid of par for $490,000 as 3s, $330,000 as 3 1/4s and $60,000 as 4 1/2s. Other members of the successful syndicate are Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., R. L. Day Co., the Equitable Securities Corporation and Campbell. Phelps Co.
This is the afternoon on which the membership of Equity will decide its executive destinies: the annual meeting, plus elections, is being held at the Astor Hotel at 2 o'clock.

Climaking a long controversy, the Senate voted today to outlaw betting on horse racing in Texas. The action quickly drew from Raymond R. Russell, president of the Alamo Downs track at San Antonio, the cry:

Old man par-he's 71-took a terrific beating today as sixteen of the country's outstanding professionals crashed through with forty-five birdies in the opening eighteen-hole matches of the third annual Inverness round-robin best ball tourney.
Jeremiah Ryan, prominent labor union leader here for a half century, died yesterday in Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital of a heart attack suffered Monday. His age was 70.
First steps, were taken today to extend for two years the manufactures excises and "nuisance" taxes, which are to expire automatically at midnight June 30.

Havey C. Couch, chairman of the board and of the executive committee of the Kansas City Southern Railway, held 21,115 of its common and 1,040 of its preferred shares on Feb. 25, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on March 3 and made available yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
Gilbert Miller's production, "Yes, My Darling Daughter," which opened at the, St. James Theatre tonight under the direction of Alfred Dellagre, received a moderate reception.
The expenditure of $240,487 by the New York Central Railroad last year for the flotation of bond issues was disclosed yesterday in its annual report to the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The thirty-ninth annual meeting of the New Jersey Bar Association will open tomorrow at the Hotel Traymore.

An appeal for State aid in checking the growth of starfish in waters adjacent to oyster beds will be made here and in other States where oyster production is an important industry, it was announced yesterday at the close of the joint three-day conventions at the Hotel Pennsylvania of the National Shellfisheries Association and the Oyster Growers and Dealers Association of America.
Sunny weather fit for the wedding of any king-or former king-came today to old Touraine to grace the wedding of Edward, Duke of Windsor, and Wallis Warfield.

John P. Bottomley, Inc, has placed a mortgage for $145,000 with a savings bank for, the Tiebout Equities Co, Inc, on the apartment building at 2,395 Tiebout Ave. the Bronx. Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc, was co-broker.

Creation of a central body by the C. I. O. as a rival to the Central Trades and Labor Council, controlled by the A. F. of L., appeared certain yesterday as a result of the expulsion on Wednesday of fortyfive locals affiliated with the C. I. O. by the executive committee of the Central Trades, of which Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, is head.

Miss Eleanor Pearson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Page Pearson of this place, was married here this afternoon to David Drew Rice, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Newton Rice, also of Gardner, in the First Congregation Church.

More than 15,000 members of the International Association of Machinists in fourteen lodges in New York, New Jersey, Eastern Pennsylvania and Connecticut have voted to leave that organization and join the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Peggy Larimer, daughter of Mrs. William Gray Larimer of 405 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Larimer, to Thomas F. C. Frost, son of Mrs. Thomas F. C. Frost of London and the late Mr. Frost, took place at noon yesterday in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The Rev. Dr.

Buyers and merchandise executives of department stores, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, organized the infants' and children's wear merchandise group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Ave. 3.923. 2-story brick stores. 25x65.2x irreg: Dorothy Kuester against Louis Shapiro; due, $12,256; taxes, , $1,725; to plaintiff for $7,500.

The forty-third commencement exercises of the School of Nursing of the Presbyterian Hospital, 622 West 168th Street, were held yesterday afternoon in the hospital gardens. Five hundred parents and friends of the seventy-three graduates witnessed the ceremony in spite of a light rain.

Thousands of motorists on their way to the Triborough Bridge were delayed during the rush hour last night when traffic on the East River Drive, an approach to the bridge, was rerouted to First Avenue at Ninety-third Street, while firemen fought a two-alarm blaze in an unoccupied building at 226-240 East 106th Street, at the East River.

While awaiting reports from numerous committees the British and dominion Prime Ministers devoted the session of the Imperial Conference today to further discussions of foreign affairs with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.
The Rev. Michael J. Glennon, for eighteen years pastor of St. Teresa's Catholic Church, died this morning at Beach Haven, where he had gone for a rest.

Bar packages of gin are being used by price-cutting retail liquor stores as a means of attracting customers, it was disclosed here last night. Displaying the bar packages put up by well-known liquor companies alongside the same company's goods put up for package stores, the price-cutting stores are calling attention to the price contrast between the two.

Trout fishing on Long Island? That is a question raised by many recent letters, one of which is herewith quoted, in part: "My problem is merely this: that I must travel a great distance to enjoy lake or stream fishing. I reside at Rockville Center, L. I., and do most fresh water fishing at Green Pond, Oak Ridge and Stillwater, 60, 78, 103 miles respectively from Rockville Center.

Several leading figures in the automotive industry are among the fifty incorporators of Automotive Safety Foundation, Inc., which obtained a charter today under the Membership Corporations Law. The objects of the non-profit corporation are:
The seventeenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York is expected to attract a large number of bankers and bond men to the Sleepy Hollow Country Club at Scarborough, N. Y., today.

President Roosevelt called on Congress today to create seven national planning agencies along the lines of the Tennessee Valley Authority to conserve national resources and solve the problem of floods, droughts and soil erosion, with the production and sale of public power, as a corollary to any program presented.

The Minister of Health's order preserving Grange Court at Leominster from demolition and removal to the United States was made, it is now learned, on the strength of what was described as "only rumor."
Thomas Kittredge Cummins, vice president and treasurer of the Edison Electrio Illuminating Company of Boston, died today at his home here at the age of 73. He had been ill for several weeks.

Most commodity futures were lower in fairly active trading on,the local markets yesterday. Crude rubber, copper, tin, lead, hide and cottonseed oil futures lost ground, sugar advanced and coffee and cocoa were steady. On the cash market butter, printcloths, wool tops and gasoline advanced, but all the grains, cocoa, tins, cotton and rubber declined.

Driving home to his third victory of the season, Jake Freedman's Singers Folly, a Whitney cast-off, defeated his ex-stablemate, Piccolo, from the C. V. Whitney barn, in the mile and a sixteenth of the Bee's Purse, feature today at Suffolk Downs. He paid $5.60 in the $2 mutuels.

Scoring a 79, her best round of the tournament, as her nearest rival cracked on the final eighteen holes, Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol won the women's New Jersey State Golf Association championship at the Green Brook Country Club today with a fifty-four-hole total of 243.

Charges involving the financial activities of prominent bankers, including members of the firm of J. P. Morgan Co., officials of the Guaranty Company, Speyer Co., J. W. Seligmarl Co., Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Harvey Couch, a former member of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, were made in the Senate today.

Liquidation by holders of wheat was the order of the day in the world markets today. The improvement in the crops prospects in this country as a result of generous rains in the last ten days appeared to have changed the market trend, both here and abroad, with the main aim of traders now being to anticipate the expected heavy hedging that will come as harvest operations broaden in the Southwest.

Although "not altogether out of the danger zone," as Dr. Robert Emmet Walsh expressed it, Mickey Cochrane, recovering from a multiple fracture of the skull received in a ball game at the Yankee Stadium last week, is making steady progress at St. Elizabeth Hospital.

Net profit of the AddressographMultigraph Corporation in the first four months of this year amounted to $757,646, after deductions for depreciation, Federal income tax and other charges, according to a report issued yesterday. This is equal to $1 each on the 753,592 shares of capital stock and compares with $470,721, or 63 cents a share, earned on 746,313 shares in the four months ended on April 30, 1936.

Diplomas were presented to twentynine members of the graduating class at the Greenwich Country Day School this morning at commencement exercises. Members of the class of 1937 are Richard Buchanan Holman of Rye, N. Y.; Gordon Michler of London, England;

David Schenker, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, asserted today that the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation controlled or was able to exert substantial influence over a $1,694,494,103 industrial and financial empire in 1929.

The Roxy will receive from Twentieth Century-Fox this morning a comedy romance, "Fifty Roads to Town," featuring Don Ameche, Ann Sothern, Slim Summerville, Stepin Fetchit and Jane Darwell....Beniamino Gigli comes tonight to the screen of the Fiftyfifth Street Playhouse as the star of "Forever Yours,"

Production of steel has declined this week to 77 1/2 per cent of capacity, the lowest rate at which the industry as a whole has operated this year, compared with a revised figure of 85 per cent for last week, according to Iron Age. The sharp drop is attributed to the strikes that have wholly or partially shut plants of three large companies.

President Roosevelt called upon Congress today to take more care in legislation creating government positions to insure that, except for policy-making posts, they shall be subject to the merit system.
Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Hamlin Blake of this place and Sugar Hill, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Stanley Blake, to William George Cullimore of Englewood.
The members of the Japanese Economic Mission were received as guests of honor here yesterday at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Miss Althea McCammon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic J. McCammon of 167 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, has selected June 26 for the date of her marriage to Roland Offerman Rasch, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. William Rasch, also of Brooklyn and North Haven, Sag Harbor, L. I. The Rev. Allan MacRossie, uncle of the prospective bride, will perform the ceremony at noon at Sherry's. Only near relatives will be present.

A private settlement in the $500,000 suit brought against William F. Kenny, contractor, and his son, Thomas A. Kenny, was reached yesterday in Supreme Court during a recess in the trial. The compromise stipulated that its terms would not be revealed.
Frederick B. Snite Jr., sleeping peacefully in his "iron lung," today completed another 160 miles of the 12,000-mile journey to his Chicago home.
Morgan G. Hogge, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, who retired in 1934 after thirty-two years in the Chicago school system, died last night in the Swedish Covenant Hospital. He was 73 years old.

Bishop William T. Manning, Dean Milo H. Gates of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and members of the faculty and alumni of Trinity School joined last night in a testimonial dinner to the Rev. Dr. Lawrence T. Cole, rector of the school, who is retiring after thirty-four years of service.

Education plays a greater part in national and community life at the present time than ever before, Dr. William E. Grady, Associate Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday at the twenty-eighth annual commencement exercises of the Mills School for Kindergarten-Primary Teachers, held at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

A copy of the shrine in the Library of Congress which contains the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence was unveiled yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in Bloomingdale's department store as part of the program of the Constitution Sesquicentennial Commission.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $638,970,274 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on June 1 was $41.27, compared with $41.80 at the beginning of May.

A rise of $88,000,000 in the volume of money in circulation in the week ended on Wednesday was chiefly responsible for a decline of $80,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, according to the weekly banking statistics issued yesterday by the system.

Use of recording machines for candidates taking the oral speech examinations for teaching positions was recommended yesterday in a report submitted to Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, by a special committee appointed last September to investigate their value.

The right of holders of debentures of the International Match Company who have not assented to the plan of liquidation to exchange their debentures for voting-trust certificates will expire on June 21, the International Match Realization Company, Ltd., announced yesterday.

The New York Athletic Club, which has been running the threequarter-mile race as a feature of its annual Spring track and field games with the avowed intention of having it serve as a vehicle for a world record, may attain that objective tomorrow at Travers Island when the 139th meet of the club is staged.

Another victim of Sunday afternoon's clash between pickets and police outside the South Chicago plant of the Republic Steel Corporation died today as 7,000 strikers and their sympathizers took part in a mass funeral for three of the seven killed in the riot.

The 27,000th baby to be born in the Woman's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street, since the institution established its present location in 1910 was born Wednesday afternoon at 2:24 o'clock, it was announced yesterday by the United Hospital Fund of New York.
Movements or the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

" Enemies of the people" have penetrated into Osoaviakhim, the huge organization devoted to building up the Soviet Union's military reserves by training civilians and youth of pre-military age in many tactical branches, especially aviation, parachuting and chemical defense.

Mrs. Ruth D. Hart of 129 East Tenth Street brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to invalidate the Reno divorce obtained in 1935 by Boies C. Hart, her former husband. Mr. Hart is a vice president of the National City Bank.

Dr. and Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour have left the Hotel Gramercy Park to pass the Summer in Pawling, N. Y. Mrs. John R. Drexel Jr. of Pinehurst, N. C., is at the Gotham. Wolmar Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, is at the Ritz-Carlton from Washington.

Alfred E. Smith, whose picture was taken down in many Tammany clubhouses last year when he bolted the Democratic national ticket, has two pictures in a 138-page booklet issued yesterday by the Society of Tammany, or Columbian Order.

Fifty-one insignia were awarded to members of the Brooklyn College varsity baseball, tennis and track squads and a total of twenty-eight medals were granted to participants in intramural basketball, handball, track, wrestling and boxing,tournaments, according to the list released by Louis R. Oshins, business manager of athletics yesterday.
Homers by Zeke Bonura and Tony Piet and the wildness of four Boston pitchers enabled- the White Sox to score their fifth straight victory, 11 to 4, over the Red Sox today.

While the pilot was warming up an airplane in which to rush a doctor and nurse to his side, word was received today here that Gordon T. Finch, vice president of Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd., investment bankers, had died at his Summer home in Muskoka. His age was 52. He died of a heart ailment.

A "cooperative direct-action" plan by manufacturers to improve conditions in the millinery industry, which will feature standardizing of discounts at 2 per cent instead of 8 to 10 per cent, together with more stringent control of merchandise returns and elimination of secret rebates, is being developed by the Eastern Women's Headwear Associtation, whose 250 members represent from 50 to 60 per cent of the annual millinery production, it was learned here yesterday.

The Presbyterian Church of America, after hours of debate this afternoon, rejected an overture calling upon its members to recognize and practice "total abstinence" from intoxicants as the "only true principle of temperance."

President Roosevelt's proposal for minimum wage and maximum hour legislation appeared headed for trouble today when members of the Joint Congressional Committee considering the Black-Connery bill said they would fight for authority to restrict imports, if necessary to protect manufacturers from foreign competition.

The Rev. Joseph L. Lucas, who for the past ten years has been conducting and establishing Jesuit missions in the Philippine Islands, will be guest of honor tonight at a reception, entertainment and dance given by the Philippine Mission Bureau of New York at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Miss Mildred Florence Peck, daughter of Mrs. Tallcott Moore Peck of Jackson Heights and the late Mr. Peck, was married to Harry Hull St. Clair of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hull St. Clair, last night by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, in his study.

John Henry Lewis, Phoenix, Ariz., Negro, successfully defended his lightheavyweight crown tonight by gaining a technical knockout over Bob Olin of New York in the eighth round of their scheduled fifteen-round fight.

The new municipal ferryboat Mary Murray was launched yesterday afternoon at the shipyard of United Dry Docks, Inc., at Mariners Harbor, S. I., in the presence of Mayor La Guardia, Commissioner of Plant and Structures F. J. H. Kracke, and about 500 spectators.

" We are two in this movementGeneral Franco and I." These were General Emilio Mola's words when, on July 26, 1936, General Francisco Franco, the Rebel Generalissimo of the Spanish Civil War, crossed from Morocco to Algeciras and advanced toward Malaga. He was one of the first Rebel generals who formally named General Franco their Generalissimo and declared he would be dictator when they captured Madrid.

Among the leases of space for business purposes reported yesterday by brokers was one for three floors, comprising about 12,000 square feet, made by Edward Garratt, Inc., furniture dealer and interior decorator, in 160 East Fiftysixth Street, through Butler Baldwin, Inc., broker.

Prince Fumitaka Konoye, '38, of Tokyo, son of Japan's new Premier, Prince Fumumaro Konoye, has been elected captain of the Princeton University golf team for the coming year, the retiring captain, R. Burton Parker, '37, of Bellevue, Pa., announced today.

" Industry and business are suffering from entirely too much apprehension and misinformation about the Robinson-Patman act," Judge Edwin Lamar Davis, member of the Federal Trade Commission, today told delegates to the National Conference of Sales Executives who are holding a two-day session at the Stevens Hotel.

Within twentyfour hours after the death of his father-in-law, Albert Schofield of Malden, husband of Judge Emma Fall Schofield, died today at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in Medford of spinal meningitis. His age was 51. Judge Schofield's father, former Mayor George Howard Fall of Malden, died yesterday.

Belle Livingston, hostess of lavishly furnished night clubs during prohibition and now the occupant of two rooms in a furnished rooming house at 205 East Sixty-third Street, near Third Avenue, was slightly injured at 11:50 o'clock last night when she was thrown to the pavement after the sleeve of her dress was caught in the handle of a passing automobile as she was walking across Seventh Avenue at Fifty-fourth Street.
The Barnard School for Girls, 554 Fort Washington Avenue, will hold graduation exercises this morning for a class of twenty-one. The Rev. Dr. Tagart Steele, vicar of the Chapel of the Intercession,

Mrs. A. Spencer Jennings gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carltonfor Mrs. Walter Gibb, who returned from London on the Queen Mary. Other guests were Mrs. Charles D. Armstrong, Mrs. William Van -A. Hester, Mrs. Percy Grey and Mrs. George A. Wyeth. In the luncheon party there of Mrs. Richard H. Swartwout were Mrs. Joseph B. Long and Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips.

Miss Clare Baxter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Baxter of Brooklyn and Bay Shore, L.I., was married yesterday to Norman Hilborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hedley Herbert Hilborn of Brooklyn and Belle Terre, L. I. The Rev.

To those aware of the restraining role played by the army on the National Socialist regime in Germany, the visit of Marshal VON BLOMBERG to Rome does not seem calculated to aggravate the threatening situation arising out of the joint action of Germany and Italy in withdrawing from the Spanish Non-Intervention Committee.

A resolution urging the repeal of the capital gains tax as an "invitation to tax dodgers" was adopted yesterday at the Congress of Amer-. ican Enterprise at Carnegie Hall, at which- public officials and industrial leaders conferred on the problem of educating the public in the fundamental position that private enterprise occupies in the American economy.
The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended June 3 were announced today: COLONEL Barker, F. A., Washington, D. C., on May 26 ordered home, to retire July 1.
Most oil companies operating in the metropolitan area of New York City have fixed the maximum price for Nos. 2 and 4 heating oil for
Elmer J. Smith, a teacher in district and private schools in Rochester and Western New York towns for more than forty years, died today at the age of 88.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 1; CAPTAIN Thibault, I. at, Third Naval District, to instruction at the Naval War College, Newport, R. I.

William O. Douglas, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged today legislation to reform the nation's bankruptcy laws to protect investors in financially distressed corporate concerns from exploitation by "reorganization adventurers."

Arthur C. Lang, 53 years old, of Old Lyme, Conn., was killed at 8:30 A. M. yesterday in a plunge from the window of a room on the seventh floor of the Hotel Holley, at 36 Washington Square. Mr. Lang was a retired business man, having resigned as a vice president of the Gold Dust Corporation, a soap concern, about ten years ago.

The reported proposal of Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador to London, following the Deutschland and Almeria incidents, that British, French, German and Italian warships be bound to collective reprisals should any one of them be attacked,

James Howard Whitty, owner of the world's largest general collection of the writings of Edgar Allan Poe and one of the nation's outstanding authorities on the life of the poet, died last night at his home here at the age of 78. His death followed an attack of pneumonia.

Proportional representation may have its defects, but no greater compliment has been paid to one of its chief advantages than the persistency with which its introduction has been fought in this city by the Tammany machine.

Declines in grains, livestock and meats have carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices lower again, the index dropping to 142.5 on Tuesday from 143.4 (revised) the Tuesday previous.

The Scrap Export Associates of America, with offices at 350 Fifth Avenue, New York, has filed papers with the Federal Trade Commission under the export trade act, which grants exemption from the antitrust laws to an association solely engaged in export trade.

A total of $6,047.88 has been contributed to the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army by policemen, mailmen, firemen and sanitation employes in this city, it was announced last night by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the appeal.

PARNELL, from the play by the late Elsie T. Schauffler; screen adaptation by John Van Druten and S. N. Behrman; musical score by Dr. William Axt ; directed and produced by John M. Stahl for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. At the Capitol.
When the wedding breakfast was over after the marriage of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield today, twenty-two newspaper men and women passed the gate of the Chateau de Cande.

The receiver of the Wisconsin Central Railway has accepted the bid of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis of $1,200,000 and interest plus a premium of $200 for certificates bearing a dividend rate of 3 1/2 per cent, it was learned today.

Stuttering need not appear only in a person's speech but frequently is found in the way he drives an automobile, plays a piano, operates a typewriter or plays golf, according to Dr. James Sonnett Greene, medical director of the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, New York.

Upon completion of the present plans for financing, the directors of the Food Machinery Corporation intend to increase the dividend rate on the common stock and, if possible, to avoid the distribution of preferred shares as a dividend, John D. Crummey, president, stated in a letter sent yesterday to stockholders.

While the Federal Government's investigation of the disability insurance racket continued secretly in grand jury chambers yesterday, it was disclosed that Dr. John Wyckoff, dean of the New York University Medical College, who -died on Tuesday, had been an unwitting tool in three cases of false claims against-insurance companies.

Baxter St, 145, 25.7x100, also Mulberry St, 81-83, 49.8x100.4, also Mulberry St. 89, 25.4x100; Pasquale Nappi to Alphonse De Lucia, 3,611 Ave J, Brooklyn. Houston St., 434 E, n s, 20x105.10; Bowery Savings Bank to Bessie Rosenberg, 67-45 75th St, Middle Village, L. I., and Max VM. Salick, 68-10 79th St, Middle Village, L. I. ($3).
The Museum of Modern Art began moving yesterday from its present quarters at 11 West Fiftythird Street to 9 Rockefeller Plaza, newest building in Rockefeller Center.

Characterizing them as "pirate photographers" and members of a "racket," Magistrate Curran in Yorkville Court fined two street photographers $10 each yesterday on charges of violating a city ordinance against littering the streets.

With a rousing reception befitting its triumphant success the Egyptian delegation was welcomed home today from Geneva. Tens of thousands at Alexandria greeted Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha and Makram Ebeid Pasha, Minister of Finance,

Total revenue from sales In March to ultimate consumers of electricity by the electric light and power industry aggregated $177,579,300, against $165,650,200 in March, 1936, an increase of 7.2 per cent, according to the Edison Electric Institute.

" Hamlet" was presented today in the great courtyard of Kronborg Castle, Shakespeare's own setting, under the frowning castle walls and fantastic pinnacles, by the Old Vic Company of London, before 1,800 spectators.

More than twice as many new leases and renewals of old leases have been closed for apartments in the Croydon, at 12 East Eightysixth Street, thus far this year as were closed in the same period of 1936, according to Wilbur T. Emerson, managing director.

Enthused not only by the number of entries that have been received but also over the new members who have joined the organization, the United Hunts Racing Association expects its Spring meeting at Roslyn, L. I., a week from tomorrow to be one of the beat in years.

Some contradictions 'in stories by one of the government's most important witnesses were developed by the defense in the Parker conspiracy trial today, as more "alibi" witnesses insisted that' Ellis H. Parker Sr.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to fluctuate within narrow limits, and under a light volume of business they ended with losses of 5 to 7 points. Owing to the widest spread of the season in the July position between Livqrpool and New York and steady foreign buying, resistance developed on slight recessions so that prices failed to move far in either direction.
The six-story warehouse at 249-55 West Seventeenth Street through to 236-42 West Eighteenth Street has been leased by Gimbel Brothers to Marshall Field Co. for a shipping center.

The marriage of Miss Leona Lewis of Elwood, Ind., to Dr. Oscar Riddle of Oyster Bay, L. I., noted member of the research staff of the Carnegie Station for Experimental Evolution at Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., took place here yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Emmy Lou Asch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Asch of this city, to Howard L. Lilienthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lilienthal, also of New York.

Maurice Wertheim, investment banker, who bought The Nation, a weekly magazine, from Oswald Garrison Villard two years ago for the Civic Aid Foundation, a nonprofit organization established and controlled by him, announced yesterday its sale to Freda Kirchwey, one of its editors.

Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College will give the commencement address this morning at the exercises of St. Agatha Episcopal School for Girls, West End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street. Miss Muriel Bowden, headmistress, will confer the diplomas and the Emma G. Sebring college scholarship. The Very Rev. Dr. Milo H.

Miss Ruth Bayley Shanley, daugnter of Mrs. Bernard M. Shanley Jr. of this place, was married this morning to William Howe Davis, son of Mrs. Thomas A. Davis of Orange and the late Judge Davis, in the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows here.

The New York Curb Exchange has received a copy of the National Leather Company's final notice to its holders of common shares that the offer to exchange ten shares of common stock for one share of capital stock in the A. C. Lawrence Leather Company will expire on June 17, after which the common shares of National Leather will be of no value.

Pensioned ON HIS OWN APPLICATION PATROLMAN James J. Trainor, 46th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 5, 1906. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-William C. Wood, from 19th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 1 day.

SALAMANCA -- General Emilio Mola, Rebel commander in the north, and four others were killed when their airplane struck a hillside near Burgos in a fog. The northern command was divided by General Franco.

Bryant Equities, Inc., represented by Abraham L. Sobil, attorney, sold to the Sabog Realty Corporation the apartment house for seventytwo families at 1,006 Gerard Avenue, northeast corner of 164th Street, the Bronx.

For the first time in fifteen weeks the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City increased their holdings of direct obligations of the United States Government in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks issued yesterday.

The Senators took advantage of the wildness of Jake Wade and Vic Sorrell, Detroit pitchers, to even the series with a 5-to-4 victory today, A pass issued to Buddy Lewis by Sorrell in the eighth inning forced Joe Kuhel across the plate with the winning run. The defeat sent the Tigers to fourth place.

Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury announced today that $800,000,000 of Treasury notes would be offered on Monday as the Treasury's June financing program. The proceeds will go into the working balance of the Treasury's general fund which, it is now estimated, will be about $1,000,000,000 at the end of the fiscal year on June 30.

Japan's sudden retreat from her belligerent stand over the Swatow incident is now found to have been due to the fact that the entire case collapsed abruptly when Kiyoshi Aoyama, a Japanese policeman, confessed he had started the trouble.

A few days ago Mr. HOWARD W. BLAKESLEE of The Associated Press delivered the commencement address of the Medical College of Virginia. It is not the first time that he and other newsmen who have made the interpretation of science their specialty have been thus honored by technical institutions.

Manufacturing concerns paid the largest taxes on excess profits in 1934, with trade and financial groups following in order, according to a break down of taxes on incomes and excess profits for that year made pub lic by Secretary Morgenthau.

The monetary gold stocks of the United States have passed another "billion dollar mark," reaching a total of $12,027,000,000 on Wednesday. This total reflects an increase of $5,198,000,000, or more than 76 per cent, over the total of $6,829,000,000 in existence on Jan. 31, 1934, immediately after the revaluation of the dollar.

In appreciation of the services of President Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez to El Salvador, a motion was made in Congress today to place a bronze plaque in the Hall of Congress bearing a quotation from his last message to Congress.
Chicago at New York (2)-French and Carleton vs. Hubbell and Castleman. St. Louis at Brooklyn-Weiland vs. Hamlin. Pittsburgh at Boston-Bowman vs. MacFayden.

Acting as a voluntary mediator, Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky helped yesterday to settle a four-month-old strike that had resulted in fifty-nine arrests. The strike was at Stanley's Restaurant, 2,726 Broadway.

United States Representative Charles D. Millard of Tarrytown was chosen by the executive committee of the Westchester County Republican Committee this evening as its candidate for Surrogate in the November election. Surrogate William J. Sheils of New Rochelle, a Democrat, now occupies the office.

That high-geared Yankee machine stalled at League Park today. Everything went wrong. Lefty Vernon Gomez was not in form. The machine hit into several double plays. Mel Harder had one of his best days and to the joy of about 7,000 persons, downed the Yankees for the Indians, 6 to 2.

Mrs. William W. Bishop, the former Harriett Warne of Detroit, will represent the class of '67, first graduating class at Vassar College, at the Alumnae and Class Day exercises on Saturday, at which 800 alumnae, the largest number in the college history, are expected.

Mike Cestone, Montclair letter carrier, reached the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship today when he eliminated Charley Whitehead of Plainfield, defending champion, 2 and 1, at the Ridgewood Country Club. Cestone's triumph capped a day of startling upsets.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Miss Margaret Rosseland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Rosseland of this place, and Edgar Jurrien van Dyk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob van Dyk of Detroit, were married this afternoon in Prospect Presbyterian Church in Maplewood.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while total gold holdings were at the lowest.

Nature has given recurrent and poignant warnings through dust storms, floods and droughts that we must act while there-is yet time if we would preserve for ourselves and our posterity the natural sources of a virile national life.
The defending champion and three other top-ranking contenders gained the quarter-finals of the women's trans-Mississippi golf tourney today.

Miss Josephine Drexel Henry daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Seto?? Henry of Pen Ryn, Andalusia, Pa., and Joseph Wharton Lippincott Jr., whose engagement was announced in March, will be married on the afternoon of June 18 in St. Michael's Church, Torresdale, Pa. The Rev. John La Farge will perform the ceremony.

The House passed today the Dies "hot oil" bill by a vote of 188 to 92 and then substituted its bill for that passed by the Senate, thus paving the way for a conference over differences, which relate mainly to the time to which the 1935 law will be extended.

Max Schmeling's "one-man fight" was held yesterday at the New York State Athletic Commission meeting, and after a bruising session that had its repercussions long after he left the board's headquarters, the German ex-heavyweight champion admitted himself a beaten man.

Miss Christine Murdoch Kendrick, daughter of Mrs. Murdoch Kendrick of Philadelphia and Tinybrook, Strafford, was married this afternoon to Dr. Craig Wright Muckle of Haverford, son of the late Colonel and Mrs. John S. Muckle at Tinybrook. The Rev. Howard Weir of Holy Trinity Church officiated.
An extra dividend of 60 cents has been voted on the common stock of the Brown Fence and Wire Company. With this payment, the company will have paid $1.20 for the fiscal year which ends on June 30.
President Roosevelt sent today to the Senate for confirmation the nomination of James M. Landis for reappointment as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Emil C. Von Bergen, formerly a member of H. L. 42, residing at 319 E. 234th St., Bronx, died June 2. Funeral will take place from St. John's Lutheran Church. 1,343 Fulton Avenue, Bronx, at 10 A. M., Saturday, June 5. The Deputy Chief of the 7th Division shall detail one Captain, one Lieutenant and twelve Firemen, as funeral escort.
THE title of the running broad farce should have been "No Contest, or the Import of Missing Men." The cast of characters included the revered military men of the New York State Athletic Commission:

Immediate passage of the WagnerSteagall bill for slum clearance and low-cost housing to forestall a national housing emergency which, they said, might involve wholesale evictions, rent strikes, disease and riot, was demanded today by five heads of city and State housing authorities, meeting here under the auspices of the newly formed American Federation of Housing Officials.

Two pair of dance programs will be presented during this season of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts. The Mordkin Ballet will appear Friday and Saturday nights, July 16 and 17, and the Philadelphia Ballet on Thursday and Friday nights, July 29 and 30.

Reorganization of the life-saving worse of the Boston division of the United States Coast Guard along lines already under way in the New York and Norfolk divisions was ordered today by Rear Admiral R. R. Waesche, commandant.

The maximum sentence of twentynine to thirty years at hard labor in State prison was imposed today on Gladys MacKnight and her erstwhile admirer, Donald Wightman, who one week ago were convicted by a jury of second-degree murder, resulting from the hatchet slaying of Gladys's mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight, in her home in Bayonne last July 31.

The Interstate Light and Power Company of Galena, Ill., a subsidiary of the Northern States Power Company of Minneapolis, a unit in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Act of 1935.
The Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield, the American-born woman for whom he renounced the throne of England, became man and wife in this ancient chateau at noon today.

A recommendation for an "immediate investigation" of service contracts between the Niagara Falls Power Company and the Aluminum Company of America was considered today by the Public Service Commission. The recommendation was made in an opinion by Commissioner Maurice C. Burritt and endorsed by a four-to-one vote of the commission.

Bishop John A. Duffy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Buffalo conferred degrees and scholastic honors yesterday afternoon on twenty-five seniors at the commencement of Notre Dame College, on Grymes Hill, S. I.
Radio continued to score the sharpest gains in advertising volume during May, with magazines following and newspapers third, according to a compilation made yesterday.

KINGS BATCHER, ELLA (Oct. 10, 1936). Gross assets, $29,671; net, $26,798. To Charles Hallenbeck, $500; John G., Allan B. and Donald H. Surpless, $333 each; Hortense Ross and Red Star Animal Relief, $500 each; Paula V. Vance, $100; cousin, Lena Haskell, Belle Pierson. $3,000 each and personal property each;

Bank clearings for the last week were irregular as a result of the Decoration Day holiday and firstof-the-month settlements. Despite the holidays in the stock market on May 29 and May 31 the total for New York showed a gain over the preceding week, while all other centers declined.
The "hiring and firing" of French labor may soon be regulated by commissions composed equally of employers and workers.

Special Master Howard B. Lewis denied today a petition of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company for the right to intervene in the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company's reorganization proceedings under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The following additional applications from New York City for registration as broker or dealer in the over-thecounter market were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission (symbols: S, sole proprietor; P, partnership; C, corporation).

Miss Florence Mitchell Chance, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Mitchell Chance of Ardmore, was married this afternoon to Morton Gibbons-Neff Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Gibbons-Neff of Wynnewood. Canon Ernest C. Earp and the Rev. Louis Pitt performed the ceremony in the Church of the Redeemer at Bryn Mawr.
Prince Fumimaro Konoe completed today the formation of a Cabinet to replace the army-supported government of General Senjuro Hayashi, who resigned Monday under party pressure.

Another strike threat on the B. M. T. subway loomed last night as 6,000 day employes of the transit company, meeting at Arcadia Hall, 918 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, voted unanimously to "call a stoppage of all employes" if certain alleged conditions were not remedied.

Miss Elsa Kroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar J. Kroll of this place, and John Bayard Cuningham of Brooklyn Heights, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Cuningham of Hamilton, Ohio, were married this afternoon in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John J. Moment, the pastor, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. W. A. Beardsley of Hartford, Conn.

Utility executives attending the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute voiced criticism of the government's power program today. The speakers included Charles W. Kellogg, president of the institute;

Retail sales of 1,502,963 passenger cars and trucks in the first four months of 1937, topping the record of any previous corresponding period in the motor car industry, were reported today to the Automobile Manufacturers Association meeting here.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

Secretary MORGENTHAU'S announcement yesterday, that the Government will offer $800,000,000 Treasury notes at the quarterly June financing, named a considerably larger figure than the market had expected.
Edward J. Flynn, Bronx County leader, and Frank V. Kelly, head of the Brooklyn Democratic organization, conferred with President Roosevelt today on the New York City Mayoralty situation.

Major. Gen. John J. Phelan of New York, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, will receive an annual salary of $7,500 for his services under a bill of Senator Crawford of Brooklyn, signed today by Governor Lehman.

Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister, started his inspection of the Italian armed forces this morning by watching an impressive aerial display at Furbara in the presence of King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Benito Mussolini.

Stocks closed steady in second slowest trading in more than two years; turnover, 551,700 shares. United States Government obligations steady at fractionally higher levels, other bonds firm and dull; transactions, $7,313,400.

Professor Niven discovered buried pre-historic cities beneath the Valley of Mexico near Mexico, D. F., in 1911. Patient explorations of the sites for the next twenty years convinced Professor Niven that these were the settlements of the first human inhabitants of the country and perhaps in the world. He estimated the civilization was founded from 7,000 to 10,000 years ago, and that the people were Mongols.
During the week ended June 2 member bank reserve balances decreased $90,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves resulted from increases of $88,000,000 in money in circulation and $35,000,000 in

At the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute at Chicago Oscar H. Fogg, vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., was elected yesterday as a trustee of the institute for a three-year term.

Twenty patrolmen and five detectives who were caught in a raid last Friday night on an apartment at 438 St. Nicholas Avenue, were served yesterday with departmental charges accusing them of "participating in a gambling game known as craps, for money," and failing to report the existence of the game to their superiors.
Sir Abe Bailey's Cecil and James Bank's His Grace ran a dead heat in the Coronation Cup over the full Derby route at Epsom Downs today. Lord Ivor Churchill's Chrysler was third, three lengths behind.

Alvin E. Dodd was re-elected president of the American Management Association at its annual meeting at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday and James 0. McKinsey, chairman of Marshall Field Co., was reelected chairman of the board. Mr.

Adoption of a plan under which various corporations which have functioned as associates of General Mills, Inc., discontinue their corporate identities was announced yesterday by James F. Bell, chairman of the board.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 2 unless specified: At Annapolis: New York, June 3; Claxtot. At Nawiliwill: Oglala, Whippoorwill. At San Diego, June 3: Sand Piper, Wrlht. Balch, Boston Yard to sea. Paul Jones, at Chefoo, June 3. Leary, Washington Yard. Mahan, at New York Yard. Marblehead, at Lahaina Roads. Omaha, Guantanamo to Santiago, Cuba, June .3.

Representatives of thirteen maritime labor unions with a total membership said to range from 200,000 to 250,000 men employed on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and the Great Lakes, organized the American Marine Labor Council last night for the avowed purpose of "keeping communism out of the American shipping industry."

Gold to the value of $16,003,000 was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here as record-breaking dehoarding of that metal took place in London and rumors of an impending reduction in the price of the metal again swept the financial markets with a persistence that official denials seemed unable to discourage.

Pig iron output in May, according to The Iron Age, totaled 3,520,000 gross tons, although this is subject to revision because of difficulty experienced at strike-bound plants in arriving at accurate figures.

Plans for a 280-acre amusement sectionn for the New York World's Fair, to be built in a loop around Meadow Lake on the eastern portion of the ground, were announced yesterday by Grover Whalen, president.

Miss Marjorie Ruth Korn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Korn of 101 Central Park West, was married to Lester Osterman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Osterman, also of this city, last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton, where the marriage of the bride's parents also took place. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Franklin Rosenblum.

For many centuries the North Pole has attracted and awed humanity. Daring men who have sought to reach it either perished or returned without having attained it. Nevertheless, they have enriched humanity with new knowledge.

The second performance of the Police Department's show and demonstration went off smoothly last night before 13,000 spectators in Madison Square Garden. The crowd watched excitedly while veteran mounted and motorcycle squads manoeuvred in the arena, and radio and emergency police displayed their methods of handling various difficult situations.
Members of Mary Alexander Chapter, Children of the Confederacy, of Greenwich held a party at the Riverside Yacht Club here this afternoon in recognition of the birthday of Jefferson Davis.
Electric power output increased last week, with the seasonal factor unchanged, and the adjusted index advanced to 106.6 from 106.4. It was 101.2 for the week ended May 30, 1936.
A royal relative of the Duke of Windsor spent the day- of the Duke's wedding quietly filing papers in the office here where he works.

Vast changes are in prospect for the upper East Side residential area and the new East River Drive will be a factor In promoting the improvement and expansion of this district, in the opinion of Vincent Astor, one of the largest individual property owners in Manhattan.

The Bank of Canada's ratio of net reserve rose to 60.22 per cent yesterday from 59.27 on the previous Wednesday, according to the weekly statement issued today. Total reserve advanced to $207,363,868 from $204,714,966, because of increased holdings of sterling and dollars.

Large increases in the funds deposited with savings and loan associa.tions in New York State and in the volume of mortgage loans made by them during April are shown by reports from 107 associations, according to Zebulon V. Woodard, executive secretary of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

Following is the text of the address that Mayor Charles Mercier of Monts delivered today to Edward of Windsor and the Duchess of Windsor, the former Wallis Warfield, after he had made them man and wife:
The thirty-eighth annual graduating exercises of Miss Fine's School will be held tomorrow morning in the school auditorium.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended June 2 were announced today: Harding, District Commander, S. X. (retired), died at Cambridge, Mass. Fahey, Lt. E. E., Cape May Air Station, to Biloxl Air Station. Oct. 1. Harding, Lt. J. F., Biloxi Air Station, to Salem Air Station, Oct. 1. Hesford, Lt. A. J., San Diego Air Station, to Naval Air Station. Pensacola, Fla., as instructor, Oct. 1.

A mass demonstration of how new teaching techniques can "rehabilitate" physically and socially handicapped children, in which seventeen blind boys and girls between the ages of 8 and 15 participated, marked the opening yesterday of the seventh annual meeting of the American academy of Pediatrics.
Mrs. Wallis Warfield wore a soft silk gown of "Wallis blue" today for her marriage to the Duke of Windsor - a creation in sweeping lines that accentuated her statuesque figure.
37th St., 313-21 W, 8-story brick loft and store building. 100x98.9; New York Savings Bank against 313-21 W 37th St Corp, due, $331,524; to plaintiff for $5,000.
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 95.8 from 93.8. It was 87.0 for the week ended May 30, 1936.

A growing revolt among the nation's outstanding automobile race drivers left uncertain today the participation of American pilots in the 300mile chase for $60,000 in prizes at Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island, July 3.
Stanley High, author and lecturer, will be the speaker tomorrow morning at the commencement exercises of Briarcliff Junior College here. Twenty-eight seniors will receive diplomas.

Mrs. Lucy E. Purdon, 43, wife of Rupert L. Purdon of New York, a retired army captain and president of Home Exposition, Inc., was found dead in the bathtub of her apartment at 1,028 Connecticut Avenue this afternoon, under circumstances which led officials to withhold judgment as to. the cause of death until after an autopsy tomorrow.
The old seven-story Gramercy exchange building of the New York Telephone Company at 61-63 Irving Place has been. sold to a client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.

The necessities of national defense and law and order must take precedence over all other considerations, "even over the narcotic evil," according to Uchiro Yokoyama, Japanese delegate on the League's Opium Advisory Committee.

Arnold G. Chapman, former chief engineer of the Port of Albany, died last evening in his room at the Hotel Commodore. Mr. Chapman was stricken with a heart attack two weeks ago after coming here to attend a meeting of the Society of Professional Engineers.

These persons-guests or participants in the ceremony-saw the Duke of Windsor take Mrs. Wallis Warfield as his Duchess today: Baron and Baroness Eugene de Rothschild, Edward's former hosts at Enzesfeld, Austria.

Showing that at times the best way to travel at sea as well as on land is to detour, Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee today won the second race of the preliminary trial series to select the defender of the America's Cup.
President Roosevelt proclaimed tonight that the United States is ready to cooperate with foreign nations "at all times" for the preservation of world peace.

George Whitney, member of the banking firm of J. P. Morgan Co., was resting comfortably last night at the Harkness Pavilion of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after undergoing an operation for appendicitis.

The stock markets were quiet and moderately firm today, influenced by the approaching end of the account. Giltedge issues were fairly steady, while German bonds were good in a generally idle foreign section. international stocks were weak and United States Steel and International Nickel turned downward.

Commencement exercises for eighty-seven graduates of the Fieldston School, the upper unit of the Ethical Culture schools, will be held this morning on the campus at Fieldston Road and Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, in the Riverdale section. The exercises will begin at 10:30 and will be followed at 11:30 by a reception to parents and friends of the grad. uates.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson set June 14 yesterday for the sale at public auction of the furniture and fixtures of The New York Woman, Inc., publishers of the magazine of that name, by the Underwriters Salvage Company.

Members of the Board of Elections held a special meeting yesterday to plan the Autumn election at which the new City Council will be elected through proportional representation, and voted to ask the Board of Estimate for $869,790 to finance the Council balloting.

The annual Spring promenade of the Peddie School will be held tomorrow night in the alumni gymnasium here. About 100 couples will attend the dance and spend the week-end at the school. Saturday night an informal dance will be given. On Saturday afternoon a baseball game and a tennis match will be held.

The total of contract awarded for engineering construction during the week ended yesterday was $35,606,000, according to The Engineering News-Record. Owing to the Memorial Day holiday intervening the week was short and there was a consequent drop of 18 per cent in awards as compared with the same week last year.

Murray H. Parres, reporter for The Belleville Daily Advocate, stuck to his story today that Dizzy Dean referred to National League President Ford Frick and Umpire George Barr as "the two biggest crooks in baseball," at a church dinner May 25.

Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Livingston Mills of 2 East Sixty-ninth Street and Woodbury, L. I., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Mills's daughter, Miss Dorothy Randolph Fell, to Howell van Gerbig of 11 East Sixty-ninth Street.

Passenger rates in the North Atlantic will be increased 5 per cent, it was announced yesterday. The change will be effective in cabin and tourist quarters July 19 on sailings eastbound from Canadian ports and July 26 from ports in the United States, and Sept. 20 and 27 on westbound sailings.

John J. O'Connell Jr. began testimony in the trial of eight men, charged with his 1933 abduction, by relating in Federal court late today how he was seized near his Albany (N. Y.) home and held for twenty-three days before ransom of $40,000 was paid.

Yale pounded two Wesleyan pitchers heavily today and triumphed, 14 to 1. Captain Larry Kelly furnished a colorful touch to the struggle by going to the mound in the ninth inning, during which Wesleyan's sole score was negotiated.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will participate this morning in the commencement exercises of the Todhunter School, of which she is associate principal She will introduce Hendrik Willem Van Loon, author, who will give the principal address.

The House of the Michigan Legislature passed, 63 to 31, and sent to the Senate today a bill, approved by Governor Frank Murphy, to establish a State Labor Relations Board and give the Governor power to seize and operate strikethreatened plants.
Mitchell Hepburn, Premier of Ontario, came tonight to an open break with William L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of the Dominion.

Miss Margaret Pillsbury, daughter of Horace Davis Pillsbury of Montecito, will be married to Lieutenant Frederick William Coleman 3d of Schofield Barracks, Honolulu, on July 12 in All Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church, Montecito, it was announced today.

J. H. Rivera, 37 years old, of 113 West Ninety-sixth Street, a Filipino bus boy who was employed at the Hamilton Sandwich Shop, 2,441 Broadway, confessed about 1 o'clock this morning, according to Assistant District Attorney Lawrence McManus, that he had admitted three other Filipinos, armed with pistols, to the shop early on Wednesday to rob the place.
Plans wer3 filed yesterday for alterations in the Hotel Pierre at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street, to cost $100,000. The changes will provide for shops and a cocktail lounge.

Fifteen students will graduate tonight at the commencement exercises of Franklin School, to be held in the Club House, 150 West Eightyfifth Street. Professor J. A. Krout of the History Department of Columbia University, will be the speaker.

Emmett A. Bristor, editor and publisher of The Passaic Daily Herald from 1915 to 1925, died at his home, 225 Gregory Avenue, today. Mr. Bristor, who was 59 years old, had been ill for more than fifteen years.

Spring conference of the International Trade Composition Association begins at the Hotel New Yorker this morning at 9:30 A. M. and continues all day and evening. Speakers: Ernest Trotter, Lucien Bernhard, Daniel Moscow, Robert L. Leslie, Joseph Kohan.

The Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed transfer and dividend disbursing agent for the 30,000 shares of $10 par preferred stock and the 1,200,000 shares of 10-cent par common stock of the Southwest Natural Gas Company. It also will exchange the stock of the new company for that of the old company.

Thomas E. Elder, former dean of the Mount Hermon School for Boys at Northfield, was held in $10,000 bail this morning for the July grand jury on a charge of assault with a dangerous weapon with intent to kill.

Four games, played between showers, comprised the Meadow Brook Club members' polo today, bringing into action many of the ranking players entered in the club championships. Tommy Hitchcock and Stewart Iglehart, the country's two ten-goal men, were in action.

Each of the following Reserve officers is ordered to active duty June 6 at Camp Dix, N. J., for training: Lt. Col. John L. Hascall, QM.-Res., 618 W. 7th St., Plainfield, N. J. 1st Lt. Charles H. Hale Jr., CW.-Res., G3 Unit 2, 40 Lexington St., Newarlc, N. J. lst Lt. James D. Prior, Inf-Res., 384 Turrell Ave., So. Orange. N. J.

The Seas Shipping Company, operator of the American flag Robin Line between Atlantic ports and South Africa, announced yesterday that it would meet the freight rate increases which the South African conference lines will put into effect on July 1.

A personal quarrel between the chief warden and his assistant in which prisoners took sides precipitated a riot in Matanzas jail today. Police and soldiers intervened and fired numerous shots into the air. Order was finally restored.

Every citizen of this city who cherishes liberty and democratic government must have been proud when he read Mayor LA GUARDIA'S address to the police on the occasion of the annual presentation of medals.

Amelia Earhart made a 750-mile hop over South American jungles today to get to Dutch Guiana and then had to ride twenty-five miles on a trolley-car. She brought her silvery monoplane down at the Zandery Airfield, twenty-five miles from Paramaribo, at 12:50 P. M.
The Public Service Commission approved yesterday the application of the Long Island Lighting Company for the issuance of $16,699,000 of refunding bonds.
The Lamport Manufacturing Supply Company, 511 Broadway, announced yesterday the purchase of one building in the old plant of the American Printing Company at Fall River, Mass.
Simon T. Patterson, Pittsburgh attorney, died today at his home here at the age of 52. He was born in Kittanning, a member of a pioneer Armstrong County family.

Gerard Ave (9-2487), s w cor MfcClellan St, 100x115, 1,117 Gerard Ave, Inc, to Andrews Equities, Inc. 204 E 10th St; mtg $215,000. Crotona Ave (11-3103), w s, 170 It s of 187th St, 87x80; Jaypol Realties, Inc. to Brite-Star Realty Corp, 2,705 Colden Ave; mtg $69,875. Harrison Ave (11-2868), w s, 571 it n of Morton P1, 30x100; John P. Griffith, referee, to Harlem Savings Bank.

In one of the largest demolition jobs. undertaken in Manhattan since 1929, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is tearing down four tall buildings occupying most of the west half of the block bounded by Madison and Fourth Avenues, Twenty-fifth and Twentysixth Streets, facing Madison Square.

Miss Ruth Dorothy Maloney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Maloney of New Haven, was married here this morning in St. Lawrence's Church to Joseph D. Bohan of New York, by the Rev. John K. O'Connor. The Rev. Josepn V. Stanford, a cousin of the bridegroom, was the celebrant of the nuptial mass.

At the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of Russell Sage College, President Meader reported that the college had added twelve members, including a freshman dean, to the faculty, and that the college enrollment reached a new high of 560 students during the year.

A variety of Manhattan deals announced yesterday included sales and leases of dwellings, flats and stores. Among the operators participating in the trading was Jacob Goodman, who purchased three buildings in Harlem from a savings bank.

Tributes to Richard Aldrich, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1902 to 1924 and critic emeritus thereafter, who died Wednesday morning in Rome, continued to arrive yesterday from various parts of this country as well as from Europe.

WE have had it before, and now we have it again--the story of the Constitution, its origins, friends, enemies, successes and failures. This time the narrator is Burton J. Hendrick, former Pulitzer Prize winner and author of several notable works in biography, including studies of Walter Hines Page and the Lee family of Virginia. The title is "Bulwark of the Republic: A Biography of the Constitution" (Little, Brown, $3.50).

A warning against "tinkering tendencies" in government was sounded today in an address to forty graduates of the Cornell Law School by J. du Pratt White, '90, of New York, vice chairman of the board of trustees, who spoke on "The Growth of Constitutionalism in the United States."
