Referring to Nazi persecution of Catholics and Protestants, Samuel Untermyer urged those religious groups today to join the Jewish boycott of German goods and services. He predicted that a united front would bankrupt the Hitler regime within six months.

Steps toward the creation of a National Council of Dress Manufacturers, composed of representatives of dress groups throughout the country, were taken yesterday at a conference held at the headquarters of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group, 1,440 Broadway.
President Lazaro Cardenas tonight failed Lo intervene and dictate a settlement of Mexico's nation-wide petroleum strike as he had declared he would yesterday.
Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe, the Tigers' ailing pitcher who has been the ace of the team's mound staff in recent seasons, left tonight for Miami, Fla., to consult a specialist.
Governor Lehman signed two bills today providing optional forms of government for the reorganization and modernization of counties outside of New York City.

The Theatre of Four Seasons, the first of the North Shore Summer playhouses to open its season, had a good-sized audience tonight for the first professional production in America of Ernst Toller's anti-war comedy, "No More Peace," under the direction of Charles Hopkins of the New York State Federal theatre projects.

Arthur W. Ricks, retired real estate and insurance broker, died today at his home here of an internal hemorrhage. Mr. Hicks, who was 68 years old, had sold his business in Summit, N. J., when he became ill many months ago. He was formerly president of the New Jersey Association of Underwriters and vice president of the National Association of Insurance Agents.

Colonel Robert McEwen, cattle and sheep breeder, died today at his home, Alloway Stock Farm, near Byron, at the age of 81. He was immediate past president of the Canadian Cooperative Wool Growers, having been its first president. For many years Colonel McEwen was president of the Stallion Enrollment Board.
Top-notch bowling enabled Middlesex to gain victory by an innings and 180 runs over Warwickshire in the English County cricket series today. The match started yesterday at Lord's.

William Taylor Davis, 17-year-old sophomore at the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and a nephew of Deems Taylor, has won the $1,000 scholarship for foreign study given annually by Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, it was announced by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University.

Enrique Carlos de la Casa, counselor of the Spanish Embassy, reported to the police today that negotiable coupons worth $14,000 and cashable June 15 had been stolen from his coat pocket in a downtown department store.

The Rev. Dr. Wynand Wichers, president of Hope College, Holland, Mich., was elected president of the Synod of the Reformed Church in America, which opened its 131st annual meeting here today. The Rev.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Juanita Decker of Tucson, Ariz., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Owen Decker of Elizabethtown, Ill., to Blair Duffy, also of Tucson, son of Mrs. William L. Duffy of this city

Beating a rainstorm and a field of seventy starters in the same motion, Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden clicked off an 80 for low gross honors in the women's WestchesterFairfield one-day golf tournament at the Hudson River Country Club today. Matching women's par on the outgoing nine, she encountered slight trouble on the inward journey to finish four over standard figures.
Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a rise of 5 per cent for the week ended May 29, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

Manhattan HAGGERTY, SARA FRANCES (May 26). Estate, $5,000. To Nellie H. Love, sister, executrix, 327 Central Park West. HERSHKOWITZ. FANNIE (May 23). Estate, $3,000. To Anna H. Marton, daughter, 522 W. 112th St., personal property and residue ; four sons $25 each. William Marton, son-in-law, 522 W. 112th St., executor.

Tentative British proposals for a draft scheme of enhanced security under which warships of Germany and Italy can resume their duties in the international patrol of the Spanish seacoast were communicated today to those powers and to France.

The National Distillers Products Corporation paid last year to Seton Porter. president and director, $172,411, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. D. K. Weiskopf, director and vice president, drew $83,833, and 0. H. Wathen, director, $75,120.

Mrs. J. J. Schieffelin entered the final round of the annual women's invitation net tourney at the Manursing Island Club today when she defeated Mrs. Walter Martin, 6-0, 6-4. Seeded second, Mrs. Schieffelin gained the semi-final by beating Mrs. Waring Park, 6-3, 6-2, in her first match of the day.

The New York City Housing Authority has sent a memoranduin to Governor Lehman, urging him to veto the bill introduced by Assemblyman Farbstein, known as Assembly Int. No. 698, Pr. No. 2,765, on the basis that if enacted into law the measure might cost New York City taxpayers about $12,000,000 a year.
Stocks closed higher, with industrial shares strongest; turnover, 779,290 shares. All groups of bonds steady and mixed in dull trading; transactions, $8,488,600.
The battleships New York, Arkansas and Wyoming, with 1,020 midshipmen aboard, left here today on a 13,520-mile cruise to Europe. They will be sixty days at sea and twenty-five days in port.

Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean's indefinite suspension by President Ford Frick of the National League was lifted shortly before 1 P. M. yesterday and the Cardinal hurler will be on the mound at Philadelphia today.
Simling bravely against the ordeal of a journey to Chicago in an "iron lung," Frederick B. Snite Jr., 26year-old paralysis victim, today was wheeled into Shanghai General Hospital.
The Court of Appeals reversed today Common Pleas Judge Walter B. Wanamaker's contempt citation and $50 fine against Walter Morrow, editor of The Akron Times-Press.
Two hundred and twenty-six Germans have arrived here from Seville, Spain, and are proceeding home on the German liner Monte Pascoal.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Villa Maria Academy was observed yesterday at the graduation exercises of the acad??my on Country Club Road, Bronx. ??wenty-seven students received diplomas. Bishop Emmett Walsh of the Roman Catholic Diocese of South Carolina, presided and addressed the graduates.

New authorizations and commitments by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation rose in April to $114,663,093, the largest item being $60,000,000 for the metropolitan water district of Southern California, Los Angeles.

The Rev. William F. Anderson, retired Methodist Episcopal Bishop of Chattanooga and Cincinnati, and Mrs. Anderson, who were married in Cincinnati on June 9, 1887, yesterday celebrated their fiftieth anniversary at a reception in Ambrose Hall of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The reception was held .yesterday to allow their son and five daughters, some of whom live in other cities, to attend.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. routed a robber from his Harvard College house early today and led fellowstudents in a short pursuit of the invader. The incident was revealed tonight by police.

Mr. and Mrs. William Kiehm of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Bode Kiehm, to John Donald Langston, son of Mrs. Alma M. Langston of Bartlesville, Okla., and Lloyd H. Langston of New York.

The first round of the fight of Borough President Harvey of Queens to center in the hands of himself and some of the affected Queens local boards the control of lands adjacent to the Flushing Meadows site of the 1939 World's Fair was lost yesterday.
The Yanks have reached that point now where every time they lose a ball game they lose a valued member of the cast. Yesterday it was George Selkirk as the champions bowed to the Indians.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, received a cablegram on Thursday announcing that a meeting of the executive committee of the Lutheran World Convention was being called. It will take place in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, beginning on Aug. 29.

The close of this week's sessions of the Imperial Conference today found the prospects of an Anglo-American trade treaty at a new low point as delegates studied mounting indications of dominion agricultural and British industrial opposition.
Today importation from France to the Belmont in West Fortyeighth Street is "Maternite" (Mother Love), played by Francoise Rosay, Felix Oudart, Hella Muller and Alain.

The Furriers Joint Council announced yesterday that 3,000 members of Locals 101, 105, 110 and 115 of the International Fur Workers Union of the United States and Canada had authorized their officers to call a general stoppage of 13,000 fur workers in all fur shops of New York.

The Netherlands Government concluded today a trade accord with Germany providing for increased Netherland exports. The clearing arrangements with Germany have been unsatisfactory for years. In 1936 the arrears amounted to more than 40,000,000 florins and since were reduced to 20,000,000.

Below are given noninal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied- yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc:

The most important development in the field of pediatrics in the last year was the beginning of maternal and child health work through State agencies under the Social Security Act, according to a report presented yesterday to the seventh annual meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Dr. Henry F.
Johnny Deering, 21-year-old Detroit jockey, was thrown over his mount's head sand trampled today in the running of the fourth race at Suffolk Downs.

The steel strike in the Chicago area settled down today into an endurance contest between the independent producers and the workers who have walked out under the banner of the John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization for union recognition and a contract.

Miss Dorothy Hoffman Neely, daughter of Mrs. Charles Hoffman Neely of this place and the late Mr. Neely, was married this afternoon to Wilton Snowden Burton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger O. Burton, also of Bronxville, in Christ Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Harold Hohly performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. C. W. Robinson.
Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday thirty-three transfers of Roman Catholic priests in-the Archdiocese of New York, together with fortytwo assignments of recently ordained priests, as follows:

Four hundred children of Woodstock Township, coming from all seven villages making up the area, danced around a Maypole this afternoon as their part in the sesquicentennial celebration of the founding of the place.

Miss Octavia Hamilton, daughter of Mrs. James Hamilton of Detroit and the late Mr. Hamilton, was married this afternoon to Philip Ryerson, son of Mrs. W. Newton Ryerson of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. Ryerson, at the home of the bride's aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. William Pegram Gilmour, on Strawberry Hill.

Baltimore generated some intensive home-run power tonight to take both ends of a double-header from the Jersey City Giants, winning the twilight game, 6 to 5, and taking the nightcap, 4 to 3. Each game went an extra inning.

President ROOSEVELT indicated yesterday his agreement with Senator ROBINSON that there are seven measures on which action is desirable before the present session ends and Congress escapes from the heat of a Washington midsummer.

About 100 men and women, many of them unemployed of over 40 years of age, met last night in the International Building of Rockefeller Center to form an organization which will have as its avowed purpose to find work for the middle-aged jobless.
The Boston Bees took the series from the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates today as Jim Turner hurled fivehit ball for a 9-1 victory.

Patsy Gentile,' former properieter of the Park Lane Hotel barber shop for ten years and who served the Duke of Windsor, then the Prince of Wales, on the latter's visit to this country in 1924, died of a hemorrhage yesterday morning at his home, 35-28 101st Street, Flushing, at the age of 45. Mr. Gentile had been ill for about two years.

The Florence Nightingale Medal, highest award that can be made to members of the nursing profession, was presented today to Miss Ida F. Butler, director of the Red Cross Nursing Service, by Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American Red Cross, who acted for Max Huber of Geneva, president of the International Red Cross Committee.

An unidentified man fell dead and several persons were injured in a riot early. today at the Newberry Lumber and Chemical Company's plant here. Fists, clubs and brickbats were used as company employes, who have refused to strike, repulsed a group of striking woodsmen and lumber mill workers 'who came from Munising and marched on the plant at dawn.
A sitdown strike of 150 members of the crew caused the cancellation of the sailing tonight of the Peninsular Occidental liner Florida for Havana with 260 passengers.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended April 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges of $7,665,558, as compared with a net of $6,365,812 in the twelve months ended April 30, 1936, an increase of $1,299,856.

Amelia Earhart landed at this Northeast Brazil seaport today at 4:31 P. M. after a flight from Paramaribo, Dutch Guiana, on another leg of her hop around the world. She had flown approximately 1,628 miles since her take-off at 5:10 A. M., but was 287 miles short of her previously announced goal, Natal, Brazil.

Miss Jennie Bermingham, retired New York elementary school principal, died today at her home, 9 Belmont Place. She was about 70 years old. Miss Bermingham was the daughter of the late Twiss and Elizabeth Catherine Rutledge Bermingham.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Coburn Darling of Providence, R. I., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanore Hayden Darling, to F. Wilder Bellamy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Wilder Bellamy of Katonah, N. Y.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary-Jane Moore, daughter of Mrs. A. Howard Shaw of Darien, Conn., and Joseph A. Moore of 300 Park Avenue, to Daniel Hill Sangster of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Sangster of Los Angeles.

The Tishman Realty Construction Company has purchased the fourteen-story apartment house at 885 Park Avenue, northeast corner of Seventy-eighth Street, for cash over a first mortgage of $1,692,000, extended recently by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Members of the graduating class of the West Point Military Academy, numbering 250, will receive automobile driving tests beginning Monday and continuing for three days.
John Jacob Kraus of Paterson, N. J., an expert in fiber, died today of a heart ailment at the home of his brother, Arthur H. Kraus, in Needham.

Yielding only one hit, Tom Gorman, Power Memorial Academy southpaw, pitched his team to a 4-2 victory over Mount St. Michael yesterday at Dyckman Oval in a City C. H. S. A. A. semi-final clash. A double by Bill Sullivan in the third prevented the big moundsman from registering a no-hit performance.
The comforts of civilization got a bit mixed up here. When Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Carlson returned home at supper time she turned on the gas range. Water spouted out.

Miss Eleanor Meredith Allison, daughter of Mrs. T. Ellwood Allison of Conny Meade, Wallingford, and the late Mr. Allison, was married this evening to William B. Hubbard Jr., son of Mrs. William B. Hubbard of Cornwall, Conn., and Portsmouth, N. H., and the late Mr. Hubbard.

After spending the morning watching a sham fight staged near Allumiere by several large units of the Italian Army under actual war conditions with big guns and machine guns firing over the heads of the advancing troops, Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister, had a long conference in Rome this afternoon with Marshal Pietro Badoglio, head of the general staff of the Italian armed forces.

Dr. Frederick Jones Bliss, archaeologist and educator, died yesterday in a hospital here, after an illness of several years. He was 78 years old. A funeral service was held this morning in ,Ferncliff Cemetery, Westchester County, with the Rev. Daniel Bliss, a nephew, officiating. Burial will be in Jaffrey, N. H.

The city's efforts to advance its plans for the North Beach, Queens, seaplane base were temporarily blocked yesterday in the Board of Estimate when Controller Frank J. Taylor attacked the project as certain to cost $10,000,000, an expenditure which he contended would be "unnecessary and unwarranted."

Mrs. Bertha Cowlishaw Spitz, a leader in social, welfare and civic circles here, died yesterday at her home following a long illness. The wife of Joseph Spitz, assistant director of the New Jersey Rehabilitation Commission,

Madison Grant, late head of the New York Zoological Society, who died on May 30, left a bequest of $25,000 to the society in his will, which was filed for probate yesterday. The income is to be used for the creation of "The Grant Endowment Fund for the Protection of Wild Life."

Mrs. Wilhelmine Schleppegrell Keppler, an originator of kindergarten systems in this country, died Wednesday night at her home here. She was 72 years old. Mrs. Keppler was born in Charleston, S. C. She operated her first kindergarten in that city and, at the age of 30, was married to John Keppler, an instructor at the Porter Military Academy there.

The Legislature outlawed pari-mutuel wagering in Texas today and received word that Governor James V. Allred would continue his war on gambling. The youthful executive announced he would submit proposals to tighten laws against bookmaking, dograce betting and other gambling.
The most interesting aspect of M. Leon Blum's year in power is not its effect on France, where it has telescoped into a twelve-month period reforms that seem revolutionary because of their speed.

Mexico, the only nation in the New World openly supporting the Spanish Loyalists, has gone on record favoring "judicial, not violent settlements of international disputes," in an editorial published in El Nacional, which speaks with full authority for President Lazaro Cardenas and the Foreign Office.
The alumni of Dickinson College, in accordance with the traditions of Mermaid, Flagpole and Old Stone Steps, inducted the 133 members of the class of '37 into their number today.

Shorts in wheat covered freely in today's market on the Board of Trade here. Wheat has had a big decline both here and abroad, and the drop is believed to have discounted the improvement in the crop. With the possibility that rains may continue and make for wet harvest conditions in the Southwest, there was also a little broadening in the absorption of wheat on the setbacks by commission houses.

David J. McAuliffe, Deputy Police Commissioner, in charge of police in Brooklyn, gave assurance yesterday that his men would remain strictly neutral in labor situations which may arise in the borough.

After five years of rigorous Imprisonment at Alcatraz and Fort Leavenworth the easier routine on Governors Island seemed a "cinch" to Nathan T. Corn, a soldier convicted of forgery, and so did the possibilities of escape.
The Westchester Little Opera Company will present scenes in costume from "Carmen," "The Bartered Bride," "Il Trovatore" and "Faust" tonight in the County Center, White Plains.

Finley Peter Dunne, creator of "Mr. Dooley," left a net estate of $43,087 when he died April 24, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The estate was left to his widow, Mrs. Margaret Dunne.
Mr. and Mrs. Howard Constable of Princeton will be hosts at a tea tomorrow at the Present Day Club here in honor of their daughter, Miss Julia Ellsworth Constable.

A distribution to thirteen officials of the General Motors Corporation of an aggregate of 15,403 shares of common stock with a current market value of about $845,000 as bonuses was shown in the summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders for April made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Pulling away in the stretch as did her half-brother, Mid-Day Sun, in the Derby, Sir Victor Sassoon's Exhibitionnist today outclassed a field of thirteen 3-yearold fillies in the classic Oaks.
Our own World Fair will have an amusement section of 280 acres. That is a lot of ground, but if Mr' WHALEN keeps his promise there

A tremendous new mass of paper work has been imposed on the accounting departments of the railroads by the Social Security Laws of the Federal and State governments, it was reported today to the closing session of the forty-eighth annual meeting of the accounting division of the Association of American Railroads in the Hotel Traymore by H. J. Walker of Philadelphia, auditor of disbursements for the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 29 amounted to 794,855 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,579 cars, or 2 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 148,043 cars, or 22.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 232,173 cars, or 41.3 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

The Tigers, with a fourteen-hit assault on Pete Appleton and Ed Linke, topped by Hank Greenberg's thirteenth home run of the season, defeated Washington, 10 to 3, today to take the series two games to one.
After fluctuating narrowly until mid-afternoon yesterday, the stock market picked up strength gradualIy, to the accompaniment of increased trading.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman Le Roy Emmet of Erie, Pa., and this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lydia Field Emmet 2d, to Lewis Croxton Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Blair Williams of Cleveland.

Trading was fair. on most classes. The lamb market was strong to 50c higher and other classes of traefa meat, mostly unchanged from Thursdey's close. Kosher lamb opened higher, beef stronger, veal uneven but mostly steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Colonel Howard Thayer Kingsbury, a member of the law firm of Coudert Brothers and an authority on international and military law, died yesterday in his home at 116 East Seventieth Street, after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

The Spingarn Medal, awarded annually to an American Negro for "distinguished achievement," will be presented this year to Walter White, secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Oswald Garrison Villard, chairman of the award committee, announced yesterday.

The law of 1936 under which the Board of Education of New York City furnishes free transportation to some 141 physically handicapped pupils attending parochial schools was attacked as unconstitutional today in the Court of Appeals by Joseph Lewis, a taxpayer.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 2: REAR ADMIRAL Allen, W.- H., Washington, D. C., from Naval Operations to General Board, Navy Department. CAPTAIN Wadsworth, A. S., Destroyer Squadron 14 to continue treatment at the Norfols Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, Va.

A collection of Chinese and Malayan arms -and armor, the third section of the George C. Stone bequest, will be placed on view for the public at the Metropolitan Museum tomorrow in Gallery E-15. It will continue to be shown until July 4 and will be followed later in the Summer by the fourth and final selection-Persian and Indian material, comprising some of the richest in the bequest.

Degrees will be conferred on thirty seniors of Georgian Court College here at commencement exercises tomorrow afternoon by the Most Rev. Moses E. Kiley, Bishop of the Trenton diocese of the Roman Catholic Church.

The marriage of Miss Harriet M. Franklin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Franklin of this place, to W. Raymond Boyd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Boyd of Glen Ridge, N. J., took place this evening in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. J. McVickar Haight of Pelham Manor performed the ceremony, assisted by the rector, the Rev. J. H. Coffin.

Pairings and starting times for the first two rounds of the national open championship, as released yesterday by the United States Golf Association, reveal the fact that the field in the event which starts Thursday at the Oakland Hills Golf Club, Birmingham, Mich., consists of 170 contestants.

The Chamber of Deputies this evening passed an Anti-Tipping Bill by a margin of two votes. The vote was 267 against 265 after an all-day discussion had given the opponents of the measure a number of opportunities to fire a series of broadsides at the bill, which, it is generally considered, is doonmed to die in the Senate.
Basque refugee children encamped in this South England village today cheered announcement of the death of General Emilio Mola, Spanish Insurgent.

Clear-cut victories in the English county cricket championship kept Yorkshire and Sussex well ahead of the field. The White Rose County went into the lead last week and maintained a narrow margin over Sussex today by deeating Worcestershire by an innings and 81 runs. Sussex triumphed over Essex by 162 runs.

The 1938 P. G. A. championship will be held at the Shawnee Country Club at Shawnee-on-the-Delaware, it was announced last night at the Hotel Astor at a meeting of the tournament committee. A bid of $15,000 won the award, the highest in the history of the association.
Arnold D. Scammell, organist and composer of church music, died late last night at a nursing home. He was 70 years old and resided in this village.
Miss Ursula Bridget Newell, one of the best women golfers of Britain, who reached the final in the women's championship last year, died suddenly here today at the age of 25.

While Nanking's military force is consolidating its newly acquired position in the Chungking region, General Liu Hsiang, the Governor of Szechwan Province, has gone to his home town near Chengtu, apparently smarting under loss of face during the recent negotiations with the central government.

Receiverships in the public utility industry in the years 1931-36 have been greatly overemphasized, John T. Madden, dean of the New York University School of Commerce, said today at the closing session of the Edison Electric Institute convention.
The Treasury started a drive today to spur the filing of delinquent Social Security returns. The returns had proved disappointing and it was thought that this possibly was

The country's railroads, as a fuelconsumption group, have been the foremost leaders in the abatement of the smoke nuisance, H. D. Blackwell, educational director of the Smoke Prevention Association, said yesterday following the closing session of the association's convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The final graduation exercises of the Marquand School of the Central Branch of the Y. M. C. A., 55 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, were held last night in the Y. M. C. A. auditorium. The school goes out of existence this month. Dean Irving H. Berg of New York University was the speaker.

Climaxing a tournament of upsets, Ian -MacCallum of the home club and Paul De B. Scott of the Essex County Country Club reached the final of the New Jersey State golf championship today at the Ridgewood Country Club. It was not the brilliance of the victors so much as the disappointing play of the vanquished which cast two outsiders in finalist roles.
The board of trustees of George Washington University accepted today two gifts totaling $500,000 for the construction of a new library and a hall for the School of Government.

Though a lower range of quotations in tiverpool brought an early decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, the announcement that no change in Washington's gold-buying policy was contemplated started a slow recovery which left the list 1 to 2 points higher.

Writers were urged to join the fight against fascism by Walter Duranty, Ernest Hemingway, Muriel Draper and Archibald MacLeish and other speakers at the American Writers Congress at Carnegie Hall last night.

Irving Fisher, Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale, said at the southern session of the National Economic Conference here tonight that those who can prevent inflation "if they will, and I think they will, are Chairman Eccles and his colleagues of the Federal Reserve Board, Secretary Morgenthau, President Roosevelt and Congress."

A search for Dr. C. V. Akin, quarantine officer of New York City, who had been reported missing since leaving Raleigh, N. C., on May 31, ended today with the disclosure by his son, Charles Akin Jr., that his father was in Columbia.

Mrs. Sadie Schildkraut, "the mother of cooked vegetarian dishes," died on Tuesday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Helen Altman, in Woodmere, L. I., after a long illness. Her age was 51. Her husband, Herman Schildkraut, owns a hotel in Lakewood, N. J.

Bo Lisman, Long Beach (Calif.) racing star, carried off the major part of the honors in the weekly motorcycle racing program at the Yankee Stadium last night before a cheering crowd of 5,000 enthusiasts. Lisman came through to capture both of the two-lap match races that featured the card.

Dwellings and flats formed. the bulk of realty sold yesterday in Brooklyn. Several properties were disposed of by banks. Caroline Bussing sold through Hy. and D. Agar, Inc., brokers, the four-story apartment house for twenty families at 7,410 Seventeenth Avenue, Brooklyn. The flat was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $52,000, which was extended for five years.

The American Labor party of the Fifth Assembly District of the Bronx, has forwarded resolutions urging passage of the WagnerSteagall Housing Bill to President Roosevelt and other government officials.

President Roosevelt, at a press conference, indicated his willingness to compromise the courts reorganization issue, but expressed confidence that the main points of his program would be enacted at this session of Congress.

A novel experiment in night club entertainment-and one which this department heartily endorses--is being tried by the new Surfside, combination club, casino and bathing beach, which opened last weekend on the oceanfront at Atlantic Beach, L. I.

While labor disturbances checked trade activity and disrupted production schedules in some sections of the country, the movement of trade was more active this week, with key cities not affected by strikes reporting gains in sales ranging from 3 to 6 per cent over the volume in the week preceding, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Declines in retail sales were registered in the strike-affected sections.

The Police Department discontinued the practice of noting issuance of summonses on drivers' licenses prior to conviction about a month ago, it was disclosed yesterday by Assistant Corporation Counsel Paxton Blair.

Emphasizing again today his insistence upon enactment of his judiciary reorganization program at this session of Congress, President Roosevelt, nevertheless, has turned the question of its immediate future over to administration leaders at the Capitol to work out the best plan to end the controversy.

Helmuth Hirsch, 21-year-old United States citizen who was convicted of bringing infernal machines into Germany, was guillotined today despite repeated American appeals to Chancellor Adolf Hitler for clemency.

The commencement exercises of the Ann Reno School, 32 West Eighty-sixth Street, were held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Delmonico. Lowell S. Trowbridge of Boston University was the speaker. Claire Sheffield of Hackensack, N. J., received the prize for highest academic standing.

Rumsey Hall School will hold its commencement exercises tomorrow and Sunday. The headmaster, Louis H. Schutte, will present the diplomas, certificates and prizes. The baccalaureate sermon will be delivered by the Rev. Dr. J. Chauncey Lindsey of the Berkeley Divinity School. New Haven.
Czechoslovakia today gained a 2-0 lead over France in their European zone semi-final round Davis Cup engagement when Roderick Menzel and Ladislaus Hecht won the opening singles matches.

Boxing authorities and the German press greeted the New York State Athletic Commission's decision in the James J. Braddock case with such an outcry as European sport has not experienced in many a day.

Passengers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian motorship Vulcania include Mr. and Mrs. George Debevoise, Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Emerson, Mrs. Benjamin Loeb, Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Sawtell, Mr. and Mrs. A. S. Hermann, Bertham Christian and Mrs. G. T. Whyte.

More than thirty substitute school teachers who recently failed to pass an "interview" examination for appointment to the permanent teaching staff brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to compel the Board of Examiners of the Board of Education to permit them to take new tests or to place their names on the eligible lists without the tests.

A moving account of how he was threatened with ruin, his brother beaten so badly that two of his ribs were broken, and one of his trucks rendered useless by emery powder in its oil, was related by William Brown, a truckman, from the witness stand in the Supreme Court yesterday.

The Federal Music Project Chamber Orchestra was heard last night at the Theatre of Music in its regular weekly concert. Herman Neuman conducted. Edwin and Jewel Bethany Hughes, duo-pianists, were soloists.

More than 2,000 persons attended a dinner in honor of the Rev. Joseph L. Lucas, veteran Jesuit missionary to the Philippines, last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The dinner was under the auspices of the Jesuit Philippine Missions Bureau.

By a vote of 2,373 out of 2,909 ballots cast, employes of the Third Avenue railway system selected the Transport Workers Union, affiliate of the C. I. O., as their collective bargaining agent yesterday. There were 3,002 workers eligible to vote.
The stock markets were extremely idle today, the last day of the account, and most of the sections were weaker owing to the gold uncertanties.

House leaders reached an agreement today for revision of the joint resolution providing for an inquiry into tax avoidance practices and the Rules Committee was called to meet Monday to approve the compromise.
Catholic grammar schools in the State to Wuerttemberg were closed today by local govermental decree, which said lack of sufficient attendance was the reason.

Several dwelling properties in New Jersey have charged hands in deals reported yesterday by brokers. The five-story apartment at 920 Hudson Street, Hoboken, has been sold by the Hasad Realty Corporation, Morris Bogdonoff, president, to Samuel Reznick, operator. The house is situated on a plot 66 by 110 feet, contains 105 rooms,

De Witt C. Tanner, formerly general patent attorney of the Western Electric Company, has been made consulting patent attorney of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, it was announced yesterday.

The American Bankers Association announced yesterday that it opposed the McAdoo bills providing for branch banking across State lines and had reiterated its stand in favor of granting to national banks permission to establish branch banks within State borders to the same extent that branch banking was permitted to State banks.

Three months have passed since Colonel Adam Koc, commander of the Pilsudski Legionnaires, proclaimed on the authority of Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz, successor to the late Marshal Pllsudski, that the real power of the State and the general principles of political reorganization in Poland would be accompolished through the new "Camp of National Unity."

The new six-story elevator apartment house for forty-two families at 3,750 Bronx Boulevard, facing the Bronx River Parkway, was sold by the Taymil Realty Corporation to an investing client of Grudin Sawitch, brokers. It occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of?? $110,000 held by the Bronx Savings Bank.

THE FRONT--Madrid was heavily shelled not only in the central district but in the working people's section of the city. The Rebels were reported to have concentrated 800 guns for the attempt to break the fortress ring at Bilbao. Page 1.

Despite a spirited effort yesterday by the Teachers Union and allied groups to get the Board of Estimate's approval of four educational bills benefiting substitute teachers, custodians and clerks, the board voted to inform Governor Lehman that if he signed the bills the city would be unable to meet the added cost of almost $10,000,000.

The investigation by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce of the financial control of domestic railroads was broadened today to include the New York Central Lines, the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Virginian Railway Company.

The New Jersey Power and Light Company applied yesterday in Supreme Court for an injunction restraining the scheduled sale at auction on June 9 of 712,411 shares of the Jersey Central Light and Power Company supporting National Public Service debentures.

Miss fa Sarah Y. Ely, long a New Jersey educator, died today at her home, 52 Carroll Street, at the age of 88. Miss Ely retired in 1913, after serving for forty-seven years on the faculty of the old State Model School here For the last twenty-six years of that period she was supervisor of the girls' department.

The government is being urged to give more attention to compensating agreements with France to facilitate the efforts being made by that country to obtain higher quotas for imports of Chilean sodium nitrate.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, yesterday named 1,703 youths, of whom 894 are from the metropolitan area, to attend the Plattsburg Citizens Military Training Camp, opening on July 2 at the army training center on Lake Champlain.

The Senate Civil Liberties Committee, investigators for which watched union handbill distributors beaten and chased from Ford Motor Company gates May 26, summoned two Ford employes today to testify at a hearing in Washington July 1.

The twelve-story brick garage occupying the blockfront in Columbus Avenue between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Street, with a depth of 125 feet, was sold at auction yesterday. The action was brought by the president and directors of The Manhattan Company, as trustee, against the Uppercu Realty Corportion to satisfy a judgment

Mrs. Thomas E. Barber, for twenty-five years a Presbyterian missionary in Colombia, died on Wednesday in Pasadena Hospital, Pasadena, Calif., of pneumonia, according to word received here yesterday. The widow of a missionary, she was Miss Ethel Irene Towle before her marriage. Her age was 57.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, confirmed yesterday the report, recently published in The Campus, undergraduate newspaper, that the college cooperative store which sells school supplies to students had suffered "a considerable loss" during the six-month period ended Jan. 1, 1937.

A Philippine merchant marine composed of four ships, two in the Pacific service and two in the European trade, is planned by the National Development Company, J. Bartlett Richards, American Trade Commissioner at Manila, reported to the Commerce Department.

Trade here improved sharply during the week, with a number of establishments here noting increases that ranged from 12 to 20 per cent. These gains were on top of substantial rises during the first part of June last year.
Brig. Gen. George H. Brett, Nineteenth Wing commander, announced today the army's air force for defense of the strategic Panama Canal Zone will be increased by sixty planes by next February.

The activities of the Biddle Purchasing Company of New York, through more than 2,400 buyers, have enabled them better to meet the competition of the great national chain stores, in the opinion of government attorneys whose brief in the Federal Trade Commission's proceeding against the Biddle concern was made public today.

Premier Mitchell Hepburn's announcement last night that he had divorced himself and his Ontario Liberal government from the leadership of Prime Minister Mackenzie King and his eulogy of Premier Duplessis of Quebec merely confirmed the opinion held for some time in Ottawa that he plans to enter the Canadian Federal arena at the head of a party of Fascist tendencies.
A jury hearing the impeachment trial of Sheriff J. L. Corbitt, charged with failing to protect a Negro from a mob, was told today the mob "lynched the wrong Negro."

Total shipments of hosiery in April were 11,376,479 dozen pairs, against 10,176,031 dozen pairs. in April, 1936, a gain of about 12 per cent, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reports in its current Statistical Bulletin. There was a seasonal decline from the March figure. the bulletin says.

Diplomas were given yesterday afternoon to twenty-eight graduates of the high school of the Dalton Schools, 108 East Eighty-ninth Street, at the annual commencement. Dr. Lin Yutang, Chinese writer, delivered the address.
A Catholic priest today said the first mass that a Jalapa church has heard in more than five years. The Rev. Francisco Arapue was permitted by the Governor to officiate.

Charles Leroy Hall, sexton at the West End Collegiate Church, Seventy-seventh Street near Broadway, since 1904 and a major league baseball player of fifty years ago, died on Thursday at his home, 2,233 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 73 years old.
Details of the "adjusted compensation plan" of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., were made public yesterday in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Up to about three or four years ago, cries were raised lamenting the fact that the rough and tumble fighting ball player was a thing of the past. Baseball rapidly was deteriorating into powder puff game of catch.

Barring the unexpected, there will be but one closing this evening, when "High Tor" packs its bags at the Martin Beck Theatre after giving 171 performances there. It had a distinguished run, for midway in its career the New York Drama Critics Circle bestowed upon it the annual award-the second time in two years a Maxwell Anderson play had been so honored.
Warden Joseph H. Brophy, of Auburn Prison, said today that a brief "sit-down" strike by several prisoners in the prison machine shop had ended with their return to work- "at no increase in pay."

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $15,150,075, to be represented by one State and fifty-four municipalities, as compared with the revised total of $14,289,603 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $29,940,623.
Two units of Rutgers University will hold commencement exercises tomorrow, the New Jersey College for Women in the morning and the Rutgers School of Education in the afternoon.
Mrs. Young Estes of Jacksonville announced today the engagement of her daughter, Miss Genevieve Livingston Estes, to Nicholas Ridgley du Pont of Wilmington, Del.

Judge and Mrs. Origen S. Seymour of Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Frances Seymour Beals of 410 East Fifty-seventh Street, to Miles H. Vernon of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Miles Vernon.

The Empire State, training ship of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy, sailed yesterday from Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, for her annual cruise to Europe. She carried 154 cadets in the deck and engine departments and was in command of Captain J. H. Tomb, superintendent of the academy.

Time and motion studies and wage incentive methods were reviewed yesterday before the Institute of Management, a research group of the American Management Association, at its annual meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 917,000 bales against 928,000 a week ago, 928,000 two weeks ago, 930,000 three weeks ago and 714,000 a year ago;

Some twenty Government bureaus and committees have been engaged in surveying the lands and waters of the United States and telling us how we shall save farms from being blown away by the winds or washed into the sea by thousands of streams.

The Sixth Avenue Rebuilt campaign will open Wednesday with a two-week exhibit showing the progress made on the avenue the last eighty-five years and depicting it as it might appear in the year 2000, according to an announcement made yesterday by V. Clement Jenkens, president of the Sixth Avenue Association.

Field Marshal Gustaf Mannerheim's seventieth birthday was celebrated by Finland today with spontaneous enthusiasm. From early morning until late evening Baron Mannerheim received deputations at three-minute intervals from military organizations, welfare and other societies organized and directed by him.
Miss Helon Scanlon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Scanlon of Bryn Mawr, was married this morning to D. Haven Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur S. Scott of Bryn Mawr.

One of the largest horse shows ever held here since the event was inaugurated forty years ago opened today with visitors from all parts of the metropolitan district in attendance. Tonight nearly every house in the park was the scene of a week-end house party and the club filled to capacity.

Syracuse University authorities announced today that the entry of the university's jayvee crew in the Poughkeepsie regatta June 22 had been withdrawn. Athletic officials said four members of the squad had accepted Summer jobs necessitating their immediate appearance and that a fifth was ill.

With the probability existing that at least a new American record Will evolve from the race, a three-quarter-mile invitation event will feature the 139th track and field games of the New York A. C. at Travers Island today. Four fleet milers will fire away at Joe Mangan's American mark of 3:01.4 and, if they can reach it, Jules Ladoumegue's world clocking of 3:00.6.

Lord Wyfold, an outstanding figure on the British turf for more than fifty years, died in Reading today at the age of 85. Entering politics in 1884, he became chairman of the National Union of Conservative Associations and for many years represented South Oxfordshire-where most of his sporting interests lay-in the House of Commons.

Peter J. Picket well known in Queens as a caterer, particularly to political organizations, died at his home, 18-48 120th Street, College Point, on Thursday evening. He was born fifty years ago in College Point, where. his flather conducted a hotel.

On the hotel-room table the cards were cut to the ace of spades-the "death card." On She floor sprawled the body of J. J. Munsey, an Indian fighter and miner who devoted most of his eighty-two years to searching for gold, finding some and spending it.

An indictment for attempted bribery returned last Winter against Thomas R. Hughes and Frank White, former "runners" for a law firm, in Assistant District Attorney Bernard Botein's investigation of irregularities among lawyers and others in accident suits, was dismissed yesterday by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions on the recommendation of the prosecutor.

Movements or livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 6,000 including 2,500 directs. Market generally steady to 10c lower than Thursday's average; late sales at full decline; top $11.55; bulk good and choice 200-300 pounds, $11.25-S11.45:

Preservation of the historic United States Capitol intact and defeat of a bill before Congress for technical correction of an "overhang" of its dome were asked today by the convention of the American Institute of Architects at the closing sessions today.

The volume of trading by members of the New York Stock Exchange fell sharply in the week ended on May 8, compared with the week ended on May 1, but the percentage of total volume remained about the same, 22.42 per cent, against 22.24 per cent, according to the weekly analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mickey Cochrane has made such satisfactory progress at St. Elizabeth's Hospital that he may be transferred to the Ford Hospital in Detroit either tonight or tomorrow. This was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Robert Emmet Walsh, who has been treating the Tiger man-ager for a triple skull fracture suffered at the Yankee Stadium over a week ago when he was struck down at the plate by an accidental "bean ball" thrown by Bump Hadley.

" And to one he gave five talents." He was a Negro boy born in Missouri, the son of slave parents (and once traded for a horse), who as a man has made so great a contribution to his country that, as reported in Thursday's TIMES, "Southern notables of two races " paid honor to his genius by having a bronze bust made of him.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Ingfred T. Madsen of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Helene Madsen, to Alfred Gawthrop Genung, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Miller Genung, also of Plainfield.

System Properties, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the International Hydro-Electric System, has received $850,000 in cash, representing the proceeds of the sale to the Central Maine Power Company of two undeveloped water-power sites, one on the Androscoggin River and the other on the Kennebec River, according to an announcement yesterday by Irwin L. Moore, president of the International Hydro-Electric.

Dazzling Don Lash gave the Central Intercollegiate Conference something to remember him by tonight under the floodlights in Marquette University Stadium by racing to two new meet records as he led his fellow-Hoosiers to their second straight track and field team title.
In larger events and international excitements it would be a pity to look the import of the agree reached by seven small nation Northern Europe,
The House held a memorial service today for the late Speaker John W. Byrns of Tennessee on the anniversary of his death last year.

Steel workers who have to keep their nails manicured and wear white coats are now starting to turn out "metallic diamonds" in a modernistic industrial plant built by the Firth-Sterling Steel Company in McKeesport.

The Southern California Telephone Company had listings of a total of 639,705 telephones in service as of May 31, an increase of 2,582 units during the month and a new high record. In May, 1936, the company reported a gain of 1,898 stations.

On the ground that the year-old Presbyterian Church of America had departed from the "historic position of American Presbyterianism," fourteen ministers and three elders of the denomination turned their backs on it tonight and announced in a statement the formation of a new organization known as the Bible Presbyterian Synod.

The oppression of peoples in Germany, Spain and Italy and the hardships suffered by Negroes taken from their native land to become slaves were depicted yesterday afternoon by 250 children of Madison House, a settlement at 226 Madison Avenue.

Talk of drafting United States Senator Robert F. Wagner for the Democratic nomination for Mayor increased yesterday, following the return of Frank V. Kelly and Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn from Washington, where the Brooklyn and Bronx leaders discussed the local political situation with President Roosevelt on Thursday.

Diplomas were awarded last night to seventy-one graduates of the high school department, and twenty-seven graduates of the grammar grades of All Hallows Institute, 164th Street and Walton Avenue, the Bronx, at exercises in the Town Hall.

Colonel and Mrs. Harold S. Wonson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Wonson, to Walter H. Lillard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Huston Lillard of Tabor Academy, Marion, Mass.
The Japanese people discovered that the new Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoe, had a radio personality when he went on the air for five minutes last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two important bills which Governor Lehman deserves much credit for approving are the Kleinfeld bill and the Killgrew bill, which eliminate the provision for fixed terms of office for clerks of the Municipal Court and the magistrates' court respectively.

Alexander Russell Bond, patent attorney and editor of scientific magazines, died Thursday night of pneumonia at his apartment in Tudor City at -the age of 61. He left his residence at 815 Kensington Avenue, Plainfield, N. J., two weeks ago when he became ill to move to Manhattan. His office was at 230 Park Avenue.

President Lazaro Cardenas went far toward breaking the backbone of the nation-wide petroleum strike today without actually dictating a settlement. He brought the full resources of the government's new petroleum company into play getting the capital and the nation's railroads and factories an ample supply of gasoline and oil.

Jessica of Cosalta, a home-bred owned by Miss Marie J. Leary of the Cosalta Kennels of Greenwich, Conn., today carried off the title of best in show at the annual specialty exhibition of the Shepherd Dog Club of New England, held on the polo field of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.
Emmet J. Flynn, 45, one-time movie director for Mary Pickford, Valentino and other stars, was found unconscious in a boarding house room today and died at Hollywood Police Hospital two hours later.

The title defending New York omen's tennis team and the Bos:on squad today swept into the final of the Sears Cup competition at Longwood. New York defeated Philadelphia, seven matches to two, and the Bos:onians routed Baltimore by the lame margin.

Continuing the three-day commencement program at the New York Military Academy, the competitive company drills for the efficiency cup and a special exhibition drill by the Cavalry Troop D Were held this afternoon.

Miss Betty Barbara Sieben-Morgen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Sieben-Morgen of Westfield, was married to George Cokelet Worth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Cokelet Worth of North Plainfield, this afternoon in the home of the bride's parents.

Chancelor John G. Bowman patted a layer of cement over a three-foot slab of Indiana limestone, two Pitt seniors lent the weight of burly shoulders, and the cornerstone of the University of Pittsburgh's Cathedral of Learning grated into place today.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Josiah Macy of Morristown, N. J., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Wise Macy, to James Suydam Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Jones of Far Hills, N. J.

Department stores, dry goods establishments and specialty shops had an average profit last year of 2.6 per cent on sales, compared with a profit showing of 1.6 per cent in 1935, according to the annual "Departmental Merchandising and Operating Results" report of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which was issued yesterday.

THOUGH the medical men stubbornly refuse to admit it, dizziness is both contagious and infectious. At least, it is contagious and infectious under abnormal pressure in a baseball atmosphere. How else would science explain the scene and sound effects yesterday in the office of President Ford Frick of the National League?

General Emilio Mola's commanderin-chief, Generalissimo Francisco Franco, his soldiers and the officers of his staff said a military farewell today to the dead chieftain of the Northern Spanish Insurgent armies.

Filling the creel: The tale of a big trout is contained in a message from Quebec.... An eight - and - one - quarter - pound brown trout was taken this week from the Seigniory Club waters at Clear Lake by Mrs. George Safford of New York. . . . Mrs. Safford hooked the trout on a dark Montreal with a No. 8 hook. . . .

With the adoption of a committee report proposing the mandatory possession of a college degree for all applicants for law school admission, the New Jersey Bar Association moved tonight to reduce present overcrowding of the legal profession.
Most commodity futures advanced in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. On the cash markets cocoa, tins, cotton, rubber and wool tops advanced, but all the grains and lard declined.

Two or more neighborhood hoodlums who invaded Trinity Church Cemetery, 153d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, early yesterdaymorning overturned or broke 164 gravestones. causing damage estimated at $20,000.

Latvia notified the State Department today that she would default on war debt payments due June 15. On that date there is due from her $134,883 in a new installment and $1,284,261 in arrears, a total of $1, 419,144.

The House Appropriations Committee favorably reported today a bill to extend the life of the Public Works Administration two years and authorizing, an additional appropriation of $40,000,000 to care for applications for loans and grants for non-Federal projects in cases where elections have been held and bond issues voted.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Sarah Barrea Prince of 230 East Fifty-first Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Duffield Prince of Upper Montclair, N. J., to Kingsland Adams Coffyn, son of Mrs. Adams Coffyn of 16 East Ninety-sixth Street.

The nervousness in the gold market here, which has existed in the last few weeks regarding the permanence of the United States buying price for the metal continued today when sellers threw into the market the record amount of [Pound]4,225,000 at a discount of 7%d a fine ounce on the parity figure in United States currency.

Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, found another $7,500a-year life job for one of his district leaders yesterday. The leader is Joseph B. Whitty, up to yesterday an Alderman and Democratic leader of the Second (Brighton Beach-Sheepshead Bay - Canarsie) Assembly District.

An audience of 3,000 attended the performance of "Samson et Dalila" given last night by the Hippodrome Opera Company. It was the first production of the jubilee week celerating the organization's fifth anniversary and was received with enthusiasm.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in May totaled $26,599,544,565, a decrease of 7.7 per cent from the turnover in April, but 7.3 per cent in excess of the aggregate in May, 1936.

Representative Manuel Penabaz, Nationalist from Oriente Province, asserted tonight that he had been warned by members of the majority bloc in the House that he would be attacked by the army owing to the addresses he made on the floor of the lower house against the army's domination of Cuba.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, outspoken champion of the Confessional Protestant Church, made the first of what is to be a series of speeches here tonight for the declared purpose of warning his church members to be on guard for the forthcoming church elections.

All the major theories of the business cycle are analyzed, compared and to some degree synthesized in a volume entitled "Prosperity and Depression," issued today by the intelligence section of the League of Nations.
The Black-Connery bill to outlaw child labor and establish minimum wages and maximum hours of labor for low-income workers received today the guarded endorsement of the American Federation of Labor.

The steel industry added more than 12,000 employes to its payrolls during April, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday, bringing the number to the record total of 589,000, as compared with 577,000 in March, and 480,000 in April, 1936.

Miss Harriett Gilchrist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce O. Gilchrist of Oradell, N. J., was married here tonight in Grace Church to Horace Arthur Wadsworth of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Wadsworth of Salem,Mass. The Rev. Edgar L. Cook performed the ceremony.
Blown down from Canada, wintry weather swept along the east slope of the Rockies today, smashing all records at the Denver Weather Bureau for "Summer-time snow."

The American 3-year-old cnampionship will be decided this afternoon at Belmont Park as the seven best 3-year-olds in training were named yesterday for the mile-anda-half test of the rich Belmont Stakes. War Admiral, winner of all his starts this year, including the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, is fit and ready and is sure to rule an odds-on favorite.

Following rejection of original bids on twenty-eight obsolete steel cargo vessels by the Maritime Commission as "obviously unfair to the government," the prices offered being considerably less than the current market for scrap iron, the commission announced today that it would receive new bids on July 8, with offers invited from foreign as well as domestic interests.

Jake Mooty, pitching in a relief role, walked three batters in a row in the ninth inning and forced home Catcher Buddy Rosar with the run that gave the league-leading Newark Bears a 5-to-4 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs tonight before 13,668, one of the largest crowds to witness a flood-light contest here.

Eighteen students will be graduated from the Irving School here at exercises tomorrow evening. Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, will be the speaker. The diplomas and prizes will be presented by C. W. Olson, headmaster.

Fundamental Investors, Inc.-As of June 3, total assets, at market value, exceeded $11,000,000. Undistributed earned surplus available for dividends and other corporate purposes for the first five months of this year were $348,904; unrealized appreciation of investments was $803,370 and shares outstanding increased from 366,209 at the end of 1936 to 467,667.
con-ference of representatives of the nation's railroads and fourteen non-operating brotherhoods was adjourned until Tuesday after oper.-ators had considered the unions' demands for compensation.

Dipped in the whimsy bath by the Twentieth Century-Fox chemists, Frederick Nebel's novel, "Fifty Roads to Town," emerged at the Roxy yesterday with its original melodramatic content washed out and an inlay of gibbering farce in its place.

A model and relief map of the city's Camp La Guardia, Greycourt, Orange County, N. Y., work camp for the rehabilitation of homeless men, is now on display in the office of Public Welfare Commissioner William Hodson, it was announced yesterday.

Governor Lehman vetoed today four bills amending the tax law which he said would have substantially reduced the State's revenues. Two of the bills, sponsored by Senator Buckley of New York and Assemblyman Gamble of Westchester, would have provided for a reduction in the stock transfer tax on shares sold for less than $5.

far as can be learned here, there is no apprehension in the Dominion capital of any disturbance in the price of gold, particularly in view of the statements of President Roosevelt in Washington today and on recent occasions.

President Roosevelt, after indicating that he was willing to accept a compromise on the number of new judges to be named to the Supreme Court under his court reorganization program, immediately turned today to a series of conferences at the White House designed to expedite enactment of administration measures he wishes passed this session.

With but five inches of rain in four months, less than a third of normal and the driest period on record, San Juan faces a water shortage. Rationing is expected to be ordered unless there is quick relief.
Joseph Chalmers Lee shot three business associates today at the plant of the George H. Jackson Company, Ltd., formerly the Atlas Horseshoe Company, which Lee partly owned.

The Reds defeated the Phillies, 9 to 8, today, to make a clean sweep of the two-game series. Davis's relief pitching helped the Reds to victory. He replaced Brennan in the ninth after two runs had scored, men were on first and second, and one was out. Hollingsworth got credit for the victory, however.

Brig. Gen. C. A. Smart, former Conservative member of the Quebec Legislature for the neighboring city of Westmount, and newly appointed to Quebec's Legislative Council, died suddenly today at the age of 69.

Republic Steel laid groundwork for test cases in court over the postoffice ban on mailed parcels addressed to men in struck plants. Page 1. Steel strike in the Chicago area settled into an endurance test. Tour of the Republic plant revealed much productive activity by men still at work. Page 3.

Cotton-mill activity declined less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 147.8, its highest point since the week ended Jan. 2. It was 143.8-for the previous week and 121.2 for the week ended May 30, 1936.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived at 11:45 o'clock this evening at the little station of Arnoldstein, coming from Italy. About fifty boys and girls, wearing the local peasant costume, had collected around the station an hour before and had tried to persuade a detachment of gendarmes to allow them to get a glimpse of the bridal couple.

The United States District Court of the Southern District of New York yesterday approved an order to pay creditors of the International Match Company an additional dividend of 5 per cent. This will be the third dividend of 5 per cent to be paida upon all claims allowed against this bankrupt concern.

Winning her second straight race in the preliminary series to select the defender of the America's Cup, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new Ranger made a most impressive showing today. She defeated her ownerskipper's older boat, now Chandler Hovey's Rainbow, by 1 minute and 58 seconds over thirty miles.

Supreme Court Justice James C. Cropsey of Brooklyn underwent a second operation for a glandular condition yesterday at the Brooklyn Hospital, where he has been a patient since May 19. A preliminary operation was performed on May 21.

Eighty friends of the late T. E. Lawrence have contributed to a book about him that has just been published by Cape in England under the title "T. E. Lawrence." The book is edited by A. W. Lawrence. According to English reviewers, the book presents "about eighty different Lawrences."

Speyer Co., one of the firms named by Senator Truman of Missouri on the floor of the Senate Thursday in an attack on "New York bankers and investment bankers" in connection with railroad financial reorganizations, sent the following telegram to Senator Truman yesterday:

France armed her side of the Spanish border with anti-aircraft guns today to repel any attack by Spanish planes. The step was taken after repeated protests had been made by authorities of the French city of Cerbere when it was machinegunned recently by Spanish Insurgent attack planes in a raid on government-held border positions.

Miss Madeleine Kelleher Johnstone, daughter of Harold Halleck Johnstone of this city, was married in Pequot Chapel this afternoon to Lieutenant Joseph Warford Williams Jr., U. S. N., son of Judge and Mrs. J. C. Williams of Martinsville, Ind.

The first step in the organization of a Joint council of maritime unions to be affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization was taken yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the spokesmen of six unions in the offices of the American Radio Telegraphists Association, 10 Bridge Street.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

After winning in three successive classes, Miss June Hanes's 8-yearold chestnut gelding Molyneux held the lead for the hunter championship at the close of the opening session of the fifty-first annual Tuxedo horse show today. Molyneux's chief rival was Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer's Hexameter, who won the blue for lightweight hunters.

Rockland County, famous for its trees and as the birthplace of Joyce Kilmer, the man who wrote the poem "Trees," was up in arms today searching for the persons responsible for the removal of hundreds of red maples allegedly for transplanting at the site of New York City's World's Fair.

M. G. Wenger, postal inspector, joined today in the search for the Western Air Express skyliner, missing since Dec. 15, after additional letters found in near-by mountains were identified as part of the plane's cargo.

Executives of the H. J. Heinz Company and two rival unions signed an agreement today calling for an election to be conducted next Tuesday by the National Labor Board to decide which union shall represent the workers as collective bargaining agent.

There is an uneasy feeling here that the liberty of the press will be considerably curtailed, if actual censorship is not imposed at times, under the powers of Article XL of President Eamon de Valera's new Constitution, which article was passed through the Dail Eireann today only after strong opposition from both the supporters of former President William T. Cosgrave and Labor.
Certificates of merit for honors during the year and Cum Laude awards were presented yesterday at Adelphi Academy, 282 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, at the final assembly of the year.
With the backing of the Fifth Avenue Association and other mercantile groups, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to establish a new restricted retail district in the center of Manhattan.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Business in the wool market continues slow. "There is slightly better interest in medium bright fleeces, which are slightly firmer; in fact one or two. sales are reported at a cent advance for the week. Fine wools.

TODAY we have three novels, among which "A Mighty Fortress" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50), by Le Grand Cannon Jr., seems to me the most able. It would, no doubt, stand out in almost any society, if not for its force or literary power or "message" then for the refreshing simplicity with which it is written and its genuine American quality.
She said, "I can never endure It--the weight of this pain." She not knowing that bodies procure Somehow the strength to retain Every grief that assails them. She said, "I shall never survive!"

Under the same smiling skies that have favored all save one nual outing of the Bond Club of New York in the last seventeen years, more than 450 bankers and bond men deserted Wall Street to spend today at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here.

Miss Octavia Hamilton, daughter of Mrs. James Hamilton of Detroit and the fore late Mr. Hamilton, was married here this afternoon to Philip Ryerson, son of Mrs. W. Newton Ryerson of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. Ryerson, at the home of her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. William Pegram Gilmour.

Lighthorse Harry Cooper, No. 1 choice to win the national open at Birmingham, Mich., next week, and Horton Smith shot their way Into the lead in the $4,600 Inverness four-ball matches today with a pair of par-shattering performances.

The Most Rev. Jean Marius Laval, D.. D., Auxiliary Catholic Bishop of New Orleans, died early 'today at St. Mary's Hospital at the age. of. 88. Bishop Laval became suddenly ill yesterday. The Rev. Charles B. Anderson, his assistant, said the illness was a complication of an old ailment.

New York City's emergency unemployment relief tax program, which raised about $71,000,000 for relief last year, will be continued until June 30, 1938, under action taken at City Hall yesterday by the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly.

Dissension has divided the official ranks of the Townsend old-age pension plan with a general bolting from the leadership of Dr. Francis E. Townsend, originator of the plan, according to reports tonight from Washington, D. C., and Los Angeles.

Another prominent Soviet official was removed from his post tonight. General R. P. Eideman, president of Osoaviakhim, a civilian organization for building up an army reserve, was removed and replaced by P. Gorshenin, former second secretary of the Young Communist movement.

Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa said today he would go to the United States this month on a pleasure trip. Mr. de Souza Costa said the trade accord with the United States would be revised to enable competition with other countries that have trade compacts with Brazil, especially Germany, whose treaty is based on barter.
Immediate, courageous and Intelligent participation in public affairs was urged on the graduates of the Riverdale Country School last night by William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College.
Rear Admiral and Mrs. Henry Hughes Hough are expected to arrive at the Weylin today from Boston. Mrs. Robert D. Huntington of the Pierre has gone to Buckmeadow, her country place in Mill Neck, L. I.

The Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, just named -Vice Moderator of the General Assembly of - the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, will be welcomed home tomorrow at services in the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Twenty-seven students were graduated last night at the 173d commencement exercises of Columbia Grammar School, held in the American Woman's Association Clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. Student speakers were Ira Skutch, Allan B. Ecker, John London, Donald Dike and Felix Lilienthal.

For twenty-five years the name of Minsky has stood high among the leaders in the now banned field of burlesque. Yesterday, however, the Minsky traditions threatened to become a Frankenstein to two of the family, Morton and Herbert K. Minsky, owners of the Oriental Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-second Street, when License Commissioner Paul Moss rejected their application for a license for the house.

All drinkers of the sincere milk of grammar must be grateful to that Californian correspondent of THE TIMES who has performed an operation on the line in KIPLING'S "Recessional" that has pained them so long.

Following a public hearing yesterday before the Aldermanic Committee on General Welfare on a bill banning the sale of ice cream from wagons and carts on the streets, Chairman James J. Molen said the committee was disposed to report favorably on the measure.
The Febus (Spanish Government) News Agency reported several of the crew of a Spanish oil tanker were injured today when their ship was torpedoed about one mile off Palamos.

Many baccalaureate sermons will be preached tomorrow, and pastors in their sermons at the regular morning worship will give advice to the young people who are being graduated from colleges and secondary schools this month.

The Communist International appealed today for swift and united action by the proletariat of all countries in defense of the Spanish Government against the redoubled threat to its existence implicit in the Almeria bombardment and the withdrawal of Germany and Italy from the Non-Intervention Committee.

Frederic Ashton de Peyster of 510 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of his younger daughter, Miss Helen Van Cortlandt de Peyster, to Eric Alexander von Raits, son of the late Lieut. Col. Jvan Alexander von Raits of the Austrian Army and the late Mrs. von Raits.
Th State Banking Department announced today its approval of branch offices for the Commercial Credit Corporation of New York at 1,125 Broadway, Albany; 535 Washington Street, Buffalo;
One postoffice employe was slightly injured today when bombs sent by parcel post exploded almost simultaneously in three Parisian postoffices.

Edgewood School graduated a class of eighteen at commencement exercises today. The speaker was Dr. Samuel Jea Sheliabarger of Riverton, N. J., former Professor of English at Princeton University, who was inproduced by his daughter, Miss Marianne J. Shellabarger, a member of the class.

Profits and losses showered the Giants in great profusion at the Polo Grounds yesterday when before a record ladies' day crowd of 29,819 the forces of Colonel Bill Terry battled the Cubs for more than five hours to split a doubleheader right down the middle.

Deep fissures extending down to the water through ten feet of ice appeared in the lee floe on which the Soviet North Pole expedition is encamped, according to a message tonight from Professor Otto J. Schmidt.

Retired Fireman Patrick J. Sullivan (2), formerly a member of Engine 215. residing at 93 Lexington Ave., Freeport, L. I. died June 1. Charge Dismissed The charge of violation of Section 38, R. R., 1926, on which Battalion Chief Henry Holzberger, 37th Battalion, was tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on May 25, 1936, found guilty and sentence suspended, is hereby dismissed.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.
As the site for a taxpayer a plot 133 by 300 feet at the northeast corner of Nassau Road and Washington Place, Roosevelt, L. I., has been purchased by the Godfrey Investing Corporation of Manhattan.

The residence of the late Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt at 60-64 East Ninety-third Street, one of the largest of the modern private dwellings in Manhattan, has been sold by her daughter, Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis, to a "wellknown New Yorker" who will occupy it. Pease Elliman acted as brokers in the deal.

The new Polish liner Batory is making for New York at reduced speed as a result of a fire which started in the engine room on Thursday, it was learned yesterday. Officials of the Gdynia-America Line, owners and operators of the ship, said the fire started in some waste oil.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking at the commencement exercises of the Todhunter School yesterday in the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, advised the graduates to develop a sense of curiosity and an ability to be sympathetic and understanding of "the many sides" of modern life.
Lieut. Col. Ralph Heyward Isham, New York financier and retired British army officer, and Christine, Viscountess Churchill, widow of the first Viscount Churchill, announced their engagement today.

The first attempt of the Anglo-American Oil Company to find oil in Great Britain was started today at Grove Hill near Hellingly, Sussex, by Lord Apsley, representing the Minister for Coordination of Defense.

Boston College halted Bernie Pearlman's nine-game winning streak as the Eagles avenged an early season defeat by beating Long Island University, 6 to 2, today. It was Pearlman's first loss of the season and the fourth defeat for the Blackbirds in twenty-five games.

Nearly 700 reservations have been made for the fiftieth annual convention of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, to be held on June 16 to 18 inclusive at Saranac Inn, it was announced here yesterday by the league.

The marketing of an issue of $10,000,000 of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $14,733,500. This compared with only $5,035,000 in new loans placed on the market last week. During this week a year ago a total of $58,693,000 in new bonds was offered.
