Nearly 1,000 members of the Actors Equity Association attended the organization's twenty-fourth annual meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday and voted for officers and members of the council. The resuits of the election will not be an nounced until Monday.

Four men, Democratic precinct officials and workers, received Federal prison sentences today for conspiring to steal votes in the November general election. Three women who pleaded no defense were placed on probation for three years by Federal Judge Albert Reeves.

The American Bemberg Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $10.50 a share on account of arrears on the outstanding $100 par 7 per cent preferred stock, in addition to the regular semi-annual dividend of $3.50 a share.

Dizzy Dean and the Cardinals' batting punch both were restored to the Gas House Gang yesterday. Beginning to hit with emphasis in the fourth frame, the Frisch boys pounded Luke Hamlin in the seventh for a five-run splurge and beat the Dodgers, 14--4.

Despite the exodus from Wall Street of bond and investment men to attend the annual outing of the Bond Club yesterday, there was a slightly better tone evident in securities on the New York Stock Exchange, with prices up moderately. United States Government issues continued steady and mixed in quiet trading.
Both games of the Browns-Athletics double-header today were decided in the tenth inning and each team got a victory. The Browns took the first, 7 to 6, and the Athletics the second, 4 to 3.

At least seven persons were burned to death today when they were trapped in a Greyhound passenger bus which overturned and burst into flames on a highway near Shiloah Springs, 48 miles north of Redding.

The Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company, Louisville, Ky., has appointed the Lawrence C. Gumbinner Advertising Agency to handle the advertising of Spud cigarettes, effective immediately. Max A. Geller will be the account executive in charge.

Combined United States imports and exports of foodstuffs in April, 1937, totaled $107,424,000, an increase of over 34 per cent, as compared with the April, 1936, volume of $79,900,000, according to preliminary figures released today by the Foodstuffs Division, Department of Commerce.

Federal Judge Phillip Forman denied today an application for a temporary injunction restraining the enforcement of New Jersey's anti-fireworks law. The court held the statute, enacted this year by the Legislature, to be valid,...

The exclusive story" of the Paul H. Wendel affair was offered for sale to several newspaper men more than a week before Wendel was actually kidnapped, the defense charged today in the Parker conspiracy trial before Federal Judge William Clark.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Carter Mebane of New Brighton, S. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Ruffin Mebane, to John Arthur Rianhard, son of Mr. and Mrs, Henry Work Rianhard of West New Brighton.

Asserting that a sufficient number of restaurant liquor licenses have been issued in New York City to take care of the needs of the public, Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, announced yesterday that new applications for that type of license would not be granted after July 15.

The commencement program at Manhattan College will get under way formally today with Class Day exercises. Brother Alphonsus, dean of the School of Arts, will address the 250 graduates, who, with their parents and friends, will assemble in Smith Auditorium on the campus for the program, which is scheduled to start at 3 P. M.

The railway wage negotiations under way in Chicago appear to be running true to form; that is to say, they are consisting of a long series of slow bargaining. From this it may be predicted that the results of the conferences will follow precedent by resulting in the unions accepting about one-half of what they originally demanded.

The patrol plan submitted by Great Britain yesterday to France, Germany and Italy has two merits. Its adoption would be expected to lessen somewhat the danger of recurrence of inflammatory incidents, and would offer a way by which, without loss of face, HITLER and MUSSOLINI could renew their representation on the London Non-Intervention Committee.

Despite Premier Leon Blum's personal intervention, the Senate tonight finished discussion of the government's Press Bill and maintained its own amendments to the text already voted by the Chamber, to which the measure now returns.

A bitter disappointment at 3 to 5 on the occasion of his last essay, the Everglades Stable's Deliberator showed a sharp reversal of form today to account for the twenty-fourth running of the $5,000 added Quickstep Handicap. D. W. Butler's Manners

Stocks moved within a narrow range and closed steady and dull; turnover, 342,440 shares. Bonds firm and generally higher in quiet trading; transactions, $4,338,900. Curb Exchange Stocks steady-in slowest trading since corresponding day a year ago: 73,645 shares traded.

Among the interesting features incorporated in the "house of tomorrow" at the North American Homes Exposition in Madison Square Garden was a bathroom styled by Henry Dreyfuss, as the "bathroom of today and tomorrow." His aim was to create a

The second war of independence that the Poles are now waging on the domestic front under the motto "Poland for the Poles" is directed first of all against the Jewish "nation" within their midst-composed of 3,150,000 persons, or nearly 10 per cent of the tota population.

Miss Janet Elizabeth Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson Richard Edwards of Brooklyn, was married last night to Talbot Babcock, son of Mrs. E. Howard Babcock and the late Dr. Babcock, also of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert P. Frazier and the Rev. John H. Fitzgerald in Christ Church, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.
Judge R. C. Stewart issued an order today restraining officials of the Committee for Industrial Organization from helping 106 sit-down strikers in the Dixie-Vortex Paper Cup Company plant.
MIss Elizabeth Jamison of Los Angeles became the bride here today of Paul Swan, Congresisonal medalist two was in charge of aircraft maintenance with Admiral Byrd's ??.
Utilization of the $1,000,000 Quoddy Village-model community of the suspended $36,000,000 Pasamaquoddy Bay tide-harnessing power project-for the National Youth Administration got under way today.

Miss Jeanette Grogan Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Bluet Johnson of Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Charles Henry Guerin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Guerin of Lynbrook, L. I. The Rev. Dr. J. Frederic Berg performed the ceremony in the Reformed Dutch Church of Flatbush.

SINCE the time of Plutarch, historians have never tired of observing that history repeats itself. The present situation in Spain, with its repercussions abroad, recalls the troubled events of a century ago, when savage civil war racked the Iberian Peninsula and the great powers of Europe intervened, intrigued and took sides.

THIS book is the story of a child. The child entered a convent when she was 15, and died of consumption at the age of 24, and within thirty years she was canonized as a saint. But the story of St. Therese of the Infant Jesus--the Little Flower of Lisieux-remains a simple and childlike story even through the years of her maturity and in her teaching and influence.

Miss Jane Eno Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Barber Howe of this place and New York, was married in St. Mark's Church here this afternoon to M. Nelson McGeary, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. M. Nelson McGeary of Greensburg, Pa. The ceremony was performed by Bishop John T. Dallas of New Hampshire, who was assisted by Canon H. Adye Prichard,- rector of the church.

Within a few days now, the national open championship, No. 40 in the series that began way back in 1895 with only elesen entities, most of them imporations from Scotland, will get under way at he Oakland Hills Golf Club, Birmingham, Mich., and the question before the House of Golf is: Who will it be?
SUMMER camping is now unde way, which makes it time for all Scouts to think of menus for days out-of-doors and of trying their culinary skill over hot wood ashes and rude fireplaces.
The Resettlement Administration's venture in producing moving pictures came under the scrutiny today of the Senate Special Committee on Government Reorganization.

J. Edward Breuer, in announcing that he will conduct several auction sales of improved and unimproved properties in the metropolitan area during June and July, says that more buying interest is being displayed in such sales than has been the case for several years.

Some early variety of wheat was cut in Kansas this week and the general harvest will start in about two weeks. The crop is estimated the largest since 1931. Additional rain improved pastures and raised hopes for a big corn crop. However, the Memorial Day holiday cut retail trade here 5 to 10 per cent under last week, and slightly under a year ago.

Amelia Earhart paused at this Northeast Brazil seaport today to have the control apparatus of her round -the- world monoplane adjusted. She planned to leave about 5 A. M. tomorrow (3 A. M., E. S. T.) on a 287-mile hop to Natal, near

A house costing less than $5,000 has been developed for Westchester County after two years of study and experimentation by local financial institutions and the FHA, according to Thomas G. Grace, State director of the administration. Such a dwelling, on a plot 62 by 100 feet, has been erected at a cost of $4,500, including land,

Miss Dorothiea Culver, daughter of Mrs. Rudolph C. Culver of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr. Culver, has chosen June 19 as the date for her marriage to Roderick- O. Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Williams of this city and Langatuck, Conn.
Dizzy Dean, suspended for three although he struck out three times, pitched the Cardinals to a 3-tovictory over the Phillies. It was his seventh triumph of the season, against four defeats.

THE air lines of the country are going in for larger and larger planes, ships with longer range and greater speeds. Already operators are calling on Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General, pointing out that even with present equipment it is costly business for them to drop in at "flag stops" where there are few passengers, very little mail and not much express.

Steadily plowing southeastward from Hawaii through tropical seas, the Steelmaker is carrying the Princeton University, Franklin Institute and Cook Observatory eclipse expedition nearer the point where the sun will be covered by the moon next Tuesday for a period longer than at any time in the last twelve centuries.

Striking crewmen refused tonight to obey the company's demand that they leave the Peninsular Occidental liner Florida. P. O. attorneys talked of legal steps to compel evacuation and spokesmen for the 150 strikers retorted, "We will meet force with force-first, of course, by law." Company officials asked the

Seventy-five seniors received diplomas last night at the graduation exercises of the First Institute of Podiatry in the auditorium of the Town Hall. Dr. Maurice J. Lewi, president of the institute, presided.
Three leading early Summer sectional flower shows will be held this week and next in the vicinity of New York, one on Long Island and the others in Westchester and Rockland Counties.
Three thousand students of the Department of Agriculture Graduate School will receive credit this month for their year's work without any of the fanfare of the usual commencement days.

EFFECTS of the midnight sun have been evident of late on American evening reception of European short-wave signals near 16 as well as near the 19meter waves. In midwinter, when the northern zone is dark and cold, signals from Europe near 16 meters are seldom heard after 3 P. M. here: but now as the sun circles

VIENNA. AUSTRIA'S Chancellor, Dr. Kurt von Schuschnigg, is today sailing seas as stormy as any he has yet faced. The Austrian policy of sole dependence on Italy as protector. against Nazi Germany shows signs of breaking down as the bonds between Germany and Italy grow stronger.

A strong plea for wider public interest in the preservation of historic buildings in the United States, particularly those of early years possessing real artistic and architectural merit, was made by Philip Dane Orcutt of the Boston chapter of the American Institute of Architects at the sixty-ninth convention of the institute held last week in Boston.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Jeanie 0. Abbot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Abbot Jr. of San Rafael, Calif., to Henry Greenwood Bugbee Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry G. Bugbee of 124 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Wednesday's statement of our foreign trade for April, and for the four first months of 1937, emphasizes the present extraordinary character of our international balance sheet. In April alone the surplus of imports over exports, $10,000,000, was the largest for that month in more than half a century.

De Witt Clinton and Textile tied for team honors, each tallying 17 points, in the third annual swimming meet sanctioned by the P. S. A. L. over a fifty-yard course yesterday in the Ravenhall pool at Coney Island. Richmond Hill's swimmers were third with 16.

Scoring a total of 74 points, the Department of Parks showed the way to nineteen other departmental teams in the New York municipal athletic carnival yesterday at Randalls Island Stadium, repeating its victory of last year.

Arrangements have been completed for the holding of the Summer week-end golf tourney under the sponsorship of the New York Athletic Club over the links of the Hotel Champlain Golf Club at Bluff Point-on-Lake Champlain June 26

MR. PREVITE-ORTON probably knows as much as any living man about the art of reading, writing and editing historical works. As one of several famous editors of the Cambridge Medieval History and of the English Historical Review, as author of many books, monographs and articles, as University Lecturer in History and as Fellow and Librarian of St. John's College, Cambridge, he has occupied for many years a place of marked eminence among scholars.

The Berkshire festival concerts by the Boston Symphony Orchestra are to be given in a tent in August again this year, as a permanent music shed cannot be completed in time at Tanglewood, Stockbridge, now owned by the orchestra. The canopy will be placed north of the formal garden.

A cable of protest against "the impudent aggressions from Germany and ne Italy against open cities and Spanish merchant ships," signed by re twenty-nine Spanish writers, artists and educators including Pablo Picasso, the painter, was made public by the Spanish Embassy today.

Bashful, 18-year-old Miss Betty Jameson defeated two Curtis Cup stars, one the defending champion, today and marched into the final of the women's trans-Mississippi golf tournament with her 'teen-age pal, Miss Patty Berg.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

RICHARD ALDRICH, for twenty-two years music critic of THE TIMES, has gone from us. As critic emeritus, since 1924, and contributor of editorials and book reviews to the paper, he was active almost to the day of his sailing, May 10, to visit his brother in Italy.

OF the still young Italian opera composers of today the most fortunate is Lodovico Rocca of Turin. His "Dibuk" was launched from ??a Scala on a tour of Italian and American houses, then Poland, Czechoslovakia and Croatia to date.

The usual replenishing of seasonal goods for immediate delivery was held down to a minimum in the New York wholesale market last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Both wholesalers and retailers endeavored to reduce their stocks. Accounts are waiting until prices are stabilized before placing generous commitments for staple and Fall merchandise.

An attempted hold-up of Jack Caputo, president of the Kings County Ice and Fuel Company, and two of his employes as they left the plant at 601 Van Sinderin Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, was frustrated when a third employee exchanged shot with the bandits at the corner of Van Sinderin and Lavonia Avenues.

A brief statement by the Astronomer Royal, Dr. H. Spencer Jones, to the board of visitors at their annual gathering at Greenwich Observatory today, that "the moon is moving off its calculated position," caused such a flurry in London tonight that Dr. Jones had his telephone removed.

Running with a torn heel, but as easily as if he had wings, War Admiral yesterday clinched the 3-yearold championship before 35,000 persons by winning the sixty-ninth Belmont in time that shattered Man o' War's track record set seventeen years ago.

Barring labor troubles, operations in this district continue at high levels. Strikes in the steel industry reduced production to 65 per cent in the Cleveland-Lorain area and to about 30 per cent in the Mahoning Valley. At Pittsburgh a drop of 2

Plile lJU on the grounds of the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant are hundreds of thousands of tons of neatly baled scrap metal. The small bales represent the last of salvaged material from the 199 idle ships which Henry Ford bought from the United States Shipping Board in 1925 for $1,706,000.

Miss Nancy Haldeman Putnam, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Currier Putnam of Windytop, Germantown, and the late Mr. Putnam, was married this afternoon to Philip Kay Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Schwartz of Mount Airy. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Malcolm E. Peabody in St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill.

A large new apartment house will rise immediately at the northeast corner of Popham and Chase Roads, Scarsdale as the result of the placing of a $500,000 building and permanent loan on the project at five per cent for ten years.

The last remaining panels of glass were placed in position in the ex- le terior walls of the new Corning Building on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street last week. Said to be the first office

Now that "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse" has transferred to the Savoy, the Haymarket will offer on Tuesday "To Have and to Hold," first seen at the "Q" Theatre in January. Keneth Kent retains the chief part, which Lionel Brown wrote especially for him, but the newcomers are Marie Ney and Dorothy Hyson.

Refundings by public utility companies featured last week the announcements of bonds called for redemption prior to maturity. The number of calls increased slightly over the preceding week, but most of them were for small parts of outstanding issues.

For a gallant deed of nearly eleven years ago, Lieutenant Richard Aldworth, United States Army Air Corps, retired, now superintendent of Newark Airport, received this morning the Distinguished Flying Cross at this post; from which he used to fly. Those present were Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commander of the General

In a double ceremony yesterday afternoon in St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Richmond, S. I., Miss Elizabeth Mandeville Bracher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vasa K. Bracher of Dongan Hills, was married to Robert C. Vincent, and her sister, Miss Cornelia Housman Brancher, became the bride of John Thomas Gwynne. The Rev.

BASSER-Mr. and Mrs. Max (nee Irma Fine), joyfully announce the arrival of Nan Marguerite on June 2 at St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway. BEJOSA-To Mr. and Mrs. Harry Belosa, a daughter, on June 2, 1937, at Park East Hospital. BERNSTEIN-Di. and Mrs. Eugene Bernstein (nee Eudice Elkind)- announce the birth of a daughter, Natalie Rachel, on June 3, at the Gotham Hospital.
Slot machines and punch boards have been ruled out of this village because the village's eighth grade pupils learned about them in the study of arithmetic.

JUST as tall and as genial as ever, Pie Traynor remarked that it certainly was swell weather, which nobody could deny. He had just led his Pirates into town and was about to herd them toward the Polo Grounds for the afternoon encounter with the Giants. As usual, Coach Jewel
ENGULFED as we are in architectural and decorative styles, in pontifical advice and rules from the homemaking and landscape gardening magazines in model

More than 100 detectives and policemen were searching the lower East Side yesterday for trace of 8-year-old Julia Pembroke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Pembroke, 15 Essex Street. The child disappeared while at play in Seward Park on Thursday afternoon. Her father is unemployed.

Miss Grace Kathryn Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Walsh of this city, was married to William A. Hennesey, son of Joseph Hennesey of New York and the late Mrs. Hennesey, yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima by the Rev. John

There appears to be wide difference of opinion on the probable effects of the passage by the State Legislature of a bill empowering the Tenement House Department to carry out alterations to tenements violating the Multiple Dwelling Law, and to charge the cost as a first lien against the building.

A pilotless airplane was a pile of twisted wreckage today because it developed a wanderlust. The plane, owned by a flying club, was being warmed up outside a hangar at Hythe last night when the throttle jammed. With no one at the controls, the craft roared into the air to circle for thirty-five minutes over Hythe, Lympne and Folkestone.

Eight graduates of the rabbinical college of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America will be ordained as rabbis this afternoon at the fiftieth anniversary convocation exercises in the quadrangle of the seminary, 122d Street and Broadway.

Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano received Sir Eric Drummond, the British Ambassador, this morning and informed him that Italy accepted in principle all points in the British proposals to assure the safety of international naval patrols off Spain.

The net income of the City and Suburban Homes Company showed an increase during the year ended April 30, 1937, for the first time seven years, the firm's annual report, signed by John A. Cahill, president, discloses. In this period the net income totaled $1,314,474 as against $1,175,759 reported for the similar period last year.

Analyzing some recent statistics on home building trends as compiled by the Bureau of Labor and comparing them with the loaning resources of the savings and loan associations throughout the country, the United States Building and Loan League states that the majority of residential construction is being done in the cities of largest population and those ranging from 50,000 to 100,00 in population.

The fears and disturbances that have been aroused in recent weeks over the persistent rumors that the Treasury in Washington was planning to reduce its gold-buying price have themselves provided, in the opinion of many bankers here, the best guarantee that no such step will be taken. They have given an emphatic demonstration that, as a
The Agriculture Adjustment Administration reported today that 2,698,059 tons of sugar were charged against quotas of offshroe areas in the first five months of this year.

On the 3d of last March Henri Dardillac, a native of Saint-Auvent, a village of 1,300 population near Limoges, 300 miles southwest of Paris, was guillotined in the public square of Limoges for murdering a couple of automobilists.

Miss Edithe Hertz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Hertz of 322 Central Park West, will be married this afternoon at Essex House to William Stephen Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Harry Brown of Greenport, L. I., by the Rev. Dr. David De Sola Pool of the Spanish Portuguese Synagogue.

Nine liners with 6,550 passengers left for Europe during the twentyfour hours ending at 12 o'clock last night and it was estimated by the police on duty at the piers that fully 12,000 visitors saw them off.
Cooper Union will hold its seventy-eighth annual commencement on June 10, in the Great Hall, it was announced yesterday by Gano Dunn, president of the institution.

FOR the second annual exhibition by Midwestern artists, the A. C. A. Gallery has as sembled oils, water-colors or graphics by a score of representatives of the arts in Minnesota, Illinois, Missouri, Iowa and Indiana. Joe Jones, one of whose pictures was recently acquired by the Metropolitan, is perhaps the best known of the group, most of whom are relatively young. Mr. Jones has sent two small but characteristic watercolors.
President Judge William M. Hargest of the Dauphin County Court today granted to three railroads temporary injunctions restraining

A 7,000-mile taxicab ride to Mexico City and return will begin Monday for Miss Emily Curtis Fisher, 76year-old retired normal school instructor. She prefers automobiles to trains, but neither owns nor drives car. So she engaged Fred
The third regatta in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship series, conducted by the Knickerbocker Yacht Club today, drew the biggest fleet to date, 109 boats. The wind,

New Jersey farmers who took part in the agricultural conservation program last year grew green manure crops on 69,418 acres, W. H. Allen, AAA executive officer for the State, has reported. Growing those crops, he added, was the most widely used soil-building practice of the 1936 program in the State.

In the insurance of mortgages on one to four family dwellings the Federal Housing Administration has established certain minimum requirements which it believes serve to assure the economic soundness of the security behind the mortgages and at the same time also to raise the standards of housing. These minimum requirements
Mayor Edward J. Kelly ordered the Republic Steel Corporation today to cease housing workers in its South Chicago plant.

AT the moment or this writing--and a warm moment, toothis corner has no way of telling whether it stands alone or is endorsed by the cash customers in its opinions of "I Met Him in Paris" and "Parnell," the two major Hollywood operations of the week. It probably does not
The entire fleet of intercollegiate eights for the rowing regatta June 22, will be encamped here by June 15, Peter H. Troy, chairman of the Poughkeepsie committee, said today.

Summer handbags that are stiff and cool to the touch and do not get out of shape in hot hands are real finds. Designers have looked afield for materials to fill this bill and have hit upon horsehair. New bags of horsehair and cross-grain morocco come in gay plaids in a range of colors, so that it is easy to find one that matches a Summer costume.
The committee of the outdoor art show in Washington Square reported last night that yesterday was the show's most profitable day, the artists taking in $544.25.

Taking a firm stand on governmental expenditure, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America has issued a statement deploring balancing of the national budget by cutting unemployment relief.
THE United States Army's private empire in New York Harbor, just off the Battery seawall, will have a week of celebration, beginning next Sunday. The purchase 300 years ago

ON a fatal twentieth of November. 1819, a Nantucket whaler. the Essex, was cruising on the vast and lonely Pacific. A sudden shout from her lookout turned her decks into a rush of ant-like activity as her crew launched three boats at once.

The description of strikes as a form of industrial warfare is unusually apt in the case of the strike being prosecuted against three independent steel companies on a widely scattered front by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

The Alabama Supreme Court, in a four-to-two decision acquitted today Sheriff J. L. Corbitt of Henry County, whose impeachment had been asked because of "negligence, grave fault, connivance and cowardice" in connection with the lynching on Feb. 1 of Wes Jordan, a Negro, supposed to have assaulted a white woman.

Glorious Summer weather greeted the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in Carinthia. The Gail Valley, in which Wasserleonburg Castle is situated, is one of Austria's loveliest corners. Yesterday it looked its best, with a soft Summer breeze stirring the May fruit trees that characterize the district.
For the first time in its history the Zionist Organization of America will hold its annual convention in New York, it was announced yesterday. Plans are being worked

The Indians, in the midst of a hot scramble to overtake the league-leading Yankees, welcomed home their youthful pitching star, Bob Feller, tonight, hopeful he will soon get into the line-up with his blazing fast ball.

UNKNOWN to them, telephonists between New York and Philadelphia may now be talking over the new coaxial cable or television "pipe," designed to carry images or 240 two-way conversations simultaneously.

A defense for the teaching of Latin in the high schools is made by Miss Florence D. Townsend, chairman of the Latin Department of Evander Childs High School, writing in the current issue of High Points, official Board of Education publication.

A busy week has been arranged at City College for the graduating class of more than 1,800 men and women who will receive degrees, diplomas and commissions at the ninetieth annual commencement in the Lewisohn Stadium on June 16.
THE Russian attempt to establisn a weather station at the top of the world-the North Pole-is the most spectacular gesture yet made in the slow conquest of the frozen Arctic Ocean.

The Rev. Dr. G. Campbell Morgan, pastor of Westminster Congregational Church of London, will preach tomorrow in the Tabernacle Presbyterian Church of this city, of which until a few years ago he was pastor.

Jurisdiction over workers in the taxicab industry in the city was transferred yesterday to the Transport Workers Union by its fellow C. I. 0. group, the Union of Automobile Workers of America, thus placing the T. W. U. in sole control of the organization for the C. I. O. of all transit workers in New York City and throughout the nation.

Discussing the possibilities and consequences of inflation, Irwin S. Chanin of the Chanin Organization, declares that inflation in any form will ultimately cause cessation in residential construction and will also produce high rents and substandard housing, particular to families of moderate incomes.

Although wholesalers of dry goods usually have come into the primary markets with secondary buying of Fall merchandise late in May or early in June, there was little indication here last week that they would do much more buying for Fall, and certainly will not purchase more than minor quantities this month, in the view of buying office executives here.
MR. ASCH has major aims, He wishes to create a great, revoutionary novel that will carry the message: "Unite". We are all sufering. he believes, and suffering from the same thing. That is want.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School scored a convincing team triumph to retain its championship in the eleventh annual City C. H. S. A. A. outdoor track and field meet, held at Boys High Field, Brooklyn,. yesterday.
The Dominion Government and the Ontario Government this week announced plans to aid development of the mining industry.
Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret Rose may be the darlings of the British people, but when they deserve criticism, great or small, they get it.

Farmers received considerably higher income from marketing of principal farm products in April of 1937 than the corresponding month last year, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today in making public comparative figures.

Vandals who visited the Trinity Church Cemetery at 153d Street and Amsterdam Avenue Thursday night, overturning 164 gravestones, made a second visit to another part of the burial place twenty-four hours Later, it was discovered early yesterday, when between forty and fifty additional stones were -found tipped or broken.

After an eighty-mile-an-hour chase that began five miles away from the scene of a $25 hold-up, two 17year-old youths were captured by radio car policemen shortly before 1 o'clock this morning when their car, from which they had

With the over-heavy inventories of retailers during recent weeks serving as a warning against speculative buying, advance purchasing for the coming Fall season will be much more conservative than the heavy commitments which featured last June and July, merchandisers here reported yesterday.

Jack Rourke, veteran trainer and track coach at Colgate University, and Fred Swan, line coach at Tempie, have been chosen to help Andy Kerr in preparing the Eastern AllStar football team which will play the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 8, it was announced yesterday.

James W. Scott, a director of the American Ice Company and a former president of the National Ice Association, the National Ice Company and the Burns Brothers Ice and Coal Corporation, died on Friday in the Lenox Hill Hospital of injuries received on Tuesday in an automobile accident. He was 69 years old and lived at 51 Eightyeighth Street, Brooklyn.

Advocating an extension of the mortgage period from twenty to thirty years, Joseph F. Mittelman states that home building is being retarded due to increased building costs and advances in down payments and monthly charges on mortgages because of increasing sales prices.

After listening to arguments in the Federal court for more than an hour Judge William H. Kirkpatrick stopped attorneys today and announced that he would refuse the petition of the Apex Hosiery Company for an injunction ousting 250 sit-down strikers from its mills.

The Fine Arts Federation of New York will present its plaque to Mayor La Guardia in recognition of his contributions to all branches of the arts in the city at the annual luncheon of the Municipal Art Society, to be held at the Biltmore Hotel Wednesday.
Air-conditioning research, points out Air Conditioning Trends, is beIng intensified in scores of manufacturers' laboratories and engineering experiment stations.

The public breach between National Socialism and the Vatican has brought the fundamental conflict in Germany between totalitarianism and Christianity into a new stage. Recent Church-State relations can be compared to the manoeuvering of opposed armies forced to engage in battle. Cardinal Mundelein's

One of the greatest golfers of modern history, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, will be in the field that starts play tomorrow at the Plainfield Country Club, Plainfield, N. J., for the women's Eastern title.

Miss Florence Virginia Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. R. Wilson of 35 Park Street, and William B. Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Ackerman of Turtlepoint, Pa., were married at Westminster Presbyterian Church this afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Raymond W. Smiley, pastor of the church.

Alumni of the University of Virginia will deliver the three principal addresses during the final celebration for the class of 1936 which begins June 11 and will continue through the following Tuesday, when degrees will be conferred by president Newcomb upon more than 400 graduates.

A steady to firm undertone ruled yesterday in quiet trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. There was little change in the attitude of the market from that prevailing in most of the short week. The two-hour turnover amounted to $4,338,900, compared with $3,863 400 on Saturday May 22.

Aircraft, engines, equipment and spare parts manufactured in the United States in 1936 were valued at $78,148,893 and 30,575 employes were engaged in the industry, the Bureau of Air Commerce annual survey disclosed today.

WASHINGTON.-Instead of 5,000, the old quota, each member of Congress, Democrats and Republicans alike, will have in his hands this year the distribution of 10,000 copies of the farmers' bulletins published by the Department of Agriculture. One of the most

Miss Lillie May Clarkson, daughter of Mrs. Rutgers Clarkson of this city, and Walter Stager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram W. Stager of Nutley, were married tonight in the First Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott officiated.

The first bulletin published by the Consumers National Federation, recently organized to serve as a clearing house for consumer organizations, contains a survey on "Price Control Conflicts" by Arthur R. Burns, Associate Professor of Economics at Columbia University. The article discusses the

A campaign for $15,000 to build a special pavilion at the Los Angeles Sanatorium for New York girls suffering from tuberculosis was launched yesterday at a luncheon of the New York chapter of the sanatorium at the Hotel Astor.

Failure to obtain credit from the bank on the promised guarantee of the Provincial Government has forced the Hail Insurance Board of Alberta to suspend operations, A. H. Tovell, chairman, announced today.

The properties of Archie M. Andrews, former head of the Hupp Motor Corporation, were placed under the control yesterday of J. Edward Lumbard Jr. and temporary received by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson.

The following Foreign Service changes since May 28, were announced by the State Department today: Jules Wadsworth of Middletown, Conn., Vice Consul at Shanghai, China, assigned to Danzig, Free City of Danzig, as Vice Consul.

VIOLENTLY belying its name was the Pacific, and in Los Angeles Harbor our mis-named jolly-boat nosed for the ooze or joggled on the peak of a tall wave before the next plunge. On the last upswing we grabbed some ropes and scrambled up the sides of the noble Star of Finland. This stout Alaskan fishing craft, you must know, now flies the Paramount house-flag and is in command of Captain Gary Cooper, alias Holmes.

Misplays by Brown in the third and fourth innings gave Tufts openings for the defeat of Brown, 5 to 1, to even this year's series today. John Hughes, Tufts pitcher, limited the Bruins to five scattered hits, while his mates collected ten off Bob Dye. Brown filled the bases with none out in the first and threatened repeatedly, but couldn't score unti the ninth.
Stewart McDonald, head of the Federal Housing Administpation, has been appointed chairman of the government delegation to the International Congress of Architects in Paris, July 18-25.
The Rhode Island State baseball team, New England Conference champions, swamped their traditional rivals, Connecticut State, today. The score was 17-0.

Business continued its sharp upward trend in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. Despite extremely warm temperatures in many leading centers, retail trade soared to the highest level for this season of the year since 1929. Department stores

The Passaic County centennial canoe championships will be held on the Passaic River in Paterson, N.J., this afternoon. Thirteen events are listed on the program, which is sponsored by the Paterson Canoe Club.

The annual report by President Sills of Bowdoin College announces gifts of $234,059.96 for the period from April 1, 1936, to March 31, 1937. The largest single item, other than additions to the Kling and Hubbard Funds, is the Field House, presented

A gift of $550,000 from Charles R. Walgreen, president of the Walgreen drug store chain, to the University of Chicago for the establishment of an institute to study American principles was announced today by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the university, at the annual luncheon of the alumni.

THE battles of French realism in fiction have been ought out and won so many years ago that new issues can no longer be raised about the questions of art versus morality which once sent Flaubert's "Madame Bovary" before the public prosecutor and. later on, made Zola's name in the days of "Germinal."

The Argentine track team that will compete in the Pan American Exposition at Dallas, Texas, from July 15 to July 18, will include Juan Zabala, winner of the marathon in the 1932 Olympic Games, according

A plan for the refunding of $10,753,000 bonded indebtedness of Asbury Park was heard here today in chambers by Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie. The program was outlined by Ward Kremer, Special City Solicitor of Asbury Park, and is. according to him. the first

Five hundred child refugees from Bilbao, Spain, their cheeks lumpy with candy, sailed from Cuba for a haven in Mexico today. Immigration officials balked plans for the children to disembark from their ship, the Mexique, for an entertainment in Havana,

Taxes on the childless for the benefit of large families and tax relief to self-supporting, would-be parents was advocated yesterday at the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the Eugenics Research Association to protect the birth rate of the socially desirable- which, it was said, is "dropping like a plummet," and precipitating a "birth crisis in the United States."

By COMPTON PAKENHAM RETURNING to the Vienna Philharmonic, after making the work with the British Broadcasting Corporation's ??chestra, but remaining under the victor label, Bruno Walter supplies e long expected re-recording of ??ahm's Third symphony, in F, ??us 90, replacing with the aid of date-to-date mechanics either the Simens Krauss (H. M. V.) or Kawkowski (Victor M-42) sets, both which have lost much of their een with the passage of time.

Class Day exercises were held today at the Stockbridge School of Agriculture, two-year vocational course at Massachusetts State College. The school is holding its eighteenth commencement this week-end.

THE seventh annual American Folk Song Festival will be held by the American Folk Song Society next Sunday afternoon at Traipsin' Woman Cabin on the Mayo Trail, about eighteen miles southwest of Ashland, Boyd County, Ky.

Proposals advanced last week by the Governors of Pennsylvania and Michigan served to draw more tightly the lines in the fight over attempts to permit emergency governmental operation of basic industries in this country.

THIS book costs half a dollar. It can be read in half an hour. It tells a sharp, memorable story about one of the things that trouble our strange day most-the fear and the fury that dictators use in their march to power: Leaderless men find a master, and the city falls.
The War Department released the following orders tolay, dated June 4: MAJOR GENERAL Baker, W. C., Chief of Chemical Warfare Svc., ten days leave, June 6.

In the American steel belt that girdles the southern shores of the Great Lakes there is labor trouble, and blood was shed last week on a scale that recalled the famous Homestead steel strike of 1892-one of the bitterest disputes in American labor history--in which Pinkerton operatives imported to protect non-union workers fought a pitched battle with strikers in which ten men were killed, sixty injured.

Gloom in Wall Street continued last week. Pessimism did not concern itself with prices, which held virtually steady, but with volume, which continued to ebb. Stock trading on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to only 2,955,280 shares, the lowest total for a fiveday week since that which ended on Feb. 16, 1935. On the Curb

After trailing the field of eight for all but a half mile of the mile and one-sixteenth route, F. L. Flanders's 5-year-old Blackbirder weaved his way through the pack in the stretch to win by a length from Mrs. C. E. Allen's Trouper today in the Massasoit Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

Miss Edith Laws, daughter of Mrs. Jessie Laws of Rochester, Minn., and the late John Laws, was married yesterday to Thomas Howell Jr. of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Howell of Summit, N. J. The ceremony was

For the eighth working day in succession, alarmed holders of gold offered large amounts here today in exchange for currency, although there was a slightly more confident feeling in the market, which was helped by President Roosevelt's reassuring statement yesterday that there would be no change in the United States buying price.

Arthur Ponsonby of Previews, Inc.,'has leased the C. E. Miessner property at Pomona, through the Gillies Agency. Previews also reported the leasing of the Garden City property of Henry McDaniel through Oliver Chichester.

There is to be a total eclipse of the sun on Tuesday-a paradoxical eclipse. It begins on June 9 and ends on June 8. It will be the longest to occur in more than 1,200 years, yet there is no place from which it can be viewed with entire astronomical satisfaction.

Dr. Valeria Parker, social hygiene authority, was slightly injured about 6 P. M. yesterday on the Grand Central Parkway Extension, Astoria, Queens, when her parked car was struck by an automobile driven by Dr. Harold S. Vaughan of 610 Park Avenue. Dr. Vaughan

Bacteriology has made such "giant strides" in a comparatively short time that it is today saving the lives of tens of thousands of children annually in this city alone, Dr. Charles Bramman Meding observed last week as he celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of his entry into the medical profession and of his becoming a trustee
More than 400 chemists will gather at the University of Minnesota, June 10 and 11, and at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, June 12, to participate in the annual colloid

The weather at the North Pole cleared sufficiently this morning for I. P. Mazuruk to take off from the ice where he landed 32 miles from the Soviet base and he arrived safely in the main camp at 7:12 A. M. He had been separated from the other planes since May 26.

Baltimore defeated the Jersey City Giants, 5 to 3, today to make it three straight over the visitors. Ben Cantwell, Jersey City pitcher, was debited with his second setback in nine starts this season.

Providing the beer is not consumed until the schooner General A. W. Greely reaches the waters of the Far North, members of the MacGregor Arctic expedition will be permitted to accept gifts of the beverage, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner Burnett ruled today "in the cause of science."

Children and grown-ups at Metropolitan Hospital on Welfare Island were treated yesterday afternoon to a preview of the National Boy Scout Jamboree that will be held in Washington, D. C., from June 30 to July 9. The show was given by Troop 472, and was the first of a weekly five-month entertainment program by Manhattan Council Scout Troops for the patients on the island.

Crowds in Harlem's "Little Italy," centering about 112th Street and First Avenue, were so dense at 7 o'clock last night following the accidental shooting to death of a neighborhood youth that a large detail of police had difficulty in keeping the avenue open. The lad who was killed was Dominick Stabile, 17 years old, of 430 East 115th Street, a grocery clerk.
George Dallas Dixon, former assistant to the president of the' Pennsylvania Railroad, died last night in his home here after an illness of several weeks. He was 80 years old.

By July, 1938, when the surplus from the 1937-38 coffee crop has been burned, Brazil will not have any more surplus to destroy. Fernando Costa, president of the National Coffee Department said he would launch a coffee anti-destruction campaign in July of this year in order to attain a statistical equilibrium which, incidentally, has

THE BIRTH OF CHINA" is an exciting book-far more exciting than its title and its rather stern, forbidding subtitle. "A Survey of the Fornative Period of Chinese Civilization"--a cold description of this dramatic exposition of the early inhabitants of the country we now call China.

Ninety visiting educators from institutions in the United States, Canada and Europe, will join the faculty of Teachers College for the thirty-eighth annual Summer session there, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Walter E. Hager, secretary of the college.

Thousands of footsore spinsters gathered tonight in Hyde Park, London's forum for those with grievances, to hear their leaders denounce the government for not providing pensions for unmarried women who reach and admit the age of 55.
Donald Glendenning, 32, president of the Cleveland Air Service Company, was fatally injured tonight when a small monoplane he was flying fell nose first in a field near the Cleveland Airport.
Disaster in a variety of forms cracked down on the Pirates yesterday as Pie Traynor's front-running Pittsburghers moved into the Polo Grounds to launch a three-game series with the Giants.

Discussing the subject of rising building costs, Thomas Holden, vice president in charge of statistics and research for the F. W. Dodge Corporation, in the current issue of The Agricultural Record, points out that past experience shows that three sets of powerful economic brakes usually operate to stabilize rising prices when the construction industry is only half way up in recovery period.

The ivory tower as a safe place for writers was ridiculed yesterday by speakers addressing 500 men and women, all writers of sorts, meeting at the New School for Social Research, where yesterday and today the American Writers Congress is in session.
Dr. John J. Cadigan, head of the Latin Department at the Boston Latin School since 1926 and former member of the Boston Board of Health, died yesterday at the age of 66.

Retail business in local department and specialty stores this week was satisfactory, viewed generally, and gains ranging from 20 to 25 per cent over the corresponding week of last year were recorded. One leading
James A. Mollison, British transatlantic flier, has given up hope of a raconciliation with his wife, Amy Johnson, his friends said today.

A program of detailed and continuous cooperation between the architectural profession and the construction industry to eliminate "jerry-built" houses and hastily erected commercial and industrial structures during the "steady climb toward prosperity in building" is urged by E. Kent Hubbard, president of the Connecticut Manufacturers Association.

SHANGHAI.-Largely because of persistent domestic pressure, the Chinese Government has relaxed its rigid censorship of press and speech which has been enforced for the past decade. The Chinese can print or say practically anything they choose now, if their disparaging comment is directed against Japan or some other foreign power.

WHETHER the automobile develops into "a malignant growth or a pearl of great price" will depend primarily upon the vision, initiative and boldness an planners in scrapping on the the present street and highway system and completely rebuilding it to bear the traffic of the future, Dr. Miller McClintock, head of the Bureau for Street Traffic Research at Harvard, told the Automobile Manufacturers Association in Detroit last week.

Many industrial accidents ordinarily attributed to the carelessness of workers can be prevented by proper plant design, Edward R. Grannis of the National Safety Council, Chicago, states in a report to the American Chemical Society. Greater attention to the safety factor when planning industrial buildings would do much to eliminate such accidents, he says.
Tex Carleton, veteran side-arm right hander, pitched the Cubs to a 6-to-3 victory today, limiting the Bees to eight hits.

General retail conditions improved in the Ninth District this week. Warmer weather brought department store sales to 10 per cent above the week previous. Sales were featured by a heavy turnover in women's apparel. Initial Summer stocks in women's shops were depleted and wholesalers reported considerably reorders for the week.

Development of the ninety-threeacre tract bounded by Lafayette and Metcalf Avenues and the Bronx River for park purposes will result in a marked improvement in real estate values and building activity in the immediate vicinity, states Charles Rubinstein, Bronx broker. The Board of Estimate

Sufficiently recovered to permit his removal to Detroit, Mickey Cochrane, indomitable pilot of the Tigers, was released from St. Elizabeth's Hospital yesterday, placed in an ambulance and put on a train for his home city.

Greenwich Academy held its 110th commencement in the auditorium this morning. Nicholas Roosevelt of New York delivered the address, his subject being "The American Tradition." The salutation was given by Arthur Calvert Smith. president of the board of trustees. Mrs. Ruth West Campbell, headmistress, awarded diplomas and prizes.

The German bombardment of Almeria as a reprisal for the bombing of the German pocket battleship Deutschland by planes belonging to the Spanish Loyalist forces has aroused spirited discussions among those members of Congress who fancy themselves international lawyers.

Mrs. Harris T. Baldwin, National League of Women Voters vice president in charge of the league's legislative activities at Washington, will speak here on Wednesday at a Nassau-Suffolk meeting of the New York League of Women Voters in the clubhouse at Bethpage Park.
The need for caution in reaching assumptions as to the future course of affairs in Washington has been pointedly emphasized by events of the recent past.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Knox Kennedy of Bermuda and this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kennedy, to Arthur Livingston O'Brien of Garden City, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Henry L. O'Brien of Brooklyn, took place this afternoon in the chapel of the Cathedral of the Incarnation. The ceremony was performed by Dean Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d.

Citing the tax situation throughout the country as one of the most serious impediments to real estate recovery, Harold Van Buskirk, president of Harold Van Buskirk, Inc., managing agents for the Oakhill Park development near Scarsdale, Westchester County, states that municipalities can do much to lighten the burden of taxpayers by encouraging residential building and developing.

Allotments of nearly $300,000,000 in loans and grants have been made by the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works to finance the construction of school buildings in the last four years, according to a survey made public yesterday by the research section of the Projects Division.

The picture of seven TVA's in place of one came out of the President's message to Congress last Thursday. It came out somewhat blurred, for Mr. Roosevelt spoke in general terms and the bills which Senator Norris and Representative Mansfield immediately introduced in their respective chambers differed in a number of significant details.

Eightytwo birdies and five eagles trickled into the cups today as Tommy Armour, the Silver Scot, and his longdriving Scottish partner, Jimmy Thomson, shot themselves from nowhere into a tie for the lead in the Inverness best-ball match-playtourney which ends tomorrow.
Continued protests from fishermen during the past few days indicate a growing sentiment against those who have been taking the small weakfish at Peconic Bay.

Properties of title and mortgage companies in liquidation or rehabilitation sold by the State Mortgage Commission in May brought prices which will assure to the certificateholders a full return of principal in every case but one, and some interest in a number of others, according to William Soper, assistant to John E. Allen of the commission's servicing corporation.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Whipple of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn McLean Whipple, to Samuel Hunter Austin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erle H. Austin of Rocky Mount, N. C.

The United States imported 3,478 tons of refined copper in the first four months of this year, compared with 2,884 tons in the corresponding period of 1936, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Exports were 86,830 tons, against 61,043 in the first four months of 1936.

Miss Sally Marie Picker, daughter of Mrs. John M. Picker of 41 Convent Avenue and the late Mr. Picker, was married in St. Patrick's Cathedral at noon yesterday to Gene T. Gunn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick F. Gunn, also of New York. Mgr. Peter H. McLean, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.
Halleck Lefferts, headmaster of Pomfret School, gave the commencement address today at Rectory School. Diplomas were presented by John B. Bigelow, headmaster, to the following graduates:

There is no evidence of any change of importance in the New England business situation. On the average, manufacturing activity continues about as it has been during recent weeks and off very slightly, if any, from the high point of the first quarter of the year. New business in many

After calling at Camper Nicholson's Gosport yard to ship a spare mast and gear for Endeavour II, T. O. M. Sopwith's luxurious yacht Philante sailed tonight for the United States, where she will act as the mother ship of both Endeavours.

The One Hundred and Fifth Commencement program of New York University will be formally opened this afternoon at 4 P. M. with baccalaureate exercises in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Libray on the University Heights campus.

The cornerstone of two new dormitories at the Stevens Institute of Technology will be laid after the commencement exercises next Saturday afternoon, it was announced today by President Harvey N. Davis.

While there appeared quite general agreement that the immediate net results-of the fair trade practice conference held last week for the popular-price dress industry by the Federal Trade Commission might be viewed as discouraging, it is nevertheless becoming evident that one of the broadest movements yet developed for the correction of trade evils in the women's apparel field is slowly taking form.
Mrs. James W. de Graff will open the gardens at her home, Cherridune, on Friday for a garden party and tea to aid the First Presbyterian Church here.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 3,000 head including 2,500 direct; practically an fresh receipts direct; nominally steady; shippers took none; estimated holdover 1,000.

A hot Memorial Day week-end followed by fairly seasonable temperatures brought a sharp upturn in retail sales here during the first week in June. Gains with some of the stores over last year ran as high as 35 per cent, with the average for the larger stores about 10 points below that figure.
Senate foes of the Roosevelt court bill threatened bluntly today to filibuster to the point of exhaustion against any compromise increasing the size of the Supreme Court.

The New England Southern Conference, Methodist Episcopal Church, went on record today as approving the action of the State of Texas in repealing permission for pari-mutuel betting on horse races and expressed hope that all States similarly situated might do likewise A resolution said:

The Duke of Windsor and his bride today found the peace and privacy for which he asked when they were married Thursday. They settled down to domestic life in old Wasserleonburg Castle, in Southern Austria's Dobratsch Mountains.

A team of all-America lacrosse players, sponsored by the United States intercollegiate Lacrosse Associaion, will sail for England on June 8 to play a seven-game series with he pick of British teams, it was announcedd today.

OCEAN travelers are again on the lookout for sea monsters. Recent reports have it that a giant sting-ray measuring fifty feet across battled the freightor Lewis Luekenbach for two days in Mexican waters; that a thirtyfoot sea serpent with a flowing red mane and dinner-plate eyes appeared briefly off the Scottish coast: that Mediterranean

Thousands of Japanese children, many weeping bitterly, took part today in Buddhist funeral ceremonies for the "departed spirits" of 12,000 dolls that "died" in the past year. While the children stood in front of long tables on which the shattered remains of their dolls 'lay,

Now that the Paris Exposition has been declared open by President Lebrun, the majority of the foreigners who came to attend the inauguration ceremony two days ago have left the city. Many will return when the various buildings have been completed, about the middle of next month.

French naval authorities tonight ordered warships attached to the port of Saint-Jean-de-Luz to protect French fishing boats from that and neighboring ports after armed Spanish Insurgents had boarded and searched the French fishing boat Croix du Jour.

ROSENFIELD--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph (Estelle Gottlieb), 824 West 176th, announce bar mitzvan of son, Adrian Martin, June 12. Temple Rodeph Sholom. Dinner, Hotel Bolivar. Reception at home saturday evening. SLAOMON--Mr. and Mrs. Al. Salomon 41-31 Case St., Elmhurst, announce bar mitzvah of Burton, June 12 , 10:30 A. M., Flushing Free Synagogue, Sanford Ave., Flushing.

The sixtieth anniversary of the New York Hospital School of Nursing will be observed on Wednesday at the annual Alumnae Day at the hospital, York Avenue and East Sixty-eighth Street. The school is the second oldest school of nursing in the city.
Although proposed as a safety measure, a bill for restriction of freight train-lengths introduced in the Senate would increase hazards, according to the Association of American Railroads.
Running true to pre-game predictions, the Andover nine triumphed in the annual meeting with Exeter today. The score was 8 to 0.

The nation-wide strike of 17,000 oil workers will be ended by President new Lazaro Cardenas by Monday, it was officially announced late tonight. No details were given in the announcement, but it is believed that the President is dictating a settlemeant.

The United Automobile Workers Union massed its membership for a rally in sight of the Ford Motor Company today as a challenge to its organizing campaign came from an "independent" group of Ford employes.

The engagement of Miss Zelda Radow, daughter of Mrs. Bernard Radow of this city and Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Radow, to Stanley H. Weintraub, son of Mrs. Fred Weintraub of New York and the late Mr. Weintraub, has been announced by her mother.

Beautiful roses in abundance are not to be had without adequate protection to the plants on which they grow. It is remarkable, however, how many gardeners will buy the best of varieties, spare no trouble or expense in preparing the beds for them and then neglect to guard them against insects and diseases.
THE present season offers lovers of the sea and its stories what may be the last chance to see whaling's most ambitous memorial. "Whaling Enrined," a project in which the Colonel E. H. R. Green
FRANCIS H. PIERPONT. By Charles H. Ambler. Svo. Chapel Hill, N. C.: The University of North Carolina Press. $5. A life of the Union war Governor of Virginia and father of West Virginia.

Sound recording of bird songs by short-wave radio and mapping by aerial photography are leading features of the plans of a scientific expedition being sent to the Bay of Fundy under the auspices of Bowdoin College and with the cooperation of Harvard and Cornell Universities and several other institutions.

Substitution of picketing as labor's principal weapon in C. I. O.'s current dispute with some of the independent steel companies for the sit-down strike employed in the recent disturbances in the automobile industry places the legal aspects of the steel strike on more familiar grounds than were the problems involved in the automobile strike.

The sixth annual Young Artists Contest, under the auspices of the MacDowell Club of New York, will be held early in October, it was announced yesterday. The object of the contest is to provide, without expense, a recital in the MacDowell Auditorium for outstanding young musicians.

Some members of the Joint Congressional Committee considering the BlackConnery Wages-and-Hours Bill have served notice that they will fight for authority to restrict imports if necessary to protect manufacturers from foreign competition. A few will simply demand "permissive authority" by which the proposed Labor Standards

Miss Elizabeth Pond, daughter of Charles M. Pond of Hartford, was married to Robert H. Dalton, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Dalton of Holland, Va., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Hartford Theological Seminary. The Rev. Frederica Mitchell of Keene Valley, N. Y., Performed the ceremony.

At least one nurse and one physician should be assigned to every high school, Mrs. Beatrice C. Spier, chairman of the committee on children's health of the United Parents Association, declared in a report made public last week.

THE Countryman Press of Weston, Vt., has entered into a publishing alliance with Farrar Rinehart of New York, by the terms of which certain items will be published under a joint imprint. Other books will be issued in limited editions by The Countryman Press, and later on in trade editions by Farrar Rinehart.

Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, declares that the recently organized Home Builders Guild possesses potentialities not only for real usefulness but also to provide a service which riay have an important bearing upon the development of a national program of well-planned home production in future years.

Weary Legislators, preparing for final adjournment of their fivemonth regular session, sent tonight to Governor Earle's desk the Frey bill restricting employment in Pennsylvania industry to forty-four hours a week.

A series of four surveys, all dealing with problems of immediate interest to food manufacturers, will be launched in the next ten days by committees named at the semiannual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at Hot Springs, Va., early last week. The committees will meet to

A 100-to-1 shot came through today to win the New Jersey State amateur golf championship when Ian MaoCallum, Ridgewood Country Club player, defeated Paul De- B. Scott of the Essex County Country Club, 3 and 2 in the final.

Workers at two local mines of the Republic Steel Corporation were idle today as the strike in steel plants made its first effects felt here. The Pabst Aurora mines suspended operations yesterday when strike-bound Republic plants in the East were unable to unload iron ore shipments.

Vicar General of United States Army chaplains during the World War, the Right Rev. Mgr. William M. Foley will celebrate tomorrow the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination as a priest. A solemn jubilee mass will be held at St. Ambrose Church, his home parish.

Eight players gained the fourth round as the twentieth annual Brooklyn tennis championship tourney, with three former holders of the title among the seventy-five entrants, got off to a fine start yesterday on the clay courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush.

The marriage of Miss Loretta Anne McManus, daughter of Mrs. Katherine McManus of this city, to Joseph F. McCloskey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. McCloskey of West Orange, took place this afternoon in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Michael J. Corr.

Six records, including a Long Island mark, were shattered today as Central High School of Valley Stream triumphed in the second annual Nassau County track and field championships with a total of 28 points.

George B. Underwood, associate State director of the FHA in New Jersey, has resigned that post to take effect June 15 to become associated with John R. Franke of Irvington, N. J., realtor and banker, in the formation of the UnderwoodFranke Mortgage Company.

FIVE expeditions will be sent out this Summer by the American Museum of Natural History in search of specimens for the enrichment of its halls. Exploration has become a routine matter to members of the museum's staff, for every year they invade deserts and jungles, traveling vast distances and invariably returning with valuable accessions. Fordham's baseball team, labeled at the start of the season one of the weakest college nines in the city, climaxed its 1937 campaign yesterday with a 9-to-4 triumph over redoubtable Long Island University and thus entrenched itself as mythical metropolitan champion for the second successive year.

Traffic fatalities in New Jersey at the end of the first four months of 1937 were greater than any comparable period in the last six years, it was reported today by State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee. The number killed this year was 380 which was 139 more than in the

Miss Elizabeth Vaux Ingersoll, daughter of Mrs. Edward Ingersoll of Spring House Farm, Penllyn, was married this afternoon to Dr. Stephen Stockton Woolston of Chestnut Hill. The ceremony took place in St. Thomas Church. Whitemarsh.

Mrs. Aurelia McDearmon Caldwell Glass, wife of United States Senator Carter Glass, died this morning at her home, Montview Farm, near Lynchburg, after a long illness of a heart ailment.

A garden course conducted by the Federated Garden Clubs of Connecticut will be given at the Connecticut College for Women in New London on June 16 to 18 inclusive. The program will cover particularly trees and shrubs,

AT Potsdam by the historic "Bittle Elm," where the Hohenollerns used to receive the petitions of their subject, stroll men in uniform. y the shores of the Wannsee, now sparkling once again in the warm sunlight, wander men in graygreen blouse and gray trousers and men in the blue-gray of the air force.
The statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for May 31 shows that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation rose to 130.67 per cent from 129.04 per cent on May 15.

Early one beautiful Saturday morning in June, 1946. Leonidas J. Nickleby, 26, of 1,178 weat Seventy-third Street, Social Security No. AK 165,987, wsa washing down his small Fod coupe in front of the gaage, preparatory to staring out for a week-end in Commenticut, when he was approached by a Federal marshal's assistant and told he was drawing too much water from the hydrant.

THIS book is based on a false premise. The subtitle tells us that America was once Asia's good neighbor, and asks if we can be so again. The obvious assumption is that at present we are bad neighbors. Mr. Karig tells us that his story is without a hero.

Lurching away from a Sing Sing prison guard and jostling attorneys from his path, Chang Soo Lee, Korean houseman who was convicted at White Plains on March 11 of poisoning two friends of his employer, leaped from an eighth-story window in the Supreme Court chambers of Justice Sydney A.

More than 10,000 physicians from every section of the United States will gather here this week for the eighty-eighth annual meeting of the American Medical Association, largest organized medical body in existence with more than 100,000 members. The meeting, which will
Across the Great Plains area, once center of the nation's Spring wheat and livestock industries, another "Sahara" is in process of formation.
Honorary degrees of Doctor of Letters were presented here today at the annual commencement

NEW methods of illuminating a room are being evolved by that latest of technological experts, the lighting engineer, in cooperation with the decorator. Although the play of light and shadow has always been taken into account in the well-decorated room, it is

Marked improvement featured retail trade here last week, with several of the local department stores scoring sales gains of from 12 to 20 per cent over the comparative period last year. High temperatures spurred the call for Summer apparel, with home furnishings likewise doing well.

There is "no greater fallacy" than to believe that the time of opportunity in America is past, Carl Raymond Gray, retiring president of the Union Pacific Railroad Corporation, declared today at the 136th annual commencement of Washington and Jefferson College.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Low Bacon gave a large dance tonight at their home here. Many small tables were set up in the garden for supper. Dinners before the party were given by Mr. and Mrs. David E. Finley in honor of H. M. van Haersma de With, the Netherlands Minister, and Mrs. de With; by Mrs. Warren Delano Robbins, Mrs. Emory Sands and Mrs. Higgins Chapin.

Transfer of Archbishop Edward Mooney from Rochester, N. Y., to Detroit as head of the newly created Archdiocese of Michigan has led to some conjecture about the future of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower at Royal Oak, Detroit suburb.

THE honor of having written a new and scientifically incontestable chapter in anthropology is the thing Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Pearson, amateur explorers, seem proudest of when they discuss their current film, "African Holiday."

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. George Lansing Farrington of 19 De Koven Court, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Clinton Farrington, to Harvey F. Raymond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen I. Raymond, also of Brooklyn.

A 120-year-old homestead, presented to the city for restoration and preservation as an example of an early American home, has been returned to the donor. Batavia's Common Council wrote to Geroge Cary, Buffalo architect who gave the home to the city.

Miss Ruth Margot Dunn, daughter of Mrs. Andrew J. Dunn of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Dunn, was married yesterday morning to Thomas B. McGowan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. McGowan, also of Brooklyn, by the Rev. James Saunders, cousin of the bridegroom, in St. Saviour's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

Police drove a crowd of about 350 irate racing fans off the racing strip at Thorncliffe Park today after they had deplayed the. start of the third race for more than two hours.
On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight, June 6: PATROLMAN-Owen F. Devery, 43d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 9, 1911.

HOUSTON is preparing to become the Texas gateway to the Pan-American High way. In the near future her civic leaders expect a tremendous tourist trade to pour in from the North and deep. South on the way into Mexico, and eventually into Central and South America. The city has more than 100 hotels now, but anticipates a demand for more.

Raymond Pond, head coach of the Yale football eleven, gave his blood today in an effort to save the life of William Hinchliff, for twentythree years Yale tennis coach and an authority in this sport, who is ill in New Haven Hospital with a streptococcus infection and arthritis.

Millions of gas masks have been secretly prepared in Germany and will now be distributed to the populace, Colonel General Hermann Goering, the Air Minister, announced tonight. He contends that the new mask, although inexpensive, is impervious to all known poison gases.
Commencement exercises for thirty graduates of Georgian Court College were held today. The degrees were conferred by the Most Rev. Moses E. Kiler, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Trenton.
Europe probably has had no more critical moment since the World War ended than the Valencia Cabinet meeting Monday morning, after German warships had bombarded Almeria.
William Yost, who for 22 years until 1922 was the Far Eastern representative of the American Express Company, died Friday night at the Beth David Hospital after aI long illness. He was 48 years old.

A large rustic lodge, nearing cornpletion on Barrett Hill in the Carmel Country Club section of Carmel, Putnam County, N. Y., has been sold to Howard L. White of the New York Herald Tribune. The cottage is situated at an elevation of 1,100 feet and commands views of Putnam, Dutchess, Fairfield and Westchester Counties.

Mr. and Mrs. John Vance Hewitt of 40 East Eighty-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Drennan Hewitt, to Charles Clark Austin, son of Mrs. Eberhard Heller of this city and the late Charles Wilbur Austin.

Subtle refining of present style trends in the period and modern types of design now widely found in all classifications of home furnishings, rather than radical changes, are indicated for the Fall season, according to the forecast prepared by the Style Trend Council of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers.

Summer came to the New York Police Department last week. When the thermometer soared toward 90 degrees in the shade, Commissioner Valentine issued an order permitting the doffing of the trim blue jackets--"blouses" the department calls them-in favor of the regulation blue shirt. A black four-inhand tie was prescribed. Suspenders were banned.
Mrs. Theodore Inslee Jones of White Plains, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Olley Virginia Jones, to James Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Robbins of Milton, Mass.

The marriage of Miss Patrice McCormick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. McCormick of Tarrytown, N. Y., to John Holt Baxter of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kirkman Baxter of Beverly Hills, Calif., took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. John the Baptist, Brooklyn.

UNITED STATES postal authorities are going to have a busy Summer. Even before the 5-cent Army and Navy stamps were placed on sale it was officially announced that a stamp to honor Virginia Dare would be released about the middle of August.

Voters at the municipal election this Fall will find themselves required, for the first time; to use voting machines for the election of city-wide candidates and paper ballots for the election of City Councilmen under the proportional representation system of voting.

IN all probability no other orches tra today is providing as many unfamiliar works to its patrons as the Illinois Symphony Orchestra. This Chicago unit of the Federal Music Project has achieved the proud record of performing fifty-one novelties in the course of the thirty-seven Sunday afternoon concerts it has given to date in Chicago's Great Northern Theatre.

The fact that graduate and professional schools today limit the number of women they admit is evidence of an increasing reaction against the educated woman, in the opinion of Dr. Marjorie Hope Nicolson, dean of Smith College, who delivered the address at the sixteenth annual commencement of New Jersey College for Women here today.
