A syndicate known as Beverly Lake Park, Inc., of which John T. Holmes is vice president, was the buyer of the 440-acre Iselin estate property in New Rochelle and East Chester, Westchester County, reported last week by the Cross Brown Company, brokers in the transaction.
George H. Scott died today at the Home Memorial Hospital after an operation yesterday. He was 87 years old. A resident here seventy years, Mr. Scott was in charge of the
The Montreal Trades and Labor Council, representing 50,000 union workers, sent a letter to (Buck) Jones today because the movie star built his new California home with non-union labor.

Until General Emilio Mola's death in an airplane accident plunged the Nationalists [Insurgents] into mourning, they jubilantly viewed the week's earlier events as foreshadowing "the beginning of the end" of the war.

Miss Margaret Sprague Lippincott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sprague Lippincott of Wayne, Pa., was married here yesterday morning to Alfred Rockwell Sumner, son of Eliot Sumner of Villanova, Pa., and the late Mrs. Sumner. The ceremony was performed in the Church of the Transfiguration by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

An unusually large number of the large copper cents used in this country from 1793 to 1857 will be sold at auction in addition to many early silver and gold coins next Wednesday afternoon in the Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Fortyseventh Street, by order of Wayte Raymond and J. G. Macallister.
Charles L. Chapin of this city, president of the Chapin Gould Paper Company, died this morning in his eighty-first year. He was born in Springfield and educated here.

A continuing split between A. F. of L. and C. I. O. union leaders today virtually put to an end a strike of Providence meat packing and provision house employes and dispelled fears of any week-end meat shortage for Rhode Island consumers.
The cornerstone of an addition to the Hospital of St. Barnabas and for Women and Children will be laid here Wednesday afternoon at a ceremony that will begin at 4 o'clock.

Jamaica High's formidable base. ball' team beat Curtis High of Staten Island in their semi-final contest of the annual City Public Schools Athletio League tournament yesterday. A crowd of 3,000 at the Jamaica Stadium saw Coach Frank Brennan's lads score nine runs in the fifth and, win by 11-3.
Old Castle Garden Feis, under the auspices of the Home for Irish Immigrant Girls, Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, noon.

The marriage of Miss Florence James, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Edward James of Verona, to William Armour Crawford, son of Mrs. David Crawford of Cedar Grpve, took place this evening in the First Congregational Church here.

The commencement activities of the Peekskill Military Academy will begin tomorrow with a review on the Depew Athletic Field. The baccalaureate services will follow in the Ford Auditorium. The Rev. Dr. Livingston Robinson of Chicago will address the cadets, officers and their guests.

A decided rebound in business has been felt during the current week throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District. Few threats of labor troubles have disturbed business and there has been increasing activity in practically all lines.

John M. Cornehlsen Jr. of Mineola has been appointed director of the men's residence at St. Lawrence University to succeed Mark B. Banks, who has resigned. Mr. CornehIsen is district director of the National Youth Administration for Long Island.

Fraldy Cat, sprinter from the Hal Price Headley Stable, won the $3,000 added Belle Isle Handicap today, and Charles T. Fisher's High Maria galloped in four lengths in front to take the $2,000 St. Clair Stakes.

The pinching, smelling, thumping method of buying fresh fruits and vegetables, has at last been made unnecessary in New York. From now on, housewives will generally be able to find out the quality of an item simply by asking their grocers, "What U. S. grade is it?"
Doing their part to make Rabbit Maranville Day a real success for their manager, the Montreal Royals salvaged the final game of a threegame series today by handing Toronto a 6-1 trouncing.

In an effort to induce Governor Herbert H. Lehman to sign three bills affecting substitutes, about 400 teachers formed a mass picket line in front of his home at 820 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon, carrying placards and chanting pleas for favorable action.

The marriage of Miss Mae Nancy Morales, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Morales of West New York, N. J., and the late Mr. Morales, to Dr. Edward R. Crozier, son of Mrs. Joseph Crozier of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Mr. Crozier, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
FEW professions seem to have as much fascination for the layman as the profession of medicine. If one may judge by the sales figures, books which

Prince Fumitaka Konoe, son of the recently named Premier of Japan and captain-elect of the Princeton golf team, captured the university open golf championship today by turning back Sophomore Ed Clark, 4 and 3, in the thirty-six-hole final on the Springdale course.

Within a short time all Public Service Corporation transportation workers in New Jersey will have one day off in seven, it was learned today. A five-day week was put into effect today for Public Service head office, commercial office and branch commercial and sales offices for the Summer months.

District Attorney Oscar Jones announced tonight that Frank O'Neil, a tool dresser, 40, son of John O'Neil, slain New York municipal judge, is recovering in a hospital here from injuries reported received when he went to New York for his father's funeral.

Miss Alice Wardle Byers, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Mortimer W. Byers of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Allen Krepps Holding, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. C. Holding of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Charles Henry Webb, chaplain of St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, performed the ceremony in the Church of The Messiah and Incarnation, Brooklyn. He was assisted by the rector of the church, the Rev. Dr. Frederic M. Adams.
The arrival of hot weather spurred retail sales to almost unprecedented proportions in the Eighth Federal Reserve

THERE are some historical characters who dwindle in perspective as time goes by until they have passed the vanishing point. There are others who seem, if anything, to take on bolder and more striking outlines with the lapse of centuries.

IN picking out Winfield Scott for a new biography Arthur D. Howden Smith has found a field not too much explored. In spite of the fact that he held high commands in three wars was politically important between wars, and had a picturesque and peppery personality.

One of the largest home development deals in Queens Borough this season has just been closed in the purchase of an acreage tract providing facilities for 1,500 dwellings in the southerly section of Elmhurst by Stewart Willey, a builder for many years in various sections of Queens.
A home builders' guild has been organized by the National Association of Real Estate Boards. Its main object will be in the direction of cooperative effort to reduce the cost of home construction.
After Harvard had tied the game by an eighth-inning rally, Holy Cross scored in the ninth to defeat the Crimson by a 5-to4 count before 2,000 spectators at Soldiers Field today.

Miss Marian Elizabeth Hughes, daughter of Mrs. Myra R. Hughes of Royal Oak, Mich., was married to Herbert William Janzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. A. Janzer of Glendale, L. I., this evening in the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Hyland R. Johns, brother-in-law and sister of the bride.
Edwirn Carnes Weeks, a member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Henderson Co., 40 Wall Street, died at his home here today at the age of 73 after a fortnight's illness.

Sheriff Ralph Elser or Manoning County, aided by forty-five deputies and a squad of Struthers police, successfully crashed the C. I. O. picket lines today and for the first time since the strike was called ten days ago delivered a freight car loaded with food into the yards of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

LIFE-SAVER: The dockmaster at the Battery, tip of Manhattan Island, is Peter (Buck) McNeil. Up to last week he had rescued sixty persons from drowning; then he chalked up his sixty-first, hauling out a would-be suicide who had jumped over the seawall. For his life-saving

The action charging slander, brought by Ernest A. Simpson, former husband of the Duchess of Windsor, against Mrs. Joan Sutherland, was twenty-third on the list made public today for special jury action in the Kings Bench Division.
One hundred and thirty-five contracts for supplies under the terms of the Public Contracts Act were let by nine government agencies in the week ended on June 3.

War Admiral, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the PreaKness, captured the $50,020 Belmont Stakes before 35,000 persons at Belmont Park and clinched the 3-year-old championship. Samuel D. Riddle's racer, 9-to-10 favorite, coasted through the stretch to win by four lengths at the end of a mile and a half, his time of 2:28 3-5 shattering Man o' War's track record set seventeen years ago. Sceneshifter was second and Vamoose, 60-1 shot, third.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler today gave five shiploads of German workers a joint holiday cruise and a lesson in battle tactics while his naval armada played at war. A skeleton German fleet, a large part of its units away in Spanish waters, took part in the first war manoeuvres off Helgoland since

IT used to be said that cavalry officers thought, talked and dreamed only of horses. They were pikers compared to the young men that constitute the Army Air Corps, with their talk, thoughts and dreams of flying.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Carter Barney, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Nicholson Barney of 189 East Sixty-fourth Street and Fredericksburg, Va., and the late Dr. Barney, to Dr. John Elmer Lewis of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Henry Lewis of Ottawa, Ont., took place yesterday at noon at the home of her mother. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church.
OF all the drama's annual rumors, none is surer to turn up tan the one that would have John Barrymore sloughing off time and the movies and acting "Hamlet" on a state once more.

The marriage of Miss Mary Victoria Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Preston Smith of Upper Montclair, to Rudolph Svenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Svenson of North Caldwell, took place today in St. James Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Robert W. Trenbath.

FOWLER, CHRISTINE B. (May 30). Estate more than $10.000. To B. Sherman Fowler, husband, executor, 30 W. 54th St., residue. HUSTON. ANNIE (May 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mabel Castleberry, daughter, 210 W. 101st St.; Amy V. Huston, daughter, 504 W. 110th St Ethel H. Goodwin, daughter. Palenville and Walter C. Huston, son, Glen Head, L. I., one-fourth residue, each.

In its monthly report the employment bureau of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations reveals a slight increase during May in the labor turnover in the building service field. Calls upon the bureau for men rose 1.7 per cent over April and 9 per cent over the average for the eight months ended Dec. 31, 1936.
The wedding of Miss Helen Elizabeth Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Chase of this city, to Charles Snead Allen of Durham, N. C., took place tonight in the Church of the Messiah.

The marriage of Miss Nancy H. Vane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Sailer Vane, to Edward Charles Winn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert J. Winn of Yonkers, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents in Scarsdale. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James E. Doris.

Eight log cabins and eighteen sites for Summer homes were sold during the Decoration Day holiday period in the Highland Lakes community, near Stockholm, N. J., reports the Seckler Shepperd Company, developers of the 1,500-acre tract. Among the buyers were:

THERE is no "sit-down" in war-shadowed Europe's radio progress. Politically the Old World may be confused, but in radio it seems to be moving in one direction-ahead, despite barbed-wire frontiers and fortifications.
Ten New Jersey track records were shattered as about 500 athletes competed in the nineteenth annual State Interscholastic Athletic Assoclation championship meet today at Essex Field.

Ground was broken today for a new $280,000 recreational center at St. Albans, the National Cathedral School for Boys. The ceremony was a part of the commencement exercises, during which diplomas were given to twenty-nine youths. The Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Bishop of Washington, and Canon Albert

Miss Mary Isabella Stuart Brown, daughter of Mrs. Harold McCleave Brown of 157 East Eighty-first Street and the late Mr. Brown, was married here this afternoon to Bradford Willet Stiles in the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, of which the bride's grandfather, the late Rev. Thomas McKee Brown, was the founder and first rector. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Winthrop Peabody.

William E. Cotter, '13, of New Rochelle, N. Y., was named president of the University of Notre Dame Alumni Association at the annual commencement dinner here tonight. He is vice president and general counsel of the Union Carbide and Carbon Company of New York.

Tom M. Girdler, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, protested to Postmaster General Farley in a telegram today against the refusal of local postmasters at Niles and Warren to accept food for delivery into his company's plants.

Eighteen dog show organizations promoted obedience test classes during the ten months ended last April. During the season of 1937 it is expected that these competitions will be greatly increased in number, in addition to showing larger entry lists, much higher quality of work in the several divisions, and even more enthusiastic Interest on the part of the spectators.

NOW that June is here we may as well agree that the 1936-37 local art season is over. Activity, of course, is by no means at an end. This will continue for several months, no matter how hot the town gets, operating under the auspices of a Summer interregnum. Then, some time

BLECHER--CHARNAS--Mr. and Mrs. Julius Charnas, 35 Crown St., Brooklyn, N. Y.. announce the engagement of their daughter, Arline Enid, to Mr. Samuel Blecher, son of Mr. Max Blecher, Brooklyn. COTTON - BERGER - Mr. aud Mrs. Max Berger announce engagement of their daughter, Rae, to Mr. Bert Cotton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Cotton.

After a conference at which President Roosevelt outlined his legislative program for this session, House leaders returned to the Capitol today agreed that Congress would be here most of the Summer.
" The Flying Wasp" Sean O'Casey has written a series of essays on the modern theatre that ought to appeal to an American drama critic.

Yale clubbed a pair of New York A. C. pitchers for ten lusty blows to score a decisive 10-to-3 victory over the Winged Footers today. A sixrun outburst in the third inning, which was touched off by a home run by substitute catcher Paul Wargo, settled the outcome early in the loose game.

Harris Noon, trotter owned by Harry Elias of Oradell, N. J., and driven by Charles Pennock, turned in a winning heat of 2:07 3/4, the outstanding race of the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

WITH the consistency of an early, June heat-wave, this department annually finds itself acknowledging the arrival of Summer by checking the list of rural playhouses which will dot our fair landscape during the season at hand and foretelling the schedules of their attractions.

William F. Carey Jr., 24 years old, of 1 Beekman Place, son of the Commissioner of Sanitation, was held in $200 bail yesterday, on a charge of driving an automobile while intoxicated, by Magistrate Anna M. Kross in the West Side

Miss Jane Langford, daughter of Colonel Edward J. Langford and Mrs. Langford of this place, was married this afternoon to John Norton Terry, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Warren Terry Jr. of Ossining, in St. Augustine's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Annesley T. Young, the rector, officiated. The ceremony was followed by a reception at the Langford home here.

Prince Charming II, a chestnut gelding who in 1933 and 1934 won more hunter championships than any other horse in the country, stamped himself as an important factor in the ring again at the closing session of the fifty-first exhibition of the Tuxedo Horse Show Association today.

District Supervisor Newton Ronan of the State Department of Public Works has asked for a complete report from County Attorney Ernest W. Hofstatter on the taking of trees from the State Highways in Rockland County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The City of New York is a growing community. As such it must face increasing costs of government. But the city must maintain a proper basis of taxes to meet these costs. The attention of successive administrations has - for many years been centered upon expenditures and not at all upon the assets from which those expenditures might be paid.

THE growing popularity of the "miniature" camera among today's photography enthusiasts (whose numbers ae increasing daily now that warm weather is here again) serves to direct attention to the interesting results which may fans achieve through enlarging their own negatives.

The Derbyshire S. C. star, S. A. Fletcher, led home a field of seventy-five starters in the twentymile Coronation road walk held recently by the Dunlop Walking Club from Coventry to Birmingham in England. He covered the course

SIAN, CHINA. ONTROLLING more than 150,000 square miles of territory in the heart of the rugged fastnesses of China's great northwest, an isolated Chinese Soviet Government has. gained such measure of influence in the last two years that it virtually dictates to Nanking regarding China's foreign and domestic policies.

Providence College defeated Boston College, 8 to 5, to avenge an earlier setback today. Gus Hagstrom, Friar catcher, on four trips to the plate, got two doubles and two singles and drove in four runs. The Friars landed on Somy and Lane for twelve hits, while Karl Sherry allowed the Eagles seven.

Although the new college to be opened by New York City in Queens next Fall is announced as a liberal arts institution, an informal poll taken last week shows that many young residents of the borough would prefer to see it emphasize vocational and pre-professional training.

The New Orleans Spot Cotton Merchants Association issued a statement today signed by E. O. Jewell, president, opposing the "impossible and destructive effort to control hours and wages by national legislation." "We look upon the effort

A horseback tour of the 1,2161/2acre site of the New York World's Fair in 1939 at Flushing Meadow yesterday convinced Grover A. Whalen, president, and Harvey D. Gibson; chairman of the fair's finance committee, that construction of the fair grounds was advancing with amazing rapidity."

Vigilis, the Kremlin's journalistic spokesman, thundered heavily and repeatedly in Izvestia this week against Fascist activities in Spain, which, in Soviet eyes, reached their climax of highhandedness in the bombardment of Almeria by a German naval squadron. Thus far, however, there is

Housing properties in three boroughs passed to new owners in transactions reported yesterday. An investor bought from Louis S. Lewis the six-story building for twenty-four families at 208 West 141st Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, in a deal arranged by Low Gross, Inc.

A defense motion to defer the hearing of the government's case against James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington-Rand, Inc., and Pearl L. Bergoff was granted by Judge Erwin S. Thomas of Federal court. He has now set June 22 for the twice-postponed hearing.

Thirty-four students will receive Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science degrees at commencement exercises of Wagner Memorial Lutheran College on Grymes Hill, Staten Island, Tuesday. Dr. John L. Tildsley, Associate Superintendent of Schools of New York City, will give the commencement address.
Senator Lonergan called upon the Treasury today to take a "definite position" on the question of removing the tax exemption from bonds of the government, the States and their subdivisions.
Retail trade continued at a brisk pace in the Fifth District this week. In Richmond the volume was approximately 9 per cent above the same week last year.
A labor dispute held the New York and Cuba mail liner Oriente at her East. River pier yesterday for the second time in eight days, delaying her sailing for Havana until after midnight.

Lady Aurea McLeod of Great Britain suggested today that peaceloving nations use collective armed force if necessary to "maintain world law."
With higher hopes of victory than any of their predecessors have enjoyed since 1932, the United States Davis Cup team sailed for England yesterday on board the Columbus

Bill Walker, veteran southpaw hurler, found the warm weather to his liking today and set the Buffalo Bisons down with five hits as the Rochester Red Wings won, 6 to 3, to end a six-game losing streak.

Mr. and Mrs. Archbald R. Montgomery of White Oak Farm, Glen Moore, formerly of Ithan, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Elliott Montgomery, to Davidson K. Girvin, son of Mrs. Robert M. Girvin of Rosemont, and the late Mr. Girvin.

The marriage of Miss Sara Buckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wade H. Buckley of Laurel, Miss., to Merrill Garcelon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Garcelon of Newton, Mass., took place here this afternoon in the chapel of Calvary Episcopal Church, Gramercy Park. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker Jr.

PLANS for Summer activities in this vicinity are beginning to take shape and it looks as though things would be fairly lively until what is called, by force of habit, "the season" begins again. The Lewisohn Stadium plans only two events instead of its frequently larger program, the reason for the change being that there are not enough companies of sufficiently large dimensions at liberty.

A fund of $50,000 was presented to the University of Pennsylvania today by the class of '87, which commemorated the fiftieth anniversary of its graduation by heading a parade of some 2,000 alumni from the dormitory quadrangle to Franklin Field. At its head, walked former Senator George Wharton Pepper, its president.

Recording a total of 30 points, Sayville's team won Class A honors today in the thirty-sixth annual Suffolk County Public High Schools Athletic Association track and field games on the new Greenport High athletic field.

Joseph L. Hills, dean of the College of Agriculture of the University of Vermont, who is completing fifty years of service at the university, will be the guest of the Agricultural Alumni Association at a testimonial banquet June 12, which is alumni day.
Mr. and Mrs. Jay G. Willson of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bernice Ruth Willson, to Matthew Logan Wilson, son of Mrs. John L. Wilson and the late Mr. Wilson.

Net profit of the McLellan Stores Company for the twelve months ended on April 30 is estimated at $1,243,938 after depreciation, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings, the company reported yesterday.

Influenced by steadiness abroad and mill price fixing, quotations on the Cotton Exchange again improved yesterday and ended with gains of 3 to 7 points. Despite beneficial rainfall in dry areas and predictions of favorable weather conditions for this week, the market continued to display decided resistance.
More than 51,000 officers, soldiers and civilians of New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Puerto Rico will begin this month intensive military field instruction.
Germany's Davis Cup tennis squad, favored to win the European zone eliminations, got no better than an even break in the opening singles matches with Italy today.

Cloudless skies greeted the 1,000 students, parents and others who assembled at Vassar College today de to witness the colorful parade of returning alumnae, led by the class of '87, attired in white dresses and tall gold peaked hats and carrying yellow canes.

The alumni upset tradition by defeating the Upsala College nine today, 5-2, when, with four out of five batters hitting safely for a total of nine bases in the fifth, the graduate team gained its three-run winning margin. Slifkin hit a homer and Magnussen a triple during that attack. Vinnie Hollertz held the Varsity to two hits.

Curtis Lees, 25, a sit-down striker, married his childhood sweetheart, 19-year-olds Ida Kunkel, of Merchantville, N. J., in a sidewalk ceremony outside the strike-closed J. C. J. Strahan Company, Inc., plant today.

A definite revision of advertising techniques, substituting to some extent entertainment, facts and "howto" material for straight selling copy, has been started this year and will continue on a broader scale for the next several years, advertising authorities predicted here yesterday.

LONDON is to have a televeision cable linking its centers where events of public interest are likely to occur. Success in televising the coronation led to plans for extension of the cable designed to relay events to the transmitter at Alexandra Palace.

On the eve of the opening of the Steel Workers Organization Committee's drive to organize Northern Minnesota's 12,000 iron miners an independent union today claimed victory in first representation elections.

WORD has gone forth that the strawberry crop is large and excellent. Southern berries long have been flowing to market; now the home-grown fruit from the farms of New Jersey and New York is beginning to arrive in quantity. The housewife has her preserving jars and kettles in readiness; she is concocting frozen desserts, strawberry tarts and chiffon pie and, above all, that American rhapsody in redstrawberry shortcake.

Prime Minister Chamberlain has lost the first round of his battle to tax business profits, but the most absorbing phase of the struggle is yet to come. The Prime Minister feels that his prestige has suffered little damage from the abrupt decision to abandon his "national defense contribution." He remembers how often

THE current lull in the local musical world is but the calm before a Summer storm, for within the next four weeks a half dozen or more enterprises will be opening in and around the city for the business variously described by the press agentry as al fresco music, music neathh the skies, twilight concerts, music over the water and under the stars, with the stars under the stars, Summer symphony,
Willis Hudlin registered his sixth straight victory as the Indians defeated the Senators, 8 to 6, in the opener of their four-game series today.

All truck lines operating from Omaha were tied up today by a strike of union drivers, helpers and dock hands. The first walkout here, which occurred late last night, was followed by similar action in other Midwestern cities in which the lines have branches.

The marriage of Miss Agnes Veronica Rush, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James I. Rush of East Orange, to Theodore Thomas Franzen, son of Mrs. Thomas Franzen of Newark and the late Mr. Franzen, took place today at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament here.

John L. Lewis admitted in Washington that the C. I. O. was considering plans to invade the civil service field in opposition to two established A. F. of L. unions. Page 1. T. M. Girdler, Republic Steel president, wired Postmaster General Farley demanding end of alleged C. I. O. interference with mails.

To the Editor of The New York Times! Your editorial of June 2, in relation to the President's message of June 1, raises the question as to a citizen's duty in relation to taxes. Under a free government, such as ours, the citizen's duty ends when he pays taxes in accordance with the statute. He is under no duty to accumulate income for the sole purpose of providing revenue for the State.

Suffern High School won the first interscholastic track and field meet of the Rockland County P. S. A. L. in a close race with Spring Valley High School in the stadium in the Tallman Mountain section of the Palisades Interstate Park today.

Powerful threats are being piled up to challenge American supremacy in Gold Cup speedboat racing. The arrival last week of two Italian entries brings the total now to six foreign seekers of this 34-year-old blue ribbon American trophy.

Palms line the streets of ancient Almeria-that port of Southeastern Spain which the Romans called Portus Magnus-and whitewashed houses sit in the tropical sun. The Moors in their day of greatness came here to build a citadel whose ruins still dominate the little city beside the blue bay.

About 1,000 members of thirtythree male choruses will participate in the "pop" concert of the Associated Glee Clubs of America to be given in the Stadium on Randalls Island next Saturday evening, or, in case of rain. June 19.

Maxwell Stevenson, president of Maxwell Park, Inc., is preparing to erect more than twenty residences on a six-acre tract on East Fulton Avenue, Hempstead. The property adjoins Hofstra College of the New York University and a number of the new houses, it is stated, will be occupied by faculty members of Hofstra College.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday the 1937 list of sixty architects and architectural firms who have been approved to work for the city. In making the list public the Mayor followed a precedent he established in 1935 when he discarded the policy allowing a few architects to receive the bulk of city work.
AN Indian, with the lack of self-consciousness which is the most marked characteristic of his race, sits on the stone steps at the entrance to Chapultepec Castle.

With the club championships coming nearer, a faster pace was noted today -in the Meadow Brook members' polo. Two teams put on a tight, frequently well-played match on. Cochran Field that was a tie until the bell rang when Stewart Iglehart, on an easy shot, poked through the winning goal in the 11-to-10 battle. Several riders stopped with the final bell, however, and the deciding shot was virtually unopposed.

Between Monday and Friday Japan lost her oldfashioned, super-party Cabinet and acquired a new- style national. union administration. It is the most important political step since the old order began. to crack, and whether it succeeds or fails it closes an era.

New York City high schools are making a new attack on the problem of the slow-learning student. One phase was announced last week with the beginning of a new course of study at Seward Park High School. Within the next year

Lord Kylsant, former shipping leader, died at his home in Coomb, Carmarthenshire, today at the age of 74. He had been in failing health ever since he was released from jail after serving a sentence in connection with the Royal Mail shipping scandals.

I, John D. Rockefeller, residing and having my domicile in the city, county and State of New York, declare this instrument to be my last will and testament, and I hereby revoke all former wills by me made at any time whatsoever.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Collens of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Collens, to Robert Letchworth Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robert Wilson of Buffalo.

At the monthly meeting of the Bank Credit Associates of New York the nominating committee listed for president Edward Adams of the Grace National Bank, it was announced yesterday. Paul R. Vervoort and Donald Ferguson were nominated for vice presidents, C. Joseph Kennedy for treasurer and
The first eight-oared crew of Tabor Academy will sail on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria on June 19 to defend the Thames Cup which it won at the Henley Regatta last year.

The New York Miilitary Academy's annual commencement was ended today with the awarding of commissions and warrants to the seventy-four members of the graduating class. More than 2,000 parents and guests of the corps, were on hand to witness the awards by Captain Frank A. Patillo, susuperintendent of the academy, and hear the address to the graduates by James Lee Loomis, '97, president of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company.

Reports of building activities in Queens and adjacent sections of Nassau County, Long Island, indicate a steadily increasing volume of residential construction and the buying interest, according to local brokers, is showing no evidences of curtailment.

Recent events in Spanish waters have afforded a fresh demonstration of the promptness with which the now familiar political contrivance known as the Berlin-Rome axis can be requisitioned whenever Italo-German interests call for collaboration.
The one Newark Bears stretched their winning streak to six in a row with a 7-to-3 victory over Syracuse today.

M0ORE than ever before, perhaps, in its quarter century MVI of colorful history, 'he 500 mile race, which on Monday marked the silver anniversary o the Indianapolis Speedway, was a proving ground for mechanical improvements and experiments which will later be reflected in the automobiles of motoring America.

With the fur fashion show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on two nights last week attracting more than 3,000 persons, and with the three-day registrations likewise exceeding that figure at the exhibits in the Hotel Pennsylvania, reports here yesterday agreed the Fall season in the fur industry has gotten off to a good start.

The Teaching Staff The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued, as of the datees indicated, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore.

More than 300 years ago Manhattan was chosen as a place for a settlement because it was an island, lying at a meeting of waters, Its vast, protected bay, its access to the interior by way of the tidal waters of the Hudson and to the New England shores by way of Long Island Sound, made New Amsterdam and later New York the Key port of North America.

The first week of Summer witnessed extremely slow securities markets and fairly steady prices. Astronomically, Summer is still a fortnight away. But so far as the current markets are concerned, the season has already set in.

Marked progress in Italy's effort to become economically self-sufficient has been made in the field of textiles, it was shown at a recent convention at Forli of producers of textile fibers, the Agenzia d'Italia reports in its current English edition. Papers were read showing
Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," presented at the Hippodrome last night by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, was enthusiastically received by an audience of good size.

NAOMI JACOB'S best fictional work has hitherto been that in which she followed the fortunes of a Jewish family, whether mainly of one generation, as in "Barren Metal," or carried, in saga fashion, through lengthier periods, as in her "Founder of the House" and "Four Generations."

A transcontinental race to save the life of a Los Angeles boy started here last night as two automatic pencils of a certain make were rushed through the Holland Tunnel in a police radio car to Newark Airport and aboard a westbound plane. The plane was held ten minutes, leaving at 12:09 A. M.

While business as a whole on the Pacifio Coast continues somewhat spotty, the level is said to be from 5 to 10 per cent higher than a year ago. Collections have been decidedly better than a year ago. Aided by a .

Mrs. Margaret Strong De Cuevas, chief beneficiary under the will of John D. Rockefeller, is one of the least prominent of the numerous Rockefeller family. She and her husband, who is referred to as the Marquis de Piedrablanca de Guana de Cuevas, have passed most of their time abroad and are not widelv known in New York.

ENTRIES thus far for the eighth annual national soaring contest shows that forty-five pilots and thirty-one soaring craft were registered on June 1 for the meet to be held at Elmira, N. Y., June 26 to July 11. Dr. Karl O.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 4, unless specified: Annapolis to Kiel, Germany: Arkansas, New York. Wyoming. San Francisco to San Pedro: Bridge, San Francisco. At San Diego: Dahigren, Kalmia, Ranger, Sturtevant.

The winners of ten prizes awarded by the Department of English at Hunter College have been announced by Dr. Blanche Colton Williams, head of the department. The awards are for literature, research, creative writing and journalism.

FROM William Zorach, one of our leading American sculptors, comes a plea that the Metropolitan Museum expand its acquisition policy so as to embrace not only contemporary painting but also the work of plastic artists. Mr. Zorach writes:

Calling attention to the growth of the tourist industry in the United States, the current issue of The Architectural Forum declares that while in 1922 it was estimated barely 1,000 tourist camps were in existence, there are at the present time fully 40,000 camps, showing an annual revenue of approximately $600,000,000.

TODAY Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra in an all-Wagner concert, with Erno Rapee conducting. Viola Philo, soprano, and Jan Peerce, tenor, are the soloists: WJZ, 12:301:30 P. M. Prelude and Liebestod, "Tristan and Isolde"; Funeral March from "Siegfried"; duet from first act, "Die Walkuere' ; overture to "Die Meistersinger."

Miss Elizabeth Ann Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Palmer of Scarsdale, was married to Stanley Duncan Mercer, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Duncan Mercer of White Plains, this afternoon in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here. The Rev. George Hugh Smyth, the pastor, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Charles O. Wright of the First Baptist Church of White Plains.

A two-year experiment in community cooperation has finally brought results in terms of better citizens, more alert pupils and diminished juvenile delinquency, Harold Fields, chairman of the department of social studies at Benjamin Franklin High School, disclosed yesterday.

A change in the House rules, designed to make it more difficult for "porkbarrel feasts" and log-rolling tactics to swell the totals of appropriation bills, is being contemplated in high quarters and probably will be offered during this session.

Alumnae and Class Day festivities today opened the Commencement week for the class of 1937. The events of the day included a luncheon in honor of the graduating class and for Trustees and Alumnae. Class Day exercises were

Embattled vigilantes set aside their weapons tonight as jail cells held three leaders of Upper Michigan's violence-studded lumberjack strike. Joseph Ashmore, Deputy State Labor Commissioner, said a strikers' committee claiming to represent a majority of the timber workers
Some of the romance of the army faded today when the Air Corps announced that it is using mechanical devices to play bugle calls without buglers.

Letters were sent yesterday to the executives of several leading chains affected by the tax situation in Pennsylvania, Louisiana and other States by Herbert E. Evans, vice president of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, urging them to consider the possibility of selling their stores to consumers, and to service them with merchandise as cooperatives, instead of closing them.

Miss Alison Williams Coe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Coe of this place, was married here tonight in the First Congregational Church to Theodore Klein Hess of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Hess of Waterbury, by the Rev. Allan Hackett.

Miss Elita Steers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Walker Steers, was married tonight to Norman Touet Neel, son of Mrs. Walter P. Neel, in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. John J. Quelly performed the ceremony.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in- leading cities for the week ended June 2, which included five business days in most of the reporting centers, aggregated $8,320,000,000 or 1 per cent above the total reported for the preceding
Dick Shaughnessy of Dedham, Mass., national all-bore champion, tied the world record today by breaking 96 of 100 targets in the 410-gauge competition of the North-South skeet shoot.

Trustees of Bucknell University, meeting in semi-annual session today, created the office of dean of men, and named Dr. Robert L. Sutherland, head of the Department of Sociology, to the post. Seven new faculty members were appointed. They are Dr. Richard

OFall Victorian writers who attained to a position of note, perhaps Charles Kingsley led the most uneventful life. But as clergyman and reformer his life was a constant ferment. Kingsley meant much to those immediately about him; indeed. with the doctrine of evolution and with industrial changes to the fore, his opinions meant much to a considerable circle of readers.

Twelve of the chief officials of the Townsend Old Age Pension organization resigned today as a unit in protest against the activities of the founder, Dr. Francis E. Townsend, who, they alleged, had jeopardized the passage of the organization's legislation by Congress by attacks upon the Roosevelt administration.
The annual matches of the New York State Rifle Association and the State competition of the National Guard and naval militia, in which more than 500 marksmen are listed, began at Camp Smith today.
Melvin Schwartzman of New York, second seeded, today gained the final round of the New Jersey Center junior singles tennis championship. He defeated Alter Milberg of Brooklyn, 7-5, 9-7.
With Cardinal Hayes presiding, the first commencement of Ladycliff College at Highland Falls washeld on the college campus this morning.

Several different inferences were drawn from Senator Robinson's remarks about the President's judiciary plan after his two-hour conference with Mr. Roosevelt Thursday night. One was that the section affecting the Supreme Court will be deleted for legislative action at another session of Congress, unless supervening events persuade the President to drop it. Another was that the Maverick bill as a whole will be

The engagement of Miss Adelaide Merrill Drew, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Almus Drew of Bradenton, Fla., and Camp Rich, Milton, Vt., to Edward Landon of this city, son of Mrs. Charles Baldwin Landon of Milton and the late Mr. Landon, has been announced by her parents.

Frederick A. Muschenheim and Thomas F. Horton greeted each other fondly in Parlor R of the Hotel Astor Wednesday and exchanged reminders that they had been associates for half a century. Mr. Muschenheim is president of the hotel corporation and Mr. Horton has been head barman since its

SCIENTISTS of South Africa are puzzled by the strange behavior of fifty false killer whales, which recently lashed themselves to death against the jagged rocks of St. Helena Bay on the Cape coast. Last year there were similar mass suicides along the Mamre coast.

Former Governor Alfred M. Landon told members of the graduating class of Baker University today they were "graduating into a world which is suffering from a painful but on the whole stimulating reaction."
WITH automatic tuning a feaof the new 1937-38 radios, a new line of eighteen receivers, several of the models equipped with a lever for robot tuning of- seven favorite stations,

Graduates under 17 years of age who intend to take up employment, are required to apply for registration at continuation schools from June 14 to 18, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, superintendent of schools, announced last week. Any minor over 14 years of age is eligible for a vacation work permit.

Out on a Summer sea, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new yacht Ranger did some slippery work today and defeated Gerard B. Lambert's veteran Yankee by two minutes and five seconds over twenty-eight miles, half of it to windward and the rest down hill. It was Ranger's third straight victory in the first trial series to select a defender of the America's Cup.

Exhibits of collections of gourds at recent horticultural shows have greatly stimulated interest in these easily grown and very decorative subjects. While the seed-which may be planted at this time-can be obtained in mixture, leading seed houses offer many separate varieties or species.

The German and Polish police reached an agreement today on the exchange of officers for training in the methods of the respective organizations. Three high Polish officers will come to Germany for several months of study and three German officers will be sent to Poland.

A clear illustration of the encouraging outlook for real estate in the suburban areas of New Jersey is seen in the statement by Alexander Summer, Teaneck broker, last week that his firm closed more sales in May than in any previous month during his business career.

LONDON. HERE are some tradespre-emninently the manufacture and sale of flags and other decorations-for which the coronation has been a veritable bonanza. Unfortunately, to the occupation of bookselling it has brought a severe slump.

J. P. Morgan, who was carried aboard ship when he sailed from England, was in much improved health today. He has gained strength sitting for considerable periods on deck in splendid weather.

The athletes from Public School 9 of Brooklyn annexed the seventh and eighth year team crown for the fourth year in a row at the Public Schools Athletic League's thirty-fourth annual city elementary schools outdoor track and field championships at the General George W. Wingate athletic field in Brooklyn yesterday.
MR. HENDRICK'S most able, interesting and illumingating volumr falls into two parts,unequal in length and whooly different in character.

A nervous, hesitating witness told in the Supreme Court yesterday how James Plumeri, one of the two men on trial as leaders in the trucking racket, had threatened to cut his ears off if he attempted to solicit business from any of Plumeri's customers.

The hardest period of the year for the lawn usually comes during July and August. It is a wise plan, therefore, to prepare the turf in advance for this trying period. This may be done by getting the sod in as healthy and vigorous condition as possible in anticipation of prolonged periods of heat and drought.

Artists, writers, musicians and townspeople of the seven villages making up this township joined today in the presentation of a pageant portraying in dramatic highlights the history of the Catskill County since it was bought from the Indians in 1707.
Johnny Maher led West Catholic High School of Philadelphia to its fourth consecutive national Catholic track and field championship today.

The iron alloys committee of the Engineering Foundation, research agency of the national engineering societies, has completed a synthesis of the world's knowledge of plain, unalloyed steels and cast irons, working in cooperation with the steel, automotive, chemical and other industries.

The Duchess of Segovia, wife of Don Jaime, second son of former King Alfonso XIII of Spain, gave birth to her second son today. Alfonso, wreathed in smiles, hurried to the hospital to felicitate his son and daughter-in-law, the former Emanuela de Dampierre.
Eastern track and field circles tossed a powerful threat into the National Intercollegiate A. A. . championships here June 18 and 19 with the entry today of a five-man team from Columbia University.

Some 300 women physicians and research workers will convene this morning in Atlantic-City for the two-day sessions of the Medical Women's National Association. The gathering is preliminary to two others which overshadow it in importance. One is the convention

Breaking 242 out of a possible 250 targets the Nassau Trapshooting Club won an interclub shoot from the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday over the traps of the latter organization. The home team had a total of 240.

A LONG the beaches of the Pacific Northwest, and high in the passes of the mountains, the cabins in auto camps must be snug and tight against gusty winds. Tourist camp managers believe they have found the ideal answer to this requirement, and are converting old street cars into homes for touring motorists.

Little Cottage, owned by Mrs. James C. Clark of Far Hills, N. J., won the Farmington Valley Plate today in a handicap steeplechase over the picturesque course of the Farmington Valley Polo Association.

The Dodgers on the bench lost an umpire-baiting contest in the fourth inning yesterday but the Dodgers on the field won a ball game from the Reds, 5-4, with a ninth-inning uprising that was good for four runs.
The national open lacrosse title passed from the Mount Washington Club to the Baltimore Athletic Club today when the Wolfpack bowed, 7 to 5.

Three armed men staged a holdup shortly after last midnight in a fourth-floor apartment at 441 Ocean Avenue, at Caton Avenue, in the heart of Flatbush, Brooklyn, an apartment house in which Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May and other prominent residents of Brooklyn live. The thugs obtained

Abraham Lincoln High School's handball team captured the crown for the second time in three years yesterday when the Brooklynites conquered Newtown High of Queens and Evander Childs of the Bronx in the round-robin final for the city P. S. A. L. championship on the James Madison High School courts In Brooklyn.
Robert Riggs, 19-year-old Los Angeles ace, and a fellow Californian, Walter Senior of San Francisco, gained the final today in the men's singles of the New England tennis tournament.

A warning that "patients suffer the consequences" when physicians fail to utilize laboratory diagnostic procedures in their medical practice was voiced today by Dr. Roy R. Kracke, Professor of Pathology at Emory University, in his presidential address before the American Society of Clinical Pathologists.

MORE than a week has passed since the coronation, but the decorations are still up, the busmen's strike continues to die slowly, the underground railway is choked with passengers, many streets are still almost impassable, and at all hours of the day great crowds stand staring at the front of Buckingham Palace.

Creation of a desire to own a home rather than stimulating the fear of rising rents, building costs or inflation should be more generally followed in selling new houses on a sound basis, declares Edward V. Siedle, Rye broker, in pointing out that buyers of higher-priced homes in the Westchester section are increasing.
The one hundred and some Long Lakes and the eighty-odd Rice Lakes in Minnesota-the State's perennial outdoor dilemma-are going to get individual names.

Before an Alumni Day crowd of 7,000, Pennsylvania finished its Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball and entire athletic campaign by defeating Princeton on Franklin Field to in fourteen innings, 9-8, today.

A little wirehaired fox terrier, white with ginger markings, captivated the onlookers at the eighth annual allbreed exhibition of the Greenwich Kennel Club, held today on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

One young man was drowned and another, who had exhausted himself trying to save his companion, was towed to shore by two young women this afternoon in the first drowning incident in this vicinity this season.

Officials of the Columbia Yacht Club yesterday opened facilities for the organization on Long Island Sound at Anderson's Dock, City Island. This marked the first time the club has utilized Sound waters since it was organized in 1867.

THE article, "When Lincoln Posed," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of May 9, telling how George P. A. Healy painted the famous portrait of the Civil War President which will some day come to the nation through the will of the late Mrs. Robert Todd Lincoln, has stirred up something in the nature of a historical controversy.

United Automobile Workers rejected overwhelmingly today a proposal by their leaders to end their strike at the Ford Motor plant here but were asked immediately to reconsider their action in time for a projected resumption of work Monday.

A SUGGESTION by Representative Sol Bloom of New York to all foreign governments which function under constitutions that they issue stamps commemorating the Constitution of the United States is -bringing favorable responses, according to Mr. Bloom. Thus far France, Ecuador,

FORT DEFIANCE, ARIZ. SILVER coins jangling on velveteen jackets, jet-black hair neatly done in braids, great drops of turquoise dangling from coppery ears, sixtysix Navajo headmen (they don't and never did call themselves chiefs) stalked into the Tribal Council House at Window Rock, here, recently to debate the need for a Navajo Constitution.

WASHINGTON.-Minimum wage measures, unless accompanied by regulation of commodity prices, will lead to the destruction of small enterpises and to the creation and extention of monopolies, Nelson B. Gaskill, former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission,

The withdrawal of fourteen ministers and three elders from the Presbyterian Church of America was characterized today as "a happy solution" of the denomination's internal differences by the Rev. Edwin H. Rian, general secretary of its

Marshal I. B. Gamarnik, Assistant Commissar of Defense and a member of the Central Committee of the Communist party, was charged today with others as yet unnamed as Trotskyists "performing espionage deeds and selling the Fatherland to German and Japanese Imperialists."
EXCURSION - This evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre. A special performance, with the, tickets sold free of tax, for the benefit of the Stage Relief Fund.

The policy of manufacturers of national brand shirts to keep their prices unchanged during the current season while quotations on unbranded shirts have been jumped sharply has resulted in the former capturing a larger portion of the market, according to the executive of one of the large companies yesterday.
NAIROBI, Kenya Colony.-Passengers on the Nairobi-Mombasa express, were suddenly thrown off their sleepers as the train was brought to a standstill following a violent shock.

Academic guests from seventy colleges and 2,000 alumni, parents and friends are expected to attend the celebration of the centennial of Colby Junior College this week. Beginning on Thursday with a historical pageant, the exercises will end on Monday, June 14, with
Sox scored in all except nings today to defeat the 11 to 4, and entrench Manager Rogers Hornsby's team more firmly in the American League cellar.

Miss Lucile Duffy of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John A. Duffy of Louisville, Ky., was married yesterday morning in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer to James A. Ruddy, son of Mrs. Austin J. Ruddy, also of New York, and the late Dr. Ruddy. The bride's cousin, the Rev. Raymond Meagher, performed the ceremony and was the celebrant of the nuptial mass.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has con-tinued its advance, reaching 109.3 for the week ended May 29. This compares with 109.3 (revised) for the previous week and 98.5 for the week ended May 30, 1936. Gains were registered by all except the carloadings indices. The largest increase in weighted influence took place in the automobile output series, production showing a contra-seasonal gain.

Running with such effortless grace as to give the impression that he could have gone much faster had he so desired, Glenn Cunningham raced to a new American record for three-quarters of a mile at the sixty-ninth annual Spring games of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

American exports to the Far East have been hampered by the uncertain situation in China, Gerold Eckelmann of Shanghai, who formulated Germany's "unbreakable" codes during the World War and is at present a creator of commercial codes, said here yesterday. He is visiting this country to establish private code systems for. several large companies.

Mr. and Mrs. Langhorne Gibson have arrived at the Weylin from Greenwood, Va. Mr. and Mrs. Franklyn L. Hutton have returned from the South, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria. They will sail in a few weeks for London to visit their daughter, Countess Kurt Haugwitz-Reventlow.

The cost of new streamlined equipment and comfort features for passengers, which are essential if the railroads of the country are to meet competition, requires increased freight revenues to meet these additional expenses, the Class I railroads of the United States argue in a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Winning the last five matches, the Boston women's tennis team captured the Sears Cup tennis trophy today with a 6-to-3 decision over the New York team at the Longwood Cricket Club.

Miss Adele le Bourgeois Alsop has arrived from London at Red House and with her for the week-end are her brother, Reese F. Alsop, and Thomas Williams of New York. The wedding of Miss Alsop and Henry A. C. Howard of London is to take place at Tyringham in September.

Miss Alice Marble still is looking for-her first British tennis tournament victory. For the third successive week the comely San Francisco girl who holds the United States singles championship was beaten in the final round of an English tournament today.

The British plan to bring Germany and Italy back into the Spanish patrol scheme following the bombing of the German pocket battleship Deutschland by suggesting safety zones for patrol warships and, in the event of unprovoked attacks, collective diplomatic action by British, German, Italian and French naval commanders on the spot, has not met with entirely favorable response from Germany or even from France.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Mae C. McGuinness of Larchmont, N. Y., to Andrew M. Conneen Jr., of South Orange. The ceremony was performed May 20 in the Church of St. Augustine, Larchmont Manor. Mr. and Mrs. Conneen have returned from their wedding trip.

The opposition expressed by Car dinal Mundelein to the anti-Catho lic campaign of the German Nazi, was praised last night by former Supreme Court Justice Jeremial T. Mahoney in an address at thi tenth anniversary dinner dance o the Saratoga Springs Cure and Con valescent Home at the Riverside Plaza, 253 West Seventy-third Street.
Expositions of the Arab viewpoint in Palestine were presented last night by speakers at a'dinner honoring Ameen Rihani, poet and statesman, at the Town Hall Club.

In the annual prelude-to commencement, Manhattan College's graduating class observed Class Day Ceremonies on the campus yes-terday afternoon. About 1,000 persons, including 250 seniors, attended the exercises at which Brother Alphonsus, dean of the School of Arts and principal speaker of the occasion, stressed the necessity of initiative and personality for success in life.

A preliminary survey of. twentyfive representative public utility companies throughout the United States discloses that for the twelve months ended April 30 their net income was approximately 10 per cent higher than in the preceding twelve months. Despite the larger earnings, however, the' market
Settlement by compromise of a $70,280 claim of the United Trust Company against the United Telephone and Electric Company has been approved by Federal Judge John P. Nields. He authorized

John Dalton of 77 Charles Street, Jersey City, clerk of the Circuit Court in Hudson County since 1926, died here yesterday at the Point Pleasant Hospital. He underwent an emergency operation there last Saturday. Mr. Dalton was motoring with Assistant County Counsel Eric H. Jentz when stricken.

As the result of a growing number of inquiries concerning real estate deals and market trends in the New York district, the Real Estate Board of New York has expanded its statistical staff and is preparing to issue a monthly review of conditions in this field.
Buttonwood Farm, the Berwyn estate of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howell Cummings, was the scene today of the annual pony show for the benefit of the Chester County Hospital.

By directed verdict, Lucien Boutin and Emile Lacombe of Lewiston today were freed of a conspiracy charge by a Superior Court jury. The charge was an outgrowth of the general shoe strike in Lewiston and Auburn, which has involved nineteen factories employing more than 6,000 workers.

SHARP contrast is found in those Summer cruises that include both semi-tropical Bermuda and the pine forests of the Gaspe Peninsula in their itineraries. Such circle tours take care of the problem of whether one should go to a Northern or Southern resort for the holidays-by giving the voyager a taste of each.

The eighty-fifth anniversary of the Children's Village was celebrated this afternoon. More than 200 visitors inspected the school, dormitories and shops, including thirty-five buildings. Frederick Ecker of Bronxville was chairman of a meeting held on the lawn.

The Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that B. C. McMordie of B. C. McMordie Co. of Fort Worth, Texas, had been sentenced by Judge T. Whitfield Davidson of the United States District Court of the Northern District of Texas to serve four years in Leavenworth penitentiary for violation of the Securities Act of 1933.

The Black-Connery wages and hours bill, by which President Roosevelt proposes to "extend the frontiers of social progress," was vigorously assailed tonight by Senator Vandenberg as making for a "centralized, authoritarian State with its tyranny of oppressive, government-blessed monopolies."

Nearly 150 leaders in history, political and economic science, foreign affairs and business will take part in the second Conference on Canadian-American Affairs, to be held June 14 to 18 at Queen's Untversitv. Kingston, Ont.
Count Morse, handicap star from Warren Wright's Calumet Farm Stable, proved conclusively at Washington Park today that he is champion of the Middle West.

The downward price movement in wheat received additional impetus today from further general and heavy rains over the American Northwest's Spring wheat area and from the lack of any response in Liverpool to yesterday's advances here. The rains in the Northwest rounded out virtually a perfect picture of crop conditions at the present time and appeared to knock the last prop from under the bull position.

Close of play scores in English first-class cricket mathces started today follow: Lancashire 233 (Iddon 114, Sims five wickets for 63 rns); Middl4esex 132 for four wickets (Edrich 58 no out), at Lords.

State Department officials said tonight that President Roosevelt had declined Cuba's nomination for the 1937 Nobel Peace Prize and had asked that the name of Secretary of State Cordell Hull be substituted.

THE last midseason openings brought one definite fact to light: styles are no longer being created with only one or a few types of women in mind; on the contrary they cater to a large number and to a wide diversity of taste. This accounts for the variety that gives the keynote to the clothes that will be worn in the French capital during the coming season.

PEIPING, China - The pressure of political events in North China is working subtle but unmistakable changes in this ancient capital. Travelers returning to Peiping after a prolonged absence are struck by the transformation in a city which tour books describe as "ageless and changeless."

WARNED in Boulder City to get away before sun-up to avoid the Death Valley drive in noon heat, we filled the twoquart canteen, the big three-gallon water bag, as if we were starting to search for Stanley in deepest Africa. Learned later that wasn't necessary. On the drive to the coast from Boulder City the road is perfeet, water always within reach; cool sweet drinks, too.
The Canadian Government, faced by the paradox of rising relief rolls as unemployment decreases, has hardened its heart and cut a large slice from its relief expenditures.

Exports of copper and copper manufactures in April of this year, including copper refined from imported material, were valued at $7,811,651, a decrease from March, but $4,612,485 above the same month of 1936, the Commerce Department reported today.
Net tonnage figures for the port of San Francisco last month were slightly below the totals records for May, 1936, according to the Marine Department of the Chamber of Commerce.

Judge Hiram H. Keller of Doylestown, president judge of Bucks County Court, and Clyde L. Gerberich of Mount Joy, past president of the General Alumni Association, were elected to the board of trustees of Gettysburg College to. day.

With the object of explaining in a clear and simple manner the benefits and methods of proper wiring in the home, a "Handbook of Interior Wiring Design" is being issued by the Edison Electric Institute, 420 Lexington Avenue.

With warm weather and the start of the vacation season creating a heavy demand for all types of Summer merchandise, particularly wearing apparel, retail sales figures rose sharply throughout the country last week.

LONDON-Only a few details remain to be settled before the British Government takes the first and, perhaps, the most important step toward the modernization of the United Kingdom's greatest industry-coal.

The announcemnt that the Corral smelters near Valdivia have turned out, for the first time after years of experimentation, commercial steel produced from Chilean iron materials, has evoked interest in business circles, although the smelters' capacity of production and the product's cost and quality still remain to be seen.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's country estate, Greentree, at Manhasset, L. I., will be the setting for the annual Greentree Fair to -be held on Friday for the benefit jointly of the Baby Milk Funds of the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County and the New York Hospital.

LONDON.--"Hamlet" comes back to Kronborg Castle at Elsinore in Denmark this Summer. It was at Elsinore that Shakespeare placed the tragedy. The play opens on "a platform before the castle" and continue in "a room of State in the castle."
Mrs. Elizabeth Chanler Chapman, widow of John Jay Chapman, essayist and poet, died here today at her home, Good Hap, after a brief illness at the age of 71.

The wedding of Miss Virginia Cassidy, daughter of Mrs. Maude Kane Cassidy of this place, to Arthur Norman Ransford of Williamstown, Mass., son of Mrs. Julia D. Ransford and the late Norman Ransford, took place this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church, New Rochelle. The Rev. Robert R.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: It is an improper and futile thing to argue with a reviewer concerning his estimate of one's book. Moreover, I have no desire to disagree with Mr. Charles Poore as to his estimate either of Rivera's or my own portion of "Portrait of America," reviewed in your issue of April 11.

Many luncheons, dinners and other entertainments were held today in connection with the annual horse show, which came to an end late this afternoon. The appearance today of the West Point cadet horse show team added considerable color to the show.

THE Irish nation's plan to estebw lish-the new State of Eire wills if brought to fruition, mean new stamps for the collector. For one thing, Irish 'Free State. postal paper is expressed in British currency terms, pence-and shillings. Adoption of Eireann monetary units would most certainly be reflected in the inscriptions on frture stamps.

When Eamon de Valera ends his first term of office as President of the Irish Free State this month and turns to the people for a fresh mandate it is virtually certain that the Fianna Fail administration will be returned to power for another five years.

Miss Dorothy Elliott, daughter of Mrs. John H. Elliott of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Elliott, was married yesterday morning to Howard Chamberlain Moore, son of Mrs. William C. Moore, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Moore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Dudley at the Elliott home, 1,834 Caton Avenue, and was followed by a breakfast at the RitzCarlton Hotel.
Dr. Ernest C. Bryant, Professor of Physics at Middlebury College since 1895, is retiring. His active teaching tenure sets a Middlebury record.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Henry Gorham of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Louise Gorham, to John Barbour Gray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Barbour Gray of Evanston, Ill.

Bilingual children who come from homes where English is not spoken or used only occasionally are just as intelligent and make just as rapid progress in their school work as monoglots, according to a survey covering 3,000 elementary school pupils of this city, made public yesterday.

Increasing interest in industrial sites in Belleville, N. J., is seen in the town's recent announcement of its fifth successive annual reduction in tax rates. Officials report that inquiries regarding available properties are coming from many sections of the country, and plans are being prepared for the erection of two factory structures.

The wars of yesteryear are still costing the government $30,000,000 a month for veterans' pensions alone. Veterans' administration records show that about 595,000 veterans drew $24,974,658 in pensions for April, while 317,809 dependents ol deceased veterans collected $7,984, 279. A handful were peacetime

The marriage of Miss Abby C. Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton M. Allen of this place, to Laurent H. Martineau, son of Colonel and Mrs. L. L. Martineau of Windsor, took place yesterday at St. Justin's Church. The Rev. Charles .L. Hewett performed the ceremony. A reception followed at the Allen home.

The United States Army transport Ludington rode safely at anchor in Limon Bay today with danger of fire in a hold packed with 690 tons of explosives removed. Smoke which started pouring from a hatch when the ship was at sea Thursday was smothered soon after the Ludington reached port here with a crew of sixtythree men. After an investigation,

The bones of Marshal Chang Tso-Lin, the Chinese warlord who was master of Manchuria for nearly a generation, lay today in a new grave, his memory highly honored by the Japanese Army controlling his old domain, now Manchukuo.

IN 1935 Gerald B. Lambert, owner of the famous schooner yacht Atlantic, sailed that vessel to England. together with the sloop Yankee, which he had purchased from the syndicate that had built her as a possible defender for the America's Cup, to participate with the latter boat in the several regattas held annually in English waters.

Max Schmeling decided last night to abandon all intentions of going to law in an attempt to recover damages he claims to have suffered. as a result of James J. Braddock's failure to meet him for the heavyweight championship of the world on Thursday night last.

With the Duke of Windsor married at long last to "the woman I love," the conservative section of the British public, including the "ruling classes" and the "West End" of London, are trying hard to forget the last jolt administered to their outward disregard of their former King by the unknown vicar from the depressed areas.

More New Yorkers than usual are leasing their apartments for Fall occupancy before leaving on their Summer vacations, according to Douglas L. Elliman, who anticipates "a scarcity of desirable apartments with rents already on their way upward."

The fact that M. LEON BLUM was able last week to round out a full year as Premier of France-despite the predictions freely made, when he took office, that France was headed for dictatorship-is no doubt largely the consequence of M. BLUM'S own qualities as a good tactician, a man of principle and a timely advocate of social reform.

BEER-Andrew, on Saturday, June 5, beloved husband of Mary K. and father of Andrew E. Beer, in his sixty-ninth year. Funeral services at his late residence, Downing Ave., Sea Cliff, L. I., on Monday, June 7, at 11 A. M. Interment private. BERG-At Schenectady, N. Y., June 4, 1937, Margaret Gwendoline, wife of Dr. Ernest J. Berg. Funeral service at the convenience of the family.

The thirtieth annual commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle began here today with class-day activities featured by the traditional daisy-chain procession and the presentation of awards for distinguished service in sodality work. The baccalaureate service will be held tomorrow and the degrees will be conferred at 4 P. M. Monday.
Although unwilling to concede that business has been slow, men's wear stores here are planning to start their Spring and Summer clearances earlier than usual, it was learned here yesterday.

" The gentlemen who take to themselves the title of critic, or have had it conferred upon them by the editors of newspapers, and who are gladly acclaimed by the public as leaders of opinion, observed, studied and followed (or else denounced and declared incompetent by dissidents) may properly be regarded, and in many cases would regard themselves, merely as contributors to the general mass of opinion, not as dictators.

Pittsburgh at New York-Blanton vs. Schumacher. Cincinnati at Brooklyn-Moore or Vander Meer vs. Jeffcoat. Chicago at Boston (2)-Root and Parmelee vs. Bush and Hutchinson. St. Louis at Philadelphia (2)Warneke and Harrell vs. Mulcahy and Walters.

Wesley Monteith Graff, chairman of the Westfield Town Republican Committee since 1933 and safety consultant engineer with the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters, died today at his home here, after several weeks' illness. His age was 47.

Under a blazing sun which took its toll among the players, Muhlenberg lost to Lafayette, 7 to 6, today, the visitors scoring all their runs in the first two innings. When the teams settled down to real baseball Lafayette held the edge.

The. Seventy-seventh Commencement exercises of Bard College were held today with President William Alfred Eddy of Hobart College as the commencement speaker. He gave an address on "The Pathetic Fallacy in Education."

Mrs. Frank Elbert Phillips of Kew Gardens, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Phillips, to Edward M. Foote Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward M. Foote of New York and Cornwall Bridge. Conn.

The Brooklyn Edison Company announced yesterday that it had signed a contract with an American Federation of Labor union granting a 5 per cent wage increase, or $700, 000 a year, to most of its 8,500 employes, effective July 1.

ONE of the minor problems of life is how to pick a favorite from a box of assorted chocolates. Few realize that it is not necessary to prod, or break, or speculate whether the deep brown sweet conceals a soft jelly, a hard caramel, a bit of pineapple, a mint, a fig, or what you wish. For the little decorative ridges atop the varieties in the box are telltale signs of what lies underneath.

Here on the Pacific rim, nearly a continent removed from the labor conflicts of the East, an early but significant showdown is imminent between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.
Governor Lehman signed today a bill establishing a Bureau of Narcotic Control in the State Department of Health. He had vetoed the bill on Monday.

Mrs. Clifford Lockhorn, top-seeded player, captured the annual women's invitation tennis tournament when she defeated Mrs. J. J. Schieffelin in three hard-fought sets on the Manursing Island Club courts today.

Realistic assessors of war possibilities have been saying for weeks that the Spanish civil war-tragic as it is-has been healthy for Europe. German and Italian advocates of conquest have tried out the methods and weapons with which they had calculated to gain quick victories on larger fields. They found that, even with

The French liner De Grasse is due in port Wednesday after an absence of more than three years. She sailed from Marseilles May 27 and will remain here only one day, sailing Thursday at 11 A. M. and from Boston Friday at 4 P. M. for Cobh, Plymouth and Havre.
The colorful rolling country in Northwestern Arizona will be the scene June 18 to 22 of one of the biggest mustang round-ups in the records of the Federal Garazinc Bureau.

With only one dissenting vote, a court ruled last night that the National Expropriation Law passed by Congress last year does not apply to urban properties. The case involved was one in the city of Veracruz and the court took the occasion to complain of a "series of absurd laws" existing in the State of Veracruz.

Like Columbus and Magellan, the yachtsmen of today are wandering farther and farther away from home anchorages. They like to imagine themselves as intrepid skippers, especially after they have owned a cruiser two or three years and have learned that a good sturdy hull and a good reliable motor under their decks will take them most anywhere.

The Supreme Court's action in upholding the constitutionality of the Social Security Act this week may bring an increase in the purchase of private homes throughout the New York suburban area, states Peter J. McKenna.

The strugglee to prevent the Spanish war from spreading resolved itself. this week into an effort to repair the gaps left in the international cordon by the withdrawal of Germany and Italy as a result of the bombing of the warship Deutschland.

Making Se his first start at Comiskey Park since last season, Johnny Whitehead, recently reinstated White Sox pitching .ace, hurled the Chicagoans to their sixth straight victory today by shutting out the Athletics, 2 to 0.
Charles E. Riley, a leader in the development of the textile industry in this country, died yesterday at his home in Newton at the age of 85.

The decline in prices of basic raw materials in the last two months has been followed by a similar drop in waste material quotations, with some buying groups withdrawing entirely from the market, dealers reported here yesterday.

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company-Twelve months ended April 30: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, $2,547,134, against $1,885,785 in preceding twelve months: gross revenues, $12,747,494, against $11,599,026. Company is a unit in Standard Gas and Electric Company system.

Sverre Kolterud, Norway's versatile skier, left on the S. S. Bergensfjord of the Norwegian-American Line yesterday for his homeland after spending six months competing in the United States and Canada. Among the numerous honors
HALF hidden in a corner seat in one of the booths at Lindy's one humid afternoon last week, a heavy-set gentleman with an impresario haircut mopped his brow and fanned himself with a menu card.
