Scotty Rankin, veteran Olympic and long-distance runner from Preston, Ont., added a third title to his list today by winning the National A. A. U. 20-kilometer run in blistering heat and against a field of ace performers.

A SUCCESSION of "No Parking" and "No Picnicking" signs along highways which by their loveliness invited tarrying is said to have given inspiration for the roadside parks now springing up on main travel routes in many States.

Joseph F. Shadgen, who drew the preliminary engineering plans for the 1939 World's Fair in New York and who has been called the "father of the World's Fair idea--a title he disclaims-has been dismissed by the fair corporation, it became known last night.

Robert B. Abbe of South.Windham, Conn., a junior at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, has received a prize of $100 offered by Wilfred L. Peel, a New York banker, for displaying "the most ability in the development and presentation of an engineering-economic plan."

Republicans swept the city with the largest majority on record in the largest vote ever cast, re-electing Mayor Walter W. Bacon, a former official of the General Motors Corporation, over Albert W. Bird, the Democratic candidate.
Irish tunes filled the air yesterday as several hundred children and grown-ups vied for prizes at Innisfail Park, stamping ground of the Irish, at 240th Street and Broadway. The occasion was the Feis

A six-day program, opening Thursday afternoon, June 17, and closing June 22, when graduation exercises will be held on the lawn in front of Nassau Hall, has been arranged for Princeton University's 190th commencement week, it was announced today by Dr. Wilson Farrand, '86, clerk of the university board of trustees and chairman of the commencement committee.
Leave of absence for twenty-three days, effective on or about June 7, 1937, to terminate not later than June 30, 1937. is granted 1st Lt. Isidore Markowitz, Med.-Res.

THAT 1938 looks good to the automotive industry is proved by the huge expenditures now being made for enlargement of plant capacities. Expansion has not been confined to any one company, but is general throughout the industry.

Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt of Newark, widow of Peter Cooper Hewitt, inventor, must defend $500,000 civil damage suit brought by her daughter Ann, Superior Judge E. P. Shortall ruled today. He overruled demurrers filed by Mrs. Hewitt and two doctors, charged in the complaint with performing a sterilization operation without the consent of Miss Hewitt,

Despite the inroads made by fast and unwearying motors in the city the horse is here to stay, in the opinon of Garrett W. Howard, chief inspector of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, who celebrated his twenty-fifth anniversary of continuous service with the A.S.P.C.A. last week.

The women's Eastern golf champonship, one of the more important medal play tests of the season, will be held at the Plainfield Country Club, Plainfield, N. J., starting tomorrow and continuing through Wednesday.

Garden Day in the Oranges will be celebrated on Wednesday under the auspices of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, Inc. Several gardens in the Llewellyn Park district which will be open to visitors include the places of Mrs. Harry H. Bottome, Mrs. Herbert S. Gay, Mrs. William Barstow, Mrs. Frederick Tomkins, Mrs. John Y. G. Walker and Mrs. Hendon Chubb.

The Yankee home-run guns, silent since last Sunday, burst forth at Navin Field today to pound the Tigers into defeat before a gathering of 27.500.

New comparative studies of Jewish and Moslem philosophy of medieval times disclose that what is generally regarded as medieval Christian philosophy is basically not all Christian, Professor Harry A. Wolfson of Harvard University, one of the world's leading authorities on medieval philosophy, told the Institute of Post-Biblical Jewish Literature at its closing session here yesterday.

Current consumer resentment against prices on national brands fixed under the various fair trade laws is causing manufacturers considerable worry, because they, rather than the retailers, are receiving the brunt of the criticism, reports here yesterday indicated.

The electrical household-appliance department is one of the most important sections of the department store which showed a loss last year, indicating that this division did not share in the improved profit showing of most other store divisions, according to H. I. Kleinhaus, executive director of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Simply because they are women, more than 10,000,000 employed women are receiving 40 to 60 per cent less than men doing the same kind of work, Mrs. Edith Houghton Hooker of Baltimore, graduate physician from Johns Hopkins University and leader in the equal rights movement, said here today.

Dr. Marvin (Mal) Stevens, football mentor -at New York University and former Yale head coach, said today that the move backed by The Yale Daily News for longer term contracts for Eli coaches was desirable.

Miss Eunice Ruth Allan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Allan of Montclair, was married this evening in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here to Daniel Good Quigley, son of Mrs. James E. Quigley of Loch Haven, Pa., and the late Mr. Quigley. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lewis Nichols of Old Trinity Parish, New York.
German Catholicism, roused to action by the Nazi regime's charges of widespread immorality among its priesthood and laity, fought back tonight.

Rollo Peters, who a dozen years ago played Romeo opposite Jane Cowl and since then has co-starred with Katharine Cornell, Ann Harding and others in successful Broadway productions, has turned his attention from the theatre to architecture and home-building.
Five hundred thousand persons, including many foreigners, are expected to witness the annual auto racing classic tomorrow over the famous Gavea circuit.

ON "Halifax Resolution Day," Aril 12, the citizens of North Carolina celebrate the first formal declaration by any American colony in favor of separation from the mother country. On May 19, 1643, the beginnings of a federation of colonies were got under way in New England. July 25 is Frontier Day in Cheyenne, Wyo.; and on June 15 Idaho recalls the first permanent white settlement, in 1860, in that State.

Japan has reached the apex of her advance in foreign trade volume and now faces the problem of maintaining her position, Choykuro Kadono, head of the Japanese Economic Mission now in this country, told THE TIMES yesterday. Under the twin influences of rising raw material prices and home production costs, he added, quotations are being pushed upward on Japanese exports.
Dickinson College dropped an exciting Commencement Day game to her ancient rival, Gettysburg, today before a big alumni crowd, 4 to 3.

Possible application of the proposed provisions of the Black-Connery wage and hour bill to stores was carefully studied in retail circles last week, but, as far as available information indicated, its application to the rank and file of retailing was considered remote.

Sixty-three per cent of the coat and suit volume is purchased directly by retailers themselves, the remaining 37 per cent being bought through resident offices, according to a report issued yesterday by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and chairman of the fair trade practice committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

Miss Caroline Sizer, daughter of Professor and Mrs. Theodore Sizer of this city, was married here this afternoon to Alexander Smith Cochran, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cochran of Woodbrook, Baltimore, in Battell Chapel, Yale University, by the Rev. Sidney Lovett.
A number of properties in Dutchess and Putnam Counties, N. Y. recently have changed hands in deals in which residents- bf New York City were buyers, reports Loretta M. Turney, broker.

Walkouts involving Filipino sugar plantation workers spread today, with the their strike leader, Antonio Fagel, claiming 4,500 idle. Fagel telegraphed from Maui Island that Kaeleku Sugar Company workers had joined the walkout.

Miss True Compton, daughter of Major Ranulf Compton and Mrs. Compton, of New Haven and Quarry Ledge, Madison, was married here this afternoon to Gordon Giffen, son of Dr. Thomas T. Giffen of Oakland, Calif. The ceremony was performed in the Church-on-the Green by the Rev. Dr. John Williams.

One of the most incomprehensible of many incomprehensible points about the air attack on the Deutschland May 29 is why the Valencia government thought it worth while to resort to an action the only possible result of which could have been to cement the friendship of Italy and Germany General Francisco Franco's two main supporters--and render it more difficult for them to abandon the Spanish enterprise.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Hoon, daughter of Mrs. Earl Hoon of this place and the late Rev. Dr. Hoon, to Robert Cawley of Princeton, N. J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Edward Cawley of Boston.
Alfred E. Smith failed to Premier Benito Mussolini today but what they said is tentatively stored away under Mr. Smith's brown derby.

Tentative appointment of George H. Nettleton, Lampson Professor of English at Yale and former head of the English Department, to be dean of the Academic Department, succeeding Professor Clarence M. Mendell, who retires this month, was announced today. His name will go before the corporation for appointment in two weeks.

WHERE are the cars of yesteryear. the cars that were once so young and fair and now are seen no more? Thieves, as you say, could account, if they would, for some of them. But what of the host of cars that are never stolen, yet vanish sooner or later from mortal ken?

To the Radio Editor: Infinitely as important to the public at large as the reforms in burlesque, squabbling politicians, and the Kentucky Derby, is the present state of affairs which exists over the presentation of radio programs.

EACH season a growing number of tourists visits Canada's Gaspe coast on the Gulf of St. Lawrence, attracted by Bonaventure Island and Perce Rock and their great sea fowl colony. The red sandstone cliffs of Perce Rock drop a sheer 300 feet to the sea;

Filed in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court today, the will of John D. Rockefeller, who died in Florida on May 23 at the age of 97. left his residuary estate, estimated at $25,000,000, in trust for his granddaughter, Mrs. Margaret Strong De Cuevas, her two young children, Elizabeth and John, and the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

Miss Nancy Elizabeth Humpstone, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. O. Paul Humpstone of 327 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to James B. Gardiner 2d, son of Harry Gardiner of Amnsterdam, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the, Rev. Dr. Charles Carroll Albertson in the ballroom of the Hotel Pierre.

Listing liabilities totaling $2,909,229.51, Max N. Natanson of 522 Fifth Avenue, a real estate operator who headed the corporations which built the Herald Square, General Motors and Delmonico Buildings, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court.

Members of the Alumnae Association of the Academy of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, Conn., entertained thirty-five children from the Barat Settlement, 221 Chrystie Street, yesterday at an outing given at the school. Features of the event included a picnic, swimming in Long Island Sound and games.

Of recent developments in the Spanish situation it may be said they have left fresh quantities of dynamite strewn about, thereby enhancing. the chances of an explosion, but there is a general tendency to refrain from smoking cigarettes among the packages lest the explosion occur.

Formation of a committee to draw up a brief outlining what American exporters and investors feel are important considerations in working out trade relations with the Philippines was announced here yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Levitt Sons, developers and home builders on Long Island and in Westchester Country, report that seventeen new homes were sold in their various developments during the Decoration Day. holiday period. These sales represented an aggregate value of $204,000, establishing, it is stated, a new weekly sales record for the firm.

William James Henderson, for fifty years one of America's best known music critics, was found in the library of his apartment in the Hotel Langwell, 123 West Fortyfourth Street, yesterday morning dying of a wound from a pistol shot in the mouth which apparently had been self-inflicted.

RHODODENDRON in sheafs and clusters will be brought out of the mountains to adorn public buildings, show windows, floats and private homes during Festival Week, June 12-18, when Asheville's residents and visitors celebrate the blossoming of this spectacular shrub.

VICTIMS of a fate that denies them a chance at screen careers because they resemble movie stars, twentytwo Hollywood doubles who act as stand-ins and who are frequently called by the studios to appear in long shots when the stars are not available are having their day at Columbia, where, still doubling, they nevertheless possess an identity of their own.
An increasing use of glass for structural purposes and in decorations and furnishings has stimulated the production by manufacturers of new types which are proving both practical and decorative.

Super-markets are now located in practically every section of the country and wherever they have made an appearance competition has taken on a keener edge, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., indicated yesterday in a preliminary report based on replies received to questionnaires sent to more than 600 brokers in all parts of the country except the West Coast. One man was taken to Cumberland Street Hospital and fourteen other persons were treated at the scene and left for their homes at 9:30 o'clock last night following a head-on collision between two street cars at Flushing and Washington Avenues, Brooklyn.

SHAKESPEAREAN characters will stalk the Summer air in eight one-hour dramas described by the broadcasters as "a most ambitious series." Connecticut's legislators this week decided stand-up drinking is all right for men, but not all right for women except in places operating under club permits. Legislative action was completed early in the week on the major revisions of the State Liquor Control Act, and the bills are now on their way to the Governor for his approval.

St. Lawrence University Theological School will hold its seventyseventh commencement June 13, but no diplomas will be issued. There was only one candidate for graduation at the little Universalist institution, but the faculty decided he had not prepared himself sufficiently for a Bachelor of Divinity degree.

The forty-seventh annual commencement of the Dwight School for Girls will be held at 11 o'clock Wednesday morning at the school on Seven Sisters Hills here. Dr. James Clelland, director of religious education at Amherst College, will give the address. Clinton V. Miserole, chairman of the board of trustees, of which Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow is a member, will officiate.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J.--A fash ion show will be held on the beach at Illinois Avenue on Thursday afternoon as a part of a series of entertainment features being staged for some 2,000 physicians and their wives attending conventions here.
Behind the two-hit pitching of Ben Simoncelli, Penn State's baseball team closed its season today with a 5-1 triumph over Syracuse. It was the twelfth victory in sixteen starts for the Lions.

More than 2,000 children paraded through the streets of Yorkville yesterday afternoon in the June walk organized by the Yorkville Neighborhood Councils and the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department.

Mrs. Bessie Thorpe disclosed today that her granddaughter, Miss Wanda Thorpe, 19-year-old Ball State College junior, had been missing from her home for a week.
Jim Braddock, heavyweight champion, started celebrating today what he says will be the happiest birthday anniversary of his life.
A 64-year-old ironworker was accused yesterday of felonious assault in that he sprinkled ground glass into food being prepared for ten persons, including himself and his 18-year-old daughter, Anne.

Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, who will retire from the bench at the end of this year, was the guest of honor tonight at the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the Nassau County Bar Association in the Bar Club House, attended by 300 members of the bench and bar.
WITH the pre-vacation period at hand and warm weather to help, retail trade moved out of the doldrums last week in many centers and some of the best gains for the year were reported.

A stockholders' plan for the rehabilitation of the Fiedelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company here was approved this week by Vice Chanceller Leon Berry. The concern has been under the control of trustees for three years.

Miss Marianna Harkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Harkins of New York, was married to William E. Warren, son of Mrs. William Warren, also of this city, and the late Mr. Warren, yesterday in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola by the Rev. Thomas J. Delihant.

The Nazi regime, almost since the moment it came to power in Germany, has been at odds with the Catholic Church. A concordat, negotiated with the Vatican in 1933, denied the church political power but allowed it to maintain its youth organizations and schools as long as they kept within the bounds of religion and education.

A building equipment showroom in the American Radiator Building and annex, 40 West Fortieth Street, will be opened on Wednesday in Roads, conjunction with the "Sixth Avenue Rebuilt" campaign to be conducted by the Sixth Avenue Association.

In the first quarter of 1937 farmers received the largest volume of their mortgage credit from individuals, their mortgage loans and renewals aggregating more than $79,000,000, or 36 per cent of the total, the Farm Credit Administration announced today.

FISCIER-MARGOLIS-Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Margolis announce marriage of daughter. Beatrice, to Jack J. Fischer, June 2. Rabbi J. M. Lawn officiated. GETTLEMAN-WEISS--Mr. and Mrs. Abner A; Weiss announce the marriage of their daughter, Bernice, to Mr. Carl Gettleman, to take place June 6 at the Gotham Hotel.

A decision recently rendered by Justice Isaac M. Kapper, Supreme Court official referee in Kings County, reduced by $55,000 the assessed valuation for 1936 taxes on two six-story apartment houses in Brooklyn. The city had appraised the property at $355,000 as of Oct. 1, 1935. The court fixed the amount

THE land that time has forgotten is the hitherto unexplored interior of New Guinea, where men fight their enemies with weapons made of stone. And the story told here is that of Michael Leahy's travels and discoveries in that unknown hinterland. It is an interesting

Miss Helen Jane Setherman, daughter of Mrs. Horace Setherman of this place, was married this afternoon to George D. Rosencrans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leland S. Rosencrans, also of Belvidere at the Methodist Episcopal Church here. The Rev. W. Gilbert Bowering performed the ceremony.
THREE teams of American bridge players are on their way to Budapest, where they will compete with teams from thirteen or more European countries in an international tournament beginning June 13.

Miss Irene Harriet Dunkak, daughter of Mrs. Everett Higby of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Henry Dunkak, was married to Joseph Anthony Campagna, son of Count and Countess Anthony Campagna of Riverdale-on-Hudson, yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks.

Having adjourned for the Summer after one of the most momentous sessions in the court's history, the members of the Supreme Court have nearly all left Washington for a rest. Two of the justices plan to
How meticulous is Uncle Sam was revealed recently in connection with the building of a mechanical cow which was to be included in an agricultural exhibit.

A platoon from the United States Military Academy at West Point will take part June 19 in ceremonies at Governors Island to celebrate the tercentenary of the purchase of the island. This was announced by

The Westchester Little Opera Company, an amateur group, closed its 1936-37 season tonight with seelections from famous operas, including Bizet's "Armen," Smetana's "The Bartered Bride," Verdi's "II Trovatore" and Gounod's "Faust," at the Westchester County Center.

IN the past year the industry used 6,500,000 tons of steel and more than 250,000 tons of malleable iron, thus becoming the No. 1 consumer of these products," D. S. Eddins, Plymouth president, said recently.

Financial assistance to home owners and prospective home buyers based on the character of the borrowers is of more importance in mortgage lending, says Morton Bodfish, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League than the appraisal value of the house and lot.

J. W. Calhoun, president ad interim of the University of Texas since June 1, was the first to view the S. M. Swenson $75,000 coin collection when it was removed from a safe which had not been opened in twenty-five years.

Many persons in the religious world today have lost their sense of direction; they are "at sea" about fundamental Christian truths, the Rev. Howard W. Ferrin, president of the Providence Bible Institute, said yesterday in his sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The first of a series of events for the fourteenth annual commencement exercises of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel began today when Mgr. Joseph A. Breslin preached the baccalaureate sermon. The benediction of the most blessed sacrament was pronounced by the Rev. John B. Murphy, the Rev.

June 6 (AP).-The thirdplace White Sox extended their winning streak to eight straight and advanced to within two games of the first place Yankees today by twice defeating the Athletics, 6 to 1 and 6 to 5. A crowd of 32,000 saw the doubleheader.

Officials of the Republic Steel Company Still billeted several hundred non-strikers in their plants tonight as the deadline for an evacuation ordered by Mayor Kelly drew near. On the other side, the strikers laid their case before President RooseVelt in a telegram, which declared that their cause was one of national importance and that he alone could bring the opposing elements together.

With Snark, a world's record holder, and Bill Farnsworth, fresh from New England after setting a new six-furlong track mark at Suffolk, included in the entries for the Queens County Handicap, the Aqueduct meeting will begin this afternoon at the old, Long Island course.

President Albert Lebrun of the French Republic opened the world-wide Rotarian congress here today in a speech that was more than a formal welcome and which aroused the cheering enthusiasm of 8,000 Rotarians massed in the great hall of the Municipal Casino.

Passengers waiting on the east-bound platform of the Brooklyn Museum station of the I. R. T. subway just before midnight were startled by the sudden appearance of a two-foot alligator which had Tra emerged from a refuse can.

The first jurisdictional clash in Quebec Province between William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, is in prospect in the Montreal steel industry.

Fordham's baseball team, which hit its stride in the closing weeks of the season, added three victories to its string as the collegiate baseball season came to a close in the metropolitan district. The triumphs, which included two over intracity rivals, gave the Rams championship honors in the city for the second year in succession.

After a week of fine weather the Greenwich Village Art Show closed suddenly yesterday in a thunder and lightning storm. It was scheduled to close at sunset but the storm cut it short two hours earlier.

MUCH of the "inside stuff" on pulp paper magazines appears anonymously and reads as though it had been written by some one named Uriah Heep. The articles usually are labeled as "Confessions." The writer implies that he has done wrong in having anything to do with the pulps and is sorry.

Packers bought lard futures here last week to remove hedges and there was a moderate speculative business, although the market showed weakness. The close on July lard was at $12.40 a hundredweight, off 2 1/2 cents from the previous week.

The New York Americans of the American Soccer League defeated St. Mary's Celtics before 1,500 fans at Starlight Park yesterday, 5-2. The contest was tied, 2-2, at half time. Two minutes after ends were changed the Americans went into the lead, when Hooper made a spectacular shot. from Kuntner's pass.

Flashing a powerful attack in the last two periods, during which they scored five goals, the First Division poloists conquered Blind Brook of Port Chester, 8-6, in a thrilling match yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn before 3,500. The latter part of the , contest was played in a drizzle.

Aldous Huxley has written a preface in praise of a book on handreading, a volume that Knopf will publish shortly. It is the work of Charlotte Wolff, and includes illustrated analyses of the hands of Bernard Shaw, T. S. Eliot,
Two former Swarthmore deans, one a graduate of the college, presented the baccalaureate and Phi Beta Kappa addresses at Swarthmore College today.
Allan V. Heely, headmaster of Lawrenceville School, will deliver the address at the thirteenth annual graduation exercises of the Princeton Country Day School tomorrow night.

A warning not to "betray ourselves into social and national catastrophe" by putting our "faith in the power of wages and income to produce happiness and shift to government responsibility for individual destiny" was given today by Chancellor Gray in his baccalaureate address at American University.
For more than a week workmen in the plants of the Republic Steel Corporation have been besieged by strikers who have thrown cordons around the company's properties in the Youngstown district.
The College of William and Mary is offering an exceptional opportunity of attending a seminar in Colonial history to one hundred persons who wish to spend a week in the atmosphere of Colonial times.

Opposion to that section of President Roosevelt's government reorganization plan which calls for placing independent boards and commissions within executive departments is contained in chapters of a study being made by the Brookings Institution for the Senate committee investigating executive agencies.
William H. Thompson, former United States Senator from Nebraska and one-time member of the State Supreme Court, died today at his home here. His age was 83. He had been ill almost two years.

Describing the Richfield Oil Corporation as the third largest Pacific Coast marketer of oil products, a final report by William C. McDuffie, reorganization trustee, was filed in the Federal Court here yesterday,

New frontiers challenging discoveries in "the realm of the spirit rather than in the geographical or material areas of life" were held out to the seniors of Washington and Lee University today in a baccalaureate sermon preached by the Rev. Paul B. Kern of Durham, N. C., Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South.

James Hauze and Gene Gisburne, athletic stars at the University of Pennsylvania, have won their ninth varsity letters, according to the list of athletic awards announced today by Russell Callow, chairman of the awards committee.

Nine C. I. O. aides were convicted last night by an Androscoggin County jury of conspiracy charges growing out of the LewistonAuburn shoe strike. Three others were acquitted by the jury, which deliberated for ten and one-half hours before returning its verdict. The trial began eleven days ago.

Miss Jeanie Rae, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Rae of Glen Rock, N. J., has chosen the evening of June 26 for her marriage to William J. Schmeelck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Schmeelck of this place.
Staving off a Cleveland counter-attack in the tenth inning, the Senators defeated the Indians, 8 to 7, before 30,000 fans today in the first game of a scheduled double-header.

Fears that sudden demands for chemicals might be the temporary result of re-armament programs have made some chemical-producing countries rely on imports because their own industries were reluctant to expand their capacity under such conditions,

A Rhonsperber-type sailplane, the first of its kind ever brought to his country, was tested yesterday over Queens by Emil Lehecka, 22 years old, glider enthusiast, of 23-22 Thirty-sixth Street, Astoria, who plans to enter the German-made craft in the international glider

Throngs from the neighborhood of Trinity Cemetery, on both sides of Broadway from 153d to 155th Street, visited it yesterday morning to view the damage wrought on many graves by vandals on last Thursday and Friday nights. Relatives of many persons buried there found headstones overturned and in some instances broken.

Miss Emily Benedict McAlpin, daughter of Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin of this place and ther late Rev. Dr. McAlpin, ill be married to John Quincy Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Le Roy Adams of Holyoke, Mass., on July 2.

Notwithstanding gold scares and troubled Spain, the Paris market's chief unsettling factor is the internal situation. From the economic standpoint it is now clear, according to financial circles, that after a year of experiment the policy of Premier Leon Blum is far from having given the promised results.

John Tobin Connery died yesterday of- heart disease in the Edgewater Beach Hotel, which he owned, after a long illness. His age was 76. Mr. Connery was president of the. Edgewater Beach Apartments and the Miami Coal Company, as well as of the hotel. He was a friend of Presidents Wilson, Harding, Coolidge and Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The Right Rev. Paul Matthews, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, will confer diplomas on twelve students here Tuesday morning during exercises at St. Mary's Hall, historic church school for girls.

Arthur Dillon, retired architect, who designed a number of well known buildings and monuments in New Jersey and New York, died last night at his home here after a long illness. He was 67 years old and the son of the late John A. Dillon, who was editor of the old New York World.

Seven Oberlin College seniors from New York City and vicinity are expected to receive the Bachelor of Arts degree at the commencement exercises on Tuesday. They are: Robert N. Bliss, 130 Morningside Drive. Miss Maxine Cook, 310 East Forty-fourth Street.

The early decline in last week's financial markets did not carry stocks to the low point of the year, and it was canceled before the week ended. But it was considerable enough to set Wall Street inquiring what it meant, for Wall Street must always have a reason for a definite movement, even that of a single day.

The wedding of Miss Virginia Coley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Coley of this city, to Kingsley Smith, son of Professor Robert Seneca Smith of the Yale Divinity School and the late Mrs. Smith, will take place June 26 in

The rightful province of woman in the world is to "be the one for whom great things are done," the Rev. Leonard Feeney, S. J., associate editor of America, said today in the baccalaureate address at Rosemont College.

Four men and a dog were left alone on a drifting ice floe near the North Pole today to spend a year gathering scientific data to enrich the Soviet Union's knowledge of the top of the world. WThe four airplanes of the. Soviet's North Pole expedition took off at 3:30 A. M. [8:30 P. M., Saturday, New York time] from the base camp established by the pathfinder plane May 21 near the Pole.

The Imperial Conference which begins its final week today stands as another example of the difficulty of finding a common meeting ground for the problems of countries scattered over the whole face of the world.

" Champion Blakeen Jung Frau, snowy white poodle turned out to the moment and presenting a striking picture against the greensward, was the victor over 857 other candidates for the highest honors today in the fifth annual all-breed exhibition of the Longshore Kennel Club held on the lawns of the Longshore Beach and Country Club.

Banks and financial journals here are commenting with reserve on the business outlook in the United States. Most of them hold to the opinion that inasmuch as the saturation point already has been reached by certain industries, 1937, unlike the preceding two years, will witness a rather sharp decline of Summer activity.

" Gone With the Wind," Pulitzer Prize winner and best seller, was summarily rejected by nearly 500 delegates to the American Writers Congress, meeting here yesterday, who balloted among themselves to pick the best books published in the year ended on May 1.
Thirty-seventh annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, 9:30 A. M. Afternoon and evening sessions.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ketchline were reminded yesterday that they had been married sixty years and one day ago at Ashland, Ohio. They celebrated the anniversary at the Hotel Biltmore, where they had dinner with a niece, Mrs. Minnie May Anderson, who came from Detroit, where she is superintendent of the East Side General Hospital, for the occasion.

Holders of old corn in Iowa and Illinois were moderate sellers of that grain early last week, depressing cash prices slightly with futures. Later offerings were light. No. 2 yellow corn is bringing to 8 1/2 cents a bushel over July, with the spread in No. 2 white 9 cents.

The executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, at a meeting yesterday at Temple Emanu-EI, Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfifth Street, endorsed a proposal to send a questionnaire to rabbis throughout the nation to get their views on the work done by the union.

One of the chief benefits which newspapers hope to achieve by comic strip advertising in dailies, now being offered by about 300 publication throughout the country, is regularity in copy, according to comment.

Financial and commodity markets are behaving in a manner which is keenly disappointing to those who expected an immediate return of confidence and activity as a result of the government's decision to drop the growthof-profits tax.

Jubilee festivals are of "divine origin," Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, vicar general of the archdiocese and rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, said yesterday in his sermon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier,

Miss Nicki Jaffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barney Jaffin of this city and Mount Vernon, N. Y., was married to Irving J. Galpeer, an attorney with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt by the Rev. Max Maccoby of Mount Vernon.

Miss Leila Ingersoll Jones, daughter of Mrs. Gilbert E. Jones of this city and the late Mr. Jones, has completed plans for her marriage to Neils Kampmann, only son of Kampmann of Aarhus, Denmark, which will take place here on Saturday afternoon in St. Peter's Church. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev.

Miss Anne Whaples has announced that her sister, Miss Jean Whaples, will be maid of honor at other wedding here June 24 to John Sheldon McCook of New York. The Rev. George Robert of West Hartford, uncle of the bride-elect, will officiate, assisted by the Rev. Quincy Blakely and the Rev. Dr. Remsen

It will be Earl Baldwin, Viscount of Corvedale, after former Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin receives his peerage from the King, The Daily Express says today. It had been expected that the viscounty--which will be used as a courtesy title during Mr. Baldwin's lifetime by his Socialist son Oliver--would be Viscount of Bewdley in recognition of the constituency Mr. Baldwin represented in the House of Commons for twenty-nine years.

L. Burton Hall, vice president of the International Silver Company, with which, and its predecessor companies, he had been associated for fifty-six years, died yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Granada. Brooklyn, at the age of 79.

Miss Mabel Clay, State regent of the New Jersey Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution since 1935 and member of an old Philadelphia family, died last night after a brief illness at her home, 10 South Union Avenue, Margate. Her age was 56.

Owen S. Kennedy of 2 Glenwood Avenue, who retired in 1924 after thirty-five years as sports editor of The Jersey Journal, died here today in the Medical Center after a two-day illness of a stomach ailment. He was born in Ottawa, Canada, seventy-two years ago.

IRWIN FALICK, furniture, 650 9th Ave,--By Wornock Mills, Inc., for $300; Western Carpet and Linoleum Co., Inc., $200; Colonial Carpet Corp., $40. M. WULFSOHN CO., INC., importers of furs, 265 W. 50th St.--By Bank of United States on a Judgment claim for $119,716.
The film "The Passing of the Third Floor Back" provided the text for the sermon preached by the Rev. Brian Hessian, vicar of a London Episcopalian Church, in a moving picture theatre tonight.

The wedding of Miss Margaret Winifred Compton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Compton of Milford, to Clyde Overton Orr, son of Mrs. Earl J. Bailey of this city, will take place in Dwight Memorial Chapel, Yale University, June 19. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Sidney A. Lovett, Yale University chaplain.

James E. Brannigan,. former member of the police department, who was assigned to City Hall during the administration of Mayor John P. O'Brien, announced yesterday his candidacy for Tammany leader of the Seventh Assembly District, a post now held by Marshall Ingram, Deputy Commissioner of Public Works.

The railroads of the Ohio steel area wired Governor Davey demanding that he take action at once to enable them to operate without damage and interference. They declared that the strike was forcing them to lay off thousands of men. Page 1.
Three naval weddings took place here today, the bridegrooms being graduates of the 1935 Naval Academy class, now holding the-rank of ensign.

It rained at Ebbets Field yesterday but the weather had nothing to do with the Red wave that overwhelmed the Dodgers and sent 11,671 Flatbush fans home through the murky semi-darkness in a state of great disgruntlement with their some-time heroes.

Speaking at a Socialist party meeting this evening commemorating the first anniversary of the formation of his Cabinet, Premier Leon Blum said he had succeeded in improving the lot of the working class without having injured the middle class or the peasantry.
The "typical modern university" was criticized today by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J., president of Fordham University, as "educating into despair."

Harvesting of Winter wheat in the Southwest and in parts of the Middle West is under way and with favorable weather it is expected to move northward rapidly. Some harvesting of wheat has been done in the Southeast, but the aggregate production there is not heavy.

Dr. Robert Liston Irish of 212 East Sixteenth Street, who was national president of the Theta Chi fraternity from 1921 to 1929, died yesterday in the Reconstruction Hospital of an infection which developed after a fall on icy pavement in Stuyvesant Square in March. He was 69 years old.

Spy-hunts, arrests of traitors and purges in ever-widening circles suggest that all is not well in the Soviet Union. Nobody can pretend to know what is really happening in Russia. After twenty years of rule by the Communist party, during which the world has heard and seen more than ever before of this tremendous country, spanning two continents, it is still an unknown land.

Thomas H. Guthrie, a cobbler and shoemaker here for more than thirtyfive years, during which period he had made shoes for many famous persons, died today at his home, 242 Halsey Street, after a brief illness. He conducted his shoe business at the same address. His age was 78.

Without a single exception, Equity's "regular" ticket, headed by Frank Gillmore, president, was victorious in the election on Friday, the tellers' report revealed yesterday. As generally predicted throughout the pre-election campaign,

Senator Sheppard of Texas, father of the Prohibition Amendment and chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, urged today that the forces of peace and prohibition unite their campaigns against war and rum. "No finer benefit could befall mankind," he told delegates to the world convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union.
England's biggest tennis bookmaker today listed Don Budge, red-headed American Davis Cup star, as an even-money favorite to win the AllEngland singles championship at Wimbledon.

The Festoon Farms four of Eatontown defeated the Burnt Mills Polo Club at Schley Field today, 5 to 1, in a game which was played between two heavy storms and at times through a light drizzle. George Oliver paced the winners' attack, scoring three goals.

Mr. and Mrs. Orson D. Munn have left the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria and have gone to Southampton, L. I., for the Summer. Miss Alice B. Riggs of Stockbridge, Mass., will be joined byDr. and Mrs. Austen Fox Riggs at the Carlyle today.
Making her first long air trip since her leg was broken in an airplane accident that caused the death of her husband and four others, Mrs. Martin Johnson boarded a plane here today for Hollywood,

Loyalty to God, loyalty to the flag, and loyalty to the home are the first considerations in character development and the whole scope of Catholic education," the Rev. M. Ernest Wilson told the graduating class of Albertus Magnus College today at the baccalaureate mass in St. Mary's Church. n St. Mary's Church.

Edward F. Roosevelt, commissioner to Latin America for the New York World's Fair, left here tonight on an airplane tour of twenty-two countries to promote participation by their governments and commercial interests in the 1939 exposition. Mr. Roosevelt, a distant cousin to the President, has been associated with the World's Fair Corporation since its inception.

With industry active and the conviction that continuance of the present boom is assured, at least until the end of the year, business .is looking with emphatic disfavor upon international complications.

Miss Nancy Allaire Titus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Titus of Mamaroneck, will be wed on the June 26 to Stanislas George Trembicki, son of Mrs. Marie Trembicki of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Harold Trembicki of Forest Hills, Queens. The ceremony will be performed in St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, Mamaroneck, N. Y., by the rector, the Rev. Frank Dean Gifford.

The body of 10-year-old Mona Tinsley, who disappeared Jan. 6, was found today in the River Idle. The body was identified by the girl's father. Frederick Nodder, 45-year-old truck driver, was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment at
The Very Rev. Noble C. Powell; dean of Washington Cathedral, delivered the baccalaureate sermon for George Washington University in the Great Choir of the cathedral here today. He said:

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Cox Leggett of 402 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Craig Bield, Redding Ridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara MacGay Leggett, to Dr. Otto Emile Billo of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Billo of Glen Ridge, N. J.

Archduke Otto of Hapsburg was a witness today of the resumption of the Spanish Insurgents' drive against Bilbao. From a hill-top near the front southeast of Bilbao the 24-year-old Archduke watched Insurgent artillery and airplanes showering shells and bombs on 'the' Basque lines near Lemona, seven miles from the Basoue capital.

Newark divided a double-header with Syracuse today, winning the opener, 3 to 1, and then dropping the nightcap, 2 to 1. The second tilt was called because of rain after one Chief had been retired in the sixth frame. The defeat in the nightcap brought an end to the Bears' sevengame winning streak.

Between 75,000 and 100,000 persons in the island's needle industry will not be at work tomorrow as a result of a decision by the employers to cease all operations pending clarification of the 1919 $1-a-day minimum-wage law revived by a Supreme Court ruling.
Rookie Julio Bonetti pitched the Browns to a 3-to-2 victory over the Red Sox in the second game of a double-header today after Boston had taken the first, 6 to 5.

About 500 Spanish children refugees, arriving at Veracruz tomorrow, will be taken to Morelia, the capital of the Central Pacific State of Michoacan and entered in a newly constructed school for socialistic education by order of President Lazaro Cardenas.

In a poll being conducted by New York Politics, 71 per cent of the Republican voters so far canvassed favor the renomination of Mayor La Guardia, Jerry Finkelstein, publisher of that magazine, announced yesterday.

A new surgical technique, known as "psycho-surgery," which, it is claimed, cuts away sick parts of the human personality, and transforms wild animals into gentle creatures in the course of a few hours, will be demonstrated here tomorrow at the Comprehensive Scientific Exhibit of the American Medical Association, which is holding its eighty-eighth annual assembly here this week.

Former Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney and other speakers protested yesterday against discrimination against Jews in Rumania and urged action on their behalf by American Jews at the twenty-eighth annual convention of the United Rumanian Jews of America at the Hotel Astor.

Long Island University will hold its seventh annual commencement exercises tonight, awarding degrees to 105 students at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Dean Tristram Walker Metcalfe will deliver the address to the graduating class and Dr. Henry Neumann,

Estimates by public welfare officials of the number of employable persons on up-State home relief rolls proved nearly 50 per cent too high when the Works Progress Administration sought to requisition 14,131 "employables" for WPA jobs and found that only 7,421 of the reported number were available and eligible, it was announced yesterday in the monthly bulletin published by Lester W. Herzog, upState WPA administrator.

A banking group composed of Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., Hemphill, Noyes Co., Minsch, Monell Co., Inc., and Robinson, Miller Co., Inc., will offer today new issues aggregating $802,000 of Suffolk County, L. I., 2.20 per cent bonds and certificates of indebtedness.

The-dances of ten European countries were presented yesterday afternoon at the Folk Festival Council's third annual festival in Central Park. Some were war dances, some courtship pantomimes and others were derived from pagan ceremonials.
Mrs. Frank Wentworth Alden of Westfield has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Vesta Louisa Alden, to George Charles Putnam, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Putnam of Waterbury, Conn.

Terming most royal marriages mere business mergers upon which the clergy gives the sanction of God," the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Eightysixth Street and West End Avenue,
Chancellor Adolf Hitler, in an aggressive mood, assured a meeting of 120,000 Nazi Brown Shirts tonight that.Germany had no intention of relinquishing her armed security.

The annual shooting of the small bore matches of the New York State Rifle Association, started here at Camp Smith yesterday, was concluded today with the running off of three matches. The shooting of the members of the Roslyn Rifle Club,

Totem, sailed by A. E. Luders Jr. of Stamford, Conn., annexed her fourth consecutive first place in six-meter yacht racing today by defeating Rebel, owned and commanded by Paul Shields, by the narrow margin of three seconds.

Arrangements have been completed under which the Manufacturers Trust Company will take over today the assets and liabilities of the Equitable Trust Company of New York, terminating an organization which has been associated with the city's financial history since 1871, when it was founded as the Traders Deposit Company.

Robert C. Boeder, pharmacist, whose drug store has been at 3,667 White Plains Road, between 215th and 216th Streets, Bronx, for fiftyfive years, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence. 3,430 Duncomb Avenue, Bronx. His age was 70.

The Committee for Industrial Organization scored its first victory yesterday in its campaign to organize the 35,000 workers in the taxicab industry of the city when the Terminal System, which operates 500 cabs and employs 1,100 drivers, agreed to the holding of an election to select an exclusive bargaining agency for its employes.

The Black - Connery Wages-andHours Bill includes many different objectives and deals, indeed, with at least three different subjects. One of these is the abolition of child labor, the second is the limitation of hours, the third is the control of wages.

The full assurance of hope in salvation is the acid test of a Christian, declared Dr. Martin LloydJones, famous Welsh physicianpreacher, in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Church, Amsterdam Avenue and West 103d Street.

The Vacation Fund of the Charity Organization Society will be benefited by the formal opening of the skyline garden of the Gramercy Park Hotel on the afternoon of June 16. At tea time in the rock garden and terrace there will be a display of country clothes and other Summer fashions. Miss Diana Gerli is chairman of the manikin committee.
Miss Mary Alicia Nickerson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Nickerson of Noroton, will be married to Walton Campbell Ament on June 26 by the Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham of this city.

Philip Arnold Goodwin, Republican Representative from the Twentyseventh New York District, died at his home here late today. His age was 75. Born .in Athens, N. Y., Mr. Goodwin had been a member of the last two Congresses. He was a former president of the National Bank of this village.
It is to be hoped that when the question of development of the North Beach airport comes before the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate tomorrow, far-sighted counsels will prevail.

The Young Democrats of Massachusetts, Inc., who staged a battle of fisticuffs at a hotel in Cambridge during their annual convention last night, will transfer their activities tomorrow to the city hotel which houses State headquarters.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Menaguale of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Menaguale, to William Herbert Connor, son of Colonel and Mrs. Clarence Herbert Connor of Pelham Manor, N. Y.

Tommy Armour, veteran of the golfing wars, missed by an inch today a putt worth $3,000 as Lighthorse Harry Cooper and Horton Smith grabbed the first prize of $1,000 in the third annual Inverness best-ball matchplay tourney.

President Ignaz Moscicki left Warsaw for Bucharest tonight on a special train. He was seen off at the station by Marshal Edward SmiglyRydz and the entire Cabinet. He will stay three days in the Rumanian capital as King Carol's guest.

Those who say the profit motive is wrong and should be abandoned for the motive of service lose sight of "the fact that business, as a whole, is already dominated by the service motive," Bishop Philip Cook of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Delaware said at the Temple University baccalaureate service today. He declared that no business could last "which is not based on service."

It is no good to start out to change the world with the idea that we do it to make ourselves more comfortable, the Rev. Lauriston Livingston Scaife declared yesterday morning in his first sermon at St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, 344 West Twentieth Street.

Carlos Pintacuda, Italian driver, won Brazil's premier automobile race around the famous Gavea circuit today, establishing a new record for the course. Two spectators were struck by cars and one was killed as the machines hurtled around the dangerous mountain and seaside course.

FredericK B. Snite Jr. of Chicago started tonight on a 10,000-mile journey homeward, after having lived for fourteen months in an "iron lung" at Peiping, where he was stricken with infantile paralysis.

" Radium," a Pete Smith novelty short subject in which photography of the element will be attempted, is scheduled to get under way this week at California Tech. A previous attempt failed because of the damaging effect of the radium on the film stock.
The fasttraveling Cubs came back to capture the nightcap, 7 to 2, from the Bees today after they had been set back, 7 to 1, by their old team-mate, Guy Bush, in the first game of a double-header.

Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, speaking to the German Large Families League here today, urged the nation to multiply exceedingly, promising that future generations would "find the means to expand their borders."
The machine is not yet master of the man and the-defense still has the edge on the offense, European military opinion holds, according to a survey of the Continent just completed.

Mrs. Mary Coles Gunari, widow of Andrew P. Gunari, who was an executive of Ralli Brothers, Ltd., importers, was killed about 10 o'clock yesterday morning when she fell or jumped from a window of her twelfth-floor apartment at 1,060 Park Avenue. She was 65 years old.

Two spectacular accidents, one involving Joel Thorne of New York, wealthy pilot and owner of some of the fastest cars on American tracks, thrilled 10,000 spectators who attended the Fair Grounds auto-racing program today.

Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church of America, told the senior class of Wagner Memorial Lutheran College last night that they face a world containing problems that the greatest men have been unable to solve.

The Soviet Union's third Five-Year Plan, designed this time "to overtake and surpass America," today was taking form in the hands of the nation's industrial leaders. It probably will go into effect next Jan. 1, immediately on completion of the second Five-Year Plan.
The Rev. Dr. Irving H. Berg, dean of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science, in his baccalaureate address to graduating seniors at the Gould Memorial Chapel yesterday,

In his baccalaureate address to seniors of the University of Buffalo, Chancellor Capen this afternoon answered indirectly recent criticism directed at some instructors and teaching methods at the university.

STARTING with the assumption that J. Herman (the Great) Dean was getting a salary of $25,000 for playing ball for the St. Louis Cardinals and that there were 168 days in the playing season, it was figured out that O1' Dizz was losing close to $150 for each day of his recent suspension.

The Rev. Carlos G. Fuller, pastor of the Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, University Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx, urged yesterday morning that Christians study and assimilate the teachings of the Saviour as they read and study their favorite poets or listen to their favorite music.

The Catholic Summer camp is not a luxury but "an honest-to-God necessity" in the life of the growing Catholic child, the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
PULPWOOD EDITOR, by Harold Brainerd Hersey. (Stokes, $3.) All about the pulp paper magazines and the men who write and edit them.

Scoring straight-set successes, four players, including William Lurie, the sixth seeded contestant, yesterday joined the fourth-round contingent in the Brooklyn tennis singles championship tourney on the clay courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush.

Favored by a fresh, true breeze by way of variety, the Echo Bay Yacht Club's special regatta today attracted one of the largest Sunday turnouts in the recent history of Long Island Sound yachtingseventy-seven craft.

A bronze bust of Grover Cleveland, the twenty-second and twentyfourth president of the United States, has been presented to Princeton University by a group of Mr. Cleveland's admirers, headed by Dr. John H. Finley, it was announced today by President Harold Willis Dodds.

Miss Frances Cathryn Westcott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Edmond Westcott of this place, was married this evening in Trinity Church to Edward Wayre Ryder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus Raymond G. Ryder.

Forty-two new missionaries will be sent to various posts this month by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. They have been appointed to twelve of the sixteen foreign countries in which the denomination carries on work.

Verdi's "Aida" was presented by the New York Hippodrome Opera ICompany at the Hippodrome last night before an audience of more than 3,000 persons. Frances Alcorn, a young American soprano, made her debut in the title role, winning immediate favor with the

Governor Lehman vetoed today two bills which would have provided for State regulation and licensing of barbering hairdressing and beauty parlors. "To the extent that it is necessary to protect the public health such purpose should be achieved by sanitary or health regulations," the Governor said.

American scientists encamped on lonely little Canton Island in the mid-Pacific spent today making last-minute adjustments to tons of intericate equipment poised to catch the secrets of the sun in Tuesday's total eclipse.

The Rev. Dr. George L. Robinson of the Presbyterian Theological Seminary of Chicago delivered the baccalaureate sermon today in Ford Auditorium at graduation exercises of the Peekskill Military Academy, before 700 persons including 300 members of the student body.

August F. Kammer Jr. of Baltusrol, who was defeated in the New Jersey amateur golf tournament semi-final Friday by the new champion, Ian B. MacCallum of Ridgewood,. won the qualifying medal today in a three-way playoff.

The krubi at the Bronx Botanical Garden is expected to bloom in several days, T. H. Everett, horticultourist in charge of the plant, said yesterday. The krubi is that huge and peculiar flower which was brought here five years ago from Sumatra, and has grown to a height of nearly eight feet in. a hothouse in the Bronx. .

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.6, which compares with 93.3 the week before, 93.5 two weeks before, 92.7 three weeks before and 93.3 four weeks before.

East Side babies took over Broome Street, between the Bowery and Chrystie Street, yesterday afternoon and. competed for prizes in the second annual baby show and parade of God's Providence House of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, 330 Broome Street.

Speaking on "The Deeper Realities of History," the Rev. J. O. Lindstrom addressed the graduating class of Upsala College today at a baccalaureate service in the Arlington Presbyterian Church here. Mr. Lindstrom is head of the religious department of the college.

The fourth annual Summer sea- t son of the Federal Music Project in the parks of Harlem and the Bronx opens tonight with a program of symphonic music in Poe Park, Bronx. This is the first event in the series in which symphonic and dance music will be performed on Mondays,
The names of 284 more Citizens Military Training Camp candidates, 194 of them from the metropolitan area, were announced yesterday by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area.

Three out of five college students are "intellectual ignoramuses" and might better have matriculated at a trade or agricultural school, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig said yesterday morning in his sermon at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

Fire that destroyed a stable barn at the AkSar-Ben racing plant today caused the death of two men and an estimated seventy-five horses and injured at least a half dozen race workers. Jockey Ed Gunari identified tentatively one of the dead men as Ed Kelly, a "rubber" for Duffy Huff, race-horse owner.
Speaking at baccalaureate services at the College of William and Mary today, the Rev. Sparks W. Melton told some 240 graduates to "collect their wits and know that God is with them."

Dutch financial markets have been influenced greatly by the continuous strength of the guilder, owing to the unabated confidence in it at home and abroad and the further economic improvement in the Netherlands. As a result, gold is flowing rapidly through the equalization fund to the Netherlands Bank.

Where and how he will spend his week-ends this Summer is no longer a problem to Thomas O'Kane, a painter, of 28 Chestnut Street, Bot Princeton. Magistrate Kenneth A. Stevens of the Princeton Borough Police Court settled it for him this morning when he sentenced O'Kane to confinement in the borough jail from Friday night to Monday mOrning every week-end through June, July and August.

After Princeton University's polo quartet and Rumson battled to a 10-10 tie today in the regular six periods at the Rumson Country Club, Cyril Harrison made a goal in the extra chukker which defeated the collegians, 11 to 10.

Miss Betty Jameson smashed her way into the top flight of women's golf today, crushing Miss Patty Berg, 4 and 3, in a battle of l8-year-old high school seniors to win the trans-Mississippi championship.

The general Assembly adjourned at 7:57 A. M. today after the House and Senate had sat all night to send the remaining phases of the administration's legislative program to Governor Earle's desk. Later Governor Earle, in an address to voters of the State, congratulated the Legislature "upon the epoch-making nature of its achievements in this session."

BEER--Andrew, on Saturday, June 5, beloved husband of Mary K. and father of Andrew E. Beer, in his sixty-ninth year. Funeral services at his late residence, Downing Ave., Sea Cliff, L. I., on Monday, June 7, at 11 A. M. Interment private.

Opposition to President Manuel Quezon's early independence plan, which has been simmering under cover among the moneyed interests, was openly voiced today for the first time by a group of rich sugar planters and financiers.
Watson Bell, South Carolina newspaper man, died here tonight of a heart ailment at the age of 43. He had lived here since ill health forced him to retire from active newspaper work seven years ago.

The church in Germany was criticized for its passive stand during the rise of the Nazi regime by Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark, in an address today at the annual baccalaureate convocation of the university's College of Arts and Sciences and School of Business Administration.
Mrs. William F. Little of Rahway, N. J., member of the State Board of Education, gave the commencement address at Bergen County Junior College here today as sixty-two students were graduated.

" Humility" in the quest for knowledge was enjoined upon the seniors of the University of North Carolina today in a baccalaureate sermon delivered by Dr. Paul D. Moody, president of Middlebury College and son of Dwight L. Moody, the evangelist.

Imagination, faith and work were recommended for "growth, happiness and a sense of achievement" to members of the graduating class at the United States Military Academy in the baccalaureate sermon here today. The Rev. Roscoe T. Foust, chaplain, told the class that "no man finds life worth livinghe makes it worth living."

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Mary Senior, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawson Senior of 10 Gracie Square, this city, and Belleair, Fla., to Morton Fearey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Fearey of Garden City, L. I., which will take place on June 29 in the Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Right Rev.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Rushling of West Caldwell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Huntington Rusling, to Charles H. Parkhurst, son of Charles P. Parkhurst of Toledo Ohio.
Richard Gustav Schmid, architect, died today in St. Luke's Hospital after a week's illness. He was 74 years old. He was head of the company bearing his name.
Emmanuel Jonidis, Greek-American pedestrian extraordinary, got off at 11 o'clock yesterday morning on his election promise walk' to Atlanta, Ga., by way of:Albany and Washington.

The steel syndicate reports reserve in the attitude of foreign customers but everlengthening home delivery terms. In May Germany's engineering industry as a whole was occupied to 94 per cent of capacity, but orders on the books of its leading branches far exceeded capacity.

The abandonment of religion by its former team-mate, education, is a primary cause of current moral ills, Arnaud C. Marts, acting president of Bucknell University, said in his baccalaureate address this morning.

Teh advent of modern science is the most important social event in all history, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told members of the graduating class of the institute in delivering the annual baccalaureate sermon at exercises held this afternoon in the Old South Church.

The twelfth anniversary of the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Fortyseventh Street, will be celebrated Wednesday by an exhibition of paintings, recently acquired by the shop to be sold to raise funds for anti-tuberculosis activities.

The Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society for Dependent Children, an affiliate of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies in the City of New York, celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of its cottage plan here today.
Rochester's pitching silenced the Montreal Royals' batting artillery today and the Red Wings swept both ends of a double-header, each by 5-2.

President Fred P. Corson of Dickinson College, in the baccalaureate sermon this morning, assailed "a parental attitude on the part of the government," which he declared has deadened individual effort, created an attitude of cynicism in the young and killed idealism, without which no progress in the world has ever been made."

For the information of holders of Park-Lexington Corporation firstmortgage leasehold 6 1/2 per cent bonds and fifteen-year debentures and certificates of deposit for bonds which are not registered in the names of the owners, the reorganization committee has announced that the modified plan of reorganization has been consummated and that new securities under the plan will be ready for delivery on Thursday at the Empire Trust Company.

Umpire Ziggy Sears forfeited the second game of a double-header between the Cardinals and Phillies to St. Louis, 9 to 0, today for alleged dilatory tactics by the Philadelphia club in what appeared to be an attempt to prolong the game until the Sunday curfew would halt the
Stocks steady and mixed in slowest five days' business since week ended on Feb. 16, 1935; turnover, 2,955,280 shares. All classes of bonds steady in dull and quiet trading; transactions, $36,123,500.

Michael J. Collins, general purchasing agent for the Santa Fe Railroad and former president of the Chicago Board of Education, died of a heart attack today. He was 76 years old and a native Chicagoan.

Continuation of the present system of State and business financing, which consists in marketing special bills and Gold Discount Bank promissory notes together, has been promised by the Reich Bureau of Statistics.

Daniel Frohman, president and a founder of the Actors Fund of America, attended the fifty-fifth anniversary party of the Actors Fund held today at its home here for retired actors and actresses on Hudson Avenue.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 86.2 on June 2, compared with 86 a fortnight before, 85.7 on April 28 and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The marriage of Miss Jean Marie O'Halioran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. O'Halloran of Newark, to Cornelius T. Blessing of East Orange, will take place June 26 in the chapel at Seton Hall College, South Orange. The Rev. William N. Bradley will officiate.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America held its fiftieth anniversary convocation exercises yesterday afternoon in the quadrangle of the seminary, Broadway at 122d Street. Eight graduates of the Seminary Rabbinical College were ordained rabbis by Dr. Cyrus Adler,
Rear Admiral Purnell F. Harrington, U.S.N. (retired), who served under Farragut in the Battle of Mobile Bay, observed his ninety-third birthday today at his home at 20 Dudley Place here.
Hardy Hardy, members of the New York Security Dealers Association, will open today an office at 10 Post Office Square, Boston, under the management of James E. Lynch.

More than 4,000 men representing fifty-five Holy Name Societies from Yonkers, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, Rye, Port Chester, Larchmont, White Plains, Tarrytown and other towns in the Westchester division held their annual Summer religious rally at the County Center here this afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. James T. Toole of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet B. Toole, to G. Kenneth Willis, son of George R. Willis of this city. Miss Toole is a graduate of the American Institute of Banking.

While Ranger and Rainbow, the two America's Cup defense yachts that will race tomorrow, lay at their moorings, Yankee went out past Point Judith to try out sails today. About everything she has in stock was set on her. Finally a fog settled down and she returned to the harbor.

For four days President Lazaro Cardenas has been engaged in perhaps the most important struggle of his administration to determine whether he is to maintain control over Mexico's powerful industrial unions.

" Misther" O'Callaghan became O'Ceallachain and Murphy was called Murchadha as the IrishAmericans participating in a festival like those held by their ancestors warmed up to their jobs yesterday and made the second day of their fesh (spelled feis) the real thing.

" In this modern world when we erect the structure of our entire lives on the foundation of but one principle-possession-it would appear that man's material gains stand as the greatest obstacle in his soul's quest for God," the Rev.

Commending the stand of President Roosevelt and Secretary of Labor Perkins for minimum wage legislation, the Eastern division of the National Woman's party went on record today in favor of equality between the sexes in all labor agreements.

Princeton University seniors, abiding by tradition, once more have placed studies above athletics, according to the results of the 1937 senior poll which were released today. The majority of this year's graduating class would rather win a Phi Beta Kappa key than a varsity "P," symbolic of athletic prowess, the poll showed.

John Constantino, men's clothing, in 509 5th Ave: Lambert Narrow Fabric Co, bindings and trimmings, in 752 Broadway; Peerless Embroidery Co, curtains and draperies, in 23 E 26th St; Precision Inductance Corp, electrical equipment for radios and automobiles, in 591 Broadway, through the J. D. Robilotto Co; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc. brokers.
Captain Charles G. Mead, a former inspector of police in New York City and retired proctor of Cornell University, died at his home in Varna last night of a heart ailment. He was 70 years old.

The completed Jacob Riis. Park, which Park Commissioner Moses planned as a second Jones Beach, will be opened formally oneJune 19, a week from next Saturday. The park has been under development for several years on a narrow strip of sand dunes a mile long on the Rockaway Peninsula.

The pledge that.he will do all in his power to make New York "a 100 per cent union city" was given yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at a meeting of Local 51 of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union at the Stuyvesant High School, First Avenue and Fifteenth Street, when the Mayor was made an honorary member of the organization.
Transatlantic passenger traffic-for the first five months of the current year was about 33 per cent greater than during the corresponding period of 1936, according to figures compiled by ship lines.

Mrs. Jeanne F. Cartier, in 555 Park Ave; David H. Bellamore, in 471 Park Ave, through Huberth Huberth; Paul McCulloch, in 65 E 96th St; Irene Holden, in 125 E 93d St; Mrs. Norma Laffan, in 15 W 11th St; Mrs. Pauline Haebler, in 1,225 Park Ave; Byrne Bowman, Inc, brokers.

Religiously mature people must learn to direct their inherited capacity for anger if they are to destroy social conditions which injure human personality, Dr. Shailer Mathews, Dean Emeritus of the Divinity School of the University of Chicago, said in the baccalaureate sermon today at Goucher College.
Although the Whitsuntide holidays and the Coronation celebration slowed down new business in many directions, industrial activity in Great Britain generally remains at a satisfactory level.

Scotland Yard began today a nationwide search for Miss Diana Battye, a society girl who disappeared from the Mayfair home of Viscountess Long last Tuesday after having received seven threatening letters.
Something over fifty years ago ALBERT RICHARDSON CARMAN, a Canadian youth just out of college, started to earn his salt as a cub reporter. He was well-born, the son of a clergyman.

The Chicago Federation of Labor voted today to oust twenty-seven of its locals, which President John Fitzpatrick said were affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization. The locals expelled, Mr. Fitzpatrick said, have a membership of 20,000. The federation's membership totals 300,000.

Miss Eleanor Van Dyck Beckwith has! chosen her sister, Sarah Goodrich Beckwith Jr., as maid of honor for her wedding June 26 to John C. E. Taylor, son of Mrs. Emerson G. Taylor and the late Colonel Taylor of Prospect Avenue.
Kingsley School of Essex Fells will graduate sixteen seniors at the thirty-seventh annual commencement Saturday afternoon. Professor Lawrence H. Conrad will be the speaker.
Making full capital of their twogoal handicap, the Bethpage Shamrocks subdued the Governors Island Yellows, 7-5, in their polo match yesterday at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island.

A new edifice for St. John's Lutheran Church, Myrtle Avenue and Interborough Parkway, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The sermon was made by the Rev. Dr. Walter-A. Maier of Concordia Seminary, St. Louis.
Stormy weather broke up an unusually humid day yesterday, scattering crowds at the beaches and delaying automobile traffic in a concerted homeward rush. Two drownings were reported.
Along with a newspaper photograph showing Neville Chamberlain, Great Britain's Prime Minister, angling for trout in the River Avon, Whidden Graham of New York sent this note:

The plans for the wedding of Miss Camilla Alsop, daughter of Francis J. O. Alsop of Indian Hollow, East Milton, and Francis Lee Higginson Wendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Wendell Jr. of Chicago, have been changed owing to the recent death of Miss Alsop's mother.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Genung Bray of South Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Sharpe Bray, to Layton Hall James, son of Mrs. Luther H. James of Scranton, Pa.

The Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, the obscure North Country vicar who married the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in the face of ecclesiastical thunderings, told his congregation tonight that "all the powers of hell" could not halt "the wheels of God."

In his baccalaureate address today at Skidmore College, President Henry T. Moore offered three wishes for the members of the class, declaring that fulfillment of these wishes would "mean the surest guarantee of an abundant life."

Cardinal Hayes will preside at the thirtieth annual commencement of the College of New Rochelle here tomorrow. Mgr. Cornelius F. Crowley, president of the college, will confer degrees on 140 students, and the Rev. Edward V. Stanford,

Thomas Stoker, 54 years old, of Montreal, Canada, was drowned shortly before 6 P. M. yesterday when he fell from the stern of chartered 24-foot cabin cruiser into the East River off Fifty-second Street.

Amateur detectives are both a blessing and a hindrance to G-men in their search for kidnappers, bank robbers and other elusive law-violators. J. Edgar Hoover, who heads all Justice Department agents, praised some amateur detectives today,...

In consequence of the Spanish complications the stock market opened this week with sharp declines, the leaders losing from 2 to 4 points. Thereafter there was a recovery, and a firm tone prevailed until Saturday, when the closing was irregular.

Annual prize awards for excellence in various fields were awarded at Harvard University today. The Jeremy Belknap prize of $50 for the best French composition written by a first-year student in Harvard College went to Martin J. Lydon of Lowell.

Frederick J. Williams, second vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in charge of Pacific Coast territory embracing seven States West of the Rockies, died here today after a brief illness. His age was 56.

Until a few days ago government securities continued their steady recovery from the slump which started early in the year and culminated in the middle of March, but the trend again has turned downward.
Germany's Davis Cup team, favorite to win the European zone competition and play the United States for the right to challenge England, took a 2-1 lead over Italy in their quarterfinal series today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "The Doctor and the Public" will strike a popular note with most readers, but it is doubtful if such a plan for publicity of physicians as individuals will ever meet with the approval of the medical profession.

Secretary Perkins announced today, on the fourth anniversary of the establishment of the United States Employment Service, that the agency has made more than 19,000,000 job placements since its establishment.

The new six and seven-hour day agreements in the building trades are retarding construction recovery here by forcing investors to postpone building operations in the belief that the rentals to be obtained are not sufficient to compensate for the costs added by the shortened working hours, according to News and Opinion,

Jersey City kept the Baltimore Orioles in the International League cellar today by winning both ends of a double-header. The Giants came from behind to make up a 4-0 deficit and win the first game, 9 to 6. They won the second game, 5 to 2, closing the series here.

The six-story elevator apartment house at 66-74 St. Nicholas Place, near West 153d Street, has been purchased by 66 St. Nicholas Place, Inc., Lawrence Fisher, president, in a transaction in which Nathaniel L. Goldstein, counsel for the Postal Life Insurance Company, arranged an extension for five years at 4 to 41/2 per cent of a $332,500 mortgage on the property.

Two passenger automobiles, each trying to pass a truck, met head-on in the middle lane of a three-lane highway near the Laurence Brook Country Club this afternoon. A man and a girl were killed outright, a woman was injured critically and three other persons suffered minor injuries.

Monroe St. 159, 23.4x100: W. Wilson et al. to Kay Weisfeld, 571 Midwood St, Brooklyn; quitclaim (50c). 36th St, 42-44 W, 33.3x98.9; Eugene N. Paul to Edward S. Waters, 310 W. 106th St; mtg $100,000. 66th St, 14 E, 25x100.5; Eugene H. Paul to Edward S. Waters, 310 W 106th St; mtg $95,000.
