Ten Catholic priests were arrested here today after Hitler Youth groups had tried to break up St. Boniface youth services in several churches, and a free-for-all fight had started between Hitler Youths and Catholic Youths before one church.

With a total of 3,030 points for the five-event test, Eulace Peacock, Temple University Negro ace, romped off with the national A. A. U. pentathlon championship today at Pershing Field. It was the third time since 1933 that he has annexed the crown.
As the result of an injury suffered in his record-smashing triumph in the Belmont Stakes, Samuel Riddle's War Admiral probably will not race again this season.

The responsibility the American university has for the social and moral ideals and practices of its students and graduates was discussed today by Dr. William Preston Few, president of Duke University, in the baccalaureate address at Duke commencement exercises.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Waller Owen of this city and Louisville, Ky., have announced the marriage on Saturday in Elkton, Md., of their daughter, Mrs. Catherine Dale Owen Davis, to Homer Parant Metzger of New York and Asbury Park, N. J.

The drive against spies and saboteurs in many branches of Soviet activity from the Red Army down is attended by fear and confusion which are threatening to prevent the fulfillment of 1937 production in the most vital industries, though previously most of them met their schedules reasonably successfully.

Endorsement of the bill introduced by Representative Emanuel Celler which' would eliminate income taxes on capital gains and allowances for capital losses when the capital asset has been held by the taxpayer for more than a year was announced yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York.

The joint committee hearings on the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill, the proposed investigation by a joint Congressional committee of income tax evasion, the $1,500,000,000 relief bill, due for attention in the Senate, and the report on the President's court reorganization plan are the major questions which will engage the attention of Congress this week.

Dr. D. Austin Sniffen, '94, was elected president of the New York University Alumni Federation for the coming year, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Butler Graham, chairman of the election committee.
The John Simon Guggenheim Foundation, 551 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday the- award of fellowships to ten scholars from Latin America for research work in this country during the year 1937-38.

Surmounting no end of terrifying obstacles, which included nearly four innings of play in an almost Stygian darkness and a thunderstorm that delayed the struggle thirty-five more minutes before the last two outs could be duly recorded,

Miss Sarah B. Brewer, who will be married Saturday, June 26, to Joseph John Wickham of Scranton, Pa., has chosen her sister, Miss Annette Brewer, as her maid of honor. She also will be attended by Miss Sally Welch of Hartford, Miss Margaret E. Olmstead of East Hartford, Miss Gertrude Larkin of Brookline, Mass.; Mrs. Robert 0. Woodward Jr. and Miss Margaret Munroe of Quincy, Fla.

Thus far this year 8,418 new stock corporations have been formed in this State, according to figures reported today by the Bureau of Corporations of the Department of State. The number is 115 in excess of the total in 1936, when 8,303 were formed in the first five months.

With a thunderstorm driving the contestants from the cement walks to a low-ceiling locker room porch, the national outdoor epee championship was staged under rather unusual circumstances at Travers Island yesterday.

Dean Robert Russell Wicks of Princeton University declared in the baccalaureate sermon at Vassar College today that "on all sides today we see the ominous results of a belief that the world can be made good and happy by force."

The new 10,000-ton motor ship Batory of the Gydnia America Line arrived at 3 P. M. yesterday from. Northern Europe. She was four hours late owing to a fire in her engine room, which started last Thursday when the vessel was 940 miles east of New York.

In an effort to shed light on the methods and ways of swindlers and thus to prevent their crimes, Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, discussed types of major frauds worked upon business and the public in a radio address last night over Station WOR.

A special match race involving Mike Bailey, Don Carlos, Bub Walker, Ed Bordnier and Sammy Becker will be a feature at the weekly program of big car automobile races which will be staged at the Cross Bay Speedway in Ozone Park Wednesday night.
The annual list of appointments to offices and committees in the Grand Lodge was announced yesLerday by Jacob C. Klinck, Grand Master of Masons in the State of New York.

The death of WILLIAM J. HENDERSON, the distinguished music critic of The New York Sun, was the passing of the last member of a great group of American writers on music, characterized by newspaper men, in affection and high honor, as "the Old Guard."
Signs multiply that the voters are becoming tax conscious, which is gloomy news for the politicians.

Christ is still the chief subject of biography, the Rev. Sidney T. Cooke, assistant rector of St. Chrysostom's Church of Chicago, told the congregation at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles, Ninth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street yesterday.

T. O. M. Sopwith, challenger for the America's Cup, is arriving today from London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary accompanied by Mrs. Sopwith, Sir Ralph Gore, F. Sigrist and Mrs. K. Strickland. J. P. Morgan is also a passenger.

Arrowbrook (70)-Leaders in thirty-sixhole qualifying round for President's Cup: Harry Parker, 167; Herman Yorks, 171; Louis Stein, 175; William Himlyn, 175; Nat Lurie, 179. Bayside (71)--First round for Governors' Cup: J. Campbell defeated Lester Scott, 8 and 7; C. Hall defeated Bob Solomon, 2 and 1; T. McGirr defeated V. Celano, 4 and 3; B. Caskey defeated Nelson Peters, 7 and 6.

More than 1,500 barbers in hundreds of shops on the upper West Side of Manhattan beginning tomorrow will be summoned to join the strike of the Journeymen Barbers International Union, thousands of whose members in various parts of the city have been striking in the last fortnight.

On the heels of the disastrous Empire Air Day, May 29, when five Royal Air Force members and seven civilians were killed, seven more Royal Air Force fliers and one civilian lost their lives in accidents this week-end.

Paul. Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, a police sergeant who is the father of four children and will continue to study for an academic degree and a patrolman will be among the 467 students who will receive degrees at the thirty-fifth annual commencement of the Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University on Wednesday morning.

A vote to cease work on all towboats in New York Harbor at midnight Wednesday in an effort to gain an eight hour day, was taken yesterday afternoon, by Local 933, Series 3 of the Harbor Boatmen's Union, an affiliate of the International Longshoremen's Association, according to Joseph P. Ryan, president of the I. L. A.

Amelia Earhart, at the jump-off point for her crossing of the Atlantic on her world flight, announced tonight she would take off early tomorrow for Dakar, French. Senegal. Weather permitting, she said she planned to leave on the 1,900-mile hop between 4 A. M. and 5 A. M.

The most ominous portent of our present time is its lack of faith," said Dean Luther A. Weigle of the Yale University Divinity School in the baccalaureate sermon at Russell Sage College today. His text was "Faith is the substance of things hoped for the evidence of things unseen."

Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann" will be presented by the Federal Music Project Tuesday night, June 22, at the WPA Theatre of Music in a new English version. Raymond Savich is staging the production.

The $800,000,000 in Treasury notes offered by Secretary Morgenthau for tomorrow will be in two series of $400,000,000 each, maturing in September, 1939, and March, 1942, and bearing interest of 13/8 per cent and 13/4 per cent, respectively, according to the Treasury's announcement of terms.

A woman and four men who jumped overboard from a thirty-foot cabin cruiser when it took- fire in Long Island Sound off Kings Point, Nassau County, last evening, were picked out of the' water by another motor boat and landed at College Point, Queens. Aside from the wetting, none was injured.

Taking as his subject "Seven Rules for Successful Marriage," the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor, said in his sermon last night at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street,

Teaching students how to use nitroglycerine and TNT to "bless humanity, instead of blowing it" to bits, is a prime need in education, declared the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of Colgate-Rochester Divinity School, Rochester, N. Y.,

Taking the lead at the threequarter mark, William A. Jenkins, competing unattached, won the special one-mile run, the feature race of the twenty-fourth annual track and field games of the NinetySecond Street Y. M. H. A. held yesterday under the auspices of the A. A. U. at Macombs Dam Park.

A warning that our civilization is menaced by a cult of violence, was sounded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, the pastor, in his morning sermon at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

Horace Finaly, who for many years has been director general of the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas, announced his resignation tonight in a letter to the president of the bank, Emile Moreau, giving as his reason an increasing divergence of opinion between himself and Mr. Moreau, who was formerly governor of the Bank of France.
The Rev. Walter Jarvie of Seton Hall College, South Orange, will deliver the commencement address at Mount St. Dominic Academy Tuesday afternoon, June 15. Six young women will receive diplomas.

Roger Strout and his wife, who arrived from Turks Islands Thursday on their thirty-seven-foot auxilary ketch Igdrasil, are sailing for New York tomorrow, completing a round-the-world cruise started from Jacksonville in June. 1934.

Amelia Earhart, at the jump-off point for her crossing of the Atlantic on her world flight, announced tonight she would take off early tomorrow for Dakar, French. Senegal. Weather permitting, she said she planned to leave on the 1,900-mile hop between 4 A. M. and 5 A. M.

The most ominous portent of our present time is its lack of faith," said Dean Luther A. Weigle of the Yale University Divinity School in the baccalaureate sermon at Russell Sage College today. His text was "Faith is the substance of things hoped for the evidence of things unseen."

Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann" will be presented by the Federal Music Project Tuesday night, June 22, at the WPA Theatre of Music in a new English version. Raymond Savich is staging the production.

The $800,000,000 in Treasury notes offered by Secretary Morgenthau for tomorrow will be in two series of $400,000,000 each, maturing in September, 1939, and March, 1942, and bearing interest of 13/8 per cent and 13/4 per cent, respectively, according to the Treasury's announcement of terms.

A woman and four men who jumped overboard from a thirty-foot cabin cruiser when it took- fire in Long Island Sound off Kings Point, Nassau County, last evening, were picked out of the' water by another motor boat and landed at College Point, Queens. Aside from the wetting, none was injured.

Roger Strout and his wife, who arrived from Turks Islands Thursday on their thirty-seven-foot auxilary ketch Igdrasil, are sailing for New York tomorrow, completing a round-the-world cruise started from Jacksonville in June. 1934.
Firemen of Company 3 are a little miffed today at the ungracious behavior of a cat they sought to rescue from a two-day sit-down atop an Elmira roof. The cat had jumped to the roof of the Henry C.

The problems of human experience are greater than hours and wages, said the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn.
The United Automobile Workers of America claimed today that all the employes in some Ford Motor Company plants already have signed union membership cards.

The engagement of Miss Eileen T. Leahy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Leahy of Astoria, L. I., to Francis X. Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas F. Walsh of this city, has been announced by her parents.
Addressing more than 2,000 persons from Philadelphia and New York at the annual Founders Day celebration and tree dedication exercises at National Farm School today, Wheeler McMillen,

Manhattan College's graduating class was urged not to neglect its religious duties after graduation, by Father Vincent J. Brosnan, pastor of the Church of the Ascension, Manhattan, who delivered the baccalaureate sermon to an audience of more than 500 persons, including 250 seniors, in the campus chapel yesterday.

Demand for Summer-type apparel and accessories was fairly active last week in the wholesale market here. Washable silk and synthetic active and spectator sports dresses were in excellent demand, and manufacturers of the better lines experienced difficulty in making delivery on reorders.
War veterans from all parts of New Jersey took part today in a Statewide memorial service in the American Legion official cemetery, Locustwood Memorial Park, near Haddonfield.

Representative John T. Bernard, newly appointed field director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, told iron range workers today that Governor Benson had pledged his active support to the unionization effort.

Four hundred and sixty-nine young men left the campus of the University of Notre Dame after receiving their degrees during the annual commencement exercises held in the university gymnasium this afternoon. Preceding the awarding of degrees, the Laetare Medal for 1937 was bestowed upon Professor Jeremiah D. M. Ford of Harvard

Dr. Henry Szoszkies, secretary of the Polish Distributing Committee of the American Committee Appeal for the Jews in Poland, arrived yesterday afternoon on the Batory of the Gdynia America Line from Warsaw.

William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company, discussing taxation methods, asserted tonight that "tax-bills continue to be incompetent." Without mentioning the proposed Congressional inquiry into tax dodging,

Nearly 95 per cent of Spain's art treasures in Catalonia have been saved from destruction, it was announced yesterday by Professor Walter W. S. Cook, chairman of the Graduate Department of Fine Arts of New York University, who has attempted to keep a running inventory of Spanish art during the civil war.

Aided by a four-goal handicap, the Governors Island Blues swept to a 14-to-7 triumph over the Bethpage Knaves today. Lieutenant Phil Brady, playing at the No. 2 post, starred for the winners with five goals.

Pena de Lemona, a bare brown ridge overlooking Lemona village, about six miles southeast of Bilbao, where an infantry battle has been in continuous progress more than a week, was retaken by the Insurgents last midnight.

More than 1,000 workers in 250 beauty shops in the lower West Bronx and in the Yorkville section of Manhattan will be called out on strike tomorrow and Wednesday by the Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Union, Local 560 B, Malvena Friedman, secretary-treasurer of the union, announced yesterday.
Ireland's championship Gaelic football team, the Mayo Club, had an easy time today defeating a picked team of Massachusetts players, 17 to 8. About 6,000 fans watched the game at Fenway Park.

Prices of cotton kept within a narrow trading range in a quiet market last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange, 12.75 and 12.50 cents appeared to be approximately the resistance points on the up side and down side, respectively, for the earlier new-crop deliveries. Net changes in the futures market for the week were declines of 3 to 7 points.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Judith Ann Wilcox, daughter of Mrs. Harold George Wilcox of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Dr. Wilcox, to Hugh Wheeler Sanford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Sanford of Knoxville, Tenn.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on April 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $8,993,929 after interest, depreciation,
Union representatives from General Motors plants in the United States and Canada agreed tonight on demands for a new labor contract, but withheld announcement of details.

A Western Air Express airliner lost nearly six months ago was found today, so frightfully battered and torn that the "largest piece above the snow where it crashed was no bigger than a washtub." The bodies of its occupants, five men and two women, must be dug from drifts twenty-five to fifty feet deem.

China's Foreign Minister, Wang Chung-hui, declared today there was only one issue between China and the United States that caused China any concern, the extraterritorial rights enjoyed by Americans in China.

Two distinct Yankee collapses proved fatal to the champions before a capacity crowd of 40,000 at Navin Field today. An error by Frankie Crosetti, which gave the Tigers three unearned runs, was the most damaging thrust in reverse.

Stimulating effects of the world armament race on the iron and steel industry of the United States were outlined today in a report of the metals and minerals division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

A baccalaureate service for the graduating classes of Brothers College and the Theological Seminary, Drew University, was held this morning in the Madison Methodist Episcopal Church. The speaker was Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of the university, who ascribed the nation's economic, social and moral troubles to a loss of faith in God and men.
Dr. Francis M. Crowley, dean of the School of Education of St. Louis University, had been appointed Professor of Education at Fordham Teachers College.

The Marquis De Cuevas, husband of John D. Rockefeller Sr.'s granddaughter, declared this afternoon that both he and his wife lacked any official information that she had inherited any part of the oil man's vast fortune;
" The Lesson of Loyalty" was the theme of the baccalaureate sermon preached to 290 members of the Holy Cross graduating class tonight by the Rev. William L. Mulcahy, '12.
Although a new State law gives women the privilege of serving on juries, women in at least six counties may have to sit back and let the men serve, as they have been doing.

The exceptional drought which was noted in the early months of this year is expected to have a disastrous effect on the cotton crops of the Northern Departments; The Department of Piura, which normally occupies third place in the production of "pima,"

Two thirty-goal polo teams opened Bostwick Field for the season today, and, after a first period that gave Pete Bostwick's group a lead that eventually won the game, the quar-tets battled on almost even terms.

A 12-year-old Cuban murder mystery was reopened here over the week-end with the arrest of Issac Saams at the request of the Cuban Government. Twelve years ago, Adam Miller, Jamaican resident of Oriente, Cuba,

St. Mary's School, Mount St. Gabriel, will graduate a class of twelve here tomorrow at the annual commencement exercises. Religious exercises, addresses and presentation of diplomas will begin at 11 A. M.

Forty girls and boys who were graduated last night from the Adelphi Academy, 282 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, were urged by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology, to find themselves jobs they could idealize.

Sandhogs who have been digging the five miles of intercepting sewer in upper Manhattan for the WardsIsland treatment plant system yesterday holed through the final sections, twenty-six feet underground,: at 144th Street and Exterior Street, Harlem liver.

Forty-nine Protestant clergymen of Westchester County met today at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills and organized the Westchester Ministerial Association. Members said the organization would strive to achieve church unity, even to the extent of physical amalgamations in some instances, to promote interdenominational fellowship and "to make a concerted drive on Albany whenever special legislation stirs our interest or requires our action."
Joey Fishbach and Bernard Jacoby advanced Into the quarter-final round as the Long Island Center junior championship got under way yesterday at the Jaokson Heights Tennis Club.
Scholastic and athletic awards were made today to students of the Woodmere Academy here at the final assembly of the upper and lower schools in the John H. Hessel Memorial Hall.

May sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company amounted to $24,561,967, an increase of 8.6 per cent over the $22,621,800 total for May, 1936. For the first five months of this year the volume of business aggregated $109,642,898, compared with $101,369,821 in the same period last year, a gain of 8.1 per cent.

Mayor La Guardia extended an official welcome yesterday morning to the 1,500 delegates at the fiftieth annual national convention of the Independent Order of B'rith Abraham in Mecca Temple, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street.

Posting a 68, four shots below the regulation figures, Thomas Potter of Sands Point and Henry Ciuci, Fresh Meadow pro, collaborated to win the Long Island Professional Golfers Association one-day amateur-pro best-ball event over the Lido Country Club course today.

Mrs. Lucy Hubbard Dabney, a native of Connecticut and a social leader here for twenty-five years, died suddenly at her ranch home, northwest of this city, yesterday at the age of 60 years. Private funeral services will be held tomorrow by Dr. Royal Hunt Balcom of Trinity Episcopal Church, Santa Barbara.

The bill extending the Public Works Administration two years was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. The PWA, under the bill, is permitted to use $95,000,000 in its revolving fund and $40,000,000 additional funds for grants up to 45 per cent to projects voted by States and their subdivisions on promises of the Federal Government to share a part of the cost.

The Pennsylvanla State College honored the memory of a graduate student who died a month ago when it presented to his parents at the annual commencement exercises today the Master of Arts degree he would have received. President Hetzel conferred baccalaureate and advanced degrees upn 858 students.

The daily average of automobile production last week, with allowance for the holiday, was lower than the revised total for the preceding period and the adjusted index has declined to 126.2 from 133.6 (revised). For the week ended June 6, 1936, the index was 102.4.

Relatives of Municipal Court Justice John F. O'Neil, fatally stabbed on April 27 as he waited for a bus at Sixth Avenue and Twelfth Street, have failed to give the police "any cooperation whatever" in their search for the assassin, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday.

A cooling bit of news on a torrid day trickles through from the Conservation Department. It has to do with petitions to allow fishing' through the ice in Lake Lamoka and Lake Waneta in Schuyler County.

War Admiral's next race will be at Saratoga, Samuel D. Riddle Said today in answer to questions about the great 3-year-old's injury in the Belmont Stakes Saturday. "I think we may have to hold him out of action this month," said Riddle, "but if no infection develops he ought to be ready for more action in that time.
Two deaths were induced by the heat yesterday as the temperature rose to a peak of 86 degrees at 5 P. M. Two boys were drowned and a bather was believed to have drowned in the Rockaways.

Unless college graduates take a part in "this social reconstruction" their college education will have failed in one of its most important objects, Dr. Henry Neumann, leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, told the graduating class of Long Island University last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Michael McNichol, one of the oldest active law enforcement officers in the State, died at his home here last night at the age of 82.

A lone swallow swooped into the alumni gymnasium of Dickinson College this morning while commencement exercises were being held, but disappeared just after the 133 members of the graduating class had received their diplomas.

Miss Jeanne Millet, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Parsons Millet of 770 Park Avenue, New York, and Shantituck, Stockbridge, made known today the attendants for her prospective marriage to Shaun Kelly Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaun Kelly of Glen Crannie Farm, Richmond.

Surpreme Court Justice Collins sighed an order yesterday temporarily enjoining the scheduled sale at auction tomorrow of 712,411 shares of the Jersey Central Light and Power Company held by the New York Trust Company as oollateral for a $20,000,000 National Public Service Corporation debenture issue.

Dr. Douglas Brown, specialist in heart and stomach diseases and a member of the medical staff of the United States Veterans' Hospital here, died at the hospital last night in his sixty-ninth year after an illness of three weeks.

Suppose for a moment our globe did not grow flowers, says MAETERLINCK in a delightful essay calling attention to the fact that flowers bloom more brilliantly, more abundantly, and more internationally than formerly. We live in a world in which people need no longer travel to see exotic plants.
The fate of the proposed Anglo-American trade treaty, with all that it implies, rests squarely tonight on the self-governing dominions of the British Commonwealth.

Eleven tutorial Summer high schools will be opened by the Board of Education in July for pupils who have failed in their subjects in the present academic year, it was announced yesterday. Dr. John L. Tildsley, Associate Superintendent temporarily assigned in charge of high schools, announced that the schools would be staffed by 650 Works Progress Administration remedial teachers.

Closer contact between bankers and sales executives was urged yesterday by Charles Penrose, vice president of Day Zimmerman, Inc., management engineers, in an address before the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York.

Sales of paint, varnish, lacquer and fillers in April were the largest in dollar value since May, 1929, the Census Bureau announced today. Sales by 579 establishments in April amounted to $44,561,902, compared with $46,200,757in May, 1929.

Independent investigations were started by the police, the District Attorney of Kings County and the Fire Marshal yesterday after a four-alarm fire of suspicious origin virtually had destroyed a six-story apartment house under construction at 60 to 70 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn.

THE records have it that Samuel D. Riddle is the sole owner of War Admiral. But the elderly owner of Faraway Farm, where the great Man o' War grazes in green pastures, would be the first to admit that his sole ownership of War Admiral may be fairly open to dispute. The public now has a big interest in the little horse.

Accidents, deaths and injuries in traffic accidents in New York City continued to show a decline last week and week-end as compared to corresponding periods of 1936, figures made public yesterday at the Traffic Bureau of the Police Department showed.

Prolonged litigation over the second codicil to the will of Edward W. Browning, real estate operator, was brought to a close yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin said he would approve a compromise by which beneficiaries accepted $75,000 in full settlement. The codicil provided gifts totaling about $300,000 to them.

Industrial activity in Canada rose slightly last month notwithstanding the effects of seasonal depressants, in the opinion of A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, who adds:

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 11,000, including 3,000 directs. Market generally 5 to 10 cents higher than Friday's average; spots up more on lightweights; packing sows strong; top, $11.60; bulk good and choice 200-300 pounds, 811.35-.55: 150-190 pounds. 10:65-811.50.

The first honorary degree ever given by Skidmore College was conferred upon President Henry T. Moore by Dr. Will David Howe, chairman of the board of trustees, at the annual commencement this morning.
L. Clark Walker, secretary of the H. W. Baker Linen Company of New York, a wholesale linen supply house, died at his home here last Saturday of a heart attack.
Towboat operators professed surprise yesterday at the threat of the Harbor Towboatmen's Union to call a strike tomorrow unless new contracts are drafted containing a provision for an eight-hour day.

Mrs. Margaret Nicol, mother of Miss Lucille Nicol, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, died on Sunday at her home, 147-36 Eightyfourth Drive, Jamaica, Queens. Mrs. Nicol, who was 78 years old, leaves, besides her daughter, two sisters, Mrs. Charlotte Furst and Mrs. Mae Munson, and a brother, Charles Nicol.

Nine organization aides of the Committee for Industrial Organization were sentenced today to five months in jail and fined $100 each. They were convicted of conspiracy to injure the business of the Charles Cushman Company of Auburn in connection with a strike of Lewiston-Auburn shoe plants.

Susquehanna University's commencement program ended this morning with the awarding of degrees. President G. Morris Smith conferred the degrees, and Dr. Ernest Minor Patterson, Professor of Economics at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania, made the commencement address.

Teri Joseffy, pianist, grandniece of Rafael Joseffy and wife of F. Howell Baker, pianist, died yesterday at the age of 32 in the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, 321 East Fifteenth Street, where her son, Anton Fenner Baker. was born last week.

Exports and imports from and Into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during April have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with April, 1936.

The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today reported favorably the Wheeler-Johnson bill to regulate the shipment in interstate commerce of goods produced through the labor of children under 16 years of age.

The National Civic Federation, in a letter to President Roosevelt, charger yesterday that "high relief officials" in Washington were fostering the growth of Communist-led unions of WPA workers in the hope that their agitation would influence Congress to increase Federal relief appropriations.

Bob Cash pitched and batted Boston College to a 2-1 victory over Holy Cross to even the annual series between the New England rivals before 3,500 spectators at Alumni Field today. The third and deciding game will be played in Worcester tomorrow.

Mrs. Moreland Oelrichs of Boston disclosed last night at her Summer home in Jamestown, R. I., that her daughter, Miss Blanche Oelrichs, was married on May 12 at Elkton, Md., to Louis Stoecklin of New York. Details of the marriage were not disclosed.

Mrs. Vera Caswell, in 19 E 98th St; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, broker. Wildey C. Rickerson, in 64 E 86th St; Manuel Magnus, through Slawson Hobbs, in 140 W 79th St; Samuel A. Herzog, broker.

The 1,395 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,045,129,044 par value as of June 1, had a total market value of $44,170,837,675, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of May 1, there were 1,407 issues, aggregating $47,058,334,548 par value, which had a total market value of $43,920,389,575.

Dr. Joseph P. O'Reilly, one of the oldest practicing physicians on Staten Island, died Sunday night at his home in New Dorp of heart disease after a brief illness. He was 63 years old. Dr. O'Reilly was born in Manhattan and had made his home in Staten Island for twenty-eight years.

District Judge Merrill E. Otis of the Federal court has informed trus- Obt tees of the Hotel Kansas Citian, under court receivership, that they could employ whomever they wished regardless of a hotel strike here.
The need of American life today is greater true culture, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick of New York told a Johns Hopkins commencement audience today.

Despite adverse current which nas reduced our speed to nine knots, the Princeton University-Franklin Institute-Cook Observatory Eclipse Expedition now is in the path of totality over which the moon's shadow will sweep tomorrow.

Amelia Earhart, en route on a-flight around I the world, took the South Atlantic Ocean in her stride today. The woman who had dared the North Atlantic in 1928 and 1932, crossed the South Atlantic from Natal, Brazil, to St. Louis, capital of Senegal, in approximately 12 hours 19 minutes.
Port authorities announced today that the bodies of two of nine persons in an airplane missing since last Wednesday had been found on one of the Desertores Islands, a half hour's flight from here.

Both Protestants and Catholics here are disturbed over a decision of the Superior Prussian Court that churches can receive no protection from the courts against secret political police action. A Catholic priest who had been ordered to hand over church documents and render a report on church affairs to the police appealed to the courts.

The new account on the Stock Exchange opened today and a firmer tendency prevailed in most sections. Giltedge issues were slightly lower, and although foreign securities mostly were inactive, German issues were in good demand.

Reflecting the spurt in retail trade in many sections last week, mail reorders on Summer merchandise were numerous here yesterday. Outstanding in the business placed were dresses, sports wear, beach wear and accessories.

ALEXANDER--Lena, beloved sister of Sigmond and Jacques. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., Wednesday, June 9, at 10:30 A. M. ANDREWS-Roger Connor, on June 7, son of the late George J. Andrews, and devoted brother of Lieutenant George J. Jr., Gerard, Vera and Ethel Andrews; former member of Engine Co. No. 67, N. Y. F. D. Funeral from his late residence,

Mahler Jr., exr. to Louis P. Mahler Jr., 88-87 195th St, Hollis Park Gardens, N. Y.

Manhattan College will confer degrees on 232 seniors this afternoon at its eighty-fourth commencement, held on the quadrangle of the campus in Riverdale. The address to the graduates will be given by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and a graduate of the class of 1873. The exercises are at 3 P. M.

Surrogate James A. Foley upheld yesterday the State Tax Commission in setting a tax of $1,335,812 on the estate of Mrs. Alice G. Vanderbilt. He thereby established a precedent upholding a new subdivision of the tax law which permits the taxing of "limited powers of appointment."

Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the German Eagle, the highest decoration for foreigners within the gift of the Reich, has been bestowed on Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy in recognition of his services for the promotion of cordial relations between Italy and Germany.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, belived to be the first choice of the Democratic county leaders for the Mayoralty nomination, sent "greetings and best wishes" yesterday to the New York County Committee of the American Labor party for its first dinner, to be held Friday evening at the Manhattan Opera House.
If there are still optimists believing in the' ultimate possibility of an ArabJewish understanding in Palestine, a visit here to study the situation would result in a severe blow to their confidence.

Seven thugs beat him so badly that he was disabled for two weeks after his brother, who was also his employer, had refused to take orders from one of the two men now on trial as leaders of the trucking racket, Nathaniel Brown, a truck driver, testified yesterday in the Supreme Court.
Miss Janet Elizabeth Hannan of Albany has received one of the twelve resident fellowships for advanced study in the social sciences granted by the Brookings Institution for the academic year 1937-38.
Common Pleas Judge Ralph W. Liddy was assured today that Edsel Ford would testify voluntarily at his oneman grand jury investigation of the recent fight at the Ford Motor Company gates.

The first international competition in the history of American trot ting will be held this year with Greyhound, United States champion, owned by E. J. Baker of St. Charles, Ill., matching strides with the Italian-owned Muscletone in a "home-and-abroad" series.

Strict attention to the small things, which is what the public remembers far better than larger things, is necessary in the hotel field as in oil and all other businesses, Frank W. Lovejoy, sales executive of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., told the Hotel Sales Managers Association at a dinner meeting at the Hotel Martiniaue last night.

Steel ingot production in the United States in May was 5,153,559 tons, a gain of 81.684 tons over April and the third highest on record, exceeded only by May, 1929, when the record of 5,286,246 tons was established, and March, 1937, when the output was 5,216,666 gross tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It was the third consecutive month with output exceeding 5,000,000 tons.
Robert S. Eisner of Red Bank, N. J., a member of the sophomore class and ranked at three goals nationally, has been elected to the captaincy of Princeton University's

Diplomas will be presented to forty-four students of the Scarborough School, a private preparatory school here, at commencement exercises tomorrow. Dr. F. Dean McClusky, director of the institution, will make the presentations and Professor Cornelius F. Kruse of Wesleyan University will be a guest speaker.

Close-of-play scores in English first-class cricket matches started Saturday follow: Lancashire, 233 and 223 for six wickets (Paynter 51); Middlesex, 369 (Edrich 175); at Lord's. Surrey, 335 and 224 (Parker 66, P. Smith five wickets for 40 runs): Essex,

Although the volcanoes on Vulcan Island and Matupi still are emitting smoke and steam intermittently, General Walter Ramsay McNicoll, administrator of New Guinea, reports that there is no reason why Rabaul should not be fully occupied as the capital of New Britain Island by the week-end, but it will not be completely habitable for some months.

Parts of the battered cabin of a skyliner which crashed six months ago were sighted high on a mountain ledge tonight, giving searchers hope that bodies of the seven who flew to their deaths in the plane, might be found tomorrow.

A development somewhat disconcerting to the Parker defense entered the conspiracy trial here today, just as the Parker lawyers were making final preparations for the long awiated appearance on the witness stand tomorrow of Ellis H. Parker Sr. .

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York has called a special meeting of stockholders for July 7 to vote on two proposals, one to guarantee a $25,000,000 issue of 31/2 per cent bonds of the Westchester Lighting Company and the other to authorize Consolidated Edison to engage in the business of distributing steam.

Norman Thomas, leader of. the Socialist party, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from a nine-week tour of Europe. He was accompanied by Mrs. Thomas. He said they had visited England, France, Germany, Spain and Soviet Russia.

Receipts of lead in the form of ore and scrap at smelters in April of amounted to 43,773 tons, compared wrth 50,673 in March and 35,512 in April, last year, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain gave the nation another example of "Tory Socialism" tonight when he made public his government's recommendations for reorganization of Great Britain's electric industry.

The $100,000,000 general rate increase sought by the railroads, on which the Interstate Commerce Commission will hear final argument next week, would not produce the additional revenues sought by the carriers but would cause diversion of traffic to competitive transportation systems, according to briefs filled with the commission today.

Trial was resumed today before Federal Judge Phillip Forman, after a tenday recess, Of the suit of five railroad companies and their subsidiaries for a permanent injunction. restraining New Jersey from collecting the full amount of taxes levied for the years 1934, 1935 and 1936. The carriers contend the sums are excessive.

A meeting preceding the departure of our four airplanes, which left four scientists alone at the North Pole for a year, was held at 2 A. M., Sunday in "Red Square" on the drifting ice floe in the midst of the Winterers' house, the airplanes and storage tents.
Miss Elise Thayer Dixon, daughter of Mrs. Philip B. Fisher of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Pierce Archer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Archer Jr. of Wynnewood.

Business failures in the United States last week fell to the lowest figure for any week since last November, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The total for the five-day week ended June 3 was 146, compared with 189 the week before and 188 in the corresponding week a year ago.
Tony Manero, swashbuckling national open champion, posted a 78, one over par. for his first practice round over the Oakland Hills Country Club course today.

Pedro Montanez's stock as a lightweight contender soared to new heights last night when the sensational Puerto Rican registered a two-round knockout triumph over Phil Baker, sturdy campaigner from Norwalk, Conn.

Increased borrowings from banks by commerce and industry, substantial increases in the purchase of United States Government obligations by non-banking investors, and the depletion of excess reserves in connection with the new member bank reserve requirements were reported today in the June issue of the Federal Reserve Bulletin.

Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany and his suite arrived in two special planes at the Belgrade Airdrome this morning to begin a tour of Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Hungary, which political circles believe is the most important German diplomatic move in the Balkans since Economics Minister Hjalmar Schacht's tour of Southeastern Europe two years ago.

Joseph Colletta, dress manufacturer, bought the two-story brick factory on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 322 Stockholm' Street, Brooklyn, which he plans to occupy immediately. e was represented by Jacob E. Hurwitz, attorney.

The Medical Society of the State of New York, composed of more than 14,000 physicians, the largest single unit in the American Medical Association, introduced a resolution today urging the immediate recognition of the principle "that the health of the people is the direct concern of government and that a national public health policy directed toward all groups of the population should be formulated."

Three teams tied for first place in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester P. G. A. at the Quaker Ridge Country Club today with sub-par scores. Maurice Walsh and Harry Mack of Sunningdale, William Goldbeck and Richard Woolworth of Lawrence Farms and Fred Moore of Dunwoodie and Percival Dixon of Lawrence turned in 67s to deadlock for top honors.
The appointment of Abraham Schindel as store manager of the Newark branch of the Hearn Department Stores was announced yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, vice president of Hearn's.

With approximately 1,000 model small homes to be thrown open simultaneously in as many communities around June 19, approximately 1,000 pages of local newspaper advertising will be used to herald the event, Wadsworth Wood, director of the National Small Homes Bureau, estimated here yesterday.
The fate of the Olympic Winter Games of 1940 hung in the balance as the International Olympic Committee opened its thirty-fourth sessions today.

Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, who was outspoken last year in denouncing the "inefficiency" and boondogglingg" of the WPA, was criticized at the June meeting of the Board of Supervisors here today for seeking $6,914 for continuation of recreational projects from which the Federal relief organization is withdrawing financial aid.

A fundamental philosophy to combat the confusion in the world of thought today was urged by the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee of Newark, State Senator from Essex County, at commencement exercises for fifty-nine graduates of Upsala College here this afternoon.

The gates of the big Ford assembly plant here, closed for twelve days by strike, opened to returning workmen today. Of the 1,800 men normally employed, about 200 went to work preparing the plant for arrival of materials.

You really can think yourself into stomach ulcers, for constant thought on the subject restricts the natural processes, Dr. Kenneth J. Tillotson, chief psychiatrist at McLean Hospital, Waverly, Mass., told the fortieth annual meeting of the American Gastro-Enterological Association here today.
Reports from Tangier, International Zone, Morocco, say 100,000 natives are on the verge of starvation in the zone bordering on the southern frontier of French Morocco.

President Roosevelt's recent reassurance concerning the price of gold will be echoed by the British Government in the House of Commons tomor row in answer to a series of seatrohing questions by Robert Boothby Conservative member.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 4: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Galpin, G. F., the West Virginia, to Reserve R.O.T.C., University of California, Berkeley. Calif.

The Inland Steel Company of Chicago has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of 3 per cent firstmorrage bonds, Series E, 1952, which it stated had been sold in January to Kuhn, Loeb Co.

Skimming the rail when the pace setters went wide at the homestretch turn, and ridden capably by Jockey Seabo, A. J. Sackett's Tabitha won the Nahant Purse, feature of today's program at Suffolk Downs, finishing a half length ahead of the favored Fair Knightess.
Notifications from three manufacturers of the establishment of minimum retail resale prices under the Feld Crawford Fair Trade Act were reported yesterday by local stores.

Phoenix Lodge, the former home of Jacques Lebaudy, self-proclaimed emperor of the Sahara, was being razed here today. The forty-acre estate had been unoccupied for several years and is badly run down.
Governor Lehman told the graduating class at Niagara University today that the most pressing need of the hour was good citizenship.

Oral Hildebrand's six-hit pitching for the Browns today was marred by eight bases on balls, but the righthander was effective in the pinches and St. Louis defeated Boston, 9 to 6. Three of the Red Sox who walked scored. In the fifth, with the bases full, Hildebrand issued Pinkey Higgins a free ticket, sending Roger Cramer home.

A strike of 60,000 employees in the silk industry within two weeks, unless employers agree to sign collective bargaining agreements, was threatened yesterday by Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, the C. I. 0. agency seeking to organize more than 1,000,000 textile workers.

The commandant of the Swiss gendarmes announced tonight that the St. Bernard dogs, one of whom bit a small girl to death, would not be destroyed as punishment. The commandant completed investigation of the cases and said he had found the dogs were of general good nature and were not a public danger.

Word has been received here of the death yesterday after a brief illness at her home in Kensington, Md., of Mrs. Katie Eiays Chappell, wife of Lieutenant Ralph H. Chappell, U. S. N. (retired), who is now in charge of the engineering and machine division of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, Washington Two sons also survive:
Frank B. Kellogg, Secretary of State in the Coolidge Cabinet, gave $500,000 to Carleton College today for the establishment of a foundation for the study of international relations.

Equaling her own course record of 77, Miss Charlotte Glutting of the Baltusrol Golf Club took a onestroke lead in the first round of the women's Eastern golf championship at the Plainfield Country Club today.

The commencement activities of the Peekskill Military Academy, which began yesterday, were continued here today with the final battalion review being taken by Captain C. W. Ficke of the 153d Infantry Brigade of Manhattan.
Syracuse got off to a good start in its three-game series with the Jersey City Giants today when it defeated the locals, 2 to 0, behind the effective pitching of Lefty Hockette and Frank Pearce.

The defeats of Miss Dorothy Traung, husky San Francisco girl, and Miss Phyllis Wade, former English titleholder, supplied the only first-round upsets in the women's British golf championship today as two other Americans, Miss Barbara Thompson of Los Altos,
There will be a brief funeral service for William J. Henderson, distinguished music critic of The Sun, who died last Saturday, at the Cypress Hill Abbey, Brooklyn, today at 3 P. M. The Rev. George T.
Miss Helen Jacobs may not be able to defend her Wimbledon singles tennis championship this year.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, retiring president of Mount Holyoke College, will confer the Bachelor of Arts degree upon a graduating class of more than 200 students at the commencement exercises next Monday. The guest speaker will be John G. Winant, former Governor of New Hampshire.

The ceremony of laying the cornerstone for the new $250,000 alumnae house at Smith College will be broadcast over the blue network of the National Broadcasting Company' June 19, from 2:30 to 3 P. M. Eastern daylightsaving time.

Mrs. John L. Woodbury of Kentucky, president general of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, was guest of honor at-the annual convention of the New York State chapters of the Children of the Confederacy yesterday at the George Washington Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bell Green of 102 West Seventy-fifth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Bell Green; to William Taylor Turner of Washington, D. C., son of the Rev. and Mrs. William Pattillo Turner of Georgia.

The International Radio Corporation has notified the New York Curb Exchange that the registration statement with respect to additional shares of capital stock to be offered has not yet become effective.

A warning against "atheism and communism being sponsored by organized groups" was sounded today by Cardinal Hayes at commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle. Degrees were presented to 140 students. More than 1,200 persons attended the ceremonies on the lawn.

The Hippodrome Opera Company will give no more performances at the Hippodrome until next September, it was announced yesterday by Alfredo Salmaggi, director. Meanwhile the house, at which Mr. Salmaggi has been producing popularpriced opera each week-end this Spring, will undergo renovation.

Business men and financial institutions lost $12,000,000 of investments of $21,324,000 in 1929 and 1930, the Securities and Exchange Commission was told today in a continuation of its investigation of investment trusts.

The marriage of Miss Ethel Baker Drumm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Drumm of this place, to Albert William Butterfield, son of Albert C. Butterfield of Pana, Ill., and the late Mrs. Butterfield, will take place the afternoon of June 19.

At its eighty-fifth commencement today Duke University awarded degrees to the largest graduating classes in its history, comprising more than 700 seniors and graduate scholars from thirty-eight States and four foreign countries.

Mother love remains the sweetest thing in life and one of its most banal dramatic themes. "Maternite," which is a Gallic variation at the Belmont, is artistically photographed, honestly played and agreeably restrained, but none of those can compensate fully for the triteness of its story.

" Socialized medicine" was attacked as regimentation by C. Augustus Norwood, manager of committees on publication, in his report at the annual meeting of the Mother Church, attended by 6,000 Christian Scientist from all parts of the world today.

Carl J. Austrian, counsel to the defunct Bank of United States, obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente an order directing creditors of the bank to show cause on Friday why a further dividend of 5 per cent should not be paid to depositors.

Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma told the agricultural commissioners of thirteen Southern States today that he thought prices of Wheat and cotton were too low, and assailed what he termed "propaganda". by administration officials which, he said, had tended to halt the rise in prices of farm commodities.

The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. of L. affiliate, engaged in a race with the C. I. 0. for the unionization of employes in the utility field, scored a victory yesterday when it obtained a contract from the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company.

Frank E. Bradner, former city counsel of Newark and a well-known lawyer in this city, died here yesterday at his home at Chelsea Court, Twenty-first Street and Ninth Avenue, after a long illness, at the age of 82.

The four powers principally concerned in the situation arising out of the bombing of the German battleship Deutschland and the bombardment of Almeria, Spain, in retaliation have been in diplomatic contact all day arguing about the matter.
The international stock market indices for June 5, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Nationalist party, and seven others departed for Atlanta by airplane today to serve terms of from six to ten years. Thus was termlnated the first sedition conspiracy case arising in overseas possessions of the United States.

Jean Harlow, blond beauty of the screen, died in the Good Samaritan Hospital here today after taking a sudden turn for the worse in the illness of uremic poisoning which had confined her to bed for a week. Her age was 26.

The New Amsterdam Theatre and office buildings at 214 West Fortysecond Street and 207-19 West Fortyfirst Street, consisting of structures of eight, nine and ten stories, have been sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to Anco Enterprises, Inc., Max A. Cohen president.

The police of the East Fifty-first Street station tried out a new kind of "lie detector" yesterday on two boys, 9 and 12 years old, after they were unable to explain satisfactorily how they had acquired a $10 bill. The "lie detector,"

Miss Mary Mellon entertained with a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Miss Edith McKnight and William H. Moore 2d, who will be married on June 28 in St. James's Church. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. C.

With sales increases last week ranging up to 20 per cent over the same period last year, Summer merchandising . in local department stores has gotten off to an active start, according to figures compiled yesterday by executives of leading department stores here.

The savings banks of the city were invited yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to reduce their interest rate on real estate loans to one-half of 1 per cent above what they pay depositors to enable tenement owners to comply with the MultipleDwellings Law.

The marriage of Miss Jessica Fiora Donati, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emilio Donati of Florence, Italy, Westerly, R. I., and New York, to Ray Palmer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Palmer of New York, took place here this morning in the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. M. Swift.

The contention that too many young people are attending college in the United States was met by Dr. Stephen P. Duggan in the commencement address at Vassar College today with the assertion that education is the best defense of American institutions.

J. P. Morgan, bronzed and all but recovered from his recent illness, entered a vigorous defense of tax evasion which was within the law on his return from London yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

A measure which would give the Interstate Commerce Commission as farreaching powers over the airlines, domestic and foreign, as it now has over the railroads was favorably reported in the Senate today by the Committee on Interstate Commerce.

Governor Lehman has vetoed bills that would have increased the pay of substitute teachers in New York City and of junior clerical assistants, custodians, custodian-engineers and custodial employes. They were sponsored by Senator Feld. and Assemblymen Neustein of New York and Schanzer of Brooklyn.

William H. Malone, former chairman of the Illinois Tax Commission, told a Federal jury in Judge William Holly's court today that in 1920 he received a gift of $700,000-in $500 and $1,000 bills-from the managers of General Leonard Wood's campaign for the Republican Preside tial nomination.

More than 2,500 persons of all denominations crowded into Dickinson High School auditorium tonight at a civic reception to Mgr. John F. Ryan in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination. He is pastor of St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church here.

After being virtually deadlocked since the new crop months first sold between 12 1/2 and 12 3/4 cents a pound in the latter part of April, trading conditions in the cotton market changed abruptly yesterday. Under heavy selling operations, prices declined $2 a bale to new low territory.

The first step in solving the twofold problem of refunding the debentures of the Gatineau Power Company and of resuming dividend payments to shareholders of the Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation is under way, according to a plan of consolidation of the two
The following men who were directors of the Equitable Trust Company, which has been absorbed by the Manufacturers Trust Company, were yesterday elected to the board of the Manufacturers Trust:

The Max Gordon Plays and Pictures Corporation will enter the motion picture field during the 1938-39 season with a program of three pictures. The first will be an adaptation of the Clare Boothe comedy, "The Women,"

Owners of more than two-thirds stock in each of three underlying companies voted today to merge their concerns with the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, it was announced here at headquarters of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey. Stockholders in two other underlying companies are to vote tomorrow on the proposed merger.
The Railroad Retirement Bill, introduced in the Senate a month ago by Senator Wagner, was reported favorably today by the Interstate Commerce Committee of the Senate.

Gross assets, $32,981; net, $24.792. For masses, $800; to Redemptorist Fathers of New York, $500; brothers, John M. Aylward, $1,000; William H. and Thomas J. Aylward, $500 each; nieces, Marion R. Duggan, $2,000, specific jewelry, 150 shares of specific stock, one-third interest in realty at 450 58th St., and one-third of residuary estate; Frances M. Hart.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following changes for the week ended June 2: An increase of $42,000,000 in loans; decreases of $21,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations and $42,000,000 in "other securities";

The Federal Government, from President Roosevelt down, was studiously maintaining a hands-off policy in the Midwestern steel strike today in the face of what administration authorities considered an attempt by both sides to have Washington solve their difficulties.

Gifts recorded by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology during the past year totaled $2,535,009, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, told more than 800 graduates and guests tonight at the annual alumni day dinner.

Should New York decide to take advantage of its present airport opportunities and develop North Beach Airport into a sea and land plane terminus of the highest class, the city would assume first rank in the country as regards such combined facilities, centrally located.

The future of housing in America depends on the recognition of the essential need for decent shelter for all the citizens and a sound cooperative effort to meet that need, it was agreed today at a national conference on housing which featured Alumni Day at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Henry L. Doherty, utilities Operator, will not have to be questioned orally in an effort brought by minority factions in the Cities Service Company to find out how he voted in the settlement of a stockholders' suit for $100,000,000 for $1,250,000.

The veteran Frank Bowden, second-seeded in the tournament, advanced to the quarter-finals of the Brooklyn tennis championship by vanquishing Carl Schweikhardt, 6-0, 6-3, in a fourth-round match on the courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush yesterday.
Walter Lippmann told the 163 Drake University graduates today to "let no one bamboozle you into fighting the old, stale wars of those who came before you and will soon be gone."

Miss Frances Maitland Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron J. Brown of 162 East Eightieth Street and Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was married to Frederick Tilney Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Tilney of this city and Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L. I., yesterday afternoon at Sherry's.

The thirty-family apartment building at 421 Pennington Street, Elizabeth, N. J., has been sold to the 421 Pennington Street Corporation by the West End Building and Loan Association of Newark for $110,000. David Cronheim, Inc., was the broker.

Governors Island Each of the following Infantry Reserve officers is ordered to active duty June 20 at Camp Dix, N. J., for training: 2d Lt. William L. Acker, 84-01 Kent Rd., Jamaica, L. I. 2d Lt. Ronald A. Baker Jr., Hotel Paris, 752 West End Ave., New York. 2d Lt. Milton R. Blum, 3,100 Brighton 2d St., Brooklyn.

The Republic Steel Corporation complied with an order of Mayor Kelly today to cease housing employes in buildings of its South Chicago plant, by moving twenty-one Pullman cars into the company's yards.

New York University has leased quarters on the seventeenth floor of International Building, Rockefeller Center, for use as offices by the electors of the Hall of Fame, of which Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson is director.

At the instigation of the German Labor Front organization known as Beauty of Work, the secret police have arrested a factory proprietor near here. He was seized on the charge that he had failed to respond to repeated demands that he improve working conditions and beautify his establishment.

The appointment of Dr. Frank Alexander Ross, a member of the Sociology Department of Columbia University since 1919, to chairman of the Department of Sociology of Syracuse University, of Syracuse University, was announced today by Dean Karl C. Leesbrick of the College of Liberal Arts.

Scoring 18 1/2 points out of a possible 21, Dr. S. Tartakower of Paris, a native of Poland and captain of its international team, today emerged as winner of first prize in an international chess masters' tournament.

The members of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday reelected John C. Botts president, Alpheus C. Beane as vice president and Clayton B. Jones as treasurer. Two new members were elected to the board of managers, Thomas F. Cahill and John H. McFadden Jr.

Reaping Reward, making his first start for Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's Milky Way Farm Stable since placing third in the Kentucky Derby, -came from far back to capture the featured Yacht Club Purse at Washintigton Park today.

Four men accused of racketeering in the city's artichoke industry pleaded guilty yesterday and faced prison terms and fines despite the fact that two juries previously convened in Federal court had been unable to decide whether they were guilty or innocent.

Striking steel workers and their Employers came out openly today in a propaganda battle for the support of the public, as a new depression threatened the steel producing valley which was just beginning to feel prosperity when the strike began on May 26.

The most important collection of Browning letters and manuscripts to be sold since the dispersal of Robert Browning's own collection in 1913 brought the high price of [Pound]3,656 at Sotheby's .today.

The marriage of Mrs. Natalie Wales Winslow, daughter of Mrs. Charles Edward Greenough of 1,212 Fifth Avenue and of Nathaniel Brackett Wales of Boston and Braintree, Mass., to Edward Latham of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Louis Latham,

Honorary degrees were conferred upon four distinguished women in the separate fields of business, natural science, medicine and letters, as 100 seniors received their bachelors' diplomas at the annual commencement exercises at Russell Sage College. The exercises were held this forenoonn in the First Presbyterian -Church on the college campus.

Kipling's line in his "Recessional""The tumult and the shouting dies"-is properly enough criticized from a purely grammatical viewpoint by Bailey Millard in. a letter to THE TIMES published June 3. But something is to be said for the phrase, beyond the necessity of rhyme, in its concluding word.

Lake Tarleton Country Club has been sold to the Family Jacobs through the New Hampshire Realty Company of Concord. The new owners will change the name of the resort, which covers an area of 550 acres, to the SkyHigh Lake Tarleton Club, and will open it late this month.

Depositary institutions in the New York Federal Reserve district were called upon yesterday to repay to the United States Treasury on Thursday a total of $3,248,265, which represents the total on deposit to the national credit as a result of the sale of Treasury bills dated March 10 and due on June 16. The call for the entire country on these bills amounts to $41,830,000.

The fundamental concepts to be carried through life, Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, told the graduating class at Norwich University today, were "duty, honor and country."

The market for United States Government bonds responded to the official announcement of the details of the Treasury's June borrowing by coming to a virtual standstill as far as trading on the New York Stock Exchange was concerned.
Government of the Dominion of Canada seven-year 21/4 per cent bonds due in 1944 and thirty-year 3 per cent bonds due in 1967 have been admitted to the list of the New York Stock Exchange.

Pennsylvania will issue a $60,000,000 series of tax-anticipation notes, payable on May 31, 1938, to meet expenses as a new biennium opens. The notes were authorized by the 1987 Legislature, which approved tax-anticipation borrowing for 19371938 up to $175,000,000.

One hundred and seven young men and women were graduated from Allegheny College this morning at the 122d annual commencement after Bishop Charles Wesley Burns of Boston gave the commencement address. Bishop Burns is the father of one of the new graduates, Miss Barbara Burns.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel took the last two singles matches with Italy today and sent Germany into the semi-final round of European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition. The final score was 4-1 in Germany's favor.

The wheat market showed a few more signs of stability today, with shorts at times free buyers, but liquidation by tired holders, combined with Southwest hedging, continued heavy and rallies failed to hold. More rains in the Northwest, weak cables, and a most indifferent export demand for both domestic and Canadian wheat made a pessimistic picture for the bulls.

The rampant White Sox closed in to within a game of the league-leading Yankees today by battering the Athletics, 12 to 6, to sweep the fourgame series and stretch their winning streak to nine straight games.

" What sort of an Irishman are you? " asked a New York policeman of a graduate of an Irish university who confessed that he had no Gaelic. To persons of many origins who have been astonished and enthralled by the now tolerably abundant translations from the Gaelic, the policeman's remark seems a little severe. At the Feis in this town Sunday, Father TEMPLE,

The Railroad Labor Executives Association, representing more than 1,000,000 unionized railroad employes, voted "no" here today to President Roosevelt's minimumwage, maximum-hour bill. It adopted a recommendation that the bill be amended to exclude railroad labor from its operation.

The Rev. Dr. David D. Vaughan of Boston, Professor of Social Service at the Boston University School of Theology, will deliver the address here tomorrow morning at the annual graduation exercises of the Pennington Preparatory School. Dr.

The Mount Meenahga estate near Ellenville, Ulster County, N. Y., has been sold to the Italian Health and Recreation Center A. C. W. A., Inc., an organization 'composed of the Italian locals of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America. It will be used as a retreat and recreation resort by the members of that organization. B. H.
A Merritt Taylor, a pioneer in the development of Philadelphia's high speed subway transit system, died at his home in Ardmore yesterday of a stroke at the age of 63.

Cold storage holdings of fishery products on May 15 were 18 per cent greater than a year ago and 62 per cent greater than the five-year average, the Bureau of Fisheries of the Commerce Department announced today.

Manager Jimmy Wilson of the Phillies yesterday drew a $100 fine, heaviest assessed this season by National League President Ford Frick, for his stalling tactics during the second game of Sunday's double-header with St. Louis-tactics which led the umpires to forfeit the game to the Cardinals, The Associated Press reported.
Mrs. Mabel McKinley Baer died here this morning at her home, McKinley Place, following an illness of several weeks of a complication of diseases. Her age was 58.

Single admissions for 1,472 music students in public schools and settlement houses of the metropolitan area have been set aside by the New Friends of Music for its series of sixteen concerts of next season, it was announced yesterday.

Scheduled to open their thirty-fifth annual convention in the Hotel Lowry here at 8:30 P. M. today, members of the American Institute of Banking found the hotel strike-bound and service virtually paralyzed. However, they went on with their plans in hope of an early settlement of the labor difficulties.
A husband's last kiss, as his wife lay dying in the bathtub of their home, became a focal point in the investigation of her death today. tion of her death today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today set July 19 for oral argument on the recommendation of Examiner E. J. Hoy that it establish through routes and joint rates via Seatrain, Inc., from official territory to southwestern and part of southern territory.
This year's class was graduated by Drew Seminary for Young Women here today at the annual commencement. The exercises were held in the Mount Carmel Baptist Church.

Two hundred rabbis, most of them alumni, were welcomed yesterday by Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, at the thirty-seventh annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, which opened yesterday morning at the Jewish Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway.

Trading was fair to slow. Lamb prices were sharply higher and steer beef strong to higher. Veal showed little change and fresh pork prices were steady to higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be weak to lower, veal about steady, lamb about $1 higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mischa Rosenbaum, 31 years old, a theatrical booking agent more familiarly known in the midtown district as Ross or Rosen, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder yesterday in General Sessions in the hammer slaying of Miss Julia Nussenbaum, 24, a violinist, in a West Forty-third Street rehearsal studio last April 18.
House amendments to the administration's resolution for an investigation into tax avoidance were agreed upon today by members of the Rules and the Ways and Means Committees.

Members of the New York State Meat Dealers Association voted in annual session yesterday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, to continue their fight against packers who enter the retail field and who refuse to make proper allowance for natural shrinkage in boxed and packaged fresh meats.

Twenty-four detectives and policemen were found not guilty in a departmental trial at police headquarters yesterday of engaging in a gambling game and failing to report to their superiors that a gambling game was to be conducted.

President Lazaro Cardenas tonight made concessions to labor, including direct government intervention in the affairs of seventeen American and British oil companies in Mexico, in order to end the nation-wide petroleum strike.

Participation in national affairs was urged today upon the ninetyone members of Ursinus College's graduation class by Dr. I. Harvey Brumbaugh, former president of Juniata College, at commencement exercises.

Miss Bertha R. Palmer of Evanston, Ill., director of alcohol education for the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, told the world W. C. T. U. convention today that even one cocktail or glass of beer taken half an hour before driving affects the driver's nervous system, hearing and vision to such a degree that his slower reactions at a critical moment cause accidents.

That humanity's future happiness and prosperity must come from increased internationalism and the abandonment of narrow nationalisms was the theme of speakers at the opening today of the Rotary World Convention. Paul P. Harris of Chicago, founder and president emeritus of the organization, was the Principal orator.
The Cape Cod Standard-Times today quoted Irenee du Pont, Delaware industrialist, as saying that "we're working under a dictatorship now."

The first opening of the new season-yes, despite the weather, it is a new theatrical season-will be under the auspices of the Federal Theatre Project and tonight at the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem. Call it "The Case of Philip Lawrence,"

As the justices of the Supreme Court scatter for the Summer-which will not be all play for them, by any means-they have left behind two new issues in the policy argument between the administration and the court.

Despite the certainty of public denunciation and the probability of being singled out for subsequent persecution by Nazi fanatics, Catholic boys and girls, responding enthusiastically to their Bishops' appeal, gave an impressive demonstration last Sunday of their religious loyalty.

Funeral services were held yesterday in the chapel of the Veterans Hospital, Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, by the Jewish War Veterans of the United States for Colonel Isaac Costa, one of their founders, who served throughout the Civil War, first in the navy, then in the artillery, and was decorated three times for bravery.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 76.2 per cent of capacity, a decrease of 1.2 points, or 1.6 per cent, from the rate last week and a new low level for the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. A month ago the rate was 91.2 per cent.

Before the present Parliament session ends, it is understood here, a bill will be passed authorizing Deputy Georges Bonnet to continue his mission as Ambassador to the United States for at least another six months. Under French law Mr. Bonnet could not hold the post of Ambassador more than six months without resigning his seat in Parliament.

Workmen's compensation insurance rates for the year beginning on July 1, approximately 2 per cent lower than those in effect at present and representing an annual saving of more than $1,000,000 a year to premium payers, were approved yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 5 unless specified: At Mare Island Yard: Algorma, June 6; Detroit, Narwhal. At San Pedro: Astoria, California, Chicago, Cincinnati, Idaho, Houston, Louisville, Minneapolis, Mississippi, Maryland, Nevada, New Mexico, New Orleans, Northampton, Pensacola, Portland, Quincy, Salt Lake City, San Francisco, Tuscaloosa, West Virginia.

The setting of "The First .Legion," which opened tonight at the Richmond Theatre, is laid in an American Presbytery of the Society of Jesus and gets off to a good start-but collapses in the third act.

Fears that his fiancee, Diana Battye, had been kidnapped were expressed today by Michael Asquith, grandson of the wartime Prime Minister. A nation-wide police search for the 21-year-old society girl, who disappeared in London last Tuesday, has produced no results.

Members of the United Automobile Workers of America, affiliate of the John L. Lewis C. I. O., marched on downtown Lansing early today and in the ensuing hours seized virtual control of Michigan's capital city.
Edward Somerville Jaffray of The Lodge, Ardsley-on-Hudson, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center following an operation at the age of 65.
Fog that rolled in from the sea following an all-night rain caused the calling off of the planned America's Cup yacht trial race today between the Ranger and the Rainbow.

Henry A. Jandl, a post-graduate student at Princeton University, was selected last night as the winner of the thirtieth Paris Prize Scholarship in Architecture of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects.
Swarthmore College honored former deans and graduates today as President Aydelotte conferred honorary degrees on four men prominent in the field of education.

The Brooklyn College of Pharmacy of Long Island University will award sixty-one degrees tonight at the annual commencement in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Dean William Christine Anderson will preside for the thirty-fifth and last time, as he retires at the end of the month.

The commencement address at Ohio University today was given by Shelby M. Harrison, General Director of the Russell Sage Foundation of New York City, who took as his subject "toward a Social Philosophy for the Individual."

Death Announced Retired Fireman Charles Alleman, formerly a member of Engine 236, residing at Medford, L. I., died May 25. Trial Results Fireman first grade Jesse S. Boyle, Engine 228. Charge 1: Neglect of duty (neglected to promptly report injury to himself). Not guilty. Charge dismissed. Charge 2:

A proposal that Congress, by means of an amendment to the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill, close the channels of interstate commerce to the products of manufacturers guilty of monopolistic practices, was put before the Senate today by Senator Borah, long an opponent of business monopoly. He held there could be no question that Congress had the power to write such legislation.

A suit seeking to hold the New York Trust Company liable for the $500,000 bond issue of the White River Bridge Corporation, of which it was trustee, was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by Clara W. Ansbacher, owner of $10,000 of the bonds.
