Harold V. Strawn of Chicago died on Sunday night at Polyclinic Hospital of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 50. Mr. Strawn registered at the Wellington Hotel, Fifty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue, on May 28. He was removed from the hotel last Thursday.

Miss Elinor Hirschhorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Hirschhorn of this city and Blairstown, N. J., was married here yesterday afternoon to Eric H. Marks of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Marcus M. Marks, at the home of the bride-groom's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dreyfuss of 36 East Fortieth Street.

The American Newspaper Guild, at its annual convention, cleared the way today for a probable decision tomorrow on a report urging that it leave the American Federation of Labor and join the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The International Labor Organization Conference Committee on Planning Public Works in Relation to Employment today agreed on proposals made by the United States Government to recommend that the conference accord urgent treatment to this subject. This means that the conference will take action at this session on this question instead of waiting for the normal second reading next June.
An operation late today removed from the lung of 12-year'old Andrew J. Blakeley Jr. a metal pencil cap which he swallowed on Thursday. He was reported resting comfortably.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad reported yesterday a profit and loss surplus of $32,782,292 on March 31, against $33,262,461 a year previously. Total assets were $239,840,554, against $242,454,968.

Sir Edward Beatty, Canadian Pacific Railway president, disclosed plans today for the construction of two new liners for service between Canada and the Antipodes if the necessary financial guarantees can be obtained.

P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the board of the International Mercantile Marine Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the company has a "good, fair chance" of earning full interest charges after depreciation this year, as the outlook is better now than it was at this time last year and indications are that earnings will be better.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals Frank G. Braham of Brooklyn was admitted to practice today ,and the following proceedings were had:

Running over the old home grounds, Snark from the Wheatley Stable found amazing speed and power yesterday on the opening day of the Aqueduct meeting, to take the featured Queens County Handicap by five lengths in 1:37 2-5.

The sun shone brilliantly once more at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but so far as a befuddled band of Pirates could make out it was still darker than pitch as the luckless Corsairs plunged to their fifth consecutive defeat, three at the hands of the Giants and two by the Bees in Boston.

Particular attention to Federal and State legislation on maximum hours and minimum wages and unfair labor practices will be given in the program for sessions of the Store Management Group in connection with the midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at Chicago, June 21 to 24, it was announced here yesterday.

American importers will be consulted in the future before "gentlemen's agreements" between American manufacturers and Japanese producers of competitive goods are concluded, they were assured here yesterday by members of the Japanese Economic Mission now touring this country.

President Ignaz Moscicki of Poland arrived from Warsaw today, accompanied by a large military and civilian suite. He was received at the station by King Carol, Crown Prince Michael and the entire Cabinet and drove to the Royal Palace along a route lined with troops with hundreds of thousands of enthusiastically cheering Rumanians.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today a blanket nomination of the graduating class at West Point as second lieutenants in the army, and named four colonels for promotion to brigadier generals of the' line.

Charles H. Fromuth, a marine artist, is dead at Concarneau, France, where he had lived for forty-five years. He was 76 years old. Born in this city, he showed his artistic ability early but had to leave school at the age of 14. Later,
Seven scholarships totaling $4,095 and permitting study in England this Summer were awarded today by Harvard University. The recipients were:
Jonn Andrew Burkhardt, secretary-treasurer of the Half Dime Savings Bank of this city for twenty years prior to his retirement in 1934, died today at his home here of a heart attack at the age of 67.

About 500 gadgets, ranging from an improved mousetrap which captures mice by the dozen to a selfnavigating diving device, were placed on public view yesterday as the annual convention of the National Inventors Congress opened its sessions at the Hotel Edison.
Panama has no "unknown soldier," but the body of Panama's lost soldier has just been found -in a government storehouse and will be buried with full military honors.

New arks' Bears opened their series with Baltimore tonight with an 8-6 victory. Home runs gave Newark the victory, Babe Dahlgren and Bob Seeds both clouting for the circuit. Leslie Powers hit two homers for Baltimore and Wilburn got one.

Liqidation of twenty-nine bank receiverships in May, bringing to 675 the total of finally closed receivrerships since the banking holiday of 1933, was announced today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency.

The Dodgers were playing "double-or-no-count" at Ebbets Field yesterday. They made an even halfdozen of the two-ply blows and it was the sixth one, a terrific leftcenter drive by Woody English, that scored Luke Hamlin to give the Kelly Greens a 5-4 victory in the tenth inning and the series with the Reds, two games to one.
A first mortgage loan of $100,000 at 41/2 per cent for five years has been placed by Nehring Brothers on 541 West 180th Street for the owner, Lorenz F. J. Weiher.

For the first time in the history of Purdue, a mother and daughter will graduate from the same course and the same class when diplomas are awarded Sunday. Mrs. Walter Q. Fitch of West Lafayette, whose husband is State leader of Farmers Institutes, and Mildred Leah Fitch are completing the course in the School of Science.

Luncheon of the New York division of the United Daughters of the Confederacy in honor of Mrs. John L. Woodbury, Justice William Harman Black, Hotel Warwick, 12:30 P. M. Luncheon of the Life Underwriters Association of the City of New York, Hotel Pennsylvania.
Dr. Philip B. Woodworth of Glen Ellyn, Ill., former dean of the Engineering School of Lewis Institute, died in Elmhurst Hospital today following an operation. His age was 71.

T. O. M. Sopwvith, Tom to his intimates, who will play the British lead in the America's Cup drama off Newport this Summer, came back to the United States yesterday in the r6le he had three years agoseeker of the world's greatest yachting prize.

Between $15,000,000 and $20,000,000 in cash was the price paid for all the stock of the "new" Equitable Trust Company by the Manufacturers Trust Company, it was learned authoritatively yesterday. The proceeds went into the Hayden Foundation.

The first two commencement exercises for divisions of St. John's University, Brooklyn, will be held this morning and afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, with a total of 308 degrees and certificates conferred.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, returned yesterday on the Queen Mary after a trip to Italy in connection with the affairs of the Italian Superpower Corporation, owned jointly by the Atlas and a semi-governmental Italian agency.

Lowell Weicker. country place of H. T. Lindeberg on Piping Rock Club grounds, Locust Valley, L I; Douglas L. Elliman Co, broker. Edgar P. Eaton, at 25 Chesterfield Road, from George M. Waugh; Harry G. Liese, at Valley Road. from Vincent Lavista, receiver; Dr. Ernst Mandel, at 148 Brite Ave. from Harry Frampton; James A. Demarest, renewal at 241 Nelson_ Road:

The Moderator and Stated Clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church United States of America have joined in a tribute to ROBERT SPEER, who for nearly a half-century has been the "dominant leader" in what is now the largest Foreign Mission Board in the world.

A small fire on the wooden trestle of the Long Island Railroad over Jamaica Bay between Hamilton Beach and Howard Beach in Queens delayed service on the Rockaway Beach line about twenty minutes yesterday afternoon.

Secretary Woodring urged Congress today to authorize an immediate start of a $36,122,000 system of levees and flood walls "for the protection of those cities which suffered most in the last Ohio River flood."

Myron C. Taylor, president of the United States Steel Corporation; Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, and Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, are among the prominent American business men arriving today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

Appleton-Century have just received from E. F. Benson the manuscripts of four short novels that they will bring out under the general title, "Old London." Like Edith Wharton's four short novels, "Old New York," each volume is intended to present a concentrated fictional portrayal of an epoch in the social life of the city. Reginald Birch will draw the decorations for the four volumes.

Dennis Shore, South African quarter-miler, went through his first workout in this country today following his arrival in New York aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He was met at the pier by Matty Geis, Princeton track coach, and Graduate Manager Asa S. Bushnell. The party immediately left for Princeton.

A lease on the Reinberg estate on the west shore of Lake Hopatcong, N. J., has been taken by American Airlines, Inc., which will use the property as a Summer resort for its employes. A nominal fee for board will be charged.

Charging that the World Fair's Commission has been appointing "outside favorites" instead of civil service: eligibles to fair positions, Civil Service Commissioner Paul J. Kern asserted last night that his commission was determined that it would not be used as "a respectable front for the spoils system."
The thirteenth annual graduation exercises of the Princeton Country Day School were held today. Allan V. Heely, headmaster of the Lawrenceville School, delivered the address.
Professor William Lyon Phelps of Yale University will deliver the address at Drew's seventieth commencement exercises tomorrow at an 11 A. M. on the campus.

Two faultless performances over the testing military course today won the individual military jumping championship for the veteran black gelding Prince at the opening sessions of the nineteenth annual West Point Horse Show on the grounds of the United States Military Academy.

Henry Roemer, president of the Pittsburgh Steel Company, in a letter to stockholders discussing the capital readjustment plan to be voted on June 15, says the company expects to close the fiscal year ending June 30 with a net profit after five years of heavy losses.

Last Day exercises of the 1937 graduating class of the New York University School of Law were held last night at the Judson Memorial Church, Washington Square, with 200 graduates and 600 other persons in attendance.

Admiral William H. Standley, U. S. N., and Mrs. Standley have come to 14 East Sixtieth Street from Washington. Hoghland Van Norden will give a dinner tonight in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Miss Lucille Sargeant and George L. de Peyster, who will be married on June 18 in the Church of St. John's of Lattingtown.

It is impossible to read such a statement of facts as was given in the letter, published in THE TIMES Sunday, from the executive committee of the trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission without realizing that the housekeeping of Greater New York has been bad. We have permitted great central areas to deteriorate, to lose population and to lose taxable value.

David B. Flemning of Mount Vernon, N. Y., vice president and general manager of the New York Central Railroad, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to hold the position of director of the American Niagara Railtroad Corporation, to Which position he was elected on April 21,
The Eastern European Division of the State Department is to be abolished and its functions combined with those of the Western European Division into a European Division, it was made known today.

Prince Fumimaro Konoe, Premier for a week, told facts about his life with cheerful candor today. "I am really not capable and not worthy to be Premier," he said. "I am a very humble person for a job that is too vast for my poor qualifications.

A five-acre estate with sevenroom residence in the Standard National Corporation's Bedford Knolls development at Bedford Village, Westchester County, has been sold to a client of E. Allen Klein. Harry L. Miller designed the house.

What changes a month brings in baseball! On May 4 last the Yankees made the acquaintance of Jake Wade, a young southpaw, and shelled the North Carolinian to cover in three innings under a withering fire.

Attorney General Cummings announced today that, to take from the jurisdiction of the Federal Court at Pittsburgh the government's suit to dissolve the Aluminum Company of America, he would invoke a statute of 1903 providing for a special "expediting court."

Mrs. Adelaide Hill, 43 years old, wife of Lamar Hill, attorney, 'was found dead of gas poisoning in her apartment at 120 East End Avenue, near Eighty-fifth Street, at about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Rewriting is urgently advised for "The Man Who Had Nothing," which opened tonight at the "Q" Theatre. Written by Maud Flannery and Thomas Browne, it is a story of a psychiatrist's conversion of a man, who had lost his memory, into a saint.

Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Walsh of Mount Vernon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Winifred Isabelle Walsh, to Edwin T. Morris Jr., and of their second daughter, Miss May Muriel Walsh, to George Low Farnsworth.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress a report on freight rates by the Tennessee Valley Authority, and conferred during the day with various administrative aides. He visited Secretary Ickes in the Naval Hospital and went for a drive down the Mount Vernon Highway.

The Indians bombarded their way to within one game of the league-leading Yankees as they defeated the Senators in the concluding contest of their series today, 17 to 5. Earl Averill's sixth home run of the season led a fifteen-hit bombardment at the expense of Joe Cascarella and Ed Linke.
Deed covenants prohibiting persons of Negro descent from owning or occupying homes in the Edgemont Hills section of Greenburgh were held valid today by Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis.

Already well oversubscribed at 5 P. M. today, the Treasury's $800,000,000 note issue will be about six times oversubscribed when late mail subscriptions have been analyzed, Secretary Morgenthau stated at a press- conference late this afternoon.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, reversing a decision of a Federal district judge in Brooklyn, decided yesterday that the Republic of Spain had the right to confiscate Spanish vessels flying the flag of that nation if they were in South American waters.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended April 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $3,135,516 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.

Evidently believing her golfers, like good wine, are bound to improve with age, England today. chose five of the crew that defeated America in the Ryder Cup matches at Southport four years ago for another fling at the invaders when the international series among professionals is held over the same layout June 29-30.
Sir Henri Deterding will continue his efforts to help Netherlands farmers by buying surplus produce for distribution in .Germany.

Martial law has been proclaimed in the Sanjak of Alexandretta as a result of riots between Turks and Arabs Friday and Saturday at Antioch and Alexandretta, At Antioch fifteen persons were reported injured, some seriously, and at Alexandretta seventeen. Troops eventually restored order.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Frances Elizabeth (Betty) Morris, daughter of Lewis Gouverneur Morris of Malbone, this city, and New York, to Harold Whitfield Carhart Jr., which will take place on the afternoon of June 30 in St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Morrisania, New York.

The six-story apartment on the southwest corner of 133d Street and Broadway has been purchased by Louis Schlechter, operator, who now holds three corner properties in the immediate vicinity. The building stands on plot 75 by 125 feet and is assessed for $180,000.
Additional stock . of the Howard Smith Paper Mills, Ltd., comprising 55,000 no-par-value shares, has been approved for listing tomorrow on the Montreal Stock Exchange, it was announced today.

Sales of fertilizers in all branches will probably pass 8,000,000 tons this year, thus achieving the largest volume since 1930, Charles J. Brand, secretary of the National Fertilizer Association, said here today. The 8,000,000 tons volume would be an increase of 25 per cent over last year.

Invitations have been issued for the marriage of Miss Louise Jenkins Hall, daughter of Mrs. Gilbert Weld Goodridge of this city, to Robert Phillips Ellis, son of Harry B. Ellis of Springfield, Mass., and the late Mrs. Ellis.

A group of Long Island officials told the board of army engineers today that improvement of Jones Inlet would stimulate commercial development in the area and open up New York State's $15,000,000 Jones Beach Park to additional thousands of excursionists.

The Brooklyn Daily Eagle announced yesterday that its affiliate, The Brooklyn Times-Union, had ceased publication. The TimesUnion had appeared Sunday morning and a four-page supplement bearing The Times-Union masthead was inserted in yesterday's late editions of The Eagle.

Freddie Miller, 129, Cincinnati, outpointed Fred (Red) Cochrane, 140, Elizabeth, N. J., in the eightround feature contest at Dexter longs. Park last night before a crowd of Rolodo 3,000. In the eight-round semi-final Joey Fontana, 127, East Side, outpointed Joe Wach, 126, East Side.

Miss Betty Curtice, daughter of Mrs. Harry Curtice of London and the late Mr. Curtice, was married yesterday morning to Dwight C. Hirsh of Los Angeles in the Congregational Church, 211 West Fifty-sixth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Frank Murtfelt.

Shareholders of Armour Co. of Illinois today approved the plans for recapitalization which provide for $75,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds or convertible debentures, or both, and an increase to 15,000,000 in the authorized number of common shares.
Dr. Clement C. Williams, president of Lehigh University, spoke this morning at Bucknell University's annual commencement, discussing "Education-the Hope of Democracy."

The Rev. Dr. Remsen Brinckerhoff Ogilby, president of Trinity College, will be the speaker tonight at the seventy-seventh commencement of the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital, to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Eighty-four graduates of the Medical College will receive degrees and twenty-eight nurses will receive certificates from the Fifth Avenue School of Nursing.

Princeton seniors think more of a Phi Beta Kappa key than of a varsity athletic letter. So they have just voted in the commencement poll. If the present junior class at Columbia has not changed its mind since freshman days it, too, prefers scholastic to athletic honors.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Marguerite Fitzgibbons, 2,440 Walton Ave., John Bryne Jr., 4,002 Carpenter Ave., Bronx, and Thomas Bryne, executor. 79 W. 3d St., children, $1,500 each; Elizabeth Bryne, widow, executrix, 79 W. 103d St., residue.

The prosecution forged the first link today in a chain of dence by which it purposes to prove that members of two "rings" in New York and Albany collaborated in plans for the abduction of John J. O'Connell Jr.

Degrees of Bachelor of Arts were conferred upon sixty-five graduates of American University today at its commencement exercises in Continental Hall. One graduate received the degree of Bachelor of Science in Government.
High police officials from thirty-four countries met in London today to begin the thirteenth annual conference of the international criminal police commission.

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee under extension and modification agreement for $1,507,500 Prudence Bonds Corporation certificates, known as "23 West Seventy-third Street issue," which are a first mortgage on the Park Royal Hotel.
Plans were filed today for the erection of a twelve-story apartment house, with penthouse and stores, on the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-third Street, to cost $700,000.

I. Miller Sons Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Feb. 28 a net income of $371,146 after deductions for Federal taxes, minority interest and $282 surtax on undistributed earnings.
The War Department released the following orders today dated June 5. COLONELS Gruber, E. L.. F. A., General Staff Corps, 4 days leave, June 7.
A massed fleet of sixty-three Insurgent war planes was reported today to have bombed the suburb of Lezama, only two miles from beleaguered Bilbao Spain.
The Thomas Negro Composers Study Group, an ensemble of twenty-five mixed voices, presented a program at the Town Hall last night which had as its theme "The Evolution of the Negro Through Music."

Strikes called by the United Automobile Workers of America today closed the Budd Wheel Company's factory here and two plants of the Ternstedt Manufacturing Company. At the former 1,500 men walked out when a deadlock developed in negotiations with the company. which makes wheels for several automobile producers and employs 2,600 workers.

Dr. Henry Sliosberg, famous lawyer and defender of Jewish rights, died today at the age of 74. He was a former president of the Jewish communityy of St. Petersburg and was president of the Russian community in Paris.

An unexpectedly prolonged examination of Mrs. Anna Bading today caused a delay, probably until tomorrow afternoon, in the appearance as a witness of Ellis H. Parker Sr. in the trial of the Federal Government's conspiracy case against him and his son, Ellis Jr., before Federal Judge William Clark.

Hoghland Van Norden gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Miss Lucille Burnham Sargeant and George Livingston de Peyster, whose marriage will take place on June 18. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds,

Edward A. Neylan, general law assistant to the justices of the Supreme Court of New York County and a personal friend of Municipal Court Justice John F. O'Neil, who was fatally stabbed on April 27, in a letter to Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday, attacked the commissioner's statement that Justice O'Neil knew his assassin and that the O'Neil family had failed to cooperate in the search for the killer.

After five years of careful nursing, one of the world's largest flowers burst into full bloom yesterday at the Bronx Botanical Gardens, but the eight-foot-tall blossom gave off such a powerful odor, resembling that of bad fish, that the hundreds who flocked to Hothouse 9 to see it did not tarry long.

MOSCOW, June 8.--Ivan Papanin, leader of the Soviet scientific expedition at the North Pole, wirelessed to Moscow today some interesting facts in regard to the Pole as a result of first researches aided by a winch that had been taken to the camp by I. P. Mazuruk's plane.

Miss Cabell Sandford Ducey, daughter of Captain and Mrs. David F. Ducey, was married tonight to Ensign John Stuart Fletcher, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. G. Fletcher. The ceremony was performed in Captain Ducey's quarters
The four popular favorites were successful in first-round matches of the twentieth annual Connecticut Women's Golf Association championship at the Brooklawn Country Club today.
Harry Cooper of Chicago is leading all golf money winners with a total of $7,992 so far this year, the Professional Golfers Association Tournament Bureau revealed tonight.

Walter S. Hawley, a native of Trumbull, descended from a Revolutionary family, died at his home today. His age was 83. A member of the general contracting firm of Tomlinson Hawley of Bridgeport, he retired in September of 1934.

Retail food costs on the whole rose in the five weeks ended on May 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average, advanced to 86.5, compared with 85.6 on April 13.
The London Gazette announced tonight that former Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin had taken the titles of Earl Baldwin of Bewdley and Viscount Corvedale of Corvedale in the County of Salop.

Newtown's strong squad last night became the favorite to carry off the team laurels in the city P. S. A. L. senior high track and field championships at Randalls Island on Friday. The Queens champion accounted for six more qualifying places in the trials at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, virtually the unanimous first choice of the party leaders for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, will not run against Mayor La Guardia in any circumstances, according to close friends here.

A contribution of $250 from Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh to the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, organized last year to combat racketeering, was announced yesterday by Harry F. Guggenheim, president of the committee.

Miss Helen C. Hanford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Munn Hanford of 70 East Ninety-sixth Street, and granddaughter of the late Rear Admiral Franklin Hanford, has chosen June 24 for her marriage to William Benedict Johnson,

Miss Alice Marble, United States singles titleholder, moved toward the final round of the Beckenham tennis tournament today as Hal Surface of Kansas City and Charles Harris of West Palm Beach, Fla., qualified for third-round play in the men's division.

With greater recognition for the American designer stressed, plans were pushed last night for the organization of the Fashion Creators of America at a meeting at the American Woman's Club, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.
James Stearns Lee, a leading Boston architect for many years, died suddenly at the Phillips House of Massachusetts General Hospital tonight after a brief illness. He was 67 years old.

Great Britain's new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir John Simon, today quelled rumors that the nation planned an immediate return to the gold standard. Challenged in the House of Commons to state his intentions, Sir John, who succeeded the Conservative Neville Chamberlain, now Prime Minister, said:

The body of John Morgan, 10 years old, of 1,589 First Avenue, was recovered from the lake at Seventy-sixth Street in Central Park shortly after midnight this morning by members of Police Emergency Squad after a search of more than three hours.

Members of the Junior Catholic Big Sisters will hold a subscription supper dance on Saturday at the Arrowhead Inn, Riverdale, to raise money for their charitable work. Miss Cecilia V. Martin heads the committee arranging the dance. Assisting her are Mrs. Harrison J.
Flash-Karpen

National vice presidents of two railroad brotherhoods declared tonight that union employes of the Conemaugh Blacklick Railroad, owned by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, would strike at midnight Thursday unless the company signed a written contract with the unions.

President Roosevelt asked Congress to vote $160,000,000 to begin subsidizing the rebuilding of the merchant marine; indicated at his press conference opposition to changes in the Wages and Hours Bill which would complicate its passage, and conferred with Representative Marvin Jones of Texas on farm legislation.

Lefty Lee Grissom, who has appeared in eighteen games for the Reds this season, today hurled his last-place team-mates to a 4-0 shut-out by holding the Bees to four hits. Grissom, while gaining his fourth victory of the season, had six strikeouts and was never threatened.
An exhibit to inaugurate the program for the rebuilding of Sixth Avenue will be opened today in the new showrooms of the American Radiator Building, 40 to 50 West Fortieth Street.

St. John's University, Brooklyn, will end its commencement ceremonies today with exercises for 392 graduates of the School of Law and 238 graduates of the School of Commerce. The Law- School will hold its exercises at 11 A. M. in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Very Rev.

In a trilingual speech, Will R. Manier Jr. of Nashville, Tenn., its retiring president, pledged Rotary International, which is holding its twentieth annual convention here, to a policy of "Freundschaft, amitis, friendship" at a Franco-German luncheon today at which the tricolor hung beside the swastika and Austrian flags.

Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of Drew University, conferred sixtyone degrees at the seventieth commencement of the university here this morning. Professor William Lyon Phelps of Yale University addressed the graduating class.
The Monmouth County Country Club dropped a close decision to Monroe Eisner's Winmont Farms riders today as they prepared for the opening of the Eastern Polo League campaign. The score was 10 to 9.
Lionel Brown's play "To Have and To Hold," presented at the Haymarket Theatre here tonight, earned an enthusiastic reception-deservedly so, in the opinion of critics.

Asserting that if "price fixing" is extended to unbranded products there will be government regulation of prices. Ralph I. Straus, secretary of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., said yesterday that prices on 1,497 branded items which have

With the exception of the Pacific Coast and some Midwestern areas, Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., has practically achieved national distribution on its five-cent, six-ounce bottles of ginger ale. These were introduced last year, giving the company three price ranges, 5, 10 and 15 cents.

The total of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday, although more than doubling last week's low total due to the holiday, was only slightly above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Eight hundred members of the New York Railroad Club attended the organization's annual outing today at the Westchester Country Club. Games were played in the daytime and tonight there was a dinner attended by executives of most of the railroads and supply houses in the metropolitan area. Charles A. Gill, president of the club, presided at the dinner.

A strike of tugboat employes which was to have been called today, was canceled last night after conferences at which a new alignment of towboat unions was affected. Joseph P. Ryan, president of the American Marine Labor Council, announced that a meeting of union members would be held tonight as scheduled but that officials would counsel withdrawal of the strike threat which would have affected more than 4,000 men.

With the arraignment in Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, yesterday of three men charged with possession of policy slips, the police said that they had rounded up the leaders of one of the main Kings County policy rings. The men were Louis Weber, 42 years old, of 140 Prospect Avenue; Pablo Rodriquez, 45, of 155 Douglas Street, and Carlos Flores, 37, of 126 President Street.

Mrs. Rosemary Harden Parker, wife of Albert Parker, an attorney, and niece of Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank, died on Monday night at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. Mrs. Parker, who lived at 1,120a Fifth Avenue, was 28 years old.

The outdoor dancing season in New York, sponsored by the WPA Federal Music Project, opened last night on the Central Park Mall and at the Colonial Playground in Harlem. About 500 young couples were dancing on the Mall at 8:30 o'clock, with the Knickerbocker dance orchestra playing.

Included in the eleven Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms was the fifteen-story Clinton Apartments, on a plot 100 by 102.2 feet, at 127-133 West Seventy-ninth Street.

Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and High Commissioner of Nicaragua, arrived from Nicaragua yesterday and will sail today with Mrs. Lindberg on the Queen Mary for London on a financial mission for the Nicaraguan Government.
Alla Nazimova, the actress, and Lavery's Garage, Inc., both of Port Chester, settled for $2,150 today a $30,000 damage suit which was about to come to trial against them in Supreme Court here.

ReceivIng the honorary degree of Doctor of Aeronautical Science from Pennsylvania Military College here today, Henry T. (Dick) Merrill, transatlantic flier, predicted hourly airplane service soon between large cities.

A German proposal to include sail-planing among Olympic sports was referred to the International Aeronautical Federation for comment after brief discussion before the International Olympic committee meeting today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 8.--Three or four unidentified men fired more than a dozen shots at United States District Judge Robert A. Cooper late this afternoon less than eighteen hours after Pedro Albizu Campos and his seven Nationalist party associates entered Atlanta prison to serve sentence of six to ten years for conspiracy to overthrow the United States Government in Puerto Rico.

Leonard Hartman, 1936 winner of the tournament and top-seeded entrant, reached the quarter-final bracket of the Brooklyn tennis championship by defeating Sheldon Morgenstern, 6-1, 6-0, in a fourthround match at the Terrace Club of Flatbush yesterday.

A fifty year record was established by the 1937 New Jersey Legislature when only 185 new laws, the lowest number since 1887, were enacted, it became known today when Governor Hoffman attached his signature to remaining bills.

Joseph T. Camier, 55 years old, a retired building contractor of 71 Park Avenue, Huntington Station, L. I., was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning this afternoon in his automobile, parked in the garage at the home of his nephew, W. R. Tietgen of Cedar Lane, Hillside. Police said Mr. Camier had been depressed since the death of his wife two months ago.

Three members of the graduating class of the University of Pennsylvania were announced tonight as winners of three prizes each for scholarship and meritorious work. They are among 1,557 men and women from forty-three States and several foreign countries who will receive degrees in course of commencement exercises tomorrow marking the close of the university's 197th year.

Unless an eleventh-hour hitch occurs, Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa will leave for the Untied States next Monday by plane. Although he reiterates that his trip is not related to any important matter requiring an immediate solution, his statement is regarded as a diplomatic one.
The eclipse was viewed successfully from this ship today for the entire duration of seven minutes, six seconds. An unidentified faint star was sighted near the sun by a member of the crew.
A lone American-long-driving, self-taught Miss Barbara Thompson--remained in the running for the British women's golf championship today as the field was reduced to thirty-two.
Leases taken by dental, drug, photography and optical firms featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. Details of these and other leases follow:
Reaching a Chancery Court settlement with his estranged wife, Bernarr Macfadden, publisher and physical culturist, won custody today of his two sons until they return to military school next Fall.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Hyland Jones of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esther Annis Jones, to Robert Gaylor Morrison Jr. of Amarillo, Texas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Morrison of Pittsburgh.

First Heat-Won by John Schroeder, Textile; Bernard Frankel, Evander Childs, second. Time--0:17.7. Second He t-Won by Jay Harris, Evander Childs; lanso Morano, New Utrecht, second. Time--0:17.8. Third Heat-Won by William Olivieri, Monroe; Paul Brown, Flushing, second. Time--0 18.3.
Despite the withdrawal of Syracuse's jayvees, the board of stewards said today there will be three races in the annual intercollegiate regatta on the Hudson River June 22.

Arthur Mitchell and T. F. Smailes, Yorkshire pros, smashed Kent's bowlers today, Mitchell hitting 86 runs, 78 of them in twentyeight minutes, while his colleague compiled 80 not out in seventy minutes.

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Strabo, who has been racing consistently well all season, stamped himself as one of the better 3-year-olds at Aqueduct yesterday when he scored an easy victory in the featured Purchase Purse at a mile.

An Italian amateur boxing team will clash with an American combination tonight at the Yankee Stadium in the international Golden Gloves competition sponsored by the Daily News A. A. A crowd of 50,000 persons is expected to be present at the event, which will start at 8:30 P. M.

Stockholders of the Homestake Mining Company of Lead, S. D., authorized a split of eight shared to one for its 251,160 shares of common stock at a special meeting here today. Fred T. Elsey, vice president, said this would increase authorized shares to 2,009,280 having a par value of $12.50 instead of $100.

Former President Miguel Mariano Gomez and forty-three members of the executive committee of the Republican party have been cited to appear before the Instruction Court to answer charges of having slandered the government authorities in a party manifest issued to the public on April 11.

With a total of eighty-six, failures declined sharply in the retail group in the five business days ended witt June 3, in comparison with the figures for the holiday period last year according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet Inc.

Dr. Laurens H. Seelye, president of St. Lawrence University, gave the commencement address at Kimberly School here today. Miss Mary K. Waring and Miss Mary A. Jordan, co-principals, presented diplomas to a class of twenty-seven.

Elder Ave, 1,151 (14-3739); Dorfan Holding Corp to Lawyers Mortgage Co, 345 Madison Ave; installments, 4 1/2 per cent; $44,200. Elder Ave, 1,151 (14-3739); Dorfan Holding Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave; due Oct. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $58,000.

Owners of stock in the New Brunswick Light, Heat and Power Company, an underlying concern, voted unanimously today to merge with the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, it was announced at the Public Service company headquarters here.

Elden Auker, veteran Detroit right-hander, blanked the Athletics with one hit today, missing a no-hit performance only because of. Bob Johnson's solid smash for two bases against the scoreboard in the fourth inning. The margin was 6 to 0.

The Rev. Charles S. Macfarland, venerable American churchman, who wrote a book in 1934 disapproving the boycott of Nazi goods and urging Americans to give Chancellor Hitler the benefit of the doubt in his attitude toward the German churches, made public yesterday a scathing indictment of the German Fuehrer, comparing him with Herod in his persecution and despoliation of the Jews, and denouncing him for undermining the basic ideal of Christianity.

New paid life insurance of the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia in May amounted to $2,345,000, an increase of 9 per cent over the same month a year ago, continuing an unbroken record of gains for the tenth consecutive month, according to Walter LeMar Talbot, president.

Coming from behind with a tremendous stretch drive, C. V. Whitney's Black Look scored by a neck over the pace-setting J. Y. Christmas's Rough Time in the six furlongs of the Gloucester Handicap, today's feature at Suffolk Downs.

Edwin S. Gard of New York City purchased the former Wolf estate home with three acres of land on Knollwood Road, Greenburgh, for occupancy after alterations. The house contains eight rooms. David F. Birch was the broker. He also sold a new home on a half-acre plot on Ludlow Drive, Chappaqua,
According to an announcement issued by the Aero Club of France, the French Air Ministry has commissioned the club to study details for a race from Istres to Damascus, Syria, and back to Le Bourget.

The administration's resolution for an avoidance inquiry was adopted today by a House bent upon asserting the independence of Congress, and it was sent back to the Senate in such form as to protect individual and corporation income tax returns from "undue" publicity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mayor La Guardia is going to try his best to make New York the outstanding citadel of high wages, fewer working hours and expensive living. However politically sagacious he may be, he must not have studied economic history very deeply.

The Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution yesterday condemning the use of WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, for the spread of "anti-Semitism and racial hatred over a national hook-up," and called on the city officials responsible to explain their action at next Tuesday's meeting in City Hall.

Keepers of anniversary records in London newspaper offices reminded us the other day that it was the centenary of the death of JOE GRIMALDI. Here he is perhaps hardly more than a name remembered faintly as the hero of the anecdote told of other entertainers fallen into melancholy.

Creston Ave (11-3164), e s, 97 n of 183d St, 50x75; Murray Spritzer to Holiday Building Corp, 300 Madison Ave. Washington Ave (11-2902), w s, 202 s of 171st St, 37x140; Jacob Block to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank. Murdock Ave (17-5025), w s, 204 s of Pitman Ave, 26x97; Emanuel Petrzilka to Emily Kotrba, 4,215 Murdock Ave.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Hicok of this city have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Florence Hicok, to Julian Manning Plemmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace A. Plemmons of Oyster Bay, L. I.

A group of State officials headed by Conservation Commissioner Osborne stopped here tonight in the Chenango Valley at the end of the first phase of a three-day inspection tour of State game farms, hatcheries and reforestation areas.

Charles Poletti, who has just taken his oath as a justice of the State Supreme got to Court after being appointed by Governor Lehman, declared today at a conference of the Women's Division of the Democratic State Committee that leaders of the Republican State Committee and of the Republicans -in the Assembly would make "a deliberate attempt to sabotage the constitutional convention" next April.

SERGEANTS-Joseph E. Curtis, from Mounted Squadron 1 to Mounted Squadron 2, assignment to. mounted duty continued. Thomas J. Feeney, 18th Division, 15th Detective District, designated as acting lieutenant. PATROLMEN-Fabian A. Powers, from 34th Precinct to 18th Division, designated as third grade detective. George A. Ackerly, from 106th Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur.

Two vacant plots were given in part payment for the purchase of an apartment building in one of the Brooklyn deals announced yesterday. A client of Milton W. Sametz purchased from Rex Realty, Inc., the six-story apartment at 34 Mdnroe Place, between Pierrepont and Clark Streets.

Mrs. D. B. Loveman, widow of the founder. of Loveman's Department Store here and a resident of Chattanooga for more than fifty years, died this morning at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Flora Mansfield on Lookout Mountain. Her age was 84.
Harry A. Clark of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. was elected yesterday president of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at the annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Monroe (Mich.) Mayor called for volunteers to help reopen the Republic Steel plant there. Page 1. Mahoning Valley Sheriffs and Youngstown Mayor ordered steel pickets to disarm. Three were held for attack on deputies. Page 1.

The Safety Bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday that traffic deaths in the city decreased by eight during May-, 1937, compared with May, 1936. Accidents decreased by 167 and injuries by sixty-eight.

AUTO RACING Cross Bay Speedway, Cross Bay Boulevard and Sunrise Highway, Ozone Park, L. I. 8:30 P. M. BASEBALL New York Giants vs. St. Louis Cardinals, double-header, at Polo Grounds, 157th Street and Eighth Avenue......1:45 P. M. Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Chicago Cubs, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn .......... 3:15 P. M. Jersey Giants vs. Syracuse Chiefs, at Roosevelt Stadium, Danforth Avenue, near West Side Avenue, Jersey City .... 3 P. M.

Civilization is faced with the task of striking a compromise between authority and individual freedom, the 132 graduates of Goucher College from eighteen States were told at commencement exercises today by Sir Willmott Lewis, for many years Washington correspondent of The London Times. He said:

A measure to authorize the Federal Government to take over all munitions factories, build new ones and undertake the manufacture of all war machines for use on land or sea was introduced today in the Senate by Senator Homer T. Bone of Washington.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, said in a letter to the Board of Estimate yesterday that an additional appropriation of $2,600,000 would be needed to complete the construction of the West Side improvement between Seventy-second and Dyckman Streets "to the satisfaction of the public."

An alleged violation of Peruvian territory by Ecuadorean troops was the subject of a note addressed to the Ecuadorian Minister here today by the Peruvian Government. It was charged that a garrison of Ecuadorian soldiers had been recently established on the Pastaza River in the Amazon basin.

Formation of the Republican Committee Against La Guardia was disclosed.yesterday by the sending of letters to all district leaders and coleaders in New York County, urging them to prevent the betrayal of the party by traitors who would hand over the Republican party to the American Labor party by the renomination of the Mayor.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara eack, daughter of Mrs. Marion C. Back of this city and Long Ridge, Conn., and of Witherbee Black of New York, to John Davidson Ware.

Carding an 81, despite a total five over par for the last three holes, Miss Jean Bauer of the Metacomet C. C. gained the lead today, in the second round of the women's Eastern golf championship at the Plainfield Country Club with a thirtysix-hole total of 78, 81-159.

Representatives of twenty-three cooperative associations of dairymen drafted plans here today for an organization to be known as the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Association. The association, they said, would represent 100,000 State producers.

President Roosevelt made it clear today that he would not welcome attempts to modify or expand the provisions of the Black-Connery Labor Standards Bill. He stated at his press conference that he was suspicious of any amendments to the measure which might complicate its passage.
A field of fifteen, including Reaping Reward, third in the Kentucky Derby, was indicated today for the $15,000 added Latonia Derby on Saturday.

The 1,000 men and women gathered here for the National Inventors Congress at the Hotel Edison spent most of yesterday listening to a discussion of the need for reducing the costs of patents and watching demonstrations of beauty aids. About 8,000 visitors joined them in looking on while models showed how various devices would remove wrinkles and double chins and enhance feminine beauty with dimples and youthful contours.

Communism in Spain "is no more a factor than communism in America," according to Dr. Norman Bethune, Montreal surgeon, who for seven months was head of the Canadian blood-transfusion unit in Loyalist Spain.

A close vote on repeal of the Georgia Prohibition Law and an apparent victory for twenty-six constitutional amendments advocated by Governor E. D. Rivers appeared in State election returns early today. A tabulation from about half the precincts of the State gave a lead of 5,968 votes for repeal. The vote stood: For repeal, 58,252; against, 52,294.

Activity in Bronx real estate yesterday centered in dwelling properties. The Glinmore Realty Company sold to Confield Estates, Inc., the six-story apartment at 651 Southern Boulevard, containing 175 rooms, on a plot 80 by 130 feet.

Daniel P. O'Connell, Albany County Democratic leader, undrwent a sharp cross-examination in Federal court today after testifying how he paid $42,500 ransom for the release of his nephew, John J. O'Connell Jr., twenty-three days after the young National Guard lieutenant's abduction in July, 1933.

he United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the First Circuit today unanimously affirmed a decision of the United States District Court of Massachusetts refusing to grant an injunction to the William Filene's Sons Company against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., of New York.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today transmitted to the Senate a report of the Disaster Loan Corporation showing that net authorizations to sufferers from floods in nine States totaled $5,013,148 and that disbursements of loans made on authorizations aggregated $2,650,900 at the end of May.

Dr. Chengting T. Wang, the new Chi nese Ambassador, presented his credentials to President Roosevelt today as "a messenger of good-will bearing the friendly greetings of the Republic of China to its sister republic."

Germany launched here today another 10,000-ton warship, which will bear the name Bluecher in memory of th heavy cruiser sunk on Jan. 24, 1915, in the Battle of Dogger Bank. Like her predecessor, she also honors the name of Field Marshal Gebhard Leberecht von Bluecher, whose timely arrival at Waterloo defeated Napoleon.

The Yankees no longer are ruling the American League roost alone. At Comiskey Park today before a gathering of 12,000, the White Sox clubbed out their tenth straight victory at the expense of the world champions and barged into a tie for the lead in the flag race.

Retired Engineer of Steamer Charles P. Cavanagh, formerly a member of Engine 16, residing at 629 W. 169th St., Manhattan, died June 5. Funeral will take place from 2,139 Amsterdam Ave, Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M. Tuesday, Jupe 8. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. The deputy chief of the 5th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

An increase of 10 per cent in ingot capacity of the Weirton Steel Company has resulted from the operation of a large-type Bessemer converter installed recently in the main plant at Weirton, W. Va., T. E. Millsop, president, announced yesterday.

La Salle Academy will hold its eighty-ninth commencement exercises tonight at the Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street, with Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle presiding. The graduating class consists of 120 members.

In recognition of the services given by former presidents of the Bond Club of New York, the governors of the club will have these one-time officials as guests of honor at the twentieth annual luncheon meeting of the club on Wednesday, June 23.

Following a meeting of the directors of the Florence Stove Company at Boston, R. L. Fowler, president, stated yesterday that net sales for the first five months of this year were about 40 per cent above those of the same period last year and that indicated net profits before Federal taxes were up about 50 per cent.

Six Long Island University plew ers have been named for the all star Brooklyn college baseball team which will oppose an all-star New York aggregation at Manhattan Beach on June 19, it was announced yesterday by Clair F. Bee, coach of the L. I. TT. nine.

Loyalty to God,' country and one's friends was urged upon the 232 graduates of Manhattan College by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, vicar general of the Archdiocese of New York and the principal speaker at the eighty-fourth commencement exercises before almost 5,000 persons on the college quadrangle yesterday.

BELLE CHANSON, doing business as Alcyr Butter and Egg Co., 368 Greenwich St. By Weinberg Butter and Egg Co., Inc., for $323: C. L. Poole Co., Inc., $203; Kurtin Kurtin, $412. Petitions Filed-By SIDNEY R. BALL, salesman (unemployed), 3,410 Kingsbridge Ave.-Liabilities, $2,246; no assets.

Construction of the new twelvestory Memorial Hospital building in the block bounded by Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets, York and First Avenues, was started yesterday. Formal ground-breaking ceremonies were held in the afternoon in the presence of members of the board of managers and the medical staff.

The stock market's confidence continued to improve today and most sections showed gains. Gilt-edge issues were dull, but among the foreign loans German bonds went ahead. International securities were irregular, some issues being in good demand while United States Steel and International Nickel shares lost ground.

Bankers will have to establish closer contact with the public if confidence in banking as an institution is to be restored, H. A. Lyon, vice president of the Harold F. Strong Corporation and former advertising manager of the Bakers Bankers Trust Company, said last night at a forum meeting of the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., at the Advertising Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. Kimball of Garden City, L. I., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Helene Hanks Kimball, to Robert Marion Souers, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Marion Souers of Brooklyn, which took place March 31 at Trinity Church, Miami, Fla.

An agreement between the Middle West Corporation and four of its subsidiaries for settlement of inter-company claims, thereby paving the way to reorganization of the subsidiaries under Section 77B of the National Bankruptcy Act, was approved with modifications today by Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Harvey Bailey of this place of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Lucy Adelaide Bailey, to the Rev. Dr. Wilbur Spencer Sheriff, son of the Rev.

Americans who have followed the reports of the Imperial Conference in London have learned several highly important facts about the extent and limits of the independence of the member States of the British Commonwealth.

Commissioner John J. McElligott promoted a man yesterday who came closest to defeating him for the post of Chief of 'the Fire Department in a civil service test four years ago. Deputy Chief James W. Heffernan, who was runrier-up in the examination, becaMe Deputy Chief in Charge.

Miss Margaret E. Lacey, member of the Board of Examiners for the last three years, will lose her position at the end of this school term, according to a recommendation made yesterday by the law committee of the Board of Education.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, which is investigating financial transactions involving the Chicago Great Western Railway, produced evidence today which it asserted proved that in 1931 the Van Sweringen-controlled Alleghany Corporation sold to the Great Western about 104,000 shares of Kansas City Southern common stock at double the price at which the stock was then selling on the New York Stock Exchange.

A committee of manufacturers of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group and representatives of the National Association of Apparel Chains met at the Hotel New Yorker last night to exchange views on various trade problems affecting both groups in an endeavor to establish closer trade relationships.

Following the dismissal at a police trial of gambling charges against twenty-four detectives and policemen, Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that five detectives and four plainclothes men who were among them had been ordered returned to uniform duty.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 7: MAJOR GENERAL Conley, E. T., the Adjutant General, 4 days' leave, June 9. BRIGADIER GENERAL Ovenshine, A. T., Fort Sam Houston, Texas, to retirement.

Ben I. Boemerwald has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of the Gilmore Whiskey Corporation. Aperitivo and Elixir Fernet are two new products which will shortly be introduced in this market by Martini Rossi S. A., according to W. A. Taylor Co., exclusive distributors in the United States.

Jumping consistently through the two days of the nineteenth annual West Point Horse Show, the upstanding chestnut gelding Moly neux, owned and ridden by Miss June Hanes of Rye, N. Y., this afternoon was awarded the hunter championship, the highest honor of the exhibition.

The securities and Exchange Commission heard today that Harvey D. Gibson became president of the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York as an indirect result of the failure of the Bank of United States. Walter E. Sachs. member of the New York banking firm of Goldman. Sachs Co.,
Two athletic notables, Charley Paddock and R. L. (Dink) Templeton, joined today in recommending and predicting drastic revision of the Amateur Athletic Union's method of handling track and field.

With hospitals facing a crisis because heavy taxation has curbed philanthropy and with doctors called upon to treat the needy at least partly at their own expense, some form of State medicine is inevitable.

The marriage of Miss Mary Mercy Bours, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alsop Bours of this place, to Robert Burns Archibald, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Archibald of Jacksonville, Fla., took place this evening in Grace Episcopal Church.

Visits to gardens in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, will precede a benefit garden party to be given tomorrow at the home of Mrs. A. J. Grymes Jr. of East Park Street, East Orange, for the Lee Stratford Memorial Foundation.
For the second consecutive year, earnings of the Zenith Radio Corporation exceeded all previous earnings records, not excluding that of 1929, the company reported yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lloyd A Belt of 610 Park Avenue and Lakewood, N. J., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Barbara Fleming Belt, to Madison Haden Haythe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Otway Haythe of Warrenton, Va.

R. S. Hecht, chairman of the board of the Hibernia National Bank of New Orleans, has been appointed by Tom K. Smith, president of the American Bankers Association, as chairman of the association's delegation to the ninth general meeting of the International Chamber of Commerce, which will be held in Berlin from June 28 to July 3.
Steve Sundra tonight pitched the Newark Bears to a 6-0 victory over a revamped Oriole team. He struck out ten batters and allowed only five hits.

BOWERY, 169, 23.5x132.5, irreg; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Randolph Trading Corp, 25 Broad St; mtg, $25,500 ($30.50). SAME PROPERTY; Randolph Trading Corp to Weiss Bowery Corp, 183 Madison Ave; mtg, $25,500. THOMPSON ST, 178, 25x100; North Baptist Church of City N. Y. to One Mond Holding Corp, 551 5th Ave ($6). 1ST ST, 68 E, 25x128.6; Aaron Kurz, ref, to Harlem Savings Bank; foreclosure ($3).

The Census Bureau said today that the 1936 death rate in the United States was 11.5 per 1,000 population, the highest since 1929. The 1935 rate was 10.9. Deaths last year totaled 1,474,177, the bureau said, an increase of 81,425 over the previous year.

German Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop, who is returning to London tomorrow after consultation with Chancellor Adolf Hitler, is bringing back a reply to the revised British proposals regarding the protection of warships in Spanish waters. The British believe tonight that the reply will be favorable.

Banks and other institutions requiring special police protection would be required to pay for it under a local law adopted yesterday by unanimous vote of the Board of Aldermen. The bill was introduced by Alderman Charles E. Keegan of the Bronx.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for the erection of many small dwellings in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens. A number of plans also were filed for alterations to several Manhattan multi-family houses. Details of the plans follow:
Miss Amelia Earhart tuned her twin-engined monoplane today for a flight across Africa as the next leg on her flight around the world.

Celebrating its 105th commencement, New York University will award today 4,098 degrees in course, seventy certificates, seven alumni awards and eight honorary degrees at exercises at Ohio Field on the uptown campus at University Heights.

The heat, humidity-bad business, also- are taking their expected whecks at the theatre. Already two units of Broadway's present little group of shows have decided they will not go on after Saturday evening, and by the time Monday rolls around there may be several other vacancies on the list.

Hugh R. Wilson, Minister to Switzerland and veteran career diplomat, has been offered the post of Assistant Secretary of State, according to authoritative information today. The office has been vacant since the advancement of Sumner Welles and R. Walton Moore to Under-Secretary and Counselor respectively, of the State Department.

Possibility of further extension of Price Maintenance Laws, which may have "dire effects on retail purchasing and selling and arouse consumer resistance," will be discussed at a joint meeting of the merchandising division and the controllers' congress of the Natinnal Rtail Dry Goods Associatinn

Five hours and twenty-two minutes out of a drizzle at Port Washington the Bermuda Clipper of the Pan American Airways landed in the hot sun on the torquoise water off Darrell's Island, in Hamilton Harbor, this afternoon, completing the first leg of the last route inspection flight before inauguration of service next week.

An American Federation of Labor union won a close victory tonight and the right to represent exclusively the more than 2,000 workers in the main plant of the H. J. Heinz Company in collective bargaining.

Mayor La Guardia's declaration on Sunday in favor of the closed shop rebounded yesterday when the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, announced that it would meet tonight to formulate demands for a closed shop on the city's own Independent Subway System.

Benjamin F. Kraus of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Mrs. Jane Rosenbloom, to Richard A. Loeb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Loeb of New York. Mrs. Rosenbloom attended Mary Lyon School in Swarthmore and Wellesley College.
The Essex County Symphony Society, Erno Rapee director, launched its second outdoor Summer season tonight in the huge stadium before an audience estimated at 10,000.

Stockholders of the H. L. Green Company, at an adjourned special meeting yesterday, authorized the creation of 80,000 shares of new first preferred stock and reclassified the present outstanding 4,777 shares of first preferred into a like number of second preferred.
Members of the New York A. C. Yachting Department will gather at the Travers Island clubhouse tonight to learn something about the club's annual race to Block Island, which is scheduled for July 10.

Announcement of financing by Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., is expected in some important quarters to be made soon. The belief now is that the proposed issue, the proceeds of which will be used for further expansion by the company, will be taken privately by a group of insurance companies.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 8.--After a visit of Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, Minister of Interior and Justice; to the city jail's 108 prisoners, some of whom had been in jail for months, not charged with any offense, but held as suspected Communists, were set free last night. Another 200 were liberated today.

While Hollywood paid silent tribute today to the memory of Jean Harlow, arrangements were being made by the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studio for a private funeral service for the actress, to take place tomorrow at 11 A. M. at the Wee Kirk O'The
Following is the text of the letter sent by Dr. Charles S. Macfarland, general secretary emerituzs of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, to Adolf Hitler, the German Chancellor:

Up in Harlem the Negro Unit of the Federal Theatre is making a laudable attempt to stand on its own dramatic feet. "The Case of Philip Lawrence," which opened at the Lafayette last evening, exploits the local problems of a race handicapped by constricted social opportunities. It is based on a flamboyant night-life drama entitled "Eleven P. M." by George MacEntee, who has written a good many theatre pieces.

The towboat committee of the Maritime Association at a meeting yesterday morning adopted resolutions condemning the proposal of the Maritime Commission to assign Coast Guard vessels to tow vessels of the government's laid-up fleet from Staten Island to the James River.

Edward S. Godfrey Jr., Commissioner of Health, said tonight that in order not to impede the flow of milk into the established markets of the State the Department of Health will not require immediately new licenses or permits of milk dealers who now ship milk into the State from outside sources. The new law takes effect July 1.

With two more deaths from diphtheria reported in the city for the week ended June 5, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, yesterday said that the total diphtheria deaths for this year will be much higher than in 1936. Already there have been thirty-three deaths compared with thirty-five in- 1936.

ALEXANDE--Lena, beloved sister of Sig. mond and Jacques. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., Wednesday, June 9, at 10:30 A. M. ANDREWS-Roger Connor, on June 7, son of the late George J. Andrews. and de-. voted brother of Lieutenant George J., Jr., Gerard, Vera and Ethel Andrews;

Miss Marjory Jane Gage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Gage of 730 Park Avenue and Deal, N. J., was married to Jorge De Silva Prado of Rio de Janeiro yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building in the presence of relatives and a few friends.

The 1937 employer desires prospective employes to have ability, specific experience, integrity, the right attitude toward his job, good manners and good humor, Walter A. Lowen, advertising agency placement specialist, yesterday told the luncheon meeting of the New York

At the annual commencement of the Peekskill Military Academy, held here today in the Ford Auditorium, Admiral Harris Laning, commandant of the 'navy yard at Brooklyn, addressed the forty-three members of the graduating class.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Lynch of Garden City, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ida Baldwin Lynch, to Robert Norman Murdoch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Murdoch of Manchester,, N. H.
The clothiers and tailors and department stores Many selling hot-weather garments for men call atten tion to the astonishingly low weight of a man's suit in ounces.
Contributions to the Republican National Committee in the three months ended May 31 amounted to $115,360.71, of which $33,405.20 was in gifts of less than $100 each.

Wet weather in the Southwest and dry conditions in Canada, together with reports of a further spread of black rust in Eastern sections of the hard Winter Wheat Belt today brought about the biggest rally the wheat market on the Board of Trade has had in a week or more.

Monroe Owsley, stage and screen actor, died yesterday on the way from Los Angeles to San Francisco. He was a native of Atlanta, Ga. Mr. Owsley was cast as the suave, dashing villain of many films, and among recent pictures in which he appeared were "The Hit Parade," "Yellowstone," "Hideaway Girl," with Martha Raye;

Sweet Briar College held its annual commencement exercises this morning with President Meta Glass presiding. Dr. William Ernest Hocking of Harvard University gave the commencement address, his subject being "Arteries of Education." Degrees were conferred upon fifty-six seniors representing sixteen States, the District of Columbia, and China.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 7, unless specified: At San Diego, June 4: Childs, Sands. At Dahlgren: Claxton, Erie, Fairfax, Roper, J. F. Talbott, Jacob Jones, Manley. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Herbert. June 8: Decatur.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today for $10,000,000 for the revolving fund of the Maritime Commission, and an authorization of $150,000,000 to enable the commission to begin quickly to rebuild the American merchant marine, which, he said, will be over 85 per cent obsolete in five years.

The annual statistical report of the American Iron and Steel Institute for 1936, issued yesterday, places at $4,206,107,006 the total investment in the iron and steel industry of the United States in 1936, compared with $4,284,556,292 the year before.

Counsel for Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, were censured today by Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme for not having notified all interested parties when applications were made in court relating to the rehabilitation of mortgage certificates.

The directors of the Wheeling Steel Corporation decided yesterday in Wheeling, W. Va., to call a special meeting of stockholders for July 14 to vote on a plan of recapitalization designed to eliminate accumulations of dividends on the present 6 per cent preferred stock, it was announced here. The plan provides for the creation of a new $5 cumulative convertible prior preferred stock and an increase in the authorized common shares to 1,500,000 from 500,000.

The House Rivers and Harbors Committee reported today the bill authorizing construction of the Florida ship canal. Two minority reports opposed the project. The reports were prepared after the committee had some time ago voted to recommend execution of a report by Major Gen. Markham, chief of army engineers, for construction of the canal.

Miss Doris A. Griffoul, 28 years old, a teacher of science at the James Monroe High School in the Bronx, was found dead yesterday in her room in the Hotel Shelton, Forty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue. A partly emptied container of poison and two glasses in which the poison had apparently been mixed were found on her night, table. Dr. Henry C. Fischer,

Seventy intramural athletic association medals have been awarded to Princeton University undergraduates for competing in Spring sports on championship teams or for winning individual titles, it was announced today by Thaddeus T. Hutcheson, president of the association.

Harlem River Houses, the new low-rent housing project at 153d Street and Seventh Avenue, will be formally leased to the New York City Housing Authority by the PWA at a ceremony on the premises next Wednesday afternoon, when Mayor La Guardia will witness the signing of the lease by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, and Howard Gray, representing Harold L. Ickes, Administrator of the PWA.

The advance guard of golf's titleseeking clans, warming up today for the forty-first United States Open Championship, found the storm signals flying and a windswept sample of what to expect when the main firing begins Thursday in the Battle of Oakland Hills.

Mrs. John L. Woodbury, president general of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, was guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon of 100 members of the organization's New York Division at the Hotel Warwick, 65 West Fiftyfourth Street. Mrs. Woodbury,

The eighth gunshot victim of the Memorial Day steel riot in South Chicago died today while public demands increased for official investigations of the clash between police and steelmill strikers, which also sent ninety persons to hospitals.

Miss Hope Jackson, whose engagement to Francis P. Garvan Jr. was announced on May 30 by her father, Robert Jackson, former Democratic National Committeeman from New Hampshire and secretary of the Democratic National Committee,
Charles Beecher Donle, nationally known for nearly a half century as a children's evangelist for the Christian and Missionary Alliance, died at his home here tonight at the age of 78.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth A. Raynor, daughter of Mrs. Gilbert J. Raynor of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Raynor, to Basil Jeno, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Jeno of Huntington, L. I., has been announced by her mother.
Al Robertson and Charley Kurtsinger, veterans who have won their share of rich stakes in the past, monopolized Washington Park's card today, winning five of the first six races between them.

Vyse Ave, 1,90, 2-story frame dwelling, 50x44.1; Home Owners Loan Corp against Margaret Formoso: due, $7,730; taxes, , $472; to plaintiff for $0,000. Montgomery Ave, 1,703, 2-story frame dwelling, 25x100; Broadway Savings Bank against Anna Greco; due, $13,413; taxes, $171; to plaintiff for $1,000.
After a struggle of many years birth control received its first official recognition here today from the American Medical Association, which represents organized medicine in the United States.

Ever since the sessions of the British Imperial Conference began, dispatches from London, have steadily reflected the obstacles presented by the Dominions to an Anglo-American trade agreement--the common dream of Secretary of State Hull and Ambassador Sir Ronald Lindsay.

Baroness Marie de Cartier de Marchienne, American wife of the Belgian Ambassador to London, left a net estate of $685,026 at her death on Feb. 18, 1930, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.
The Senate joined the House today in adopting a formal expression of regret for the death of Representative Philip A. Goodwin of Coxsackie, N. Y., who died Sunday at the age of 55.

A total of 308 degrees and certificates were conferred on graduates of four divisions of St. John's University, Brooklyn, at two commencement exercises held yesterday morning and afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Directors of the American Shipbuilding Company declared yesterday out of the current fiscal year's earnings an extra dividend of $1 a share on the common stock and one of 50 cents. On May 1 50 cents was disbursed.

In a long editorial headed "What Now?" the Westdeutsche Beobachter, leading National Socialist organ in the Rhineland, welcomes the fact that open warfare has been declared between the Vatican and the German Government. It concludes:

Lieutenant Carl O. Petersen, a veteran of both of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's Antarctic expeditions, will receive the United States Navy's highest honor, the Distinguished Flying Cross, at 11 o'clock this morning.

To the countless marvels of the American Museum of Natural History was added yesterday an incomplete exhibit, on the basement floor of the Roosevelt Memorial Building, labeled "Some Suggestions for a Future Hall of Animal Behavior."

Hitting safely in every inning but the first and eighth, the Pirates today snapped their five-game losing streak with an 8-1 rout of the Phillies. The Buccaneers made thirteen hits, including home runs by Al Todd, Bill Brubaker and Woody Jensen, off the delivery of Wayne LaMaster and Leon Pettit.

Funeral services for William J. Henderson, music critic of The Sun, who died last Saturday, were held yesterday afternoon at the Cypress Hills Abbey in Queens. The Rev. George T. Gruman, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church, Arlington and Schenck Avenues, Brooklyn, officiated. Burial was in the Cypress Hills mausoleum.

Thomas H. Allison, produce commission merchant, leaped to his death at about 8 o'clock last night from the rear platform of a Fifth Avenue elevated train of the B. M. T. into a Long Island Railroad cut near Thirty-eighth Street between, Third and Fourth Avenues, Brooklyn. The police said Mr. Allison,

Warfare in the metropolitan sector of the National League's close pennant race came to a temporary halt yesterday, when rain postponed both the Giant-Cardinal game at the Polo Grounds and the conflict between the Dodgers and Cubs at Ebbets Field.

Miss Mayna Shannon, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John T. Shannon of Boston, was married this afternoon to the Rev. Harry Bertrand Taylor of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Taylor of Linn, W. Va., in the Presbyterian Church here.

Before more than 800 persons, Ben Marden's Riviera, night club and casino, opened last night at Fort Lee, N. J., just across the George Washington Bridge from Manhattan. The new club was erected at an estimated cost of more than $200,000.

Faced with the fact that the forty-hour week and improved conditions for labor have not brought all the hoped-for results in renewed commercial activ-ity, and above all in extra revenue, the French Cabinet will have to raise at least 5,000,000,000 more francs if it is to hope to balance its budget.

Turpentine firm, 34 1/2@35c; sales, 275 barrels; receipts, 839 barrels; shipments, 143 barrels; stock, 8,969 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 971; receipts, 2,767; shipments, 194: stock, 48.221. Quote: B, $7.70; D. $7.75; E, $8; F to WG, $8.20; WW, X. $9.20.

The New York University council held its annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Fiftieth Street and Pairk Avenue. Members of the university administration and most of the recipients of honorary degrees attended.

William Gibbs McAdoo Jr., son of United States Senator William Gibbs McAdoo of California, was married to Sarah A. Lummus yesterday in the chapel of the Marriage License Bureau in .the Manhattan Municipal Building.

Bitterness, smoldering for nearly two weeks like the banked furnaces of the steel mills made idle by a strike of C. I. O. workers against independent steel companies, flared today in minor outbreaks of violence as the Sheriffs of two Mahoning Valley counties acted simultaneously to disarm the pickets around the plants.

Diplomas were awarded to twenty-two graduates of the Teacher Education Department of the Ethical Culture Schools at graduation exercises last night at the Ethical Culture School, 33 Central Park West.

The honeymooning Duke and Duchess of Windsor thanked Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany today for his good wishes on the occasion of their marriage. "For your cordial wishes we thank you heartily," the telegram to Hitler read.

Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission opened its case yesterday against the Schenley Distillers Corporation, its various branches and subsidiaries, on charges of violating the price-fixing restrictions of the Federal law.
Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister, arrived at Palermo this morning for a week's stay. He went there aboard Premier Mussolini's yacht Aurora, escorted by two destroyers.

Although, if she finds any other bears who will listen, Ranjah, a 15-year-old Coney Island performing bear, will probably wear their ears off talking about her operation from now on, she really went through the ordeal very well.

Dr. Irvin E. Deibert of Haddonfield, president of the board of the State Department of Health, announced today he would not be a candidate for reappointment when his term expires July 1. In making known his decision to retire, Dr. Deibert criticized Governor Hoffman, saying he had failed in efforts to obtain sympathetic action.

First Military Area The following officers, having reported for duty at this headquarters, are assigned to duty for the period ending June 19, next, as indicated below: Major William C. Ihde, Asst.
