C. of S. G.-I. Major Arthur D. Mann, Asst. C. of S. G.-3; Captain Thomas D. L. Cronan, Asst. C.: of S. G.-2.

David B. Hempstead of Salt Lake City, special assistant to the Attorney General, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 67 years old. Appointed three years ago, Mr. Hempstead was at his desk yesterday in the Department of Justice, seemingly in his usual health.

The American Newspaper Guild, which as a member of the American Federation of Labor had limited itself to editorial department workers, voted today to open its ranks to other "white -collar" newspaper employes and affiliate with the C. I. O.

Trading in black pepper futures on the New York Produce Exchange will be started next Wednesday, thus adding to the markets now maintained on the Exchange in cottonseed oil, tallow and frozen eggs, the Exchange announced yesterday.

Holy Cross took the third and final game of the annual series with Boston College today, 7 to 6, the game going eleven innings. The victory gave Holy Cross the series, 2-1. The Eagles put over six runs in the fourth to drive Al Jarlett from the mound and take the lead, but the Crusaders knotted the score in the eighth on two walks, a sacrifice and a single.

A strike of 300 stock handlers at the National Stockyards, which had paralyzed one of the largest livestock markets of the world, ended tonight. The strikers voted to accept a wage scale of 52 cents an hour and a contract for one year offered by officials of the stockyards company at a conference late in the day.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from a five weeks' trip to Europe. His only comment on the influx of gold into the United States and the possibility of reducing the price was:

Declaring that the job of running a city like New York has become one of science and management rather than one of politics, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia told New York University graduating seniors at class day exercises on the University Heights campus yesterday that "we of our generation have made some unpardonable blunders which history will never forget." He told the seniors to go out and "hand down a better world."

Culminating a series of events in some ways without precedent in Wall Street history, a group of insurance companies and savings banks abandoned yesterday a compromise plan of reorganization for the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway that they had reached with the Van Sweringen interests after three years of controversy.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 5: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Barnaby, R. S., Pensacola. Fla., to Fleet Air Base, Coco Solo, C. Z. Helmkamp. E. F., the Texas, to Hydrographic Office, Navy Department; orders of March 25 revoked. Moyer, F. E., Chaplain Corps, Coco Solo, C. Z., to the Cincinnati, orders of Dec. 17, revoked.

PATHOLOGIST--Salary, $2,640 to $3,500 per annum; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies: One vacancy at present at $1,800, with maintenance in the Department of Hospitals, at the Otisville Sanatorium. No other immediate vacancies expected. Ages: ,25 through 40, on June 24. Applications received to 4 P. M.. Thursday, June 24, Room 1400. Municipal Building, Manhattan.

Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University will hold its thirty-fifth annual commencement this morning at the Albee Theatre, Brooklyn, with Judge Irving Lehman of the New York State Court of Appeals as speaker. The school will confer 467 degrees.
Officials of the city of Worcester, Mass., will consider tenders today for a new issue of $500,000 of revenue notes, to be dated June 10, 1937, and due on May 20, 1938.

Henry M. Briggs, 50 years old, for more than twenty-four years a letter carrier attached to the Sheepshead Bay Station, was found guilty yesterday by a jury in Federal court, Brooklyn, on two counts of "detaining, delaying and secreting" the mail.

Kathleen and Charles Norris will arrive here tomorrow morning from Europe, where they went from California for a vacation and to attend the coronation. They expect to spend only about four hours here and probably will leave by plane for their home in Palo Alto, Calif.

A brace of Rochester errors supplied the Montreal Royals tonight with the run they needed for a 3-2 triumph over the Red Wings. Misplays by Roettger and Sturdy gave the. Royals the run in the sixth inning as they led, 2 to 1.

Thomas A. Hedley, a drug commission merchant with offices at 53 Clark Place, died yesterday at his residence, 139 East Sixty-sixth Street. Born in Warwickshire, England, seventy-nine years ago, he represented the Liverpool firm of Evans, Sons, Lescher Webb.

The management set-up for Hearn's Newark branch, which will be opened after extensive alterations have been made in the Goerke Sons store at 689 Broad Street, was announced yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, vice president and general manager of Hearn Department Stores, Inc.

Mrs. Elizabeth Whitlock Simms, widow of Stephen Chapman Simms, who was director of the Field Museum of Natural History, died today in the home of her son, Robert C. Simms, in Orlando, Fla., it was learned here.
A group of pilgrims carried out a 1000year-old ceremony today by walking barefoot across three miles of a North Sea inlet separating the mainland of Northumberland from Holy Island.

All classes of traefa beef were in fair demand. Lamb moved fair to slow. Some fresh pork cuts were active and others moved very slowly. Veal cuts were slightly more active. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be steady to weak and other classes mostly steady as reported by the U. S. Department of Agriculture.
Unemployment in the nation in April declined to a total of 6,981,000 persons, the lowest total for any month since the Summer of 1931, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

About 400 barbers on the upper West Side went on strike yesterday morning in shops between 59th and 245th Streets. Ralph Allocca, president of Local 10 of the Journeymen Barbers International Union, said he expected more than 1,500 men in 800 shops to join the walkout in the district.

George M. Moffett, president and director of Corn Products Refining Company, received $75,000 for the year of 1936 while two other officers, Frederick T. Fisher, director, vice president, secretary and treasurer, and George S. Mahana, director and vice president, received $97,000 each,
The friends, old and new, of Sir WILFRED GRENFELL will gladly be made aware that next Sunday will be the forty-fifth anniversary of the departure of his ship from Yarmouth, England, for Labrador.
The longawaited revolt of the British protectionists against the proposed British-American trade agreement broke out behind closed doors in a crowded committee room of the House of Commons today.

Application of this country's Neutrality Act to Italy and Germany because of their "undeclared war" in Spain was urged yesterday by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, in an interview at his home, 206 East Eighteenth Street.

Racing through rain out over a battered-down sea, Gerarld B. Lambert's America's Cup yacht Yankee this afternoon took the measure of Chandler Hovey's Rainbow by two minutes and three seconds over 23.7 miles, and thus won her second race in the preliminary defense series, both over the last cup defender.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,538,150 barrels, compared with 3,573,700 in the previous week, a decline of 35,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Major Gen. Ben H. Fuller, former commandant of the Marine Corps, died at the Naval Hospital early this ning of pneumonia after an illness of three days. His age was 67.

Members of Local 16 of the International Jewelry Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, voted last night to affiliate with the Committee for Industrial Organization at a membership meeting in the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street. About 400 persons attended.

President Roosevelt indicated today that he preferred the Treasury formula of an outright grant of Federal money for slum clearance and low cost housing to the plan suggested in the Wagner-Steagall act of Federal subsidies over sixty years to meet the difference between the economic rent and the rent which those in the lower income brackets could afford to pay.

The Corporation Bond Traders 105 Club of New York will hold its third annual outing at the Westchester Country Club on June 18, it was anbounced yesterday by Arthur Bloch of Speyer Co., chairman of the committee on arrangements. Three major trophies will be put up for competition in the golf tournament as the feature of the outing.

Eight hundred beauty parlor employes in the lower West Bronx went on strike yesterday morning, but shortly after the strike became effective Local 560-B of the Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Union, the strike organization, announced that it had reached an agreement with the New York State Hairdressers Association, which controls 125 of the largest shops in the district. Malvina Friedman,

Directors of the Maryland Jockey Club, operators of Pimlico race track, moved today to increase the value of the Preakness to $100,000, which would make it America's richest stake for three-year-olds.

Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York District, which includes all of Manhattan north of Twentythird Street, estimated yesterday that 30,400 employers in his district were "ignoring" their obligation to make monthly tax returns under the old-age benefit title of the Federal Social Security Act.

Dr. Paul Halsted Fairchild, civic leader and real estate man here, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack at the Hotel Pennsylvania. He had gone to the hotel after returning from a Washington business trip rather than return late to his home at 87 Boulevard, Passaic, N. J. His age was 69.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipt, 13,000, including 3,000 directs. Market generally 5-10 lower than Monday's average; packing sows steady; good and choice 200-300 pounds, 11.25-50; top, 11.55;

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company yesterday filed a suit in the Common Pleas Court in Dauphin County, Pennsylvania, challenging the constitutionality of the Pennsylvania tax on chain stores and asking for an injunction against the Secretary of Revenue

Two industrial buildings in Long Island City, L. I., have been leased through Lehr Benes, brokers. One is the one-story structure at 35-28 Forty-second Street, which was rented by the Pope-Stewart Corporation through Dane Dane, co-brokers, for use as a plant for the manufacture of trailers.

The Public Service Commission announced last night that an application of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for an exchange of preferred stocks of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, for the preferred stock of Consolidated Edison had been denied.

William G. Austin, formerly with Douglas L. Elliman, Inc., has joined Vought, Campbell, Ward Co. where he will be in charge of a newly organized mortgage deapartment. A first mortgage of $120,000 on the sixstory apartment house at 1,480 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has been taken by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company through Schimmer, Kerner Feder for a client of Henry F. Byrnes.

Tom K. Smith of St. Louis, president of the American Bankers Association, condemned the type of education that stresses "cash values" and "tricks of the trade," in an address today before the convention of the American Institute of Banking. He defended "fundamental" as against "practical" education.

Organized labor on a "work holiday" interrupted activities in Michigan's capital city today for the second successive day. Signaling an intensive organizing campaign, members of American Federation of Labor unions employed on building projects walked off their jobs to halt construction work for the day.

Miss Nancy Kershaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kershaw of Forest Hills, Queens, has selected June 26 for the date of her marriage to Everett Parsons Tomlinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Tomlinson of Montclair, N. J., and Chatham. Mass. The ceremony.

Strikes brought about a sharp decrease in steel ingot production last week, when only a small seasonal decline was to be expected, and the adjusted index broke to 102.3 from 122.0 in the previous week. It was 94.9 for the week ended June 6, 1936.

Miss Diana Battye, who disappeared from Lady Long's home in Oxford Square last week, was found early this morning near the home of her prospective mother-in-law, Lady Cynthia Asquith, in Regents Park.

Samuel Greenbaum, a member of the law firm of Greenbaum Hollander of 120 West Forty-second Street, who was prominent in Masonic activities, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home, at 910 West End Avenue. He was 63 years old.

Eugene McIntosh, a Negro long active in politics, sent his resignation yesterday as leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District organization of the City Fusion party to Ben Howe, city chairman, because he opposes Mayor La Guardia's re-election.

Women drys from fifty-two nations I called on their governments and transportation authorities today to prohibit the use of intoxicants by transportation operators while on duty and for twenty-four hours before.

Members of the 102d Engineers of Manhattan were the trophy winners in two of the three events shot at Camp Smith here today in the running off of the annual New York State matches being fired this week.

The Union Electric Company of St. Louis, Mo., which on June 3 asked the Sceurities and Exchange Commission to approve, under the Public Utility Act of 1935, the issuance of $80,000,000 of first-mortgage and collateral-trust 33/4 per cent bonds due in 1962 and $15,000,000 of 3 per cent notes due in 1942, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the two issues.
A further decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried the list below 12 1/4 cents a pound with December selling at 12.10 cents at one time.

Political and economic talks between Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia and Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany continued here today. They were interrupted only by a luncheon given for Baron von Neurath by Prince Paul, the Regent.

A variety of properties in Manhattan, ranging from the Bowery to the upper West Side, changed hands in the deals reported yesterday by brokers. The newly constructed six-story apartment at 353 East Fifty-third Street has been sold to a client of Riker Co., Inc., by Abraham Silverberg.

Passengers sailing for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include Supreme Court Justice George Sutherland of Washington, with Mrs. Sutherland; Mgr. George J. Wearing, Viscount Hinchingbrooke, Sir P. Patani, Fernando de los Rios,

THE Fabian Lectures given annually in England are not usually published, only two or three of the series reaching back to 1889 having been so -honored. The most recent, however, is now happily available under the title of "What Is Ahead of Us?" (Macmillan, $2).

Fully clothed, even to hat and gloves, Mrs. Harriet B. Allen, sixtyfive-year-old widow, plunged to her death shortly before 10 o'clock yesterday morning from a window of her two-room suite on the eighteenth floor of the Hotel Park Chambers, 68 West Fifty-eighth Street.

Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, senior leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, will be the speaker tonight at the commencement exercises of theSchool for Printers' Apprentices and the School for Machine Typesetting, 220 West Nineteenth Street. Dr. Elliott is chairman of the board of directors of the School for Printers' Apprentices.

America must look to the engineer to solve the problems of labor and industry, Gano Dunn, president of Cooper Union, told the 513 graduates of Massachusetts Institute of Technology at commencement exercises today.
The Naval Academy athletic authorities today decided to move the Navy crews to Poughkeepsie, N. Y., on Thursday instead of Sunday as was originally planned.

Joel Thorne has notified officials of the Roosevelt Raceway that he will drive the powerful eight-cylinder Alfa Romeo, which Raymond Sommer of France piloted to fourth place last Fall, in the 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup Race on July 3.

Fertilizer manufacturers were urged to interest themselves in soil conservation, since fertilizer is not used in badly eroded land unfit for crop growing and therefore certain markets for fertilizer will be lost unless they are protected from erosion,

After one of tile two men now on trial as leaders of the trucking racket had warned them that "somebody's truck might get broke or somebody's head might get cracked," the members of the Garment Center Truckowners Association paid them $500 a month for the greater part of three years, according to testimony in the Supreme Court yesterday.

Thirty-nine men who defied the Lake County Circuit Court by holding the plant of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation in North Chicago in a sitdown strike in February were fined and sentenced to jail today for contempt of court.

Miss Virginia Hustvedt, daughter of Commander and Mrs. W. M. Hustvedt, and a granddaughter of the late Judge Henry E. Cooper of Honolulu, was married today in All Souls Episcopal Church to Ensign Philip F. Hauck, U.S.N.
Henry Matter, for eight years secretary and treasurer, was appointed executive secretary of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute by the board of directors at a special meeting here yesterday.

St. John's Prep defeated St. Augustine, 6 to 3, at the Parade Grounds in Brooklyn yesterday, thus going into a tie with the losing nine for the leadership of the Brooklyn division of the C. H. S. A. A. baseball tournament.
The German Government has refused American consular authorities' first request for the ashes of Helmuth Hirsch, 21-year-old American citizen who was guillotined here last Friday.

John F. Montgomery, United States Minister to Hungary, is returning today from Washington and will join Mrs. Montgomery at the Pierre. They will go later to the Cascades, their Summer home in Manchester, Vt.

Mayor La Guardia has requested the extension of the Emergency Relief Bureau beyond July 1, when under the law all emergency home relief is to be placed on a permanent basis, David C. Adie, Commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare, said yesterday.
Miss Janet Fraser Tilney, daughter of Mrs. Addie Wood Tilney and John Mason Tilney of Windsor, Conn., became the bride of Marshall Clinton Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Clinton.

The increased activity in United States Government securities yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was for the most part at the expense of prices. Declines ranged from 1-32 to 5-32 point on a turnover of $648,500, compared with sales of only $153,800 on Monday.

MADRID, June 8.--The Insurgents launched what appears to be one of the major offensives of the war on the Cordoba front today while Madrid cleaned up after the most severe night bombardment it has yet experienced.

The fourteenth annual commencement of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel will be held at the institution here tomorrow afternoon, and Patrick Cardinal Hayes will confer degrees on twenty-seven members of the graduating class. Dr. Joseph F. Wickham of New York will be a speaker.
Miss Edna Smith of Cleveland scored a major upset in the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis championships today, defeating Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4.

Reception by the Mayor to the Japanese Economic Mission at City Hall, noon. Testimonial luncheon in honor of Harry W. Warley, president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P.M.
Ninety-four members of eight Brown Spring sports teams have been awarded the insignia of their sports by the Brown Athletic Council, Dr. Frederick W. Marvel, director of athletics announced today.

The Board of Estimate listened for several hours yesterday to arguments for and against legislation to set up a $500,000 fund to rehabilitate old-law tenements, with the cost of the improvements charged against the buildings as a prior lien.

Mike Belloise, recognized as world featherweight champion in New York State, gained an easy victory over Charley Gomer, Baltimore lightweight, in the feature-bout of eight rounds on the boxing program last night at the Queensboro Arena before a crowd of 4,000.

A public links golfer; Charles Amandoles, open champion of Staten Island, took the low gross award in the annual William Henry Beers memorial tournament over the well groomed links of the North Shore Country Club today when he posted a fine 35, 39-74, two over par.

The weighing scale is becoming uppermost in the minds or mothers as a measure of baby health, so there is a tendency toward overfeeding that is eventually injurious to the child, Dr. Thurman B. Given of the Kings County (N. Y.) Medical Milk Commission told the annual joint conference of the American Association of Medical Milk Commissions and the Certified Milk Producers Association of America in Haddon Hall today.

Arthur V. Youngman, sales promotion manager of the Mutual 90 Benefit Life Insurance Company, was elected president of the Life meeting of the association yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. He will succeed Ralph G. Engelsman, general agent of the Penn Mutual.

ORCHIDS ON YOUR BUDGET, OR LIVE SMARTLY ON WHAT HAVE You, by Marjorie Hillis. (Bobbs-Merrill, $1.50.) How to enjoy life without much money. RAW MATERIALS IN PEACE AND WAR, by Eugene Staley. (Council on Foreign Relations, $3.) A timely analysis.

Announcement has been made of the marriage yesterday at Petersham, Mass., of Mrs. Choate Perkins to Duncan Spencer of New York. Mrs. Spencer is the former Josephine Choate of Southboro and the daughter of the late Charles F. and

If he can get away from Hollywood long enough, George Cukor will be back on Broadway in the latter part of August to direct Tallulah Bankhead in "Anthony and Cleopatra," which Rowland Stebbins hopes to present early in September. . . Virginia Bruce has

Albert W. Barber, Cordle M. Williams house at 207 Hartsdale Rd. White Plains, Westchester; Richard Morcillo Morales, Saul Katz house in 4 Fairfield St, White Plains; Milton Krieger, in 544 Milton Rd, Rye; Rostenberg Associates. Inc. broker.

Seventeen thousand oil workers were ordered this evening by the strike an committee to return to work at noon tomorrow. Before this order was issued, however, new coals were added to the serious political fire lighted by the way in which the strike negotiations had been handied.

Thomas Ashurst, British employers' delegate to the International Labor Organization conference, announced today in the textile committee that all the employer delegates except the American and the French had agreed to refuse to discuss the draft convention before the committee for a forty-hour week in the textile industry.

The "retailers' platform" or "little NRA for retailing," which has been worked on for the last four months by the Platform Commission of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, was unanimously approved yesterday by the executive committee of the board of directors at a meeting at the association's headquarters here.

Contracts have been awarded by the Navy Department today for the propulsion machinery for four submarines now under construction. A contract for the machinery for two submarines being built at New London, Conn.,
New York City's supply of canned and cold storage food is in danger of being shut off by a teamster strike which began on Monday and threatened yesterday to spread to the longshoremen.

Manufacturers of certain lines of men's furnishings, such as cotton hosiery and knitted woolen gloves, are pressing retailers to take in at this time goods scheduled for Fall delivery, with the result that buyers are somewhat puzzled by their actions. One hosiery mill,

The first refrigerated airplanes in the world will be put into service next month by Northwest Airlines, it ws announced here yesterday by A. P. Werner, New York representative of the line, which operates between Chicago and Seattle.

WASHINGTON, June 8.--A formal protest against the refusal of postoffice officials to accept food and other shipments for delivery in strike-bound steel plants of the Middle West was addressed to Postmaster General Farley today by the Republic Steel Corporation.

The seventy - seventh annual commencement of the Academy of St. Elizabeth was held here today, with Mrs. Josephine Toomey McAniff, a graduate of the College of St. Elizabeth, as the speaker. Bishop Thomas J. Walsh of the Newark diocese of the Roman Catholic Church conferred the honors on the senior class and addressed the graduates.
Joseph Fishbach of New York-won the New Jersey Center Junior singles tennis championship today by defeating Melvin Schwartzman of New York in the final round, 6-3, 6-2, 6-3.

Arthur Horace Knight, art expert and connoisseur of furniture, died today at Bournemouth. His age was 56. As a partner in the famous house of Knight, Frank Rutley, with which he was associated for forty years, he sold millions of pounds'
The entire Union of South Africa was shocked today by the disclosure that the government broadcasting agency had put over a hoax in the Coronation Day program.

Ground will be broken tomorrow on a twelve-acre site on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers for the erection of the new $400,000 Home of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind. Five units will comprise the project. The Gotham Construction Corporation is the builder. William P. Katz, Inc., and Lewis R. Kaufman are the architects.

Throughout America today there is apparent an "absence of thoughtful men in places where thoughtfulness is urgently needed," Dr. John L. Tildsley, Associate Superintendent of Schools of New York City, told the graduates in his commencement address at Wagner Memorial Luthecran College on Grymes Hill, Stapleton, S. I., yesterday afternoon.

A. I. Namm Son, operator of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, is notifying holders of the company's 6 per cent first-mortgage sinkingfund certificates that the board of directors has authorized an issue of $800,000 of 6 per cent serial sinking-fund debenture bonds, in coupon form, to mature in 1947, which will be issuable only in exchange for present mortgage certificates or for portions thereof.

Paul G. Friedmann, a member of the New York Curb Exchange and a partner in the brokerage firm of Friedmann Torney, 1 Wall Street, died yesterday morning in the Harkness Pavilion of the Medical Center after an illness of five months. He was 46 years old.

Doctors must approach their work with a passionate devotion to truth and must remember that the physician is a public servant, members of the graduating class of New York Medical College and Flower Hospital were told last night by the Rev. Dr. Remsen Brinckerhoff Ogilby, president of Trinity College, Hartford. Conn.
The Boston Red Sox landed on three Cleveland pitchers for seven hits and eight runs in the ninth inning today to win, 10 to 8, what appeared an inning earlier to be a hopelessly lost game.

So far as the immediate issues of the steel strike are concerned, the Roosevelt Administration is pursuing a hands-off policy. The President has referred to the National Labor Relations Board a request for intervention filed with him by various local unions.

The first annual dinner of the builders and real estate division of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities was held last night at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Abraham Fox, chairman of the division, presided. Among the guests were Building Commissioner Fassler of Manhattan, Edwin H. Thatcher.

The largest volume of business in twelve years, from the standpoint of both dollar and unit volume, is expected by piano manufacturers this year, according to reports submitted yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Piano Manufacturers Association of America, Inc., at the Hotel New Yorker.

Lawrence Marx sailed his Alberta to victory in the international onedesign class yacht race held today off the Larchmont Yacht Club. In winning the second of a series of weekly Wednesday competitions, Alberta finished 20 seconds ahead of Robert Shields's Canvasback, the runner-up. Miss Margey Bavier's Frolic crossed the line third.

Peter B. Bradley, '38, of Pelham, N. Y., outstanding middle-distance runner, will captain Princeton University's varsity track team for the 1938 season, it was announced today by Matty Geis, varsity track coach. The stellar junior succeeds John N. Irwin 2d of Keokuk, Iowa.

Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath arrived here today from Belgrade, Yugoslavia, on his tour of Southeastern European capitals. He was received by George Kiosseivanoff, the Premier and Foreign Minister; by representatives

State Trooper Joseph A. Perry, attached to the Malaga Barracks of the State Police, died in Newcomb Hospital here today of injuries suffered Sunday night in an automobile accident. He was 37 years of age. He was riding his motorcycle

The tumult and the shouting over KIPLING'S famous line in the "Recessional" continues-or continue-to echo pleasantly in this office. Perhaps this grammatical issue does not stir as much controversy as the enlargement of the Supreme Court or the organizational methods of the C. I. O., but it inspired scores of letters to THE TIMES.

Two thousand factory employes of Johnson Johnson, surgical goods manufacturers, will receive vacation with pay this year, it was announced today by Robert W. Johnson, president of the firm. From Saturday, July 24, until Monday, Aug. 2, according to Mr. Johnson's announcement, the plant will be closed.

Churchill Downs - Latonia, Inc., lopped four days off its thirtyseven-day racing schedule for the .Latonia race track today, declaring in an official statement that betting competition offered by hand books and pool rooms had resulted in large deficits for each of the last five years.
Delegates to the national convention of the American Institute of Banking who are quartered in the twelvestory strike-bound Hotel Lowry were their own chambermaids today. They borrowed brooms, mops

An eight-room house at 110 Pelhamdale Avenue, Pelham, was bought by Robert L. Bosworth in a deal arranged by Chauncey B. Griffen, broker, who also sold the house at 16 Mitchell Place for the Bowery Savings Bank to a client.

Henry Moir, chairman of the finance committee and for many years president of the United States Life Insurance Company, died last night of a brain ailment at Strong Memorial Hospital, Rochester, N. Y., where he underwent an operation on May 22. He was 66 years old and had resided at 364 Park Street, here.

Police Commissioner VALENTINE is considered in well - informed quarters a very good police chief, so it is hard to say whether he would be a still better Police Commissioner if he did not make so many startling remarks in public. But he would
Aroused by a proposal before the Senate to grant amnesty to all wartime prisoners,. 400 Belgian war veterans protested today by showering the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier with their medals.
Basil James brought Cross S., E. F. Woodward's Valdina Farm entry, from far back to score in the Grade B Handicap, best offering on today's card at Washington Park.

All the properties of the Thomas A. Clarke estate in East Northport consisting of 102 building lots and thirty-eight acres were purchased by Walter C. Hewitt from the Bank of Manhattan Company and Edward Keogh, trustees. J. Edward

Mrs. Juliet Tuttle, wealthy widow of 1 Park Avenue, Larchmont, and 16 Park Avenue, Manhattan, was found guilty tonight of poisoning a German shepherd owned by Rosswell B. Milligan of 12 Forbes Boulevard, Eastchester, on May 15.

A lull hung over the Oakland Hills Golf Club course tonight as 167 golfers, pros and amateurs, awaited the call to arms tomorrow morning when the forty-first national open championship gets under way.

A small man, described as wearing a dark suit and a light hat, was sought today as the lone, armed and masked bandit who hijacked the Citizens Bank here yesterday of $800 in cash and fled in an automobile. He forced three bank

Fifteen WPA recreation teachers, who helped direct a child program depicting oppression in Germany, Spain and Italy, were withdrawn by WPA authorities yesterday from Madison House, a lower East Side settlement, where the "international festival" was presented last Friday.

Trenholm Marshall and Dr. George E. Vincent will be the principal speakers tomorrow at the fortysixth commencement of Rosemary Hall. The day is known as Prize Day. Miss Caroline Ruutz-Rees, founder and head mistress of Rosemary, will present the diplomas and Miss Mary Elizabeth Lowndes. headmistress with Miss Ruutz-Rees, the prizes.
Miss Anna L. Dawes gave a luncheon today at the Pittsfield Country Club in honor of the Rev. Dr. Edward Russell Bourne of Sheffield, who earlier in the day addressed Lhe Wednesday Morning Club.

Mrs. John C. Baker won three blue ribbons and five reds today to gain the sweepstakes prize in the joint flower show held annually by the Great Neck Garden Club, the Great Neck Center Garden Club and the garden department of the Woman's Club.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt shook hands with 16,650 persons at the White House last year. The official usher reported tonight that 652,735 sight-seers viewed the Executive Mansion, 130,547 at the request of representatives and Senator.

An emergency assessment of 1 cent from each member every month has been requested by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to help build up the federation's war. reserves in its fight with the C. I. O.

Police Captain John G. Stein, 57 years old, of 209-04 111th Avenue, Hollis, Queens, who is in charge of the Missing Persons Bureau at police headquarters, was reported in a serious condition yesterday at the Van Wyck Hospital, Woodhaven, from injuries he received in an automobile accident on Hollis Court Boulevard Tuesday night.

A 50year-old Negro who sold his children's three bottles of milk to buy liquor was sentenced here today to go without food for three days, to "suffer like your kiddies and see how it feels to go hungry." Recorder Thomas D. Taggart Jr. imposed the unusual penalty in police court, forbidding food the first three days of a nine months' term in the Atlantic County jail.

Holding companies in the railroad field should be abolished, Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said yesterday. He elaborated this statement by saying he meant no new holding companies should be formed, and also that the present ones should be liquidated or disposal made of their securities.

Mayor La Guardia expressed a hearty greeting from the city yesterday to fifteen members of the Japanese Economic Mission when he received them at City Hall. "Your commission will be useful not only in furthering trade and commerce between the two countries," the Mayor said, "but, what

Daily hearings are under way before the Senate Labor Committee on the Administration Labor Relations Bill in the hope of bringing it to the floor Friday. The measure passed the House of Representatives last Friday by a vote of 63 to 31. Few amendments were made in the House.
Miss Margaret E. Park, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Park of this place, was married tonight to J. Paul Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Walker Wilson of Beaver Falls, Pa. The ceremony was performed

Graduating cadets of the United States Military Academy who have done superior work will receive prizes tomorrow after marching in regimental parade. June week, which has drawn several thousand alumni, relatives and friends of cadets to the academy, will end Saturday with the graduation ceremonies.

Before a midweek crowd of 16,500, Spindletop from the Miss A. Doris barn, got up in the final strides of a three-horse blanket finish today to win the Betsy Ross Stakes for juveniles at Suffolk Downs by a head and pay the good price of $38.20 for a $2 mutuel ticket.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 10--The Planning Board has been instructed to draft plans for the creation of a new government department dealing with the national health.

Pollution of the Hudson River along the Westchester County shore was attributed today to seven villages, Sing Sing Prison at Ossining and the New York Central Railroad yards at Harmon by James L. Barron. director of sanitation for the Westchester County Health Department. He spoke at a public hearing conducted by the Interstate Sanitation Commission in the county office building here.

Scoring her second round of 78 in one day, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring won the women's Eastern golf championship in a play-off with Mrs. W. H. Beard of Charles River at the Plainfield C. C. today. The two tied at the

Speaking today at the final session of the conference of women of the New York State Democratic Committee, Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, asserted that "misleading" headlines in newspapers concerning the strike situation had spread unnecessary terrorism.

The Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill as at present drawn provides for annual subsidies to be appropriated over a period of sixty years. These subsidies are designed to meet the difference between the income necessary to sustain the slum clearance and low-cost housing projects contemplated and the rents that those in the lower income brackets can afford to pay.

The Indians and Red Sox, playing the only game which the weather permitted in the American League today, put on a twenty-five-hit sluggoing match and the Indians won, 12 to 6, without much difficulty.

While incomplete reports show that at least 1,000,000 workers received wage increases between March 16 and April 15 of this year, the Department of Commerce said today that manufacturing output was maintained at a relatively high rate during May and continued progress was shown 10: by the durable goods industry to compensate for slackening in other lines.

The marriage of Miss Aimee Belle Loeb, daughter of Mrs. Otto Loeb; of 140 West Seventy-ninth Street and the late Mr. Loeb, to Joseph ' Norman Kaplan, son of Abraham Kaplan of 275 Central Park West, former State Senator and president of the Municipal Civil Service Comn mission, and the late Mrs. Kaplan, took place last night at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfifth Street. The Rev. Dr. Samuell Goldenson performed the ceremony.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, an investment trust, lost more than $92,000,000 on certain investments on the West Coast.

Two of America's leading speedboat drivers, forming the vanguard of an invasion of Europe for the Spreckels Trophy and other regatta rewards, sailed yesterday on the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines with a good many thousand dollars' worth of

Officials of the Intercollegiate Polo Association announced yesterday the five line-ups for the college championship, which starts Saturday, with Yale meeting Princeton at Governors Island. They also announced the appointment of Thomas Brady as chief umpire.
Mayor Harold H. Burton got a personal taste of violence in the steel strike late today when he visited the Republic Steel Corporation's airplane base here.

Dr. Henry Louis Hilgartner Sr. of Austin, Texas, distinguished ophthalmologist, otolaryngologist and surgeon, attending the annual American Medical Association convention here, died of a heart attack in his sleep early today at the Hotel Chelsea at the age of 68.

One hundred and twenty seniors were graduated from La Salle Academy at the school's eightyninth commencement last night at the Town Hall. The class was the first to be graduated from Salle's new building at Second Avenue and Second Street.

As a gesture of protest by an independent private citizen, four cans of fine boneless Portuguese sardines addressed to two men in the strikebound Ohio plants of the Republic Steel Corporation, were put in the mail yesterday at the Grand Central Terminal by Dwight Scovel of Hopewell, N. J.

Maria Matyas, Chicago mezzo-soprano, was married on June 1 in Washington to Dr. Elkin C. Wilson, former Northwestern University Professor of English, who is now on the faculty of Columbia University, relatives here announced. They are now in Miami.

The Bureaw of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 7: CAPTAINS Goss, N. H., Naval War College, Newport R. I., to duty as commander of Destroye Squadron 10. Van Mater, R. E., Aircraft, Base Forceq about Jan. 1, ordered home, relieved frog all active duty; orders of March 28 revoked.
Some 2,200 automobile workers were made idle today by a sit-down strike caused by a dispute over a nonunion employee on the trim line in which the upholstery work is done in the Fisher Body factory.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Kast of Glendale, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Corinne Marie Kast, to Frederick L. Cumming Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Cumming, also of Glendale.

A strike called by the Department Store Employes Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, in Alexander's department store at Fordham Road and Grand Concourse, the Bronx, resulted yesterday in the arrest of twelve persons, but failed to halt sales for more than a few minutes. Four of those arrested were connected with the store management.

The Imperial Airways' long-range flying boat Caledonia is due next week at Foynes, at the mouth of the River Shannon, the eastern terminal of the proposed transatlantic air service, and the first North Atlantic trial crossing is expected June 24.

The mad antics of two Capuchin monkeys, Pete and Hombre, on the fire escape of a five-story apartment building at Broadway and Seventy-eighth Street last night attracted a crowd of more than 2,000 persons, blocked traffic and taxed the agility and patience of a dozen patrolmen who were summoned to retrieve the simians and clear the traffic.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on May 29 amounted to 305,745,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today. Compared with a week before, this total represents a net increase of 774,000 barrels, comprising an increase of 884,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude and a decline of 110,000 in foreign crude.

Awards to contributors to The Packer Current Items, publication of Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, were made yesterday by Miss Florence Mackie, editor-in-chief. Recipients of prizes for prose contributions were Miss Jean Lyons, Miss Nancy Farrington and Miss Shirley Levittan. Miss Mackie won first prize for poetry and Miss Cynthia Vernan received honorable mention.

Announcement of two new trophies to be contested at the Country Club Horse Show was made yesterday at a luncheon given at the Biltmore Hotel. Hosts were Richard C. Heather, chairman, and Mrs. Reed A. Albee, vice chairman, of the show committee.

Temple University ended an intensive week of pre-commencement activities tonight with dinners of the alumni of the Schools of Medicine, Pharmacy, Dentistry -and Chiropody. Graduates -of all departments participated in an "all alumni" field day and outing, while Dental School graduates attended clinics during part of the day.
Sixty-five employes of the Pechter Baking Company, who have been on a sit-down strike since last Saturday, were compelled last night to evacuate the company's three plants because of heat and hunger.

A youth charged with teaching younger boys to set fires to enable him to loot temporarily deserted apartments was in police custody yesterday after three boys described "safe" methods of incendiarism he allegedly taught them.

Miss Josephine Sanfilippo, 15year-old first-seeded player, entered the third round of the metropolitan district girls' junior tennis championship as competition began yesterday on the courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club. After drawing a bye in the opening bracket, Miss Sanfilippo scored easily over Miss Rita Silberstein, 6--2, 6--0.

He likes to do the chores on Summer nights; Filling the mangers with the clover hay, Bedding the boxstall for the day-old calf; Finishing tasks left over from the day. He listens to the horses crunching corn, And pauses, pail in hand, beside the door

Sons of men of prominence were among the 141 young men and young women who received diplomas at the commencement exercises of Deerfield Academy today. Heading the class as president was Robert M. Morgenthau, son of Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, and Mrs. Morgenthau. Besides his father and

The International Olympic Committee today decided to hold the 1940 Winter Olympic Games at Sapporo, Japan, and by a majority vote fixed August as the month for the other competitions, including track and field. Today's discussion revolved around

The first inkling that Consolidated Edison Company of New York intended to take steps to eliminate its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, by merging it into the system was given out at the parent company's annual meeting a few months ago by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman.

Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, will offer a motion in the Senate tomorrow for acceptance of House amendments to the resolution calling for appointment of a joint Congressional committee to make the investigation, proposed by President Roosevelt, of income tax evasion and avoidance by some wealthy taxpayers.
A plea for "moderation" in union activities was made by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a letter to the Seattle Construction Council today. The letter said:

Retail deliveries increased 1 per cent in the metropolitan and suburban area for the week ended June 5, the United Parcel Service reported yesterday. The smallness of the increase, in view of the sharp rise in retail trade last week, was due to the effect of the holiday upon deliveries and the full effect of the upswing in trade is expected to be shown in the figures for the present week.

The semi-final bracket of the Long Island Center junior tennis championship was filled yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club as Joe Fishbach and Bernard Jacoby, seeded first and second respectively, earned berths.

A legal battle between Haile Selassie, self-exiled Emperor of Ethiopia, and Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy was begun here today when the Negus instructed two Paris attorneys to sue in the French courts to uphold his possession of about $1,500,000 in stock in the French-owned JibutiAddis Ababa railroad.

The gold medal of the American Medical Association, given annually "for scientific exhibits of individual investigations which are judged on the basis of originality and excellence of presentation," was presented here today to Drs. Leonard G. Rowntree, Arthur Steinberg, N. H. Einhorn, J. H. Clark, George M. Dorrance and E. F. Ciccone of Philadelphia and Dr. A. M. Hanson of Faribault, Minn.

A program in memory of Richard Aldrich and William J. Henderson, music critics who died last week, was broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network last night. The NBC String Symphony Orchestra, directed by Frank Black, played a varied program which included a Sarabande and a Chorale Prelude of Bach.

Dorothy Rizzo, 3 1/2-month-old daughter of a Queens WPA worker, died yesterday in her home, a small store with some rooms in the rear at 223-07 147th Avenue, Springfield. Dr. John McNamara of the ambulance service at St. Joseph's Hospital expressed the opinion that malnutrition was responsible for the infant's death but declined to make an official diagnosis until an autopsy had been performed.

Walter O. Briggs, president of the Detroit Baseball Club, announced today that at Manager Mickey Cochrane's request the Tiger leader had been removed from the active player roster and will be carried as a non-playing manager.

Funeral services for Representative Philip A. Goodwin of Coxsackie, held this afternoon in the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Coxsackie, were attended by Senator Royal S. Copeland and Senator Robert F. Wagner. Mr. Goodwin died on Sunday.

Passengers arriving today from Mediterranean ports on the Italian motor Conte di Savoia include Charles G. Norris and his wife, Kathleen Norris, novelists; J. H. Reynolds, Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Tompkins, Miss Annie Hageman, Miss Beatrice Johnson, George Martin, Richard Hammond, Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Spencer, Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Mitton, John Crosby and Mr. and Mrs. D. T. Kiley.

Admiral Michael Pelham O'Callaghan, who served in the British Navy for forty-three years and possessed a remarkable flair for training cadets, died at his home, Deerleap Green, Hampshire, at the age of 86.
When the du Ponts say a wedding is going to be private they mean it, and they have made these preparations for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt-Ethel du Pont marriage on the afternoon of June 30:

Rutgers seniors donned caps and gowns today for the. Class Day exercises which opened five days of Senior Week ceremonies to culminate in the one hundred and seventy-first commencement of the men's colleges at the 'university, Sunday afternoon.

Dr. Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to attend a meeting in Valencia of Loyalist Ambassadors and Ministers that has been called by the government.
A duel is in prospect between Maitre Jean-Charles Le Grand, one of France's leading criminal lawyers, and Prosecutor Verne of the city of Valence.

The stenographic record of the Parker conspiracy trial reached 1,000,000 words today as attorneys on both sides continued to predict, as they have every day this week, that Ellis H. Parker Sr. will be called "tomorrow" to testify in his own behalf in the seventh week of the trial.

Political stubbornness and hypocrisy on the part of the Transit Commission, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday, are responsible for balking his efforts to remove the Sixth Avenue elevated line and pave the way for comprehensive rebuilding and development of the thoroughfare.

Edward H. Wilson, trustee of the Brooklyn Bar Association and former counsel for its grievance committee, and Assistant District Attorney John J. Kean of Brooklyn were directed yesterday by Kings County Surrogate George Albert Wingate to pay $29,305 to the estate of Joseph Auditore, wealthy
William Cardinal O'Connell conferred 442 degrees at the commencement exercises of Boston College this afternoon, on Alumni Field, University Heights.
An issue of $40,000,000 of New York State bonds, originally scheduled for sale on May 19 by Controller Morris S. Tremaine, will be sold on June 22, it was announced late yesterday.

Sir Robert Borden, Canada's Prime Miniter throughout the World War, was in "grave" condition tonight, his medical attendants said. Signs of "acute cardiac failure," they said; became evident late in the day.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the Middlewest Service Company for exemption from making a declaration in connection with the issue and delivery to the Middle West Corporation of an unsecured 4 per cent

Degrees to 171 members of the graduating class and certificates to seven secretarial students will be awarded here tomorrow night at the third annual commencement of the University of Newark in the Mosque Theatre. Dr. George H. Nettleton, Lamson Professor of English at Yale University, will be the commencement speaker.

The preparation of a bill extending the prerogatives of the Regent, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, has evoked united efforts by the Opposition to persuade Premier Koloman Daranyi to modify it in order to protect the rights of Parliament.

The outcry against the government's proposals for reorganization of the electrical industry has become so shrill that the City [the financial district] feels confident Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain will abandon the plan, just as he dropped the tax on growth of profits a week ago.

With the most favorable early June weekly weather report in several years, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke into new low ground yesterday and ended with losses of 13 to 20 points. All months but March and May dipped below 12 cents a pound when a selling movement uncovered stop-loss orders and carried prices off $1.50 a bale from the early figures.

The United Licensed Officers Association announced last night that It had been designated the spokesman of a majority of the officers of the New York Cuba Mail Steamship Company vessels as their bargaining agency in labor matters. In the deck department twentyseven officers voted for the United and three designated the National Association of Masters, Mates and Pilots. In the engineering department the United received thirty-four votes and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association six.

Paul Block, newspaper publisher, 'appealed to college graduates today to save 'democracy from machinery which, he said, was being set up to give the President the powers of a dictator. He spoke at commencement exercises at St. Francis College, which conferred upon him the honorary degree of Doctor of Literature.

Two men were seriously injured and another man and a woman also were hurt last night when strikers hurled bricks into a private bus taking thirty employes home from work at the factory of the Art Crayon Company, 25-31 Thirty-sixth Street, South Brooklyn.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 500,000 shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock, the net proceeds from the sale of which will be used to supplement the company's general funds.

Howland Pell of New York and Tuxedo died today of a heart attack on the beach at Wampage Shores, off the S. Hillen MacSherry estate. His age was 81. He had been out fishing in a rowboat with his chauffeur and was coming ashore for luncheon. He was stricken as he stepped from the boat.

Harvard University announced today awards totaling $18,000 for study abroad during the next academic year. They included these: Coolidge Fellowship, for Study of History-Robert 0. Schaifer,- Santa Monica, Calif. Harvard-Yenching Institute Fellowships for Chinese Studies-Paul K. Benedict, Poughkeepsie; Francis W. Cleaves, Needham Heights, Mass.; John A. Pope, Detroit; Edwin 0. Reischauer, Iogimachi, Tokyo. Fu. Japan.

Spokesmen for three branches of the wool industry differed before a Senate subcommittee today on specific provisions of a "truth-infabric" bill after agreeing that legislation was needed "to protect consumers as much as the industry itself."

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday authorized Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Transit Company, to pay the regular semi-annual interest installment on the company's 5 per cent gold bonds, amounting to $5,581,650, and to meet sinking fund requirements on the same securities in the sum of $1,116,330. Both are due July 1.

Yale has sold exclusive radio broadcasting rights for next Fall's home football games in Yale Bowl to the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, it was announced yesterday. This marks the continuation by the university of a policy inaugurated for the first time last Fall, permitting commercially sponsored broadcasts of the games.

Directors of the Lehman Corporation declared yesterday on its new stock a special dividend of $1.50 a share and an initial quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share, both payable on June 23 to stock of record of June 14. just before the close of the fiscal year.

A dude ranch romance which culminated in the marriage six years ago of Virginia Naumburg, daughter of a New York banker, and Jesse Langston, a Livingston cowboy, ended in the divorce courts here. Mrs. Langston,. a daughter of George W. Naumburg

The Kolynos Company, New Haven, Conn., manufacturer of tooth paste, was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to "cease and desist" from allegedly false and misleading representations in its advertising.
Arthur O. McKenna, 52 years old, of 114 Roosevelt Avenue, here, was killed this evening by a southbound passenger train at the Broad Street grade crossing of the West Shore Railroad. Mr. McKenna,

In the dull trading that has persisted in the stock market these many weeks, about the only distinguishing characteristic of individual days has to do with whether prices manage to close irregularly higher or lower. Yesterday's closing happened to be slightly lower.

The British Government today blamed Spanish Insurgents for the mine the British destroyer Hunter hit off Almeria May 13, causing the death of eight of her crew and injuries to twenty-four. A formal protest was dispatched to Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

The marriage of Miss Eline Hoist, daughter of Willem Hoist of 19 East Seventy-first Street and the late Mrs. Hoist, to Maxwell Stewart McKnight, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Stewart McKnight of Great Neck, L. I., and Miami Beach, Fla., took place on Tuesday at Chatham Hall, Chatham, Va., where the bride has been an art instructor.

Despite some demerits, the Robinson-Patman Act is the most definite of all Federal legislation designed to promote fair competition, and with its recommendations for the improvement of business methods is sound and practical, Charles J. Brand, secretary, declared at the closing session of the convention here today of the National Fertilizer Association.

Efforts by the Bank of England to have the dominions' central banks take over some of the excess gold supply, garnered here as in the United States by stabilization operations, have figured largely in the conference of bank governors that is being held simultaneously with the Imperial Conference.

Bowery, 266, 16.6x98.9; Rozalle Gross to Gold Electric Sign Co, 266 Bowery; mtg, $108.000 (50z). Water St, 273, s e s, 24.6x73. mtg. $10,000, also Water St, 275, s e s, 24.6x72.S. mtg, $20,000; Elise H. Schlegal to Henrietta Zibell at Roosevelt, L. I., one-seventh interest.

Grand Ave, 2,264 (11-3196); Bitlis Realty Corp to Bowery Saving Bank, extends mtgs to April 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $76,500. Park View Terrace (12-3318), e s, 325 ft of Wellesley St, 75x125; Newbo Realty Corp to Morris Morgenstern, 286 Fort Washington Ave. one year, 6 per cent building loan; $115,000.

The first phonographic recordings for scientific use of the "language" of the gibbon, "key" ape in the theories of the evolution of mankind, have been obtained this Spring in the mountain forests of Northern Siam by a field party from Harvard and Johns Hopkins Universities and Bard College, according to word just received here.

Under a penetrating sun that roughtheat prostrations to eighteen f its 15,000 commencement spectaors, New York University conerred 4,098 degrees in course, eight honorary degrees, seventy certifiates and seven alumni awards yeserday in a violet and white bordered mphitheatre on University Heights.

The situation on the Cordoba front, where the Rebels launched a heavy attack yesterday, was veiled in obscurity today. No news had arrived from Andujar by this evening to indicate whether the drive continued or whether, indeed, it was a genuine offensive.

MARIENWERDER, East Prussia, June 9.--Chancellor Adolf Hitler is scheduled to address 600 of his oldest and most trusted followers on Polish frontier problems here June 19. Dramatically he has chosen for his important party conference this town of 14,000 inhabitants near the Free City of Danzig.

St. John's University, in Brooklyn, closed its commencement yesterday in the Brooklyn Academy of Music with exercises for 392 graduates of the School of Law and 238 graduates of the School of Commerce. The School of Law held

PATROLMEN-Herman Hunter, from 9th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad Manhattan, assigned to duty with Midtown Squad. Richard Wood, from Emergency Service Squad 10 to 123d Precinct. William L. Egan. from 2d Division to 18th Division, designated as third grade detective. Assignment to duty as shau feur discontinued.

Thity-seven States, including New York, have received Federal aid grants amounting to $14,405,909, all but four of which are for old age assistance, which accounts for $13,599,947 of the total, the Social Security Board announced today.

Jay Cooke, investment banker, was elected chairman of the Republican City Committee today, after months of discussion and bickering among party leaders. Edwin R. Cox, whom he succeeds and who announced some time ago that he would not seek reelection, was defeated at his ward executive committee election on Monday night for a place on the committee.

A testimonial dinner was given for the Rev. John M. J. Quinn, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, the Bronx, and for many years assistant pastor at St. Patrick's Cathedral, at the Hotel Commodore last night. It marked the twenty-fifth anniversary of Father Quin's ordination.

Rural Georgia voters tonight had kept the State in the prohibition column as complete, unofficial returns in yesterday's referendum showed 94,652 for repeal and 102,929 against. As reports from outlying districts poured in, repealists saw a lead of 9,000 swept away and the drys forge to the front when 130,000 votes had been counted.

Pope Plus again referred today to the difficult German religious situation in an address to a pilgrimage from Bavaria at the papal villa at Castel Gandolfo. "The situation in Catholic Germany," he said, "is not only grave but lamentable. It is so grave,

Bishop William Appleton Lawrence of Western Massachusetts will give the commencement address at the exercises marking the anniversary of the Berkeley Divinity School of the Episcopal Church tomorrow. Bishop Frederick Grandy Budlong of Connecticut will preside.

Several apartment houses changed hands in deals in Brooklyn real estate reported by brokers yesterday. The six-story house at 4,701 Fifteenth Avenue, on the southwest corner of Forty-seventh Street, was bought by David S. Meister from the Prudential Insurance Company.
A brief and simple funeral service was held today for Jean Harlow in a suburban chapel overflowing with flowers. The service in the Wee Kirk o' the Heather lasted only twenty minutes.

Williams ?. Ganbarg was elected president of the Alumni Association of the College of Pharmacy of Fordham University at the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the association last night at the Pharmacy Building on the campus. Other officers were: Dominick Forlizzo, vice president; Reuben Cheron, secretary, and Dr. Otto F. Canis, treasurer.

The Seventy-seventh Division will hold a twentieth anniversary reunion dinner at the Hotel Riverside Plaza, 253 West Seventy-third Street, on Sept. 22, it was announced last night at a meeting of the directors of the Seventy-seventh Division Association at 28 East

A dispute arising over the discharge of 150 men at the Somerville plant of the Ford Motor Company will go to the National Labor Relations Board as a result of today's rejection of a settlement offer made by plant officials.
Ireland's champion Mayo Gaelic football team scored an easy 19-to-9 victory over a picked all-Americanborn fifteen at Innisfail Park last night before 2,000 persons.

Miss Nancy Lyle of England eliminated Miss Katherine Winthrop of Boston, 6-2, 6-2, in the second round of the Beckenham tennis tournament today. Miss Alice Marble, United States champion, was forced to

Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, will address the graduates of Berkeley Institute at the fifty-first commencement exercises to-night at the Memorial Presbyterian church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn.

Mayor La Guardia flew into a brief flurry of anger yesterday at news that three salary increases, including one for himself, had been recommended for the Mayor's office by Budget Director Leo J. McDermott, but his wrath abated when Mr. McDermott explained

High humidity made the weather oppressive yesterday. The percentage of moisture content ranged in the 90s early in the morning, the 70s between 3 and 10 A. M., the 60s until noon and between 55 and 60 during the afternoon.

The proposal of Senator Bridges to investigate the alleged censoring and interference with the United States mails in the Warren and Niles steel strike zone in Ohio may be broadened into a Senatorial inquiry of the conduct of both sides in the strike.

The cheerfulness of the stock market here today was somewhat dampened by the small volume of business that was done, although the general tendency was firm. Gilt-edge issues were weak, but among the foreign loans German bonds were strong. Interntaional shares were well supported; United States Steel and International Nickel advanced.

State, county and municipal officials and a number of New Jersey bankers today attended a reception at the National State Bank of Newark in honor of the institution's 125th anniversary. The affair was held in the Robert Treat Hotel.

Unrest among labor is "nothing essentially new or unusual," Governor Murphy of Michigan said tonight in an address at the commencement at Duquesne University. "It is simply an acute manifestation of labor's long struggle to protect itself by a larger share of its own product and to escape the haunting fear of insecurity by consolidating itself in its job," he said.

Arguing against the forty-hour week, Alexander Goldie, Canadian employers' delegate, told the International Labor Conference today that "the workers must choose between increased income and increased leisure."
Claude Passeau ended a six-game losing streak for the Phillies today, pitching his teammates to an 8-to-1 victory over the Pirates for his fifth victory of the season against seven defeats.

The Rev. William Walker, retired rector of St. Peter's Church here, died today at the age of 91. He was brought here from New York Monday, after being taken ill while on his way from St. Petersburg, Fla.

Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for a Summer vacation in Europe. Speaking of the outlook for women college graduates Miss Gildersleeve said that the chances of getting jobs are now much better.

Several airplane parties have gone into the new gold discovery area in the Lac La Ronge district, 200 miles north of here, it was reported today after Adolph Studer, a homesteader who turned prospector, said that the British Columbia Government assayist at Nelson, B. C., had put the value on his gold from $11.05 to $105.35 a ton.

Pope Plus XI received today at his villa here a group of American priests, the directors of the Catholic Press Association and a group of 200 newlyweds. He gave a special blessing to the priests, graduating students of the American College in Rome, who were accompanied by the Rev.
The government cleared the way today for a handwriting expert's opinion on the authorship of ransom notes penned by. the abductors of John J. O'Connell Jr. of Albany.

Syracuse made it two straight over Jersey City today and swept the series when it took the final game, 5 to 1. Leo Mangum and Frank Pearce divided the Syracuse pitching and limited the Little Giants to five hits.

Strikes at the plants - of three major steel companies have caused no further reduction in the aggregate volume of ingot output, according to Iron Age, which says that "on the contrary, there have been gains at some unaffected plants, bringing the estimated average for the country to 78 per cent, a slight rise over last week."

In a run-off election for president of Typographical Union No. 6, held at union headquarters, 24 West Sixteenth Street, since yesterday morning, and scheduled to continue until noon today, the race between William Ward, seeking re-election, and Elmer Brown, opposing him, was extremely close early this morning. It will be necessary to hear from the fourteen remaining chapels before the outcome will be known.

Colored pavements which will make women seem more beautiful and men appear more romantic were promised today by J. E. Stanton, a color expert for San Francisco's 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition. It is not a trick with mirrors, according to Mr. Stanton, who knows all about such things, but merely a matter of reflected light.

Serious labor troubles in this city as a result of Mayor La Guardia's sympathetic attitude toward labor were foreseen yesterday by Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, who wrote to the Mayor asking him to refrain from "employer-baiting."

The letter from Colonel LINDBERGH that President ATWOOD read at Clark University's commencement exercises tells the world nothing new about rockets or their possibilities, yet calls for comment because of its confident note. Let the mind drift back,

Sentiment for more liberal Federal financing of flood control projects developed today in the House Flood Control Committee. Representative Whittington, Democrat, of Mississippi, the chairman, expressed belief that, unless present regulations requiring local communities to pay land and damage costs on such projeca were relaxed,

J. P. Morgan, who gave an interview aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary on Monday saying that if Congress does not know how to collect taxes a man is a fool to pay them, issued the following statement yesterday:

Dewey Bentham, owner of Abner, who won yesterday's featured War Cloud Handicap at Aqueduct, was more than generous with the information that he was confident his 5-year-old son of The Porter would win. The horse had been out eight

A wave of selling orders, coupled with a lack of bids, caused such a disorderly market in the 6 per cent and 7 per cent preferred issues of the New York Steam Corporation yesterday that specialists handling them were forced to obtain the consent of a governor of the New York Stock Exchange to delay the opening. Bid and asked prices were
James J. Braddock demonstrated convincingly today he was drawing near to a sharp edge for the defense of his world heavyweight championship.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today reported for ratification three conventions that were agreed upon and signed last December in Buenos Aires, Argentina, at the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

Wearied by the continual round of removing bricks to rescue cats from chimneys, the men of Police Emergency Squad 6 found a variation in the routine yesterday afternoon when they discovered that the object of their solicitude was, for a change, a human.

Giuseppe Bamboscheck, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera company, more recently with the Hippodrome Opera company, will direct the operetta productions at Jones Beach this Summer. Edward J. Scanlon will again be stage director.

Dr. John L. Elliott, senior leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, delivered the commencement address last night at the twenty-sixth graduation exercises of the School for Printers' Apprentices and the School for Machine Typesetting, 220 West Nineteenth Street.

A campaign to stamp out misleading advertising of linen handkerchiefs will be launched by the Linen Trade Association, a committee meeting yesterday at the group's offices here, decided. Handkerchiefs, half the content of which is cotton, are being widely advertised as French or Swiss linen, giving the impression that they are all linen.
Four constabulary detachments entered the Cagayan Province wilds tonight determined to end killings by a crazed head-hunter.
Sympathy for two kittens which strayed into her home resulted in the loss here today of jewels valued at $1,000 by Mrs. J. T. MacEvoy of Belmar.

Quinlan Leland have placed for the Fifty Park Terrace W Realty Corp, Pincus Weber, president, a 41/2 per cent first mortgage for S147,000 on the six-story apartment on the southeast corner of Park Terrace West and 215th St with a savings bank.

The Wagner Labor Act was invoked by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee here today in an appeal to the National Labor Relations Board that may determine the legal status of the strike of 70,000 workers in independent steel companies of seven States.

For the first time since hearings were begun nearly two weeks ago, the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill was denounced today from within the Joint Congressional Committee charged with its consideration.

Louis Bouche of New York has won a national competition among more than 300 artists for a mural painting in the auditorium of the new Interior Department Building. His design was the unanimous choice of the jury of award and was afterward approved by Secretary Ickes and Admiral C. J. Peoples, director of procurement in the Treasury Department. It brings a prize of $5,000.
Daniel P. Hays 2d of New York City, a Harvard sophomore, was found unconscious tonight in his. room at Lowell House from what doctors described as "an overdose of sleeping tablets."

An elevator running from the track platform of the lower level to the street level in Grand Central Terminal will be available to commuters beginning next Monday between 8 and 10 A. M., it was learned yesterday.

Lieutenant Carl O. Petersen, United States Naval Reserve, received the Distinguished Flying Cross yesterday for his "great coolness and courage" as radio operator with the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition.

The endorsement of the American Federation of Housing Authorities for the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill as it now stands, and opposition by the group to the capital-grant formula of the Treasury, for which President Roosevelt has indicated a preference, were laid before the President today by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority and president of the newly formed federation.

Patrolman Raymond Mulcahy, attached to the Amsterdam. Avenue station, reported to detectives of that precinct shortly after 1 A. M. today that he had been seized from behind by two Negroes at 164th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, and that they had knocked him down and escaped after taking his service revolver. The patrolman, off duty

Chinese government officials have been advised to give preference to automobiles equipped to use fuel oil and vegetable oils, the Commerce Department has been advised by the American Embassy at Nanking.

Trading improved on most classes or traefa meats. Lamb business was only fair, however, and some few cuts were extremely hard to move. Prices generally showed little change although some unevenness continued in steer and fresh pork cuts. Kosher meats opened steady to weak under a slow demand, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Inheritance. ancestral longevity, racial factors, urban life, occupations of a professional or business nature, overeating, excessive use of tobacco and increased nervous sensitivity and strain all figure prominently in Young persons afflicted with heart disease, but alcohol does not seem to play an important part.

COLONEL T. BENTLEY MOTT has spent much of his time companioning higher ranking army officers over the big bumps of their careers. General Pershing found that no member of all the A. E. F. was so effective at smoothing down a British general or a French politician to whom it was necessary to say no.
Juda Lejd Chasjielewicz, a Jewish laborer who a year ago shot Jan Bujak, an army sergeant, near Warsaw, was sentenced to death yesterday. He filed an appeal that will be heard in the Fall.

The city of Buenos Aires, Argentine Republic, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $13,500,000 of its sinking fund external conversion loan 4 1/2 per cent bonds.

Walking uncertainly through the ancient ceremonies, Stanley Baldwin today took his place among Britain's peers as Earl Baldwin of Bewdley. Thus after a generation of public life he settled into the comfortable complacency of high estate from which he can watch national affairs and, if he sees fit, have a platform for his speeches without the further cares of party politics, elections or Commons debates.

Experimentation with other governmental forms by some countries during recent years has served to prove "the sterling worth" of the "doctrines of liberty and democracy" proclaimed in the eighteenth century, Secretary of State Hull told members of the graduating class of the University of Pennsylvania today.

The marriage of Miss Helene Clare Auspitzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard George Auspitzer of Lawrence, to Bernard Henry Fee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Fee of Far Rockaway, took place here this morning in St. Joachim's Church.

Mrs. Brookfield Van Rensselaer, who was at the Pierre after passing the Winter in Italy and the South of France, sailed on the Queen Mary to pass the Summer in Cannes. Commander William Woodruff Meek, U.S.N., and Mrs. Meek will leave the Westbury today for Commander Meek's new station at Newport.

Cardinal Hayes presided this afternoon at the commencement of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel and urged the twenty-seven graduates, upon whom he conferred degrees, to continue their educational and religious studies. He said they should become leaders in the Catholic Youth movement and keep abreast world affairs.

5th Ave, 372-382; to 9-story department store; Best Co., premises, owner; H. Butterfield, architect; cost, $35,000. Amsterdam Ave, 781; to 5-story tenement and stores; Patrick Shanley, 72 Wall St., owner; G. F. Harrell, architect; cost, $15,000.

The Ixiolirion Montanum, a bluish purple lily-like flower, was exhibited yesterday for the first time in This country at the annual Nassau County Horticultural Society flower show, which is being held at the headquarters of the society, 598 Madison Avenue.
A joint inaugural flight over the New York-Bermuda air route will be made by the Bermuda Clipper of the Pan American Airways and the Imperial Airways flying boat Cavalier on Saturday.

Out of a comparatively blue sky, you may add to the list of shows which are closing on Saturday night none other than "Dead End," the Sidney Kingsley drama at the Belasco Theatre, which is second only to "Tobacco Road" as the longest-run play on Broadway.

The curricula at the new Queens City College, on the site of the New York Parental School, between Flushing and Jamaica, will offer to students this Fall not only liberal arts courses but a "reasonably" full selection of preprofessional and scientific courses.

The Iaw profession is overcrowded and it would be better for the community, as well as for members of the bar, if there were fewer lawyears, Judge Irving Lehman of the New York State Court of Appeals told 467 graduates of Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University at the thirty-fifth annual commencement yesterday morning at the Albee Theatre, Brooklyn.

Members of the 107th Infantry of Manhattan were the outstanding marksmen in the New York State rifle matches today at Camp Smith here. In the three matches completed, the Seventy-first Regiment, Governors Cup and the Brigade and Headquarters, the Manhattan unit won the trophy in each event.

William Griffin, editor and publisher of The New York Enquirer, received last night a scroll honoring him for his work in promoting Christian-Jewish amity. It was presented by the Hosea Lodge of the Free Sons of Israel at a flag day program at 257 West Ninety-third Street.
