The Department of Commerce reported today a jump in exports of aircraft from the United States in the first four months of 1937. Exports to all countries were 176 aircraft valued at $5,696,951, against 84 worth $1,444,727 in the corresponding four months last year.
A sudden strike of nearly 1,000 employes of twentytwo warehouses and cold-storage plants throughout the city tied up the movement of perishable goods to these plants today.
About 700 WPA workers of the "white collar" class are employed in the Los Angeles area (Los Angeles County) as traffic directors at school crossings.

The American Newspaper Guild was urged today by its convention's committee on unemployment and WPA to work for a permanent Federal department or academy of arts which would provide jobs for all unemployed professional and "white collar" workers in a nationwide cultural program.

Supreme Court Justice George Sutherland of Washington sailed yesterday on the linen Queen Mary with Mrs. Sutherland for a vacation in Europe. He said he would return in September in time for Autumn opening of the Supreme Court. He declined to comment on the court controversy, beyond indieating that he was not considering retirement.
Stocks closed slightly lower in quiet trading; turnover, 624,440 shares. United States Government bonds fractionally lower in dull trading, other bonds firm; transactions, $7,471,700.

Leroy Staubs, 44 years old, a private policeman, was found guilty tonight of murder in the first degree by a jury that deliberated more than four ours. Recommendation for life imprisonment was returned with the verdict. He will be sentenced on Friday. Staubs, who previous

Mrs. Ekaterina Georguvna Djugashvili, 77year-old mother of Joseph Stalin, is dead at her home near Tiflis. She died on June 4, but the announcement, made by the Communist party of Georgia in the Tiflis newspaper Dawn of the Orient, reached here only today.

Continuation of the Zionist political policy of cooperation with the mandate "despite the many disappointments we suffered at the hands of British officialdom in Palestine" was voted at yesterday's closing session of the thirty-seventh annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America at the Jewish Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway.

Miss Caroline Alden Sayles, Saugunter of Mrs. Frederic Clark Sayles d the late Mr. Sayles, will be carried to Ward Rathbun Clark of is city, son of Mrs. S. Allen Clark Oneida, N.-Y., and the late Mr. ark on June 19.

Southern Blvd (11-2960), n w cor of Elsmere P?? 82x140: Central Savings Bank to Max Nisnewitz, 1,375 Ocean Ave, Brooklyn. Pratt Ave (17-4966), e s. 515 s w of Kingsbridge Rd, 50x100; Arthur N. Burrows to Ralph L. Berube, 214 S 1st Ave, Mt Vernon.
Miss Mary Ellen Cahill, a retired public school teacher, formerly for fifty-two years attached to Public School 27, Brooklyn, died on Tuesday at her home, 610 Eleventh Street. She was 75 years old.

In a deal involving one of the largest privately owned single properties in Manhattan, the Presbyterian Hospital of New York has purchased the seven-acre home of the New York School for the Deaf on Riverside Drive, just south of the Presbyterian School of Nursing and the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

While a crowd of 55,000 persons looked on, a team from Italy defeated an aggregation of United States amateur boxers at the Yankee Stadium last night. The battlers from the Mediterranean kingdom outscored the native warriors by the close margin of one point, winning six and losing five of the eleven championship fights on the card.

The strike of truckmen and warehouse workers in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens was extended yesterday by 1,500 men as efforts were made to end the walkout on the basis of a compromise between Local 818 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the Warehousemen's Association of the Port of New York.
St. Louis at New York-Warneke vs. Schumacher or Smith. Chicago at Brooklyn-Lee vs. Frankhouse. Pittsburgh at Philadelphia-Swift vs. Waters. Cincinnati at Boston-Vandermeer vs. MacFayden.

Dwight School for Girls held its forty-seventh annual commencement at the school here today. The Rev. James Clelland, Director of Religion at Amherst College, gave the address. There were twentynine in the graduating classes.

Good prices were paid for some choice specimens of United States coins at the numismatic sale conducted yesterday in the Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Forty-seventh Street, by Wayte Raymond and J. G. Macallister, with Walter S. Scott as auctioneer.

Building operations now under way in New Rochelle are taking up all available skilled labor there, Mayor Harry Scott of New Rochelle declared yesterday at a luncheon given yesterday by the executives of Arnold Constable Co., at the Fifth Avenue store.

The executive board of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, was authorized last night at a meeting of about 600 employes of the city's Independent Subway System "to take whatever action they deem necessary in order to establish genuine collective bargaining for the Independent Subway System employes."

A legion of decency to combat "firms dealing in contraceptives and doctors approving of their use" will be advocated by the Rev. Ignatius Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, as a partial answer to recognition of birth-control measures by the American Medical Association, he disclosed yesterday.

Fireman 1st grade Andrew P. McCormack, H. L. 113-Charge: Making a false statement with intention to deceive; not guilty; charge dismissed. Lieutenant Malachy J. Garvey, Engine 255-Charge 1: Neglect of duty (neglected to enter in company journal the details of roll-call and inspection of apparatus); guilty; sentence suspended. Charge 2: Neglect of duty (neglected to enter in company journal the details of roll-call and inspection of apparatus); guilty; sentence suspended.

Electric power production declined last week when a slight increase was seasonal, but allowance for the holiday raised the daily average, and the adjusted index advanced to 108.0 from 106.6. It was 100.2 for the week ended June 6, 1936.
Industrial disputes held in idleness tonight more than 123,000 wage-earners in eighteen States, a survey of the strike front showed.

The house of delegates of the American Medical Association, ruling body of American medicine, adopted today a report placing all the facilities of organized medicine of America at the disposal of the United States Government in whatever efforts it may undertake to bring adequate medical care within the reach of all the people.

The British Ambassador and Lady Lindsay gave today their annual garden party in honor of their King's birthday. Official, diplomatic and resident society was represented in force, and guests strolled about the gardens and until the strains of "God Save the King." played by the band, signaled the end of the fete.

Leave of absence is granted to each of the following named Reserve officers, effective on or about the date specified; 1st Lt. William J. White Jr., QM-Res.g sixteen days, June 7. 1st Et. Samuel J. Leahy, CA-Rea., twe months and fcgirteen days, June 15. 1st Lt. Philip A. Beach, Med.-Res., one month and nine days, June 23.

Japanese activity in building up her foreign trade has acted as a spur to other nations and she will soon find her position seriously challenged by producers in competing countries, C. G. Pfeiffer, president of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., said yesterday at a business

The Government of Uruguay, as the result of negotiations with the Foreign Bondholders Protective do Council, Inc., made the following offer yesterday to holders of its dollar bonds: The 5 per cent bonds of 1915 to receive 3 1/2 per cent interest;
Producers in New York's $2,000,000,000 dairy industry announced their first move today to control, under the new Rogers-Allen law, milk prices paid to them.

H. W. Warley, president of the maritime Association, told an audince of 1,000 shipping men yesterday that the Federal Government lust produce a major share of the capital required for the rebuilding f the American merchant marine.

En route to strike-crippled Flint today this correspondent saw a city of 20,000 preparing to repel an invasion of 10,000 C. I. O. members from Toledo and Detroit, bent upon preventing 1,300 steel workers from returning to the jobs they left ten days ago when a strike was called against independent producers in seven States.

Joseph Bauer, 92 years old, of Rochester, was named today as the 1938 commander of the New York State Department of the Grand Army of the Republic. Mr. Bauer was the unanimous choice of twenty-eight veterans attending the department's seventyfirst annual encampment.

Patrolman Harry Jentzen, attached to Mounted Squad 2, was tried yesterday afternoon before Third Deputy Police Commissioner Michael A. Lyons in Brooklyn headquarters on departmental charges arising from a gambling raid on an apartment at 438 St. Nicholas Avenue May 28. He was one of twentyfive policemen found on the premises.

The first general court-martial affecting an officer of the New York National Guard was completed last night in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory with findings and a sentence against Major Charles R. Morrison of the 245th Coast Artillery Regiment.

There wasn't a champion or a former champion left in the tournament at the conclusion of today's two rounds in the British women's golf championship as eight contenders qualified for tomorrow's quarter-finals.

BYRNE, CATHERINE M. (Feb. 2, 1937). Gross assets, $11,320; net, $9,857. To cousins, Frank V. and Catherine I. Carey, one-half of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $3,500: mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $7,820. Lewis C. Grover, attorney, 16 Court St.

Fifteen members of the Roosevelt Hospital School of Nursing received diplomas last night at the thirtyeighth commencement of the school. The ceremony took place in the American Woman's Association Clubhouse, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Power-house workers accepted peace terms and restored current to Michigan's Saginaw Valley. Page 1. Rioting broke out early this morning in Youngstown, Ohio, between police and pickets at a Republic Steel plant. Page 1.
An estimated 1,200 employes of the Clark Thread Company went on strike today at the block-square plant here. Most of the day shift walked out and most of the night shift refused to enter.

After winning seven straight games from Yale, Fordham was turned back by the Elis today, 6-4, in a game marked by thrills. Three times Monroe Jubitz, Yale's pitcher, baffled the heavy-hitting visitors with the bases filled. The game, which was witnessed
The final session of the second season of the Composers' ForumLaboratory, given last night at the Theatre of Music, attracted an audience whose numbers established a record for this series.

Mexico's two-week nationwide oil strike against seventeen foreign companies ended at noon today as scheduled, but it was believed it would be several days before the gasoline and oil supply service was brought up to normal again.
St. Marks Pl, 28, 4-story tenement andstores, 26x120; Central Savings Bank of New York against Josephine B. Campbell: due, $23,214; taxes, , $596; to plaintiff for $5.000.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Morton W. Stark of this city on, Saturday at Lying In Hospitali Mrs. Stark is the former Miss Evylin Brill, daughter of Mrs Henry Brill of this city, and the late Mr. Brill. The child, whose

The question of union labor flared into the open at the Board of Education meeting yesterday, when the charge was made that the city is losing from 20 to 35 per cent on building contracts because of this policy.

Hans von Stuck, German automobile racing driver, claimed today to have bettered his own world record for a kilometer and established a new international mar' for a mile on the concrete highway linking Rio de Janeiro and Petropolis.

Senator William H. Smathers, New Jersey Democrat, advised the New Jersey Manufacturers Association today that he opposed "the letter and spirit" of four resolutions unanimously adopted by the association on May 8. Senator Smathers said he was "as unanimously opposed to the resolutions as was the apparent unanimity of their approval by the association."
A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Katharine E. Canfield from Cass Canfield of New York on grounds of "cruelty." An agreement was reached as to the custody and support of their two children.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition BERNARD STUART, INC., restaurant, 2,150 Broadway.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $52,646 and assets of $44,678. The petition states that receipts fell off substantially due to mass picketing during a strike recently.

Police Commissioner Valentine and Fire Commissioner McElligott were equally insistent yesterday that their respective baseball teams would win the interdepartmental game on June 19 at the Polo Grounds. They said so after the

Scoring in a hard-fought match, William Lurie became the first player to gain the semi-final round in the twentieth annual Brooklyn tennis championship at the Terrace Club of Flatbush yesterday. He defeated Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok by 3-6, 6-1, 8-6 in what was regarded

To the Editor of The New York Times: Too little publicity has been given to the recently enacted State Labor Relations Act. Industry, as a whole, has been suffering from the fear that one or two major labor organizations are on the way to snuff out the independent business existence of employers by corralling all employes in a mass group.

Recent news from Brazil continues to indicate improvement of its political situation. Dr. JOSE CARLOS DE MACEDO SOARES, who by Presidential appointment became Minister of Interior and Justice last week, has already begun to justify the favorable expectations of his admirers at home and abroad.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000, including 4,000 directs. Market generally steady to strong; spots 5c-10c higher than Tuesday's average; bulk. good and choice, 190-300 pounds, $11.30-$11.50. top $11.50;

At closing exercises today at Avon Old Farms, Dr. Percy G. Kammerer, provost, addressed the graduates, while awards for academic honors were presented by Dean Richard. H. Spears and for non-academic honors in the fields of village govern- day a ment and community service by study i Commander Harold Hunter, aide to the provost.

Fall merchandising plans and purchases' will be made next week by the Frank Rubinstein Stores Corportion, operating nineteen women's apparel and children's wear stores in the South, at its new headquarters at 519 Eighth Avenue.

Miss Patricia Cunningham, daughter of Mrs. Lula Bass Cunningham of Chula Vista, Calif., was married here yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to Alfred L. Flesh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo M. Flesh of Piqua, Ohio, by Bishop Hayward S. Ablewhite of Marquette, Mich.
Miss Marjorie E. Engle, daughter of William C. Engle of this city, has chosen June 19 as the date for her marriage to Charles F. Hart Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Hart of East Orange.

Three men and a woman pleaded guilty yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions In Brooklyn to a charge of conspiracy to cheat and defraud by using fictitious names prefaced with authoritative-sounding titles to sell tickets over the telephone for a non-existent charitable affair.

The Prudence Management Corportion. Frank Slater president, bought from Morris Luskin, operator, the two six-story elevator apart-t ment houses at 2,610 University Avenue and 2,609 Aqueduct Avenue, south of Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx. The buildings,

After several hours of questioning the police today released the four brothers, Luis Miguel, Anibal, Jose and Rafael Arzuaga, and Jesus Casellas, a cousin, seized in connection with the firing on United States Judge Robert A. Cooper here yesterday.

In response to inquiries about a story published today in a Syracuse paper reporting that a boom had been started for her as successor to Senator Copeland, Mrs. Caroline O'Day said that she was "greatly surprised and very much amused" at the report.

The text of Secretary Hull's address at the commencement exercises of the University of Pennsylvania today was as follows: I am always happy to come to our higher institutions of learning on such occasions as the present. My feelings spring naturally from an appreciation of the honor bestowed upon me, for which I am deeply grateful.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Erbacher of Scotch Plains have announced 1 the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irma Drey Erbacher, to George Houser Litch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Litch of Bloomfield.
Edward S. Greenbaum, American trustee in bankruptcy of the Kreu-. ger Toll Company, and Grayson M.-P. Murphy, chairman of the protective committee for the company's

Miss Constance Dillon Ripley, daughter of Baillie Ripley of 26 East Eighty-first Street and Litchfield, Conn., was married to Thomas David Williams of Branford, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dennis Williams, yesterday afternoon at her mother's home here.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. took a further step yesterday toward barring permanently The New York Woman and Brown, Young Co., securities dealers of 60 Wall Street, from all future deal ing in securities in the State.

ABELSON--Louis (B'nai B'rith Home for Aged). Funeral 10 o'clock, June 11, Weiss Chapel, 604 South Broadway, Yonkers. ADAMS--At Norristown, Pa., June 8, Georgiana Heermance, wife of the late Julius Leroy Adams. Funeral Norristown. Friday. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, noon Saturday.

State mediation brought an eight-hour delay tonight in plans to reopen the strike-closed Newton Steel Company mill here after more than 150 police were mobilized for an attempt to break a C. I. O. picket line.

The opening program of the twentieth Summer season to be given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Wednesday evening, June 23, at the Lewisohn Stadium will consist of the prelude to Wagner's "Die Meistersinger"; the Brahms violin concerto, with Albert Spalding as soloist, and the Beethoven Fifth symphony, it was announced yesterday. Vladimir Golschmann will conduct.
Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M.

Senator Royal S. Copeland reiterated his opposition to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization proposals in a speech last night at the fifty-fourth annual dinner of the Alumni Association of New York Medical College and Flower Hospital.

Mark Sullivan, Washington newspaper writer, declared today in an address to a graduating class of forty-two at St. John's College that a powerful school of thought had been able to establish itself in several great countries which "declares that the individual's right to direct his own existence must be in large part surrendered."
Mr. and Mrs. E. Carlton Hotchkiss of Old Greenwich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Virginia Hotchkiss, to Daniel Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Miller of Stamford.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed sub-depositary for the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company refunding mortgage 5 per cent sinking fund gold bonds due on Jan. 1, 1973.

A seven-year-old wicketkeeping record was equaled today by William Price, popular Middlesex stumper, playing against Yorkshire at Lord's. Price caught seven Yorkshiremen, the entire side being dismissed for 218 runs.

Frederick J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, issued a statement yesterday to explain the broadcast of anti-Semitic speeches over WNYC last Saturday night, after the Board of Aldermen had asked why the city's radio station had been used for that purpose.

Detective Mary Shanley of the pickpocket squad added another "pinch" to her record yesterday. This time, however, she had to fire two shots to accomplish the deed. Detective Shanley, who is a brunette weighing 150 pounds and who took a part in the recent Police Deapartment show,

Jim Turner and Lou Fette each held the Reds to six hits today, while the Bees moved into fifth place by sweeping their first double-header of the season, 5-2, 5-0. Fette, knocked out of the box yesterday by the Reds, hurled the shut-out, which gave him his seventh victory in nine starts.

The first biography of Goya to appear in English since 1914 has been written by Charles G. Poore and will be published, illustrated from Goya's paintings and etchings, by Charles Scribner's Sons in October. The biography occupied ten

The H. C. Frick Coke Company will bore 700 feet under the Monongahela River to tap a 7O.000 acre coal reserve in Greene County. Government approval has been obtained. Company engineers estimated the boring would require forty days. Plans include an electrified track hauling system in the tunnel.

Graduation exercises for the Lexington School for the Deaf will be held tonight at the school, 904 Lexington Avenue. Sol E. Rains, president of the board of trustees, will give the annual message to graduates, and Clarence D. O'Connor will speak.

TWENTY YEARS AS MILITARY ATTACHE, by Colonel T. Bentley Mott (Oxford, $2.50.) Reminiscences of an army officer. A MIND MISLAID, by Henry Collins Brown. (Dutton, $2.) Mr. Brown writes of his three years of recovery after a nervous breakdown.

Mrs. Oliver H. P. La Farge of this city has announced the engagement of her step-daughter, Miss Margaret La Farge, to Samuel McClintock Hamill of 101 East SeventySecond Street and Cherry Grove, Princeton, N. J.
Final sessions of the second annual amateur musical instrument contest will be held this evening at 8:30 o'clock on the Central Park Mall, the Department of Parks announced yesterday. Winners of the

Two expeditions to determine whether swordfish and other "big game" denizens of the deep existed in numbers in the Gulf Stream, 150 to 200 miles off the New Jersey coast, returned here today without a single specimen of what was sought.

Threatening weather prevented Amelia Earhart's take-off today for her next hop in her flight around the middle of the world. Miss Earhart, who left Miami, Fla., June 1 and reached here yesterday, announced she probably will fly to Niamey, about 1,350 miles straight east, tomorrow.
John L. Sanford has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Anne Iglehart Sanford, to Daniel* A. Boone Dugan, son of Mrs. Ferdinand Chatard Dugan and the late Mr. Dugan.
Anglican church circles have been informed from Berlin of an incident showing the amazing complications of German life produced by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's persecution of various religious creeds.

Howell H. Thomas, a lieutenant colonel in the Reserve Corps, died last night at the University Club, where he made his home. He was 55 years old and a son of the late John B. Thomas, founder of the drug firm of Thomas and Thompson, in which the son inherited an interest. He was an attorney but had not practiced for 18 years.

The State completed Its case yesterday against James Plumeri, alias Jimmy Doyle, and John Dioguardi, alias Johnny Dio, a nephew of Doyle, in their trial for extortion in connection with a trucking racket in the garment district.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company has notified its employes that it will no longer contribute to the relief fund and group insurance plan.
With 3 per cent rentes below 60 and 4 per cents of 1917 at 59.85, the public credit of France sank today to the lowest mark at which it has been since the franc crisis of 1926.

Maurice Duperrey, president of the Rotary Clubs of Paris, who was nominated by Otto Fischer of Stuttgart, Germany, was elected unanimously today as president of Rotary International and will assume that office on July 1. The election was scheduled for tomorrow morning, but when no other candidates were presented Mr. Duperrey was chosen by acclamation.

Another shake-up in the higher ranks of the Red army, carrying still farther the sweeping reorganization begun some time ago, was laconically announced today by Defense Commissar Klementy E. Voroshiloff.

Commercial leasing activity reported yesterday by brokers was featured by a number of units taken by firm whose business expansion calls for more space. Prominent among the leases made was the contract signed by the New York State Liquor Authority for 15,700 square feet in the Graybar Building at 420 Lexington Avenue. Increasing functions of

Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Siegelman, who were married secretly on March 27 in Crown Point, Ind., will sail for Europe June 29 on the Statendam. Later they will make their home in Chicago. Mrs. Siegelman is the former Miss Marjorie Reitler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Reitler of the Ritz Tower. She was graduated this month from Syracuse University.

The Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, State Senator from Essex County, announced here today his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor. Coincident with Dr. Clee's an nouncement, Lloyd B. Marsh, County Clerk of Passaic County, who announced his candidacy for the nomination several weeks ago, said he would withdraw from the race and support the Senator. Mr.

The first award of the Fine Arts Federation of New York's plaque for distinguished service to the fine arts was made yesterday to Mayor La Guardia at the annual luncheon of the Municipal Art Society at Hotel Biltmore. Representatives of six of the seventeen societies comprising the federation paid tribute to Mr. La Guardia's intelligent and unflagging interest in the arts.
Workers of the Pittsburgh Steel Company will vote tomorrow to determine if the Steel Workers Organizing Committee is to represent them in collective bargaining.

Miss Ann Blaine Hays of Carlisle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael S. Hays, was married tonight to Pennsylvania's youngest State Senator in history, Robert Lee Jacobs of Carlisle, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Ralph Jacobs. The ceremony was

Unfilled orders for men's wear wool goods were estimated. unofficially here yesterday at slightly more than 50,000,000 yards, including some 7,000,000 yards for army and CCC requirements. Production was estimated to be running at under 50,000,000 yards, ineludmen's wear numbers, So that the backlog is equal to more than fourteen weeks' output. Unfilled orders for women's wear fabrics were estimated at about 12.000,000 yards.
A strike affecting 7,200 persons ended today and conferences began toward settlement of others involving 8,300 Ohio workers.

The troubles of the Chicago Great Western Railroad due to the efforts of Patrick H. Joyce, its president, and some of his associates, to acquire a substantial interest in the Kansas City Southern Railroad, plans of which were blocked by the Missouri Public Service Commission, featured today's session of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

A dispatch to THE TIMES yesterday from Chicago reported that "for the "first time since the current strike "began" Mr. LEWIS'S C. I. O. has now moved to invoke the Wagner act. For two weeks a very substantial part of the steel-producing capacity of the country has been crippled.

Samuel Julian Stember, 45-yearold Brooklyn resident who quit his job as a chenille maker to pass more than four months fighting with the Loyalists in Spain, and who returned last Sunday, reported yesterday that men from several European countries were fighting with Americans for the Loyalists.

The questionable status at present of the projected Anglo-American trade treaty was emphasized in a long Commons debate tonight in which government spokesmen attempted to soothe alike the demand for such a treaty by the Liberals and the dominions' fears that the treaty would encroach on the practice of empire preference.

Miss Eleanor Mary Hone, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Hone of Greenwich, has completed plans for her marriage to James Leroy Yerks of Greenwich. The ceremony will be performed at St. Mary's Church here on June 26 by the Rev. James Q. Dolan, the pastor.

Declaring that a united anti-Communist front would appear like a class struggle and civil war, the national council of Colonel Francois de la Rocque's French Social party declined tonight to join the Fascist Liberty Front.

Mass romance blossomed in the village church of this French-Canadian community today as four brothers took four brides in Quebec's first recorded quadruple marriage in a single family. The four Lavoie brothers were
Father Coughlin's National Union for Social Justice must defend itself in a jury trial of a $30,000 damage suit brought by an 18-year-old Rochester boy for loss of his right eye.
Two pitchers held the Cubs hitless and scoreless in seven innings at Ebbets Field yesterday but, unfortunately for the Dodgers, the regulations provide that nine innings must be played.

In view of the enactment of a Chain Store Tax Law by the Pennsylvania Legislature, directors of the American Stores Company today declared a dividend of 25 cents, payable July 1 to stockholders of record June 15, instead of the usual 50cent dividend.

The impending retirement of Augustin Pierre Becq de Fouquieres, who for decades has had the task of introducing new foreign Envoys to the French President at the Elysee Palace, was announced today. Mr. de Fouquieres,

The forty-family apartment building at 29-39 Seventh St, Weehawken, N J, has been purchased by Charles Newman, Inc. from the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The house is of brick, and stands on a plot 150 by 100 feet. The buyer paid cash above a first mortgage of $180,000. J. B. Wolfe, Inc, was the broker.

Japanese, Italian and English gardens featured the sixth annual Westchester County Flower Show, which opened here today at the County Center under the auspices of the Westchester County Horticultural and Agricultural Association, Inc.

Thanks to the skillful navigation by Captain Earl D. Lucas, the Steelmaker carried the Princeton University- Franklin Institute-Cook Observatory Eclipse Expedition close to the point where the noon hid the sun for the maximum time.
Charges against twenty-eight Detroit and Michigan bankers that grew out of the banking holiday of 1933 were dismissed today by Federal District Judge Patrick T. Stone.

Mrs Henry Alvah Strong, philanthropist of Washington and. Rochester, Dr. Helen Taft Manning; dean of Bryn Mawr College, and Dean: Elizabeth Peet of Gallaudet College received honorary degrees tonight from George Washington University.

Thomas J. Larkin, a director of the Belgian-American Chamber of Commerce, who was American agent for several Belgian manufacturers of building materials, died yesterday in his apartment in the Fifth Avenue Hotel of uremic poisoning after an illness of three weeks. Born in County Galway, Ireland, sixty-one years ago, he came to this country at the age of 19.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wadley Raoul of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Raoul, to Samuel A. Bingham Jr. of Tryon, N. C. Miss Raoul was graduated from the Madeira School, Washington, D. C., in 1933 and is a member of the graduating class at Vassar College. Her junior year at college
Renewal of the verbal war between the Foreign Ministers of Bolivia and Paraguay again has brought the Chaco situation to a serious crisis.

Captain Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett, the explorer, announced yesterday he would sail on his ship, the Morrissey, on his annual scientific expetition to Greenland and the polar regions on June 22. He said a vacancy remained for a boy from 14 to 18 years of age, who would share the expenses, to join the party and participate in its scientific work. Captain Bartlott is. staying at the Murray Hill Hotel.

If a man is a member of a C. I. O. textile union and also a member of the New Jersey National Guard, he will be suspended from the union in the event his National Guard unit is called for strike duty.
Samuel Goldwyn's variation on the boy-gets-girl theme, "Woman Chases Man," will settle down today for an engagement at the Radio City Music Hall.

Raymond Wheeler Tucker, a member of the brokerage firm of F. P. Ristine Company of New York and Philadelphia, died this morning at his home here after a long illness. Born fifty-nine years ago in Elizabeth, he was a son of the late William B. and Mary S. Tucker and a member of an ??'d Elizabeth family. He was a veteran of the SpanishAmerican War and saw service in Cuban waters.

Only the solidity of a four-foot stone wall protecting the pedestrian walk on Riverside Drive at 135th Street from a sheer drop of seventyfive feet to Twelfth Avenue saved three persons in a bus from almost certain death at about 3:30 P. M. yesterday.

An appeal to Poland, signed by fifty Christian religious leaders, asking that the Polish Government put a stop to anti-Semitic agitation, was made public yesterday by the Amercan Jewish Congress on the eve of a meeting to be held at the Hotel Astor tonight to discuss the problems of Polish Jews.

HE Oakland Hills course over which the national -open golf championship is about to start is a long pull for the contestants. The last time they held the open championship there the title was won by the smallest player in the field, Cyril Walker. But that doesn't mean that Tony Manero and Bobby Cruickshank will start as topheavy favorites this time.

To John G. Winant, former head of the Social Security board, was awarded an LL.D., as one of three honorary degrees conferred at the annual commencement of Oberlin Coiiege yesterday, when 277 degrees were conferred on seniors:

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor gayly posed for photographs today on the grounds of their Austrian castle and bantered with the visiting newspaper camera men. He complained of the hot weather, but the Duchess, accustomed to American Summers, did not seem to mind the heat.

Irving Odessky, 35 years old, of 3,018 Brighton First Street, Brighton Beach, former manager of the Bensonhurst branch of the Public National Bank and Trust Company, at Twenty-first Avenue and Eightysixth Street, Brooklyn, who pleaded guilty to embezzlement of $26,000 of the funds of the institution, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch in Federal court,

JERUSALEM, June 9.--There is little doubt now that the Royal Commission is seriously considering the partition of Palestine in which case part of the country would be Jewish under British supervision, and the other part, to which in all probability Trans-Jordan would be annexed, would become purely Arab, also under British tutelage.
Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Restaurant at Sherry's for Countess Bohdan de Castellane and Mrs. Robert M. Littlejohn. Other guests included
Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, was reported yesterday to be convalescing rapidly from an operation for appendicitis at the Roosevelt Hospital last week.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that it had 359,630 stockholders recorded for the second quarter of 1937, compared with 358,080 for the first quarter and 345,265 for the second quarter of 1936.

The report of the United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended April 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $5,216,036, equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 46 cents a share on the combined class A and B common stocks.
The Department of Commerce reported today that sales of United States automobiles and trucks to South America are exceeding last year's exports of other countries in that market.

Max Epstein, chairman of the board of the General American Transportation Corporation, received remuneration of $60,000 from that company last year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, left last night for Washington after having conferred here with Edward J. Flynn, Bronx County leader, and Frank V. Kelly of Brooklyn on the choice of a Mayoralty nominee.

Collection rates on open-credit accounts receivable of department stores were 46.9 per cent in April of this year, against 46.8 per cent in March, and 45.1 per cent in April of 1936, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce monthly survey showed today.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 8: COLONELS Greely, J. N.. F.A.. General Staff Corps, one month and seven days' leave, July 1. Cooper. A. J.,. C.A.C., .General Staff Corps, two days' leave, June 10.

The Sherburne Game Farm which we left this morning, continuing our inspection tour through the State with Commissioner Osborne, is both an old landmark and a historic spot to any one interested in game management.

The forty-first annual commencement of the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture will be held at 3 P. M. today at the institute, Webb and Sedgwick Avenues. the Bronx. Lewis Nixon, president, will present degrees of Bachelor of Science in Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering to the graduating class of sixteen members.

Cooper Union will confer 142 bachelor's degrees, diplomas and certificates, and six professional degrees at its seventy-eighth annual commencement tonight in the Great Hall of the union. Gano Dunn, president of the union, will also present twenty-three scholarships and thirty-four prizes.
Employes of the Bridgeport plant of the General Electric Company voted 2,790 to 1,991 today for the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, C. I. 0. affiliate, as sole bargaining agency.

An investigation by the New York County grand jury on a recent survey by the Board of Education. on promiscuous sales of hypodermic needles to narcotic addicts in the vicinity of public schools on the lower East Side led yesterday to the arrest of nine druggists and drug clerks on Special Sessions bench warrants.

Several leases for Park Avenue apartments featured the many contracts for residential space reported yesterday. Among those arranged was one for twelve rooms and four baths at 32 East Sixty-fourth Street which was taken by Milton R. Opton. real estate operator,

One snake that cranes its neck like a chicken and growls like a dog, three others that move under water like submarines and fifteen wall-climbing, ceiling-crawling lizards were among eighty-seven reptiles that arrived at the Staten Island Zoological Society yesterday from the Malay Peninsula.

Now that the Republic Steel Company has served notice on the Postoffice Department that it will take all "available legal steps" to require the department to deliver all packages addressed to the occupants of its plants at Niles and Warren, Ohio, the argument has reached a stage where an examination of the facts may be useful.

In the belief that the present patent laws provide merely "a license to fight," the National Inventors Congress yesterday telegraphed to Senator William G. McAdoo of California urging him to introduce into Congress a measure seeking more protection for inventors.

In the final race of the preliminary series to select the defender of the America's Cup, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new Ranger made faster time today over thirty miles of windward and leeward sailing than ever was set in an international match

Movements vessels follow; all dates are June 8, unless specified: At Rockland: Balch, Schenck. At San Diego: Kalmia, Ortolan. Acushnet, Norfolk to Washington Yard via Potomac River points. Augusta, at Chinwangtao, June 9. Babbitt, at Bahia Honda.

BELZER. JOSEPHINE A. (June 3). Estate, more than $10,000. To Orphan Asylum of the City of Brooklyn, $1,000 for books; three specific bequests; Ella V. Belzer, sister, executrix, 56 E. 87th St., residue. BENNETT, TYLER HEWETT, (Jan. 28). Estate, about $1,000. To Esther Brady Bennett, widow, executrix, Hotel-Wellington.
Buyers who turned yesterday's tax sales into an arithmetical field day held potential title today to many parcels of land that could be delivered on the point of a toothpick.

Messages commending his public denunciation of Adolf Hitler for the German Chancellor's attacks on Jewish and Christian religious organizations and leaders were received today by the Rev. Dr. Charles S. Maofarland, general secretary emeritus of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, at his home here.

Pratt Institute will award diplomas and certificates to 555 graduates at the fiftieth annual commencement exercises this afternoon in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Professor William Lyon Phelps of Yale University will deliver the address. . .
The election of delegates to the Constituent Assembly will be held next Feb. 24, according to a bill approved this afternoon by the House of Representatives.
A sit-down strike of forty truck drivers tied up operations of the H. Brooks Matlack Oil Transportation Company today. The drivers sat

President Roosevelt conferred with Langdon W. Post on pending housing legislation, discussed Puerto Rican affairs with Governor Winship and Dr. Ernest Gruening, and the labor situation at the Newport torpedo station with Senator Green.

Carded-yarn manufacturers are in a strong statistical position, it was announced her today by Don P. Johnston of Wake Forest, N. C., chairman, who presided at the semiannual meeting of the group, attended by sixty executives representing more than 50 per cent of the total.

The 108th annual parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union will be held this afternoon in four districts of the borough. There will be twenty-seven divisions marching. Four parties of public officials will review them.

The College of St. Elizabeth will confer seventy degrees tomorrow afternoon at its annual commencement here. Dr. Julia C. Harney, supervisor of elementary and junior high schools in Jersey City, will regive an honorary degree and will give the address.

Atley Donald rang up his eighth straight victory tonight as the Newark Bears made it three in a row over Baltimore with a 10-5 triumph. Donald was chased off the hill in the eighth but held a 6-3 lead at the time.

The League's Opium Advisory Committee adopted a resolution today diplomatically holding Japan responsible for the growth of the narcotic drug traffic in those parts of China under Japanese influence, as charged by Stuart Fuller of the State Department recently.

Miss Catherine Vivian Fairsnider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Fairsnider of this place and St. Petersburg, Fla.. was married here tonight to Robert Gordon Tunnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Tunnell of Yonkers, at the home of the Rev. Joseph T. Cunningham, who performed the ceremony.

Dr. William L. Fowler, 72, of 345 West Putnam Avenue, a veterinarian, was found dead of carbon monoxide gas at 6:40 o'clock this morning in front of a garage about a block from his home. He had lain down near his car, with a pipe rigged from the car exhaust to his face. On a car seat was a note which said:

Real estate activity in Manhattan varied yesterday, when deals were reported involving sales of housing properties and a midtown site for an addition to the St. Thomas Choir School. St. Thomas Church bought from the Coleman Holding Corporation the two-story garage on a plot 50 by 100.5 feet at 114-116 West Fiftysixth Street.

Department store earnings both in dollars and as a percentage of sales last year showed further recovery from the low levels of the depression, according to the annual study of the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Business School which will be published on June 24.

William Davis has been elected vice president of the Lewis H. May Company, in charge of the management department. Owing to the death of Paul H. Fairchild, late president of the Twenty-third Street Association,

Henry M. Briggs, for more than twenty-four years a letter carrier attached to the Sheepshead Bay station, who was convicted in Federal court, Brooklyn, on Tuesday of "detaining, delaying and secreting the mail," was sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch to a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary.

There is a sufficient shortage of skilled labor in the building-construction trades to halt the prospective and long-awaited building boom, in the opinion of C. W. Young, president of the Young Management Corporation, investment managers.
Yugoslavia's former dictator, General Pera Zhivkovitch, and his aides were attacked yesterday by political opponents at Celje and were forced to flee in an ambulance.

Philip Gahm of 3 West Eightyseventh Street, pianist, composer and music teacher, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 71. A native of Mergentheim, Germany, he had lived in this country since 1884.

W. A. Thorn, director of the Dominion Meteorological Observatory here, announced today that the observatory was cooperating in the preparation of weather reports to facilitate a proejected transpolar fight by Soviet airmen from Moscow to San Francisco.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in a decision handed down yesterday ruled that trustees for mortgage certificate issues should not set up depreciation funds or other reserves, but should instead distribute money allocated for these purposes to certificate holders. The decision was followed

Wendell L. Willkie, who is president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, and chairman of the board of its subsidiary, the Consumers Power Company, made public here yesterday the text of a statement summarizing the company's agreement with the C. I. O. reached in Washington at midnight Tuesday. The statement was as follows:

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Thursday, June 10.--In a sudden flare-up of rioting early this morning outside the Youngstown plant of the Republic Steel Corporation, one striking picketer was shot and slightly wounded, two policemen were severely beaten and fourteen pickets were arrested.

Engagement of $4,387,000 of gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In London the dehoarding seemed to be further diminishing and the price quoted was slightly higher than on Tuesday.

A high official of the Japanese Embassy admitted today that North China authorities had proposed a deal to Japan, under which China would be willing to accept Japanese cooperation in financing the construction of Tsangchow-Shihchiachaung Railway if Japan would restore East Hopei to China.

Albert L. Talcott, an attorney here for nearly fifty years, died suddenly today following a heart attack. He was active until two days ago. Born in Jefferson, Ohio, seventy-eight years ago, Mr. Talcott was graduated from Mount Union College and the Yale Law School. He came to Cleveland in 1890.

The Chicago North Western Railway will show a deficit for May somewhat larger than the deficit of $404,000 reported for May, 1936, according to Fred W. Sargent, president. He said that industrial strikes had cut the company's earnings last month.

Heavy Eastern selling of wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today turned the market down after an initial advance of 2 cents or more a bushel, but in the late trade there was enough commission-house support to cause a moderate rally.

After five years of silence on the subject, General Charles G. Dawes today told his "inside" story of the $90,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the former Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, and of the events leading- up to it.
The forty-first birthday anniversary of King George VL was commemorated today with the ceremony of "trooping the color," perhaps the most resplendent military spectacle the British monarchy provides.

John T. Ryan, a lawyer who was long a leader in Irish-American affairs and was associated in recent years with Frank P. Walsh, attorney-and chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, died of a heart ailment on Tuesday at his apartment in the Hotel New Yorker. Mr. Ryan, whose office was at 70 Pine Street, was 64 years old.

A sharp drop in State and municipal financing in May from the total for the corresponding month last year was reported yesterday by The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for last month was $46,172.286, against $96,541,554 for May, 1936. For the first five months of 1937 the aggregate was $504,717,234, against $516,656,075 for the same period last year.

With the same simple ceremony first before the Mayor of the village and later in the Protestant church as last week united the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield, Andre Tardieu, former Premier of France, was married today to Mrs. Angelique Julia Larjenton.
Holy Cross College graduated its largest class today when 295 seniors received their degrees from the Rev. Francis J. Dolan, president, in the presence of more than 3,000 relatives and friends.

Activity in United States Government bonds was reduced yesterday to a minimum, and interest was centered in local traction issues and high-grade railroad securities in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Sales for the day amounted to $7,471,000, compared with $7,952,500 on Tuesday.

Ernest Simpson's suit for alleged slander against Mrs. Joan Sutherland is scheduled to come before the courts Friday, when it is expected to be disposed of without "sensations" or the attendance of "important personages" as witnesses, as was first rumored.

Edward Herman, the Mrs. Isabelle Mosher residence on Pleasant Ridge Rd. Harprison, Westchester; Peter C. Doern Jr, Inc, broker Malcolm Nichols, in 12 Alta Drive, Mount Vernon; Harry S. Leslie, in 35 Vernon Place; Mrs. Morris Berney, in 555 Pelhamdale Ave; George A. Guerdan, in 2 Brassie

The pamphlet report of the Swedish Match Company for 1936 includes for the first time the foreign match properties that were acquired from the bankruptcy estate of the International Match Corporation last year under the three-part agreements and settlements in which the Kreuger Toll Company estate also figured.

Miss Winifred Dana Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Van Wyck Gould of Great Neck, has chosen the afternoon of July 1 as the date for her marriage to Clifford Coddington, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Morgan Coddington of this city and Harwichport, Mass.

The Navy Athletic Association has voted $150,000 for the erection of a museum building on the grounds of the Naval Academy at Annapolis, and the board of control of the Navy Institute is now conducting a mail vote of its members to determine if they approve an appropriation from the institute of $50,000 toward the proposed building, which would contain offices for the Navy Athletic Association and the Navy Athletic Department.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Russell I. Hare of Paris, who are now at the Gotham, of the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Hare, to Delbert A. Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Johnson of Cleveland.
More than 1,500 invitations have been sent out for the commencement of the School of Nursing of the Long Island College Hospital tonight in the Hotel Towers, Brooklyn.
More than 1,500 invitations have been sent out for the commencement of the School of Nursing of the Long Island College Hospital tonight in the Hotel Towers, Brooklyn.

The first annual Princeton architectural round-table conference, bringing together more than seventy faculty members, architects and graduate students in architecture, will open in the Princeton Graduate College tomorrow afternoon and continue through Sunday morning, it was announced today by Melville C. Branch Jr. of Richmond, Va., secretary of the conference.

Prize awards to twenty-one inventors who had exhibits at this year's convention of the National Inventors Congress at the Hotel Edison were made yesterday at the annual luncheon of the organization. The congress closed its fourday session last night. About 25,000 visitors attended the demonstrations of various devices during the convention.
Thomas E. Capner, an uncle of Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, died at his home here early this morning at the age of 79. The Governor arrived here from Trenton soon after hearing the news.

Wholesale price levels declined fractionally in the week ended on June 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average, dropped to 87.1, compared with 87.4 in the preceding week and 78.4 on June 6, 1936.

A young hospital nurse confessed today-that she had made up a fantastic tale of being kidnapped by two men early this morning, in an effort to regain the friendship'of John Rockefeller Prentice, Chicago attorney and grandson of John D. Rockefeller.
A "determined" effort to bring American banking functions "under political control" was charged here today by Robert J. Izant of Cleveland, a bank executive.

Nora Dinkov, mezzo-soprano, will be guest artist at a concert sponsored by the Committee for Cultural Organization of the American League Against War and Fascism, to take place tonight at 69 Bank Street.

Cardinal Hayes presided last night at commencement exercises of Cathedral College, at the Cathedral High School auditorium, Fiftieth Street and Lexington Avenue, with more than 1,090 persons attending.

Evidence. of racketeering in fruits and vegetables at food markets in New York and other cities has been turned over to the Department of Justice by the Federal Trade Commission, Congress was informed today by the commission.

The New Jersey State Highway Extension Sinking Fund Commission awarded yesterday to various banking groups $3,585,000 par value of bonds of municipalities in that State at a premium of approximately $285,337.
JOSEPH STALIN'S mother took her boy out of the cobbler's shop where his father placed him and sent him back to

Dr. Philip F. O'Hanlon of 121 West Ninety-fifth Street, died last night at his home after an illness of three years of heart disease. His age was 74. Dr. O'Hanlon served as coroner's physician in New York from 1895 to 1911 and was police -urgeon from 1911 until 1923, when he retired on a pension and resumed private practice.

The Argentine Government has realized net profits of 192,000,000 pesos ($64,400,000 at the official rate of exchange) through the sale of official exchange in the period since November, 1933, when control of exchange was instituted, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

A Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved today the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill. Chairman Van Nuys, Democrat, of Indiana, said that the committee had voted to substitute the bill for the Gavagan measure recently passed by the House. He said that he understood this would be satisfactory to Representative Gavagan, Democrat, of New York, author of the House bill.

Canadian wheat in store on June 4 showed a decrease of almost 3,000,000 bushels in the week and was more than 107,000,000 bushels less than in the corresponding week in 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statis'?cs reported today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved the application of the White Horse Pike Bus 'Company, Inc., which operates passenger express and mail buses between Philadelphia and Atlantic City to continue as a common carrier between these two points.
Three American diplomatic envoys were among the 872 passengers arriving on the United States liner Manhattan, which docked late yesterday afternoon from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh.

The Educational Review which was founded nearly fifty years ago by Dr. NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER and edited by him for more than a quarter of a century, and then edited by Dr. F. P. GRAVES for a few years, has been continued once a month as a section of School and'Society under the editorship of WILLIAM MCANDREW (who disdains an academic title).
Defense attorneys for 19-year-old Tommy Smith scored today when a witness testified that she saw Mary Ellen Babcock, 18, alive, almost three hours after the State contends Smith said he killed her.

A strike of building service employes was called yesterday at the several stores of Ludwig Baumann Co. At the company's principal store, 500 Fifth Avenue, forty porters, machinists and elevator operators quit work. Eight men joined the strike in the Harlem and Bronx stores.
Reports of excessive rainfall in the northwestern sections of the Cotton Belt exerted a steadying influence on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices gained 4 to 10 points.

Mrs. Gladys P. Booth of Plainfield has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rhoda Hills Booth, to Burton Anderson Strait Jr., son of the late Commander Burton A. Strait, U. S. N., and Mrs. Strait of Annapolis, Md.

Announcement has been made by Miss Marion V. Zechlin of 60 Gramercy Park of the engagement of her sister, Miss Dorothy Zechlin, to Frederic A. Bauer, son of Dr. and Mrs. August F. Bauer of Maplewood, N. J.

The directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share, payable July 22 to stock of record June 21. This is the first dividend declaration made by the company during the current year. It will amount to $6,583,848 and will, be paid out of the profits of the company.
The marriage of Miss Lillian Pitchford of London to Albert D. Millar, also of London, formerly of New York, took place here yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of Municipal Building.
Miss Florence Helen Bennett, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Pattison Adam of this place, was married tonight to William Stanley Metcalf of New York and Penzance, England.

The Public Service Commission ruled yesterday by a vote of 4 to 1 that it has jurisdiction to entertain a complaint that the New York Telephone Company has fixed "unjust, unreasonable, arbitrary, discriminatory and extortionate" terms and conditions for publication of subscribers' names in its Red Book or classified directory.

Plans for modernizing a Yorkville property were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of 152, 154 and 156 East Eightyfourth Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, to a syndicate headed by T. E. Rhoades,
Government troops, in a coup de main on the Guadalajara front, captured an important position and took 107 prisoners, one 105 millimeter cannon, four machine guns and a large quantity of rifles.

Governor Wilbur L. Cross, speaking today at the graduation exercises of Kent School, commended to the seventyseven youths receiving diplomas the classical foundation which had been given to them for their further education at college, in professional school and in their subsequent careers as "good citizens."
Ben Huffman's fourth-inning double, which drove three Browns home, was the blow heard round Sportsman's Park today in the Browns' 6-3 victory over the Senators.

The Yankees beat the White Sox at Comiskey Park today by 10-3 before a throng of 15,000 and snapped several streaks. The triumph ended the best winning streak the White Sox have enjoyed in twenty-nine years, ten straight, stopped a losing Yankee run of three straight,

Three former Ohio convicts were executed in the electric chair at Indiana State Prison today, its first triple execution. They were William A. Kuhlman, Frank Gore Williams and Joseph Poholsky, convicted of the murder-of Harry A. Miller, a wealthy Cincinnati retired fire captain, at his home in New Trenton, Ind.

The Appellate Term of the Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday that $1,000 was not too much for the French Casino to pay in assuagement of the feelings of a patron who had been taken to the West Forty-seventh Street police station after he protested a $6 cover charge. The payment, together with $111.90 in costs, had been ordered by a jury in City Court, where the customer brought suit for false arrest.

Ward Van Alstyne of Irvington, N. Y., who is a vice president of Aluminium Union, Ltd., a Canadian corporation accused of being part of an aluminum trust headed by the Aluminum Company of America, testified yesterday in Federal court in the company's action to have service of the government's complaint against it voided.

A Senate subcommittee today overrode the wishes of Senator Byrnes of South Carolina and his relief economy group, reporting intact to the Appropriations Committee the $1,500,000,000 WPA Appropriation Bill for the next fiscal year. Mr. Byrnes desired a reduction to $1,000,000,000.
Millhands who are out of sympathy with the strike supported by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee pressed a "back to work" campaign today.

The shadow that armaments have cast over recovery in every country was sharply stressed today by Assistant Secretary of Labor Edward F. McGrady, speaking for the United States Government at the International Labor Conference.

Leonard Hartman, defending the title he won a year ago, yesterday moved a step nearer repeating that performance by winning his quarter-final-round match in the twentieth annual Brooklyn tennis championship tournament at the Terrace Club of Flatbush.
All local records were broken in the number of exhibits and the attendance at the opening today of the flower show of the garden clubs of Rockland County at the Ramapo Riding Academy here.
Sir Cecil Hanbury, Conservative Member of Parliament and partner in one of the leading companies engaged in trade with the East, died today at the age of 66.

Patrolman Raymond Mulcahy, attached to the Amsterdam Avenue station, reported to detectives of that precinct shortly after 1 A. M. today that he had been seized from behind by two Negroes at 164th Street and Amsterdam. Avenue, and that they had knocked him down and escaped after taking his service revolver.

The thirty-fourth annual graduation of the Loyola School, Park Avenue and Eighty-third Street, will be held this afternoon in the Waldorf-Astoria. The Rev. Coleman Nevils, rector, will preside. Hugh J. Grant, of the Class of 1921, will address the graduates.

Bradley L. Eaton, treasurer and director of Church E. Gates Co., died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Eaton, who was 86 years old, lived at 299 Park Avenue. He had been connected with the lumber company, which is at Oak Point Avenue and the East River, for forty-six years.

The question of participation in group showings came to the fore once more in the women's coat trade yesterday when "eight leading style houses" were found guilty of violating the regulation banning such participation at a hearing of the grievance committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at its offices here.
In both the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate the financial results of the social policy of Premier Blum's government came in for severe criticism today.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson took under advisement today a petition of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway for leave to apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to refund equipment trust certificates of $27,000,000.

The five-story dwelling on a plot, 21 by 100 feet, at 1 East Ninetysecond Street has been leased to a New York lawyer. Alterations planned for the structure include the installation of an electric elevator.

Locked together with Mrs. V. Wyse's Bachelor Dinner all the way down the stretch, F. L. Flanders's Blind Pig gained a nose decision in the camera finish that decided the Elks Day purse, feature of today's program at Suffolk Downs. He paid $8.20 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, declared last night at the Hippodrome in his first speech since his return from Europe that in Russia, which he termed the mightiest bulwark in Europe against fascism, there had arisen a bureaucratic circle which attempted to hold or gain power. by violence and intrigue, thus impeding the progress of the nation as a socialistic State.
Departing from past practice, Reed College today granted five honorary degrees as a special feature of its twenty-fifth anniversary celebration.

Miss Catherine Sinclair Sisto, daughter of Joseph A. Sisto of South Orange, N. J., and the late Mrs. Katherine Sinclair Williams Sisto, was married to Ernest John Miller, son of Gordon MacKenzie Miller of Montreal, yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

Mrs. Hamilton Disston of Chestnut Hill has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Effie Fleming Disston, to John A. Mayer of the Wellington, this city, son of Mrs. Herman A. Mayer of Woodbridge, Terre Haute. Ind.

King George and Queen Elizabeth tonight cabled their sympathy to Lady Borden in the death of Sir Robert. The message read: "The Queen and I offer you our deep sympathy in the death of Sir Robert Borden, whose eminent services to Canada and the empire will always be gratefully remembered.

Twentyfour municipalities operating power plants in New York State were called upon today to reduce electric rates immediately by the Public Service Commission, which branded their profits "excessive." "Reports submitted by the municipalities,"

Thomas Kirby, long active in church and fraternal work in Brooklyn and Queens, died yesterday in the Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn. He-was 71 years old and lived at 8,544 106th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens.

Three hundred and forty-six employes of the Conemaugh Black Lick Railroad, operated by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, walked out at 11 o'clock tonight in response to a strike call. Indications were that the strike would tie up Bethlehem's Cambria plant, employing 15,000 men, within twentyfour hours.
With no race today, the owners, afterguards and professional crews of the America's Cup defender candidates had a day off.

Six members of the German commission investigating the causes of the Hindenburg disaster reported to the Reich Air Ministry today that although there were eight possible causes for the explosion of the dirigible none could be proved during the present investigation.

The American Birth Control League and the National Medical Council on Birth Control struck back today at the Rev. Ignatius Cox, Professov of Ethics at Fordham University, who yesterday took issue with the American Medical Association for its recognition of birth control measures.
James J. Braddock today received with a whoop of joy the news that the last legal obstacle blocking his world championship fight with Joe Louis had been rmoved.
Market eased slightly and closed irregularly lower in quiet trading; turnover, 567,250 shares. All bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $7,193,200.

Harry W. Colmery, national commander of the American Legion, whose members will hold their annual national convention here in September, will be the guest of honor at a luncheon on Thursday, June 24, at the Hotel Roosevelt, under the auspices of the Fifth Avenue Association, it was announced yesterday by Captain William J. Pedrick, association president.

Miss Anne Thomas Stewart, daughter of John A. Stewart 3d of this place, was married here this afternoon at the home of her grandfather, John A. Stewart Jr., to T. Wilkinson Satterthwaite Jr., son of Mrs. Weeks Satterthwaite of New York and of T. Wilkinson Satterthwaite.

For two hours yesterday afternoon about thirty-five pickets, cartrying placards asking for support, marched in front of the Montauk Democratic Club, Eighth Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, where Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Brooklyn Borough President Ingersoll and other State and city officials were attending a luncheon in connection with "Brooklyn Sunday School Day."

The largest single order for military aircraft since the World War was awarded today by Secretary Woodring when he signed a contract with the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., of Santa Monica, Calif., for 177 twin-engined bombers of the type known to the service as B-16.
While the gold crisis continued yesterday to lose some of its edge, further weakness in the franc came forward to challenge it as a major concern of the foreign exchange market.

Mrs. Louis A. Parks's chestnut gelding Holystone, from her stable at Sewickley, Pa., won the blue ribbon tonight in the open lightweight hunter event of Chicago's charter jubilee horse show at Soldier Field.

2d Lt. Frederick S. Gillespie, Inf. Res., 59 Midland Ave., Arlington. N. J.. is ordered to active duty June 20, at Fort Hancock, N. J., for training. Lt. Gillespie will rank from June 20, 1937. He will be relieved from active duty July 3. Each of the following Corps of Engineers Reserve officers is ordered to active duty, June 20, at Fort du Pont, Del., for training:
Aldermanic President William F. Brunner is scheduled to receive a cup of wine from the cellars of the Austrian Government from the Committee for the- Presentation of Austrian Art,

Although rumors are in circulation predicting the imminence of higher commissions on New York Stock Exchange deals and have linked the membership of the committee on commissions headed by E. A. Pierce, the committee in question has not met in two months.

The 1937 race for the Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball championship became a wide-open affair as Harvard swept both ends of the double-header with Dartmouth before 2,000 fans at Spldiers Field today.
The Basque Government published today a letter personally presented by a delegation of Basque Catholic clergy to Pope Pius. The delegation went and returned in great secrecy.

The marriage of Miss Harriet Elizabeth Ridlon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Francis Ridlon of Wakefield, Mass., to Harry Rathbun Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Harry Jackson of Plandome, L. I., took place here this afternoon in Christ Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. Leslie Glenn, who was assisted by the Rev. Stuart Clark Harbinson of Emmanuel Church, Wakefield.

The Public Works Administration announced today a liberalization of the terms of a $20,000,000 grant to Pennsylvania. PWA-spokesmen said that they understood the new offer, modifying relief labor requirements, would be acceptable to Pennsylvania authorities.

Forty-seven striking employes of Littman's, Inc., women's wear shop at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, who with forty other employes have been conducting demonstrations in front of the store for a week, were arrested late yesterday afternoon and booked at the

Police Commissioner Valentine admitted yesterday that two detectives assigned as bodyguards for Samuel Rosoff, subway contractor, at the time of the slaying of Norman Redwood, sandhog union official, had been demoted to the uniformed ranks and transferred to new commands.

The American Newspaper Guild, newest affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, went on record tonight in favor of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal, while reaffirming its demand for a constitutional amendment

As the first full-length Wells novel since "Mr. Britling Sees It Through," Scribner's announce that they will publish in October "Brynhild, or The Show of Things," by H. G. Wells. The literary sets of England supply the main characters.

Chain-store sales last month reached the largest volume for the current year, notwithstanding the handicaps to retail trade of weather and strikes, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday, influenced to some extent by the inactivity of the security and commodity markets, declined from the corresponding week in the previous year but were above the total for the preceding five-day week.

The building at 225 East Fiftyfirst Street, recently altered by the Maryland Realty Company, Inc., to provide a series of duplex apartments, is now fully rented, according to the Burgoyne Hamilton Co., Inc.

Miss Marion Langdon Train, daughter of Commander and Mrs. Harold Cecil Train, was married this afternoon to Ensign Townsend. Hathaway, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Amos Hathaway of Bakersfield, Calif. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bride's parents by Captain Edward D. Webb, Chaplain, U. S. N.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 11.--Eight of the most important generals of the Red Army will be tried behind closed doors today by a special session of the Supreme Court of the Soviet Union on charges of treason.

Charles C. Merriam, trading as Caswell Agency, New Haven, Conn., has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop representing that his Hollywood Nights perfume is a "new sensation in perfume," that it originates in Paris, has been endorsed by Hollywood's most discriminating stars,

An all-Scottish final tomorrow for the 1937 British women's golf championship was assured today when Miss Jessie Anderson of Perth and Miss Doris Park of Edinburgh fought their way through the quarter and semi-finals.

The A. F. Brown Company property here, consisting of four and one-half acres of land, nineteen factory buildings and a power house, was acquired today by Samuel Lefkowitz of 152 West Forty-second Street, New York, for a Manhattan real estate company on a bid of $6,600.
President Eamon de Valera's government after four and a half years in office will terminate its existence on Monday after the Dail Eireann passes the final stages of the new Constitution.

Count and Countess Bohdan de Castellane gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for her daughter, Miss Helen Van Cortlandt de Peyster, and her fiance, Eric A. yon Raits. Other guests were the Duke and Duchess Armand de Richelieu, Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff,

While alcoholic beverage tax collections for May showed an increase of $423,062.57 over the corresponding period of last year, they showed a slight decrease compared to the April collection, Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, revealed today.
Montclair Academy will present diplomas to a class of thirty-one at the annual commencement tomorrow at 3:30 P. M. in Unity Church here.

The Reds evened their four-game series with the Bees today by coming from behind with a two-run drive in the ninth to score a 6-5 victory over Ira Hutchinson, who, as usual, had to overcome a poor start. The Reds reached Hutchinson for four runs in the second, but the Bees overhauled them by scoring in the third, fifth and sixth.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Cornelia Durant Robbins, daughter of Mrs. Loring Robbins of Pittsfield, Mass., and the late Mr. Robbins, to Russ Van Vleck Bradley, son of Mrs. Van Vleck Bradley of Greenwich, Conn., and of Harold Hall Bradley of Pasadena. Calif.
Mrs. Louise Brooks Howard, granddaughter of Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury of this city, is to be married to Nelson Cover of Baltimore, it was learned today.
The living costs of wage-earners rose substantially last month, according to a survey published yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, 247 Park Avenue.

The string quartet in C major by David Stanley Smith has been chosen for publication by the Socity for the Publication of American Music, it was announced yesterday. This is the fourth work of Dr. Smith's to be selected by the society. The others were a string quartet, Op. 46; a sonata for violin and piano, and a sonata for piano and oboe.

Clad in a new polka-dot dress and wearing a cheerful grin, a dusky, gray-haired 70-year-old follower of Father Divine led thirty or more students of the PWA Adult Education Center at St. Martin's Church in Harlem to the platform of a small auditorium of the church yesterday morning.
President Roosevelt today received on behalf of the government a painting given by James Montgomery Flagg as an aid toward the campaign of fire prevention being carried on by the Forest Service.

Charges of blacklisting and of interference with the right of employes to organize, brought against three Auburn shoe concerns by the National Labor Relations Board, were dismissed for lack of evidence today by Dr. John A. Lapp of Washington, trial examiner.

After leaving a note describing in detail how to reach the spot where his body would be found, Stephen F. Kourch, a former Russian nobleman, 42 years old, of Cambridge, graduate of the Harvard Business School in 1930, shot himself through the heart with a rifle in Belmont.

Commencement week at Polytechnic Institute opened yesterday with alumni day, when about 400 old graduates visited the institute at 99 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. More than 250 alumni attended a dinner last night in the gymnasium at which Harry S. Rogers, president of the institute, was speaker.
The total acreage of wheat and coarse grains seeded in Canada during 1937 will be less than last year. according to a crop report issued today by the Bank of Montreal.

A funeral service will be held at 2 P. M. today at the Universal Funeral Chapel, 597 Lexington Avenue, for Joseph Gahm, pianist, composer and music teacher. Mr. Gahm died on Wednesday at the, Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 71. Burial will be in Winthrop, Mass.

The Maracaibo Oil Exploration Corporation has contracted to employ Ernest L. Wilson for one year as its vice president, the company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Wilson, in addition to an annual salary of $6,000, is to have an option to buy 10,000 unissued shares of $1 par value capital stock at $5.40 a share for the year commencing on July 1, next.

NEWARK, N. J., June 10.--Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of the Burlington County detectives, took the witness stand today in the seventh week of his trial in the Federal court here to answer in his own words the government's conspiracy charge against him and his 26-year-old son, Ellis, Jr.

While the veterans Dick and Hubert Glendon were shaking their heads over a near-gale that curtailed the work of the Columbia crews today, an evening train pulled into Poughkeepsie on the opposite bank and left thirty-one young men who are expected to carry the main burden for the East in the Intercollegiate Rowing Associatin regatta on June 22.

When the future Sir ROBERT BORDEN became leader of the Canadian Conservative party in 1901 his prospects were of the gloomiest. The ablest lieutenants of Sir JOHN MACDONALD were gone. BORDEN ended a period of inefficient party management. He showed vigor, common sense and courage.

Directors of the Consolidated Chemical Industries, Inc., at the regular meeting yesterday in San Francisco declared an extra dividend of 12 1/1 cents a share together with the regular quarterly distribution of 37A cents.. Both are payable on Aug. 1 to holders of Class A and B stock of record of July 15.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in May amounted to 1,304,039 gross tons, the second best for the month on record. The record for any month was 1,539,738 tons, made in May, 1929.

L. Albert Samstag, real estate executive, formerly a manufacturer of novelty jewelry, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at his home, 9 West Seventy-fourth Street. He was born in Washogton but had lived in this city since bQyhood. His age was 59.
Archduchess Ilena of Austria disclosed tonight that three specialists had been summoned to examine her mother, Dowager Queen Marie of Rumania, in her Summer residence at Sinaia, Rumania.

More than twenty-four hours after she is reported to have told her household she was going to Huntington, a few miles away, presumably to show some property to a prospective buyer, Mrs. William H. Parsons still was missing tonight From her Long Island farmhouse.

President Roosevelt appointed Charles Harwood of Rye, N. Y., today to be district judge of the Canal Zone.
