Mr. Harwood, who is 57 years old, acted as special assistant to the Attorney General in the prosecution of the Federal Government case against some of the mortgage guarantee companies in the. New York area and conducted the trial which resulted in the conviction of three officers of the Westchester Title and Trust Company.
The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. approved today three of the treaties signed last year at the Inter-American- Conference for Maintenance of Peace at Buenos Aires.

The Board of Superintendents is conducting an investigation into the reasons why more than fifty teachers have asked for transfers from the John Adams High School, Queens, during the seven years that Dr. William A. Clarke has been its principal, Jacob Greenberg, Associate Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.

A bill giving the Treasury Department authority to issue currency against about $800,000,000 in gold deposits accumulated under the Federal Gold Purchase Law was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma.

Senator Joseph Robinson of Arkansas, the Senate majority leader, told a committee representing the People's Lobby today that there was no likelihood of a decrease in Federal expenditures for social welfare work.

By a two-to-one decision the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today rejected the plea of Madison Square Garden officials for an injunction to stop the heavyweight fight between James J. Braddock, world champion, and Joe Louis, scheduled for June 22 at Comiskey Park, Chicago.

Ending a deadlock which threatened to split the Westchester Young Republicans and the members. of the "Old Guard," the executive committee of the Westchester County Republican Committee agreed this afternoon on Harold Mercer of White Plains as its candidate for County Clerk in the Autumn election.
The largest class in the history of the Newark College of Engineering will be graduated tomorrow night at commencement exercises in the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company auditorium here.
Gilbert Hunt of Washington advanced into the semi-final round of the Pennsylvania State tennis championship today by vanquishing William T. Tilden 3d of Philadelphia, 6-4, 6-3.

Conflict between the Municipal Civil Service Commission and the World's Fair Corporation headed by Grover A. Whalen resulted yesterday in the commission's move to close all its civil service lists to the corporation until the latter makes public the appointments it has made from them.

The force of 3,050 special employes maintained by the Treasury Department at the peak of bonus disbursements now has been reduced to 490 persons and further reductions are expected about July 1, it was learned today from Treasury officials.

Frances Pottasch, 15-year-old pianist, won the first prize of a gold medal as the outstanding performer in the final sessions of the senior division of the amateur musical instrument contest, held on the Central Park Mall last evening.

Continued apathy toward the bond market on the part of most investors left traders yesterday free to make appraisals of certain outstanding obligations affected by special situations, with the result that the market generally held within a narrow range in exceedingly light trading.

A woman was killed and nine other persons were injured, most of them slightly, in an accident which involved a police emergency truck, two other trucks and four private automobiles in Jamaica, Queens, at 4:30 P. M. yesterday.
The standing among the eleven professionals in the running for four remaining places on the Ryder Cup team shows Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., leading.

George W. Burpee, a partner in the New York engineering firm of Coverdale Colpitts, testified today in the United States District Court here that valuations placed on carrier properties of five railroads by New Jersey for purposes of taxation were excessively high.

Piloterror, the most important factor in the majority of recent airplane accidents, is in part caused by "oxygen want" when airplanes are operated at 10,000 feet or higher, Dr. Allan L. Barach of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, New York, said today at a meeting of the pharmacology section of the American Medical Association convention here.

American producers have under way construction of new plants for the production of various types of synthetic fibers, but little may be expected in the way of an increase of viscose process rayon yarns this year, it was said here yesterday.

Nothing could better illustrate the erratic economic situation created by the currency-tampering of the past four years or more than the recurrent fright of financial markets over the present " gold situation." In times gone by, an increase in gold production and in gold imports by the United States was invariably considered an auspicious financial indication.

The 3,000 truckmen and warehouse laborers who have been on strike in 192 warehouses in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens will return to work this morning as a result of an agreement reached yesterday between the Warehousemen's Association of the Port of...
Amelia Earhart dropped her light monoplane down to a perfect landing at this African outpost along the Niger River today to complete another span on her leisurely flight around the world.

The California polo four, which arrived here a week ago for the season on Long Island, took the field for the first time today and met with defeat at the hands of Stewart Iglehart's Whites. The score was 12-4.

Dr. Frederick R. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation, told the graduating class at Cooper Union last night that the seventyeight-year-old institution represents a type of education which has been neglected in America because "our universities have not had the intelligence to recognize that instruction in the creative arts is as high a service as they could render."

The market for new wheat on the Board of Trade today showed extreme sensitiveness to unfavorable Spring wheat advices. Prices raflied 3 cents or more a bushel on reports of black rust in North Dakota and Minnesota, but when these reports were denied they dropped about 2 cents from the top to close unchanged to 3/8 cent up.
Bert McDowell, Baton Rouge (La.) amateur, posted the only double figures for any hole played

The Dartmouth Athletic Council today ratified the election of Richards H. Heneage as varsity golf captain, as well as awarding letters in varsity lacrosse and golf and numerals in five freshman sports.

Volume on men's Summer furnishings in local retail stores has spurted considerably this week, with slacks, bathing suits, sport shirts and similar accessories moving very freely, store executives reported here yesterday. Sales in some instances ran 15 per cent ahead of last year, it was said. Gabardines and tropicals continued to attract the bulk of the business

Store buyers yesterday considered plans to encourage manufacturers to affix a uniform label or tag to housewares and bathroom accesseries manufactured in the standard shades, recently approved at the conference held by the National Bureau of Standards of the Department of Commerce.

Suburban National, Inc., sold a tract of land on Spring Brook Road, in the Spring Brook Estate, Morristown, N. J., to Henry W. Rogers. The broker was Eugene V. Welsh, who also sold a plot in the Spring Brook Estate for Mrs. Dumont Foote to Urban S. Fowle for a new home.
Joe Louis, challenger for the world heavyweight championship held by Jim Braddock, worked today under the eyes of Illinois State Boxing Commission representatives.

BERLIN, June 10.--There are certain signs that the long-delayed Protestant Church elections may be sprung on the German public suddenly in the near future. The chiefs of the national church movement favored by Hanns Kerrl, Minister of Church Affairs, have been spending considerable time in Berlin recently.

The King Pirate," by Edward and Theodosia Thompson, staged at St. Martin's Theatre tonight, is virtually a chronicle play of Sir Walter Raleigh's release from London Tower, his last voyage to Guiana, his betrayal by King James I and his return to face execution.

Officials of the Chevrolet Motor Company and the Fisher Body Corporation, both General Motors plants here, and leaders representing 2,200 striking U. A. W. A. workers of the two plants adjourned a peace conference late today until tomorrow.
The Red Sox and Senators appeared to have strengthened their clubs today, five days before the trading deadline, by exchanging their managers' "problem children" in a deal that involved five players.

An extensive campaign to sell the virtues of brandy to the United States will be necessary if this country is to consume an amount commensurate with its size, Michel Martell, partner in the 222-year-old cognac firm of J. F. Martell of Cognac, France, said here yesterday.

Senate action today assured a Congressional investigation into charges of income-tax evasion and avoidance. Only President Roosevelt's signature was needed to start the inquiry after the Senate approved the House form of a resolution to create a joint investigating committee.

Unmindful of warning showers which started shortly after noon, the Giants and Cardinals went through all the motions of beginning the third and concluding game of their series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The Friends Seminary held its 151st commencement exercises last night at the Friends Meeting House, East Fifteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square. The speaker was the Rev. Harold E. Nicely of the Brick Presbyterian Church, East Orange, N.J.

The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind will hold commencement exercises this afternoon in Schermerhorn Hall at the school, 999 Pelham Parkway, Bronx. Dr. Merle E. Frampton, principal, will give the address and award diplomas and prizes.

In connection with New YorkBermuda air service, which is to begin scheduled operations with passengers next week, it was ascertained here yesterday that air mail would be carried one way only, from Bermuda to the United States, by one of the two participating airlines, Imperial Airways.

An effort to enlist support of tobacco retailer throughout the country will be made tonight at the convention of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America for the Miller-Tydings Bill, which would validate State fair trade acts in interstate commerce, but on which President Roosevelt has asked Congress to delay action.

The Dies Immigration Bill, designed to strengthen statutes for the deportation of "gun-carrying" aliens, was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate. The purpose of the bill is to lengthen the arm of the Federal law to permit the government to deport certain types of alien criminals who heretofore have escaped

The Tigers put on a two-run rally with one out in the ninth inning to defeat the Athletics in the series finale today, 4 to 3. Billy Rogell singled with the bases filled to provide the margin of victory.

The formation of the strictly Polish Camp of National Unity for the political reorganization of the country is also giving a new turn to the policy of the Polish Government toward the Slavic minorities within Poland, which comprise some 7,000,000 persons, or roughly 20 per cent of the total population.

Baffled by an elementary question that arose in connection with a problem presented in their recent mathematics final, a group of seniors in the Princeton Country Day School decided that only Einstein could answer it, so they took it to .him, it became known today.

Haile Gold Mines, Inc., New York City, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Ac. of 1933 covering 650,000 shares of 25 cents par common, of which 150,000 have been optioned to an underwriter for resale at the market and 78O,000 may be offered at the market if underwritten.

The Hamburg - American liner Hansa, arriving today from Hamburg, Bremen and Channel ports, has among her passengers Frederick William Best, Felix Schwering, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Engelke, Johan Lindroth, Mrs. D. de Waal Meyer, Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Klau, Mrs. Anna Joetze, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Schumacher, J. A. Binning, Mr. and Mrs. D. L. Mahood, Dr. and Mrs. Friedrich Solmsen, Mrs. Ada Varnung and Mr. and Mrs. August Hofmann.

Commencement exercises of the Guggenheim School for Dental Hygienists were held-last night in the auditorium of the Julia Richman High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue. Professor Charles Gray Shaw of New York University was the speaker.

A visit was made today to the Rome Fish Hatchery by Commissioner Osborne's party on its swing around this part of the State. New trout ponds are being constructed along the bed of the abandoned Black River Barge Canal for a distance of almost a mile.
Dr. Roswell Gray Ham, presidentelect of Mount Holyoke College, will be the commencement speaker tomorrow at the exercises in the Hartridge School here.

Yesterday's news from abroad underlined in striking fashion one reason why dictatorships are unhealthy. They are secret Governments. They keep the world in a state of turmoil and alarm because they are able to operate without debate and without publicity. Nobody can be sure why they act or what they are going to do next.

Nicaragua has prohibited the ex-. portation of cattle to Costa Rica, although for years a considerable number has been imported here annually. When Costa Rica placed an import duty on cattle from Nicaragua to protect local cattlemen, Nicaragua retaliated with an export tax and now has decreed complete prohibition of such exports to Costa Rica.

The more closely the proposed Congressional investigation of tax evasion and tax avoidance is considered, the more difficult it becomes to see any justification for it. There are three possible types of tax evasion: The first is actual fraud. Where that exists it is the duty of the Treasury to bring immediate criminal action against the taxpayer guilty of it.

The Rural Electrification Administration closed today its allotment books for the current fiscal year after earmarking $46,499,482 for specific rural electrification projects out of a total of $50,000,000 made available for loans this year under the terms of the act of 1936.

Axel Sahlin, prominent construction engineer, died in his eighty-second year today at the home of a relative. He was decorated three times by his native Sweden and had lived in the United States twenty years. He formerly was superintendent of the Maryland Steel Company at Sparrows Point, Md.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $82,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday.

Miss Dorothy Conner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Horace Conner of 130 East Sixty-seventh Street, and Rye, N. Y., was married to Dr. Howard G. Bruenn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Bruenn of this city, yesterday at the home in Rye of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Augustus Godley.

The protection and security of the United States Governrient, and an American standard of living must be assured to the widows and orphans of disabled World War veterans, State Commander Milton Cohn told the opening session of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War convention meeting here.
Sinclair Lewis, a graduate of 1907, has presented to Yale University the manuscript of his novel, "It Can't Happen Here," according to an announcement today by President James Rowland Angell.

The Associated Glee Clubs of America will present a combined chorus of 1,000 voices in its first New York open air "pop" concert in the Stadium on Randalls Island tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. The concert is tendered the public by invitation of Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Moses, who will attend with other city officials.

A plea that the American people overcome the- "habit of expecting everything of the Federal Government" and "get back to self-reliance" was made here today by Jesse H. Jones, speaking at the Temple University commencement exercises, at which he received the degree of Doctor of Laws and degrees in courses were awarded to 1,091 graduates.

During the week ended June 9 member bank reserve balances increased $75,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases from $52,000,000 in money in circulation, $30,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $18,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold, offset in part by an increase of $23,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Warnings of the perils confronting American life and especially American education were sounded today by two speakers at the opening ceremonies of the five-day centennial celebration of Colby Junior College for Women.

Properties in a wide area of the West Side figured in Manhattan real estate sales reported yesterday. The six-story apartment at 105-7 Christopher Street, in Greenwich Village, has been purchased by Loomis J. Grossman from William

Mayor La Guardia said last night that he was opposed to salary restorations for all appointive city ,officers receiving $5,000 a year or more, though he favored restorations for the bulk of civil service employes earning less than $5,000.

The Roosevelt Court Bill neared the Senate floor today, after more than four months of controversy, when a majority of the Senate Judiciary Committee approved the draft of its report recommending rejection of the legislation.
Government crop experts predicted today that the wheat harvest in the United States this year would be between 825,000,000 and 850,000,000 bushels--the largest in six years.
Hugh Leo Kerwin, director of the conciliation service of the Labor Department, died tonight of a heart attack after a brief illness. His age was 64. He was a native of Blossburg, Pa.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 10.--Mayor Lionel Evans made the first move today to swear in special police and buy extra equipment, as threats of a city-wide general strike followed the riot early in the morning at one of the gates of the Republic Steel Corporation, when two policemen were beaten,

Late as it is in the Spring season--or early as it is in the Summerexhibitions' continue to open in the galleries. Two of those which arrived yesterday are about as dissimilar as any pair of offerings the galleries have put forward in along time.
The first of the carriers to report for May, the Alton Railroad, showed a reduction in the deficit, after charges , to $174,074, compared with $188.016 for the same month in 1936.

John Hughes, 28-year-old New Yorker who shot and killed an 82-year-old German here on Feb. 26, has been adjudged dangerously insane after three months under observation and will not be tried for murder. The German authorities would prefer that Hughes were placed in the hands of the United States Consulate and transported to America.

The first man to break par in the first round of the national open golf championship over the Oakland Hills course here today--and still here tomorrow--was Mike of the many Turnesas. There are seven golfing Turnesas but only Mike and Jim are here to uphold the family prestige on the links.

A building and permanent loan for $130,000 has been arranged by Morgenth?? Corp, M. Morgenthau Jr., president, and Maquire Mullowney, Inc., on the six-story apartment under construction on the southwest corner of 97th St and 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Ridge Colonial Gardens, Inc, Jesse L. Dann, president, is the owner.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, called a strike of about 1,800 employes of the United Drydocks, Inc., last night at its plant at Mariners Harbor, S. I.

The Westdeutsched Beobachter, Nazi party organ for the Rhineland, declared today that German firms should not be represented abroad by Jewish agents. Such suggestions usually are made in party organs only with the approval of Nazi higher-ups.

The French Surete Nationale searched tonight for a Rumanian doctor and a Brazilian Boy Scout leader who disappeared mysteriously from the liner Raoul Soarez. Pedro Peroni, the Boy Scout chief, vanished while looking for "a beautiful blond German girl." Dr. R. Dadiani disappeared while looking for Peroni.
Dr. William Foster Peirce, for fortyone years president of the centuryold Kenyon College here, will retire following the commencement of the college beginning tomorrow.

Willie Turnesa of Briar Hills launched the defense of his Westchester amateur golf championship over the wind-swept Century Country Club course today and was signally successful. The youngest of the Turnesa clan tied for the medal in the qualifying round with Howard Bergman, a so-called weekend linksman from Metropolis.
The Godfrey Investing Corporation sold to Rose Gordon the one-family house at 731 East Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, through the Boise Nash Realty Company.

The revised list of the thirty-nine track and field stars who will constitute the starting fields in the seven events at the fourth annual Princeton invitation track meet, scheduled for Palmer Stadium Saturday, June 19, was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics in Princeton University.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler has ordered the construction here of a sixtystory skyscraper that will rival all but the Highest New York buildings. It is not to be a commercial building like the American skyscrapers but the Hamburg regional National Socialist headquarters and a monument to the Third Reich's "power and glory," to use the words of the German press. The first floor will be taken up by a mammoth auditorium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Krock's article "The Facts in Strike Mail Service Dispute" is an admirable justification of the Postoffice Department, but certain other fundamental facts and possibilities of this matter should not be overlooked.

Net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries for the first quarter of 1937 amounted to $1,658,438, equal to 26 cents a share on 6,399,002 shares of no-par capital stock, compared with $815,968, or 13 cents a share, in the 1936 period.

Patrolman George W. Bergmann of Traffic P was elected president of the St. George's Association of the Police Department, newly formed organization for Protestant members of the force, at a meeting last night in the line-up gallery at police headquarters. More than 400 members attended.

With a total of 42,883,000 engineering construction contracts awarded in the week ended yesterday exceeded the figure for the same period of 1936 by 20 per cent, according to The Engineering News-Record. Last year's figure for the week was $35,626,000.
Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, laughed today after he learned why nearly half his audience in the town of Niskayuna left a meeting which he was addressing.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 10.--A new champion loomed in the inter-city matches for the Griscom Cup at the Plainfield Country Club following the 11-to-4 defeat suffered by the defending Boston team at the hands of Philadelphia today.

A New York Stock, Exchange membership has been transferred from the late Nathaniel King to James O. Studdiford of Eisele, King Studdiford and another from John R. MacKinney to John A. Hance of Jesup Lamont.
King Boris today conferred on Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, the highest Bulgarian decoration, after which the monarch was host at a luncheon for the statesman.

With world output of rayon aggregating 1,303,165,000 pounds in 1936, which was an all-time high, Japan supplanted the United States as the largest producer, according to figures compiled by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., and contrained in the current issue of The Rayon Organon,
The United States Treasury yesterday notified depositary banks in this Federal Reserve district that it had called for repayment on Monday $6,296,830 of its deposits with them.
Total government expenditures for the current fiscal year through June 8 reached $7,000,121,468, according to the Treasury Daily Statement for that date made available today.

Graduates of the Berkeley Divinity School were told today by Bishop William Appleton Lawrence of Western Massachusetts "that to life overgrown with materialism he should emphasize the life of the spirit with God.

A court action against the Pittsburgh Coal Company, which supplies the Youngstown area in Ohio with coal from Pennsylvania, was recommended today by Frank E. Mullen, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, for the purpose of finding out if the company's subsidiary railroads were violating the law.

A sudden thunderstorm, loosing torrents of rain, interrupted heat that rose to 83 degrees yesterday afternoon but failed to break it. In less than an hour, between warm sunshine before and after the storm, the temperature dropped four degrees, but at 5 P. M., more than an hour after the storm, it was back to 80 again.

Sir Robert L. Borden, wartime Prime Minister of Canada and the first statesman under whom Canada became a nation with a separate voice in foreign affairs--although that was only formally recognized by the statute of Westminster, seven years later--died early today at his home here at the age of 82, sixteen days before he would have celebrated his eighty-third birthday.

Urie F. Mandle and Harry Heiferman have become associated with Nat Levy Co., 302 Fifth Avenue, which has changed its name to the Nat Levy-Urie Mandle Corporation, dealing in costume jewelry and dress accessories.

The National Bank of America and the National Union Bank announced today that their officers had approved plans for a merger of the two institutions. The new bank will be known as the National Union Bank of America in Paterson and will occupy the

In separate conversations with the French, German and Italian Ambassadors today Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden reached a virtual agreement regarding the measures to be adopted for protection of warships patrolling Spanish coast and the guarantees for their safety to be required from the warring factions there.

Members of the Bond Club of New York, headed by Frank F. Walker of Eastman, Dillon Co., president, will be guests today at the fifteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of Philadelphia at the Philmont Country Club, Philmont, Pa.

A sharp drop in originating shipments and a larger than seasonal decrease in new passenger-car registrations caused the index of business activity in the Pittsburgh district to fall nearly 2 points last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The famous festival of the Red Rose will be celebrated here Sunday. This unique historical service grew out of a stipulation in 1772 by the Colonial glassmaker, Henry William Stiegel, to the Lutherans of Manheim that a ground rent of "one red rose" was to be paid to "Henry W. Stiegel, his heirs or assigns in the month of June yearly forever hereafter if legally demanded."

With much thwacking of their whimsy sticks, Dorothy Parker, Alan Campbell and Variety's Joe Bigelow have beaten out an antic farce for Samuel Goldwyn. "Woman Chases Man" is as descriptive a title as any and' it fits the new show at the Music Hall.

More than 2,000 members of the Doll and Toy Workers Union, at a meeting in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, voted yesterday to secede from the American Federation of Labor and join the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Miss Agnes Forshew Schlegel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Schlegel of Scarsdale, was married last night to Herbert Spencer Gardner Jr. in the Church of St. James the Less, Scarsdale. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Henry Fitzgerald, rector of Christ Church, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and the Rev. Alan Chalmers of St. James the Less.

Sam Snead. the boy with a milliondollar future, and Denny Shute, recent repeater in the P. G. A., put themselves in an enviable spot as the forty-first national open golf championship got under way on the fearsome Oakland Hills Country Club course today.

The engagement of Miss Frances Preston to Matthew Hale, son of Mrs. Matthew Hale of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Hale, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Veryl Preston of 25 West Ninth Street.

Protesting a prospective cut of 40 per cent in the personnel of the Federal Theatre Project in New Jersey, the cast of the play, "The Trial of Doctor Beck" started a sit-in demonstation after tonight's performance at the Shubert Theatre, Branford Place off Broad Street.

President Roosevelt nominated Charles Harwood to be district judge of the Canal Zone, received from James Moritgomery Flagg a painting donated to the government to aid the campaign for prevention of forest fires, and transacted routine business.
Attorney General Bennett ruled today that women are eligible as trial jurors in every county in the State, in spite of special or local acts which'had limited jury service to "male citizens."

Sing Sing sentences of seven and one-half to ten years each ere imposed yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions on Joseph Berger, 29 years old, of 643 Warwick Street, and Gabriel Klar, 31, of 618 Chester Street, both of Brooklyn, in the fatal stabbing of Frank Cicero, 33; a truckman, at a testimonial dinner in the Manhattan Opera House on the night of Jan. 17 last.

A gift of $615,773 for long-range,pioneering research in increasing the rate at which plants, especially trees, store solar energy in forms suitable for human use was announced today by Harvard University.

The forty-sixth annual prize day of Rosemary Hall School, Greenwich, held this afternoon, was marked by many events and ceremonies. Members of the graduating class, formed in procession, marched to St. Bede's Chapel, where a brief service took place, followed by exercises in the gymnasium at which Miss Caroline Ruutz-Rees, founder and headmistress of the school, presented the diplomas, and Miss Mary Elizabeth Lowndes awarded the prizes.

Malcolm Williams, character actor and husband of Florence Reed, died yesterday of heart disease at his apartment in the Hotel Windsor, 100 West Fifty-eighth Street. He was 67 years old. His last appearance on the stage is listed in the records as in a play called "Purity," which opened on Broadwav Christmas night. 1930.

Coach Lou Werner's Newtown High athletes, Queens P. S. A. L. champions since 1933, are favored to carry off the city crown this evening at Randalls Island Stadium, where the Public Schools Athletic League will stage its thirty-fourth annual senior high school outdoor track and field championships.

Mrs. Ruth Gray Wilson, painter and art instructor, died last night at her home, 25 Gordon Place here, after a short illness. Mrs. Wilson had been an art teacher at Wilson College in Chambersburg, Pa., and later exhibited her oils and watercolors in various cities of the East.

Great Britain took the first step today toward expanding her claims to territories of the South Pole, a step that might involve dispute with American explorers' claims to vast territories in the icy region.

An agreement affecting working conditions of hairdressers and cosmetologists of the Bronx was signed yesterday afternoon between the Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Union, Local 560 B, and the New York State Hairdressers Association.

Dr. Hiram Colver McNeil, wellknown chemist, died here on Tuesday night after a long illness. Professor McNeil, 70 years old, was a chemist who had worked in several bureaus of the Federal Government, as well as a university instructor. He was especially noted for investigations into the structure of natural silicates, into moisture determination, fractional crystallizations and analytical separations.
The Circuit Court of Appeals' refusal to restrain James J. Braddock from boxing Joe Louis was greeted at fight headquarters with satisfaction today.

Diplomas were presented to twentynine members of the senior class of Moses Brown School by L. Ralston Thomas, headmaster, at exercises in Alumni Hall. Dr. James L. McConaughty, president of Wesleyan University, gave the commencement address.

Strong indications that the Soviet Union is preparing an early airplane flight across the North Pole from Russia to the American Pacific Coast were disclosed in private talks in official and diplomatic quarters tonight.

The possibility of a Senate investigation into the entire strike situation in the Middle West arose here today when an administration group, led by Senator Guffey, sought to turn the agitation for an inquiry into alleged interference with the mail by strike picketers into a study of grievances on both sides.
The four-story walk-up at 929 Tiffany Street, between Beck and East 163d Streets, the Bronx, was sold by the Federated Realty Corporation, operators, to an investing client of Isidore L. Nitzberg,

Miss Elizabeth Blackford Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Boutwell Smith of Galveston, Texas, was married this afternoon to John Norman Henry Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. John Norman Henry of Gladwyn.

United States Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois transmitted today to the house of delegates of the American Medical Association, supreme ruling body of organized medicine, a personal message from President Roosevelt asking the medical profession to cooperate with him in the solution of medical problems within such provinces as organized medicine felt the "government should undertake."

The Consolidated Edison Company was accused yesterday of recognizing the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. of L. affiliate, in preference to the C. I. O., without permitting the 40,000 employes of the company and its affiliates to make a choice.

With cloak and suit manufacturers beginning to anticipate their needs for the Fall season, trading in the wool goods market showed signs of improvement this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Miss Diana Spofford Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shepard Morgan of 840 Park Avenue, and Wayne Gridley Jackson, son of Mrs. William Brinckerhoff Jackson of this city, have completed plans for their marriage, which will take place next Tuesday in the Congregational Church in Norfolk, Conn.
Reflecting the weakness in the London Metal Exchange, sales of copper were made yesterday at 13.66 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports, the lowest for the current movement.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Diamond Match Company and the Electric Auto-Lite Company had dismissed petitions to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for a review of orders of the commission denying confidential treatment to certain data filed in registration statements.

The national board of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, announced yesterday its opposition to "any form of partition, crystallization or cantonization of Palestine or any measure to whittle down the mandate that gives the Jews the opportunity of creating a Jewish national home in Palestine."

Kinship of spirit should be the dominant force of the commencement season, Dr. George H. Nettleton, Lampson Professor of English at Yale University, told the 177 graduates of the University of Newark at the commencement in the Mosque Theatre here tonight.

George V. Muchmore, prominent in the Sons of the American Revolution and an organizer of the Passaic Valley Chapter, died today at his home here at the age of 84. Mr. Muchmore established a coal and lumber business which he sold some years ago.

The idea of mailing food to the strike-bound plants of the Republic Steel Corporation, as a private gesture of protest against the suspension of such mail by postoffices in Ohio, seemed to strike the imagination of a number of citizens yesterday on reading of the four cans of sardines mailed by Dwight Scovel of Hopewell, N. J.

The complete production schedule of Paramount Pictures for 1937-38, announced yesterday, will include between fifty and sixty feature productions, of which twenty-two were classified as "million-dollar pictures" by Neil Agnew, vice president in charge of distribution, who made the announcement at the the company's annual meeting of sales and production heads in Los Angeles.

The growing importance of the nurse as an educator was stressed yesterday by Dr. Livingston Farrand, retiring president of Cornell University, in an address at the sixtieth graduation exercises of the New York Hospital School of Nursing, York Avenue and Seventieth Street.

Thousands of gayly, if sometimes incongruously, clad children, mothers and teachers, marched in review before Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and other State and city officials in Prospect Park yesterday at the climax of Brooklyn's 108th Sunday School parade.

Edward I. Conner Jr. starred today in the monthly oneday golf tourney conducted by the New York Athletic Club over the course of the North Hempstead Country Club. Conner registered the low gross for the morning round of nine holes, getting 39, and in the afternoon won in the first flight of match play. Close to a hundred players participated.

Waddill Catchings of New York, banker, advocated today nationwide groups of investment companies to re-sell large blocks of outstanding securities outside of the New York Stock Exchange. He said at the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of investment trusts that the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, of which he formerly was president, tried to organize such a group just before the crash in 1929.

Seegold Products, Inc. inter-office communications, floor in 12 E 44th St; James P. Foraker, additional space to Excel Metal Cabinet Co, Inc, in 101 Pak Ave; Michael Kallesser, and additional space to s. Duane Lyon, Inc. in 130 W 42d St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker.

In his first official comment on the recently proposed additional powers for the Securities and Exchange Commission, Edward B. Hall, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, urged tonight that Congress consider carefully before

Unorganized employes of the M. A. Worsted Company were conducting a sit-down strike today because, according to the management, they heard that other employes who have joined the Committee for Industrial Organization wanted to swap shifts with them and were preparing to stage a sit-down strike of their own.
Three horses once under the banner of John Hay Whitney finished one-two-three in the featured Ladkin Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, although they carried the colors of different owners.

Mr. and Mrs. Ten Broeck M. Terhune of 45 East Sixty-sixth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Terhune, to Herbert N. Rawlins Jr., son of Herbert N. Rawlins of this city and Southampton and of the late Mrs. Natalie Hatch Rawlins.

Charles G. Norris and his wife, Kathleen Norris, American novelists, returned on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia yesterday after a visit to Europe, during which they attended the coronation and studied conditions in Europe.

Trading somewhat uneven: some meats met with a fairly dependable demand, others sold slowly. Steer hinds and ribs ruled steady to strong. Lamb carcasses mostly unchanged. Fresh pork uneven, some cuts slightly higher, others lower.

The Phillies made it two in a row over the slipping Pirates today by pounding Bill Swift and Joe Bowman for a 5-to-4 victory. Late Pittsburgh rallies in the eighth and ninth innings just missed tying the score as the Phillies caught the potential tying run off third base with one out in the nint inning to save the victory for Bucky Walters.

The Bank of Canada decreased its holdings of gold coin and bullion more than $3,000,000 in the last week and' increased its holdings of sterling and United States dollars more than $5,000,000, according to its weekly statement, issued today.

The charge made by Charles Poletti, counsel to Governor Lehman and soon to assume a place on the Supreme Court, that the Republicans sought to sabotage the coming constitutional convention in the State was ignored last night by William S. Murray, Republican State Chairman.

Reports of uprisings and disorders among Manchukuoan and Mongolian troops in Chahar are partially confirmed by the Japanese authorities here. They declare, however, the disturbances were of minor importance and were easily checked.

Cardarrone, owned by William O'Toole's Blue Ridge Farm of Chicago, raced to an easy victory in the featured Wilmette Purse at Washington Park today. Coming back after finishing third to Count Morse in the Great Western Handicap last Saturday, Cardarrone, made the favorite, left no doubt as to his superiority.

Completing the longest trip ever made in this country by the newly motorized cavalry, the First Cavalry Motorized, United States Army, arrived in New York at 5:30 P. M. yesterday from Fort Knox, Ky., a distance of 1,000 miles.

Before 10,000 cheering townsfolk, 200 special deputies blasted away a C. I. O. picket line from in front of the local steel plant last evening and cleared the way for about 500 men to go back to work.

Officials of the Federal Water Service Corporation indicated yesterday that the company would register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
The Bankhead Farm Tenancy Bill was unanimously approved today by the Senate Committee on Agriculture, which voted to report it to the Senate with a recommendation that it ne passed.

A neighbor told in Federal Court today the license number of a "suspiciously operated" sedan, which was parked near the Albany home of John J. O'Connell Jr. the night the latter was kidnapped in 1933.
The five-story school building at 109 East Sixtieth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, has been leased by the Mutual Life Insurance Company for "a new venture in the educational field."

Dr. Irvin Abell, Professor of Surgery at the University of Louisville School of Medicine, was chosen president-elect of the American Medical Association today, to take office at the eighty-ninth annual convention next year in San Francisco.

A full day's schedule of exercises marked today's "June Week" program at the Military Academy, where the culminating event, the graduation of the 298 cadets comprising the class of 1937, will take place Saturday morning.

Ground was broken today for a new $400,000 home for the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, on a twelve-acre tract at Forrest Avenue and Sylvan Oval near Yonkers Avenue, here. The new structures are to be of Colonial design and comprise five fire proof units;

The office furniture, equipment and supplies of The New York Woman, Inc., were sold at auction yesterday by order of the United States District Court of the Southern District of New York in liquidation proceedings on the premises of the publication at 11 East Thirty-sixth Street.

Miss Louise de Carron, teacher of languages and member of a distinguished Huguenot family, died last night of pneumonia at her home here. Miss de Carron was born in France, coming to this country forty years ago. She became an instructor in Miss. Low's School at Stamford, Conn.;

Intercession by the State Department in behalf of Jews in Poland suffering from anti-Semitic agitation, was asked last night by 1,500 representatives of 400 Jewish organizations at an emergency conference summoned by the American Jewish Congress in the Hotel Astor.

A par-shattering 71 by Joseph Thompson, son of a prominent Canadian professional, topped Charles H. Mayo Jr., defending titleholder, for the qualifying honors in the Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship tourney at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

In a vigorous attack on the Black-Connery Labor Standards Bill, the National Association of Manufacturers told the joint Congressional committee that, if Congress was determined thus to "strait-jacket" American industry,

American naval architects and marine engineers will play indispensable parts in building up the American merchant marine under the terms of the new Federal Shipping Act, James A. Farrell, former president of the United States Steel Corporation, told the 1937 graduating class at Webb Institute of...

Graduation exercises of the Pingry School will be held here tomorrow night in the school gymnasium. Conover English, secretary of the board of trustees, will present diplomas and certificates, and E. Laurence Springer, principal, will speak.

One hundred and fifteen men in a power plant in Michigan have given the country a timely demonstration of what can happen when practically the whole emphasis of public policy is put on labor's rights and very little emphasis is put on labor's duties and responsibilities.
With allowance made for the holiday, the dip in lumber production last week was only seasonal and the adjusted index remained unchanged at 95.8. It was 84.3 for the week ended June 6, 1936.
Three separate Federal court actions today were unfavorable to Harley L. Clarke, founder and erstwhile president of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 13,000, including 6,000 directs. Market generally 10 to 15 cents higher than Wednesday's average: packing sows strong to 10 cents higher; late trade closed with part of advance lost; top, $11.60; bulk good and choice 200-300 pound average, $11.35-55: comparable 150-190 pound, $10.75$11.45. Most packing sows, $10.25-70. Shippers, 1,500: estimated holdover, 1,000.

His greatest contribution to New York City, Mayor La Guardia declared last night, is that its government can never be as "bad and inefficient" as he found it when he took office. He spoke at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore given for him by the Neighborhood House of

Dr. C. T. Wang, the new Chinese Ambassador, at his first press conference today pledged his country "to help promote international trade through cooperative efforts, thereby laying the foundation for world peace."

Governors of American Rotary districts who were elected today at the International Rotary Convention include: Robert R. Bangham, Wilmington, Ohio; William M. Brandon, Davenport, Iowa; Charles N. Cadwallader, Lincoln, Neb.; John W. Chapman, Santa Fe, N. M.; The Rev. Harry A. Cochran, Taylorville, Ill.; The Rev. A. Elliston Cole, Bloomington, Ind.; Edward M. Conant, Minneapolis, Minn.; H. V. Cooper, Vicks. burg, Miss.

William V. Hinckley, chairman of the National Council of the American Youth Congress, made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt urging that the National Youth Administration be expanded and made permanent.

The imposing residence of the late Jacob H. Schiff, one of a rapidly dwindling group of large private dwellings on Fifth Avenue, has been sold along with adjoining property. to a realty group which will raze the mansion and erect in its stead an eighteen-story apartment building.

The stock markets here were extremely quiet today and most of the sections lost ground Gilt-edge issues were better at the close, although among the foreign loans German bonds eased on profit - taking.
Nicky Jerome, 126, Williamsburg, earned the decision over Henry Hook, 124, Indianapolis, in the feature eight-round boxing bout at Fort Hamilton last night before a crowd of 4,500 persons.

William Russell Noyes, former trust officer of the Equitable Trust Company, who served as a second lieutenant with the United States Army in the World War, was found dead of a stab wound yesterday in asement furnished room at 314 West Eighty-ninth Street. He was 56 years old.

Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, as American agents for Kingdom of Bulgaria 7 per cent settlement loan of 1927, announced yesterday that July 1, 1937, coupons will be paid on or after that date at the rate of $11.38 for each $35 coupon and $5.69 for each $17.50 coupon in full settlement for and against surrender of these coupons.

The Davega Stores Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on March 27 a net income of $387,484 after depreciation, amortization, interest, provision for bad debts and repossession losses, Federal and State income taxes,
Mrs. Edward Bailey Downing of Seattle has announced the wedding of her daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Downing, to James Willis Bigelow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray E. Bigelow of Shippan Point, Stamford.

The management of the New York Stock Exchange ordered yesterday an investigation, to be conducted by the business conduct committee, into the recent market gyrations of the preferred issues of the New York Steam Corporation.

Miss Marjorie Louise Burrows, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Griggs Burrows of Kew Gardens, was married last night to Wilbur Le Compte McIntyre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Daniel McIntyre of East Orange, N. J. The ceremony was performed in the Church of the Resurrection, Richmond Hill, on the twenty-ninth wedding anniversary of the bride's parents, by the Rev. Arthur Cummings,

Miss Elizabeth Shelby Sinclair and Louis Wood Hoyle, whose engagement was announced during the Winter, will be married on the afternoon of June 29 at the home of the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Arthur Sinclair, at 277 Park Avenue. The ceremony will be attended only by near relatives and a few friends.

The International Olympic Committee at its session today cleared the way for admission of instructors as competitors in the Olympic Games.. The I. O. C. inserted a clause in the Olympic rules barring persons engaged in training as a gainful occupation but admitting teachers of sports, as part of a general curriculum, such as those in primary schools.
Twenty-five hundred trade associations have been invited to participate in an annual competition to determine the outstanding achievement of a trade association.

By cable and very quietly, the outstanding song and dance show thus far announced for next season has just acquired its star. George M. Cohan will be: the principal person in that musical comedy which, flying the Sam H. Harris banner, will have a book by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart and a score by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart.

Rain stopped the Cubs for ten minutes at Ebbets Field yesterday, thereby proving infinitely more effective than Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers. For when play was resumed after the downpour, Charley Grimm's boys promptly scored four runs in the second frame and went on to win, 9-3.

The Crestmont Golf Club team of John F. Dolan and Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., New Jersey women's titleholder, today carded a combined eighteen-hole score of 172 to capture low gross honors in the second annual mixed foursome tournament of the women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Echo Lake Country Club.

Negotiations for a contract between the Third Avenue Railway Company and the Transport Workers Union, spokesman for the company's 3,500 employes, began yesterday at a conference in the company's offices at 129th Street and Third Avenue.

Miss Rosemary Barbara Cullen, daughter of Mrs. Michael J. Cullen of Jamaica, Queens, and the late Mr. Cullen was married yesterday morning to Dr. John J. McKenna, sonl of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel T. McKenna of Queens Village. The Rev.

There is much spiritual comfort to be derived from ability to appreciate the truth in the arts and music, Professor William Lyon Phelps of Yale University told 555 graduates of Pratt Institute yesterday afternoon at the fiftieth annual commencement exercises in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

The Athletic Board of Control at Yale today announced a total of 155 athletic awards for the Spring. Included were twenty-six major Y's to members of the track team for performances in the dual meets with Princeton and Harvard. Also listed were thirty-two minor Y's.

The Roxy will harbor today's lone screen newcomer to Broadway, that being the Gene Raymond-Ann Southern comedy romance, "There Goes My Girl." Assisting the principals are Gordon Jones, Richard Lane, Frank Jenks and Bradley Page.

Surprising virtually every one in court, both defendants in the trucking racket trial pleaded guilty yesterday to all ten counts of an indictment charging them with conspiracy, assault, malicious mischief and extortion.

The Federal Power Commission approved today an application of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, for authority to merge the Somerset, Union and Middlesex Lighting Company, a subsidiary.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve -Reserve banks reached a new high or low point for the year, but the ratio of reserve for the New York bank went to the lowest of 1937.

The Manufacturers Housing Promotion Council, composed of fiftyseven manufacturers of building materials and equipment and formed two years ago as a promotion body, will merge with the Producers Council, an affiliate of the American Institute of Architects, it was learned here yesterday.

A strike was called at the Chevrolet foundry in Saginaw this afternoon and 5,000 men quiet work over the disciplining, it was stated, of a single union worker accused of "slowing down the production line."
Appointment of Robert Rae as general manager of the Dominion Bank, succeeding Dudley Dawson, who died on May 24, was announced today. Mr. Rae had been assistant general manager since 1931.

As another step in its study to determine the various factors that contribute to trading activity on the various Stock Exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission began today the publication of daily figures on odd-lot transactions in stocks, rights and warrants by oddlot dealers and specialists on the New York Stock Exchange.

There was a pitched battle this afternoon between a detachment of Spanish guards and Anarchists at Puigcerda, one of the Spanish frontier towns. The trouble occurred when the guards attempted to search a house where a number of Anarchists were supposed to have hidden a large sum of money.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee won its most impressive collective bargaining election victory tonight, a 90 per cent margin of all votes cast in the two near-by plants of the Pittsburgh Steel Corporation.

The statement by James A. Emery, general counsel of the National Association of Manufacturers, before the joint Congressional hearing today of the proposed Fair Labor Standards Act of 1937 read as follows:

William F. Hitt of Middleburg, Va., was elected to membership in the Jockey Club at the regular meeting of the organization yesterday, it was announced. The stewards of the Jockey Club also were in session.

There being no lack of opportunity for the President to utter some general comment on labor lawlessness, his continued silence is accepted in Washington as a studied policy. This is disturbing many of his stanchest supporters in Congress.

The Mary Owen Borden Memorial Bowl offered by Bertram H. Borden in honor of his late wife, was won by Mrs. Townsend Coleman of Rumson with an arrangement of clematis at the Rumson Garden Club June flower show this afternoon in the carriage house on Mr. Borden's estate here.

The unwonted mildness of the Japanese Army and Japanese diplomats concerning the revival of Nanking's authority in Northern China is further evidenced by the fact that thus far there are no indications that the Japanese plan to protest against plans now afoot for holding elections in Hopei and Chahar to choose delegates to the National Congress scheduled for late this year.

Although William Ward, incumbent, received fifty more votes than his opponent, F. Elmer Brown, in their contest for the presidency of Typographical Union No. 6 (Big Six), according to an unofficial count at the union's office, 24 West Sixteenth Street, the election board decided not to make the vote official for two or three days. Mr.
Deapartment store sales showed a seasonal increase from April to May and the adjusted index remained at the level of the preceding six months, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Mrs. Mary Carroll Hill Mills, widow of Dr. James J. Mills, formerly of Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, Md., died yesterday at the home of relatives, 48-36 Fortyfourth Street, Woodside, Queens, at the age of 61. Mrs. Mills, a descendant of John Pope, an early Governor of Arkansas,

An adverse balance of 584,000,000 yen was registered up to today in Japan's foreign trade, according to official figures. This is the largest adverse balance Japan has recorded and its progress is being carefully watched by business and banking circles as well as by the government.
The National Labor Relations Board declared today that removal of a plant from one community to another to avoid collective bargaining is an unfair labor practice under the Wagner Act.

Mrs. John Barry Ryan has left the Plaza for Old Place, her Summer home in Stockbridge, Mass. Mrs. Nelson Page of Rome, Italy, who arrived on the Conti di Savoia, is at the Ambassador. Mrs. Marius de Brabant of 7 East Fifty-first Street has gone to Plaisance, her Summer place in Centerpoint, L. I.

Peonies were the outstanding blooms at the second day of the Westchester County Flower Show being held here at the County Center. Mrs. H. Edward Manville of Pleasantville received a gold medal for an exhibit of bamboo plant. She also received a special award for a display of all American annuals.

David Schenker, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, disclosed today that the commission may ask Congress to regulate the acquisition by investment trusts of controlling interests in other companies.

The offering of $60,000,000 of Commonwealth of Pennsylvania 1 1/2 per cent tax anticipation notes on next Tuesday swells the total of new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week to $88,744,361.
Colonel and Mrs. H. Murray Jacoby gave a dinner last night at their home, 1,165 Fifth Avenue, for M. Amine Youssef Bey, Egyptian Minister to the United States.

As noted at various times during the week, three plays are closing their New York runs after this evening's performances. Most renowned of the trio is Sidney Kingsley's "Dead End," which played at the Belasco Theatre for eighty-five weeks. or 684 performances.

The Real Estate Board of New York condemned yesterday the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill on the ground that it would hamper rather than aid efforts to enable families in the low-income groups to live in decent homes.

Leaders of the United Automobile Workers, in asking General Motors Corporation today for a revision of their present agreement, made a pledge to "live up to our contracts." As General Motors received notice that the union would seek new wage and hour adjustments, the corporation announced that more than 37,000 of its employes were idle in five cities because of "unauthorized" strikes.

Price movements in commodity futures in the local markets were mixed yesterday, with interest centered in cocoa. Cocoa, rubber and cotton seed oil futures were higher, grains and lard were lower and coffee, copper and sugar contracts were irregular.

Benjamin Rush Lummis, who was active in Catholic welfare work, died yesterday in his home at 314 West Seventy-seventh Street after a long illness. He was 81 years old. He had been engaged in the real estate and insurance business here for the last fifty years.

The marriage of Miss Panchita Wall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francisco Wall of Scarsdale, N. Y., to Joseph Fowler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Coolidge Fowler of Bronxville, N. Y., took place here yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church.
Retail trade here continued notably active this week. Department store executives estimated the increase for the week at around 15 per cent over the corresponding period last year.
Joseph W. Frazer, vice president of the sales division of the Chrysler Corporation, said in Detroit yesterday that business was considerably better now than a year ago.

The American Labor party, its leaders as well as rank and file, must sever all connection with the old parties if it is to become the representative of the farmers and workers of the nation, United States Senator Ernest Lundeen of Minnesota said last night at the first

Vice President Garner is going fishing. He said after today's Cabinet meeting that President Roosevelt had given him permission to leave Washington on Sunday for four or five weeks of fishing in Texas.

Governor Townsend of Indiana conferred today with representatives of the Inland Steel Company and the Youngstown. Sheet and Tube Company, seeking means of ending strikes in their plants in Indiana Harbor emplaying 19,000 men.

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, left the International Labor Office conference tonight to catch the Berengaria for home, where, it is expected here, his services will be used as mediator in the steel strike.

WASHINGTON, June 11.--The formation and personnel of a protective committee for common stockholders of the Chicago North Western Railway Company, which is in process of reorganization, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Jacobo Ficher of Buenos Aires has won the prize of $500 offered by Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge "to the resident of any American country who submits the best original composition for string quartet," it was announced yesterday. Mr.
Shipments of pneumatic tire casings in March were 5,737,051 units, compared with 4,370,630 in February and 3,857,352 in March, 1936, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

A Republic Steel Corporation food supply plane, which had just returned from a trip to picketed plants at Warren, was riddled with shotgun slugs and almost brought down today as it came in for a landing at the-Great Lakes Aircraft Corporation field here.

An appropriation of $194,328,000 for flood control, river and harbor improvements and related public works started today on its way through Congress. Although the total as recommended by the House .Committee was $47,181 below the Budget Bureau's estimates, it exceeded the current year's appropriation by $3,736,378 and would bring the War Department's total appropriation for the next fiscal year to $610,079,894.

Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade finished at about the lowest levels of the session today, with late selling stimulated by reports of showers in Saskatchewan. During the day prices fluctuated in an erratic fashion within a range of about 3 cents a bushel.

Donald B. Woodward, through Walter McKeekan Management Corp, duplex in 144 E 24th St; Charles T. Cotterhill through Brett Wykoff, in 21 E 87th St; Howard Hirsch, through Douglas Elliman Co, Inc, in 375 Park Ave; Charles T. Hindley. through T I B Corp, in 65 E 55th St; Arthur T. Sutherland, through Pease Elliman, Inc, in 311 E 72nd St; Lorello O'Hara, broker.

FORT LAMY, French Equatorial Africa, June 11 (AP).--Amelia Earhart sped over 1,000 miles of Sahara Desert today, completing the second hop across Africa in her round-the-world flight. She took off from Gao, French West Africa, at 6:15 A. M. Greenwich, time [2:15 A. M. New York time] and arrived in the Lake Chad country here after a flight of six hours forty minutes.

Robert Pierre Raskob, son of John J. Raskob, New York and Middletown, Md., financier, and Mrs. Raskob, married Miss Dolores Hartor here today in St. Thomas Aquinas Cathedral in the presence of 200 invited guests.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 5 amounted to 692,140 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 102.715 cars, or 12.9 per cent.

Miss Jennie O'Neill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Neill of Tenafly, was married tonight to Paul Wellington Day Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Wellington Day, also of Tenafly. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George M. Lockwood, pastor of the Tenafly Presbyterian Church, at the home of the bride's parents.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS PATROLMEN--John Jaquillard, 85th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 19, 1905. Charles E. Wells, 83d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 15, 1912. Joseph Cattaneo, 111th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 11, 1912.

MOSCOW, Saturday, June 12.--Marshal Mikhail N. Tukhachevsky and seven other generals who had been high in the councils of the Red Army were sentenced to death by shooting yesterday at a closed trial on charges of treason. The sentences must be carried out immediately under the law of Dec. 1, 1934, decreed after the assassination of Sergei Kiroff, Leningrad Communist leader.

Champion Marlu Rampant, a homebred from the Marlu Farm Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Pollak of West Long Branch, N. J., today won best in show honors at the second. annual specialty event of the Welsh Terrier Club of America, held on the lawns of Halcyon Farms, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Clark.

Treatment of. cancer with the recently installed million-volt X-ray generator at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.has been "very promising," Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Institute of Cancer Research of- Columbia University, told the annual meeting of the New York Electrical Society yesterday.
Rutgers University's first exclusive alumni day program planned in the last several years is expected to bring more than 1,000 graduates back to the campus tomorrow.

Leroy N. Staubs, 44-year-old former special policeman of this city and a former member of the Baltimore Police Department, was sentenced to life imprisonment here today for murdering his wife, Mrs. Anna Marlin Staubs, 39, last April 10.
The twenty-story Hotel Taft, occupying the block front on the east side of Seventh Avenue, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets, will be sold at auction on June 17 in the Vesey Street salesroom.

Leaders in Congress at a meeting called by Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, Minister of Interior and Justice, expressed the opinion today that they did not favor the extension of the state of war in Brazil after its expiration on June 18. The prevailing opinion, however, was for legislation necessary to continue the trials of Leftists now in jail.

STONY POINT, L. I., Saturday, June 12.--Mrs. Anna Kupryanova, Russian-born companion of the missing Mrs. William H. Parsons, and her former husband, Alex Kupryanoff, were taken to the State police barracks in Bayshore early today for questioning. No charges were filed against either.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Total volume in round lots and volume of trading by members for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange increased in the week ended on May 15, compared with the previous week, according to the weekly analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, but the percentage of total volume represented by member trading decreased from 22.42 per cent to 20.28 per cent.

Contracts for large quantities of textile apparel supplies for the Civilian Conservation Corps, bids on which were opened at the local quartermaster depot within the past ten days, have been awarded as follows:

The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by its Bureau of Finance to approve the plan of reorganization of the Spokane International Railway Company and the Coeur d'Alene Pend d'Oreille Railway Company.

Slater, an official of the strike-beleaguered Corrigan-McKinney plant of the Republic Steel Corporation, received today two cans of sardines mailed to him from New York City by Dwight Scovel of Hopewell, N. J. Sent first class, the sardines were delivered to the Republic plant with the regular mail.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced last night that the Railroad Marine Workers' Union, which is affiliated with the longshoremen's group, had been selected by the employes of the marine department of the Long Island Railroad as their labor bargaining agency.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission will be forced to close its doors if it is unable to get back $80,000 cut from its appropriation for the giving of civil service examinations, Paul J. Kern, a member of the commission, said at City Hall yesterday.

Rear Admiral Harris Laning, commanding officer of the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, who will be 64 years old on Oct. 19, has received official notice that he will be relieved of active duty on or about Oct. 1.

The Treasury's offering of $800,000,000 of notes on Monday was subscribed slightly more than the six times predicted by Secretary Morgenthau, Acting Secretary Wayne C. Taylor announced this afternoon.

Several hundred persons, including members of society of the North Shore colonies and many of the younger set home from college and boarding school and prospective debutantes of the season, attended the annual benefit fair this afternoon at Greentree, the estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney on the Northern Boulevard.
The Bond Club of Philadelphia held its ffiteenth annual outing today at the Philmont Country Club and its golf team held one from the New York Bond Club to a tie.

The American Newspaper Guild reelected Heywood Broun as its international president, recommended the selection of either Chicago or Toronto for the 1938 conference city and approved a program of collective bargaining at the closing session today of its fourth annual convention.

Fresh trouble is brewing among London's busmen. A. F. Papworth, member of the Central Bus Committee, which after the unsuccessful "coronation strike" was suspended by the executive council of the Transport and General Workers Union, declared tonight that the employers--the London Transport

Mayor La Guardia is likely to be re-elected "by default" because Tammany cannot put a candidate in the field against him "capable of making any sort of a fight," Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion Committee, told a Bronx County rally of Fusion supporters at the Concourse Plaza Hotel last night.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 10 unless specified: At Annapolis, June 11: Cuyahoga, Potomac. At Newport, June 11: Erie, Fairfax, Jacob Jones, Manley, Roper, J. F. Talbott. At Chefoo: Finch, Tulsa.

Miss Laura Frances Buck, daughter of Mrs. Adrian A. Buck of Esplanade Gardens and the late Mr. Buck, was married to Charles Decker Herb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Herb, also of Mount Vernon, this afternoon in the Church of the Ascension.

Accused of fatally stabbing her alleged common-law husband, William Russell Noyes, former trust officer of the Equitable Trust Company, in their furnished room at 314 West Eighty-ninth Street on Thursday afternoon, Mrs. Mary J. H. Noyes, 41 years old, was held without bail for hearing Tuesday by Magistrate Brough in Homicide Court yesterday. She pleaded not guilty.

Barnes Ave (16-4572), s e cor Burke Ave, 100x100; Samuel H. Dorf to Boras Realty, Inc 11 W 42d St; mtg $19,500. Seymour Ave (16-4475), e s, 300 ft s of Allerton Ave, 50x100; Daisy Bauer to Carmelia Darienzo, 762 E 226th St.

District Attorney William C. Dodge, in a statement issued yesterday, defended the action of the late Assistant District Attorney Richard H. Gibbs who in 1934 recommended the dismissal of the bail for James Plumeri, John Dioguardi and the late Dominick Didade, arraigned on four indictments in General Sessions.

Cincinnati at New York-Derringer vs. Schumacher. Pittsburgh at Brooklyn-Blanton or Brandt vs. Henshaw or Mungo. St. Louis at Boston-Warneke vs. MacFayden. Chicago at Philadelphia-Parmelee vs. La Master.

Miss.Mabel Searles Valentine of Columbus, Ohio, was married to Howell Edwin Sayre of Brooklyn this afternoon at High Farms, home of Carl Sayre, the bridegroom's brother, and Mrs. Sayre. The Rev. Frank B. Cowan of the First Presbyterian Church of Glen Cove officiated in the presence of members of the families.

The sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $85,000, down $6,000 from the last previous transaction, was reported yesterday. The price was the lowest since April 23, 1935, and contrasted with $134,000, the high for 1937.

Walter P. Chrysler headed the list of 307 corporations and individuals who bought the 1936 Democratic National Convention souvenir book autographed by the President, according to the Democratic National Committee's report of contributions received for the three months ended May 31, filed with the clerk of the House today.

The State Banking Department has been unable to find depositors in the Bank of United States who are entitled to almost $1,000,000 as their pro rata share 'of payments already authorized, it was disclosed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente took under consideration a request to authorize an additional 5 per cent dividend.

Raymond L. Bennett, president of the senior class of Germantown Friends School, who was graduated cum laude at commencement exercises of that institution tonight, has received the new Stanley R. Yarnall scholarship at Temple University.

With the exception of the container division, the week saw little change in the glass industry, The American Glass Review says today. There has been a falling off in demand for virtually all lines, and this can be attributed to the season.

Discovery of the bodies of two Italian antiFascisti in woods near Bagnoles-del'Orne adds a new mystery to the relatively long list of murders of political refugees in this country. The police are questioning a young Italian.

Directors of the American MaizeProducts Company have declared the usual quarterly dividend of $1.75 on the preferred stock, but have taken no action on the common stock for the current quarter, ending June 30. The last dividend on the common was 25 cents quarterly, paid on March 31.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, refused yesterday to reassign fifteen WPA recreational workers to Madison GUI House Settlement, 226 Madison Street, from which they were shifted to other WPA projects because But of a children's pageant last Friday to reflecting on Germany, Italy and the Spanish Rebels.

Mr. JESSE H. JONES of the Reconatruction Finance Corporation has given a timely and much-needed warning against "the habit of expecting everything of the Federal Government." It is a pernicious habit, because it leads, as Mr. JONES points out, to a breakdown of individual and local self-reliance.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred la Frankenthaler ordered set aside yesterday an agreement by which Nyamco Associates, Inc., a subsidiary of New York Title and Mortgage Company, received amortization payments under junior particinations it held in mortgages certificated by the title company before any payments were credited to the senior liens.

Mayor La Guardia became honorary curator of wild-life conservation in the Boy Scouts yesterday, receiving the honor from a troop of fifteen who visited him at City Hall. One Scout carried a raccoon named "Zeke," while others bore a milk snake, a bullfrog, a toad and a turtle.

Miss Nancy Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes of this place and Fishers Island, N. Y., was married this afternoon in the First Congregational Church here to Alfred Faris King Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Faris King of Dongan Hills, S. I. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev. John Insley Blair Larned, Suffragan Bishop of Long Island.
More than one-fourth of the officers of the Salvation Army in Japan withdrew from the organization today and formed a rival army with the avowed intention of purging the ranks of British influence.

David Cowen, president of A. Goodman Sons, Inc., of 634 East Seventeenth Street, makers of noodles and matzoths, died Thursday night at his home, 7 West Eighty-first Street, of a heart ailment. His age was 71.

Miss Natalie Ryan, youngest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan, will be married to Thomas Ludlow Clarke, son of Mrs. Thomas Ludlow Clarke and the late Mr. Clarke, on Tuesday at Old Place, the Ryan country home in Stockbridge, Mass. The ceremony will be attended only by immediate relatives and a few intimate friends of the couple.

William J. Smith Cary, 24, of Stanwhich Lane, who inherited about $1,000,000 from his grandfather, William J. Smith, contractor, was seriously injured here at 1:50 this morning and four young men in the car with him were also injured.

James L. Selfridge, a Village Trustee here since 1925 and a former buyer for New York textile houses, died today at the Ossining Hospital of injuries suffered early this morning when he fell downstairs at his home, Toddridge, on Elm Road, here. His age was 70.
President Roosevelt commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentence of Thomas Jordan, 36year-old cook, of Mount Vernon, N. Y., charged with murder during a hold-up here on April 3, 1931.
A Federal grand jury late today indicted twenty-five election officials and party workers with conspiracy to deprive voters of their right of franchise in the Nov. 3 election.

William Humbert Adams, 40 years old, of 363 Webster Avenue, Brooklyn, who pleaded guilty in the Brooklyn Federal court to embezzlement of $2,680 from the Bay Parkway branch of the Lafayette National Bank, at 6,614 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch to serve a year and a day in prison.

Allen Clymer Austin, engineer and inventor, died last night at his home here after an illness of more than two years. Mr. Austin was born in Auburn fifty-two years ago and had lived in Syracuse thirty-six years. He was organizer and founder of the Austin Taylor Engineering and Construction Company, and was associated with other engineering firms.

Reginald Joseph Mitchell, one of the most brilliant figures in the British aircraft industry, died in Southampton today at the age of 42. He gave his name to no company or aircraft, yet he designed a military airplane believed to be the fastest in the world and now being produced in large quantities for the Royal Air Force.
The Rev. Dr. Leon Kurt Willman, Methodist Episcopal pastor, educator and author, died suddenly at his home here today. He was 63 years old. Funeral services will be held Monday at 11 A. M.

Lafayette College, at its commencement exercises today, conferred degrees in course on 173 members of the class of 1937 and heard Dr. Arthur E. Bestor, president of the Chautauqua Institute of New York, commencement speaker, declare that our democratic way of life was challenged by the threat of communism or a totalitarian State.

Mexico urged today the holding of an interAmerican monetary conference in the near future and suggested that it be held in Mexico, D. F. Her position was given in a reply to the recent inquiry of the PanAmerican Union of the American governments as to their attitude on the conference, which was proposed in a resolution of the inter-American peace conference at Buenos Aires.

The stock markets here continued extremely quiet and fairly steady today. Giltedge issues were strong at first, but the best levels were not maintained. Among the foreign loans, German bonds lost ground. Transatlantic shares were in some demand and International Nickel had a good tone.

President Roosevelt signed the resolution providing for the investigation of tax evasion, commuted to life imprisonment the death sentence imposed upon Thomas Jordan, convicted murderer, and, after his press conference, departed for Annapolis to board the yacht Potomac for a week-end cruise on Chesapeake Bay and the Potomac River.
