The Minsky brothers instituted suit yesterday to compel License Commissioner Paul Moss to permit them to reopen their Oriental Theatre, at 1,662 Broadway, near Fiftysecond Street, as a motion-picture and vaudeville house.

Behind the locked doors of the Freed. Heater Company's plant at Oaks, near Norristown, Edward Nigg, general manager, started a one-man sit-down strike today against forty-five employes. "Any employee belonging to the C. I. O. or any other union can no longer work for us," Mr. Nigg said, adding that the employes had staged a walkout.

Frank E. Gaebelein, headmaster of the Stony Brook School, announced today that thirty-eight students would receive diplomas at commencement exercises tomorrow morning. The baccalaureate exercises were held last Sunday.

Need of more local parks and recreational facilities was stressed by President Roosevelt in a message to the National Conference on State Parks, which is meeting at Swarthmore College this week. Colonel Richard Leiber of Indiana, president of the conference, read the message, which said in part:

In an atmosphere which was at times extremely hostile to Premier Leon Blum and his government, the Senate today imposed its will in the matter of the application of the forty-hour week in hotels and restaurants.

George E. Warner, known for three decades as the "last Democratic Mayor" of this traditionally Republican city, died today at his home after a long illness. The 81year-old former judge succumbed to a heart attack.
The New York State Disabled American Veterans of the World War declared this afternoon for a strong program of armament and defense as the best means of keeping the United States out of war.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil CompanyInc., has concluded arrangements for the sale of $75,000,000 of debentures to five mutual life insurance companies, it was announced yesterday by John A. Brown, president.

Benny Kaufman, East Side speedster, and Charles (Pee Wee) Cullum of Los Angeles were seriously injured during the weekly motorcycle racing competition at the Yankee Stadium last night. A crowd of 12,000 saw Kaufman hurt during the Partideo team race and Cullum injured while racing in a four-man handicap event.

Plans for restoration of Herbert Hoover's birthplace at West Branch, Iowa, were revealed today in connection with a visit by the former President to this city and West Branch while motoring from the East to his home in California.

Members of the 107th Infantry, the old Seventh Regiment, of Manhattan, were trophy winners again today in the New York State matches shot at Camp Smith here. They won the McAlpin and the two-man team match, two of the three matches fired.

Cedric Ellsworth Smith, retired member of the publishing firm of Edwin Valentine Mitchell of Hartford, Conn., died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 40 years old. Mr. Smith was graduated from the Lawrenceville School in 1918.

Germany took a 2-0 lead over Belgium in their semi-final round European Zone Davis Cup tennis series today. Heinrich Henkel defeated Andre Lacroix, 6-1, 6-1, 6-1, and Baron Gottfried von Cramm won from Charles Nayert, 6-3, 6-0, 6-4, in the opening singles matches.

Announcement was made last night that an agreement had been reached between 1,500 members of Local 10, Journeymen Barbers International Union, and the United Master Barbers of America. The members of the union, who had been on strike since Tuesday, will return to work at 10 A. M. today.

Movements ot livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow. HOGS Receipts, 9,000, including 5,000 direct. Market mostly 10c lower than Thursday's average; spots on heavy butchers' and packing sows 15c off;

Miss Jessie Anderson, 22-yearold daughter of a Scottish professional, succeeded Miss Pamela Barton as British women's golf champion today. A stubborn fighter with a magic putting touch, Miss Anderson played steady golf all the way to crush Miss Doris Parks, another Scottish star, 6 and 4, in the thirty-six-hole final round.

Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, United States champion, today reached the final round of her fourth successive English tennis tournament. The blonde American easily disposed of her semi-final round opponent in the Beckenham tournament, Mrs. Phyllis Mudford King, 6-4,
President Roosevelt left this afternoon for a week-end cruise on Chesapeake Bay and the Potomac River after a press conference which dealt with several subjects of minor consequence.
Extensions of the Independent City Subway into Queens and the Bronx at a cost of $74,000,000 will be considered by the Board of Estimate at a public hearing next Friday.

The movement of share prices yesterday was in the nature of a creeping decline, with final quotations generally representing the day's lows. Again it was the case of lack of demand rather than of pressure of offerings that edged the list downward.

Miss Lois Miller Smedley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Miller Smedley of Brooklyn and Canaan, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Alan Gilbert Simpson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Gilbert Simpson of Douglaston, L. I.

Aldermanic President William F. Brunner received an illustrated album yesterday from Miss 'Fritzi Scheff, musical comedy singer, who made the presentation for the Committee for the Presentation of Austrian Art, Science and Culture at the World's Fair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Terms like "capital grant" and "rental subsidy" are rather puzzling to the public at large, and everybody interested in housing must be grateful to THE TIMES for clarifying the issue in the editorial "How to Pay for Housing."

The familiar task of "finding a formula" proved unexpectedly troublesome today for Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and the Ambassadors of France, Italy and Germany, who are trying to reach agreement on the security of the patrolling warships off Spain.
John Van Wicheren Reynders purchased for $135,000 the Frederic Ewing estate of five acres on Woodland Drive, Greenwich, through Ladd Nichols.

An increase of about 11 per cent in construction in thirty-seven States was made last month, compared with May, 1936, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation, which estimated the total for May, 1937, at $244,112,800, compared with $216,070,700 a year ago and $269,934,200 for April of this year.

Sixty-five students received diplomas yesterday at the eighty-second annual commencement exercises of the Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School, Ninety-second Street and Seventh Avenue, Dyker Heights, Brooklyn.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved irregularly over a range of $1 a bale yesterday but ended with gains of 2 to 8 points. A denial by Secretary Wallace that statements had been made reflecting the view that farm prices were high enough, stimulated short covering.

Three eight-oared shells and a four joined Columbia today as Navy's squad took to the Hudson late this afternoon. The shells arrived this morning and were rigged at once, but it was not until 5 o'clock that Coach Buck Walsh had his men out for a limbering paddle upstream above their quarters.

China's Treasury gave $1,000,000 (Chinese) today to General-Yang Fu-cheng, erstwhile co-leader of the Sian mutiny, in which Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was kidnapped, and told him to take a trip around the world.
Miss Mary Louise Lakamp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Lakamp of this city, was married today to George J. Goeckeler, son of Mrs. Agnes Goeckeler and the late Mr. Goeckeler.

Houston St, 508-512 E, n s, 70x145.10 to 3d St (410-412 E) x 70.7x154.3: John Sullivan, referee, to Chemical Bank and Trust Co, as trustee; foreclosure ($48.50). Water St, 433, s e cor Market Slip, 26x80; Milton R. Weinberger, referee, to Nahconrek Realty Corp, 67 Wall St; foreclosure (S1).
An assertion that President Roosevelt would not be a candidate. for a .third term came tonight from Colonel House, once known as the "maker of Presidents" and the "sphinx of politics."

Mr. Frances Winslow Kemble Penrose of 340 East Fifty-seventh Street, daughter of Parker H. Kemble of Boston, and former wife of Boies Penrose 2d of Devon, Pa., was married to Baron Louis de Chollet of this city yesterday morning in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

The W. K. Kellogg Company, cereal manufacturer, was reported tonight to have transferred part of its headquarters office staff to Chicago. It was understood that thirty office employes were sent to Chicago to set up headquarters in the Palmer House.

For the second time within a month new bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to the tax-exempt field. Fourteen State and municipal issues, however, were placed on the market with an aggregate dollar value of $9,155,000.

Lehman Brothers headed a banking group that won yesterday a new issue of $3,500,000 of relief, public works, general county and refunding bonds of Nassau County, in a sale marked by keen bidding by several New York banking syndicates.

Frederic G. Melcher, editor of Publishers Weekly, and Lewis B. Traver, president of the American Booksellers Association, have been chosen as co-chairmen of the association's committee to arrange for the presentation of the White House Library to President Roosevelt early in the Fall.
The sixty-fifth annual commencement exercises of Stevens Institute of Technology will be held this afternoon in the William Hall Walker Gymnasium on the campus at Castle Point, Hoboken.

The 1,200 employes or the J. I. Case Company plant walked out today a few minutes after reporting for work. Unofficial spokesmen for the men agreed with A. W. Leland, president of the company, that their action was "not a strike authorized by the United Automobile Workers of America," with which they are affiliated.

As the season of presenting candidates for honorary. degrees recurs, there returns to many the proud memory of having been presented by Dean ANDREW F. WEST of Princeton University. There was published in 1929 a collection of these succinct biographies done with the clean, swift strokes of a master in the art.

President Roosevelt asserted today that he was giving no thought to legislation embracing any form of federalized medicine. He made this statement at his press conference in reply to a question asked in view of a speech before the American Medical Association yesterday at Atlantic City by Senator Lewis, inviting the association to cooperate with the administration to provide medical care for the poor.

Ralph Vessa, 55 years old, of 157 Withers Street, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday afternoon in an unusual accident near his hope. Vessa was watching a group of men play an Italian game of bowls, commonly called "bocce," on a vacant lot at the corner of Withers and Leonard Streets.

They gave Zeke Bonura an automobile as Chicago's "most popular player" today, and the big first baseman showed his appreciation by banging out four hits, driving in five runs and leading the White Sox to a 14-to-8 victory over the Senators.

Henry Cotton, crack British professional, and Denny Shute, American Professional Golfers Association champion,, will meet in a world championship match over the 72-hole route after the Ryder Cup matches in England late this month, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

Joe DiMaggio broke out with his tenth and eleventh home runs of the season, the hitting epidemic spread to the Yankees generally and Charley (Red) Ruffing came up with a fivehit game, the net result of all of which was a decision for the world champions over the Browns by 10 to 0 at Sportsman's Park today.

Miss Eleanor Wilma Sauer, daughter of Mrs. Charles P. Sauer of 85-11 Wareham Road, Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married last night to William C. Bagley Jr. of New York. The ceremony took place in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Hollis, and was performed by the Rev. Dr. Raymond Deitz.
Fair trade practice rules to "eliminate the chaos" in the millinery industry were presented yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission at a public hearing in the Hotel Astor.

Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, arrived here by airplane today. He was greeted at the airdrome by Premier Koloman Daranyi and members of the Hungarian Cabinet and then drove to his hotel. Tomorrow he will begin conversations with Hungarian statesmen and will have an audience with Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent.
Joseph A. Lyons, the Australian Prime Minister, who is attending the Imperial Conference here, and Robert W. Bingham, the United States Ambassador, met today for a private conversation.

The case of an unsuccessful Chicago stockbroker who became a millionaire soon after a radical operation on the thinking centers of his brain, in which about threequarters of his left frontal lobe had been removed, was described today before the annual meeting of the American Medical Association by Dr. Ward C. Halstead, University of Chicago neurologist.

The res solution extending the "nuisance" taxes for two years was adopted today by the House, 230 to 93, after a spirited debate in which the ad ministration was accused of spend thrift ways and the Republicans were blamed as the authors of "hid den taxes."

John F. Kraemer of Port Washing ton, N. Y., university 150-pound single sculls champion, has been elected to the captaincy of the Princeton lightweight varsity crew for the 1938 season, it was announced tonight.

The two flying boats which will operate passenger service next week on regular schedule between New York and Bermuda will take off this morning with a company of government officials, newspaper publishers and airline executives from Port Washington, L. I., for Hamilton Harbor.

Conrad P. Soffel, formerly Fire Department chief and for the last five year superintendent of the city-operated bathing beach, died this morning at his home at the age of 77. He was proprietor of a grain and hay business and retired fifteen years ago. Surviving are his widow, tQ whom he was married fifty-three years ago; two daughters, Mrs.

Manhattan 72d St, 120-22 W.; 50x102.2; for 1-story stores; Syncol Equities, Inc, 391 E. 149th St, Bronx, owner; Scacchetti Siegel, architects; cost, $10,000. Alterations Central Park S, 214; to 4-story tenement; Union Dime Savings Bank, 1,065 6th Ave, owner; John S. Burrell, architect; cost, $15,000.
Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince will conduct his City Symphony Orchestra at Manhattan Beach tomorrow afternoon for the first time.

A plan to lower expenses of European contestants in the 1940 Olympics at Tokyo was advanced today as the International Olympic Committee adjourned without acting on dates for the Winter games three years hence.

Manufacturers of proprietary medicines and toilet goods are seriously considering conducting a joint advertising campaign to answer the Macy series of "price-fixing" ads now running in newspapers here, it was learned yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes will preside at a pontifical mass in celebration of the 100th anniversary of St. Joseph's Church, Sixth Avenue and Washington Place, of which the Rev. John J. Hickey is the pastor, to be offered tomorrow at 11 A. M. The celebrant of the mass will be the Most Rev.

The Railway Audit and Inspection Bureau, Inc., private detective agency, received $55,000 from the Consolidated Edison Company from 1933 to 1936 for labor espionage among the company's 40,000 employes, according to testimony given yesterday before the National Labor Relations Board.

The development of standard definitions of terms used in retailing to describe various types of merchandise will be undertaken, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the advisory committee of consumer goods of the American Standards Association at its headquarters here.
Three hundred employes of the Hoffman Beverage Company, manufacturers of beer and soft drinks at 402 South Grove Street, here, went on strike tonight.

LAST Fall we had the first volume of an annual anthology of prose and verse called "New Directions," edited by James Laughlin 4th, who not so long ago was the enfant terrible of The Harvard Advocate and later edited an exceptional literary department in the SocialCredit magazine, New Democracy.

New York's team of women golfers took a slight lead in the annual competition for the Griscom Cup at the Plainfield Country Club today by defeating the defending Boston squad, 13 to 2. Philadelphia downed Boston by 11-4 yesterday.

Holders of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation on June 4 numbered 161,881, a decrease of 4,312 since March 6, while holders of preferred stock of record on May 1 totaled 61,557, an increase of five since Jan. 30, the company announced yesterday.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding on May 29 was $385,795,967, a decrease of $9,235,312 from the end of April, but an increase of $55,264,507 over a year ago, according to the monthly acceptance survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.
Captain Oscar G. Haines, for more than twenty years head of the United States Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation in the New England District, died today at the age of 52.

A new kind of democracy, emphasizing the greatest good for the greatest number but allowing little room for "our traditional and treasured individualism," lies ahead for the United States, in the opinion of history students at Mount Holyoke College.

If there is a spot on the map where a nation would choose not to be, President Benes has always said, that spot is Czechoslovakia. He now repeats the remark with special feeling. But he is pretty dubious when asked where in Europe he would choose to be. On one point only he is decided. "Not where Poland is," he declares.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a little better tone in the wool market today, due chiefly to the increased interest in medium wools, especially in the bright wool States, where operations are more active.

Dr. FREDERICK KEPPEL said a wholesome word at the Cooper Union commencement when he reminded his auditors (and later his readers) that "we "are all problem children-and remain " problem children as long as we live." Every one of us has a problem of his own to handle and it's different from that of every other individual.

Clifton's Beau, 6-year-old brown gelding owned by Mrs. Harry Frank Jr., which formerly showed under the name of Firenze Clifton's Beau, became one of the outstanding candidates for the hunter championship as the forty-fourth annual Westchester County Horse Show opened at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club today.

The Rev. Francisco Olazabal of 85-45 145th Street, Jamaica, Queens, leader of the Latin-American Council of the Church of God, died on Wednesday in Alice, Texas, from injuries suffered in an automobile accident, according to word received here yesterday. He was 50 years old.

The Montclair (N. J.) Art Museum has acquired for its permanent collection two paintings by contemporary American artists, "Coast Guard Station," by Edward Hopper, and "Epilogue in Gray," by Robert Brackman.

Senator Wheeler of Montana declared tonight at a banquet of the American Retail Coal Association that abandonment of the free competitive system of business in favor of regulatory powers concentrated in the hands of a few men or governmental bureaus might result in the loss of economic and political freedom.

Premier ABERHART of Alberta might seem to have trouble enough, but he is looking for more. He has delivered two allocutions on the press, which he regards as " one of the most dangerous of our democratic institutions." He rehashes all the old charges of commercial and financial control.

Charles S. Lockwood, who was born in the old Lockwood home on Maple Avenue here, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles of a heart attack. His father, Edgar Lockwood, was senior member of John Monroe Co., a banking firm in New York.
To save wrapping paper, the government today: Urged housewives to bring a plate or glass to the store for carrying purchases of sauerkraut, salads and pickles.

Twice defeated in its pleas for an injunction restraining Heavyweight Champion James J. Braddock from meeting Joe Louis until he first carried out his contract to fight Max Schmeling, Madison Square Garden yesterday announced its intention of continuing the legal fight to prevent the bout scheduled for Comiskey Park in Chicago on June 22.

The Bergen Center Holding Corporation, which last Fall bought the large vacant plot at the southwest corner of Bergen and Glenwood Avenues, Jersey City, N. J., has enlarged its plottage by purchasing the adjoining property at 9 and 11 GlenWood Avenue.
Two decisions upholding the legality of the Commodity Exchange Act were affirmed today by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals. They invonlved anneals of William S. Moore,

The conference method of adjusting economic problems between the United States and Japan by consultation was praised by President Roosevelt, Secretary Roper and other officials in extending greetings today to members of the Japanese Economic Mission of ten business men now touring the United, States.

Governor Davey's peace conference seeking to settle the C. I. O. strike against independent steel companies, which began at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was adjourned at 1:45 this morning until 11 o'clock Tuesday morning.

The Fairchild Aviation Corporation has notified the New York g Curb Exchange that it is distributing as a dividend one share of the common stock of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation for each share of Fairchild Aviation stock, payable June 17 to holders of record of June 15.

Willie Turnesa of Briar Hills and Howard Bergman of Metropolis, comedalists yesterday, moved into the semi-final round of the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Century Country Club today, but by different routes.
The Public Service Commission called today for a prompt reply to its demand that twenty-four municipalities operating power plants reduce their electric rates.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Kays Brown, daughter of Mrs. James William Brown of Orange and the late Mr. Brown, to William Stanwood Till, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Walter Till of East Orange, took place this evening in Grace Episcopal Church, Orange.

More than a score of German manufactured products have been added to the list of goods eligible for barter transactions with the United States, according to cable advices received yesterday from Berlin by business organizations here.

The Black-Connery Labor Standards Bill, designed to control wages and hours for millions of workers, was condemned today by Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, as the "epitome of legislative tragedy."

Mount Holyoke College alumnae have made centennial gifts of $200,284 during the last two years, according to Miss Gertrude V. Bruyn, field secretary. This includes $188,292 announced at the centenary celebration.

Out of the mailbag: Regarding a discussion caused by the photograph depicting Neville Chamberlain, Great Britain's Prime Minister, fishing in the British Isles, "Sparse Gray Hackle" submits the following:

An attempt to oust S. A. Morse, president, and three others, including W. J. K. Vanston of New York, from the directorate of the Union Gas Company of Canada failed today when four separate ouster motions were declared lost at a special adjourned meeting of shareholders.

Puppy Dogs, 6 Months and Under 9 Months--First, Halcyon Kennels' Halcyon Ante Up; second, Aglar Cook's Corbscot De Aguilla. Puppy Dogs. 9 Months and Under 12 Months-First, Halcyon Kennels' Halcyon Ambitious; second, Gilbert Hirsh's Usedit. American-Bred Dogs--First, Marlu Farm Kennels' Marlu--Redlander; second, Halcyon Kennels' Twin Hill Commander; third, Miss Jean G. Hinkle's Port Fortune Playmate 2d; fourth, Dri-Bath Company's Corbscot Banks.
Remember "The Front Page"? RKO-Radio has, and placed a commemorative laurel on its tomb yesterday in the form of a distaff edition known, for one reason or none, as "There Goes My Girl," at the Roxy.

Maureen Orcutt Crews, the golfer, won a final decree of divorce today from John D. Crews, Miami bond broker. She was authorized to resume her maiden name. She abandoned a request for alimony, although her deposition, made in New York,

A protective committee has been organized to represent holders of 7-per cent preferred stock of the International Paper and Power Company opposed to the plan of recapitalization proposed by the company, the members of which represent in the aggregate 300 shares of the 7 per cent stock.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company applied this afternoon to the Interstate Commerce Commission for leave to withdraw $471,138 of dividends on the common stock of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad Company now held by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company of New York as trustee under a first and refunding mortgage.

Annual Children's Day will be observed in many Protestant churches tomorrow. Virtually every Methodist congregation will celebrate Children's Day. Some will give up the 11 A. M. service to the Sunday School pupils.

More than fifty persons were rounded up in the day in a series of surprise police raids in an effort to end the window-breaking racket which has cost Chicago business men more than $500,000 in the last year.

Despite a heavy rain, fifteen players competed in the WestchesterFairfield Women's Golf Association tournament today at the Tamarack Country Club. Mrs. Edwin Bulkley of Siwanoy turned in the low score of the day.
With allowance for the holiday, the daily average of cotton mill activity was higher last week, when a seasonal decline was in order, and the adjusted index advanced to 150.7 from 147.8.

The representatives of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals believe they ended yesterday their dispute with Miss Marion Rita Ross, who, it seems, has a tender spot in her heart for homeless cats.

Miss Elizabeth Covington Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander James Campbell, was married to Merwin Gaylord Camp, son of Mrs. George Edward Camp and the late Mr. Camp of this city, at Christ Episcopal Church in Watertown this afternoon by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Thomas C. Cline.

Three former clerks in the main postoffice at Washington and Johnson Streets, Brooklyn, who pleaded guilty to obstructing the mails, received suspended sentences yesterday from Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal court in that borough.

The Works Progress Administration is opposed to performing maintenance work which normally would be done by municipalities and paid for out of municipal budgets, but its application of this principle differs with varying circumstances of cities, officials said today.

Despondent at his failure to effect a reconciliation with his wife, Harry Brown Cook 3d, 21-year-old son of Lieut. Col. Harrison Cook of Atlantic City, shot himself over the heart yesterday in his room at the Hotel Holland, 351 West Fortysecond Street.

Funeral services for George F. Baker, chairman of the First National Bank of New York, who died on May 30 on board his yacht Viking in Honolulu Harbor following an emergency operation for peritonitis, will be held next Wednesday at 2:30 P. M. at his home, Viking's Cove, Locust Valley. Burial.
The Pan American Union said today the Mexican Government had communicated its desire for early calling of an inter-American monetary conference in Mexico, D. F.

Miss Ann Gordon Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Hanmer Clark of 114 East Seventyfirst Street and Peconic, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Alexander Pitcairn, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Aiken Pitcairn of Pittsburgh and Stoney Lake, Ontario, in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr.
John Hanes of Port Chester and his daughter, Miss June Hanes, gave a luncheon in connection with the forty - fourth annual Westchester County Horse Show, which opened here today.

A street corner campaign to raise funds for the American Association Against Communism, Inc., 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, of which the Rev. Dr. Edward Lodge Curran, a Catholic priest of the diocese of Brooklyn, is president, was opened last night on Broadway and at other sections throughout the city.

2lst St, 342-346 W. 50x91.11; William M. Smith, 2 Romer Rd. Dongan Hills. S. I., et al. to Mardem Realty Corp, 68 William St; 5 years, 41/2 per cent; $55,000. 73d St, 155 W. 20x102.2; John J. Bardet et al to David Davis. 1,060 E 17th St, Brooklyn: 5 years. 5 per cent: $6,000.

The trial on treason charges yesterday of eight of the Red Army's high-ranking generals-and its inevitable aftermath-will have farreaching consequences both within the Soviet Union and throughout Europe.

The election of Henry B: Dates of Cleveland as national president of the Illuminating Engineering Society was announced today at a meeting of the New York section of the society at Briarcliff Lodge. Mr. Dates is a Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Case School of Applied Sciences, Cleveland.

The body of Major Gen. Ben H. Fuller, retired, former commandant of the marine corps, was buried in the Naval Academy Cemetery today, near the grave of his son, Captain Edward Fuller, U. S. M. C., who was killed in the battle of Belleau Wood during the World War.

Miss Ann Bulkley Lea, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Tatnall Lea of this city, was married this afternoon to Ralph Dadd Osborne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Osborne of Llewellyn Park on the twenty-fifth wedding anniversary of the bridegroom's parents.

Falling quotations for forward French exchange in the foreign exchange market yesterday gave renewed evidence of an increasing flight of capital from France. Although vigorous intervention by the official control succeeded in lifting the spot franc quotation 3/8 point to 4.451/4 cents, this movement was belied by the strong demand for both dollars and sterling from French sources and by the weakness of franc futures, in which the control does not operate.

Lower prices for grains, textiles, livestock and rubber have caused a further drop in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices, the index declining to 140.9 on Tuesday from 142.4 (revised) the Tuesday previous.
Three delegates sent by General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish Insurgents, to Germany's Strength Through Joy convention received a big ovation here today.

If Ben Marden's shiny new Riviera, which opened this week atop the Palisades on yonder side of the George Washington Bridge, -is not exactly a Frank Gould Palace de Mediterrane at Nice nor a Palm Beach Casino at Cannes;

Members of the Long Island Golf Association's executive committee ended the two-year reign of Charles H. Mayor Jr. as the section's amateur ruler yesterday as the quarterfinals were reached in the sixteenth annual Long Island amateur championship tourney at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing.

Two Department of Parks playgrounds and a recreation building will be opened to the public this morning. One playground is at Fifth Avenue, between West 130th and West 131st Streets, Manhattan, and the other is at Avenue L, between East Seventeenth and East Eighteenth Streets, Brooklyn.

Burnham C. Stickney, inventor of typewriter devices and a patent attorney, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in his office at 1 Park Avenue. Mr. Stickney, who was 74 years old, resided at 99 North Avenue, Elizabeth, N. J. He had been employed by the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company and its predecessor, the Underwood Typewriter Company, for thirty-five years.
Directors of the Allied Kid Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stork. A regular quarterly payment of 25 cents a share was made on May 1.

The work of rehabilitating the impoverished mountain peoples of the Carolinas, West Virginia, Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee must be accomplished mainly by aiding more than 1,000,000 underprivileged children now living in those areas, the Rev. Dr. William C. Covert said yesterday before a luncheon meeting of the Save the Children Fund, Inc., at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

A large investment deal on the upper West Side was announced yesterday when the 256-260 West Seventy-second Street Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York Dock Corporation, sold the twelve-story apartment house at 260 West Seventy-second Street to a client of Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., broker in the transaction.

Beauty shop operators who remove excess hair from women's faces by the use of electrolytic needles are not engaged in the practice of medicine, the Appellate Division declared in an unanimous decision yesterday.

Royall Victor Jr. of Syosset, L. I., a student at Harvard College, filed marriage intentions in City Hall here today to wed Miss Isabel Gardiner of Contoocook, N. H., daughter of Mrs. Foster Gardiner of Brookline, Mass.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 10: COLONELS Blakely, C. S., F. A., two months and fifteen days' leave, June 16, with permission to visit foreign countries. Booker, P. W., F. A., Fort Bliss, Texas, to duty with the Organized Reserves, Buffalo, N. Y.; to sail from San Francisco about Aug. 11 for New York, N. Y.

Miss Miriam Ruth Mottsman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Mottsman of 241 Central Park West, was married to Seymour Emanuel Sims, son of Mrs. Barnett Sims of this city, formerly of Mount Vernon, and the late Mr. Sims, yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents by the Rev. Dr. Elias Margolis.
The Rev. J. J. Burggraaff, pastor of the First Reformed Church of Lodi, and Mrs. Burggraaff yesterday observed the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage.

Ed Dudley of Philadelphia took a three-stroke lead over Vic Ghezzi of Deal, N. J., in the elevenplayer race for the four remaining positions on the United States Ryder Cup team today by shooting his second straight 70 in the national open golf championship.

A new Fall fabric for suitings and skirtings offered within the last week is being bought actively by both jobbers and garment cutterm. The cloth, made from a blended yarn of cotton and acetatecut staple, is available in a wide range of dark. colors at 30 cents to the wholesaler and the cutter, in a thirty-six-inch width to retail over piece goods counters at 50 cents.

Officials of Price Brothers Co. Ltd., said today that the company had Sold 1,000 square miles of timber limits at Sault an Cochon, Charlevoix County, to the Anglo-Canadian Pulp and Paper mills for $1,250,000 price Brothers had owned the tract several years but never had exploited it.

Plans submitted during May to the State Department of Labor for 185 new industrial construction projects outside of New York City reached a total estimated investment of $2,823,135, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported yesterday.

Opening a new drive to obtain passage of ever-normal granary legislation at this session of Congress, Secretary Wallace told the Senate Agriculture Committee today that if current agricultural trends were allowed to continue,

The unanimous decision of the Court of Appeals yesterday that the Electric Bond and Share Company is entitled to recover from New York State a refund of taxes in the amount of $104,274 brought joy to the public utility companies' officials.

If jury dodgers are not fewer this Fall it will not be the fault of the Women's National Democratic Club, which swelled the list of eligibles yesterday with the names of thirty members. As the first mass registration of women under the new Kleinfeld law, effective in September, the influx upset routine in Room 301 of the Hall of Records, headquarters for the Manhattan Jury Commissioners-but the welcome mat was spread.

There is a London club to which even the most unclubable of non-joiners might be proud to belong. The Centenarian Club, a member writes to The Times of London, was founded to "in" spire men and women to become able"bodied and clear-minded centenarians."

The Board of Estimate decided yesterday to use paper ballots this Fall for the election of City Councilmen under the proportional representation system of voting and appropriated $869,790 for the Board of Elections to conduct the election.

Recent dissensions among Dr. Francis E. Townsend and national officers of his old-age pension plan came into court today when the $200-a-month pension advocate swore out a warrant against J. W. Brinton, who resigned last week as vice president and general manager of the national organization.

What is probably the strongest field of steeplechasers named thus far this season is scheduled to face the starter today in the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap, feature event of the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association, on the estate of Charles V. Hickox at Roslyn, L. I.

Bills considered during the last session of the Legislature gave persons interested in real estate cause for "breathing sighs of relief that certain things were, and that others were not done," George L. Allin, chairman of the legislation and law committees of the Real Estate Board of New York, told 500 members of the board and of the Mortgage Conference at a joint luncheon in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

In one of the more ambitious programs to be announced by an independent studio, Sol Lesser of Principal Productions today made public his plans for the 1937-38 season. He will deliver to RKO and to Twentieth Century-Fox ten pictures budgeted at $3,500,000 and will make one, Rupert Hughes's "Celluloid," which is a history of Hollywood, for the open market at a cost of nearly $1,000,000.

The Lafayette nine scored its third victory of the season over Lehigh before a commencement day crowd today, 10-5. This brings Lafayette's string of straight victories to twelve. Lafayette really won the game in the second, scoring seven runs on three hits, two walks and two errors.

Town Clerk Frank A. Westberg of the village of Highland Falls issued marriage licenses today to twentytwo members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy. Eighteen ceremonies will be performed in the cadet chapel, and the others in the Catholic chapel.

Captain E. D. Jones, commanding the cutters George W. Campbell and Cayuga, carrying about 130 graduates of the United States Coast Guard Academy on a European cruise, was instructed today by Rear Admiral R. R. Waesche, Coast Guard commandant, to keep clear of the waters around Spain.

Members of the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, and officials of the B. M. T. met yesterday afternoon at the office of W. S. Menden, president of the B. M. T., 385 Flatbush Avenue Extension, and for nearly two hours discussed a collective bargaining agency for the B. M. T. employes.
The Federal Theatre Project announced last evening a reorganization of its personnel and activities, one brought about by the reduced funds set aside for work relief.

A stained glass clerestory window in the medical bay of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, was dedicated yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning as a memorial to the de Peyster family. A simple tenminute service was held in the nave of the cathedral before the new window.
Defeated for the first time this season, Yorkshire relinquished its lead in the English county cricket championship today to Sussex, winner over Gloucestershire by five wickets.

Mrs. Florence Couthoui, a theatre ticket broker for 35 years, died today in her home here. She was 65 years old. Mrs. Couthoui entered the ticketselling business after the death of her husband. At one time she operated twenty-three agencies, situated in all of the larger hotels and clubs, in addition to operating a restaurant and numerous cigar stands.

Ernest Aldrich Simpson swore under voluntary oath in King's Court today that he was paid neither by money nor other consideration to permit the former Wallis Warfield Simpson, now the Duchess of Windsor, to divorce him without contest.

Mrs. Edith Sloat, 29 years old, of 617 West 168th Street, who admitted stealing $16,000 from a Coney Island dress shop by padding payrolls and raising checks, was sentenced yesterday by County Judge Algeron I. Nova in Brooklyn to serve ten to twenty vears in the

The 298 members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy paraded for the last time this morning as part of the cadet corps in a review of the full 1,600 by the alumni. In the afternoon they in turn reviewed the members of the corps who will remain when they receive their diplomas tomorrow.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 9: REAR ADMIRAL Marshall, A. W., Commandant 15th Naval District, to Naval Operations, Navy Dept., Washington, D.C.

Miss Madeleine H. Rummler, daughter of William R. Rummler of Chicago and the late Mrs. Rummler, was married to Seaward Maxwell Woodard, son of Mrs. Corrinne Woodard of Detroit, yesterday afternoon in the Carpenter Suite of the Waldom-Astoria by the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Cooper of the Church of the Ascension.

The New Mexico Gas Company of Santa Fe has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 8,000 shares of $50 par value 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock to be offered by the Southern Union Securities Company and 44,000 7o-par value common shares reserved for conversion of the preferred.

Miss Lois Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Foster of Manhasset, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to James B. Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Moore of Bayside. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lester Leake Riley in Zion Church, Douglaston.

Three usurers paid fines of $500 each yesterday rather than go to the workhouse for three months after they had pleaded guilty to violating the State Banking Law by lending money without State licenses. William Schieren, 27 years old, of 96-75 West Ninth Street,

Harley L. Clarke replied today to the amended complaint filed yesterday by the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, which increased from $3,000,000 to $5,000,000 the amount sought from him on charges of fraud.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Van Cleve, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garret Van Cleve of this place, to Robert A. Huntley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Huntley, took place this evening at the Van Cleve residence. Ninety guests were present.

The marriage of Miss Alyce Pressprich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald W. Pressprich of Purchase, to Samuel Lord Brookfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Brookfield of New York, took place this afternoon in Christ Church here.

New York State's third and fourth class postmasters voted support yesterday for bills now before Congress which would place all postmasters under civil service and give fixed salaries to postmasters of the fourth class on the same pay basis.

Mrs. Edna C. Dunham Plant of Greenwich was ordered today to be more specific regarding charges contained in her divorce suit against Phil Plant, wealthy sportsman. Superior Court Judge Dickenson granted a motion by Mr. Plant's attorneys that counsel for Mrs. Plant amend the charges by showing:

MANHATTAN CONTENT, WASHINGTON (Des. 15,1936). Gross assets, $55,600; net, $39,682. To Virginia Kay and Mildred Dottenheim, $3,000; Joseph Mayer, $1,000; Alice Florine Content and Blanche Content, sisters, one-half residue each. Chief assets, $17.480. Griffiths Content, attorneys,. 120 Broadway.

The Monroe City Commission asked Governor Frank Murphy tonight to declare martial law to prevent bloodshed after the Committee for Industrial Organization had called a triState mass meeting here on Sunday.
A two-year labor agreement for the New York scrap iron industry was signed yesterday, it was announced by Benjamin Schwartz, director general of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel.
Precedent in Soviet state trials remains unbroken. All the eight Red Army chiefs arraigned for treason and sabotage have pleaded guilty to all the charges.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Frederick C. Rawolle Jr., a brilliant young Yale graduate, who received his medical degree from Johns Hopkins University on Monday, was found dead today in a wooded section of Stamford near the State line, the victim of a bullet wound, which a medical examiner said was self-inflicted.

Mrs. Zarmig Gurjian, store in 323-45 W 34th St; Ed.din L. Singleton and Charles L. Hanscom, in 12 E 44th St; Louis E. Coleman, in 48 W 46th St; Hollywood Service, additional space in 105 W 40th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker.

With Cardinal Hayes presiding, commencement exercises were held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for 251 graduates of the Cathedral High School (Archbishop Hughes Memorial), at 560 Lexington Avenue. More than 2,500 persons attended.

Miss Eunice Sanborn, daughter of Bruce W. Sanborn, St. Paul attorney, was married here today to Frederick Brewster. son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Brewster of New Haven, Conn. Three hundred guests attended the ceremony.

The largest number of degrees and diplomas in the history of Sarah Lawrence College will be presented to students tomorrow at the annual commencement. Twenty-one Bachelor of Arts degrees and 105 diplomas will be awarded by Miss Constance Warren, president of the college.
Sale of Fairmount Park, 234-acre racing plant near here, by Robert S. Eddy Jr., and his associates- to a new syndicate of which
Joseph M. Lacalle, composer and retired music critic, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 111-36 128th Street, Ozone Park, at the age of 77. Mr. Lacalle was born in Spain.

Philip M. Whitman of Englewood, Pittsburgh, a senior at Haverford, was announced tonight the winner of the Clementine Cope Fellowship, with a stipend of $700, for graduate study at another institution.

The tanker Ulysses, which was recently purchased from the American Tanker Corporation and remodeled as a whale factory, sailed yesterday from Gothenburg, Sweden, on a whaling expedition to the Antarctic, it was announced here.
William F. Warms, who was in charge of the Ward line steamer Morro Castle when it burned off Asbury Park, N. J., on Sept. 8, 1934, returned to the sea yesterday.

Dr. Guy E. Snavely, president of Birmingham-Southern (Ala.) College and executive secretary of the Association of American Colleges, will give the address at the sixty-third annual commencement exercises of Centenary Junior College and Centenary Academy here tomorrow afternoon at- 3 o'clock.

The fastest creature that lives, so rare that it stirred entomologists to enthusiasm and so swift and mechanically perfect that aircraft designers were invited to study its design, was exhibited at the University of Rochester Museum today.

Passengers sailing today on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia include Princess Miguel de Braganca, Colonel Giovanni Ferrando, Giacomo Rimini, opera baritone, and his wife, Rosa Raisa, singer; Giuseppe Sturani, conductor, with Mrs. Sturani; Giorgio Polacco, conductor;
Dr. Cecil B. Ferguson, who has been treating Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe's throwing arm, said today the Detroit Tigers' right-hander should be able to take his turn on the mound after a few days' rest.

Appointment Ununiformed Fireman Frederick W. Fox Jr., Engine Co. 34, having completed his probationary period of three months satisfactorily, is appointed as a fireman, Fourth Grade, with compensation at the rate of $2,000 per annum.
One more of the eight men on trial for the 1933 kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., was linked directly with the abduction for the first time today through identification by a government witness.

WASHINGTON, June 11.--Without the formality of a resolution the Senate Postoffice Committee today ordered a broad inquiry into the charges of interference with the mails in the steel strike areas of the Middle West, and of the activities of the steel companies themselves in connection with the current labor trouble.
Representatives of railway management and of railway labor unions are to meet in Chicago on June 24 to discuss proposed reforms in methods of adjusting labor disputes under the railroad labor law.

Slomka Brothers, Inc., report the sale of the one-family dwelling at 1,814 Seventy-fifth Street, Brooklyn, for Augusta Goldman to Concetta Pellitteri; the two-family dwelling at 2,117 Eightieth Street for R. Green to F. Wechsler, the latter house containing thirteen rooms, and occupying a plot 30 by 100 feet.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: After Max Schmeling handed Steve Hamas and Walter Neusel their first knockouts he challenged Champion Jim Braddock through the New York State Athletic Commission. He was told that he would first have to defeat the sensational young Joe Louis on June 19, 1936, before his challenge could be honored.

The New York Produce Exchange announced yesterday the appointment of the following committee chairmen: Standing Committees -- Complaint, Robert M. Morgan; finance, Robert F. Straub; floor, Axel Hansen;
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 909,000 bales, against 917,000 a week ago, 928,000 two weeks ago, 928,000 three weeks ago and 727,000 a year ago;

The Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Washington, D. C., advised the United States today through the American Institute of Banking to "take severe doses of what is known as patriotism."

The government confronted Ellis H. Parker in the Federal court here today with seemingly contradictory statements by him to the Mercer County grand jury in April, 1936, shortly after he turned over to the authorities Paul Wendel as the "confessed" kidnapper of the Lindbergh baby.

About 3,500 workers, or 80 per cent of the national jacquard silk manufacturing industry, are affected in one-year contracts signed here today by Sidney Hillman, as chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, and David L. Cole, counsel for the Master Weavers Institute, the employers' organization.

Eight physicians who conducted a three-hour examination were reported today to have found the Dowager Queen Marie of Rumania suffering from a serious disease of the liver. The queen was seriously ill in March when gastric hemorrhages followed an attack of grippe.

The greatest round of golf in all championship history died in the making today when slashing Jimmy Thomson, the world's longest hitter of a golf ball, lost a chance for a 64 by missing a two-foot putt on the seventeenth hole of the Oakland Hills Country Club, where the open championship is being played, and by steering an iron shot off into a bunker at the finishing hole.

Mrs. Blanche Hardee Lamb, a former concert singer, died here last night at her home, 30 Howard Avenue. She was 55 years old. She also was a soloist in New York, New Jersey and Westchester churches and had appeared in many amateur performances.

James J. Braddock, in five rounds of boxing today, gave evidence that he intends to fight Joe Louis at close range, hoping to finish him with a right-hand punch to the chin. The Negro challenger for the world heavyweight championship always has been most effective at long range.

The second escape from a Department of Correction prison van within two months was revealed last night with the arrest in Harlem of Michael Acosta, 22 years old, of 188 State Street, Brooklyn, a burglary suspect.

Luncheon in honor of Teresa Mooney of the division of appointment of the Board of Education, Hotel Commodore, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Dr. Stephen A. Bayne, Dr. Jacob Greenberg, Frank Canning, William T. Blunt, Albert C. Helm.

Freddie Fitzsimmons, chubby knuckleball expert and dean of the Giant pitching staff, yesterday became the property of the one National League club over which he has been able to display greater mastery than any other.

Samuel Kronsky, Inc, has arranged a first-mortgage building loan of $118,000 for the construction of a six-story apartment on the east side of Broadway, 100 feet south of Isham St, Manhattan, for the Waybern Realty Corp.
The Athletics bombarded four Cleveland pitchers today for sixteen hits, including two home runs by Wally Moses, and defeated the Indians, 11 to 3. The defeat dropped the Indians into fourth place.

Crews of two steamships sat down for two hours today in what a National Maritime Union leader declared was an "educational strike" directed against the International Longshoremen's Association, an affiliate of the American Federation Labor.

The seven-State steel strike that has made 73,000 workers idle for three weeks spread to this industrial city at midnight as workers walked from the sprawling Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, adding thousands to the idle.

Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan disclosed today that Governor Frank Murphy had refused to be considered a candidate for appointment to the Supreme Court. The Michigan Governor's name was mentioned when Justice Van Devanter notified President Roosevelt he would retire.
The Fairfield County Hunt Club honored Miss Helen Bedford and J. Hanchet Taylor, former masters of the fox hounds, at a dinner dance this evening.

The United Drydocks Corporation offered a compromise in the form of wage increases and improved working conditions yesterday to about 1,500 strikers, as its shipbuilding plant at Mariners Harbor, S. I., lay idle.

The roses which were judged today at .the sixth annual Westchester County Flower Show, being held at the County Center here, attracted much attention. Mrs. Matthew Carney of New Rochelle won the greatest number of first prizes in this class. Mrs. Charles D. Draper of Roslyn, L. I., was the winner in the three sweet pea classes.

An almost faultless performance by Richard K. Mellon's black gelding, Sensatin, won another blue ribbon for the Mellon Stables at Ligonier, Pa., in the Charter Jubilee horse show at Soldier Field tonight. Ridden by Tony Spink, Sensatin took first prize in the class for thoroughbred hunters.

NEWARK, N. J., June 11 (AP).--The Newark Bears continued to set a thundering pace in the International League race tonight as they overwhelmed the Buffalo Bisons, 11-3, before 16,705, the largest crowd to witness a floodlight contest in Newark's history.

Sharp advances in both exports and imports between the United States and the principal foreign countries in April over the same month in 1936 were reported today in the monthly survey by the Department of Commerce.

Bruce Williams of Joplin, Mo., was elected first vice president of Rotary International today at the first meeting of the new board of directors. The convention ended with election of vice presidents. Others named were Armando de Arruda of Pereiras, Brazil, and Carlos P. Romulo of Manila.

The Transport Workers Union of America, C. I. O. affiliate, won an overwhelming victory yesterday in the collective-bargaining referendune of the 1,100 employes of the Terminal Transportation System, Inc., operator of one of the city's largest taxicab fleets.
